title: Investigation Of Columbia
description: A special district attorney's unit set up four years ago after a scandal involving Columbia Pictures is investigating possible embezzlement at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: 2 PRIVATE EYE SERIES, A COMEDY, 'BRIDESHEAD'
description: TELEVISION'S partiality toward odd couplings stems from purely practical tactics. Two leads are usually better than one simply for purposes of audience identification. A handsome man paired with a beautiful woman should appeal to both sexes. A youngish character teamed with an older one will bridge the generation gaps. Those theories, hardly unassailable, do make for curiously awkward plots.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ARISE OVER WAR ACT
description: The death of a United States marine in Lebanon today has focused new attention on President Reagan's decision to send troops to Lebanon and has led to new questions about the authority of the War Powers Act.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON POSTER ART
description: So powerful has television become in the West that it has supplanted poster art as the major tool of mass persuasion. True, many European political parties still produce marvelous posters, and American groups that can't afford television spots still rely on posters. But nowadays, works such as the 1968 peace dove that Ben Shahn did for the Eugene McCarthy Presidential campaign seem designed less to win mass support than to warm the hearts of the already faithful.

title: Mr. Schmidt at the Exit
description: The sounds you are hearing from West Germany are not just normal political noises. They are the sounds of a collapsing consensus that buttressed three remarkable decades of stability, economic growth and alliance with the West. Instability is now the outlook, whatever the date and result of the coming national election.

title: ANTIQUES SHOW OFFERS AMERICANA WITH A RAKISH AIR
description: AMERICANS have always loved Americana but never more so than in recent years, and that is one reason why New York's Fall Antiques Show, which opened yesterday with its focus on American furniture and artifacts, has become in just four years one of the most important and popular antiques events in the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARSHALL: Hero for Our Times. By Leonard Mosley. 570 pages. Illustrated. Hearst. $18.50.

title: CHINA CALLS HONG KONG PACTS INVALID
description: The Chinese Government, in a rebuke to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said today that it was not bound by the three 19th-century treaties that ceded Hong Kong to Britain and would recover all of the colony ''when conditions are ripe.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Back to Hoover

title: Question of Timing
description: S o many legal questions have plagued the City Council over the last year that there would hardly seem room for any more. Somehow, one has managed to crop up:

title: WOOLWORTH FINDS BUYER FOR ITS BRITISH HOLDINGS
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell, for $279 million, the 52.6 percent interest it holds in Britain's Woolworth chain. The sale, part of a plan to divest itself of unprofitable properties, would result in a loss of about $80 million in the current fiscal year ending Jan. 31, the company said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ACADEMY'S REPORT ON TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGY
description: Following are excerpts from the executive summary of ''Scientific Communication and National Security,'' a report by a panel of the National Academy of Sciences:

title: Sandinists Report C.I.A.-Backed Rebels
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge said today that Nicaraguan forces soldiers killed 24 ''counterrevolutionaries'' in northeast Nicaragua and recently captured 76 others who, he asserted, were carrying equipment supplied by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Nippon Sales to China
description: The Nippon Electric Company said it had won an order from China for several hundred personal computer units. The company declined to disclose details because it is awaiting approval from the Coordinating Committee for Export Control for the Communist Area through Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

title: FOOD TOWN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
POLICE PLAN AS CAMPAIGN TO PRESUADE 40,000 TO TAKE QUALIFYING TEST
description: The signs are simple and startling: THE POLICE ARE LOOKING FOR YOU. In a few weeks, those signs -14,000 of them - will be posted around New York City's black and Hispanic neighborhoods and in hundreds of subway cars and buses.

title: SHIFTS BY TRUDEAU HINT A SOFTER LINE ON INVESTMENT
description: In the second stage of a Cabinet overhaul, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau appeared today to be placating both the United States Government and Canadian business by turning over sensitive economic posts to members known for their caution and moderation.

title: BALLROOM DANCING CHAMPIONSHIPS AT THE GARDEN
description: Those who thought that ballroom dancing went out with Ginger Rogers's strapless gown and Fred Astaire's white tie and tails will have to think again. The 12th annual United States national ballroom championships, a lavish display of camp and costumery, will be held today, tomorrow and Sunday at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. The event has drawn more than 1,000 entrants from across the country who will compete for 25 individual and pairs titles.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Company has appointed A. Whitman Marchand and Richard L. Solar senior vice presidents.

title: POP JAZZ
description: TEN years ago, Peter Nero, the pianist, left behind the world of nightclubs in which he had started playing more than a decade earlier to devote himself completely to a concert career with his trio and with symphony orchestras. But now he is back in a club, the Cafe Carlyle, which may be a bit more posh than such rooms as the Hickory House and Jilly's, where he started.

title: NEW-HOME SALES UP A SLIGHT 2%
description: Sales of new single-family houses rose a slight 2 percent in August, continuing a seesaw performance that has left sales at almost exactly the same level as a year earlier, new Government figures indicated today.

title: Economic Nominee
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved, by a vote of 7 to 4, President Reagan's nomination of a Harvard economics professor, Martin Feldstein, to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Citicorp Move West Is Led by a Texan
description: Citicorp's charge into California, one of the major current developments in the banking industry, is being led by Betty Sue Peabody, a Texan who proved her banking abilities as head of Citicorp's upstate New York branches.

title: BREWERS LOSE, LEAD BY 3 AS ORIOLES WIN
description: Dennis Eckersley slowed Milwaukee's drive to a division title Thursday, and Wade Boggs broke out of a batting slump to bat in three runs and lead the Boston Red Sox to a 9-4 victory over the Brewers in Boston.

title: U.S. SUPPORTING STATE PLAN TO SET HOSPITALS' COST
description: Secretary Richard S. Schweiker of the Department of Health and Human Services told the Carey administration yesterday that he intended to approve New York's proposal for a unified system of hospital reimbursement for the state, one that would create a fund of hundreds of millions of dollars for the hospital care of the uninsured poor.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE CONSCIENCE OF A NATION
description: The outrage resounding after the massacre in Beirut has been heard in Israel. But that isn't what counts most here. The heart of the matter is what Israelis think of themselves.

title: REAGAN'S HONDURANS
description: Hondurans, voting in record numbers in November, elected their first civilian Government in 10 years. But today, the electorate's hopes have been derailed as the Reagan Administration pursues a policy in Central America that is helping to turn Honduras's democratic Government into little more than a facade for a new military dictatorship.

title: MADISON SQUARE PARK AREA ENTERS CONDOMINIUM ERA
description: On a grim day in October 1966 the New York City Fire Department endured its worst catastrophe. The floor of a drugstore collapsed as firemen fought a stubborn five-alarm blaze that engulfed three buildings on Broadway near 23d Street. Twelve men died.

title: NURSES' STRIKE IN JERSEY BRINGS LAYOFFS
description: A strike by 550 registered nurses and 125 licensed practical nurses at the 705-bed St. Barnabas Medical Center continued through its 11th day today while 125 supervisors and nonstriking head nurses cared for a drastically reduced patient load.

title: REAGAN AT MEETING SEEKS NEW INTEREST FOR FEDERALISM PLAN
description: President Reagan met with state and local officials today in an effort to revive interest in his ''new federalism'' proposal. According to participants, he heard complaints about the ''killing'' effect of the general economic recession on all such ambitious plans.

title: Funds' Assets Fall $1.1 Billion; Funds' Assets Fall $1 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $1.1 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $224.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LAW LIMITS HOSPITAL SPENDING
description: An innovative program to curb the soaring cost of health care by offering hospitals financial incentives to cut their budgets goes into effect in Massachusetts tomorrow, the first plan of its kind in the country.

title: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION HARMFUL TO THE C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: New 'Odd Couple' are Nancy Walker and Joan Rivers.
description: ''THE ODD COUPLE'' is coming back to life - this time with Nancy Walker and Joan Rivers. Yes, with two women in the roles of those mismatched roommates originally created on Broadway in 1965 by Walter Matthau and Art Carney.

title: News Analysis
description: While all six defendants in the Brink's murder trial face charges of murder and robbery, the legal approaches they have taken in their cases are as dramatically different as their decorum in the courtroom.

title: Saving the Thrifts, and Then Some
description: The bill now sailing through Congress in the name of ''saving'' the thrift institutions - savings and loan associations and savings banks - addresses only part of the revolution in the nation's financial system. A comprehensive reform will still be needed, and the sooner the better.

title: New Charges Filed At Fulton Market
description: Eleven men, four companies and a seafood industry group were named yesterday in Federal charges of extensive theft, extortion, fraud and labor payoffs at the Fulton Fish Market.

title: Tang to Buy McLouth Assets
description: Tang Industries, the Chicago-based metals manufacturer, said it had reached a definitive agreement to buy ''substantially all of the operating assets'' of the troubled McLouth Steel Corporation of Detroit for $75 million.

title: POP: WARREN ZEVON AT THE RITZ
description: WHEN he first performed in New York six years ago, Warren Zevon wasn't so much a rock-and-roller as a singer-songwriter with a feisty, cynical edge. He seemed like a performer capable of exploding into something quite different, though one wasn't sure just what.

title: Jets Delaying Ticket Refund
description: The Jets will not offer refunds to season-ticket holders until the National Football League determines whether games put off by the player strike will be rescheduled, the club announced yesterday.

title: AMERICAN DREAM OF CHINESE FAMILY TURNS BITTERSWEET
description: The Tsoung Shing Coffee Shop - a little bit of China in the center of Queens - is a place of many beginnings. It officially opened three years ago, but its roots date back far longer - to the streets of Hong Kong and a man named Ming You, who left his home and pregnant wife to make a fortune in New York.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Intruder Kills Boy, 12, And Wounds Sister, 10
description: A 12-year-old boy was stabbed to death and his 10-year-old sister was seriously wounded yesterday afternoon by an intruder who crawled into their Brooklyn apartment through a garbage chute and attacked them as they screamed for help, the police said.

title: 11 CHILDREN OF VIETNAM WAR HEAD 'HOME' TO U.S.
description: Eleven children of mixed Vietnamese and American parentage arrived here today on their way to the United States.

title: Mississippi Sheriff Killed After Swap for Hostages
description: A sheriff was shot dead after he voluntarily took the place of four hostages Wednesday night.

title: FESTIVALS INCLUDE 34 FILMS BY OZU
description: The 20th New York Film Festival, which continues at Lincoln Center through Oct. 10, may be the most visible cinematic event in the city right now, but it is by no means the only place for adventurous film fans to be this month. From the early triumphs of Greta Garbo and Ingrid Bergman to the passive tension of the Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu and the deliberately provocative works of America's most avant-garde directors, the depth and diversity of film itself will be on display throughout the city.

title: Ruling on Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company has been ordered by the European Court of Justice to resume the sale of right-hand-drive vehicles in West Germany.

title: MILAN'S TASTE FOR THE MODERN
description: Especially to the foreign visitor, Milan for the next few weeks may very likely resemble a city ready to burst its well-finished seams. Foreign journalists and buyers have begun arriving in polite hordes for the new spring ready-to-wear showings that begin on Sunday. Last week, visitors on their way to the textile exhibition crossed paths at the Malpensa airport with visitors from the International Furniture Fair. The taxis were busy. Even the restaurants, with the exception of the most expensive, were full.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Orioles vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Baltimore, twilight-night doubleheader. If they're still in the race, the Orioles must sweep this four-game series. California Angels vs. Texas Rangers, at Anaheim, Calif. Two victories this weekend will win a divisional title for the Angels.

title: JUDGE IN TEANECK STRIKE
description: He wanted the law obeyed, but insisted the punishment ''be handled with dignity.'' He imposed fines, but worried about the financial hardship that might result. He said he could not force the two sides together, but in the end did just that. In short he left the courthouse guessing, as he has for much of his time on the bench. Judge Sherwin D. Lester of Superior Court, the New Jersey jurist who jailed striking Teaneck teachers and school employees when they defied his back-to-work order, has a reputation for making multifaceted decisions that lend themselves to varying interpretations. As one lawyer here says simply, ''It's very common for adversaries to walk out of his courtroom and say to each other, 'Which one of us won?' ''

title: Battleship New Jersey Ends Sea Trials After Her Refitting
description: The battleship New Jersey has successfully completed sea trials after extensive refitting in preparation for her scheduled return to the fleet next January, the Pentagon announced today.

title: NEW MARKET: FUTURES OPTIONS
description: First there were commodity futures contracts. Then there were stock options. Now, starting today in New York and Chicago, there will be options on commodity futures.

title: NEW POLICY: PAYING BILLS ON RECEIPT!
description: The check is in the mail. Well, almost. Starting Friday, the Federal Government is going to try to save money by paying its bills on time. Under the Prompt Payment Act, signed into law last May, it will be against the law as of Oct. 1 for the Federal Government to pay its bills late. And if it does, it will be obligated to pay contractors and suppliers an interest penalty at the rate of 15 percent.

title: Research Ship Catches Fire
description: Fuel tanks of a 115-foot research ship caught fire today in the Gulf of Mexico and its 22-member crew was evacuated safely, the Coast Guard said.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
Semiconductor Net
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said its net income for the first quarter plunged 94 percent, to $64,000, from $1.07 million a year earlier, although sales increased 8 percent, to $350.4 million, from $325.7 million.

title: ISABELLE HUPPERT IN LOSEY'S 'TROUT'
description: JOSEPH LOSEY originally hoped to make ''The Trout'' years ago, with a young Brigitte Bardot in the title role of a coldish, bemused, rather predatory country girl. Perhaps Miss Bardot was what he needed, because the character's sexual magnetism and her profound effect on the lives of everyone around her become improbable unless they are very palpably demonstrated.

title: 3 WOMEN MAKE JAZZ, POETRY AND FOLK GO TOGETHER
description: guitarist, Bobbie Louise Hawkins, a poet, and Rosalie Sorrels, a folk singer, have proved for the last four years, they can coexist happily on the same bill.

title: Westinghouse Sale to Cooper
description: Cooper Industries has agreed to purchase the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's lighting business, it was announced.

title: PARTY-SWITCHER'S BID IS REAGAN TEST
description: Rocco Bianco was standing with grimfaced companions in a line along the grimy front of his union headquarters waiting to sign up for unemployment checks, in one of many such lineups in the grim and grimy steel towns that stretch along the Ohio and Beaver Rivers here in Beaver County.

title: CUOMO IS GIVEN PRAISE BY CAREY AT FUND DINNER
description: Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo publicly made peace at a fund-raising dinner last night, with Mr. Carey praising the man he had opposed as ''a progressive, independent, experienced, tested and extraordinarily capable candidate.''

title: SIHANOUK APPEALS TO U.N. TO RETAIN CAMBODIA'S SEAT
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former ruler of Cambodia who now heads a coalition of forces opposed to the occupation of that country, told the United Nations General Assembly today that his government was not a government in exile.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS HOPEFUL ON NEW BILL
description: The nation's loss-ridden savings institutions expressed enthusiasm today about the prospect that they would soon be able to offer a new consumer account that they say promises to end their outflow of deposits.

title: DANCE: A SOLO BY MOLISSA FENLEY
description: THE world is blowing up around us, Molissa Fenley reminds us obliquely in her latest, mind-boggling dance solo, ''Eureka.'' Nearly every moment is pushed to a physical extreme and every moment counts.

title: SOUTHEAST DROPS ITS BID TO BUY FLORIDA NATIONAL
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation yesterday gave up its seven-month struggle for control of the Florida National Banks of Florida and agreed to swap a 23 percent stake in Florida National for assets.

title: No Headline
description: CUMMINGS WILL PLAY FOR ATHLETES IN ACTION

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle Saturday incorrectly identified George Gregory Korkola, who is being extradited from Spain on charges re- lating to illegal arms dealing. The ar- ticle should have identified Frank E. Terpil, not Mr. Korkola, as a former Central Intelligence Agency agent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no contradiction between permanent peace for Israel and the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A10:1.)

title: PITT HEADS LIST AFTER 3 VICTORIES
description: Pitt, the consensus No.1 team in the preseason rankings, is toprated in The New York Times's first weekly computer ranking of the college football season.

title: 'VORTEX' FROM SCOTT B AND BETH B
description: ''VORTEX,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 6:15 and Sunday at 7, appears to be the chef d'oeuvre of the film-making couple who call themselves Scott B and Beth B and their production company B Movies. It should also be good news for people who are amused by the pop sensibility that interprets a rudely bland kind of cinema tackiness as a statement not just on movies but also on the human condition.

title: GALLERY SEASON, IN ALL ITS VARIETY, OPENS UPTOWN AND DOWN
description: IN case you hadn't noticed, the new season in the galleries starts just a week or two before the first leaves turn red. It's a jumpy, unfocused sort of time - a moment at which no one knows quite what to expect. Contrary to what is sometimes thought, the New York galleries are not at all standardized. The better they are, the more individual they are. Contrary (once again) to what is sometimes thought, the best galleries are always looking for the new and the good and doing their best to bring it to fruition. They don't forget the old and the good, either, and the first day of October is a good time to see what comes of it all.

title: PENTAGON ACCUSED BY G.A.O. OF ILLEGAL LOBBYING
description: The General Accounting Office said in a report today that officials in the Air Force and the office of the Defense Secretary ''have violated Federal anti-lobbying laws'' in a joint campaign with the Lockheed Corporation to push through Congress a program to buy 50 C-5 air cargo planes.

title: Elbow Operation
description: Larry Christenson, the Philadelphia Phillies pitcher, will undergo surgery Friday for the removal of loose fragments from his right elbow. Christenson has been bothered with tenderness in his pitching elbow occasionally during the season.

title: POLAND TO MINT COINS BEARING POPE'S FACE
description: The Polish Government, eager to rebuild its depleted reserves of foreign exchange, has decided to mint some $20 million of gold and silver coins stamped with the face of Pope John Paul II.

title: A Listing at the Met
description: T he Stagebill handed out at Tuesday night's performance of ''La Gioconda'' at the Met contained the roster of opera patrons, a rather long roster at that.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE fall social season fairly exploded this week with parties and r eceptions, private and public, large and small. The Marquis and Marquise Francois d'Aulan (he of the new sparklingw ine Piper Sonoma) were given a small dinner at Tucano the other n ight by Mary Lee Fairbanks on the same evening that the British F inancial Association of Chartered Accountants met at Windows on the W orld for an evening of haggis and bagpiping. Sotheby Parke Bernet o pened its doors to the Mostra Mercato Internazionale Dell' A ntiquariato. This sale of Italian antiquities, never before held o utside of Italy, was arranged by Sotheby on behalf of the A merican-Italian Foundation for Cancer Research. Which was enough to b ring Diana Vreeland, Jerry Zipkin and Bianca Jagger to York Avenue t o an auction at which Calvin Klein bought a week at Elsa Perretti's h ouse in Porto Ercole for $1,300.

title: LEXICON
description: Washington continually generates new words to express old ideas. Here are some examples now circulating:

title: DODGERS END SLIDE AT 8, TRAIL BRAVES BY A GAME
description: Unlike all the other nights at Dodger Stadium this week, it was not the Dodgers who stumbled and fumbled tonight.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Nuclear Powers Urged To Forgo 'First Use'

title: CLASSICAL GUITAR: DAVID TANENBAUM
description: DAVID TANENBAUM, one of finest of the younger generation of guitarists, played a distinguished program handsomely at Goodman House on Wednesday night. The Mozart-Bream Larghetto and Allegro (K.229) was followed by Bach Lute Suite in A minor, and these were succeeded by two substantial 20th-century works - Walton's set of Five Bagatelles and Henze's ''Royal Winter Music.''

title: FORGOTTEN VICTIMS OF ILLEGAL DISCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: UMBERTO ROMANO, ARTIST DIES
description: Umberto Romano, a semi-abstract painter known for his portraits and murals, died of heart failure Monday night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived on East 83d Street and in Chatham, Mass.

title: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Included a gain on sales of properties and recoveries on former nonearning assets of $382,519 for the latest qr and $55,277 for the earlier period

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Collector's Item
description: Sports collectors thrive on one-of-a-kind artifacts. At 1 P.M. today, there should be considerable interest when the 1942 Rose Bowl trophy is auctioned at Bryan University Center at Duke University in Durham, N.C.

title: J.W.T. Officer Moves To McDonald & Little
description: Elsewhere in the Bates organization, McDonald & Little, its Atlanta subsidiary, yesterday announced a new president and chief creative officer.

title: CARTER SAYS REAGAN HAS FAILED TO ACCEPT HIS RESPONSIBILITIES
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, responding to criticism from President Reagan, said tonight that while his Administration made mistakes, ''we did not spend four years blaming our mistakes on our predecessors.''

title: BILL GEORGE, BEARS' LINEBACKER
description: Bill George, a former linebacker with the Chicago Bears and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, was killed today in a three-car accident. He was 51 years old.

title: U.D.C. DISCHARGES CONSULTANT ON MINORITY HIRING
description: A consultant on minority hiring for the state's Urban Development Corporation was dismissed yesterday after it was disclosed that in testimony he acknowledged having got payments from an organizedcrime figure to keep nonwhite workers off construction jobs.

title: East Side favorites for steak, seafood.
description: ALMOST since it opened in 1926, the Palm steakhouse on Second Avenue and 45th Street has been a favorite with journalists, sports figures and lusty eaters of all sorts. With caricatures of celebrity customers on its walls and sawdust on its floor, this noisy, jampacked New York classic, with its robust, masculine overtones, remains a personal favorite. This is true even though many visits over the last year make it plain that the four-star rating it earned six years ago must be reduced to three. The Palm is still the best steakhouse in the city, but the kitchen is slightly less consistent than it used to be.

title: BANKS, CANADA TO AID DOME
description: Control of Canada's largest independent oil company, Dome Petroleum Ltd., is passing to the federal Government and four of the country's biggest banks as a result of a bailout agreement that provided Dome with $1 billion (Canadian).

title: PLAYS
description: T he triple play is a rarity in baseball, but the Mets, defying the odds as usual, have made two triple plays in the last two months, both against the Chicago Cubs, and they lost both games.

title: Nova Scotia Bank Indicted
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia, in Halifax, and seven persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury in connection with a fraudulent tax shelter scheme involving more than $122 million, the Justice Department said today.

title: Musial and DiMaggio
description: Stan (The Man) Musial and Joe DiMaggio are scheduled to be in the lineup to sign autographs this weekend at the 1982 New York Superstar Baseball Card Show at St. Vartan Cathedral, 630 Second Avenue, between 34th and 35th Streets.

title: Socal Deadlock
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said its directors met yesterday with President Suharto of Indonesia in Jakarta to try to break a deadlock in talks over renewal of a contract for production of Indonesian crude oil by P.T. Caltex Pacific Indonesia, a joint venture of Socal and Texaco Inc. Caltex hopes to extend its contract until the year 2001, and has a deadline of November 1983 to complete negotiations. The Indonesian Government now receives 85 percent of the crude oil Caltex produces, and at issue in the negotiations is its request to receive more.

title: Interest Rate Futures Rise After Big Swings
description: Interest rate futures closed with modest gains yesterday after a session marked by volatile price swings. Brokers said, however, that the closing prices could have been quite different if traders had been able to respond to moves in the cash market after futures trading ended.

title: CEDING OF ZULUS' LAND IS BLOCKED
description: South Africa's highest court issued a ruling today that blocks, at least temporarily, the Government's plan to turn nearly 900,000 South African blacks into citizens of the independent kingdom of Swaziland by ceding strips of tribal territory on the kingdom's borders.

title: Discovering heirlooms.
description: SOTHEBY'S had the idea first -an heirloom discovery day -and it caught fire. Anyone could bring in an item for appraisal by one of Sotheby's experts, at a nominal fee,. The first heirloom discovery day was held in March 1974 and, despite a blizzard, 20,000 people showed up at the Madison Avenue gallery. With that kind of success, Sotheby's started heirloom discovery days all around the country, at notable art or historical institutions, intended to raise funds for them.

title: OF TWO POPES, JEWS AND YASIR ARAFAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Solomon Defeats Forget in Canada
description: Harold Solomon of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., posted a 7-6, 6-3 victory over France's Guy Forget today to advance to the quarterfinals in the $250,000 Molson Light Challenge tennis tournament.

title: A MARINE IS KILLED AND THREE OTHERS ARE HURT IN BEIRUT
description: A United States marine was killed and three others were wounded today as undetected explosives were ''accidentally detonated'' at Beirut International Airport, an American military spokesman announced.

title: LeFlore Is Arrested
description: Ron LeFlore, the Chicago White Sox center fielder, who served a prison term in Michigan for armed robbery before becoming a major league player, was arrested in Chicago by the police on charges of possession of a controlled substance and two counts of failing to register two weapons. He was arrested by narcotics officers who used a search warrant to locate the drugs and weapons.

title: Hoechst Talks With Kuwait
description: The Hoechst chemical group is discussing industrial cooperation with the Kuwait National Petroleum Corporation, which has acquired nearly 25 percent of the German company.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Announced that Manager George Bamberger has signed a one-year contract. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Named Bill Ficke a ssistant coach.

title: 'SHARON, KING OF ISRAEL,' SEPHARDIC TOWN CHANTS
description: The banner across the stage Wednesday night read, ''Kiryat Malachi Welcomes the Volunteers'' - Americans who had come to Israel to help the war effort -but the shouting, foot-stamping and applause in the packed community hall was for someone else, Ariel Sharon.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of Belo Corp.  To Assume Chief's Title
description: The A.H. Belo Corporation, owner of The Dallas Morning News, has announced that James M. Moroney Jr., president and chief operating officer, will assume the additional title of chief executive on Dec. 31.

title: A Shaky Streak
description: At the close of last season, Randy Smith had played in 841 consecutive National Basketball Association games, three short of Johnny Kerr's league record.

title: JUDGE IN GIBSON TRIAL TERMS PROSECUTION CASE INADEQUATE
description: The judge in the trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris today called the prosecution's case inadequate and said he was ''looking for some direct evidence'' to tie the men to the charges of conspiracy and misconduct.

title: Begin Again Disclaims Blame for the Massacre
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he bore no responsibility for the mass slaying of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.

title: ISRAELI LOOTED ARCHIVES OF P.L.O. OFFICIALS SAY
description: Before they withdrew from West Beirut this week, Israeli troops looted the research center of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its director said today. Several Israeli soldiers also reportedly broke into the offices of the Institute for Palestine Studies, a private establishment, but removed only a few items.

title: 2 Philadelphia Papers Are Struck by 8 Unions
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Daily News were struck by eight unions early today after a breakdown of contract negotiations, officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1982
description: International An American marine was killed and three others were wounded at Beirut International Airport as undetected explosives were ''accidentally detonated,'' a United States military spokesman announced. The blast occurred soon after the airport was reopened to the first commercial flights since June 7, the day after the Israelis invaded Lebanon. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Contrasting U.S. and Israeli policies were reflected in the general debate at the United Nations General Assembly. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said that Israel must yield territory to gain peace and that Palestinians had an ''undeniable claim'' to an identifiable place. But Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir ruled out any further ''territorial amputations'' and said Palestinian refugees in search of homes and jobs should find them in Arab countries. (A1:5.)

title: ROCK: TRANSLATOR, WEST COAST FOUR
description: on Translator's debut album, ''Heartbeats & Triggers,'' the quartet sounds like a tougher version of the 1960's Los Angeles psychedelic band, Love. And like most San Francisco bands, Translator rocks harder onstage than on record.

title: Voting on Chrysler Pact To Conclude by Oct. 14
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers Union will decide by Oct. 14 whether to accept the tentative contract with the Chrysler Corporation, and union officials said today the outcome was in doubt.

title: SENATE 'CHRISTMAS TREES' SPURS A VIGIL
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum calls it his ''watchdog filibuster,'' a patient monitoring of every bill, every amendment to prevent fellow senators from pushing through what he calls ''special interest legislation'' in these last frenzied hours before a pre-election recess.

title: Settlements by Hyatt
description: More than half the claims filed on behalf of victims of the Hyatt Regency skywalk collapse have been settled out of court, the hotel's lawyers reported. Michael Waldeck, who represents the Hyatt Hotels Corportion, operator of the Regency, and Lawrence Berkowitz, who represents the Crown Center Redevelopment Corporation, the owners, said insurers had settled 190 of 334 lawsuits and other claims, paying out more than $29 million. Two suspended walkways in the hotel collapsed on July 17, 1981, killing 114 persons and injuring 200.

title: STARCH BLOCKERS SEIZED BY F.D.A.
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration today announced the seizure of more than a million starch blocker diet tablets in five states. It said it planned to continue efforts to halt the manufacture and distribution of the pills on the ground that they were drugs that were not approved.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Breathing Room for Library

title: Connecticut Antiques
description: The 16th annual Connecticut Antiques Show will be at the State Armory on Capitol Avenue at Broad Street in Hartford this weekend.

title: NO SUCCESSOR IS NAMED
description: Charles J. Hynes, New York City's Fire Commissioner since November 1980, announced his resignation yesterday. The announcement was made at a City Hall news conference at which Mayor Koch said he had not chosen a successor and did not have any candidates in mind. Mr. Koch also said Mr. Hynes, whom he credited with lifting the morale of firefighters, had not been asked to leave.

title: MEXICO'S LAME DUCK LEADER: AN AUDACIOUS ADIOS
description: Almost daily since he announced the state takeover of Mexico's private banks this month, President Jose Lopez Portillo has been receiving donations to a new National Solidarity Fund from trade unions, peasant groups and even individuals.

title: PRICES ADVANCE MODERATELY
description: While traders and investors wait for developments that might clearly point to higher or lower interest rates, prices of outstanding debt securities fluctuated between gains and losses before closing modestly higher yesterday.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. filed a registration statement for up to one million shares of common stock that will be exchanged for $30.8 million principal amount of 10 5/8 percent notes due 1990 held by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Indian President Off to U.S.
description: President Zail Singh left here today for the United States where he will undergo a heart examination and possible surgery at the Texas Heart Institute in Houston.

title: 5 DIE AFTER TAKING TYLENOL BELIEVED TO CONTAIN CYANIDE
description: Five persons in Chicago suburbs died after swallowing capsules of Extra-Strength Tylenol, and cyanide poisoning was known or strongly suspected to be the cause, the authorities said today.

title: FILM-TV STRIKE BACKED
description: The Motion Picture Editors Guild has voted to strike if wage and benefit demands by more than two dozen unions are not met - a walkout that would virtually shut down film and television production for the third straight year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'House With Broken Heart' Celebrating New Life

title: SENATE APPROVES JOB TRAINING PLAN
description: A sweeping new job training program to replace the expiring Comprehensive Employment and Training Act was unanimously approved today by the Senate, clearing the way for the House to do the same before Congress adjourns this weekend. The vote was 95 to 0.

title: KNICKS TOUGHEN ON WILLIAMS
description: The Knicks have apparently taken a tough line with Sly Williams, their free-agent forward, since he rejected a contract offer. Williams and Trent Tucker, the top draft choice, were not among the 17 players who showed up yesterday for a meeting before the opening of training camp today at Monmouth (N.J.) College. Tucker, who was unsigned, took his physical examination earlier, but failed to report yesterday.

title: ART: SHINOHARA'S HEADLONG COLLISION WITH AMERICAN CULTURE
description: WHEN Ushio Shinohara arrived in the United States from Japan in 1969, he'd already confounded the bourgeoisie in his native land. Coming of age after Hiroshima, he had staged a rebellion against his academic training, burning his canvases, making art from junk, mounting destructive happenings with a group called the Neo-Dada Organizers. And he'd copied works by Robert Rauschenberg and other American heroes -partly because he admired their art, partly to suggest the dependence of Japanese artists on foreign influences - in a one-man movement he called ''imitation art.''

title: Fast Gold, 35-1 Shot, Captures Pegasus
description: Fast Gold, the lightweight in a field of eight and the second longest shot on the board, scored a three and a quarter length victory tonight in the $218,600 Pegasus Handicap at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: RICHARD R. WOOD
description: Richard R. Wood, a Quaker peace worker and former editor of The Friend, died Monday at his home in Moorestown, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Strachan Points Finger
description: Mike Strachan, the former running back for the New Orleans Saints who was sentenced Wednesday to three years in prison on two charges involving the sale of cocaine, said that George Rogers was the Saints' main supplier of the drug. Rogers led the National Football League in rushing as a rookie last season.

title: BAKSHI'S 'GOOD LOOKIN'
description: THOUGH it's his latest cartoon feature to arrive in New York, Ralph Bakshi's ''Hey Good Lookin' '' is not exactly his newest, having been ''in work'' since 1975. Between the start of production and the film's completion, this most innovative and audacious of contempory animated film makers has produced ''Wizards'' (1977), ''The Lord of the Rings'' (1978) and ''American Pop'' (1981).

title: Shultz speech excerpts, page A10.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the General Assembly today that Israel must yield territory to gain peace in the Middle East and that Palestinians had an ''undeniable claim'' to an identifiable place.

title: BEHIND BY 5-0, GIANTS WIN, 7-6
description: The San Francisco Giants, who were trailing by 5-0, scored seven runs in the last three innings tonight to beat the Houston Astros, 7-6, and keep alive their hopes for the National League Western Division championship.

title: NO PROGRESS IN N.F.L. TALKS
description: A long day of negotiations between representatives of the players and the owners produced no progress toward settlement of the National Football League players' strike, which today reached its 10th day.

title: Mexico's West Coast Wracked by Hurricane
description: A hurricane moved into Mexico with winds of 120 miles per hour today, and officials said that dozens of people were missing and 50,000 people had been forced to flee their homes.

title: FARMERS' PRICES RISE BY 2.3%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose during September for the first time since spring, climbing 2.3 percent above the August level, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-After a tax credit of $624,000...C-Net income

title: ARTISTS OF UNION SQUARE HAVING AN OPEN HOUSE
description: Even in Union Square, so laden with artistic tradition, the narrow, corniced, limestone building at No. 41 is special. Apportioned into 125 artists' studios, it includes that of Isabel Bishop, the last of the so-called 14th Street School, which included Reginald Marsh and Edward Laning. This weekend, 41 Union Square is opening itself to the public, and the studios and work of 91 artists will be on exhibit. This unusual show, called ''Open Studios'' by its participants, marks the second time No. 41 has gone public.

title: Harold Gal Is Named by Times As Deputy Living/Style Editor
description: Harold Gal has been appointed deputy living/style editor of The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor.

title: Toll Is Now 6 In Soviet Jet Mishap
description: The Luxembourg police lowered their death toll figure today and said only 6 of the 77 people aboard a Soviet airliner were killed when it crashed here last night. The plane was en route from Moscow to Lima, Peru, with a scheduled stop in Luxembourg.

title: DANCE: DAVID HURWITH, NINA MARTIN AND TROUPE
description: NINA MARTIN and David Hurwith raised the question of who or what dancers can trust at their Monday night concert at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.9 percent in August after four consecutive monthly increases, the Commerce Department reported. The Administration, which had forecast a decline in the indicators, said recovery would be slower than it had expected. Unemployment claims, meanwhile, rose to a record level, suggesting that the September jobless rate could reach 10 percent for the first time since 1941. (Page A1.)

title: 'LOOK AT ALL THESE PEOPLE,' MILWAUKEE SAYS OF $70 MILLION DOWNTOWN MALL
description: ''I tell you,'' Mel Zunker said, ''it got so bad that we had downtown taverns, mind you, taverns, that were closing up at 6 P.M. because it was so dead here.''

title: HOW TO UNDERMINE U.S. PUBLIC EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: COLLEEN DEWHURST IN UGO BETTI REVIVAL
description: ''THE QUEEN AND THE REBELS,'' the 1949 Ugo Betti play revived last night on Broadway, is about a busload of travelers detained against their will in a revolution-torn nation. The audience soon learns all too well what the boredom of incarceration must feel like - but the audience, at least, is free to leave. The actors, poor souls, are not, and whose heart wouldn't go out to them? No matter how talented or zealous they may be, they remain imprisoned in an inert melodrama that refuses to yield a single honest emotion or original thought.

title: Major Provisions of the Legislation
description: Following are the major provisions of legislation to help the nation's ailing banks and savings and loan associations.

title: TALVELA, EPIC OF A BASSO IN EPIC OPERA
description: At the beginning of ''Boris Godunov'' the giant stands, as stiff and gorgeous as a Russian icon in 80 pounds of gold-encrusted robes, radiating power while he lifts high the orb and scepter of a newly crowned czar. At the end, Martti Talvela, the splendid Finnish basso, crashes backward down the long stairs from the throne in a horrifying plunge to death following a heart-rending farewell to his small son and heir. It is like an oak tree toppling, except the audience is all too aware that the falling object is flesh and blood. He has just shouted ''Mercy! Death! Forgive me, Lord!'' in Russian, his fists raised to heaven.

title: BAD NEWS FOR THE CHICKEN
description: T wo million dollars, says the San Diego Chicken, ''is not a poultry sum.'' Being sued for that amount of money has ruffled his feathers.

title: Mabel Albertson, 81; TV and Movie Actress
description: Mabel Albertson, an actresscomedian perhaps best known for her television and film portrayals of nosey neighbors and interfering grandmothers, has died at the age of 81.

title: AILING BOSSY IMPATIENT TO PLAY
description: In the same way he confounds opponents with feints on the ice, Mike Bossy, the Islanders' all-star right wing, may confound the team's doctors and officials, all of whom do not want him to skate for the next five or six days because of injuries he suffered Saturday.

title: Nun, 79, Mugged At BMT Station
description: A 79-year-old Roman Catholic nun dressed in her habit was mugged yesterday by a young woman as she left the BMT subway station at Ninth Street and Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-Net income after extraordinary gains of $181,000 for the qr and $515,000 for the 9 mos

title: A Rough Voyage To the Davis Cup
description: John McEnroe's Davis Cup opening singles match against Peter McNamara today in Perth, Australia, has to be an anticlimax. In this case, getting there was hardly half the fun.

title: Soviet War Games End
description: The Soviet-led Warsaw Pact ended land, sea and air maneuvers in Bulgaria today, the official Hungarian press agency reported. Reports in the Yugoslavian press have said that more than 60,000 troops and staff were involved in the ''Shield '82'' exercises.

title: It's Not the Same
description: Pro football fans made their point last Sunday. Neither live Canadian football nor a rerun of Super Bowl XVI can replace the real thing on American television.

title: NEW MUSEUM UNEARTHS OLD NEW YORK'S HERITAGE
description: If a whale washes ashore in lower Manhattan, it belongs to Trinity Church. That right is guaranteed in a 1696 document that was signed by the British colonial Governor of New York. And as far as anyone at the church can tell, it has never been challenged.

title: Market Place; Winnebago's New Outlook
description: BEFORE the energy crisis slowed sales of its fuel-thirsty motor homes, Winnebago Industries made some investor-employees rich in its hometown of Forest City, Iowa.

title: From a life of Gandhi to Paine.
description: THOUGH his epic film ''Gandhi'' - scheduled to begin its New York run Dec. 8 - is still occupying much of his time in these days leading up to its opening, Sir Richard Attenborough has given a thought or two to what his next project might be.

title: INDEX OF ECONOMY FOR AUGUST DOWN 0.9% AFTER 4 RISES
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators declined in August, breaking a string of four successive increases, the Commerce Department said today.

title: YANKS DENY HEATON A VICTORY
description: A four-run rally by the Yankees in the ninth inning off two relief pitchers extended their winning streak to four games and cost Neal Heaton of the Cleveland Indians his first majorleague victory tonight.

title: MANY AGENCIES JOINED IN RETRIEVING VIETNAM CHILDREN
description: A group of private American aid agencies accustomed to working together on humanitarian undertakings arranged for the first substantial group of children of American and Vietnamese parentage to leave Vietnam for this country.

title: STAGE: 'BASEBALL WIVES'
description: ''BASEBALL WIVES,'' a play that did well in spring training as an Off Off Broadway effort earlier this year, played its first game of the season on Off Broadway Wednesday night and it came out a winner, thanks largely to a cast lineup of sluggers who were belting the script out of the park that is the Harold Clurman Theater.

title: The Windshield Mystery
description: The experts agree that cars designed for safety could save thousands of lives. Yet the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is fighting against new safety requirements, insisting that Big Auto is already overburdened by expensive regulations. But that excuse does not explain why the agency refuses to eliminate one ''safety'' rule - the one that prohibits introduction of a new injury-reducing safety glass.

title: OTB's New Entry
description: L ong before the doors opened at the OTB parlor on John Street yesterday, the line of bettors stretched for part of a furlong toward Nassau Street. They stood with Racing Forms in their hands and what passed for hopeful expressions on their faces.

title: New Carnegie Season
description: Carnegie Hall opens its 1982-83 season Sunday with concerts by the American Symphony Orchestra and Italy's I Musici. The American Symphony, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary season, will perform an all-Russian program at 3 P.M., featuring works by Tchaikovsky, Shostakovich and Prokofiev. I Musici, the Baroque ensemble, will perform a Vivaldi program at 8 P.M. Tickets to both concerts are available in all price ranges at the box office or through CarnegieCharge, 247-7459.

title: PAMELA HARRIMAN, THE POWER BROKER
description: The butler stood waiting with an umbrella. The parlor maid held a bag of tea sandwiches. The secretary carried a stack of correspondence. The chauffeur sat at the wheel of a waiting sedan. The husband paced the hall. ''I just came down to tell her goodbye,'' explained former Gov. W. Averell Harriman, seconds before the door to his Georgetown mansion flew open.

title: The Rainmakers Ride Again
description: The ''balanced budget amendment'' has sprung back to life for a tawdry purpose - to improve Republican chances in next month's Congressional election. On the day he closed out a fiscal year with a deficit of well over $100 billion, President Reagan and his allies sought to drown out this news with the irresponsible promise that this amendment will some day protect the economy.

title: Advertising; Bates Unit Loses Its President
description: ROBERT A. BRUNS, president since March 1981 of Ted Bates Advertising/New York, quit Monday over a ''disagreement on policy,'' the agency confirmed yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; Gloom Dulls The Azaleas
description: MARTINSVILLE,Va. THESE are gorgeous days on the slopes of the Blue Ridge, with the laurel and the wild azalea just starting to feel the breath of fall. But in the industrial towns of the Roanoke Valley, the gloom is so thick you can cut it with a buzzsaw.

title: Harvester Sheds Hauler Business
description: The debt-ridden International Harvester Company said it had sold its off-highway hauler business to the Payhauler Corporation, a company formed by three former Harvester employees. It did not give the price, which it said was in cash and notes.

title: CHRYSLER '83 PRICES TRIMMED SLIGHTLY
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that its 1983 model cars will cost an average $3 less than the 1982 models. The move followed small price increases on 1983 cars announced by the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation in August, and it means prices by the Big Three auto makers will increase an average of 1.2 percent next year.

title: A.L. LLOYD EXPERT ON THE FOLK SINGING OF MANY COUNTRIES
description: A.L. Lloyd, the English folk singer and musicologist who collected songs from the Australian bush to Transylvania, died Wednesday at his London home, his family said today. He was 74 years old.

title: Excerpts from report, page A11.
description: A panel of experts appointed by the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that there has been ''substantial and serious'' leakage of American technology to the Soviet Union. The leakage included ''a significant portion'' that is ''damaging to national security,'' the panel said in a report released today.

title: A Vote of Confidence
description: Jerry Reinsdorf, chairman of the board for the Chicago White Sox, considered replacing his manager, Tony LaRussa, earlier this season.

title: BOMB EXPLODES AT GULF PLANT IN TEXAS
description: A bomb, apparently planted in an extortion attempt, exploded tonight at a huge Gulf Oil Corporation petrochemical plant as a police bomb squad was seeking to defuse five ''suspicious devices.''

title: DIVISION 1 BASKETBALL MAY LOSE 39 TEAMS
description: At least 39 of the 277 major college basketball teams may be demoted from Division I if proposed rules on attendance and scholarship aid for athletes are adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association at its convention in January.

title: CONFEREES ADOPT STOPGAP FUND BILL
description: Congress missed the deadline tonight for action on a catch-all spending bill needed to finance the Government in the next two and a half months, even though House and Senate conferees adopted a compromise measure resolving differences in the legislation approved by each chamber.

title: Bridge: Hugh Kelsey Still Writing Great Books on the Game
description: Some 15 years ago a totally unknown young Scot made a name for himself with an excellent book on the subject of defense. Since then, a string of equally valuable books on advanced play have given Hugh Kelsey a well-deserved place in any list of the world's best bridge writers.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Comings and Goings
description: Because he has been having problems recently with his arthritic knees, Willie Stargell will not start at first base for the Pittsburgh Pirates on Sunday in what will be the 41-year-old slugger's final game. Manager Chuck Tanner has decided to use Stargell as a pinch-hitter, if possible. ... When the United States defends its Wightman Cup tennis title in London, Nov. 4-6, the American team will be made up of Chris Evert Lloyd, Rosemary Casals, Anne Smith, Barbara Potter and Sharon Walsh. ... ... Henry Rono, the star distance runner from Kenya, may face disciplinary action from the Kenyan Amateur Athletic Association because of his withdrawal from his national team. ... Dave Zyglewicz, retired for 10 years, returns to the ring for one more fight because, he says, he wants to end his career as a winner. Zyglewicz, 38 years old, fights the cruiserweight Clyde Muggett tonight in Latham, N.Y. He was knocked out in the first round by Joe Frazier 13 years ago.

title: BUCKLE UP OR PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
U.S. SEEKS EXPORT DATA FROM PIPELINE SUPPLIERS
description: In what appeared to be an expansion of efforts to stall construction of a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Europe, the Reagan Administration has written to 39 companies to request detailed information about all exports of oilfield technology over the past seven years.

title: REGAINING ISRAEL'S SOUL
description: The guilt-purging convulsions that are tearing Israel apart are a testimony that, contrary to the verdict of many, the soul of Israel is not lost. What we are witnessing in the aftermath of the Beirut massacre is not the end but rather the beginning of the real struggle over Israel's soul.

title: BID TO RETAIN BRINK'S DEFENDANT FOR U.S. TRIAL FAILS
description: The judge in the Brink's murder and robbery case today rejected a prosecution request to drop state charges against one of the six defendants and transfer him to Federal authorities for trial on broader bank robbery and racketeering charges.

title: Callers Report Blasts, But They're Fireworks
description: Police and fire department phones were ringing on both sides of the Hudson River last night as callers reported explosions in New Jersey and New York, but the blasts turned out to be a fireworks display launched from a barge.

title: Committee Set On Manville
description: A special committee representing people with asbestos-related diseases was approved yesterday in the bankruptcy proceedings of the Manville Corporation.

title: Women's Race Set For Park Tomorrow
description: About 1,800 runners will take part in the third Avon Women's Half Marathon tomorrow in Central Park. The race, a warm-up for the New York Marathon on Oct. 24, begins at 9 A.M. at Park Drive East and 67th Street.

title: HOUSE SET TO VOTE ON BUDGET CHANGE
description: In a day filled with intense political maneuvering, Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives reluctantly agreed today to allow a vote Friday on a proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget except in wartime.

title: METS SIGN BAMBERGER FOR 1983
description: With the conviction that ''the new young kids are going to turn things around here,'' George Bamberger agreed yesterday to remain as manager of the Mets for another year.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 14
3 Groups Sue U.S. to Halt Sale of Public Lands
description: Three environmental groups filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court against the Reagan Administration's plans to sell up to 35 million acres of land to private interests to help reduce the national debt.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. TO USE JAPAN AIR BASE NEAR SOVIET

title: 83 CONFINED AT SCHOOL IN TEANECK FOR DEFYING ORDER TO END WALKOUT
description: Eighty-three Teaneck teachers and other school employees were held today under sheriff's guard at an elementary school here for defying a court order to end their 14-day strike.

title: Electrolux, AEG Talks
description: Electrolux of Sweden broke off talks on acquiring a portion of a subsidiary of AEG-Telefunken A.G., the insolvent West German electical company, an AEG spokesman said today.

title: Herzog Views Award
description: Manager Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals does not fit the traditional mold of managers who boost their players for individual awards.

title: DOW DROPS BY 1002, TO BELOW 900
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading as investors' anxiety over the recession intensified. At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 10.02 points, to 896.25, the first time since Sept. 1 that the blue-chip barometer has finished below what many analysts consider its critical 900 level.

title: ON THE BENCH, NO TIME FOR POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankruptcy Second of four articles on business, personal and legal aspects.
description: Barring an 11th-hour rescue by Congress, the nation's bankruptcy court system - together with billions of dollars in assets and hundreds of thousands of jobs - could be thrown into legal limbo Monday. Late yesterday, in a sudden shift in position, the Senate was trying to forge a consensus for integrating the entire bankruptcy court system into the district courts. But it is unlikely that such a proposal could be passed by both houses of Congress in time to meet a Supreme Court deadline of next Monday for reforming the bankruptcy system.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AN ADDRESS BY SHULTZ ON WORLD PROBLEMS TO U.N. MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Geroge P. Shultz to the General Assembly:

title: 58 DISTRICTS CALLED KEY TO HOUSE FIGHT
description: With Congressional elections just a month away, the Democratic and Republican Congressional campaign chairmen said today that the battle for the House of Representatives would hinge primarily on the 58 districts where neither party has an incumbent running.

title: U.S. Must Prove Fairness Of Draft Resister Case
description: In a potential setback to the draft registration program, a Federal district judge ruled today that the Government must prove it is fairly prosecuting an admitted draft resister.

title: JAMES H. CHADBOURN
description: James H. Chadbourn, Fessenden Professor of Law Emeritus at Harvard Law School, died Tuesday of cancer at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary.

title: ST. LOUIS LOOKS TO RECOVERY FROM U.S. BUDGET CUTS
description: One City, Fiscal '82 Last article of a series appearing periodically on the impact of the Reagan budget on St. Louis. ST. LOUIS - This city's ambitious effort to revive itself, derailed last year when the Reagan Administration cut $80 million from its Federal aid, is back on the tracks, although not moving at full steam, St. Louis officials say.

title: One Good Turn
description: Many of the football Giants had promised Joel Simon that they would appear last Dec. 14 at Easter Seals fund-raising parties in Clifton and East Brunswick, N.J. They would mingle with guests, give away autographed footballs and help raise money for research.

title: HABIB SAID TO ASSURE EGYPTIAN OF PACT ON LEBANON
description: Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy, met for two hours this morning with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali and assured him, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said, that an agreement on the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon would be concluded within weeks.

title: 'FAVORITE YEAR' WITH PETER O'TOOLE
description: CAN a pie-eyed, girl-chasing, very forgetful matinee idol make a successful live television debut? The team behind a ''Your Show of Shows''-like comedy program don't know the answer to that one, but they've certainly got their fingers crossed during the week his appearance is scheduled. That is the premise of ''My Favorite Year,'' a funny and good-natured comedy that marks the directing debut of Richard Benjamin. Mr. Benjamin works in a steady, affable style that is occasionally inspired, always snappy and never less than amusing.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ROYALS WIN AND TRAIL BY 2
description: Willie Aikens knocked in seven runs with two homers to give Kansas City an 11-4 victory tonight over the Oakland A's and pull the Royals within two games of the first-place California Angels in the American League West.

title: WHERE TO SEE LEAVES TURN RED AND GOLD
description: THE tide of fall foliage colors is sweeping south from the Canadian border toward the metropolitan area a week earlier than usual this year, and the display of autumn color in the Northeast promises to be one of the most spectacular in recent memory.

title: CHALLENGE IN VIRGINIA
description: No wonder Ronald Reagan came to Virginia to campaign for Representative Paul Trible, the Republican senatorial candidate. Mr. Trible now appears in danger of losing a seat the President's party had counted on adding to its slim Senate majority.

title: BENEFIT CHANGES TAKE EFFECT TODAY
description: Dozens of changes in Federal law affecting millions of beneficiaries of Government programs take effect on Friday, the first day of the new fiscal year, or shortly thereafter.

title: Friday; CELEBRATING AT ST. JOHN
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on which construction started in the 1880's and then stopped for 41 years, announced a decision several years ago to resume construction. But only this week was the first stone emplaced. To celebrate, a gala concert is planned tonight starting at 8. With James Belushi as master of ceremonies, performers will include the Alvin Ailey Dance Center Workshop; the Big Apple Circus; Al Carmines, who will sing some of his songs at the piano; the cast from ''Godspell''; Max Roach, drummer, and Paul Winter, saxophonist. Tickets are $10 and $25. Call 662-2133, Ticketron: 977-9020, or Chargit: 944-9300. RARITIES AT THE ARMORY

title: MONEY FUNDS' NICHE
description: To the Editor:

title: College Top 20 Computer ranking based on games through Oct. 10 ; OPPONENTS' PERFORMANCES Avg. Margin Avg. Margin Rank Team Record of Victory Rating Record of Victory 1 Pittsburgh 3-0-0 12.6 1.000 7-0-0 24.5 2 Florida 3-0-0 7.0 .885 8-0-0 14.3 3 Penn State 4-0-0 15.7 .768 6-3-0 13.6 4 Arizona State 3-0-0 18.2 .748 4-5-0 5.5 5 Boston College 2-0-1 17.6 .743 4-2-0 7.8
I.M.F. KENYA HALT REPORTED
description: The International Monetary Fund has suspended a one-year financial aid package for Kenya because the country has been unable or unwilling to reform its economic policies, monetary sources said today.

title: ORIOLES SWEEP AND TRAIL BY 1
description: The Baltimore Orioles extended the race for the American League East championship at least nine more innings tonight, sweeping a doubleheader from Milwaukee and reducing the Brewers' lead to one game.

title: Police Conduct 4th Subway Sweep
description: Transit Authority police saturated lower Manhattan with 395 extra officers last night in an eight-hour ''full enforcement'' sweep to insure public compliance with local laws and transit rules and regulations.

title: Fox Cancels Inquiry Meeting
description: A spokesman for the Los Angles County district attorney's office said the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation had called off a meeting that had been scheduled as part of a ''preliminary inquiry'' about possible financial irregularities at Fox.

title: Arbed Labor Cuts
description: Arbed Saarstahl G.m.b.H., a West German steelmaker, said it had proposed to its unions that 3,000 jobs be cut from its present work force of 20,500. The company, which is seeking aid from the federal Government, said the cuts were necessary because of an anticipated decline in output.

title: Federal Waiver Allows Ailing Baby to Go Home
description: A 15-month-old New Jersey child who needs a respirator to breathe was able to leave Children's Hospital and return home today because Federal officials granted him a waiver to regulations that would have prevented his departure.

title: ABOLISH 55 M.P.H.
description: Since the imposition of the 55 mile per hour speed limit in the 1970's, large numbers of Americans have been stopped by police officers, questioned and charged with a violation of the law for what is a political and ''economic'' offense, one that should not be processed by the criminal justice system at all.

title: PONDERING THE YEAR 2000 WITH KAHN, HAIG & CO.
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 30 - ''The practical application of nonconventional financing options to the embryonic synthetic fuels industry?''

title: INDICTMENT IN HARTZ CASE
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted Fern Caron, a former vice president of the Hartz Mountain Corporation of Harrison, N.J., on charges of perjury in connection with reported bribes and procurement of prostitutes by the company.

title: PLAN WOULD SHUT 75% PERCENT OF SUBWAY RESTROOMS
description: A committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a proposal yesterday to close about three-fourths of the public restrooms in the city's subway system.

title: U.S. Leads in Davis Cup, 2-0
description: The United States took a 2-0 lead in the Davis Cup semifinal with Australia tonight when John McEnroe and Gene Mayer won the first two singles matches.

title: A Happy Ending
description: Can someone who has played quarterback all his life find happiness at defensive end? Doug Guyer says yes because he thinks playing somewhere beats not playing at all. Thus, he will be starting at defensive end again today when unbeaten Boston College plays its home football opener against Temple.

title: News Analysis
description: Despite President Reagan's display of anger at the House defeat today of a proposed constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, White House aides seemed pleased at having sprung a surprise on the Democrats and forcing a vote the Republicans can use against them this fall.

title: RATE HOPES PUSH DOW 11.49 HIGHER
description: Expectations of a cut in the discount rate pushed up the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday by 11.49 points, to 907.74, in moderate trading.

title: Yankees Fall in 12th, 3-2
description: If the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox had been among the teams still fighting for division championships, the game they played at Yankee Stadium last night would have been one of the most scintillating in their long rivalry.

title: BEGIN CALLS BLAMING OF ISRAEL FOR KILLINGS 'TOTALLY DESPICABLE'
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in a letter made public today by the Israeli Embassy, said that "the whole campaign over the last 10 days" to blame Israel for the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut was "unbelievable, fantastic and totally despicable."

title: UNIONS SHUT DOWN 2 NEWSPAPERS IN PHILADELPHIA IN WAGE DISPUTE
description: A tentative contract agreement was reached tonight to end a one-day strike of 4,400 employees at The Inquirer and The Daily News, according to the lawyer for one of the eight striking unions at the city's two newspapers

title: GROMYKO CONDEMNS REAGAN'S PROPOSALS ON MIDEAST
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, today described President Reagan's Middle East plan as a ''diktat'' that demonstrates ''hostility toward Arabs.''

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1982
description: International Helmut Schmidt was ousted as Chancellor of West Germany by Parliament, which replaced him with Helmut Kohl, leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Party. Mr. Kohl became the sixth Chancellor as Parliament voted no confidence in Mr. Schmidt. (Page 1, Column 4.) Iranian troops opened a new offensive along the Iranian-Iraqi border 100 miles northeast of Baghdad. American intelligence sources reported that Iraqi forces were holding their ground just inside Iran and had lashed back with several counterattacks. (1:5.)

title: OUTSIDE STORAGE FOR OUT-OF-SEASON CLOTHES
description: ''No matter how spacious the apartment, New Yorkers never seem to have enough closets,'' says Irwin Vassall of Neet Cleaners and Dyers, 2387 Broadway. ''Even people who live in 20-room apartments overlooking Central Park worry about where they are going to store the clothes they won't be wearing during the current season.''

title: Soviet Aircraft Keep a Watch On Maneuvers by U.S. Navy
description: Soviet aircraft have repeatedly buzzed a 15-ship United States naval task force on exercises in the north Pacific, the Navy command here said today.

title: 2 Hangings in Zimbabwe Are First Since 1980
description: Two Zimbabwe dissidents convicted of murder have been hanged in the country's first executions since independence in 1980, a Government spokesman said today.

title: JUSTICE REQUIRES CHILD TO TESTIFY TO GRAND JURY
description: A 10-year-old boy must testify before a grand jury that is investigating a burglary, despite his parents' fear that the experience will be too traumatic for him, a Manhattan judge ruled yesterday.

title: IN FROM THE COLD TO A SPY REUNION
description: They were virtually all ''old boys'' and they were all in from the cold today. There were no disguises, no pseudonyms, no forged documents, no coded messages. This time the operatives who worked behind enemy lines, flew reconnaissance missions and conducted the nation's espionage work lingered in the hotel lobby and pinned on their plastic name tags.

title: Bridge: Record Number of Players To Compete in World Play
description: The world championships to be played here for the next two weeks will have far more competitors than any comparable event in the history of the game.

title: Workers at Caterpillar Strike in Five States
description: By United Press International Striking employees of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in five states manned picket lines yesterday with little hope that their strike against the farm equipment manufacturer would come to an early end.

title: New York Day By Day
description: A Face in the Cab

title: A 'NEW YORKER' REACTS TO INVASION OF HIS SPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Clippers Seek Buyer
description: Faced with the prospect of having his team taken away from him at a meeting of National Basketball Association owners on Oct. 13, Donald T. Sterling has confirmed that he is looking for a buyer for the San Diego Clippers, a team that he bought a little more than a year ago. ''I am not sure I was ready to own a pro team,'' said Sterling.

title: Miss Gaynor Off Critical List
description: The actress Janet Gaynor, injured in a Sept. 5 automobile accident, was removed from the critical list today at San Francisco General Hospital, and her condition was described as ''serious but stable.'' The 75-year-old actress was in the intensive care unit, where she is expected to remain two more weeks, a hospital spokesman said.

title: PEKING AFFIRMS IMPORTANCE OF U.S. TIES
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China told Secretary of State George P. Shultz yesterday that regardless of some current problems, ''the development of relations between our two countries is of fundamental importance to the two peoples.''

title: JAZZ: RICKY FORD, TENOR SAX, WITH QUARTET
description: A jazz concert by a quartet led by the tenor saxophonist Ricky Ford at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday evening was described in the program as ''his second annual Carnegie Recital Hall concert.'' If Mr. Ford plans to continue his concerts there annually, he might consider how to make the best use of this tiny hall.

title: MARINE UNITS MOVING CAUTIOUSLY INTO SHELL-LITTERED AREAS OF BEIRUT
description: United States marines took up positions in the vicinity of Beirut International Airport today, using ''extreme caution'' in moving into areas littered with unexpended explosives.

title: REAGAN ENTERTAINS JUSTICES
description: President Reagan acted as host today at an elegant luncheon for the Supreme Court Justices and politely told his guests that he and other Americans do not always agree with their rulings.

title: WITNESS IN GIBSON TRIAL TELLS OF MAILING PAYCHECKS
description: A prosecution witness testified today that late in 1979 the former Newark City Councilman accused of defrauding taxpayers of $115,000 through a ''no show'' job asked to have his paychecks mailed to him at his home in Florida.

title: YES VIRGINIA, NEW YORKERS ONCE DIALED EXCHANGES
description: It is now a full 20 years since New York Telephone introduced the all-digit phone number. An entire generation has grown to maturity using numbers instead of names.

title: MUSIC: SHIRLEY VERRETT
description: The New York Philharmonic has become the Shirley Verrett Show the last few weeks. Miss Verrett, the American soprano, sang her own set of concerts for subscription listeners last week, and Friday afternoon she replaced another soprano, Montserrat Caballe, who has been ill and was unable to appear.

title: OLYMPIAN AHEAD OF HER TIME
description: W hen many of the current women's liberation adherents were just a gleam in their mother's eye, Fanny Blankers-Koen was defying public opinion and becoming the greatest woman athlete in the world. She set world records in seven track-and-field events.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Battle of 'Inchon'

title: PRO FOOTBALL TALKS STAY DEADLOCKED
description: After only four hours of meetings and not more than 90 minutes in joint session, negotiators for the National Football League players and the owners broke off contract talks this afternoon, with nothing resolved.

title: CORPORATE HELPERS OF A SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVESTER-AUSTRALIA PUT IN RECEIVERSHIP
description: The debt-ridden International Harvester Company announced today that its Australian subsidiary would go into courtsupervised receivership, the equivalent of bankruptcy proceedings in this country.

title: Anthony J. Cafiero Dies at 82; Judge and Legislator in Jersey
description: Anthony J. Cafiero, a former New Jersey Superior Court judge and State Senator, died Tuesday at Burdette Tomlin Memorial Hospital in Middle Township, N.J. He was 82 years old, and lived in Middle Township.

title: BONN PARLIAMENT VOTES OUT SCHMIDT AND ELECTS KOHL
description: Helmut Kohl, leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Party, was elected the sixth Chancellor of West Germany today, replacing Helmut Schmidt after a noconfidence vote in Parliament.

title: SQUATTER HELD IN KILLING OF BOY IN BROOKLYN IS CALLED A LONER
description: The man charged with fatally stabbing a 12-year-old boy and wounding his 10-year-old sister in their Brooklyn apartment Thursday was described yesterday as a loner who lived rent-free with six dogs in the building's basement and was occasionally cared for by tenants.

title: 2d Suspect Seized In Queens Slaying
description: A second suspect has been arrested and charged with murder in the suffocation slaying last month of a 91-year-old Queens woman, the police said yesterday.

title: Greyhound Cuts Another 245 Jobs
description: The Greyhound Corporation said it had eliminated another 245 jobs in its Greyhound Lines transportation division to cut costs.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1982; Markets
description: The basic money supply rose $400 million in the week ended Sept. 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The gain was modest, but it shocked economists and credit market participants, who had expected a decline of a few billion dollars. Interest rates, down earlier, rose sharply late in the day, closing slightly higher. (Page 33.)

title: Company News; Libbey Shares Sold by G.&W.
description: A British company, Pilkington Brothers P.L.C., has agreed to pay about $108 million in cash to Gulf and Western Industries for Gulf's 27.3 percent common stock interest in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, a diversified industrial manufacturer with 49 percent of its turnover in flat glass products.

title: HARRY S. SAMUELS
description: Harry S. Samuels, a lawyer who specialized in corporate mergers, died Monday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Nastase's Burden
description: Ilie Nastase is in Mexico City playing for Rumania against Mexico in tennis matches for the 1983 Davis Cup. He says his mind sometimes drifts to December, when the first Ilie Nastase Hamptons Invitational, a $305,000, 24-man tournament, will be played in North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: NIEKRO KEEPS BRAVES IN LEAD
description: Atlanta's Phil Niekro, who is not even a power pitcher, became a power hitter tonight. Niekro's seventh home run of his career, and his first in more than six years, broke open a 1-0 game in the eighth inning and helped give the Braves a 4-0 victory over San Diego.
