The victory preserved a onegame lead over Los Angeles with two to play and moved Atlanta one step closer to its first National League West championship since 1969.

title: CHAMBER: LAURENTIANS
description: Anthony Burgess is known as a novelist, but not so known as a secret composer. Yet compose he does, and not badly, as was proved by the second and apparently final performance of his setting of T.S. Eliot's ''The Waste Land'' Thursday night by the Laurentian Chamber Players in the Abraham Goodman House. Eliot's widow and publisher have permitted only two performances. The first was given by the same forces at Sarah Lawrence College, from which these musicians derive their employment and corporate name, in 1979.

title: N.I.T. Director Isn't Giving Up
description: With the National Collegiate Athletic Association tying up more and more major colleges for its annual Division I basketball championship, the National Invitation Tournament, which gets the leftovers, seems in trouble. Peter A. Carlesimo, the N.I.T.'s executive director, says his tournament will survive.

title: U.S. SEEKS TIGHTER CURBS ON EQUIPMENT FOR SOVIET
description: The Reagan Administration, in its broadest effort yet to slow the sale of technology to the Soviet Union, is seeking to toughen the system that the United States and its allies use to control the flow of equipment to Communist countries, according to Defense and Commerce Department officials.

title: A Jail Plan That Can Work
description: Jails are ugly places, and they generate uglier feelings. Talk of building a new one in New York arouses such fierce neighborhood reaction that political leaders run for cover. Yet the need for new jails remains acute. The city's latest jail proposal suggests a way around the political obstacles. It merits the support of the City Planning Commission and Board of Estimate.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pedestrian-Bicycle Wars

title: Remedies for the Ailing Infrastructure
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fred Grgurev, who scored 44 goals and had 25 assists for the New York Arrows during the 1980-81 season, signed a two-year contract with the Arrows, who have won the Major Indoor Soccer League championship four times. Last season, Grgurev played for the New Jersey Rockets, scoring 27 goals and picking up 17 assists. ... Ron LeFlore, the White Sox outfielder who was arrested Thursday by Chicago narcotics officers on charges of possessing a controlled substance and failing to register two weapons, was suspended by the team for the remaining three games of the season. He will be paid, however.

title: ORDERS LOWEST IN 2 YEARS
description: In another negative economic report, the Commerce Department said today that new orders for manufactured goods fell 2.8 percent in August, to the lowest level in two years.

title: Dutch Curb South Africans
description: South Africans will need a visa to enter the Netherlands from Jan. 1, the Foreign Ministry said today, indicating Dutch opposition to the policy of apartheid.

title: IRANIANS MOUNT MAJOR OFFENSIVE ON IRAQI BORDER
description: The Teheran radio said many people were killed and hundreds injured when a bomb exploded in Teheran, Reuters reported. Page 3. By DREW MIDDLETON

title: TEHERAN BLAST SAID TO KILL MANY
description: Many people were killed and hundreds were wounded when a bomb exploded in central Teheran Friday night, destroying a five-story hotel and three passing buses, the Teheran radio said today.

title: ROOM FOR MORE THAN THE MAJOR PARTIES
description: To the Editor:

title: AWAIT HOUSE ACTION
description: The Senate, preparing to head home to the voters, has passed anticrime legislation intended to impose stiffer prison terms on drug pushers, violent criminals and people who repeatedly commit ''street crime.''

title: Sharp Tremor, Largest of 5, Shakes California Community
description: A sharp earthquake, the largest of five temblors in four days, jolted a sparsely populated region in the high desert today, dumping merchandise from shelves and waking residents here but causing no injuries.

title: About New York
description: The class on social climbing met the other night in an office filled with high-gloss burgundy furniture, stock decorator art objects and angular silk flowers in low vases. It was, naturally, in a building just off Fifth Avenue. Champagne was served in plastic cups, and then Stephen M. Pollan gave the lecture.

title: COURT ORDERS PRODUCER TO PAY BACK INVESTORS
description: Ashton Springer, a co-producer of ''Eubie!'', ''Bubbling Brown Sugar'' and other shows, has been temporarily restrained from further Broadway producing, according to a court settlement approved this week.

title: POISON DEATHS BRING U.S. WARNING ON TYLENOL USE
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned consumers throughout the country yesterday to stop using Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules until investigators could trace the source of cyanide-tainted capsules that have killed seven persons in the Chicago area since Wednesday.

title: Linseman Suspended
description: Ken Linseman, a center for the Edmonton Oilers, has been suspended for four games as a result of a match penalty he received Sept. 29 in a National Hockey League exhibition game against the Toronto Maple Leafs. He received the penalty for grabbing at the eyes of a Maple Leaf player during a fight. His suspension will take effect Oct. 7 unless he decides to start it from the beginning of the regular season on Tuesday, in which case he must inform league officials within 24 hours of the announcement of the suspension.

title: ARTHUR BRACKMAN
description: Arthur Brackman, founder and president of the Free-Lance Photographers Guild, died Sept. 24 at his home in East Hampton, L.I., after a long illness.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M. Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Philadelphia (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 7 P.M.) Milwaukee at Baltimore, or Oakland at Kansas City. If the Orioles are still in the race, their game will be shown to completion. A's-Royals is a backup game. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Los Angeles at San Francisco, Following game above. (Television - Channel 4, approximately 4 P.M.).

title: GLENN GOULD SUFFERS A STROKE
description: Glenn Gould, the pianist, was in a hospital in serious condition today after suffering a stroke, his family said. It was not known if his hands were paralyzed, the family indicated in a brief statement.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions yesterday about a new Massachusetts law on spending by hospitals incorrectly identified Dr. Mitchell T. Rabkin. He is president of Beth Israel Hospital in Boston.

title: Oldest Nuclear Generator Retired From Service
description: The nation's first commercial nuclear generating plant, the 25-year-old Shippingport Atomic Power Station, was retired from service today to begin a dismantling program expected to take five and a half years.

title: News Analysis
description: For the moment, the establishment of a judicial commission to investigate the Beirut massacre appears to have stabilized Prime Minister Menachem Begin's political coalition.

title: BILL OPENS TRADE ROLE TO BANKING
description: Senate and House conferees reported today that they had resolved their differences over the Export Trading Company Act - a bill that would authorize bank holding companies to set up companies that would sell a broad range of export services.

title: DEMOCRAT STILL LEADING IN COAST GOVERNOR RACE
description: The polls show that Californians may be ready to elect the nation's first elected black Governor to deal with the serious problems of government finance, economic recession and unemployment.

title: MANHATTAN PROSECUTORS TO SEEK INDICTMENT OF 83-YEAR-OLD PHYSICIAN ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Manhattan prosecutors will ask a grand jury next week to indict an 83-year-old physician on charges that she has illegally prescribed drugs from her West End Avenue office.

title: Alexander Gets Control of Bank
description: Alexander & Alexander Services announced that it controls more than 80 percent of Banque du Rhone et de la Tamise.

title: Nets and Knicks Open
description: The New Jersey Nets opened training camp yesterday at Jadwin Gymnasium on the Princeton campus with 15 players, including four rookies. They were without their No. 1 draft choice, Eric Floyd of Georgetown, but the general manager of the Nets, Bob MacKinnon, said the team was ''very close'' to an agreement with Floyd.

title: COMPUTER PICKS BEST WINE BUYS
description: IT is Saturday in New York and consumers are browsing through wine s hops, choosing a bottle or two for tonight's dinner, a case or two f or a party or perhaps even a greater quantity for laying away. One t hing they are noticing is the wide variations in price for the same w ines in different stores, variations that may amount to 50 percent o r more.

title: AEG Unit Closing
description: Neff Werke, a kitchen equipment subsidiary of AEG-Telefunken, disclosed that it had filed for bankruptcy. The company said that Bosch Siemens Hausgeraete, a joint venture of Siemens A.G. and Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., had acquired its trademark and begun negotiations aimed at the possible acquisition of Neff's assets.

title: A VIETNAM LOVE STORY
description: It may be hard to believe yet another story about the Vietnam War needs to be told, but, lost among the issues of Agent Orange and post-Vietnam syndrome, there is a love story.

title: GTE TO BUY SPRINT PHONE SYSTEM
description: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Southern Pacific Corporation to buy Southern Pacific's long-distance telephone operation and other communications assets.

title: MEXICO CRISIS SEEN AS A THREAT TO ALL
description: The President of Mexico, Jose Lopez Portillo, told the United Nations General Assembly today that Mexico's financial crisis was the crisis of all the third world and that it threatened the stability of the world monetary system.

title: U.S. Steel Sells Stake in Building
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it had sold an 81 percent interest in its 64-story headquarters building here for $200 million and expects to sell the remaining interest by December. The purchaser was the California Public Employees Retirees System.

title: Reinvestment Of Dividends
description: DIVIDEND reinvestment plans, which were born in the 1960's and matured in the 1970's, appear to be on a growth path for the 1980's. For more and more corporations are offering them to their stockholders today - and throwing in some fillips besides.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is the most political White House I have ever dealt with. It reminds me of a combination of Johnson and Nixon, and if that doesn't frighten people, we've got a problem.'' - Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri. (1:6.) *

title: HOUSE, BY 46 VOTES, REJECTS PROPOSAL ON A BUDGET LIMIT
description: The House of Representatives today decisively defeated a proposed constitutional amendment mandating a balanced Federal budget. The vote was 236 to 187 in favor of the proposal, but that fell 46 votes short of the two-thirds necessary to approve an amendment for consideration by the states. Transcript of news session, page 13.

title: SENATE VOTES TO EXTEND COMMODITIES COMMISSION
description: The Senate today approved legislation extending the life of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for two years. At the same time it defeated an Administration proposal to levy a fee on all commodity futures transactions that was intended to finance most of the agency's operations.

title:
Patents;
New Way To Produce Peroxide
description: WASHINGTON THE Cetus Corporation in Berkeley, Calif., which describes itself as the oldest and largest biotechnology company, received a patent this week on a process for the production of valuable industrial materials.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: CITY OPERA: 'ALCESTE'
description: Gluck's ''Alceste'' has landmark status in opera history, no denying that. And there may well be a way to stage this respected work that would make it seem as majestically moving as it must have been for 18th-century audiences. Its simplicity and stress on the drama itself came as a shock in an era when being excited by vocal stunts and virtuosic ornamentation had become the main reason for going to the opera.

title: Leach One-Hitter Tops Phils
description: If it had not been the final weekend of the season with nothing at stake, the Mets and Philadelphia Phillies might have remembered it as a classic of sorts: Terry Leach and John Denny pitched one-hitters against each other for nine scoreless innings.

title: Hospodar Traded to Whalers
description: The Hartford Whalers and New York Rangers were involved in a trade and an exhibition game today. The Whalers obtained Kent-Erik Andersson, a right wing, from the Minnesota North Stars this afternoon and traded him to the Rangers for Ed Hospodar.

title: OFFICER IN 'ANGEL' CASE WOUNDED BY ROBBERS
description: An off-duty Newark police officer was shot and critically wounded today in a robbery here.

title: The City; Jury Awards Girl $29.2 Million
description: A 5-year-old girl unable to walk, see or talk was awarded $29,220,000 by a Brooklyn jury yesterday after her lawyer had argued that her condition developed because of a careless diagnosis of an illness when she was 6 months old.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP BY 1.6%
description: Spending for new construction rose 1.6 percent in August, the Government reported today. It was the fifth gain in the last six months for an industry long stifled by high interest rates.

title: REAGAN MEETS PANAMA LEADER
description: President Reagan, who strongly opposed the Panama Canal treaties, told President Ricardo de la Espriella of Panama today that he was ''looking forward to a warm working relationship'' between their two countries.

title: FANFARE AS DISNEY OPENS PARK
description: It may be some time before Wall Street echoes the trumpet fanfares that heralded today's opening of Walt Disney's futuristic addition to the Disney World complex in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Sanctions Hurting In France; Dresser Order Shifted by G.E.
description: An order for gas compressors has been switched from a company in France to one in New York State as a direct result of President Reagan's sanctions against European companies supplying equipment for the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLEASED BY BONN'S CONSERVATIVE TURN
description: Reagan Administration officials today made plain their satisfaction that West Germany will now have a Christian Democratic-led conservative Government.

title: Boeing 767 Order
description: The Boeing Company said that Thai Airways International had placed a $100 million order for two longrange versions of its new 767 series jetliner, the first airline to order the model.

title: New York Day by Day
description: A Sign of the Past

title: TEXT OF LETTER FROM BEGIN TO CRANSTON ON THE MASSACRE AND ISRAEL'S INQUIRY
description: Dear Senator Cranston, I thank you for your letter of Sept. 22. I read it with great attention, as its author and contents deserve. Let me say at the outset that you have a perfect right, even from afar, to criticize Israel's actions or proffer advice because you are a real friend of our people and country. You will agree, dear Senator, that an equal right is due to the democratically elected representative of our country to accept or not to be in a position to accept such criticism or advice.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Voters across America should count heads and take names. In November, we must elect representatives who will support the amendment when we propose it again in the spring.'' - President Reagan. (1:6.)

title: New Polish Labor Law Advances in Parliament
description: A committee of the Polish Parliament has approved the draft of a new labor law, setting the stage for a debate later this month that could lead to the dissolution of the suspended independent union Solidarity.

title: LEBANON REPORTEDLY URGES WIDER DEPLOYMENT AREA FOR U.S. FORCE
description: The Lebanese Government is reportedly urging the United States to deploy its Marine Corps peacekeeping contingent here in an area significantly larger than the one it now controls around Beirut International Airport. The purpose would be to put pressure on the Israelis to withdraw their forces entirely from the Beirut area.

title: REAGAN'S HOSPITAL PROPOSALS WOULD HURT THE POOR AND OLD
description: With the American Hospital Association cheering on the sidelines, the Administration wants to weaken or destroy many Federal regulations affecting 1,500 hospitals, thereby threatening the health and safety of millions of patients - especially the elderly and the poor.

title: Electronic Mail Rate Faulted by House Panel
description: The Postal Service charges too little for an electronic mail service used by businesses, and the difference must be made up by other customers, a House panel said today.

title: Dome Shares Skid On Aid-Plan News
description: Dome Petroleum shares lost more than a third of their value on the Toronto Stock Exchange today as investors reacted to the $6.6 billion refinancing package designed to save the troubled Canadian oil giant.

title:
PATENTS;
Solution Is Used to Stop Formation of Cataracts
description: At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, a process has been devised for preventing or reversing the formation of cataracts.

title: BRIEFING
description: How High Is High?

title: GERMANY'S GENIAL CHIEF
description: Helmut Kohl's virtues are not the established virtues of Bonn, where journalists and diplomats give high marks to irony, worldliness and expertise. Better than anyone, Helmut Schmidt is the incarnation of these sophisticated Bonn virtues.

title: Rockets' Reid Retires
description: Robert Reid, a 6-foot-8-inch swingman who had played with the Houston Rockets for five seasons, has announced his retirement from basketball to devote more time to the Pentecostal religion. His decision came the day before the Rockets opened training camp and led Coach Del Harris to say, ''One day ahead of camp, we're faced with the prospect of starting over offensively.''

title: Official Blames Tainted Pies For Food Poisoning of Child
description: Contaminated turkey pot pies served in public school lunches apparently resulted in the food poisoning of a child, a school official said today.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS BENEFIT WORKERS, LEHRMAN SAYS
description: Lewis E. Lehrman charged yesterday that half-empty state mental hospitals were being kept open for the benefit of state workers rather than patients.

title: DODGERS WIN,4-0
description: Rick Monday's grand-slam home run in the eighth inning broke up a scoreless pitching duel tonight and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GROMYKO
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assembly, as translated by the Soviet Mission:

title: 'LITTLE WARS,' LEBANESE MOOD PIECE
description: The Lebanon we see in Maroun Baghdadi's ''Little Wars'' is not the place we saw in another recent film about Lebanon, Volker Schlondorff's ''Circle of Deceit,'' nor even the place we see on the news. Unlike the German Mr. Schlondorff, who brought back a visitor's sensationalized vision of the battlefront, the Lebanese Mr. Baghdadi has made a much quieter film.

title: Battle of Heavyweights
description: Trevor Berbick and Renaldo Snipes, a pair of heavyweight contenders who both have lost to Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council champion, will meet today in a nationally televised 10-round bout at the Sands Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. Since he lost a 15-round decision to Holmes, Berbick has knocked out Conroy Nelson in two rounds and scored 10-round decisions over Muhammad Ali and Greg Page. Snipes, who was stopped by Holmes in the 11th round after knocking the champion down in the seventh round, has since fought a draw with Scott Frank and lost a 10-round decision to Tim Witherspoon.

title: Mrs. Reagan Heading West
description: Nancy Reagan will visit her family in Arizona next week and promote her new book in California. She will travel to Phoenix on Monday for an overnight visit with her mother, Mrs. Edith Davis. Mrs. Reagan's father, Dr. Loyal Davis, died in August. She will fly to Los Angeles on Tuesday to promote her new book, ''To Love a Child,'' concerning the foster grandparents program.

title:
PATENTS;
Presence of Speech Disclosed by Detector
description: A detector to disclose the presence of speech, as distinguished from noise, has been invented for use in satellite communication and speech storage systems.

title: PRISON EVALUATION OPENED TO PUBLIC VIEW AT A YOUTH INSTITUTION
description: Given a chance to say whatever he wanted, a diminutive 11-year-old boy with a reputation for conning and fighting glanced warily at the man with the note pad and asked, ''Why you asking me all them questions?''

title: CSX EARNINGS PLUMMET 59.6%
description: The CSX Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter plunged 59.6 percent, while revenues dropped 14.3 percent.

title: Another Derailed Tanker Explodes in Louisiana
description: A railroad tank car loaded with chemicals exploded into a vast fireball and mushroom cloud today, touching off more fires in the wreckage of a chemical freight train that derailed Tuesday, officials said.

title: 3d Bank Aide Is Found Dead
description: A senior official of the Banco Ambrosiano, which was declared insolvent last August, fell to his death today from the fourth floor of one of the bank's office buildings, a spokesman for the bank said. It was the third apparent suicide since June involving a bank figure.

title: SIMPSON-MAZZOLI IMMIGRATION BILL: BACK TO THE BRACERO FIASCO?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Sets Campus Visit
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts; Lauren Bacall, the actress, and James Taylor, the singer, will visit Northeastern University in Boston and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst on Tuesday in support of the nuclear freeze movement.

title: R. CONRAD COOPER DIES AT 79: EX-STEEL INDUSTRY NEGOTIATOR
description: R. Conrad Cooper, who was chief negotiator for the steel industry in its talks with the United Steelworkers Union from 1959 to 1968, died today at Sewickley Valley Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: China Plans Missile Shot Into East China Sea
description: China said tonight that it would launch an unarmed missile into the East China Sea to the northeast of Taiwan and west of Okinawa later this month, and warned shipping to keep clear.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CENTER PIECE

title: Economic Meeting Set
description: The annual meeting of the leaders of the world's seven major industrialized countries will take place next spring in Williamsburg, Va., the White House said today. The meetings, begun in 1975 and attended by the state heads of the United States, Canada, France, West Germany, Britain, Italy and Japan, deal with cooperation in tackling economic problems. A White House spokesman said the meeting would last two days.

title: WHY 5 PEOPLE FOUND THEMSELVES BANKRUPT
description: It was a strange situation for a high-ranking, well-paid officer of the United States Army. In a small room in a Federal courthouse, he and his wife sat facing creditors and responding to questions. Maj. Gen. Harvey D. Williams, who had heaped loans for two Cadillacs and a second mink coat for his wife onto a staggering pile of debts, had finally found himself in the same financial boat with a bartender in New Hope, Pa., a restaurant manager in nearby Phoenixville, a telephone operator in Essex County, N.J., an unemployed tool grinder in California and hundreds of thousands of others, the employed as well as the jobless, in soaring numbers across the country.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday incorrectly gave the time for an auction at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center. It is not tonight but Saturday, Oct. 16, at 8 P.M.

title: WAIFS OF GUATEMALA FIND A RESPITE FROM RAVAGES OF POVERTY AND WAR
description: He is a quiet little boy, even for this orphanage where many children have much to be silent about. And until now Domingo Caal had never talked about the day, four months ago, when he saw his parents murdered.

title: U.S. IS URGING A DELAY IN BANKRUPTCY RULING
description: The Justice Department today urged the Supreme Court to delay the effective date of its June 28 decision striking down key powers of Federal bankruptcy judges. If this were not done, the department said, the bankruptcy court system would be ''placed in constitutional limbo'' at midnight Monday.

title: Shcharansky Visit to U.S.
description: Avital Shcharansky, the wife of the imprisoned Soviet dissident, is planning to visit Washington Sunday to gather support to gain her husband's release. Anatoly Shcharansky is serving a 13-year sentence for treason. He recently began a hunger strike.

title: MARINE KILLED IN LEBANON JOKED ABOUT DEATH
description: The first casualties among the United States Marines serving in the multi-national peace-keeping force in Lebanon included two young marines carrying on family traditions of service in the corps.

title: GUNMEN THREATEN NUN AND PUPILS IN ROBBERY AT SOUTH BRONX SCHOOL
description: Three gunmen invaded a parochial school in the South Bronx yesterday and stole $3,000 in tuition money after putting a gun to the head of a nun and threatening to kill her and others, including three children, the police said.

title: FLORIDA DOCTOR ADMITS WOUNDS WERE SELF-INFLICTED
description: A doctor in northern Florida who had told the police he had been slashed and stabbed in two incidents after warning that a rural town had high rates of cancer admitted today that his wounds were self-inflicted.

title: SPECIALS: IT'S WISE TO ASK THE PRICE
description: After bad service, the most frequent complaint from readers about restaurants is the continuing practice of having captains or waiters describe daily specials not on the menu, and without stating prices. It is confusing enough to hear and remember everything so that one can make a choice; not knowing the prices makes the experience that much more harrowing.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $400 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $400 million in the latest reporting week, a modest gain but one that shocked economists and financial market participants who were expecting a decline of a few billion dollars.

title: N.C.R. COMMISSIONERS CLASH ON INDIAN PT. SAFETY INQUIRY
description: The five commissioners of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission clashed sharply with one another and drew strong criticism from members of Congress today at a House subcommittee hearing on the inquiry into safety at the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: PARLEY ON TV NEWS TO BE TELEVISED
description: CBS News will televise a one-hour prime-time documentary in December based on a conference about television's role and responsibilities in relation to terrorism, privacy and business. CBS News is sponsoring the conference with Columbia University.

title: Barring Raiders of the Lost Ark
description: Congress can write a constructive end to a bitter and protracted argument over how best to curb the plundering of ancient art. This is the meaning of the Senate Finance Committee's welcome reconsideration of a bill that would limit the mindless destruction of the past.

title: ROLL-CALL ON THE AMENDMENT
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 236 to 187 by which the House of Representatives refused today to approve a proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget. Although the ''yes'' votes were in the majority, approval by two-thirds of those voting was needed. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the amendment. Voting ''yes'' were 69 Democrats and 167 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 167 Democrats and 20 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. Representative Bob Stump of Arizona is running for a re-election as a Republican but for voting purposes in the current Congress has retained his listing as a Democrat. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes; Smith, yes.

title: TOP-LEVEL SHAKE-UP IN DORMITORY AGENCY IS ORDERED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced a shake-up and investigation of the State Dormitory Authority, which invested $304 million with a securities concern that went bankrupt.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES 10-WEEK INTERIM SPENDING BILL
description: Congress today gave final approval to a 10-week stopgap spending bill, and President Reagan is expected to sign the legislation.

title: Keep an Eye on Hospital Care
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to relax regulation of participating hospitals ranks low on the hierarchy of reforms needed to control the costs of Medicare and Medicaid. Cost sharing, freer competition and new payment methods are far more important.

title: TALKS SUSPENDED A DAY IN TEANECK SCHOOL STRIKE
description: Talks between the Teaneck Board of Education and striking teachers and other school employees were suspended for one day today by a state mediator who said that both sides were ''intransigent'' and that their positions were ''locked in concrete.''

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's impromptu news conference in the White House briefing room yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable Network News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: LINGERING DAMAGE TO SALES OF TYLENOL IS EXPECTED
description: Industry analysts predicted yesterday that sales of the various varieties of Tylenol, which is the country's largest selling nonprescription pain relieving medication, would suffer some lingering damage from the deaths in Illinois, although no malfeasance or neglect by its manufacturers, Johnson & Johnson, has been suggested.

title: TO BRING THE HOMELESS IN FROM THE COLD
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GRACE ABOUNDING. By Maureen How- ard. 175 pages. Little, Brown. $13.95.

title: The Sky Is Loosening
description: Another detailed report tells us what we already know but would rather not think about - that our infrastructure is decomposing. A still-to-be-polished draft study by the Regional Plan Association - a private research body that has been analyzing conditions in New York City and its surrounding counties for 50 years - documents the magnitude of the decay ravaging the bridges, sewers, streets, rails and water tunnels that are the circulatory system of our daily lives and commerce.

title: JOE TORRE'S GOOD YEAR
description: LOS ANGELES T he manager of the Atlanta Braves sat in the office at one end of the clubhouse at Dodger Stadium and put the telegram back in its envelope. ''It's from the Judge Parker Band,'' Joe Torre said. ''They play at Gus Fletcher's Livery Stable and Music Hall in Marietta. Gus Fletcher was the town drunk. That's what they told me.''

title: BURGER BATTLE SHIFTS TO COURT
description: The battle of the burger has moved from the television screens to the courtrooms. The fight began with an advertising offensive by Burger King, the No.2 fast-hamburger chain, which has been losing its share of the market to McDonald's, the sales leader, and Wendy's, the fastexpanding No.3 chain.

title: Prestige Grows
description: Women's sports keep growing in partipication and prestige. Two measures of that progress will be evident here Monday night at the third Women's Sports Foundation annual awards dinner.

title: PHALANGISTS SEIZE SUSPECT IN GEMAYEL KILLING
description: The Phalangist Party of President Amin Gemayel said today that the party's security agents had seized a man who confessed to killing Bashir Gemayel, the President-elect who was killed in a bomb explosion on Sept. 14, nine days before he was to take office.

title: New York Day By Day
description: A Party For Harlem School of Arts

title: Whitman Wins
description: Ed Whitman of Hackensack, the 1981 Dodge Open winner, won the second major title of his career when he closed with rounds of 72 and 68 today and captured the $25,000 Michelob-New Jersey PGA Championship at the Forsgate Country Club. Whitman, a 29-year-old assistant pro, came from one shot back in today's doubleround final and finished with a 72-hole total of 278, six under par for the 6,436-yard course and three shots ahead of Gary Ostrega of Montammy.

title: Transactions: FRIDAY
description: BASEBALL

title: Peace at Mars Hill
description: The anger on the Mars Hill (N.C.) College football team over the dismissal of Coach Claude (Hoot) Gibson early this week has apparently subsided. On Thursday, 65 of the 95 players on the team supported a boycott.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Cos. filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $200 million of debt securities.

title: STUDY FINDS NO MASS MARKET FOR NEWSPAPERS ON HOME TV
description: The vast majority of Americans are not yet prepared to read the news each day on the home television screen, according to researchers who led a two-year newspaper industry experiment offering that service.

title: THE WRONG DUKE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apache Petroleum Co. said it had completed the acquisition of Dow Chemical oil and gas holdings in the United States for about $400 million.

title: ANGELS WIN, 4-0, CLINCH A TIE
description: The California Angels clinched a tie for the American League West championship last night with a 4-0 triumph over the Texas Rangers at Anaheim.

title: TWO FIREMEN SPOTTED A LINK
description: It all started here, with a sore throat. Soon three people were dead in two towns, and later four more would die. Anxiety was spreading through Chicago's suburban cities. And a firefighter, Lieut. Philip Cappitelli, monitoring police radio calls at home on his day off, was growing suspicious. He called a friend, Richard Keyworth, a fellow firefighter and arson investigator in a neighboring town and aroused his suspicions.

title: AT PLAZA AND MET, ECHOES OF THE PAST
description: By Fred Ferretti A sense of the elegance of other eras was evoked and traditions were begun, in different ways, at two unusual parties held in two of the city's institutions along Fifth Avenue on Thursday night.

title: SENATORS IN CLASH OVER 'PEACE DAY'
description: Senator Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, charged on the floor of the Senate tonight that a move to proclaim Oct. 10 as National Peace Day ''will give aid and comfort to the enemies of this country.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 20. 1. To rebuild its depleted reserves of foreign exchange, Poland will market abroad gold and silver coins depicting the face of Pope John Paul II.

title: Hanoi Accepts U.S. Aid In Identifying Remains
description: Vietnam has agreed for the first time to allow United States technicians to visit and give training in the identification of human remains in the search for Americans missing since the Vietnam War, the State Department said today.

title: Marion Tait, Ex-Vassar Dean And Classicist, Is Dead at 70
description: Marion Tait, dean of Vassar College from 1948 to 1965, died Thursday at her home in Concord, Mass., after a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title:
CRAFTS;
'USELESS' CLAY, USEFUL ART
description: ''THE Art of Clay,'' featuring the works of 40 leading American ceramic artists, opened last weekend at The Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale. An interesting collection, it showcases very few utilitarian objects; that, along with the direction and title of the show, raises the perennial question of where crafts stop and art begins. Clearly the lines between the two have blurred in recent years, and this invitational show does not provide a capsule answer. What it does do, however, is instruct.

title: SCHOONER TO CARRY FREIGHT
description: BRIDGEPORT UNION Square Dock was drying after rain the night before, the sun was blanketed by layers of clouds and Long Island Sound was choppy. Passengers were boarding the schooner Phoenix for a sail around Bridgeport Harbor. The two-masted Phoenix had been the flagship of the 1982 Long Island Sound America, a 10-day event before Labor Day that celebrated the beauty of the Sound.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Introduction to Manhood

title: Cost of Passports for Adults Set to Rise to $35 From $10
description: Adults seeking passports will pay a fee of $35 instead of $10, but the new passports will be valid for 10 years instead of five, the State Department has announced.

title: 60 DIE IN TEHERAN AS BOMB BLAST RIPS DOWNTOWN SQUARE
description: At least 60 people were killed and 700 injured when a huge bomb exploded in Teheran's main square, the Iranian state radio reported today.

title: New York Feels Pinch
description: Economic conditions are beginning to show signs of softness in the Empire State, which during the past three years has been remarkably recession resistant.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption today on the Dance page of the Arts and Leisure section, announcing a new work by the Feld Ballet Company, is incorrectly captioned.

title: DEMOCRATS SHAPING ELECTION AS REFERENDUM ON ECONOMY
description: From Virginia to California, Democratic House candidates with serious hopes of ousting incumbent Republicans are making the 1982 election a referendum on the economy.

title: BRITON CHARGES SAUDI TORTURE
description: The Observer newspaper said today that a British businessman held without trial in Saudi Arabia for 11 months had been tortured by the police and given only ''derisory'' treatment for the injuries they inflicted.

title: LETTERS FROM OLD JAPAN
ON MARRIAGE, HOMES AND I.R.A'S
description: Below are some answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I was a widow and my present husband was a widower when we married several years ago. We settled in my house, sold his house and then made use of the tax law provision that allows someone to exclude up to $125,000 of the capital gain on the sale of a house if 55 or older. Now we want to put my house, which I owned with my first husband, into our joint names. But we're concerned that we may lose the right to claim the $125,000 exclusion on the house should we later sell it. Is our concern justified? A. Unfortunately, you have already sacrificed your right to claim the exclusion again. That is because it is an opportunity that can be claimed only once in a lifetime of a taxpayer - and in your case, marriage has made two separate taxpayers one.

title: CHINA'S PROGRESS HURTING LAND
description: China is causing widespread and serious damage to its natural environment in its effort to quadruple its economic output in the next 20 years, according to a survey of the published writings of more than a score of Chinese scientists.

title: BREACH WIDENS
description: With each side blaming the other for the impasse that continues, representatives for the National Football League players and the owners broke off negotiations today on a note of acrimony and frustration.

title: BEYOND AMERICAN OLIVES, THERE IS WIDE VARIETY
description: ANYONE who has ever wandered through Mediterranean open-air markets and seen the vats of varicolored olives glistening in the sunlight will recognize the possibilities of the olive. Some olives are soft and fleshy, bursting open like ripe persimmons; others are firm, others are wrinkled - the varieties seem almost endless. Some are shaped like tiny apples, some approach the perfect oval, the shapes are as diverse as the colors: purplish black, deep blue-green, straw yellow, dark red-wine, a spectrum of browns and greens from rich chocolate to chartreuse.

title: Sudden Rent Increases
description: Question: I have a rent-stabilized apartment that includes an indoor garage. In addition, I contracted to rent an outdoor parking space for $12 a month. Suddenly, the rent on the outdoor space was raised to $20 a month. Was this legal? ... C.B., Bronxville, N.Y. Answer: The Westchester County Rent Guidelines Board says you appear to have a legitimate complaint. The rent for any parking spaces reserved for rent-stabilized apartments is regulated by the same guidelines that govern the apartments themselves. As with apartments, these rents cannot be arbitrarily readjusted before the new guideline adjustment date. The current guidelines, which are still in effect because the board has not yet agreed on new ones for the year that began Friday, are 12, 15, and 18 percent for one- , two- and three-year leases, respectively. The board will attempt to set new limits at its November meeting. For information about filing a complaint, contact the board's office at Two World Trade Center, Room 5870, New York, N.Y. 10047; telephone (212) 488-7142.

title: Edgemont Upsets Pleasantville, 6-0, on Snisky's Late Score
description: Edgemont defeated Pleasantville, 6-0, in a major upset. Coach Jim Gold's Panthers, playing their first varsity season after dropping their football program in 1979, won the game on Gary Snisky's 8-yard run with seven minutes remaining. Pleasantville won all 10 games last year and opened with a shutout victory against Bronxville last week.

title: BEHIND-SCENES LIFE OF J. ROBERT DOLAN
description: WHITE PLAINS ONE of the things that happens when politicians march off to autumnal campaigns is that administrators, like warriors' wives, have to stay behind and do the chores.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Sailing Gear Discounted At City Island Center

title: ANGELS CAPTURE WESTERN TITLE
description: The California Angels took the lead on Fred Lynn's two-run homer in the fifth inning today and held on to clinch the American League Western Division title by beating the Texas Rangers, 6-4. The title was the first for Gene Mauch in his 23 years of managing.

title: Devon Cream Tea
description: To the Editor: The article about Devon cream teas (''Britain's Best at Teatime,'' Travel, Sept. 5) brought back memories for me, for during the Munich crises (1939) I was evacuated at the age of 8 1/2 to the village of Otterton and lived for several months with the miller and his wife, an elderly couple whose name was George Rawlings (I only knew his wife as Auntie). I spent many happy hours in the mill, which is driven by a water wheel and a race drawn from the River Otter, named for the animals that lived in the water.

title: Parley on Noise Control To Be Held Nov 4th
description: The plea by Lucy Burke Meyer for a moratorium on noise (Opinion Page, Sept. 12) is well taken. Yes, we do have too much noise and, yes, a day on which all noise would be banned might be an effective gesture to increase awareness of noise while giving our nerves a rest.

title: Q&A
description: Question:We are planning a trip abroad in February, leaving Kennedy International Airport on a Saturday morning. Last year the bank branch in the United Airlines terminal was closed on Saturday. Is there any other place at JFK, open 24 hours a day and weekends, to exchange currency? We will need foreign currency for the first weekend abroad before the banks open. - J.D., Westport, Conn. Answer:There are no currency-exchange services available on a roundthe-clock basis at Kennedy Airport; such services are planned in conjunction with flight schedules and are offered by American Express, Citibank and Deak-Perera. All three have locations near the exits to ground transportation on the first floor of the international arrivals and departures building.

title: ECONOMIC ILLNESS
description: To the Business Editor: Paul L. Pryde quite convincingly asserts that the Reagan Administration is not using the tax system to help solve the nation's unemployment problems because its tax legislation was designed to ''encourage the substitution of capital for labor.''

title: JUstice Joins Busing Foes
description: The Reagan Adminstration has always been cool toward racial busing, but last week it turned frosty. In a shift that officials insisted represented no change in policy, the Justice Department said it might, when requested, enter busing cases on the side of those who opposed that method of school integration.

title: THE RUN BEGINS FOR CUOMO, LEHRMAN
description: By Frank Lynn, Ronald Smothers, Maurice Carroll and E. J. Dionne Jr.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Dr. T.V. Tupper Weds Eileen Spinner
description: Eileen Elizabeth Spinner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Spinner Jr. of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Dr. Thomas Virgil Tupper, son of Althea R. Tupper of Bay City, Mich., and the late Rev. Thomas C. Tupper. The Rev. Cosmo Saporito performed the ceremony at St. Bernadette's Roman Catholic Church.

title: WILL WE REALLY GET A TV STATION?
description: IT WON'T be long before New Jersey finally gets its very own commercial TV station. The tax bill recently signed by President Reagan contained a special amendment inserted by Senator Bill Bradley that paves the way for WOR-TV (Channel 9) to move from New York City to the Garden State.

title: Seeing Europe
description: To the Editor: The answer in Q and A (Travel, Aug. 15) to the Utahan who wanted advice on seeing Europe as fully but as economically as possible omitted one of the best tools available to a traveler in his category. This is George Ferguson's ''Europe by Eurail,'' '82-'83 edition, available from Forsyth Travel Library, P.O. Box 2975, Shawnee Mission, Kan. 66201, for $8.95 plus $1 for postage.

title: ARTISTS' WORKS ARE AT THE CENTER OF THE ACTION
description: Painters and sculptors have been drawn to photography since its beginnings. Many of the medium's early practitioners - Roger Fenton and Henri Le Secq, for example - studied painting before converting to the camera. Others, such as Edgar Degas and Thomas Eakins, made photography a sideline while continuing successful careers in painting. Nevertheless, a division between what was art and what was photography was established, and it persisted into the 20th century. Man Ray, who practiced drawing, painting, sculpture and photography, at one point felt compelled to publish a pamphlet called ''Photography Is Not Art;'' later he reversed himself, saying, ''for me, art is not photography.''

title: Military Analysis
description: Early this week two United States aircraft carriers and their battle groups began manuevers in the north Pacific south of the

title: MEMORIES ARE MADE OF THIS
description: Many generalizations can be offered on the way in which a food column - particularly one with recipes - is created. It might have to do with a new trend - say the present emphasis in America on the cooking of pasta. It might have to do with the emergence and public awareness of uncommon flavors - fresh coriander leaves, to choose one example. Or it might have to do with pure nostalgia - food associations from the past.

title: MANY IN CONGRESS SAY THE BUDGET OVERWHELMS OTHER KEY CONCERNS
description: House and Senate members, heading home to concentrate on re-election campaigns, expressed resentment today that fiscal issues had preoccupied the last 20 months of this session of Congress at the expense of other legislation.

title: ISRAELI FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS HE EXPECTS PULLOUT FROM LEBANON THIS YEAR
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel says he expects that all Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces will be withdrawn from Lebanon by the end of the year under a timetable to be negotiated by the United States.

title: Second Helpings
description: An affluent person is someone who can afford seconds: a second house, a second car, a second marriage, a second drink. Americans, fond of asking for extra helpings in all three categories, have been very rich indeed.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SUNDAY CONCERTS
description: Alone or as duets, musical artists are getting the nod this fall in a Sunday afternoon series of 10 free concerts that the Nassau Office of Cultural Development is sponsoring at libraries throughout the county. Playing Mozart, Beethoven, Chopin and Brahms, the pianist Ian Shapinsky opens the series today at 3 P.M. at the Peninsula Public Library, 280 Central Avenue in Lawrence.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Movie on a Movie The problems that plagued the filming of Werner Herzog's ''Fitzcarraldo'' were no secret. During production - four-and-onehalf years - five persons died in a supply plane crash, the crew lived in fear of hostile Indians and torrential rains, the leading actor Jason Robards quit the film and was replaced by Klaus Kinski and Mick Jagger couldn't keep up with the schedule and he also decided he had to leave - his part was written out of the movie. Mr. Herzog virtually defied death - and implicitly required his crew to do so - to complete his film about a man who wanted to build an opera house in the middle of the Amazon jungle. ''Fitcarraldo'' will be shown at the closing night of the New York Film Festival next Sunday, Oct. 10 and will open in New York on Oct. 11 at the Paris Theater.

title: YANKEE DECLINE BRINGS VARIETY
description: To the Sports Editor: The Yankees' demise this year (''The Yankees: Anatomy of a Team's Decline,'' The New York Times, Sept. 19, 1982) reads like the ''Decline and Fall of the Holy Roman Empire.'' How boring it would be if the same team year after year had a vise grip on first place. Losers make winners possible and this year the Yankees have enabled other teams to quaff from the cup of success. How sweet it is! JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

title: TWO FINE OPERAS IN SEARCH OF A GOOD RENDITION
description: Virgil Thomson has his 85th birthday year tucked safely behind him, and should be basking in the praise that flowed his way. By now, one might think he would be happily ensconced in whatever pantheon we preserve for great American composers. But neither of his two operatic collaborations with Gertrude Stein, ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' and ''The Mother of Us All,'' has yet received a major production from a New York opera company.

title: GUYANA'S ECONOMY IN A SEVERE CRISIS
description: Guyana's long-stagnant economy has gone into a tailspin, pulling many of its citizens' living standard down with it.

title: Hospital Clerk Accused Of Threatening Marcos
description: A 57-year-old hospital clerk has been arrested by Federal agents and charged with threatening the life of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.

title: Julie Kuniholm Wed to John Weaver in Delaware
description: Julie Gibbs Kuniholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gardner Kuniholm of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married yesterday to John Mark Weaver, son of Mrs. Donald J. Morgandale of Wellsboro, Pa., and James Arthur Weaver of Tioga, Pa. The Rev. John C. Scobell performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: CITY OPERA: GLUCK'S 'ALCESTE' IS SUNG
description: Gluck's ''Alceste'' has landmark status in opera history, no denying that. And there may well be a way to stage this respected work that would make it seem as majestically moving as it must have been for 18th-century audiences. Its simplicity and stress on the drama itself came as a shock in an era when being excited by vocal stunts and virtuosic ornamentation had become the main reason for going to the opera.

title: DRAMA 'OUR TOWN' IN MADISON
description: MADISON LET Thornton Wilder have the first word. When describing ''Our Town,'' he wrote, in part: ''It is an attempt to find a value above all price for the smallest events in our daily life. I have made the claim as preposterous as possible, for I have set the village against the largest dimensions of time and place.''

title: VINTAGE HOLLYWOOD
description: Lester Glassner aptly describes his house on Manhattan's Lower East Side as ''a private museum.'' To a visitor, it also resembles a private fun house, chockablock as it is with a collection that has its origins in Mr. Glassner's childhood in the 1940's, when he whiled away idle hours at the movies and the five and dime.

title: Miss Brewer Is Married
description: Donna Marie Brewer, daughter of Dr. Timothy F. Brewer 3d and Norma Flicker Brewer, both of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to John Morris MacKenna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil S. MacKenna of Beverly Farms, Mass. The Rev. Edward M. Konopka performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in Essex, Conn.

title: STATE ASKED TO ASSUME COST OF COURT REPAIRS
description: New York State should begin assuming the cost of renovating and maintaining all court facilities throughout the state, a task force has recommended.

title: MR. KIPLING'S ALIBI ON ACCOUNTABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Tofel, Law Student, to Marry Jeanne Straus, Radio Station Official,
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Helen Straus, to Richard Jeffrey Tofel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Tofel of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: New York Times Magazine October 3, 1982
description: William Safire 10 On Language The Awful Tooth Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer The Male Weepie Robert Jastrow 30 The New Soviet Arms Buildup in Space James Reston 40 A Talk With Trudeau In an interview in Ottawa, Canada's Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Times columnist James Reston discuss the Atlantic alliance, multinationals, Canadian unity and world economy. Dorothy Seiberling 42 A New Kind of Quilt When 18 women artists decided to design quilts in collaboration with professional quilt makers, they learned a new respect for a traditional skill even as their group effort stretched it to the limit.

title: Newgate Callendar
description: Rick Boyer, who up to now has contributed only a Sherlock Holmes pastiche, now weighs in with BILLINGSGATE SHOAL (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.). It is the story of a dental surgeon who works out of Concord, Mass., but spends a great deal of time in his Cape cod house. A young fellow drowns under strange circumstances, and Dr. Adams feels that the death is somehow his fault. In order to ease his conscience, he starts investigating on his own, and suddenly things start happening to him.

title: A NEW KIND OF QUILT
description: Dorothy Seiberling is a former deputy editor of this magazine.

title: 3 Brazilian Politicians Die in a Copter Crash
description: The ruling party's candidate for governor in Bahia State and two federal congressmen were among 13 men killed near here Friday in a helicopter crash.

title: FOR MANY SOVIET ARTISTS IN EXILE, THESE ARE LEAN TIMES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Laurence Shames is a freelance writer with a special interest in the arts. By LAURENCE SHAMES

title: CORNCOB CAPITAL OF THE WORLD
description: TOM WEIL, a novelist, lives in St. Louis. By TOM WEIL

title: The View From Germany
description: John Vinocur complains that gaps in political insiderism at Bonn cocktail parties are filled with American-baiting (''Germany's Season of Discontent,'' Aug. 8). Should it surprise him that, as one close to the political action, he gets asked some direct questions about America's West European foreign policy, a policy that no one could represent as a model of consistency or diplomacy in the past few years? Undeniably, American-baiting is an old game in West Germany.

title: NEWEST CADILLACS ADD TO ELEGANCE
description: CHRYSLER CORPORATION said last week that it had cut $3 from the price of an average 1983 model. That reduction, company officials said, would keep Chrysler competitive with General Motors and Ford, both of which had jacked up their prices ever so slightly.

title: CASINOS LURING JET-SET DAY-TRIPPERS
description: "DAY TRIPPERS" - the casino-bound visitors who arrive in the morning and then head home at night - are not limited to automobiles and buses.

title: Lisa Edmondson And J.S. Kiernan, Plan Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Edmondson of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Edmondson, to John Sheridan Kiernan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Kiernan of Newtonville, N.Y.

title: Maria Regina Wins by 35-6
description: Maria Regina of Uniondale defeated Xavier of Manhattan, 35-6, yesterday, in a Catholic High Schools Football League game. The victory was the second of the season for undefeated Maria Regina, while Xavier suffered its first loss after an opening triumph.

title: No Headline
description: Penn Reaches 3-0, Best Start Since '68

title: Horse on His Mind
description: Ozzie Smith not only is excited about the prospects of the St. Louis Cardinals' reaching the World Series, which opens Oct. 12, but also is looking forward to Oct. 11, when Windy Disco, a horse he owns with his manager, Ed Gottlieb, will run in a six-furlong race at the Oak Tree meeting at Santa Anita. ''We've spent a year and a half getting her ready for this race,'' said Smith, the shortstop the Cardinals acquired from the San Diego Padres in a trade for Garry Templeton. ''It's great to have an athlete as super as she is and never have to worry about her becoming a free agent.''

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1982
description: International In Teheran, a bomb killed at least 60 people and injured 700 others in that city's main square, the Iranian state radio reported. Most of the casualties occured in nearby hotels, restaurants and passing buses. No group claimed responsibility for the bombing, which ocurred Friday night. But the Teheran radio blamed it on ''American mercenaries.'' (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Helen Watson Has Nuptials
description: Helen Mary Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Wentworth Blodgett, son of Lee Billings Blodgett of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and Lawrence W. Blodgett of Klllingworth, Conn. The Rev. James L. Kellaway performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: RED SOX SHUT OUT YANKEES
description: There went .500. With Brian Denman pitching his first major league shutout, the Boston Red Sox defeated the Yankees, 5-0, yesterday at Yankee Stadium and ended the Yankees' chances of finishing the season with as many victories as losses.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: In Praise of Nantucket
description: This letter is in praise of Olga Carlisle, who wrote ''In Praise of Nantucket'' (Aug. 8). The article captures the history and physical aspects of the island and manages to capture, in a most touching way, the feeling of the place and the people. Give us more. DANIEL S. SLAWSON, Cuernavaca, Mexico

title: A LOOK AT OLD WESTBURY'S FUTURE
description: Dr. Clyde J. Wingfield recently completed his first 100 days as the new president of the State University of New York College at Old Westbury. In an interview in his office, he talked with John T. McQuiston of The New York Times about the future of the 14-year-old college and the need for a tougher admissions policy.

title: Man, 28, Is Slain in Dispute
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally stabbed yesterday during a dispute with his brother, the police said. The victim, 28-year-old Larry Amaker of 342 Lafayette Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, was stabbed repeatedly in the chest and stomach during the dispute at 4:30 A.M., the police said. He was dead on arrival at St. Mary's Hospital. Mr. Amaker's brother, who was not identified, was taken into custody, and authorities said they were deciding whether to file charges.

title: DEBUNKING THE MYTH OF P.T.  BARNUM
description: ''As a general thing I have not 'duped the world' nor attempted to do so ...I have generally given people the worth of their money twice told. The Mermaid, Woolly Horse, Ploughing Elephant were merely used by me in advertising to attract attention.'' - From ''The Selected Letters of P. T. Barnum, edited by Arthur H. Saxon, to be published by the Columbia University Press.

title: FALL GLORY: VIRGINIA'S SKYLINE DRIVE
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES is a White House correspondent for The New York Times. By FRANCIS X. CLINES

title: No Headline
description: Some, no doubt, will complain that John Vinocur's assessment of West Germany -and, in particular, his portrayal of anti-Americanism there - was harsh or one-sided.

title: TROOPERS USE UNMARKED CARS
description: LIKE veteran bird watchers able to spy warblers in the underbrush, Connecticut speeders have become adept at spotting the two-tone blue state police cruisers on radar patrol. That won't be so easy for motorists from now on, because many troopers are using unmarked cars.

title: WOMAN'S GOAL IS TO RESTORE CARS
description: car restoration competition in Danbury in July, used to play in a corner of her parents' garage and gas station in Killingworth as a child.

title: Nancy P. Brace Is Married To Jeffrey Michael Kirsch
description: Nancy Page Brace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic F. Brace of Greenville, Mich., and Hutchinson Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Kirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kirsch of Westhampton Beach, L.I. Circuit Court Judge Dwight L. Geiger performed the ceremony in the garden of the Bay Harbor Club in Stuart, Fla.

title: Still Punching at 38
description: Dave Zyglewicz, 38 years old, has postponed his permanent retirement. In what was supposed to be his final bout, he came back from a seven-year absence from the ring and knocked out Clyde Mudgett, the Indiana cruiserweight champion, at 1 minute 44 seconds of the second round Friday night in Latham, N.Y. ''I want to fight in the 1990's,'' he said.

title: Of all the Islander forwards and defensemen whose skates flashed across the ice and flickered like a distant star that first season, 10 years ago, only Bobby Nystrom remains.
description: Why he remains has something to do with hard work, of course, and it has something to do with waking up at night in a cold sweat after all his money was stolen by his best friend - who also happened to be his agent.

title: Reds Lose 100th
description: Frank DiPino and Vern Ruhle combined on a five-hitter tonight to lead the Houston Astros to a 4-2 victory over Cincinnati, which for the first time in the club's history has lost 100 games in a

title: STOKOWSKI'S ORCHESTRA IS RUNNING ITSELF NOW
description: The American Symphony Orchestra opens its 20th season today poised somewhere between its romantic past and its still unrealized ambitions. The first 10 years were dominated by its founder and conductor, Leopold Stokowski, and his withdrawal in 1972 almost killed the orchestra.

title: The Tylenol Poison Puzzle
description: What began last week with the death of a 12-year-old Chicago girl suffering from a simple cold became a nationwide hunt for cyanidetainted Extra-Strength Tylenol and for whoever put the poison in at least three lots of Tylenol capsules, marked MC 2880, 1910 MD and 1801 MA.

title: TREVOR NUNN RESHAPES 'CATS' FOR BROADWAY
description: Steve Lawson recently adapted Bernard Pomerance's play ''The Elephant Man'' for television.

title: DRAWING A BEAD ON PUBLIC MONUMENTS
description: The left bank of the Gowanus Canal, an unlovely piece of real estate in South Brooklyn, seems hardly the most propitious site for an outdoor art show. Yet there, at Smith and Fifth Streets, on a five-acre former dump rife with weeds, trash middens and expired auto bodies, blooms the Gowanus Memorial Art Yard. A city-owned facility preempted for the moment by sculptors, it - along with two other indoor locations - serves as a setting for ''The Monument Redefined,'' a vastly ambitious show with more than 150 participants, whose stated aim is to encourage new interpretations of the public monument.

title: Ann S. Thomas Bride Of Anthony W. Caner
description: Ann Stearns Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Thomas Jr. of North Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Anthony Wayne Caner, son of Mrs. David B. Harris of Cambridge, Mass., and Harrison K. Caner 3d of Dedham, Mass.

title: 'LEMON' LAW ON CARS IN EFFECT IN CONNECTICUT
description: A new law designed to make it easier for buyers of new cars and trucks in Connecticut to replace a ''lemon'' took effect yesterday.

title: MITTERRAND TRIES TO BLUNT CRITICISM ON THE ECONOMY
description: PARIS EVERY now and then Francois Mitterrand gets accused of falling into a kind of revisionist Gaullism. When the weekly economic stats once again fail to glisten, when no one leaning out an Elysee Palace window has heard an ovation for weeks, there's a familiar fallback position - words that want to take flight, the old lyricism, the evocation of a France-of-the-mind that de Gaulle saw as the ''Madonna in the frescoes.''

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE VANITY OF THE TAKEOVER GAME
description: LIKE poker players who have been engaged in an all-night high-stakesc ontest, three major American corporations have just staggered out o f the Merger Bar looking pretty roughed up.

title: A Way to Limit Wars of Attrition In Civil Suits
description: By all the rules of civil litigation it's the hired guns, the lawyers, who shoot it out while the judge waits for the dust to settle. Now the Judicial Conference, the top policy-making body for Federal courts, has proposed rule changes whose primary effect would be to put judges in the saddle with orders to make peace among litigants.

title: 'BOLL WEEVIL' FACES 'REAL DEMOCRAT' IN FLORIDA RUNOFF CONTEST TUESDAY
description: Will the real Democrat please stand up? That is the question dominating the Democratic primary in Florida's Fourth Congressional District. That contest will be decided in a runoff Tuesday by the voters of this seaside-and-citrus region in the northeastern corner of Florida.

title: LATEST TECHNOLOGY MAY SPAWN THE ELECTRONIC SEEATSHOP
description: The movement of factory jobs out of the United States and into countries where low wages prevail has long been a sore point with American labor unions. They have new cause for upset, because advances in computer and telecommunications technologies are beginning to move office jobs offshore as well.

title: EVEN SITUATION COMEDIES NEED ROOTS IN REALITY
description: It is nearly always impossible to predict on the basis of a first episode how a weekly series will develop, but there is no denying that some premieres can be irritating, others can be promising. As with all of the popular arts, some things on television have the basic assets of a feasible premise and the unmistakable signs of some talent toiling in the production process. Others appear to be desperate attempts to come up with any idea, no matter how silly or preposterous, that just might find itself a winner in the giant gamble of the audience ratings. For current example, there are two new situation comedies, both of which happen to be on NBC.

title: AROUND THE WORLD WITH A NEW STRATEGY
description: A CURRICULUMIN FLUX

title: MILAN: SUDDENLY NEXT SUMMER
description: Italian designers, many still shaking off the sands of a summer just ended, today begin unveiling in Milan what they have created for a summer a year away.

title: Ode to Harry Gray
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Harry Gray Is on the Prowl Again'' (Sept. 19) some of us find his prowling preferable to others' predatory practices, which lack grace if not money. In Harry Gray one has to scent A man for business ever meant, In others, this odd sense of smell, No brilliance sniffs therein to dwell. He's not alone, in his achieve, As others great success do weave, But his have lasted more than most, Which should itself win worthy toast. Some men their brilliance cannot hide, While others' glory would have cried, But earning good chance to well- lead, Will they success breed and then feed? The answer's different in each case, Because success has its own grace Which Harry treats us to with works, That others make look like mere clerks. RICHARD SHEMTOB

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We'll get him one way or the other. Even nuts make mistakes.

title: L.I. FISHERMEN ASK LONG-LINING BAN
description: COMMERCIAL fisherman on Long Island have asked the Federal Government for fast action on a proposal that would ban some foreign fishing fleets within 100 miles of the United States coastline in the peak fishing season.

title: MISUSE OF CREDIT CHARGED IN BENDIX TAKEOVER FIGHT
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, said today that bank credit totaling $5.6 billion was tied up throughout September in a ''spectacular misuse'' of savings committed to financing the takeover battle between the Bendix Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: AND NOW IT'S THE BUSES' TURN
description: ''To some extent, the bus station, even if it is only a bus stop, gives a community its very identity.'' - A bus industry executive testifying at the hearings on the bus deregulation bill. By ERNEST HOLSENDOLPH

title: Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Merriman Schmitz, Lisette Gallo Are Married
description: Lisette Gallo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Gallo Jr. of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Merriman Schmitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Schmitz of Chardon, Ohio. The Rev. Charles Quinn and the Rev. Peter J. Rofrano performed the ceremony at Our Saviour Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: A Dialogue of Fear
description: Whatever their actual words in meetings last week and again tomorrow, what are Secretary of State Shultz and Foreign Minister Gromyko saying to each other? We can pretty well guess.

title: Mater Dei Wins, 7-6
description: Bob Donahue completed a short pass for a touchdown and kicked the decisive extra point in the final quarter to lift Mater Dei over Keansburg, 7-6, yesterday in New Monmouth.

title: A CHILD WITH A COLD, COLD EYE
description: NOVEL ON YELLOW PAPER By Stevie Smith. 288 pp. New York: Pinnacle Books. Paper, $3.50. OVER THE FRONTIER By Stevie Smith. 288 pp. New York: Pinnacle Books. Paper, $3.50. THE HOLIDAY By Stevie Smith. 192 pp. New York: Pinnacle Books. Paper, $2.75.

title: THE EGO AND THE ART OF DAVID GEFFEN
description: DAVID GEFFEN'S phone rang all morning, the sound richocheting like c oins off the David Hockney paintings that hang serenely in his F ifth Avenue apartment. First, Sherry Lansing, the president of 20th C entury-Fox Productions, was on the phone. Then Steve Ross, the c hairman of Warner Communications. Mr. Geffen hung up. He knew he waso n a roll and smiled. The phone rang again.

title: HE WAS THE AUTHOR OF HIMSELF
description: THE NOEL COWARD DIARIES Edited by Graham Payn and Sheridan Morley. 698 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $22.50.

title: 36 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department cited 36 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, it named seven restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and three that were closed after failure to do so. VIOLATIONS Candle Bar, 309 Amsterdam Ave. Mike's Pizza, 2038 Amsterdam Ave. Blimpie's, 313 Ave. of the Americas. Kee Hong Bakery, 196 Canal St. Michael's Restaurant, 277 Church St. Las 2 Almendras, 117 Dyckman St. Fortune Express, 102 Greenwich St. Lenox Lunch, 280 Lenox Ave. Michele's Kitchen, 1392 Madison Ave. Bowery Savings Bank Employees Cafeteria, 1 Penn Plaza, concourse level. Pine Coffee Shop, 95 Trinity Pl. La Rueda Restaurant, 1581 St. Nicholas Ave. Observatory Snack Bar, 350 Fifth Ave., Empire State Building, 86th floor. Il Hwa Korean Ginseng Center, 401 Fifth Ave. Golden China, 119 E. 23d St. Mercantile Stores Co. Employees Cafeteria, 128 W. 31st St., sixth floor. Popeye's, 125 W. 42d St. Victory Sea Food, 313 W. 125th St. Carvel, 2083 Starling Ave., Bronx. Pan's Restaurant, 1965 University Ave., Bronx. Jennifer's Coffee Shop, 332 E. 149th St., Bronx. D & S Pizzeria, 424 Avenue P, Brooklyn. Al's Pizzeria, 451 Meeker Ave., Brooklyn. Masada Restaurant, 2178 Nostrand Ave., Brooklyn. Angelo Ices, 126 Scholes St., Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Real Man In the 1920's, Samuel Dashiell Hammett, a former detective, created a genre of American fiction: the hard-boiled detective story. Later, his stories and novels - such as ''The Maltese Falcon'' and ''The Thin Man'' - were made into movies.

title: Facing the Future With Optimism
description: Linda Flayton's recent article, ''Great Expectations? Not Quite'' (Opinion Page), encourages pessimism among youth. She urges us to scale down our expectations of tomorrow because the electricity for the spacious house of our dreams won't be available, as won't the gasoline for our luxury cars.

title:
DINING OUT;
CLASSIC FRENCH IN NYACK BISTRO
description: FOR almost a year, Raoul's has occupied the charming, American brick shell of Nyack's old Village Hall. Reine, Serge and Guy Raoul (owners of the first Raoul's, still on Manhattan's Prince Street), leaving the exterior untouched, have renovated the interior attractively and successfully in the French bistro tradition popular earlier this century. The bistro style begins at the entry doors, etched glass and warm oak that fold back exposing the entire front room and bar, the gleaming wood floors, sculptured pressed tin walls, fluted cast-iron columns rising high to ceilings and stately flower arrangements. The dining room beyond picks up the theme. And a storage house at the rear of the hall has become a sleek, open kitchen connected to the dining areas by a small jail that now keeps nothing but wines.

title: AMERICA'S PRODUCTIVITY BASE IS THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Brady to Stay in Senate For Postelection Session
description: Senator Nicholas Brady, Republican of New Jersey, says he plans to stay in the Senate through the postelection Congressional session rather than resign shortly after the November election, as he had earlier indicated.

title: IT'S JUDY BLUME, NEW YORKER
description: Judy Blume had a lot of fantasies when she was a little girl - she dreamed about being a detective, playing Esther Williams's younger sister in the movies, and having a Latin lover - and none of them came true. But her major fantasy did, for Mrs. Blume, at the age of 44, has just become a New Yorker, with a spanking new apartment overlooking the Hudson River, having moved from Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Federal Funds vs. Drunk Driving
description: Congress dangled a $125 million carrot before the states last week, approving legislation that would reward their efforts to get drunken drivers off the road. It was Congress's first attempt at a nationwide campaign against drunk driving, which accounted for about 25,000 deaths last year.

title: FIVE BEGIN NEW LIFE IN HOUSE FOR ELDERLY
description: OSSINING IN an unusual variation of the state's Enriched Housing program, five elderly county residents began living together last week in an 80-year-old Victorian house here. There are 27 residences and 225 people in the program statewide, but Ossining is the first community in which a house was bought and renovated specifically to provide a home for the ''frail elderly.''

title: NOVELS OF HISTORY AND IMAGINATION
description: THE SEA RUNNERS By Ivan Doig. 279 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. THE BAREFOOT BRIGADE By Douglas C. Jones. 313 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $15.50.

title: NEW PUSH IN THE U.S.
description: JOHANNESBURG WHEN Noel Phillips returned from the United States to his native South Africa in January 1981, he thought it would be, in his words, ''forever.'' Mr. Phillips had resigned as executive vice president for sales and marketing at Volkswagen's American subsidiary because he was tired of commuting between Detroit, New York and the home that he maintained in one of Johannesburg's affluent northern suburbs. His three daughters were at school in South Africa and his wife was eager to get back.

title: MARRIED AND ABANDONED
description: A NEW WOMAN By Janine Boissard. Translated by Mary Feeney. 195 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $11.95.THE CAGE By Susan Cheever. 180 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95.

title: A NUCLEAR FREEZE TO THIN UNEMPLOYMENT LINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Pass on Cover of Book Upsets Secret Service
description: The Secret Service judged a book by its cover and found it guilty. ''This Is Judy Woodruff at the White House,'' the memoir of a White House correspondent for NBC News, has just come out with a jacket bearing a picture of Miss Woodruff's White House press pass.

title: Detention Adds A Bitter Twist To Teacher Strike
description: Students may sometimes think of school as a prison, but for 151 teachers and other school employees in Teaneck, N.J., last week one actually was. They were held under guard in an elementary school auditorium after defying a court order to end their two-week strike.

title: Ellen Weld Has Bridal
description: Ellen Ludington Weld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Weld Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Alexander Chester Tilt, son of Albert Tilt 3d of Tetonia, Idaho, formerly of Greenwich, and the late Cornelia Murray. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: 6 PLEAD GUILTY IN FULTON MARKET INVESTIGATION
description: New criminal charges, several guilty pleas and another prison sentence have come out of the continuing investigation of organized crime in the Fulton Fish Market.

title: Peace, Ludolph Star as Irvington Overwhelms Union by 48-0
description: Keith Peace and Bill Ludolph each ran for two touchdowns, and a tight defense allowed only 15 yards as powerful Union rolled over Irvington, 48-0, yesterday in Union.

title: BRAVES CLINCH A TIE BY BEATING PADRES
description: The Atlanta Braves guaranteed themselves at least a tie for the National League West championship tonight with a 4-2 victory over San Diego that was a sideshow to what could safely be described as the largest birthday party in North America.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN OLD STANDBY IN WEST ORANGE
description: PALS CABIN remains a constant in a changing world. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the West Orange establishment, which opened in 1932 as a roadside stand selling hot dogs and hamburgers for 10 cents apiece.
