The restaurant grew like Topsy until now it is a sprawling, bustling steak house that can - and usually does - seat about 400 customers at a time.

title: NOTES FROM THE PIGSKIN ROAD
description: D. KEITH MANO is the author of seven novels, of which the latest, ''Take Five,'' was recently published by Doubleday. By D.KEITH MANO

title: Pittsburgh Fares Rise to $1
description: Mass transit fares for Pittsburgh commuters rise to $1 from 75 cents Sunday, making a ride with Port Authority Transit of Allegheny County one of the most expensive in the country. Commuters in Detroit and Fairbanks, Alaska, also pay a basic fare of $1, according to the American Public Transit Association.

title: Norwegian Party Fights Funds for Missiles
description: Norway's opposition Labor Party has declared its opposition to financing launchers for new North Atlantic Treaty Organization missiles in a move that could threaten the minority Conservative Party Government.

title: Fweeze, Wabbit!
description: Vivisectionists in Britain were breathing easier last week. Richard Adams resigned as president of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. In the climax of a long feud with the society's old guard, the author of ''Watership Down,'' a best-selling novel of cruelty to rabbits, quit just before he was to be fired. Mr. Adams accused the organization of ''institutional lethargy'' in failing to support the efforts of younger members who illegally freed laboratory animals.

title: 4 SUSPECTS IN OMEGA 7 BOMB PLOT SEIZED
description: Three men were arrested yesterday in New Jersey and one was seized in Florida by Federal agents investigating an attempt to bomb a Cuban diplomat's car in New York City two years ago.

title: A SCHOOL SERIES THAT INSPIRED
description: To the Sports Editor: The richest memories in sports are the oldest and glancing at a scholastic football score in the September 26 Times sports section proves it: John Jay 38, Erasmus 0. Here the Brooklyn high schools were playing an early-season game, one of the first heavy Saturdays of the season.

title: Salvador Rebels Report Gain
description: The leftist insurgents' Radio Venceremos said today that they had killed at least 14 Salvadoran Government soldiers in 11 attacks in the provinces of Usulutan, San Vicente and Cuscatlan over a seven-day period ending Thursday. Meanwhile, two Government contingents were reported moving toward guerrilla camps near Petacones and Montecillos in San Miguel Province.

title: WARMING YOUR HOUSE WITH THE SUN
description: THE Benjamins thought their oil bill was too high, so when they b uilt their new house, they decided to do something about it. Their n ew house is twice as large -3,000 square feet - as the old one, but t heir oil use has been cut by half. The difference is made up by the s un.

title: ENTRANTS MUST FILE BY NOV. 1 FOR '83 PULITZERS IN LITERATURE
description: All entries for hte 1983 Pulitzer Prizes in the five letters categories - fiction, history, poetry, biography-autobiography and general nonfiction - must be submitted to the Pulitzer Prize Office at Columbia University by Nov. 1, the university announced.

title: AN UNUSUAL SQUEEZE
description: For those who are trying to pick the winners in the world championships in Biarritz, France, where attention will be focused for the next two weeks, a question mark hangs over the performance of the Brazilian players. A few years back a group of brilliant young stars from Rio de Janeiro was riding high on the world scene. They had won the world Olympiad Team title in 1976 in Monte Carlo, and in 1978 in New Orleans they won the Olympiad Open Pairs title and finished second in a new team event for the Rosenblum Cup.

title: REPORT FINDS LAG IN TRAINING MILITARY LEADERS
description: Since World War II, military planning in the United States has suffered because ''education and experience has prepared few top officials to participate effectively,'' according to a study by the Congressional Research Service.

title: SHOPPING FOR THE SHOP OF YOUR DREAMS
description: MANY people who dream of opening a small shop to supplement family i ncome are often scared off by the difficulty in finding and paying f or just the right kind of space.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The debut recitalists of last week included four practitioners of instruments with a restricted repertory plus one with an instrument that has the broadest, oldest repertory of them all - the human voice.

title: Colleges Are Warned Of Enrollment Decline
description: College presidents may be deluding themselves if they think their institutions will not be affected by a 25 percent drop in the population of college age by the mid-1990's, a college trustees' group warns.

title: COLLEGE JOINS OTHERS ON L.I. IN SETTING TIES WITH BUSINESS
description: OLD WESTBURY CREATED 14 years ago as an experimental campus, designed to encourage the enrollment of minority and nontraditional students, the State University of New York's College at Old Westbury is taking steps to broaden its student base and create more contact with the Island's business and cultural commmunity.

title: Anthony Demas Takes Vivi Veras as Bride
description: Violetta Veras, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Veras of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Anthony Demas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Demas of Woodside, Queens. The Rev. Peter Kyriakos and the Rev. Theodore Baglaneas performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y.

title: A COMEDY-MYSTERY SET IN ENGLAND IN 1694
description: The New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center picks up in excitement with Peter Greenaway's fine, risky new English film, ''The Draughtsman's Contract.'' The film, which was first shown last night, will be screened again today at 4:30 P.M.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS DIG IN FOR TOUGH WINTER IN LEBANON
description: The Israeli Army is making preparations for a new, expensive and possibly demoralizing experience: winter in the Lebanese mountains.

title: Beefing Up the Thin Blue Line
description: For every person deemed fine enough for New York's finest it takes eight who think they are. With openings for about 5,000 city, transit and housing officers over the next few years and a little over a month before the deadline for the qualifying exam, the New York City Police Department was in the unaccustomed position of needing 40,000 candidates in a hurry.

title: Dougherty's Passes Lead Garden City Past Plainedge, 44-0
description: Sean Dougherty completed eight of nine passes for 138 yards and three touchdowns to lead Garden City to a 44-0 triumph over Plainedge in an American League Conference II-B game. In addition, Dougherty scored a touchdown and passed for a 2-point conversion. The junior quarterback is the son of Garden City Coach Doc Dougherty whose Trojans are undefeated in two games this season. Plainedge has a 0-1-1 record.

title: SELLING APARTMENTS TENANTS OCCUPY
description: "POOR Joe,'' says the cartoon character in the short televised film that backs up the campaign to sell cooperatives at Glen Oaks Village. ''Month after month he sends his hard-earned money to his landlord. Hey Joe! There's a better way - a co-op of your own!''

title: MICRONESIA MOVES TOWARD INDEPENDENCE
description: The United States has signed an agreement giving limited independence to the Federated States of Micronesia, a group of islands in the central Pacific that includes the site of the former major Japanese naval base of Truk.

title:
OPINION;
THREE GENERATIONS OUT OF THE MIDDLE EAST
description: THE two experiences are represented by a set of hand cymbals. One experience unfolded in New England, the other a generation later in Westchester. Study the miniature brass cymbals. They have been etched by different hands and so appear on the surface to be distictive. But strike them together and listen to the sound they make. They are identical.

title: Joseph T. Raho Marries Barbara Goodman in Rye
description: Barbara Emily Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lawrence Goodman of White Plains, was married yesterday to Joseph Thaddeus Raho, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Raho of Rye, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Peter Sidler performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: 45 Puerto Rico Children Hurt
description: A low wooden grandstand gave way under hundreds of schoolchildren Friday as they were watching a clown in a circus tent. The police said 45 children suffered injuries, most of them minor. The most serious injury was a broken leg.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: FOR those who have wondered why municipalities have difficulty living within their annual budgets, there is an explanation from officials in New Milford. They have made a ''conservative'' estimate that their legal expenses for this year may exceed their allocation by more than $40,000.

title: DEBATE CONTINUES ON DIESEL SUBS
description: WASHINGTON IN an unusual postscript on the Falkland Islands war, the performance of an Argentine submarine may have a bearing on the fortunes of Connecticut's Electric Boat shipyard.

title: PHALANGISTS IDENTIFY BOMBER OF GEMAYEL AS LEBANESE LEFTIST
description: The Phalangist Party's radio said today that the person who planted the bomb that killed President-elect Bashir Gemayel last month was a member of a Lebanese leftist group.

title: Margaret Spath Is Bride of Charles A. McLeod Jr.
description: Margaret Mary Spath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Spath of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Charles Anderson McLeod Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McLeod, also of Pelham Manor. Msgr. Vincent W. Jeffers performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Home Angle Emile Ardolino, who wrote the proposal for the ''Dance in America'' series and produced or directed almost all shows in that series, said: ''I obviously feel that dance has a place on TV and I don't think that one should compare it to the experience of dance in the theater. One is not better than the other.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL CHIEF CLAIMS A BUDGET VICTORY
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is claiming victory in her battle of the budget.

title: 4th Blast in Derailed Train Damages 20 Houses
description: The latest in a series of chemical explosions in a derailed train here damaged at least 20 houses, the state police discovered today.

title: Fiction: Breaking In
description: Thirty-two years ago this month, Fawcett Books published a first novel called ''The Brass Cupcake'' as a Gold Medal paperback original. Its first printing was 325,000 copies and its author was John D. MacDonald.

title: 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE' COMES TO 3 DINNER THEATERS
description: THE proliferation of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' has become a countrywide phenomenon. The 1879 Gilbert and Sullivan operetta is in the public domain, which means it is free for all producers who want to put on a sure-fire hit.

title: CRAFTS
description: AN ENTICING preview exhibition promises that the Morristown CraftMarket, which will take place at the Morristown Armory next weekend, will match the high standards it has set in other years.

title: POTATOES CALLED 'PEANUTS'
description: RIVERHEAD LONG ISLAND farmers never meant to grow peanuts, but that is what they are calling the dismally small potatoes dug out of 18,308 East End acres in the early days of the 1982 harvest.

title: ALCOHOLISM AGENCY'S EX-HEAD ACCUSED
description: TRENTOM THE State Attorney General is investigating charges that the former head of New Jersey's largest alcoholism services organization diverted public funds to his own use and left the agency with a budget deficit that could keep it from making payments to support local alcoholism councils around the state.

title: A SOPHISTICATED CHOICE OF SEAFOOD
description: PAPPAS opened in Williston Park a couple of years ago, and from the outset the quality of the seafood served was commendable. Not only has this quality been carefully maintained, but also the selection of fish and shellfish has now been expanded, making the restaurant more appealing than ever.

title: GROWTH POSING SEVERE THREAT TO THE OLD CITY OF DAMASCUS
description: This ancient oasis capital with its ramparts and palaces, mosques, public baths and caravanserais, is seriously threatened by modern times.

title:
GARDENING;
REVITALIZING AN OVERGROWN GARDEN
description: FALL is an excellent time for planting. Trees and shrubs planted in the fall get a head start on their spring-planted counterparts by having their root systems better established and more ready to grow with the coming of warm weather. Here are some suggestions for renovating or revitalizing an overgrown garden.

title: 100 AGENTS HUNT FOR KILLER IN 7 TYLENOL DEATHS
description: The death of a seventh victim from Tylenol capsules laced with deadly cyanide was confirmed today by the local authorities. Officials also reported finding, for the first time, contaminated capsules in an unsold bottle of Tylenol from a store shelf at a suburban shopping center.

title: LIBRARY MAY TRIM 2 REFERRAL PROGRAMS
description: THE Westchester Library System is preparing for possible reductions in two popular referral programs it sponsors -the Learning Network and the Adult Education Hotline.

title: INDIANS' CULTURE RECORDED IN YARN
description: NEW LONDON MEXICO'S Huichol Indians have no written language, but their rich mythology has been recorded through vividly colored strands of yarn. Pressed into intricate allegorical designs on plywood boards, the yarn is so bright that the effect is almost three-dimensional.

title: QUARTERBACKS AS RECIEVERS
description: To the Sports Editor: I was interested to read Gerald Eskenazi's article of September 13 about the Dolphin Jet game.

title: THE NEW SOVIET ARMS BUILDUP IN SPACE
description: Robert Jastrow is the founder of the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies and served as its director until his retirement last year. He is now a professor of earth science at Columbia University and Dartmouth College. On Oct. 4, 1957, the Soviet Union launched a 184-pound ball of machinery 560 miles above the earth. Called Sputnik I, this first artificial satellite circled the planet once every hour and 35 minutes and sent a steady stream of radio beeps back to earth.

title: Gregory Calotta Marries Anita M. Meluso in Jersey
description: Anita Marie Meluso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo J. Meluso of Wyckoff, N.J., was married there yesterday to Gregory Calotta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Calotta of Suffern, N.Y. The Rev. David Ernst performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church.

title: Don Holloschutz Weds Janice Eileen Ginsberg
description: Janice Eileen Ginsberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Ginsberg of Wyncote, Pa., was married yesterday to Don Holloschutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Holloschutz of New York. Rabbi Simeon Maslin performed the ceremony at Knesset Israel Synagogue in Elkins Park, Pa.

title: A VISUAL RACONTEUR AT JERSEY CITY COLLEGE
description: JERSEY CITY NARRATIVE painting sounds feasible enough as an idea. After all, given the prevailing creative muddle, who can say that the picture that tells a story is any less art than the one that doesn't?

title: A BOXING CONTENDER FROM WHITE PLAINS
description: foot-3 1/2-inch boxer, ''but before a bout, road work is a must.''

title: Journey In Medieval Europe
description: Journeys may be measured in distance or in time. Among those that may be measured in time, a series of tours scheduled for next year spans nearly seven centuries. In distance, it stretches across two countries and one channel.

title: LEHMAN ARTS CENTER STARTS THIRD SEASON
description: THE third season of the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx opened with a flurry yesterday, with a record of two solid years of successful programming behind it, a growing number of ticket holders and a performance by the Intimate P. D. Q. Bach, a group spoofing classical music.

title: SNIPES DEFEATS BERBICK
description: Renaldo Snipes chose not to run, but to stand and fight, and scored an impressive 10-round unanimous decision today over Trevor Berbick, who chose not to walk out only an hour and a half before the nationally televised bout.

title: FREE TESTS HELP LUPUS PATIENTS
description: ''ISTOPPED going to the doctor because paying the bills had become so hard,'' said Carol Goldklang of Plainview. That was back in 1976. Now, Mrs. Goldk@lang has a checkup every six weeks and, despite rising medical costs, her bills have dropped dramatically.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The recent cooking-school listing gave an incorrect telephone number for Chinese Home Cooking in Westbury. The number to call for information is 333-0019.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SHADOW By Blaise Cendrars. Translated and illustrated by Marcia Brown. Unpaged. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Bomb Kills 60 In Teheran
description: The Iranian regime has executed thousands of suspected enemies, but Teheran last week still was not secure.

title: Early Dining
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: AMTRAK'S IMPROVING TRACK RECORD
description: M embers of the Reagan Administration, who tried but failed to reduce the national rail system to an East Coast line last year, once joked that Amtrak trains were so unpredictable they would be an ideal basing system for the MX missile.

title: Adam J. Cirillo, 72, Dies; Led 10 City Champions
description: Adam John Cirillo, one of the most successful high school football coaches in the city, died yesterday at his home in Staten Island. Mr. Cirillo, who had suffered from cancer for a long time, was 72 years old.

title: HOW MUCH MORE?
description: THE Vredeling Proposal is a classic illustration of what might be t ermed The First Law of Social Engineering: the loftier and the more u niversally desirable the objectives of proposed legislation, the p oorer will be its draftsmanship, the more cumbersome its i mplementation, and the more depressing its results.

title: Dog Beverage
description: Soft drinks for humans are big business, but soft drinks for dogs? Carol Graham, a former advertising executive, reported last March that her idea was catching on slowly. In four months, she said, Rosebrand Products Inc., a company that she had formed on Madison Avenue, had sold some 40,000 cases of Juicee Treat, a bottled drink for dogs.

title: SHOWS 'FOCUSING ON FIBER, OLD TOYS
description: KATONAH ''FIBER'' is the last in a series of crafts events at the Katonah Gallery and an elegant spread it is. Also noteworthy this week is an orgiastic remembrance of things past at The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Canadian Oil Dispute To Be Decided by Court
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Premier of Newfoundland have failed to settle their differences over whether the federal Government or the province should have control over at least two billion barrels of oil lying off the Newfoundland coast.

title: WHEN CONFESSION IS ALL
description: The confessional mode has enjoyed a recent vogue in poetry, especially in the last decade. Such soul-baring, or actually an exposition of private emotional concerns, has generally been missing in dance. A confessional approach, which can succeed in making art out of life's torments, is not to be confused with the kind of psychological themes that were the hallmarks of American dance in the 1950's. Neurosis as a subject - objectively examined - is not the same as self-examination .

title: Politics Makes Strange Numbers
description: If the 1982 Congressional elections become a referendum on Reaganomics rather than on the qualities of the 850 people running for the House and Senate, it could be as much because of President Reagan's tone and tactics as because of the lingering recession. Last week, as the 1982 fiscal year creaked to a close with only one spending bill for 1983 in place, Mr. Reagan gave the Democrats the opportunity to question not just his handling but his understanding of the economy. They also engineered the defeat of a pet Reagan project, a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, before the White House had a chance to blitz for approval.

title: WROTE BEST-SELLING 'HISTORY OF ART'
description: Prof. H.W. Janson, known the world over for his best-selling ''History of Art'' and for more than 30 years professor of the history of art at New York University, died Thursday on a train between Milan, Italy, and Zurich. He was 68 years old.

title: STUDY FINDS ENERGY DEPT. MANAGEMENT FAULTS
description: Financial mismanagement and inadequate internal controls are rampant in the Department of Energy, according to a new report prepared by the General Accounting Office.

title: Buckeye Star Signs
description: First-round draft choices in the college draft have been slow in signing with National Basketball Association teams, but three agreed to terms this weekend. Clark Kellogg of Ohio State said he would report today for his first practice with the Indiana Pacers.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ESSEX
description: THERE was a time when sailing ships carrying cargoes from distant p orts moored at the foot of Main Street in Essex. They unloaded e verything from rum to ivory tusks, and they sailed off with the b ounty of the Connecticut River Valley: flour, leather, livestock andl umber. Glaciers had gouged out the harbor eons earlier, but several o f nature's quirks - silt and sandbars - eventually constricted the m outh of the Connecticut.

title: Burning Freight, Lethal Chemistry
description: A train hauling tankers of hazardous freight across Louisiana derailed last week, spilling a Pandora's boxcar-load of toxic chemicals. With firefighters sidelined by the intensity of the resulting flames and the combination of chemicals involved, one of the cars exploded yesterday, damaging or destroying about 20 homes in Livingston, 30 miles west of Baton Rouge.

title: Nebraska Meatcutters To Suspend Strike
description: Meatcutters who struck the country's largest beef processor four months ago will go back to work Monday while contract talks continue, union leaders say.

title: BANK FAILURE HITS TOWN IN TENNESSEE
description: Steve Keeton, a 31-year-old sawmill owner in this tiny Tennessee lumber town, depended heavily on the liberal lending policies of the Hohenwald Bank and Trust Company to establish his fledgling G & S Lumber Company.

title: THE STYLE OF THREE PRESIDENTS
description: TUMULTUOUS YEARS, The Presidency of Harry S. Truman, 1949-53. By Robert J. Donovan.

title:
WEST GERMAN TURMOIL;
STUTTGART, West Germany -One thing that can be said for certain about the past weeks' turmoil in West German politics is that the iconoclastic and uncompromising Greens are steadily gaining influence and, in their refusal to strike a deal with a more established party of any stripe, threaten to become a destabilizing force in the new era of German politics emerging today. But it was also clear in these confused weeks that it is not too late for the mainstream parties to regain the confidence of the younger generation - not by using Green vocabulary and not by the politics-as-usual that often passes for leadership in West Germany but by plain-speaking and realistic leadership. We Germans need to strip our politics of the moralism and emotionalism that marks both the Greens and the mainstream parties.
description: The Greens are a loose coalition of environmental, feminist and antiwar groups who base their views on the futurist literature associated with the international scholars' and businessmen's Club of Rome and its concern for the limits to growth. The Greens feel that the mainstream parties do not address the real problems of West Germany and believe that a fundamental change is needed. Romantic and nonmaterialist, they attract young people who share their criticism of industrial society and deep, sometimes fanatical aversion to nuclear energy - although the Soviet SS-20 missiles pointing toward German cities do not seem to be regarded as a threat.

title: Rome, O'Neill Go Gloveless
description: For about an hour last week Connecticut Gov. William A. O'Neill and challenger Lewis B. Rome emerged from the shadow of the Senate campaign. But even during their spirited debate in New Haven, they found it difficult to get out from the shadow of that perennial Connecticut issue, the income tax.

title: MONTGOMERY, ALA.
description: ON election night, Alabamans had a hard time admitting they had actually nominated George C. Wallace to a fourth term as governor. For over an hour, WSFA-TV broadcast reversed vote totals that erroneously showed Lt. Gov. George McMillan ahead in the Democratic runoff. Up the road in Birmingham, both major television stations projected Mr. McMillan as the winner based on key precincts exit polls. The next day, polltakers concluded that many voters pulled the Wallace lever in the privacy of the booth but were too embarrassed to admit it on the outside.

title: GREENS GIVE BONN POLITICS NEW CONTENT
description: Dorli Rauch does not much resemble the average West German politician. Mrs. Rauch, a slight, soft-spoken 32-year-old schoolteacher and mother of two, seems more at ease in a heavy sweater and coveralls on her farm near here than on the political stump.

title: Mayor Koch's New Campaign
description: After a gubernatorial campaign in which money was no problem, Mayor Koch must now turn his attention back to the city, where money is the main problem.

title: East Berlin
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Yeager Is Bride
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Unadilla, N.Y., yesterday, Nancy Kite Yeager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Yeager of Unadilla, became the bride of Scott Hanson McLean, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roderick A. McLean of DeWitt, N.Y. The Rev. James Thyren performed the ceremony.

title: THE NUCLEAR BLACKOUT
description: After a two-month summer recess, the U.S.- Soviet talks on the control of nuclear weapons have begun again in Geneva. It would not be unreasonable to say that these may be the most important diplomatic negotiations of our time, or any other time, but the odd thing is that so few people know anything about them.

title: MURAL IN LIBRARY TELLS CITY'S HISTORY
description: BRIDGEPORT FIVE mornings a week for the last six years, Bernard Riley has climbed a 14-foot scaffold in the reference room of the Bridgeport Public Library, taken up his No. 4 drawing brush and spent the day depicting the history of Bridgeport on the end wall of the high-ceilinged room.

title: No Headline
description: JOHN PAUL SAYS TERRORISM IS NEVER JUSTIFIABLE

title: No Headline
description: L.S.U. UPSETS FLORIDA BY 24-13

title: THE STYLE OF THREE PRESIDENTS
description: REAGAN, By Lou Cannon. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York:

title: THE BIBLE'S INSPIRED ART
description: Chaim Potok's most recent novel is ''The Book of Lights.'' He is currently special-projects editor of the Jewish Publication Society of America. Walking along a Jerusalem street on a hot summer day less than 10 years ago, it occurred to me that the undertaking I was involved in - translating the Hebrew Bible into English - was quite extraordinary. My colleagues and I, members of a committee of the Jewish Publication Society of America, were working in the city that lay at the heart of Jewish history; we were translating the book that was at the heart of Judaism and the Jewish people; and we were using as a matter of course a radical, new and, in many ways, heartless, scholarly methodology that was a gift to us from the heart of Western secularism.

title:
STAMPS;
U.S. HONORS ST. FRANCIS
description: The United States is marking the 800th anniversary of the birth of St. Francis of Assisi with a 20-cent commemorative that will be issued this Thursday in San Francisco, the city named after him. The first-day ceremony will be part of the activities the city's civic leaders have been organizing for the past year to observe the anniversary.

title: TIMELY WRITER WINS TUNE-UP
description: Timely Writer got some well-paid exercise and a confidence-booster yesterday with a 7 1/2-length victory over older horses in the $35,000 Avatar Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: KENNEDY OPENS CONTACTS WITH CUBAN-AMERICANS
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has begun an open political discussion with a group of prominent, mostly conservative Cuban-American businessmen here.

title: WILLIAM BERNBACH, ADVOCATE OF THE SOFT SELL IN ADVERTISING, DIES AT 71
description: William Bernbach, the founder and former chairman of the Doyle Dane Bernbach advertising agency, died of leukemia yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: HOSPITAL CAREER TAKES MUSICAL TURN
description: ''IF you have a dream and say, 'I can be anything I want to be,' and have a modicum of talent, you might prevail,'' said Arnold H. Goldstein of Roslyn Heights.

title: CHORUS SINGERS ARE PROFESSIONALS, TOO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lucy Kraus writes frequently about music and musicians. BY LUCY KRAUS

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Team Gains Davis Cup Final

title: No Headline
description: John Vinocur argues that the division of Germany is a ''result of Hitlerism.''

title: AZORES' EXILES FORSAKE U.S. AND GO HOME
description: Twenty years ago Jose da Silva's parents took their 3-year-old son away from rural poverty in the windswept Azores 900 miles west of Portugal to join a million and a half fellow islanders and their descendants in the United States.

title: NATO FOREIGN MINISTERS MEETING IN CANADA
description: Foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met today at this country retreat to discuss their differences and the problems facing the alliance.

title: FIRST DEBATE ENLIVENS GUBERNATORIAL CAMPAIGN
description: NEW HAVEN IN a head-to-head campaign debate, perhaps the best indication of what is on the candidates' minds is what issues they carefully sidestep, and what they mention twice. In the first debate of the gubernatorial campaign on Monday, an event that marked the only lively part of a so-far lackluster campaign, the confrontation between William A. O'Neill and Lewis B. Rome was limited to just an hour, but the candidates found time to repeat themselves on what they thought was most important.

title: TWO WEEKLIES ARE SOLD
description: THIS time it was for real. Two weekly newspapers, The Old Lyme Gazette and The Mystic Compass - after three highly publicized and thoroughly fictitious ''sales'' - have been sold to Cities Communication Inc. The media conglomerate, which now owns 13 weekly newspapers along the Connecticut shoreline, published its first issues of The Gazette and The Compass on Thursday.

title: Nancy Shaw And Lawyer Are Married
description: Nancy Joanne Shaw, daughter of Mrs. Russell Channing Shaw of Fair Haven, N.J., and the late Mr. Shaw, was married yesterday to Guy Cary Dempsey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dempsey of New York and Sharon, Conn. The Revs.

title: WORKERS HAVE A RIGHT TO KNOW MORE . . .
description: AMONG the X-rated videos available for private viewing in Europe t hese days is a public relations show which chronicles how a s elfless, caring multinational corporation is hamstrung in its a ttempt to create jobs and wealth by a cynical labor movement armed w ith restrictive legislation passed by the European Economic C ommunity.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM: INCIDENTS ON ISLAND SPUR NEW CONCERN
description: GREAT NECK A PORTRAIT of a bigot, as painted by law-enforcement officials and religious leaders, emerges as a male Caucasian between the ages of 14 and 19. Frustrated, arrogant, unable to achieve scholastically, he comes, more often than not, from a low- to middle-income family that has nurtured his dislike and distrust of a particular ethnic group.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 1 1 5 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 2 3 5 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.''

title: JERSEY CITY TO DRAFT A CODE OF ETHICS FOR CABLE TELEVISION
description: JERSEY CITY A STRICT code of ethics covering cable television is being drafted by officials of this city. ''It would be a clean break from the way business has been done in the past,'' Tom Golodik, a spokesman for the city, said.

title: ORIOLES TIE FOR LEAD AFTER DEFEATING BREWERS
description: The Baltimore Orioles today beat Milwaukee for the third time in 25 hours, 11-3, tied the Brewers for first place and sent the American League Eastern race into the final day of the season. In the showdown Sunday, Jim Palmer will pitch for the Orioles against Don Sutton in a matchup of veteran right-handers.

title:
GARDENING;
REVITALIZING AN OVERGROWN GARDEN
description: FALL is an excellent time for planting. Trees and shrubs planted in the fall get a head start on their spring-planted counterparts by having their root systems better established and more ready to grow with the coming of warm weather. Here are some suggestions for renovating or revitalizing an overgrown garden.

title: BUy a Loan and Borrow Trouble
description: The quiet crimes of moneylenders seldom gain the kind of attention that armed robbery draws. But that may change as a result of disclosures last week in Federal investigations of irregularities that led to the collapse of the Penn Square Bank in July.

title: Morgan Stands Out As Bergen Catholic Tops Hackensack
description: Mike Morgan, a senior halfback, scored a touchdown on a pass reception and two more on runs to lead Bergen Catholic to a 38-0 victory yesterday over Hackensack in Hackensack.

title: A Good Service
description: To the Editor:

title: JEFFERSON TROUNCES LINCOLN
description: Jefferson's Orange Wave, led by the fullback Ricky Johnson and the tailback Anthony Simpson, racked up 298 yards of total offense, all of it on the ground, to trounce Lincoln, 30-0, on the loser's field. Johnson had 102 yards on 10 carries, including touchdown runs of 3 and 1 yards. Simpson did not score, but carried the ball 16 times for 90 yards.

title: PITT TOPS WEST VIRGINIA
description: Dan Marino, Pittsburgh's quarterback, heard boos directed at him in Pitt Stadaum for the first time today. Then, as if to remind the booers why they used to cheer him, he led the Panthers on two scoring drives in a rally that beat West Virginia, 16-13, before 57,250 fans.

title:
PERSONNALLY SPEAKING;
GOING TO PASTURE DOESN'T MEAN GOING TO SEED
description: LIFE is just a dream by the time you arrive. It is like a kaleidoscope in which your successes and failures, and your health and illnesses, whirl around while -month by month, day by day - you move nearer to the end of the road.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''AS SOON as I saw the headline - 'Boyfriend Wins Stay on Abortion' - it captured me,'' said Sherrye Henry, the hostess of a daily radio program on WOR. She was explaining the raison d'etre for her first book, ''Alone Together: A Novel About An Independent Woman'' (Doubleday & Company, $14.95).

title: ADVOCATES FEAR FOR AUTONOMY OF CIVIL RIGHTS COMMISSION
description: WASHINGTON AS President Reagan reshapes the civil rights policy of the Federal Government, no agency scrutinizes his actions more closely than the United States Commission on Civil Rights, a bipartisan watchdog agency. And no President has made so great an effort to change the membership of the commission to reflect his own philosophy.

title: Miss Atwater Is Married To a Banker
description: Sarah Hamilton Atwater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian W. Atwater of Rochester, was married there yesterday to Robert Charles Mayer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer of Washington. The Rev. Robert Wainwright, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Charles Lavery, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: THE STYLE OF THREE PRESIDENTS
description: CRISIS, The Last Year of the Carter Presidency. By Hamilton Jordan.

title: U.S. Held Ill-Prepared To Face Big Blackout
description: The Federal Government is not adequately prepared to deal with a major disruption of the nation's electrical power systems, the General Accounting Office says.

title: A TALK WITH TRUDEAU
description: RESTON: I want to philosophize with you, if I may, not about the Soviet Union or the Middle East, but things closer to home. I guess my primary question to you is whether you are worried about the state of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Piscataway Is Defeated
description: Bridgewater West was a 6-0 winner over Piscataway yesterday in a defensive battle in Bridgewater. Both teams struggled for three scoreless periods before Bridgewater West broke loose on Gary Sedlazek's 23-yard scoring pass to Jeff Masters in the fourth quarter.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC This week offers the opportunity to sample two different international styles of orchestral conducting.

title: FOR THOMPSON, LIFE HAS BEEN A 'NIGHTMARE' SINCE ABSCAM
description: WASHINGTON ON A Saturday afternoon in February 1980, Frank Thompson Jr., then the Representative from New Jersey's Fourth Congressional District and one of the senior Democrats in the House, was at home watching a basketball game on TV when two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents came to his door. They told him he was ''the subject of an investigation.''

title: No Headline
description: NOTRE DAME TRIUMPHS BY 11-3

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''TELL them to hang in there, we're coming.'' That was the message to thousands of commuters on the Upper Harlem Line that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority official in charge, Peter E. Stangl, said he wanted to convey.

title: THE MUSIC AGENDA JUST KEEPS GROWING
description: THE enlarged, improved and renamed Connecticut Symphony Orchestra held its opening concert last night. Founded last year as the Western Connecticut Symphony because of its affiliation with Western Connecticut State College in Danbury, the ensemble has appointed Skitch Henderson its music director and dropped the ''Western'' from its title to proclaim its aim of eventually serving the entire state.

title: DPT'S GOOD OUTWEIGHS THE BAD
description: LEGISLATORS in the United States and abroad are being pressured to abolish mandatory DPT vaccinations because one of every 700 children has suffered convulsions or gone into shock after the vaccine has been administered. Furthermore, certain foreign studies indicate serious brain damage in one of every 50,000 inoculated children.

title: SEEING PARIS WITH ATGET
description: Levy Atget Collection at the Museum of Modern Art. By BARBARA L. MICHAELS

title: A BLOOMING BEACHFRONT
description: TEN years ago, the Fairfield Beach community consisted mainly of rundown summer cottages on a private beach overlooking Long Island Sound. But within the last three years the area has changed substantially as cottages have been snapped up for six-figure prices and renovated at considerable expense.

title: LOCAL DIGS
description: ''There is no need to travel to Egypt or Greece to experience an archaeological dig when there are so many sites right here in Westchester,'' according to Sheila Cohen, member of the Material Archives and Laboratory for Archaeology, a nonprofit organization of 400 volunteers.

title: HOUSEWIVES OVEREAT? NONSENSE!
description: HOUSEWIVES don't overeat because we're mad at our parents. Housewives don't overeat because we're insulating our shaky psyches from the cold, cruel world with a fat buffer. Housewives don't overeat because we have no will power.

title: CENSUS DEPICTS AGING CITY AREAS
description: A portrait of the New York City area that is gradually being drawn from studies of the 1980 census depicts a region whose population is older than that of the United States as a whole.

title: FOR WESTERN REPORTERS, INTRIGUE IN MOSCOW
description: ''Hello, hello,'' the voice says, an urgent note detectable over the static that is a regular accompaniment of telephone calls in Moscow.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I don't want to be perverse about this, but I did gradually come to one curious but firm conclusion as I watched the hyper-elaborate musical that librettist-lyricists Betty Comden and Adolph Green had made out of the door-slam that ends Ibsen's ''A Doll's House.'' Nora Helmer, when she walked out on husband Torvald to try her luck in the great outside world, did not really become a new woman at all. At least not as she made her way through all that scenery at the Mark Hellinger. In ''A Doll's Life,'' which is what Doll's House II was called, Nora Helmer remained exactly the little schemer she always had been, and I wouldn't have trusted her within an inch of my wallet.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: U.S. Mediator Resumes Teaneck Teacher Talks
description: Talks resumed today, after a 24-hour recess, in an attempt to end a walkout by nearly 600 teachers here. They are threatened with being discharged next week if they do not return to work.

title: Command Told Sharon To Resign, Paper Says
description: Israel's entire army high command, led by the chief of staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, confronted Defense Minister Ariel Sharon last week and told him to resign, The Sunday Times of London reported. The Israeli Army called the report ''totally wrong.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE 22-foot-high red steel tower will never be seen by those for whom it was built. It sits in the courtyard of the new $9 million State Library for the Blind and Handicapped in Trenton, which was dedicated last Friday.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON COLLEGE BEATS TEMPLE

title: A CHARITY FLIGHT
description: Five cents for each pound of body weight will buy a 15-minute flight over a 30-square-mile area of Connecticut fall foliage today. From 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., Skitch Henderson, the orchestra leader, and other licensed pilots will take passengers flying out of Danbury Municipal Airport in their Beechcrafts, Cessnas and Piper Cubs for the benefit of the American Lung Association.

title: Lehrman Hospital Plan Is Attacked by Official
description: New York State's Director of Employee Relations yesterday criticized as ''irresponsible and inaccurate'' Lewis E. Lehrman's charge that half-empty state mental hospitals were being kept open for the benefit of state workers.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: A Sob Story The Male Weepie PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: Data Bank to Contain Facts on Newspapers
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities is awarding $949,000 to create a computerized data bank that will eventually provide bibliographical information on more than 300,000 American newspapers published since 1690.

title: THE FIRST FALTERS
description: It started with Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's idea of using the condominium device to enable small businesses to own the space they use. The result was the New York Industrial Condominium at 545 West 45th Street, believed to be the first of its kind in the United States.

title: NOW SUPPORTING SOME MEN INSTEAD OF WOMEN FOR OFFICE
description: The National Organization for Women has chosen this year to support many male Democratic candidates instead of their female opponents in an attempt to reduce the strength of the Republican Party in Congress.

title: Benjamin J. Katz, a Professor Of Economics at N.Y.U., Dies
description: Dr. Benjamin J. Katz, professor of economics at New York University, died Friday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was a resident of Oradell, N.J., and was 59 years old.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MEXICO CITY
description: M exico City is in the process of changing gear - from the lameduck Government of President Jose Lopez Portillo to the incoming administration of Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, who takes office Dec. 1; from the unprecented boom of recent years to the period of austerity that lies ahead, and even from drinking imported wine to making do with the local variety. For the moment the city is obsessed by adjustment, and any visitor will be immediately struck by the mood.

title: U.S. Cases of Measles Are Almost Eradicated
description: Federal health officials were unable to meet a 4-year-old goal of wiping out domestic cases of measles by Oct. 1, but one expert says success is right around the corner.

title: Record Crowds For Baseball
description: One year after a 50-day strike interrupted the season, major league baseball has broken its yearly attendance mark.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: moor, Pa., circa 1870. THE BURNING HOUSE, by Ann Beattie. (Random House, $12.95.)

title: HOMES AT COST
description: Seven members of the Eastern Mennonite Board of Missions, a Lancaster, Pa., group, volunteered their services in Central Islip, L.I., last week to transform a boarded-up, two-bedroom house into a livable home for a young postal worker and his family.

title: IN PRAISE OF THOSE ORNAMENTAL SUMACS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bertha Reppert is a writer and specialist in herbs. By BERTHA REPPERT

title: Belleville Stuns Passaic, 3-2
description: Robert Cancelliere, who also was reponsible for scoring the opposing team's points, kicked a field goal to hand Belleville a 3-2 upset victory over powerful Passaic yesterday in Belleville.

title: Debra Schuster Wed To Steven B. Tanger
description: Debra Lynn Schuster, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schuster of Dayton, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Steven Barry Tanger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley K. Tanger of Greensboro, N.C. Rabbi P. Irving Bloom performed the ceremony at the Schuster home.

title: U.S. Moves In With Both Feet
description: Amid all the violence and bitterness of recent days and decades, the United States moved last week to reassert its role as the primary Middle East peacemaker. A day after it once again began to police a world trouble spot, Secretary of State George P. Shultz used the United Nations forum to tell Israel and the Palestinians they each had to recognize the other's right to live securely and to make territorial and other concessions to assure peace.

title: THE 'STAR-SPANGLED BANNER' GOES ON VIEW IN GRAND STYLE
description: A newly cleaned and restored Star-Spangled Banner, the flag that inspired Francis Scott Key in 1813 to write the words that later became the national anthem, can now be seen at the National Museum of American History, but just for one minute each half hour.

title: DEER HUNTING ALLOWED AGAIN IN SECTION OF HARRIMAN PARK
description: The Palisades Interstate Park Commission announced yesterday that it would allow deer hunting this fall in Harriman State Park, as it did last year to a storm of protest. The commission called the hunt part of its three-year program to reduce the herd to 1,500.

title: HARRY KRAWIT
description: Harry Krawit, former president of the Peck Advertising Agency of New York City, died Thursday at his home in Miami Beach.

title: TEANECK SCHOOL STRIKE OPENS RIFTS IN COMMUNITY
description: TEANECK THE jailing of a number of teachers here last week for disobeying a back-to-work court order has opened rifts between school administrators, board and staff members and parents and thrown doubt over future contract negotiations.

title: WHAT I LEARNED WHEN THE DOOR OPENED
description: IENTERED my 20th summer expecting it to be the worst one of my life. As usual, I faced the unpleasant prospect of finding a job. Each previous summer, all I could find had been the mindless assembly-line type of work. I didn't expect anything better this year. Still, I needed the money for school.

title: WRIGHT MORRIS HONORED ON SERVICE IN LITERATURE
description: Wright Morris, the author of 33 books, has been chosen to receive the $14,000 Common Weealth Award for distinguished service in literature.

title: ONE-DAY DRIVES INTO HISTORY
description: MARLISE SIMONS reports for The Times from Mexico City. BY MARLISE SIMONS

title:
ANTIQUES;
4TH ANNUAL SHOW AT STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON THE fourth annual Antiques Show and Sale at the State Museum this week will include many items of high quality and considerable local interest.

title: DODGERS ELIMINATE GIANTS IN 15-2 ROUT
description: The San Francisco Giants fell out of the National League West race with a resounding crash today as the Los Angeles Dodgers overwhelmed them, 15-2.

title: TENANTS PROTECTED ON HEAT
description: Apartment dwellers and people who live in other multifamily buildings in New York State are expected to have new legal protection this winter against utilities cutting off their heat, according to Lisa Rosenblum, the director of the New York State Public Service Commission's Consumer Services Division. "It is the first time," Miss Rosemblum said, "that tenants of mulifamily dwellings have these protections in cold weather."

title: Elizabeth M. Mallon Wed To Michael W. Gonsalves
description: Elizabeth Mary Mallon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Mallon of Roslyn Estates, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael William Gonsalves, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Gonsalves Jr. of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Daniel E. Fagan performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: Marsala Captures 5,000
description: Charles Marsala, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, scored a victory yesterday in his first race of the season in the Iona College Interscholastic Cross Country meet at Van Cortlandt in the Bronx.

title: AN ARCHITECTURAL TOUR
description: MIDDLETOWN A SPECIAL house tour that traces the architectural history of this town from the early 18th through the mid-19th century will take place today from noon to 5 P.M.

title: THE CASE OF THE FILCHED RHODODENDRONS
description: ''THAT'S the way some people do their gardening,'' the policeman told me. ''They just drive up in a station wagon, open the door and reach out for a quick grab. They don't even need a shovel.''

title: THE BORDERLINE PERSONALITY
description: The Borderline Personality I read with interest Louis Sass's ''The Borderline Personality'' (Aug. 22). Although the concept of the borderline personality as ''a metaphor for our unstable society'' is a compelling one, historically it does not hold up.

title: Index; International
description: Deng opens an offensive against Chinese leftists 3 U.S. signs agreement on limited independence for Micronesia 3 Azore islanders in the U.S. are turning to their homeland 4 Around the World 5 Salvadoran says rain damage ex- ceeds guerrillas' efforts 7 Argentina investigates a secret Italian lodge 8 For Western reporters in Mos- cow, intrigue is part of job 10 Soviet dependence on U.S. food is seen as nuclear deterrent 11 Iraq says that it crushed the lat- est Iranian offensive 15 Israeli troops dig in for a snowy winter in Lebanon's mountains 18 Syrians reportedly agree to leave Lebanon if Israel pulls out 19 Pope says terrorism is never jus- tifiable 23 Government/Politics Kennedy opens discussions with Cuban-Americans in Miami 30 ''Boll weevil'' in bitter runoff contest in Florida 30 Environmental agency's chief claims victory in budget fight 35 Shortcomings in military plan- ning found in research study 36 Reagan, in radio speech, vows victory in war on drugs 38 State Archives to get Governor Roosevelt papers 46 ''Lemon'' law goes into effect in Connecticut 53 Health/Science Grant awarded for study of Alz- heimer's disease 58 PARADE TODAY The Pulaski Day Parade will take place today at noon, moving up Fifth Avenue from 26th to 52d Street, and then east to Second Avenue. (1:4.) Industry/Labor Teamster leader and four begin conspiracy trial tomorrow 39 Arts/Entertainment ''The Draughtsman's Contract'' at film festival 83 Music debuts in review 83 Style It's Judy Blume, New Yorker, her dream come true buys 74 New protection for tenants on heat cutoffs 74 Obituaries Prof. H.W. Janson, author of ''History of Art'' 44

title: Schmidt Ousted As Bonn Shifts To the Right
description: West Germany's weakened Free Democratic Party helped last week to scuttle the eight-year Chancellorship of Helmut Schmidt, the country's most popular politician - and perhaps, some members feared, to sink itself.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: MY SWEET AUDRINA By V.C. Andrews. 366 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $14.95.

title: HOW SENTENCES ARE REDUCED
description: JOSEPH GIORGIANNI of Trenton, whose 15-year jail term was recently restored after widespread publicity, is only one of many convicted criminals who have tried to have their sentences reduced under guidelines prescribed by law.

title: JEANNE MOREAU ENTERS A SWEET SEASON
description: ''I feel,'' said Jeanne Moreau, ''that I have a little more knowledge about myself now.'' She was serenely working her way through lunch and a box of filter cigarettes on a recent afternoon in an East Side restaurant. ''The privilege of my age - I am 54 - is that I have more confidence. I'm calmer. I know more about myself and yet - how shall I say it - I feel, yes, less egocentric.''

title: Narrative History
description: To the Editor:

title: Harriet B. Staub Wed to Planner
description: Harriet Brownson Staub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Staub 2d of Stamford, Conn., and John Joseph Huston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Huston of Oreland, Pa., were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn. The Rev. Pierre Botton performed the ceremony.

title: Body of Tucson Girl, 7, Found Near Antiviolence Rally Site
description: A 7-year-old girl who disappeared Friday night as an antiviolence demonstration passed close to her house was found beaten and stabbed to death today near the parade route, the police said.

title: ADVICE FOR SURVIVAL
description: THE REAL ANTI-SEMITISM IN AMERICA By Nathan Perlmutter and Ruth Ann Perlmutter. 303 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.50.

title: 'LOAD ON LOAD OF APPLES COMING IN'
description: SINCE deciding to lose weight some years ago, I have eaten one or two apples almost every day, and I have spent a good deal of time thinking about them. Though low in calories, apples are rich in symbolism and profuse in variety.

title: Fine for Brown Campaign
description: The 1980 Presidential campaign of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has agreed to pay a $1,500 fine on charges of mixing personal staff funds with campaign money, according to the Federal Elections Commission. Governor Brown is now the Democratic candidate for the Senate from California.

title: Headphone Ban
description: Fearful that the spread of portable stereo headphone sets among strollers, joggers, bicyclists and motorists would increase traffic accidents, the Woodbridge Township Council in New Jersey voted an ordinance in July that it described as the first such in the country: it banned the wearing of headphones in the streets. Anyone could wear headphones on the sidewalks, but not in the streets.

title: READING TO THE KIDS
description: Not long ago I watched a friend of mine read to his two young children before they went to bed, and I was struck by the tenderness and beauty of the scene. The children's faces were rapt, their eyes round with imagining, their small pajamaed bodies absolutely still as their father unfolded the story from the book in his lap. When he had finished, they threw their arms around his neck and kissed him.

title: JUVENILE-COURT REFORM URGED
description: Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has called for nationwide reform of the juvenilecourt system to end ''legacies of injustice'' and establish a mechanism to balance the interests of children, parents and society.

title: IN THE ART:CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART In the first years of the 17th century, one of the painters who took most from Rubens and did most with it was Henrik Goltzius (1558-1617) who lived for most of his life in Haarlem. His ''Venus and Adonis'' of l614, now in the Alte Pinakothek in Munich, has a glorious candor in its handling of what would in any case be one of the most voluptuous of mythological subjects.

title: A BEGINNER'S BAEDEKER TO THE GENIUS OF FASSBINDER
description: At the press conference 10 days ago following the New York Film Festival screening of ''Veronika Voss,'' Rainer Werner Fassbinder's second-to-last film, Juliane Lorenz, Fassbinder's film editor and longtime associate, was asked how his German countrymen had reacted to the news of the 36-year-old director's death last May. There had been interest and concern, she said, because he was a well-known figure, but most people didn't yet comprehend the extent of the loss - the measure of his genius.

title: IT'S ALL DOWNHILL
description: A 1.6-acre lot on Orchard Street in Yonkers is so steeply sloped that no one thought it could be built on and it became an unofficial dump -until Sacred Heart Church of Yonkers decided to build housing for the elderly there.

title: ROCHESTER GETS 1557 BOOK
description: The University of Rochester library has just acquired its two millionth book since the founding of the college in 1850. It is a rare 1557 folio edition of ''The Workes of Sir Thomas More Knyght, Sometime Lorde Chauncellour of England, Wrytten by Him in the English Tongue.'' It is considered one of the most significant books in the English Renaissance, according to Prof. Kenneth Jay Wilson of Rochester, an authority on More's work.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Bossy worked out with the Islanders yesterday for the first time since suffering a groin injury last week. The team said he would accompany it on the season-opening trip to western Canada this week. ... Only hours after they obtained Kent-Erik Andersson from the Minnesota North Stars and then traded him to the Rangers for Ed Hospodar Friday, the Hartford Whalers acquired Mark Johnson, a center, from the North Stars for a fifth-round draft choice in 1984. ... Russ Sloan, athletic director at Fresno (Calif.)

title: PRINCETON WINS ON RALLY, 28-23
description: When it comes to moving the football, Princeton seldom bothers with a running play. Its method is the pass, one after another. If one fails, then Princeton sends up one more.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
RECENT AUCTION SALES CONFIRM MARKET'S UPTURN
description: The coin market's seeming resurgence, first apparent a month and a half ago at the national convention of the American Numismatic Association, has now been confirmed at a series of public auctions. Three important auction sales held in New York in mid-September all attracted large turnouts of active bidders and all produced prices that were well above pre-sale estimates.

title: No Headline
description: John Vinocur's report about Germany contained a startling paragraph about the so-called Kinderfeindlichkeit. I am at a loss to understand how he could have been so misinformed.

title: KEAN FACING TOUGH OPPOSITION ON PRISON BONDS
description: TRENTON SELLING people on the idea of spending money for new prisons is difficult under ideal circumstances - that is, when no one objects. When there is organized opposition, as there is to Governor Kean's proposal to spend $170 million on prison construction, the chances of public approval are even dimmer.

title: ECONOMIC ILLNESSS
description: To the Business Editor: It is a heartening experience to read a concurring opinion on the nation's economy, especially one at variance with the conventional wisdom.

title: U.S. Warned On Spanish Bases
description: A lot of left-leaning Spaniards are looking forward to the election of a new Parliament Oct. 28 with an eagerness probably not shared at the State Department and the Pentagon. At the moment, the Socialist Party is riding high in the polls and may be able to form Spain's first leftist government since Franco destroyed the Second Republic in 1939.

title: No Headline
description: Louis Sass left the impression that the explanation of the etiology and pathogeny of the borderline personality could be found only in terms of old theories of psychoanalytic nature, which are, in fact, invalidated by the new genetic and clinical studies.

title: ARMY TURNS BACK HARVARD BY 17-13
description: One week after a humiliating 62-8 defeat by North Carolina, Army recaptured some pride today with a 17-13 triumph over Harvard at Michie Stadium.

title: TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE
description: ACCEPTABLE LOSSES By Irwin Shaw. 303 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95.

title: Deerfield Triumphs Over Lawrenceville, 20-15; BY WILLIAM J. MILLER
description: George Sorbara, a running back from Naples, Fla., scored twice in the final five minutes to give Deerfield an opening-game 20-15 victory over visting Lawrenceville. It was the New Jersey's school first loss in two games.

title: THE WOUNDED HEALING THE WOUNDED
description: SECOND HEAVEN By Judith Guest. 320 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Prehistoric Gnat
description: It was an old gnat, but it wasn't any old gnat. Scientists at the University of California at Berkeley said it was 40 million years old and in a mummified state, with much of its soft tissue apparently intact.

title: No Headline
description: It is regrettable that Louis Sass, in his otherwise excellent article, failed to refer to the value of group psychotherapy for borderline patients. Mental health clinicians have found that the group experience, when offered concurrently with one-to-one psychotherapy, facilitated treatment considerably. SAUL SCHEIDLINGER, Professor of Psychiatry, Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, Bronx, N.Y.

title: The Case of the Docile Watchdog
description: When the Urban Development Corporation needed someone to police minority hiring by construction firms at New York City's new convention center, Moses S. Harris, director of Black Economic Survival and a man known as an aggressive advocate of minority hiring, seemed like a logical choice. Mr. Harris and his organization received a $60,000-a-year contract for the project in April.

title: SUFFOLK SCENES REPRISED
description: STONY BROOK SIX months ago, when David Cassedy, curator of the art collection at the Museums at Stony Brook, began working on ''Suffolk Scenes and Landmarks,'' the exhibition that opens Wednesday at the complex's Art Museum, he thought that by contrasting 19th-century landscape paintings with 1982 photographs of the same sites, he would be assembling a show that would dramatically detail what a century of progress has done to the area.

title: Home Prices Still Weak
description: The recent slight declines in mortgage interest rates may eventually put upward pressure on home prices, but it has not happened yet. For the second consecutive year, prices of existing and new homes in major metropolitan areas are not keeping pace with most measures of inflation.

title: THE 'CRUSH' IS ON IN STATE'S VINEYARDS
description: ALTHOUGH the words ''vineyard'' and ''vintage wine'' conjure up images of grape harvests in Europe or California, the big ''crush'' is on now in New Jersey, a state noted more for its sweet corn and tomatoes than for champagne and Chardonnay.

title: Crackdown On Casino Union
description: Casinos without mobsters may seem as fanciful as casinos without gambling, but that didn't stop an Atlantic City regulatory commission from moving last week to reduce the influence of organized crime on organized labor. The Casino Control Commission ordered Local 54 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International, the city's largest casino union, to remove three officers by Oct. 12 or face sanctions.

title: OPERATING ENGINEERS TO RETURN TO WORK TOMMORROW
description: Operating engineers are expected to return to their jobs tomorrow, ending a three-month strike that had halted work on an estimated $2 billion in public construction projects.

title: SALE OF SCHOOL FOR $1 CAUSES BITTERNESS
description: NEW HAVEN THE sale of a public school here to an Orthodox Jewish school for $1 earlier this year triggered a bitter court fight, strong differences of opinion within the Jewish community, and claims of anti-Semitism, corruption and conflict of interest. As a result, a Federal court has ordered changes in the way the city disposes of surplus property.

title: THREE SCHOOLS GIVEN $675,000 TO STUDY A DISEASE OF THE AGED
description: The Commonwealth Fund has made a grant of $675,000 to three schools of medicine for research in Alzheimer's disease, a progressive brain disorder afflicting more than one million aging Americans.

title: U.P.I. TO SPEND $20 MILLION TO IMPROVE AND EXPAND OPERATION
description: United Press International, the nation's second largest news agency, today announced a $20 million program to enlarge its news gathering efforts and to improve its communications systems.

title: Spain Arrests 3 Colonels; Fears Plot Against State
description: Three colonels were arrested today on suspicion of plotting against state security, the Defense Ministry said.

title: COMIC BOOK EXTOLS ST. FRANCIS
description: ON THE first page of a comic book entitled ''Francis, Brother of the Universe,'' a man wearing a brown robe with a cowl is shown kneeling beside a large rock. Above his head is a ''cloud balloon'' - his thoughts - with the words:

title: DISSENT IN NASSAU G.O.P.
description: THE one Nassau Republican leader who dissented from Joseph M. Margiotta's effort to depose State Senator Ralph J. Marino as first vice chairman of the G.O.P. organization and Mr. Margiotta's successor is now urging the two to resolve their differences through negotiations.

title: DENG OPENS DRIVE ON HIS LEFTIST FOES
description: A rare retraction of an army newspaper article has signaled an expected offensive by the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping against his leftist opponents in the aftermath of the recent 12th party congress.

title: BRISTLING TACTICS
description: The LLoyds Bank International Tournament in London ended in a tie for first place among the grandmasters Tony Miles of Britain and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia, International Master Lev Gutman of Israel, and Mark Hebden of Britain and Darryl Johansen of Australia. Each scored 7-2 in the 130-player Swiss-system event, but Miles, the current British champion, captured the trophy on tie-break points.

title: Recent Sales
description: Closter $115,000 80 Carlson Court *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old bilevel; new patio, *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, one-car garage; taxes $2,214. Dumont $95,000 145 Lenox Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old split level; new tile floor *2*in kitchen, formal dining room, storage attic; taxes $2,230. Emerson $84,000 133 Hartland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; *2*new roof, den, one-car garage; taxes $1,810. Maywood $72,000 131 Stewart Street *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial Cape Cod; central air- *2*conditioning, new redwood deck, one-car garage; taxes $1,449. Norwood $140,000 757 Broadway *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; fireplace *2*and family room, two-car garage, basement; taxes $2,578. Paramus $82,000 174 Arundel Road *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old ranch; covered patio, *2*one-car garage, formal dining room; taxes $1,192. OTHER AREAS Huntington, L.I. $160,000 2 Cyril Drive *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old center hall colonial; finished *2*basement with sauna, marble floors, library; taxes $4,200. New Milford, Conn. $44,900 Unit 13, Bostwick Place *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old town-house style condominium; *2*taxes $400, monthly common charges $67. Larchmont, N.Y. $127,000 76 Myrtle Boulevard *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 59-year-old frame colonial; modern eat-in kitchen, *2*full basement with half bath; taxes $3,009.

title: Noie McGown, Philip Defliese Jr.  Married Upstate
description: Lenore Ann McGown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hamilton McGown Jr. of Cooperstown, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Philip L. Defliese Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Defliese of Garden City, L.I., and Bolton Landing, N.Y.

title: ANother Finger in Technology Dike
description: For Government security agencies, plugging the leak of American technology to the Soviet Union has mainly meant restricting communications among scientists. Now an expert panel from the National Academy of Sciences says the Government has been playing Dutch boy at the wrong dike.

title: Hugh White Marries Mary C. Brennan
description: Mary Claire Brennan, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Martin J. Brennan of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Hugh James White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh White of New York. The Rev. Robert F. Grippo performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE RECOVERY THAT WON'T START
description: WHEN President Reagan came to Washington, he had a dream that the s luggish, inflated United States economy could be rescued quickly and painlessly from its problems. In public at least, Mr. Reagan still clings to the dream, despite a continuing barrage of bad economic news. And, with November's Congressional elections pressing upon him and his party, the President is intent on convincing the nation to share his faith.

title: STATE IS GETTING GOVERNOR ROOSEVELT'S PAPERS
description: The gubernatorial papers of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the 46th Governor of New York State, will be transferred on Monday from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here to the State Archives in Albany.

title: John Bell 4th Marries M. Ramsay Gross
description: At the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore yesterday M. Ramsay Gross, daughter of Marjorie Reid Foley of Baltimore and Emory Frederick Gross of Towson, Md., was married to John Cromwell Bell 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bell 3d of Media, Pa. The Rev. Ernest Smart performed the ceremony.

title: DENARDIS RIVAL COUNTS ON NEW HAVEN SUPPORT
description: MORE than the five other Congressional districts in the state, the Third District, which stretches out from New Haven to Clinton and Killingworth to the east, Stratford to the west and north to Wallingford, has the most unaffiliated voters. That is perhaps indicative of an independent nature in the large number of academics in the district's seven colleges and universities.

title: A Correction
description: The name of a magazine that lists expensive properties for sale was incorrectly given in ''Marketing Those Million-Dollar Mansions'' in the Real Estate section of Sept. 5. Its correct name is The Diplomatic World Bulletin.

title: 29 DESIGN AWARDS GIVEN TO THE TIMES
description: The New York Times won 29 of 187 awards, including one of three gold awards and three of the 19 silver awards, in the third annual design competition of the Society of Newspaper Design.

title: Karen R. Sargent Wed To Arthur Raporte Jr.
description: Karen Rose Sargent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Sargent of Rock Hill, S.C., was married there yesterday to Arthur James Raporte Jr. The Rev. J. Randolph McFadden, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the garden of Brattonsville, a mansion and site of the National Register of Historic Places.

title: 2 Men Charged in Threat To Bomb Texas Oil Plant
description: Two men were jailed under $1 million bond each today after being charged with trying to extort $15 million from Gulf Oil by threatening to blow up a Texas petroleum plant where five bombs were found.

title: ONE FOR THE PLAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE BUDGET CUTTERS DIDN'T WANT TO CUT
description: WASHINGTON THE Cardinal streaks across the West Virginia line in the predawn hours, near White Sulphur Springs, hurtling through the mountain passes that take it through Alderson and Beckley, to Charleston and Huntington. The Amtrak train passes through some of the nation's most picturesque terrain, inhabited by some of its poorest citizens.

title: CELEBRATING THE ARTS OF FARM LIFE
description: RIVERHEAD DANIEL WELLS is a 27-year-old farmer who is the 12th generation in his family to coax potatoes from the fertile soil of Riverhead. Despite radical changes in agricultural production over the centuries, for more than 300 years, ever since the English King granted the first local Wells, William, his acreage, members of the family have been doing some things the same way, such as quilting, raising sheep for wool and leather, churning butter and preserving the earth's bounty.

title: FOOD SALES BY U.S. CALLED PEACE TOOL
description: A private research group said today that the Soviet Union's continuing heavy dependence on farm imports from the United States could lead to the most significant change in relations between the two superpowers since the cold war began 35 years ago.

title: Yale Debt to U.S.
description: Auditors of the United States Department of Health and Human Services charged in February that some colleges had earned interest improperly by banking Federal funds that should have been spent immediately. Yale University was named as the biggest offender.

title: U.S. URGED TO REVERSE BUSING POLICY
description: The Justice Department's announcement Monday that it might support local efforts to overturn school busing plans stemmed from exploratory requests it had received to take action in cases in St. Louis and Boston, according to a department official.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The leading economic indicators fell 0.9 percent in August after four monthly rises, the Commerce Department said. The drop prompted the Administration to say that recovery would be slower than anticipated. The Labor Department, meanwhile, said initial claims for unemployment insurance rose to 703,000 in the week ended Sept. 18, suggesting a 10 percent unemployment rate could be possible for the month.

title: Pamela Gannon Becomes Bride of John W. Bishop
description: Pamela Noel Gannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent N. Gannon of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to John Warren Bishop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren A. Bishop of Rochester. The Rev. William Folprecht performed the ceremony in the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: BILL IS PASSED TO EASE TAX EXEMPTION LAW FOR SAME CONCERNS
description: Just before it recessed early this morning, the House approved and sent to President Reagan a bill easing the rules under which closely held corporations can qualify for exemption from corporate income tax. Mr. Reagan is expected to sign the measure.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ During the past year, several groups have been formed to perpetuate the music of important jazz musicians who have died. They have included the Vibration Society, based on the music of Rahsaan Roland Kirk, Dameronia, which plays the compositions of Tadd Dameron, and Sphere, built around the music of Thelonious Monk.

title: Q. & A. WITH THE REAL ESTATE BOARD'S PRESIDENT
description: RICHARD M. ROSAN has served a dozen years in city government. In hisl ast post he was director of the city's Office of Economic D evelopment. Since July 1980, he has been the president of the Real E state Board of New York, a leading real estate industry o rganization. Recently, he discussed a number of issues affecting thei ndustry and the government's role in development in New York City.

title: Home Oil Industry Sags
description: With the approach of the heating oil season pushing up demand and reducing what had been a rapid rate of inventory liquidation, oil prices have firmed in recent weeks, providing some relief to companies.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton State Wins by 21-20
description: Bob (Flip) Faherty threw a 15-yard touchdown pass to John Armando with 11 seconds remaining and then passed to Kevin Gall for a 2-point conversion to give undefeated Trenton State a 21-20 victory over Glassboro State in a New Jersey Conference game yesterday in Trenton.

title: LIFE WITH BETSY
description: A THOUSAND PARDONS By Katinka Loeser. 181 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: WIDOW'S QUESTIONS LED TO UTAH RADIATION TRIAL
description: As he lay dying, Leonard McKinney believed that leukemia was a contagious disease and that he had got it from a neighborhood girl named Odessa. If it was not Odessa, he thought, it must have been one of the other leukemia victims in and around his town of Fredonia, Ariz. Several people in the area had cancer, and many people thought that was odd.

title: U.C.L.A. Spooks, If Any, Are Safe
description: Can Mr. Chips be brought in from the cold? A Federal appeals court ruled last week that this is nobody's business, except for the Central Intelligence Agency. Three judges ruled unanimously against a University of California at Los Angeles student who had sought information about agency activities on campus under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: THE SKILL OF STARING DOWN DIRTY PLAYERS
description: DIRTY athletes penetrate every sport. Some of them almost get skillful at the art of being dirty. But not quite. It's their failure to develop true and lasting skills along with a character flaw that feeds their being dirty in the first place. I never knew a truly great athlete who was a dirty player. If you've never played against a dirty player, let me tell you a few of their tricks.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ORIENT MARTIN LUTHER KING is here, and so are Robert and John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson and Lady Bird, Pablo Casals and, more intensely than any of them, Albert Einstein. Linnaeus, the 18th-century naturalist, is here too, the flowers and plants that he identified and catalogued just now taking shape in clay, larger than life size.

title: TRIAL OF TEAMSTER STARTS TOMMORROW
description: Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, begins what is expected to be a two-month defense of his union stewardship in a Federal District Court in Chicago Monday.

title: IF IT'S FALL, IT'S FESTIVAL TIME
description: HE is a nationally known artist and author who adopted his professional name by taking the surname of one of his favorite teachers and his first name from the middle letters of the word America. But Eric Sloane is also an honorary chief of the Warren Volunteer Fire Company, and so grateful is the company to Mr. Sloane that it recently dedicated its new ambulance to him.

title: ON FINANCING INFRASTRUCTURE
description: THE statewide need for the construction and repair of roads, bridges, sewer systems, water systems and solid-waste-management facilities is staggering.

title: Deborah Battin Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Wick Battin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Spragg Battin of Sharon, Conn., and P. Phillip Huffard 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Huffard Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. John W. Rick 2d performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: LUTHER VANDROSS: POP-SOUL PYROTECHNICS
