description: Luther Vandross, a 31-year-old former jingle singer and native New Yorker, looms as this decade's most promising all-around pop-soul musician. A singer, producer and songwriter, in that order of importance, Mr. Vandross introduced a new softer-edged style of soul singing last year on his self-produced solo debut album, ''Never Too Much.'' And his just-released second album, ''Forever, For Always, For Love'' (Epic FE 38235), a glowing collection of original love songs, augmented by remakes of Sam Cooke's ''Having a Party'' and the Temptations' ''Since I Lost My Baby,'' is a tour de force of pop-soul vocal pyrotechnics.

title: COMPELLING IMAGES ARE BALKE'S HALLMARK; NEW HAVEN
description: William Blake (1757-1827) was by general consent one of the most delightful of documented human beings. It is hard to resist someone whose first reaction to a rented cottage was to write and say that ''Heaven opens here on all sides her golden gates. Voices of celestial inhabitants are most distinctly heard, and their forms more distinctly seen. My cottage is a shadow of their houses.'' Rare is the realtor who finds a letter like that on his desk.

title: U.S. SAYS PRODUCERS OF CARS CAN'T MEET '83 DATE FOR AIRBAGS
description: The Transportation Department told a Federal appeals court Friday that automobile makers could not meet a deadline next September requiring that all new cars have air bags or automatic seat belts.

title: REGISTRANTS FAILING TO REPORT MOVES
description: The Selective Service System has been advised by the General Accounting Office that the failure of draft registrants to notify the service of address changes would seriously impede any future conscription.

title: Thomas More Kane Weds Marilyn A. Murray on L.I.
description: Marilyn Ann Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen E. Murray of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., was married Sept. 24 to Thomas More Kane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald V. Kane of Water Island, St. Thomas, V.I. The Rev. Anthony Stanganelli performed the ceremony in St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syossset, L.I.

title: RESURRECTING A CEMETARY
description: Can a neglected cemetery become an asset to a neighborhood? Citizens of the Ozone Park section of Queens think one can. They are campaigning to get the city to recognize and refurbish a longabandoned burial ground at Redding Street and 149th Avenue.

title: USING 'STAIN KILLERS' BEFORE PAINTING
description: MANY do-it-yourself home painters have been frustrated by ugly stains or discolorations on walls, ceilings or exterior surfaces that no amount of painting seems to cover up for long. Even after several coats of paint are applied, the stained or discolored area continues to ''burn through'' and soon shows up as a visible blemish once more.

title: No Headline
description: NEW BONN CHIEF TO SEE MITTERAND

title: COMMUNITY THEATER MARKS ITS 50th YEAAR
description: WEST HARTFORD COMMUNITY theaters come and go but, from all indications, the Mark Twain Masquers looms as a landmark to longevity. The organization that produces plays in the Roberts Theater on the campus of the Kingswood-Oxford School here, will begin its second half-century of performances with Friday's revival of ''You Can't Take It With You'' - the Masquers' 237th production. In celebration, a champagne reception for members will be held at the theater this afternoon from 2 to 4 P.M.

title: OLD ACTORS DON'T FADE AWAY-THEY ACT
description: RIDGEWOOD THE casting call was a bit unusual. The actors not only were to be experienced, but also preferably more than 65 years old. ''Second Sight'' and ''Poetic License,'' two one-act Equity Showcase plays, have an age range of 65 through 92. The older the thespian, the better his or her chances of at least looking the part.

title: ITALY'S BOUNTY OF FUNGHI
description: SARAH FERRELL is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. BY SARAH FERRELL

title: WALLENBURG TRIBUTE SET AT DOUGLASS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IT WAS a year ago Tuesday that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat credited with saving thousands of Jews toward the end of World War II, became the second man ever granted honorary citizenship by the United States. (The first man so honored was Sir Winston Churchill.)

title: 50 on Scottish Bus Injured
description: Fifty people, most of them soccer fans from Glasgow, were injured today when a bus collided with two horses that strayed onto a major highway.

title: WESCHESTER TRIES TEACHING INSTEAD OF JAILING
description: Convicted shoplifters and writers of bad checks in Westchester County are going from courtroom to classroom under a pilot program of alternative sentencing in which defendants pay tuition.

title: CASUALTY OF A FAILED SYSTEM
description: CHICAGO KEVIN ROSS once was courted by college recruiters and says he had his class papers typed by school secretaries. Now Ross is struggling in a storefront grammar school in what amounts to an eighth-grade class, filled with pigtailed girls and little boys who carry lunch boxes. He is 23 years old and 6 feet 9 inches tall.

title: Paul Jacobson to Wed Gail Einbender
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Einbender of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Einbender, to Paul Timothy Jacobson, son of Col. Gerhard L. Jacobson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jacobson of Hamilton, Va., and Glenwood, Minn.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Frustrations at the Fed

title: Dr. Noel P. DeFelippo Marries Michele T. Visconti
description: The marriage of Michele T. Visconti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Visconti of Woodbridge and Old Lyme, Conn., to Dr. Noel P. DeFelippo took place in New Haven yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Noel J. DeFelippo of Brooklyn.

title: Namath Case Dropped
description: A drunken-driving charge against Joe Namath has been dropped in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: STEEL INDUSTRY WOES WEIGH HEAVILY ON JOHNSTOWN
description: Tony Oravec, a welder, stood in the sun-splashed parking lot cut into a mountain above the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant.

title: SYRIANS REPORTED WILLING TO LEAVE
description: Syria told the United States today that it would withdraw its army from Lebanon if the Lebanese Government requested it and if the Israeli armed forces also pulled out of all Lebanese territory.

title: TEANECK PRINCIPAL A WINNER AS COACH
description: Here's what Jason Tirado, the linebacker, Francis Hayden, the running back, Robert Carluccio, the fullback on injured reserve, and Ron Rukenstein, the nose guard, had to say about the strike:

title: DESIRE, AMBITION AND FATHER
description: THE GOOD SON By Craig Nova. 436 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95.

title: N. ROCKLAND 10-7 VICTOR
description: North Rockland defeated Clarkstown South, 10-7, yesterday in the league opener for both schools for its 13th straight victory. Clarkstown South opened the scoring with a 24-yard touchdown pass from Tom Taggart to Jerry Donegan.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN, IN RADIO TALK, VOWS DRIVE AGAINST DRUGS

title: Light on Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: AT 26, PRODUCING 'JOSEPH' ON BROADWAY
description: IT may be typical for a stagestruck theater major fresh out of college to make the rounds and suffer one turndown after another, but it is atypical for her to find her name above the title of a Broadway musical some three years later -as a producer.

title: A BAR ALTERNATIVE
description: OCEANSIDE ONE alternative to Long Island's bar scene is Dev's Place, a coffeehouse here, recently renovated, where people of all ages are welcome to play scrabble, backgammon or other table games, sip a cup of coffee or just talk against a background of soft music and a liquor-free atmosphere.

title: PALESTINIANS IN LEBANON ALARMED BY ARRESTS AND RUMORS OF TRANSFER
description: Still shaken and fearful in the aftermath of the massacres at two refugee camps here, many of Lebanon's Palestinians are wondering what will become of them under the Government of President Amin Gemayel.

title:
GARDENING;
REVITALIZING AN OVERGROWN GARDEN
description: FALL is an excellent time for planting. Trees and shrubs planted in the fall get a head start on their spring-planted counterparts by having their root systems better established and more ready to grow with the coming of warm weather. Here are some suggestions for renovating or revitalizing an overgrown garden.

title: MORE ABOUT NEW RECEIVERS
description: Courtships and other promotional campaigns flourish on the principle that reluctance often yields to a carefully maneuvered increase of temptation. This is the strategy plainly evident in the current offerings of the audio industry. Those glossy new models beckoning from the shelves look as if they were trying hard to be irresistible - each more so than the next.

title:
WHEN REAGAN'S EX-CONSERVATIVES WON'T BE;
WASHINGTON - A huge tax hike. Flirting with Peking. The New Right agenda stymied by Congress.
description: Many leading conservatives are increasingly critical of this Reagan record. That Ronald Reagan and conservatives differ on some issues, however, should scarcely be surprising. The conservative resurgence neither started with Mr. Reagan nor will end with him.

title: THE POT AND THE KETTLE
description: ''I just wish those who bear such a heavy burden for overspending and taxing us into this recession could resist playing politics with the problems they caused.'' - Ronald Reagan.

title: CURBS SOUGHT ON CAMPUS DRINKING
description: STONY BROOK UNIVERSITIES and colleges from one end of Long Island to the other are in the process of limiting the sale and use of alcoholic beverages on campus, and many are also searching for ways to change student attitudes toward drinking.

title: ARGENTINA INVESTIGATING SECRET ITALIAN LODGE
description: Reports that prominent Argentines have been members of a secret Italian lodge called Propaganda 2 are being investigated here after the recent arrest in Switzerland of the Italian industrialist who headed it.

title: Pipeline Gets Silent Treatment
description: The United States and its European allies struck what may be the ultimate diplomatic impasse last week, so boxed in that trying to talk their way out became pointless.

title: CIVIC GROUPS: A VITAL LINK TO THE FUTURE
description: HAVING been raised on Long Island, I always felt, and still do, that my childhood was touched by a certain privilege. My family's small Cape Cod house in Uniondale was not very different from the others in the development. However, standing together, as they did, these plain houses could easily be described as links in a chain of community spirit.

title: ISRAEL, IGNORING U.S., KEEPS TROOPS IN BEIRUT OUTSKIRTS
description: Israel, ignoring both United States and Lebanese Government policy, is keeping troops and armored vehicles in Baabda, site of Lebanon's presidential palace.

title: THE WEEKEND MOTHER
description: Christine Doudna frequently writes about behavioral issues.

title: SHIFT ON PARRISH SHOW PROTESTED
description: SOUTHAMPTON THE recent announcement that the Parrish Art Museum's annual juried exhibition, a fixture for 29 years, is to be discontinued has met with considerable opposition among the artists of the region. Although the show is slated to be replaced by a group invitational selected by the curatorial staff, many artists feel that this is a poor substitute and are marshaling their arguments in petitions and letters to the exhibitions committee, which voted to establish the new format, and to Garrick L. Stevenson, president of the museum's board of trustees.

title: INDIA'S ACTORS TAKING POLITICS INTO THE STREETS
description: Political street theater has become a familiar sight here in the evening, especially outside factories and slum areas, and the actors tend to be received with everything from warmth to small riots.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY CHOICES ARE CLEAR, AND THAT'S THE TROUBLE
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Social Security was young, Congress learned it could be a veritable treasure trove of good things for the voters. Starting with guaranteed old-age benefits, lawmakers have added more generous eligibility requirements, protection against the financial burdens of disability and protection against the rising cost of living.

title: Economic Illness
description: To the Business Editor: In a letter to The New York Times entitled ''The Economy's Illness Is Being Misdiagnosed'' (Sept. 19), Paul L. Pryde asserts that ''the United States is undergoing a fundamental economic transformation from a manufacturing society to one engaged in the production of information''; and on this basis he projects a ''new wave of economic growth.''

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: EVEN as Congress debates interpretation and enforcement of the Federal Clean Water Act, scientists and state officials still cannot say clearly how seriously pollution has affected surface waters in New Jersey.

title: HIGH COURT FACING A DOCKET CROWDED WITH TOUGH ISSUES
description: The Supreme Court opens its new term Monday with its docket both the most crowded in its history and the most politically charged in recent years.

title: THE REAL IMAGE OF FOUR-H CLUBS
description: MENTION the Four-H club and the image that comes to mind is of children, animals and a rural setting. But as National Four-H Week opens today, it is an image that the organization's Westchester officials call limited and misleading for a complex program that is supported by tax dollars from Federal, state and county governments.

title:
OPINION;
THE THREE C's OF TAX CREDITS
description: THE buzz words in the enduring saga of tuition tax credits are choice, competition and credit - the three C's of education. It is an issue that has been introduced repeatedly in Congress in various forms since the early 1950's. The 97th Congress alone has considered some 20 bills dealing with tax relief for the parents of nonpublic school children.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ SAYS IT CRUSHED LATEST IRANIAN OFFENSIVE

title: PESHAWAR, PAKISTAN
description: AT the entrance to the Khyber Pass, the gateway to Afghanistan that lies just west of Peshawar, there is a series of tablets telling of all the conquerors who have subjugated, or tried to subugate, this part of the world: the ancient Aryans, the Persians, Alexander's Greeks, Genghis Khan and Tamerlane, the Mogul sons of Islam, and finally the British. ''According to the British,'' says one tablet, ''it was here that they met their equals and looked them straight in the face and fought against them up to the last day of their rule.''

title: Staples Tops New Canaan
description: After two weeks of non-league action, the Fairfield County Conference began divisional play with four games. Staples, Trumbull, McMahon and Norwalk emerged victorious.

title: No Headline
description: PUBLIC WORKS REPAIR FALLS IN NEW YORK AREA

title: Charles Van Bergen, 66, Dies; Associate CBS News Director
description: Charles Van Bergen, associate director of operations for CBS News, died of a stroke Friday while on vacation in East Hampton, L.I. He lived in Manhattan and was 66 years old.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER ADMITTING MEREDITH, OLE MISS MERGES ITS OLD AND NEW IMAGES
description: It is hard to believe, some would argue in retrospect and embarrassment, that a tranquil, small college town like this could erupt into a bloody battlefield in a dispute over the admission of a student.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar Holly Farms 400, from North Wilkesboro, N.C., featuring Darrell Waltrip, Bobby Allison and Richard Petty. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.). Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, the Bronx, 2 P.M. The Yankees, despite a disappointing year, will draw more than two million fans at home for the sixth straight year. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Philadelphia. Manager George Bamberger of the Mets is willing to wait until next year. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570, WGBB, 1:30 P.M.) Pennant Races Milwaukee at Baltimore. This game will decide the American League Eastern Division championship, with Don Sutton of the Brewers starting against Jim Palmer of the Orioles. There will be live reports from Los Angeles at San Francisco and Atlanta at San Diego. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.).

title: SOME RECENTLY INTRODUCED NEW PRODUCTS
description: Camera manufacturers are continuing to introduce a variety of new cameras and accessories, even before this fall's big Photokina show. Here are some that should prove of interest to many readers of this column: Cameras

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NOT too long ago, the Island's home fires kept burning at a reasonable cost to homeowners, and permits were given freely by the Long Island State Park and Recreation Commission to anyone who wanted free wood. However, because of the rise in fuel prices, the crush of homeowners seeking free wood became so great that park officials decided to arrange a lottery system to determine a limited number of winners.

title: Jean Parker, H.D. Murphy Are Married
description: Jean Carlton Parker, daughter of Mrs. James Perkins Parker of Gibson Island, Md., and the late Mr. Parker, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Howland Donaldson Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grayson Mallet-Prevost Murphy of New York. The Rev. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: TRIPLETS. By Joyce Rebeta-Burditt. (Dell, $3.95.) Jill Dunn Kenyon and her sister and brother - the triplets of the title - are part of a troubled family in this novel by the author of ''The Cracker Factory.'' Annie Gottlieb compared it to television's ''Hill Street Blues'' in her review, noting that both the book and the show exemplify a new style, ''a strange hybrid of heartfelt drama and apocalyptic farce.'' She concluded that Joyce Rebeta-Burditt ''has written a survival manual for the heart, a wise, painfully funny book that will make you laugh and cry.''

title: Miss Dockrell Wed to Edmond Horsey
description: The marriage of Margot Bolton Dockrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Loftus Bolton Dockrell of Roseland, N.J., to Edmond Philippe de Vilmorin Horsey took place at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J., yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Henry Ridgely Horsey of Dover, Del., a Justice of the Supreme Court of Delaware, and Alexandra Leigh Hunt Horsey of Newark, Del.

title: TAYLOR DANCE STAR TO INSTRUCT AT Y
description: BEGINNING this week, Carolyn Adams, the former principal dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company, will teach modern dance classes on Mondays to beginners and advanced students at the Mid-Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Scarsdale.

title: COUNTDOWN FOR A WISH LIST
description: Although it has always been difficult to separate the civilian and military aspects of either the United States' or the Soviet Union's space program, tomorrow's 25th anniversary of Sputnik is properly a celebration of science. Planning committees for the International Geophysical Year of 1957 had discussed the usefulness of artificial satellites for scientific work. Both superpowers announced that they would try to launch satellites during that year. The fact that the Russians succeeded first was more of a political embarrassment than a technological setback for Americans, though the military implications of the feat were not lost on any close observer.

title: B.A. Cutter Weds Claudia M. Steers
description: Claudia Marie Steers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Coster Steers of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Bruce Alan Cutter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Van Tassel Cutter Jr. of Deltona, Fla. The Rev. Robert McDermott performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart.

title: RICHARD BENJAMIN CREATES A COMIC VALENTINE TO THE 50'S
description: It isn't exactly ''Your Show of Shows,'' but with its resurrection of the antic lunacy of live television 30 years ago and its evocation of the broad parodies and essential brashness of that school of New York comedy, ''My Favorite Year'' will do nicely, and Richard Benjamin is happy with it.

title: TWO IN HOUSE SPAR OVER HIGHWAY AID
description: While two powerful leaders in the House clashed over legislation to renew Federal aid to national highway programs, a substantial part of the aid lapsed temporarily this week.

title: WHWN COMPETITION HURTS BIG
description: To the Editor: In view of the recent decision by a Federal court that the continued control exercised by the National Collegiate Athletic Association over broadcast rights to college football is unlawful, I believe the public should be accurately advised concerning the respective views of the parties.

title:
OPINION;
AT TAG SALES, A LITTLE LARCENY HELPS
description: AS fall days grow shorter, the classified columns advertising tag sales grow longer. Trees drop their leaves and sprout cardboard squares and paper plates marked with bold arrows. Cars follow the arrows like squirrels bent on a final frenzy of foraging.

title: ISLANDERS AND RANGERS LEAD A TREND TOWARD SPEED
description: The games that count start Tuesday, as the National Hockey League opens its 66th season of competition with 21 teams pursuing the quest for the Stanley Cup. For the New York Islanders, a successful quest would bring their fourth straight Stanley Cup, one championship shy of the league record of five straight, held by the Montreal Canadiens of 1956-60.

title: FOR GREENS ITS MAKE WAVES,NOT WAR
description: BONN FOR the leader of a party that regards itself as cleaner and nobler than others, Petra Kelly of the countercultural, antinuclear Greens sounded like an old-fashioned national power broker after her party broke into the state parliament in Hesse last weekend. If Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats remained deadlocked after national elections, she suggested, ''it could well be that on the federal level we would have to determine who would become Chancellor.''

title: THE CAPITAL'S MANY MOODS
description: ALAN RIDING is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The New York Times. BY ALAN RIDING

title: U.S. ASSUMES A POLICEMAN'S LOT IN MIDEST PEACE PROCESS; WASHINGTON
description: Amost striking thing about the events of last week was how Arab and Israeli leaders alike readily accepted and even sought the renewed American military presence in Lebanon. For one reason or another - Israeli dependence on American ties and military aid, the futility of the military option for Arabs now, the fact that only Washington might be able to pry negotiating concessions from Israel - the United States has fallen into and assumed the role of Middle East policeman. While Arabs and Israelis continue to complain about the United States, their need for Washington to play a prominent role is more pronounced than ever.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE HOW,WHEN AND WHY OF TELLING CHILDREN ABOUT SEX
description: PARENTS hope their children will exercise good judgment about everything. Considerable effort goes into providing children with the information and values necessary for good judgment in such matters as school work, chores, dressing, driving and friendship, but sex education is frequently given scant attention. Nevertheless, parents have the expectation that the same thoughtful process will be used with respect to decisions regarding sexuality. This silence leaves children without the strength of parental support and understanding. They are left on their own to manage a very important part of their lives.

title: SALVADOR CALLS FLOOD TOLL GREATER THAN WAR'S
description: Officials here say that five days of torrential rain, floods and mudslides last month did more damage to El Salvador's economy than the guerrilla war.

title: Sports of The Times; Doug Kotar and His Other Family
description: Almost every day now, somebody from the Giants visits Doug Kotar at the Newark hospital where he's recuperating from surgery that disclosed an inoperable malignant brain tumor. The other morning Coach Ray Perkins was there.

title: F.B.I. Will Resume Checking Fingerprints for Institutions
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will resume fingerprint checks of potential employees for financial institutions and local and state governments, the agency has announced.

title: GETTING SET FOR 'COLDEST WINTER'
description: MUCH colder weather and slightly higher energy prices are expected t o make the coming winter an expensive one for householders in the m etropolitan area. But they can moderate rises in their heating billsb y following proven, simple procedures to boost the energy efficiencyo f their homes.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: The Awful Tooth KIMBLE MEAD

title: WILLIAM FLOYD WINS FROM LONGWOOD, 26-6
description: John Ragimerski, a first-year quarterback as a senior, completed nine of 14 passes for 253 yards and two touchdowns to lead William Floyd of Mastic Beach to a 26-6 League III victory over Longwood. He also kicked two extra points and intercepted two passes as a defensive back. Last week Ragimerski passed for 277 yards and two touchdowns and intercepted two passes. William Floyd has a 2-0 record while Longwood is 0-2.

title: GALA FUND-RAISER
description: The Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company of Paterson is introducing 60 young people to the magic of dance and theater, and when the ensemble people tell you that this takes a lot of money, they are not giving you a song and dance.

title: 'THE PROBLEM IS NOT BEGIN, IT IS ZIONISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tori Oelsner Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Carol Victoria Oelsner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren James Oelsner of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., to Anthony Kane Baker of Mill Neck, L.I., took place yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Peter Bezencenet of Paris and the late George F. Baker Jr. of Oyster Bay and New York and a great-grandson of George F. Baker, the banker.

title: STATE TRIES TO SHAPE FUTURE JOB MARKET
description: Last of three articles By RUTH MARI

title: Labor Party Tugs Itself Back From the Left
description: Britain's Labor Party, despite its multiple fractures - a militant Trotskyist faction and the 1981 defection of influential moderate leaders who founded the Social Democrats, is still Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's most formidable opponent. With national elections next year a strong possibility, Labor struggled at its annual conference at Blackpool last week to pull itself into a shape that would lure back its natural constituency - working families and a record three million unemployed.

title: Long-Shot Odds On Holes-in-One
description: To the Sports Editor: Consecutive holes-in-one (Mailbox, The New York Times, Sept. 19, 1982) are calculated as independent events occurring in the same time frame.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER In past seasons, the American Place Theater's American Humorist Series has been largely devoted to comic writers such as Robert Benchley and H. L. Mencken. For its 17th program, the company has turned the Subplot Cabaret over to an experimental performance artist, Bruce D. Schwartz, who is a puppeteer, clown and one-man sideshow.

title: 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE' SWASHBUCKLES IN 3 AREA SHOWS
description: THE proliferation of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' has become a countrywide phenomenon of epidemic-like proportions. The 1879 Gilbert and Sullivan operetta is in the public domain, which means it is available free for all producers who want to put on a sure-fire show.

title: BY SALLY BEDELL
description: It was a routine day last Aug. 19 for Jac Venza, the director of performance programs at WNET in New York City. In his small, crowded office, there were back-to-back meetings and phone calls filled with good news (''The Skin of Our Teeth'' from San Diego's Old Globe theater will be available to broadcast this season), bad news (a delay in the delivery of three of the BBC's productions of Shakespeare's plays), hope (a way to help finance the coming Broadway production of ''Alice in Wonderland'' in exchange for television rights), and frustration (slow negotiations for the rights to musical numbers for this season's special about Duke Ellington, ''Jump for Joy'').

title: OIL STOCKS SHOWING STRENGTH AGAIN
description: OIL stocks are on the rise again. Nothing spectacular, perhaps, but t hey have risen 10 to 12 percent over the past six weeks. And it has r evived thoughts of early 1980, when they were last at their peaks.

title: WHEN TAX EXPERTS CONFRONT TAXPAYERS
description: ITH one revenue-raising and ''tax reform'' measure just passed, expert eyes are already turned to the next, as last week's Senate Finance Committee hearings on a proposed flat-rate income tax testify. The Week in Review asked three experienced tax hands - Senator Robert Dole, chairman of Senate Finance, Stanley S. Surrey of the Harvard Law School and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, and Charles Walker, an economist and Washington lobbyist who was Deputy Treasury Secretary for President Nixon - to talk about tax bills past and future. Excerpts of their discussion with Edward Cowan, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: 5,000 Demonstrate in Rome For Lebanese and the P.L.O.
description: About 5,000 students marched through the center of Rome today in what was billed as a ''day of solidarity'' with the Palestinian and Lebanese people.

title: WHAT HAS ACOUSTICAL SCIENCE DONE FOR US?
description: Over the last 25 years or so, architects and acoustical engineers have been busily reshaping the way that concertgoers hear music, and perhaps even the why. It has been done with the help of live-wire salesmanship and a brash young discipline called acoustical science, whose lack of consistent success in solving the basic problems of music-listening in enclosed areas still does not argue convincingly for its maturity. Not that these scientists have been deprived of experimental opportunities. I myself, while not attempting to mark every sparrow's fall in this particular field, have been able to attend the openings of more than 20 halls in various American cities, most of them new structures but about a third of them remodeled older theaters. In a few instances, such as Philharmonic (now Avery Fisher) Hall, the New York State Theater and Chicago's Orchestra Hall, corrective surgery in several expensive stages has been deemed necessary to remedy acoustical defects. All this building and rebuilding activity has been episodic, coming in surges whose periodicity probably could be charted by a good astrologer or stock-market analyst. Last month, for instance, was a particularly active time, with champagne being broken across the bows of no less than five important halls - six, if you count the acoustical retouching of the New York State Theater.

title: 2 Held in Texas Bomb Blast
description: Two men were arrested Friday night in Arizona on suspicion of being involved in a $15-million dollar extortion scheme related to a bomb explosion at a Gulf Oil chemical plant near Houston. No one was injured in the explosion Thursday. The suspects, identified as Theodore McKinney, 45 years old, and Michael Allan Worth, 34, both of Durango, Colo., were being held in a jail in Phoenix, pending arraignment, officials said.

title: Martin Edward Doyle Weds Kathleen Smith
description: Kathleen Elaine Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Smith of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Martin Edward Doyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Doyle of Hector, N.Y., were married yesterday. Canon C. George Widdifield performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills.

title: LOCK'S OF LONDON: GENTLEMEN'S HATTERS
description: DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND is the author of some 30 books, including a series on ''The English Gentleman'' and books on espionage. He lives in a castle in Scotland. By DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND

title: Private Advice
description: Drivers of the Datsun 200 SX have proved more than twice as likely to suffer severe collision injuries than drivers of the Oldsmobile Cutlass or Mercury Marquis. Owners of the Chevrolet Corvette on average had collision bills four times larger than owners of the Ford LTD or Dodge Aries.

title: More Damage Is Found At Upstate Atom Plant
description: The 610-megawatt Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear power plant, idle since March 28 for repairs of the pipes in its reactor, will remain closed until September 1983.

title: CApitol Finale: Every Cause For Itself
description: In true pre-election form, members of Congress rounded out their last week in Washington with frantic competition for the limited oil available for the squeaky wheels on several hundred bandwagons. They sought bailouts for business, punishment for criminals, training for the jobless, help for the handicapped, protection for the environment and a host of lesser measures that sometimes provoked greater controversy.

title: ROSE DOUBLES IN 9TH TOPS METS
description: In the 161st game of a losing season, the Mets learned an old lesson tonight: Even though he is 41 years old and hitting only .269, you can't argue with Pete Rose.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara J. Frey Bride of Peter Hewitt
description: Barbara Jean Frey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Frey of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Ogden Hewitt, son of May McLaren Hewitt of Berwyn, Pa., and Pompano Beach, Fla., and the late Joseph Ogden Hewitt.

title: Youth Slain at Mall in Jersey
description: A 16-year-old Boonton Township youth was shot and killed at the Rockaway Townsquare Mall here Friday night in an apparently ''motiveless'' attack, the Morris County Prosecutor, Lee Trumbull, said today. The youth, Christopher Thomas, an honor student at Morris Catholic High School, died at Dover General Hospital of a chest wound, Mr. Trumbull said.

title: THE ONLY GAME IN TOWN
description: John Bradford hears the passengers talking on the bus he drives from Co-Op City to midtown. He hears people say how selfish the football players are, how needless the strike is.

title: Martha Johnston, Physical Therapist, And Bradway Widing Have Wedding
description: Martha Isobel Johnston, daughter of Joan S. Johnston of Riverside, Conn., and H. Frederick Johnston of Greenwich, Conn., was married in Greenwich yesterday to Bradway Griscom Widing, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Widing Jr. of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Richard Sterns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: EDUCATIONAL VALUES; Welcome Students
description: Racism blocks the path to higher education in South Africa, where a white child has a hundred times better chance of attending college than anyone born black. Of 21 million blacks, fewer than 9,000 are attending university.

title: The Children of War Come 'Home'
description: Forgetting Vietnam was harder last week. Seven girls and four boys, the children of American fathers once stationed in Vietnam, were finally coming ''home'' to the United States.

title: TRIBAL IMAGES BURSTING WITH CREATIVITY
description: HEMPSTEAD ALMOST a century ago, the keen British observer John Ruskin is said to have expressed astonishment at the extraordinary extent of art-making among certain aggressive peoples. There can be little doubt that sculpture, like the work of the cannibalistic, headhunting tribes living along the Sepik River, New Guinea, inspired the remark. Examples of their powerful, very ornate carvings were gathered by 19th-century explorers and were regarded as remarkable curiosities in European ethnology museums.

title:
GARDENING;
REVITALIZING AN OVERGROWN GARDEN
description: FALL is an excellent time for planting. Trees and shrubs planted in the fall get a head start on their spring-planted counterparts by having their root systems better established and more ready to grow with the coming of warm weather. Here are some suggestions for renovating or revitalizing an overgrown garden.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Crying is Easy ''You know, I'm 86 years old,'' said George Burns, the comedian, in a telephone interview. ''And in this picture I'm supposed to be 81.

MARIE HECKEMEYER remembers the lighthouse. She remembers kerosene lamps and the coal stove and the absence of indoor conveniences. She remembers getting in a boat every morning to go to school. She remembers the way her 7-year-old brother lost his footing on the rocks and drowned in the swift currents of the Hudson - the mainland a quarter of a mile away.

title: DEVON CREAM TEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Works Knicks Hard
description: Hubie Brown ran his first practice session as coach of the Knicks Friday as if he were a drill sergeant sending recruits through their first lessons.

title: WHY THE FOOTBALL PLAYERS MUST HAVE A WAGE SCALE
description: THE dispute between the owners and the National Football League Players Association so far has resulted in the cancellation of two games for each team. This is not so momentous as a shutdown of the basic steel industry or of the nation's railroads, but a sizeable number of people feel it to be a matter of significance. However, there does not seem to be any wide understanding of the disputed economic issues or their origin.

title: PRESS GROUP SAYS ECONOMIC ILLS REDUCE FREEDOM
description: A deteriorating world economy, leading to stringent government regulations, has added to the problems confronting newspapers in the Western Hemisphere, according to a report on freedom of the press issued this week by the Inter American Press Association.

title: AN ATTRACTIVE WATERFRONT SPOT
description: STAMFORD JUDGING by the noisy and enthusiastic crowds that the Rusty Scupper has generated in just two months, it must be filling a need: for a waterfront restaurant, an attractive spot for a business lunch, a ''happy hour'' hangout for singles, or all of the above.

title: JUST WHAT COVERAGE IS NEEDED?
description: FOR the owners of cooperative or condominium apartments, insurance i s an issue with special quirks and problems. Experts agree that two p olicies are necessary to cover all the potential problems that coulda rise. The owner of an apartment should have a policy covering his i nterests and liabilities and the cooperative corporation or c ondominium association should have one covering the building as a w hole. Sometimes the policies overlap; sometimes there are gaps.

title: IN SALVADOR, HOPE IS AN IMPROVEMENT
description: WASHINGTON THE scene was a diplomatic reception at the home of an American official in San Salvador. Huddled in corners were animated groups of politicians from the four key conservative parties and the centrist Christian Democrats.

title: Miss Livingstone Wed to George Steers
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday, Charleen Elizabeth Livingstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Livingstone of Belmont, Mass., and Cooperstown, N.Y., was married to George Harvey Steers, son of Judith Steers of Brookville, L.I., and J. Rich Steers of New York. The Rev. W. Murray Kenney, assisted by the Rev. Clark Thompson, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: ALGERIA AND THE MOVIES
description: HERITAGE By Peter Driscoll. 437 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95. MAX By Howard Fast. 395 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title: No Headline
description: WASHINGTON WINS BY 46-25

title: BANK TO REMOVE BUCKLING MARBLE FACADE
description: Embarrassed officials of the Lincoln First Bank have begun stripping the buckling Italian marble panels from the 27 stories of their nine-year-old headquarters and replacing them with plywood in an $18 million salvage effort.

title:
REVISING TRADE POLICY;
MIAMI - America must get its trade act together.  It's no secret that America is losing out in the international marketplace and is in danger of falling even further behind unless we develop a comprehensive national export policy that involves changing some of our ways.
description: A first step in that policy would be reorganization of the trade bureaucracy into a strong department of international trade and investment that could speak and negotiate with a strong voice on behalf of America's ' commercial interests. This does not mean creating a new bureaucratic agency or merging the Commerce Department with the Office of the United States Trade Representative. Rather, the Government should unify certain trade and investment responsibilities now divided among the Office of the Trade Representative, the Commerce Department and several other executive branch agencies. Conceivably, the change might include the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.

title: BILL COMMITS F.B.I. TO ASSIST IN HUNT FOR MISSING CHILDREN
description: Four years ago this weekend, thousands of New Englanders converged on Webster, Mass., to search for a little boy who had disappeared near Interstate 52. He has never been found.

title: Runners' Convention
description: What is billed as the largest cross-country meet in the United States will have its 10th running Saturday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Beginning at 9:45 A.M., more than 5,500 runners from 22 schools in eight states will run 26 races of 2.5 miles at 15-minute intervals in the Manhattan College interscholastic cross-country meet. Teams from as far away as Dallas have been entered.

title: CORPORTATE OFFERINGS MAY GROW
description: In the absence of any new Treasury note or bond issues until mid-October, many analysts expect the volume of corporate offerings to increase. Most of the new issues have not been formally announced, although many have already been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CARTER ASSERTS BEGIN WILL NOT GIVE UP SETTLEMENTS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter says he believes that Prime Minister Menachem Begin has no intention of ever removing Israeli settlements from the West Bank and ''has a single-minded commitment'' to annex the occupied territories.

title: NEW YORK ACTS TO END THREAT OF SEWAGE SPILL
description: New York City officials hope to divert $88 million from the construction of a new sewage plant so they can repair two crumbling treatment plants in Brooklyn that now threaten to release raw sewage into surrounding waters.

title: 'KOYAANISQATSI,' BACK TO PSYCHEDELIA
description: ''KOYAANISQATSI'' is a slick, naive, chic, maddening, sometimes very beautiful movie that, if it were a book, would look great on a coffee table. The film is an 87-minute essay in images and sound on the state of American civilization. As non-narrative films go, it is remarkably seductive, but so are the color photographs in the National Geographic.

title: DETROIT TEACHERS REJECT A TENTATIVE SETTLEMENT
description: The Detroit Department Federation of Teachers rejected a tentative contract agreement today that would have returned the city's 200,000 students to school by Tuesday.

title: NATO SEEKS ACCORD OVER SOVIET TRADE
description: The foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met here today and agreed to look for ways to better coordinate Western policy on trade with the Soviet bloc.

title: THE NEW HELMUT
description: Detentniks devastated by the defeat of Helmut Schmidt, the self-styled East-West ''intermediary,'' are busily characterizing his successor as West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, as a ponderous, dull cornball - a provincial politician with no sweeping weltanschauung.

title: L.S.U. (3-0) PACED BY HILLIARD
description: Jerry Stovall's third season as Louisiana State's football coach was probably going to be his last if something did not happen in a hurry to turn the losing program around.

title: THE WAR TO ATTRACT ALL-SAVER MONEY
description: A major marketing war has erupted among banks, brokerage firms, mutual funds and other financial service companies to lure the tens of billions of dollars invested in ''all-savers'' certificates when the program was authorized a year ago.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Notre Dame at Michigan State (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., tape); Georgia at Mississippi State (Television USA Cable, 9 P.M., tape) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1 P.M. $50,000-added Boojum Handicap (Television - Sports@Channel, 7 P.M., tape); Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. Other Events Harness Racing: Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape); Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M.

title: Holder of Most Stock Will Head Autotote
description: James H. Pierce has been named chief executive of Autotote Ltd., a manufacturer of computerized wagering systems. Mr. Pierce, 52, will succeed Martin I. Zwerin, 57, who is taking early retirement but will remain at the company through early 1983 to aid in the transition. Mr. Pierce, who is acquiring a large block of Autotote stock and will be its largest individual shareholder, is also scheduled to become chairman of the company.

title: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES FOR HOUSE FOCUS ON LOCAL ISSUES
description: Republicans with plausible chances of defeating incumbent House Democrats are running local, not national, campaigns, focusing more on the characteristics of their districts or the weaknesses of their opponents than on matters like the economy. Knowing that the recession makes many Republicans vulnerable on the economy, national party leaders here have stressed the importance of recruiting attractive candidates and have provided the money for it. They have also emphasized building up local campaigns and polling to find particular weaknesses and strengths.

title: City Opera to Rumrill
description: The New York City Opera, having talked to a number of agencies, has decided to take its advertising to Rumrill-Hoyt, a division of Compton Advertising.

title: People
description: * Art Heller elected executive vice president, media-programmingmarketing services, of Griffin Bacal Inc.

title: LIMITING MIDEAST ARMS
description: Prospects for peace in the Middle East depend, in part, on a little-discussed question: The future relations of the United States and Soviet Union to the region, including particularly the flows of arms. This deserves fresh thought, especially in Washington and Moscow.

title: SPAIN SEIZES 3 OFFICERS AS COUP PLOTTERS
description: Three army officers arrested over the weekend were reported today to have been planning a military coup for Oct. 27, a day before national elections that are expected to result in a Socialist government.

title: Chemical Fires Keep Town Empty a 5th Day
description: About six cars continued to smolder today, five days after the fiery derailment of a train loaded with chemicals.

title: BONN'S NEW LEADER FACES SERIOUS SHORT-TERM POLITICAL CHALLENGES
description: West Germany's new Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, is facing a number of short-term political problems that could distract him and his three-party coalition from their larger agenda, officials here believe.

title: KILLINGS IN ROCHDALE VILLAGE CAUSE NEIGHBOR TO FEAR NEIGHBOR
description: Julia Fletcher says she wants to double-lock the door of her apartment in Rochdale Village in Queens and never go out again. ''But I've got to go out,'' the retired New York City social worker said. ''I moved here from Brooklyn because it was getting rough there. Now it's getting rough here. I don't know where I'm going.''

title: Jersey Will Subsidize Mortgages With Bonds
description: New Jersey residents buying single-family houses for the first time will be able to get 30-year mortgages at interest rates below 12 percent under a plan by the state's Mortgage Finance Agency, officials said.

title: 'PERNICIOUS MYTH' ABOUT THE THIRD WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: DORMITORY UNIT WAS POORLY RUN, OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: Early findings of poor management, but not illegality, prompted a leadership shake-up and investigation of the New York State Dormitory Authority, state officials and aides to Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: FALL POSES ANOTHER TEST FOR CONSERVATISM OF THE OHIO ELECTORATE
description: From 1868 to 1924, the nation sent seven Ohio Republicans to the White House, from Grant to Harding, and the idea has persisted among Ohioans and even among others that if any state stands for America, this one does. Or, as Ray Bliss, the state's legendary Republican leader, said with a sigh when Senator Robert H. Taft's name was put in nomination at the party's 1952 convention, ''Ohio, the mother of Presidents, is pregnant again.''

title: P.L.O. Names Colonel As New Chief of Staff
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has appointed Col. Mohammed Affani as the organization's chief of staff to replace Brig.

title: Washington Watch; Governing Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission is edging closer to a decision about whether to propose abolishing boards of directors for mutual funds and whether fund shareholders should retain their right to vote.

title: Reading of Grievances Leads To Release of Prison Hostage
description: An inmate held a guard hostage for more than eight hours today, then surrendered after a list of his grievances against the Kentucky State Penitentiary was read over a radio station.

title: No Headline
description: HABIB, ENDING TOUR, MEETS; WITH SYRIAN CHIEF

title: 'Well, It's Over With'
description: BALTIMORE AFTER the game and the season ended, along with his managerial career (at least until it resumes), Earl Weaver hopped up the steps of the Baltimore Orioles' dugout yesterday and waved goodbye with his cap to the thousands of faces who were cheering him. Soon he hurried through the tunnel into the Orioles' clubhouse and now he was in his office.

title: Last Day to Register
description: Today is the last day to register by mail to vote in New York State in the general election Nov. 2, according to Betty Dolen, the executive director of the New York City Board of Elections.

title: A.M.C. Prices Up 1%
description: The American Motors Corporation has announced that prices for a typically equipped 1983 model A.M.C. or Renault car would rise $90, or 1 percent, from comparable 1982 models.

title: Advertising; Scrabble: Ingenuity Vs. Money
description: BOARD games - time-killers such as chess, checkers, Monopoly and Scrabble - are experiencing their first sales declines in memory, still another victim of the cash-absorbent video games craze.

title: Nancy Meyrich and Richard Krasnow Are Married
description: The marriage of Nancy Meyrich, a law-library consultant and cataloguer with the New York County Lawyers Association, to Richard Pearson Krasnow, a partner in the New York law firm of Weil Gotshal & Manges, took place yesterday at the Terrace Restaurant atop Butler Hall. Cantor Ellen Math officiated.

title: Wheaton Offered $1 Million
description: Wheaton College says it has received an offer of $1 million for endowed scholarships, the largest scholarship gift in its history. The grant, from the Gebbie Foundation of Jamestown, N.Y., provides $200,000 now, and $200,000 for each $4 million raised in the college's capital campign up to $16 million.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: ''I got the impression he felt he was being rejected by blacks and whites, and he took pressure from both sides.'' This comment and others like it appeared in news reports last week as those who knew George Banks reacted to his arrest in connection with the murder of 13 people in rural Pennsylvania. Mr. Banks, the son of a white mother and a black father who has been charged with the 13 killings, was pictured as a man filled with resentment for both races.

title: COMPETITIVE EFFECT OF NEW BANK BILL
description: A price war between traditional rivals, thrift institutions and small commercial banks, could result from the landmark banking bill that won final Congressional approval in a voice vote in the House Friday night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Nuclear Law

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 4, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Iran-Iraq war at 4 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GUARDIAN ANGELS SEIZED IN PROTEST AT SCHURZ PARK
description: The police arrested 24 Guardian Angels on disorderly conduct charges near Gracie Mansion last night, after they refused to abandon a cluster of cardboard shacks in which they had been living to protest what they called the city's failure to meet the needs of homeless people.

title: Why Hold Checks Hostage?
description: Friday: Joe deposits check in bank account. Monday: Joe writes rent check on proceeds. Wednesday: Rent check bounces. Much embarrassment. Joe, furious, reaches third assistant to bank branch manager on fourth phone call. Deposits require four business days to clear, the functionary explains, unsympathetic. Ten days if they come from out-of-state bank.

title: South Africa Police Charged With a Black Woman's Death
description: South African security police have been formally accused in the case of an 18-year-old black woman who died two weeks after being released from detention.

title: GENERAL FOR A SPECIAL FORCE
description: In a quiet ceremony that befitted soldiers trained to fight behind enemy lines, Brig. Gen. Joseph C. Lutz signed the orders that brought into service the Army's new Special Operations Command at Fort Bragg, N.C.

title: POLISH PARADE BRINGS OUT CANDIDATES
description: There were V-for-Victory signs from Lewis E. Lehrman and waves for the crowd from Mario M. Cuomo. Frances A. Sclafani, who wants to be Attorney General, was all smiles, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who wants to remain a Senator, waxed philosophical.

title: RUSSIANS COME AND GO, BUT NOT GROMYKO
description: Cordell Hull was Secretary of State when Stalin named Andrei A. Gromyko as his Ambassador to Washington. John Foster Dulles was in the office when Nikita S. Khrushchev made Mr. Gromyko his Foreign Minister, and seven more secretaries came and went before the master of Soviet diplomacy sat down for three hours last Tuesday to take the measure of George P. Shultz at the United Nations. He and the Secretary of State are scheduled to meet again Monday at the Soviet Mission in New York.

title: St. Francis Beats Mount St. Michael
description: St. Francis Prep withstood a second-half rally to defeat Mount St. Michael, 12-11, yesterday, in a Catholic High Schools Football League game at St. John's University in Jamaica.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BIG MOVERS IN STOCK MARKET
description: Blue-chip stocks such as General Electric and International Business Machines scored solid gains in the stock market's spectacular summer rally. But the best performers on the New York Stock Exchange for the first nine months of 1982 were typically much smaller companies that are unfamiliar to most investors.

title: Governor Candidates In Illinois Clash on TV
description: Gov. James R. Thompson's ethics and former Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d's personality brought the sharpest clashes today when the two Illinois gubernatorial candidates appeared in a broadcast interview.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Belk Stores Services Inc., Charlotte, N.C., has named Robert N. Wildrick senior vice president. He will continue as general manager of Belk Stores Services Inc., New York.

title: DANCE: BONNIE WEIN'S NEW WORKS
description: IF only it had been emotionally torrid or icy. If only it had been daft, outrageous or ribald. If only it had been dramatically intense or formally rigorous. If only it had possessed at least some sort of urgency. But Saturday night's program of dances by Bonnie Weins at the Merce Cunningham Studio was bland from start to finish.

title: KEAN SEEKS AGENCY TO HELP MAINTAIN ROADS AND SEWERS
description: Governor Kean plans to ask the Federal Government, the New Jersey Legislature and the public for permission to establish a new ''bank'' to help pay for $10 billion in repairs and maintenance for sewers, water treatment systems and roads statewide.

title: FOR 2 SMALL COLLEGES, A BIG DAY ON TV
description: For one glorious Sunday, Wittenberg and Baldwin-Wallace became America's teams. For most television viewers, they were the only teams they had this afternoon because of the pro football strike.

title: Ethiopians Accused Of Massacre in Ogaden
description: Western Somali guerrillas accused Ethiopian soldiers today of killing 500 civilians in the Ogaden region of southeast Ethiopia.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
description: International Six Israeli soldiers were killed and 22 others wounded in an ambush six miles east of Lebanon's capital on the Beirut-Damascus highway. The attackers were not identified. Military analysts said that the ambush, the second in three days on Israeli troops in the area, could provoke retaliatory raids by Israeli artillery on Syrian and Palestinian positions across the cease-fire line. (Page A1, Column 6.) The foreign ministers of NATO agreed to set in motion a series of studies on how Western security interests are affected by energy policies and the extension of credits to the Soviet bloc nations. The ministers' discussion was seen as a step toward easing the conflict among NATO partners over financial dealings with the Soviet Union and its allies. (A1:5.)

title: Yankees Lose Finale
description: The Yankees concluded the season yesterday by losing to Boston for the third time in three games, 5-3, in 11 innings. That gave them a 79-83 record, their worst since 1967, when they were 72-90.

title: American League Championship; Brewers vs. Angels
description: Tomorrow - Milwaukee at California, 8:25 P.M. Oct. 6 - Milwaukee at California, 8:15 P.M. Oct. 8 - California at Milwaukee, 3:15 P.M. *Oct. 9 - California at Milwaukee, 1 P.M. *Oct, 10 - California at Milwaukee, 4:20 P.M. *If necessary. National League Championship Braves vs.

title: FOOTBALL ALL-STAR ROSTERS
description: Rosters for the proposed All-Star Game planned by the National Football League Players Association, scheduled for Oct. 10 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington. NATIONAL EAST Offense Wide Receivers - Art Monk, Washington; Earnest Gray, Giants; Pat Tilley, St. Louis; Harold Carmichael, Philadelphia. Tight Ends - John Spagnola, Philadelphia; Gary Shirk, Giants. Tackles - Jerry Sisemore, Philadelphia; George Starke, Washington; Gordon King, Giants. Guards - Terry Stieve, St. Louis; Mark May, Washington; Steve Kenney, Philadelphia. Centers - Jeff Bostic, Washington; Guy Morris, Philadelphia. Quarterbacks - Joe Theismann, Washington; Neil Lomax, St. Louis. Running Backs - John Riggins, Washington; O.J. Anderson, St. Louis; Wilbert Montgomery, Philadelphia; Robert Newhouse, Dallas.

title: 2 Ward Units Closing
description: Montgomery Ward & Company has announced that it will close two of its nine catalogue distribution centers - in Albany and Portland, Ore. - at the end of the year, idling 1,100 workers.

title: 11 CHILDREN FROM VIETNAM LAND ON THE COAST
description: Eleven Vietnamese-American children who left Vietnam last week to rejoin their American fathers arrived in the United States today.

title: Bridge: California Pair Gets Lead In World Mixed Pairs Play
description: A California pair leapfrogged to the head of the standings after the third session of play in the World Mixed Pair Championship here this afternoon. John and Peggy Sutherlin of San Francisco recorded an astonishing 73 percent and moved from 61st in the field of 450 pairs to the top spot.

title: Supreme Court Blues
description: Even before the Supreme Court calls the first case of its new term on this first Monday in October, six of the nine justices hold that the Court is in trouble. They spoke out individually during the summer recess, each giving a useful glimpse into life atop the law's Olympus.

title: Soviet Official Arrives In Peking for Talks
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Leonid F. Ilyichev of the Soviet Union arrived in Peking today for talks on the prickly relations between the two nations, the first high-level official visit to China by a Moscow envoy in three years.

title: Variations on a Theme
description: Whatever happened to ''Have a nice day''? It's still comme il faut for ending transactions at the butcher shop or the dry cleaner's. But New Yorkers who pay attention to such matters have noticed that some telephone information operators no longer chirp the cheerful phrase after giving the desired number.

title: MANY VARIABLES TO DETERMINE NEXT YANKEE ROSTER
description: Whether Clyde King or Billy Martin is the manager of the Yankees next season, what kind of lineup would he devise from this alignment? 1B-Jason Thompson; 2B-Willie Randolph; SS-Andre Robertson; 3B-Buddy Bell; LF-Dave Winfield; CF-Omar Moreno, RF-Ken Griffey; C-Butch Wynegar, and DH-Don Baylor. Or would Baylor be the first baseman and Steve Kemp the designated hitter? Maybe neither Thompson nor Baylor would be the first baseman; maybe the first baseman would be Griffey and the right fielder Jack Clark.

title: TV: A STRAVINSKY-BALANCHINE GALA
description: THE packaging for tonight's ''Lincoln Center Special,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8, is somewhat curious. The title, ''Stravinsky & Balanchine - Genius Has a Birthday!,'' is unnecessarily pompous, much in the manner of those inflated radio commericals for the Metropolitan Opera (''Welcome to civilization!''). And the opening moments display George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, the founders of the New York City Ballet, in what looks like an old routine from the vaudeville act of Gallagher and Sheean.

title: DEBT BURDENS TAKE BIG TOLL OF BUSINESSES
description: For more than half a century, the Burnside Steel Foundry made tools for heavy industry. With annual sales of about $10 million, it was a source of economic strength on Chicago's industrial South Side, and employed dozens of workers.

title: 6 ISRAELI SOLDIERS KILLED IN AMBUSH ON LEBANON ROAD
description: Six Israeli soldiers were killed and 22 others were wounded today in an ambush six miles east of Lebanon's capital on the Beirut-Damascus highway, the Israeli military command said. Military officials said the attackers were not identified.

title: How Old Is Man?
description: Paleoanthropologist Richard Leakey recently announced the discovery of an important humanlike fossil jawbone in the Samburu Hills of Kenya. Once, any new fossil of early man was acclaimed as ''The Missing Link.'' But Mr. Leakey modestly noted that the new discovery merely filled a gap in the fossil record, as, indeed, almost any new fossil must.

title: Harbor Pilots in Israel Strike For a Day Over Salary Scale
description: Israel's harbor pilots staged a one-day warning strike today, effectively halting all commercial traffic at Israel's ports, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Yankees Records
description: BATTING AB H HR RBI PC Rodriguez 9 3 0 1 .333 Piniella 261 80 6 37 .307 Mumphrey 477 143 9 68 .300 Randolph 553 155 3 36 .280 Winfield 539 151 37 106 .280 Griffey 485 134 12 54 .276 Gamble 316 86 18 57 .272 Wynegar 277 74 4 28 .267 Evans 31 8 0 2 .258 Smalley 499 127 20 67 .255 Collins 348 88 3 25 .253 Mazzilli 323 81 10 34 .251 Nettles 405 94 18 55 .232 Murcer 141 32 7 30 .227 Cerone 300 68 5 28 .227 Robertson 118 26 2 9 .220 Mayberry 248 54 10 30 .218 Patterson 15 3 1 1 .200 Balboni 107 20 2 4 .187 Mattingly 12 2 0 1 .167 Foote 48 7 0 2 .146 Ramos 11 1 1 2 .091 Team - AB, 5,526 H, 1,417 HR, 161, RBI, 666.256 PITCHING W L IP SO ERA Kaufman 1 0 9 1 5.19 LaRoche 4 2 50 31 3.42 Guidry 14 8 222 162 3.81 Rawley 11 10 164 111 4.066 Righetti 11 10 183 163 3.79 Erickson 8 8 111 49 4.61 Frazier 4 4 112 69 3.47 May 6 10 85 2.89 Gossage 4 5 93 102 2.23 Howell 2 3 28 21 7.71 Morgan 7 11 150 71 4.37 Alexander 1 7 67 26 6.08 Wever 0 1 3 2 27.00 McGlothen 0 0 5 2 10.80

title: PURCHASERS CITE LAG IN 3D QUARTER
description: The third quarter saw a gradual decline in the industrial sector, the nation's purchasing managers report in their latest survey. Although there was no sharp plunge, the survey shows, business activity slackened and employment was lower.

title: 11 TURTLES FOUND DEAD ON BEACHES ON LONG ISLAND
description: Leatherback turtles, an endangered species, have been dying in large numbers on Long Island's South Shore, and marine scientists are trying to find out why.

title: BEIRUT CONFESSION ON ISRAEL TV
description: Israeli television broadcast an interview today with a man who identified himself as a Lebanese Christian militia commander and who said that he killed 15 Palestinians in the Beirut refugee camps during the massacre last month.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982; The Economy
description: Federal and state tax policies head the Supreme Court's docket of business-related cases to be heard in its new term. (Page D1.)

title: MERGER ADVISERS UNDER FIRE
description: In the world of mergers and acquisitions, it is conventional wisdom that -whatever the fates of the companies involved - the investment bankers always win. But the Martin Marietta-Bendix-Allied-United Technologies takeover wrangle, which has overturned many truisms, may have disproved that one, too.

title: Dr. Judith Weisman, Surgeon, Is Bride
description: Dr. Judith Weisman and Dr. Ronald George Malseptic, physicians at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, were married yesterday at the Woman's Club of White Plains. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Edward Kearney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: KNICKS SEE GRUNFELD AS 3-POSITION PLAYER
description: At a time when few National Basketball Association teams appeared to be rushing into the free-agent market, the Knicks did not hesitate to sign the free agent Ernie Grunfeld. Their thinking appeared clear: they were buying insurance at the small-forward position, their most troublesome. Grunfeld played small forward in college, with the Milwaukee Bucks after they made him their top draft choice in 1977, and with the Kansas City Kings.

title: Losing Big
description: When Guide Rock defeated Republican City, 80-0, in an eight-man high school football game in Nebraska last month, the winning coach felt more upset than the loser did.

title: GIANTS FOIL DODGER TITLE BID
description: Joe Morgan's three-run homer put an end to the Los Angeles Dodgers' hopes for a division championship today. The blow by the San Francisco Giants' second baseman broke a 2-2 tie in the seventh inning and led the Giants to a 5-3 victory before 49,518 fans at Candlestick Park.

title: DARRYL DAWKINS FACES TOUGH LEARNING EXPERIENCE
description: PRINCETON, N.J. ''C'MON, Darryl, see the ball,'' Coach Larry Brown was yelling. The command was to his newest pupil, Darryl Dawkins, last Friday during the opening practice at the training camp of the New Jersey Nets here on the campus of Princeton University. ''Pick it up, use your feet,'' Brown shouted. ''Use 'em!''

title: Swami Muktananda, Hindu Leader in India
description: Swami Muktananda, an internationally known Hindu religious leader, died late Saturday at Thane, near Bombay, the United News of India reported.

title: Lord, Geller Welcomes Analog and DuCair
description: Richard J. Lord, president of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, communicates the good news of two incoming accounts, one with $1 million in billings and another that has not had its budget set.

title: A TRAGEDY USED FOR DEFAMATION
description: To the Editor:$

title: Wendy J. Gilmore Is Bride Of Scott Raffa, Consultant
description: The marriage of Wendy Jane Gilmore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Gilmore of Roslyn Heights, L.I., to Scott Greggory Raffa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Greggory Raffa of Searington, L.I., took place yesterday in Manhattan.

title: PEALE MARKS 50 YEARS IN MINISTRY
description: On a morning of memory and emotion, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the homespun preacher who made ''positive thinking'' a part of the American vocabulary, yesterday marked a half century at the pulpit of Marble Collegiate Reformed Church. Thousands packed the historic church to pay him tribute.

title: Court to Hear Players' Motion
description: Among the crisscrossing litigation filed during the National Football League players' strike, which today reached a 13th day, was a motion filed last Wednesday by the players association against the league that will be heard here Monday in Federal District Court.

title: Bridal for Sandra E. Gilbert and Marc D. Freidus
description: The marriage of Sandra Ellen Gilbert to Marc David Freidus took place yesterday on the grounds of the Gill St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Marc Hurvitz performed the ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Gilbert of Whippany, N.J. Mr. Freidus is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Freidus of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Sotheby Officer Joining Goldman, Sachs Unit
description: ''I wanted to return to my first love, which is investment banking,'' said Peter J.R. Spira, who is leaving the troubled Sotheby Parke Bernet Group for the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.

title: STAGE: 'TALKING WITH,' A FIND FROM LOUISVILLE
description: FOR two seasons now, the excited talk has been streaming north from Louisville about Jane Martin, the new playwright uncovered by that city's highly regarded Actors Theater. Miss Martin has received great acclaim both for her ability to write one-woman playlets and for her modesty. In a profession generally dominated by egomaniacs, the pseudonymous Miss Martin has kept her identity a tightly held secret. While it's perhaps safe to presume that she is not the late Col. Harlan Sanders - or, as was once speculated, Phyllis George - all other bets are off.

title: Index; International
description: Gromyko, the ultimate survivor A2 Guyana to buy planes and personnel carriers from Brazil A4 Around the World A5 Israel must take some blame for killings, generals tell Sharon A6 Phalangist, on Israeli TV, says he took part in massacre A6 Habib, ending Middle East tour, meets with Syrian leader A7 West German leader faces serious political problems A12 General Around the Nation A14 Lewis B. Rome works for Connecticut voters' attention B1 Killings cause fear among Rochdale Village residents B2 Police arrest 24 Guardian Angels near Gracie Mansion B3 A.C.L.U. urges warrants for F.B.I. operations like Abscam B9 Government/Politics Pulaski Day Parade draws election candidates B3 Conservatism again tested in Ohio elecion B8 Arts/Entertainment ''Koyaanisqatsi,'' a movie essay, to be shown tonight C14 ''The Tyrant's Heart,'' Hungarian film, shown at festival C14 Manhattan Theater Club opens with Louisville work C16 ''Visit From the Footbinder,'' by Emily Prager, reviewed C17 Bonnie Weins offers dance at Cunningham studio C17 De Danaan, Irish traditional- music group, plays Town Hall C18 Celebration of Stravinsky's 100th birthday on Channel 13 C19 Papp plans year-round Shakespeare despite losses C20 Susanne Marsee is Carmen at City Opera C20 SportsMonday Baseball: Brewers beat Orioles for American League East title C1

title: MONEY GROWTH LEEWAY SEEN
description: At a meeting this week of Federal Reserve officials in charge of setting monetary policy, many Wall Street analysts expect them to do what they can to help the economy by keeping interest rates from rising significantly.

title: WHY BE ABLE TO DO 140 IF 55 IS THE LIMIT?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Sewers and drainpipes don't make attractive political platforms.'' Governor Kean of New Jersey. (A1:2.)

title: FANNING TO RETURN TO EXPOS' FRONT OFFICE
description: Jim Fanning, who left the front office of the Montreal Expos on Sept. 8, 1981 to replace Dick Williams as manager, said yesterday that he would return as vice president in charge of player development.

title: U.S. EXPECTS 11 NUCLEAR PLANTS WILL NEED CHANGES
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff has concluded that at least 11 nuclear plant units will require ''modifications in the near future'' to guard against a potentially disastrous rupture of their reactor walls. The staff said, however, that there was no imminent danger of such an accident.

title: THE SPECIAL NEEDS OF ALCOHOLIC WOMEN
description: Female alcoholics have special needs that are not being met, mainly because they are reluctant to seek treatment because of the social stigma attached to alcoholism, according to experts who attended a conference in New York on drinking.

title: Muhammad Stops Mwale in Fourth
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad secured his position as the World Boxing Association's top light-heavyweight contender Saturday night by knocking out Lotte Mwale of Zambia, the World Boxing Council's No.1 contender, at 1 minute 47 seconds of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-rounder.

title: Advise and Consent
description: Earl Campbell of the Houston Oilers is a strong man, a very tough runner to bring down. He gained 4,444 yards in three years at the University of Texas, then led the National Football League in rushing in each of his first three pro seasons, beginning in 1978. His 224 yards gained in two games this season again lead the league.

title: Akiyda Captures Prix de l'Arc
description: The Aga Khan's Akiyda made a bold move along the rail and won by a head from fast-closing Ardross today in the $285,000 Prix de l'Arc Triomphe at the Longchamps race course.

title: Susan Ostrov Married To Kenneth H. Brief
description: Susan Ostrov, daughter of Beatrice Ostrov of Long Beach, L.I., and Alfred Ostrov of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Kenneth H. Brief, son of Helen Brief of West Orange, N.J., and the late Herman Brief.

title: Iranian Air Force Plane Is Reportedly Hijacked
description: An Iranian Air Force C-130 Hercules transport plane was hijacked and flown to the Dubai airport today but later left for an unknown destination, the official United Arab Emirates news agency reported.

title: Barbara Potter Wins
description: Barbara Potter came into the United States Women's Indoor tennis championships not looking past the first round, but she left tonight with the first prize of $22,000.

title: WILSON WINS TITLE
description: Dave Beard of the Oakland A's developed a tender pitching arm, and Mark Ryal, an outfielder for the Kansas City Royals, found his glasses fogging, both rather suddenly in the ninth inning of the clubs' season finale today - and it all had to do with Willie Wilson of the Royals winning the American League batting crown.

title: Gainers and Losers
description: Through the Third Quarter of 1982 Stocks with largest percentage price change from end of 1981. Does not include issues suspended from trading during the quarter. New York Stock Exchange Year Sept. To-Date 28 52- 52- 1981 1982 Percent wk wk Stock High Low Close Close Change

title: Grete Waitz Wins Race in Stockholm
description: Grete Waitz of Norway, in top form again after a foot injury, captured her seventh consecutive victory in the women's 15-kilometer event today at the world's biggest cross-country meet.

title: A MESSAGE TO GARVEY
description: SAN FRANCISCO STEVE GARVEY was the last man in uniform, long after the crushing loss, long after Joe Morgan's triumphant curtain call, long after the public-address system played ''I Left My Heart in San Francisco.''

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A fair fly ball is hit down the right-field line. The outfielder mishandles the ball and it drops inside the stands without touching the ground. What is the ruling? Does it matter what base the batter has reached?

title: WOMAN FOUND BEATEN TO DEATH IN CHELSEA HOME
description: A 72-year-old woman who had installed a heavy lock after a robbery attempt two years ago was found beaten to death yesterday in her oneroom Chelsea apartment in what the police said was an apparent robbery.

title: MUSIC: A NEW FLUTE WORK BY REICH
description: STEVE REICH'S music worked its narcotic magic at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. There was one new work and three older ones, but together they formed a single musical experience. It may have been narcosis that we felt, though some would have argued for sharpened self-awareness. Whatever the effect of this music, whether it soothed or aroused the senses, no one could deny its ability to take us from one world of consciousness into another and to shatter our sense of time in the process.

title: 'WE HAVE TO START FROM SCRATCH'
description: In the year of the new offense, the new manager and the new magic, the Mets won four straight games at their best; lost 15 straight at their worst; lost 24 of 29 in August; lost 97 of 162 over all; swept no doubleheaders and finished sixth.

title: Commodities; Traders In Rate Futures
description: WHO trades interest rate futures? The question is being increasingly asked in the trade for three reasons: there are no precise figures and the growth of financial futures has been such that they are expected to account for roughly half of all exchange-traded commodity contracts by yearend, compared with the current level of just over 40 percent. And not all interest rate futures have been equally successful.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Imposing Facade

title: Pitches 4-Hitter
description: The Mets, who opened the season last April by beating Steve Carlton, closed it today by losing to Carlton and the Phillies, 4-1. It was the 23d victory of the year against 11 defeats for Carlton, who pitched a four-hitter and struck out 13 batters for a season's total of 286, the most in the National League.

title: 2 More Arrests Made In Bomb Threat to Plant
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested a third and fourth suspect in a $15 million bomb threat directed against the Cedar Bayou plant of Gulf Oil Chemicals.

title: MUBARAK ASSERTS THE ISRAELIS ARE 'BEATING DRUMS OF WAR'
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin was ''once again beating the drums of war'' in the Middle East.

title: THE BEAM AND THE MOTE
description: Donald B. Sole was South Africa's Ambassador to Washington for five years. Just before going home last May he wrote a letter to The New York Times objecting to a comment about South Africa's ''vicious racism.''

title: COMING OUT OF LEFT FIELD, STEINBRENNER?
description: To paraphrase George Santayana, those who ignore history are destined to repeat the same mistakes -a lesson that seems to apply to happy George Steinbrenner, the baseball wizard and boss of the New York Yankees.

title: News Analysis
description: Before Britain's political parties began holding their annual conferences, Sir Harold Wilson, the former Prime Minister, delivered a harsh judgment about the Labor Party.

title: FOR BALLROOM DANCERS, 1-2-3 ELEGANCE AND STYLE
description: The ballroom floor at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum yesterday was a secondhand maple basketball court, coarsely sanded. The taperecorded music blared over loudspeakers.

title: Maybelline-Marschalk; Dodge Choice Narrows
description: The Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group, will be splitting with the people who make Maybelline products on Jan.1. It has been a four-year relationship.

title: COAL HAULERS DEAD SET AGAINST COMPETITION
description: To the Editor:

title: DOFFING HATS TO TRADITION
