description: It all started, like so many minor controversies in England, with a letter to The Times of London. ''As Chief Beadle of the Burlington Arcade, Piccadilly,'' wrote Jim Agnew, ''may I enlist the support of your readers for the defence of our top hats, which are in peril?''

title: PRIVATE SCHOOL ROLLS FELL BY A THIRD FROM '64 TO '79
description: Despite surveys that found widespread dissatisfaction with public education in recent years, enrollment in private elementary and high schools has declined over the past two decades, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEST FRIENDS

title: Coins Save Teen-Ager Hit in Chest by Bullet
description: A teen-ager who slipped five coins into his shirt picket while waiting for a friend received only bruises when a bullet struck his chest moments later.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Players column in Sports Pages on Sept. 25 was incorrectly bylined. The writer was Ira Berkow.

title: Farley to Buy Unit of NL
description: Farley Industries, a privately held concern with interests in coal mining, folding machines, health foods and graphics arts, said it had agreed to purchase the metal products business of NL Industries Inc. for $120 million.

title: Salesman's Revenge
description: James Robbins had his first big assignment. This was in 1976, just after he had made it out of the stockroom.

title: ISRAEL HAS TO ACCEPT BLAME, GENERALS TELL SHARON
description: The Israeli radio said today that when a group of Israeli generals confronted Defense Minister Ariel Sharon last week, they told him that Israel had to accept moral responsibility for the massacre of civilians in Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut last month whatever the findings of a pending judicial commission of inquiry.

title: Baseball; AMERICAN LEAGUE; YESTERDAY'S GAMES
description: Boston 5, Yankees 3 (11 inn.). California 7, Texas 6. Chicago 6, Minnesota 1. Detroit 9, Cleveland 1. Milwaukee 10, Baltimore 2.

title: 4 of 8 Newspaper Unions Back Philadelphia Pact
description: A contract was approved today by members of the largest union representing workers at Philadelphia's two major newspapers, where a labor dispute had briefly shut down production.

title: GUYANA DECIDES TO PURCHASE BRAZILIAN MILITARY EQUIPMENT
description: President Forbes Burnham of Guyana said today that his Government was buying reconnaissance planes and armored personnel carriers from Brazil because of the possibility of a territorial war with Venezuela.

title: TALKS IN TEANECK GO ON IN STRIKE BEFORE MEDIATOR
description: Talks between the Teaneck Board of Education and striking teachers and other school employees continued here today, and a state mediator in the case said tonight that before a settlement could be reached there would have to be ''further change'' in the positions of both sides.

title: Tuskegee Aerospace Plan
description: Next year, Tuskegee Institute will become the first predominantly black college in the nation to offer a bachelor's degree in aerospace engineering, officials of the school say. The program and an aerospace center will be built with a grant of $9 million from the United States Department of Education.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Names a President
description: A. Dano Davis, son of one of the founders of Winn-Dixie Stores Inc., has been named president, succeeding Bert L. Thomas, 64 years old, who died of a stroke last Wednesday two days before the annual meeting.

title: Red Brigade Suspects Are Seized in Naples
description: The Italian police arrested 10 suspected Red Brigade members and seized arms and documents in their heaviest blow against the guerrilla network for many months, police sources said today.

title: KILLINGS POSE CHALLENGE TO JAIL GUARD QUALIFICATIONS
description: BARRE, Pa., Oct. 1 - In the wake of a shooting spree that left 13 adults and children dead in northeastern Pennsylvania, one question persists about the prison guard charged in the slayings: How does a man like that, a former felon convicted in a crime with a gun, become a prison guard, anyway?

title: HOUSE PANEL REPORT QUESTIONS CUTBACKS IN STATISTICS PROGRAMS
description: The Reagan Administration, a House committee has concluded, has eliminated or reduced at least 50 major statistical programs that measure the state of the economy, the health of the nation and the effectiveness of Federal programs.

title: ROME STRIVES FOR RECOGNITION IN CONNECTICUT GUBERNATORIAL BID
description: Lewis B. Rome got into the habit of rising at 5 A.M. when he was the majority leader of the State Senate, in the early 1970's, so he could put in two hours at his law office before arriving at the Capitol. Those were the leisurely days. Now, in the challenger's role in a campaign for Governor, he rises at 4 A.M. in his quest for votes.

title: Market Place; Early-Call Bond Clauses
description: ONLY a year ago Wall Street bond ads stressed safety - urging investors to buy short term. Now they stress liquidity less and urge investors to buy long-term bonds and thus ''lock in'' high yields.

title: YEAR-ROUND SHAKESPEARE IS AMONG PAPP'S PLANS
description: Despite mounting concern over finances because of a sharp reduction in profits from ''A Chorus Line'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' Joseph Papp is plunging ahead with an ambitious new season that will feature year-round Shakespeare, an exchange with the Royal Court Theater of London and new works by American playwrights.

title: 5 Killed as Twin-Engine Plane Crashes Into Arizona Woods
description: Five people were killed today in the crash of a twin-engine plane that went down in a heavily wooded area after taking off from Pulliam Airport here.

title: CAPSULE DEATHS: A HUNT ON FOR MORE THAN ONE SUSPECT
description: Attorney General Tyrone Fahner of Illinois hinted today that his special investigation force was looking for more than one person in its search to determine who spiked the Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules with cyanide, killing at least seven people in this area.

title: WARRANTS URGED FOR F.B.I. OPERATIONS LIKE ABSCAM
description: A study by the American Civil Liberties Union of undercover operations staged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation concludes that the bureau should be required to obtain a judicial warrant before staging a ruse that offers someone the opportunity to commit a crime.

title: Mistaken Identity
description: It was not the cheese that told Charley Feeney something strange was going on when he checked into his room at the Sheraton Harbor Island Hotel in San Diego last Friday. The bottle of champagne was a little unusual, but it was accepted with thanks.

title: ALL-STAR CAST THRIVES IN ATMOSPHERE OF TEAMWORK
description: THEY have been likened to the members of an exclusive club - the Fortune 500 of baseball. At times, it does seem that the only acquisition Gene Autry forgot to make when the California Angels were being assembled was a tour guide. Imagine baseball fans being led through the locker room before a game, down the Avenue of the Angels.

title: TO RAISE OPERA FUNDS, MIX NAMES AND RECIPES
description: The notion of having celebrities contribute recipes for a cookbook to benefit a worthy cause is not new, but when the beneficiary is based in Washington, it draws from a noteworthy range of contributors, some of whom may even venture into the kitchen from time to time.

title: MAN O' WAR WON BY NASKRA'S BREEZE
description: Naskra's Breeze caught Sprink in the final jump yesterday to win the $173,100 Man o' War Stakes at Belmont Park and become the first New York-bred horse with a legitimate chance at winning an Eclipse Award.

title: CLEANER WATER IN SPITE OF REAGAN'S E.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH ON THE PRIMARY: NO ANGER OR HINDSIGHT
description: On Thursday afternoon, Sept. 23, Edward I. Koch was walking with friends and aides along Madison Avenue in midtown Manhattan, shaking hands and waving to people waiting for express buses to the Bronx and Queens. Mr. Koch was, he said, ''campaigning up to the last minute,'' and he recalled the reception as ''very warm and supportive.''

title: PATERNO PUTS FAITH IN PENN STATE PASSING
description: WHEN Penn State got inside the Alabama 2-yard line in the fourth quarter of the 1979 Sugar Bowl, trailing by 14-7, Coach Joe Paterno as always didn't hesitate to order two straight dives into the line on third and fourth downs. Matt Suhey and then Mike Guman failed to score. Penn State, ranked No.1 and undefeated going into the game, lost its best chance to be the final No.1 team as Alabama won, 14-7.

title: No Headline
description: SUDAN DECIDES TO SEND TROOPS TO HELP IRAQ IN WAR

title: Continental Air Tries Frequent-Flier Twist
description: In newspaper ads in 50 markets and TV spots in 25, Continental Airlines will tomorrow be announcing its new gimmick as summed up by the Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein headline: ''Fly now. Pay never.''

title: Service Dismantling Aging Titan 2 Missiles
description: The Air Force has begun to dismantle its aging Titan 2 missiles and said it hopes to complete the process soon.

title: JOHN R. STRACHAN, 66, A RETIRED POSTMASTER OF MANHATTAN OFFICE
description: John R. Strachan, retired Postmaster of Manhattan, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A TRAGEDY USED FOR DEFAMATION
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT TO WEIGH TAX ISSUES
description: Legal disputes over state and Federal tax policies dominate the Supreme Court's docket of business cases as the Justices prepare to open their 1982-83 term.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebrating St. Francis

title: FREEDOM COMES PAINFULLY FOR 4 POLES IN U.S.
description: They were four men who had barely known each other when they were sent to retrieve a yacht abandoned in Athens when martial law was imposed in Poland. One by one, they had decided not to go home.

title: Pamela Johnson Is Wed
description: Pamela Johnson, daughter of Roberta Johnson Swirsky of Woodbridge, Conn., and Leonard A. Johnson of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday to Kenneth Van Leeuwen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Van Leeuwen of Babylon, L.I. Justice of the Peace Eugene Kaplan performed the ceremony at the Woodbridge Country Club.

title: IRISH MUSIC: DE DANAAN AT TOWN HALL
description: TRADITIONAL Irish music separates singers from instrumentalists. Saturday at Town Hall, De Danaan honored that split by defying it, as the Irish quartet ended its American tour with the singer Maura O'Connell. De Danaan has had hits in Ireland with Miss O'Connell, but its reputation was made with fire-and-brimstone instrumentals.

title: CITY OPERA: MISS MARSEE IN 'CARMEN'
description: THE New York City Opera provided its production of Bizet's ''Carmen'' on Sunday afternoon with a competent cast, some wellorchestrated fight scenes and a rousing Act IV finale.

title: Military Analysis
description: Western analysts say that the Sudan's decision to send troops to help Iraq repel Iranian attacks along its frontiers could lead to similar action by other Arab governments, particularly those Persian Gulf countries that are deeply concerned by Iran's aggressive policy.

title: E.J. SCHERAGO, AD DIRECTOR, AND MARSHA SAMUEL WED
description: Marsha Samuel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Sidenworm of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Earl J. Scherago, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Scherago of Lexington, Ky. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Livingston, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: Haas, on 65-262, Wins Texas Open by 3

title: Salvadorans Report Hammering the Rebels
description: About 5,000 Government troops pounded rebel strongholds in the eastern half of El Salvador in two operations today, military sources said.

title: Dr. Genie Bailey Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Genie Lark Bailey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kermitt Grey Bailey of Kenly, N.C., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Benjamin Lieberman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Lieberman of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Charles M. Jones, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Sarah P. Duke Gardens at Duke University in Durham, N.C.

title: Explosion Kills Algerian
description: A large stock of fireworks stored in a military camp near here exploded today, killing one of the warehouse guards and injuring others, the official press agency said. The explosion in Boudouaou, 22 miles east of Algiers, destroyed the barracks, the agency said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: A VISIT FROM THE FOOTBINDER. And Other Stories. By Emily Prager. 190 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Mets Records; FINAL
Nova Scotia Bank Reply
description: The Halifax-based Bank of Nova Scotia has charged that tax fraud charges filed against it in the United States are an attempt to hold the bank responsible for the acts of others. The Justice Department had announced that the bank, Canada's fourth largest, and seven individuals had been indicted by a Federal grand jury in what was called a fraudulent tax shelter scheme involving more than $122 million.

title: HOME VIDEO GAMES NEARING PROFITABILITY OF THE FILM BUSINESS
description: Electronic trolls, monsters and visitors from space have intensified their invasion of American homes to such an extent that nearly 15 million American homes are expected to have video-game modules plugged into their television sets by the end of the year.

title: Dr. Cynthia Soffen Wed To Dr. David Cooper
description: The marriage of Dr. Cynthia May Soffen to Dr. David Allen Cooper took place yesterday at the Forsgate Country Club in Jamesburg, N.J. Rabbi Albert Ginsburg performed the ceremony.

title: RISE IN UNEMPLOYMENT SEEN FOR WEST GERMANY
description: Gerhard Stoltenberg, the West German politician who apparently will be the chief financial planner in the new Bonn administration, said today that the number of Germans out of work would likely exceed two million this winter but that Germany's flagging economy could show signs of recovery ''in the course of 1983.''

title: Century Publishing Adds Bowling Digest
description: Norman Jacobs bought Baseball Digest 14 years ago and started Century Publishing Company in Evanston, Ill., which then proceeded to publish Digest magazines for other sports until there were six.

title: Motorist Fixing Towline On Expressway Is Killed
description: A Brooklyn motorist towing a neighbor's disabled van on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was killed and the neighbor seriously injured early yesterday when another car crashed into them after they stopped to secure their towline, the police reported. The driver of the third vehicle was also seriously hurt.

title: 'THE TYRANT'S HEART,' A HUNGARIAN FANTASY
description: THERE'S one in every crowd: Miklos Jancso's''The Tyrant's Heart'' is a bad dream of a movie in an otherwise estimable New York Film Festival this year. This Renaissance fantasy uses wind machines, conveyor belts, masks, duck-shape codpieces, occasional tomtom accompaniment and a bear's cage decorated with origami birds. It also employs an abundance of mime, which is a good many people's least favorite performing art.

title: PREDATED HUDSON
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Once More, With Irony

title: THE FISH THAT COULD BRING $250,000
description: LATE last month while casting at night from a jetty in New Jersey's Absecon Inlet during a wild and wet northeaster, Albert McReynolds of Atlantic City hooked and landed a 78 1/2-pound striped bass - a potential all-tackle world record -after a struggle of an hour and 20 minutes.

title: A BLACK RESPONSIBILITY
description: The time has come for the black community to seriously confront the issue of teenage pregnancy.

title: Robert D. Jackson 3d Weds Edith Barschi
description: Edith Beth Barschi and Robert David Jackson 3d were married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green by Rabbi Bonnie Steinberg. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard K. Barschi of New York. Mr. Jackson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Jr. of Los Angeles.

title: BISHOPS JOINING NUCLEAR ARMS DEBATE
description: Since the spring, senior officials in the Reagan Administration and the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have been quietly debating the emotional and volatile issue of nuclear war.

title: Islamic Calligraphy In Special Show at Met
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has selected 45 objects from its comprehensive collection of Islamic art for an exhibition to illustrate the great calligraphic tradition of Islam.

title: FOUGHT DRUG ABUSE IN HARLEM
description: The Rev. Oberia D. Dempsey, a Harlem minister who crusaded against narcotics for more than two decades, died Saturday of a pulmonary embolism at Harlem Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: BREWERS AND BRAVES TAKE DIVISION CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: Nearly two weeks ago, at a clubhouse meeting of the Atlanta Braves, Joe Torre, the manager, had an announcement to make. ''I don't know how we're going to do it,'' he said. ''But we're going to win.''

title: FAMILIAR ACTORS AT CENTER STAGE
description: As if arranged by Shakespeare instead of television, the presence of Reggie Jackson and Tommy John at centerstage for the California Angels tonight will be baseball's adaptation of ''Measure for Measure,'' or ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' or ''Two Gentlemen From the Bronx.''

title: Hijacking Drama Across Persian Gulf
description: Four hijackers demanding political asylum in the United States seized an Iranian military transport plane, freed 79 passengers and forcedthe aircraft on a tour of the Persian Gulf today.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: B-Including tax credits of $1 million for the qr and $2,720,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $653,000

title: DOW OFF 4.13 AFTER LATE RALLY
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday after an afternoon rally erased some of the earlier sharp losses. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 4.13 points, to 903.61, after being down 11 points at 11 A.M. The late recovery was attributed mostly to bargain hunting. Last week, the blue-chip barometer fell 11.78 points.

title: Strike One!
description: When the National Football League thinks about the effect of the strike on fan appeal, it likes to listen to the baseball propogandists who point out that in 1982, the year after the great baseball strike, fan attendance set records. However, that may be due more to the great gains made by teams like the California Angels and Atlanta Braves, who were involved in pennant races.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE W.P.A. GUIDE TO NEW YORK CITY. The Federal Writers' Project Guide to 1930's New York. With a New Introduction by William H. Whyte. Il- lustrated. 680 pages. Pantheon Books. Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1982
description: International Israeli jets attacked missile positions of Syrians in Lebanon, reportedly destroying a number of sites along the Beirut-Damascus road. The attack followed Sunday's ambush of an Israeli bus in which six Israeli soldiers were killed and 22 were wounded, 11 seriously. (Page A1, Column 6.) Lebanon's Premier was asked to stay by President Amin Gemayel. The President, a Maronite Christian, had to choose a Sunni Moslem under rigid Lebanese tradition, and he decided to ask Shafik al-Wazzan to remain at the urging of Saeb Salam, the 77-year-old former Prime Minister, who is probably the most influential Moslem leader in Lebanon. (A1:5.)

title: Clark Equipment
description: The Clark Equipment Company said its credit subsidiary had bought the White Motor Corporation's credit unit.

title: RACIST BIAS IN JAIL SENTENCING LAID TO U.S. JUDGE IN VIRGINIA
description: A Federal prosecutor's contention that a Federal district judge sentences defendants on the basis of race must be investigated, according to a group of black lawyers and the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday following the surprise announcement late Friday by the Federal Reserve that the nation's basic money supply rose $400 million in the latest reporting week.

title: Amex Options On Treasuries
description: The American Stock Exchange said trading in put and call options on selected United States Treasury securities would begin Oct. 22. The exchange plans to list options on the 13 3/4 percent Treasury notes due May 15. It also intends to trade options on 13-week Treasury bills, to be introduced shortly afterward, and options on 90-day negotiable certificates of deposit, to be introduced pending approval of the contract by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: LIABILITY TO PAY MEDICAL BILLS OF CRIMINAL SUSPECTS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide who pays the medical bills when a criminal suspect is wounded while being captured or held for trial.

title: STATE EXAMINERS BACK POWER FOR STATEN ISLAND
description: Two state hearing examiners said today that New York City's clean-air requirements for a proposed Staten Island power plant were ''unreasonably restrictive.'' They said the rules should be waived to allow the State Power Authority to proceed with construction of the 700-megawatt electric plant fueled by coal and garbage.

title: BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Hired Danny Liwhiler, former outfielder, as traveling scout for team's farm system. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Released Paul Moskau and Grant Jackson, pitchers. TEXAS (AL) - Promoted Joe Klein, farm director, to vice president and general manager.

title: LIFE LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgage Rate Down in Month
description: The average interest rate charged home buyers for new mortgages declined to 16.23 percent in September, the lowest rate since May 1981, the Government reported today.

title: We Haven't Seen Anything Yet
description: In February 1981, less than a month into his Presidency, Ronald Reagan gave Congress his first budget proposals, which were for the fiscal year just ended. He vowed to break the growth of spending, slash taxes and shrink the deficit.

title: WHERE JOHN FOWLES ENDS AND CHARACTERS OF HIS NOVELS BEGIN
description: THOUGH intricate in form and self-consciously literary in execution, the novels of John Fowles have, at the same time, featured rich vigorous narratives and old-fashioned characters of great vulnerability and charm. Whether it is Sarah in ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' Jane in ''Daniel Martin'' or Lily in ''The Magus,'' the most powerful of those characters have always been women - women who like the princesses lointaines of medieval romances remain mysterious and aloof.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball California Angels vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Anaheim, Calif. The American League's three-of-five-game playoff gets under way. Reggie Jackson has another chance to play his favorite role, Mr. October, but the Brewers' home-run hitters will be trying to upstage him.

title: IN JERSEY, DISH ANTENNAS PULL IN TV AND FUROR
description: You half expect the thing to take a jerky step on its gawky tubular steel legs and fire a laser blast vaporizing the neighbor's charcoal grill.

title: LEROY GRUMMAN, THE BUILDER OF AERONAUTICS GIANT, DIES
description: Leroy R. Grumman, who founded an aircraft-repair company in a little Long Island garage and guided it as it grew into one of the nation's largest defense contractors, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 87 years old and had homes in Plandome Manor, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: IN U.N., PEKING OFFICIAL PRAISES THIRD WORLD
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China told the 37th session of the United Nations General Assembly today that the third world had wrought sweeping changes in the world in recent years, and he affirmed that China stood proudly among the ranks of third-world nations.

title: TIMETABLES FOR SUBWAY GO PUBLIC
description: To a backdrop of skepticism, criticism and delays, a public timetable was installed in the New York City subway system yesterday. The timetable, showing a 24-hour schedule of train movements through a station, was posted at Cortlandt Street, a station beneath the World Trade Center.

title: SAW RECORDINGS AS ART FORM
description: Glenn Gould, the Canadian pianist who retired from a flourishing concert career in 1964 to become a recording artist best known for his Bach interpretations, died yesterday in Toronto General Hospital.

title: Murder by Capsule
description: Even among murderers, the Tylenol poisoner bears a special odium. Instead of killing outright, he subverted medicine to an agent with which the victims killed themselves.

title: UNION PACIFIC'S STEADY COURSE
description: Not all top executives are eager to plunge into the high risk and excitement of a takeover battle. James H. Evans, chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Pacific Corporation, prefers a lowerkey approach to expansion.

title: U.S. LAW VS. EUROPE'S
description: The dispute over the Administration's imposition of sanctions against multinational firms that have contracts for the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe is merely the public eruption of a virtually invisible conflict of will, and law, that the United States and its principal European trading partners have been engaged in for several years.

title: NEW CRACKS IN THE MIGHTY YEN
description: Not too long ago, thanks to Japan's buoyant exports and favorable balance of payments, the yen was one of the world's most favored currencies. But that time is over - the world recession has reached even super-efficient Japan.

title: Fire at Derailed Train Raises Fear of New Blasts
description: A flammable chemical escaping from a tank car caught fire tonight at the site of a week-old train derailment. Officials said the fire greatly increased the chance for explosions.

title: THOR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quake in Alaska Island
description: The United States Geological Survey reported a moderate earthquake this morning 30 miles south of Adak Island in the Aleutian Island chain. There was no reported damage, according to a spokesman for the Geological Survey.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 17 weeks to Sept 18
Chess: They Also Ran Very Hard Who Didn't Quite Qualify
description: Some of the also-rans ran pretty hard in the third Interzonal Tournament, in Moscow. The Cuban grandmaster Guillermo Garcia held the lead until losses in the closing rounds to Larry Christiansen of Modesto, Calif., Aleksandar Belyavsky of the Soviet Union and Ruben Rodriguez of the Philippines threw him back to fifth place.

title: SOUTH BRONX IS GIVEN PLEDGES OF FEDERAL AID
description: The Reagan Administration, signaling significant Federal financial aid for the South Bronx, agreed yesterday to provide a $10 million loan guarantee for the construction of trucking facilities at the Hunts Point produce market. It also signed a $27.6 million contract with an electronics business in the area.

title: Quarterback Returns
description: Homer Jordan, the Clemson quarterback, is back on campus and has attended a team meeting, so his suspension apparently has ended after one game.

title: ISLANDERS OPEN DEEP IN TALENT
description: A generation ago the cry in baseball was ''Break up the Yankees!'' Today the Islanders, the best team in hockey, are in the same enviable position. As they prepare for the National Hockey League season that begins Tuesday night, the Islanders will field the same squad that won a third consecutive Stanley Cup last May. There is not one new member of the team.

title: Court Denies Request On Naming Prosecutor
description: A Federal court has turned down a request for a special prosecutor to investigate the 1979 gun battle in Greensboro, N.C., that left five members of the Communist Workers Party dead, it was disclosed today.

title: Court to Hear Tax Case Tied to Lobbying Issue
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a tax case with important implications for the political rights of taxexempt organizations.

title: TRANSPLANTS ARE SURGING AS SURVIAL RATES IMPROVE
description: TRANSPLANTS of several types of organs have surged dramatically in numbers in recent months. Survival rates have improved as well. Both trends are an apparent result of surgeons' greater ability to perform transplants and of new drug therapies to help prevent rejection of the transplanted organs. They signal a revived interest in an area of surgery that some surgeons had abandoned through much of the 1970's.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday on Johnson & Johnson incorrectly identified the maker of Head and Shoulders shampoo. It is Procter & Gamble.

title: Korean Company Plans U.S. Plants
description: The Gold Star Company of South Korea, a maker of electronic products, said it planned to invest heavily in production facilities in the United States. It said the investment could result in the employment of 3,000 Americans and generate annual sales of $500 million by 1990.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $135,000 for the qr and $614,000for the 9 mos...C-Net income including tax credits of $289,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos and a gain of $30,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the saleof investments

title: AREA OFFICER IS SHOT TO DEATH IN INDIAN CITY HIT BY RIOTING
description: The deputy commander of 4,000 Government troops sent to restore order to an Indian city where Hindu-Moslem rioting has killed 30 people was found shot to death today.

title: Injured Rookie Suing Patriots
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Greg Taylor, a rookie running back released Sept. 16 by the New England Patriots, filed a multimillion-dollar suit against the club in United States District Court in Boston today.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1982; The Economy
description: A midnight deadline for curbing the powers of bankruptcy judges was postponed by the Supreme Court. The Justices, by their intervention, kept the bankruptcy courts from sliding into a kind of legal limbo in which, some experts said, they might not have been able to function. Congress now has until Dec. 24 to meet the Court's objections to the scope of the powers it conferred on the judges in the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978. (Page D1.)

title: NEWS SENSATIONS, NEW OUTRAGES AND THEMES
description: THERE is a portrait gallery of familiar faces in the lobby of Alice Tully Hall, where the 20th New York Film Festival is midway through its three-week schedule. As it honors a variety of contributors to past festivals, the photographic exhibition also reminds audiences that this year, most of the festival's favorite luminaries are conspicuously absent.

title: South Africa Bars the Return Of Passport to Black Bishop
description: The South African Government refused today to return the passport of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the general secretary of the South African Council of Churches.

title: FINANCIAL FUTURES SET BRISK PACE IN LONDON
description: The London International Financial Futures Exchange has briskly entered the raucous world of currency and interest rate trading. In the new market's first three sessions, volume has climbed from a vigorous 3,243 contracts on opening day last Thursday to well over 4,000.

title: REAGAN, IN OHIO, PRESSING CAMPAIGN ATTACKS
description: President Reagan, stepping up the pace of the Congressional campaign, today contended that the current high unemployment had resulted from Democratic inflation of the past, and that the voters' choice on Nov. 2 would be between ''Government as master or Government as servant.''

title: WOOLCO PROSPECT QUITS
description: A Saudi Arabian Sheik notified the F. W. Woolworth Company yesterday that he had decided to abandon his efforts to acquire the Woolco discount department store chain, which is scheduled to be closed next year.

title: Portuguese Premier Meets Trudeau on Visit to Canada
description: Francisco Pinto Balsemao, the first Portuguese Prime Minister to pay an official visit to Canada, began his stay today with a working lunch with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: CONCERT: TOURING VIENNA SYMPHONY
description: THE Vienna Symphony Orchestra has not made a major international impact in recent years. But now it is embarked on an ambitious world tour that includes 21 days in this country, its first American appearances in 10 years. The tour brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall last night, where its concert proved not all that interesting as far as the orchestra itself was concerned, but rather more so for the conductor, Christoph Eschenbach.

title: Thin, Bearded Man Sought in Slaying
description: The Morris County police are seeking a suspect described as a thin, bearded man in his 20's in the fatal shooting last Friday night of a 16-year-old Boonton Township youth at the Rockaway Townsquare Mall.

title: ASIANS FORM GROUP ON HAZARDOUS PRODUCTS
description: Consumer advocates have organized an investigative network to report on hazardous products being sold in the Asia-Pacific region and to seek action from governments to ban or restrict them.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Toys R Us
description: The Canadian Government has given permission to Toys R Us to open stores in Canada, the company said.

title: Witness Is Absent From Gibson Trial
description: A key prosecution witness in the ''no-show job'' conspiracy trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and Earl Harris, a former City Council president, failed to appear at the Essex County Courthouse here today, but Judge Paul R. Huot refused a prosecution request that he issue a bench warrant for his arrest.

title: RANGERS ACQUIRE A FOURTH OLYMPIAN
description: The Rangers yesterday acquired a fourth player from the United States Olympic team that was coached by Herb Brooks, now the Rangers' head coach. In yesterday's waiver draft, they took Bill Baker, a defenseman, from the St. Louis Blues, who in turn took Tim Bothwell, also a defenseman, from the Rangers as compensation.

title: THE ANONYMOUS INVESTIGATOR
description: When a Chicago woman was asked what she thought of Tyrone Fahner, the Illinois Attorney General, who is heading a special force investigating seven deaths here that have been linked to cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol, she responded: Ty who?

title: TYLENOL A WIDELY USED SUBSTITUTE FOR ASPIRIN
description: Tylenol, the widely used alternative to aspirin, is an analgesic, or pain reliever, and fever-reducing drug. The drug is often used by people who are allergic to aspirin or who suffer medical problems, notably stomach ulcers or such bleeding conditions as hemophilia, that make aspirin use unsuitable.

title: Hospital Income Plan Clears Its Last Hurdle
description: A new system that will give financially distressed inner-city hospitals a greater share of reimbursement funds received approval yesterday by the Hospital Association of New York State.

title: Texaco Canada
description: Texaco Canada Inc. said it would immediately close an oil refinery near here because of excess capacity.

title: BONN TO PURSUE TIES WITH EAST, NEW CHIEF SAYS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that his new Government intended to pursue good relations with Communist Europe and that it wanted ''friendship and partnership, but not dependency'' in its ties with the United States.

title: Further Layoffs Due In Hospital Walkout
description: Officials at St. Barnabas Medical Center said today that they would lay off 166 more employees this week because of the nurses' strike that began last month. At present 1,000 employees are working at the medical center.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: AS the ability to bring the benefits of transplant surgery to patients has improved, surgeons have been faced with a frustrating problem: a shortage of organs. At last count, 7,793 Americans were waiting for kidney transplants, and hundreds of people have died before they could get lung, heart and other transplants.

title: DISCOUNT CORP OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clue on Genetic Change
description: An apparently fundamental principle of genetic change in evolution is that in the absence of natural selection for a certain characteristic, a species can in time lose that characteristic. This hypothesis would account genetically for the decline of wings to vestiges in flightless birds or the disappearance of eyes in cave animals.

title: BAY MILLS LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
THE 'FAIRNESS' ISSUE: BLACK TIE IS OUT
description: Black-tie dinners are out. So, for the time being, are Ronald Reagan's riding breeches. These are only the more superficial changes at the White House this fall as the President and his staff seek to refute the suggestion that Mr. Reagan is too friendly to the wealthy and too indifferent to those suffering from unemployment.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Brooklyn Bridge As a Source of Inspiration

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: SCIENTISTS have reported growing mouse embryos under completely artificial conditions in laboratory dishes for 10 days, fully half of their normal gestation period of about 20 days.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Please explain how the ''infrared wireless earphone'' I rented recently at a play in New York works.

title: Corporate Setback in Tylenol Case
description: The poisoning of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules in the Chicago area is bringing a multiplicity of troubles for Johnson & Johnson, the corporate parent of McNeil Pharmaceuticals Laboratories, which produces the pain-relief capsules.

title: No Headline
description: KING HUSSEIN ARRIVES IN IRAQ WITH HIS ARMY CHIEF

title: JOHN G. FORREST, FINANCIAL EDITOR
description: John G. Forrest, the financial-business news editor of The New York Times when he retired in 1963, died yesterday at Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and had lived in Scottsdale for the last 12 years.

title: Business and the Law; Trademark Controversy
description: PARKER BROTHERS may have lost its monopoly on Monopoly and the reasoning of the court decision striking down its trademark has the owners of thousands of other trademarks on consumer goods up in arms.

title: NLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEASURE EXPECTED TO SPUR EXPORTS
description: The trading company, which developed East India and much of North America and spearheaded the recovery of postwar Japan, is expected to revitalize United States exports. But the new companies authorized by Congress are not likely to be formed for a while.

title: Rise Is Seen In Confidence
description: Confidence in the economy improved in the third quarter, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The business research group said its index of confidence advanced to 55 from 52 in the second quarter and 47 in the first quarter.

title: HE CITES ECONOMY
description: Mayor Koch imposed a hiring freeze yesterday on all mayoral agencies, citing the local impact of what he called ''the national depression'' as well as the cost of the city's recent labor settlement with its nonuniformed workers.

title: Double-Teamed
description: At age 22, Cliff Robinson is starting his fourth National Basketball Association season, perhaps with his fourth N.B.A. team. The Houston Rockets have signed the 6-foot-9-inch forward to an offer sheet, reportedly worth $2.4 million over five years.

title: THE PROPER APPROACH TO FEDERAL TAX REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Compensation
description: The base pay of top executives of medium-sized companies rose an average 9.7 percent last year, keeping up with inflation. But overall compensation fell, hurt by lower stock prices.

title: Advertising; New Movie Magazine Scheduled
description: JOE ARMSTRONG, fomerly of New York, New West and Rolling Stone magazines, has been out of public view for a couple of years dreaming up a magazine of his own, a magazine that will cover a field that has been a consuming interest for most of his 39 years.

title: Helping Get Out The Boxing Vote
description: Robert W. Lee, deputy commissioner of the New Jersey State Athletic Commission, is running for the presidency of the World Boxing Association at the convention under way at San Juan, Puerto Rico.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The latest qr net was reduced by $914,000 or 8 cents a shr, as result of changerequired by F.A.S.B. No 52 regarding the Mexican peso devaluation

title: CYANIDE CASE FOCUSES ON FIND IN PARKING LOT AT ALL-NIGHT RESTAURANT
description: Federal, state and local agents investigating the deaths of seven people from cyanide placed in Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules focused considerable attention today on a rural parking lot on a toll road northwest of here.

title: MILAN: ITALIAN DESIGNERS TURN TO CLEAN LINES
description: The good news about Italian fashion is that the costume party is over. The people who gave you the renaissance no longer feel they have to return to it for design inspiration. So last season's doublets and breeches are out, neat clean lines are in and the Italians are back in the fashion race.

title: NO ACCORD AT SHULTZ-GROMYKO TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union concluded their second round of talks yesterday in disagreement on virtually every issue. A senior American official said later there was no prospect of an early resolution of any of the major differences between the two countries.

title: VW America Prices Up
description: Volkswagen of America Inc., a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said today that suggested retail price increases on its 1983 cars will average about 3 percent above the comparable 1982 model.

title: Witness Tells of Order Not to Report Radiation
description: The Atomic Energy Commission ordered a veterinarian to delete all references to atomic radiation from his report on the deaths of thousands of sheep down wind of above-ground nuclear blasts in 1953, a Federal judge was told today.

title: Dancer to Develop Direct Marketing Unit
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, 11th-biggest agency in the United States and a powerhouse in packaged goods advertising, is joining the the other agencies that have already developed direct marketing capability either by acquiring companies or personnel. It has chosen the latter route in a very modest way.

title: FROM SMOKESTACKS TO HIGH TECH
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI PLANES HIT SYRIAN-HELD AREA OF EAST LEBANON
description: Israeli planes attacked Syrian missile positions in Lebanon today, reportedly destroying a number of sites in a mountain pass along the Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: Death of A Biology Teacher
description: The newspapers described him variously as ''a derelict'' and ''a vagrant'' who was ''deranged,'' ''irrational'' and ''homeless.'' What he really was was a high school biology teacher from Havana. Yes, by the time he climbed into the polar bear's cage in the Central Park Zoo and was killed two weekends ago, he had become mentally disoriented, but it would be too easy for all of us to remember Conrado Mones that way.

title: NEW, IMPROVED FRAUD HOT LINE
description: Centuries ago, when the citizens of Venice wanted to inform their Government about a neighbor's wrongdoing, they could drop an anonymous note into the snarling mouth of one of the city's many conveniently located stone lions. Now history is repeating itself.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Affiliated Bank Corp. of Wyoming said its proposed acquisition by a Dallas businessman, John D. Murchison Jr., for $50 a share had been terminated because of a failure to agree on terms.

title: Moves Made to Deport A Rumanian Archbishop
description: Deportation proceedings opened today against a Rumanian archbishop who, the Justice Department says, led a violent anti-Semitic group in World War II.

title: SALES OF FLU DRUG BY DU PONT UNIT A 'DISAPPOINTMENT'
description: On the surface, it would appear that Endo Laboratories, the pharmaceutical subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, has everything going for it this year.

title: A SALUTE TO LONG NEGLECTED 'FATHER OF AMERICAN ROCKETRY'
description: AT Pakachoag Hill in Auburn, Mass., this morning, some high school students are scheduled to fire small rockets into the air as a pyrotechnic salute to the memory of Robert H. Goddard on the 100th anniversary of his birth. Dr. Goddard launched the world's first liquid-fueled rocket from the same hill in 1926, one of the achievements that brought him acclaim as the father of American rocketry.

title: Jersey Crime Drop Of 11% Reported
description: Overall crime in New Jersey dropped 11 percent in the first six months of 1982, the state police reported today, the largest decline since authorities began compiling figures in 1967.

title: Knowlton Harvard Post
description: Winthrop Knowlton has been appointed the first director of the business and government center at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. The center will study such factors as the performance of the American economy, international competitiveness, capital formation and regulatory reform. Mr. Knowlton, who will become a public service professor at the school, is a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a partner of White, Weld & Company. He had been chief executive officer of Harper & Row Publishers Inc., first as president and then as chairman, and remains its chairman.

title: MOFFAT COMMUNICATIONS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Amid the Biltmore's Chaos, An Oasis of Serenity

title: Bethlehem Sale
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its ship repair yard at Hoboken, N.J., to Braswell Shipyards Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Widow of One Cyanide Victim Sues Tylenol Manufacturers
description: The widow of one of seven people killed by cyanide contained in an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule filed a $15 million damage suit today against the makers and sellers of the pain reliever.

title: Textron Layoffs
description: Textron Inc.'s Bell Helicopter division said it plans to lay off 550 employees between now and December, reducing its staff in the Dallas-Fort Worth area to about 6,000. It said it could no longer delay the move in view of current economic conditions and sales projections for the immediate future. It said a hoped-for upturn in commercial helicopter sales had not occurred.

title: New Order for F-18A
description: Secretary of the Navy John Lehman announced a one-year agreement today with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to build 63 F-18A fighter-attack planes for $1.14 billion. The agreement ended an effort by the Navy to reduce the price of the planes. Mr. Lehman said the contract represented a cost of $22.5 million a plane, the same as the present price, despite inflation. The Northrop Corporation is the prime F-18A subcontractor and the General Electric Company is the engine builder.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Remembering the Weather

title: Chairman Is Elected At Midwest Exchange
description: John G. Weithers, 49, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of Chicago's Midwest Stock Exchange, the nation's thirdlargest stock exchange in trading volume. He succeeds Richard B. Walbert, 66, who is to retire but who will remain on the board, effective next January.

title: Spain Car Plant Plan
description: Spain's Automoviles Talbot S.A., a subsidiary of Peugeot S.A., has agreed on a three-year restructuring plan for its Madrid car factory, a company spokesman said today.

title: EMBASSY ROW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz raised his glass and offered a toast to the capital's diplomatic community the other day.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $2,175,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations and losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $261,000 for the qr and $2,371,000 for the 6 mos...C-After income from discontinued operations of $107,000 for the qr and $29,000 for the 6 mos...D-Net income

title: No Headline
description: VENEZUELA UNITS FIGHT REBELS

title: Market Place; Bearish Case For Stocks
description: STOCK market bearishness, while essentially out of style, is gaining adherents, especially so now that the averages have begun to waver.

title: A PLACE FOR AIR BAGS IN AUTOMOBILE SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SET TO RENEW ARMS TALKS
description: American and Soviet negotiators gave no hint of possible departures from their positions as they returned here today for the second round of talks on the reduction of strategic, or longrange, nuclear arms.

title: IS JORDAN PALESTINE? OF COURSE.
description: Is Jordan really Palestine? Ariel Sharon says yes. King Hussein says no. The State Department agrees with Hussein. It provides no evidence to support the King. But neither does the King; he just says it's ''ridiculous.''

title: LEHRMAN HAS SPENT $8 MILLION ON CAMPAIGN AND CUOMO $1 MILLION
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for Governor, has spent $8.8 million so far in his campaign and his Democratic opponent, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, has spent $1.67 million, according to the finance reports filed by the two candidates yesterday.

title: A BARON REFLECTS
description: WHEN France, under its Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, nationalized the 175-year-old Banque Rothschild and much of his financial empire last year, the aristocratic Baron Guy de Rothschild was swift to react, reaching back to World War II and France's Vichy Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People are always asking me what the world will be like economically in the year 2000.

title: KODAK INTRODUCES A HIGH-SPEED FILM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced what it said is the world's fastest color film for 35-millimeter cameras. Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, said the film would help Kodak stay ahead of Japanese competition.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chili Davis, the San Francisco Giants' rookie center fielder, underwent surgery on his left ankle and will be in a cast about six weeks, the club said. Davis was injured sliding back to second on a pickoff attempt last week. ... Larry Milbourne, the infielder, said he would not return to the Cleveland Indians next year unless his contract was improved. ... The Minnesota North Stars acquired Jordy Douglas, a left wing, from the Hartford Whalers as part of last week's National Hockey League trade that sent Mark Johnson and Kent-Erik Andersson to the Whalers. Hartford then sent Andersson to the New York Rangers. ... The Women's Sports Foundation, at a dinner here last night, named Martina Navratilova, the tennis player, the professional sportswoman of the year and Mary Decker Tabb, the runner, the amateur sportswoman of the year. ...

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRINK'S DEFENDANT PLACED NEAR ROBBERY SCENE
description: An admittedly frightened and nervous 19-year-old former bank teller testified today that she saw Samuel Brown, a defendant in the Brink's murder and robbery case, pacing nervously outside the Nanuet National Bank while two Brink's guards were inside last Oct. 20.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HISPANIC TOUCH

title: CHAIRMAN OF G.O.P. AND DIRECTOR OF VETERANS AGENCY RESIGN POSTS
description: The chairman of the Republican Party and the chief of the Veterans Adminstration announced their resignations today, denying they were pushed out and saying they had pressing personal financial needs to attend to.

title: Alastair Reid to Read Poetry at N.Y.U.
description: Alastair Reid will give a reading in the Loeb Student Center of New York University Oct. 14 at 8 P.M. under the sponsorship of the Poetry Society of America and the Poetics Institute of N.Y.U.

title: DANCE: RUBY SHANG
description: RUBY SHANG added her own footnotes to recent dance history with an event that she staged Friday night on the corner of 40th Street and Seventh Avenue. To be exact, the audience was on the corner, and the dancers were visible upstairs in the second and third-floor windows of a studio called Fancy Dancer Inc.

title: Rumanian Official Dismissed
description: The Rumanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu, has dismissed his Deputy Agriculture Minister, Agustin Todea, because of the country's inefficient food supply system, the official Rumanian press agency said today. The agency also announced reprimands for other officials.

title: World Cup Site in Doubt
description: Although President Belisario Betancur has made no announcement, officials here indicate that financial and logistical problems will cause cancellation of Colombia's plans to act as the host of soccer's World Cup in 1986.

title: Brewers; Pitchers (Age, Throws, Won-Lost, ERA)
description: Pete Vuckovich (29, R, 18-6, 3.34)

title: PLAYS
description: At Frankie Frisch Field in the Bronx, where he used to bounce line drives off the Third Avenue El for Roosevelt High School, they called him Banjo Legs. Fourteen years later, at Milwaukee County Stadium, his nickname has become Spider Man, a tribute to his ability to spear flies.

title: CARSON SIGNS NEW PACT WITH NBC
description: Johnny Carson, who celebrated his 20th anniversary as host of ''The Tonight Show'' on NBC-TV on Sunday, has signed a ''long-term'' contract to continue as host for an undisclosed period.

title: B.A.T. Appoints Top Saks Executive
description: Melvin Jacobs, a vice chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Saks Fifth Avenue, the 33-store, high-fashion chain owned by B.A.T. Industries of London.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A 'Magic Window' On Subway Crime

title: The Editorial Notebook; In the Matter of Witches Which Some Readers Wish to Believe Never Existed
description: A witch is a woman who professes or is supposed to practice the black arts. A warlock is her male equivalent. To say then, as did a recent Times editorial, that ''A few of those hanged (in Salem) probably were witches or warlocks'' is not to imply a belief in travel by broom. It is to use two words as precise as ''medicine man'' or ''shaman.'' One does not have to have faith in a medicine man's powers to say there are such people. The same goes for witches.

title: 100-POINT LAG FOUND IN BLACK'S S.A.T. SCORES
description: In its first complete look at how students who are members of minority groups perform on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, the College Board said today that blacks score on average about 100 points lower than the national norm.

title: U.N. COUNCIL ASKS END TO GULF WAR
description: A unanimous Security Council called on Iran and Iraq tonight to stop firing and withdraw their forces from each other's territory.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BETWEEN THE CONNECTICUT CANDIDATES FOR U.S.  SENATOR
description: These are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican who is seeking re-election to his third term, and Representative Toby Moffett, his Democratic challenger. Opening

title: OFF THE STUMP, KOCH ON SPOT AS THE MAYOR
description: Helen Simone complained about flooding on her street - especially when it rains. Ted Abrams said that Rockaway Boulevard had become a haven for drug pushers. A question about potholes brought a rueful rumble of recognition, and the mere mention of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority elicited a healthy chorus of boos.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS FOES OF U.S. HAVE DUPED ARMS FREEZE GROUP
description: President Reagan today criticized the National Movement for a Freeze on Nuclear Weapons as a group of ''honest and sincere people'' who were being manipulated by ''some who want the weakening of America.''

title: HURRY-UP PLAN TO ORDER 50 AIRLIFT PLANES IS ASSAILED
description: Opponents of a Pentagon plan to spend about $10 billion to buy 50 C-5B cargo airplanes said today that a new, more versatile plane could be produced almost as rapidly and at a lower ultimate cost.

title: STILL THE GREATEST
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKRUPTCY COURT CURB POSTPONED
description: The Supreme Court stepped in today to prevent the nation's bankruptcy court system from entering into legal limbo by postponing a midnight deadline it had set for ending the broad powers Congress had conferred on Federal bankruptcy judges.

title: Swedish Copters and Ships Hunt for Foreign Submarine
description: Swedish helicopters and ships crisscrossed the Baltic coastline near here today in search of a suspected foreign submarine, the latest in an increasing number of submarines reported in Swedish territorial waters.

title: BREWERS-ANGELS A DUEL OF POWER HITTERS
description: The numbers could not lie. Even Mike Caldwell, the starting pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers Tuesday night in the first game of the American League championship series against the California Angels, was willing to admit that.

title: WEICKER-MOFFETT DEBATE SHARPENS CONTRAST ON TIES
description: Representative Toby Moffett yesterday depicted Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as a loner without effectiveness in the United States Senate, while Mr. Weicker stressed the importance of political independence.

title: CITY OPERA: CAROL VANESS
description: EARLIER this season, the soprano Carol Vaness took ill during the first act of the first New York City Opera ''La Traviata'' and was forced to bow out as Violetta in mid-performance.

title: DEVILS GET VADNAIS, 2 OTHER DEFENSEMEN
description: The Devils, in desperate need of defensive help, chose three players today in the National Hockey League's waiver draft, and they were all defensemen, among them Carol Vadnais of the Rangers.

41-Oklahoma27 19-Maryland18 43-Richmond10 13-Pitt.16 Oct. 9-Boston Col. 16-at Va. Tech 23-Penn St. 30-E. Carolina Nov. 6-at Temple 13-at Rutgers 20-Syracuse WESTERN MICHIGAN 28-Grnd Val.St.3 34-Marshall0 24-Kent St.14 3-B.

title: An Appraisal
description: WHEN Alwin Nikolais's dance company opens tomorrow night in the City Center, the sentimen- tal memories of years spent in the shabby family atmosphere of the theater on 55th Street will fade before the splendor of a spacious new interior and a major renovation of the orchestra seating.

title: FROM BEHIND THE SILENCE, A MIND EDGES FORWARD
description: THE classic question the first-timer asks about personal computers is ''what can they do?'' The standard response offered by computer buffs and salesmen alike ranges from ''look at this neat sort-anddump routine'' to ''anything you want them to do.'' Neither answer is particularly edifying or helpful. The fact is, outside the business milieu and game country, microcomputers are, for the most part, a marvelous technological inspiration in search of meaningful applications.

title: U.S. VOWS TO LEAVE CONFERENCE IF ISRAEL IS EXPELLED
description: The United States delegation is threatening a walkout from a major telecommunications conference here because of an Algerian proposal for Israel's expulsion from the gathering of 157 nations.

title: LEIGH INSTRUMENTS LTD reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes a special gain of $92,000...C-Net income including a special gain of$452,000; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Coming Home
description: It is not rare for Congress to perform acts of genuine virtue, but what is rare is for Congress, having done so, to fail to preen about it. That's just what happened in the closing hours Friday night. Though hardly anyone knows it, the rush to adjourn produced a law concerning children that should warm American hearts.

title: People
description: * Richard Angle promoted to associate publisher of Time.

title: THE ASSASSIN BUG FINALLY REVEALS ITS FATAL CHARM
description: NEAR an old paint can in a lowland rain forest of Central America, termites crawl in and out of the entrance to their nest. Suddenly, a fragment of the nest itself appears to approach the entrance.

title: AMERASIAN CHILDREN START SETTLING IN
description: In Luis Villegas's house today, two small bodies were parked in front of a television set, two more children chattered across the kitchen table and one orbited the refrigerator while his mother rummaged for snacks.

title: Sloan's Supermarkets Names a New President
description: Vincent Cook, who started with Sloan's Supermarkets in 1973 as a dairy manager, has been named president of the family-held, 40-store Manhattan chain.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
KOHL PLANS NO CHANGES ON GAS PIPELINE PROJECT
description: Senior officials of the new Christian Democratic Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl indicated today that it would do nothing to hinder companies from fulfilling contracts for the new Soviet natural gas pipeline.

title: Kenya Denial on I.M.F.
description: Kenya's Finance Minister, Arthur Magugu, denied today that the International Monetary Fund had suspended a loan to Kenya and said the country's efforts to control public spending were starting to bear fruit.

title: Bridge: Canadian Experts Capture Mixed Pairs in Fine Finish
description: Two Canadian experts finished strongly here Sunday night to win the World Mixed Pairs Championship. George Mittelman and Diana Gordon of Toronto thus brought their country its first victory in world competition, with 24,162 match points.

title: GAF CITES INTEREST BY 7 CONCERNS
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had been approached by four companies interested in either acquiring it outright or participating in a leveraged buy-out. At the same time, GAF said, three other companies have indicated an interest in buying its building materials group.

title: Duran vs. Batten
description: The undercard has been announced for the World Boxing Association junior welterweight title fight Nov.12 between Aaron Pryor and Alexis Arguello.

title: BASEBALL FILLS VOID LEFT BY THE N.F.L.
description: During momentary breaks between plays, points or pitches at sports events, television directors often use the occasion to comment visually on the state of the union, femininity or their network's attributes. Last Sunday afternoon, a CBS camera zeroed in on a banner during the Division III college football game between Wittenberg and Baldwin-Wallace.

title: Oklahoma Banks Planning to Merge
description: The First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City intends to buy Oklahoma National Bank, First National's president, Ted Shaw, said.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON TAX CREDITS FOR TUITION SIMILAR TO REAGAN PLAN
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a case that could determine the constitutional fate of President Reagan's proposal for Federal tax credits to parents who pay private school tuition.

title: Concern Halts Manufacturing Of Capsule Forms of Tylenol
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that it had stopped making both Regular and Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Man in the News article Aug. 30 on Archbishop Jozef Glemp incorrectly located his birthplace. He was born in Inowroclaw.

title: A.T.&T.'S BREAKUP PROPOSALS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its 22 local phone company subsidiaries disclosed a detailed plan today for dividing the nation's telephone services once the subsidiaries are divested.

title: POLITICAL LEVERAGE NO EASIER THE 2D TIME AROUND
description: ''Most people in this district don't blame Reagan for high unemployment,'' said Peter Kostmayer, a liberal Democrat who is trying to capitalize on economic issues to win back the Congressional seat he lost in 1980. ''They don't blame anyone. They don't much think anyone can do anything about it.''

title: NIEKRO AND ANDUJAR TO START IN OPENER
description: On the first anniversary of his dismissal as manager of the Mets, Joe Torre led his Atlanta Braves yesterday into St. Louis, where they will open the playoff for the National League pennant tomorrow against the Cardinals.

title: LEBANON RETAINS ITS PRIME MINISTER
description: In a move designed to satisfy Lebanon's mutually mistrustful Moslem and Christian leaders, President Amin Gemayel asked Shafik al-Wazzan today to remain as Prime Minister.

title: ABRAMS ASKS STATE TO DELAY RESALE OF LOVE CANAL HOMES
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams yesterday urged New York State to delay plans to resell homes near the Love Canal toxic waste dump in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: MUSIC: PATANE LEADS THE AMERICAN
description: THERE was an appropriate sense of extramusical celebration at the opening concert of the American Symphony's 20th season Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, when Giuseppe Patane led a program of music by Prokofiev, Shostakovich and Tchaikovsky.

title: No Headline
description: Herald Tribune Starts Second Asian Edition

title: Gunman on a Bicycle Wounds 3 in Brooklyn
description: Three persons, including a 15-year-old student, were shot yesterday afternoon outside the Walt Whitman Junior High School in Brooklyn by a gunman on a bicycle, the police reported. A 16-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested early today and charged with attempted murder in the case.

title: N.F.L. AND PLAYERS AWAIT COURT RULING
description: With the National Football League strike two weeks old today and the likelihood increasing that a third weekend of games would not be played, both sides spent most of the day mapping strategy.

title: Western Union in Bid To Buy E.F. Johnson
description: The Western Union Corporation, the big telegraph company, announced yesterday an agreement to acquire the E.F. Johnson Company in a $132 million deal that raised the possibility of opposition from Western Union's biggest stockholder, the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: FAILURE TO REGISTER FOR DRAFT LEADS TO 2 1/2 YEAR SENTENCE

title: Gold Options Open With Spirited Trading
description: The first trading in options on gold futures began yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange. Despite a day of sinking gold prices, there was spirited two-way trading in the new options. An estimated 3,200 options were traded, each based on a Comex 100-ounce futures contract.

title: Death in Absentia For Polish Defector
description: The former Polish Ambassador to the United States, Romuald Spasowski, was sentenced to death in absentia today for defecting and seeking political asylum after the imposition of martial law in December 1981.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, has elected H.J. Bremermann Jr. vice chairman and head of its Nashville-based life insurance group.

title: DEBATE WILL FOCUS ON NONECONOMIC MATTERS
description: Congressional leaders from both major parties will debate on national radio and television Tuesday night and seek to focus campaign attention on foreign and defense issues.

title: MCDONNELL TO GET F-18 PLANE AWARD
description: The Navy decided on the last big piece of its long-range aviation plan today by announcing that it had agreed to a $1.14 billion contract with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for the F-18 fighter and attack aircraft.

title: U.S. AND THE THIRD WORLD AT ODDS OVER PATENTS
description: An international patent conference opened today that pits the Reagan Administration against the third world and some Western allies.

title: Amax Lead Unit
description: Amax Inc. said its Amax Lead and Zinc division was discussing the possible sale of its 50 percent interest in the Buick lead and zinc mine and lead smelter and related facilities in southeast Missouri to the Exxon Minerals unit of the Exxon Corporation. Amax said the talks were in a preliminary stage. The other 50 percent interest is held by a subsidiary of the Homestake Mining Company.

title: Ahmed al-Bakr Dies; Former Iraqi President
description: Former President Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr died today, Baghdad television announced. He was 68 years old. Mr. Bakr was President from 1968 until 1979, when he was replaced by Saddam Hussein, who still holds office.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I don't design shoes, I make them,'' intoned Walter Steiger, sounding just like a Smith Barney television commercial. If Mr. Steiger sounded a trifle smug, he has, well, ear-r-rned the right to do so. In the past 15 years, his shoes have become the favorites of such designers as Yves Saint Laurent, Karl Lagerfeld and Claude Montana. Last week, Mr. Steiger was in town to oversee the opening of his first New York store, at 739 Madison Avenue, which, with its red lacquer facade and small windows, looks more like a jewelry store.

title: TORONTO'S ORDER AWES CITY DELEGATION
description: Donald R. Manes, the Borough President of Queens, found it ''unbelievable'' that there was no graffiti on subways and buildings. Ruth L. Sims, former First Selectman of Greenwich, Conn, found the streets ''extremely clean and neat,'' and Stanely Simon, the Bronx Borough President, found the whole downtown area just ''wonderful.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DUO RECITAL: NOVELTIES
description: BRIAN SCHWEICKHARDT and John Cobb played music for clarinet and piano at the Abraham Goodman House Sunday night. Aside from Brahms's familar F minor Sonata, it was an evening of novelties both past and present.

title: REECE, THE DEFENDER
description: This is Beasley Reece's seventh professional football season, if two games doth now a season make. In his rookie year, 1976, back when they played 14-game schedules, Reece's nose was broken one afternoon. The next year his kneecap was broken. In 1978, it was his leg that got cracked like a walnut. In 1981, he ripped cartilage in his knee. And in the two full seasons that his larger appendages were kept fairly whole, he was breaking every single finger on both hands.

title: Dome Holders File Lawsuit
description: A group of shareholders of Dome Petroleum Ltd. filed suit in the Ontario Supreme Court against the Canadian Government and four Canadian banks for damages in connection with Dome's refinancing plan. The suit calls for recovery of damages for expropriation of capital property.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding To Acquire Newsome
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications will be acquiring Newsome & Company, the 37-year-old Boston public relations firm, and in the process they will be getting a new president, and, ultimately, a new chief executive, for its subsidiary Carl Byoir & Associates, the world's third-largest public relations company.

title: GASTINEAU SHUNS ALL-STAR LEAGUE
description: The proposed All-Star League of striking pro football players received a setback yesterday when Mark Gastineau, the Jets' all-pro defensive end, said that he would not play in the league's first game.

title: Suit by Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company, the food and agricultural products company, has filed an antitrust suit against 15 railroads and 3 railroad associations. The suit, filed in Federal District Courts in Chicago and Washington, charges that the defendants unlawfully agreed on prices for the shipment of wheat and wheat products from the Middle West to destinations in the East. Walter Mulhall, a Pillsbury spokesman, said that, if successful, the company could be awarded between $1 million and $3 million.

title: High Court Denies Brenner's Appeal
description: The Supreme Court refused today to step into a dispute involving the promoter Teddy Brenner and his suspension by the World Boxing Council.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For the Police, A New Talk-Show Role

title: AFRICAN KINGDOM'S SECRET: GROOMING A NEW RULER
description: This independent black kingdom, which is clamped in a vise between white-ruled South Africa and Marxist Mozambique, is undergoing the first royal succession it has experienced in this century as tribal elders try to fill the political and cultural vacuum left by the death of King Sobhuza II.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Saturday misidentified a striking Philadelphia Inquirer reporter. She was Carol Horner.

title: WHAT EXACTLY ARE RUSSIANS GETTING?
description: In 1979 two Soviet Embassy officials went to the public library in a small town in Tennessee and copied pages from an environmental impact statement concerning Government construction of a plant to manufacture military explosives.

title: KEEPING ISRAEL SECURE
description: New Israeli parliamentary elections have not yet been called, but the campaign is already on, and it will determine the fate of President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative. American officials can do little to promote acceptance of the initiative, but they should not undermine it with sales of advanced weapons to Arab countries.

title: 'SAY AMEN, SOMEBODY'
description: THE beauty of gospel music comes shining through in ''Say Amen, Somebody,'' a rousing documentary by George T. Nierenberg, who has also made a documentary about jazz tap dancing. In ''Say Amen, Somebody,'' Mr. Nierenberg visits with two of gospel's legendary performers, Thomas A. Dorsey and Mother Willie Mae Ford Smith. It's Mr. Dorsey who gives the film its title, as he tells a long story to the camera crew and lets them know they ought to be a little more vocally responsive. Mr. Dorsey isn't used to listeners who aren't noticeably moved by what he has to sing and say. The film makes it clear why.

title: BRIEFING
description: OSHA Calling Card

title: FINANCES FORCE FRESHMEN TO SWITCH COLLEGES
description: Private colleges across the country report that an unusually large number of freshmen changed their plans for going to college primarily because of anxiety over their ability to pay for commitments made last spring.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $167,400 or 2 cents a shr from the sale of stock

title: 14 Are Reported Killed In North Lebanon City
description: At least 14 people were killed today on the second day of fighting between factions in the northern city of Tripoli before a cease-fire was agreed to tonight, radio stations reported.

title: GRIST FOR A U.S. CAMPAIGN AGAINST NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: Inman Asserts Panel Is Biased
description: Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, one of the nation's top intelligence experts, said today that he had resigned his post as consultant to the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence because the panel was politically biased.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: LAST month, less than two weeks apart, the National Association of Secondary School Principals announced the publication of new materials to prepare students for college admissions tests and the College Entrance Examination Board disclosed that the scores of the Scholastic Aptitude Tests (S.A.T.), one of the keys to college doors, had risen for the first time in 19 years.

title: The War Isn't Over
description: The cease-fire in Lebanon remains precarious. Although it is a great relief that Beirut can finally begin picking up pieces of everyday life after such a long ordeal, what seemed evident at the time of the Israeli invasion remains true.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including income of $20,000 for the qr and a loss of $392,000 for the yr fromdiscontinued operations; results for the previous yr include a gain on the disposal of real estate equal to 28 cents a shr

title: No Let Serves
description: The United States Tennis Association is experimenting with eliminating service lets, believing that the change can speed up the game without altering basic rules of the sport. The ball, after tipping the net, would be in play.

title: Tories Meet at Brighton; The Mood Is Buoyant
description: Britain's Conservative Party assembled today for its annual conference with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher still riding high in public esteem for her handling of the Falkland war with Argentina.

title: LAWSUIT THAT SOUGHT HOMES FOR HOMELESS DISMISSED BY A JUDGE
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday threw out a lawsuit that had been brought on behalf of thousands of homeless persons released from state psychiatric hospitals and living on the streets of New York City.

title: GLITCHES MAR DISNEY'S EPCOT DEBUT
description: The houselights at Epcot Center's American Adventure exhibit dimmed, the curtain rose and a spotlight beamed. ''Excuse me, Mr. Twain,'' said a deep, recorded voice.

title: POWER TO THE CABLE TV OPERATORS?
description: To the Editor:

title: SPUTNIK RECALLED: SCIENCE AND MATH IN TROUBLE AGAIN
description: FIVE years ago yesterday, the Soviet Union's launching of the satellite Sputnik not only ushered in the modern space age but shocked Americans into the recognition that Russian science and technology were capable of surpassing their own.

title: Local Rejects Chrysler Pact
description: A tentative contract between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers was rejected today by the first large union local to vote. About 90 percent of the 4,000 union members at the Newark assembly plant voted, with 60 percent rejecting the agreement, which would give workers pay raises tied to profits.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET TO OPEN NEW TALKS
description: The Soviet Union and China are about to begin their first official negotiations since late 1979, when the Chinese broke off normalization talks to protest the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Turner Telecasts Enjoined by Court
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday forbidding Ted Turner's WTBS station from televising the National League's championship series over a nationwide cable network.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International N.V. will float a 100 million Swiss franc Eurobond, which will be sold and serviceable in francs but repayable in dollars, on the public Swiss capital markets through Soditic S.A.

title: FEMALE CANDIDATES SET MARK
description: There are 56 women running for Congress and 1,620 running for seats in state legislatures this November, both record numbers, the National Women's Education Fund reported Sunday.

title: Murderer Reportedly Admits 14 More Slayings in Florida
description: A convicted murderer serving a life prison sentence has signed detailed confessions to 14 more slayings, bringing to 25 the number to which he has formally confessed, a police sergeant says.

title: COURT THREATENS SCHOOL STRIKERS WITH DISMISSAL
description: A Superior Court judge said today that he would begin ordering the dismissal on Thursday of striking Teaneck teachers and other school employees who continued to defy his backto-work order. The threat by Judge Sherwin D. Lester came after an all-night negotiating session that ended with the two sides close to agreement.

title: STRINGS: FITZWILLIAM QUARTET
