description: BRITAIN'S Fitzwilliam String Quartet returned to New York Saturday with an original and demanding evening of music at the Metropolitan Museum. The first half of the program -Haydn's two-movement Quartet in B flat (Op. 103) and the E minor Quartet by Faure (Op.121) - was notable for its reticence and introspection.

title: Knicks Sign Tucker
description: The Knicks signed Trent Tucker, their top draft choice, to a three-year guaranteed contract tonight. According to a source familiar with the negotiations, the contract calls for an escalating yearly salary that starts at $200,000 and ends at $275,000.

title: A SLIP-UP BARS 10 FROM BALLOT FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Ten Democratic candidates for State Supreme Court in Manhattan will not be on the Democratic line next month because the county Democratic organization failed to file nomination papers on time with the City Board of Elections.

title: ANTI-SHARON PETITION CIRCULATES
description: Although public debate over the degree of Israeli responsibility has died somewhat since the establishment of a judicial commission of inquiry, there is still considerable ferment in the army, with significant numbers of senior officers reported backing the resignation of Defense Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Ralston Plans Sale To Quaker Oats
description: The Quaker Oats Company said it had agreed in principle to buy the Ralston Purina Company's pet-food business in Europe.

title: L.I. MAN FAILS IN A COURT BID ON NAZI LINK
description: A 62-year-old Long Island man who was said to have commanded a Nazi concentration camp, in which 12,000 East Europeans, including 2,000 Jews, were executed during World War II, lost his bid in United States Supreme Court yesterday to retain his American citizenship.

title: Space Record in Sight
description: The Soviet Union celebrated the 25th anniversary of the launching of Sputnik 1 in its own way, by announcing that the crew now orbiting the earth in the Salyut 7 space laboratory will set a new space endurance record. The current record, also held by the Soviet Union, is 185 days.

title: FUNDS FOR EDUCATIONAL SHOWS
description: Four grants totaling $3.5 million to develop educational television and radio programs have been announced by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and Annenberg School of Communication Project. The programs will cover the Constitution, mathematics, politics in the Far East and Western Europe, and American art.

title: JORDANIAN AVOWS SUPPORT FOR IRAQ
description: Jordan's Foreign Minister, Marwan al-Kasim, told the United Nations General Assembly today that his country had ''an unequivocal national commitment to stand by Iraq in its defense of its national soil and its legitimate rights to its lands and waters.''

title: Leafs Lose Nylund
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs said that Gary Nylund, their first-round draft choice, would require surgery and would be out indefinitely with damaged knee ligaments suffered in an exhibition game last month. ... The Boston Bruins have demoted Marco Baron, a goaltender, several weeks after having released Rogie Vachon, a veteran goalie. Pete Peeters, obtained in an offseason trade with Philadelphia, and Jim Craig are the goalies on the Bruins' roster.

title: Philippines Accuses 10 In a Series of Bombings
description: The Government today filed charges of conspiracy to commit rebellion against 10 people, including a former United States Army sergeant who it said confessed to planting firebombs in four Manila hotels on orders of a Filipino realtor in California.

title: 10 YEARS AFTER HOOVER: NEW IMAGE, NEW TRAINING
description: The young woman on her belly in the dirt, waist-length auburn hair trailing on the ground beside her, clutched a .38-caliber pistol in both hands and grimly fired again and again at the distant, paper image of a man facing her across the field.

title: Coast Utility Suit Threat
description: Three Washington public utilities said today that they would sue the Bonneville Power Administration in an effort to shed responsibility for their share of nearly $7 billion in debt from two abandoned nuclear power plants.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAB TESTING: TEDDY BEARS TO BOURBON
description: Several times a year, the Federal Center for Fire Research builds part of a house, sets it ablaze and steps back to watch.

title: A.M.A. ACTS TO PROVIDE DRUG DATA TO PATIENTS
description: The American Medical Association, which helped kill a Carter Administration proposal to require warning leaflets with prescription drugs, today began a voluntary drive to give patients more information about 20 such widely used medicines.

title: 10 Russians Are Reported Captured by Afghans
description: Ten Soviet soldiers were captured in a city near Kabul recently by anti-Government insurgents who executed six of the men and took the other four toward Pakistan, Western diplomatic reports said here today.

title: DETROIT'S TEACHERS GO BACK TO CLASSES
description: Detroit's public schoolteachers voted today with evident reluctance to end their 22-day strike and resume classes immediately for the system's 200,000 students.

title: Old Pros Complain
description: Some pro football players from two decades ago, members of the Dallas Texans' American Football League championship team of 1962, do not have much sympathy for today's players in their current strike against the National Football League owners. ''It's hard to comprehend what these guys want,'' said Fred Arbanas, a former receiver for the Texans, the team that later became the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Sonics Trade Walker
description: Wally Walker, whom the Seattle SuperSonics signed to a one-year guaranteed contract on Monday, was traded yesterday to the Houston Rockets.

title: RUBBLE IS SHOVED ASIDE FOR TENTS FOR REFUGEES
description: Bulldozers began to clear the rubble of south Lebanon's refugee camps today as the first step toward housing thousands of homeless Palestinians in tents this winter.

title: Hearing Set On Panhandle
description: The Energy Department said today that it would hold a public conference on a request by the Panhandle Eastern Corporation to import liquefied natural gas from Algeria.

title: WALTER TERRY, A DANCE CRITIC, AUTHOR AND LECTURER, IS DEAD
description: Walter Terry, dance critic for the now-defunct New York Herald Tribune and the Saturday Review and an internationally known champion of the dance through his books and lectures, died Monday in Montefiore Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: N.F.L. ALL-STARS ARE DELAYED
description: The National Football League Players Association, citing what it called legal harassment by club owners, yesterday postponed for a week the beginning of play in its All-Star League.

title: Dons Study Court Future
description: The University of San Francisco is studying the possibility of restoring its basketball program, which was dropped earlier this year amid charges that rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association had been violated.

title: TENNECO, 3 OTHERS TO PAY GAS REBATE
description: Tenneco Inc., a pipeline company, and two major natural gas producers have agreed to pay $40 million in penalties for improper pricing policies before 1975, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission announced today. The money will go to consumers.

title: ANGOLAN SEES U.S. 'PARANOIA' IN QUESTION OF CUBAN TROOPS
description: Angola's Foreign Minister today derided American reports that progress had been made on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angolan territory and on independence for its neighbor, South-West Africa.

title: MISTRIAL IS DECLARED IN SUIT AGAINST DONAHUE
description: A Federal judge has declared a mistrial in a lawsuit against Phil Donahue, the television talk show host, that could affect reporters' ability to interview confidential sources.

title: To the Rescue
description: T he New York Aquarium in Coney Island is a wonderful place to look at marine life - but you should see the ones that got away. Take Dolphin.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TORRE AND HERZOG RELY ON BULLPENS
description: The battle of the bullpens, they were calling it, on the eve of the playoff for the National League pennant. And Whitey Herzog, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, put it bluntly:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams-Millis Corp., High Point, N.C., said its chairman, James H. Millis Sr., would assume the additional duties of president and chief operating officer following the resignation of William B. Mewborne Jr.

title: U.S. SHIFTS EMPHASIS IN NEW DRIVE ON DRUG ABUSE
description: The Reagan Administration, acknowledging today that law-enforcement efforts had yielded only short-term success, announced an expanded campaign against drug abuse to focus on demand and seek help from the private sector.

title: MOVIE MAKING IN NEW YORK TRIPLES IN 5 YEARS
description: The morning was rainy and gray, but by 7 o'clock the line of people waiting to sign in stretched around three sides of a block and then some. By 10 o'clock nearly 4,000 protesters were massed behind police barricades at Broadway and 20th Street, the men in 1950'sstyle felt hats, the women in dark coats with a sprinkling of motheaten fur pieces. From dozens of upstretched hands rose large placards with the solemn-faced pictures of a man and a woman and the words, ''Free Them.''

title: LOSSES FORCING CHANGE IN FRENCH AUTO INDUSTRY
description: France's automobile makers, long considered the most dynamic of the country's manufacturers and widely respected abroad for their technological skill, are in trouble.

title: Time Warps, and Woofs; Underground Fantasy
description: There is something pathetic about the New York subways spending $2 million for timetables in 700 locations. Consider this report from a regular BMT rider:

title: Economic Scene
description: year-old Republican Mayor of Cleveland, who has the strong support of the local business community, says he has been ''pushing hard to get the Reagan Administration to reconsider its policies for dealing with high unemployment here and in other parts of the country.''

title: Ex-Officer of Bank Going to Fox Film
description: Gerald K. Bergman, a former executive at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, has been named executive vice president of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation and president of 20th Century-Fox Enterprises.

title: ANGELS CAPTURE OPENER AS BAYLOR BATS IN 5 RUNS
description: Don Baylor, a potential free agent who has not been offered a new contract, and Tommy John, a traded player who has received a new contract, combined tonight to put the California Angels one game up on the Milwaukee Brewers in the American League pennant playoff. Their efforts also gave Manager Gene Mauch a victory in his first postseason game

title: Hijacking Drama Ends And Iranians Are Held
description: Two Iranian noncommissioned officers who hijacked an Air Force transport plane to the United Arab Emirates Sunday were in jail in Iran today after allowing the plane to return home, an Iranian diplomat said.

title: Greater Pleasures
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Since Mimi Sheraton enjoys the look of a disordered dining room after a meal (De Gustibus, Sept. 25), I wish to invite her to greater heights of pleasure at my house.

title: Last-Minute Departures Shake Rangers
description: It was no earthquake, but some strong tremors have shaken the Rangers in the last few days. Today, they reacted with the cautious concern of men checking the foundations of their houses to see if permanent damage had been done.

title: USE OF 'BELL' NAME DEBATED
description: What's in a name? Well, maybe billions of dollars, according to some companies in the telephone equipment business.

title: 'YOL,' A BIG, ANGRY EPIC OF CONTEMPORY TURKEY
description: YILMAZ GUNEY'S ''Yol,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M. is a big, angry epic of contemporary Turkey, a film whose political and ethnic concerns are likely to be equated -wrongly - with cinematic achievement.

title: THE POPE'S NEW DINNERWARE
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A 24-place set of bone-white dinnerware made by the Edward Marshall Boehm porcelain studio and emblazoned with the papal emblem has been designed for Pope John Paul II, Helen Boehm, the studio's owner, said yesterday.

title: IN CELEBRATION OF A RARE COLLECTION OF ISLAMIC ART
description: THE evening glowed with an Eastern aura - cool, quiet, with the suggestion of something mystical - as the guests Monday night took in visions of princes and hermits and mythical animals, sultans sedately sipping tea and a shah summoning demons to battle.

title: AT POLICE AUCTION, CARS AND HOPE
description: Some people were confident, carrying pouches of money or certified checks and ''the book'' to help determine whether the cars they were bidding on yesterday were good buys. There were others who did not carry enough money, but had plenty of hope.

title: Cardinals; Pitchers (Age, Throws, Record, ERA)
description: Joaquin Andujar (29, R, 15-10, 2.47)

title: NEW LIGHT IS SHED ON SALVADOR CRIME
description: At 11:37 P.M. on Jan. 3, 1981, two Salvadoran National Guardsmen stepped into the Salon Las Americas, the restaurant at the Sheraton Hotel in San Salvador, and moved quickly toward a rear table where three men sat. One of the Guardsmen lifted a .45-caliber submachine gun with silencer and began firing while the second pulled the trigger on his 9-millimeter submachine gun.

title: Cure for Workaholism
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: How rare and wonderful it is to find a problem that is raised in one article answered in another! The scourge of workaholism is grimly depicted (Personal Health, Sept. 29), including improbablesounding cures such as jogging with a friend and making lists of leisure pursuits. But the cure for the disease is far better depicted on page C14 (''Brazilian Playboy: The Last of a Breed''), in the description of the Brazilian playboy Jorge Guinle, who has so brilliantly solved the problem by steering clear of it altogether - replacing it with romance, not compulsive a la Don Juan (that would indeed be a form of workaholism) but dedicated and pleasure filled. PROF. ROLF MEYERSOHN Herbert H. Lehman College Bronx

title: Bridge:; European Pairs in the Lead At World Championships
description: European partnerships dominated the World Open Pair Championship going into the final qualifying session here tonight, with two American partnerships in a position to challenge for the lead.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Monument in a Crate

title: Beryl S. Austrian, 83, A Decorator of Lobbies
description: Beryl Siegbert Austrian, an interior designer credited by many in the business with having developed the field of lobby decorating, died Friday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clearing Work Stopped At Clinch River Site
description: Workers at the Clinch River Breeder Reactor project obeyed a Federal court injunction today and stopped work on clearing a site 13 days after it began.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball St. Louis Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, National League playoff, first game, at St. Louis. During the regular season, the Braves won seven of the 12 games between the teams.

title: DO YE KEN JOHN GLENN?
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio is not ''running'' for the Presidency, he's ''flying'' for it all over the country at the controls of his own plane.

title: Market Place; Processors Are Favored
description: WHEN the economy recovers, some cyclical stocks do better than others. Which ones do best depends on the nature of the recovery. This time the odds seem to favor users of commodities - not producers of them.

title: LEWIS S. JACOBSON
description: Lewis S. Jacobson, a retired lawyer, died Sunday at his home in Somerset, N.J. He was 82 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan. Mr. Jacobson founded the firm of Jacobson & Winter, and practiced law for 55 years in Perth Amboy and Edison. He was a graduate of Rutgers University and of Rutgers Law School.

title: CITY'S PLANNING AGENCY VOTES PLAN FOR JAIL NEAR CHINATOWN
description: The City Planning Commission has unanimously approved a proposal to build a new city jail adjacent to the lower Manhattan civic center, on the western edge of Chinatown.

title: HARVEST TIME FOR HOME WINE MAKERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eunice Fried is a wine writer based in New York. By EUNICE FRIED

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ROADBLOCK SCENE DESCRIBED BY WITNESS IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Moments before two police officers were killed after the $1.6 million Brink's robbery last Oct. 20, Kathy Boudin emerged from a getaway truck and persuaded a police sergeant at a roadblock to have one of his officers put away his weapon, the officer testified today.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BRIEFING
description: Focus on Nuclear Weapons C onservative pressure groups used ''negative'' television advertising to send several Democratic liberals in Congress into forced retirement in 1980, so it is not surprising that the technique has been adopted by some liberals for 1982.

title: MRS. SULLIVAN AND MOYNIHAN SPLIT ON ARMS
description: In the first debate of their campaign, the two candidates for United States Senator from New York tonight disputed the relative military might of the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: MUSIC: MUTI LEADS 'FAUST SYMPHONY'
description: THE temptation is to say that Liszt's ''A Faust Symphony'' is the most studiously boring large-scale work he ever composed. However, the competition is too stiff to risk that. Let's just suggest that until its final five minutes, when a male chorus and a tenor come on to deliver an apotheosis that derives from Beethoven's Ninth and anticipates several of Mahler's choral movements, ''A Faust Symphony'' consistently storms the heights of ennui.

title: DECRIMINALIZING HEROIN
description: It is time to raise a new cry for the decriminalization of heroin and other drugs such as cocaine and marijuana. American courts and prisons are tremendously overworked. We can no longer afford the burden placed upon them by the enforcement of drug laws. We should recognize the futility of attempting to cure society's drug problems through the criminal justice system and, instead, make drugs that are now illegal available to adults who want them. This approach appears to be the least expensive and best way of substantially reducing courts' work loads, and, as a bonus, making a significant dent in the rate of street crime.

title: 1. Brightly Colored Boots
description: Some of the most cheerful footwear in town is to be found at Santini & Dominici, the local branch of an Italian chain. The shop has just got in a collection of boots in brilliant color combinations that are being snapped up almost as soon as they appear in the window. A short boot joins colors such as red, yellow and blue; black with violet and blue; pink with purple and yellow. Another boot has a black patent bottom and a tall top (it's meant to be worn crushed down) in colors such as turquoise, red, yellow or green. Both models are $90. The shop is at 697 Madison Avenue (62d Street).

title: MAKER OF TYLENOL CLEARED OF BLAME
description: A toxicologist examined the main plant that manufactures Extra-Strength Tylenol today and ruled out the possibility that capsules of the pain-killer had been contaminated with cyanide here.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ERIC FLOYD AND NETS REACH AGREEMENT
description: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd, the all-America guard from Georgetown and the Nets' first-round selection in last June's collegiate draft, agreed to contract terms today.

title: South African Oil Well
description: South African officials said today that the nation had made the first significant find in its offshore search for oil. Oil and gas flowed from a well 140 miles off the coast owned by the state-financed Southern Oil Exploration Corporation.

title: Military Analysis
description: Heavy fighting in the hills east of Baghdad, reported yesterday by intelligence sources, indicates that the Iranians, despite their failure to break through on Friday, are maintaining pressure along this sector of the front.

title: TENNESSEE SENATOR UPSET ABOUT KEY ABORTION VOTE
description: ''I'm uneasy about it,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee. ''When they keep pounding day after day with that stuff, it's going to stick with some people.''

title: 4 Die in Baltimore Blaze
description: An early morning blaze in an east Baltimore row house without smoke detectors, killed four people today, the authorities said.

title: St. Regis Paper
description: The St. Regis Paper Company said it plans to sell its paperware division within 30 days to a private concern it declined to name.

title: PREREQUISITE TO MIDEAST PEACE: ISRAELI-P.L.O NEGOTIATIONS
description: To the Editor: Robert Goldmann speaks of a far-reaching consensus among American Jews that Jews be allowed to live in the West Bank and Gaza and that a ''judenrein area in the Middle East and elsewhere'' will not be tolerated.

title: Cleveland Newspaper Pact
description: Members of Newspaper Guild Local 1 and the teamsters' union voted overwhelmingly in favor of a new contract with the Cleveland Plain Dealer Monday, ending the threat of a strike. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents drivers, voted to accept the pact, 244 to 30. The guild's vote count was not released.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: In lieu of a football season, we bring Metropolitan Diary readers: LATE-BREAKING SCORES By Hugo Flesch

title: Movie Quiz
description: A man who's never even had a bank account wins $3 million in a state lottery. A Frank Capra film, with Gary Cooper in the lead.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN the Country Music Association hands out its 1982 Country Music Awards next Monday, insiders are going to be watching a 28-year-old Kentuckian named Ricky Skaggs, who has been nominated in five of the most prestigious award categories.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Instrument Corp. said it had received about $100 million in orders from Tele-Communications Inc. for cable TV electronics equipment.

title: 'GENES DO NOT COME IN COLORS'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Food Dye's Unclear Status

title: CUOMO ATTACKS AMOUNT OF LEHRMAN'S SPENDING
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for governor, barnstormed through the airports and editorial boards of New York's North Country today, accusing his Republican opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman, of trying to buy the election.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Age and Sad Experience

title: DANISH CONSERVATIVES PROMISE AUSTERITY
description: Denmark's new Prime Minister, the conservative Poul Schlueter, today presented austerity measures to revive the country's debt-ridden economy.

title: KOHL'S FOREIGN POLICY: GROUNDS FOR CONTINUITY
description: The Administration appears to hope that the replacement of Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic-led coalition in Bonn by a new Christian Democratic Government headed by Helmut Kohl will lead to a conservative foreign policy more in tune with its own. Such hopes seem likely to be disappointed, however. While there may be a change in tone and atmospherics, overall the accent, as Mr. Kohl indicated, will be more on continuity than change.

title: KEY WITNESS IN GIBSON TRIAL FOUND IN HOSPITAL
description: A key witness who failed to appear in court Monday to testify for the prosecution in the ''no-show job'' conspiracy trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and Earl Harris, a former City Council President, has been located at a Newark hospital, where he had been admitted after a possible overdose of prescription drugs.

title: MINERALS & RESOURCES CORP LTD reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $7,111,000 for the current yr and $14,605,000 for the previous yr

title: Talks on Cuba's Debt
description: Japanese banks expect the formation soon of a steering committee of Spanish, French, Japanese, British, Canadian and other banks for talks on the rescheduling of Cuban debts of $1.3 billion due before the end of 1985, banking sources said today. Leon Torras, governor of Cuba's central bank, is visiting Tokyo to explain a request for rescheduling 32.5 billion yen, or about $120 million, of syndicated loans supplied by Japanese banks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Snag in Fugazy Plan For Adding More Cabs

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
MUNICIPAL BONDS ADD TO GAINS
description: Tax-exempt buyers accorded a warm welcome yesterday to the State of Connecticut's $100 million issue of general obligation bonds as prices in the municipal market extended recent gains and yields fell.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently dined in a Montreal restaurant on a first-rate pate called cretons. The menu implied it was made from cracklings (roast pork skin) or something similar. It had a high flavor and a slightly crackling grittiness. Are you familiar with this?

title: Looking for Oil in India
description: Dalbir Singh, India's energy minister, said today that 37 foreign oil companies had been invited to submit exploration bids by Jan. 15. The companies include 22 based in the United States.

title: PHILIP EISEMAN
description: Philip Eiseman, a retired Boston banker and civic leader who played a leading role in the development of bank holding companies, died Friday in London vacationing.

title: 5 WAYS TO TRY TO AVERT TAMPERING WITH DRUGS
description: Five main packaging techniques are available to manufacturers of over-the-counter drugs to make their products more nearly tamperproof, a packaging expert said yesterday.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1982
description: International Lebanese Army soldiers conducted their first intensive search of downtown West Beirut, sealing off commercial and residential streets and taking scores of people into custody. Unofficial estimates put the number of those detained at more than 400. (Page A1, Column 6.) Sweden said it had trapped what it suspects is a Soviet submarine in coastal waters near a secret Swedish naval base. It said it was dropping depth charges to force the vessel to the surface. (A3:1-3.)

title: Bomb Threat Delays Flight
description: A bomb threat held up a New Yorkbound Varig Airlines jetliner for four hours today while policemen searched the plane for explosives, a spokesman for the Brazilian airline said. No bomb was found aboard the Boeing 747 plane, the spokesman said. Airport officials had received an anonymous telephone threat late Monday, he said.

title: CIVILIAN PRESIDENT ELECTED IN BOLIVIA
description: The Bolivian Congress, meeting for the first time in more than two years of military dictatorship, overwhelmingly elected Hernan Siles Zuazo tonight as President of a civilian government. He is scheduled to be sworn in on Sunday.

title: From Jets to Jabs
description: The heavyweight boxing picture, crowded as it is with mediocrities, is in need of new contenders, and there may be one no farther away than Kew Gardens, Queens. That is the home of Ed Gregg, a 6-foot-5-inch, 211-pound slugger with 11 knockouts in his 11 professional victories, against a lone draw, who is only one or two stepping stones away from crossing the line from prospect to contender.

title: CUTTING CRIME TIED TO JAILING OF BUSIEST CRIMINALS
description: Crime could be sharply reduced without overloading prisons by giving the busiest criminals the longest sentences, according to a six-year study by the Rand Corporation. The sudy suggested a method for identifying chronic law breakers.

title: Chinese-Soviet Parley Begins
description: Chinese-Soviet talks, the first in nearly three years, resumed today in an effort to improve relations between the two Communist powers, foreign diplomatic sources said.

title: Stocks Climb; Dow Up 3.58
description: Increased institutional buying sent stock prices moderately higher yesterday with the biggest price moves posted by issues responding to specific news developments.

title: HARVEY KUENN: MAN OF STRENGTH
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. The little red light was flashing on his telephone when Harvey Kuenn reached his hotel room in Stockton, Calif., last June 1. The operator gave him a message to call Harry Dalton, his boss.

title: STRUGGLE SHAPING ON BOMBER AWARD
description: In a new battle for contracts to build radarevading Stealth bombers, Rockwell International and Lockheed have joined forces to compete with Northrop for Air Force orders worth at least $20 billion, industry officials said today.

title: TRAILING THE RIGHT WHALES IN THE BAY OF FUNDY
description: All eyes scanned the sea in the Bay of Fundy, eagerly awaiting a telltale blast of water or the unsignaled surfacing of an enormous black body from the placid Atlantic.

title: INLAND SEES LOSS
description: The Inland Steel Company said today that it expected a third-quarter loss nearly double that of the second quarter, which was $23.2 million, compared with a profit of $29.5 million a year earlier. In New York, Joseph Wyman, an industry analyst with Shearson/ American Express, said virtually all of the major steel companies will report operating losses for the third quarter.

title: American Brands
description: American Brands Inc. said it had agreed to settle an antitrust suit arising from the acquisition last year of the Ofrex Group Ltd. by the company's British Gallaher Ltd. unit. The proposed settlement with the Justice Department provides for American Brands' divestiture of the Ace Fastener Company division of Swingline Inc. American Brands' chairman, Edward W. Whittemore, said the company had agreed to the settlement although it did not believe the Ofrex acquisition violated antitrust laws.

title: FOUR ARAB NATIONS ANNOUNCE U.S.TRIP
description: The United States was informed yesterday that King Hassan II of Morocco will head a four-nation Arab delegation to Washington later this month to discuss ways of promoting Middle East peace efforts.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 6, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: World Slump Idles Greek Shipping
description: In the sheltered waters of Eleusis Bay, an armada of idle ships lies at anchor, illustrating the worst slump in international shipping in almost 30 years.

title: MARCUS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 19
News Analysis
description: A new way of redistributing public and private health insurance funds to hospitals in New York State so that the wealthier lose a little income and the poorer gain a lot is being described by state health officials as the most important development in hospital care for the poor since the introduction of Medicare and Medicaid 16 years ago.

title: Cookbook's Origins
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Kenyan Officials to Get A Code of Conduct
description: President Daniel arap Moi, reacting to charges of corruption in his Government, announced today the formation of a committee to write a code of conduct for Kenyan officials.

title: Judge Allows Liberals To Designate DelBello
description: A State Supreme Court justice today upheld the Liberal Party's designation of Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, as its candidate for lieutenant governor.

title: CORPORATE 'FREE-FOR-ALLS' INCITED BY U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Friends Bid Farewell to Bernbach
description: THROUGH the men, women and children crowded into the United Nations Chapel yesterday morning ran the threads of William Bernbach's life, a long and active life of 71 years that reformed the face of advertising throughout the world before his death on Saturday. It was a life that touched on many other lives and added a human dimension to his own favorite saying, ''An idea can turn to dust or magic, depending on the talent that rubs against it.''

title: Kornhauser Gets Cyro
description: Kornhauser & Calene has been tapped to be the agency for Cyro Industries, a joint venture of American Cyanamid and Rohm of West Germany that makes acrylic molding and extrusion resins. But, most importantly, it spends between $1.5 million and $2 million for advertising. The previous agency was Gray & Rogers, Philadelphia.

title: CRUCIAL YEAR FOR DEVILS' RESCH
description: Things get lost when a tenant moves into a new building, things like keys and a Stanley Cup. But such incidents were merely minor on a night when major league hockey came to New Jersey.

title: An Experienced Leader For a Youthful Concern
description: The DNA Plant Technology Corporation is a fledgling company bent on developing better fruits and vegetables through biotechnology. What is unusual is its impressive list of financial backers and management. The latest addition is Richard Laster, who has been president of the Maxwell House division of General Foods and has just joined DNA Plant as its first president and chief executive.

title: Kunwar Inderjit Singh, Former Nepal Premier
description: Former Prime Minister Kunwar Inderjit Singh died of throat cancer Monday in Bangkok, Thailand, the Government said today. He was 77 years old.

title: A CASUAL ELEGANCE SETS THE MILAN TONE
description: The first few days of the Italian ready-towear shows for spring and summer established the return to the casually elegant style that has become known as the Italian look. In today's shows, designers attempted to expand their share of the fashion turf.

title: Third Man Convicted Of Draft Resistance
description: A Federal jury deliberated only 64 minutes today before convicting Mark Schmucker, a Mennonite, of resisting the draft. He was the third person convicted this year for failure to register for the draft.

title: CORPORATE 'FREE-FOR-ALLS' INCITED BY U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor: Edgar Bronfman's article was a rare, illuminating and courageous statement from a C.E.O. who was at the center of one of the most dramatic corporate takeover deals.

title: MORSE DIAL, 87, RETIRED CHAIRMAN OF UNION CARBIDE
description: Morse G. Dial, former president and retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Carbide Corporation, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 87 years old and had lived in Greenwich, Conn., for many years.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The first hotel in the Bronx was dedicated on an October day in 1923. Gov. Alfred E. Smith spoke at the ceremony. The hotel was called the Concourse Plaza, and a newspaper called Bronx in Tabloid said it would ''enable the social life of the borough to assemble amid luxurious surroundings, in keeping with its prestige as the sixth greatest city in the country.'' For many years it lived up to those advance notices.

title: CORPORATE 'FREE-FOR-ALLS' INCITED BY U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Eight Plead Not Guilty In Slave Labor Case
description: Eight of 10 persons indicted for running an international slave ring have pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiring to bring about 50 Indonesians into the country illegally and to sell them to wealthy homeowners.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRING BACK BACH

title: BILL TO CURB URANIUM IMPORTS ANGERS TWO KEY U.S. ALLIES
description: A proposal pending in Congress to limit uranium imports has angered two major American trading partners and, according to Administration officials, may endanger the Government's drive to lower international trade barriers.

title: Thompson Re-enlists
description: Word was received in New York yesterday that in faraway Washington, the Marine Corps had made up its mind to stick with J. Walter Thompson, its recruitment-ad agency for 36 years, for another three-year hitch. There is no dollar figure on the budget yet, because Congress has not acted, but the agency does know that there is a ceiling: $15 million.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Children and Hospitals
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jane E. Brody's article on parents' preparation of their children for hospitalization (Personal Health, Sept. 22) had many fine points. Here are a few others that I've found valuable in preparing children:

title: Dog Days
description: A dog needs a collar, a leash and an owner willing to walk behind it with a small scoop and a piece of paper. A dog will swim and run with you, but cannot ski.

title: VIVIAN MERCHANT, 53, ACTRESS
description: Vivien Merchant, the British actress who starred on the West End and Broadway in many of the enigmatic plays written by her former husband, Harold Pinter, died Sunday at her home in London, her family announced yesterday. She was 53 years old.

title: HOWARD JOHNSON'S SETTLES DISPUTE OVER OVERTIME PAY FOR $5 MILLION
description: The Howard Johnson's restaurant chain has agreed to pay $5 million in past overtime pay to 5,000 current and former employees nationwide, the United States Labor Department said today.

title: STAGE: 'LENNON' A BIOGRAPHY, OPENS
description: ''LENNON,'' the musical play that finally braved its official opening at the Entermedia last night, is not quite the ghoulish enterprise one might fear. Though indeed a biography of the late John Lennon, it is less an exploitative exercise in sensationalism than a sincere attempt to uncover the main man behind the Beatles's legend. Perhaps, in retrospect, a little more sensationalism would have helped. If ''Lennon'' is rarely tasteless, it is always flavorless - or, to put a finer point on it, dull.

title: WARSAW'S NEXT STEP: SOLIDARITY ON TRIAL
description: A new phase in the history of repression in Poland is about to begin, probably in the next few weeks. A group of intellectual prisoners has been selected for a major political trial that, in effect, is going to be the trial of Solidarity.

title: The 1982 Election: Pennsylvania Fourth of 10 articles appearing periodically on states with important gubernatorial races.
description: Both Gov. Dick Thornburgh and the Democratic challenger he has largely ignored have keen eyes for the silver linings that are supposed to exist in dark clouds.

title: Strike Spurs Sad Song
description: Jerry Taylor was a Dallas schoolboy when the Texans won their title. Now he is a 33-year-old Cowboys fan and he takes an agonized view of the strike in a song he has written, called ''Football Withdrawal.''

title: RTC TRANSPORTATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 5
description: B-After extraordinary gain of $2,050,000 for qr and the 9 mos

title: Begin's Wife Is Hospitalized
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's wife, Aliza, was taken to a hospital Monday because of respiratory pains and blood circulation difficulties, hospital officials said tonight. Her condition was descibed as ''serious but stable.''

title: 'LIGHT': DUAL REVELATION
description: IN Edgar G. Ulmer's 1939 ''The Light Ahead,'' which will be shown tonight at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, at least as much is revealed about Yiddish theater of the 1930's as about life in a Russian shtetl, where the story takes place. (Parts of it were actually filmed in New Jersey.) In the village of Glupsk, near Odessa, a collection of comically foolish characters are gathered, and together they create a portrait of Jewish life. The material isn't always as charming as it means to be, but it certainly isn't run-ofthe-mill. How many other films have running subplots about deciding which kind of chicken makes the best soup?

title: DUNLOP OLYMPIC (AUSTRALIAN CO) reports earnings for Yr to June 30
United Telecom To Buy Aero-Flow
description: United Telecommunications Inc. said it had agreed to buy Aero-Flow Dynamics Inc., a New York-based distributor of industrial products, for $34 million in cash and stock. United Telecom would buy about 45 percent of Aero-Flow's common outstanding for $60 a share, with the rest to be converted into United Telecom common at the rate of 3.069 shares of United Telecom for each share of Aero-Flow.

title: CAMPAIGN DEBATE TAKES ON A BIPARTISAN TONE
description: Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders agreed more than they disagreed in a nationally televised debate on foreign and military policy tonight, and they joined in criticism of President Reagan's efforts to halt the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Europe.

title: B.P. to Cut Fleet
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. said its B.P. Shipping Ltd. subsidiary will reduce its owned tanker fleet by about one-third, to 29 ships from 45, by selling or scrapping three very large crude carriers, four medium crude carriers and nine product carriers. Even at its reduced level, the fleet will continue to incur substantial losses, the company said. The reduction, together with proposed lower manning levels in the remaining fleet, will mean the loss of about 625 jobs.

title: AUTO SALES FELL 15.9% IN '82 YEAR
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that the 1982 model year ended in late September with another drop in sales, closing out the worst year for auto sales since 1961.

title: BAYLOR IS A SUCCESS DESPITE DISTRACTIONS
description: From the on-deck circle, Reggie Jackson had the opportunity to see the latest example of the change in Don Baylor. The change takes place when Baylor is needed most, when there are Angel runners on base.

title: BODY OF A MAN FOUND IN HOME OF RICHMOND
description: The body of a man in his mid-20's, who apparently committed suicide, was found last night in the East Side apartment of former Representative Frederick W. Richmond, the police reported.

title: BLOCK ISLAND CONSERVATIONISTS BUYING ACREAGE TO SET IT FREE
description: Standing on a flowering bluff above the dark Atlantic, with the wind whipping his thinning hair and billowing the fields of wild goldenrod and purple aster behind him, William P. Lewis 2d pocketed a letter of intent he had just been handed. It was the confirmation of the first part of his dream.

title: Warner, CBS Sign Distribution Pact
description: Warner Bros. Inc. signed a three-year contract yesterday with CBS Theatrical Films to distribute the films produced by the two-year-old division of CBS Inc.

title: SUNERGY COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $17,000

title: TICKET SALE TO BEGIN OCT. 15 FOR VATICAN ART EXHIBITION
description: Tickets for ''The Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art,'' which officials from the Metropolitan Museum of Art expect to be its most popular show since ''The Treasures of Tutankhamen,'' in 1978-79, will go on sale Oct. 15 at Ticketron outlets around the country and by phoning Tele-tron.

title: PREREQUISITE TO MIDEAST PEACE: ISRAELI-P.L.O. NEGOTIATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: BENDIX BID IS DEFENDED BY AGEE
description: While a gathering of the financial community yesterday expressed concern that the controversial Bendix-Martin Marietta takeover battle had produced an antimerger backlash, William M. Agee, chairman of the Bendix Corporation, defended his actions and denounced the defensive activities of the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: Henry Ford Expects Loss
description: The Ford Motor Company will have its second losing quarter this year when results are posted later this month, according to Henry Ford 2d, former chairman, who now serves on Ford's finance committee.

title: Kosher Cooking Classes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: All 92d Street Y West cooking classes held at the Spanish-Portuguese Synagogue (i.e. Chinese, Moroccan, Japanese and Wine Tasting) are strictly kosher (''The 1982 Guide to New York Cooking Schools,'' Sept. 8). Separate kosher-style classes (some ingredients may not be kosher) take place at the 92d Street Y. BATIA PLOTCH Director 92d Street Y West Manhattan

title: A HOSPITAL WHERE ETHNIC CHANGE IS CONSTANT
description: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's A series of articles appearing periodically. By DENA KLEIMAN

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GROWING UP. By Russell Baker. 278 pages. Illustrated. Congdon & Weed. $15.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS SEARCH FOR ARMS IN HEART OF BEIRUT
description: Soldiers of the Lebanese Army today made their first intensive search of downtown West Beirut, sealing off business and residential streets and taking scores of people into custody.

title: New U.S. Pipeline Sanctions
description: The Reagan Administration tonight imposed an export ban on four West German concerns in retaliation for their supplying equipment for construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline.

title: Sale by Allied Unit
description: Midwec, a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell to Charles Industries, a private company in Rolling Meadows, Ill., its coil and capacitor product lines. Allied is a chemicals producer. The sale by Midwec, based in Scottsbluff, Neb., would include manufacturing plants there as well as CEBU, the Philippines-based unit.

title: DANCE: ELIOT FELD OPENS FALL SEASON AT THE JOYCE
description: IT may seem rather soon for Eliot Feld's ballet company to return to the Joyce Theater, just four months after its opening. But then again, the Joyce is Mr. Feld's very own theater, envisioned as a home, and last night the Feld Ballet looked totally at home there.

title: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES LEADING IN '82 CONGRESSIONAL FUND-RAISING
description: Republican House and Senate candidates, whether incumbents, challengers or those seeking open seats, have raised and spent more on the average than Democrats in the same categories, a Federal Election Commission report showed today.

title: U.S. AGENCY URGES FOOD STAMP CUTS
description: The Federal Food and Nutrition Service, in an effort to control the costs of the food stamp program, has recommended a change that would reduce benefits for people who are 60 to 64 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on tuition tax credits incorrectly stated a provision of a bill pending in the Senate. As amended in committee, it provides full tax credit for families with ad- justed gross incomes up to $40,000 a year and lesser credits for families with incomes up to $50,000.

title: CONVICTED DOCTOR FIGHTS FOR LICENSE
description: Massachusetts officials are considering whether to revoke the license of a doctor who served time in Federal prison after pleading guilty to indictments that said he had a ''malicious interest in making more money, cutting his costs and saving his time in disregard for the life and health of his patients.''

title: Dan River Issues Stock
description: Dan River Inc. said its directors had established a new series of cumulative voting preferred stock and had issued all 1.7 million shares of the new series from previously authorized preferred. The textile and apparel maker based in Danville, Va., said the securities were issued to a stock bonus plan for salaried employees.

title: Trial to Start in Cairo Oct. 17 Of 302 Accused of Treason
description: The trial of 302 Moslem fundamentalists charged with trying to overthrow the Government will start Oct. 17, the opposition Socialist Labor Party newspaper reported today.

title: Never Too Old
description: Last Sunday at Columbia University's Baker Field, 34 baseball players from the metropolitan area chased a dream. The occasion was the first stage of tryouts for the team that will represent the United States at the 1983 Pan American Games in Caracas, Venezuela, and at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, where baseball will be featured in the games for the first time, as a demonstration sport.

title: SWEDEN TRAPS SUB AND DROPS DEPTH CHARGES
description: Swedish naval forces said today that they had trapped what they suspect is a Soviet submarine in coastal waters near a secret naval base and that they were dropping depth charges to force the vessel to the surface.

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
ISLANDERS LOSE
description: With Glenn (Chico) Resch excelling in goal, the New Jersey Devils withstood several strong attacks in the second and third periods tonight and gained a 3-3 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins in the Devils' first National Hockey League game at their new home in Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: 'CELESTE,' A MEMOIR OF PROUST
description: ''CELESTE,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a small-scale, remarkable little film based on ''Mr. Proust.'' This is the memoir of Celeste Albaret who, for nine years before Proust died in 1922, was his cook, companion, secretary, friend and surrogate mother during the creation of ''Remembrance of Things Past.''

title: SUN AND WINE SAVE CALIFORNIA'S GRAPES
description: SUNSHINE and cool breezes have salvaged the vintage of 1982 from disaster in California as wine producers all across the state bring in the grapes in the most difficult harvest in a decade. Two severe and untimely rainstorms in September, a crucial month in the ripening process, had threatened the California grape crop with destruction and prompted cries of alarm among the growers and wine makers, who are not accustomed to problems with the weather.

title: TV: 'THE CASE OF DASHIELL HAMMETT'
description: TV, Channel 13, tonight at 9 offers an introduction to this interesting personality who led separate lives, not at once, but in different times of life.

title: CORBY DISTILLERIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a $406,000 special gain; yr-ago results have been restated for accounting change

title: ANXIOUS POLISH PRIMATE CANCELS VATICAN TRIP
description: Worried over Government plans to outlaw the suspended independent trade union Solidarity, the Polish Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, today canceled a visit to the Vatican this weekend.

title: Safeway Says Net Doubled
description: Safeway Stores announced that net income in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 11 more than doubled, to $39.1 million, or $1.50 a share, from $15.5 million, or 59 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: FLORIDA INCUMBENT SURVIVES CHALLENGE IN PRIMARY RUNOFF
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr. survived the toughest campaign of his career and won a convincing victory today in his Democratic runoff against a wealthy oilman who had attacked the seven-term incumbent for supporting President Reagan's economic policies.

title: Bush Assails Critics of Reagan; Bush Says Demagogues Attack Reagan as Cold
description: Vice President Bush today denounced as ''demagogues'' those who asserted that President Reagan lacked compassion for the unfortunate.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including gains from equity in the net income of an affiliate of $244,000 or 5 cents a shr for the current qr and $705,000 or 15 cents a shr for the yr-ago qr

title: The Field Is Narrowed For A.T.& T. Account
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has narrowed the field in the agency competition for the business telecommunications account that will be split off from the giant corporation's regular account on Jan.1.

title: TV: CBS ADDS NEW GIMMICK TO DETECTIVE SERIES
description: STILL another team of husband-and-wife private detectives makes its debut tonight, on CBS-TV at 10, in the new weekly series called ''Tucker's Witch.'' The gimmick in this instance is that Amanda Tucker (Catherine Hicks) has special psychic powers, not unlike those possessed by young Matthew Star (Peter Barton) on a new NBC series. The added twist is that Amanda's special talents are unpredictable, sometimes working, sometimes not. This leaves her husband Rick (Tim Matheson) shaking his head in wonder or bemusement much of the time.

title: CHAMBER: VIVALDI BY I MUSICI
description: THE 12-member Italian chamber group, I Musici, has done much over the last 30 years to restore the music of Antonio Vivaldi to the mainstream of musical life with their recordings. But on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of its first violinist, Pina Carmirelli, I Musici reminded a listener that the opinions of the composer's contemporaries were not far off.

title: Furniture Makers Await a Recovery
description: Furniture makers are waiting for falling interest rates to pull them out of a three-year slide. The $9 billion-a-year home furniture industry has been hurt by high interest rates and economic stagnation. ''Things are tough - to put it bluntly,'' said Douglas Brackett, vice president of the Southern Furniture Manufacturers Association.

title: Mr. Baker,; Meet Miss Bellamy
description: ''M rs. Carol Bellamy'' got a letter yesterday at City Hall from Howard Baker, the Senate majority leader. ''Dear Mrs. Bellamy,'' Mr. Baker began, and then he said the President had asked him to call on her to make ''a most unusual sacrifice.''

title: PRESIDENT'S COST PANEL UNDER FIRE
description: Representative William D. Ford, chairman of the House Post Office Committee, said today that President Reagan's advisory committee on reducing the cost of government was deliberately organized to avoid the conflict-of-interest requirements of Federal law.

title: Required Reading 'With Relish'
description: Senator S.I. Hayakawa, Republican of California, speaking before the Senate on the dispute over who makes the biggest hamburger. Oct. 1, 1982:

title: Eye Drop Complaint Is Dismissed by Police
description: A woman suffered severe eye burns Monday after using a new bottle of eye drops, but medical authorities who tested the solution said today that it had not caused the woman's injury.

title: TYLENOL MAKER RECALLS CAPSULES AFTER STRYCHNINE INCIDENT IN WEST
description: The manufacturer of Tylenol today announced a nationwide recall of all Tylenol capsules, Regular and Extra-Strength, and said it was halting production of the capsules since a California man was stricken after taking Tylenol capsules laced with strychnine.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Bidding For Electrical Contract Work
description: The Government is investigating charges of widespread bid-rigging in the electrical contracting industry, the Justice Department said today.

title: Square D Plans An Acquisition
description: The Square D Company, a maker of electrical and electronic equipment, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire San Diego-based Topaz Inc. for $55.3 million in cash or stock.

title: Japan's Steel In a Key Role
description: Japan will be the biggest producer of crude steel in the non-Communist world this year despite the Japanese steel industry's slump, people in the industry said today.

title: Elsinore, Which Owns Casinos, Picks President
description: Robert R. Maxey, a well-known figure in the gambling casino industry, has been elected president and chief executive of the Elsinore Corporation, an owner of casinos.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago results restated for change in accounting for compensated absences

title: Field Venture
description: Field Enterprises Inc., the private communications concern, said it would enter the cellular-radio business in a joint venture with the Dallas-based Paging Network Inc. Under terms of the equal partnership, called Cellnet Partners, the closely held Paging Network will file applications with the Federal Communications Commission to provide the mobile telephone service in the San Francisco-Oakland and San Jose markets, and Field would acquire an interest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can't avoid it, we here in Michigan are in the middle of a depression.

title: Indecent Debate
description: President Reagan and Senator Denton of Alabama don't think much of Americans who agitate for a faster pace of arms control. They have a perfect right to resist, but not with the name-calling and innuendo to which they now resort.

title: JUDGE RULES STARCH-BLOCKING PILLS ARE DRUGS
description: A Federal district judge today classified starch-blocker diet aids as drugs and ordered an end to all sales until experts could determine whether they were safe.

title: Woolco Move Is Defended
description: The president of the F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday defended the struggling retailer's decision to close its Woolco discount store chain and sell its British subsidiary.

title: Science's Open Secret
description: The quest for knowledge is necessarily an open process, and national security requires secrecy. Hence an inevitable tension between scientists and security officials. But that tension has recently turned into frank hostility. In the latest of several imbroglios, the organizers of a laser-optics conference last month were compelled by guardians of military secrets to withdraw a quarter of the papers they planned to hear.

title: Real Estate; Developer Adjusts to Recession
description: AS the climate for new office development has grown more unfavorable across the country, the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, one of the biggest developers of commercial space in North America, has responded by shrinking plans for some projects, putting others on hold and dropping some plans entirely.

title: 3 Injured in Car Bomb Blast
description: Frank Rosenthal, who was once linked to organized crime in an affidavit to the Nevada Gaming Commission, suffered burns but escaped with his life when a bomb exploded in the car he was starting. The explosion Monday night also shattered a restaurant window, slightly injuring two Secret Service agents who were in Las Vegas to check on security for President Reagan's planned visit to the city Thursday.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STRYCHNINE TERMED AS TOXIC AS CYANIDE BUT 2 POISONS DIFFER
description: Strychnine, the poison found in Extra-Strength Tylenol that caused a California man to become ill last week, is as powerful a poison as the cyanide added to Tylenol capsules that killed seven people in the Chicago area. The poisons come from different sources, however, and work in different ways. Each can be fatal in relatively small amounts within minutes.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: The 1982 results reflect LIFO method of inventory valuation; the 1981 results restated for F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: ABC Radio at Nadler
description: Nadler & Larimer has won the ABC Radio Network account that has been served for three years by Muller Jordan Weiss. The ad budget is about $1.2 million. Nadler & Larimer is owned by the Mickelberry Corporation.

title: FOR 500,000 GUATEMALANS, THE WAR COMES HOME
description: The guerrilla war in Guatemala has uprooted 500,000 people, officials say.

title: A Prior P.L.O. Pullout Is Demanded by Israelis
description: Israel said tonight that it was ready to withdraw from Lebanon at the same time that Syria withdrew, but it insisted that all remaining Palestinian guerrillas must leave the country immediately.

title: Land Fraud Indictment Says 2 Swindled 3,000
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted two former Beverly Hills land promoters on charges of defrauding thousands of investors in a large land fraud case.

title: HEARING AIDS: SMALLER, EVEN FASHIONABLE
description: Designer glasses, move over. Two Purdue University professors, David Goldstein and Carl Binnie, predict designer hearing aids may be next to enjoy a sales boom.

title: 2 GERMAN MUSEUMS GIVE BREAD A PLACE IN HISTORY
description: In a country where bread has been a basic food throughout recorded history, it would hardly devoted to tracing the practical to find a museum symbolic signfificance of the staff of life. But in Germany there are two such establishments - the German Bread Museum in Ulm, on the Danube midway between Stuttgart and Munich, and the European Bread Museum to the north in Mollenfelde, near Gottingen.

title: Careers; Increasing Production Efficiency
description: YEARS ago Thomas Watson, founder of the International Business Machines Corporation, adopted the slogan ''Think.'' Appearing in I.B.M. offices, it reminded employees to think for the sake of the company (and presumably for the sake of an individual's future with the company). It encouraged what might be called self-directed productivity.

title: OIL IN ATLANTIC: INTEREST WANES
description: After four years of offshore drilling that has yielded some of the most expensive dry holes in the history of the oil industry, the nation's major oil and gas companies are in a broad retreat from exploration off the Atlantic Seaboard.

title: FOUR DEAD AMONG 16 ALIENS LEFT IN TRUCK ON TEXAS ROAD
description: Four illegal aliens from El Salvador were found suffocated Monday night in a truck abandoned by smugglers in the south Texas desert, the authorities said today. Twelve surviors were also found, eight of whom were hospitalized for treatment for dehydration.

title: 2 DEFENDANTS PLEAD GUILTY IN VANDALISM AT JERSEY WATERSHED
description: Two men about to stand trial on charges stemming from the disruption of Newark's water supply system last year pleaded guilty today to reduced charges in Superior Court.

title: Stephanos Stephanopoulos, Ex-Greek Premier, Dies at 83
description: Stephanos Stephanopoulos, a former Prime Minister of Greece, died here Monday after a long illness.

title: Workers Return to Plant After Bombs Are Found
description: The Gulf Oil Chemicals Company, which closed the Cedar Bayou refinery last Thursday after five bombs were found hidden inside the plant, asked about one-third of the facility's 1,100 employees to return to work today.

title: Service for John G. Forrest
description: A memorial service for John G. Forrest, retired financial-business news editor of The New York Times, who died Monday, will be held at 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Scottsdale United Presbyterian Church, Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: THE VICTIMS OF PERU'S ANTI-TERRORIST LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS PRISON REFORMER FACING A PAROLE CASE
description: David R. Ruiz, a twice-convicted armed robber who brought a lawsuit in Federal court that forced changes at the Texas Department of Corrections, is back in jail in Austin on charges of parole violation. If the charges are upheld, he could be returned to prison.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Iran Is Said to Jail Hijackers On Return of Air Force Plane
description: Two Iranian noncommissioned officers who hijacked an air force transport plane to the United Arab Emirates Sunday were in jail in Iran today after allowing the plane to return home, an Iranian diplomat said.

title: Marriott Net Up 5.7%
description: The Marriott Corporation disclosed that earnings in its third fiscal quarter ended yesterday increased 5.7 percent, to $29.8 million, or $1.10 a share, from $28.2 million, or $1.05 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues advanced 25.5 percent, to $631.6 million, from $503.4 million, the hotel operator, which is based in Washington, D.C., said.

title: Atom Test Monitoring Described as Insufficient
description: The Federal Government should have had a comprehensive radiation safety monitoring program operating when above-ground atomic tests began in Nevada in 1951, a biophysicist testified today.

title: KOCH SAYS JUDGES REFUSE TO SEND MINOR CRIMINALS TO WORK CAMPS
description: Mayor Koch accused Criminal Court judges yesterday of refusing to sentence minor criminals to work camps that the city opened a month ago. He said only 22 persons had been sent to the camps, which can accommodate 125.

title: RELIGIOUS RIOTS IN INDIA APPEAR TO WANE
description: After a month of sporadic fighting among Moslems, Hindus and the police that has left 29 people dead, the latest and largest eruption of violence in the northern Indian city of Meerut appears to have been contained.

title: Now Chebor Has New Perspective
description: Last spring, Solomon Chebor, a Fairleigh Dickinson senior from Kenya, was trying to overcome a lingering knee injury. He felt so bad, he said then, that he could not defend his 3,000-metersteeplechase title in the IC4A outdoor championships.

title: STRIKE BY TEANECK TEACHERS ENDS WITH A 3-YEAR ACCORD
description: The 19-day strike of Teaneck's public schools ended late tonight as teachers and other school employees ratified a three-year contract agreement. The pact, reached late this afternoon, came after nearly 26 hours of continuous talks.

title: ADAPTING AMERICAN FOODS TO JAPANESE CUISINE
description: ZUCCHINI slices dipped in light batter and crisply fried do not seem at all out of place on tempura platters served in Japanese restaurants in New York, yet zucchini is virtually unknown in Japan. Its use in this country is just one example of the adaptation that traditional Japanese cooking has been making to the products it encounters as it becomes established abroad, especially in America.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Rehired three coaches: Bill Fischer, Ron Plaza and George Scherger. BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Released Tyrone A dams, forward-guard, and Lloyd Terry, a free agent. INDIANA (NBA) - Signed a second- r ound draft choice, Jose Slaughter, a g uard, to a multiyear contract. Released A ndre Wakefield, guard, and Chris Giles, f orward. NETS (NBA) - Signed their No. 1 draft c hoice, Eric Floyd, guard, to a multiyear c ontract. SEATTLE (NBA) - Traded Wally W alker, a forward, to Houston for a 1983 s econd-round draft choice. WASHINGTON (NBA) - Asked waiv- e rs on Jim Chones, forward, and Nate D avis and Anssi Rauramo, free-agent g uards.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: STANDARD classic and regional French cooking has been established for centuries, some of it interlaced with borrowings from other countries. With the arrival of the jet age, the chefs of Europe found themselves traveling around the world, sampling the foods of their colleagues in Japan and China and taking home various ''new'' flavors to offer their clientele.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are two kinds of women: those who can't seem to walk out of the house, or back into it, without looking like pack horses, and those who carry nothing but a divine little handbag. The pack horses can't understand what they ever did to deserve their burdens or how the elegant ones manage to live in New York without juggling packages, shopping bags, plastic sacks and totes. They are usually irritated or envious when they spot an uncluttered figure.

title: Lacey Davenport vs. Horatio Alger
description: How do you run for the Senate against a kindly Republican legislator whose manner has been affectionately popularized in the character Lacey Davenport in Garry Trudeau's ''Doonesbury'' comic strip?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the new titles of Arthur E. Strickman. He will become chairman and chief executive officer of the Rapid-American Corporation's Lerner Stores subsidiary.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-Includes a gain of $3.5 million or 41 cents a shr resulting from the sale of a 20 percent interest in Mobile Tyco Solar Energy Corp; results for the latest and yr-ago qrs include results of Ludlow Corp from date of acquisition, Sept 22, 1981

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS OPTIMISTIC ON ELECTORAL OUTCOME
description: The White House arranged a proclamation of optimism today for the coming elections, with Republican Congressional leaders offering far rosier public predictions than some of those being expressed privately by President Reagan's aides.

title: ELECTRIC OMELET PAN
description: IT is no accident that one of the first lessons in cooking classes on French cuisine is how to make a proper omelet. Preparing this fundamental and versatile dish is an excellent introduction to the technique of stove-top cooking. It combines blending fresh ingredients and seasonings, determining proper cooking temperature and handling a pan.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DO you feel, in your job, your marriage, your life, as if you're banging your head against a stone wall, trying harder and harder but accomplishing less and less? After years of greeting each day with enthusiasm, do you now awake wishing the morning would go away, but force yourself to get up to face yet another day of hard work from which you derive little or no This is the second of two articles. satisfaction? Are you no longer excited by the activities and accomplishments you used to find stimulating? Are you becoming increasingly drained, physically and emotionally?

title: LEHRMAN PROPOSES JOB FREEZE IN STATE GOVERNMENT
description: Touring Hasidic neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would freeze hiring by the state government ''for as long as it is necessary to get the budget under control.''

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1982; Companies
description: Domestic auto sales fell 15.9 percent for the 1982 model year ended Sept. 30, the worst performance by the five car makers since 1961. Analysts said the outlook for 1983 appears nearly as bleak, partly because of a large inventory of 1982 models still unsold. In the Sept. 21-30 period, Chrysler's sales rose 39.5 percent, but G.M.'s fell 7.6 percent and Ford's 1.5 percent. (Page D1.) Ford will have its second losing quarter this year, Henry Ford 2d said. (D5.)

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Burroughs Corp. filed a shelf registration statement for $100 million of debt securities, bringing its total amount of debt securities available for issue to $125 million.

title: STOCK INDEX CONTRACTS CLOSE NARROWLY MIXED
description: Prices of stock index futures closed narrowly mixed yesterday, while the actual averages posted strong gains. Brokers said that this divergence in price trends was not uncommon because the spot, or nearest, futures contract is the December one, while the actual averages reflect the latest day's trading.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SAY THEY DOWNED A MIG IN ANGOLA
description: The South African Air Force shot down an Angolan MIG after an encounter over southern Angola today, according to a brief announcement made in Pretoria.

title: Ukraine Youth Wins Illinois Court Hearing
description: Walter Polovchak, the Ukrainian boy granted political asylum, will get a hearing before the Illinois Supreme Court in his effort to avoid returning to his parents' custody in the Soviet Union.

title: HURDLES TO A STABLE U.S.-CHINESE RELATIONSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S DEBATE IS CUOMO'S FIRST WITH LEHRMAN
description: Mario M. Cuomo and Lewis E. Lehrman were scheduled to meet this morning in their first debate of the New York gubernatorial campaign, but last night the two sides were arguing about the format for the debate.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $136,000

title: Delmarva Delays Plant
description: The Delmarva Power and Light Company of Wilmington, Del., said yesterday that it had postponed the completion of a $1 billion electric power plant because the demand for electricity had eased. Delmarva said it had stopped all investments in the oil-fired Vienna 9 plant and would lay off 6 percent, or 165, of its workers by the end of March.

title: BODY FOUND IN RICHMOND'S HOME IS IDENTIFIED
description: An apparent suicide victim whose body was found Tuesday evening in the East Side apartment of former Representative Frederick W. Richmond was identified yesterday as 21-year-old Gregory Bergeron, formerly of Boston.

title: FINANCIAL RETAILING AT SEARS
description: Stan Janda of nearby Manassas, Va., walked into the Sears, Roebuck & Company store at the Fair Oaks Mall the other day to return an item. Soon, however, he found himself browsing through racks of literature at the store's financial service center, where employees were selling insurance, stocks and bonds, and homes.

title: BAKER FENTRESS CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: CLARK CO. SHUTTING 3 PLANTS IN MICHIGAN
description: The Clark Equipment Company announced today that it would shut three Michigan plants over the next 15 months and greatly reduce capacity at a fourth because of ''economic factors.'' Clark, which builds construction machinery, materials handling equipment and automotive parts, said at a news conference that about 1,730 of the company's 4,200 workers would be affected.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Whenever I take a shower a powerful, sewerlike stench comes back up out of the drain after the shower has been running for about a minute. How can I eliminate this?

title: 3 Israelis Captured by Syria Are Well, Red Cross Reports
description: The Israeli Army announced today that Red Cross representatives had visited three Israeli soldiers captured by Syria during the war in Lebanon and reported they were in good physical condition.

title: SUBSTANCE MAY FIGHT HERPESAND GONORRHEA
description: Test-tube research shows that gossypol, a cottonseed oil extract used as an experimental male contraceptive in China, apparently kills the genital herpes virus and the microbe that causes gonorrhea, experts in biomedical research said yesterday.

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
DATA ASSOCIATION
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. T he catcher says he was ''scared''; the pitcher says he never allows himself to become ''too high or too low.'' Ted Simmons and Don Sutton describe almost opposite reactions to last Sunday's conclusive game in Baltimore, when the noise of the home fans nearly willed a championship for the Orioles.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL DEFENDS POLICY ON CUBANS IN ANGOLA
description: A senior State Department official contended today that the United States was politically realistic in seeking simultaneous accords on the departure of Cuban troops from Angola and on independence for South-West Africa, the disputed territory also known as Namibia.

title: CYANIDE IS DISCOVERED IN TYLENOL IN AN APRIL DEATH IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules discovered in the Philadelphia apartment of a student whose death six five months ago was ruled a suicide have been found to contain cyanide, the police in Philadelphia said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Andrea H. Milbank, 57; Assisted Arts Programs
description: Andrea Hunter Milbank, a leader in charitable activities for the arts, died Tuesday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 57 years old.

title: 3 Suspects Accused in Jersey Of Bogus Credit-Card Scheme
description: Three persons reputedly involved in a scheme to manufacture thousands of counterfeit credit cards were arrested here today after a stockpile of the cards and equipment to make them were confiscated from a warehouse, authorities said.

title: Tesoro in Talks On Equity Sale
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Company said it is discussing with the Government of Trinidad and Tobago the possible sale of its 49.9 percent equity interest in the Trinidad-Tesoro Petroleum Company.

title: CAPITOL FOOD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $59,000

title: HENRY STREET SETTLEMENT CUTS ARTS PROGRAMS
description: Facing a projected deficit of $800,000, the Henry Street Settlement, an 89-year-old Lower East Side institution, has temporarily closed its Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center and ended its arts programs.

title: STOCK MARKET SURGES ON HOPE THAT RATES WILL DECLINE FURTHER
description: Expectations that interest rates will continue to drop, as they have recently, set off a stock market rally yesterday that drove up the Dow Jones industrial average by 37.07 points, its second-biggest rise in history.

title: MOYNIHAN AND MRS. SULLIVAN CAMPAIGN IN FINANCIAL DISTRICT
description: Two entourages pushed successively south along Broad Street in the downtown financial district yesterday. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan led the first and was greeted like a celebrity and, in some cases, like an old friend as he campaigned for a second term as a Democrat-Liberal. Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan, his Republican, Conservative and Right to Life opponent, led the second march and drew a polite but puzzled reception.

title: No Headline
description: SWEDISH NAVY STILL HUNTING A SUBMARINE

title: Leaseway Deal
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation of Cleveland said it would buy three auto-hauling subsidiaries of Ralph C. Wilson Industries for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: LAMPS: THE MOST FOR THE MONEY
description: SHOPPING for a lamp is easiest if you have a good idea of the kind of lighting you expect from it. Is the light to shine downward or upward or to spill out into the room? Think about where the lamp will be placed. If, for instance, a table lamp is going in a heavily trafficked area, you might want to consider a weighted lamp that will not tip easily. If the same lamp is to be used for reading as well as general lighting, one with a three-way socket would be useful.

title: Death of Vivien Merchant Is Ascribed to Alcoholism
description: Vivien Merchant, the actress, died of alcoholism, a coroner ruled today.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: AN attractive headboard is often a major decorative element in a bedroom, and an upholstered one can provide softness and pattern. A new convertible headboard on the market enables you to mount fabric or sheet material yourself, eliminating the need for an upholsterer and giving you the freedom to change fabric when you wish.

title: An Appraisal
description: WHEN a plan by Maya Yang Lin, a 21-year-old Yale architecture student, was selected last year as the winner of a nationwide competition to find a design for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial on the Mall near the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, it was hailed by the architectural press with words such as

title: EXCERPTS FROM LEHRMAN'S PROGRAM
description: Following are excerpts from a ''Program for Job Growth and Tax Reduction'' offered by Lewis E. Lehrman, Republican-Conservative candidate for Governor of New York:

title: WOMETCO CABLE TV INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 11
No Headline
description: Administration Denies Plan to Cut Food Aid

title: New York Amtrak Train Crashes in Alabama
description: An Amtrak passenger train, the Crescent bound for New Orleans from New York, collided with a tractor-trailer truck today, derailing 12 of the 13 passenger cars and injuring 16 passengers, officials said.

title: CHASE AND HANOVER BANKS SUE DRYSDALE OVER DEFAULT
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company filed suits yesterday seeking $306 million in damages from the defunct Drysdale Securities Corporation and the Government-securities trading firm that Drysdale set up last winter.

title: World Bank Bond Offer
