description: The World Bank is raising $250 million with a 20-year bond in the United States domestic market, the lead manager, Salomon Brothers, said through its international office here. The bond carries a 12 3/8 percent coupon at par, it added.

title: CANUCK GOAL TOUCHES OFF CONTROVERSY
description: ''S omething wrong is going on here,'' said Billy Smith, the outspoken Islander goalie, after the 2-1 loss to the Canucks in Vancouver, British Columbia, Tuesday night. ''It's very fishy.''

title: Treasury Futures Show Strong Price Increases
description: Prices of Treasury bond futures soared yesterday and once again pushed up Treasury bill futures. The session was marked by surprising and confusing interest rate movements and unfounded rumors that the Federal Reserve's discount rate, now at 10 percent, would be cut yesterday after the close.

title: 20th ANTIQUES FESTIVAL AT ARMORY IS CANCELED
description: The 20th National Arts and Antiques Festival, scheduled to run from tomorrow to Oct. 17 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, has been canceled.

title: Gerber Shutdown
description: Gerber Products said it was closing its Rochester baby food plant because of a decline in sales caused by a revival of breast feeding.

title: Search Is On for Three In Deaths of 4 Aliens
description: Seven Salvadorans taken away by smugglers from a truck where four of their countrymen suffocated in stifling heat were found today waiting in an orange grove near this town in south Texas.

title: Human Contact
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: To me happiness as an enduring state of mind is still rather unknown territory, but if satisfaction about getting off the bus at the right stop (''Hers,'' Sept. 16) is counted among its ingredients, then it is not surprising that glassy stares are an accompaniment - those dead cod's eyes, which seem to indicate that nothing is getting through.

title: Don't Blame the Budget Process
description: Though the balanced-budget amendment was rejected decisively by the House last week, the idea behind it still has political force. Voters and politicians alike are frustrated by the failure to get the Federal budget under control, and fearful of the consequences.

title: Union Camp In Acquisition
description: The Union Camp Corporation said it had completed the acquisition of Bush Boake Allen, a London-based producer of flavors and fragrances, in a transaction valued at about $75 million.

title: CAUTION IS URGED IN GENETIC TESTING
description: Experts told a House subcommittee today that genetic screening of workers might be a valuable research idea but that it was fraught with scientific uncertainty and serious ethical problems and that great caution must precede its use in the American workplace.

title: CLASSES DISCUSS THE STRIKE BRIEFLY
description: Beverly Bond adjusted the wide-rimmed glasses on her nose, scanned the 23 faces in front of her in her fifth-period class at Teaneck High School and paused to collect her thoughts. It was the first time in 19 days that she had faced this particular group of students, and she was sure there would be questions.

title: EAST GERMANY HELPS PARTY IN GREECE PUBLISH
description: East Germany has set up a front organization in Luxembourg to finance the publishing house of the Greek Communist Party in Athens, according to documentary evidence obtained in Luxembourg.

title: ATOM FREEZE WINS NARROWLY IN ALASKA CITIES' VOTE
description: Voters in Alaska's three largest cities cast ballots Tuesday on a nonbinding proposal calling for a freeze in nuclear weapons. A virtual standoff resulted, with proponents of the freeze winning slightly more than half the total vote.

title: Bumble Lives!
description: For a while he was known only as Ketchup Man - the mysterious person who advised the Reagan Administration a while back that the red stuff could be counted as a vegetable and substituted for the real thing in federally supported school lunches. Now, however, we're pretty sure we've got him nailed. His real name is Bumble, and preketchup he was best known for hauling a kid named Twist around a small English town, complaining about his appetite (''Oliver Twist has asked for more!'') and trying to get him apprenticed.

title: PENNA AIMS HIGH WITH FILLY IN GOLD CUP
description: ''Mr. Penna,'' the young attorney began, reading from her notes, ''would it be correct to say that you were the leading trainer in Argentina in 1951?''

title: Decision Aids All-Star League
description: A Federal judge's ruling in Washington yesterday eliminated one obstacle in the way of a union-organized All-Star League made up of striking pro football players.

title: FLORIDA SENATOR ATTACKS G.O.P. DRIVE
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, began his re-election effort today by attacking the Republican campaign against him as ''devious, diabolocal political skulduggery.''

title: Seized Property Troubles U.S.
description: The Government is holding $82 million in seized automobiles, trucks, boats and aircraft and is losing money because it cannot dispose of the property quickly enough, Representative Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said today.

title: Birdie, Birdie
description: Why would the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, Conn., bring in sentinel swans to get rid of Canada geese? What's wrong with Canada geese? And what is a sentinel swan, anyway?

title: SPAIN'S ELECTION CAMPAIGN OPENS WITH OUTCOME CLOUDED BY PLOT
description: Spain's general election campaign opened officially today with a new note of uncertainty in the air. Until last weekend, polls and politicians had agreed that the Socialist Party, led by 40-year-old Felipe Gonzalez, the country's most popular politician, would finish first in the voting on Oct. 28. The only question seemed to be whether Mr. Gonzalez would win a majority of the 350 seats in the Congress, the legislative house of Parliament, or be forced to form a coalition.

title: Edwin K. Reid Is Dead at 69; A Former Mayor of Demarest
description: Edwin Kitchen Reid, former Mayor and Councilman of Demarest, N.J., died Tuesday at Moore Memorial Hospital in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 69 years old and had moved to Pinehurst in 1979.

title: FUNDS RATE DROP SPURS BOND RALLY
description: Touched off by a sharp drop in key interest rates, the credit markets staged a broad rally yesterday, with some Government securities prices climbing a point.

title: MESA PETROLEUM PLANS ANOTHER ROYALTY TRUST
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said yesterday that it was planning to create a new investment vehicle for stockholders of the Texas oil company to be known as the Mesa Offshore Trust.

title: Brewers at a Loss for Words and Hits
description: After he had showered and changed, Gorman Thomas placed a chair in his clubhouse stall. He sat down, leaned back, his left elbow on his left knee, his chin cupped in his left hand. ''I've got nothing to say,'' Thomas said. Thomas was making a statement of fact more than a request to get lost.

title: NEW REPORT AFFIRMS ASPIRIN IS A THREAT TO PREGNANT WOMEN
description: Pregnant women should not take aspirin because it can cause excessive bleeding in the mother and baby in the first few days after birth, a study says.

title: BRIGHT IDEAS ABOUT LIGHTING FOR THE HOME
description: it is invisible and changeable, yet it has color, intensity, direction and sometimes shape. It can be warm or cold, soft or harsh. It can shimmer, sparkle, glow or glare. It can be friendly, merciless, tiring or comforting.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ANTIQUES AND TOURS
description: Antiques Show and Sale, Human Resources Center, Beinecke Auditorium, Albertson, L.I., 516-747-5400, ext. 1152.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALTERNATIVES

title: JUDGE TO ACCEPT NON-MANVILLE SUITS
description: A Federal court in New Jersey has ruled that the bankruptcy petition filed by the Manville Corporation does not bar asbestos victims from pursuing their lawsuits against other manufactuers and users of asbestos.

title: GENERAL FOOD GETS ENTENMANN
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy Entenmann's Inc. bakery, from the Warner-Lambert Company for about $315 million in cash.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday about the Manhattan Democratic organization's filing of nomination papers incorrectly identified Judge Jack Rosenberg's court. It is Criminal Court.

title: WORLD BANK AIDE SEES CHINA AS BIG BORROWER
description: China may eventually rank with India as the World Bank's two largest borrowers, according to a top bank official who has completed talks with the Government here.

title: Indictment on Draft Charge
description: The student president at the University of Northern Iowa has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to register for the draft.

title: Bridge: Americans Take the Lead In Play for 2 World Titles
description: American players were at the head of both world events going into play here tonight. Chip Martel of San Francisco and Lew Stansby of Oakland, Calif., took the lead in the World Open Pair Championship, while Gail Moss and Jacqui Mitchell of New York regained the lead in the women's series.

title: REAGAN IS ANGERED BY G.O.P. HECKLER
description: As a crowd listened in astonishment, President Reagan was interrupted in mid-speech by a Republican heckler at the White House today. The President responded with his most fiery oratory of the campaign and a blunt order to the heckler: ''Shut up!''

title: Frank Oftring, Ex-Coach, Dies
description: Frank A. Oftring Jr., who returned to Holy Cross College as basketball coach more than a decade after having starred on the team that won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship, died Monday at the age of 58.

title: UNPROMISING APPROACH TO WEAPONS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO SYMPHONY IS STRUCK
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra has canceled the first two weeks of the season, which had been scheduled to begin tonight, after its musicians struck the orchestra ''reluctantly and with regret'' on Tuesday.

title: SETTLING OLD SCORES
description: The newly chosen head of Georgia's Democratic Party is a tall, coolly affable, rumpled man sporting a ''Joe Frank Harris for Governor'' button. Joe Frank - one uses the middle name - was the underdog in the recent primary and reversed the national trend by beating a more liberal candidate; my Georgia source, who supported him, promptly became the party's State Chairman.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 7, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Exercise Routine From John Henry
description: If John Henry Shirtmakers went to Chalk, Nissen, Hanft for some innovative thinking, it has not been disappointed. Inspired by the fact that the client's products are, as the advertising will say, ''tailored to look lean and trim'' at a time when many men are trying to look the same way, the agency has come up with a premium concept that ties in beautifully: ''A daily exercise routine to keep you in shape'' on a tape recording that retailers will be giving away with purchases of the shirt.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Islanders signed the defenseman Ken Morrow and the right wing Duane Sutter to multiyear contracts. Each was entering the option year of his contract. ... George Raveling, head coach at Washington State University, has been selected as assistant coach to Bobby Knight of Indiana on the 1984 United States Olympic basketball team. ... Maurice Cheeks, who had stayed away from the Philadelphia 76ers' training camp because of a contract dispute, returned to practice even though the club has refused to act on his demands.

title: VISIT TO SHCHARANSKY RULED OUT
description: A Soviet diplomat, noting that Soviet-American relations were at an ''all-time low,'' today turned down a Senator's request to visit Anatoly B. Shcharansky, an imprisoned dissident.

title: U.S. MOVING TO FIX UNIFORM FEE SCALE ON MEDICARE CASES
description: Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, today proposed a new system of paying hospitals for the services they provide under Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: LAND REPAIR EXTENDED ON HUDSON PARKWAY
description: Another detour was added yesterday to the Henry Hudson Parkway, a road already known for its tie-ups, potholes, steel plates and wear and tear on automobiles.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices soared on expectations of falling interest rates, with institutional investors buying heavily. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.07 points, its second-biggest rise ever, to 944.26, its highest level in 14 months. Since mid-August, when rates first began to fall, the Dow has risen almost 160 points. Volume was 93.6 million shares, up from Tuesday's 69.8 million. (Page A1.)

title: FEW IN HONG KONG SEEK DEMOCRACY
description: In Hong Kong's colonial system of government, a relative handful of Britons have complete control, even though 98 percent of the city-state's five-million-plus residents are Chinese.

title: Iraq Says It Killed 2,352 Iranian Soldiers
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes and ground forces had repelled a new Iranian offensive near the Iranian border city of Sumar, killing 2,352 Iranian soldiers and capturing scores of others.

title: Dispute Mars Pentathlon
description: Janusz Pyciak-Peciak of Poland withdrew from the modern pentathlon world championships today after his protest that his horse had either been drugged or given excessive water was dismissed by the jury of appeal.

title: Bolivia Misses Loan Payment
description: Bolivia missed a payment of $25 million to foreign banks today and is now close to $50 million in arrears on its $450 million rescheduling agreement, banking sources said.

title: Caterpillar Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Corporation said it was laying off 350 nonunion employees at its Davenport and Bettendorf plants because of a strike by union production employees.

title: HERS
description: SCIENTISTS want to redesign our genes. To hear them tell it, we could all escape the fix our forebears left us in if only they could splice here or graft there or give our DNA a little twirl. Those of us who have yet to accept even simple technology must look askance at their proposals. And rightly so. They have demonstrated miscalculation in the past and have left us with unexpected consequences (need I cite specific examples?).

title: Polaroid Instant Slides
description: A new process for producing instant slides was displayed today by the Polaroid Corporation at Photokina '82, an annual trade fair in Cologne, West Germany. Polaroid hopes its entry into the 35-millimeter film market will shore up flagging sales. The Polaroid Autoprocess 35-millimeter System produces color and black-and-white slides in three minutes.

title: HURDLES TO A STABLE U.S.-CHINA RELATIONSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading
description: 'No Chauffeur'

title: A CITY JOBS AGENCY HELPED 30,000 FIND WORK DURING 1981
description: The New York City Department of Employment said yesterday that it had placed 30,000 youths and adults in jobs last year, almost all in private business, and that it hoped to do better this year by strengthening ties between government and privately run training programs.

title: 1787: FRANKLIN'S SILENT DEFEAT ON PRAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Weakfish and Blues Are Running
description: 1 Margate, N.J.:There are weakfish along the shore in 65 feet of water from Atlantic City to Cape May. Bluefish are mixed with them. Offshore angling for albacore and bonito has improved. Barnegat, N.J.: Large and small weakfish are against the beach; fluke are three miles off; offshore anglers are catching mako sharks; longfin tuna and albacore are over Barnegat Ridge, and bluefish are numerous. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Good catches of small blues offshore, including over Manasquan Ridge; fluking and bottom fishing is slow. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Small to medium-sized bluefish moving in and out, and a few anglers have been getting bigger blues using chunk bait a short distance offshore. Crabbing is excellent. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn: Angling for small to medium-sized bluefish is excellent. Porgies and blackfish are plentiful. Freeport, L.I.: Bluefish of all sizes plentiful over Cholera Banks; longfin and yellowfin tuna providing offshore action; flounder fishing improving; blackfish, sea bass and porgies plentiful. Captree State Park, L.I.: Large weakfish, some up to 15 pounds, are being taken in the inlet, frequently on live eels. Boatmen are catching big bluefish outside the inlet, and surf fishermen are landing them also. Blackfishing is good. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Flounder plentiful, as are blowfish. Crabbing is excellent. Shinnecock, L.I.: A few striped bass are beginning to show. Bluefish are in the inlet and off the beach. Montauk, L.I.: A run of striped bass appeared off Montauk Light. The fish, mostly 25 to 40 pounds, were caught on live eels or plugs. 4 Southold, L.I.: Porgie fishing had been good in Peconic Bay, but commercial draggers moved into the area.

title: AGAINST SCHOOL PRAYER
description: As a practicing Christian, I believe that the religious argument against school prayer is a lot stronger than many religious and secular people understand. On this issue, Christians, among other people of faith, had better speak up on the grounds of their faith.

title: 2 Muscovites Seized In Front of U.S. Embassy
description: Soviet guards dragged two screaming women away from the entrance to the United States Embassy today after the women said they wanted to talk to American officials about relatives imprisoned in Siberia, witnesses said.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: TORONTO (AL) - Added seven minor league players to its roster: Dave Shipanoff, Dennis Howard and Colin McLaughlin, pitchers; Tim Thompson, first baseman; Tony Fernandez, shortstop; Jeff Reynolds, third baseman, and Ken Kinnard, outfielder. Sent four players outright to Syracuse of International League: Anthony Johnson, outfielder; Dave Baker, third baseman; Paul Hodgson, first baseman, and Jackson Todd, pitcher.

title: HOME BEAT
description: SHE started as a custom tile maker and then began making other ceramic objects based on what she saw on her 80-acre Pennsylvania farm.

title: Guatemala-Mexico Deal
description: A senior Guatemalan official said today that Guatemala and Mexico could begin a barter trade system between the two countries but that the decision was in ''Mexico's hands.'' Deputy Agriculture Minister Luis Humberto Figueroa said at a news conference that the Governments of both countries, in view of a scarcity of dollars, were ready to put into effect a barter system in which Guatemala would trade meat products to Mexico for oil.

title: Brazil Oil Purchases
description: Brazil's state oil company, Petrobras, will double, to 100,000 barrels a day, its purchases of crude oil from the Saudi state oil concern, Petromin, the Petrobras president, Shigeaki Ueki, said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Nieuw Amsterdam Revisited

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN STIRS U.S. INTEREST
description: President Reagan has sent letters to the leaders of Mexico and Venezuela expressing ''great interest'' in their ''very constructive'' proposal for a negotiated settlement to restore peace to the border between Nicaragua and Honduras.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago figures are not comparable because the company was formed in Jan 1981 and account for only 6 mos of operations; the net loss is after noncash charges of $1.7 million for amortization of the write-up of properties to estimated fair market value at the time Royal was formed; the company also hada $671,286 noncash nonrecurring writedown in the carrying value of its Canadianoil and gas properties because of lowered estimates of Royal's proved oil and gas reserves in Canada

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PACT AT CHRYSLER LOSING VOTE SO FAR
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers are rejecting the new contract with the Chrysler Corporation by a ratio of 2 to 1 in early voting. With 22 of the company's 54 local unions reporting, there were 12,379 votes against the contract and 6,253 in favor.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: The yr-ago earnings were restated to reflect accounting change

title: BRIEFING
description: Carlucci Successor?

title: Steel Import Complaint
description: The United States specialty steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America will file a complaint with the Government Thursday against what they contend are illegally subsidized specialty steel products imported from the Britain, industry sources said today. They did not specify what specialty products would be named.

title: PESO COLLAPSE ENDS SHOPPING SPREES
description: They're all gone now, and they are sorely missed. There was the man who bought silk sheets, at $1,400 a pair, for his 9-year-old girl. And there was the one who picked up a load of video recorders to take home, putting the $27,000 bill on two credit cards.

title: GCA-Matra Pact
description: The GCA Corporation said it had signed an agreement with the Matra Group, a French communications and industrial conglomerate, to produce equipment used to manufacture semiconductors. The equipment would be made in Europe. GCA, a semiconductor maker based in Bedford, Mass., said further details about the agreement would not be released until it had been approved by the United States and French Governments.

title: PRESIDENT LEAVES 20th CENTURY-FOX
description: C. Joseph LaBonte has resigned as president of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation in Hollywood. The company - owned by a Denver oilman, Marvin Davis - confirmed the resignation, although it made no announcement of it.

title: H.U.D. Rejects Funds For Steel Plant Takeover
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has decided not to finance a proposed employee takeover of a steel plant in Weirton, W.Va., a department spokesman said today. The plant is planning to close.

title: AUSTRALIA REJECTS ATOM OFFER
description: Australia has turned down an American offer to share highly classified uranium enrichment technology, partly because of concern over Congressional opposition to the venture, according to American and foreign Government officials.

title: JUST HOW MUCH LIGHT DOES A ROOM REQUIRE?
description: HOW much light do I need in my living room? Lighting designers are typically reluctant to give a definitive answer. A technically accurate assessment requires specific computations, and an esthetically appropriate answer depends on many variables, including personal preference. One person's glare is another's gloom.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Milacron Cutback
description: Cincinnati Milacron said it would consolidate its British machine tool operations, closing one plant and reducing manufacturing levels at other plants.

title: San Francisco to Buy Transit Cars in France
description: Alsthom-Atlantique S.A., the diversified French engineering group that sold pipeline equipment to the Soviet Union in defiance of Reagan Administration sanctions, said yesterday that it expected to sign a $184 million contract to provide 150 rail cars for the San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit system.

title: HELPFUL DECORATORS FOR SMALLER JOBS
description: THE Clapps, Pamela and Jeffrey, are typical of many couples who set w hat they thought was a realistic decorating budget -$10,000 for the c ombined living-dining room - when they moved from a suburban house o n Long Island to a rented apartment in Manhattan.

title: Operating Chief Named At K.& E. Advertising
description: John B. Balson, who joined Kenyon & Eckhardt only eight years ago as a vice president, has been named president and chief operating officer of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising, its largest operating unit. It was one of a number of high-level executive changes announced yesterday by Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, president and chief executive of the parent.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,514,000 for the qr and $8,881,000 for the yr and a provision of $31,067,000 for the yr for estimated loss onthe disposal of discontinued operations...C-Comparable results for the yr-ago fourth qr are not available because of a special accounting review...D-After a loss of $106,885 from discontinued operations and a provision of $43,740,000 for estimated loss on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: News Analysis
description: Of the 12 politically active people who gathered at Harriet Burkhalter's house Tuesday night to watch a nationally televised debate sponsored by the League of Women Voters, only Howard Hanson seemed to be really stirred up. And Mr. Hanson was less stimulated by what the debaters in Washington had to say about foreign policy than he was by his campaign to make Minnesota candidates take a position on walleyed pike.

title: COLLECTOR FORCED TO SELL HENRY FORD MEMORABILIA
description: Hard times are forcing Wilfred J. Allen to sell 44 years of Henry Ford memorabilia that he has collected since he graduated from the automobile manufacturer's school for orphans.

title: Alpine Is Issuing Series Of Artists' Catalogues
description: Catalogues raisonnes - comprehensive listings of artists' works - including Philip Pearlstein, Frederic Cozzens and Fernand Leger, are being published by Alpine Fine Arts Collections.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Seasons

title: Soviet Project And U.S. Aid
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, said today that he would ask the Reagan Administration to approve use of American technology for a planned coal slurry pipeline from Siberia to Moscow.

title: 'TIME STANDS STILL'
description: PETER GOTHAR is a fresh, energetic director from Hungary, a nation that ordinarily produces much more muted stylists. Mr. Gothar's ''Time Stands Still,'' which is on view at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center tonight and Saturday, begins with a starkly beautiful black and white sequence, then blossoms into color, and sustains its visual ingenuity all the way through. There are times when the purpose to which Mr. Gothar's effects are being used is less apparent than the effects themselves, especially for audiences not fully conversant with events in Hungary during the film's 1956-1968 time frame. Nevertheless, ''Time Stands Still'' has a lot of visual excitement and surprise.

title: FARMERS OF PUNJAB ARE INDIA'S SHINING EXAMPLE
description: Except for his turban, 23-year-old Darshan Singh could have been any farmer in Iowa, sweating the sweat of a prosperous tiller of some of the world's most productive soil as his three-year-old tractor chugged along through a thick crop of thighhigh grain.

title: FENWICK-LAUTENBERG DEBATE FOCUSES ON ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, and Frank R. Lautenberg, her Democratic opponent, tangled over economic policies here today in the second debate of the campaign.

title: Energy Producer In Chapter 11 Bid
description: Energy Sources Inc., a Dallas-based oil and gas producer, said it it had filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. The company, which reported a $5.8 million loss for the first nine months of this year, said it was working with its principal lender, Texas Commerce Bank, to develop a plan of reorganization while continuing operations under Chapter 11.

title: Scott Adams Is Dead at 72; Ex-Librarian and Professor
description: Scott Adams, a retired librarian and educator and former librarian of the National Institutes of Health, died Sunday at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky. He was 72 years old.

title: REFURBISHING CHESTS OF CAMPHORWOOD
description: The effectiveness of camphor in protecting clothing against the ravages of insects has never been in doubt, and long before mothballs were manufactured of synthetic camphor, there were chests of camphorwood.

title: Advertising; Marschalk Completing Network
description: BY the end of the year, Marschalk Campbell-Ewald Worldwide should have an office in Spain. And that, according to Richard D. O'@Connor, its vice chairman and chief executive, will mean that 30 offices of the agency are flying the corporate banner in 24 countries and that the international network is completed.

title: RANGERS BEATEN IN OPENER BY LATE GOAL
description: Abe Pollin, who owns the loss-plagued Washington Capitals and had threatened to dissolve them last summer, put forth an idea last night.

title: FIRE KILLS FAMILY'S 5 CHILDREN IN FRAME BUILDING IN NEWARK
description: Five children, including a 4-month-old boy lost when his mother stumbled during a desperate escape attempt, were killed in a house fire here early today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER. By Ken- neth Blanchard, Ph.D., and Spencer Johnson, M.D. 111 pages. Morrow. $15. WORKING SMARTER. By the editors of Fortune. 210 pages. Illustrated with graphs. Viking. $13.95.

title: Joy in Long Marriage
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Sometimes I feel almost apologetic when young people exclaim over how long my husband and I have been married (31 years), as though we lack the imagination or spunk to split. Thank Joyce Colony (''Hers,'' Sept. 23) for telling the courage, humor and perseverance it actually takes. I only wish she had conveyed more of the joy and deep gratification of growing up, older and old together - she makes longlived marriages sound more grim than they have to be. CORINNE K. KLAFTER Great Neck, L.I.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMF Inc. said it had sold its Lawn and Garden division to a group of investors led by the division's president, William I. Brown, for an undisclosed amount of cash and securities.

title: St. Joe Minerals President Quits
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, acquired by the Fluor Corporation in 1981, said yesterday that James L. Broadhead, St. Joe's president, had resigned to pursue other interests.

title: Home at Last
description: They travel around the world, as part of their name suggests, but the Harlem Globetrotters' visit to Harlem this week was their first since 1965.

title: COOK'S PROBLEM: TOO MANY NET GUARDS
description: Larry Brown, the coach of the Nets, admits that he knew little, if anything, about Darwin Cook at this time a year ago. ''I knew little about his background, except that he had started a few games for the Nets during the previous year,'' Brown said after a recent practice here on the Princeton University campus. ''But I didn't have any idea about the type of player he was.''

title: G.E. NET UP 11.4% AS SALES SLIP 3.8%
description: The General Electric Company, citing its increased productivity and diversity, announced that net income in the third quarter of 1982 increased 11.4 percent, although sales slipped 3.8 percent.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
Four Astronauts Are Named For 10th Space Shuttle Flight
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has announced four of the five crew members for the space shuttle's 10th orbital flight, tentatively scheduled for next fall, the first mission to involve only Defense Department operations.

title: JUDGE BARS FORCING BOY, 10, TO TESTIFY, 3 'FREE' IN BURGLARY
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday refused to enforce another judge's order that had directed a 10-year-old boy to testify before a grand jury considering whether to indict two teenagers for a Roosevelt Island burglary.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates First Capital Corp., a Gulf and Western Industries subsidiary, filed for $150 million of investment notes due from one year to five years, and said it would sell the notes directly to the public through AFC Securities Inc., an indirect subsidiary.

title: U.S. TELLS LEBANON TO INSURE RIGHTS FOR PALESTINIANS
description: The United States publicly cautioned the Lebanese Government today not to let its desire to re-establish law and order in Beirut lead to ''a basic violation of rights.''

title: TOP POSTAL AIDE WARNS AGAINST COMPETITION
description: The chairman of the United States Postal Service's board of governors called today for retention of the Government monopoly over the bulk of first-class mail service.

title: FOR MUBARAK, A YEAR OF TURMOIL AND A YEAR OF SURVIVAL SINCE SADAT'S DEATH
description: They are faded and wind-beaten and covered, like everything else in this dusty capital, with a perpetual film of soot. But billboards bearing portraits of Anwar el-Sadat still loom over Cairo's tangled streets, a year after his assassination by a group of militant Moslems.

title: LEBANON'S PRIORITY: ISRAEL-SYRIA EXIT
description: With the Lebanese Army gradually reestablishing control of Beirut, the Government of President Amin Gemayel has begun to focus on Lebanon's most urgent concern: the occupation of 80 percent of the country by Israeli and Syrian armies.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A MIXED BAG OF STUDIO GLASS SHOWS
description: Shows of studio glass are currently being featured at three New York galleries. At Departure Gallery, glass by Katherine Bernstein, Vernon Brejcha and Paul Marioni makes a varied but uneven show.

title: Nedomansky Helps In Ranger Debut
description: Vaclav Nedomansky's strange and serpentine route to New York and a Ranger uniform finally ended last night, 15 years after the Rangers attempted to smuggle the former Czechoslovak star into the United States.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves. National League championship playoff, first game, at St. Louis at 8:15 P.M., after rainout yesterday that came two outs short of five complete innings, an official game. Manager Joe Torre of the Braves has chosen Pascual Perez to start; Whitey Herzog of the Cardinals will use Bob Forsch. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.) Figure Skating Skate America, at the Olympic Ice Center, Lake Placid, N.Y. Scott Hamilton of Bowling Green, Ohio, the two-time world champion, heads a field of 63 skaters from 17 countries in this second annual competition, which opens this morning and lasts three days. Rosalyn Sumners of Kirkland, Wash., and Tiffany Chin of Toluca Lake, Calif., lead the women's singles field. The women's singles competition begins at 7:30 A.M., and the men's at 1 P.M. The opening ceremonies are at 7:30 tonight.

title: UNPROMISING APPROACH TO WEAPONS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Theater To Be Closed Oct. 16
description: The New Westchester Theater will close after a Billy Squire concert Oct. 16, executives said yesterday.

title: COUPLE ON WAY TO GRANDSON KILLED AT 2D AVE. AND 60TH ST.
description: A Manhattan couple carrying gifts to their grandson were struck and killed in a crosswalk at 60th Street and Second Avenue yesterday by a delivery truck that careered off the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Technology; Videodisk's Data Future
description: SO far, the videodisk has been used mainly to play recorded movies on television sets. But computer industry experts see the day coming soon when disks similar to one type of videodisk now on the market will play a major role in the storage of computer data and office documents. Such disks will increasingly take the place of paper files, microfilm and the magnetic disks and tapes now used to store information.

title: Irish Leader Wins No-Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey of Ireland survived a no-confidence motion tonight in the parliamentary caucus of the ruling Fianna Fail Party by what was reported as a 58-to-22 vote in his favor.

title: ARCTIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including income tax credits of $173,000 for the qr and $246,000 for the yr, gains of $21,000 for the qr and $458,000 for the yr from interest expenses absorbed by discontinued operations and gains of $2 million for the qr and $3.8 million for the yr from participation in net proceeds from the sale of assets of discontinued operations...C-The company changed its fiscal yr-end from Mar 31 to July 31 and thus has no comparable yr-ago results

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From 40 Countries To One School

title: The Editorial Notebook; Winking at Price-Fixing
description: ''His policies,'' declared Senator Howard Metzenbaum, ''are draining the pocketbooks of millions of Americans.'' The Senator's target was William Baxter, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division. Mr. Baxter had announced that he would not prosecute all manufacturers who fixed the prices that retailers charged for their products just because the Supreme Court found the practice illegal. The Court's judgment, said Mr. Baxter, was ''very, very stupid.''

title: FINKELSTEIN SEEKS ROLE AT CHOCK FULL O' NUTS
description: Jerry Finkelstein, a New York publisher who has been increasing his holding in the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation, said yesterday that he and associates planned to take a first step today toward seeking control of the company, which has said it would oppose the Finkelstein group.

title: Bulls Are Picketed
description: Members of the National Organization for Women picketed an open practice by the Chicago Bulls at the Bradley University fieldhouse in Peoria, Ill., Tuesday night. The NOW members said they were protesting the presence of Quintin Dailey, Chicago's No. 1 draft selection, who is on probation in a case involving an assault against a nursing student in San Francisco. Dailey pleaded guilty to the assault charge last summer after an initial charge of assault with intent to rape was dropped in plea-bargaining.

title: Fifth Person Arrested In Refinery Bomb Plot
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested a man who a bureau agent said admitted placing five bombs inside a refinery of the Gulf Oil Corporation in Baytown, Tex., in an attempt to extort $15 million from the company.

title: Wright Morris Honored On Service in Literature
description: Wright Morris, the author of 33 books, has been chosen to receive the $14,000 Common Wealth Award for distinguished service in literature. The award, including a commemorative sculpture, will be presented at a ceremony on Oct. 13 before an invited audience at the New York Public Library.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bruins Drop Craig
description: Jim Craig, the goaltender for the United States Olympic hockey team in 1980, was released by the Boston Bruins one day before their National Hockey League season opener. The Bruins open their regular season tonight in Boston against Montreal with two goalies, Pete Peeters and Mike Moffat.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's quite clear that all external forces in Lebanon must leave Lebanon if Lebanon is going to have its authority restored.

title: Pope Calls on Poles to Pray
description: Pope John Paul II today called for Poles to pray for the gains made in their country in the last two years. He was speaking to his countrymen in St. Peter's Square.

title: Boxtop Candidate
description: Kim Kelly said she ''just sat down and brainstormed.'' This is how the assistant sports information director at Clemson University came up with the campaign to re-elect Terry Kinard, the Tigers' free safety, an all-American.

title: Ambrosiano Follow-Up
description: Three financial experts appointed by the Vatican have concluded that the Vatican bank should not be held liable ''from a strictly legal point of view'' for the debts of the collapsed Banco Ambrosiano, an Italian Roman Catholic magazine reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Self-Reliance

title: YUGOSLAVIA, ITS ECONOMY FRAIL, TURNS TO AUSTERITY
description: Yugoslav leaders, faced with huge foreign debts, an energy shortage and other problems, have urged tough austerity measures to save the country's stumbling economy while seeking new credits from Western banks.

title: 2 MOTORISTS DESCRIBE SHOOTOUT AFTER BRINKS'S HOLDUP
description: Two motorists who happened upon a police roadblock after the $1.6 million Brink's robbery last Oct. 20 testified today that a defendant, Samuel Brown, was among a group of men that jumped from the rear of a getaway truck and began firing handguns and automatic weapons at three police officers.

title: DANCE: NIKOLIAS OFFERS A PREMIERE
description: THE Nikolais Dance Theater presented the New York premiere of Alwin Nikolais's ''The Mechanical Organ II'' last night at the City Center Theater at the opening of a three-week season.

title: 4 Shot to Death At Club in Bronx
description: Four persons were shot and killed last night at a social club in the South Bronx, the police said. The shootings, which occurred at 8:20 P.M., left three women and one man dead, according to Sergeant James McGovern, a spokesman at the 41st Precinct.

title: Yankee Coaches Are in Demand
description: The Yankees' base-line coaches, Mike Ferraro at first and Joe Altobelli at third, are now in another kind of line, the one in which candidates for managing jobs can be found.

title: GARDENING
description: Spring Bulbs

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption on a United Press Inter- national photograph in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified the Brewers catcher in the American League playoff game. He was Ted Simmons.

title: SUMMATIONS END AT TRIAL OF TEAMSTER LOCAL HEAD
description: One of the New York metropolitan area's major union leaders, John A. Cody, sat impassively in a courtroom today as prosecutors and a defense lawyer, in their summations, presented conflicting portraits of his public and private life.

title: Ruling on Bell Fees
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would resume an investigation of the rates charged for Wide Area Telephone Service, or WATS, despite a court ruling questioning the basis of the inquiry.

title: ARABS: IS REAGAN TENACIOUS?
description: Official and other leaders I spoke to in recent days in Israel, Jordan and Egypt are asking, ''Will President Reagan hold to the course'' laid out in his Middle East peace initiative calling for a West Bank-Gaza association with Jordan?

title: JOHN UPDIKE'S LATEST NOVEL, 'BECH' SEQUEL, DRAWS ON HIMSELF
description: It is a magisterial house, an elegant, white Colonial mansion that overlooks the sea. Beyond the neatly groomed garden of roses and marigolds, beyond the grove of trees already blushed with autumn colors, one can see the ocean and the Massachusetts coast, and, if one looks closely, a little piece of land known as Misery Island. Inside, Oriental rugs decorate the floor and an outsized mirror reflects the coming and going of guests.

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONCERT: YOUNG ENSEMBLES
description: NEW Music for Young Ensembles brought us two of its 1982 prize winners Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall - Brian Fennelly's ''Canzona'' for clarinet, three string players and piano and ''Five Fables for Three Instruments'' by Josef Alexander. These co-winners represent the organization's continuing yearly competitions, which promote music that is brief, playable by small ensembles and technically accessible to even marginally professional players.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEXICO TURNS SOUR FOR DETROIT
description: When Detroit auto makers found their sales in the United States plummeting in the past two years, they could look south, to Mexico. In that oil-rich country, where consumers had embarked on a love affair with the car that Americans had abandoned, thriving sales and endless expansion all seemed possible.

title: RAIN PUTS OFF NATIONAL OPENER
description: The opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant was interrupted for almost two and a half hours by rain today and then was called off, with the Atlanta Braves nursing a 1-0 lead over the St. Louis Cardinals in the fifth inning.

title: STAGE: NANCY MARCHAND AS SISTER MARY IGNATIUS
description: THE bad news came a few months ago, when CBS-TV unceremoniously dropped one of the best series on television, ''Lou Grant.'' But there's some good news, too. Now that the actress Nancy Marchand has ended her five-season run in the role of Mrs. Pynchon, that show's patrician newspaper publisher, she has returned home to the New York theater. And she's come back in a remarkably gutsy way. In her first stage appearance since she played the dizziest of the sisters in ''Morning's at Seven,'' Miss Marchand has chosen to do the unthinkable: she has succeeded Elizabeth Franz in Christopher Durang's long-running black comedy ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You.''

title: U.S. STUDIES SHIFT IN ALLOCATING HOUSING FUNDS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is studying the possibility of shifting more than $1 billion in Federal grants from local public housing authorities to cities or states, a department official said today.

title: Excerpts from program, page B4.
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for Governor, proposed an eight-year program yesterday to reduce New York State's personal income tax by 40 percent and cut the state's sales tax in half, to 2 percent from 4 percent.

title: Accounts
description: * Trusthouse Forte to AC& R Advertising for its Exclusive Hotels division.

title: I.B.M. Forecasts Gain in Earnings
description: The controller of the International Business Machines Corporation, James Forese, said today that I.B.M. expects third-quarter earnings to surpass last year's $693 million but that the company should not be considered ''recession-proof.''.

title: THE NEST IS EMPTY BUT THE BIRDS HAVE LEFT THINGS BEHIND
description: T last the nest is empty. One by one the chicks have flown off to begin careers, set up apartments, get married or do whatever chicks do nowadays. At last the old birds have the nest to themselves.''They're gone!'' the old birds cry, running from room to room in the still and empty house. ''They're gone!''

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MAGAZINE MIRRORS GROWTH OF TAIWAN
description: Tien Sia, Taiwan's first full-fledged business magazine, seems to be a microcosm of the nation's economy, reflecting both its success and its problems.

title: Market Place; Takeover Talk Is of Harcourt
description: WHEN a takeover bid is feared, companies sometimes move preemptively by talking up the price of their shares to a level that would deter suitors. William Jovanovich of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich may be trying that tactic.

title: VIDEOTEX TO EXPAND WHAT A TV CAN DO
description: LATER this fall many television sets across the country may develop a split personality. As before, they will keep viewers abreast of the rarefied happenings at General Hospital, in Dallas and in the rest of the world. In addition they will become display terminals for a wide range of information as well as instant-access reference libraries. At the touch of a button at any time one will be able to summon onto the screen the latest weather forecasts, stockmarket reports and news reports, along with recipes, restaurant menus, shopping guides, garden tips and the advertisements that are expected to support the new service.

title: MAN IN JERSEY SHOOTS 4, THEN COMMITS SUICIDE
description: A former church organist on probation for assaulting his wife killed one person and wounded three others before shooting himself to death today, investigators said.

title: Soviet-Chinese Agenda Is Set in Peking Parley
description: Chinese and Soviet negotiators, agreeing to avoid areas of sharp disagreement, reported progress in preliminary talks and set an agenda that included discussions of the border dispute, Chinese sources said today.

title: Begin's Wife Is Said to Show Improvement in the Hospital
description: Aliza Begin, wife of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, showed a slight improvement today after being hospitalized Monday with respiratory and circulatory problems, a hospital spokesman said.

title: MAINE STIRRED UP BY SENATE CONTEST
description: The now-close contest for a Senate seat that once looked like an easy Republican gain has turned bitter, at least by the standards of Maine politics. Senator George Mitchell and his Republican foe, Representative David Emery, are swapping accusations like ''distortion'' and ''sleazy.''

title: GIBSON STAFF CHIEF IS UNABLE TO RECALL MANY ACTIONS IN '81
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's chief of staff, a key prosecution witness in the misconduct-in-office trial of the Mayor and a former City Council President, testified today that he could not recall many of his actions relating to the placing of a former City Councilman in a reputed no-show job.

title: ESPOSITO REJECTS G.O.P. BACKING FOR 7 DEMOCRATS
description: Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic Party chairman, has rejected the Republican Party's offer of an endorsement for seven Democratic candidates running for newly created seats on the State Supreme Court.

title: STAGE: PERFORMERS PAIR
description: THOUGH visual artists are increasingly involving themselves in theater, it is still unusual to find performance events within the walls of art museums. Joan Tewkesbury, the screenwriter and director, is producing two such performance pieces at the New Museum of the New School for Social Research. The plays, linked as ''Two Titled: 'Bissie at the Baths' and 'Counter Angel,' are of marginal dramatic interest, but the designs are ingenious environmental installations.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AN important control often neglected during the regular maintenance of the home heating system is the thermostat. It is the main determinant of the amount of energy consumed, turning the burner on and off. If improperly or carelessly adjusted, or if poorly situated and not working at maximum efficiency, it can waste a great deal of energy and can make the house less comfortable than it should be.

title: Suharto to Visit U.S.
description: President Suharto left today for three weeks of state visits to the United States, Spain, South Korea and Japan. He is to fly to the United States on Sunday for a five-day stay.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: The latest periods were restated to reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: INDONESIA ACCUSED OF ABUSES IN TIMOR
description: A bipartisan group of senators and representatives, citing reports of widespread hunger and human rights abuses in East Timor, has urged the Indonesian Government to allow international relief agencies into the area.

title: GETTING A HOME OFFICE TO WORK
description: AFTER discovering how expensive rented office space is, Beverly E lam, a publicist, seated above, called the designer Lisa Rose, s tanding, of Aubergine Interiors to discuss a home office in her r ental apartment. Miss Elam had seen an apartment decorated by Miss R ose in a newspaper, liked her style and called her.

title: 118 Die in Epidemic in India
description: At least 118 people have died in an encephalitis epidemic in West Bengal State. The deaths occurred in the Burdawn, Birbhum, Bankura and Midnapore Districts, according to West Bengal's Minister of State for Public Health, Ramnarayan Goswami.

title: NO LINK TO CHICAGO FOUND IN CALIFORNIA CASE
description: Investigators said today that the timing in the case of a man here who was hospitalized after taking Tylenol capsules containing strychnine appeared to rule out the possibility that someone had mimicked the fatal cyanide contamination of the drug in Chicago.

title: People
description: * Paul D. Kurnit has joined Griffin Bacal as an executive vice president.

title: Mitterrand in Burundi; Next Stop Is Zaire
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived in this tiny landlocked country today on the first leg of a seven-day official visit to French-speaking countries in central Africa.

title: ISRAELI PARATROOPS ACCUSE SHARON OF SLANDER AND DEMAND APOLOGY
description: Veterans in an elite reserve paratroop brigade signed a petition today that accused Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of slandering them and that demanded a public apology.

title: Amway v. Canada
description: Canadian customs officials and the Amway Corporation are trying to settle $118 million in lawsuits out of court, a spokesman for the Canadian customs department said. The four lawsuits, filed in Canadian federal court in Toronto in 1980, accuse Amway and its Canadian subsidiary of providing false invoices to cover more than 1,700 shipments of products into Canada between Jan. 6, 1977, and Jan. 28, 1980. Canada is seeking $118 million in duties, taxes and penalties.

title: REAGAN CRITIC CALLED PARTY MAVERICK
description: The Republican candidate who was told to ''shut up'' by an exasperated President Reagan in a confrontation in the White House today is a political maverick whose campaign slogan is ''Looks Like Lenin, Talks Like Lincoln.''

title: Bank Nationalization
description: The legislature has approved a constitutional amendment to permit the nationalization of Mexican banks that was decreed last month.

title: ANGELS MOVE TO 2-0 LEAD IN PLAYOFF
description: Bruce Kison, the pitcher the Yankees didn't want in exchange for Tommy John, followed John's good pitching performance with an even better one tonight in the second game of the American League championship series.

title: CONCERT: MASS OPENS THE BACH FESTIVAL
description: THERE are no successful performances of Bach's Mass in B minor, only failures more or less honorable. That is overstating the case, certainly, but musicians who have wrestled with this mighty score for a good part of their careers will understand the sense in which the overstatement is meant. They also know they need not apologize for falling short of success on this exalted plane.

title: 'WE SIMPLY CANNOT REMAIN A NATION WITHOUT BORDERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: World Press Review Raising Ad Rates 15%
description: World Press Review, a monthly magazine that monitors what the media are saying the world over, is raising its circulation base to 150,000 from 137,500 with the January issue.

title: PRINCETON ELECTRONIC PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Dan River Sues Over Icahn Stake
description: Dan River Inc. said it had filed suit in United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the New York financier Carl C. Icahn and other private investors who are seeking to purchase Dan River stock. The action charges that Mr. Icahn and his investor group violated various Federal and state laws in the process of increasing its stake in Dan River to about 15 percent.

title: ROYSTER IS DREAM COME TURE
description: ST. LOUIS J oe Torre, wishing his tribe's lead to increase, awoke one morning from a deep dream of peace. ''Jerry Royster,'' said the Atlanta Braves' manager, opening his orbs. ''Jerry Royster.''

title: GARDENING
description: Leaf Sweep Check weekly behind and between rooftop planters and sweep up the latest fallen leaves. Hidden in corners, they provide a home for overwintering insect pests and diseases, and they clog drains, causing autumn and winter flooding. Copy nature's recycling system and pile as many leaves as possible onto the containers, covering with a bit of soil to keep them in place. In yards, too, leaves should be turned under where there is no grass or ground cover - even ailanthus trees are finally useful.

title: REGGAE: BOB MARLEY'S WIDOW, RITA, AT RITZ
description: SINCE the death in 1980 of Bob Marley, reggae's standard-bearer, Jamaican singers galore have tried to claim his mantle and his international following. Most of them are more subtle about it than his widow, Rita Marley.

title: A-10 ATTACK PLANE REMAINS IN DOUBT
description: In the eyes of Senator Barry Goldwater, it was a classic example of the backroom political deal, but the effort to continue production of the A-10 attack plane is turning out to be more complicated than that.

title: No Headline
description: Blues Beat Red Wings, 2-1, in Opener

title: The Affluent Engineers
description: New York's operating engineers, who run cranes, bulldozers and other heavy construction machinery, ended a three-month strike this week, making it possible for thousands of other building tradesmen to return to work as well.

title: Rochester Gets 1557 Book
description: The University of Rochester library has just acquired its two millionth book since the founding of the college in 1850. It is a rare 1557 folio edition of ''The Workes of Sir Thomas More Knyght, Sometime Lorde Chauncellour of England, Wrytten by Him in the Englysh Tongue.'' It is considered one of the most significant books in the English Renaissance, according to Prof. Kenneth Jay Wilson of Rochester, an authority on More's work.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Del Electronics Corp., Mount Vernon, N.Y., has named Dominick R. Congrusti president and general manger.

title: AMTRAK TO UPGRADE FOOD AND DINING SERVICE
description: Among the Amtrak passengers who find fault with the railroad's cuisine is W. Graham Claytor Jr., president of the national passenger railroad.

title: Silas Leaves Camp
description: Saying that he is angry because club officials refuse to believe he is injured, James Silas, captain of the Cleveland Cavaliers, left the team's training camp in Kirtland, Ohio, yesterday. Silas has not played since Saturday, when, he contends, he injured his back.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: HARRIMAN DONATES $1 MILLION FOR SOVIET STUDY
description: Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman has donated $1 million to the Russian Institute of Columbia University as part of a broad effort to revive American studies of the Soviet Union, which some experts fear have declined to their lowest level since World War II.

title: BROCK HOTEL ENTERPRISE NAMES NO. 2 OFFICER
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation operates 53 Holiday Inns plus other hotel properties and a successful new pizza chain that includes electronic games and entertainment by animated life-size animal characters.

title: Decision File; Squeezing the Line On Lemonade
description: When is lemonade lemonade? The Food and Drug Administration is not sure. ''We don't know how much lemon juice it takes to make lemonade,'' said Howard N. Pippin, spokesman for the agency. ''We have no standard.''

title: SEARCH EXTENDED TO BEIRUT SUBURBS
description: Soldiers of the Lebanese Army extended their sweep of West Beirut today to the southern suburbs, continuing a search for hidden arms and a roundup of people for questioning.

title: Government Workers to Face 24% Rise in Health Insurance
description: The Federal Government's 9.2 million employees and retired employees face increases averaging 24 percent next year in health insurance premiums, the Office of Personnel Management said Tuesday.

title: Flood Aid for Guatemala
description: The State Department said today that the United States had given Guatemala $289,000 in flood relief assistance. Five days of heavy rain in mid-September caused widespread damage.

title: A BULB PLANTING FOR CENTRAL PARK
description: Volunteers will be planting 23,000 bulbs - daffodils, hyacinths, crocuses, scilla and allium - throughout Central Park on Oct. 17 from 10:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M.

title: Mortgage Rate Dip Seen
description: Richard Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said mortgage rates could fall to 12 percent within several months.

title: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
THE CASE OF THE MISSING SPY BENEFITS
description: In the sometimes curious ways of Washington, a still-pending case involving espionage and intrigue has come to light in the form of an employment grievance.

title: A Hospital Dispute
description: Norwood Hospital in Boston has denied having anything to do with an incident that has provoked a multimillion-dollar damage suit by Greg Taylor, a former running back with the New England Patriots. Taylor, who was cut by the team in mid-September after the opening game against the Baltimore Colts, contends that he suffered a leg fracture in the game and that the Patriots and the hospital did not tell him the extent of his injury.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Harvester Unit
description: The finance subsidiary of International Harvester Australia Ltd. has joined its parent in receivership after creditor banks failed to agree to a new debt restructuring, a company spokesman said. Receivers were appointed for the truck and farm equipment maker on Oct.1 because of its inability to overcome a serious liquidity problem. The group owes about $300 million (Australian) to 30 merchant and retail banks and was operating under a system of agreement with its lenders when the latest problems arose.

title: Frank Spector, 87, a Leader In Communist Party on Coast
description: Frank Spector, a longtime Communist Party leader in California who was once ordered deported to the Soviet Union, has died of cancer at the age of 87, according to a friend.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AT BELZBERG REALTY UNIT
description: Bruce C. Juell, president and chief executive officer of First City Properties Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., a real estate development company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, has resigned after seven months in the job.

title: LIBYAN SEEKS EXPULSION OF ISRAEL FROM U.N.
description: Abdulati Obeidi, Libya's Foreign Minister, called on the United Nations today to expel Israel, which he referred to only as ''the Zionist entity,'' on the ground that it was not a peaceloving nation.

title: HARDWOODS FOUND RICH IN CREOSOTE
description: Conscientious homeowners have long fretted about firewood. Because they believed hard, dry woods would reduce the creosote hazard in their flues, they avoided the less expensive and more plentiful soft and green woods in wood stoves and fireplaces.

title: HOW DECORATOR FEE IS DETERMINED
description: SINCE most designers and decorators make their profit on the discounts to the trade on merchandise sold to the client, those who take on small jobs generally charge an initial consultation fee. The average is $500 and represents 10 hours' design time at $50 an hour.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
AN AMERICAN CLASSIC
description: Once in a great while a book takes us unawares. Reading it, we know we have been touched by truth. Its vision may be of another time or place, but we sense the feelings as our own. We feel the power of authenticity.

title: Alice Baber, 54, Artist Of Lyrical Abstractions
description: Alice Baber, a painter known for her lyrically abstract work, died of cancer Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived in New York and Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: IN MILAN, SOME EASY SPRING SALES
description: Their names do not appear on the programs, and they rarely march down the runway, but some of the best-known designers in Italy and France are responsible for collections other than the ones that brought them success. Their identities are no closely guarded secret, however. Gossip about who is doing what line is one of the conversational staples of people who just happen to sit next to each other as the spring and summer openings here go into the home stretch. Since the shows frequently run late, there is plenty of time for speculation.

title: ISRAEL'S LEBANESE ALLY FAVORS TREATY
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the leader of a pro-Israeli Lebanese militia organization controlling southern Lebanon, said today that any negotiated plan for the withdrawal of foreign forces must include continued links between Lebanon and Israel.

title: 4 Indicted in Bombing Death Of Inmate Awaiting Execution
description: An inmate on death row was killed in his cell by a homemade radio-bomb planted by men hired by the stepson of his two murder victims, the authorities said today.

title: Court Reverses Self, Allows Reactor Site Work to Go On
description: A Federal appeals court, reversing its own ruling of Monday, said today that construction could resume on the Clinch River breeder reactor.

title: HINCKLEY SEEKS AID OF A.C.L.U. ON HOSPITAL RULES
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., complaining of restrictions placed by St. Elizabeths Hospital on his contacts with reporters, has asked the American Civil Liberties Union for ''legal assistance,'' the head of the A.C.L.U. office here said this evening.

title: 1787: FRANKLIN'S SILENT DEFEAT ON PRAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Stark Elected Director By Columbia Pictures
description: Ray Stark, the Columbia producer whose latest film is ''Annie,'' has been elected a director of Columbia Pictures Industries. His election comes as a surprise because there have been reports that Mr. Stark, whose contract with Columbia is up next December, has recently been dissatisfied and might shift to another studio.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1982
description: International Washington cautioned Lebanon not to let its effort to reestablish order in Beirut lead to violations of human rights. A State Department spokesman said the United States, France and Italy, whose peacekeepers are in Beirut, had expressed concern that the Lebanese Army's roundup of suspected criminials and undocumented residents not trample on civil liberties. (Page A1, Column 1.) Lebanese Army troops extended their sweep of West Beirut to the southern suburbs, continuing a search for hidden weapons and a roundup of people for questioning. (A11:1.)

title: WARSAW'S NEXT ERASURES
description: One of the most dangerous aspects of the offensive that Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski is expected to launch Saturday against Solidarity is a cosmetic reform intended for both Polish and Western consumption. Government sources close to General Jaruzelski say that he plans to replace the independent Solidarity with old-style official unions answerable to the regime and dependent on its support. What is most troubling is that although this ''reform'' will obviously be an empty, diversionary tactic, it may well succeed in muting foreign criticism and further crippling Polish resistance.

title: U.N. DEBATE IS SOUGHT ON THE ISSUE OF CYPRUS
description: Citing the eight-year occupation of a third of his country by Turkish troops, the President of Cyprus called on the United Nations today to schedule a new debate on the ''Cyprus question.''

title: BOLD BOLIVIAN IN TOP SPOT
description: When Hernan Siles Zuazo, the Presidentelect of Bolivia, was last President in the 1950's, he confronted a crippling miners' strike by visiting the most belligerent mine.

title: UNSUPPORTABLE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Shcharansky's Wife Pleading For Help From U.N. Agency
description: The wife of the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky asked the United Nations Center for Human Rights today to seek her husband's release from prison.

title: Bridge: Americans in Top 4 Places Entering the Open Finals
description: A group of American experts surged to the top of the standings when the semifinals of the World Open Pair Championship concluded here this afternoon.

title: Runaway Wheel Kills A Motorist in Queens
description: An 18-year-old motorist was killed in a freak accident on the Long Island Expressway yesterday when the wheel of an oncoming truck came off, jumped a center divider and smashed through his windshield, the police reported.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIAL OPENS FOR 3 IN JUDGE'S KILLING
description: Opening statements were made today in the trial of three defendants charged in the first assassination of a Federal judge in this century.

title: RATES PLUNGE IN LIVELY RALLY
description: In a dramatic credit market rally, interest rates tumbled sharply yesterday while prices of Government notes and bonds soared in response to reports that the Federal Reserve would tolerate moneysupply growth above its previously announced targets.

title: PRESIDENT TO SIGN IMMIGRATION BILL
description: President Reagan is expected soon to approve a bill making it possible for thousands of Asian-born children of American servicemen to immigrate to the United States.

title: Economic Scene; The Cleveland Of Tomorrow
description: CLEVELAND THE motion picture ''Atlantic City'' opens with a shot of the Traymore Hotel, a huge relic of the glory days of luxury and ease by the seaside, being blasted out of existence by an implosion set off with plastic charges. Atlantic City, leaving its obsolete past behind, was entering the era of gambling casinos.

title: Chase Executive Goes To Investment Firm
description: Richard J. Higgerson, who was demoted by the Chase Manhattan Bank in a July reorganization that followed the Penn Square and Drysdale affairs, has left the bank and has joined the Securities Groups, a private investment firm.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FORSCH PITCHES 3-HITTER AS CARDS CAPTURE OPENER
description: Joe Torre got a frightening look at his pitching staff under fire tonight when the St. Louis Cardinals opened the playoff for the National League pennant by pounding the Atlanta Braves, 7-0.

title: Levi Leads by 1 On 6 Late Birdies
description: Wayne Levi birdied six of his last seven holes for an 8-under-par 64 and took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the $350,000 LaJet Golf Classic.

title: Giants Set Ticket Plans
description: The Giants have advised seasonticket holders that if any games are canceled instead of merely delayed because of the player strike, refunds will be mailed automatically to subscribers of record. Tickets for games rescheduled, the team said, will be honored as if the games were played on the original dates.

title: Ewing's Priorities
description: Some National Basketball Association clubs have been looking forward to acquiring Pat Ewing before he is graduated, but he does not even want to talk about the pros until his senior year. ''People might seem shocked,'' said Ewing, the 7-foot sophomore center at Georgetown, in an interview with The Washington Post.

title: RIGHTING JUSTICE'S SCALES
description: It came too late for any personal satisfaction for the man involved, and hardly anyone noticed anyway because of the last-minute rush to complete more pressing business.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results for the latest qr and 6 mos include results of Continental Divide Distributors Inc acquired in Sept 1981, Continental contributed 73.5 percent of Mortronics revs and 72 percent of its net income for the latest 6 mos

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THIS week has been a partygoer's dream - or nightmare, depending on h ow one views the prospect of running to three or four parties a n ight. On Tuesday, for example, there were cocktails at Luchow's f ollowed by a benefit preview of ''Cats''; a dinner at the W aldorf-Astoria honoring John L. Tishman; the Peter Stuyvesant Ball a t the Vista International Hotel; a ''Come to the Cabaret'' party at t he Plaza for the Musicians Emergency Fund, and a fifth anniversary c elebration for the ''I Love New York'' campaign at Club A.

title: BRIEFING
description: U.S.I.A. on the Move

title: L.I.U. WINNING WITH A FOREIGN TOUCH
description: Long Island University's soccer team, a National Collegiate Athletic Association quarterfinalist last year, is ranked third in the nation this year. It has played 10 games and won them all. Its coach, Arnold Ramirez Jr., is happy about everything ''except that same old stuff about being a foreign team.''

title: No Headline
description: Weekly Jobless Claims Again Near 700,000

title: MEXICO'S PRESIDENT-ELECT TO MEET WITH REAGAN IN SAN DIEGO TODAY
description: Mexico's incoming President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, is expected to suggest new ways for the United States to help alleviate this country's acute economic crisis when he meets President Reagan in San Diego on Friday.

title: No Headline
Sears Names Head Of Trading Unit
description: Roderick M. Hills was named chairman yesterday of Sears World Trade Inc., a recently formed trading-company subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Big Auto Union Local Adds to 'No' Vote on Pact
description: A 2,800-member United Automobile Workers local today added to the roar of dissent on the proposed contract with Chrysler.

title: THE TRIBECA SCENE: ARCHITECTURE, RESTAURANTS AND BARGAIN HUNTING
description: THE first thing that should be said about TriBeCa is that it is not SoHo. The two neighborhoods, which abut each other at Canal Street, can seem similar - they both contain residential lofts housed in some of the city's finest 19th-century industrial and commercial architecture; they have fashionable restaurants and, superficially at least, similar populations to fill them, and they both have a kind of grittiness to them that makes clear that, however strong the signs of prosperity, these places are not the Upper East Side.

title: Steinbrenner Denial
description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, denied in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday that he illegally refused a summons to testify about a $500,000 default. Testimony showed that Steinbrenner settled a possible assault claim by paying $500 to Marcel Aronheim, who said he had put the summons under Steinbrenner's arm last May 4 at Yankee Stadium only to be thrown out of the ball park.

title: Warden Is Stabbed to Death By Prisoners in Louisiana Cell
description: A warden was fatally stabbed after he opened the cell of three prisoners to give them ice cream, the authorities said today.

title: India and Bangladesh Extend Agreement on Ganges River
description: India and Bangladesh signed a memorandum of understanding today for a two-year extension of an interim agreement on using water from the Ganges River.

title: Double Knockdown
description: Two boxers knocked each other down at the same time in the first round of a scheduled four-round bout in Copenhagen last night. Gert Bo Jacobsen, a Danish light-welterweight, and Chris McCallum, a Scot, hit each other in the same split-second.

title: PRIME CUT HALF-POINT, TO 13%
description: The nation's major banks dropped the prime lending rate to 13 percent from 13 1/2 percent yesterday, a reaction to the continuing decline in the cost of money to the banks.

title: AREAS AS VAST AS WHOLE STATES NOW CHANGE HANDS IN ALASKA
description: Land transactions of a size that staggers the imagination are going on here between the state of Alaska and various Alaskan native corporations on one side and the Bureau of Land Management of the Department of Interior on the other.

title: Jail Is Jail
description: Last spring, with a burst of publicity that drowned out the misgivings even of his own aides, Mayor Koch announced a $3 million plan to set up work camps on Harts and Rikers Islands for the shortterm incarceration of offenders against the ''quality of life.''

title: ISLANDERS DOWN FLAMES FOR FIRST VICTORY
description: The New York Islanders defeated the Calgary Flames tonight, 5-4, in a wide-open game that was characterized by careless play on both sides.

title: FALSE 'LESSON OF REPRESENTATIVE LEE'
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE LINE ON THE OVERSEAS ACTION
description: Some of the most popular spy reading in town isn't by John LeCarre or Ken Follett. It's published by the Central Intelligence Agency and is available to anyone who wants it.

title: GEORGE BURNS, SADAT AND THE ANDES
description: IN ''Two of a Kind,'' the television movie on CBS-TV, Channel 2, tomorrow night at 9, a 21-year-old retarded man sets out to free his 81-year-old grandfather from the clutches of depression. This is clearly uplift drama, a popular television commodity, and a happy ending is assured even without a Dory Previn song entitled ''We'll Win This World.''

title: MUSIC: MAXIM SHOSTAKOVICH DEBUT
description: MAXIM SHOSTAKOVICH asked the United States Government for political asylum in April 1981, and last night he made his New York Philharmonic debut at Avery Fisher Hall. Fittingly and perhaps inevitably, the music he conducted was that of his father. Less predictably, the program consisted of two of Shostakovich's greatest, most politically troubled and, for a long time, neglected scores.

title: ENOUGH IS ENOUGH
description: It was McCarthyism, it was low-road politics, it was disinformation - all delivered in the familiar aw-shucks style. And when President Reagan charged that ''some who want the weakening of America'' were ''manipulating honest people and sincere people'' in the nuclear freeze movement, actually it was he who tried to manipulate honest and sincere Americans.

title: Trapper's Defense Rests In Idaho Murder Trial
description: Defense lawyers in the murder trial of Claude L. Dallas Jr. rested their case today as a Nevada search team began digging up what are suspected to be remains of one of the two game wardens he admitted killing.

title: FANS FROM HINTERLANDS ROOT FOR THE BRAVES AS THE HOME TEAM
description: Two or three decades ago, Southern boys from 8 to 80 were united in their belief that Yankees were powerful bad except in the summertime, when the likes of DiMaggio and Whitey Ford and others in pinstripe flannels made them a mid-century radio version of ''America's team.''

title: FROM BAVARIA, STRAUSS LOOKS TO BONN ROLE
description: For the last few weeks, Franz Josef Strauss, the Premier of Bavaria, has been touring the state to remind his people that legislative elections are being held Sunday and that he and his party would like to win by an even bigger margin than in 1978.

title: Antiwar Films Open Independent Festival
description: A triple feature of films on war-related subjects begins a monthlong New York Independent Film Festival today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, 52 West Eighth Street. The festival includes 36 films and runs through Nov. 4.

title: REAGAN NAMES PANEL TO ASSIST IN M.T.A. TALKS
description: President Reagan has appointed an emergency panel to help accelerate the pace of negotiations between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and 4,500 Conrail employees.

title: U.S. AGENCY RELAXES RULES ON PASSENGERS BUMPED BY AIRLINES
description: Airline passengers bumped from a flight will no longer receive financial compensation if the delay in reaching their destination is less than an hour, the Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today.

title: G.O.P. OUTSPENDS DEMOCRATS BY 5-1
