description: The national Republican Party outspent the national Democratic Party by more than 5-to-1 in the first 18 months of the current election campaign, the Federal Election Commission reported today.

title: WARSAW IS BRACING FOR NEW PROTESTS
description: On the eve of a parliamentary session that is expected to outlaw the independent Solidarity union, the Polish Government has been seizing opposition activists and bracing itself for any flurry of demonstrations.

title: FINANCIAL MARKETS CLIMB, WITH STOCKS AT RECORD VOLUME
description: The financial markets rallied dramatically yesterday, fueled by hopes that interest rates would continue to decline.Stock market volume surged to a record level of 147.1 million shares and prices rose sharply. In the credit markets, interest rates tumbled and prices of Government notes and bonds soared. The dollar plummeted, while prices of gold and silver climbed.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM'-OLD DISCRIMINATIONISM
description: If Aid to Families with Dependent Children and 35 more Federal welfare and local aid programs are turned over to the states, as proposed under the Reagan Administration's ''new federalism'' plan, civil rights protections will be set back 18 years.

title: Ex-President Ford Criticizes Ottinger
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford, campaigning today for Assemblyman Jon S. Fossel in his Congressional race against Representative Richard L. Ottinger, said that Mr. Ottinger's voting record showed he was a ''big spender and irresponsible'' fiscally.

title: WARNER IN MADISON FUND BID
description: Warner Communications Inc., a media conglomerate, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Madison Fund Inc., a New York-based investment managment company.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEDICARE PAYMENT PROPOSAL BY U.S. HAILED AND ATTACKED
description: The Federal proposal for a new system of Medicare payments to hospitals drew reactions yesterday that ranged from enthusiasm to skepticism in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: SIDNEY Z. VINCENT
description: Sidney Z. Vincent, executive director emeritus of the Cleveland Jewish Community Federation and former president of the Conference of Jewish Communal Service, died Saturday at his home in Cleveland.

title: Illegal Trip Reported
description: Wichita State, which has been found guilty of violating National Collegiate Athletic Association rules six times, more than any other member, acknowledged that the N.C.A.A. was again looking into the school's recruiting. The athletic director, Ted Bredehoft, said the inquiry resulted from Wichita State's notification to the N.C.A.A. on Sept. 10 that there had been a new violation, but he gave no details.

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The company corrected its revs figures from yesterday's editions

title: 'Q,' MAYHEM AND HORROR
description: A FEW words - only a very few - about ''Q,'' a horror film opening today at the Rivoli and other theaters: It's about a giant, dragonlike creature that flays or beheads its victims and that has laid an egg. It's also about a good-for-nothing (Michael Moriarty) who finds the egg and decides to use it to his own advantage.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ANGELS EXCEL AGAIN WITH SQUEEZE PLAY
description: Jet pilots and astronauts call it the ''Go/No Go'' spot. It's the point of no return when the aircraft must be committed to lift off; there's no turning back.

title: THE AMERICAN TILT IN TALKS ON NAMIBIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Election Aide Pleads Guilty
description: Michael Rupenthal, an accountant with the Federal Election Commission, pleaded guilty today to a charge of embezzling more than $500,000 of the commission's money this year, the United States attorney handling the case said. Mr. Rupenthal, 35 years old, could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Raulston Schoolfield, Impeached Judge, Dies
description: Judge Raulston Schoolfield, removed from the criminal bench on charges of bribery and extorting campaign help from racketeers but later elected as a lesser jurist, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: LEBANESE ARMY SEARCHES FOR 3D DAY
description: For the third day, Lebanese Army units sealed off neighborhoods in predominantly Moslem West Beirut today and carried out house-to-house searches for arms caches and individuals without proper identification papers.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Caterpillar Plans 2,000 Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it would lay off 2,000 nonunion employees because of a strike by the United Automobile Workers union. The company said the layoffs of technical and clerical employees had resulted from a lack of work linked to the strike, which began Oct.1.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LOUIS E. MENZE
description: Louis E. Menze, who coached Iowa State University to its only four conference basketball championships, died at his home Wednesday.

title: N.F.L. FOOTBALL: OWNERS' FOUL PLAY...
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe-U.S. Steel Accord Expected
description: The United States and Western Europe are close to settling their 10-month trade dispute over steel, industry and government sources reported today.

title: A JOBLESS RATE OF 3.5% MAKES STAMFORD AN ECONOMIC OASIS
description: ''A gold rush is what it is,'' Fred Caporizzo said as he took a break from his job as an electrician at a six-story office building rising here. ''Five years ago, we had nothing to do. Now anyone who wants a job can have one.''

title: PAROLE DENIED TO 34 IN BUNGLED SEYCHELLES COUP
description: Parole was denied today to 34 mercenaries convicted of commandeering an Air India jetliner last November to escape the unsuccessful coup in the Seychelles, according to the South African Press Association.

title: SLIDE HAMPTON'S TROMBONE WORLD
description: THE glories of the trombone are being extolled and demonstrated this weekend at Seventh Avenue South by Slide Hampton, a left-handed trombonist, who is leading a group called the World of Trombones, an ensemble of nine trombones backed by a four-man rhythm section.

title: THE VOICES THAT BLEND INTO REAGAN'S SPEECHES
description: There are three distinct speaking roles that Ronald Reagan must play as President, and his wordsmiths insist that his great strength as the nation's patriot-orator overcomes any chronic shortcomings of the two other roles. These, of course, are the briefing-crammed President who can be a faltering target at news conferences, and the extemporaneous President who can ramble noteless and incautious at political gatherings as aides hold their breath.

title: Track Reopened After Crash
description: A section of Southern Railway's line was reopened to traffic today, one day after the Amtrak Crescent passenger train hit an empty log truck and derailed, injuring 16 persons. The train, once known as the Southern Crescent, runs from New York to New Orleans and back.

title: Sam Israel Jr., a Leader In Coffee Trading, Dies
description: Sam Israel Jr., a coffee importer and vice chairman of ACLI International, a commodity trading company, died Tuesday in New Orleans after a long illness. He was 72 years and lived in New Orleans all his life.

title: Braves Set to Call on Niekro Tonight
description: Phil Niekro may start the second game of the National League playoffs for Atlanta Friday despite having only one day's rest from his last start, and with a swelling above the thumb of his right hand.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Satellite Company has arranged a $350 million loan through a syndicate of 12 banks led by the Bank of America.

title: 24 CHILDREN OF AMERICAN FATHERS, HAPPY BUT TEARFUL, LEAVE VIETNAM
description: Twenty-four children of American fathers and Vietnamese mothers flew out of this city's Tan Son Nhut Airport today after American officials agreed to a lastminute Vietnamese demand that two of the children be accompanied by their Vietnamese half-brothers and sisters. The departure was the second of its kind in little over a week.

title: Friday; THE NEW SWINGLES
description: Using scat syllables and sounding at times more like instruments than human voices, the Swingle Singers, formed in the 1960's, used to focus on Baroque music. But the New Swingle Singers perform everything from Bach and Mozart to Gilbert and Sullivan and John Lennon and Paul McCartney. The vocal octet, which includes its founder, Ward Swingle, will be at the Top of the Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, tonight through next Friday. Peformances are at 8 and 10 tonight and tomorrow; 3 and 8 P.M., Sunday, and 8 P.M., Tuesday through Thursday. Tickets are $12.50 tonight and tomorrow; $10 other times. Information: 982-9292 or 473-7270. ART COMES TO THE GARDEN

title: ROUNDUP OF THE NEW PLACES TO DINE
description: Where there are co-ops, croissants are not far behind. Inevitably, when warehouses and factories are turned into luxury apartments, souvlaki stands and the corner steam-table cafeteria no longer suffice.

title: WHEN NEW STARS STEP IN
description: WHEN the curtain rose on the dancing orphans of ''Annie'' on Wednesday, it marked the debut of the show's seventh Miss Hannigan, the mean matron of the orphanage who spends most of her waking hours trying to squelch her irrepressible charges. The new Miss Hannigan is hardly a novice, to be sure. She is June Havoc, the stage and screen veteran, who headlined as ''Dainty June, the Darling of Vaudeville'' at the age of 7 and has spent so many years in show business she refuses to count them anymore.

title: PANEL APPROVES PARTIAL REMOVAL OF A PARK GROVE
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved a Parks Department project to restore the Bethesda Fountain area in Central Park, including the removal of part of a grove of pin oaks planted as a memorial to servicemen who died during World War II.

title: Consumer Debt Rise Is Small
description: American consumers took on just $66 million more in installment debt than they paid off in August, the weakest credit-spending performance since last December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Remedies for Medicare
description: After tinkering with the problem of soaring hospital costs for nearly two years, the Reagan Administration is finally aiming at serious reform. The other day, the Office of Management and Budget broached the idea of a means test for Medicare. Now Secretary Schweiker of Health and Human Services has proposed a bold restructuring of the way Medicare pays hospitals.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices rose sharply again and volume surged to a record of 147.1 million shares. The previous record, 137.3 million shares, was set Aug. 26. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.71 points, to 965.97. Economists observed that the two-day rally, unlike most bull markets, appears to be based on a belief not that the economy is recovering but that it is in such bad shape that the Federal Reserve Board will have to let interest rates decline. (Page A1.) Wall Street feels big volume may soon become routine. (D1.)

title: 'ART OF ISLAMIC BOOK,' A PRINCELY SELECTION AT ASIA SOCIETY
description: THE exhibition called ''Arts of the Islamic Book'' at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, is of the highest and most varied curiosity. How could it be otherwise when the art in question ranges in time from the late 9th to the early 19th century and in place of origin from Kairouan in Tunisia to Cordoba and Seville in southern Spain, and from there all the way across to Turkey, Iran the Arab lands and the subcontinent of India?

title: Magnavox Patent
description: The Magnavox Company has sued Activision Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., in Federal court, charging that it made microprocessor-based television game consoles that infringe on a patent licensed to Magnavox. Magnavox brought two similar actions in 1974 and more recently against Mattel Inc., and the judges in the cases ruled that the patent had been infringed.

title: THEATER: LLOYD WEBBER'S 'CATS'
description: THERE'S a reason why ''Cats,'' the British musical which opened at the Winter Garden last night, is likely to lurk around Broadway for a long time - and it may not be the one you expect.

title: NOVEL TRIBUTE TO DUTCH FOUNDERS
description: It all began at a meeting of the Jane Street Block Association. A handful of residents of Jane Street, who make up a tight-knit community, were planning their third street festival, this one with a Nieuw Amsterdam theme.

title: BELMONT TO HOLD RICH CARD
description: Seven older horses and four 3-year-olds, including a filly, were entered yesterday for the $500,000-added Jockey Club Gold Cup tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: U.S. Denies Accusation In Draft Resister Cases
description: The Justice Department denied today that the Government was prosecuting the noisest opponents of draft registration and requested a week to prepare to disprove the charges.

title: MISSILES TOO ACCURATE FOR OUR OWN GOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: MINNESOTA NEWSPAPER EDITOR QUITS IN PROTEST OVER NEW STAFF CUTS
description: The editor of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune has resigned in an angry condemnation of a new round of cuts in the newspaper's editorial and production staffs.

title: Mexico Eases Import Rules
description: Mexico has decreed that more than 300 products may be imported along the border with the United States at a preferential rate of 50 pesos to the dollar.

title: Beirut Bourse Reopens
description: The Beirut Bourse reopened today after being closed for four months because of the Israeli intervention in Lebanon. The president of the brokers association, Nabil Aoun, told a news conference that most share prices rose in today's trading by about 50 percent from the levels at the last session, on June 6. Mr. Aoun said that this was because of renewed business confidence after the end of full-scale fighting and the election of a new Lebanese president.

title: Abbott Net Up by 17.7%
description: Abbott Laboratories, the first of the nation's major pharmaceutical companies to report sales and earnings results for the third quarter, said yesterday that net income in the latest three months increased 17.7 percent, while sales advanced 13.9 percent.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Dart to Restructure Kraft Inc. in Europe
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. said yesterday that it would restructure the European operations of Kraft Inc. at a cost of $79.9 million. The cost will be charged to earnings for the recently completed third quarter.

title: NEW PACT MAY AVERT TV AND MOVIE STRIKE
description: A tentative agreement between producers and entertainment industry workers calls for a 26.2 percent pay rise over three years and could avert a threatened strike against the television and film industry.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''BLESSED EXCESS'' might be the motto for ''All Nite Soul,'' an annual event that will return to St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and East 54th Street, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Like its predecessors, the 13th ''All Nite Soul'' program will no doubt extend beyond its projected 12-hour span in order to accommodate the more than 250 jazz and gospel musicians scheduled to perform.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first time in 30 years a person has been ordered deported for fascist activities, and it won't be the last.'' - Allan A. Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Special Investigations in the Justice Department. (A1:6.)

title: Court Will Not Bar Dioxin Brochures
description: A Federal judge today denied a request by the Dow Chemical Company to halt publication and distribution by New York State of brochures and other material on the hazards of dioxin, specifically Agent Orange, a defoliant once produced by Dow.

title: Friends of Rudolf Hess Ask He Be Released From Prison
description: A full-page newspaper advertisement appealing for freedom for Rudolf Hess, Hitler's former deputy, was published today by a group led by the 89-year-old prisoner's son.

title: 3 ISSUES DOMINATE FLORIDA GOVERNOR RACE
description: A gubernatorial race is in many ways a handy primer on a state's current events, for politicians tend to restrict themselves to those issues uppermost on everyone's mind. It is Florida's distinction this election year to have as its principal issues three topics that were around long before the recession colored all political talk: crime, refugees and the environment. It costs as much to borrow money here as elsewhere in the nation, and there are not enough housing starts to even go into the matter. Unemployment is high, even though it is lower than the national average. In August, the latest figures available, Florida's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 7.7 percent, while the nation's was 9.8 percent. But in Florida, these concerns seem overridden by a nagging perception that paradise has been destroyed in some regions and is seriously threatened in others.

title: JORDAN REPORTED TO AMNESTY P.L.O.
description: King Hussein of Jordan has announced an amnesty for hundreds of Palestinians accused of committing ''crimes against state security'' in Jordan in the civil war of 1970, according to today's issue of Le Monde.

title: WHERE TO SHOP FOR SOLID VALUES MINUS THE GLITTER
description: The secret of shopping in TriBeCa is to put aside all of the ritual notions that surround Sunday outings to SoHo: those lazy $10 taxicab rides southward after coffee and croissants and the walk down West Broadway's retail row in your best suede.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CARIBBEAN FESTIVAL ON
description: The Mighty Sparrow, the Calypso singer-songwriter from Trinidad, will be a highlight of this week's opening concerts of Expressions '82, a festival that emphasizes the African heritage in the culture of the Americas.

title: PRECIOUS METALS FUTURES ADVANCE BY DAILY LIMIT
description: The prices of precious metals and Treasury debt futures soared their daily permissible limits yesterday, largely in expectation of further declines in interest rates. Many other commodities also rose because of the decline in interest rates.

title: VERMONT SENATE RACE PITS FATHER FIGURE AGAINST YOUNGER CHALLENGER
description: ''Vermonters don't like to be known as behind the times,'' said Blaine Blodgett, proprietor of the Calvis ice cream parlor in the heart of this picture-postcard town. ''So the issue is, 'Has Senator Stafford been there too long?' People don't ask, 'Has he done a good job?' They ask, 'Is he up-to-date?' ''

title: Nathaniel Rosen Recital
description: Nathaniel Rosen, the American cellist who won a gold medal in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Competition in 1978, will make his New York recital debut Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Harcourt Brace
description: William Jovanovich, chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., said the publishing company was not for sale. Responding to published reports that the Gannett Company was planning a $30-a-share offer for Harcourt, Mr. Jovanovich said, ''There is no takeover activity that we know of and none that we anticipate, nor would tolerate.'' A spokesman for Gannett, which owns newspapers and television stations, had no comment on the reports.

title: Rizzoli Creditors
description: Rizzoli Editore, Italy's largest publishing group and owner of the country's leading daily newspaper, Corriere della Sera, is likely to seek protection from its creditors under ''controlled administration,'' Rizzoli announced. It said a special shareholders meeting would be called to debate the measure. Rizzoli debts total about $209 million, of which $14 million is owed to Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Elizabethan Realism Based on 'Nickleby'

title: LONG, UPHILL ODDS FOR TYLENOL
description: It is a challenge marketing people hope they never have to face - restoring the image of a product linked in the public mind with death.

title: RANGERS LOSE NEDOMANSKY
description: Two days after signing Vaclav Nedomansky to a one-year contract, and hours after watching him score a power-play goal in New York's first game of the season, the Rangers lost him yesterday to the St. Louis Blues.

title: CENTRAL CAROLINA BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TASTY BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $780,697 for the qr and$1,029,451 for the 9 mos and loss on disposal of property of $781,266 for qr and 9 mos

title: Bloom of Dallas Gets Abbott
description: The bright-eyed Bloom Agency in Dallas has become agency for Abbott Laboratories' Murine eye drops and Murine Plus, as well as another eye product called Clear Eyes.

title: MCDONALD'S LINKED TO 47 STOMACH DISORDER CASES
description: Federal authorities disclosed today that at least 47 people in White City, Ore., and Traverse City, Mich., had developed severe stomach disorders after eating hamburgers at McDonald's franchise outlets.

title: GENERAL YDIGORAS OF GUATEMALA, BAY OF PIGS FIGURE, IS DEAD AT 86
description: Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, who was President of Guatemala when the United States Central Intelligence Agency trained Cuban exiles there for what turned out to be the unsuccessful Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in 1961, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage in a Guatemala City military hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: Angola Denies Report That MIG Was Downed
description: The Angolan Defense Ministry denied today that the South Africans had shot down a Soviet-built MIG fighter over southern Angola.

title: PHOTOS OF JEWS BEFORE WAR IN EUROPE TO BECOME BOOK
description: A project that began in secret, evading first the police and then the Nazis nearly a half-century ago - the photographing of Jewish life in Germany and Eastern Europe before it was eradicated by the Germans in World War II - is finally coming to fruition in a crowded apartment on the Upper West Side.

title: JAMES WEI
description: James Wei, a policy adviser to President Chiang Ching-kuo of Nationalist China, died here today a week after suffering a heart attack. He would have celebrated his 75th birthday next week. Mr. Wei was a former director general of the Ministry of Information and president of the Central News Agency.

title: MAKING A PLANT GROW: A HIDDEN ART ON STAGE
description: On the Lower East Side, Martin P. Robinson and Ron Taylor have been sharing the season's most bizarre theatrical role. Together, they play a houseplant.

title: Transactions BASEBALL   CHICAGO - NL -
description: Promoted Terry Barthelmas, director of stadium operations, to vice president in charge of business operations and announced that John Cox, assistant general manager, will also be traveling secretary.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Buffalo Savings Bank said it had agreed to acquire Palmetto Federal Savings and Loan Association in Palmetto, Fla., for $38 million, or $33 a share, in cash.

title: GIBSON WITNESS CONTRADICTS ANOTHER'S TESTIMONY
description: A witness in the misconduct-in-office trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today contradicted previous testimony by the Mayor's former chief of staff, Harold Hodes, that he could not recall any discussions concerning the performance of Michael A. Bontempo as chief of security at the Pequannock Watershed.

title: Hamilton Is First In Skating Event
description: Scott Hamilton, the world-champion figure skater and winner of last year's Skate America competition here, took first place today in men's compulsory figure skating.

title: Money Fund Assets Still Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped by $168 million, to $224.6 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ASSERTIONS ON CALVI DENIED BY VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II entrusted Roberto Calvi, the late chairman of the Banco Ambrosiano, with negotiating for the assumption by Opus Dei, a controversial conservative church body, of any possible Vatican debts resulting from the collapse of the Milan bank, Mr. Calvi's widow charged in an interview published today.

title: Bond Is Set at $1 Million In Refinery Bombing
description: Bond was set at $1 million today for a former Durango policeman accused of planting five bombs in a Texas refinery in a $15 million extortion plot.

title: Help for Dyslexia
description: When Carrie Rozelle's three sons were growing up, they had trouble reading about their stepfather, Pete, who is the commissioner of the National Football League. They are dyslexic - that is, their ability to read is impaired.

title: DALCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After loss of $1,976,000 from discontinued operations

title: Educator Testifies On Drinking Age
description: The president of Rutgers University testified today that drunken driving and highway deaths could not be reduced simply by raising the drinking age in New Jersey to 21 from 19.

title: Where Are the Children?
description: Nearly two million American children disappear from their homes each year - most of them just long enough to give their parents a good scare and bad dreams. But about 150,000 of them are then reported missing.

title: TWO WESTERN WORLDS OF INDOCHINA REFUGEES
description: Thu Ng Le was a teacher for 20 years before she fled Vietnam with her family in 1975. Today, she works for the Hawaii Department of Education as a liaison agent with other Vietnamese refugee families.

title: Brahms Series
description: The 150th anniversary of the birth of Johannes Brahms, which falls May 7, 1983, will be marked with a series of eight concerts by the Guarneri Quartet, the first of which will be given tonight at 8 o'clock at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart published Tuesday that listed races for the House of Repre- sentatives between candidates who opposed each other in 1980 omitted one such pairing. In Minnesota's Fourth Congressional District, Representa- tive Bill Frenzel, Republican, is op- posing Joel Saliterman, Democrat.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1982
description: International Polish activists are being detained on the eve of a parliamentary session that is expected to outlaw the independent trade union Solidarity. The Government's prize catch is Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the leader of the Silesian union and an organizer of Solidarity's fivemember underground committee. (Page A1, Column 5.) An effort to topple Somalia's leader, Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre, appears to have bogged down. But the Ethopian-backed insurgents, supplied with Soviet weapons, still hold some Somali territory, and the American-supplied forces of the pro-Western Government seem unable to dislodge them. (A1:1-3.)

title: The Wrong Pitch
description: The day before Tommy John was to pitch the California Angels to victory last Tuesday in the first game of their American League championship series, fans might have been surprised if they were watching the movie ''Hopscotch'' on the NBC-TV network.

title: VOCAL RECITAL: HAGEGARD, JUDITH BLEGEN
description: LISTENING to Judith Blegen and Hakan Hagegard sing part of Wolf's ''Das Italienisches Liederbuch'' at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night was a lesson in the nature of vocal music. These were finely modeled presentations of attitudes and sensation, mixing textures and dramatic stances, the two soloists alternating lieder, singing to each other and off each other with the sort of control and refinement that made one hardly conscious of listening to vocalization - just to the music itself.

title: Davis Cup Pairs U.S., Argentina
description: The draw for the 1983 Davis Cup tournament took place today at Roland Garros Stadium, and it gave the toughest first-round match to the United States, the 1981 champion.

title: Article 206218 -- No Title
description: The Education Department is dividing $3.3 million in student aid funds among 50 colleges and trade schools that it had penalized for having high default rates on loans to students.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 mos include a gain of $2,556,000 from the sale of stock

title: Reliance Group
description: Reliance Group Holdings, a holding company with operations in insurance, leasing and management services, said it had proposed combining with the Leasco Corporation, a computer equipment leasing business that it already owns. The proposal is contingent on the removal of a dividend restriction that was imposed under Leasco's $100 million principal amount of 11 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 1997.

title: ETHIOPIAN DRIVE AGAINST SOMALIA BOGS DOWN
description: An Ethiopian-sponsored military campaign to overthrow Somalia's leader, Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre, seems to be bogged down.

title: 'DARK CIRCLE,' LIFE NEXT TO THE ATOM
description: ''DARK CIRCLE,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center today at 6:15 P.M., is a well-made, extremely grim documentary look at what life holds for people in and around the Rocky Flats Nuclear Weapons Facility near Denver. The film is the joint effort of Judy Irving, Chris Beaver and Ruth Landy.

title: TO STOP THE KOREAN ARMS BUILDUP
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Struck in Italy
description: Bank employees and engineering workers went on strike today to press for the opening of annual wage talks, trade union sources said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani THE BOY SCOUT HANDBOOK AND OTHER OBSERVATIONS. By Paul Fussell. 284 pages. Oxford University Press. $15.95.

title: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sharon Says the U.S.  Blocks Road to Peace
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon accused the United States tonight of blocking the path to peace in Lebanon. He said the Americans did this ''for reasons of their own,'' which he did not specify.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Veronika Voss and portrayer are not alike.
description: BE careful not to confuse Rosel Zech with Veronika Voss. ''No,'' the 40-year-old actress said, cautioning against comparisons with the faded, drug-addicted movie star she portrays in the Rainer Werner Fassbinder film that opened the New York Film Festival and begins an engagement next Wednesday at the Cinema Studio, West 67th Street and Broadway - ''I am an actress; I played this part.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
CORRECTION
description: A Company News item in Business Day Tuesday incorrectly described the sale of two Saxon Industries units. If a Federal bankruptcy court approves, Saxon will sell its business products division to an investors' group headed by Bennett S. LeBow and its Chukerman division to the Schwarz Paper Company.

title: Olof Palme Sworn In; Devaluation Is Rumored
description: Olof Palme, head of the Social Democratic Party. was sworn in today as Sweden's Prime Minister amid widespread speculation that his left-wing Government would devalue the currency soon to help the country's flagging economy.

title: FRENCH STEEL TOWN TELLS ITS STORY WITH AN S O S
description: For misery, Longwy will do. In the valley, the carcass of an abandoned steel mill. On the slopes above, row houses, the color of mud. At the peak of the farthest ridge, a slag heap, a brown pyramid of waste and junk, with a sign on top that says ''S O S.''

title: HUDSON COUNTY PROSECUTOR FACES CONSPIRACY AND EXTORTION CHARGES
description: The Hudson County Prosecutor was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Newark on charges that, before he took office, he extorted more than $100,000 from two real-estate companies.

title: FROM CAUCASUS' MUSICAL MELTING POT TO TRIBECA
description: THE mountainous Caucasus region of the southern Soviet Union between the Black and the Caspian Seas has been a musical melting pot for centuries. Mongol invaders, sweeping across the barren Central Asian steppe brought their high, keening songs of horses and conquests, and more subtle and courtly musical traditions infiltrated the region from the Persian royal courts in what is now Iran.

title: AVANT-GARDE: TAPES AND SLIDES
description: sound, Mr. Kucharz evoked urban street scenes, combining photographs and paintings with appropriate, descriptive adjectives, repeated again and again in fuguelike patterns. In Mr. Kucharz's purely musical compositions, the listener was surrounded by speakers, and separate tapes were run featuring brass instruments or synthesizers, each repeating a single note or chord at selected preordained intervals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: East River Island Dedicated to U Thant

title: HIS DEPARTURE IS 5TH IN WEEK
description: Ross Sandler, Mayor Koch's special adviser on mass transit, is leaving his post at the end of the year, Mr. Sandler said yesterday. The resignation brings to five the number of changes this week involving top officials in the Koch administration. Louis A. Friedrich, Deputy Budget Director since 1978, also announced yesterday that he was leaving at the end of the month to join a private financial management and consulting concern.

title: THE DANCE: ELIOT FELD REVIVES 'EXCURSIONS'
description: ''EXCURSIONS,'' a happy little ballet Eliot Feld choreographed in 1975 to Samuel Barber's music, was revived last night at the Joyce Theater by the Feld Ballet.

title: NEW NUCLEAR VISION
description: One useful result of the widespread movement against nuclear war has been to provoke a series of new ideas in the defense establishment.

title: A RESURGENT PENN LEADS IVY LEAGUE
description: Jerry Berndt, the football coach at the University of Pennsylvania, described the long bus ride from Hanover, N.H., after his team defeated Dartmouth in its opening game three weeks ago, the first victory on the road for the Quakers since 1976.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALASKA FISHING AREA REPORTS HIGHEST INCOME
description: The Census Bureau reported today, to the amazement of Alaskan officials, that the 1,094 residents of Bristol Bay, a salmon-fishing area in southwestern Alaska, had the nation's highest per capita income in 1979.

title: FRANCE IS PLANNING NEW EMPHASIS ON EXPANSION OF NUCLEAR ARSENAL
description: The French Government said today that it had decided to build up a nuclear strike force at the expense of conventional armaments.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S.-Soviet Arms Talks Resume in Geneva
description: Full United States and Soviet delegations met in a renewed effort to slow down the arms race today with no word from either side on how they might narrow their differences.

title: N.F.L. FOOTBALL: OWNERS' FOUL PLAY...
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Chemical Co., Morris Township, N.J., has appointed Robert F. Traflet executive vice president.

title: REAGAN SAYS NEW JOBLESS FIGURES 'VERY POSSIBLY' WILL SHOW INCREASE
description: After working 29 years for the Singer Manufacturing Company, Albert Fehrenbacher found himself in an unemployment line today for the first time. ''I'm giving up voting for the rest of my life,'' he said ruefully, ''because I don't trust politicians.''

title: Still on the Run
description: Wilma Rudolph remains one of the busiest sports personalities in America. ''I must go to 50 banquets a year, and I turn down more than that,'' says the woman who captured three gold medals (100- and 200-meter dash, 400-meter relay) in the 1960 Olympic Games.

title: Two Men Surrender in Texas In Alien Smuggling Operation
description: McALLEN, Texas, Oct. 7 (AP) -Two men surrendered today in connection with an alien smuggling operation that left four Salvadorans dead Monday and eight others hospitalized, the Federal authorities said.

title: MANY SCHOOLS GOVERN LOOKS OF MAJORETTES
description: Peggy Ward, the majorette sent to the sidelines when she failed to get down to 126 pounds, is back on the football field twirling her baton. But scores of other high schools have rules restricting the weight of majorettes and cheerleaders, according to the National Federation of State High School Associations.

title: Mexico Expecting Loan
description: Mexico has told foreign bank creditors it expects to sign a letter of intent soon for a credit agreement with the International Monetary Fund, banking sources here said today.

title: Federal Marshals Kill Armed Brooklyn Man
description: A 41-year-old Brooklyn man was killed yesterday by two United States deputy marshals after he wounded one of them with submachinegun fire, authorities said.

title: LEBANESE PREMIER PRESENTS INTERIM SPECIALISTS' CABINET
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan today formed a Cabinet made up of virtually unknown specialists who are expected to serve until a government of politicians can be established.

title: GEORGE KIRBY DISCOVERS HE CAN STILL ENTERTAIN
description: The stage is dark. The only illumination in Dangerfield's comes from dulled spots of orange from shaded candles on the tables. The three-piece band is riffing, and the talk is low. Then, without introduction, the voice comes through the microphone, singing softly: On the road again, I'm so glad I'm on the road again. On the road again. Seeing faces I may never see again.

title: Icahn Dispute Over Dan River
description: The New York Stock Exchange said it was investigating the issuance this week of 1.7 million shares of a new series of preferred stock by Dan River Inc. A spokesman for the exchange said a review was routine.

title: CONIFER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Royal Shakespeare to do 'All's Well' in mid-April.
description: AMID mounting concern over the health of the theater this season, there is good news: the Royal Shakespeare Company will be on Broadway not once, but twice. The company, which will open Wednesday night in C.P. Taylor's ''Good,'' will return in mid-April with its acclaimed new production of ''All's Well That Ends Well.'' Shakespeare's difficult comedy will be staged by Trevor Nunn, the Royal Shakespeare Company's artistic director, who has moved his version of ''All's Well'' into an Edwardian setting.

title: McNamara Urges Shift In U.S. Atomic Strategy
description: Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara suggested a shift in United States military strategy today in which Atlantic alliance and Warsaw Pact nations would renounce the use of a nuclear response to an attack ''until it has been determined beyond any reasonable doubt'' that the assault was intentional.

title: BREWERS' SLUMP IS UNTIMELY
description: After he arrived home shortly before 5 o'clock this morning, Harvey Kuenn, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, thought about his team's lack of production in the first two games of the American League championship series and wondered if there was anything a manager could do.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aboriginals Protest for Land
description: About 400 aboriginals and supporters marched and chanted slogans today in a protest to draw attention to native land claims. About 200 people were arrested, charged with violating a law prohibiting protests during the Commonwealth Games. Queen Elizabeth II is in Brisbane for the sports event, which ends Saturday.

title: THEATER: MIROSLAV KRLEZA, 'IN AGONY'
description: AT least for half of its duration, ''In Agony'' justifies Miroslav Krleza's theatrical reputation as a kind of Croatian equivalent of Strindberg. In this intensely psychological marital drama, which is having its English premiere this week at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, a disastrously married couple battle each other into submission.

title: NEW WAY REPORTED TO TAKE HYDROGEN FROM WATER
description: Researchers reported yesterday that they had developed the cheapest method yet for using solar energy to extract hydrogen from water. They said the technique could ultimately lead to the use of hydrogen as a basic energy source to replace fossil fuels.

title: James V. Russo, a Producer Of Comedies and Musicals
description: James V. Russo, who was the producer-stage manager for Broadway comedies and musicals that starred Bette Davis, Joe E. Brown, and Milton Berle, died of a heart attack Monday at the Palm Springs Health Care convalescent home. He was 68 years old and had lived nearby in Palm Desert, Calif..

title: SOVIET SPY EFFORT IS RELATED BY U.S.
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union had tried to steal a top-secret radio frequency scanner used in spy planes and reconnaissance satellites, but that United States agents had foiled the effort.

title: POLICEMAN'S TESTIMONY CHALLENGED IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Defense attorneys for Kathy Boudin, a defendant in the $1.6 million Brink's murder and robbery case, charged in court today that a police officer lied on Tuesday while testifying about remarks that Miss Boudin made to a police sergeant at a roadblock in Nyack after the robbery last Oct. 20.

title: Marijuana Use Is Held As Risk in Pregnancy
description: A Boston University researcher who studied marijuana use among pregnant women said today that a woman's overall style of living during her pregnancy , rather than any single factor, appeared to be the main contributor to adverse effects in her offspring.

title: Heinz Said to Plan Zimbabwe Unit
description: A Zimbabwe Government decision to increase the price of vegetable oil has cleared the way for a $30 million investment by the H.J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh, business sources said.

title: A 'Hockey Nut' Goes a Long Way
description: The man has a proper British accent, and he sports what appears to be an old school tie. But what is he doing at a hockey game, and what is the meaning of the monogram ''LIHNC'' on the tie?

title: Benitez to Fight Hearns Dec. 3
description: It could be a cold night in Alaska when Thomas Hearns and Wilfred Benitez finally meet in a boxing ring. The two fine boxers, each of whom has lost only to Sugar Ray Leonard, were originally supposed to meet in a welterweight title fight on Harold Smith's ''This Is It'' card at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 15, 1981. Instead, they will fight for Benitez's World Boxing Council junior-middleweight title Dec. 3. Anchorage was listed as a possible site by Don King, the promoter.

title: SMOOTH SHIFT FOR A CO-OP ON EAST SIDE
description: Because many renters consider cooperative eviction plans inimical to their interests, such plans are generally thought to engender great bitterness between sponsor and tenants, often resulting in protracted legal battles.

title: SWEDEN SAYS THE SUB MAY HAVE ESCAPED
description: Swedish military officers suggested today that the submarine that had been hunted since last Friday near a naval base in the Stockholm archipelago might have escaped out into the Baltic. They suggested also that a second submarine might have been detected.

title: Union Leaders Bolster Angels
description: If the California Angels win the American League championship series - which they can do with one more victory -and then the World Series, they could foster a new philosophy in the formation of major league teams.

title: AUTHORITIES SAID TO EXAMINE POSSIBLE TYLENOL EXTORTION
description: Johnson & Johnson will face a difficult marketing task in trying to restore Tylenol's image. Page D1.

title: ART: JULIAN SCHNABEL BREAKS RULES AND PLATES
description: THE work of Julian Schnabel, the young and overhyped hero of our current Expressionist revival, is everything that painting tried not to be in the last decade or so - loud, passionate, sloppy, full of boisterous assertions and at times preposterously portentous. For all of the roots of the paintings in Abstract Expressionism, Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg, their sometimes glib, messy divagations of imagery with vaguely religious overtones, their aggressive surfaces of broken plates and other stick-out objects and their tacky use of materials - velvet, yet, as a painting surface - still came as something of a shock, overturning the rules in no uncertain terms.

title: CUOMO CLASHES WITH LEHRMAN IN FIRST DEBATE
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Lewis E. Lehrman argued virtually uninterrupted for 50 minutes yesterday in their first debate of the New York gubernatorial campaign.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split expected to be paid Oct 18

title: DEL ELECTRONIC (CO) reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Field Hockey Event in Boston
description: The second annual American Cup field-hockey tournament, featuring the top four women's national teams in the world, including the United States, opens tonight in Boston.

title: Undefeated Gregg Defeats Stinson
description: Eddie Gregg, who started boxing after he failed to make the New York Jets football team as a tight end in 1977, remained undefeated as he beat Marvin Stinson tonight at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Market Place; Money Fund Advantages
description: WILL bank liquid asset accounts draw away a substantial part of the money market funds' $200 billion asset base? A new law now ready for the President's signature would authorize such accounts for commercial banks and thrift institutions, and this prospect vexes some money funds.

title: Identity Mix-up At Belmont Park
description: The Belmont Park stewards announced yesterday that a horse who finished second in a maiden race three weeks ago had earlier been inadvertently switched with another horse and had then run under the wrong name.

title: Advertising; O.& M. Out Of Dodge Contest
description: OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL announced yesterday that it had withdrawn from the agency competition that the Chrysler Corporation is conducting for its mammoth Dodge car and truck advertising account.

title: 1 Dead, 63 Hurt in Crash
description: A U-Haul truck carrying more than 60 University of Virginia students, many of them members of a fraternity, flipped over onto a small car headed in the opposite direction, killing one person and injuring 63, the authorities said. Sixteen of the injured were admitted to Lynchburg General Hospital, and four were listed in critical condition.

title: N.F.L. REFUSES TO HAVE PRIVATE MEDIATOR
description: For the second consecutive day the National Football League Players Association yesterday made an overture to the league's Management Council in an effort to resume negotiations for a collective-bargaining agreement that would end the player strike. And for the second straight day the union was rebuffed.

title: Agents Seize Weapons In Drug Raid in Jersey
description: Federal agents arrested four people on gun and drug charges and confiscated a cache of weapons in a raid today on a home used by a narcotics ring, a Federal spokesman said.

title: 'ONE MAN'S WAR,' NORMALITY AMID ABNORMALITY
description: EDGARDO COZARINSKY has aptly described his ''One Man's War'' as ''a documentary fiction.'' He has also referred to it as a dialogue between found objects. The objects, in this case, are the remarkably calm, somewhat banal wartime journals of Ernst Junger, a German writer and army officer living in occupied Paris, and newsreel footage of Paris as it really was. Mr. Cozarinsky has woven these elements together in an eloquent and provocative way.

title: G.S.A. hunts New Deal art.
description: KAREL YASKO of the General Services Administration in Washington has been recovering and cataloguing works of art produced for New Deal arts programs for more than a decade. This year, the pace of his search for these works of the 1930's and 40's has picked up.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: How to Save Money By Spending $3 Million

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Burnham Post Filled
description: When I.W. Burnham stepped down as chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the brokerage firm, at the age of 73 last spring, he said he was ''making room for the younger men.''

title: PROMENADE CAFE GETS A LISTING IT DIDN'T WANT
description: The celebrated name appeared at the very bottom of the list, well after mention of Munch & Brunch, Tasty Donuts and the Glide Inn Bar: the Promenade Cafe at Rockefeller Center yesterday made the city's newest compendium of restaurants cited for violations of the city health code, along with establishments big, small and in between.

title: VOIGHT IN 'LOOKIN' TO GET OUT'
description: ''LOOKIN' TO GET OUT'' is about a couple of small-time New York gamblers, Alex Kovac (Jon Voight), the pretty one, and Jerry Feldman (Burt Young), his best friend, who seem to belong in an earlier era of fiction, though the time is approximately the present. They are Damon Runyon retreads updated to the Golden Age of a Las Vegas that is meant to be as gaudy and innocent as Alex and Jerry.

title: Iranian Aide Defects in Oslo
description: Parviz Khazai, Iranian charge d'affaires in Norway, said today that he had defected to protest ''the terror regime'' of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Iran. Mr. Khazai cited the execution of 20,000 people, the detention of 50,000 political prisoners and the war against Iraq, which he said had cost 200,000 lives.

title: EUPHORIC DAY FOR WALL STREET
description: From the president of the New York Stock Exchange to a trainee on the floor of the American Exchange, Wall Street workers concluded yesterday that, despite record-breaking volume, the industry breezed through what might soon become just another day at the corner of Broad and Wall.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Once More for the Taxpayer

title: No Blame Found In Fatal Car Chase
description: An investigation of a high-speed chase by Bethel police concluded that the officers were not to blame when the car they were tailing crashed, killing four Newtown teen-agers and injuring two.

title: Prints by Audubon.
description: JOHN JAMES AUDUBON'S ''Birds of America'' prints, the naturalistartist's most important work, will be auctioned by Christie's in a three-session sale tonight at 7 and tomorrow at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. at the Warwick Post Oak Hotel in Houston. The auction, the first in Houston by the New York arm of the London-based art-auction house, is of a rare, but incomplete, unbound set of 434 hand-colored firstedition prints.

title: Ex-Player Sentenced
description: Rick Foley, formerly with the Chicago Black Hawks and the Philadelphia Flyers, was sentenced to six months in jail in Brantford, Ontario, for illegal credit-card use and defrauding merchants.

title: FEAR GROWING ON HARVESTER BANKRUPTCY
description: The International Harvester Company, its markets continuing to lag badly, its losses mounting and its net worth approaching zero, is again dangerously close to bankruptcy, analysts said today.

title: Iran Says It Shelled Iraqi Oil Installations
description: Iranian artillery shelled Iraqi oil installations and docks at Chahar Cheraqh across the Shatt al Arab waterway inside Iraq on Wednesday, setting part of them on fire, the Teheran radio reported today.

title: STATE'S TOP COURT RESTRICTS IN-ABSENTIA TRIALS
description: Criminal defendants who fail to appear on the day they are told their trials are to begin may not automatically be tried in absentia, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: L.I. ANIMAL DEALER BITTEN BY KING COBRA AT AIRPORT
description: An importer of rare animals was bitten on the hand by a deadly king cobra yesterday morning as he inspected a shipment of reptiles at Kennedy International Airport.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Bonn's Chancellor Planning To Visit the U.S. Next Month
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will visit Washington in the middle of next month for talks with President Reagan, West German Government sources said today.

title: Eliot's 'Cats' Enjoys Spurt of New Interest
description: T.S. Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats,'' which has been a steady long-run hit in bookstores and libraries since the Nobel laureate wrote it in 1939, is profiting from the attention given to ''Cats,'' the musical derived from the book.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Brewers vs. California Angels, American League playoff, third game, at Milwaukee. Don Sutton tries to save the Brewers from elimination in three straight. He is opposed by Geoff Zahn. (Television - Channel 7, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 3:15 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, National League playoff, second game, at St. Louis. Because the opener was rained out Wednesday, the two teams stayed in St. Louis to play tonight before moving to Atlanta. Tommy Boggs gets the start for the Braves, John Stuper for the Cardinals. (Television - Channel 7, 8:25 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:25 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Rangers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Islanders vs. Oilers, at Edmonton, Alberta. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 97.5; 9:30 P.M.).

title: Militiaman and Prison Guard Are Killed in Attack in Ulster
description: A part-time corporal in the Ulster Defense Regiment and a prison guard were killed today in an attack near here.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 14 weeks to Sept 11
description: B-Net loss; the latest qr had 14 weeks compared to 13 weeks in yr-ago period and the latest 6 mos was for 28 weeks against 26 weeks in yr-earlier period

title: 'FAST WALKING'
description: ''FAST WALKING'' is a prison melodrama of such consistent, proud witlessness that it deserves mention though not attendance. It was written, produced and directed by James B. Harris, whose only claim to fame is as the producer of Stanley Kubrick's early films, ''The Killing,'' ''Paths of Glory'' and ''Lolita.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PITFALLS OF A FILTER FOR THE SUPREME COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MILITARY PACT IN TROUBLE IN SPAIN
description: American officials have made it clear to the Spanish Government that renegotiation of the new agreement covering United States military bases in Spain would be difficult if not impossible, according to Western European diplomats here.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 2 Scientists Get Prize That May Be an Omen

title: Town in Jersey Enforces Its Ban on Headphones
description: The ban on wearing headphones on the streets of this central New Jersey community went into effect today, and the first summons was issued, as expected, to a man who earlier said he would challenge the law as unconstitutional.

title: Roman trattoria, 14 Chinese chefs.
description: INSTANT success is a rarity anywhere, most of all perhaps in the operation of a restaurant. But that is exactly what was achieved by the owners of Trastevere, a tiny Roman trattoria that opened on East 83d Street just about two years ago and that was rated three stars in The New York Times. Now it looks as though lightning has struck twice, if not in the same place, then at least with the same menu and the same owners at their second effort, Trastevere '84 on 84th Street, just east of Lexington Avenue.

title: MORE FROM MILAN: SUITS AND SUPPLE LEATHERS
description: Treating his clothes as if they were fine jewels, Giorgio Armani has been inviting small groups of buyers and press people to see them under controlled conditions in his headquarters on the Via Durini.

title: Elephants Trampling Honduran Grass
description: It would be worse than a blunder, it would be a crime, if the regional disease of insurgency and terror is permitted to spread into Honduras. This least developed Central American republic has been mostly spared so far, probably because it lacks a wealthy oligarchy and practices no systematic repression. But it is becoming a proxy battlefield for the conflicts of its neighbors, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala. And lamentably, American help has consisted mainly of funneling weapons to Honduran generals all too eager to use them.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: There were 13 weeks in the latest qr against 14 weeks in yr-ago period and 52 weeks in the latest full yr versus 53 weeks in yr-earlier period

title: TEXAS PRISON REFORMER WINS PAROLE FIGHT AND IS FREED
description: David R. Ruiz, a twice-convicted armed robber who successfully challenged the Texas prison system in a Federal lawsuit, has won his latest battle over charges of parole violation.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: A DIARY OF ISRAEL, 1956 TO 1982
description: AM, whose photographs of the Middle East frequently are seen in this newspaper, is not a typical globetrotting photojournalist. He seems to prefer working close to home, in territory he knows best - which in his case is the land of Israel, where he has lived since 1936 and photographed since 1956. His ''Israel Diary, 1956-82,'' an exhibition at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through Nov. 7, is an intimate account by photojournalistic standards. While the pictures are not perceptibly innovative in style, they reveal a concerned and compassionate individual eye.

title: 'LISTEN, I KNOW HOW TO WIN'
description: ST. LOUIS Before the National League championship series opened here last night, Ted Turner, the owner of the Braves, was talking about taking a jet to Atlanta this morning for a business meeting and then coming back here for tonight's second game with the Cardinals.

title: B.P. Ships Said To Interest Iran
description: Iran is holding talks with a shipping subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company to buy two of the company's supertankers, shipping sources said. B.P., which has said it wants to dispose of more than a third of its tanker fleet, declined comment on the report.

title: U.S. Plans to End Restraint on Ford
description: The Justice Department tentatively agreed to terminate a 44-year-old court order limiting dealings between the Ford Motor Company and certain credit companies.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the yr-ago qr and 9 mos reflect a writedown of $9.4 million for Book Digest; results for the latest 9 mos reflect a writedown of $1.8 million for Book Digest

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS LOAN CHARGE TO BANKS TO 9 1/2%
description: In a clear signal that it expects interest rates to decline further, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that it had lowered the interest rate it charges on loans to banks to 9 1/2 percent from 10 percent.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTGEBOUW
description: Threatened by budget cuts at home but carrying on with pride abroad, the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam began a two-concert engagement last night at Carnegie Hall, the end of a two-month American tour celebrating the 200th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Netherlands.

title: SPUTNIK'S LEGACY: GLOBALISM
description: Twenty-five years ago this week, the Soviet Union put Sputnik I into orbit and, with that, the Space Age began. What is the legacy of the quarter-century?

title: The Most and the Least
description: THE LIFE OF JOHN BERRYMAN. By John Haffenden. 451 pages. Routledge and Kegan Paul. $22.50.

title: WINNER OF NOBEL PRIZE
description: Lord Noel-Baker, an Olympic athlete and Labor Party stalwart who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1959, died today at his home in London. He was 92 years old.

title: Illinois Takes Boy, 14, Who Was Kept in Attic
description: A 14-year-old boy was kept a virtual prisoner at his home here from the time he was born, taking his meals in the attic and never going to school or to the doctor, officials say.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified a floor member of the New York Stock Exchange. He is Robert Guarino of Wedbush, Noble, Cooke.

title: BAPTIST CHAPEL IN JERUSALEM DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: A Baptist chapel in Jerusalem, whose congregation had grown from 35 to 350 in recent years, was destroyed by fire early today and the police said they suspected arson.

title: ENTERPRISE ZONES ARE DESIGNATED FOR CONNECTICUT
description: Parts of six cities were designated enterprise zones today, as Connecticut began what state officials said was the first statewide experimental program of its kind in the nation to try to stimulate jobs and investment in decayed urban neighborhoods.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago per shr figures have been adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock divd paid in Mar

title: DEFECTORS DETAIL HANOI ROLE IN RUNNING CAMBODIA
description: Two Cambodian diplomats who defected to Thailand last May say that Vietnamese political advisers have been directing the Cambodian Government's day-to-day decisions.

title: REAGAN MEETS NEXT PRESIDENT OF MEXICO
description: President Reagan pledged to Presidentelect Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado of Mexico today that the United States stood ''ready to work with you'' to solve Mexico's economic difficulties. At the same time, Mr. Reagan said, the United States recognizes Mexico's right to solve its problems ''in its own way.''

title: Rockets Sign Teagle
description: The Houston Rockets signed their first-round draft choice, Terry Teagle, who set the Southwest Conference record for career scoring while with Baylor University.

title: No Headline
description: A Soviet all-star team will come to Canada and the United States to play a six-game ''Super Series'' against National Hockey League clubs from Dec. 28 to Jan. 6, the league and the N.H.L. Players Association announced today.

title: Futures Prices Diverge For Gold and Silver
description: Gold and silver futures prices moved in opposite directions yesterday after both metals had soared to their daily permissible limits the day before. The unusual divergence was attributed largely to technical factors caused by Thursday's advances, brokers said.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. ''Shut up.'' Mr. Reagan made the remark at a White House rally for Republican candidates after Mr. Arnold heckled him and accused him of abandoning conservative principles.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Yr to July 31
The New York Times/John Sotomayor
description: Youngsters Join Succoth Celebration Henshie Kaplan, 4 years old, held willow branches, and Naomi Levitin, 3, cradled a prayer book at a gathering yesterday at the headquarters of the Lubavitch, 770 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. They were taking part in the eight-day Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, which ends today.

title: EX-HOSTAGE LOSES IRAN SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court here ruled today that lawsuits by former hostages against Iran must be dismissed under President Carter's hostage release agreement, but it left open the possibility that the hostages could sue the United States.

title: A DAY OF POLITICAL FENCE-MENDING IN RACES IN 2 STATES
description: Vice President Bush today publicly made peace with Senator Lowell P. Weicker, Jr., endorsing Mr. Weicker's re-election bid and joking about the aborted effort of his older brother, Prescott Bush Jr., to deny Mr. Weicker renomination.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Mixed Verdict In Ordinary Prose

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 12
GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRESIDENT SAYS HE AND DEMOCRATS SHARE BLAME FOR UNEMPLOYMENT
description: President Reagan, conceding that the increase in unemployment last month to 10.1 percent was ''bad news,'' said today that he would be willing to accept responsibility for the rise in unemployment since he took office if Democrats accepted responsibility for the unemployment that existed before then.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: KEY TEAMSTER LEADER IS CONVICTED OF LABOR RACKETEERING BY L.I. JURY
description: John A. Cody, the head of a key teamsters local in the metropolitan New York area, was convicted today of Federal charges of labor racketeering and tax evasion.

title: Guilty Plea Entered In Reagan Home Fraud
description: A Costa Mesa businessman pleaded guilty Thursday to a charge that he falisfied financial papers for a loan to buy President Reagan's former Pacific Palisades home. Federal District Judge Malcolm Lucas set sentencing for Nov. 22 for the businessman, William C. Ogle.

title: CARDS-BRAVES RAINED OUT FOR SECOND TIME
description: For the second time in three days, the National League playoff was rained out tonight, raising the possibility that the start of the World Series also might be delayed next week.

title: PRETORIA THREATENS TO EXTEND CURBS ON BLACKS' MOVEMENTS
description: In what was hailed at the time as a landmark decision, South Africa's highest court ruled two years ago that the authorities who regulate the movement of blacks could not prevent a woman from living with her husband if he had a right of permanent residence in an urban area.

title: GUATEMALAN RAIDS BRING FEAR TO MEXICAN BORDER
description: In its drive against leftist guerrilla groups, Guatemala's Army is making regular incursions into Mexico, causing terror among the 30,000 Guatemalan refugees camped near the border and posing an increasingly difficult problem for Mexican authorities.

title: Familiar Sounds
description: Carmine Abbatiello has decided that things will be different after he drives his 10,000th winner. The change, though, won't be seen for a while since it took him 28 years to drive his first 5,000 winners, an achievement that won him a ''night'' at Roosevelt Raceway on Thursday.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $235,000 in the qr and $774,000 in the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $214,000 in the qr and $538,000 in the 9 mos

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Brewers vs. California Angels, American League playoff, fourth game, at Milwaukee. (Television -Channel 7, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 1 P.M.) Braves vs. St. Louis Cardinals, National League playoff, third game, at Atlanta. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, exhibition game, at Convention Hall, Atlantic City, 7:30 P.M. This is the exhibition opener for both teams. Darryl Dawkins, now with the Nets, will be playing against his former teammates.

title: Devils Agree With Vadnais
description: The Devils reached a contractual agreement today with Carol Vadnais, the 37-year-old defenseman whom they claimed from the Rangers in last Monday's waiver draft.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest 6 mos reflect a provision of $2,457,000 for losses on the termination of the company's apparel yarn product line and conversion of its yarn dyeing and processing business to a commission basis

title: Sweden Devalues Krona 16%
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme today ordered a 16 percent devaluation of the Swedish krona and a general price freeze as part of an austerity policy for his new administration,

title: PACT REACHED IN NURSES STRIKE
description: The union representing striking nurses at St. Barnabas Medical Center announced early today that it had reached a tentative settlement in its contract dispute with the hospital.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE FELL IN SEPTEMBER
description: New York City's unemployment rate dropped to 9.2 percent in September, down from 10.7 percent in August, while New York State's rate rose slightly, to 8.6 percent, and New Jersey's was unchanged at 9.2 percent.

title: F.B.I. Records Show Officials Stole Half Of Ransom Money
description: A police lieutenant and the president of a cab company stole $300,000 of the $600,000 ransom paid in the kidnapping of a Kansas City boy in 1953, Federal Bureau of Investigation records disclosed.

title: Bomb Blast Damages J.D.L.'s 38th St. Office
description: A high-powered explosive blew out two walls of the Jewish Defense League's mid-Manhattan offices shortly before midnight last night, but the police said that no one was injured and that damage was apparently not great.

title: Michigan Man Is Guilty Of Killing 7 in Family
description: Robert Lee Haggart, a 32-year-old livestock auctioneer, was found guilty today of killing his estranged wife and six members of her family in February, one day before the couple were to have been divorced.

title: BREWERS SET BACK ANGELS AND TRAIL BY 2 GAMES TO 1
description: Neither the California Angels nor a fan in the stands could prevent the Milwaukee Brewers from playing at least one more game this year.

title: News Analysis
description: When the unemployment figure of 10.1 percent was announced in Washington yesterday, Democrats got the political lever that they believe can turn the 1982 election into a sweeping victory.

title: FORGOTTEN SORROWS IN TIMOR
description: Aggression forgotten is aggression rewarded. Because Britain could send a fleet to the Falklands, Argentina paid in bitter coin for its seizure of the islands. Indonesia had better luck seven years ago: it grabbed East Timor, a former Portuguese colony, and heard only token protest. The principle was the same but Indonesia's crime is nearly forgotten.

title: BELOW THE SPEED PEOPLE GET KILLED AT
description: To the Editor:

title: STAR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
SWEDES PRESS THEIR SEARCH FOR TRAPPED SUB
description: The hunt for a submarine presumed trapped near a naval base in the Stockholm archipelago entered its second week today as ships and helicopters continued their sweeps of the area.

title: LEARNING THE LESSONS OF 19 SEASONS
description: ST. LOUIS Odd as it might seem, Phil Niekro was once a rookie. It's in black and white in the record book. Niekro is 43 years old now, young for a lawyer or carpenter, positively patriarchal for a ballplayer.

title: McDonald's Ad Bid Denied
description: A Federal judge today denied a request from the McDonald's Corporation for a temporary restraining order that would have barred further airing of a Burger King advertising campaign against McDonald's Big Mac hamburgers.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MOUNTING BILL FROM RETAIL THEFT
description: A professional shoplifter recently invited to address a group of 150 Long Island retailers told them there wasn't a single store represented in the gathering from which she hadn't stolen goods. She said she averaged $3,000 a week and varied her approach by the season, using a large coat with special pockets in the winter and a wrapped package with a false top or bottom in the summer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sebastian Coe is not likely to run competitively for at least six more months, according to his former coach, George Gandy.

title: A Restless Buddy Bell
description: The Texas Rangers' general manager, Joe Klein, said that the team didn't want to lose its third baseman, Buddy Bell, but all he had to do was ask to be traded and the possibility of a deal ''would increase a hundred-fold.'' Bell, who is known to be coveted by the Yankees, said he might just do that.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avon Capital Corp.'s $100 million issue of guaranteed notes due in 1990 was assigned an 11 3/4 percent coupon and priced at par, through Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Police in Massachusetts Arrest 22 in Drug Case
description: Policemen posing as marijuana smugglers today cracked a ring that officials said used an extensive network of trucks and warehouses to distribute millions of dollars of the illegal substance throughout the state.

title: American General Gains in NLT Bid
description: The American General Corporation of Houston received approval from the Tennessee Insurance Commission for its $1.5 billion merger with the NLT Corporation of Nashville.

title: JOBLESS RATE IS UP TO 10.1% IN MONTH, WORST IN 42 YEARS
description: Unemployment in September rose three-tenths of a percentage point to 10.1 percent of the work force, the highest monthly figure in 42 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGIL STARK, INVENTOR AND A MANUFACTURER FOR PIPELINE PROJECTS
description: Virgil Stark, an inventor, a philanthropist and the president of the North American Utility Construction Corporation of New York, died Sept. 25 in Cannes, France. Mr. Stark, who had a home in Cannes and also lived in Manhattan, was 80 years old.

title: TROUBLED PUBLISHERS AT FRANFURT FAIR
description: The world economic recession is biting into book sales, with governments chopping the budgets of lending libraries and readers shunning hardback editions in favor of cheaper paperbacks.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Hart Island is a wild, windswept place, its shores edged with twisted trees. Goldenrod and stalks of Queen Anne's lace disintegrating into dust choke the hills at the northern end, around the abandoned Nike missile silo and the square monument with ''Peace'' emblazoned on the side put up by prison inmates in 1948.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WARSAW OUTLAWS SOLIDARITY UNION
description: The Polish Parliament overwhelmingly approved a law today that bans Solidarity, the independent trade union that once captured the imagination and allegiance of nearly 10 million Poles.

title: THE WHO'S 'FINAL' TOUR ARRIVES IN NEW YORK
description: The Who, one of the most successful and widely admired groups in rock, arrives in New York today for three concert dates on a mammoth tour that its members insist will be their last.

title: INVESTEX INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Letter: On Water Standards; How Clean Is a Clean Hudson?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Tightens Banking Rule
description: The Federal Reserve Board has closed a loophole that allowed banks to offer liquidity to holders of accounts similar to money market accounts.

title: Brush Fire Spreads on Coast
description: A brush fire caused by arson and pushed by 50-mile-an-hour gusts of wind spread rapidly across hills south of this suburban community today, burning more than 3,000 acres of brush and forcing the evacuation of an elementary school.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: First Rewards in Search For Early New York

title: COCAINE DEALER ACCUSED OF PLOT TO KILL JUDGE
description: A convicted cocaine distributor and his son were indicted today on charges of conspiring to murder five persons involved in the cocaine case, including the Federal judge who sentenced the father.

title: Track to Be Sold At Watkins Glen
description: The bankrupt track here that served for decades as the site of the Watkins Glen Grand Prix auto race will be sold at auction Nov. 10 to help pay a $3.14 million debt.

title: LOVE (CAPITAL EL) NOTE TO THE UNDERGROUND
description: I grew up on the New York subways during the 1930's and early 1940's. What a wonderland they were for us in those days! We were then living in Sheepshead Bay, in south Brooklyn. To go anywhere from there, especially to Manhattan (called ''The City''), you had to rely on the subways, the trolley or the car. But in those late Depression days not many New York families had cars, and if they did they were infrequently used. So inevitably you took the ''train,'' another expression in the oral tradition of New York that outsiders could not fully grasp.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
I.T.T. TO END ITS CONTROL OF STANDARD TELEPHONES
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced today that it would offer to the public 40 percent of the stock that it owns in one of Britain's more profitable companies, Standard Telephones and Cables.

title: MOYNIHAN CALLS DATA ON JOBLESS '2D DEPRESSION'
description: Outside an office where New Yorkers were waiting to collect unemployment insurance benefits, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that ''this is the day we begin the second Depression of the 20th century.''

title: The First Debate
description: Mario Cuomo is very good at debates. He spots the weakness in an opponent's argument the way Ted Williams's eyes used to know, when the pitch was still 30 feet from the plate, that it was going to hang high and sweet for him. And then Mr. Cuomo swings and knocks it out of the park.

title: Kohl to Meet Mrs. Thatcher
description: West Germany's new Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, will go to London Oct. 19 for talks with the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, a Government spokesman said today.

title: JAZZ COSMOS WIN FUTURITY
description: Heavily favored Jazz Cosmos, driven by Mickey McNichol, won photo finishes in both heats on a sloppy Red Mile track today to win the $116,200 Kentucky Futurity. The race is the third leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old trotters.

title: TYLENOL: THE FEAR SPILLS OVER
description: Just a week ago, drugstore shelves around the country were stacked with bottles of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules. Today, the space that the nation's leading over-the-counter pain reliever occupied is empty, an eerie reminder of the seven deaths linked to poisoned Tylenol capsules.

title: LEBANESE ARMY BULLDOZES 'ILLEGAL' MOSLEM HOMES
description: Lebanese troops used bulldozers today to demolish what were described as illegally built shops and houses on the southern outskirts of West Beirut. The demolition came as the army continued for a fourth day its hunt for illegal residents and hidden arms.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Police and the Law

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including credits of $3,200,000 from changes in accounting estimates and commodity inventory adjustments...C-Including a gain of $7,900,000 or 52 cents a shrfrom the sale of river barges; shr earnings for the latest yr reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: TREAT HALLOWEEN AS TRICK, BECAUSE WE FOOL OURSELVES
description: Given our acute national distress over youthful misbehavior, violence and vandalism, why do we continue to tolerate, indeed to encourage, the annual mid-fall madness called Halloween? Why do we spend 364 days discussing and framing stratagems and rules to discourage juvenile disruption during school hours and vandalism after hours, but then, on Oct. 31, allow our kids to roam the neighborhood terrorizing smaller children, bugging home owners and damaging or destroying property?

title: 'Minute of Silence' Found Unconstitutional
description: Federal District Judge L. Clure Morton today declared unconstitutional a law passed this year by the Legislature requiring a minute of silence in public schools before classes. Gov.
