Lamar Alexander signed the law last April 29 and some school systems began their ''minute of silence'' soon afterward.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Final Resting Place For One Who Lost Himself

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Qtrly results are for 13 weeks for the latest period and 12 weeks for the yr-ago period

title: 'LITTLE PEOPLE,' THE STORY OF DWARFS
description: Including documentary films in the New York Film Festival, where the emphasis is on fiction, is, I suppose, a good thing, but it's also somewhat unfair to the documentaries and to fiction. A documentary, to be of interest, doesn't have to work in the same way that a fiction film does.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: B-Including equity earnings of $307,000 from AES Data and $569,000 from its Lanier Financial Services division...C-After a loss of $591,000 from AES Data

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW ART

title: Boxers Awaiting A Third Group
description: No sooner had the World Boxing Association's convention ended this week in San Juan, P.R., than a group of American promoters and managers began talking about forming a third sanctioning body to rival the W.B.A. and the larger World Boxing Council.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1982; The Economy
description: The September jobless rate rose 0.3 of a percentage point, to 10.1 percent, force, the highest monthly rate since 1940. The Labor Department said that 11,260,000 people were out of work last month and that the total number of employed fell 119,000, to 99,720,000. Officials noted more job losses in manufacturing and an unusual decline in wholesale and retail jobs. (Page 1.) New York City's jobless rate fell to 9.2 percent. (11.) In California, President Reagan warned the Democrats not to try to exploit the new data. (10.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Brooklyn Center

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $1,700,000 for the qr and $1,900,000 for the 9 mos

title:
PATENTS;
Gas Process to Pickle Vegetables and Fruits
description: A new process to preserve fresh fruits and vegetables has been invented for the Department of Agriculture.

title: NEW ORLEANS BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per shr figures reflect a 20 percent stock divd paid Oct 1

title: Starting Over
description: This began as a wonderful running year for Matt Centrowitz of the Bronx. Now, he says, he is starting from scratch again.

title:
PATENTS;
Fanuc Ltd. Registers Robot Arm With a Grip
description: An industrial robot that can rotate two arms, one of which has a gripping member, was patented this week for Fanuc Ltd. of Tokyo. The grip, or mechanical fingers, can move a piece being worked or a tool.

title: THE NINE LIVES OF 'NEW FEDERALISM'
description: Every time skeptics conclude that President Reagan's ''new federalism'' initiative is dead or dying, there is another White House meeting on the subject. Typically, a White House aide emerges and reports that the Administration has found a way to ''breathe new life'' into the proposal.

title: HONDURAS AND NICARAGUA GIVE OPPOSING VIEWS AT THE U.N.
description: The Honduran Foreign Minister said at the 37th session of the United Nations General Assembly today that his country had been working to solve some of the conflicts in Central America but was now threatened by those conflicts and by regional terrorism.

title: SHUTDOWN THREAT OVER WAGE STANCE
description: A demand by the National Football League Players Association for a strike settlement based on a wage scale could lead to the closing of the season, the chairman of the N.F.L. Management Council executive committee said yesterday.

title: SAUDI ARABIA EXPELS 69 VISITING IRANIANS AFTER RIOT IN MEDINA
description: Saudi officials deported 69 Iranians after a riot in the Moslem holy city of Medina, the Interior Ministry said today.

title: Stoughton Suspended
description: Blaine Stoughton, the Hartford Whalers' leading scorer last season, has been suspended by the National Hockey League for eight games as the result of his cross-checking Paul Baxter of the Pittsburgh Penguins in the face last Saturday. Brian F. O'Neill of the league office cited the ''deliberateness of the action'' in announcing the suspension yesterday.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO DEPORT 10 OTHER NAZIS
description: Government prosecutors said today that they were pressing 10 more deportation proceedings against suspected Nazi war criminals and had enlarged the search for additional suspects through the first systematic culling of Nazi rosters by American investigators.

title: GEORGIAN, KEEPING JOB DAY BY DAY, GLUMLY AWAITS YET ANOTHER PINK SLIP
description: Look to the country roads leading to the cities in the dark before dawn and see the army of workers at the wheel. In the dim light of the dashboard they are yawning, watching the wristwatch and the mileage and mindful of a clock that lies ahead unpunched. Their lunches are in sacks on the seats beside them. Their families are secure in the mortgaged homes behind them. The arrangement is foursquare and tidy and in the best interest of all, and when it is altered, as layoffs have been altering it nationwide for some time now, the new arrangement claws at the dignity of people.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DOW SOARS 20.88 MORE,TO 986.85
description: Stock market prices surged again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 20.88 points on very heavy volume, giving the New York Stock Exchange its second-biggest price gain and trading volume for a single week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we talk about the City Council and potential conflicts of interest, we are considering a gray area filled with personal problems for each Councilman.'' - Councilman Peter F. Vallone of Queens, chairman of the Standards and Ethics Committee. (1:1.)

title: ARABS AT U.N. SEEK ISRAELI OUSTER
description: The members of the Arab League here agreed today to seek the expulsion of Israel from the General Assembly, Arab envoys said.

title: Beckman Orders 5 Payless Holidays
description: Beckman Instruments Inc. is ordering its 9,000 employees to take five payless holidays this year to offset the effects of depressed sales of industrial instruments and electronics components.

title: DR. HARVEY BRANDON
description: Dr. Harvey Brandon, who practiced internal medicine in New York City from 1936 until last April, died Thursday night at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital.

title: BRIEFING
description: Haig Memoirs in Offing

title: 'NICKELODEON' AND 'ASHILE GORKY'
description: Charles Musser's hourlong documentary ''Before the Nickelodeon'' traces the pioneering film career of Edwin Porter, whose turn-ofthe-century innovations helped move film from the level of ''animated photographs'' toward something continuous and coherent. It isn't always easy to make modern audiences see the originality of techniques now taken for granted - such as even the most primitive forms of film editing - but Mr. Musser's film illustrates and explains these things with admirable clarity.

title: Bridge: World Open Play Leaders; Include 7 American Pairs
description: Players from the United States dominated the World Open Pair Championships here Friday. When play was concluded about 2 A.M. today, the top four positions were held by Americans, and there were three more in the top 10.

title: Japan Explains Move On F-16 Deployments
description: The Japanese Government has agreed to the deployment of United States F-16 fighter-bomber squadrons in northern Japan because they will counter the Soviet military buildup in the Far East and demonstrate America's commitment to defense of the region, Japan's Defense Agency chief said today.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UNDER PRESIDENCIES SINCE DEPRESSION
description: The following is an outline of unemployment in the Presidencies since the Depression. Data for 1929 through 1946 include workers 14 and 15 years old. Since 1947 only those 16 and older are included.

title: S.& P. to Rate Certificates
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that, upon request, it would rate certificates of deposit insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $32,000...C-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An announcement in Weekend yes- terday gave incorrect dates for Christie's auction of John James Audubon's ''Birds of America.'' The sale, at the Warwick Post Oak Hotel in Houston, is next Friday at 7 P.M. and Saturday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: TIMELY WRITER FAREWELL NEAR
description: Time has never been on Timely Writer's side, and it may run out today for the star-crossed colt. The Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park this afternoon will probably be his last race, the final chapter in a career that has been laced with missed opportunites and untimely setbacks.

title: H.U.D.'S GRANTS WILL STILL BE INCOME-ORIENTED
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Recording Music on Computer
description: WASHINGTON THE owner of a home computer will be able to record music and play it back with equipment patented this week for the RCA Corporation.

title: FERNANDO LAMAS, ACTOR , AT 67
description: Fernando Lamas, the silver-haired star of numerous ''Latin lover'' movies, died today of cancer. He was 67 years old.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CYANIDE DEATH INVESTIGATED IN WYOMING
description: The team investigating seven deaths here from Tylenol capsules tainted with cyanide had agents in Wyoming tonight to question several people about the unexplained cyanide death there in July of a young man who reportedly took Extra-Strength Tylenol.

title: EXECUTIVES SEE TEPID RECOVERY
description: The heads of many of the nation's biggest companies today predicted only a tepid recovery for the economy next year and scant hope for improvement in unemployment or investment in industry anytime soon.

title: KNICKS ARE UPHELD ON KING OFFER SHEET
description: Kingman Brewster, the special master appointed to arbitrate disputes arising from the settlement of the 1976 Oscar Robertson antitrust suit, denied yesterday the Golden State Warriors' challenge to the Sept. 28 offer sheet the Knicks had presented to Bernard King, the free-agent forward.

title: Avanti Motor Is Purchased
description: A Washington, D.C., businessman, Stephen Blake, announced he had purchased the Avanti Motor Corporation, a manufacturer of handmade luxury automobiles, for $5 million.

title: PENN ST. IS CALLED 'GREATEST'
description: Bear Bryant of Alabama, who has coached more football victories at 319 than anyone in history, said today that ''Penn State is probably the greatest team in the country, maybe the greatest team in the history of college football - this year.''

title: STOMACH ILLNESS TERMED RARE TYPE OF DYSENTERY
description: Federal epidemiologists, seeking to learn more about a newly recognized disease linked to eating hamburger, characterized it yesterday as an intestinal ailment that often hospitalized its victim with pain as severe as that experienced by women in childbirth.

title: 8 Killed in Church Van
description: A truck swerved to avoid a stalled automobile and hit a church van today near this central California community, killing eight persons, the police reported. They said all the victims were riding in the van.

title: Regan Backs Extra Money Growth
description: In a marked change in the Administration's position, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today encouraged the Federal Reserve to permit extra growth in the money supply, if that is what the Fed wants to do.

title: Copter Breaks Apart in Flight
description: A helicopter broke apart in flight Wednesday and plunged onto a suburban golf course's fairway, killing the pilot but not injuring anyone on the ground. Witnesses said the helicopter had seemed to explode in the air after developing engine trouble.

title: COLGATE'S EFFORT TO CHANGE IMAGE UPSTAGED BY SUCCESS IN FOOTBALL
description: Colgate University, one of the nation's leading private liberal arts colleges, is seeking to improve its scholastic reputation as it tries to tone down a longstanding image as a school of active fraternities and boisterous football games.

title: Huge Sums in Unsure Hands
description: How much confidence to repose in a ''repo'' is now a $260 million question in Albany. Enough to build a campus? That much of the assets of New York State's Dormitory Authority has been frozen following the start of bankruptcy proceedings involving Lombard-Wall, a securities firm. And Governor Carey, Comptroller Regan and other officials are worrying about similar embarrassments.

title: TRANSIT ADVISER LEAVES WITH GOALS UNREALIZED
description: Although he was helpful in some ways, Ross Sandler, who has announced his resignation as Mayor Koch's special adviser on mass transit, was not able to bring about the major improvements in bus and subway service that Mr. Koch had hoped for, city and transit officials said yesterday.

title: LOSS IS RANGER'S 2D
description: The Devils felt like they had won more than their first game tonight after defeating the Rangers, 3-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. They felt like they had won some respect, some self-esteem and some new fans.

title: Another Strike Angle
description: National Football League players idled by a strike will not be allowed to join the fledgling United States Football League unless contractual matters are resolved, says Dave Dixon, one of the new league's founders. Jim Kovach, a linebacker with the New Orleans Saints, had said that a number of N.F.L. players were considering the possibility of signing one-year contracts with U.S.F.L. teams if the N.F.L. season is canceled.

title: Palace Denies the Queen Ordered Andrew Home
description: Some London newspapers asserted today, and Buckingham Palace denied, that Queen Elizabeth had ordered her son Prince Andrew to return to Britain from a vacation in the Caribbean with an actress who has appeared in sexually explicit movies. Buckingham Palace called the reports ''complete rubbish.''

title: Dome in Talks On Refinancing
description: The troubled Dome Petroleum Company Ltd. of Canada met in New York with its international bankers, of which Citibank is the lead bank, in an effort to agree to a refinancing plan for the oil company, which is based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: KEROSENE HEATERS QUESTIONED
description: SUN Inc., the largest importer of portable kerosene heaters in t he United States, announced this week that it planned to sue C onsumers Union, the nonprofit publisher of Consumer Reports. The s uit would challenge the cover story in the magazine's October issue,w hich questioned the safety of the small, increasingly popular d evices.

title: Bendix Acquires 28% of Eotec
description: The Bendix Corporation said it had acquired 28 percent of Eotec, a maker of fiber optics products, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Schmitt Company
description: The Peter J. Schmitt Company, a food wholesaler based in Buffalo, announced it would buy most of the assets of Star Supermarkets Inc., a Rochester retail food chain. Star said it would receive about $9.4 million in the sale. Schmitt is a subsidiary of Loblaw Companies of Canada.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Near 1,000 Mark
description: The Dow Jones industrial average once again is tapping on the door of 1,000, a benchmark that has eluded the nation's most popular market indicator since mid-1981, early in the Reagan Administration.

title: LIQUOR SALES REGISTER DECLINE
description: The sound of the cocktail shaker is fainter these days as a change in public taste is apparently diminishing the consumption of martinis, manhattans, whisky sours and other drinks based on liquor. In the first half of the year American liquor sales declined 6.6 percent, with virtually every category of alcoholic beverage showing significant losses. Wine sales, on the other hand, have continued to grow, although moderately.

title: Seoul's Foreign Debt
description: South Korea's foreign debts outstanding as of Aug. 31 were $35.8 billion, Prime Minister Kim Sang Hyup said today. Testifying before the National Assembly, Mr. Kim predicted a year-end figure of $36 billion.

title: L. I. Man Recovering From King-Cobra Bite
description: A Long Island animal importer who was bitten on the thumb by a king cobra was reported yesterday in good condition and recovering.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amana Refrigeration Inc.'s Amana Radarange microwave ovens are not the only ovens to pass four safety tests made by an independent testing agency, as asserted in the company's commercials, the F.T.C. charged in a complaint filed yesterday.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After losses of $394,000 for the qr and $350,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $42,261,000 for the qr and $43,541,000 for the 6 mos

title: STAGE: OSBORN'S 'ON BORROWED TIME'
description: Paul Osborn's ''On Borrowed Time,'' opening the season at the Hartford Stage Company, is a fanciful comedy about death as a great comforter. In this fantasy, a success on Broadway in 1938, the enemy is not the extinction of life but man's inability to respect the individuality of his neighbor. As such, the play, adapted from the novel by Laurence Edward Watkin, is not only akin to Mr. Osborn's ''Morning's at Seven,'' but also to such warm-hearted films as Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

title: Ford Studies Plan To Delay a Bill
description: The Ford Motor Company is studying a plan to put off payment of bills for up to seven years for machine tools ordered for a 1986-model-year transmission, a company spokeswoman said.

title: An Apology
description: Relying on a story in another newspaper (subsequently corrected), a recent Editorial Notebook quoted Assistant Attorney General William Baxter as saying a Supreme Court decision on price-fixing was ''very, very stupid.'' Mr. Baxter was indeed critical of the decision, but he did not use those words. We apologize.

title: Your Money; Smaller Effect Of Deductibles
description: THE advantages of insurance deductibles, used by many high-income and not-so-high-income taxpayers to reduce their premium costs, will be limited next year as a result of two sections of the 1982 tax law.

title: CALIFORNIA G.O.P. CANDIDATE DISMAYED BY AIDE'S RACIAL COMMENT
description: Attorney General George Deukmejian expressed dismay today over a statement to reporters Thursday by Bill Roberts, his campaign manager, that Mr. Roberts counted on racial reaction to help them win the governorship over Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, who is black.

title: FRANCE AND 18 AFRICAN LANDS DISCUSS O.A.U. SPLIT
description: The leaders of France and 18 African countries began meetings here today in an effort to find a way to save the Organization of African Unity, the regional group that virtually collapsed this summer.

title:
PATENTS;
Controlling Blade Pitch In Big Wind Turbines
description: A system for controlling the pitch angle of the blades in a wind turbine and regulating the speed was patented this week for the United Technologies Corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News report by Reuters Thursday in Business Day incorrectly reported a statement by James Forese, controller of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Forese said I.B.M. expects a rebound in the economy in 1983 with a growth rate below 5 percent annually.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 207678 -- No Title
description: A state court jury awarded $11.2 million Thursday to the parents of an infant who suffered brain damage in his crib. Jurors ruled that Jacqueline and Steven Smith of Houston were entitled to damages from the crib manufacturer, Welsh Company of St. Louis, and the retailer, ABC Baby Furniture and Infant Wear Inc. One side of the crib collapsed in July 1981, and the couple said Christopher, then 7 months old, suffered brain damage from lack of oxygen when his neck became wedged between two sections of vertical dowel.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Bush to Visit Cape Verde
description: Vice President Bush is to visit the Cape Verde Islands, the most politically moderate of Portugal's former African colonies, a Government statement said today. The statement said Mr. Bush would come to the islands soon but gave no dates for the visit.

title: WHAT THE S.A.T. TEACHES
description: At first glance, the rise in the average Scholastic Aptitude Test scores seems no big deal. What's two points in verbal skills and one point in math on tests that are scored from 200 to 800? And on the negative side, the College Board has disclosed that black students on average still score more than 100 points below whites.

title: Qaddafi Threatens to Kill Anti-Libyan Exiles
description: Libya has broadcast a threat by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to have exiles who work against his regime assassinated.

title: HIGH ORBIT AND THEN SPUTTERNIK
description: Sputnik, which weighed all of 184 pounds, had an impact far out of proportion to its size. Its most immediate consequence was to embarrass the United States into making rapid improvements in its educational system. But today we are in danger of losing all that we gained, and there are those who say the time has come for another ''Sputnik.'' I don't think we need precisely that, but we do need a good and painful shock, the kind that Sputnik administered.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT OILERS ON TWO LATE GOALS
description: The New York Islanders, with the help of the Sutter brothers, won their second game of the new season tonight, defeating the Edmonton Oilers, 6-4, at Northlands Coliseum.

title: Treasury Aide Resigns
description: Mark Stalnecker, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for Federal Finance, has resigned effective Oct. 15 to return to the private sector, the Treasury Department said today. He will be replaced by C. Warren Carter, a vice president of Aubrey G. Langston, the New York securities firm.

title: Decision Due on 3-Mile Island
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has set a Dec. 10 deadline for deciding whether to lift its 1979 order that shut down the undamaged reactor at the Three-Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania. The order closing Unit 1, the undamaged reactor, was issued shortly after the accident in March 1979 that crippled the Unit 2 reactor and contaminated it with radiation.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED TO AID TELEFUNKEN
description: The West German Government and banks today settled the last outstanding points of a financing package for the troubled electrical goods manufacturer AEG-Telefunken, the Economics Ministry said.

title: Drug Industry Group Begins Drafting Packaging Standard
description: A drug advisory group began drafting an industry packaging standard Thursday in hopes of deterring future criminal tampering such as the cyanide poisoning of Tylenol capsules that killed seven persons in the Chicago area.

title: AMCOLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
LOSS TO THE BREWERS DEFLATING FOR ANGELS
description: The feeling of uncertainty in the American League championship series switched clubhouses today. The Milwaukee Brewers, one game from the end of their season, had brought that feeling here after the losses to California in the first two games at Anaheim.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEHRMAN BLAMES CAREY FOR STATE'S JOBLESS RATE
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor, campaigned across the state today, blaming former President Jimmy Carter and Governor Carey for high unemployment rates.

title: LOUIS J. CAPOZZOLI, RETIRED JUDGE
description: Louis J. Capozzoli, a former United States Representative, state legislator and justice in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, died of a heart attack yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 81 years old.

title: China Is Said to Insist On a Pullback by Soviet
description: China has told the Soviet Union during exploratory talks that Soviet troops must be withdrawn from the Chinese and Mongolian borders because they are a threat to China's security, foreign diplomatic sources reported today.

title: U.S. PLANS A NEW DRIVE ON NARCOTICS
description: President Reagan wants to initiate a broad program to combat the distribution of narcotics by organized crime, Administration sources said today.

title: Intel Earnings Drop by 23.6%
description: The Intel Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Sept. 30 fell 23.6 percent, to $8.4 million, or 18 cents a share, from $11 million, or 25 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Richard L. Taylor, 39, Director At Harlem Branch of Y.M.C.A.
description: Richard L. Taylor, executive director of the Harlem branch of the Y.M.C.A., died Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center after a long illness. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan

title: DES MOINES LOSES A NEWSPAPER VOICE AS ECONOMIC 'FACTS OF LIFE' PREVAIL
description: A picture of an appealingly freckle-faced newspaper delivery boy has appeared recently on billboards around here. He offers a folded copy of The Register, which the promotional message below describes as ''Now ... a good deal more!''

title: THE CARDINALS' OZ OF WIZARDRY
description: ST. LOUIS Even when he makes a routine good play, the chant begins. ''Ozzie, Oz-zie,'' the Busch Stadium loyalists roar for Ozzie Smith, the wonderful wizard who is the Cardinals' shortstop. After four seasons of performing in the shadows that surrounded the San Diego Padres then, he is out there on the big stage of the National League championship series that moves to Atlanta tonight.

title: ITALY, REACTING TO BEIRUT ROUNDUPS, ASKS BOLSTERING OF PEACE FORCE
description: Italy called on the United States and France today to join with it in demanding that the three countries' peacekeeping authority in Beirut be strengthened.

title: NOW CONVENES TO PICK LEADERS
description: About 2,000 delegates of the National Organization for Women descended on this city's Convention Center today for the first gathering of the troops since the defeat last June of the equal rights amendment to which they had devoted almost single-minded attention the previous year.

title: INDEX
description: International Guatemalan thrusts bring fear to Mexican border 2 Reagan promises to work with Mexico on its economic trouble 3 Bolivians hail leader home from exile 3 Around the World 4 South Africa threatens new curbs on rural blacks 4 Hunt for trapped submarine con- tinues in Sweden 5 Arab League to seek Israel's ex- pulsion at General Assembly 6 Italy asks strengthening of Beirut peace force 6 Baptist chapel in Jerusalem de- stroyed and arson is suspected 6 Saudis deport 69 Iranians after a riot in Medina 6 WASHINGTON TALK Briefing 10 The nine lives of "New Federalism" 10 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Columbus Day will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins at noon, Fifth Avenue and 44th Street; moves north to 86th Street, east to Third Avenue. Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1982
description: International A law to ban Solidarity was overwhelmingly approved by Poland's Parliament. The law abolishes all labor organizations, including the independent trade union that once commanded the allegiance of nearly 10 million Poles. (Page 1, Column 1.) Lebanese troops used bulldozers to demolish what were described as illegally built shops and houses in a shantytown in the southern outskirts of West Beirut. Officials said the buildings were put up by Shiite Moslems without Government approval as long ago as the 1975-76 civil war. (6:3-6.)

title: ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-The company reported that it had no revs for the yr-ago periods

title: GIBSON WITNESS NOW SAYS HARRIS WASN'T INVOLVED
description: An important prosecution witness in the misconduct trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris today recanted much of his grand jury testimony that had implicated Mr. Harris in a conspiracy to reinstate a former official to a ''no show'' job.

title: U.A.W. CONCEDES WORKERS ARE REJECTING CHRYSLER PACT
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers conceded today that rank-and-file members were rejecting the union's tentative contract with the Chrysler Corporation.

title: BOLIVIA HAILS CHIEF HOME FROM EXILE
description: More than 100,000 jubilant Bolivians turned out today to welcome back President-elect Hernan Siles Zuazo after more than two years in exile.

title: Israeli Is Jailed for Looting
description: A military court sentenced an army private to three and a half years in prison today for looting a Lebanese store, the military command said. Pvt. Shimon Barzilai was convicted of stealing property from a store in Aleih, a town overlooking the Beirut-Damascus highway east of Beirut. The command did not say what items were stolen.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: 7 AT AN EXHIBIT ON OBSCENITY CHARGE
description: Seven persons were arrested Friday night by undercover police officers and charged with promoting obscenity after a Criminal Court judge viewed videotapes they were selling at an exhibit in Manhattan, the police said.

title: UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $506,000 for the qr and $931,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $131,000 for the qr and $883,000 for the 9 mos

title: CONCERT: SPECTRA'S 'TRIBUTE TO LOVE'
description: Merely stringing together items on a concert is not necessarily the same as program-building. And giving those items an overall title does not automatically unify them.

title: SOLIDARITY'S RISE AND FALL
description: Following is a chronology of events from the origin of the independent trade union movement in Poland to yesterday's outlawing of Solidarity by the Government: 1980 July 2 - Factory workers in Warsaw strike to protest increase in meat prices and to demand higher pay. Scattered wildcat strikes sweep large factories across country in subsequent days. July 17 - Army moves to maintain essential services in southern city of Lublin when 80,000 workers join a general strike. Aug. 14 - Workers take over Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk; work stoppages spread in Baltic industrial region. Aug. 24 - Government agrees to negotiate with strikers. Sept. 5 - Independent unions form a single national labor organization, Solidarity, as Lech Walesa emerges as leader. Oct. 24 - For first time in any Soviet-bloc country, an independent union achieves legal status. Nov. 28 - East Germany and Czechoslovakia denounce developments in Poland. A few days later joint military manuevers of Soviet bloc begin on Polish borders and continue periodically for months.

title: No Headline
description: Roddey Mims, Photographer For U.P.I. and Time, Dies at 46

title: JAPAN PLANS MILD ECONOMIC STIMULUS
description: The Japanese Government today adopted a package of mildly stimulative measures to increase the growth of its sluggish economy.

title: ALGERIA HALTS PAYMENT OF CLAIMS AGAINST IRAN
description: Four American companies that were awarded nearly $6 million in claims against the Iranian Government by an international tribunal have not been paid because Algeria has not authorized release of the funds, American and Algerian officials indicated today.

title: THE PATTERNS OF CUISINE
description: Whether to be deplored or celebrated, the current interest in food, and the much-heralded culinary revolution we are supposed to be in the midst of, are hardly new phenomena. Throughout recorded history there have been fashions in food, however primitive or refined.

title: ATLANTIC OIL CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Transactions BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Signed its first-round draft choice, Terry Teagle, guard, to a two-year contract.

title: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about recordings.
description: Certainly no one would argue that there's a paucity of Brahms in the record catalogues, particularly where his orchestral music is concerned. According to the current Schwann, one can now choose among 13 integral symphony sets and as many as 17 recordings each of the individual symphonies - to which must be added the many classic mono recordings still in print, and performances on foreign labels not listed in Schwann. The concertos, overtures and orchestral variations are also healthily represented. On the other hand, Brahms's solo and chamber music is considered less salable, and has therefore been less frequently recorded; and the full extent of his vocal writing could stand a bit more competitive exploration.

title: 38 CITY YOUNGSTERS ANSWER CALL AS TRAINERS
description: THE first job was a bruised knee, nothing extraordinary, just the sort of bruise a knee acquires when it belongs to a quarterback who has been sacked. All it needed was analgesic spray, a gauze pad, some undertape and some adhesive tape. When the wrapping was done, the knee looked like an Egyptian display at a museum, and the next player was on line, ready to become part of the exhibit.

title: CONSPIRACY TRIAL OF TEAMSTER LEADER IS SET TO BEGIN
description: The trial of Roy L. Williams, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which the judge has described as the ''most significant'' wire-tapping case in the history of electronic eavesdropping, will come to trial this week.

title: 'Plus ,Ca Change,' German Style
description: West Germany moved to the right 10 days ago, but not so the rest of the world would notice. Last week, shortly after he took office at the head of a coalition dominated by Christian Democrats instead of Social Democrats, Chancellor Helmut Kohl was assuring everyone that nothing much would change. In his first news conference, ''friendship and partnership, but not dependency,'' was the way Mr. Kohl described Bonn's future relations with the United States. His predecessor, Helmut Schmidt, however bitter he might be about his defeat, could find little to argue about there.

title: BEgged to Differ, Lawmakers Don't
description: Anyone looking for an argument in last week's Congressional leadership debate was hard pressed to find one. The participants, who went to the mat under the auspices of the League of Women Voters, nodded in agreement with each other more often than they wrestled.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: All in the Family

title: NUCLEAR UTILITIES PLAGUED BY COSTLY EQUIPMENT BREAKDOWNS
description: AMID considerable publicity, the Carolina Power nad Light Company took a billion-dollar plunge into nuclear power in the early 1970's. Nuclear themes graced the cover of its annual reports and shareholders were told of fast rising nuclear output. In 1973, the company predicted that nearly two-thirds of its power would come from nuclear energy by 1982.

title: Diane L. Rhodes Bride of Joseph Baker
description: Diane Lynn Rhodes, daughter of Mrs. George Frederick Rhodes of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Rhodes, was married yesterday to Joseph Burrill Baker, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Oliver Baker of Morristown and Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David P. Hegg 2d performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J., assisted by the Rev. Colley W. Bell, headmaster of the St. John Baptist School in Mendham, N.J.

title: SELF-CARE AIM OF HEALTH PROJECT
description: HEALTH power to the people is the theme of the Self-Care Project founded by a Yale professor, which came about through recognition that the layman has a vital role to play in his own health care.

title: POP: COUGAR'S LAMENTS
description: ''Oh yeah, life goes on/ Long after the thrill of living is gone,'' goes the chorus of ''Jack and Diane,'' the current No. 1 hit by John Cougar. This depressing little song, which proclaims that life after high school is strictly a downhill proposition, has captured the teen-age mood of the moment.

title: Miss Cohen, P.J. Kurshan Are Engaged
description: Harriet Newman Cohen of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Philip M. Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha E. Cohen, to Peter J. Kurshan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Kurshan of Woodmere, L.I., and New York.

title: WHERE OFFICERS HELP TROUBLED OFFICERS
description: To a New York City transit police officer who patrols filthy trains and dark tunnels eight hours a day, it often takes someone who does the same thing to understand the stress an officer endures. So some officers have turned to the Diagnostic and Counseling Services, the first independent counseling and medical treatment organization run by and for police officers.

title: DEAN OF BLACK BROOKLYN POLITICS A POWER AT 85
description: In 1953, Wesley McDonald Holder, a researcher in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, decided to take on the borough's Democratic Party organization and manage the campaign of an insurgent candidate for Municipal Court.

title: THE CASE FOR CONVERTIBLE BONDS
description: MANY investors these days are torn by the decision to either lock inh igh bond yields or bet that stocks will continue to rally. Rather t han choose, a number of them are opting for convertible debentures, a hybrid security that its fans call the best of all possible w orlds. A convertible debenture is sold as a $1,000 face value bond, w ith a fixed maturity and coupon, but it allows an investor to e xchange the bond for a fixed number of common shares, usually those o f the issuing corporation. The convertibles sell at a discount or p remium in the secondary market (100 is par), and their yields vary a ccordingly.

title: THESE DAYS, COLD WAR SEEMS A MERE WARMUP
description: After talking for 7 1/2 hours, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko found they agreed on very little. ''Relationships are strained,'' a senior State Department official said last week, ''with many points of disagreement and tensions. I suppose that is one of the few things we can agree on.'' A Soviet Embassy official, more bluntly, said, ''Relations are at their lowest point in history.''

title: HIS PITCHING SHAKY, MAUCH RECALLS '64
description: The subject was not raised in a question. The questions directed at Gene Mauch, the manager of the California Angels, had to do with the disappointment of Tommy John in today's fourth game of the American League championship series, and the uncertain condition of Bruce Kison, the starting pitcher in Sunday's game that will decide a pennant.

title: ARTFULLY HANDMADE SPANISH CERAMICS
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a writer and a professor of humanities at the Stevens Institute of Technology.

title:
STAMPS;
HONORING THE EXPLORER WHO DISCOVERED FLORIDA
description: Ponce de Leon, who conquered Puerto Rico for Spain and then discovered Florida, thus adding the mainland of North America to the Spanish dominions, appears on a new 20-cent commemorative from the United States being issued this Tuesday in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

title: HYDROPLANING GETS A BOOST
description: Last Oct. 18, Bill Muncey died in the final heat of the unlimited hydroplane world championship race when his boat, Atlas Van Lines, flipped.

title: A CLOSER LOOK AT THE NEW TAX LAW
description: THE ink is barely dry on the country's latest tax act, but already l egions of lawyers and accountants are trying to devise ways around s ome of the revenue-raising provisions.

title: Miss Lethbridge, Jeffrey Hull Wed
description: At the Prince of Peace Lutheran Church in Hamburg, N.J., yesterday Bonnie Joan Lethbridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford E. Lethbridge of Sussex, N.J., was married to Jeffrey Randolph Hull, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Hull of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Richard C. Izzard performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
KIPNESS LENDS VISION TO REALIST SCHOOL
description: ON-HUDSON AS has been apparent for some years now, realist painting in the United States has been making a comeback. Until Oct. 30, the River Gallery in Irvington-on-Hudson is showing work by Robert Kipniss, an artist whose relation to the realist revival is interesting and highly individual.

title: MCGEE DROPS ROLE AS CARDINALS' GOAT
description: Willie McGee appears to be using the National League playoffs to audition for ''Raiders of the Lost Ark II.'' He keeps tripping into quicksand, then suddenly finds a branch serendipitously leaning from a windswept tree to grab hold of.

title: THE V.A. DIGS IN FOR MORE BUDGET BATTLES
description: When he announced his resignation as chief of the Veterans Administration last week, Robert P. Nimmo said ''Economics can catch up with me, too.'' However, it was more than personal finances that had caught up with Mr. Nimmo. His blunt-edged efforts to cut back programs and tighten eligibility requirements had prompted veterans to refer to him as ''Mr. Nommo,'' as in ''you don't deserve no mo'.''

title: Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: A SURGE TO 10.1% IN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: America's unemployment rate in September crossed the double-digit point for the first time since 1940, to 10.1 percent, the Labor Department reported Friday. Nearly 11.3 million people were unemployed - 450,000 higher than in August and a rise of more than 3 million in the last 12 months. President Reagan, warning the Democrats not to ''make a political football out of this bad news and cruel fate,'' pointed to recent declines in interest and inflation rates as indicators of a pending turnaround in the economy.

title: 2 Lead Singers in 'Ballo' At the Met Cancel Dates
description: Katia Ricciarelli and Renato Bruson have withdrawn from their scheduled appearances in the Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera.'' Miss Ricciarelli has decided not to sing the part of Amelia; Mr. Bruson has canceled on his doctor's orders.

title: PORT AUTHORITY FORESEES ECONOMIC PROBLEMS
description: A warning signal on economic prospects for the metropolitan area was sounded by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in its latest assessment of business, industry and trade in the region.

title: RUMINATIONS ABOUT THE FILM FESTIVAL
description: As this is being written, the 20th New York Film Festival still has one more week to run. Though I haven't seen all of the festival films, I can't imagine a more agreeable or more enchanting memory of this year's event than the radiantly good-humored performance of Claudia Cardinale, the co-star - with Klaus Kinski - of Werner Herzog's ''Fitzcarraldo.'' The Herzog film, which may be the German director's first to reach a fairly large American audience, brings the festival to a fine, spirited close tonight.

title: 'Thunder Thighs!'
description: Surely the boys who play football for Ringgold High School in Monongahela, Pa. have heard their share of taunts from the connoisseurs in the stands. Taunts, however, go with the game. Anyone willing to pursue athletic prowess in public knows that suffering the audience's wit and wisdom is the price of glory. But what about Ringgold High's drum majorettes? Are they being castigated for failure to prance like a pony and catch the baton?

title: President's Job Rating Is Down Slightly in Poll
description: The latest nationwide Gallup Poll on how Americans rate President Reagan in office shows that a small plurality continue to disapprove of his job performance.

title: Miss Chase Wed To Jeffrey Peters
description: Catherine Harrington Chase, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sherret Spaulding Chase of Ashokan, N.Y., and San Carlos, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Blair Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Homer Peters of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and Jackson, N.H. The Rev. William H. Stemper performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Chase home in Ashokan.

title: Stepinac Wins
description: Archbishop Stepinac upset Holy Cross, 33-21, in a Catholic High Schools Football League game at White Plains.

title: SO WHAT'S NEXT?
description: Americans had every reason to be bothered and bewildered by the economic news last week. The unemployment rate hit 10.1 percent in September, the first time it had reached double-digit figures since the end of the Great Depression.

title: LET THE VOTER BEWARE
description: In the last few days, President Reagan has blamed the Democrats for almost everything except the Tylenol crisis. They are responsible, he says, for the worst unemployment and bankruptcy record since the Great Depression, and he implies that, along with other misguided people, they are even trying to ''freeze'' the nuclear arms race to the benefit of the Soviet Union.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Sept. 26 incorrectly described the prices at Disney World in Florida. A three-day pass ($28 to $35) is good for both the Magic Kingdom and the Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow Center. A oneday pass ($12 to $15) is good for either attraction but not both.

title: Bullhead Fishing Is Easy and Relaxing
description: WHILE well-to-do anglers are going after bonefish or tarpon on the Florida flats, or the Atlantic salmon in Canada, Iceland and Norway, or running many miles to sea in quest of billfish and tuna, the bullhead fisherman, often with his entire family about him, is enjoying low-cost sport in lakes and ponds usually no more than a few miles from home.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Listening to a debut concert is a little like listening to a complete stranger talk to you for about two hours. Even if that stranger has been taking elocution lessons and hardly stumbles over a word, that is no guarantee he is going to keep your attention. First impressions, after all, depend on personality as well as volubility.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE It is stepping-out-on-a-limb time again. Yet in one instance, it seems pretty safe to predict that a major event of the entire dance season will be the ''Ballet International'' series at the Brooklyn Academy.

title: SALVADOR REBEL LEADER QUESTIONS U.S. MOTIVES
description: The leader of the political arm of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement has described as ''artificial smoke'' reports that the Salvadoran Government, with American encouragement, is making efforts to establish contact with the rebels.

title: Hispanic-American Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B. Stinson Jr. Weds Katherine Imbrie
description: Katherine Palmer Imbrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Imbrie of Seekonk, Mass., was married in Providence, R.I., yesterday to Frederick Boyd Stinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stinson of Lynn, Mass., and Moultonboro, N.H. The Revs. Charles Baldwin and Howard O'Shea, the Methodist and Roman Catholic chaplains, respectively, of Brown University, performed the ecumenical ceremony in the Manning Chapel at Brown.

title: DEMOTION OF BASKETBALL TEAMS OPPOSED
description: A proposal by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council that would demote many of the 277 major college basketball teams from Division I has been described as discriminatory against private and urban colleges. It has also been called fiscally irresponsible and just another power play by the big-time football schools to gain full control of the two richest college sports - major football and major basketball.

title: CHICAGO MAN IS ARRESTED
description: A 20-year-old Chicago man was arrested today and charged with extortion after investigators said he threatened to poison hospital patients with cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules unless he was paid $8,000.

title: LAKE DISTRICT FEASTING
description: ISRAEL SHENKER is the author, most recently, of ''In the Footsteps of Boswell and Johnson'' (Houghton Mifflin).

title:
ART;
UNUSUAL CONCEPTS EXPLORED
description: SEA CLIFF VALID experiments energize the art process and are an essential part of discovery. But what is valid? A step that starts with a known vocabulary and method, yet manages to suggest a new way of inventing, might be one definition. This is also a description that fits the unusual concepts, on view through Oct. 30, in dual exhibitions of mixed-media art by Horace Glenn Lee and Sol Ewen at the Sea Cliff Photograph Company gallery.

title: Hooked or Sunk?
description: When Albert McReynolds of Atlantic City caught a 78 1/2 pound striped bass last month, he landed the all-tackle world record fish. But the $250,000 prize that goes with that honor may be the one that got away.

title: RENEWING AMERICAN CAPITALISM
description: Robert Heilbroner foresees Government officials on corporate boards and corporate access to Government financing.

title: HELPING HANDS FOR PLAYGROUND
description: GLEN COVE AT 5 A.M. Thursday, three adults and two children will arrive at the Landing Elementary School's lower playing field to stake out, with nylon cord and red and blue ribbon, an area approximately 170 by 50 feet.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
CAR POOLS: RULES OF THE ROAD FOR A SUBURBAN RITUAL
description: WE all know her. She was on the phone the last week in June, rounding up participants for the fall car pools to the athletic practices, religious school and music lessons. ''Just getting things in order for next year,'' she told you. ''You know how suddenly September comes around, and I want to make sure you save a place for me!''

title: ARCHITECTURE OF A DIFFERENT COLOR
description: Michael Graves is a 48-year-old native of Indianapolis who has practiced architecture in the shadow of Princeton University for the last 18 years. For most of that time, he attracted little attention beyond architecture's academic salons, where his work has been the subject of interest for at least a decade. In the last few years, however, Graves has burst into a kind of celebrity shared by no other architect of his generation - and, indeed, probably by no other architect practicing today except Philip Johnson, who has been cultivating his own persona since before Graves was even born. Michael Graves's latest building, a 15-story office and municipalservices building for the city of Portland, Ore., has been more eagerly awaited than any new building in the country except perhaps the Johnson and Burgee firm's American Telephone and Telegraph Company headquarters in New York, and it is at least as controversial.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTGEBOUW PLAYS BERLIOZ AT CARNEGIE
description: Threatened by budget cuts at home but carrying on with pride abroad, the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam began a two-concert engagement Friday night at Carnegie Hall, the end of a two-month American tour celebrating the 200th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Netherlands.

title:
DRAMA;
OF 'BLITHE SPIRITS,' 'MICE AND MEN'
description: PRINCETON CHRISTINE BARANSKI should haunt every house. It would do wonders for the real-estate slump. Right now, however, the talented Miss Baranski is sending delightfully hospitable shivers up and down playgoers' spines in the McCarter Theater's production of ''Blithe Spirit.''

title: Betsy Linzer Engaged
description: Betsy Anne Linzer and Garrett Lord Silveira, 1981 graduates of Skidmore College, have become engaged. Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Linzer of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Silveira of Stamford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Michael Sobel Weds Mary Row in Cambridge
description: Mary E. Row, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald V. Row of Lincoln, Mass., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Michael Sobel, son of Dr. Raymond Sobel of Hanover, N.H., and Alma Watson Sobel of New York and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Richard Preston Unsworth, a Presbyterian minister and headmaster of the Northfield Mount Hermon School, performed the ceremony in Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: THE SUBWAY VIEWED AMBIVALENTLY
description: The New York subway has for decades attracted the attention of photographers who find in it, and above all in the people who ride it, some sort of metaphor for the human condition. But never has any photographer covered the New York subway in so grandiose a fashion as Bruce Davidson. There are only 54 die transfer prints in his current exhibition at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street (through Nov. 14). However, they are so large that they fill all three galleries on I.C.P.'s second floor, and because of their size and color they are imposing in a way that the smaller black-and-white photographs of, say, Walker Evans are not.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S TALK
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's announcement yesterday of steps to impose new trade sanctions against Poland, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: EAT WHAT YOU ARE
description: Food for Thought

title: REAGAN HAS QUITE A BIT
description: As joblessness hit a post-Depression high last week, President Reagan traveled the country doing what he could to keep fellow Republicans employed in Congress. He tirelessly blamed Democrats for the conditions that led to 10.1 percent of the workforce being without work, accused them of turning the issue into a ''political football,'' of all things, and then signed a two-year-old, Democratic-sponsored, Carter-endorsed bill that he said would create hundreds of thousands of jobs.

title: The Picture Darkens
description: President Reagan would like the country to read the surge of buying on Wall Street as a sign of economic spring. Unfortunately, it was a foreboding of winter. The stock buyers were not betting on an imminent recovery. They were mostly professionals reacting to the Federal Reserve System's apparent desire to force interest rates lower. That makes stocks relatively more attractive than other investments. Any such decision at the Fed, however, would have to be based on a darkly bearish view of the future.

title: Susan Pearson, Hank Prussing Wed in Brooklyn
description: Susan Pearson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pearson of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Hank Prussing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Prussing of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. George L. Knight and the Rev. Charles J. Scalise performed the ceremony at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, which is decorated with murals painted by the bridegroom.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "America cannot stand idly by in the face of these latest threats of repression and acts of repression by the Polish Government. I am, therefore, today directing steps to bring about the suspension of Poland's most-favored-nation tariff status as quickly as possible." - President Reagan. (16:1.)

title: CONCERT: LUKAS FOSS WORKS PLAYED AT COMPOSER'S FORUM
description: Composers' Forum turned its proceedings over to Lukas Foss Thursday night at Symphony Space. Four of his pieces were played, and in most of them the composer seemed to be showing us how unpleasant our modern mechanistic age can be.

title: Pierce Joins Pistons
description: Ricky Pierce, whose 26.8-point scoring average for Rice was secondbest in the nation last year, has signed a multiyear contract with the Detroit Pistons. They had made the 6-foot-5-inch forward their second choice in the college draft.

title: Pamela Ireland Bride Of Stephen C. Ashby
description: Pamela Ireland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Ireland of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Colin Ashby, son of Sybil Ashby of Toronto and Denis Ashby of Markham, Ontario. Chaplain Kathryn Cook of the Unitarian Fellowship of Northwest Toronto performed the ceremony at The Toronto Hunt.

title: Rep. Railsback to Take Post With Film Makers
description: Representative Tom Railsback, the Illinois Republican who was defeated in a primary this year after 16 years in Congress, has a new job with the motion-picture industry.

title: T.P. Cohan Weds Heather Hayman
description: Heather Marie Hayman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hayman of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Timothy Paul Cohan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Cohan of Weston, Conn. The Rev. John Bednarik performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: Convinced that what Long Island needs is a chamber orchestra featuring musicians who play in other professional orchestras but would like to think ''small,'' the Council for the Arts at Glen Cove is providing a home for the New York Virtuosi. It is a new ensemble founded and led by the conductor Kenneth Klein of Massapequa, the musical director of the Nassau Symphony. Some 30 strong, with many of its members drawn from the New York Philharmonic, the orchestra, backed by a $10,000 grant from the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development and an anonymous donor, makes a debut today at 3 P.M. at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove.

title: THE SPIRITS AND THE AFRICAN BOY
description: AKE The Years of Childhood. By Wole Soyinka. 230 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: SLUMPING TOOL INDUSTRY
description: Machine tool manufacturers are suffering a downturn in their business that is much worse than during the 1974-75 economic recession. The need to modernize factories and improve worker productivity gives tool manufacturers hope for the future.

title: THE PUSH IS ON FOR LEGISLATION
description: WASHINGTON The Reagan Administration intends to push regulatory reform into a new, more ambitious phase next year, one that seeks to change not simply administrative regulations but also the laws that are now on the statute books.

title: CARDS TOP BRAVES, LEAD SERIES BY 2-0
description: The St. Louis Cardinals moved within one game of the National League pennant tonight when they tied the Atlanta Braves in the eighth inning and defeated them in the ninth, 4-3.

title: Mosquitoes, Ecology And Fire Island
description: I may be a lone voice in the wilderness, but I question the use of broad spectrum insecticides such as Dibrom-14 for control of the mosquito nuisance out here on Fire Island, when ecologically safer and more effective alternative methods are available to the overanxious Suffolk County vectors (among them the natural selective biological agent B.I.I.).

title:
BENDIX ET AL -A PERSPECTIVE FROM HARVARD;
THE UNDERMINING OF BUSINESS CREDIBILITY
description: MANY Japanese companies use an approach called ''Asking the five w hy's'' when trying to isolate and remove the causes of defects in t heir products. They begin by identifying the immediate cause of an o bserved defect, then ask why that cause was present, and so work t heir way back to the underlying causes. They understand that the s ame kind of defect will occur again unless these fundamental causes a re eliminated.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Tolerant Fed?

title: HYPERTENSION: LET US NOT DISCARD EFFECTIVE THERAPIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Draft Conviction
description: With the conviction of Mark Schmucker in Cleveland last week, the Justice Department maintained a perfect record of prosecuting men who fail to register for the draft -three wins, no losses, and about a half-million to go.

title: Barbara Boucher Married to Douglas Wells in Rye
description: Barbara Ann Boucher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Philip Boucher of Rye, N.Y., and Hillsboro Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Douglas J. Wells, son of Glenna McCuin of Carthage, N.Y., and Burlington, Vt., and the late Merlin Wells. The Rev. John O'Neill performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: MAJOR BRUSH FIRES RAGE ON COAST, DESTROYING AT LEAST 100 HOMES
description: Two major brush fires fanned by 60-mile-an-hour gusts of wind raged through Southern California today, consuming at least 100 houses and mobile homes. One fire blazed a 20-mile path to the Pacific Ocean.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
AT 73, HE SHAPES OPERA COMPANY
description: PORT WASHINGTON AT the age of 73, when most men's thoughts have turned to retirement, Laszlo Halasz has taken on a new job. The founder and first director of the New York City Opera in 1944, who still conducts leading orchestras and opera companies throughout the world, is at the helm of the Nassau Lyric Opera Company, charged with transforming a regional ensemble that began eight years ago as the Manhasset Bay Opera into a polished, professional operation.

title: Seamus Heaney Wins $12,500 Bennett Award
description: Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet who has taught at the University of California and Harvard University, is the 1982 Bennett Award winner ''in recognition of his distinguished achievement in the art of lyric poetry.''

title: LONG BRANCH STAYS UNBEATEN
description: Dan George, a senior quarterback, ran for a touchdown and returned a punt for another as unbeaten Long Branch (3-0) defeated Raritan, 31-0, yesterday in Long Branch.

title: OHIO CITY, VICTORIOUS IN BID FOR JOBS, IS STILL WARY
description: Through the euphoria over the International Harvester Company's decision to consolidate its truck assembly plant operation here, community leaders are sounding a note of caution.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
TARGET SHOOTING: SPORT FOR THE 'GOOD GUYS'
description: PORT CHESTER ''YOU come here to the range and you see what the gun can do to the target,'' a private investigator was saying. ''No one wants to shoot at a person, except maybe the bad guys -they get carried away sometimes.''

title: LEHRMAN ADDRESSES STATE N.A.A.C.P. CHAPTER
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for Governor, appeared before the New York State Conference of the N.A.A.C.P. today, stressing the need for jobs and urging passage of the death penalty to curb the ''plague of crime,'' especially in the cities.

title: LIFE WITH CANCER: A SURVIVOR'S GUIDE
description: ''I don't want to sound Pollyannaish,'' Natalie Davis Spingarn said as she sat in a sunny, plant-filled room of her town house in Washington's historic Georgetown section. ''I mean, cancer is just not something you advise people that they should go out and get on a summer day.''

title: VICTIM OF FATAL ASSAULT IDENTIFIED AS PROSECUTOR
description: A 31-year-old man who died Friday, eight days after he was assaulted on the Upper East Side, was identified yesterday by the Police Department of Benicia, Calif., as the deputy district attorney of Solano County, northeast of San Francisco.

title: System Down
description: To The Business Editor: When I was shopping for my word processor, I had even more trouble getting the Digital Equipment Corporation's attention than Stanley Klein did in ''Reprogramming at Digital'' (Sept.26).

title: Gen. Raul Madero Gonzalez, Mexican Revolution Figure
description: MEXICO CITY (AP) - Gen. Raul Madero Gonzalez, whose brother proclaimed the Mexican Revolution, died Friday of a respiratory ailment, the El Nacional newspaper reported today.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Designer Togs Plus Imports

title: SWEET COMPULSIONS
description: America, perhaps more than any other nation, has a mania for chocolate in all of its forms. One of these is white chocolate, which is not a true chocolate at all but a blend of whole milk and sugar that is cooked until condensed to an almost solid state. Cocoa butter, which is mechanically pressed out of cocoa beans, is sometimes added to produce the chocolate flavor of white chocolate; otherwise, the flavor is produced artificially.

title: SCHOOLS TRY TO STEM SCIENCE BRAIN-DRAIN
description: CRANFORD THE sixth annual New Jersey Science Convention took place here last week against a backdrop of crisis stemming from the exodus of teachers into higher-paying jobs in industry.

title: Toward Having Water to Burn
description: If the age of fossil fuels is ever to seem as long ago as the age of steam, it may take a pollution-free combustible like hydrogen. There is even more water on Earth than oil in Arabia.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FOR GOOD PUPILS, SPECIAL AWARDS
description: NEW HAVEN BEFORE 1900, when the system of using report cards became common, school teachers found other ways to show their approval and appreciation of star pupils' achievements. For collectors today, the most popular of these has proven to be ''rewards of merit'' - certificates and other mementos given for scholarship and punctuality, and, in one rare early 19th-century case, simply for sitting still and ''being good for two hours.''

title: PITT DEFENSE HOLDING TEAM TOGETHER
description: PITTSBURGH EVEN now, the quarterback is getting all the attention. A photographer from Newsweek was in town last week to take some glossy pinups of Dan Marino, all part of the continuing publicity campaign that began during the preseason when Marino was touted for the Heisman Trophy. Well, trophies have been the last thing on his mind recently. Instead of cheers, Marino has heard some notes of discord on ''The Hill'' where the University of Pittsburgh is situated. There have been rumors about the condition of his right arm and questions about his ability to run the University of Pittsburgh offense. It has been suggested that Marino misses Jackie Sherrill, the former coach, who went to Texas A&M.

title: Land Without TV
description: One of the few country's untouched by broadcast television a year ago was Fiji, and it had become a touchy issue in the Pacific island group.

title: NOVELTY POWERS A SPEAKER
description: The quasi-Faustian quest for the perfect loudspeaker has lately led into strange but promising directions. Innovative emphasis now seems focused on the patterns of sound dispersion, with new approaches to this problem prominent among several recently introduced speaker models.

title: Updating Man's Ancestry
description: Thank you for an interesting and balanced article on ''Updating Man's Ancestry'' (by Jeremy Cherfas and John Gribbin, Aug. 29). It seems that these days the creationists are back in the forefront of the popular press, arguing against evolution and man's descent from more primitive primate forebears. I was pleased to see that Mr. Cherfas and Mr. Gribbin could dismiss this debate with the simple sentence, ''Scientists, of course, no longer doubt that this is so,'' and then move on to present an informative article on some of the real issues facing scientists who study human evolution. ROBERT M. SCHOCH Department of Geology and Geophysics Peabody Museum of Natural History Yale University

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Sayville Sets Back Islip, 40-0
description: Mike Karszen and Tom Silver scored two touchdowns each as undefeated Sayville routed Islip, 40-0, in a League V game. It was Sayville's third victory. Karszen scored on runs of 4 and 25 yards as he rushed for 254 yards on 29 carries. Silver scored on runs of 10 and 4 yards.

title: Susan Orr Becomes Bride
description: Susan M. Orr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Orr of Stratford, Conn., was married yesterday to Cameron Gilchrist, son of Joan S. Tait of Bridgewater, Conn., and John H. Gilchrist of Newtown, Conn. Justice of the Peace Suzanne Steward performed the ceremony at Gatsby's Restaurant in Brookfield, Conn. The bride is a scientific programmer in the systems operations division of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation in Danbury, Conn. Mr. Gilchrist is a computer programmer/analyst with Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford.

title: HOSPICE IS EASING PATIENTS' LAST DAYS
description: JAMES A. BOERST was 39 years old with a business he cherished, a loving wife, two winning children and an irrepressible sense of humor. He also had incurable cancer.

title: NEW BOOK FOCUSES ON WOMEN
description: FOR Lynn Gilbert of New Milford, the opportunity to photograph the sculptor Louise Nevelson for the Pace Gallery in New York started her on a five-year project that resulted in a book, ''Particular Passions,'' written with Gaylen Moore. The book was recently published by Clarkson Potter.

title: WITH THE TABLES TURNED, PALESTINIANS LIVE IN FEAR
description: Two Palestinian men were out on the streets of West Beirut last week watching as the Lebanese Army sealed off their neighborhood with armored cars and conducted house-to-house searches for hidden guns and ''illegal aliens''- primarily Palestinians without proper identity papers. In a city that was virtually ruled by the Palestine Liberation Organization until six weeks ago, the sight of the Lebanese Army herding people about with impunity was novel to say the least. ''Do you think we are going to become like the Palestinians in the West Bank?'' asked one of the men.

title:
DINING OUT;
VIETNAMESE CUISINE IN CHESTER
description: THE old shopping center on Route 24 in Chester is perhaps a more fitting site for a Vietnamese restaurant than its former home in an out-of-the-way country inn in nearby Long Valley.

title: New York Eye-Bank to Honor Head of Advertising Concern
description: The New York Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration will present its first humanitarian award to O. Milton Gossett, the chairman and chief executive officer of Compton Advertising.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ The annual 12-hour gathering of jazz musicians, ''All Nite Soul,'' that first took place at St. Peters Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, in 1970, will be held there for the 13th time Sunday night starting at 5 P.M. It will continue until Monday morning at 5 A.M. by which time it is expected that the audience will have turned over several times and more than 250 musicians and singers will have taken part in the celebration.

title: SECRET TALKS ON N.F.L. STRIKE CANCELED BY A MIX-UP
description: A private meeting between the chief negotiatiors for the National Football League Players Association and the N.F.L. Management Council, arranged by two Harvard professors and scheduled to be held Friday evening in North Andover, Mass., never occurred after Ed Garvey, the executive director of the union, said he was not informed in time of where the meeting was to be held.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS REPORT SOME GAINS IN TALKS ON O.A.U. SPLIT
description: African leaders meeting here with President Francois Mitterrand of France reported some progress today but failed to find a conclusive formula for ending a dispute that has paralyzed the Organization of African Unity.

title: A New Look Outdoors At Monticello
description: Major projects adding to the already powerful allure of Thomas Jefferson's mountaintop estate at Monticello in Virginia are the restoration of the orchard and vegetable garden and the continuing archeological excavation of what was once the estate's manufacturing area.

title: High PCB Level Found In Montana Waterfowl
description: High levels of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, which are suspected of causing cancer, have been found in Montana waterfowl.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
SPRINTING TO THE ENDS OF A BELL-SHAPED CURVE
description: SOMETIMES I feel as if I'm sitting on top of a bell-shaped curve looking through binoculars. Toward one end is my work as a counselor with retarded adults in White Plains. Toward the other end is my life with my two daughters, both of whom have been in talented and gifted programs in New Rochelle.

title: Miss Moran Plans Bridal
description: Kathryn Pharr Moran, a production coordinator with McCaffrey & McCall Inc., a New York advertising agency, and Willem Karel van Aalst, an assistant treasurer with the international department of the Bankers Trust Company, plan to be married Nov. 13. The ceremony will take place in the Most Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in New Orleans.

title: HORN STARS AT SUMMIT
description: Leroy Horn, a junior halfback, scored two touchdowns and ran for 208 yards on 16 carries to send Summit to a 30-0 victory over West Milford yesterday in Summit.

title: Bury the Series
description: To the Business Editor: Recently, the Bureau of Labor Statistics discontinued one of its statistical series called ''real average weekly spendable earnings.'' The wisdom of this decision is brought home forcefully by the way the series is used in the article by David Gordon, ''Prayerful Economics'' (Sept.19).

title: Constance N. O'Brien Wed
description: Constance Nancy O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donal Clare O'Brien Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Bryant Ashforth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., assisted by the Rev. Robert A. Bryant, performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

title: COOPERATION HELPS PUBLISH DANE'S BOOK
description: Klaus Rifbjerg, one of Denmark's most popular and prolific writers, has just had his ''Anna (I) Anna,'' published in the United States by the Curbstone Press, a small house in Willimantic, Conn.

title: Cat and Mouse Off Sweden; the Cat Is Wary Too
description: Something was down there and the Swedish Navy was determined to bring it up. The something, evidently a foreign submarine, appeared equally determined to stay down until it could escape.

title: MUSICIANS TURN TO OTHER CAREERS
description: UNTIL two years ago, Ronald Apperson made his living as a musician, performing with the Hartford Symphony and teaching tuba at a handful of colleges around the state and southern Massachusetts.

title: Injection Exemptions Barred
description: A state law that allowed pupils to be exempted from mandatory inoculation against measles and other childhood diseases for religious reasons has been struck down by the State Court of Appeals. Judge John C. Eldridge, who wrote the court's opinion, issued Tuesday, said the law unconstitutionally mixed government and religion.

title: Oil's Twilight
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Twilight Nears for Age of Oil'' (Aug.29), Douglas Martin presented a fascinating picture of the decline in the growth of world oil demand and OPEC-dominated economic events.

title: REAGAN ORDERING STEP TO CUT TRADE BY POLES WITH U.S.
description: President Reagan, responding to the outlawing of the Solidarity labor union in Poland, announced today that he was going to suspend the favorable trade status that Poland has had for 22 years.

title: NEW SOVIET TACTIC IN A WAR IS SEEN
description: A British specialist on Soviet military affairs says the Soviet high command may be rewriting its operational planning for invading western Europe. The Soviet aim, he says, would be to win any war in Europe in three to four days before commanders of the North Atlantic Organization could obtain approval from political leaders to fire their tactical nuclear weapons.

title: DEVILS RALLY TO TIE AFTER TRAILING, 5-1
description: The New Jersey Devils scored four straight goals tonight and tied Toronto, 5-5, before a sellout crowd of 16,382 at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: CONSUMER RATES

CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR HIRE: TRAINEE W EXPER.
description: WE have a new dog. I swore I would never do it again after our last dog was killed by a car, but a sad-eyed mutt turned up in the arms of an even sadder-eyed child and the combination was irresistible. We are now in the process of trying to train this new family member, to integrate him into our way of life. I use the term ''we'' loosely since the primary responsibility for encouraging acceptable behavior in the house has fallen to me. (What a surprise.)

title: Janet Arfin, Robert Kingan Married in Woodbury, L.I.
description: Janet Arfin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. Arfin of Hillsborough, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert W.I. Kingan, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kingan of Hillsborough, Northern Ireland. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club.

title: STRENGTH AND SIMPLICITY FORGE A FINE NEW RONSTADT ALBUM
description: ''Get Closer'' (Asylum 60185-1), Linda Ronstadt's first studio album in two-and-half-years, contains the strongest rock and roll performances of her career. The increase in her vocal powers since the controversial ''new wave'' album, ''Mad Love,'' bears out the impression Miss Ronstadt made last spring at the Concerts for Nuclear Disarmament, where, for the first time, her rock belting gave no hint of her voice being forced beyond comfortable limits.

title: They Took More Care of Them
description: Rank has its privileges, especially when the rank is Prince and the person holding it is third in line to the British throne.

title: HAMBURG ATTEMPT AT PACT WITH GREENS FAILS
description: The Social Democratic minority government in the city-state of Hamburg said today that it had been unable to reach a working arrangement with the Green Party and that it had agreed with the opposition Christian Democrats to hold new elections in December.

title: Robert Mansfied Marries Robin L. Beil in Manhasset
description: Robin Lynn Beil, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Randall Beil of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Alexander Mansfield, son of Jane Plumer Mansfield of Wayland, Mass., and Bruce Alexander Mansfield of Wellesley, Mass.

title: KOCH SAYS ACCORD COULD FORCE TAX RISE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the contract reached with the uniformed unions could force the city to find new sources of revenue, possibly including increased taxes, and to make further cuts in dayto-day expenses.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Lot of Talk In 1958, David Susskind began his own show ''Open End,'' televised conversations of no predetermined time limit. Over the past 25 years, viewers have seen an estimated 6,500 guests. Now called the ''David Susskind Show,'' it is one of the longest running talk-discussion shows on television. And on Sunday, to begin its 25th season, Mr. Susskind will reminisce from 8 to 10 P.M. on Channel 5 - the show will include clips of past shows and a discussion with his wife, Joyce Susskind.

title: Fair Site Explosive Removed
description: Emergency workers have removed a barrel of flammable and explosive white phosphorus from the construction site of the 1984 World's Fair. Officials said other barrels might be buried on the site, where warehouses had stood for a century.

title: Mallory Blimm Is Bride Of Keith E. Harrington
description: Mallory Gibbs Blimm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Blimm of Federalsburg, Md., was married yesterday to Keith Eaton Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman William Harrington of Oxford, Md. The Rev. George A. Kyle performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Los Angeles Man Found Slain On Road Near Guatemala City
