description: The bullet-riddled body of a 42-year-old Los Angeles man who disappeared a week ago was found Thursday along a rural road 11 miles south of here, the police said last night.

title: BLACK TABLE-DRESSING
description: Black tabletop accouterments have progressed from fads to dinner-party classics. Color trends in home furnishings come and go, but one that appears to have come and stayed is the fashion for black on the dining tabletop.

title:
GARDENING;
MUMS CAN BE YEAR-ROUND FLOWERS
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS, along with turning leaves, pumpkins and apples, have long been a part of the fall scene. If allowed to follow their own inclination, they will flower at just the right time to add their bold colors to those of their autumn surroundings. Over the last 30 years, however, we have learned to accept the mum as a year-round flower, although it is somehow a bit disconcerting to discover mums in bloom in garden centers in August when summer annuals are still flowering in the garden.

title: Thomas M. Rosenthal, Naurene Donelly Wed
description: The marriage of Naurene Margaret Donelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert E. Donelly of Lawrenceville, N.J., to Thomas Mark Rosenthal took place yesterday in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville School. The Rev. Howard M. Fish, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IS GIVEN RECORD $50 MILLION THIS YEAR
description: Columbia University has received more than $50 million from individuals, corporations and foundations this year, the largest one-year gift total in its history.

title: No Headline
description: PENN STOPS BROWN TO LEAD IVY, 24-21

title: UPDATING MAN'S ANCESTRY
description: The article should be read in conjunction with the results of a recent Gallup poll which indicates that 44 percent of the American public believes that ''God created man pretty much in his present form within the last 10,000 years.'' The alarming gulf between the scientific experts and a large fraction of the public could hardly be more strikingly illustrated. JOHN T. EDSALL Professor of Biochemistry Emeritus Harvard University

title: Mind Boggling
description: To the Business Editor: I find it mind boggling, as noted in William Safire's ''The Meddler on The Roof'' (Sept.26), that grown men in this time of a disastrous national and world economy can involve themselves and their resources in something like the Bendix/Marietta et al. imbroglio, and frightening to realize that it is from such men that presidents and other politicians choose advisers. Do they really believe that they are doing serious work?

title: THE BODIES AND SOULS OF AMERICAN MEN
Bruce Mac Nair Weds Catherine Broomfield
description: Catherine Rainy Broomfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Broomfield of Worcester, Mass., was married in a Bahai ceremony at Stonehenge in Ridgefield, Conn., yesterday to Bruce William Mac Nair, son of James D. Mac Nair of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Londonderry, Vt., and the late Shirley Hardenburg Mac Nair. A ceremony performed by the Rev. David W. Pomeroy of the United Church of Christ followed.

title: FRENCH FARE IN A LITTLE HOUSE
description: SEVERAL months ago, Ma Chaumiere opened in a bright, trim little house a short distance from the center of Smithtown. It makes a sincere effort to prepare and serve a varied selection of provincial and classic French dishes, but the results are generally short of satisfactory.

title: WHERE IS THE EARTH GOING-AND HOW QUICKLY?
description: PRINCETON SCIENCE has long known that the earth's orbit around the sun is but one of a hierarchy of motions. What has not been known until recently is the velocity of the earth and whether our world, the solar system and our galaxy - the Milky Way - are moving somewhere independently of their standard orbits.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 1 5 2 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.50.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 1 6 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power.

title: SUHARTO DUE IN U.S. TODAY ON STATE VISIT
description: Indonesian officials hope that the state visit of President Suharto to the United States, due to begin Sunday, will be able to smooth over some of the tensions that have grown over the last year between Washington and Jakarta.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: HOSPITAL CHAPLAIN ASSISTS THE YOUNG
description: When the Rev. George Handzo speaks to his small flock on Sunday mornings, he does not address families seated on oak pews in a Gothic sanctuary. Most of the worshipers who sing, pray and listen to his message are children, and they arrive carrying the medical paraphernalia that accompanies the treatment of cancer.

title: Bag With $35,000 Is Found In Louisville Locker Cleanup
description: The dean of students at Bellarmine College was cleaning junk from lockers when he and the maintenance chief found a paper bag that contained $35,000 in cash.

title: PROPOSED HOUSING FOR THE AGED DIVIDES PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON ECONOMICS and emotions have merged in a dispute over a proposed federally subsidized housing project for the elderly and handicapped in Princeton Borough.

title: U.N. IS LOSING ITS ATTRACTION FOR TOURISTS
description: Tourists wearing everything from kimonos to Bermuda shorts still visit the United Nations, armed with cameras and maps of New York City.

title: Barbara Burns Bride Of Elwyn C. Comstock
description: Barbara Jean Burns and Elwyn Charles Comstock were married in St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Rock, N.J., yesterday. The Rev. George M. Reilly performed the ceremony.

title: BREWERS WIN AND TIE PLAYOFFS
description: The combination was unlikely, but it was deadly as far as the California Angels were concerned. Moose Haas, who had not started in four weeks, and Mark Brouhard, who had not played in four weeks, kept the Milwaukee Brewers alive today, leading them to a 9-5 victory over the California Angels and into a fifth and deciding game of the American League pennant playoff Sunday.

title: HARVARD LAW REVIEW SELECTS MINORITY EDITORS
description: The Harvard Law Review has selected a record number of minority editors in the first year in which an affirmative action plan has been in effect.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART It has a pompous title, ''Women of the Americas: Emerging Perspectives,'' and a rather shapeless theme: ''the variety and excellence of art by contemporary women throughout the Americas.'' But the show of work by 26 women artists, divided between the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue (at 68th St.) and the Kouros Gallery (831 Madison Avenue, at 69th Street) presents an interesting mix.

title: Manchester United Wins and Moves to Top
description: A late goal by Bryan Robson gave Manchester United a 1-0 victory over Stoke today and enabled United to regain the top of the English League First Division soccer standing.

title: JUSTICE FORTAS TO BE SUBJECT OF NEW BOOK
description: Bruce Allen Murphy, the political scientist who earlier this year explored the complex political and social ties between two prominent jurists in his book ''The Brandeis-Frankfurter Connection,'' is about to tackle another Supreme Court notable: the late Abe Fortas.

title: FARMER WINS 25-YEAR FIGHT OVER CAPE ROAD
description: In 1957, Hope Ingersoll began a fight to prevent state officials from running a highway through her family's farmland to help vacationers get to Cape Cod.

title: WHEELCHAIR ATHLETE A WINNER
description: WESTPORT JOHN HUMINSKI remembers how, as a boy, he often would fall down several times while trying to run out a base hit in a baseball game. ''But I'd keep getting up and eventually I'd make it,'' he said. Mr. Huminski fell down even more frequently while playing football with his boyhood friends in Norwalk, but that, too, did not deter him from competing.

title: NIAGARA PAPER CHANGING SCHEDULE
description: With the demise of The Buffalo Courier-Express, which folded on Sept. 19, The Niagara Gazette plans to switch completely to morning publication Nov. 1.

title: CONCERT: JOEL MANDELBAUM
description: Joel Mandelbaum, director of the Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College, presented a program of his own compositions in the Abraham Goodman House Wednesday night. Most of the works were songs or arias, which were sung by Jane Bryden, Constance Beavon, Paul Sperry and Roger Andrews.

title: CHICAGO ARCHBISHOP WILL SEEK OUTSIDE ADVICE ON FINANCES
description: Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin says he will consult outside experts in handling the financial affairs of the Roman Catholic archdiocese of Chicago, the nation's largest.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Paying the Price For Kickbacks
description: Teamster boss John A. Cody had the muscle to halt most construction throughout the metropolitan area, and he did for nearly three months during the summer. That could have been his last power play.

title: BLACK WOMAN ELECTED PHILADELPHIA SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: A spotlight would shine on anyone who took over this city's chronically troubled school district. The glow is especially intense now: The new superintendent is the first black and the first woman to hold the post.

title: Fiji
description: To the Editor: The article ''In Fiji, the Fantasy Is Almost Real'' (Travel, Aug. 1) reminded us of an experience we had on our visit there. v. e stayed at the Fijian, a two-story hotel built around a horseshoe beach.

title: VOGUE WORD WATCH
description: Some words or phrases appear like comets in the evening sky of language; they are watched by lexicographers and are used by speakers who like to be hip, with it and au courant - or, as they would now say, ''on the qui vive.''

title: Lisa A. Repp Has Nuptials
description: Lisa Andrews Repp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Inslee Repp of West Hartford, Conn., and South Pomfret, Vt., was married yesterday to Robert Waterman Seymour, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allyn Seymour, also of West Hartford. The Rev. Donald E. Boyer performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Sports of The Times; Talking Baseball: Dogout Style
description: AS anyone can tell from listening to Tom Lasorda on television between rainouts from St. Louis, the man can talk for hours without a pause - and without provoking the seven-second delay beep back in the studio.

title: AMERICANS ON THE PROWL
description: THE NAMES By Don DeLillo. 339 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: Emily Wood, S. B. Starkey Will Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Edwin Wood 3d of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Battle Wood, to Samuel Borden Starkey, son of Mrs. Austin C. Starkey and the late Mr. Starkey of Gulf Stream, Fla., Princeton and Bay Head, N.J.

title: Mary Loughead Wed to Banker
description: Mary Margaret Loughead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brierley Loughead of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to William Stamford Brenizer, son of Mrs. Marshall Brenizer of Nantucket, Mass., and Dr. Addison G. Brenizer Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. Canon Richard J. Hardman performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: RECITAL: PETER TAKACS PLAYS PIANO
description: Peter Takacs, a Rumanian-born American-raised pianist who teaches at Oberlin but who concertizes regularly, was warmly received at his New York debut recital in 1980 at the Abraham Goodman House. Wednesday night he returned to New York with an often admirable recital at the 92d Street Y.

title: 2 EXPERTS AT RUTGERS ANALYZE ECONOMY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TWO Rutgers University economists who counseled opposing candidates in the last gubernatorial campaign still disagree as to what has caused the economic slump that has left so many people jobless and what should be done to keep the economy moving.

title:
STALKING NATURE'S WONDERS WITH MOVIE CAMERAS INSTEAD OF GUNS;
P.S. Wood writes frequently about the world of nature.
description: Time was when sportsmen certified their love of nature by mounting the stuffed heads of warthogs, kudu and elk on their gunroom walls. Naturalists were gunners, too. The basements of the world's museums of natural history are lined with banks of shallow drawers containing the skins of rare birds and the pelts of small furry animals stretched out in ranks with cotton wool poking through their empty eye holes.

title: Lesley Pryde Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Lesly Anne Pryde, daughter of Dorothy Pryde of Melbourne, Australia, and the late Dr. Anthony Pryde, to John Douglas Haley, a doctoral candidate in molecular biochemistry at theUniversity of Melbourne and son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Haley of New Canaan, Conn.

title: WILL 'CANDIDE' THRIVE IN THE OPERA HOUSE
description: What might be called the second resurrection of ''Candide,'' Leonard Bernstein's frothy, ambitious musical setting of Voltaire, is scheduled to take place Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. If the New York City Opera's resurrection takes place as planned - in other words, if this new version is applauded by the critics and the public - then we may come a little closer to answering the question that has haunted ''Candide'' since its birth: Is it an opera, a musical, an operetta or some as yet unidentified mutation?

title: RESTORING THE FIRST FERRARI
description: SETAUKET THE first automobile constructed under the prestigious Ferrari marque - a 1947 Corsa Spider - is being fully restored at Grand Prix SSR, a Ferrari dealership and restoration shop here on Route 25A. Grand Prix has worked on the car for more than two years, rebuilding the power train, rejuvenating the body and doing all the other operations required for the total reconstruction of a classic motor vehicle.

title: 2 ISSUES DOMINATE ALASKAN CAMPAIGN
description: Political passions aroused by the proposed shift of the state capital from Juneau to a place near Anchorage and charges that state fish and game laws are unfair dominate the Alaska campaign for Governor.

title: MRS. THATCHER FIRM ON HER AUSTERITY POLICIES
description: At the end of the annual Conservative Party conference here, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged on Friday not to waver in her tough economic policies, despite the severe recession and rising unemployment.

title: PUBLIC TV'S IMAGE IN BUDGET SQUEEZE
description: HARTFORD IN the parking lot of a television station on Hartford's New Britain Avenue, representatives of the Connecticut Chevrolet Dealers Association were lining up a group of shiny new automobiles for a commercial the group was about to videotape.

title: A Landlord's Rights
description: Question: I occupy one apartment in a three-family house that I own. The other two are rented; one is rent-controlled, the other was decontrolled in 1976 and its tenant currently has a three-year lease. Upon renewal, am I restricted to the Rent Guidelines Board's percentage increase guidelines, or can I charge what I alone decide is a reasonable increase?...J.H., Brooklyn Answer: Officials of the Rent Guidelines Board and the Conciliation and Appeals Board say that because your building has fewer than six apartments, they are not subject to rent stabilization (although they may remain under rent control, as one is).

title: Marital Discrimination In Insurance Is Charged
description: A Cleveland woman has asked a Federal district court if an insurance company can cancel a woman's automobile policy when she marries a man with a bad driving record.

title: EXPERT FAULTS U.S. ON 50'S ATOM TESTS
description: An eminent physicist has said that as radioactive fallout drifted from atomic bomb testing in the Nevada desert in the 1950's, the protective measures the United States took were substandard and ''not in the spirit'' of what was known as early as the 1940's about the health hazards of radiation.

title: No Headline
description: WALKER SETS MARK IN 33-10 TRIUMPH

title: 'Starch Blocker'; Suit Backfires
description: Though the Food and Drug Administration ordered manufacturers in July to discontinue marketing ''starch blocker'' diet aids, the product has stayed on store shelves. In Chicago last week, it took a Federal court order to sweep the pills away.

title: Money Talks, as Do Candidates
description: Whether or not he gets to reduce taxes for other New Yorkers, Lewis E. Lehrman seems determined to drop himself into a lower income bracket. Financial reports filed last week showed the Republican businessman had so far spent $8.8 million in his campaign for governor - $6.3 million of it from his own pocket - as against $1.67 million for his Democratic opponent, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: FAMILY TRIPS: WHAT PARENTS KNOW
description: WILLIAM E. GEIST is a reporter on the Metropolitan desk of The New York Times.

title: Big Books from Small Firms
description: Americans spent roughly $287 billion on health care last year, according to Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizens Health Research Group, which he and Ralph Nader founded. Mindful of the realities behind this immense expenditure publishers have been commissioning a great many books designed to help the public combat illness and promote well-being. Two titles - ''Pills That Don't Work'' by Dr. Wolfe and his colleagues and ''The Pill Book'' by The Pill Book Co., Inc. - are particularly interesting because they show how large publishers are drawing on new sources of editorial energy and expertise. Politics Fuels a Publishing Program.

title: VOLCKER SUGGESTS FEDERAL RESERVE MAY SHIFT TACTICS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he considered inflation under control and that he now wanted to help try to pull the economy out of the recession.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Ordinarily, one might not feel free to recommend an amateur orchestra one had never heard that chose to present itself in concert at Carnegie Hall. But the Boston Philharmonic, which will perform nothing less than Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony Monday night at Carnegie, is no ordinary amateur orchestra.

title: HONDURAN CHIEF 'TOO BUSY' TO ATTEND PEACE TALKS
description: The Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, has turned down a proposal to meet in Caracas next week with the leaders of Mexico, Venezuela and Nicaragua to discuss the tense situation along the Honduras-Nicaragua border.

title: CONCERTS AND OPERA ADD TO FALL'S ALLURE
description: JUST when the October foliage display entices us into driving around the county on a Sunday afternoon, the Center for Music in Westchester is throwing in an incentive: two free concerts at the John Jay Homestead in Katonah. The fine musicians, all county residents, are the Serafin duo of Jack Katz, violin, and Marsha Cheraskin-Winokur, piano; the Westchester Wind Ensemble, the soprano Berenice Bramson and the pianist R. Clipper Erickson. On the program next Sunday at 3 P.M., the Serafin duo offers sonatas by Beethoven, Prokofiev and Franck. On Oct. 17, there will be quintets for piano and winds by Mozart and Beethoven, and a group of songs with instrumental obligato. New memberships in the center will be accepted, of course, but the concerts are free and open to everyone.

title: Riverdale Beats Horace Mann As Butler Gets 3 Touchdowns
description: Frank Bertino, the Riverdale coach, hurt his back last week and had to wear a brace, but he said he felt no pain after the Indians defeated their local rivals, Horace Mann, 28-12. ''It's amazing how therapeutic a victory can be,'' he remarked.

title: BOLIVIA TRIES A LAST RESORT: DEMOCRACY
description: After nearly 200 Bolivian regimes in 157 years, skepticism was hard to avoid w-n assessing the expectable life span of the elected Government of President Hernan Siles Zuazo, which was scheduled to take office today. But after more than two years of corrupt military dictatorship, most people in this Andean nation were fervently wishing him success.

title: GRIZZLIES SEEN AS IMPERILED IN WYOMING
description: Yellowstone Park officials, finding it increasingly difficult to protect grizzly bears here, say the animals could disappear from the park unless drastic steps are taken.

title: Feldman Earns Praise For Property-Tax View
description: State Senator Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, has struck at the heart of the property-tax issue by assailing the fairness and efficacy of the tax (Opinion Page, Sept. 5). Additionally, there now exists some question as to the ability of the tax to continue financing government services in this era of ''New Federalism.''

title: CONCERT: WASHINGTON SQUARE
description: The Washington Square Contemporary Music Series began its new season with a program in the New York University Theater. To judge from Thursday's concert, the word ''contemporary'' was synonymous with the word ''atonal''; dissonance was the rule.

title: Andrew R. McMurtry Marries Laurie J. Hill
description: Laurie Jean Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence William Hill of Bowie, Md., was married yesterday to Andrew Robert McMurtry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert George McMurtry of New York and Warren, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence Harris performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Upper Marlborough, Md.

title: Vilas and Wilander Gain Clay-Court Event Final
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina and Mats Wilander of Sweden won semifinal matches today in the $175,000 Count of Godo clay-court tennis tournament.

title: SAMPLES OF STITCHERY
description: America Hurrah, the folk-art shop that resembles a displaced ivycovered cottage on Manhattan's Upper East Side, has just opened a mini-exhibition of 20 samplers. The uninitiated will surely walk away from the show impressed by the fact that, though samplers are children's work, they are surprisingly accomplished.

title: Shcharansky's Mother Reports on His Status
description: Ida Milgrom, mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, was reported to have told a friend by telephone from the Soviet Union today that she had been given conflicting pictures of her son's health by Soviet officials.

title: SCHOOL-PRAYER ARTICLE ATTACKED AND LAUDED
description: Betty McCollister has the courage to disclose her true thoughts, and The New York Times has the courage to print them. My heartiest congratulations to both. Mrs. McCollister's thoughts make honest sense. JAMES S.DRAGO Union City

title: Expos and Virdon Close
description: Bill Virdon, who was dropped as manager by the Houston Astros Aug. 10, is surfacing as the leading candidate to replace Jim Fanning as manager of the Montreal Expos. Virdon is expected to be named Tuesday.

title: DId Iacocca Overdo the Comeback Pitch?
description: Whatever the public has thought of Lee A. Iacocca's cheerful assurances of Chrysler Corporation's improving health, Chrysler workers seem to have taken him at his word. With about half the vote in last week, the rank and file appeared to reject the company's latest contract proposal, largely because they believed Chrysler could have offered more.

title: Prisoner Jailed in 3 Killings Charges Violation of Rights
description: The man accused in the deaths by shooting of Courlandt S. Gross, the retired chairman of the board of the Lockheed Corporation, Mr. Gross's wife and their housekeeper, has filed a complaint in Federal district court charging that his rights have been violated in prison.

title: SPOT BUILDER IS TREADING WATER
description: TO make his point, Morris Gartenstein reached into the animal world.' 'It's like you're holding a tiger by the tail,'' he said. ''You c an't let it go and you can't pull it back.''

title: HERZOG'S 'FITZCARRALDO,' A SPECTACLE
description: Forget everything you've heard so far about Werner Herzog's ''Fitzcarraldo,'' which brings the 20th New York Film Festival to a metaphysically rowdy, upbeat end tonight at Lincoln Center. The film will be shown in Avery Fisher Hall at 8:30 and will open its regular commercial engagement tomorrow at the Paris Theater.

title: No Headline
description: NORTHWESTERN TOPS MINNESOTA

title: OFFBEAT MUSIC THRIVES IN LOFT SETTINGS
description: James Staley has found a novel way to make use of the living room of his downtown loft: he puts on concerts. Fifty or 60 evenings every season, Mr. Staley tidies up his cluttered, comfortable dwelling, puts out some folding chairs and creates Roulette, a makeshift performance space. It's a home-grown operation and very friendly. For a time, concertgoers were greeted with complimentary wine and crackers - and Roulette, at 228 West Broadway, has quickly established itself as an attractive place to encounter offbeat and experimental music.

title: Replacement Costs For Power Clarified
description: This is to correct a serious error in the Sept. 5 article, ''Accord on Utility Is Called Illusory.'' While it is true that the GPU Service Corporation has estimated that it will cost $760 million (actually more than $1 billion when adjusted for inflation) to clean up the damaged reactor at Three Mile Island, replacement power costs for Jersey Central Power & Light Company customers are nowhere near the $500 million mentioned in the article.

title: THE MARKET RALLIES, AGAIN
description: With unemployment still rising, the stubborn stock market rally that began in August escalated last week and the bond market strengthened as investors anticipated lower interest rates.

title: MONTAUK WORRIED BY LAKE POLLUTION
description: ON a clear day the sun shimmers across the surface of Lake Montauk, giving the cool, dark blue water a clean, nearly transparent quality that belies the fact that the once pristine lake is now polluted by human waste.

title: 2 Falkland Soldiers Win Top British Valor Award
description: Two British soldiers killed while storming Argentine positions in the Falkland Islands conflict last spring have been awarded Britain's highest decoration for military valor, the Victoria Cross.

title: THE PLAYERS ARE THREATENING THE SYSTEM
description: AS both a retired National Football League player and a businessman, I can view the football strike with some knowledge of both sides.

title: Air Traffic Sequel
description: The once-mighty Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization was in shreds, its nationwide strike crushed, when Robert E. Poli, its president, resigned Dec. 31, 1981. By then, 11,500 Patco members had been dismissed by the Government, and the union, no longer a bargaining agent, was bankrupt.

title: BIGSBY PACES E. ORANGE
description: Bill Bigsby, the quarterback, ran for a touchdown and set up another with a long pass as East Orange handed Columbia its first loss, 13-12, yesterday in East Orange.

title:
GARDENING;
MUMS CAN BE YEAR-ROUND FLOWERS
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS, along with turning leaves, pumpkins and apples, have long been a part of the fall scene. If allowed to follow their own inclination, they will flower at just the right time to add their bold colors to those of their autumn surroundings. Over the last 30 years, however, we have learned to accept the mum as a year-round flower, although it is somehow a bit disconcerting to discover mums in bloom in garden centers in August when summer annuals are still flowering in the garden.

title: A CONFLICT OF MOTHERS
description: MY mother and I have known each other for almost 35 years. Our relationship had always been strictly mother-daughter; friendship was left for friends. Discussions concerning children, cleaning or family catastrophes were within bounds; talks about husbands, sex or true feelings were not.

title: COVER STORY
description: During the late 19th and early 20th centuries technological advances in color printing and experiments with Art Nouveau and Art Deco fostered the golden age of magazine design in the United States and Europe. Scores of well-produced magazines - many adorned with exquisite covers by painters and illustrators - flooded the marketplace. Vanity Fair, Fortune and The New Yorker are usually singled out for their consistently striking covers by celebrated artists, among them John Held Jr., Miguel Covarrubias and Paolo Garretto. The covers of other, more mainstream periodicals, such as Good Housekeeping, Delineator, Collier's and Ladies' Home Journal, to name a few, were often intriguing, stylized paintings by leading illustrators. By today's standards, these covers had only a minimum of typography to interfere with the integrity of the art; their purpose was more esthetic than commercial. At this time many cultural, satirical and political journals with relatively small circulations were also being published, particularly in Germany and France. Their covers employed innovative typographical designs and illustrational approaches, reflecting the graphic concerns of the avant-garde and the contributions of such painters as Juan Gris, George Grosz, Salvador Dali, Joan Miro and Fernand Leger.

title: THE BEST WORLD SERIES GAMES? TAKE THESE THREE
description: THE most memorable World Series game of our time? Nostalgia, Martin Ragaway has said, is little more than an exercise in grammar: One finds the present tense and the past perfect. Berra and Cosell notwithstanding, that makes baseball a grammarian's paradise.

title: STUDENTS PLAN GREENVALE RENAISSANCE
description: GREENVALE MOST motorists, waiting impatiently in heavy traffic for the light to change at the intersection of Northern Boulevard and Glen Cove Road, know very little about the community they are passing through. Known a century ago as Bull's Head and later as North Roslyn, Greenvale is an unincorporated section of the Town of North Hempstead, an area of modest one-family houses with a residential population of about 1,000.

title: COLLEGE TIGHTENS ITS BEHAVIOR CODE
description: The State University of New York at Stony Brook is cracking down on violators of its student conduct code by enforcing long-neglected prohibitions against smoking marijuana in public places, drinking by minors and parties that violate the school's curfews.

title: Don Shewey writes frequently about the theater.
description: When he was a teen-ager, Ulu Grosbard worked as a diamond-cutter, whose job is the first step in the process of turning a raw stone into a precious jewel. As a director, he likes to work the same way, finding a new play and being the first to give the gem inside a chance to shine. Mr. Grosbard has been in on the making of ''The Wake of Jamey Foster'' since it was an unfinished first draft in the typewriter of Beth Henley, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Crimes of the Heart.'' And when the play opens Thursday at the Eugene O'Neill, Mr. Grosbard will have spent the better part of two years almost exclusively devoted to ''Jamey Foster'' as director and co-producer.

title: POLICY IN PARALYSIS
description: Maybe the $50,000 Einstein Prize will reopen public debate on the proposal by four American security experts that Washington move toward a policy of no-first-use of nuclear weapons. Such debate is vitally needed because, without it, a government paralyzed by inherited policy cannot give this controversial idea the serious consideration it deserves.

title: SOLO PERFORMANCE POWER
description: The solo dance concert, as everyone knows, is the most difficult theatrical presentation for any dancer to sustain. It is no surprise that solo concerts are far and few between. In dance history, traces are left by only the most charismatic -Isadora Duncan, Anna Pavlova, to name the most obvious. The footprints of lesser solo dancers leave no mark once their time is gone. There is no company to recall their name. The choreography itself seldom become sufficiently unglued from their bodies to be passed on.

title: Isola's Passing Excels
description: Frank Isola completed six of seven passes for 220 yards and five touchdowns, including three to Lane Lehrhoff, to lead Lawrence to a 44-0 victory over Port Washington in an American League Conference I-B game. It was the third victory of the season for undefeated Lawrence. Port Washington is winless in three games.

title: A ROUNDTABLE: CRIME IN THE SUBURBS
description: The affluence, privacy and proximity to the city that draw so many residents to New York's suburbs also seem to be luring an increasing number of those who prey on them. Between 1970 and 1980, burglaries and robberies rose more than 100 percent in 30 Nassau communities, officials say, and other counties report similar surges. But if bigcity crime has come to the suburbs, are the many small, independent police departments able to keep up? Last week, three experts discussed suburban crime with Richard Levine, an editor of The Week in Review, and James Barron, a metropolitan reporter for The Times who covers Long Island. Excerpts follow.

title: Reagan Reschedules Address on Economy
description: President Reagan will address the country Wednesday on the economy after reports of the highest unemployment in four decades, the deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said today.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: In the James A. Michener tradition of ''Chesapeake,'' ''Centennial'' and ''Covenant,'' his new novel, ''Space,'' takes its place, surely and quickly, at the top of the hard-cover fiction list. In another, equally remarkable tradition, Jim Davis's most recent Garfield book - ''Garfield Takes the Cake'' - makes its debut on the trade paperback list, and in first place.

title: WEST VA. DEFEATS BOSTON COLLEGE
description: For the first time since he became the starter as a freshman nearly a year ago to the day, Doug Flutie looked more like his teammates' kid brother on the football field today rather than the elusive quarterback whose scrambling style had frustrated opposing defenses.

title: BELLEVILLE STOPS CLIFTON BY 37-0
description: Mike Murphy, a junior fullback, ran for 207 yards on 23 carries and scored three touchdowns to guide Belleville to a 37-0 defeat of Clifton in Clifton.

title: Senate Workers to be Heard
description: Charges by Senate restaurant workers that they are being denied the right to form a union will be taken up by the International Labor Organization when it meets next month in Geneva, Stu Smith, executive director of the Capitol Employees Organizing Group, said Wednesday. He said the labor group would be asked to investigate the Senate's failure to act on his group's petition for recognition as the bargaining agent for the 200 workers.

title: CHICAGO SEARCHES FOR A NEW THEME SONG, BUT MINUS SWING
description: It began last May, at the conclusion of a luncheon in Armed Forces Week. The generals lined up and marched smartly down the aisle as military anthems blared. Then it was Alderman Louis Farina's turn. The band struck up ''My Kind of Town'' and the stiffness of the audience gave way to toe-tapping and swaying.

title: THE BEST RIGHT STUFF
description: THE PURPLE DECADES A Reader. By Tom Wolfe. Introduction by Joe David Bellamy. Illustrated. 396 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.50.

title: FORMER MINISTER IN IRAN FINDS PEACE RUNNING DALLAS BAKERY
description: Dr. Manoucher Ganji believes he and his family have received a wonderful gift in their new land: anonymity. Mr. Ganji, 51 years old, once Minister of Education in the Iranian Government, fled his homeland on foot in the turmoil after the overthrow of Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi. Four years have passed since then, and Americans' interest in events in Iran has dwindled.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Is it possible to join an organized trip across the Sahara by camel? If so, to whom do I write? -H.P., Gardiner, Maine Answer:Mountain Travel (1398 Solano Avenue, Albany, Calif. 94706-1892; 415-527-8100) is a tour operator that offers such a trip; their ''Sahara Camel Expedition'' takes 15 people through the Hoggar Mountains of Algeria by camel and on foot. Touareg nomads serve as guides to the group who pass through a region containing rock carvings, paintings and archeological remains as well as geological sites such as basalt gorges, volcanic spires and erosion-carved river beds. The 19-day trip is scheduled twice a year, in late October and again in late January. Land arrangements cost about $2,000 a person; air fare is extra.

title: No Headline
description: LEVI'S 68 PUTS HIM 4 AHEAD

title: THE EMPTY SUCCESS OF HERR ZURN
description: THE SWAN VILLA By Martin Walser. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 247 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: Bronx Virtues To the Editor:$
description: It is refreshing to read an upbeat, optimistic article (Sept. 12) describing the fine attractions Pelham Parkway offers as a place to live.

title: HE LIKES TO WRITE AND LIKES TO COOK
description: A FEAST MADE FOR LAUGHTER A Memoir with Recipes. By Craig Claiborne. Illustrated. 414 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: AFTER TEANECK, MORE BATTLES ARE LIKELY
description: While the settlement of Teaneck's 19-day teacher strike last week solves a short-term problem, it also underlines the difficulties of financing public school systems in New Jersey. The state ranks third in the country in the amount of money spent on each of its public school students, but the manner in which the money is generated and distributed to school districts has been an ongoing source of controversy.

title: JERSEYANS CUT VACATIONS, BUT SHORE BECKONS
description: New Jerseyans are taking fewer long vacations, but they still think it's a treat to go to the Atlantic shore, the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University reported.

title: SNAGS SEEN IN PLAN TO DISARM BEIRUT
description: A demilitarization plan for East Beirut has been postponed pending completion of the Lebanese Army's sweep of West Beirut, Lebanese newspapers and Government sources reported today.

title:
ART;
ETCHINGS THAT FASCINATE
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR FOR the connoisseur and the layman alike, the etchings of John Taylor Arms (1887-1953) hold an almost obsessive fascination. One cannot fail to marvel at the brilliance of his technique, at his surpassing skill in rendering light and shadow, mass and detail, tone and nuance. Even the casual observer will find himself captivated, as was the artist himself, by the craftsmanship that he lavished on even the slightest of his creations.

title: LAY CATHOLIC EDITORS ENJOY PAPERS' FREEDOM
description: Catholic New York, the official newspaper of the Archdiocese of New York, has begun its second year of publication. In a year rife with stories about the death of newspapers, its editor, Gerald Costello, counts his blessings and the paper's growing number of subscribers.

title: L.I. HOMES STAR IN TV MOVIES
description: AS a rule, the custom of taking home movies involves gathering the family and whoever else happens to be nearby for the purposes of recording ordinary domestic scenes in formal family rituals. But for Laura Sommer of Oyster Bay, the practice has taken on another dimension. Her ''home movies'' have starred such celebrities as Bette Davis and Maureen Stapleton.

title: APARTHEID CALLED HERESY BY CHURCH
description: Just as the power-wielders who speak in the name of Afrikaners, the dominant white group, were getting set this week to start building their bridge to the people of mixed race, a tremor was felt here that seemed to leave the chasm between the two groups wider than ever.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATS ARMY
description: Rutgers came to Giants Stadium today with more skills than the Army team could handle, and the Scarlet pounded out a 24-3 victory before a crowd of 28,431.

title: CRAFTS
description: MONTCLAIR A well-rounded collection of works by about 20 artists has been assembled at Dexterity Ltd. for a show entitled ''Breakthroughs in Glass - New American Glass Art.''

title: M. D. Reed Weds JoAnn McGovern
description: JoAnn Catherine McGovern, daughter of Joseph A. McGovern of Stoneham, Mass., and Kennebunkport, Me., and the late Elaine McCaffrey Mc-Govern, was married yesterday to Michael Dimitri Reed, son of Adrian Reed of Centreville, Md., and Mrs. Keith Wellin of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Leonard Coppenrath performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, Mass.

title: THE HOLOCAUST IS A NEW CHALLENGE FOR A SHAKESPEARE STAR
description: LONDON When Alan Howard opens at Broadway's Booth Theater on Wednesday in the Royal Shakespeare Company production of ''Good,'' he will display not the operatic bravado with which he swashbuckled through nine of Shakespeare's kings and princes in six years, but an evening-long series of myopic blinks and uncertain smiles, the tentative tics of a mild-mannered academic.

title: Floyd Does It Again
description: When Ray Floyd finished the second round in the $350,000 LaJet Golf Classic in Abilene, Tex., with a score of 146 Friday, he figured that he had missed the cut for the final two rounds. But after flying home to Miami, he learned that he was eligible to play the final rounds.

title: SOUTH BRONX NEIGHBORS HOLD DEVASTATION AT BAY
description: There are many times when Beck Street is so quiet you can hear the wind in the maples. ''I was looking for a nice place with a country-like atmosphere,'' recalled Ann Wiggins, standing before the 82-year-old house on Beck Street that has been her home since 1946. ''I found this - with trees along the street. I love this area. There was no reason to run.''

title: FLORIDA ACTS TO GUARD OYSTERS
description: In a move designed to save one of the state's most important commercial oyster beds, the Florida Department of Natural Resources has purchased 75 acres of prime real estate on St. George Island in Apalachicola Bay for $1.1 million.

title: NO MORE BRAVADO
description: ''I believe that the current world chess title series too will end up in a victory for Anatoly Karpov,'' says a quotation in the September issue of the British Chess Magazine attributed to the 19-year-old Soviet grandmaster Gari Kasparov.

title: SIX HEARTS FROM A TO Z
description: If a bridge historian were offered a time machine capable of making three stops he would surely use it to solve some mysteries. He would start by sitting in on Vanderbilt's famous cruise through the Panama Canal in 1925, and he would find the name of the mysterious young woman who intruded into the men's foursome experimenting with ''a new game'' and suggested the word ''vulnerable'' to represent a partnership that was a game to the good. Vanderbilt and his friends could never remember her name. The last male survivor of this group was Francis Bacon III, who died recently in New York, but the intruder might still be alive.

title: Life Term at 15
description: ''I have no alternative,'' the judge said. ''I have to protect society.'' And so last Feb. 8 Judge Robert E. Hodnette in Circuit Court in Mobile, Ala., sentenced 15-year-old John Anthony Cruse to life in prison.

title: Demonstration Proves Fatal
description: An official of a company that makes security equipment was stabbed to death by a friend Friday as he was demonstrating a bulletproof vest. Lieut. Tom Mundy of the police said that Mark Wagstaff, 30 years old, co-owner of Wagstaff Enterprises, put on the vest at a breakfast meeting of the Pyramid Club and asked the friend, Jim Shepherd, to try to stab him in the chest. The first attempt failed but not the second, the police said. Mr. Shepherd was described as ''in extreme shock.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT is a Friday afternoon on the Long Island Expressway and I am driving west, which means that I can give a 40-mile-an-hour smirk to all the people who thought they'd get an early start on the weekend and wound up clogging the eastbound lanes.

title: PARTY STAKES GROW IN DARING RIVALRY
description: THE fight for the United States Senate between Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Toby Moffett, which was viewed at the outset as a race between two liberals, is becoming a more clear-cut contest between a Democrat and a Republican. As the debates of the Senate candidates have unfolded, Mr. Weicker, the two-term Republican incumbent, has sought to position himself as the man in the political middle, under attack by both the Democrats and the conservatives.

title: FIJI
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article on Fiji, I would say Fiji is pure, unadulterated fantasy come true. It is the South Sea island paradise that one saw on the silver screen so many times.

title: Chinese Wins Title
description: Guo Yuehua of China, the defending world champion, captured the third World Cup table tennis title today, defeating the European champion, Mikael Appelgren of Sweden, 22-20, 21-5, 21-9.

title: CAN'T THEY DO BETTER BY COLLEEN DEWHURST?
description: The next time I see Colleen Dewhurst I want to see her with her hair combed. I know perfectly well that this is going to be hard to arrange. Directors like to cast Miss Dewhurst in parts that call for her to look as though she'd just clawed her way through a rain forest -and while it was raining. In the current production of Ugo Betti's ''The Queen and the Rebels,'' director Waris Hussein has even got her slathering cold cream all over her face and the creaming is supposed to constitute an improvement. While slathering, Miss Dewhurst is heard to murmur something about keeping up appearances. Actually, her appearance suggests she is about to swim the English Channel. Why are directors so fond of Dewhurst en dishabille? Obviously because the spectacle provides them with such wonderful contrasts.

title: CHAFEE FAVORED IN RACE WITH STRONG CHALLENGER
description: The tall ships are at anchor now, bobbing gently in the shimmering water, and most of the tourists have long since returned home. But an occasional sloop comes into view, its sails billowing in the autumn breeze, and the elegant shops on Thames Street continue to attract off-season vacationers.

title: NASSAU POLICE LAG IN HIRING
description: FACED with a budget squeeze and court-ordered hiring quotas, the Nassau County Police Department finds itself sharply limited in its efforts to hire new recruits. It has been seven months since a Federal judge ended a court-ordered hiring freeze and approved a proposal to ''immediately hire'' 150 new police officers. But so far the county has been able to hire only 33 new recruits. The task of hiring the remaining 117 has turned out to be far more difficult than county officials had anticipated.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WOMEN'S CREDIT UNION DOES MORE THAN SURVIVE
description: WHEN the Westchester Women's Federal Credit Union opened its doors in January 1977, it did so amid a nationwide movement to establish separate financial institutions for women, to counter what its founders regarded as discrimination by male-dominated commercial-banking institutions.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: Alexandria Revisited

title: GETTING AROUND THE CLAUSE
description: ABILL to resolve the controversy over the due-on-sale clause has b een agreed upon by a joint Senate-House conference committee and it i s a measure to make lenders rejoice while buyers and sellers weep. T he legislation would in a few years give lenders the unquestioned a uthority to enforce the clause.

title: HOW TO FASTEN WINDOWS TO HELP FOIL A BREAK-IN
description: ALTHOUGH every security-conscious homeowner will have good-quality locks installed on all outside doors in the front, back or side of the house, many do not give the same amount of attention to the windows - particularly first-floor windows along the sides and back of the house, where a break-in is most likely to occur.

title: Lydie Denise Szabo Wed to Jeffrey Thomas Brown
description: Lydie Denise Szabo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Szabo of Berwick, Pa., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Delmont D. Brown of North Baltimore, Ohio. The Rev. Norman J. Catir performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner.)

title: TWO CHAIRMEN UNDER FIRE
description: For a while, it seemed that two of the regulatory agency chairmen named by President Reagan, Mark S. Fowler at the Federal Communications Commission and Reese H. Taylor Jr. at the Interstate Commerce Commission, were something less than what was called for under the President's commitment to deregulation.

title: American League 300 or more turns at bat
China Accuses Reagan On Taiwan Accord
description: China accused President Reagan today of violating the terms of the recent Chinese-American communique on Taiwan by making China's peaceful reunification a prerequisite for ending arms sales to the Nationalist-ruled island.

title: STATE'S CORRECTION HEAD ATTACKS PRISON STUDY
description: New York State's Correction Commissioner has disputed a new study by an independent group, saying it was trying to stir discontent among inmates in an effort to change the state's prison system.

title: WHat He Really Did in The War
description: He lied to American immigration officials 32 years ago to win an entry visa. He lied about his Nazi sympathies during World War II, about his role in bloody riots in Bucharest in which hundreds of Christians and Jews died.

title: SEARCH FOR THE TYLENOL KILLER: MANY CLUES, BUT NO SOLUTION
description: It is a simple yellow brick building on a busy road next to a noisy carwash. There is a small patch of grass near a large patch of pavement and a bundle of trees turning bright fall colors.

title: HEART STUDY LED TO CHANGES IN LIFE STYLE
description: SEVEN years ago, at the age of 43, Dr. Robert J. Adams learned that his chances for suffering a heart attack were higher than usual for a man his age.

title: SETTING GOALS AT STOCK EXCHANGE
description: JOHN J. PHELAN JR. of Locust Valley, who spent 47 of his 51 years as a resident of Garden City, remembers vividly the summer when he was 16. That was when he worked for his father, a Wall Street stockbroker.

title: ANNA FREUD, PSYCHOANALYST, DIES IN LONDON AT 86
description: Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud and an eminent psychoanalyst in her own right, died at her London home today at the age of 86, her family said. ---- Focused on Child Analysis

title: Cordoba Leather
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE POETS
INQUIRY SET ON ROLE OF PUBLIC ADVOCATE
description: ALFRED NARDELLI, dismissed by the state's Public Advocate for publicly opposing a cost-containment agreement for the Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant, said last week he had put his job on the line because Joseph Rodriguez, the Public Advocate, wanted him ''to play ball with the Governor.''

title: LIGHTHOUSE KEEPERS ON WANE
description: EVERY Tuesday, two young Coast Guardsmen leave Sandy Hook aboard a 41-foot boat and head for West Bank Lighthouse in Lower New York Bay. They are among the few remaining links with a romantic past, for, of the 385 lighthouses maintained by the Coast Guard, only 52 still have keepers. The rest are automated.

title: Crash Victims Rescued
description: Two men who clung to seat cushions for two days after their small plane crashed in the Atlantic were rescued Friday. James L. Wright, 39 years old, and Bruce McDonald, 25, both of St. Simon's, Ga., suffered fish bites, jellyfish stings, sunburn and dehydration while they were adrift. A spokesman at Fishermen's Hospital here said the men were doing ''very well.''

title: TIMES
description: IN running down the roster of members of one of Long Island's most influential law firms, the word ''former'' comes up again and again. If what you were has anything to do with what you are, then the titles that follow the word ''former'' give an indication of why this law firm - Suozzi, English & Cianciulli - is considered to have such political and legal weight.

title: USING THE WORLD AS HIS PULPIT
description: On a Monday morning not long ago, Pope John Paul II awakened at 5 A.M., as he customarily does, to begin his daily period of private devotions and preparation for his regularly scheduled 7 o'clock mass in the small but resplendent papal chapel in the inner reaches of the Vatican.

title: MODERNIZING BACH'S KEYBOARD MUSIC
description: With the ''authenticity'' movement now so normal to our musical life, we are becoming a little less pompous about stylistic rectitude and period instruments. The uses of the past and the needs of the present seem, for the moment at least, not particularly a matter of good versus evil or one esthetic enclave against the other. Both camps seem assured of continued life and health, so the current concerns in performance practice have turned less to the ''how'' and more to the ''how well.''

title: FOUR MARSHES ALONG HUDSON RIVER TO BE NAMED A FEDERAL SANCTUARY
description: Four marshes along the Hudson River will be formally designated as a Federal estuarine sanctuary on Tuesday, protecting them from change and making Federal funds available to New York to conduct scientific and educational programs there.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AFTER 10 years in Bristol, the grass suddenly looked a lot greener in a number of other cities, particularly Hartford, for the Bristol Red Sox of the Eastern League late last summer. But then a projected move to the capital city fell through when the Hartford City Council balked at approving funds for the renovation of Dillon Stadium.

title: N. DAKOTA SENATOR APPLIES LESSONS LEARNED IN 1980
description: Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, is probably the only 74-year-old lawmaker running for re-election this year who has challenged somebody to a fist fight.

title: STATION MOVES TO 'WEE HOURS'
description: ''THE people we play, the minstrels of the night, sound better in the wee, small hours,'' William O'Shaugnessey said. ''They sound better after midnight.''

title: HEINRICH VON KLEIST COULD NOT LAST
description: NO PLACE ON EARTH By Christa Wolf. Translated by Jan van Heurck. 130 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: FOUR INCUMBENTS DEFENDING SEATS IN THE ASSEMBLY
description: WHEN the Democratic-controlled Assembly devised its original reapportionment plan last spring, Republicans charged that it was designed to increase Democratic representation in that house. That plan, however, was rejected by the United States Justice Department. The one ultimately approved by the State Legislature last July is still likely to enhance Democratic strength in the Assembly, but it will not do so at the expense of the Republican Party in the county, according to many local legislators.

title: ITALY REVISITED
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORTAGE OF CIGARETTES IS PLAGUING EGYPTIANS
description: Egyptians seem to have a nearly insatiable appetite for tobacco and tobacco products. While cigarette consumption in many Western countries has declined amid concern about the damaging health effects associated with smoking, it increases here at a rate of nearly 8 percent a year, according to Government studies.

title: No Headline
description: WASHINGTON PASSES BEAT CALIFORNIA, 50-7

title: Signs of State In Lebanon
description: In Beirut last week, the clatter of reconstruction and the shouts of street vendors replaced the cacophony of war. With French and Italian troops sealing off neighborhoods, the Lebanese Army swept through Moslem West Beirut, detaining hundreds of people who lacked residence documents, mainly Palestinians, destroying Moslem shantytowns and uncovering 200 tons of weapons in a warren of underground escape tunnels leading to refugee camps south of the city. (American marines were stationed at the airport.)

title: RANGERS DEFEAT PENGUINS
description: Assertive goaltending by Steve Weeks and clever scoring by the top three forward lines gave the Rangers their first victory of the season tonight, a 5-3 triumph over the Penguins.

title: Prosecutor Withdraws In Rep. Deckard's Case
description: A prosecutor has filed a petition to withdraw from an investigation into a traffic accident involving Representative H. Joel Deckard, Republican of Indiana.

title: ROUNDUP OF THE USUAL SUSPECTS
description: WHENEVER I think about how I started writing, I quickly focus upon the house I lived in from the age of roughly 7 to the time, less than a decade later, I was sent off to boarding school. ''To the manor born,'' not ''manner,'' is how I always thought Hamlet's phrase was written - thus shifting the emphasis to heritage, the silver spoon, and away from heredity, the shiver of sperm. The house still stands, a Southern-colonial affair, red brick, white pillars and close to an acre of lawns and eclectic gardens: a vine with figs; a cork tree; a tree that bloomed with hard, pink berries, like French peppercorns; a eucalyptus, whose long leaves moved like canoes across the surface of the pool. California. When we bought the house - from the actress Mary Astor - there were lemon groves on three sides, stretching for blocks. The air, of course, smelled lemony and even looked gilded with reflected light. The neighborhood kids would help pick the fruit, at least from the lower branches, and pack the harvest into wooden crates that sprang up overnight at curbside in front of the mansions. We used to bite holes in the skin and suck out the juice and pulp, licking our wrists for salt. The groves were cut down a few years after we arrived, and the polo fields, which we could see from the edge of the cliff across San Remo Drive, were subdivided not long after.

title:
GARDENING;
MUMS CAN BE YEAR-ROUND FLOWERS
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS, along with turning leaves, pumpkins and apples, have long been a part of the fall scene. If allowed to follow their own inclination, they will flower at just the right time to add their bold colors to those of their autumn surroundings. Over the last 30 years, however, we have learned to accept the mum as a year-round flower, although it is somehow a bit disconcerting to discover mums in bloom in garden centers in August when summer annuals are still flowering in the garden.

title: ALABAMA TOPPLES PENN STATE BY 42-21
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant and his Alabama football team continued their mastery over Penn State teams coached by Joe Paterno today, as the Tide broke open a close game in the last five minutes on a strange kicking play and won, 42-21.

title: SCHOOL-PRAYER ARTICLE ATTACKED AND LAUDED
description: I want to compliment Betty McCollister about her piece on the issue of prayer in the schools. It is one of the most moving and thoughtprovoking - and, let me say, convincing - presentations of the problem I have ever read. It should be broadcast widely. LLOYD B.WESTCOTT Rosemont

title: THE FOOD IS SIMPLE, BUT PLEASING
description: DANBURY IN this era of slick, quick, formula-and-theme restaurants, it is comforting to come across a modest eatery that is as homey and oldfashioned as Strawberry Place on Route 7 just south of Danbury.

title: UNION COALITION AND CITY REACH CONTRACT ACCORD
description: New York City and its uniformed forces yesterday reached a tentative agreement on a new two-year contract that provides wage increases of 16 percent and other improvements for 35,000 police officers, firefighters and correction officers.

title: THE HOST GUARDS
description: You'll be able to see a mariner in distress being hoisted to safety by helicopter, tour a 180-foot buoy tender and inspect the recruit training center at the Cape May Coast Guard base -all as part of an open house at the base tomorrow (there's no school - it's Columbus Day) from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.

title: STRONG U.S. SECURITIES
description: Foreign demand for Treasury securities has been very strong this year, contrary to some predictions that sagging oil prices and reduced oil surpluses among OPEC nations would mean less foreign buying. The strong demand from foreigners is one reason why domestic interest rates have been able to decline, despite record large borrowings by the Treasury.

Although planting tulips successfully is child's play, they require the patience of an adult because they do not fulfill our need for instant gratification. The onionlike bulbs set in the ground now will not bloom until spring.

title: CATALOGUE IS FULL OF CRAFTS TO ORDER
description: CONNECTICUT craftsmen are broadening their horizons. In addition to marketing their work at local and out-of-state fairs, some of them have gone into the mail-order business through the Goodfellow Catalogue of Wonderful Things No. 3.

title: MILTON AVERY: PAINTINGS ON PAPER AT THE WHITNEY
description: STAMFORD THE show ''Milton Avery on Paper,'' at the Whitney Museum (1 Champion Plaza) falls short of being a centennial by three years. This seems exactly right for an artist whose true age has only just been discovered - he lived from 1885 to 1965 - and whose work isn't easily categorized.

title: SONNY MAE MORTGAGES IN THE HOPPER
description: ABOUT 300 Westchester and Rockland County home buyers will obtain fixed rate, 25- to 30-year, m ortgages at 13 5/8 percent interest by the end of the month, and 15 m ore will get similar loans within a year. But first, they have to f ind moderate priced houses - and that, apparently, isn't easy. The money is available regardless of income through a special state program that provides loans at about 2 percentage points below the present normal commercial interest rate. Half the borrowers will have to make only a 10 percent down payment and the other half, a 20 percent down payment. But the maximum price of a home eligible for such a mortgage is $71,460, except for ''target areas'' selected by county officials as neighborhoods needing investment. In these areas, the maximum house price is $87,340. One-sixth of the funds will be used for mortgages on new construction of single-family homes only. The limits in this category are higher - $84,240 in most areas and $102,960 in target areas. The mortgages became available in August from a $220 million bond issue in June by the New York State Mortgage Agency, a quasi-public body informally known as Sonny Mae. The agency allocated $33.6 million to Westchester and Rockland, which are treated by the state as a single unit. The agency buys up old mortgages from banks, and the banks use the funds to issue new mortgages, which have to be approved by the agency. Fourteen banks in the two counties are participating in the program. Woody A. Pagan, first deputy director of the agency, said Sonny Mae had approved 55 bank loans for a total of $2.5 million by the end of September. By the end of October, he said, he expects it to approve $22 million in loans. About 17 percent of the funds will be issued gradually over the following 10 months for mortgages on new construction, he added. Susan Steward, director of the White Plains Housing Information Service, who has helped about 25 families make loan aplications, said it was ''almost impossible to find a house for $72,000'' in Westchester. She argued that a limit should be set locally, not in Washington. Mr. Pagan explained that the limits were set in Washington because Sonny Mae bonds are tax-exempt. He said the agency would try to get the limits raised before new bonds are issued, probably in November. The new bonds are expected to provide Westchester and Rockland Counties with an additional $25 million for loans, he said. The program has two objectives: to put new money into old neighborhoods and to help first-time home buyers. In the old neighborhoods, or target areas (which make up 20 percent of the program), any buyer is eligible; in other neighborhoods, only first-time home buyers are eligible. The target areas, largely low-income neighborhoods, were chosen by officials of the Urban County program, part of the County Department of Planning. Mr. Pagan said that even with the higher limits in those areas - designed to attract new residents -there had not been enough applicants for loans. ''In New York City,'' he said, ''middle-class people are sometimes attracted to poorer areas. But in Westchester, people don't seem to want to do that. For the people who already live there, even if you cut the interest rate to 13 5/8 percent, it's still too high.'' Westchester had a hard time qualifying for the money, according to Mr. Pagan. The Federal guidelines are complex and they did not seem to suit the county. Mount Vernon, which has many low-income areas, did not have a single neighborhood that qualified when the program first came out, Mr. Pagan said. Areas where incomes were low often turned out ''to have nothing but garages and parking lots, and there were no singlefamily homes to lend money for,'' he said. One couple who decided to invest in a target area - Dennis and Gayle Verzi - found a two-bedroom, 50-year-old Cape Cod house in New Rochelle that they could buy for $44,500 with a 10 percent down payment. They expect to move there from an apartment in Queens in November, a few weeks before the birth of their first child, who is due around Christmas. ''It's not a depressed area, just an older area,'' Mr. Verzi said. ''The people who picked it as a target area just want to keep it from getting depressed.'' Mr. Verzi, who is 29 years old, is coordinator of physical medicine and rehabilitation at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers, and his wife, who is 24, is a hairdresser. ''O UR problem was that we just finished paying off our education loans and we haven't been able to save anything yet,'' Mr. Verzi said. ''I'm doing fairly well financially, and my wife has an income potential, but we wouldn't be able to buy without the program because we haven't got enough for a big down payment.'' Robert and Sally Goehrke, both 26, also moved to a target area, the Battle Hill section of White Plains, ''because there isn't much around at $80,000 or $90,000,'' Mrs. Goehrke said. The couple moved from their one-bedroom White Plains apartment into a 50-year-old Dutch colonial, which they bought for $84,000. They, too, move in anticipation of a new baby, due early this month. Mr. Goehrke is a marketing manager for Clairol products, and Mrs. Goehrke is a pharmacist. ''This is just perfect,'' she said, ''and there's no way we could afford it if we had to pay 16 percent interest. Our costs will be about $1,000 a month, including taxes, and they would be about $150 more without this loan. We just could not have done it.'' The target areas are in Mount Vernon, Yonkers, New Rochelle, White Plains and Port Chester. Lawrence Salley, director of the Urban County Program in Westchester, said he is working with Sonny Mae officials to expand into Peekskill, Ossining Village, Tarrytown, North Tarrytown, and the Fairview section of Greenburgh. Most of the applicants so far have been young people, mainly married couples, according to David J. Dalrymple, assistant vice president of the People's Westchster Savings Bank. He said the bank had about 70 loans ''in the pipeline,'' accounting for $3.2 million of the bank's $4 million in available funds for the Sonny Mae mortgages. Without the bond issue, borrowers at his bank would pay 16 percent and 3 points (a one-time fee of 3 percent of the mortgage), Mr. Dalrymple said. The Sonny Mae rules set the rate at 14 percent, with no ponts, or 13 5/8 percent and 2 points. title: SOVIET PLANE IS SAID TO TRY TO CONTACT TRAPPED SUB
description: A Soviet spy plane is crisscrossing the Baltic trying to make contact with what Sweden suspects is a foreign submarine trapped near Stockholm, informed sources said today.

title: Seaver Cool to Reds
description: Tom Seaver says that under no circumstances will he play more than one additional year with Cincinnati.

title: COURSES IN SAFETY FOR AUTUMN SPORTS
description: NORTH SALEM ''THERE is only one way to go canoeing and that's to play it safe,'' Chip Mathews, the county's Supervisor of Camping, said to a group of eight novice paddlers last week at Mountain Lakes Camp here.

title: Nancy Marie Knobloch Married to Sean Isacsson
description: Nancy Marie Knobloch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Knobloch Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Sean Patrick Isacsson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Joseph Isacsson Jr. of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Alfred Isacsson, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: ST. JOHN'S TOPPLES PACE BY 26-7
description: St. John's University knocked Pace University from the ranks of the undefeated, 26-7, yesterday afternoon to virtually clinch a second consecutive Metropolitan Conference football championship.

title: Deborah L. Kramer Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Louise La Gorce Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frank Kramer of Washington, was married at St. Alban's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Henry Read Jackson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Jr. of Crestwood and Woodstock, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward I. Swanson.

title: CHINA'S CAREER LADDERS ARE CROWDED BY GERONTOCRACY
description: Hao Jianxiu is a success story by any criterion. As a teen-aged textile worker in Qindao, she devised a spinning method that bears her name. Eleven years later, she graduated as a textile engineer and swiftly became deputy director of a factory. She also rose to prominence in the trade union apparatus, the Women's Federation and the Communist Party. Yet what surprises Chinese is not these accomplishments in themselves, nor even her positions as minister of China's textile industry and new alternate member of the Communist Party secretariat. It is that Hao Jianxiu has come so far so young. She is 47 years old. At such an age, many American executives and officials approach the top of the ladder, but not in China.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The "Special on Cable" column today in The Guide, section 2A, lists an incorrect network for "Saturday Night at the Fights." It will be broadcast on ESPN at 8:30 P.M.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: moor, Pa., circa 1870. THE BURNING HOUSE, by Ann Beattie. (Random House, $12.95.) The author's third collection of stories. GRACE ABOUNDING, by Maureen Howard.

title: STREAMLINING THE FORD FOUNDATION
description: When he was president of the Rockefeller Foundation, Dean Rusk advised keeping an eye on the more affluent Ford Foundation, because what the ''fat boy in the canoe does makes a difference to everybody else.'' That was years ago, when the Ford Foundation, the world's wealthiest philanthropy, was pouring millions of dollars into agricultural research overseas and educational reform at home, influencing the policies of the United States and other governments, supporting scholars, revitalizing blighted neighborhoods and giving substantial backing to the civil-rights movement. Ford interests ranged so widely, from the arts to arms control, that the byword among grant seekers was always ''Try Ford first.''

title: PUTTING ALMA MATER BEHIND HER
description: CRISP leaves, cool air, fall foliage. The stores are filled with corduroy, my summer cottons return to the back of the closet, and I return home.

title: Less Common Denominators
description: Since statistics are the political ammunition and lifeblood of modern society, Washington has been awash in numbers for years. Now the Reagan Administration has decided to reduce the flow as part of its program to cut governmental costs and functions.

title: CUTS IN UNEMPLOYMENT AID MAY SPREAD TO MORE STATES
description: The Federal Government has reduced the duration of unemployment insurance benefits in 13 states this year, and Labor Department officials say the length of coverage will probably be cut back in eight to 16 other states even though unemployment is now at its highest rate in 42 years.

title: THE SOCIALISTS LEAD A BUT A POOR ECONOMY NIPS AT THEIR HEELS
description: If Felipe Gonzalez and his Socialist Party win the Spanish general election on Oct. 28, as most politicians here expect, they will not have far to look for problems to solve. Their top priority will inevitably be the economy, especially unemployment.

title: Columbia Topples Princeton
description: Columbia ended a 10-game losing streak spanning two seasons with a 35-14 homecoming victory over Princeton at Baker Field yesterday. The game featured four third-quarter touchdowns by the Lions, among them the longest scoring pass of John Witkowski's career and the team's first touchdown of the season on the ground. Columbia improved its record to 1-3 and Princeton dropped to 2-2.

title: Headliners; Not Just Rubles
description: Some people worry about the arms race and technology leaks. W. Averell Harriman worries about that and more, such as America's flagging interest in Russian studies. Mr. Harriman, who was Ambassador to Moscow from 1943 to 1946, turned up last week as the donor of $1 million to Columbia University's Russian Institute.

title: BOY, 2, IS KILLED AND 34 ARE HURT
description: Unidentified gunmen threw hand grenades and fired submachine guns at worshipers leaving the Rome synagogue today at the conclusion of Sabbath services.

title: A NETWORK FOR STUDIES ON WOMEN
description: The latest outgrowth of the modern women's movement - a National Council for Research on Women - has just been formed in New York City. The council, a network of 28 scholarly centers, most of them less than 10 years old, ''will promote collaborative research projects and the exchange of people, programs and research developed by the members,'' according to Mariam Chamberlain, its president.

title: BOLD ART FOR COLLECTORS
description: In Papua New Guinea, art is still being produced by nearly 800 remote tribes, many of which are so isolated that tourism is unlikely to threaten their lifestyles or corrupt their work. There are restrictions on the export of art produced before 1960 and of objects that are no longer made or are sacred, but it is still possible to collect some very fine examples. The art is bold. The faces are grotesque and the motifs sometimes unsettling. Spiders and fish skeletons, snakes and hairy grasshoppers inspire some designs. Because fertility and birth are a recurring theme, the art can be explicit.

title: JACK RAISNER TO MARRY RUTH WEINFELD DEC.27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Juda Weinfeld of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Weinfield, to Jack A. Raisner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Raisner of Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE sum of $22,000 is a lot to pay for a bed, but this is no ordinary bed. It is a Roto Rest Kinetic Treatment Table, and the auxiliary of Northern Westchester Hospital Center is trying to raise the money to purchase one.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA RESERVATA
description: As the final offering in a two-day symposium devoted to St. Francis of Assisi, the Catholic Center at New York University sponsored a program of music associated with his life and teachings. This was a happy focal point for a concert, and Musica Reservata of Westchester, an a cappella choral group, filled Washington Square's Holy Trinity Chapel Wednesday with a melodious euphony.

title: CHARTING THE WAY TO THE ELEMENTAL
description: A wide variety of trips and tours is available throughout the world for travelers who wish to study man and his traditions. Offerings range from the programs arranged by nonprofit groups that match members of the public with scholars and scientists working in the field to relatively deluxe programs sponsored by museums and private agencies.

title: NATO UNDER STRAIN
description: For 30 years, America's tie to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has preserved peace between East and West. For the same period, America's tie to West Germany has preserved NATO. Today, the NATO tie is in danger primarily because the West German tie is under such strain.

title: Golden Bells
description: If ever a man took his own advice to heart, the author of ''The Power of Positive Thinking'' may be the one.

title: CAROLINIANS SEE GOVERNOR IN PCB LANDFILL DISPUTE
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. has agreed to push efforts to detoxify soil tainted with polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, in a Warren County landfill that has been the object of continuing protests.

title: Schweiker's Plan For Fixed-Price Hospital Fees
description: Hospital expenditures in the United States totaled $90.6 billion last year and are growing by 15 percent annually. While medical economists argue over how and where to cut costs, Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, last week waved a scalpel at Medicare, the insurance program for the elderly that cost $50 billion in fiscal 1982 and could reach $100 billion in 1987.

title: Danbury Captures 3d Straight
description: It's been six years since Danbury last ruled the Fairfield High School Football Conference. Coach Gus Edwards doesn't want to get too excited yet, he can't help but like what he's seen so far this year.

title: CITY CONTRACTS AT A GLANCE
description: Only 7,300 sanitationmen and small groups of uniformed superior officers remained without a new contract agreement yesterday after the tentative settlement between New York City and the unions representing 35,000 policemen, firefighters and correction officers.

title: TAKING THE TRUE MEASURE OF A PROPERTY
description: IN 1947, the old Fish family farm in Philipstown, N.Y., including ano utbuilding that was falling into ruins, was sold to Continental V illage, a development concern. After setting out roads, the company d ivided the land into one-acre plots, and the division lines ignored d ilapidated shacks like the old outbuilding.

title: THE CREDIT AND GRATITUDE DUE MENACHEM BEGIN
description: To the Editor:

title: NEVIS: A TESTING PLACE FOR IDEAS
description: NEARLY three decades ago, the world of physics was set astir by the discovery of neutrinos, subatomic particles of pure energy without charge, mass or weight able to traverse the universe at the speed of light without disturbing a single atom.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW ATTRACTION FOR CENTRAL AVENUE
description: ANOTHER fine Chinese restaurant has opened on Central Avenue, not a surprising addition considering the vast diversity and popularity of Chinese cuisine. The good restaurants have individual styles, not to mention their specialties. Diners could visit these places serially, and several times over at that, without encountering the same dish twice. To the rich variety of cooking already represented in the county, Hunan Wok contributes a sophisticated style. The kitchen has some fine versions of standard dishes, a number of intriguing creations not found elsewhere and an impressive way with sauces, distinct complements to each dish.

title: TABLES SET FOR A FANTASY
description: FLOWING from a gourd on the table is a necklace of garlic cloves. In front of the orange and blue Imari china are a silver spike and an antique cross. There is not one live thing, not even a flower, on the table that Barbara Cates arranged for her ''Halloween Dinner Alone With Count Dracula, Transylvania, Halloween 19?''

title: James Budenholzer Weds Clare Pierson
description: Clare Marie Pierson, daughter of Mrs. T George Harris of New York, and the Rev. Robert L. Pierson of Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Philip Budenholzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Vincent Budenholzer of Holbrook, Ariz.

title: GUNMEN ABDUCT BUSINESSMAN, POLICE REPORT
description: A Westchester County businessman, reportedly carrying a $10,000 cash payroll, was abducted Thursday morning by gunmen, the police said yesterday, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the search for him.
