title: INGMAR BERGMAN BIDS FAREWELL TO MOVIES
description: Peter Cowie is a British critic and film historian whose ''Ingmar Bergman: A Critical Biography'' is being published this fall by Scribner's.LONDON ''I have just made my last film,'' declared Ingmar Bergman on arrival in London, ''and it lasts 3 hours 14 minutes.'' He smiled with seraphic contentment, then added, ''It was meant to be 2 hours 45 minutes, but as it is my final production I think I can indulge myself just a little. Besides, the French distributors love the idea of having made a long film!''

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: MOUNTAIN IN THE CLOUDS A Search for the Wild Salmon. By Bruce Brown. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: AIRLINES FIGHTING FREE-SEAT RULING IN CANADA
description: A Canadian Government regulation that would force airlines to provide a free additional seat to overweight or disabled passengers is being challenged on Constitutional grounds by an association representing 105 airlines operating here.

title: Anne Holloway And C.D. Greene Married in Jersey
description: Anne Toolin Holloway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Proctor Holloway of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Dunning Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E.N. Greene Jr., also of Fair Haven. The Rev. David N. Cousins, assisted by the Rev. Arthur H. Tildesley, performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Crime and Punishment in Salvador
description: This much is certain: On Jan. 3, 1981, unforgivable murder occurred in the Salon Las Americas of San Salvador's Sheraton Hotel. The victims were Michael Hammer and Mark Pearlman, American labor officials, and Jose Rodolfo Viera, director of the Salvadoran Government's Institute for Agrarian Transformation.

title: PARKER OF KENNEDY PLAYS THE KEY ROLE IN ROUT OF CLINTON
description: Darnell Ethridge of John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx, is almost certain to become a 1,000-yard rusher before the end of the season, but while the DeWitt Clinton defense was keying on him yesterday, his teammate, Vernon Parker, was doing most of the damage as the Knights shut out the Governors, 28-0.

title: ISRAELI INQUIRY INTO BEIRUT MASSACRE TO FOCUS ON 2 KEY QUESTIONS
description: A judicial commission begins its investigation next week into the massacre of several hundred Palestinians in refugee camps in Beirut last month.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE SLIPPERY SAVINGS STATISTICS
description: RECENT statistical work is provoking a reassessment of American s avings behavior in the 1970's. The record is dismal, but not quite a s dismal as it appeared on the basis of earlier data.

title:
CAMERA;
THE COMING AGE OF ELECTRONIC MOVIE MAKING
DELPHI
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDOVSKY 'BOHEME'
description: It has been said that Giacomo Puccini wept as he wrote the last act of ''La Boheme.'' More than 80 years later, the wrenching cry, ''Mimi!'' emitted by the tenor Rodolfo as he kneels at his dead sweetheart's bedside is still a two-hankie moment for many people in the audience.

title: D.A. Coots Weds Elizabeth Farley
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Churchill Farley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence W. Farley of Westfield, N.J., and Osterville, Mass., to Douglas Alden Coots took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Westfield. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Max Alden Coots of Canton, N.Y., father of the bridegroom.

title: CITY AUDIT CRITICIZES SCHOOL'S BILINGUAL AGENCY
description: The division responsible for monitoring bilingual education programs of the New York City public schools was not fully carrying out its duties, according to an audit report by the Office of the City Comptroller.

title: MASS TRANSIT MAKING SOME STRIDES IN SUFFOLK
description: ON a Saturday afternoon, a milling throng of teen-agers waits at Walt Whitman Mall for a Huntington Area Rapid Transit bus to return them to Northport.

title: Republic Airport Curfew Protested
description: I am aghast at recent state-mandated moves that would cripple and, in some cases, mortally wound Long Island businesses that derive their well-being from the daily, unrestricted operation of Republic Airport.

title: Questioning Creighton Moves
description: To the Sports Editor: After reading of the efforts and expenditure being made by Creighton University on behalf of Kevin Ross (''Casualty of a Failed System,'' The New York Times, Oct. 3), I could only think that all was for naught.

title: UGANDA IS EVICTING THOUSANDS OF RWANDANS
description: On the 20th anniversary of Uganda's independence from Britain, news has emerged of what appears to be a systematic campaign by the Kampala authorities to uproot people of Rwandan origin from their homes and force them to enter crowded refugee camps.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Central America Peace Pressures
description: The Reagan Administration has been underwhelmed all along by Mexico's peacemaking efforts in Central America, but to say so out loud could be bad politics south of the border and in Congress, which must approve economic and military aid for El Salvador and its neighbors. Last week, a bipartisan group of 107 representatives urged President Reagan to ''respond positively'' to last month's proposal by Mexico and Venezuela ''to end the military confrontation and begin the process of political dialogue.''

title: THE LURE OF REMOTE PLACES
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, formerly a Times correspondent in the Pacific, lives in Hawaii.

title: L.I. ELECTIONS: FOCUS ON ASSEMBLY
description: DEMOCRATIC and Republican leaders are focusing on three or four Assembly races in Nassau and Suffolk Counties as their best opportunities for increasing their respective party strength in the lower house, which is controlled by Democrats.

title: COURT DELAY SEEN IN CASINO DISPUTE
description: Unless it can get some help from Congress, New Jersey may have to wait a year or more to learn from the Federal courts whether its efforts to regulate casino unions are on sound legal ground.

title: CRIME RECORDS UNIT ASSAILED IN AUDIT BY STATE COMPTROLLER
description: The New York State Comptroller has charged the State Division of Criminal Justice Services with allowing major weaknesses to continue in its financial management and operating practices. The division was also charged with failing to carry out earlier recommendations designed to improve its effectiveness.

title: PAPUA NEW GUINEA'S PRIMAL APPEAL
description: JOSEPH GIOVANNINI, the architecture critic of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, has a special interest in primitive structures.

title: THE NORWEGIANS MAKE THEIR DEBUT
description: Allen Robertson is a freelance writer currently living in Europe. BY ALLEN ROBERTSON

title: The Yankee Mall
description: No one is saying that tenants of the new Yankee Mall will be able to hear the crack of bats, but the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Alliance for Progress are promoting the location of their $2 million project as a definite attraction. That's a switch for this High Bridge section of the South Bronx.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
IN THE REAL WORLD, WHERE'S THE GOOD LIFE?
description: ONE year ago, I entered the work force in search of the real world. As an undergraduate, I thought once I had my college degree I would discover the mystery of reality, or at least get a glimpse of this seemingly hyped-up intangible - the real world. College was a walled-in garden, a mere preparation for the reality to come, or so I'd been told. I wanted proof; I braced myself for the hunt.

title: OCTOBER: WHEN SUMMER SMILES AGAIN
description: a month of falling leaves and falling temperatures. The sun-warmed breeze takes on a brisk edge that gilds summer-lush greens and strews leaves across sidewalks, lawns and windshields. The dayby-day ''goldening'' of the Meadowbrook Parkway is a wonder to behold -what a ride on a chilly morning after yet another frosty October evening has fired the foliage!

title: PARODY BY PAPER STIRS CAMPUS FIGHT
description: The student newspaper at a branch of the University of Minnesota has charged the university's president and the Minnesota Board of Regents with violating the paper's constitutional rights.

title: Felicitous Feline
description: Mr. Possum, regrettably, is no longer around to immortalize a practical new feline, Hype the Cat. We spotted him strolling along Broadway, beaming exuberantly before posters of a musical show based on Mr. Possum's verse.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday incorrectly described a transaction that led to the closing of the Hohenwald Bank and Trust company in Tennessee. It involved the deposit of checks by John H. Candler Jr., the Coca-Cola heir.

title: Ways to Improve State Tourism
description: I enjoyed reading, even though I didn't totally agree with, an article on the Connecticut Opinion page by Edward McKeon Jr. (''Tourism: It's Not a Pretty Job,'' Sept. 26). I always read articles about tourism because I used to be in the tourist promotion business myself.

title: Bus Rider Killed, 25 Hurt
description: A high school bus carrying 40 to 45 spectators home from a Friday night football game crashed through a railing on the Galveston Causeway and toppled to the northbound lanes, killing at least one person and injuring about 25 students, the authorities said. The bus was apparently forced off the road by a car that fell off the bridge into the water.

title:
THE WORLD IN SUMMARY;
Tories Stick
description: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Party were hanging tough last week, resisting the electoral appeal of tax cuts and other job-creating measures, which they viewed as threatening gains against inflation. Unemployment was 14 percent, double the rate when Mrs. Thatcher came to power three years ago, and business bankruptcies were up 35 percent over last year, but Government leaders vowed to keep up the deflationary pressure.

title: LIVING IN 1982 AND 5743
description: AN ORPHAN IN HISTORY Retrieving a Jewish Legacy. By Paul Cowan. 246 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95

title: No Headline
description: COLGATE RALLY BEATS HOLY CROSS BY 21-17; Colgate Rally Beats Holy Cross by 21-17

title: Man With Gun on Train Speaks of Two Victims
description: A Spanish-speaking man who has been barricaded in an Amtrak sleeping car for two days told the police tonight there was a dead woman with him. He also alluded to a dead man as he warned he was prepared to kill himself.

title: VAN CORTLANDT PARK: A HAVEN FOR CROSS-COUNTRY
description: The Manhattan College Invitational, billed as the nation's largest high school cross-country event, attracted more than 5,900 runners from 241 schools and eight states to Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday, but most of the attention centered on two runners who did not compete.

title: Lisa D. Friendly Wed to Engineer
description: The marriage of Lisa Donnen Friendly, daughter of Fred W. Friendly of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dorothy Greene Friendly of Manhattan, to Timothy Aloysius Nicholson took place yesterday in the Memorial Church at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Q. Nicholson of Anaheim, Calif.

title: Arafat Meets Hussein On Mideast Proposals
description: King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met today to discuss Arab and American proposals for resolving the Palestinian problem.

title: OPening a Door To Amerasians
description: For thousands of children and young adults in Asia, the United States is more than a symbolic fatherland. But until last week, Washington took little official notice of the offspring of Americans, mostly servicemen, in that part of the world.

title: PAST AND PRESENT FUSE IN AFRICAN POP
description: Sunny Ade is a pop star in Nigeria. He records three or four albums every year, and each album easily sells 200,000 copies among the nine or 10 million Yoruba people who are Mr. Ade's principal constituency. He records for his own label and performs in his own nightclub, so he does not have to share his earnings with any of the international communications conglomerates that own a piece of so much of the Third World's pop music. Sunny Ade is a rich man. In Nigeria, he is known as King Sunny Ade.

title: BROOKHAVEN PONDERS TOWN HALL SITE
description: PATCHOGUE THERE is no question that Brookhaven Town needs a new Town Hall, says Supervisor Henrietta Acampora. The question is where it should be built.

title: 36 Die in Salvador Fighting
description: Six policemen and at least 30 leftist guerrillas have died in a clash on an eastern branch road of the Pan-American Highway. The military high command said in a commmunique today that the battle flared near Berlin, 70 miles east of here, when a rebel force ambushed a police convoy Friday.

title: STUDENT DOCTORS PLAYED PATIENT
description: NEWARK ON THE morning after the inconclusive results of the MR. FIT study were announced, Dr. Norman Lasser shrugged his shoulders and said: ''I guess one of the questions we have to ask now is, 'What do we tell our students?' '' Dr. Lasser was the principal investigator at the MR. FIT treatment center at the New Jersey Medical School here and is now director of the preventive cardiology program at the school.

title: H. G. Garfield Jr., Bentley Andrews Wed in Virginia
description: Bentley Robinson Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hunter B. Andrews of Hampton, Va., was married there yesterday to Howard Gerald Garfield Jr., son of Mrs. William A. Garfinkel of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Mr. Garfield of West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Rodney L. Caulkins performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Colette Atkinson Married to William Kennedy Jr.
description: Colette Marie Atkinson, a municipal bond marketing specialist in Chicago for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., was married yesterday to William J. Lunney Kennedy Jr., an assistant vice president of Citicorp in Chicago. The Rev. Thomas P. Reilly performed the ceremony at St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: MILITARY AND FEDERAL WORKERS TO RECEIVE A 4% PAY INCREASE
description: President Reagan signed an executive order Friday that gives a 4 percent pay increase to 3.5 million white-collar Government employees and military personnel.

title: FOR PASHMAN, RETIREMENT'S BARELY A BLIP
description: HACKENSACK ANYONE tracking the long judicial career of Justice Morris Pashman of the State Supreme Court would have noticed a ''blip'' - but nothing more - on the screen on Sept. 27. That was the day Mr. Pashman reached the mandatory retirement age of 70.

title: Polish 'Spring'; Officially Ends
description: Internal opposition, Western opprobrium and the Reagan Administration's pressure tactics failed to stay the hand of Poland's military rulers last week. While beefed-up police forces patrolled Warsaw, an obedient Parliament approved a law that officially outlawed Solidarity, the Communist world's first free trade union. In its two heady and revolutionary years, the mass movement had drawn the allegiance of nearly 10 million Poles largely because it delivered more democracy than they had ever known and held the promise of even more.

title: Deregulation
description: To the Business Editor: Professor MacAvoy, in his ''The Time to Deregulate Gas Is Now'' (Sept.26), is right that now is the time for complete deregulation of natural gas production, but perhaps for the wrong reasons. If the public and Congress are to be persuaded to do away with the partial deregulation and market disorder provided by the Natural Gas Policy Act, some misconceptions must be laid to rest. Concern about a fly-up of gas prices in 1985 under N.G.P.A. is exaggerated. Although the current price of oil is somewhat higher than framers of N.G.P.A. anticipated in 1978, the average price of natural gas has also risen substantially and unexpectedly. One reason is ''category creep'' - an increase in production of gas in higher priced categories and a decline in production of lower priced gas. In addition, prices of ''deep'' gas, now free of controls, have been bid above levels that would clear the market in 1985.

title: TIMELY WRITER IS DESTROYED
description: Timely Writer, making what was to have been the last start of his career and poised to go out a winner, was humanely destroyed after shattering his left foreleg less than half a mile from the finish line of the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Miss Sumners Wins In Skate America Event
description: Rosalynn Sumners of Kirkland, Wash., the United States women's figure skating champion, captured the gold medal at the Skate America international competition today.

title: A MEXICAN CITY RELIVES NICARAGUANS' REBELLION
description: As the old DC-3 lumbered some 2,000 feet over the city, a huge explosion echoed across the valley and a ball of fire rose out of streets already littered with overturned jeeps, burning tires and broken glass.

title: ACTORS SHINE IN SUBSTITUTE PLAY
description: LINDENHURST WHEN the rights to Edward Albee's ''The Lady From Dubuque,'' the originally scheduled opening play of the Studio Theater's 22d season, were withheld, the director, Macey Levin, had a cast, a theme (dealing with death) and a benefit for the Cancer Care Organization set for Oct. 24 - but, suddenly, no play.

title: Bullfight Arena Collapses In Mexico, Killing 14
description: The bleachers of a bullfight arena collapsed tonight, killing 14 people and injuring 400, Mexican state television said.

title: A NEW BOOK DUE FROM DIET WRITER
description: SAMM SINCLAIR BAKER of Mamaroneck says he no longer is shocked when strangers come up to him and say, ''This body is yours.'' What they usually mean is that they are among the readers who have dieted their way to trimness with the help of one of the six diet books Mr. Baker has co-authored.

title: MITTERRAND KEEPS THE LINES OPEN TO AFRICA
description: Gaullist, Giscardian or Socialist, France has always had an extraordinary gift for talking one way, acting another and getting away with both. This remains true in Africa, where the talk now is in a register that soothes the third world but the action is mostly the same as it has been since the early 1960's: a military and economic presence that gives France continuing influence far beyond the scale of its role in other world affairs.

title: 8th 'Test Tube' Birth in U.S.
description: The Eastern Virginia Medical School has announced the birth of its seventh baby conceived outside the mother's body. It was the eighth such birth reported in the United States.

title: Former College Head Convicted of Fraud
description: A former university president described as an avid gun collector has been convicted of using school money to buy ammunition for his own purposes.

title: Surplus Schools And Inequalities
description: I read with great interest Paul Harenberg's article on the fair distribution of our educational dollar (''Inequities in Financing Hobble Schools,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 19). Clearly, there are vast inequalities from one school district to another, and still another relevant impropriety exists in the disposition of excessed school buildings and properties facing school districts everywhere on Long Island from Woodmere to Northport.

title: AMPUTEES' DEVICE BEING DEVELOPED
description: An electro-mechanical artificial leg that accepts subconscious signals from the wearer has been developed at the Moss Rehabilitation Hospital for use by people with amputations above the knee.

title: Judge Rules Army Must Let Homosexual Continue Duty
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a 34-yearold career soldier cannot be barred from re-enlistment simply because he is an avowed homosexual.

title: 50 IMPROVED SCHOOLS WIN PRIZE
description: Fifty high schools across the United States that have shown scholastic improvement have been chosen to share a $1 million award from the Ford Foundation. At least 30 percent of the enrolled students in the schools are from low-income families.

title: Mailbox; Many Athletes Bent the Rules
description: To the Sports Editor: Dr. Joseph R. Wilder's observations on dirty players (''The Skill of Staring Down Dirty Players,'' The New York Times, Oct. 3) have little connection with reality. ''Dirty players,'' writes Dr. Wilder, ''are usually brain-weak and personality-stunted, and a skillful athlete can exploit them.''

title: TYLENOL SPOTLIGHTS A $6 BILLION INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON THE Tylenol scare might be compared to a time-release capsule containing ingredients whose side effects are not now and may not for years be understood. But an its immediate consequence has been to draw attention to the over-the-counter drug market, whose growth has been fueled by a trend toward more self-medication as well as the Government's controversial reclassification of many drugs from prescription to nonprescription.

title: AS THE BIRDS OF PREY HEAD SOUTH
description: BEDFORD FOR some it is an autumn passion. Armed with binoculars, they climb into the grandstands here to watch creatures with some downright unsavory reputations. There's cheering for favorites. Some observers even keep statistics.

title: AMERICANS CAPTURE TWO TITLES AT WORLD BRIDGE TOURNAMENT
description: After considerable confusion in the early hours of this morning, American players proved to have won two world bridge titles here. Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., who had held the lead earlier in the open pairs, climbed back to the top position.

title: School-Prayer Article Attacked and Lauded
description: In her Opinion Page article dealing with the proposed return of prayer to the public schools (Sept.19), Betty McCollister stated her opposition to such a measure and expressed concern over what she perceived to be a related rise in anti-Semitism.

title: RIVER USE TO BE SUBJECT OF MEETINGS
description: ON Tuesday, the first in a series of six symposiums on the Connecticut River will be held to explore issues related to river use and the distribution of water resources. At each symposium, issues important to the area in which the meeting is held will be highlighted.

title: RIO ARTIFACTS MAY INDICATE ROMAN VISIT
description: Artifacts found in a bay near Rio de Janeiro may mark the wreck of a Roman ship that could have reached Brazil 17 centuries before Portuguese adventurers discovered the region, according to a leading underwater archeologist.

title: ALSATIAN WINTER'S MEAL
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: Husdon County Will Need a New Broom
description: As a successful attorney and, lately, as Hudson County Prosecutor, Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. helped refine and enforce New Jersey law. Last week, a Federal grand jury in Newark said he had also conspired to break it.

title: India Expected to Buy 40 French Warplanes
description: India will sign a contract to buy 40 Mirage 2000 jet fighters from France during next week's visit here of Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France, the United News of India said today.

title: DANCE-DRAMA: BERTRAM ROSS, CHARACTERIZATIONS WITH VOICE
description: Because he held the stage so well, Bertram Ross also held one's attention Wednesday night in the Theater of the Riverside Church. On this occasion, the former principal male dancer of Martha Graham's company spoke as well as moved - and spoke and moved with equal confidence - in an ambitious program of solo dance-dramas.

title: Writers Beware!  To the Editor:$
description: It was with a citizen's bemusement and a zoning victim's horselaugh that I read your piece on the pleasures of owning a house in New Rochelle (Sept. 19). ''Here there is clearly a priority on maintaining the residential life style,'' City Manager Samuel Kissinger is quoted as declaring. ''This is what makes New Rochelle.''

title: THE MAN WHO WILL DIRECT PHASE 2
description: Christopher Clay DeMuth is an informal, amiable man of 36 with prematurely greying hair. The Presidential Task Force on Regulatory Relief is nominally headed by Vice President Bush, but Mr. DeMuth, as executive director, is the man who runs it. He is also the man who is shaping the second phase of the Administration's deregulation push. He is self-confident enough to admit that not everything has been done perfectly and that more needs to be done.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE AND PRIVATE PAIN
description: PRIVILEGE The Enigma of Sasha Bruce. By Joan Mellen. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $17.95.

title:
COINS;
NEW BOOK ON COIN PHOTOGRAPHING TECHNIQUES
description: Photography has played a fundamental role in stimulating the growth of coin collecting because the illustrations of numismatic items in catalogs, books and newspapers have long helped to attract new converts to the hobby, as well as simplifying buying and selling. Yet, coin photography remains a primitive craft as it is widely practiced - at least in the opinion of Gerald Hoberman, a talented South African photographer who has written a major new book on the subject.

title: BIRD WEEKEND ENLIVENS CAPE
description: CAPE MAY THERE is seldom a traffic jam at the state park just west of this seaside city, but there was one last weekend. And Richard Kane, an official of the New Jersey Audubon Society, wielded a bullhorn to guide the crowds in front of the historic Cape May Lighthouse.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE 'NEW' CITY OF HARTFORD
description: A NEW city is under construction in Hartford and it promises to be a good-looking city. There are some blunders and there is some visual foolishness but the vast scale of the new buildings and the color drawings by architects indicate that the final result should be an impressive downtown.

title: Witchcraft
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; Market Triumphs; Breech of a Contract
description: The Dutch merchant who wrote his government that the colonizers were O.K. and a few babies had been born, saved the big news for last. ''We bought the island for 60 guilders worth of goods from the Indians.''

title: A LOWER-COST ROUTE TO SOLAR HEATING
description: IN the minds of laymen, a solar-heated house is a building with an a rray of large flat panels on its roof, through which air or a s pecial liquid is pumped to gather, store, and circulate the warmth o f the sun.

title: Robert H. Shaw Jr. Weds Jill A. Randall in Bronxville
description: Jill Ann Randall and Robert Hill Shaw Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert Bedingfield at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jack Paul Randall and Mr. and Mrs. Shaw, all of Bronxville.

title: LIMELIGHT FOR 2 'INVISIBLE' BREWERS
description: MILWAUKEE JUST a week ago the Brewers had to win at Baltimore in order to finish first in the American League East; today they have to win here against the California Angels in order to qualify for the World Series. If they do, with their Pete Vuckovich pitching against Bruce Kison, they will become the first team in the 14 major league championship series to survive after having lost the first two games of the best three-of-five playoffs. But the Brewers will be visible today primarily because of two teammates who had been virtually invisible in September - Bryan (Moose) Haas and Mark Brouhard.

title: RATE RISE URGED FOR PORT CHESTER WATER
description: ABOUT 10,000 water consumers in the Rye-Port Chester area learned last week that they may have to absorb a second rate increase this year by a company whose management efficiency is under review by the agency considering granting the increase.

title: SUNDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball California Angels vs. Brewers at Milwaukee, Game 5 of American League championship series, (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880; 4 P.M.) St. Louis Cardinals vs. Braves at Atlanta, Game 3 of National League championship series, (Television -Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880; 8 P.M.) Boxing Milt McCrory vs. Victor Abraham, 10 rounds welterweights; and Davey Armstrong vs. Greg Coverson, 10 rounds lightweights, from Joe Louis Arena, Detroit. Undefeated McCrory, is ranked No.1 by both the W.B.A. and W.B.C. and has a 19-0 record, with 17 knockouts. Abraham is 23-9 with 8 knockouts. Coverson, with 18 knockouts, is trying for his 30th straight victory without a defeat against Armstrong who is 21-1, with 13 knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Gymnastics United States National Women's Gymnastic Championships, University of Utah, Salt Lake City. Tracee Talavera, Julianne McNamara and Amy Koopman are among the top female gymnasts competing. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.).

title: TWO UNPROVINCIAL SHOWS AT THE JERSEY CITY MUSEUM
description: JERSEY CITY ''PAIR GROUP'' and ''Construction in Process'' are two shows running concurrently at the Jersey City Museum (472 Jersey Avenue at Montgomery Street). However, beyond a bias toward the nonobjective, a markedly somber atmosphere and a closing date of next Saturday, they have nothing in common.

title: CHILDREN OF TROUBLED HOMES TRY SUICIDE AT A GREATER RATE
description: Suicide attempts by young people occur more often in families with one or both parents missing or in families where drug or alcohol problems inhibited communication, a new study says.

title: Dobby Ferry Trounces Pleasantville
description: Undefeated Dobbs Ferry overwhelmed Pleasantville, 34-0, for its third victory. Coach Frank Violante's Eagles have shut out all three opponents this season and have won 19 of their last 20 games. John DiGuglielmo threw two first-quarter touchdown passes to Joe Guiliano. Rocky D'Agostino had touchdown runs of 19 and 42 yards to give Dobbs Ferry a four-touchdown halftime advantage. D'Agostino carried 11 times for 129 yards. Rich DiGugliemo, who gained 133 yards rushing, closed the scoring with his eighth touchdown this season. Pleasantville, undefeated last year, has lost two games in a row.

title: MY SUMMER VACATION
HOW RESOLUTE IS REAGAN ON CIVIL RIGHTS?
description: The Reagan Administration assured the Supreme Court last week of its commitment to the ''fundamental principle of nondiscrimination in matters of race,'' but the statement provoked skepticism among civil rights groups and leaders.

title: Elizabeth Lyng Is Married To Alfred William Sauter
description: Elizabeth Wright Lyng, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth Henry Lyng of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Lyng, was married yesterday to Alfred William Sauter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Lawrence Sauter of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Jeffrey Wampler performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Westfield.

title: CRIME
description: Jack S. Scott's four-year-old series about Stanley Rosher, the apish British cop, has always read as though Mr. Scott really enjoyed writing the books. Genuinely funny, full of black humor and farce, they are so sharply etched, so keenly observed, that there is something actually Daumier-like about them. And as in Daumier's prints, there is something serious under all the fun.

title: Lauren Hamilton, Actress, Is Married In New York to James Cox Chambers
description: Lauren Hamilton, daughter of James Cox Hamilton and Margaret Hamilton, both of Cambridge, Mass., was married in New York yesterday to James Cox Chambers, son of Robert Chambers and Anne Cox Chambers, both of Atlanta. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: HELP FOR LEARNING-DISABLED CHILDREN
description: LAURA is 8 years old and cries bitterly at the slightest insult. Sam is 10 and he sometimes kicks and teases his dog. William is 12 and has temper tantrums.

title: Idaho Rapist Escapes From Boise Prison Van
description: A man sentenced to 323 years in prison after conviction as a rapist escaped from a prison van here Friday by hiding in a box and pulling a gun on a startled guard and inmate driver.

title: OPENING CONCERT CANCELED IN STRIKE
description: LAST Tuesday's opening concert by the New Haven Symphony was canceled because of a strike by the musicians. But the Hartford Symphony ended its two-week strike on Tuesday when musicians agreed to new wage proposals.

title: 'The Purple Decades'
description: Here's almost 20 years of Tom Wolfe's electric prose, 20 classic pieces, including ''The Pump House Gang'' (California surfers and their culture), ''The Last American Hero'' (Junior Johnson, Southern moonshine delivery driver turned stock car racer), ''On the Bus'' (Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters' cross-country LSD bus trip), ''These Radical Chic Evenings'' (Leonard Bernstein's trendiness), ''Mau-Mauing the Flak-Catchers'' (the fun of extorting poverty program cash from whitey in the 60's) and memorable hunks of both ''The Right Stuff'' and ''From Bauhaus to Our House.'' Nothing new, but a sampling rich enough to prompt a close look at Wolfe. Who is he and what is he up to? ''Only a language experience.'' That's what Walt Whitman once called ''Leaves of Grass,'' and that could also suggest Mr. Wolfe's distinctive Americanness and hint at one valuable part of his achievement. What he conveys is excitement or shock in the face of anomaly, and he does so by deploying various devices of verbal intensity and oddness. He will repeat a tag and repeat it and finally work it to life: ''the right stuff,'' ''burned beyond recognition,'' ''the good old boys,'' ''just like that.'' He likes shock assonance, as in ''rat shacks,'' ''rot bog,'' ''black gas,'' ''an utter shuck,'' ''wavy gravy,'' ''the pick of the litter'' and of course ''flakcatcher.'' He will weasel himself into the reader's own intimate space with expletives and street-corner familiarities: ''Hell, yes!'' ''Fat chance, sahib,'' ''Is that irony or isn't it?''

title: Nancy J. Schaffer Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Jane Schaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Schaffer of Duxbury, Mass., was married in Washington yesterday to Charles Alexander von Stackelberg, son of Baron and Baroness Constantine Stackelberg of Washington. The Rev. Dr. Wilhelm Bofinger performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles.
description: LOS ANGELES Right outside the director Tim Hunter's office at the Disney studios, a visitor passes a glass case commemorating ''Bambi,'' full of pictures and porcelain figurines of the lovable fawn and his furry friends. But in Mr. Hunter's office there are no souvenirs of Disney's animated menagerie. Instead a large poster from Jean-Luc Godard's ''Every Man For Himself'' faces the man who recently won acclaim for his direction of Disney's ''Tex,'' an observant and affectionate study of a boy in his teens (Matt Dillon) coming of age in rural Oklahoma.

title: IN SECOND DISTRICT, RIVALS FROM 1980 MEET AGAIN
description: THIS time in the race in the Second Congressional District, voters should have a better grasp of the pronunciation of the two candidates' names, as well as the pronounced differences between the Democratic incumbent and the Republican challenger.

title: BACH SERIES: MUSIC SACRA IN CANTATAS
description: The Basically Bach festival moved to Park Avenue's Central Presbyterian Church on Friday night. The chorus and orchestra of Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg offered a large and perspiring audience the sixth Brandenburg Concerto for two violas and strings and three cantatas - ''Weinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagen,'' ''Gottes Zeit ist die allerbeste Zeit'' and ''Schmucke dich, o liebe Seele.''

title: 'Democracy'
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNSELING CAN AID OUSTED EXECUTIVES
description: IN 28 years, John Riverton had worked himself up to the post of senior vice president of a national transportation company headquartered in Connecticut. Then, at the age of 50, with a wife and young daughter, a fine home and a sense of the good life, he lost his job.

title: Jennifer Davis To Wed in Fall
description: The engagment of Jennifer Van Holland Davis to William John Rauch has been announced by the future bride's parents, Jill Johnston Davis and John Van Holland Davis of Camden, S.C. Mr. Rauch is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Rauch of Indianapolis and Harbor Springs, Mich.

title: Delinquent Elders
description: Some 13,800 parents in New York City were seriously delinquent in court-ordered child support payments in November 1981. They were, the city's Human Resources Administration said, people who had jobs but who had ''obstinately'' refused to support their children, forcing their estranged spouses to obtain public assistance.

title: Barbara Geen Becomes Bride of Richard Lemaster
description: At the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday Barbara Brinton Geen and Richard K. Lemaster, 1982 graduates of Duke University, were married by the Rev. Howard Major.

title: AN AMERICAN FREEDOM THE C.I.A. CAN AFFORD
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: DEATH IN LIFE: Survivors of Hiroshima. By Robert Jay Lifton. (Basic Books, $10.50.) ''I reintroduce this description of Hiroshima in a spirit of new hope,'' Robert Jay Lifton says in his prefatory note. ''That hope is founded on our evolving capacity to acknowledge Hiroshima and to make proper use of it.'' First released in 1967, this study is based on interviews with 75 survivors 17 years after the atom bomb hit. Our reviewer, Jerome D. Frank, called it ''beautifully written, moving and vivid.''

title: NAVY IS CONSIDERING USING NEW YORK PORT AS BASE FOR A FLEET
description: The Navy has decided to make the Port of New York the home base for two Naval Reserve frigates and is considering assigning a fleet of a dozen or more cruisers and escort ships to the port, according to George A. Sawyer, an Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LESS than three months before he leaves the House of Representatives, Gregory W. Carman, Republican of Farmingdale, will have a taxpayer-financed consolation prize for being squeezed out of office by reapportionment. While his colleagues spend this month campaigning for re-election, Mr. Carman will be on a Congressional trip to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, China, India, Germany, Switzerland and France.

title: FUTURE EVENTS
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. NIGHT ON THE TOWN Oct. 13 - Supporters of the Manhattan League for IHB Services for the Blind will adjourn to Regine's for supper and dancing after seeing the musical "Nine" from choice orchestra seats at the 46th Street Theater. The proceeds from the annual theater party will be used to support children's services for the Inudstrial Home for the Blind. Tickets, $50, $75 and $100 for the show, $50 for supper dance.

title: Paris Three-Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick J. Honold Jr.  Weds Karen Chesney
description: At St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, N.J., yesterday Karen Anne Chesney, daughter of Joan Schulerud Chesney and Edward A. Chesney, both of Hackettstown, N.J., was married to Frederick John Honold Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Honold of Fanwood, N.J. The Rev. Francis Reinbold performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Waltrip Chasing Allison
description: With the national driving championship more sharply at stake, Bobby Allison enters today's National 500 Grand National stock-car race at Charlotte, N.C., with a 15-point lead over Darrell Waltrip.

title: GOING THEIR OWN WAY
description: Shortly after the beginning of the Second Vatican Council, 20 years ago tomorrow, Pope John XXIII told a visitor that he intended to open the window and permit fresh air to blow through the Roman Catholic Church. In the United States, the papal breeze turned into a tornado.

title: BLACK PACKAGING
description: Black is the newest, most elegant way to present beauty products. Here is a sampling. 1. Ralph Lauren's Tuxedo spray cologne, two ounces, $22.50. 2.

title: RANDOLPH IS WINNER BY 23-8
description: The Gangemi brothers, Nick and Joe, each scored a touchdown and led a productive running attack yesterday as unbeaten Randolph upended Morristown, 23-8, for its third success. The game was played at Randolph.

title: APPLES OF AUTUMN: TILL YEAR'S END, A TIME TO INDULGE
description: TO the casual observer, it would seem that apples are never out of season. They appear to be on permanent display at produce stands the way onions, bananas and potatoes are.

title: REGION FEELS LOSS OF ENERGY OFFICES
description: FOR three years after the gasoline crisis of 1979, members of Congress from New England found that the surest, quickest information on their region's energy outlook came from a small brownstone walk - up two blocks behind the Cannon House Office Building here.

title: WHITHER MERGERS IN THE WAKE OF BENDIX
description: THE Bendix-Martin Marietta takeover battle, which ultimately e mbroiled United Technologies, the Allied Corporation and innumerablei nvestment bankers and lawyers, shocked many in the American businessc ommunity. It provided a rare and unseemly spectacle, of companies a nd the men who head them, fighting to control each other -at the p ossible risk of their mutual destruction. Finally Bendix merged withA llied in a $1.96 billion deal.

title: A Bad-Luck Colt Right to the Finish
description: The tragic injury that caused Timely Writer to be humanely destroyed yesterday ended a racing career that was almost unbelievable for its numerous untimely setbacks.

title: ATARI DEMOCRATS
description: In the realm of economic policy, two developments merit mild applause. Supply-side economics as a fatuous promise that tax favors to the unneedy would make America great again quietly expired when President Reagan swung behind the tax increase Senate Republicans forced on him. And Martin Feldstein, the new and impeccably conservative Council of Economic Advisers chairman, drove the final nail into the coffin at his confirmation hearing by dismissing supply-side policy as ''decisively proven wrong.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN TURTLE BAY
description: HIDDEN away in a corner of Turtle Bay is a small private garden flanked by a double row of b rownstones. There, where the roar of midtown traffic seems almost a w hisper, a copy of the fountain at the entrance of the Villa de M edici spouts water and an old willow tree stands, graceful and s haggy.

title: RAND STUDY ON SUBURBS CRITICIZED
description: ACONTROVERSIAL Rand Corporation study that found many of the country's suburbs suffering the same ills as those in the central cities has provoked anger among representatives of some of the 84 municipalities cited, including New Rochelle and Mount Vernon.

title: THE LIGHTNING ROD FOR AILING ECONOMY
description: OTTAWA FOR the last several months, Statistics Canada, the national agency that compiles economic data, has been keening the bad news in weekly bulletins: unemployment up to 12.2 percent, industrial production down 16.4 percent, inflation at 11 percent.

title: THE BIG BLACKOUT
description: Some of the best designs of any season are created in the color black. For this fall and winter, however, designers here and abroad have blanketed their collections with black clothes that are both sexy and elegant. Red is hot. Pink is pretty. White is bright. Blue is cool. Beige is safe. Gray can be aging, yellow tricky and mauve a mistake. But black? Well, black is magic, the best background of all; other colors shine when placed against it. By itself, black does something for everyone. It is a flattering foil for every complexion and figure shape. In a word: slimming.

title: LESS RISK, MORE WORRY FOR THE BANKS
description: BANKERS are generally an optimistic lot. But today they are worried. And what's worrying them most, they say, is the dramatic movement away from risk throughout the financial world in recent months.

title: TODAY'S ARTIST WORKS ALONE UNLIKE THE MASTERS OF OLD
description: If any one general statement can be made about the art world of today it is that the best artists learn, but are not taught. The ancient hierarchy of master and apprentice, senior and junior, has quite gone. In its place is a free-floating molecular system of equals.

title: Guyana Rejects a Proposal By Venezuela Over Essequibo
description: Guyana has rejected a Venezuelan proposal that the two countries refer their territorial dispute over the Essequibo region of Guyana to the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, for settlement.

title: Regarding Positions On Abortion Funds
description: A flood of phone calls to the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion followed a misleading statement in the article on Westchester's State Senate races (''Democrats See Uphill State Senate Battle,'' Sept. 26). It said that the incumbents Joseph Pisani, John Flynn and Mary B. Goodhue had ''voted to maintain the state's use of Medicaid funds to pay for abortion, although all three said that they were morally opposed to abortion.''

title: STUDY ASSAILS OUTSIDERS' POWER OVER COLLEGES
description: The nation's colleges and universities must strengthen themselves to cope with outside forces that are gaining power in shaping academic programs, goals and ideals, the Carnegie Foundation has concluded.

title: 70 Florida Parents Jailed In Child-Support Cases
description: A county judge, overtaxing the facilities of the Marion County Jail, has sentenced 70 parents to serve time for failing to make child-support payments.

title: A BEWILDERING FALL FOR THE RETAILERS
description: FOR years, retailers have enjoyed their self-image as the vital c onduit between the factory and the consumer, the link that has helped transform the United States into the world's greatest consumer economy. And for years, millions of Americans went along, happily buying the staples and the luxuries that kept the plants and the store counters busy.

title: RENEWING AMERICAN CAPITALISM
description: Robert Heilbroner points to Volkswagen, Renault and Fiat as cases of financial linkage between government and business, then proceeds to imply that while the first of the three has proven successful, the others have been glaring failures.

title: FROM BOUND FEET TO UNBOUNDED HORIZONS
description: ''DOES discrimination against women really exist?'' I innocently asked the editor of a feminist publication in Boston. She looked at me incredulously, almost indignantly, and proceeded to present me with statistics.

title: James Atlas is an associate editor of The Atlantic.
description: Everyone knows that Hollywood likes happy endings, but when Joan Micklin Silver was invited to adapt Ann Beattie's novel, ''Chilly Scenes of Winter,'' for the screen, she found herself working with a property that outdid even the movies' optimistic version of reality.

title: PULLOUT BY EXXON JOLTS A BOOMTOWN
description: On May 2 the bulldozers stopped, and so did the trucks and the construction crews. That was the day Exxon USA announced it was halting work on its $5 billion Colony Shale Oil Project. It was the day when a boomtown went bust.

title: ARTS COUNCIL OFFICIAL VOWS TO CONTINUE HER FIGHT
description: REGARDLESS of the outcome of charges against her, Eileen Lawton, who was named executive director of the State Council on the Arts in 1978, says she will carry on her fight to clear her name.

title: AIR CRASH VICTIMS' CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HIROSHIMA NO PIKA Written and illustrated by Toshi Maruki. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $12.50. By Natalie Babbitt

title: DOCTORS DEFEND HEART STUDY THAT 'FAILED'
description: DESPITE inconclusive evidence from the largest study ever done to see if heart-attack death rates can be cut, New Jersey medical experts continue to advise the public to stop smoking, control high blood pressure and lower serum cholesterol levels.

title: South Africa Squeezing Blacks
description: South Africa's governing National Party held a convention last week and the main topic, as usual, was the country's race laws. Prime Minister P.W. Botha won endorsement for granting limited political rights to nonwhite minorities - 2.5 million people of mixed race and 800,000 Indians.

title: Fire and Traffic Deaths Drop
description: The National Safety Council has reported a 13 percent drop in traffic deaths for the first six months of this year and an 11 percent decrease in fire deaths since 1980. The council reported that 4,900 people died in fires last year and 20,770 died in traffic accidents from January through June.

title: CORRUPTION ISN'T BIG LEAGUE ONLY
description: THE 80's may go down in history as the age of popular corruption in America. Of course, there is nothing new about corruption. But in time past, only the top echelons in business, government and the military - even the professions - were in a position to aggrandize by questionable means.

title: Nurses at St. Barnabas End 20-Day Walkout
description: Striking nurses at St. Barnabas Medical Center voted to accept a two-year contract today, ending their 20-day walkout.

title: First article of a series appearing periodically on the effects of changing economic conditions on some American families.
description: By almost any standard used to identify the upwardly mobile middle class, Walter and Dianna Sue Bryant once qualified.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SNUFF BOTTLES IN 2 MUSEUM SHOWS
description: MONTCLAIR SCHOLARS stroll through a country landscape, a poet rides into a snowy winter wind, children pick peaches, lions cavort and frogs and grasshoppers pose like artists' models in exhibitions now on view at the Montclair Art Museum and the Newark Museum.

title: Delphi
description: To the Editor:

title: Renewing American Capitalism
description: Robert Heilbroner's prescriptions for the renewal of American capitalism are essentially correct (''Does Capitalism Have a Future?,'' Aug. 15). To control inflation and achieve substantially higher rates of savings and investment he calls for a much more active role for the Federal Government.

title: NOW ACTION GROUP JOINS POLITICAL FRAY
description: MEMBERS of the 18 Connecticut chapters of the National Organization for Women are aggressively rallying the vote for candidates in the upcoming elections in the state who support feminist issues.

title: A TALK WITH DON DELILLO
description: Robert R. Harris was literary editor of The Saturday Review.

title:
GARDENING;
MUMS CAN BE YEAR-ROUND FLOWERS
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS, along with turning leaves, pumpkins and apples, have long been a part of the fall scene. If allowed to follow their own inclination, they will flower at just the right time to add their bold colors to those of their autumn surroundings. Over the last 30 years, however, we have learned to accept the mum as a year-round flower, although it is somehow a bit disconcerting to discover mums in bloom in garden centers in August when summer annuals are still flowering in the garden.

title: SABICAS GIVES GUITAR FESTIVAL ROUSING START
description: New York's first International Guitar Festival got off to a rousing start Friday evening when the man known only as Sabicas, an acknowledged master of Flamenco guitar for more than 40 years, performed for an overflow crowd at Cami Hall. Sabicas, who was born in Pamplona, Spain, in 1917, has played throughout the world and has made more than 50 recordings.

title: JAZZ: PERRY ROBINSON'S SEXTET
description: Two scat singers, Janet Lawson and Judy Niemack, joined the clarinetist Perry Robinson in the front line of his sextet Friday at Jazzmania. It was a canny lineup, because the compass of Mr. Robinson's clarinet was neatly bracketed by the singer's registers.

title: Milton Avery's Collector
description: The article on Milton Avery does not give proper credit to my father, the art collector Roy R. Neuberger, for his role in furthering Mr. Avery's reputation (''Milton Avery,'' by Hilton Kramer, Aug. 29). To the contrary, he is portrayed as mercenary by the statement: ''In 1950, (Avery's) dealer, Paul Rosenberg ... sold his stock of Avery paintings - some 50 works - in a package deal to the collector Roy. R. Neuberger at a price that was guaranteed to depress whatever remaining market there was for the artist's works.''

title: TUESDAY, LAST DAY TO REGISTER
description: HARTFORD THE general election is still three weeks away, but the last day to register is this Tuesday, Oct. 12. ''To accommodate people who have not yet registered, all towns will be holding special evening sessions,'' said Maura L. Melley, the Secretary of the State, whose office supervises elections.

title: 'MASTERPIECE THEATER' WEAVES A RICH NEW TAPESTRY
description: ''Masterpiece Theater'' returns tonight at 9 on Channel 13 for a new season on public television and, not surprisingly, the long-running package of imports is as comforting as an old and trusted friend. Admittedly, some productions are better than others, but over the years, the series has become a dependable source of intelligent ambition, decent and occasionally brilliant execution and nearly always stunning performances. Still reeling from, say, this past week's presentation of ''Bare Essence,'' CBS's four-hour TV movie of unsurpassed trashiness, discriminating viewers can only be grateful for an opportunity to settle into something like ''To Serve Them All My Days.''

title: THEY CATER TO NEW YORK'S DISK ADVENTURE
description: John McGlinn, a New York-based composer and musicologist, is music and dramatic consultant for the Houston Grand Opera.

title: ABOUT PIPE ORGANS
description: Add pipe organs to the list of endangered species. According to Richard Grant, organist and president of Allen Organ Sales, the theater pipe organs at Radio City Music Hall and the Beacon Theater on Broadway in New York City are the only working ones left in the area.

title: BREEDING GROUNDS FOR CAPSULE MURDERERS
description: To the Editor:

title: REDISTRICTING PITS SOME VERY STRANGE BEDFELLOWS
description: With just over three weeks until the Congressional elections, attention focuses on television blitzes, the unemployment rate and the relative quality of get-out-the-vote operations. But a process completed months ago has already done much to shape the House delegations for the 98th Congress.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ROME
description: How nice to visit Rome when summer is past and tourists no longer outnumber Romans at places where tourists gather. The difference between August and October is not as great in Rome as elsewhere, because tourists come all year, but let us give thanks even for the small difference.

title: THEATER: MICHAEL ADLER, ANTHEM FOR BRITISH POET
description: Michael Adler, a young American actor, has had the rashness to write a monologue about the brief, tragic life of the British war poet Wilfred Owen and to cast himself in the role. Mr. Adler's monodrama, ''Anthem for Doomed Youth,'' which takes its title from the Owen poem, is at the Actors' Playhouse. As author and as actor, Mr. Adler is unsuited to his task.

title: ITALY CELEBRATES TWO GREEK BRONZES
description: David L. Shirey is chairman of the master of fine arts program at the School of Visual Arts. REGGIO DI CALABRIA,Italy

title: IN PRAISE OF A REVIVAL IN FAITH
description: ''HERE is the place where religion steps in. Not in the biology classrooms ...,'' E.M. McCollister declared in an Opinion Page article on July 25.

title: HOMESTEADERS REVIVING NORTH DAKOTA TOWN
description: The school bell has announced autumn in this remote little village. To Bud Ki@s@sner that is a sweet sound. To other old-timers here it is not quite so sweet.

title: BIRDSONG HOPING HE'LL EASE GLOOM
description: Several months ago, during a quiet moment in a hallway at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Bill Blair, an assistant coach for the Nets, playfully grabbed Otis Birdsong and said: ''This man here is the league's highest-paid assistant coach.'' They laughed at the remark, but it was clear that the levity could not ease the pain and the frustration that Birdsong felt.

title: LUXURY, SEX, AND MUSIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alice Hoffman's most recent novel is ''White Horses.'' CRY TO HEAVEN By Anne Rice. 534 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: HOW FAR SHALL WE GO WITH MINIMALISM?
description: The ruling spirit of our age is Minimalism. Or, if you object to sweeping generalizations in opening paragraphs, maybe we could narrow it down and say that it certainly is one of the ruling spirits. A Zeitgeist, if not the Zeitgeist. Regardless of what cosmologists may contend, we seem to live in a shriveling universe, one in which heroes easily fit onto 12-inch television screens and $30,000 autos are the size of kiddie cars. A 50-cent candy bar fits neatly into a tooth cavity. Doctors who treat the century's most characteristic illnesses are known as shrinks. Whole libraries are condensed onto a couple of microchips. Dieting has replaced gourmandizing as the mark of the leisure class. The Reader's Digest has given the Bible a slim, new look.

title: U.S. NOW BACKING GUATEMALA LOANS
description: The State Department says that because of what it sees as improvements in the human rights situation in Guatemala, it has recommended that the United States no longer block development bank loans to that country, according to Administration officials.

title: A RETICENT INVESTIGATOR
description: When Yitzhak Kahan was chosen to be Chief Justice of Israel's Supreme Court this year, he initially turned the offer down.

title: POLISH TARIFF STEP IS CALLED SYMBOLIC
description: In moving to deprive Poland of its ability to export manufactured goods to the United States at favorable tariffs, President Reagan has decided on another largely symbolic step to demonstrate his repugnance at the martial law crackdown, Administration officials say.

title: EASING OF PRICES SEEN
description: The slowdown of inflation, after three years of double-digit growth rates in 1979-81, has been a bright spot in the midst of an economic recession. Producer prices, for example, rose at an annual rate of only 3.7 percent in the first seven months of this year, and are not expected to accelerate any time soon.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ton, six-story structure that draws 25,000 tourists to Margate each summer, is wearing thin and is about to be reconditioned, thanks to a local preservation group.

title: S.A.T. Scores, in Black and White
description: Experts who think the Scholastic Aptitude Test is a good predictor of college achievement and those who don't think so agree on at least one thing: The higher the family income, the higher the students' average test scores. So critics questioned the College Board's wisdom last week when, for the first time, it broke down S.A.T. results by race and ethnic group in such a way that the differences between blacks and whites overshadowed the differences between poor and wealthy.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: A''FIRST'' for New Jersey's environmental movement occurred last week. The head of a major national environmental organization came to the state to campaign for a Congressional candidate, Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of Spring Lake Heights.

title: Weicker, Moffett; On Party Ties
description: Political accountability has been an underlying issue all along between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Republican other Republicans love to hate, and United States Representative Toby Moffett, the Democrat who has learned to love other Democrats. Last week it became the overriding issue as the Senate candidates from Connecticut broke their pattern of discussing state problems and argued about ideology and integrity.

title: Lebanese Planning to Reopen Their Satellite Ground Station
description: Lebanon's only satellite ground station, in the mountains east of Beirut, is expected to resume working next week, Government officials said today.

title: L.A.'S ECCENTRIC LITTLE SUBURB
description: MARCIA SELIGSON is a writer who lives in Los Angeles; her books include ''The Eternal Bliss Machine'' and ''Options.''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: NOT-SO-EXCLUSIVE VIP LOUNGES
description: At one time private airport lounges, which go by different names depending on the airline involved but which are commonly called VIP lounges, were exclusive clubs where admission was by invitation only, usually to frequent fliers or prominent persons. Today most of them are open to anyone who is willing to pay for the privilege of getting away from the crowd.

title: Poland: Still Defiant
description: Having just spent almost a month studying at Jagellonian University's summer school in Krakow, I was especially interested in John Darnton's article on Poland (''Poland: Still Defiant,'' Aug. 22).

title: BRITAIN'S OLDEST BALLET TROUPE ON TOUR
description: The Ballet Rambert is the oldest English company dancing today, its earliest full, public performances predating by a year those of Sadler's Wells (now Royal) Ballet. The outgrowth of scattered ballet productions in London in 1926, Ballet Rambert was responsible for ''the beginning of English ballet in the 20th century,'' as Dame Marie Rambert, the company's founder, rightly put it. But there will be no English classics on stage at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College when the company makes its New York debut on Friday, in a three-day run that starts its first American tour.

title: RENEWING AMERICAN CAPITALISM
description: Robert Heilbroner's article is concerned, of course, with the ''high-stream'' economy, and it therefore ignores the gentle persistence, at lower levels, of historically earlier ways of doing business, e.g., small business in a big-business economy. Realism as well as compassion demands that we continue to respect all levels of constructive human enterprise.

title: 'I, THE JURY' BRINGS BACK MIKE HAMMER'S NEW YORK
description: THE film ''I the Jury,'' which opened Saturday at the National and other theaters, has something to do with the Central Intelligence Agency and a sex therapy clinic. More than that is hard to guess. Directed by Richard T. Heffron, photographed on location in New York City by Andrew Laszlow and coaxed along by Bill Conti's witty score, the movie careers by at a fast and cheeky pace. Its clues are strewn across a glossy landscape of city streets and pretty girls in various stages of dress and death by torture, and are delivered in an impenetrably gritty New York accent.

title: GEORGE KENNAN CALLS ON THE WEST TO END SANCTIONS AGAINST SOVIET
description: George F. Kennan called today for an end to economic sanctions against the Soviet Union and warned that the West would by its own talk ''really make war inevitable by making it seem inevitable.''

title: MAN FREES A CHILD IN TRAIN STANDOFF
description: An ''erratic'' gunman released early today one of two children he had held for almost four days aboard an Amtrak sleeper car, the police said.

title: Change In Atlanta
description: ATLANTA TO get from Montgomery to Louisville, you must change planes in Atlanta. To get from Tallahassee to Knoxville, you must change planes in Atlanta. Anybody who has ever lived south of the Mason-Dixon Line fully expects to have to change in Atlanta on the way from this world to the one beyond.

title: INSIDE ANDROPOV'S MIND
description: That handsome woman in the Crimea who calls herself a faith healer might have put new life in Comrade Brezhnev, but such feeling cannot last long; the struggle for succession in Moscow is on, and I, Yuri Andropov, represent the policy line that will win.

title: BREWERS AND CARDINALS WIN LEAGUE CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, ordered by their manager four months ago to go out and enjoy themselves, completed that assignment today by winning the American League pennant with a 4-3 victory over the California Angels.

title: NEW SAINT IS INSPIRATION FOR THE MESSAGE OF HOPE
description: For Roman Catholics and non-Catholics alike, the Rev. Maksymilian Kolbe, who was canonized yesterday by Pope John Paul II, has become an inspiration for the message of hope over despair.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CITY MAN

title: Baby Found Near Plane In Which Parents Died
description: A 21-month-old boy who spent 12 hours near the wreckage of a plane crash that killed his parents was rescued Saturday suffering only ''scratches and bruises,'' the authorities said.

title: ANCIENT PAPYRUS A RIDDLE NO MORE
description: A Yeshiva University professor has cracked a 2,000-year-old linguistic puzzle and discovered portions of Jewish psalms addressed to Egyptian gods in a previously untranslatable Egyptian manuscript.

title: MEDIATION DUE IN TALKS
description: The chief negotiators for the National Football League players and owners agreed today to seek Federal help to end the impasse that has wiped out the National Football League schedule for the last three weekends.

title: THE NEW PRESIDENT TAKES A PRAGMATIC APPROACH
description: Judy Goldsmith, the former professor of English literature who was elected today to lead the National Organization for Women through a critical period in its history, describes herself as ''strongly pragmatic with a no-frills political and economic approach to contemporary issues.'' She turned back a challenge by four other candidates for the presidency, including a strong bid by Sonia Johnson.

title: MOUNTAINEER LINEBACKER IS EVERYWHERE
description: Comparisons are being made to Lawrence Taylor, the linebacker from the University of North Carolina who starred as a rookie for the Giants last season. But Darryl Talley says he is not sure he warrants that kind of mention yet.

title: PENN STATE'S BIZARRE BLOOPER
description: Penn State suffered from so many mistakes and breakdowns in its 42-21 loss to Alabama Saturday that Mike Suter, who made the biggest mistake, could take solace in knowing that at least he was not alone.

title: Nevada Senator Is Reported Reagan Choice for Party Job
description: Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada is President Reagan's top choice to replace Richard Richards as chairman of the Republican National Committee, according to an article in today's issue of The Reno Gazette-Journal.

title: Farrell Takes 4th Straight
description: Undefeated Monsignor Farrell scored 21 points in the final period and outlasted St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., 40-21, yesterday in a Catholic High Schools Football League game on Staten Island.

title: Douglas Baker Heads Stage Booking Office
description: Independent Booking Office, a theatrical service agency, has named Douglas C. Baker as its executive director. Mr. Baker most recently was employed by Gatchell and Neufeld Ltd. for whom he supervised New York and touring productions of the musical ''Annie.''

title: COURT-STRIPPERS STYMIED, CONSTITUTION INTACT
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: CHANGES IN 'GODUNOV'
description: THE cast changes in Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night did not affect the imposing heart of the opera, which remained Martti Talvela as an imposing Boris. Rather, the many secondary characters, which in such Russian musical and literary works give the epic ground to the main figure while also composing his detailed shadow, were shifted.

title: 'LOUSY BUMS' JIBE AT POLES BY REAGAN GETS ON THE RECORD
description: An off-the-cuff remark by President Reagan, calling the Polish military Government ''lousy bums,'' became a point of friction over the weekend between White House officials and broadcasters who aired it on nationwide television.

title: BRIEFING
description: Chill on Space Front

title: DEMOCRATS EXPECT TO WIN MORE GOVERNORS' RACES
description: Democrats, who now control 27 of the nation's 50 governors' offices, stand a good chance of increasing their margin over Republicans in the Nov. 2 elections, according to officials in both parties. They say the Democrats are likely to win back some of the large states in the Middle West that Republicans have controlled in recent years, including Ohio, Michigan and Minnesota.

title: HAMBURGERS FRY, MUSIC PLAYS AND VOTERS REGISTER
description: While Larry Soucy registered to vote, raising his right hand and solemnly swearing ''to be true and faithful to the State of Conecticut and to the Constitution and government thereof,'' the woman behind him was ordering a hamburger and fries to go.

title: ISRAEL DEMANDING THAT LEBANON SIGN A SECURITY ACCORD
description: Israel announced today that its troops would not withdraw from Lebanon until the Beirut Government signed a security agreement with Israel and all Israeli prisoners in Syrian and Palestinian hands were returned.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: WYOMING SUES U.S. TO BAR PERMIT FOR GAS DRILLING NEAR TETON PARK
description: Wyoming is suing the Interior Department and Secretary James G. Watt over a plan to allow drilling for natural gas near Grand Teton National Park.

title: VADNAIS HAPPIER AFTER FIRST GAME
description: Two hours before the Devils played the Maple Leafs here Saturday night, the face of Carol Vadnais was a picture of gloom, but after New Jersey had rallied for a 5-5 tie, the former Ranger was cheerful and pleasant.

title: Company Held Suspect Had U.S. Listening Pact
description: A company being investigated for purportedly trying to smuggle high-technology equipment into Soviet bloc countries was building a satellite ground station that could have eavesdropped on top secret American satellites, a newspaper reported today.

title: MUSIC: MAHLER BY HAITNIK
description: BERNARD HAITINK and the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam devoted an entire program to Gustav Mahler's Seventh Symphony on Saturday night. This second of two Carnegie Hall concerts found the Concertgebouw on familiar ground, as the orchestra has a distinguished tradition of Mahler performance that dates back to the 1920's.

title: Gant Captures National 500 Race
description: Harry Gant roared away from Bill Elliott over the last four laps today and won the National 500 Nascar race.

title: Jersey Panel Faults Auto Insurers
description: A special legislative commission, finding that women under 25 have more accidents for each mile driven than do men under 25, has concluded that the criteria used by the automobileinsurance industry to set its rates have ''little or no impact on driving performance.''

title: Iris Randy Tashman Bride Of Clifford Mark Snapper
description: Iris Randy Tashman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tashman of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Clifford Mark Snapper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Snapper of Brooklyn. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Nancy Markim Married
description: Nancy Markim, daughter of Billie Markim of New York and Alfred Markim of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to Frederick C. Birks, son of Mrs. James McMasters of Brooklyn and the late Frederick V. Birks of New York. Judge Bernard Rudd of the Essex County District Court performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Heights Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. The bride is technical director of MTV for the Video Corporation of America in New York, where Mr. Birks is supervisor of production engineering. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: FURTHER RATE DROPS PREDICTED
description: A buying panic erupted in the credit markets last week, bringing spectacular price gains and yield declines and leading Wall Street professionals to forecast even lower interest rates in the weeks ahead.

title: WRONG PLACE FOR A NEW YORK CITY JAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SAINT OF AUSCHWITZ IS CANONIZED BY POPE
description: The Rev. Maksymilian Kolbe, the Polish priest who volunteered in Auschwitz to die in another man's stead, was proclaimed a saint of the Roman Catholic Church today.

title: CANDIDATE CUOMO SHIFTS ROLES AS DAUGHTER IS WED
description: Mario M. Cuomo was stumped. ''I keep trying to remember my part,'' Mr. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for Governor, said to his oldest daughter, Margaret. ''Lift the veil, kiss you on the left cheek.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Harness Racing Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M. The $171,800 Charles I. Smith trot for 3-year-old New Jersey-bred colts and fillies. Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape) Hockey Rangers vs.

title: NOW ELECTS OFFICERS AND PLOTS ITS FUTURE
description: After a spirited race, the National Organization for Women announced today its new slate of officers, elected at the organization's 15th annual convention. These officers will navigate the largest women's rights organization in the country in redefining its goals after the defeat of the equal rights amendment.

title: Market Place; Money Fund Competition
description: THE argument that the liquid asset accounts that deposit institutions are to offer soon will capture little of the $200 billion held by money market funds could be wishful thinking.

title: Canoeist Drowns At Harriman Park
description: A 20-year-old man drowned when a canoe in which he and three others were riding overturned on a lake at Harriman State Park early today, police said.

title: English National Opera Plans U.S. Tour in 1984
description: The English National Opera is planning a five-city tour of the United States next May and June of 1984. The company expects to perform in Houston, Austin, San Antonio and New Orleans and to end its tour at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York.

title: TV: TWAIN'S 'MYSTERIOUS STRANGER'
description: MARK TWAIN ain't easy, at least as far as adaptations are concerned. It's primarily a matter of tone. His narratives can be downright ordinary, but his attitudes and interwoven comments pull them up to extraordinary levels. The problem is that too many adaptations capture only the story, reducing Tom Sawyer or Huck Finn to one-dimensional cuddly characters. The bite is lost.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1982. Edited by John Gardner with Shannon Ravenel. 374 pages. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $14.95.

title: NEW CORPORATE ISSUES SETTING VIGOROUS PACE
description: A dramatic drop in interest rates last week opened wide the floodgates of new financing for corporations. If the rate climate remains favorable this week, issuing companies could flock to the market again.

title: Sharon Falkner Cunliffe Wed to Michael T. Corbett
description: Sharon Falkner Cunliffe, daughter of Mitzi Solomon Cunliffe of New York and Marcus Falkner Cunliffe of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Tobias Corbett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Corbett of Longview, Wash. The Rev. David Garcia performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in the Bowery.

title: Montclair St. Wins
description: Mark Casale scored a touchdown on a 1-yard run and threw two touchdown passes, one of 17 yards to Ken Oliver, the other for 18 yards to John Schwartz, to lead Montclair State to a 31-8 victory over New York Tech Saturday night. Casale completed 24 of 39 passes for 296 yards for the Indians (4-0-1). Tech's record is 1-4.

title: IRAN SAID TO PREPARE FOR DECISIVE PUSH
description: Iran has deployed as many as 100,000 troops on the southern front at Basra and perhaps 75,000 more in the hills east of Baghdad in preparation for attacks against Iraqi forces that could prove to be the climax in the Persian Gulf war, according to neutral military sources in Baghdad.

title: SWEDES NOW SAY SUBMARINE MAY HAVE ESCAPED TO BALTIC
description: Sweden's military conceded tonight for the first time that a foreign submarine that penetrated its coastal waters nine days ago may have escaped into the Baltic Sea.

title: Tudor Warship Attracts A Royal Diver
description: Prince Charles dove into murky waters off England's southern coast today to watch divers struggling to salvage the Tudor warship Mary Rose, the pride of the fleet of King Henry VIII.

title: Commodities; Why Some Avoid Rate Futures
description: THAT crumbling interest rates sent financial futures prices soaring last week was hardly a surprise. Prices of interest rate futures always move up when the yields on newer debt instruments are, or promise to be, lower than those on existing issues.

title: Two From Citicorp Join Hotel Concern
description: Two Citicorp executives have left the bank to join John B. Coleman & Company, which operates luxury hotels and manufacturing businesses. Fenton R. Talbott, 41 years old, who was senior vice president of Citibank's consumer services group, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Coleman company. Jeffrey E. Stiefler, 36, a vice president and business manager at Citibank for midtown and northern Manhattan, will be executive vice president.

title: Princess Rooney Wins
description: Princess Rooney, a Florida shipper who had won all four of her starts at Calder by a total of 37 lengths, made an easy transition to Belmont Park yesterday with an eight-length victory in the $116,800 Frizette Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sunset Park Harvest

title: 3 WORKERS HURT IN AN EXPLOSION AT NEWARK PLANT
description: An explosion ripped through a chemical plant here early this morning, injuring three workers - two of them critically - and touching off a fire that engulfed large portions of the plant.

title: A SMALL, FAR-OFF PLACE
description: President Reagan is host in Washington this week to President Suharto of Indonesia. The visit is inevitably going to be, in large part, an occasion to compliment an Asian leader important to the United States. But there is one uncomfortable issue that Mr. Reagan must raise if he is fairly to represent American concerns.

title: A New Jobs Program
description: Recognizing that politics again turns on jobs and not just inflation, Congress has finally created a successor to the maligned Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (C.E.T.A.) program. Though much less ambitious, the new legislation promises a credible effort to train the chronically unemployed for private jobs. What with Washington retreating on other domestic fronts, even so modest an undertaking on behalf of the poor deserves applause.

title: AMERICA AND CHINA: THE NEXT 10 YEARS
description: For the United States and China, 1982 marks t he start of the second decade of the new relationship ushered in by t he Shanghai Communique, issued at the conclusion of my first visit t o China, in 1972.

title: WOMEN IN MINES FIGHT TO BE ACCEPTED
description: Women say they are in the coal mines to stay, even though they are still fighting for acceptance nine years after the first woman broke the sex barrier in that male-dominated world.

title: 3 BROOKLYN ROOMING HOUSES MUST BE LICENSED, STATE SAYS
description: Three adjacent rooming houses for psychiatric patients and the elderly in Sea Gate, the private community on the western tip of Coney Island, have been found by the state to be operating illegally.

title: Advertising; Agencies Also Have Lean Year
