description: THE economy has been rougher on the ad agencies so far this year than their managers estimated going in, and now they think the fourth quarter is going to be worse.

title: Advertising; Plapler Leaves For Own Shop
description: Larry Plapler, a partner in Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver, which he helped to found 11 years ago, has quit the agency. He said Friday that he would be opening his own agency this morning.

title: VOLCKER'S TALK STIRS CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM
description: A statement over the weekend by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that Fed policy would be less tightly bound to money supply data was welcomed by private economists. But they also hinted that the results of the policy shift might prove to be limited.

title: Buffalo Savings In Palmetto Bid
description: The Buffalo Savings Bank, whose assets climbed to $9 billion from $3 billion earlier this year through mergers, has announced that it has agreed to acquire the Palmetto Federal Savings and Loan Association in Palmetto, Fla., for $38 million.

title: Bank in Illinois Closed
description: The Tri-State Bank of Markham, Ill., has been closed and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will pay off the bank's insured depositors, William Harris, Illinois commissioner of banks and trust companies, has announced. Mr. Harris said he had been monitoring the bank because of excessive loan and operating losses that he said had resulted from unsound practices. Deposits in Tri-State totaled $16.3 million on Sept. 18.

title: To Repair America
description: America's roads, bridges and transit, water and sewage systems are in terrible disrepair. After two decades of neglect of this ''infrastructure,'' hundreds of billions of dollars are needed to undo the damage. The New York City region alone could use about $40 billion in new infrastructure capital. Yet there is little hope that Federal grants, the primary source of such funds in the past, will be provided to meet the need.

title: LEVI'S 68-271 WINS
description: Wayne Levi needed only six holes to pick up three shots on the field en route to a final-round 68 and a six-stroke victory today in the LaJet Classic.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., has appointed David A. Thompson vice president of personnel and David C. Jones vice president of public affairs, and has elected to its board William D. Smithburg, president and chief executive officer of Quaker Oats Co.

title: The Judicial Election Farce
description: The myth that New Yorkers choose their judges at the polls suffered a double dose of reality in Brooklyn and Manhattan last week.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Just Like in Pictures

title: PIANO: ALICIA DE LARROCHA'S SWEEP
description: ALICIA DE LARROCHA, the Spanish pianist, played music by Poulenc, Schubert, Ravel and Debussy at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night. It was an original, if oddly balanced, program - with Schubert's A major Sonata (Op.120) totally isolated in style and tone from the French music that surrounded it.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO SEIZE INDIANS' COLLEGE
description: The Federal Government is attempting to take possession of a college for Indians near Sacramento, Calif., charging that an audit shows the school padded enrollment figures and illegally leased some of its land.

title: MUSIC: ROSEN, LOWENTHAL PLAY DUETS
description: NATHANIEL ROSEN, cellist, and Jerome Lowenthal, pianist, offered music for every taste at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. For those inclined toward youthful passion, there was Richard Strauss's F major Sonata (Op.6).

title: AL FRESCO PARTY EASES CHAUFFEURS' WAITING
description: While 500 guests danced to the music of the Meyer Davis Orchestra at the Meridian House Ball the other evening, another jovial gathering was taking place out on a nearby street under a full moon and a tethered 12-foot blimp.

title: WOMEN ON THE BENCH: A SHARING OF INSIGHTS
description: Only a few years ago, the entire population of the country's judges who were women could have met in a very small room. This weekend, a mere 25 percent of them converged on New York City, and they were more than 200 strong.

title: Nighttime Sun Mirrors In Orbit Called Feasible
description: A space agency study reports that the technology is available to place a series of half-mile-wide solar reflectors in orbit to provide the light of 56 moons and illuminate major population centers at night.

title: Bernice Kanner, Writer, Married to David Cuming
description: The marriage of Bernice Kanner, who writes the On Madison Avenue column for New York magazine, to David Cuming, a vice president of the Alleghany Corporation, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Justice Joseph Cerbone of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: REALTIONSHIPS
description: ''W HOSO would be a man,'' said Emerson, ''must be a nonconformist.'' As for being a woman, Emerson didn't say. Today, many people simply assume that conformity is a sex-linked trait -linked, that is, to being female. There's only one problem with the notion that women generally conform more easily than men to popular opinion or are more ''persuadable'': It isn't true.

title: Susan Feinberg Marries in Scarsdale
description: Susan Ann Feinberg, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Wilfred Feinberg of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Wayne Joseph Stelk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Winston Stelk of Oak Lawn, Ill. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Woman's Club.

title: Japanese Trade House Is Growing in the U.S.
description: The Nissho Iwai Corporation ranks only sixth in size among Japanese trading companies, yet it generated sales last year of more than $30 billion, trading 10,000 commodities throughout the world.

title: ISRAELI STATEMENT ON PULLOUT
description: Following is the text of an Israeli Cabinet statement today on Lebanon: The Cabinet discussed the situation in Lebanon and adopted the following resolution: 1. Israel continues to strive for a peace treaty with Lebanon. 2.

title: Advertising; Altschiller Wins Cellier des Dauphins
description: Altschiller, Reitzfeld Solin/NCK will be doing advertising for Cellier des Dauphins Wines on behalf of the Union des Vignerons des Cotes du Rhone.

title: Bhutto's Widow Seeks Medical Care Abroad
description: Pakistan's military authorities have ordered one of the country's best known political dissidents, Nusrat Bhutto, to appear before a medical board that will consider a request to seek treatment abroad.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The tragic fate of so many Jews destroyed without pity in the concentration camps has already been condemned, firmly and irrevocably, by the conscience of humanity.

title: Helmet Firm Sued
description: An 11th grade football player is suing a helmet maker, charging the firm's ''inadequate'' equipment resulted in his permanent paralysis during the first high school game he ever played.

title: LITTLE JOY FOR BUSINESS LEADERS
description: This looks like any number of old Northeastern factory towns. The only employer of any consequence is represented by a sprawling brick edifice of little architectural note beyond its sheer bulk, but the employer in this case is a hotel, the Homestead.

title: NEW RANGER LOOKS TO FUTURE, NOT 1980
description: When the Rangers selected the defenseman Bill Baker from the St. Louis Blues in the National Hockey League's waiver draft a week ago, the move prompted some snide remarks.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS REAGAN ON POLAND
description: The Soviet Union today assailed President Reagan's new sanctions against Poland, saying he was trying to worsen its economy to the detriment of the Polish people.

title: BUSINESS CHIEFS SEE NEED TO CUT MILITARY SPENDING TO TRIM DEFICIT
description: The chairmen of many of the country's biggest corporations are saying that the Federal Government's deficit has become so large that the Reagan Administration should consider cuts in military spending, along with cuts in spending on Social Security.

title: NEW YORK OFFICIAL REPORTS RECESSION IS FORCING DEFICIT
description: A senior New York State official said yesterday that state tax collections were falling sharply because of the recession. Unless new taxes are enacted by the Legislature, he said, the state could end the fiscal year with a deficit of more than half a billion dollars.

title: Cecil Cooper Goes From 'Goat' to Hero
description: The pennant had been won and the waves of questions had been answered when Cecil Cooper headed for the trainer's room next to the Milwaukee Brewer clubhouse, where he could be safe from the sprays of champagne and mustard and more questions.

title: JAPANESE AUTO MAKERS SAID TO PROFIT IN U.S.
description: Despite import restrictions, the American operations of three of Japan's automobile companies have been solidly profitable, a Japanese financial publication has reported.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1982
description: International Israeli troops will not leave Lebanon until the Beirut Government has signed a security agreement with Israel and all Israeli prisoners in Syrian and Palestinian hands have been returned, Israel announced. The Israeli Cabinet also demanded again that the Palestine Liberation Organization leave Lebanon first, before the mutual withdrawal of Syrian and Israeli troops begins. However, some Israeli officials said that was merely an opening argument. (Page A1, Column 6.) Solidarity called for resistance to a new law replacing the outlawed revolutionary organization with tame, Government-sanctioned unions. A letter smuggled out of Bialoleka Prison, signed by nine interned Solidarity leaders, said that joining the new unions would ''constitute an ignoble act of collaboration.'' Another message, signed by four fugitive Solidarity leaders, called for a four-hour strike on Nov. 10, the second anniversary of the union's registration by a Warsaw court. (A1:5.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Publishing Venture

title: Chicagoan Is Charged With Threat to Poison
description: A Chicago man accused of trying to extort $8,000 from a hospital by threatening to poison patients with cyanide in Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules was ordered held today on bond.

title: Miss Reynolds Married To L.M. Cornacchia Jr.
description: Maureen Anne Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Reynolds of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Lawrence Michael Cornacchia Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornacchia, also of Garden City. The Rev. John A. Alesandro, Chancellor of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Legend has it that one day long ago a cowboy stumbled upon one of nature's most awesome sights, the Grand Canyon. ''Wow,'' the cowboy is supposed to have exclaimed. ''Something sure happened here.'' Last week something spectacular happened in the financial markets. The stock market rose 79 points, trading surged to a one-day record of 147 million shares on Thursday and interest rates plunged until one Treasury bond now carries a price fully one-third higher than the face value at which it will eventually be paid off.

title: THE BREWERS ARE AWESOME
description: THIS Brewer club is so powerful that it has the most awesome lineup I have seen in my 38 years in baseball. Their batting order from the first hitter to the last (from the Alpha to the Omega) can hurt you in some way. They averaged 5.5 runs per game and have four players who drove in more than 100 runs and a fifth who had 97 r.b.i. Their team batting average of .279 was second only to Kansas City. Their Alpha hit .302 and their Omega hit .295. And in between they have averages like .331, .284 and .313.

title: WRONG PLACE FOR A NEW YORK CITY JAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: A FILM FOR CHILDREN ON INCEST
description: ''My Dad's O.K.,'' said 10-year-old Maureen, ''but he does things. ...'' ''What do you mean?'' asked her best friend, Jeannie, as they lounged in the sunny park near Maureen's home. ''Well,'' Maureen said, ''he comes in and pretends to tuck me in at night - but he doesn't. He puts his hands under the covers.'' ''Tell him you don't like it, to go away,'' Jeannie said. ''I can't,'' Maureen replied. ''It's a secret. I promised not to tell.'' ''But it's really his secret, not yours,'' Jeannie said thoughtfully. The conversation, about a subject that is real enough in the lives of many children, is the fictional dialogue in a new film intended to be shown to children to help protect them from sexual abuse by family members and adult acquaintances.

title: DERAILMENT STILL KEEPS 1,500 AWAY FROM TOWN
description: Before the sound of the boom, the predawn passage of Illinois Central Gulf's Train SGS 2-28 through this sleepy town was considered just another routine run of freight cars to the North and East from the Louisiana petrochemical centers of Geismar and Baton Rouge. Trains like this one, which ran a mile long and included 35 tank cars filled with a variety of hazardous and poisonous chemicals, are common sights here.

title: ROME JEWS MOURN VICTIMS OF ATTACK
description: Several thousand Jews gathered at the heavily guarded Rome Synagogue for a prayer vigil tonight to mourn the child who was killed and the 37 people who were injured in a terrorist attack there Saturday.

title: RECEPTION BY WESLEY WALKER
description: Today was no any-given-Sunday for Wesley Walker, the wide receiver for the Jets. It was different for a reason other than because he did not have a game to play as a result of the players' strike. It was different because, at 1 P.M. Monday, Walker will be married to Judy Epstein.

title: Jersey Woman Dies In Parkway Crash
description: A woman was killed and her husband injured when the car they were in hit a wooden guiderail on the Garden State Parkway near here and overturned, the state police said.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THOUGHTS OF TIMELY WRITER'S COURAGE EASE THE GRIEF
description: Francis Martin chooses to think that although everything that happens is meant to be, nothing is really as it seems. He tries to look at the other side of the obvious, to find a purpose in tragedy and a catch in joy.

title: HARD-SELL PROMOTION OF THE MOVIE 'GANDHI' BEGINS
description: To the studios that make or distribute them, different movies present different problems. Any movie starring Robert Redford and Jane Fonda, Burt Reynolds and a case of beer, or a group of adolescents discovering sex almost sells itself. But how do you sell a $22 million epic about the life of a prophet of nonviolence who was assassinated 34 years ago?

title: UNFLAPPABLE SUTTER KEPT CARDS IN FRONT OF THE PACK
description: In the old days it would've been the cavalry - horses pounding across the dusty horizon -that was coming to the rescue. Now, it's a man with a mess of curls spilling out from under a funny red cap and a beard and an even, though determined walk. He is Bruce Sutter. He is a one-man cavalry. He is more than enough.

title: NO TALKS WITH P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'BUGLES AT DAWN,' MUSICAL
description: ''THE cold passed reluctantly from the earth and the retiring fogs revealed an army stretched out on the hills, resting.'' The opening line of ''The Red Badge of Courage'' wouldn't inspire you to kick up your heels and sing, nor might the rest of Stephen Crane's Civil War novel about the emotions of youth in battle offer a spine for a show. But the courage of theater people in daring to try fashioning almost any theme into a musical has to be admired for its bravado and recklessness. The only way to know if a war story - for instance, James Michener's ''Tales of the South Pacific'' - can work as a popular musical is to try it, especially if you're Rodgers and Hammerstein.

title: C.F.A. Rejoins TV Fight
description: The College Football Association, which has fought the National Collegiate Athletic Association over control of football television rights, moved today to find alternatives to the N.C.A.A. television contracts by reactivating its seven-man television committee.

title: Elixir of Endurance
description: The old definition of a blood sport was one in which killing was involved, such as cock fighting or fox hunting. But, according to the current issue of American Health magazine, a practice called ''blood doping'' is becoming increasingly prevalent - if hidden and unacknowledged - in sporting events that involve long-distance performance, such as running, bicycling and swimming.

title: OUTDOORS: ART OF CATCHING BIG CRABS, NOW COMMON
description: ALTHOUGH blue crabs may be less numerous than they were a month ago in many areas of the Northeast where they can be captured by the casual harvester, this is the time when truly large specimens are most common.

title: News Analysis
description: King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, began here on Saturday a round of negotiations in which the future of both President Reagan's Middle East peace plan and the Palestine Liberation Organization are at stake.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BLACK-MARKET PILLS AND PSYCHICS ANNOY OFFICIALS
description: The bizarre deaths here of seven persons from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules and the pressures of the ensuing investigation appear to be bringing out some of the strangest and some of the better things in people.

title: LIMITS OF U.S. WAR POWERS RESOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Moriarity Bride Of Thomas Gallagher
description: Susan Virginia Moriarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond N. Moriarty Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., and Quechee, Vt., was married yesterday to Thomas Patrick Gallagher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gallagher of Dunedin, Fla. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

title: Taiwan Marks Anniversary
description: The Nationalist Chinese Government celebrated its 71st anniversary today with a call for reunification with the mainland under the non-Communist principles of Dr. Sun Yatsen, the founder of the Chinese republic in 1911. From the balcony of the Presidential building, President Chiang Ching-kuo told an enthusiastic crowd of 250,000 people he was confident China would be eventually united.

title: Nicaraguan Says War Could Delay Elections
description: Elections promised for 1985 might be postponed if the country is at war, the leftist junta said Saturday as Central American neighbors worked to ease tensions between Nicaragua and Honduras.

title: Seasonal Brain Disease Is Apparently Declining
description: Cases of mosquito-borne encephalitis, which has killed two people and sickened 39 others in 13 states so far this year, appear to be declining, but the South is not out of danger yet, health officials said.

title: Mauch Takes The Rap
description: MILWAUKEE HE sat on a metal folding chair in front of his locker, his eyes staring out from under the red peak of his blue cap, his elbows across his knees, smoke curling up from a cigarette dangling from the fingers of his right hand. Behind him a yellow phone rang, but Gene Mauch never moved. He probably never even heard it. But soon he got up and walked over to the entrance to the trainer's room where Reggie Jackson was standing.

title: A DIFFICULT WEEK FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: In the restorative warmth of California's tropical sunshine, President Reagan was spending this weekend at his ranch in the mountains here recuperating from what his advisers said was one of his toughest weeks.

title: The Role of Congress In Move Against Poles
description: A staff lawyer for the Senate Finance Committee said today that it was unclear whether President Reagan had authority to suspend Poland's most-favored-nation status without specific approval of Congress.

title: Cocaine Found Afloat in Gulf
description: A 35-pound bale of cocaine was found floating in the Gulf of Mexico Saturday night, but the authorities said they could not link the drug to any vessels in the area. The bale, valued at $22 million, was discovered by a Coast Guard cutter on routine patrol 15 miles east of Grand Isle, La.

title: MUSIC: NEW SWINGLE SINGERS BOW IN
description: THE Swingle Singers, whose vocal blend of Baroque, pop and jazz was one of the musical innovations of the 1960's, are back in town, now billed as the New Swingle Singers, at the Top of the Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, through Friday.

title: SHIFT FOR GERMAN PIPE MAKER
description: Mannesmann, Europe's biggest maker of steel pipe, is spending considerable money these days on other activities, as if it judged almost everything else it does as potentially more profitable than the pipe business.

title: INSURANCE EXECUTIVE AND A BANK DIRECTOR
description: Percy Chubb 2d, a retired insurance executive and chairman of the insurance underwriters, Chubb & Son, died Friday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital of a heart attack. He was 73 years old, and a resident of Chester, N.J.

title: Kirkland Asserts Policy On Poland Is 'Weak'
description: Lane Kirkland, the head of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., assailed President Reagan today for a ''weak response'' to the Polish Government's banning of the Solidarity union and said that the United States should lead an effort to force Poland into bankruptcy.

title: ACCORD IN ALASKA CALLS FOR PRISON
description: Alaska is about to settle a civil rights suit with an agreement that will obligate it to spend millions of dollars to build a 300-bed maximum security prison.

title: U.S. to Allow Ward Plan
description: A proposal by Montgomery Ward Enterprises, a subsidiary of Montgomery Ward & Company, to provide prepaid legal services for customers will not be challenged, the Justice Department has announced. Under the plan a nonprofit foundation would be set up to offer prepaid legal services for Montgomery Ward customers. Subscribers, for a monthly fee, would receive a number of services at no extra charge and would be entitled to additional services for specified charges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sights of Old Spain

title: SAUL DUFF KRONOVET
description: Saul Duff Kronovet, a tax lawyer and the president of Consolidated Properties, died Saturday when the airplane he was piloting crashed at the airport in Augusta, Me.

title: Liquor Law Stirs Opponents
description: A new city law to prevent liquor sales after 2 A.M. is producing strong reaction from opponents. A petition with 10,000 names and 2,000 postcards were delivered to City Council members before the approval of the measure Tuesday. Previously the sale of liquor was prohibited only on Sunday mornings.

title: DAKOTA VOTER LOYALTIES UNDER STRAIN
description: ''The election,'' said Representative Clint Roberts, the Republican candidate for South Dakota's only House seat, ''would be a lot easier if corn were $3 a bushel and wheat were $4.50.''

title: CITY OPERA: DIANA SOVIERO
description: WHAT was most welcome in Diana Soviero's singing of Violetta in a cast change in the New York City Opera's ''La Traviata'' on Saturday afternoon was that she was playing a part as well as singing it. The distinction is often lost on our operatic stages, but Miss Soviero not only had the prowess to negotiate the vocal difficulties, but took Violetta's difficulties seriously as well.

title: DANCE: 'POND,' NIKOLAIS'S WATERLILIES
description: BEAUTY is in the eye of the ticket-holder. And Alwin Nikolais's new work ''Pond'' is so beautiful that the audience at its New York premiere Saturday night at the City Center broke into applause before it even ended.

title: Heather Howard Smith, Lawyer, Weds
description: Heather Howard Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald William MacKay Smith of New York, was married yesterday to Roderick Anthony Cameron, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Golder Cameron of Seattle. The Rev. Dr. Laura Cameron Fraser, the bridegroom's sister, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Steel Rail Import Study
description: The Commerce Department has announced that it is investigating steel rail imports from Britain, France, West Germany and Luxembourg for possible unfair trade practices. It said shipments from Britain, West Germany and France were under study in connection with their possible sale in the United States at prices below the cost of production and also for possibly being illegally subsidized. Steel rails from Luxembourg are under investigation for possible receipt of Government subsidies, it added.

title: Nepal Cabinet Is Shuffled
description: King Birendra of Nepal restructured his Cabinet today, dropping 17 members and bringing in 25 new ones, the Government announced. The shuffle is believed to strengthen the powers of Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa, who gave up his position as Foreign Affairs Minister but kept his portfolio for Palace Affairs and acquired the post of Defense Minister.

title: 2d Devaluation Set by Finland
description: The Finnish Government devalued its currency by 6 percent today and imposed what it described as an extensive price freeze until Dec. 15.

title: Chrysler Units To Stay Open
description: Despite earlier threats to close its Trenton chemical plant at the end of the 1983 model year, the Chrysler Corporation most likely will keep the facility open at least through 1985, according to Chrysler and United Automobile Workers union officials.

title: ON FIFTH AVE., HISPANIC PRIDE AS PARADE HONORS COLUMBUS
description: Thousands of Hispanic New Yorkers honored their heritage and Christopher Columbus yesterday afternoon in a colorful, joyous, sundrenched march up Fifth Avenue, the United Hispanic-American Day parade.

title: Republic Steel Closings
description: Because steel orders have continued to drop, the Republic Steel Corporation announced, it has closed both its bar mills in Cleveland, idling about 600 workers.

title: Bridal for Robert Feinberg and Katherine Kelley
description: Katherine Virginia Kelley, daughter of Thomas Kelley and Miriam Richter, both of St. Paul, was married yesterday to Robert Mark Feinberg, son of Judge Julius Feinberg of the New Jersey Superior Court and Mrs. Feinberg of South Orange. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony at the Anchorage House in Alexandria, Va.

title: TROMBONE: SLIDE HAMPTON
description: SLIDE HAMPTON'S World of Trombones, an ensemble of nine trombones and a four-piece rhythm section that played at Seventh Avenue South over the weekend, is a group with provocative possibilities that are only beginning to be explored.

title: Peter Perpignano, Builder, Marries Margaret Cuomo
description: Dr. Margaret Immaculata Cuomo, daughter of Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mrs. Cuomo of Holliswood, Queens, was married yesterday to Peter Robert Perpignano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Perpignano of Bayside, Queens. The Rev. Anthony LoGatto performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens, and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. James McKenna.

title: RISE FOUND IN RADIATION EXPOSURE IN ATOM PLANTS
description: The total exposure to radiation of American nuclear power plant workers rose dramatically from 1969 to 1980, according to a report by a Congressional agency.

title: Born to Be Dull
description: The strike of National Football League players is beginning its fourth week, inflicting heavy financial losses on owners, players, vendors, television networks, advertisers and many other people whose livelihoods depend on pro football.

title: CONNECTICUT PLANT IS ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL DUMPING FOR YEARS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal and Philip Shabecoff and was written by Mr. Shabecoff.

title: Books: Dark Laughter
description: WHERE HAVE I BEEN? An Autobiogra- phy by Sid Caesar, with Bill Davidson. 280 pages. Crown. $12.95.

title: KNICKS' 2 CENTERS GETTING EDUCATED
description: The sound of Coach Hubie Brown's shrill whistle stopped the action at a recent Knick workout. Displeased with the way the guards and forwards were getting the ball to the centers Marvin Webster and Bill Cartwright, Brown emphasized:

title: Changing Outlook For Black M.B.A.'s
description: "Sure, I want to be chairman of the board," said Preston Satterfield, who graduated in June with an M.B.A. degree from St. John's University on Long Island. "But the reality is that even if everything goes very well for me, I will at best make low-level vice president."

title: WRONG PLACE FOR A NEW YORK CITY JAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA FIRES DESTROY 125 HOMES
description: Fast-moving brush fires, driven by the feared Santa Ana ''devil winds'' of autumn, destroyed an estimated 125 homes and injured scores of people early today and Saturday in southern California.

title: New Phillips Coal Chief Expects Increase in Use
description: Kenneth L. Smalley, a vice president of the Phillips Petroleum Company in charge of the minerals group, has been given the added post of president of the Phillips Coal Company.

title: U.S.I.A. Is Sending Folk Groups to Asia
description: The United States Information Agency is sponsoring a monthlong Asian tour by three American folk song and dance groups.

title: FREE DEMOCRATS AND GREENS LOSE GROUND IN BAVARIA ELECTIONS
description: The Free Democratic Party was eliminated from the legislature in the southern state of Bavaria today as Franz Josef Strauss's conservative Christian Social Union scored a convincing victory in local elections.

title: CANDIDATES IN HOMESTRETCH IN NEW YORK'S SENATE RACE
description: Pushing politely through blocked-off Astor Place, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan approached the speaker's stand next to the marquee for the District 65 union headquarters.

title: Copter Crashes in Scotland
description: A helicopter on a training flight crashed in a field 50 yards from the Aberdeen Airport runway this morning, killing the pilot and and co-pilot, the Aberdeen police said.

title: Granville Sues Oppenheimer
description: Joseph Granville, the wellknown stock market forecaster, has filed suit against an investment firm for more than $1.7 million, charging he was defrauded in a series of municipal bond deals.

title: POP-SOUL: DENIECE WILLIAMS IN CONCERT
description: soul soprano with a phenomenal multioctave range and strong gospel roots, has built a reputation on the more conventional side of her vocal personality. Miss Williams's appealing pop records feature a cooing high soprano singing confectionary songs of domestic and spiritual bliss.

title: No Working-Class Hero
description: New York City taxicab drivers, seemingly the epitome of the ''working-class guys'' that George Steinbrenner likes to evoke when chastising his high-salaried Yankee ballplayers, do not believe that Steinbrenner knows what he is talking about in that reference, and a majority of them think that the millionaire owner has ''ruined the Yankees.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Pittsburgh, in its National Football League game against Dallas recently, attempted a field goal on third down with seconds remaining in the first half. The kick was blocked and recovered by the Steelers, but Dallas was given the ball. Why? In the third quarter, Pittsburgh blocked a Dallas punt and was awarded possession, even though the Cowboys recovered the ball and advanced it far enough for a first down. Why? Finally, if a team in overtime misses a place kick on first down, does it retain possession for three more downs?

title: Bout to Tokashiki
description: Katsuo Tokashiki of Japan retained the World Boxing Association junior-flyweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Kim Sung Nam of South Korea.

title: HARVESTER DELAY SEEN ON DEBT
description: The International Harvester Company may have to extend its self-imposed deadline to ratify the latest changes in its debt restructuring plan beyond this week in order to persuade some of its suppliers to grant some needed concessions.

title: BOONTON 'BRAINSTORMS' ON A HOST OF TOWN ILLS
description: Something remarkable happened at the high school last week. A group of citizens spent four days ''brainstorming.'' And when they had finished, they had a clear vision of what was wrong with their town and what they intended to do about it.

title: U.S. May Sell Dairy Surplus
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that the Administration was considering selling surplus dairy products on the world market.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1982; The Economy
description: Wall Street expects interest rates to drop even further as the Federal Reserve Board intensifies its efforts to stimulate the economy as well as to bolster the fragile international financial system. A big question in the market is how much further rates may fall. (Page D1.)

title: Independent Publisher
description: In his fourth year as publisher, editor, writer, photographer and circulation director of the New England Football Newsletter, John Rice is pleased to report that he expects to lose ''only about $2,000 this season.'' He remembers that in the publication's first year, 1979, the red ink amounted to about $10,000; nearly $12,000 was lost in 1980.

title: MARTIN WARD, HEAD OF PLUMBERS' UNION, DIES
description: Martin J. Ward, president of the 380,000-member plumbers' union, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Is the N.R.A. in Trouble?
description: For years the National Rifle Association has had its way with the gun control issue, handily beating back serious legislation in Washington and choking off local initiatives. Its power is based on the money and passion of its adherents and its sophisticated use of the mails and the media.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Glow Is Gone

title: STUDIO INVESTIGATION CENTERS ON CONTRACT OF PRODUCER AT FOX
description: An inquiry by the Los Angeles District Attorney precipitated by the suicide of Norman Garey, a lawyer for Daniel Melnick, the movie producer, is focusing on a contract between Mr. Melnick and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation that was terminated last August.

title: SOLIDARITY CHIEFS URGE RESISTANCE TO UNION BAN
description: Leaders of the outlawed trade union Solidarity called tonight for resistance to a new law replacing their revolutionary organization with tame, Government-sanctioned unions.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Takes Final by 6-1, 6-1
description: Chris Evert Lloyd routed Andrea Jaeger, 6-1, 6-1, and won the $125,000 Maybelline Tennis Classic for the third straight time today.

title: SYRIA CHALLENGES ARAFAT AUTHORITY
description: Syria, in perhaps its sharpest attack on Yasir Arafat, said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization leader was not authorized to speak for the group in talks in Amman with King Hussein of Jordan.

title: Washington Watch; Coal Pipelines Gain Support
description: WASHINGTON THE White House, increasingly sensitive to the sharp rise in unemployment, may be softening its opposition to legislation that would clear the way for construction of seven or more large pipelines to carry coal.

title: U.S. WEIGHS AID FOR BOLIVIA AS CIVILIAN TAKES POWER
description: Civilian government returned to Bolivia today with the installation of President Hernan Siles Zuazo after more than two years of military rule.

title: Kurds in Iraq Free American Captive
description: An American held by Kurdish rebels in Iraq for almost five months has been freed and is in Switzerland on his way home, the United States Consulate said today.

title: Carl Leopold Wermer Weds Dr. Alison Knox
description: At the First Reformed Church in Fishkill, N.Y., yesterday Dr. Alison Marie Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Knox of Millwood, N.Y., was married to Carl Leopold Wermer, son of Prof. and Mrs. John Wermer of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Rodney Koopmans performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Americans Capture Titles In World Open Pairs Play
description: Two Dutch players and their many supporters at the world bridge championships here went quickly from euphoria to doubt to gloom early this morning.

title: The Talk of Kinshasa
description: If cities moved, Kinshasa's gait would be a fitful lurch. Its life rises and breaks, moments of high fever giving way to collapse and dulled sleep. Beneath the town, the Congo River smashes into rapids, but at Kinshasa the water sits - a dark brown lake, syrupy, cola gone flat.

title: Germans See Slight Growth
description: The contraction of West Germany's economy will not slow before the middle of next year, a panel of respected economists said today. The best the country can hope for is a 1 percent growth in real terms in 1983, the group added.

title: 10,000 Rwandans in Uganda To Leave After Being Evicted
description: Ten thousand Rwandan refugees have chosen to leave Uganda for Rwanda or Tanzania rather than obey a Ugandan order to move into two overcrowded refugee camps, a United Nations official said by telephone from Kampala today.

title: Landaluce Wins By 10 1/2 Lengths
description: Landaluce, the undefeated 2-year-old daughter of Seattle Slew, scored a 10 1/2-length victory in the $65,600 Anoakia Stakes at Santa Anita today.

title: Excerpts from debate, page B5.
description: The major candidates for United States Senator from New York argued over defense spending yesterday and accused each other of being unfair in discussing it.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $58,000 for the qr and $196,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including a tax credit of $320,000...D-Including a tax credit of $608,00

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANCHORAGE NEWS COMES BACK TO OUTSELL COMPETING TIMES
description: The two-page promotional advertisement in The Anchorage Daily News featured a photograph of its 250 employees wearing broad smiles, waving at the camera and holding a banner that said, ''Now Over 50,000.''

title: News Analysis
description: ''This is the great divide in New York politics: the voters of New York have not had so clear a choice in a generation,'' Lewis E. Lehrman declared last week in his first debate with his Democratic rival for governor, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Including a gain of $9.7 million from the sale of the company's Italian subsidiary

title: Investigators Seek Explosions' Cause
description: Investigators were working amid the seared rubble of a recycling plant today to find out what caused a series of explosions there Sunday morning that critically injured two workers.

title: A WORTHIER JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: 700 Teachers Strike At L.I. College
description: Part-time teachers at Nassau Community College went on strike today, according to Stephen Leonard, a spokesman for the Adjunct Teachers Association.

title: Tosco-AZL Link
description: The $95 million takeover of AZL Resources by the Tosco Corporation has been approved by directors of both companies, and AZL shareholders are expected to vote on it later this year, officials said.

title: POPE PIUS XII AND THE HOLOCAUST: A 'DAMNING' APPRAISAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowens Comes Back
description: Dave Cowens is back. The former Celtic star, now 33 years old, played in an exhibition game Sunday for the Milwaukee Bucks against Phoenix after a two-year retirement and scored 4 points.

title: GARVEY, DONLAN IN TALKS ON MEDIATION
description: The executive directors of the National Football League Management Council and the N.F.L. Players Association met for five hours in Washington yesterday to discuss mediation procedures that could help resolve the three-week-old strike.

title: PALMER SHIFTS DEFTLY TO BOOTH
description: Jim Palmer lost the last game for the American League Eastern Division title, but he pitched almost perfectly as an ABC analyst in Sunday's decisive fifth game for the league championship between the Milwaukee Brewers and California Angels.

title: LEBANON RECOVERY: SOME OPTIMISM
description: As Beirut begins to dig out from the rubble of seven years of war, there is a cautious optimism that if the new Government of President Amin Gemayel can assert itself, Lebanon will rapidly rebuild and again become the banking and financial capital of the Middle East.

title: A SHORTAGE OF OIL SEEN AFTER 1985
description: An oil shortage and price run-up is likely to undermine any Western economic recovery after 1985 unless countries do more to reduce dependence on imported oil, the International Energy Agency warned today.

title: Lilco Finds 9 in 10 Have a Color TV
description: Ninety percent of the homes on Long Island have at least one color television, and 70 percent have airconditioning, according to a survey of customers by the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: CAREERS THAT WOMEN CAN NOW PURSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: A PLENTIFUL BUT MISMANAGED AMERICAN RESOURCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Katherine Weidel Wed To Richard L. Reuter
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York yesterday Katherine Weidel and Richard Louis Reuter, 1977 graduates of Cook College-Rutgers University, were married by the Rev. Charles U. Quinn.

title: Prices Soar in Heavy Trading; Futures Rise Daily Limits
description: Prices of tax-exempt and corporate fixed-income securities soared yesterday in unexpectedly heavy trading. While the Government securities market was closed because of the Columbus Day bank holiday, all Treasury bill and bond futures, which always reflect moves in the cash market, advanced by their daily permissible limits.

title: London Market At New High
description: The London stock market soared to its highest level today, although company failures still are running at record levels and the British economy shows little sign of pulling out of recession.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd declared on May 7, 1982

title: ISRAEL PUTS CAPTURED ARMS ON DISPLAY
description: Each evening at 5 o'clock, the gates to Khordani, an army base near here, are opened and thousands of Israelis begin streaming in to walk through an exhibition of captured equipment that is stunning in size and variety.

title: Midway President Led New York Air
description: Midway Airlines of Chicago said yesterday that it had named Neal F. Meehan, former president and chief executive officer of New York Air, as Midway's president and chief operating officer.

title: An Easy Decision
description: Bryan Trottier had a conflict of interests last night when he was scheduled to appear in two leagues. He opted to play with the Islanders in a National Hockey League game against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Train Kills Woman in Newark
description: A woman was struck and killed today by a Conrail passenger train in the Broad Street station here. The woman, identified as Frances Horowitz, 59 years old, of Dover, was standing at the platform when she was hit by the train at 5:26 P.M., according to a railroad spokesman. Mrs. Horowitz was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where she was pronounced dead at 6:25 P.M., the spokesman said. The train was going from Hoboken to Dover.

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books Of The Times
description: THE NAMES. By Don DeLillo. 339 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: Body of 5th Salvadoran Found in Smuggling Case
description: The body of a Salvadoran has been found in a drainage ditch, increasing to five the number of victims from an aborted alien smuggling plot.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Canadiens 4; Nordiques 3
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Montreal took a 3-0 lead in the second period and then held off Quebec.

title: El Salvador Reports Flare-Up of Rebel Raids
description: Leftist guerrillas overran a 100-man army outpost 50 miles north of San Salvador, killing at least nine national guardsmen, officials said today. It was one of several new attacks on major targets carried out by the leftists.

title: THEATER: 'AMERICAN PRINCESS,' COMIC MUSICAL
description: THE title character of ''American Princess,'' a new musical at the Intar Theater, is a nice young single Jewish woman, Amanda Waxman (Mary Testa), who is overly devoted to spending her father's money and who wouldn't mind marrying a ''gorgeous goy with a M.B.A.'' Since we've met this heroine many times before - whether in Alan King's stand-up routines, Philip Roth's fiction or the Goldie Hawn film ''Private Benjamin'' - one may well question whether there's any reason to resurrect her again for yet another 90 minutes of ribbing. Judging from ''American Princess,'' there is not.

title: Connecticut Light
description: The Connecticut Light and Power Company, a unit of Northeast Utilities, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to borrow Eurodollars - United States dollars on deposit overseas - to avoid high domestic borrowing costs. Officials said that they are asking for approval to enter into a $75 million Eurodollar credit deal with 10 foreign banks.

title: Banks Shut for Holiday
description: Government offices and major banks were closed yesterday in observance of the Columbus Day holiday. Tables that do not appear today because of holidays are: Government Agency Bonds; Treasury Bills, Bonds and Notes; Foreign Exchange; Money, and the Japanese and Canadian stock exchanges.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TOXICS COMPANY WILL BE SUBJECT OF NEW INQUIRY
description: The Police Department of Waterbury, Conn., opened a criminal investigation yesterday into employee charges of illegal chemical dumping by a downtown toxic-waste treatment company. Lieut. Val Bochicchio of the detective division said the inquiry had been ordered by Mayor Edward D. Bergin.

title: AFRICANS AT U.N. CRITICIZE DELAYS ON NAMIBIA
description: Uganda's Foreign Minister, Albert Picho Owiny, told the 37th session of the United Nations General Assembly today that there was no justification for linking independence for South-West Africa and the presence of Cuban troops in Angola.

title: NEWBORNS FOUND ABLE TO IMITATE FACIAL EXPRESSIONS
description: MOTHERS have long been aware that by the time their babies are 3 months old, they readily respond to and imitate such facial expressions as smiles, frowns and pouts. Experiments at the Mailman Center for Child Development at the University of Miami Medical School have now shown that such imitation occurs within the first day or two of life.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONETARISTS DIVIDED ON FED'S STAND
description: Monetarists, the economists who watch the Federal Reserve most closely, were widely divided today over the signficance of the changes disclosed last week by the nation's central bank.

title: A PERSISTENT BREWER GETS A GOOD BOUNCE
description: Charlie Moore, the right fielder for the Milwaukee Brewers, approached the bouncing baseball in the fifth inning of the final game of the American League championship series. Reggie Jackson of the Angels rounded second and headed for third.

title: Kathleen O'Keefe Is Bride Of Gregg Amber, Lawyer
description: Kathleen Ann O'Keefe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. O'Keefe of New Cannan, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn., to Gregg Alan Amber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerry G. Amber of Colorado Springs.

title: Coast Guard Rescues 3 In Seas Off Cape Cod
description: Three men clinging to their overturned sailing vessel in 30- to-40-foot seas about 300 miles southeast of Cape Cod were rescued today by the Coast Guard.

title: BRIEFING
description: Collecting Old Debts

title: ON MAKING THE GRADE
description: ''The call'' - the one they have all been waiting for - is going out to the fortunate few among 4,508 applicants who mobbed an employment office last month after word spread that a complete staff was being hired for the new Long Island Marriott Hotel.

title: Shipyard Explosion Kills One
description: An explosion ripped through an oil tanker at a repair dock today, killing at least one man and burning three critically, the authorities said.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring pretax gain of $180.6 million for the qr and 9 mos from the previously announced amendment of a contract with Texaco Inc; results for the latest third qr include an unrealized gain of $4.1 million or 10 cents a shr from the translation of long-term foreign currency exposures

title: Price-Cutting On Saudi Oil
description: Saudi Arabian light crude oil, used as the benchmark in setting world oil prices, has been sold at a slight discount recently, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today.

title: PRICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 29
TIMELY WRITER BURIED QUIETLY AT BELMONT
description: Timely Writer was quietly buried under a flagpole in the Belmont Park infield Sunday night, one day after he shattered his left foreleg less than half a mile from the finish line for the Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: British Prices Up
description: Wholesale prices in Britain rose fivetenths of 1 percent in September after a rise of three-tenths of 1 cent in August, the Industry Department said today.

title: Mrs. Lloyd in Cup
description: Chris Evert Lloyd heads the United States team in the Wightman Cup matches to be played at Royal Albert Hall in London Nov. 4-6. Virginia Wade, Sue Barker and Jo Durie will play in the singles matches against Mrs. Lloyd, Barbara Potter and Anne Smith. Rosie Casals, who will play doubles, is the fourth American team member.

title: STATE FORMS UNIT TO INVESTIGATE DUMPING OF HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: There were no graduation exercises, no diplomas, no cheers from relatives, only a trip to the firing range, where 28 men and one woman sharpened their aim by firing bullets into targets with the short, snub-nosed revolvers that they will carry as undercover agents.

title: Smithkline Layoffs
description: The Smithkline-Beckman Corporation said it would put its domestic employees, including all officers, managers and other workers, on a five-day unpaid furlough before yearend. A company spokesman attributed the layoffs to a slowing of orders, ''mostly in our industrial products area, caused by the economy.'' Smithkline's stock closed at 71 5/8, down 2 3/8 from Friday.

title: Pentron Loans
description: Pentron Industries, which makes housewares, coils and plastics, said that it was negotiationg extensions of waivers of certain requirements under its loan agreements with its lead lender, the Union Commerce Bank in Cleveland. The company said it expected to get either an extension of amendments on the waivers on or before Oct.15. The company said that it had been in technical violation of certain loan convenants but that the Union Commerce Bank had waived the violations as of the end of the fiscal year 1982, which ended June 30.

title: BOLIVIAN MILITARY COMMAND IS REPLACED
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo replaced the entire military high command today in an attempt to place the armed forces under the authority of the new civilian Government.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEXICAN CONNECTION

title: Market Place; News Service Technology
description: CAN a tiny radio manufacturer piggyback its way to success as a supplier of hardware for a service offered by a leading news company? An obscure Florida manufacturer hopes so. Early returns on the Dow Jones Dowalert service indicate that Johnson Electronics may be right.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Diplomats See African 'Homelands'
description: The United States Embassy said today that American diplomats were making their first official visits to South Africa's so-called homelands, which Washington does not recognize as separate, independent countries.

title: LED MANY STOCKHOLDER FIGHTS
description: Randolph Godfrey Phillips, a retired financial consultant who led many highly publicized stockholder actions against corporate leadership, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Whose Birds Are They?
description: We think of them - the songbirds, hawks, shorebirds and waterfowl -as being ''ours.'' They live all around us and seem to be an integral part of our lives in the spring and summer months before they leave in the fall for Central and South America to avoid our winter cold.

title: WOLVERINE WORLDWIDE INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 11
Furnace Fumes Overcome 6
description: Six persons were overcome by gas fumes in their two-family house late today after they began using their furnace for the first time this season, fire officials said.

title: Cassie Murray Married To William Plapinger
description: Kathleen Jane Murray, an architectural preservationist with the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, was married in New York yesterday to William Arthur Plapinger, an associate with the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. Family Court Judge Stanley H. Nason performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: THE MIDEAST ROOTS OF THE ISRAELI MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SEARCHES CONTINUE AT BEIRUT CAMPS
description: The Lebanese Army began its second week of intensive searches and identity checks in Palestinian sections of West Beirut today and continued to raze illegal dwellings built by Shiite Moslems near the international airport.

title: Joseph A. Kaiser Dies; Retired Head of Bank
description: Joseph A. Kaiser, retired board chairman of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in Brooklyn, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: DICTAPHONE
description: The Dictaphone Corporation, a unit of Pitney Bowes, has introduced a word processor that would give users the ability to retrieve electronically stored information by typing questions in English, rather than in a specialized computer language.

title: HARVESTER PUTS PLAN TO DEALERS
description: The International Harvester Company begins a campaign tomorrow to persuade its truck and tractor dealers to approve new concessions needed to reduce the debt burden of the financially troubled maker of trucks and agricultural equipment.

title: DOW IS OVER 1,000 FIRST TIME IN YEAR
description: In the fourth day of an exuberant stock market rally, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 25.94 points yesterday and closed above 1,000 for the first time since mid-1981.

title: POPE, SPEAKING TO POLES, SAYS THE NATION DESERVES BETTER
description: Pope John Paul II voiced his pain and solicitude for his Polish countrymen today at a meeting that was attended by a group of leaders of the Warsaw regime.

title: POLICE HAVE FEW LEADS IN SLAYING OF PROSECUTOR
description: The police said yesterday that they had no serious clues to the assailant of a 31-year-old California prosecutor who died Friday of injuries suffered Sept. 30 when he was assaulted following an an argument on the Upper East Side.

title: Diving Machine Leading to Discoveries
description: A cross between a diving suit and a submarine is taking scientists into parts of the ocean where they have never gone before - cold, dark regions where luminous fish sparkle like stars on a moonless night.

title: KENNETH FRIEDE
description: Kenneth Friede, who retired in 1975 as New York regional manager of TV Guide magazine, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: MRS. REAGAN HAILS PARENTS' MOVEMENT ON TEEN-AGE DRUGS
description: Nancy Reagan today hailed the growth of a national parents' movement against teen-age drug abuse and maintained that drinking alcohol was ''just as much a problem'' as using illicit substances.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,861,000 for the qr and $5,854,000 for the 9 mos

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Better Than Nothing

title: TRADE DISPUTES MAR CANADA-U.S. TIES
description: Although both sides have made efforts in the past year to soften the rhetoric, the United States and Canada remain at odds on a number of trade and investment issues.

title: Health Aide in Denver Warns on Visine Drops
description: The director of the Rocky Mountain Poison Control Center urged people in Colorado today to stop using Visine A.C. eye drops after a Colorado man was reported to have suffered eye damage from drops spiked with acid.

title: Alabama Blacks Back Wallace as G.O.P. Foe
description: The state's most influential black political organization today threw its support behind former Gov. George C. Wallace in his bid for a fourth term, but not with great enthusiasm.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE MIDEAST ROOTS OF THE ISRAELI MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: MUBARAK FLYING TO THE SUDAN TO SIGN PACT ON JOINT POLICIES
description: President Hosni Mubarak will fly to Khartoum on Tuesday to sign an agreement to coordinate the political and economic policies of Egypt and the Sudan.

title: Roblin Loan Pact
description: Roblin Industries, which makes metal products, said its banks had granted it waivers of certain covenants in the existing loan agreement. As a result, it said, it was in compliance with the terms of the existing loan agreement. The company announced Friday it had reached agreement with its major bank lenders for deferral until Dec.15 of interest payments due on its term and revolving credit bank loans.

title: POP: THE WHO, BRITISH ROCKERS ON FAREWELL TOUR
description: THE four members of the Who are depicted as video images on the back of their new album, ''It's Hard,'' and each of them is striking a characteristic pose. Kenney Jones, the newest band member and a deliberately low-keyed replacement for the flamboyant Keith Moon, looks utterly anonymous behind his drums. John Entwistle, the stolid bassist, stands firmly at stage left. The vocalist Roger Daltrey is running in place and getting ready to twirl his microphone cord like a lasso. And Pete Townshend is wrenching sounds out of his guitar while leaping high in the air.

title: TESTS POINT TO GENUINE READING GAIN
description: ALMOST everyone seemed disposed to accept the idea that achievement was slipping in the New York City public schools during the 1970's, when pupils regularly registered low scores on reading tests. But now that scores are rising, universal consent that improvement has occurred seems to be slow in coming.

title: TERRORIST SUSPECT REPORTED SEIZED IN BOLIVIA AND FLOWN OUT ON A JET
description: A suspect in a 1980 right-wing bombing that killed 85 people in Bolgona, Italy, was wounded and captured in a gun battle in Bolivia and placed on a secret Alitalia flight to Rome, Bolivian officials said.

title: Monetarism In the Future
description: Lawrence K. Roos, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, visited New York last week at a time of conjecture that Federal Reserve policy makers would allow growth in the nation's money supply to remain above their targets and would focus their efforts instead on giving the economy a boost by lowering interest rates.

title: PIONEERING COGNITIVE PSYCHOLOGIST HAS EVERYONE'S MIND ON HIS
description: GEORGE A. MILLER, a professor of psychology at Princeton University, taught himself to juggle a few years ago and somehow it's been bothering him ever since. ''Now I can juggle,'' he says, demonstrating with empty hands. ''I know I have learned something, but I don't know what I have learned.'' Dr. Miller learned juggling from a book. There is nothing in the book but words and pictures. But, Dr. Miller observes, his large hands still moving, juggling is neither. ''I can propositionalize about juggling, but what I've learned is not propositional and not in pictures.''

title: Former I.B.M. Official Is Genigraphics Chief
description: Flavil Q. Van Dyke, who has spent his career until now at the International Business Machines Corporation, has thrown in his lot with a smaller company that has just gone on its own.

title: HONDURAS-NICARAGUA ACCORD
description: The Foreign Ministers of Honduras and Nicaragua met here Friday and agreed that their Defense Ministers would hold talks to try to settle their charges against each other of threatening Central America's peace.

title: MARVELS
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass. THE lowly lobster's place on the ocean floor roughly coincides with the rank scientists have long given it in the evolutionary line of ascent. But recent marine studies now suggest that it is, in fact, one of the most complex and, in a sense, most sophisticated of living creatures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Giving New Life To a Strange Game

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Why Queens Is Queens

title: Police Accused of Spying On Coast Citizens' Group
description: Undercover officers began infiltrating a citizens' group after its formation in 1976 and delivered accounts about it to the current and former police chiefs, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CLIMBS BY 8.7%; KAISER SHOWS SHARP INCREASE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter, aided by two one-time gains, increased 8.7 percent, while sales edged up 1.8 percent.

title: PIANIST: MICHAEL OELBAUM
description: THE urgency that Michael Oelbaum brought to the first movement of Beethoven's Opus 111 Piano Sonata on Sunday night in Merkin Concert Hall swept aside the niceties of musical respiration. It was a reckless performance, at once distressing and effective; it made the opening measures of the Arietta seem almost shocking in their reflective poise.

title: 2 SWEDES AND BRITON WIN NOBEL FOR CLUES TO BODY'S CHEMISTRY
description: Two Swedes and an Englishman won the Nobel Prize for medicine yesterday for their discoveries in controlling prostaglandins, a natural substance implicated in a wide range of human and animal illness.

title: Fisher Closings
description: The General Motors Corporation's Fisher Body division is considering closing three plants in Detroit because of excess capacity and obsolete facilities, Fred Craig, a G.M. spokesman said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CAMPAIGN DEBATE BY SENATOR MOYNIHAN AND MRS. SULLIVAN
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat-Liberal who is seeking election to his second term, and Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan, his challenger from the Republican, Conservative and Right to Life Parties. Social Security

title: Bonn Is Investigating Report About Slave Labor on Pipeline
description: A spokesman for West Germany's governing Christian Democratic Party said today that it was investigating charges that the Soviet Union was using slave labor to build the new natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shifting Rocks Kill Girl in Jersey
description: A 15-year-old girl was killed when some boulders she was climbing on shifted and pinned her, the police said today.

title: British Steel Losses Widen
description: The British Steel Corporation confirmed reports today that the company has almost abandoned its financial targets for 1982-83 after its losses widened sharply during the summer.

title: The Surprise Party
description: THE dinner in Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's honor was held in ''21's'' Hunt Room, with balloons and flowers, and the celebrated Gloria Vanderbilt of the jeans empire, the glazed black hair, the exceedingly white make-up and the bright red lips, was the first to arrive.

title: Rexall Leader Headed G.& W. Fashion Unit
description: The Rexall Corporation has a new leader. The drug company's chairman, president and chief executive is John E. O'Brien, who had been president of No Nonsense Fashions Inc., a division of Gulf and Western Industries.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have read that Matagorda Island, Tex., where a private rocket was tested on Sept. 9, is unsuitable for orbital launchings. Since the earth is basically round, what difference does it make where something is launched to go around it?

title: Cut in Krona Is Assailed
description: Sweden's Nordic neighbors have condemned its 16 percent devaluation of the krona and are trying to protect themselves from what they see as its disruptive effects.

title: WITNESS PLACES DEFENDANT AT SCENE OF MURDER OF FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A lawyer who lived in the same apartment complex as Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. testified today that the man accused of killing the judge shoved her out of his way in the apartment parking lot shortly before the judge was shot.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: WORLD STEEL EXECUTIVES EXPECTING POOR DECADE

title: Thousands Protest in Tokyo Against Expansion of Airport
description: More than 5,000 protesters, some of them burning rubber tires, surrounded the New Tokyo International Airport today in a demonstration against the expansion of the airport onto nearby farmland.

title: CITY SHOULD CUT 10,000 JOBS TO PAY COST OF RAISES, STATE MONITOR SAYS
description: New York City will have to reduce the size of its work force by about 10,000 positions to help pay for its new labor contract, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board said yesterday.

title: 'Solidarity Is Alive!'
description: So chant thousands of striking workers in the Lenin shipyards at Gdansk, where Solidarity was born. And so much for General Jaruzelski's ''normalizing'' of Poland with docile, factory-based union substitutes. The coffin is empty, and the Communist pallbearers confront a secular resurrection.

title: Cover-Up Charged
description: Joe O'Sullivan, the attorney for a student nurse at the University of San Francisco who says she was sexually assaulted by Quintin Dailey when Dailey was an all-America basketball player there, has accused the school of a ''civil conspiracy'' in an attempt to cover up the incident, Mr. O'Sullivan said he would file a civil suit today in San Francisco Superior Court. A spokesman for the school denied there was a cover-up.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 15
PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
THE VERY RICH AND THE VERY POOR CALL FLORIDA COUNTY HOME
description: Two Americas collide in a Rhode Island-sized county in the Florida sun. There is a life of ease in the millionaires' seaside spa of Palm Beach, with its Gucci shoes and Rolls-Royces. Forty miles inland, at the laborers' colony at Belle Glade, many who cut sugar and harvest celery are finding themselves out of work for the first time in years.

title: 2 Die in Nursing Home Fire
description: A faulty television set ignited a fire at a convalescent home that killed two elderly patients and hospitalized seven other people, officials said today. ''Most of the victims were treated for smoke inhalation,'' said Walter Johnson, spokesman for Coronado Community Hospital. ''The two who died had cardiac problems subsequent to their smoke inhalation.''

title: Flash Fire in a Texas Church Buckles Walls and Injures 8
description: A flash fire has buckled the walls and blown the windows out of a wood-frame church, injuring eight people. The authorities said today that bottled gas used to supply the heater apparently accumulated after a valve was left open Sunday, and the gas ignited while a class was in session at the Jesus' Name Holiness Tabernacle Church.

title: SHIPYARD WORKERS DEFY THE REGIME IN GDANSK STRIKE
description: Workers at the Lenin Shipyard, the birthplace of the independent trade union Solidarity, struck early today to protest legislation outlawing the union. The protest spread to other factories and to the streets of this Baltic port city.

title: N.B.A. to Review Deals by Clippers
description: Larry O'Brien, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, has ordered the 22 other franchises not to make any trades or conduct any business dealings with the San Diego Clippers, the troubled 23d franchise, without permission from the league office. It is the second time in three seasons O'Brien has taken such an action against an N.B.A. team.

title: CITY'S RETAIL SALES SLOW IN SEPTEMBER
description: Sales by New York City's largest retailers edged up in September but continued to reflect the same generally slow pattern that has been evident for almost all of 1982, according to a spot check.

title: SWEDES SET OFF MINE AGAINST 'POSSIBLE SUBMARINE'
description: The Swedish navy said that a powerful mine was set off today after it received ''indication of a possible submarine'' in an area south of the scene of the navy's recent search for a foreign submarine.

title: PLAYERS
description: ATLANTA Joe Torre's blue Braves cap was no longer tugged down over his dark eyes but tipped back on his head. It was over now, the game and the long, crazy-quilt season. And in defeat he had to dodge the sprays of champagne in the joyous Cardinal clubhouse in order to congratulate Whitey Herzog, the rival manager.

title: Cab Crash Injures 3 in a Restaurant
description: A taxicab cut off by a van jumped a curb yesterday and broke two large windows of a Chinese restaurant in midtown Manhattan, slightly injuring three patrons and the driver, the police said.

title: Israel's Invasion Toll Is Placed at 368 Dead
description: The military command announced tonight that 368 Israelis had been killed and 2,383 wounded in the war in Lebanon.

title: FELD BALLET 'STRAW HEARTS,' A NEW SUITE
description: ''STRAW HEARTS,'' Eliot Feld's newest ballet, is a gentle piece of pastel whimsy, affectionately danced by the Feld Ballet, and it's a sweet crowd-pleaser.

title: Auto Stockpiles Cut
description: The five United States automobile makers trimmed their inventories to an average 70-day supply at the end of September from an 88-day stockpile just a month earlier, an industry trade journal said today. Ward's Automotive Reports attributed the decrease to temporary plant closings, sales incentives and price reductions.

title: People Express Follows Plapler
description: As promised, Larry Plapler, who opened Plapler Inc. yesterday at 575 Madison Avenue, did have a $10 million account to announce - he said that People Express Airlines had followed him from Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver, along with the team that serviced it there. Plapler Inc. now has a staff of 12, Mr. Plapler said.

title: VICTIMS OF CRIME GET BRIEF REPRIEVE
description: Grand View Street had been quiet for the first time in more than a year because the police had put up barricades to halt a 24-hour-a-day parade of drug traffickers and thugs who preyed on poor and elderly residents.

title: ARAFAT-HUSSEIN TALKS SEEM INCONCLUSIVE
description: The negotiations between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will probably not achieve a formula for a Middle East peace settlement, according to officials close to the talks.

title: Chattem Consolidates Business at Marschalk
description: Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is picking up some $8 million in billings from Chattem Consumer Products, part of Chattem Inc. of Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE week was fierce with event and opening. Throughout most of it p rotocol and, in some instances, place cards seemed to have vanished.E gon Von Furstenburg gave a dinner, without place cards, to celebratet he opening of his Madison Avenue boutique bearing his name, at No. 8 00. But pheasant and gypsy violinists could not conceal that the b outique is a fashion mystery.

title: MITTERRAND ASKS STREAMLINING OF ANNUAL ECONOMIC MEETING
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France is proposing that the leaders of the industrialized democracies streamline their annual economic meetings to end their growth in size and turn them into small seminars.

title: MEXICANS HOPEFUL ON I.M.F. AID
description: The Government is confident that the International Monetary Fund will provide it with much-needed emergency credit without imposing an austerity program that could plunge the country into a prolonged depression, senior Mexican officials said today.

title: BROWN UNIVERSITY AWARDING STIPENDS FOR VOLUNTEER WORK
description: Brown University has awarded scholarship aid to students who have taken time off from college for volunteer public service.

title: Conversion is Proposed for Spy Ship
description: A panel of leading geologists, convened in response to a Congressional directive, has concluded that the multimillion-dollar cost of converting the giant Glomar Explorer from a salvage ship to a platform for deep-sea drilling seems ''modest when weighed against the scientific benefits it promises to yield.''

title: Porsche, Audi Prices
description: The price of average-equipped Porsche cars will increase 3.1 percent and the price of Audi cars will rise fivetenths of 1 percent, Volkswagen of America said today.

title: Wang British Plant
description: The British subsidiary of Wang Laboratories will build a $68 million computer manufacturing plant at Scotland's Stirling University, British Government sources said. They added that the Government would provide the normal financial assistance available to companies investing in British enterprise zones. The factory will employ up to 700 people when complete, they said.

title: Trade That Brewed The 6-Pack Series
description: ST. LOUIS Call it the Six-Pack Series. Here they are, two teams from America's foamiest cities - the Brewers, the team that has made Milwaukee famous again now that Stroh's has bought out Schlitz to form a triumvirate on tap with Miller and Pabst, against the Cardinals, owned by August A. Busch Jr., the braumeister of Michelob and Budweiser here on the banks of the Mississippi.

title: Back to Business
description: Alex Ramos, the once undefeated middleweight boxer from the Bronx, sadly learned that love conquers all. But now he has a rematch lined up.

title: MODERN DANCE: ELEANOR KING SHARES BILL WITH ELEANOR ZALL
description: THE city's most eclectic dance programming is to be found at the Theater of the Riverside Church, which regularly presents dance that fits easily into no particular familiar category. Take Eleanor King, for instance, who shared a program Saturday night with Deborah Zall.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Exxon Finance N.V. said it had completed a two-part sale of $300 million of 11 percent guaranteed notes due in 1987 at an average price of 98.412; Exxon said $165 million of the bonds were sold in negotiated transactons between Oct.7 and Oct.11.

title: Change of Scene
description: The Athletics Congress national cross-country championships, originally scheduled for Belmont Park on Nov. 27, will be held instead at the Meadowlands, on Nov. 28.

title: A Look Down at Lightning
description: Photographs of lightning in cloud tops have produced new insights into the behavior of severe storms and important data for the development of a space-based sensor for monitoring lightning as part of weather-forecasting observations, according to scientists at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala.

title: Hilton Hotels' Net Off by 27%
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the fiscal third quarter fell 27 percent, to $19.3 million, or 73 cents a share, from $26.4 million, or 99 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Revenue dropped 29.1 percent, to $30.9 million from $43.6 million.

title: News Analysis
description: In an interview early this year, Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, discussing the vaunted political recuperative powers of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., said, ''He's supposed to have nine lives, but I think he's probably used all of them up.''

title: No Headline
description: Panel of Israelis Opens Inquiry Into Massacre

title: WERNER HERZOG'S STRUGGLE FOR MIND OVER MATTER
description: ''HOW pure is the diamond that has come out of all this dirt and mud?'' Werner Herzog asked rhetorically about ''Fitzcarraldo,'' the film that closed this year's New York Film Festival to critical acclaim and that opened yesterday at the Paris Theater.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Helping Volunteers To Decide Whom to Help

title: FIRST ARKANSAS BANKSTOCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income...D-Including an extraordinary gain of $497,201 from the early retirement of capital notes

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: REP. CHISHOLM'S ANGRY FAREWELL
description: ''They've said I like whitey, that I'm too close to Hispanics, that I'm not black enough,'' Shirley Chisholm said. ''I resent people evaluating me on the superficial manifestations of my behavior. Why don't they ask me to explain?''

title: GUATEMALANS TELL OF MURDER OF 300
description: Guatemalan soldiers participating in an offensive against rebel forces entered the tiny Guatemalan Indian village of San Francisco on July 17 and killed over 300 men, women and children, according to survivors who have taken refuge in Mexico.

title: Colombia Bank Nationalization
description: Colombian President Belisario Betancur said today that the Government had nationalized Banco del Estado, the fourth-largest private bank in the country, under an emergency decree declared Friday.

title: GUYANA'S LEADER THRIVES AS HIS NATION FOUNDERS
description: Amid growing food shortages and hardship, increasing layoffs and dismal economic prospects, the Government of Forbes Burnham has never been more unpopular - or more solidly in power - according to Guyanese who support and oppose him.

title: Fonar Scanner Tie
description: The Fonar Corporation of Melville, L.I., said it had signed an agreement valued at $31 million for the purchase and distribution by Universal NMR Inc. of Fonar's mobile nuclear magnetic resonance whole body scanner. Under the agreement, Universal will purchase 25 Fonar scanners and become the exclusive national distributor of the units. The contract covers a period of three or four years, depending on when the scanner receives Food and Drug Administration approval, and is renewable for an additional three-year period.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: LOOKING at a phonograph record, you can readily see the grooves in which the stylus rides as it picks up the stored audio information. You can't easily discern the individual analog indentations in the grooves representing, say, a particular clarinet in the orchestra playing Franz Krommer's Clarinet Concerto. But you can visually discover certain things about the recording's content from the physical medium itself.
