You can, for instance, determine the silences between movements, the comparative lengths of the movements and even - if you wish, and with a bit of patience - those times when the orchestra dominates and those when the solo parts are at their strongest.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: MOST children acquire their knowledge about sex and sexuality in ''a chaotic, disorderly and incomplete collection of learnings,'' the Sex Information and Education Council of the United States contends. The council, known as Siecus, urges that schools provide sex education as a means of bringing order into the existing chaos, but it warns that the issue is often deliberately turned into a political controversy.

title: GEORGE BAMBERGER'S WORLD SERIES SCOUTING REPORT
description: In SportsMonday yesterday, Manager Clyde King of the Yankees gave his scouting report on the Milwaukee Brewers, the American League's representative in the World Series. Today New York's other baseball manager, George Bamberger of the Mets, reports on the National League's representative, the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Youth Who Fled Russia Wins Paganini Medal
description: Alexander Markov, a 19-year-old violinist who emigrated from Russia to the United States six years ago, has been awarded the Gold Medal at the 1982 Paganini International Violin Competition in Genoa, Italy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cargill Inc., Minneapolis, has elected Daniel R. Huber president of the Commodity Marketing division.

title: Threat of Holy Wrath Pays Off in Car Theft
description: The hostess of a gospel radio program threatened to call down the wrath of God on the thief who stole her car.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS
description: Like the hare, the Rangers sprang to a 3-0 lead last night at Madison Square Garden. Like the tortoise, the Islanders kept pushing resolutely along, and eventually it was they who won, 4-3.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Amenities Are Preserved For an Alma Mater

title: TV: 'TAKE YOUR BEST SHOT' ON CBS
description: FOR most people, the actor is an enviable creature who spends an exciting life upon the wicked stage or, at the very least, in a lucrative television series. In reality, the poor thing spends most waking hours looking for a job, making little money and competing for roles that offer little or no artistic satisfaction. This is the side of an actor's life that is explored in ''Take Your Best Shot,'' a new made-for-television movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock this evening. The executive producers and writers are Richard Levinson and William Link, whose past credits (''Columbo,'' ''My Sweet Charlie,'' ''That Certain Summer'') have secured them reputations several cuts above the average.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Milwaukee Brewers, World Series, first game, at St. Louis. The Brewers pit their hitting power, with four players who drove in more than 100 runs each, against the Cardinals' speed, defense and ace reliever, Bruce Sutter.

title: APECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,387,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,351,000 for the qr and $2,630,000 for the 9 mos

title: NARCO SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $121,000 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations and a gain of $310,000 or 17 cents a shr for the qr and 9 moson the sale of land

title: TRAIN GUNMAN YIELDS CHILD, THEN GIVES UP, WITH 2 DEAD
description: A gunman who apparently feared that the police would kill him surrendered today and was charged with murdering his sister and her infant son in a three-day standoff in an Amtrak sleeper car. He had released the woman's 3 1/2-year-old daughter unharmed.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $55,929,000

title: FALTER
description: WASHINGTON AFTER 10 years and expenditures of more than $50 billion, the nation's drive to clean up its sewage - a mix of domestic and industrial waste - appears to be faltering. The goal of achieving ''fishable-swimmable'' waters wherever attainable by next year is receding under the impact of rising costs, changing political pressures and scientific uncertainties as to the best course of action.

title: THE MIDEAST ROOTS OF THE ISRAELI MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: INCREASING JOBLESS RATE IN TEXAS SHAKES ITS POLITICS AND CONFIDENCE
description: Texas, once thought to be the state of perpetual boom, is being swept by unemployment on a scale it has not experienced in recent times.

title: COLLEGES FEELING STRAIN OF DELAY IN U.S. FUNDS
description: With some Federal loans and grants now delayed for more than three months, college students who depend on them to pay tuition and living expenses have found their schools willing to help fill the gap.

title: PLAYS
description: Marshall Edwards is not the kind of ballplayer from whom great things might be expected. Consider that it took him eight years to get out of the minors. And consider that, at age 30, he is still regarded as a reserve, a rookie waiting behind the Milwaukee Brewers' talent-packed starting lineup.

title: Man in China Tries to Hijack A Tour Bus Full of Americans
description: A man tried to hijack a bus full of American tourists in north central China Sunday but was overpowered by the police before he could carry out his plan to defect to Taiwan, tour sources said today.

title: Warriors to Match Offer
description: The Golden State Warriors will match the five-year, $4.5 million offer sheet that the free-agent forward Bernard King has signed with the Knicks, but have made no decision whether to keep him after that or trade him, a team spokesman said today.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market, caught up in a historic rally, surged onward despite the Columbus Day holiday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 1,000 for the first time since April 28, 1981, rising 25.94 points, to 1,012.79. It has gained 110.96 points in the last four sessions as the conviction that interest rates will continue to fall has spread among investors. Volume for the day rose to 138.5 million shares, the second highest ever after last Thursday's 147.1 million shares. The high turnover was considered impressive because many banks and companies were closed for the day. (Page A1.)

title: Wells, Rich, Greene Closing Two Offices
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, the 21st-largest American agency, with 1981 billings of $435 million, is closing a couple of its offices and consolidating their business in others.

title: Required Reading; A New Stage?
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser, in remarks to the Executive Club, Helsinki, Finland. Oct. 6, 1982: In brief, in my judgment, we are at one of those stages similar to the immediate post-World War II period -and then later in the 50's - when basic and long-term historical commitments may be in the process of being shaped. The first phase produced the prolonged Cold War; the second produced a prolonged and rather uncertain detente. I believe we are at a stage in which we may be faced with acute intensification of the already unstable American-Soviet rivalry, but it is still possible that the present conditions of uncertainty could be exploited to start again stabilizing the relationship and developing what should become a genuinely more comprehensive and reciprocal detente.

title: THIRD-WORLD GAMES
description: In the furor over events in Lebanon, some of the few real keystones of a little practical order in the world are being threatened.

title: NEW TOOLS IN THE M.D.'S OFFICE
description: The health-care industry, seeking new profits in a potentially lucrative market, is moving dignostic testing out of the medical laboratory and into the doctor's office. At least one Connecticut man is lucky the shift is taking place.

title: Dr. Bernard B. Siegel, Specialist on Allergies
description: Dr. Bernard B. Siegel, chairman of the allergy division at the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn, died Sunday of a heart attack at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: EGYPT TO GET EARLY WARNING CRAFT
description: Grumman Aerospace announced today that it had signed a contract with Egypt that was expected to result in a $500 million sale of four Hawkeye early warning aircraft to Cairo.

title: Anacin's Maker Moves To 24-Hour Plant Shifts
description: American Home Products said yesterday that its Whitehall Laboratories were increasing production ''around the clock'' of its Anacin-3 aspirin-free pain reliever to meet demand because of the poison found in capsules of the leading brand, Extra-Strength Tylenol.

title: DUTCH POLICE BATTLE PROTESTERS
description: Protesters fought with the police here today after officers drove squatters from a building they had occupied to demonstrate against housing shortages.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Including interest and other income of $45,741...C-Net income including interest and other income of $196,563

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Seating Co. said it had agreed to be acquired by Fuqua Industries, which already owns 39.8 percent of American's stock outstanding; American shareholders will receive 1.1 Fuqua common share for each American share.

title: Moore Bout Put Off
description: Davey Moore's World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title defense against Gary Guiden Oct. 23 at Atlantic City has been postponed because of a cut Moore received in training.

title: Zimbabwe Tries a White M.P.
description: A white Zimbabwean member of Parliament went on trial today on charges of plotting against the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe. Wally Stuttaford, who was detained last December, pleaded not guilty.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There has to be a cutback in the labor base. It will also be necessary to look to the revenue side.

title: Bridge:; Two Major Upsets Mark Rosenblum Team Contest
description: Most of the top-ranked teams survived early play in the Rosenblum Team Championship, the concluding event of the World Bridge Federation's Olympiad, but there were two major upsets. One of the strongest American teams was defeated, as was a top European team.

title: MILAN SEASON: A LESSON LEARNED
description: The criticism hurt last season, in the pocketbook as well as in the heart. The world was not ready for the Renaissance page and medieval knight costumes that fascinated the Italian fashion designers then. So this time they cleaned up their act for spring and summer. Lines are clean and flowing. Black and white and beige and other neutral colors are dominant.

title: British Failures Up
description: Business failures in England and Wales continued at record levels in the third quarter, with 2,899 company liquidations, according to a survey by Dun & Bradstreet Ltd. This was up from 1,664 failures in the period last year.

title: WHY BOPHUTHATSWANA NEEDS AMERICAN STARS
description: Liza Minnelli had them streaming by the thousands this weekend to this nominally independent tribal ''homeland'' in the parched and scrubby reaches of the northern Transvaal.

title: Maintaining U.S. Bases Defended by Marcos
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the futility of the United Nations and the need for a regional balance of power make it necessary to maintain United States military bases in the Philippines.

title: 2 WEEKS AFTER TRAIN DERAILED, RESIDENTS TO BEGIN TREK HOME
description: About 2,700 people who had been evacuated from Louisiana's worst railroad disaster were told today that they could go home.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third qr include nonrecurring gains equal to 16 cents a shr for the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in Showtime, a pay television service, and 11 cents a shr on the purchase of $58 million of the company's debentures

title: CATHOLIC ELITE
description: When 1,000 of Boston College's alumni and friends came home to the school's Great Hall for a banquet Sunday night, it looked like a convocation of power brokers: a demonstration of the Irish and Italian Roman Catholic communities' ascension to the heights of Massachusetts and Washington.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Settlements, Short Memories
description: New York City and its uniformed services unions brought down the curtain on this year's round of labor talks by agreeing to a 16 percent wage increase over two years. The negotiators mercifully spared the city a strike; the burden of financing the settlement may not be so merciful.

title: DEMOCRATS OPPOSE TV ON REAGAN TALK
description: Officials of the Democratic Party filed a formal protest yesterday with the major television networks, urging them not to carry an address on the economy by President Reagan tomorrow night because of its partisan political nature.

title: No Headline
description: In New Jersey, the unmentionable is now openly discussed and the unthinkable may even happen. Politicians are talking about, yes, the income tax, and two of the state's senior legislators are proposing that it be increased.

title: East Bloc Ministers to Meet
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that the foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact would meet here in the second half of October. They last met in December 1981 in Bucharest.

title: A RICH FOE AND REAGAN VEX G.O.P. INCUMBENT
description: After visiting a place where the Government was giving free powdered milk to his needy constituents, Senator David Durenberger spoke of the anxieties that can afflict a freshman Republican seeking re-election in this season of need.

title: STEELMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONTINUED RATE DROP EXPECTED
description: Government securities dealers meeting here expressed optimism today that the combination of a weak economy and a Federal Reserve policy aimed at pushing more money and credit into the financial system would continue to bring interest rates down for months to come.

title: Chess: Andrei Sokolov of Moscow; Wins World Junior; Title
description: Andrei Sokolov, a 19-year-old Muscovite, scored 10-3 to win the World Junior Championship in Copenhagen. Igor Stohl of Czechoslovakia took second place - finishing a point behind Sokolov - in an international field of 52 entrants under the age of 20.

title: THE STRATEGY OF PRICING AUTOS
description: Along with the usual shiny new models and assertions of better mileage, performance, durability and quality, the nation's automobile companies have come up with some good news for potential buyers of 1983 cars: prices only slightly higher than on the 1982 models after years of steep annual increases.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW PATTERNS
description: The shrill argument over I.Q. and race will probably be with us as long as the walls between blacks and whites are standing, but some data emerged last week that should at least throw a few grappling hooks over those walls.

title: Jubilant Fan Dies In Milwaukee
description: One celebrant was killed after the Milwaukee Brewers won the American League pennant Sunday. Jackie Kamke, 22 years old, was fatally injured during the third hour of post-game celebration when she fell under a wheel of a truck on which she and about 10 other persons were climbing after leaving a tavern.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock divd declared Sept 27, 1982

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: SUNE KARL BERGSTROM
description: For a long time the name Dr. Sune K. Bergstrom has been more or less synonomous with prostaglandin research, to which he has devoted 35 years of his life. His name has also been associated since 1975 with the Nobel prizes, though as a representative of the benefactors rather than one of the beneficiaries. He is chairman of the Nobel Foundation in Stockholm. But it was only a matter of time, most scientists agree, before Dr. Bergstrom's research would be honored by the foundation he directs - for the work was too important to be ignored through any concern over apparent conflicts of interest.

title: DISSIDENT UNIONIST RAISES LEADERS' IRE
description: Ronald W. Weisen, speaking at the union hall up the street from the Homestead Works, was at it again. ''We've sued U.S. Steel five times,'' Mr. Weisen, the head of local 1397 of the United Steelworkers of America, was saying. ''As I told McBride, how come we got to do that? The international should be doing that. The international should be representing the members. That's what we pay dues for.

title: Thrift Unit Losses Mount
description: Eighty-two percent of the nation's savings and loan associations lost a record $3.3 billion in the first half of this year, more than double the losses in the similar period of 1981, the Government said today.

title: Article 214215 -- No Title
description: Jostens Inc. of Minneapolis said that its board of directors would not accept a leveraged buyout proposal from a group of investors to aquire the company for $26.50 a share. Based on 12.6 million shares outstanding, the offer would be worth $333.9 million.

title: WHO WILL PAY WHAT FOR HEALTH CARE?
description: The fate of the Reagan Administration's proposal for a new system of paying hospitals for Medicare services depends, to a large extent, on difficult decisions yet to be made by Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: REAGAN, IN TEXAS, HAILS SURGE BY STOCK MARKET
description: President Reagan, making his first campaign stop since the unemployment rate climbed Friday, appealed to voters here today to focus instead on the boom in stock market prices as ''a vote of confidence in America's future'' and ''a leading indicator of what's coming down the road'' for the economy.

title: COTTON FARMERS IN MISSISSIPPI ANTICIPATING A BUMPER CROP
description: Wayne Bush, a farmer, and most of his neighbors have reason to smile as they look out over the cotton fields in the Mississippi Delta. It has been almost two decades since they saw as much cotton ready for harvest.

title: What's Fair in Medicare
description: A month before the election: an odd time for President Reagan's budget office to revive the idea of subjecting Medicare coverage to a means test. Secretary Schweiker of Health and Human Services hurriedly fled from the proposition and proposed reforming the way hospitals are paid. Yet neither approach precludes the other. The cost of health benefits is an urgent problem and controversial remedies have to be faced.

title: Heinz Signs Zimbabwe Deal
description: Pittsburgh's processed food giant, H.J. Heinz, today signed a $30 million partnership deal with the Zimbabwe Government for the joint takeover of a local vegetable oils company.

title: Argentina Arrests A Falkland General
description: Gen. Americo Daher, who commanded Argentine ground forces during the first weeks of the war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, is under arrest for his recent criticism of the way his superiors handled the conflict, military sources said today.

title: British Airways Loss
description: British Airways is expected to announce a loss of more than 500 million, or about $850 million, for the year ended March 31 in its annual results next week, industry sources said today. The loss is higher than previous estimates and comes despite a small trading profit during the year.

title: Advertising; TV News Skirmish Heats Up
description: A new factor in the tooth-and-nail fight that New York's three n etwork-owned TV stations are having over viewers for their evening n ews programs is the 5 P.M. edition, which has been a three-way race o nly since WCBS-TV entered the fray in January.

title: THOMAS AND OGLIVIE AILING
description: Gorman Thomas, one of the Milwaukee Brewers who had made Harvey's Wallbangers famous, admitted today that ''we didn't play the Wallbanger kind of ball, but we played well enough to win, and now we're playing in the World Series.''

title: SEA GIVES UP THE MARY ROSE, PRIDE OF HENRY VIII
description: The Mary Rose, which sank during an engagement with the French under the gaze of King Henry VIII in 1545, returned to the surface today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 13.00-13.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CUOMO REJECTS 'DRAMATIC' CUTS IN TAXES
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, said yesterday that looming deficits in the state budget ruled out any ''dramatic'' tax cuts, but that there should be ''discreet'' reductions over the next few years in taxes that discourage business development.

title: BREWERS SELECT CALDWELL
description: The Milwaukee Brewers and the St. Louis Cardinals today named Mike Caldwell and Bob Forsch to pitch the opening game of the 79th World Series, the first in 14 years between teams from the Midwest.

title: A Remorseful Fan
description: A Milwaukee Brewer fan was the one who caught the fly that resulted in a homer for Bob Boone of the California Angels in the playoff game last Friday afternoon won by the Brewers, 5-3. Eddie Becker, from Racine, Wis., caught the ball at the edge of the left-field bleachers.

title: WRONG CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICY
description: Almost two years after they were adopted, the Reagan Administration's confrontational policies in Central America have produced not victories but, rather, widening conflict and dwindling options for peaceful solutions.

title: Bush, in City, Sees Economic Upturn
description: Vice President Bush, campaigning for Republicans in New York City, said yesterday that the country had ''come through the worst'' and faced a bright economic future despite record high employment.

title: Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it had agreed to sell its holdings in Dow Chemical Korea Ltd. and the Korea Pacific Chemical Corporation to the Korea Explosives Group for $60 million.

title: Report Says Suzuki Will Offer to Resign
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan will offer to resign as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, the Kyodo News Agency reported today.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1982
description: International Shipyard workers in Gdansk, the birthplace of Poland's independent trade union Solidarity, struck to protest the outlawing of the union, and the protest spread quickly to factories and the streets. Clashes between demonstrators and riot policemen continued for many hours, with the protesters burning barricades and the police hurling volleys of tear gas and concussion grenades. (Page A1, Column 6.) A throng of Sikh militants armed with swords and spears stormed Parliament House in New Delhi in a protest over the deaths of 34 Sikhs in police custody. Four persons were reported killed and five wounded and at least 60 policemen were said to be injured. Varying reports said the demonstrators totaled 3,000 to 5,000 members of a group that seeks greater Sikh autonomy within India. (A1:5-6.)

title: 4 DIE, MANY HURT, AS ANGRY SIKHS STORM INDIA'S ASSEMBLY BUILDING
description: Four people were reported killed and five wounded today, and at least 60 policemen were said to be injured, when Sikh militants armed with swords and spears stormed the Parliament House. The attack was in a protest related to the deaths of 34 Sikhs in police custody in Punjab last month.

description: Player Avg HR RBI First Base Keith Hernandez .299 7 94 Second Base Tom Herr .266 0 34 Third Base Ken Oberkfell .289 2 34 Mike Ramsey .230 1 21 Shortstop Julio Gonzalez .241 1 7 Ozzie Smith .248 2 43 Catcher Glenn Brummer .234 0 8 Darrell Porter .231 12 48 Gene Tenace .258 7 18 Outfielder Steve Braun .274 0 4 David Green .283 2 23 George Hendrick .282 19 104 Dane Iorg .294 0 34 Willie McGee .296 4 56 Lonnie Smith .307 8 69 Pitching W L S ERA Joaquin Andujar 15 10 0 2.47 Doug Bair 5 3 8 2.55 Bob Forsch 15 9 1 3.48 Jim Kaat 5 3 2 4.08 Jeff Lahti 5 4 0 3.81 Dave LaPoint 9 3 0 3.42 John Martin 4 5 0 4.23 Steve Mura 12 11 0 4.05 John Stuper 9 7 0 3.36 Bruce Sutter 9 8 36 2.90 Milwaukee PlayerAvg HR RBI First Base Cecil Cooper .313 32 121 Second Base Jim Gantner .295 4 43 Ed Romero .250 1 7 Third Base Roy Howell .260 4 38 Paul Molitor .302 13 71 Don Money .284 16 55 Shortstop Rob Picciolo .243 0 4 Robin Yount .331 29 114 Catcher Ted Simmons .269 23 97 Ned Yost .276 1 8 Outfielder Mark Brouhard .269 4 10 Marshall Edwards .247 2 14 Charlie Moore .254 6 45 Ben Oglivie .244 34 102 Gorman Thomas .245 39 112 Pitching W L S ERA Dwight Bernard 3 1 6 3.76 Mike Caldwell 17 13 0 3.91 Rollie Fingers 5 6 29 2.60 Moose Haas 11 8 1 4.47 Pete Ladd 1 3 3 4.00 Bob McClure 12 7 0 4.22 Doc Medich 12 15 0 5.04 Jim Slaton 10 6 6 3.29 Don Sutton 4 1 0 3.29 Pete Vuckovich 18 6 0 3.34

title: Union Vote Set At Medical College
description: Professional employees, including physicians, dentists and registered nurses, at facilities of the New York Medical College in Valhalla and New York City are scheduled to vote Thursday and Friday in a union representation election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board.

title: BALLET: NORWEGIANS IN 'THE TEMPEST'
description: EVERYTHING billows in Glen Tetley's ballet version of ''The Tempest.'' And in some way, the yards of fabric that soar and swirl spectacularly across the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music provide a suitable metaphor for the premiere last night that swept in the most important dance series of the season.

title: PRIME RATE IS CUT TO 12% FROM 13% BY FOUR BIG BANKS
description: Four of the nation's largest banks yesterday announced reductions of a full percentage point in their prime lending rates, to 12 percent, the lowest level in more than two years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified the general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals baseball team. He is Joe McDonald.

title: 'MR. SUMM'S' FINAL WORD
description: In this season of computer-addressed fundraising brochures, a few are bound to go astray. So when the letter arrived under the gold seal of the Republican Presidential Task Force, requesting ''a most unusual sacrifice'' ($120) to forestall the danger that ''the golden gates of opportunity will be slammed shut by liberal Democrats,'' Walter L. Foulke was not particularly surprised, even though he is a liberal Democrat.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tombstone Change

title: Article 217193 -- No Title
description: The discussion turned to Indiana's Second Congressional District, which posed a special problem for the Sun Company. The committee chairman, Robert P. Hauptfuhrer, was the first to express an opinion.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: B-Including a gain of $82,500 from the cumulative effect on prior yrs of a change in accounting

title: PALESTINE AND JORDAN: TERRITORIAL DESIGNS AND HISTORICAL REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A GUIDE FOR THOSE WHO AVOID MEAT
description: Sarah Newell, a member of The Times Book Review staff, has been a vegetarian for 15 years. By SARAH NEWELL

title: High Wine Prices
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I love wine and I have money, but I am one that will not pay these high prices - store or restaurant - for any wine (''Recession Causes U.S. Wine Boom to Falter,'' Sept. 23). The young folk decades behind me and coming up will stick to jugs.

title: DONOVAN DINNER DAIS: NO REAGAN, NO BUSH
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, already the first Cabinet officer to endure two investigations by a special prosecutor, has emerged from a long period of public isolation to face a another unpleasant distinction: becoming the first Labor Secretary in 42 years to suffer a double-digit unemployment rate.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 12.00-12.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Economic Scene; An Abundance Of Statistics
description: IN 1922, the humorist Robert Benchley published an essay titled ''How to Understand International Finance.'' Mr. Benchley observed that, for weeks and weeks, officials had been rushing about holding conferences and having their pictures taken going up and down the steps of buildings. Then, after each conference, the newspapers printed a lot of figures showing how much money was owed by Germany and other countries.

title: A.C.L.U., in '82 Review, Calls Administration Foe of Rights
description: The Reagan Administration has become ''an implacable and increasingly isolated foe'' of civil rights and liberties, the American Civil Liberties Union maintains.

title: COURT ORDER CUTS HAITIAN TOTAL IN MIAMI DETENTION SITE TO TWO
description: Sometime soon the last Haitian refugee ordered released under a broad court ruling will leave the Krome Avenue detention camp, a forbidding enclosure surrounded by double cyclone fences, barbed wire and sharp sawgrass that was an unhappy home for all too long.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AIDE TO COAST G.O.P. CANDIDATE RESIGNS AFTER REMARKS ON RACISM
description: The manager of George Deukmejian's Republican campaign for Governor resigned today after a controversy erupted over his statements last week about racism among voters.

title: DANCE: MARLEEN PENNISON SUMS UP A DECADE
description: MARLEEN PENNISON and Dancers summed up a decade's activity Sunday with ''The Illustrated Version'' at Miss Pennison's studio at 117 Hudson Street. The program, an anthology of brief dances and excerpts from longer pieces, ranged from ''Bethena'' of 1973 to a bit from a work-in-progress and, in addition to performing in them, Miss Pennison commented informally about her creations.

title: Shanghai Catholic Seminary Admits 36 in Its First Class
description: China's breakaway Catholic Church has opened its first seminary for student priests in Shanghai, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: NO BANKRUPTCY RELIEF FOR THOSE WHO CAN PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST TELEVISION SPOT GIVES MRS. SULLIVAN A SENSE OF PROGRESS
description: ''It is not her,'' Margaret DeBech whispered. A moment later, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan of Brooklyn, the Republican-Conservative-Right to Life candidate for United States senator from New York, handed her a leaflet.

title: Merchandising Leader Is Nominated at Sears
description: The man in charge of buying the myriad products that Sears, Roebuck & Company sells would seem to have an impossible job. Joseph H. Batogowski, 43, has just been nominated for that job, and its complexity doesn't seem to faze him.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FALWELL'S LETTER RAISES TAX DISPUTE
description: People for the American Way, a liberal citizens' group, asked the Internal Revenue Service today to suspend the tax-deductible status of contributions to the Moral Majority Foundation.

title: PSYCHIATRISTS DESCRIBE KAFKAESQUE PORTFOLIO
description: The boundary between reasonable fear and paranoia is one of the many twilight regions of the espionage field. Intelligence agents who cross into that psychological danger zone can end up losing their jobs, their families and, in extreme cases, their lives.

title: FOR HOTEL SCHOOLS, ENTENTE CORDIALE
description: ROBERT A. BECK remembers it well. There he was, an American in Paris, the former dean of Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration, about to start a program to teach the French about food and hotel management.

title: WORKERS DRAFTED
description: The Lenin Shipyard here was struck by workers today for a second day, and fierce street battles broke out again in the streets between riot policemen and workers demanding the restoration of the outlawed trade union Solidarity.

title: CULLEN-FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Needham, Harper
description: Joseph P. Landy, 54-year-old former advertising manager-U.S.A. of Mobil Oil, is moving back to the agency side as executive vice president, director of account services of Needham, Harper & Steers/New York. He has also worked for Doyle Dane Bernbach and Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $237,200 for the qr and $355,200 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: 3d Man Charged in Texas With Smuggling Aliens
description: McALLEN, Tex., Oct. 12 (AP) - A third man wanted in connection with an alien smuggling operation that ended in death for five Salvadorans surrendered to the Border Patrol today, a patrol spokesman said.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $757,000 for the qr and $1,779,000 for the 9 mos and an extraordinary gain of $6,743,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-After a loss of $8,820,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,858,000

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want harmony and unity in the party. Now the party needs a new system under a new leader.

title: KNIGHT, WELL AGAIN, IS BACK AT SCENE OF 1980 INJURY
description: Last month, during physical examinations before the start of the Knicks' training camp, each player was tested for leg strength on a machine. Toby Knight's score on his left leg was 1,300, the highest of all. By comparison, his reading during his rookie season of 1977-78 was 800.

title: CHILDREN'S LUNCHES: SAFETY TIPS
description: With more and more children taking brownbag lunches to school, parents are faced with the task of making sure those lunches are safe and nutritious.

title: LONDON HAILS FALKLAND VICTORY ANEW
description: As many as 300,000 people lined London streets today to cheer parading veterans of the Falkland war as Britain celebrated yet again its successful military campaign in the South Atlantic.

title: Choreographer Is Strangled
description: A Bay Area choreographer has been found strangled in his apartment. The police said Jan Sejda, 54 years old, was found Sunday morning by a member of his Polish dance troupe after the director did not show up for the company's performance at a Polish festival in Golden Gate Park.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
HAYES-DANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALLET THEATER, IN LABOR DISPUTE, CANCELS 3D DATE
description: The American Ballet Theater announced yesterday the cancellation of its season at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The company, currently in the sixth week of a labor dispute with its dancers, was scheduled to open the four-week season Dec. 7.

title: A.O. Smith Names 2 To Office of Chairman
description: The A.O. Smith Corporation of Milwaukee, a major maker of auto and truck frames, said yesterday that it had named Robert A. Rietz vice chairman and David H. Stieber executive vice president. The two men will join a new office of the chairman that will direct top-level policy.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
GROWING NUMBERS USE ORIENTEERING TO TRY UNKNOWN
description: fire orienteering technique,'' said Dick Murphy, giving no hint that his tongue was set firmly in cheek. ''Just walk straight through the forest till you hit water - then make a right.'' Mr. Murphy is one of about 175,000 Americans who brave the woods in all weathers in the fall and spring to practice an increasingly popular sport that involves, in primitive terms, getting from here to there without getting lost. Or, perhaps, without getting totally lost.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A GROTTO

title: SUSPECT IN BOLOGNA BOMBING OF 1980 IS RETURNED TO ITALY
description: A right-wing extremist suspected of participating in the 1980 bombing of the Bologna railroad station, in which 85 people were killed, was brought here today from Bolivia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quo Vadis? Into Chapter 11

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Debating the Debates

title: LOWER RATES STIR HOPE OF DEFICIT CUT
description: The abrupt decline of short-term interest rates in recent days, apparently the mainspring of the stock market rally, is being cheered by Administration officials who hope that it portends a smaller budget deficit.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Demographics of Age

title: GUNMEN KILL GUARD AND WOUND 2 IN BRONX ARMORED-TRUCK ROBBERY
description: Four gunmen opened fire on two armored-truck guards outside a Bronx milk plant yesterday, killing one guard and seriously wounding the other and a bystander, the police said.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,422,000 for the qr and $2,360,000 for the 9 mos and a loss of $7.3 million for the 9 mos on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: Ogilvy & Mather Unit Sets Ad Program
description: And while we are in Williamsburg, do let us drop by and find out what plans the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation has for Ogilvy & Mather Partners.

title: BELL'S LONG-DISTANCE BATTLE
description: It seems an astounding prediction: In five years, A.T.& T. could have less than 50 percent of the long-distance telephone market that it had dominated for so long.

title: Bonn-U.S. Tire Accord
description: Continental Gummi-Werke A.G. has signed a cooperation agreement with the General Tire and Rubber Company of the United States under which the American company will annually produce 500,000 Continental tires for sale on the United States market, a Continental spokesman said today.

title: Advertising; TV Is Big Medium For Radio
description: YOU want to hear about a boom in advertising? How about a category whose spending soared 43 percent last year over 1980 and jumped another 28 percent in the first half of this year?

title: A.R. Gurney Jr. is a playwright whose latest work, ''The Dining Room,'' is playing at the Astor Place Theater.
description: ''WHAT a dinner! I don't call it a dinner: I call it a meal,'' snorts a character in George Bernard Shaw's ''Heartbreak House'' as he emerges from a casually cooked, fitfully attended repast in the odd English country manor where the play takes place. Shaw sees the disintegration of dinner as yet another example of the decline of the English upper classes at the time of World War I.

title: Miss Morgan Loses Plea
description: The Superior Court judge who dismissed most of Vicki Morgan's $10 million suit against the estate of Alfred Bloomingdale today dismissed a motion asking him to reconsider his decision. Judge Christian Markey originally dismissed the suit on Sept. 28, ruling Miss Morgan was just ''a well paid mistress'' to the department store heir, not a live-in lover.

title: SOVIET SAYS POLAND CAN RELY ON HELP IN UPHOLDING REGIME
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, said today that Poland's martial-law Government could rely on Moscow's help in its effort to maintain Communist rule.

title: BREWERS WIN OPENER AS CALDWELL PITCHES 3-HITTER
description: The Milwaukee Brewers opened the 79th World Series tonight with a 17-hit offense and a dazzling three-hit pitching performance by Mike Caldwell that devastated the St. Louis Cardinals, 10-0.

title: Jim Crowley Suffers a Heart Attack; Crowley Suffers A Heart Attack
description: Jim Crowley, the last surviving member of Notre Dame's famous Four Horsemen backfield of the early 1920's, was in critical condition today in Moses Taylor Hospital after suffering a heart attack.

title: DEVILS, BRUINS IN 2-2 TIE
description: Lindsay Middlebrook, starting in goal for the New Jersey Devils as Chico Resch rested, kept the Boston Bruins scoreless for 52 minutes 31 seconds tonight. Then the Bruins rallied and gained a 2-2 tie. The tying goal came with 2:11 left.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $1,056,000 for the qr and $3,106,000 for the 9 mos and after securities losses of $34,000 for the qr and $33,000 for the 9 mos...C-Aftertax credits of $1,524,000 for the qr and $3,867,000 for the 9 mos and after securities gains of $7,000 for the qr and $6,000 for the 9 mos; the 1981 results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Houston Bancshares Inc in Feb; BancTexas Group was formerly Commerce Southwest Inc

title: Librado Chavez, Farm Leader; Was Father of Cesar Chavez
description: Librado Hernandez Chavez, a longtime advocate for migrant workers died today. He was 100 years old. Mr. Chavez, who was the father Cesar Chavez, the president of the United Farm Workers, died of a stroke at Alexian Brothers Hospital shortly before 9 A.M., according to Marc Grossman, a family friend.

title: RIGHTS UNIT AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR COURT-MANDATED BUSING
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights voted today to reaffirm its support for mandatory busing as a means of ending school segregation.

title: Tip Leads to Chicago Arrest
description: The police, acting on a tip received in their investigation of the cyanide poisonings of seven people here, arrested a man early today, but said he ''did not appear'' to be linked to the Tylenol deaths. The man, Roger Arnold, 48 years old, of Chicago, was arrested because of a tip that he had two bottles of cyanide, but the police said no poison was found.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''We need a quick, certain remedy for the football strike,'' says Neal Small of Manhattan. ''The President must call out the National Guard to play nationally televised football this Sunday.''

title: SHARON CALLS ON U.S. JEWS FOR SUPPORT
description: Occupied West Bank, Oct. 12 - Defense Minister Ariel Sharon called on American Jews visiting this five-year-old settlement here today to help persuade the United States to work toward an Israeli-Lebanese peace treaty.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE five senses - sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch - are all subject to our conscious scrutiny, and when something goes wrong with one of them, most of us are able to describe the problem with considerable precision. Not so, though, for the ''sixth sense'' - balance. We are rarely aware of it when it operates properly, and when it malfunctions, most of us have difficulty describing what we feel.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORP (MY LEBANON, PA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Newport General
description: The Newport General Corporation of Providence, R.I., and its subsidiary, the Vel-Cord Southern Corporation, said they had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: SUB AND DEVALUATION DIVERT SWEDES
description: This is the time of year when Swedes search for any diversion from the evidence that the last warm days of autumn have irretrievably fled the country.

title: Metropolitan Life Purchase
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said it had agreed to buy State Street Research and Management Company, a closely held investment management concern in Boston. The value of the cash deal was not disclosed, but sources close to the deal estimated it at $100 million.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a net charge of $6,213,000 for plant closing

title: CONCERT: MAHLERITES HEAR THE 2D
description: CULTS attach themselves to performers for all sorts of strange reasons, and such a cult seems to have formed in Boston around Benjamin Zander and his Boston Philharmonic Orchestra. On Monday night this largely amateur ensemble, complete with two vocal soloists and the Chorus Pro Musica of Boston, took over Carnegie Hall for nothing less than Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony. The performance was presented by the New York Mahlerites, and the hall was nearly filled with mostly young, earnest people who gave Mr. Zander and his forces a fervent standing ovation at the end.

title: ETHNIC ARGENTINA: PASTA AND VERDI CONNECTION
description: From the rich pastas to the love for opera, Argentines are a Latin American people uniquely influenced by Italy.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Brands filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for $300 million of debt securities.

title: SPANISH SOCIALIST A DARLING OF PUBLIC, IF NOT ARMY
description: The picture of a youngish man, rather baby-faced, slightly cross-eyed but undeniably handsome, has gazed down for days from posters attached to almost every light stanchion on Madrid's Gran Via.

title: Heckler of President Fails in Second Bid For G.O.P. Backing
description: A Republican candidate for Congress who heckled President Reagan in the White House last week has again failed to win the financial backing of party leaders in his California home district for the general election campaign.

title: BOTH SIDES TO MEET WITH NEW MEDIATOR
description: Sam Kagel, a highly regarded 73-yearold private mediator and arbitrator from San Francisco, was selected today to mediate the strike of pro football players.

title: U.S. Witness Unshaken At Trial in Judge's Killing
description: A Government witness remained steadfast today in her identification of Charles V. Harrelson as the man she saw near the place where a Federal District Judge, John H. Wood Jr., was murdered.

title: TOWERS URGED FOR HOUSING U.N. FAMILIES
description: New York City and United Nations officials are exploring plans to build two 27-story residential towers on city-owned land along the East River to house the families of foreign diplomats and others.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: results for the latest 9 mos include net proceeds of $17.2 million or 35 cents a shr, generated during the first qr from the sale of tax credits and a net gainof $57 million, or $1.16 a shr, during the first qr primarily from major land transactions

title: INVESTMENTS THAT HURT THE U.S. ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RIGHTS OFFICIAL DEFENDS TAX BREAK FOR RACIALLY BIASED SCHOOLS
description: The question of Federal tax exemptions for racially discriminatory private schools finally got a hearing before the Supreme Court today. Four lawyers distilled months of political controversy into a detailed debate over the evolution of the Internal Revenue Code and the meaning of the word ''charity.''

title: Reds' Austere Stand
description: Although the Cincinnati Reds lost 100 games last season for the first time in the history of the franchise, the club will not change its ''basic philosophies'' regarding player salaries and acquisitions, according to its president, Dick Wagner.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JERSEY TRANSIT AGENCY THREATENS 25% FARE RISE
description: The board of directors of NJ Transit voted today to increase bus and commuter rail fares by an average of 25 percent in December if the State Legislature fails to approve an additional $19.5 million in funds by Nov. 15.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NO BANKRUPTCY RELIEF FOR THOSE WHO CAN PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Bel Canto Opera to Do J.C. Bach's 'Temistocle'
description: The American premiere of Johann Christian Bach's Baroque opera ''Temistocle'' will be presented by the Bel Canto Opera Company Oct. 30 at 8 P.M. and Nov. 7 at 3 P.M. at 220 East 76th Street.

title: NO DANGER ON ACID EYEDROPS
description: The contamination of two bottles of Visine A.C. eyedrops with hydrochloric acid in Grand Junction, Colo., was not the result of manufacturing problems and was apparently confined to that area of the state, the Food and Drug Administration and the manufacturer of the product said yesterday.

title: Excerpts from program, page B4.
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that, if elected Governor next month, he would ''use all the powers of my office'' to persuade the Legislature to enact a cap on the state budget, with the savings going to reduce taxes and rebuild crumbling public works.

title: COURT TO RULE ON UTILITY COOPERATION CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review Federal rules designed to force utility companies to cooperate in the development of competing sources of energy. The case could produce one of the most important regulatory decisions of the new term.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
Needham, Harper Adds Anheuser-Busch Parks
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, which has been grabbing up new accounts to make up for the McDonald's loss, has still another new assignment - promoting the three theme parks that Anheuser-Busch operates in its Busch Entertainment Corporation.

title: Credit for Mr. Volcker
description: There has been ''no change in the basic thrust'' of policy, says Paul Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The Fed's stance against inflation will remain firm. But many Fed watchers - including the institutional investors who pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to the 1,000 mark - believe the Fed is prepared to accommodate economic recovery with a modest growth in credit. We hope and expect they're right.

title: HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL FETE ADDS 'FROSTING' TO 200TH YEAR
description: On the opening day of its bicentennial celebration Monday, the Harvard Medical School found it had not seven but 10 Nobel laureates among its main speakers.

title: Heublein Is Suing General Cinema
description: Holders of Heublein Inc. and R.J. Reynolds Industries yesterday approved Reynolds's acquisition of Heublein for $1.3 billion, and Heublein said it filed suit against the General Cinema Corporation to recover $30 million in profits from Heublein stock.

title: PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THEATER: LUDLAM OFFERS HIS 'EXQUISITE TORTURE'
description: CHARLES LUDLAM does what he's driven to do, and maybe there's no point in trying to reform him. If we're going to relax and enjoy the entertainments he concocts with his Ridiculous Theatrical Company, we'll simply have to put up with amateurish supporting casts (in and out of drag), pasteboard sets and uncompromising campiness. More and more, I'm convinced that these concessions are worth making. There's real integrity to Mr. Ludlam's work as a writer, director and performer: if his idiosyncratic form of theater is trivial, he doesn't make the error of pretending it is anything else. Nor does he sell himself or the audience short: he lavishes more passion and intelligence on his unabashedly silly farces than many theater artists do on so-called serious work.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANFORTH APPEARS TO LEAD IN MISSOURI SENATE CONTEST
description: Despite an energetic challenger who calls on Democrats to rally to their party because of the economy, Senator John C. Danforth appears to hold a comfortable lead as he tries to retain a key Republican seat.

title: The Presume-'Em-Guilty Act
description: To show its pre-election muscle, the Senate passed a 232-page anti-crime bill just before recessing for the campaign. The measure contains some worthwhile features, like reducing disparities in sentencing, assisting victims of crime and beefing up narcotics enforcement. But the senators couldn't resist throwing in preventive detention - the jailing without trial of suspects who can't prove they won't commit ''another'' crime while awaiting trial.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Raines in Clinic
description: Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos has been admitted to a clinic near Anaheim, Calif., to undergo treatment for ''chemical dependence'' on a drug that the Expos would not specify. Raines, whose batting average dropped from .304 to .277 this year, said in a statement that the 30-day drug treatment program at Orange County Medical Clinic was his ''best chance'' for complete recovery from dependence. ... Now it's the other elbow.

title: 3 West Bank Settlers Seized On Suspicion of Storing Arms
description: Three Jewish settlers of Qiryat Arba, the Israeli suburb of Hebron in the occupied West Bank, were arrested by the military government on suspicion of storing explosives, it was disclosed today.

title: The Name Game
description: Wayne Gretzky set National Hockey League records for goals, assists and points last year, so it was only natural that he should be the cover boy on the league's 1982-83 official guide.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1982

title: ARAFAT NOW SEES POSITIVE ASPECTS IN REAGAN PLAN
description: Yasir Arafat said today that he could see ''some positive elements'' in President Reagan's Middle East peace plan although it was still not acceptable because it did not provide for an independent Palestinian state.

title: FOR BONN, INSTABILITY
description: Helmut Schmidt's departure as Chancellor marks the end of an era in German history. It deprives the West of its most experienced, its most effective, and, in the eyes of many, its most attractive statesman. The West Germans have lost a leader whose authority far transcended party lines. He may well have been the last of the remarkable postwar chancellors. The end of his Government signals the beginning of a period of instability.

title: AMERITRUST CORP OF CLEVELAND reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN DEFENSE OF VEGETARIANISM: SEVEN YEAS
description: WHEN the violinist Yehudi Menuhin comes to New York the first thing he does is call his favorite natural-food store and place an order: porridge, yogurt, goat's milk, sprouted wheat bread, ice cream, butter, fruits, vegetables, tofu sandwiches and kefir. In each American city where he performs, Mr. Menuhin has a favorite place to shop, making his life as a traveling vegetarian more comfortable.

title: OPERA: BERGONZI SINGS ALVARO IN 'FORZA'
description: ONLY in the final act of Verdi's ''La Forza del Destino'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, did it seem that Carlo Bergonzi was singing about something. In a cast change as Don Alvaro, the distinguished tenor mostly demonstrated his still powerful voice, ringing out with vigor throughout the second act.

title: MONDALE'S TOUGH LINE
description: Former Vice President Walter (Fritz) Mondale has been running around the country for months seeking support for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984. But lately he has been striking a more strident and protectionist theme.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO OF MIAMI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $903,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9mos reflecting the net expense of stock appreciation rights

title: Dailey Named in Suit
description: A 22-year-old student nurse at the University of San Francisco has filed a suit against Quintin Dailey, a former all-American basketball player at the school; the university itself and the chief of security. Joe O'Sullivan, the attorney for Victoria Brick, the nurse, said he thought ''someone very high up'' at the university had attempted to cover up the incident that occurred last Dec. 21, when, Miss Brick said, Dailey attacked her in a university residence hall.

title: ANRET INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $710,700 and a gain of $797,000 from the sale of anapartment project...C-Including a tax credit of $497,774 and a gain of $927,000from the sale of a motel and collection of interest not previously accrued; shrearnings reflect the repurchase of 74,593 of the company's common shr

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Milwaukee Brewers, World Series, second game, at St. Louis. John Stuper, who came out of the bullpen to win some key games as a starter, pitches for the Cardinals.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GENERAL FOODS WRAPS UP A WINNER
description: When the General Foods Corporation announced this week that it was buying Entenmann's, the fast-growing national bakery concern, some analysts wondered how well the bakery's founding family would mesh with the new corporate parent.

title: CALIFORNIA NOW GETS HIGHWAY AID MONEY HALTED FOR POLLUTION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had lifted sanctions imposed against California for failure to comply with Federal clean air rules, freeing $150 million in highway and sewer grants.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Four-Apple Cider...

title: Careers; Corporate Real Estate Managers
description: THE General Motors Corporation, worrying about the recession and the slump in car sales, made an innovative real estate deal some months ago when it received about $500 million for its New York office building on Fifth Avenue. G.M. is using the money for working capital.

title: Brooklyn Man Guilty Of Killing 2 in Queens
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Queens late yesterday convicted a 20-year-old Brooklyn man of fatally shooting a 7-year-old boy and his mother in their Elmhurst, Queens, apartment on Jan. 6, 1981, Queens District Attorney John J. Santucci said.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per shr figures reflect 10 percent stock divd to be paid Oct 15

title: Real Estate
description: HOUSTON LEADING real estate developers, lenders and consultants are taking a sanguine view of prospects for riding out the extended downturn in demand for office facilities across the country.

title: LEBANESE EX-PRESIDENT BACKS A SECURITY ACCORD WITH ISRAEL
description: A prominent Lebanese Christian leader today endorsed the idea of a security agreement between Israel and Lebanon and said that the size of the American, Italian and French force in Lebanon should be sharply increased and kept there for as long as two years.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-earlier results have been restated for a pooling acquisition

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Second Degree

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $14,000 from discontinued operations...C-I ncluding incomeof $9,600 from discontinued operations

title: Scientist Backs Plaintiffs At Atomic Fallout Trial
description: Scientific studies have repeatedly linked radiation exposure to cancer, a health researcher testified today in a Federal court trial on whether fallout from atomic tests in Nevada harmed people downwind.

title: REAGAN, IN TOAST TO SUHARTO, NAMES AN ENVOY
description: President Reagan, in a toast to President Suharto of Indonesia, disclosed tonight that he was nominating a new ambassador, moving to resolve a source of friction in relations between the United States and Indonesia over the last year.

title: 5 Shot in Italian Prison
description: Three inmates were shot and wounded today by a member of a rival Mafia-style gang in the prison of this southern Italian town, the authorities reported. Prison officials said two guards also were wounded.

title: Bubble-Burster
description: Remember when Sylvester Stallone, as Rocky Balboa, chases and catches a chicken while training for his big fight in ''Rocky II''? James (Hard Rock) Green has been using some unorthodox training tactics for his Saturday middleweight bout against Frank (the Animal) Fletcher in Atlantic City.

title: LINGUISTICS PROFESSOR TAUGHT AT COLUMBIA
description: Robert L. Allen, professor emeritus of linguistics and education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died Saturday at his home in Leonia, N.J., after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: RESIDENTS RETURN TO DERAILMENT AREA
description: Hundreds of people who fled their homes two weeks ago after a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed went back home today, although some expressed mistrust about assurances that there would be no long-term problems.

title: ELIE WIESEL TEACHES LESSONS OF ANGUISH
description: The subject was Jeremiah, but the murmurs in the back of the classroom were of Beirut. There, the students shared the latest news from the Shatila and Sabra camps. They whispered, so not to disturb their professor. But the professor was Elie Wiesel, the author, and his mind already was on the same subject.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
What a Dump!
description: For several years, local fishermen in search of lobster have been bringing up 2,000-year-old amphorae from the bottom of a bay near Rio de Janeiro. An archeologist now believes they came from a Roman ship that was blown off course and toward the coast of Brazil.

title: BILL RATES AT LOWEST IN 2 YEARS
description: Interest rates on new Treasury bills plunged yesterday to their lowest levels in more than two years. The strong demand from investors wanting to lock in current rates reflected expectations of further declines.

title: PORTER COMEBACK: ONE DAY AT A TIME
description: ST. LOUIS E verybody laughed when Darrell Porter shouted: ''Hey, where's my grape juice?'' The people around his locker would clear their throats and refer obliquely to his ''ahem, drinking problem.'' The next day in the papers he would be described as a ''recovered alcoholic'' - past tense.

title: ROBBERS KILL TWO IN BROOKLYN PHARMACY
description: A group of armed men stormed into a pharmacy in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday, announced a robbery and then fatally shot the store's elderly owner and a customer, the police said.

title: CONFIDENCE-BUILDING MEDIATOR
description: Negotiations to end the San Francisco newspaper strike were going nowhere when Sam Kagel, the mediator, slammed his briefcase shut and walked out. Both sides chased him down the street to get him to come back. Three times during that 1968 strike, which would last 54 days, Mr. Kagel used that tactic, which he described as ''the mediator's muscle,'' before getting an agreement.

title: PALESTINE AND JORDAN: TERRITORIAL DESIGNS AND HISTORICAL REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MORE INQUIRIES CHECK DUMPING BY TOXICS PLANT
description: Two Connecticut agencies joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Waterbury Police Department yesterday in investigating a hazardous-waste treatment plant in downtown Waterbury.

title: BILL ON MISSING CHILDREN SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan today signed a law mandating the creation of a national clearinghouse of computerized information to aid parents in tracking the hundreds of thousands of children reported missing each year.

title: ARMY RECRUITING THRIVES AS ECONOMY FALTERS
description: On the new downtown brick mall, between two empty shops and across the street from a shuttered department store, is one of Youngstown's most successful enterprises, the Armed Forces Recruiting Station.

title: REAGAN'S SPEECH TODAY FUELS EQUAL-TIME ISSUE
description: Democrats and Republicans are once again battling over broadcast air time, with the major networks in the middle. If some key officials in this city have their way, however, the broadcasters will soon be permanently rescued and the guarantees of access for political speechmaking, under certain circumstances, will come to an end.

title: Bridge: 2 American Teams Survive 3d-Round Rosenblum Play
description: Thanks largely to rulings that call for pairings within the same continent, only two American teams survived third-round play in the Rosenblum Knockout Team Championship here.

title: Miss Navratilova Regains a Coach
description: Martina Navratilova, concerned about protecting her No. 1 ranking on the women's tennis tour, has asked Renee Richards to return as her coach. Miss Richards has accepted, but under a revised arrangement.

title: Colavito, Howser Sentenced
description: Manager Dick Howser of the Kansas City Royals and his batting coach, Rocky Colavito, were found guilty today of interfering with a police officer after a traffic accident Aug. 19, and sentenced to 90 days in jail.

title: IRAN SAYS U.N. IGNORED WAR AFTER IRAQIS ATTACKED IN 1980
description: The Foreign Minister of Iran accused the United Nations today of ''sleeping'' when Iraq attacked Iran in September 1980 and said the organization was acting now only because the interests of the superpowers were threatened.

title: HOW POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Oct. 3 through Oct. 8 with 1,587 adults throughout Connecticut. Of this total, 1,132 said they were registered voters.

title: REFUGEES MOVING BACK TO CAMBODIA
description: Since July, thousands of Cambodian refugees from Thailand's Khao I Dang camp, north of Aranyaprathet, have been moving east across the border into a Cambodian village now known as Sihanoukville.

title: KARATE'S UNLIKELY FIRST FAMILY
description: SOMEHOW it sounds like a plot from the old television series ''My Three Sons.'' Three young brothers are playing on a California beach when they are threatened by a stranger with a German shepherd. They beg their father to let them enroll in a karate class so they can learn how to defend themselves.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: rev figures include interest income of $166,597 for the latest first qr and $256,206 for the yr-ago first qr

title: ISLANDERS AND UNION IN DISPUTE
description: The executive director of the National Hockey League Players Association accused the Islanders yesterday of violating the collective bargaining agreement by saying they would decline to play a Soviet all-star team in an exhibition later this year.

title: Major Soviet Attack On Afghans Reported
description: Soviet ground troops supported by warplanes launched a major attack last week on the rebelcontrolled city of Pagman just 10 miles north of the Afghan capital, diplomatic sources said today. It was the first time Soviet ground troops had been reported in a major operation since July.

title: Laxalt Says He Turned Down Bid to Lead G.O.P. Committee
description: Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, confirmed Monday that he had turned down an offer to succeed Richard Richards as chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: TWO BANKS SHOW RISE IN INCOME
description: The First Chicago Corporation, holding company for the First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's eighth-largest, said yesterday that net operating income for the third quarter rose 9.3 percent, to $37.3 million, or 93 cents a share, from $34.1 million, or 85 cents a share, in the 1981 period.

title: Kentucky's Early Birds
description: Friday is the first practice date allowed college basketball teams by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, and Coach Joe B. Hall of Kentucky is not wasting any time. Hall says he will hold his first practice at 12:01 A.M. Friday at Memorial Coliseum in Lexington.

title: Soldiers Shed Pounds Under Army Program
description: Fat soldiers at Fort Bragg are slimming down under a new program, a base surgeon says. Maj. Harold Timboe of the Army's 82d Airborne Division said all but one of 125 soldiers initially involved had lost weight. The soldier who did not make it, the major said, had a long leave at home with a mother who was a good cook.

title: Producer Of Paper Drops 40%
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that the generally weak economy and high interest rates caused net income in the third quarter to plummet 40 percent.

title: Expos Name Bill Virdon
description: The Montreal Expos announced the appointment today of Bill Virdon as the club's new manager under a two-year agreement.

title: TV: DYAN CANNON IN 'HAVING IT ALL'
description: ABC describes ''Having It All,'' a made-for television movie at 9 o'clock tonight, as an ''antic romantic comedy.'' But, caught between the New Permissiveness and pressure groups such as the Moral Majority, most television attempts to be antic end up as grotesque contortions. More often than not, the result is just curiously vulgar and dishonest. Consider ''Having It All.'' (The movie has no connection with the Helen Gurley Brown book of the same title that is reviewed today on page C27.)

title: MAN GETS 20-YEAR TERM IN THEFT OF RARE BOOKS WORTH $100,000
description: A St. Louis man was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison today in the theft of more than $100,000 worth of rare books from college libraries around the country.

title: A LOYAL OPPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: MANY followers of the great red wines of northern Italy have perceived a change in style, a change that became apparent a decade or so ago and that persists. The wines often seem less intensely flavored and robust than in the past, lacking the taste concentration that made them famous among connoisseurs and others willing to venture beyond the wines of France in search of quality.

title: OPPORTUNE MOMENT FOR TONELLI GOAL
description: W hen Fred Shero was coaching the New York Rangers a few years ago, he wrote a book that set forth his first commandment of defensive hockey.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NO RECORD OF TICKET ON FILM
description: Holding a winning ticket in the New York State Lottery is not necessarily being a winner, a state appeals court told a Long Island woman yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AAR Corp. said its American Aviation Resources subsidiary had obtained from a North American airline that it did not identify the U.S. marketing rights for four Boeing 767 aircraft, valued at $180 million.

title: MOFFETT'S SUPPORT BECOMING BROADER
description: Representative Toby Moffett, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from Connecticut, is attracting not only the more traditional Democratic voters but also a surprising number of moderates and even conservatives, according to a statewide poll by The New York Times.

title: Bumper Crops Predicted
description: With the fall harvest already under way and the threat of early frost damage receding, the Agriculture Department today forecast record American corn and soybean crops in 1982.

title: U.A.W. and Chrysler Plan New Contract Talks
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers said today they would start new talks on a replacement for the contract proposal being overwhelmingly rejected by the union rank-and-file.

title: Market Place; Wrap-Around Mortgages
description: AS interest rates plummet, investors are searching for ways to lock in high fixed yields. A representative of the Consolidated Capital Corporation will be explaining to security analysts in New York City today how his company goes about it.

title: MAVERICK AGAIN ROILING ALASKA GOVERNOR RACE
description: When you call on Joe Vogler, leave the blue serge at home because dog hair sticks to it like filings to a magnet. And Mr. Vogler has two poodles, a half Husky, and four black Laborador retrievers.

title: ARMY HALTS ITS SEARCHES IN WEST BEIRUT
description: For the first time in eight days, the Lebanese Army made no major searches in predominantly Moslem West Beirut today, and President Amin Gemayel reportedly ordered it to turn its attention to the Christian-dominated eastern sector.

title: Islamic Delegates Balk At Vote Against Israel
description: The 42 members of the Islamic conference failed to agree today on whether to support an Arab move to expel Israel from the current session of the General Assembly.

title: EPSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TENNECO CLOSINGS
description: Tenneco Inc.'s J.I. Case subsidiary said it would extend the previously announced closing of plants in five states to nine weeks, beginning Dec. 11. The company said the closings would affect 5,200 employees.

title: Republic Merger Clears a Hurdle
description: Republic Financial Services Inc. said the Reliance Insurance Company of Philadelphia had agreed to stop blocking Republic's merger with the Winterthur Swiss Insurance Company.

title: Blue-Ribbon Run
description: Last June, a ''Stop The Arms Race'' rally in Central Park drew wide-spread public support. Now, the organizers of that event are asking runners in the New York City Marathon to show their support for disarmament by wearing blue ribbons during the Oct. 24 race.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $257,000 for the qr and $240,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $46.8 million for the qr and $50.9 million fora the yr; shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd payable in Nov

title: 'PAPER CHASE' IS SHIFTING TO PAY-CABLE
description: ''THE PAPER CHASE,'' the critically praised television series about law students that was canceled by CBS after one season, has a new life. Seven original episodes of the series will be written and produced this fall for Showtime, the pay-cable network.

title: DOW SLIDES 9.11 POINTS, TO 1,003.68
description: The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 9.11 points yesterday after investors cashed in some of their profits following an explosive four-day market rally that had sent the key indicator up 105 points.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1982; The Economy
description: Four leading banks reduced their prime lending rates by a full percentage point, to 12 percent, the lowest level in more than two years. Other major banks indicated that they expect to follow suit, either today or later in the week, and many bankers predicted that interest rates on consumer loans would also decline soon. Morgan Guaranty was the first bank to act, followed by the Bank of America, the Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover. (Page A1.)

title: RECITAL: PANAYIS LYRAS, PIANO
description: PANAYIS LYRAS, silver medalist in last year's Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, played music by Scarlatti, Beethoven, Barber, Ravel, Debussy, Granados and Liszt at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mayor to Shun Rite for Pope
description: Jerusalem's Mayor, Teddy Kollek, has refused to attend a mass here on Oct. 22 to celebrate the anniversary of Pope John Paul II's investiture because of the audience the Pope granted to Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Mayor's office said today. Mr. Kollek said the audience with Mr. Arafat at the Vatican last month was ''astonishing.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ambulance Force Gets A Father's Thanks

title: A DECLINE IN MEXICO TOURISM
description: The beaches here glimmer with fine white sand, the coconut cocktails are only a wave of the hand away and hammocks swing beneath open-sided cabanas that protect bathers from too hurried a tan. All of this costs less than it has in nearly a decade and, by rights, American tourists should be flocking to Mexico in ever-growing numbers.

title: CARDS SUSPECT 'SPITTER'
description: After his team had lost the first game of the World Series by 10 runs, Whitey Herzog, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, recalled the scouting report his club had been given on Mike Caldwell, the Brewer pitcher.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an indistinct tape recording, a remark by Senator Dan- iel Patrick Moynihan in the debate be- tween candidates for Senator ap- peared incorrectly in Metropolitan Report yesterday. Mr. Moynihan said, ''The outgo of the retirement system is permanent, it's fixed.''

title: Behind the Bars
description: There were a lot of television sets, including 20 or so in Maine's Cumberland County Jail, tuned to the final American League playoff game Sunday when Peter Ladd went to the mound for the Milwaukee Brewers against the California Angels and emerged as the winning pitcher. The inmates of the jail in Ladd's home town of Portland were rooting for an alumnus of sorts, because Ladd had been a part-time guard at the prison. ''All the people here are watching Peter,'' said a guard, Doug Kerwin.

title: Irvine Resignation
description: Peter Kremer has resigned as president of the Irvine Company, a development concern and one of the largest landowners in southern California.

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $1,755,000 from discontinued operations

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Pop Life; Grand Old Man of Punk Writes Autobiography
description: WHO could have imagined back in 1968 that James Osterberg, then calling himself Iggy Stooge, would live to become the grand old man of punk rock and write his autobiography? It was in that year that Mr. Osterberg and his band, called the Stooges, began their assault on the conventions of rock-and-roll.

title: 10 ENVIRONMENT GROUPS SEE REAGAN MARRING HEALTH AND LANDSCAPE
description: Ten environmental groups accused the Reagan Administration today of jeopardizing the health of Americans and the beauty of the landscape ''where we live, close to home.''

title: FOOTBALL STRIKE SPURS CHANGE IN ARMED SERVICES' AD DRIVE
description: Armed forces recruiters are being forced to rethink their plans this fall because of the professional football strike.

title: STUDYING PRECEDES ATHLETICS
description: Big, far from home and 18 years old, he arrives at college, a freshman. For him, there is scant welcome, except that offered by coaches. It is mid-August. Three weeks later, his classmates will arrive on campus. By the time of freshman orientation, he will have run 250 miles for his new college.

title: NUTRI-SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MANAGERIAL SHIFTS PRIME SERIES TOPIC
description: Managers and potential managers have been a prime topic of conversation among baseball executives at social gatherings and meetings surrounding the World Series.

title: LAKE ONTARIO CEMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RADIATION EXPERT
description: Dr. Edith H. Quimby, a physicist who helped develop radioactive techniques for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The important jewels lay nestled in blue velvet, surrounded by glass and security guards. That is how they were labeled: ''Important Jewels,'' said the title on the front of the catalogue for the auction.

title: Honecker Meets Assad
description: The East German head of state, Erich Honecker, and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria reviewed the situation in Lebanon today and ''stressed the importance of efforts to achieve a strategic balance in the area,'' officials said. Mr. Honecker, on a four-day visit, later watched an aerial display by fighters and bombers at a Syrian airbase, the official press agency said.

title: LEHRMAN OFFERS SYSTEM TO RECALL JUDGES
