description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Governor, proposed a system yesterday under which voters could remove trial judges who were charged with ''illegal or improper'' conduct.

title: GIBSON AIDE CALLS BONTEMPO USELESS
description: A key prosecution witness in the misconduct trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris testified today that he had told the Mayor that the position of chief of security at the Pequannock Watershed ''served no useful purpose'' and had asked that it be taken out of the budget.

title: Nilla Cram Cook, 74; A Writer and Linguist
description: Nilla Cram Cook, an American writer, linguist and scholar who became a disciple of Mohandas K. Ghandi in the 1930's and later served as a United States cultural attache in Iran, died Monday at a hospital in Neunkirchen, Austria, after a brief illness. She was 74 years old and lived in Aspang, about 50 miles from Vienna.

title: 1. A Liquid Puzzler
description: If you've already solved puzzles like Rubik's Cube and need another challenge, try Liquid Geometry. The British puzzle, made by Loncraine Broxton & Partners, involves a maze con-sisting of three squares and about 50 small black balls, all enclosed in a circular case of clear plastic. The idea is to maneuver the puzzle so that the balls go through small openings in the maze squares until all are within the center square. The puzzle would make a handsome ornament for a coffee table when it's not driving guests out of their minds. Sointu, 20 East 69th Street, has it for $25.

title: CONVICTION OF CONFESSED KILLER IS UPSET
description: New York's highest court, ruling that the defendant had been denied his right of counsel, yesterday reversed the conviction of an Oneonta man who had on three occasions confessed to the 1977 slaying of a college student.

title: 'PLIMOTH' HARVEST FEAST, IN ORIGINAL STYLE
description: ''Barbara Standish'' confided that her husband, ''Miles,'' was ''not in the best of humors,'' even for someone ''rather choleric'' by nature. And indeed on Saturday, the opening day of Plimoth Plantation's authentic re-enactment of the Pilgrims' annual Harvest Home celebration, there was much to be snappish about.

title: Salvador Reports Rebels Hold Village
description: The military authorities said today that, for the third day, leftist guerrillas were holding one of two villages they captured after a fierce battle in which 16 Government soldiers were killed.

title: SUZUKI, UNDER GROWING CRITICISM, SAYS HE'LL QUIT AS JAPAN'S PREMIER
description: In an unexpected move, Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki said today that he would resign shortly. Mr. Suzuki's announcement came against a background of mounting criticism of his leadership within the governing Liberal Democratic Party and complaints about his economic policies. But there was no explanation by Mr. Suzuki or by other party leaders of the motivation for his precipitate decision.

title: Power of Suggestion
description: A hypnotist is trying to do something about ending college football's longest losing streak.

title: ATHEY PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADDRESSES AT U.N. FOCUS ON ECONOMY
description: In a sharp break with tradition, the scores of foreign ministers and other notables who address the General Assembly have put the world economic crisis rather than war and peace at the heart of their concern.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,664,000 from sale of property

title: QUESTIONS REMAIN ON AMTRAK SIEGE
description: A Colombian accused of holding hostages in an Amtrak sleeping car in a 70-hour siege was arraigned today on murder and kidnapping charges.

title: Old-Time Clothes
description: The Knicks, unwilling to pay a $25,000 fine, have decided not to change their uniforms this season. But for the 1983-84 National Basketball Association season, the Knicks will switch back to the orange-and-blue uniforms that they wore during their only two league championship seasons.

title: NO BANKRUPTCY RELIEF FOR THOSE WHO CAN PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOMEONE asked if it would be possible to substitute shrimp gratin of chicken with a light cream sauce - a dish much admired when I was chef at Le Pavillon. I reproduced the gratin with shrimp, altering it in minor respects, and it was a big success.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Teamster Chief's Trial
description: After months of delays and legal dispute, jury selection began today in the trial of the teamsters' union president, Roy L. Williams, and four other men accused of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PROPOSAL BY CUOMO FOR NEW YORK'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT
description: Following are excerpts from a proposal for economic development by Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Democratic-Liberal Party candidate for Governor: Fiscal Stability

title: MOLITOR DEFENSIVE ABOUT HIS OFFENSE
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, who built a reputation as Harvey's Wallbangers during the regular season but looked more like Harvey's Wallflowers in the American League playoff, came up tonight with 10 runs and 17 hits in the first game of the World Series. That's the kind of hitting performance the Brewers are capable of, right?

title: NATIONAL MORTGAGE FUND reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $68,450 for the qr and $112,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $9,500...D-Including an extraordinary credit of $22,600

title: MEDIATOR'S STRENGTH BASED ON PERSUASION
description: Sam Kagel, named yesterday by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to act as mediator in the football strike, will function, like all mediators named by the service, through persuasive techniques. He will have no law-enforcement authority.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Paying for Pollution Virtue
description: The gizmos that curb auto pollution add about $1,400 to the lifetime cost of a 1982 car. Are they worth the price? Probably not, argues Lawrence White, an economics professor at N.Y.U. and author of a new American Enterprise Institute study on pollution control. Even by a generous reckoning of the benefits, the current emissions standards amount to regulatory overkill.

title: Turkish Socialist Cleared In Defamation Case
description: An Ankara military court acquitted former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit today of charges of defaming Turkey in a purported interview with a Norwegian newspaper.

title: SUBURBS GETTING SPECIALTY FOOD SHOPS OF THEIR OWN
description: IF someone wanted to take out food at lunchtime in Westport, Conn., a year ago, the options were limited to fast-food shops, luncheonettes and delicatessens.

title: DANCE: REBECCA KELLY OFFERS HER 'NIGHT AIR'
description: THE uplifting sense that wafted out of Monday night's performance by the Rebecca Kelly Dance Concert at Kaufmann Concert Hall was of young people, especially Miss Kelly, doing what they want to do in life and being happy about it.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leaders of Egypt and Sudan Sign a Charter of Integration
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan signed an accord today aimed at consolidating economic, foreign and military policies.

title: POSTAL CLERKS GO TO TV TO IMPROVE REPUTATION
description: The postal clerks' union, determined to ''fight fire with fire,'' is beginning a television advertising campaign to counter private competition to the Postal Service.

title: HOW TICKETS TO 'CATS' BECAME A 'MUST'
description: More than six months before opening night, the Fresh Air Fund had already bought 500 seats. The Arthritis Foundation purchased 300 tickets, the Archives of American Art bought 300, and the American Red Cross bought 500 seats. Then there was the Burden Center for Aging with 300, University Settlement with 200 and the Social Service Big Sister League with 500 seats.

title: Executive Resumes Career at Warner
description: Ted Ashley has decided to chuck retirement and go back to work full time. Warner Communications Inc., the entertainment giant, announced yesterday that he had joined the company as vice chairman.

title: Harvester Making Little Progress
description: The International Harvester Company is finding it hard to persuade major suppliers to grant concessions it says it needs to avoid bankruptcy, company officials and suppliers said.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard HAVING IT ALL. By HELEN GURLEY BROWN. 462 pages. A Simon & Schuster/ Linden Press Book. $15.95.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday gave an incorrect address for the Mexican Book Center. It is at 24 East 81st Street.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RETAIL SALES RISE 1% IN SEPTEMBER
description: The nation's retail sales grew 1 percent in September, recovering from August's decline, the Commerce Department said today.

title: P.& G. Dividend
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said it plans to increase the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share next February if a 2-for-1 split is approved. The company also declared its regular quarterly dividend of $1.05 a share, payable Nov. 15, to stock of record Oct. 22.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; French Official Rejects Namibia-Angola Linkage

title: Q&A
description: Q. Someone brought up the subject of ''cooking'' in a dishwasher and said you had given the idea. Someone else proposed that there is such a thing as a ''dishwasher cookbook.'' Can you enlighten me?

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
TWO USEFUL IMPLEMENTS
description: IF there is one spice whose aroma and flavor evoke indelible images of cool-weather cuisine, it is nutmeg, the finishing touch to many vegetable purees, sauces, sausage or potato dishes, cakes, pies and holiday drinks. In my kitchen, fresh nutmeg is always within arm's reach.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1982
description: International Polish shipyard workers struck in Gdansk for a second day, and fierce battles raged again in the streets between riot policemen and workers demanding a reinstatement of the outlawed independent trade union Solidarity. The authorities ordered the shipyard ''militarized,'' subjecting the workers to military rules and discipline. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington's peace plan is unacceptable because it does not provide for an independent Palestinian state, according to Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but he said the plan had ''some positive elements.'' Mr. Arafat spoke at a news conference in Amman after nearly 12 hours of talks over four days with King Hussein of Jordan. (A1:5.)

title: 76ers Want McAdoo
description: Although Philadelphia recently acquired Moses Malone, one of basketball's top stars and last season's most valuable player, the 76ers' owner, Harold Katz, is apparently not satisfied. His latest target is Bob McAdoo, the veteran forward who helped the Los Angeles Lakers win the National Basketball Association championship last year but has not signed a new contract with the Lakers.

title: New Primary Ordered In Councilmanic Race
description: Ruling that there had been ''a gross number of irregularities,'' a State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, Anthony Mercorella, yesterday invalidated the Democratic primary in the 11th Councilmanic District in the South Bronx and ordered a new election.

title: Tashi, Emerson Quartet To Aid Food Day Fund
description: Two classical music ensembles, the Emerson String Quartet and Tashi/ Clarinet and Strings, and the pianist Richard Goode will take part in a concert tonight at 7 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street.

title: OPERA: EVELYN LEAR SINGS THE MARSCHALLIN
description: AT the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, the soprano Evelyn Lear appeared as the Marschallin in Richard Strauss's ''Der Rosenkavalier.''

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Johnny Carson Sentenced
description: Johnny Carson, the television entertainer, seeking to avoid a highly publicized trial, pleaded no contest today to one count of a misdemeanor for drunken driving and was placed on three years probation and fined $603. The sentence was the maximum short of jail that he could have gotten under California's tough drunken driving laws. Mr. Carson, 56 years old, was ordered to attend a drivers' education alcohol program and for 90 days his license was restricted to trips to and from work and those classes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE KITCHEN

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLASTIC laminates, which are widely used to cover counter tops in kitchens and bathrooms, and table tops, cabinets and other furniture, can also be used to create a maintenance-free finish on many homebuilt projects and to rejuvenate the tops of old tables and counters.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TWO POLLS OF CONNECTICUT VOTERS VARY
description: Two statewide polls of Connecticut voters' preferences in the United States Senate race have produced widely varying figures, possibly the result of several different methods used in each survey.

title: AGA KHAN'S SILVER JUBILEE: BRIDGING TWO WORLDS
description: Along the shore here, sheltered by palms, there stands a gleaming white villa whose vista leads the eye beyond lawn and garden and surf across the Indian Ocean. It is the official residence of His Highness the Aga Khan, the 49th hereditary Imam of the world's Ismaili Moslems, direct descendant of the Prophet Mohammed, benefactor and bloodstock breeder whose interests, like the ocean at his door, span Asia and Africa and parts of the Arab world.

title: TIME INC. UP 79.6%
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that its net income had dropped 68.5 percent in the third quarter, to $18.5 million, or 66 cents a share, from $58.7 million, or $2.11 a share, for the same period in 1981. It cited the recession, retrenchment in its record operations and its unsuccessful cable television business.

title: FULL DAY OF TALKS WITH NEW MEDIATOR
description: Representatives for both the National Football League players and owners spent most of today in separate and joint meetings with Sam Kagel, the mediator who joined the negotiations Tuesday night. They were prepared to continue talks well into the night, if necessary.

title: CONTINENTAL TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for pooling acquisitions

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Social Democrat Asks For Shift in Election System
description: Roy Jenkins, the leader of the Social Democratic Party, called today for urgent changes in Britain's electoral system, which he said was dangerous, undemocratic and inimical to efficient government.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP 1.7% IN 10 DAYS
description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that their sales rose 1.7 percent in the first 10 days of October, the start of the 1983 model year.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOT JOBLESS, SHE WROTE IN BEHALF OF 'OTHERS'
description: In his speech tonight, President Reagan read a letter from a woman he identified only as Judith, who implied she had lost her job and had no prospects of finding a ''home of our own.''

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can't solve unemployment without solving the things that caused it - the out-of-control government spending, the skyrocketing inflation and interest rates that led to unemployment in the first place.'' - President Reagan. (B14:1.)

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstdng have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a 100 percent stock divd

title: Columbia Passer Tops
description: The passing attack that has featured the offense of Columbia University's football team this season has sent Don Lewis, the Lions' junior split end from Miami, to the top of the National Collegiate Athletic Association statistics for receivers. Lewis caught 11 passes in the victory over Princeton last Saturday to give him a total of 34.

title: Credit Markets; U.S. BILL RATES HOLD STEADY
description: Rates on the new three- and six-month Treasury bills were virtually unchanged yesterday from Tuesday's auction results, while prices of longer-term Treasury issues rose.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROVIDENT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corporation, Morris Township, N.J., has named Robert M. Schweikher president of Allied Technologies.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLUMBIA GETS FUND FOR CHAIR ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Corliss Lamont, the author and philosopher who was the director of the American Civil Liberties Union for 20 years, has donated $1 million to Columbia University's School of Law for the establishment of a professorship in civil liberties, university officials said yesterday.

title: G.O.P. SEES OTTINGER-FOSSEL RACE AS A MAJOR TEST
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger reflected the other day on the nice things that former President Gerald R. Ford had recently said about Mr. Ottinger's Republican opponent, Assemblyman Jon S. Fossel.

title: The Beard vs. The Bats
description: ST. LOUIS I f baseball players are actors, the World Series is their Broadway theater. For them, the regular season is Off Broadway; even a league championship series is a New Haven tryout. To be remembered, it's best to make it big on the World Series stage. And this year's plot now has been established - Bruce Sutter, the Cardinals' bearded bullpen ace, against the Milwaukee Brewers' batting order, alias Harvey's Wallbangers.

title: GANNETT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun Co. Lifts Price Of Some Products
description: The Sun Company said that it had increased the price it pays for its United States crude oil by $1 a barrel, to $33, and that it was raising the price of some of its distillate products such as heating oil and diesel fuel by half a cent per gallon.

title: BANKING: LET US NOT ERASE THRIFTS' MANDATE
description: To the Editor:

title: 50 PERSONS ARE HURT, 12 OF THEM SERIOUSLY, IN JERSEY BUS CRASH
description: A chartered bus filled with elderly Roman Catholic pilgrims returning to Massachusetts from a trip to a New Jersey shrine collided head on with a tractor trailer truck in Hackettstown, N.J. yesterday evening, injuring 50 people, 12 of them seriously. Five of the 12 were listed in critical condition early this morning.

title: RACE RAISED AS AN ISSUE IN MISSISSIPPI HOUSE CONTEST
description: Robert G. Clark says the Congressional campaign here is about Reaganomics, and Webb Franklin says it is about ''whether we're going to have more centralized control by government.''

title: STUDY FINDS CONSOLIDATION OF U.S. AID HAS HURT CITIES
description: President Reagan's success in consolidating some Federal programs into grants administered by the states has adversely affected assistance programs in many cities, according to a study issued today by the United States Conference of Mayors.

title: CLINTON T. DUFFY, EX-WARDEN OF SAN QUENTIN, IS DEAD AT 84
description: Clinton T. Duffy, a retired warden of California's San Quentin Prison who introduced far-reaching humanitarian reforms into what was then the nation's largest penal institution, died Monday in a convalescent home in Walnut Creek, Calif., after a long illness. He was 84 years old and had a home in Walnut Creek.

title: Union and G.M. Set Meeting On Possible Pact Violations
description: Bargainers for the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation will meet Thursday in an unusual session to discuss possible violations of their six-month-old contract, in which the union agreed to $3 billion in concessions.

title: 3 HELD AFTER CALIFORNIA WINE IS SOLD AS TOP FRENCH
description: Federal agents said yesterday that 40 cases of fake Chateau Mouton Rothschild, one of the most expensive and famous wines of France, had been seized and three persons had been arrested after a threemonth investigation into the sale of fraudulent wine.

title: Vienna Patient Gets A Pacemaker in Error
description: A Yugoslav man who went to a Vienna hospital for treatment of rheumatism fell and broke his leg and the hospital mistakenly put a pacemaker in his chest.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
WHO CAUSED THE ECONOMY?
description: The hills are alive with the sound of political economics.

title: DOMINGO REPLACED, BOOING DISRUPTS MET'S 'LA GIOCONDA'
description: A performance of Ponchielli's ''La Gioconda'' at the Metropolitan Opera was disrupted by sustained booing last night when a substitute singer in the second act incurred the displeasure of a sizable segment of the sold-out audience.

title: LENOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHOOLING ON SUNDAYS FOR PEOPLE OVER 60
description: The thought of attending school on Sunday may not appeal to many students, but Maria Morla, who is 77 years old, says she is looking forward to it.

title: HOME BEAT
description: BOTH book and exhibit are modest. But sometimes, as the saying goes, nice things come in small packages. The packaging is the handiwork of Donovan & Green, a design and production concern.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $1.7 million after-tax loss primarily due to the sale of tax-exempt investment securities

title: AGENDA FOR BONN OUTLINED BY KOHL
description: Setting a new agenda for West Germany at home and abroad, Chancellor Helmut Kohl declared today that his conservative Government would encourage private investment, trim welfare spending, restrict foreign immigration and ''reinforce and stabilize'' its relations with the United States.

title: STRIPPING A WALL: GETTING DOWN TO BRICK
description: FOUR young women rented a gloomy ground-floor apartment in the East 90's last year and, hoping to cheer it up by exposing brickwork, stripped a 16-foot-long wall of its crumbling plaster. Instead of the even texture of solid brick, they uncovered a stained, dilapidated wall, its buckling cracks patched roughly with blobs of gray cement. Smack in the middle, like the eye of a blinded Cyclops, was a bricked-up window.

title: Coach Aims High
description: Johnny Majors said he knew what the expectations would be when he returned to his alma mater, the University of Tennessee, as its football coach in 1977. Majors had rebuilt the program at Pittsburgh, where he had made the Panthers the national champions in 1976.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Arizona Bank is the principal subsidiary of Arizona Bancwest Corp

title: 2 STUDIES DISPUTE NAPOLEON MURDER
description: In one of history's more intriguing post-mortems, scientists have reopened the case of the suspected poisoning of Napoleon Bonaparte. Citing evidence from the exiled Emperor's wallpaper and a strand of his hair, they say they now doubt that the Napoleon was murdered by arsenic.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BECH IS BACK. By John Updike. 195 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: PLANTS FOR INDOOR SILLS
description: THE leafy ''Autumn in the Atrium'' exhibition at the Citicorp Center (Lexington Avenue and 53d Street) has something of interest for both city and country gardeners. The free flower show, being held for the fourth consecutive year, is sponsored by the Garden Club of America, a national organization founded in 1913.

title: TO LECH WALESA
description: After two hundred years, After two hundred years of hope recovered and hope lost, You became the chief of the Polish people And, once more, the powers are arrayed against you.

title: HARVESTER DEBT PLAN APPROVED
description: The International Harvester Company announced today that all of its nearly 200 lenders had approved the latest modification to its financial rescue plan.

title: JOHN K. M. TIBBY
description: John K.M. Tibby, who retired in 1978 as an assistant managing editor of Sports Illustrated, died Monday at his home in Port Washington, L.I., after a long illness.

title: A CETA BLUEPRINT FOR THE NEW JOB TRAINERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEHRMAN ASSESSES RENT PLAN
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal nominee for governor, said yesterday that a major thrust of his campaign in the 20 days until Election Day would be to tell the voters what he believed were the weaknesses of the tax cut plan of his Republican-Conservative opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman.

title: DEPOSED MANAGER MISSES THE ACTION
description: ST. LOUIS T he man from Anaheim is not here at the World Series, where, at the beginning of the season, he had hoped to be, even expected to be. With good reason. He was manager of the Brewers.

title: SUCCAH VANDALISM WORRYING COLLEGE
description: The destruction of a succah built for the Jewish festival of Succoth at Dartmouth College has aroused alarm among some students and faculty members.

title: STUMBLING BLOCK
description: Second article of a series appearing periodically on the effects of changing economic conditions on some American families. An article on the stress created by the recession appears on page C1. MINNEAPOLIS - Once a month, when dinners of chicken, hot dogs or hamburger-and-noodle casseroles had become overwhelmingly monotonous, Joan Babekuhl would load her five children into her 1974 station wagon and treat them to a meal at the Ponderosa Steak House.

title: POOR LANDS AT U.N. DEPLORE WORLD ECONOMY
description: Delegates from eight less-developed nations added to the growing chorus here about the crisis in the international economy.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics; New Departures; Black Power
description: We all know how progressive the South has become, but there are still surprises. Imagine: Alabama's leading black political organization has just endorsed George Wallace for governor, the same George Wallace who once vowed: ''Segregation now! Segregation tomorrow! Segregation forever!''

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. New Jersey Nets, second game of exhibition doubleheader, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M. First game, Milwaukee Bucks vs.

title: LAWRENCE W. KANAGA
description: Lawrence W. Kanaga, 69 years old, a retired senior vice president of the Bell & Howell Company, died Monday in Glenbrook Hospital in Glenview, Ill.

title: DISGUISING HOME ELECTRONICS: HIDDEN ENTERTAINMENT
PARIS HAND LAUNDRIES: AN ART SURVIVES
description: PARIS IN the 19th century Russian nobles shipped their silk foulards and lace chemises by train to Paris to be laundered. Today foreigners still arrive with suitcases full of soiled shirts and Porthault sheets, because laundry, like cooking and sewing, is something the French do as well as any and, no doubt, better than many.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1982
description: International Polish shipyard workers who struck for two days in Gdansk over the outlawing of the independent trade union Solidarity returned to work after the martial-law authorities drafted them into military service. But new protests erupted in southern Poland, where 3,000 workers marched out of a steel plant outside Cracow. Street clashes were reported in Wroclaw in the southwest. (Page A1, Column 4.) The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Alva Myrdal of Sweden and Alfonso Garcia Robles of Mexico for their efforts to promote disarmament. Mrs. Myrdal's husband is Gunnar Myrdal, who shared the 1974 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. Mr. Garcia Robles is a 71-year-old career diplomat. (A10:3-6.)

title: Market Place; Trane's Deal For G.E. Unit
description: THE Trane Company's decision to make an all-cash purchase of General Electric's residential central air-conditioning business instead of the cash-and-stock combination originally planned suggests that Trane is no longer fearful of a takeover.

title: Switzerland Set to Extradite Turk Linked to Pope Shooting
description: The Swiss Supreme Court rejected an appeal by a Turk today against his extradition to Italy to face charges of complicity in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II.

title: Mitchell J. Epstein, 52; Led Advertising Firm
description: Mitchell J. Epstein, an advertising executive credited with a number of catchy slogans, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital, two weeks after having suffered a stroke. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. SAFETY BOARD TO STUDY AIRPORTS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it would study the safety standards practiced at selected airports around the country, including National Airport serving Washington.

title: Venezuelan Credit Talks
description: Venezuela is arranging emergency extensions of short-term foreign credits while it completes plans to refinance $2.5 billion of debt maturing by April, banking and Government sources said today.

title: Caterpillar Cuts Payout
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that its directors had lowered the quarterly dividend to 37 1/2 cents a share, payable Nov. 20 to shareholders of record Oct. 25, from 67 1/2 cents. It said that, despite the 44 percent reduction compared with the dividends paid in earlier quarters this year, the 1982 dividend would amount to $2.40, the same as in 1981.

title: Mrs. Reagan Presents Medal to Jihan Sadat
description: Nancy Reagan presented the widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt with a medal today for her husband's work. Jihan Sadat, wearing mourning black, accepted the American Friendship Medal at a ceremony at the White House.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,194,000 for the qr and $35,747,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated for comparative purposes; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: Milton H. Glover, Ex-President Of the Hartford National Bank
description: Milton H. Glover, former president and vice chairman of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, died Monday at the Hughes Convalescent Home in West Hartford. He was 83 years old and a resident of Simsbury, Conn.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW DEPARTURES; Warming Promises
description: According to an old Russian folk saying, the world is kept warm by people who believe. If so, the streets will truly melt, and the oceans boil, when enough people start believing the following assurances:

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-There are no comparable yr-ago 9 mos results because the qr ended Sept 30, 1981 was the first qr of the company's operations

title: Hasidim and Their Tales
description: Y affa Eliach, a Brooklyn College professor of Judaic studies, was at the Harold Clurman Theater yesterday with several student assistants when her new book, ''Hasidic Tales of the Holocaust'' (Oxford University Press), was introduced with readings by actors. On hand, too, were some of the Hasidic Jews whose stories they taperecorded.

title: G.M.A.C. Rate Action
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it was lowering interest rates on its nine-month to five-year mediumterm notes.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 12.00-13.00** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WIDOW OF SLAIN JURIST TAKES STAND AT MURDER-FOR-PAY TRIAL IN TEXAS
description: The widow of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. wept today as she told a jury how she found her husband mortally wounded, then said she could not forgive a woman charged with helping to plot his death.

title: Levo Decides to Rejoin Devils
description: The New Jersey Devils had more to cheer about today than their undefeated record. Tapio Levo decided to leave his native Finland and rejoin them.

title: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for reversal of interest

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.M. Sets Layoff
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will lay off 2,500 workers at its car assembly plant here next week because of a backlog of unsold subcompact ''J'' cars. The plant should return to production Oct. 25, depending on sales figures, G.M. said.

title: AN ALL-STAR GAME THAT MIGHT NOT BE
description: Had a brass band been waiting at the gate to greet the American Football Conference's Eastern Division All-Stars when they reported for their first workout today, it would have been as shocked as the players. The gate was locked.

title: PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Andrew Cuts Short His Caribbean Vacation

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
ORGANIZERS FOR THE BATHROOM
description: STORES around town are carrying several new bathroom organizers, handy for keeping the many small items that accumulate. The Cover-Up is a white plastic container that mounts on a wall and holds paper cups and six toothbrushes; it has a section for several tubes of toothpaste and other items.

title: ECONOMIC ISSUES HELP O'NEILL IN GOVERNOR RACE, POLL SHOWS
description: Unemployment and other aspects of the economy are the greatest concerns of Connecticut voters, according to a statewide poll by The New York Times, and Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has made economic development the main theme of his campaign for re-election, is drawing wide support from people concerned about those issues.

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-Including tax credit of $109,000 for the qr and $194,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: CITY HOUSING COURT CRITICIZED AT LEGISLATIVE PANEL'S HEARING
description: Landlords, tenants, judges and legislators discussed the condition of New York City's Housing Court yesterday at a State Assembly committee hearing in Manhattan. They proposed a wide range of changes, including keeping the court open longer, and urged that operating funds be increased.

title: Technology; Foreign Gains In Computers
description: EFFORTS of other nations to obtain American technology, sometimes through improper channels, have been in the news lately. Japanese computer executives are accused of stealing computer secrets. Spies are said to abound in California's Silicon Valley. And a recent National Academy of Sciences report concludes that there is a significant leakage of technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Ruling on Pabst
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said that a Federal District Court in Delaware had ruled that consent decrees obtained from a majority of Pabst stockholders by a dissident shareholder group were invalid. The consent decrees were obtained by a group led by Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier. If upheld, they would have removed the brewing company's current directors. Mr. Jacobs obtained the decrees as part of an attempt to win control of Pabst, which is based in Milwaukee.

title: Idaho Fugitive Killed
description: A man who escaped from a prison where he was serving sentences of more than 300 years died today after a shootout with the police, the authorities said. David Thompson, 24 years old, who escaped Friday from the Idaho State Penitentiary, was wounded Tuesday in a gunfight north here. He was convicted two years ago of 25 felony counts of rape, kidnapping and assaults on women.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE THEATER: 'ROCKAWAY' BY JOHN PATRICK SHANLEY
description: THE time is 1957 and the scene is a rundown bar in Rockaway. The whisky is cheap -and so is the sentiment. John Patrick Shanley's ''Rockaway,'' at the Vineyard Theater, is a commonplace situation comedy about the triumph of good will.

title: Company and Indiana Agency Cited in Fatal Ramp Collapse
description: A state agency issued 15 citations today against the Indiana Highway Department and a construction company for failing to follow proper procedures while building a bridge ramp that collapsed and killed 13 workers.

title: Wine and Roses Run Out in Albany
description: The gubernatorial campaign so far is shaped by New York's flagging economy and the implications for the state budget. Those who have seen the six-month figures for the first half of the fiscal year, which ended as the campaign began, say tax receipts are running below expectations.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NATO COMMANDER OPPOSES U.S. TROOP CUT
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization commander in Europe, said today that proposals to withdraw some or all of the American troops from Europe could devastate the Western alliance.

title: A CELEBRATION OF THE DECORATED SURFACE
description: ''PATTERN,'' opening tomorrow at the American Craft Museum II, is an exhibition that draws together 126 works by 55 artists who celebrate one significant trend in contemporary crafts, the decorated surface, in clay, metal, fiber, paper, wood and glass.

title: PROBATION IRKS TEXAS
description: Although University of Texas officials said there would be no appeal of a probation ruling handed down against the school by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for recruiting violations and the resale of tickets, they indicated today that they thought the findings warranted no punishment.

title: DANCERS TAKE THEIR CASE TO THE PUBLIC
description: The dancers of the American Ballet Theater, out of work because of a six-week labor dispute that led to stopping rehearsals and canceling appearances in Paris, Boston and Washington, brought their case to the public yesterday.

title: F.B.I. SEEKS MAN OF TYLENOL EXTORTION CHARGE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation obtained a warrant here today for the arrest of Robert Richardson, a Chicago man accused of trying to extort $1 million from the makers of Extra-Strength Tylenol by threatening to put poison in more of the popular pain reliever's capsules.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My home has copper plumbing and we have recently noticed a greenish stain in the shower, bathtub and sinks. What is the cause of this, and how can we eliminate it?

title: J.P. MORGAN INCOME UP BY 45.2% IN 3D QUARTER
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, the corporate parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, reported yesterday that operating income in the third quarter jumped 45.2 percent, to $116 million, or $2.81 a share, from $79.9 million, or $1.92 a share, in the same quarter of last year.

title: Wheat Failures Predicted In 2 Australian Areas
description: Wheat crop failures are now unavoidable in parts of Australia suffering from the country's worst drought in recent history, officials at the United States agricultural weather center said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP (IBM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sep
description: Revs figures represent gross income

title: Fortune International Planning January Start
description: Fortune International, an offshoot of the Time Inc. publication, will begin publication Jan. 10 with a planned circulation of 70,000 in Europe, Asia and South America.

title: Braun Walks Into the Hero's Spotlight
description: When Steve Braun's moment in the spotlight finally arrived after tonight's game, so did the question of whether it was appropriate to congratulate someone for receiving a base on balls?

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 results restated for the pooling of interest method of accounting for two banks acquired in early 1982

title: AQUEDUCT MEETING BEGINS
description: It just wouldn't have seemed like The Big A without dark skies and a wintry drizzle, so the weather provided a fitting opening-day backdrop for the annual seven-month return of the runners to Aqueduct Race Track yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Rises by 36.2%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose 36.2 percent from its unusually weak third quarter a year ago.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a computer error at The Associated Press, the Mutual Funds table in Business Day yesterday showed net changes incorrectly. They reflected the differences in price from Friday's quotations, rather than Monday's.

title: U.S. and Grace Join In Coal Pipe Plan
description: The Interior Department said that it had reached an agreement with W.R. Grace & Company for construction of a pipeline to carry coal from Colorado to the West Coast.

title: ISRAEL TO HELP HOUSE PALESTINIAN REFUGEES IN LEBANON
description: The Israeli Government, reversing a longstanding policy, said today that it would take an active role in housing and protecting the Palestinian refugees in southern Lebanon this winter.

title: 2 GUNMEN SURRENDER AFTER TAKING HOSTAGES IN QUEENS BANK SHOOTING
description: Two masked gunmen took five hostages yesterday in a bank in Queens after a shootout with one of two plainclothes policemen who interrupted their robbery attempt.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS ECONOMIC POLICIES PROVE EFFECTIVE
description: President Reagan said tonight that even though unemployment remained high his economic policies were effectively attacking its root causes. He said the nation could slowly work its way back to prosperity if it had ''the courage to see it through.''

title: No Headline
description: SAN FRANCISCO'S BAN ON PISTOLS IS OVERTURNED

title: WARRIORS MATCH OFFER TO KING
description: The Golden State Warriors exercised their right of first refusal yesterday and matched the offer sheet that Bernard King signed Sept. 28 with the Knicks.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Seaver Available
description: Five and a half years and one ownership later, could Tom Seaver be on his way back to the Mets? ''New York obviously would be one place I'd go,'' Seaver, who has asked the Cincinnati Reds to trade him, said yesterday. Asked if the Mets are interested in Seaver, Lou Gorman, the team's vice-president for baseball operations, said: ''To what degree I don't know. We'd have to know certain things: Is he available, what is his physical condition, what would they want back? We will talk with them again in Milwaukee or when we get back.''

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-Including $160,000 gain from the sale of trucking equipment...C-Including a tax credit of $127,000

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
TEXAS GOVERNOR IS COURTING MEXICAN-AMERICAN VOTERS IN CLOSE CAMPAIGN
description: The billboards are large and colorful, brilliant blue and orange, vivid against the blue Texas sky. The message is in Spanish: ''Hombre de Palabra. Clements.'' Apparently there are those who question the message, that Gov. William Clements is ''a man of his word.'' In south Texas, someone set up smaller sign underneath one of the billboards. It said, ''Y mi abuela juega con los Dallas Cowboys'' - ''And my grandmother plays with the Dallas Cowboys.''

title: CITY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEAN PICKS NEW CASINO AGENCY CHIEF
description: Governor Kean today named Walter N. Read, former president of the New Jersey Bar Association, to be chairman of the Casino Control Commission.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Delegating Power

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corporation sold 2 million new common shares to Dean Witter Reynolds for $16.50 a share.

title: A Bad Bounce
description: Jake Gaudaur, the commissioner of the Canadian Football League, would like to think it was a combination of factors - among them bad luck -rather than rejection by American football fans that prompted NBC-TV to discontinue showing the C.F.L. games during the National Football League strike. ''First, NBC had to black out 14 key stations in the northern tier,'' he said.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALGREEN CO reports earnings for QTr to Aug 3
Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation's Security Pacific National Bank said it had agreed to acquire Kahn & Company, a Memphis discount brokerage company. Terms were not disclosed. Kahn has more than 18,000 accounts with offices in Memphis, New Orleans, Houston and Dallas, Security Pacific said.

title: A New Melting Pot: The City in the '80's A series of articles appearing periodically
description: He arrived from Colombia alone -a stranger to this country. He spoke no English and knew no one to call. He carried one small suitcase, but a load of expectation, and as he began his journey, Marcos Martinez, at the age of 27, had only one idea in mind: to make a fortune. Wee Young Sook came from South Korea. She said she imagined dollar bills blowing off the subway tracks, a large house and plenty to eat. What she hoped for was to return to her homeland one day with enough money to do as she pleased.

title: MUSIC HALL TO STAGE 'PORGY'
description: In what is billed as the first legitimate theater venture of its 50-year history, the Radio City Music Hall will present a revival of George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' for a six-week run, starting next March 19. The production will be produced by Sherwin M. Goldman, whose 1976 Broadway revival of the 1935 show won a Tony award.

title: A CLOSED COURT'S ONE ISSUE CASELOAD
description: Only one courtroom in America is permanently closed to the public. Located in a vaultlike chamber on the sixth floor of the Justice Department, its locked door is always guarded and its walls are insulated. It is regularly inspected for signs of bugging.

title: Chairman of Mesa In Suit Settlement
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr. may soon be a bit poorer on paper as a result of a proposed agreement to settle a lawsuit by a shareholder. Mr. Pickens, 52 years old, is the aggressive chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex., who lost out earlier this year in a bid to take over the Cities Service Company.

title: 16 TABLE SETTINGS AT OLD WESTBURY
description: ABOUT all that was missing was the coffin and cape. The stake was there, just to the left of a white organdy napkin; the cross was laid carefully by the soup spoon, and a necklace of 20 garlic cloves hung over one of the two chairs - presumably that of Barbara Cates, who had set her table for ''Halloween Dinner Alone With Count Dracula, Transylvania, Halloween 19??'' The centerpiece was three antique Imari bowls heaped with gourds.

title: ENERGY RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
The King's Move
description: Among the agonizing reappraisals now evident in the Middle East, none is more poignant than King Hussein's. Israel seethes with doubt about how to exploit its victory in Lebanon. The P.L.O. is bitterly struggling to adjust to defeat. But Jordan's King, who had no part in their recent battle, stands as the most dangerously exposed. Unless he moves swiftly either Israel or the P.L.O., or even both, will resolve their debates at his expense.

title: PASSING THE BUCK
description: Listening to the Supreme Court argument on tax exemptions for discriminatory private schools, I thought to myself that the Court nowadays performs a function seldom mentioned by scholars of the judicial process: it provides a convenient way for politicians to escape responsibility for awkward decisions.

title: CENTRAL PENN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY OPERA: 'CANDIDE'
description: IN the best of all possible worlds, Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide'' would have made it to the opera house stage last night as an undiluted triumph. If Dr. Pangloss had written the scenario for the evening, he would have had the 26-year-old musical making a joyous transition from Broadway to the New York City Opera's repertory, registering the kind of success that sends audiences home whistling the tunes and repeating the wittiest lyrics to their friends.

title: DEALERS CRITICIZE BOND RULE
description: A requirement that new municipal bonds must be issued only in registered form after Jan. 1 drew criticism from securities dealers attending the annual convention of the Public Securities Association here this week. They said that the market for state and local government bonds might be disrupted and that more time was needed to prepare for the change.

title: SALVADOR'S REBELS REPORT A BIG PUSH
description: Leftist guerrillas fought fierce battles on two fronts in northern El Salvador today, reportedly capturing as many as five villages in their biggest offensive since the March elections.

title: Derailing and Fire Snarl Subways
description: A subway car that derailed on the Manhattan Bridge disrupted the northbound BMT from Brooklyn to Manhattan for seven hours yesterday, and a fire in a midtown subway station snarled the East Side IRT line briefly. There were no injuries.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARIBAS OFFICERS INDICTED OVER EXPORTS OF CAPITAL
description: Eighty-eight clients and four officers of the Paribas banking group were indicted today on charges of illegally transferring millions of dollars to Switzerland after the May 1981 election of France's Socialist Government.

title: CARDS RALLY TO DEFEAT BREWERS AND TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: The St. Louis Cardinals tied the World Series at one game apiece tonight when they defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-4, on a highly unglamorous but fatal play: a walk with the bases loaded in the eighth inning.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan asserted that his economic policies are effectively attacking the ''root causes'' of unemployment. In a televised address, he said the problem would eventually be solved if the nation stayed with his program. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan went further than ever before in acknowledging that unemployment, rather than inflation, is his Administration's main problem. (A1.)

title: TEXTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: A Judicial Inquiry

title: RANGERS WIN WITH 3 GOALS IN 3d PERIOD
description: The Rangers managed to keep their offense going full tilt through the second and third periods last night at Madison Square Garden, breaking open a 2-2 game and beating the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net losses from discontinued operations of $3.6 million for the qr and $11 million for the 9 mos and a net loss of $6.5 million for the qr and 9 mos onthe disposal of discontinued operations...C-After net losses from discontinued operations of $2.9 million for the qr and $7.7 million for the 9 mos

title: Bid for Women's Bank
description: Brasilinvest S.A. Investimentos Participa,coes e Negocios announced yesterday that it intended to make a cash tender offer for all the shares of the First Women's Bank of New York through its Bahamian subsidiary, Brasilinvest Overseas Bank Ltd. The offer, at $15 a share, is conditioned on receiving a minimum of 190,000 shares, or 51 percent of those outstanding. Brasilinvest said the bank was recommending acceptance of the offer, which is subject to regulatory approval.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sharing Limited Resources

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on pages A20-29 and B12-17. Campaign Report, B9-12. 5 Killed in Accident At a Texaco Refinery

title: CONSUMER LOAN RATES ARE DECLINING
description: Banks around the country have begun to lower interest rates on consumer loans, and in New York it appeared yesterday that banks were trying to undercut one another on interest rates for automobile financing.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EX-HOUSE MEMBER
description: Former Representative Craig Hosmer, an 11-term Republican Congressman from California, has died aboard a cruise ship bound for Mexico. He was 67 years old.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $8,059,000 or 30 cents a shr from use of the actual effective tax rate for the 9 mos ended Sept 30, 1982 which the company said currentlyreflects the best estimate of the annual effective tax rate

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Science Office Chief Says V.A. Is Stalling Agent Orange Study
description: The head of a science review panel says the Veterans Administration has needlessly delayed the start of a study on whether servicemen in Vietnam were harmed by the toxic herbicide Agent Orange.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swedish Submarine Hunt Could Last 'Indefinitely'
description: The hunt for at least one foreign submarine in the waters of the Stockholm archipelago ''could go on practically indefinitely,'' the Commander in Chief of Sweden's armed forces said today.

title: Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it would close many of its domestic plants from Nov. 20 through Nov. 28 because of weak sales. Thousands of workers are expected to be idled, but the exact number will not be known until Nov. 1, when plans are completed, according to Michael Hart, director of personnel relations.

title: STUBBORN COMBATANTS IN DISARMAMENT'S CAUSE: ALFONSO GARCIA ROBLES
description: When Alfonso Garcia Robles began promoting a treaty to ban nuclear weapons from Latin America in the mid-1960's, he was met as much by indifference as by resistance. But no obstacle was greater than his stubbornness - and the Mexican diplomat eventually got his way: In 1967, 22 nations of the region signed the Treaty of Tlatelolco.

title: INDONESIA DEFENDS ROLE IN EAST TIMOR
description: Indonesia's Foreign Minister defended his Government's role in East Timor today, and said that reports of widespread hunger and human rights abuses on the island were ''untrue.''

title: Burnup's Chief Resumes Post
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said Nick A. Caporella, who had resigned as chief executive because of his opposition to purchases of more than 33 percent of the stock by interests associated with Victor Posner, had agreed to resume the post until Jan. 1. One of his duties will be to find a successor.

title: CHANGES SET IN VIET MEMORIAL
description: The Federal Fine Arts Commission today approved two controversial additions to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial now nearing completion on the Mall. The additions are an eight-foothigh statue realistically depicting three haggard American fighting men and a 50-foot flagpole.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Royal Dutch Shell
description: The Royal Dutch Shell Group said it would cut 20 percent of the 4,000 research and development jobs at four European centers over the next three years to trim the growth of its research and development spending, which was about $446 million in 1981. The centers - two in Britain, one in the Netherlands and one in France - are in the refining and chemicals sectors.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CANADA LIBERALS LOSE BY-ELECTIONS
description: Candidates from Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's ruling Liberal Party were badly beaten Tuesday in three parliamentary by-elections as the party also lost a bid to gain control of the legislature in New Brunswick.

title: MEREDITH M. HILSON
description: Meredith M. Hilson, the New York partner in an art consulting business in Columbus, Ohio, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a brief illness.

title: 11.40 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,015.08
description: The stock market rose sharply yesterday on near-record volume with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its highest level in almost 18 months.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bolivia Re-establishes Links With Nicaragua
description: Bolivia's new civilian Government has re-established diplomatic relations with Nicaragua, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: Pepsico's Taco Bell Unit Drops Grey Advertising
description: Taco Bell, which operates 1,500 fast-food restaurants from its Irvine, Calif., headquarters, has split with Grey Advertising in Los Angeles after an eight-year relationship. Its advertising budget is a hefty $20 million.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Louis Frey, Ex-Vice President; Of Lloyds Bank International
description: Louis Frey, retired executive vice president of Lloyds Bank International Ltd., died Monday at Chilton Memorial Hospital in Pompton Plains, N.J. He was 63 years old and a resident of Pompton Plains.,

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $115,000 for the qr and yr

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS JOB TRAINING BILL, CALLING IT AN END TO 'BOONDOGGLE'
description: President Reagan today signed a bill that provides job training for unskilled, disadvantaged youths and retraining for displaced adult workers. The measure has none of the public works aspects of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, which it replaces.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dr. Eric Denhoff, 69, Pioneer In Treating Children Diseases
description: Dr. Eric Denhoff, a pioneer in the early detection and treatment of childhood diseases, died Monday at Miriam Hospital here after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: 2 Stay in Jail in Bomb Plot
description: A Federal magistrate ordered two men held in jail today after hearing testimony that they participated in a plot to extort $15 million from Gulf Oil.

title: Ayer Picks a New Fight
description: IN the arena of public service advertising Foote, Cone & Belding is helping out Smokey Bear; Dancer Fitzgerald Sample is taking a bite out of crime; Young & Rubicam is raising funds for the United Negro College Fund, and J. Walter Thompson is supporting the Boy Scouts of America. Now, the venerable (and once considered stuffy) N.W. Ayer, having already done its bit in the war on venereal disease, has entered the fight against alcoholism.

title: SMITH, A O, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Muir Aides
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had ordered administrative proceedings against Raymond L. Dirks and John D. Sullivan, former general partners of John Muir & Company, in connection with their actions there.

title: NEW DEPARTURES; Lobster's Luck
description: What guest is more welcome, and worse treated, at dinner than the lowly lobster, whose armor conceals such delectable flesh? The creature is boiled alive and crudely dismembered, its remains forming a sad junkpile.

title: Gold-Medal Performances
description: Jim Thorpe's winning performances in the decathlon and the pentathlon at the 1912 Olympic Games in Stockholm. Pentathlon LONG JUMP: First at 23 feet 2 1/4 inches.

title: FAMILIES FACING RECESSION'S STRESSES
description: DURHAM, N.H. ''THE stress on American families now is of a different order than ever before,'' said Dr. M. Harvey Brenner, an economist and medical sociologist at Johns Hopkins University. ''Their psychic pain is worse than that of families in the Depression or in the time of the Industrial Revolution, and yet, paradoxically, the country's level of material wealth is higher than ever.''

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1.8 million or 17 cents a shr from the sale of a radio station and certain common stock investments...C-Including income of $1.7 millionfrom the cumulative effect of a change in the method of depreciation

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THEATER: 'GOOD,' ON BECOMING A NAZI
description: WHEN we first meet Halder (Alan Howard), the protagonist of C.P. Taylor's ''Good,'' he is a model of the urbane university professor. A novelist and literary critic, Halder is devoted to his wife and children, as well as to his one close friend, a Jewish psychiatrist named Maurice. But the place is Frankfurt, the year is 1933, and men can change without warning. It isn't too long before Halder has not only become a member of the Nazi party but has also played a direct role in SS book burnings and euthanasia ''experiments'' in the Jewbashing Night of the Long Knives, and, finally, in Eichmann's genocide at Auschwitz.

title: POLICY AND THE ECONOMY
description: Following is a transcript of the address by the President to the nation from Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times: My fellow Americans, in recent days all of us have been swamped by a sea of economic statistics, some good, some bad, and some just plain confusing. There are times when I think that the paper traffic that crosses my desk in a week could fill a big city phone book, and then some.

title: CITY FISCAL WOES MAY DELAY NEW POLICE CLASS, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that there was a strong possibility that a plan to put a class of new police officers into the Police Academy next month would be postponed because of the city's mounting financial problems.

title: JIM THORPE'S OLYMPIC MEDALS ARE RESTORED
description: The two gold medals from the 1912 Olympic Games that Jim Thorpe was forced to return almost 70 years ago after he admitted he had once been paid to play baseball were restored posthumously yesterday.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the qr and $205,000 for the 9 mos; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the effects of discontinued operations and an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: U.N. GO HOME
description: A great opportunity is at hand to lance the boil that calls itself the U.N. General Assembly. When the Shultz plan denying the West Bank to the Israelis was put forward, the non-Egyptian Arab leaders assembled in Fez to respond. First, they told King Hussein he had no mandate to negotiate for the Palestinians. Then, far from hinting at any recognition of Israel, the Arab leaders agreed to the opposite: to launch a campaign in the U.N. and all its agencies to drive Israel out of the family of nations.

title: F.B.I. Denies Abscam Was Selective Inquiry
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the bureau did not selectively make any public official a target in its Abscam investigation, which led to the convictions of seven members of Congress.

title: HAYDEN SEEKS TO ERASE ANGRY 60'S IMAGE
description: Tom Hayden, who is running for the California Assembly, has spent $100,000 for television commercials that he hopes will portray him as a loving family man and ''not the same angry young man I was in the 60's.''

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRANCOIS J. BLANC
description: Francois J. Blanc, a retired maitre d'hotel at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, died last Thursday at his home in Palos Verdes, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: ''Interior Design: The New Free- dom,'' Leo Castelli Gallery, 142 Greene Street, 431-6279.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
South Atlantic
description: The South Atlantic Financial Corporation of Miami said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankrupty laws. The filing results primarily from the company's inability to pay the $16.9 million principal amount plus interest on its 6 3/4 percent subordinated debentures that matured last Feb. 15, and interest on its $1.7 million of 6 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures that matured last May 1. The company's securities were suspended by the New York Stock Exchange on Aug. 26 and now trade over the counter.

title: Santa Fe Tract
description: Santa Fe Industries said its Santa Fe Energy Company subsidiary had paid $35.5 million to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for a working interest in a 60-acre oil-producing tract. The property in the Midway-Sunset Field near Taft, Calif., has 58 wells producing about 1,300 barrels a day, of which about 1,100 will go to Santa Fe. The field adjoins other Santa Fe holdings in the area, from which the company derives about 20,000 barrels of oil a day.

title: PEKING SAYS HANOI STIRS BORDER TURMOIL
description: In the latest acknowledgement of border tensions, China accused Vietnam today of committing ''repeated armed provocations'' along their troubled frontier.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-After a loss of $917,000 from discontinued operations

title: AEG Plan Approved
description: The European Common Market approved today the West German Government's plan to guarantee loans totaling about $400 million intended to save the insolvent electrical giant AEG-Telefunken. The plan provides for a public guarantee on the loans, to be used to restructure the company before the end of 1983.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After a loss of $361,000 for the qr and yr from discontinued operations

title: 2 Injured in Crash On L.I. Highway
description: A 10-car crash on the Long Island Expressway yesterday injured two persons and closed down the westbound lanes of the highway during part of the evening rush hour, the police said.

title: Kodak Is Down by 9%; Teledyne Falls 19.6%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that weak demand and product-introduction costs had caused a 9 percent drop in third-quarter net income. Sales were flat.

title: Raycomm Sued
description: The Government filed a $1.2 million lawsuit in United States District Court in Newark against Raycomm Industries of Freehold, N.J., its chairman, Joseph J. Raymond, and former president, Karse J. Simon. The officers were previously indicted on criminal charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by inflating costs on a $12.8 million Army contract in 1975. The Justice Department said the civil suit seeks to recover twice the amount of the Army's losses in connection with the contract, which was for updating tool and equipment manuals.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $90,000 for the qr and $1.2 million for the 9 mos

title: Seahawks Drop Patera
description: The Seattle Seahawks dismissed Coach Jack Patera and General Manager John Thompson last night and made Mike McCormack the interim coach for the rest of this season. The announcement was made by John Nordstrom, representing the Nordstrom family that owns 51 percent of the team's stock.

title: MORGAN, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Braniff Given 30 More Days For Aid Plan
description: The Braniff International Corporation was given another 30 days to reorganize its bankrupt airline operations today after company officials told a courtroom full of creditors that in as little as 10 days, they could know whether a joint operating agreement with an unidentified airline would materialize.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Oct. 5 incorrectly reported the Westport Company's involvement in a proposed acquisition. Westport filed a suit to block the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company's offer for Northwestern Mutual Life Mortgage and Realty Investors.

title: 8 Suspicious Fires Hit Boston Neighborhoods
description: Eight more suspicious fires swept Boston's aging residential districts today, renewing a four-month outbreak of fires that officials contend are the work of arsonists, copycat firebugs and ''sick people.''

title: MARINES IN LEBANON: HOW MANY AND HOW LONG?
description: The Reagan Administration, having sent 1,200 Marines back to Lebanon last month for what was supposed to be a ''limited period,'' is faced now with a strong possibility that the American presence in Lebanon may turn out to be both longer and more extensive than first envisaged.

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Police Weigh Leads in Holdup Of an Armored Truck in Bronx
description: The police said yesterday that they had found fingerprints in the rented car used by the four gunmen who killed an armored-truck guard and seriously wounded another guard during a robbery outside a Bronx milk plant on Tuesday.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.4% IN AUGUST
description: Against a backdrop of the steepest sales decline in any month since last winter, inventories of unsold goods at American companies climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Finkelstein Discloses Slate
description: Jerry Finkelstein, the New York publisher and businessman, has announced the names of 15 members of his proposed slate of directors for the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation.

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rod Gilbert Flirts With the Camera
description: Organ music, please. When we last left Rod Gilbert, he and Pat Ashley, the talk-show hostess, had spent most of the day discussing the basics of hockey.

title: HERS
description: SAYING goodbye is one of the first social lessons a person is taught. Accompanied by a cheerful gesture, it is practiced first on parents, who go away with every intention of returning. Then it extends to family friends and playmates and finally to people encountered casually. ''Say bye-bye to the nice man,'' the baby is urged. The nice man may never be heard from again, but no thought is given to that.

title: News Analysis
description: Barely a week after three members of the Janus family died in a Chicago suburb after taking Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules that contained cyanide, their survivors were in Cook County Circuit Court, suing the drug's manufacturer and a distributor. The families of the four other Tylenol victims seem likely to follow.

title: Witness Links Cancers Of 24 to Nevada Fallout
description: Fallout from atomic bomb tests in Nevada was the most likely cause of the 24 cases of cancer being considered in a lawsuit in Federal District Court, a researcher testified today.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3.7 million

title: THE 'GREEN' DIFFERENCE IN GERMAN POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: With his election season address on the economy tonight, President Reagan went further than he has in the past in acknowledging that unemployment - not inflation - had become the No.1 problem facing his Administration and the No.1 worry afflicting voters. In almost all his recent speeches on behalf of political candidates around the country, Mr. Reagan has concentrated on arguing that his policies have brought inflation and interest rates down.

title: Cheater of Nazi Victims Gets 12-Year Sentence
description: A survivor of the Nazi Holocaust who cheated fellow survivors out of $47,000 in reparation payments from the West German Government has been sentenced to 12 years in prison.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS RESUME SEARCHES IN CAPITAL
description: The Lebanese Army resumed its searches of predominantly Moslem West Beirut for hidden weapons and illegal residents today, increasing concerns over when similar sweeps might be conducted in Christian-dominated East Beirut.

title: Rioting by Sikhs Spreads To a Second Indian Jail
description: Arson and rioting by hundreds of Sikh political prisoners spread to a second jail in northern Punjab State today. On Tuesday 2,000 Sikhs in Ferozepore central jail, 250 miles northwest of New Delhi, set fire to a prison cafeteria, food stores and tents.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WASHINGTON'S GRIEVANCE AGAINST MANAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida City Rescinds Law on Buying Guns
description: The City Council here voted Tuesday to rescind a gun ordinance it passed after a shooting spree left eight persons dead.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: Shoppers' Program Set
description: The Christian Broadcasting Network will start airing ''The Winning Shopper'' in January.

title: Out Before the Year Is
description: H alf a dozen members of the City Council, who were already not counting on returning next Jan. 1, learned this week that they will be pushed out of their jobs sooner than they had thought. Newly elected members will take office shortly after Election Day, Nov. 2, instead of having to endure the customary wait until the new year.

title: No Headline
description: DUTCH LEADER QUITS ABRUPTLY; A FORMER AIDE REPLACES HIM

title: LEHRMAN ASSESSES RENT LAWS
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for governor, said today that he had ''no plans to make any changes'' in New York State's rent-control or rentstabilization laws.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 qr and 9 mos results have been restated to reflect the 1981 and 1982 acquisitions on a pooling of interest basis

title: Bridge:; Zimmerman Team Attains The Rosenblum Semifinals
description: An American team, a French team and a dark-horse Spanish team qualified for the semifinals of the Rosenblum Knockout Team Championship by winning matches here this afternoon.

title: Boxing in Abundance
description: After dropping Canadian football from its Sunday schedule, NBC has scheduled a 10-round lightweight boxing bout as a lead-in to its broadcast of the of the World Series on Sunday. Livingston Bramble of Passaic, N.J., will fight James (Bubba) Besceme of Beaumont, Tex., in Atlantic City. ... NBC also announced that it would telecast a primetime tripleheader on Nov. 19.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Unions in Israel Strike To Protest Ultimatum
description: Israel's unions began a 24-hour strike today to protest the Government's labor policies. The action shut Ben-Gurion International Airport and the Mediterranean harbors at Haifa and Ashdod and paralyzed municipal services in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.

title: New Products Gain
description: Although the word from behind the scenes is that corporate activity in the new product field has slowed considerably, it certainly is not apparent in the marketplace itself, according to the latest edition of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. According to the survey, there were 120 introductions in September compared with 93 in the same month in 1981. And for the nine months, introductions now stand at 1,074 compared with 976 for the same period last year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: And Now the News, In Japanese

title: MINORITY GROUPS PLAYED KEY ROLE IN RISE OF SCORES IN COLLEGE EXAM
description: Higher scores of minority students were a major factor in raising average scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test this year for the first time in two decades, the College Entrance Examination Board announced yesterday.

title: Ladd Lost Temper and Game
description: If Peter Ladd, the rookie pitcher with the size-15 feet, had been as composed on the mound in the eighth inning tonight as he was in the clubhouse after the second game of the World Series, the St. Louis Cardinals might not have scored the winning run against him.

title: ECONOMY VCR'S MORE SOPHISTICATED
description: EVEN if you are only an occasional television viewer, there are times when a video cassette recorder can be a practical gadget to have, to tape a show of special interest broadcast when you are away, to provide an evening's worth of prerecorded movie entertainment or to play how-to and other educational programs.

title: Newman a Manager
description: Last summer, Paul Newman, the film star who drives in the Can-Am series, said that Indy car racing rates only second to his circuit. But yesterday, Newman agreed to become the team manager for Mario Andretti's 1983 effort to win the Indianapolis 500 and the national championship for Indy-type cars. Newman: ''This is an opportunity to challenge the best drivers and teams in racing.''

title: VIDEOTEX: LURING ADVERTISERS
description: A new novel by John D. MacDonald. A grape jelly by Welch. An electric drill by Black & Decker. A pair of kosher pickle products by Vlasic.

title: SINGING AND DANCING DEBUTS, OF SORTS
description: ''I love to curl up in bed with a good book - or a friend who's read one,'' sang Marian Seldes, to laughter and applause. Although she has been appearing on Broadway stages for years in such plays as ''Deathtrap'' and ''Equus,'' Miss Seldes made her cabaret debut as a singer only this week.

title: CHINA ENERGY: CHANCE FOR U.S.
description: China's plans to double its energy output by the end of the century to sustain its modernization drive provide the most substantial potential here yet for American business.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-After net provisions of $39,380,000 and $193,000 to cover forecasted operating losses at the company's crucible stainless and alloy division...C-Net income including a gain of $14,202,000 on the sale of the leasehold interest in the company's New York headqtrs

title: Lloyd's Inquiry On Howden
description: The committee of Lloyd's of London said today that it would examine the conduct of Peter Brewis, a former official of Alexander Howden Insurance Brokers Ltd., in connection with the April renewal of insurance for Qantas Airways Ltd.

title: Article 219690 -- No Title
description: Despite the global slump in the world oil market, 23 companies today made high bids totaling a near-record $2.1 billion for rights to drill for oil and gas in the Beaufort Sea off Alaska's North Slope.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America said it would lay off 175 more employees at its Alcoa, Tenn., plant, raising to 385 the number of layoffs there.

title: Blues Mixed With Weakfish
