description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Fine angling for weakfish alongshore with bluefish mixed in. With the ocean at 70 degrees, weakfish are not expected to school until cold hits. Small blues are in surf at high tide with striped bass. Seaside Park, N.J.: Few stripers are being taken off jetties in the 25-to 35-pound class. Bluefish from 5 to 7 pounds in surf. Belmar, N.J.: Blues from 1 to 5 pounds are plentiful at Klondike Banks. Alongshore, blackfish from 1 1/2 to 10 pounds are being caught on wrecks and rough bottom. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Good angling for small stripers in Sandy Hook surf using worms, clams and plugs. Small bluefish are in surf with bigger blues offshore. Porgies, flounder, spots and some seabass are in Shrewsbury River. Freeport, L.I.: Excellent bluefishing at Cholera Banks. Good flounder in Jones Inlet area. Atlantic Beach, L.I.: Blackfish are being taken by Atlantic Beach Bridge. Fine flounder in Reynold's Channel. Off Lido Beach, big blues are being taken trolling bunker spoons in 20 feet. Captree State Park, L.I.: Blues and weakfish are running in surf off Fire Island Field 2 and Ocean Beach. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Medium-sized flounder are showing in Shinnecock Bay. Montauge, L.I.: Abundant bluefish from 5 to 18 pounds in rips north of Montauk Point and at Cartwright Shoals. Porgies from 1 to 3 pounds are plentiful east of Shagwong Point. Blackfish and seabass are showing at Frisbies. 4 Orient Point, L.I.: Good numbers of

title: JUDGE GRANTS 10 DEMOCRATS LINE IN JUDGES' RACE
description: Ten candidates for New York State Supreme Court who had been barred from the Democratic line in the general election on Nov. 2 because of late filings by the party must get that line on the ballot, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF RIEGLE'S REPLY FOR DEMOCRATS TO PRESIDENT'S TALK ON ECONOMY
description: Following is a transcript of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr.'s remarks in Washington last night in response to President Reagan's address on the economy, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: RARE CALIFORNIA CONDOR SNARED IN YEARLONG EFFORT
description: A year-long effort by naturalists to catch specimens of the vanishing California condor for a captive-breeding program has finally paid off. Officials announced Tuesday that an adult bird was caught in a net in the mountainous country near Ventura, 60 miles north of Los Angeles.

title: 19 Guatemala Soldiers Are Killed in Ambush
description: The army said today that 19 soldiers had been killed and eight wounded in a guerrilla ambush in the north.

title: NOBEL PEACE PRIZE IS AWARDED TO SWEDE AND MEXICAN
description: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to Alva Myrdal of Sweden and Alfonso Garcia Robles of Mexico for their efforts to promote disarmament.

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DAN RIVER CHALLENGES ICAHN WITH CHARGE OF RACKETEERING
description: In a nearly empty courtroom in this Piedmont textile town, a battery of lawyers squared off today for what may become a test case of a novel legal tool that some companies are using to deter hostile takeover bids.

title: J.D. SALINGER FILES IMPERSONATION LAWSUIT
description: J.D. Salinger, the reclusive novelist and short-story writer, has filed a lawsuit charging that someone is trying to impersonate him and sell written work as if he had written it.

title: Top Officer Adds Post At American Appraisal
description: Louis R. Karraker has resigned as president and chief operating officer of American Appraisal Associates Inc., a Milwaukee company that offers appraising services throughout the world.

title: TO COMBAT BLACK TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: Secret File Found on Munson Death
description: A secret file on the death of Thurman Munson, the Yankee catcher, was discovered in the Summit County Coroner's office during a search by detectives Sept. 17, The Akron Beacon Journal reported today.

title: Union Oil Plans
description: The Union Oil Company of California may begin to expand its commercial-size shale oil project in the Parachute Creek area of northwestern Colorado by 1984. Allen Randle, vice president for shale operations, told the American Mining Congress meeting in Las Vegas that the facility is scheduled to produce 10,000 barrels a day of high-quality fuel by 1983. He added that the company was reviewing a second phase of development that could add production of 80,000 barrels a day over 10 years.

title: MIXED RATINGS FOR NBC
description: THE bad news at NBC is that despite high hopes and a rare measure of critical acclaim for its new prime-time shows, the network ran a distant third for a second consecutive week to ABC and CBS in the national prime-time ratings.

title: 5 FACTIONS WITHIN P.L.O. OPPOSE ANY CONFEDERATION WITH JORDAN
description: A serious policy dispute erupted today in the Palestine Liberation Organization over the concept of a Palestinian state being joined in federation with Jordan.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN TRIAL OF GIBSON
description: The prosecution in the conspiracy and misconduct-in-office trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris rested its case today after acknowledging to the trial judge that some of the state's witnesses might have lied.

title: Owens to Settle Asbestos Suits
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, an asbestos maker, said it had agreed to pay an average of $17,000 a person to settle its part in about 140 health-related suits filed by shipyard workers.

title: DONOVAN HONORED BY 1,000 FRIENDS
description: About 1,000 friends of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan attended a dinner tonight to support the Cabinet member, who was the subject of a special prosecutor's investigation.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviet K.G.B. Chief in News
description: A photograph of Vitaly V. Fedorchuk, head of the K.G.B. security police since May, appeared in Soviet newspapers today for the first time since his appointment.

title: STUBBORN COMBATANTS IN DISARMAMENT'S CAUSE: ALVA REIMER MYRDAL
description: She has received several different peace awards for her work in disarmament, but when 80-year-old Alva Reimer Myrdal was told yesterday at her home in a Stockholm suburb that she had been chosen as a co-winner of the Nobel Peace Prize there was fresh excitement. ''I did not believe there was a thousandth of a chance,'' she said, ''that I would be awarded the prize.''

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Japan's Steel Production
description: Japan's crude steel production in September edged down six-tenths of 1 percent from August, to 7.88 million metric tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation reported today.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'THE MANGO TREE'
description: ''THE MANGO TREE,'' a 1977 Australian film that opens today at the D.W. Griffith Theater, is the kind of soft, pretty-looking film that reassures its audience by never for a minute doing anything unexpected. It might be a perfect movie to watch on television while playing checkers with someone who talks all the time.

title: U.N. Chief 'Deeply Gratified'
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that he was ''deeply gratified'' that the Nobel Peace Prize had been awarded to Alva Myrdal of Sweden and Alfonso Garcia Robles of Mexico. ''This well-deserved tribute to the vision and determination of Mrs. Myrdal and Mr. Garcia Robles is a particularly timely reminder of the urgent need for the international community to make real progress towards disarmament,'' he said.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IT is difficult for the designer of furniture working today to know how to treat the modernist tradition. Should he view it as a great epoch of the past, noble in its way but clearly over? Or should he think of it as a developing esthetic, its era of shocking newness ended but its potential still not fully realized?

title: Sintercast Managers Are Now Its Owners
description: The company until last month was the Sintercast division of Chromalloy. Now it is Alloy Technology International Inc. and its managers are among the owners.

title: Party Explains Riegle Choice
description: Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan was chosen to respond for the Democrats to President Reagan's speech last night because he is the senior Democrat on the Banking Committee and comes from a state with very high unemployment, a spokesman for the party leadership said yesterday.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canada Selling Grain to Soviet
description: Canada said today that it had sold the Soviet Union 7.6 million metric tons of wheat and predicted it would sell considerably more over the next 12 months.

title: News Analysis
description: In private, many Arab diplomats here acknowledge that they have painted themselves into a corner by demanding Israel's expulsion from the current session of the General Assembly. These envoys say they want a face-saving escape from the decision of the Arab League members here at a closed-door meeting last week, although only Mahmoud Aboul-Nasr of Oman will say this in public.

title: GDANSK WORKERS, UNDER ARMY RULE, END THEIR STRIKE
description: Polish shipyard workers who struck for two days in Gdansk over the outlawing of the independent trade union Solidarity returned to work today, their protest ended after martiallaw authorities drafted them into military service.

title: E.F. Hutton Has Big Gain
description: The E.F. Hutton Group Inc. yesterday reported a 174.5 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter, to $30.2 million, or $1.59 a share, from $11 million, or 62 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenues for the quarter rose 24.2 percent, to $428.4 million, from $345 million for the third quarter last year.

title: AFGHAN, AT U.N., ACCUSES U.S. OF AIDING FOES AND MEDDLING
description: The Foreign Minister of Afghanistan told the General Assembly here today that the United States was interfering in the affairs of his country. Exercising the right of reply, John D. Lodge, an American delegate, took ''strong exception'' to the remarks.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOSELEY HALLGARTEN & ESTABROOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary credits of $569,000 for the qr and $789,000 fora the 6 mos...C-Net loss...D-After a loss of $623,000 from discontinued operations

title: SCHLESINGER SEES ARMS SPENDING LAG
description: Former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger predicted today that the Federal deficit would exceed $200 billion in 1984 and that the ensuing political pressures would drive military spending below the amount planned by President Carter.

title: Walks Through 1800's and Art Deco; 1800's and Art Deco Topics of Walking Tours
description: Tomorrow, the Art Deco Society is sponsoring an architectural tour that includes the East and West Sides. It begins at 2:30 at the General Electric Building, Lexington Avenue and East 51st Street, and ends about two hours later at the Hearst Magazine Building, Eighth Avenue and 57th Street.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a net gain of $31 million or 94 cents a shr from the exchange of common stock for debentures...C-Including a nonrecurring net gain of $38 million of $1.13 a shr, mostly from the sale of Canadian oil and gas properties

title: Americana in four sales
description: AMERICANA, one of the areas of the art market that has been strongest in sales during the recession, is in the spotlight again. Art and furnishings are on view this weekend and four sales are scheduled next week in the galleries of Sotheby Parke Bernet at York Avenue at East 72d Street.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 3
MAHLER TO OPEN JUILLIARD SEASON
description: JORGE MESTER, conductor of the Juilliard Orchestra, was exhilarated. ''I wanted to start off with a work that was deeply involving; something that would immediately set up an emotional relationship that would then carry us through a wonderful year.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THE whole project began for me because I was a very old friend of Michael Pate's,'' said Geraldine Fitzgerald. Miss Fitzgerald was explaining how she came to travel to the edge of the Australian outback two years ago to make ''The Mango Tree'' and win the Australian equivalent of the Academy Award for best actress.

title: Yankees, Southern Style
description: With Yankee Stadium about to undergo renovation, there is a possibility that the Yankees might open their 1983 season in the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans. The Yankees have played exhibition games there in each of the last three years.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices, swept by heavy profit taking, fell precipitously. The Dow Jones industrial average, after soaring 108 points in the previous six sessions, dropped below 1,000, declining 18.21 points, to 996.87. But declining stocks on the Big Board outnumbered those advancing by only 973 to 747. The biggest losses were posted by the blue chips and technology issues that had led the market's surge. Volume fell to 107.5 million shares. (D1.)

title: Friday; EAST SIDE COMEDY
description: Chicago City Limits, a seven-member comedy team that uses suggestions called out by the audience to create songs and scenes, has a series Friday nights at 11 in which guest comics perform their own material and then improvise with the hosts. Tonight the guest will be Paul Reiser, who did a stand-up routine in the film ''Diner.'' The site is the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Admission is $10. Information: 772-8707. KONITZ AT RIVERBOAT

title: Angola Says Guerrillas Killed 300 in Village
description: The official Angolan press agency accused the anti-Government guerrilla group Unita today of killing 300 men, women and children and wounding another 140 in an attack on a village in central Angola last week. There was no comment from the guerrilla group on the accusation.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRANCE SET TO BUY 2 I.T.T. UNITS
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its French telecommunications operations to the French Government for 215 million francs, or about $30.2 million.

title: Vietnam Turns Over Remains of 5 Americans
description: Vietnam today turned over to United States officials in Hanoi the remains of five people believed to be missing Americans and material evidence on three other Americans listed as missing in action in the Vietnam War, the Pentagon said.

title: HARD TIMES FOR CATERPILLAR
description: It was never supposed to happen in this prosperous company town. The Caterpillar Tractor Company - known for good management and efficient plants - had been one of the success stories among American heavy manufacturers.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes after-tax investment gains of $362,000 or 13 cents per shr

title: OWNER REFUSES TO LEAVE RANCH ON MISSILE RANGE
description: An 81-year-old rancher armed with two rifles and an old pistol has set up camp at his former homestead, which sits in the middle of this top-secret missile range.

title: WRONG LABEL
description: To the Editor:

title: New Quake in Idaho
description: A strong earthquake jarred an area of southeast Idaho Wednesday night.

title: WADKINS RALLIES FOR VICTORY
description: Lanny Wadkins came back from 4 down after 17 holes to beat Gary Player of South Africa, 2 and 1, today in the $250,000 world match-play championship.

title: PARADOX AT MIDTERM
description: This conservative state gave Ronald Reagan one of his biggest majorities in 1980, and probably would do it again if he were on the ballot this year. Yet there's at least a reasonable possibility that both of Idaho's Congressional seats, now held by Republicans, could go Democratic next month.

title: Hand-Wringing and the Homeless
description: Cooler weather and predictions of a cold winter force attention again to the problem of New York City's homeless. It's time for state and city officials to confront the issue. Lewis Lehrman has already issued a comprehensive statement on the subject, criticizing the state for mishandling the problem. Mario Cuomo, too, should be aroused to address it before the election; Mayor Koch now should have the time to give it his close attention.

title: Bridge: 2 U. S. Teams Contending In a Rosenblum Semifinal
description: Two American squads battled here Thursday night in the semifinal stage of the World Team Championship, and after 20 deals, concluding in the small hours, the Martel team led the Zimmerman team by 44 points, 58-14. In the other match, a dark-horse Spanish team led its French opponents by 46 points, 73-27.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a net reduction of $9 million from a provision on the closedown and disposal of assets

title: Common Ground
description: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial that is nearing completion on the Mall in Washington was inspired not by any desire to glorify America's role in the war but by guilt over the postwar neglect of the men and women who served. The idea was that in memorializing the names of 57,692 Americans who died in Vietnam, a divided nation could find common ground.

title: POLICE RELY ON CALM TALK TO BREAK SIEGE
description: Working out of a small storage closet in a basement hallway, Lieut. Robert Louden talked about baseball, television and the city's criminal-justice system yesterday with the man who was holding hostages in a hospital locker room.

title: CONVICT HOLDING TWO AS HOSTAGES INSIDE A HOSPITAL
description: A convicted robber facing sentencing today to a long prison term grabbed a guard's gun during a routine visit to Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday, shot the guard in an arm and took five hospital employees hostage in a basement locker room.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: QUICKPRINT OF AMERICA reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the acquisition of Quickprint Inc on Aug 6, 1981 represents a purchase of the outstndg shrs by the newly formed Quickprint of America Inc

title: SIGNAL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rubinstein Is Unable To Attend Israel Gala
description: Arthur Rubinstein will be unable to appear at a gala dinner Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria given in his honor by the American Committee for Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science. Mr. Rubinstein, who is 95 years old, is not strong enough to make the trip from his home in Geneva.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Did He Endorse Her?

title: INTERNATIONAL RESOURCES & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sep
TOLEDO TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $253,000 gain from sale of assets

title: A Bomb Scare At Bloomingdale's
description: A suspicious package and an anonymous telephone threat caused hundreds to flee Bloomingdale's department store last night, the police said.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball World Series: Brewers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Milwaukee, third game, 8:30 P.M. This is the first Series game in County Stadium since the Yankees beat the Milwaukee Braves in the seventh game in 1958. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:30 P.M.) Soccer Long Island University vs.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OVERTURNED TANKER TRUCK SNARLS TRAFFIC
description: A tanker truck carrying 3,000 gallons of a toxic solvent turned over on the upper level of the George Washington Bridge early yesterday, sprawled across three of the four eastbound lanes into New York City, and backed up traffic in New Jersey for three miles with delays of more than two hours over the morning rush hour. The solvent did not spill and there were no injuries.

title: New Options Approved
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved trading in options on financial instruments issued by the Treasury. With the approval, trading in the options is scheduled to start Oct. 22 on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, the S.E.C. said.

title: APPEALS COURT OVERTURNS DECISION TO PUT 10 ON BALLOT FOR JUDGESHIPS
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that 10 candidates for State Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan may not appear on the Democratic line of the ballot for the Nov. 2 general election.

title: Market Place; Cautious View On Fonar
description: THE promise of nuclear magnetic resonance is high, and so are stocks of some companies linked to this new diagnostic technique. But shares of the tiny company representing the only pure play in this high-technology business have advanced to levels that one analyst feels are ''absurd.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Honeywell's New Computer
description: Honeywell Inc. introduced a large-scale computer system that it said is up to eight times more powerful than its current top-of-theline mainframe system, the DPS 8/70.

title: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Day at the Club
description: A hectic summer schedule of games and clinics did not afford one well-known National Basketball Association player much opportunity to indulge in one of his pastimes - golf. After what happened to him on one occasion when he did have a chance to play, he wondered whether he should ever go through the trouble again.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S SPEECH ON DRIVE AGAINST CRIME
description: Following is the prepared text of President Reagan's speech today at the Department of Justice: I am delighted to be here but I want to say at the outset that I did not come today just to give a pep talk or exchange niceties. Those of you engaged in law enforcement have struggled long and hard in what must have often seemed like a losing war against the menace of crime. I am grateful to you for that and so are the American people. But besides being grateful, I have some good news for you: a major initiative that I believe can mark a turning point in the battle against crime.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Out and In

title: G.O.P. FEARS IMPACT IN TIGHT RACES
description: Marilyn Stratmeyer is part of a profound change in American politics. For the first 10 years of her marriage, she stayed home in Lennox, S.D., reared her three children, and took her husband's advice about politics. Now she is working as a waitress at the Longhorn Cafe and making her own voting decisions.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROGRESS REPORTED AT FOOTBALL TALKS
description: For the first time in eight months, negotiators for the National Football League players and owners were reported today to have made some progress at the bargaining table.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1982
description: International The United States and Israel agreed on the need for early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon, and expressed the hope that it could take place by the end of the year. At a fourhour meeting at the State Department, the two countries set up a working group to begin examining proposals for bringing about the withdrawal and for providing security for Israel's northern borders. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ten days of sweeps in West Beirut by Lebanese Army forces resulted in 1,441 arrests, the seizure of tons of arms and ammunition, and the confiscation of 23,000 forged identity papers, the Government announced. (A9:1.)

title: REAGAN A FACTOR IN GREEN'S HOUSE BID
description: Manhattan's only Republican Representative, Bill Green, said last February that if President Reagan's economic program was doing well by election time, he and other Republicans would be clamoring to share credit for it. If it was not working, he added, ''we'll distance ourselves from him.''

title: Pabst Dissidents
description: A shareholders group that is trying to take charge of the Pabst Brewing Company said today that it would appeal a judge's decision to uphold the election of Pabst's directors.

title: Alcohol Is Cited In Crash Fatal to 9
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today concluded that alcohol played a part in a car-train crash that killed nine teen-agers in Nassau County in March. The board also said the teen-age driver's decision to drive around a grade crossing to try to beat the speeding train had caused the fatal crash.

title: INDUSTRIAL NONPOLICY
description: With the 1984 Presidential election approaching and Great Society liberalism dying or dead, Democrats are begging for alternatives to supply-side economics. Rushingto the rescue are the so-called Atari Democrats.

title: ALL CITY AGENCIES GET ORDERS TO CUT '84 BUDGETS BY 6%
description: Every municipal agency in New York City has been ordered to cut its budget by 6 percent for the fiscal year starting next July, the city's Budget Director, Alair A. Townsend, said yesterday.

title: The Early Bowl
description: When the idea of a preseason college football bowl game was suggested last year by the National Football Foundation and the Hall of Fame to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, it was assumed that coaches would be opposed. It would necessitate starting summer practice even earlier for two teams.

title: Two Banks Cut Mortgage Rate
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Marine Midland Bank said yesterday that they were reducing certain credit rates in the real estate field.

title: FRENCH-U.S. CONCERN GRANTED M.T.A. PACT FOR 225 SUBWAY CARS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will announce today that it plans to purchase 225 air-conditioned, graffiti-resistant subway cars from a new company owned by French and American interests, officials in Paris and New York said yesterday.

title: M-G-M/U.A. SHIFTS KEY EXECUTIVES
description: With new personnel changes, the M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company has taken another step in the realignment of its volatile M-G-M and United Artists motion-picture divisions.

title: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A JUDGE FAITHFUL TO RULES
description: The advocates who appear before Judge Paul R. Huot know that success in his court turns strictly on their mastery of the evidence. And to act otherwise is not only to invite failure but also to risk public rebuke.

title: JOHN ELIOT'S GIFT TO THE ALGONQUINS
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Stock Market As Forecaster
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has hailed the surge of the stock market as evidence of public confidence that his policies are working and that the economy is about to swing into a healthy recovery. But is the stock market a reliable forecaster?

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LITTLE, ARTHUR D, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Options Official Elected
description: Henry G. Nothnagel, a 39-year-old option-market trader, has been elected to lead the new index and option division at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, effective Oct. 25. He will be responsible for marketing financial products.

title: Israel Lifting a Year-Old Ban On Tourist Traffic to Jordan
description: Israel has lifted a ban it imposed last year on two-way tourist traffic with Jordan in an effort to promote tourism between the two countries, Interior Ministry officials said today.

title: BLACK CLASSICAL WORKS FEATURED IN A TRIBUTE
description: A generation of black composers will be honored Sunday, when the Triad Chorale and a group of guest soloists present an R. Nathaniel Dett centennial program. The afternoon of music, beginning at 3 P.M. at the Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, will feature in addition to the music of Dett, works by Samuel Coleridge-Taylor, Florence Price, H.T. Burleigh, Hall Johnson, Carl Diton, Eva A. Jessye, W.C. Handy and Eubie Blake.

title: UNUSUAL FILMS ABOUND
description: The New York Film Festival has come and gone, but the almost yearround film festival that is New York is still offering unusual fare for the adventurous this weekend. Film buffs can see, for instance, a love story from South Korea, a rarely shown all-black Western, a tale of old age by the Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu and an avant-garde video film showing heat waves rising off the Sahara.

title: No Headline
description: Truck Filled With Dynamite Explodes Near Toronto Plant

title: HUTTON, E F, GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Memorial Is Held For Ingrid Bergman
description: A solo violin played ''As Times Goes By'' in one of London's great churches Thursday as her family and friends from the stage and film world paid tribute to Ingrid Bergman, who died Aug. 29 after an eight-year fight with cancer.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's Middle East plan calling for an association of a Palestinian homeland on the West Bank and Gaza Strip with Jordan was at center stage in the nearly 12 hours of discussions here this week between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Brewers Get Flash of the 'Real' Cards
description: Now that the Milwaukee Brewers have seen the two dangerous elements of the St. Louis Cardinals, they know what they have to do if they want to win the World Series. They have to play three more games like the first one so they can avoid seeing a little of Bruce Sutter and a lot of stolen bases.

title: A Price Placed on Glory
description: Al Worthington, a former pitcher for the New York Giants and Minnesota Twins, wants to sell his 1954 World Series ring for $10,000.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS PROFIT FALLS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, which lost $61 million in the second quarter, yesterday stunned bank analysts by reporting that its problem loans had surged to $2 billion in the third quarter and that its earnings had plunged 52 percent from the third quarter of 1981.

title: FRANCIS M. CROWLEY, EDUCATOR
description: Francis M. Crowley, dean emeritus of Fordham University's School of Education, died Wednesday at a convalescent home in Hempstead, L.I. He was 89 years old and had been a longtime resident of Port Washington, L.I.

title: ISLANDERS ROMP IN HOME OPENER
description: The Islanders made a scoring spree of their home opener tonight at Nassau Coliseum, routing the Pittsburgh Penguins, 9-0, in a penalty-filled game.

title: From Broadway to Peking, it's Miller Time
description: act plays are in rehearsal at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. A revival of ''After the Fall'' opens this weekend at the Jewish Repertory Theater. And in February, after ''A View From the Bridge'' has arrived in New York, he will journey to Peking to direct ''Death of a Salesman'' in Chinese - with a Chinese director, Yin Ro Chang, who is fluent in English, by his side.

title: MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: More on McAdoo
description: Bob McAdoo, who was so good as a spot player that he helped the Los Angeles Lakers to the National Basketball Association title last spring, has come to agreement with the Lakers, according to the team's owner, Jerry Buss.

title: MET OPERA: 'IDOMENEO'
description: IT took the Metropolitan Opera nearly a century to get around to staging Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' possibly the greatest work of its Baroque type ever written, but they got it right the first time. For sheer depth of vocal talent, grasp of the grand style and impressive decor, last night's first performance of Jean-Pierre Ponnelle'sproduction stood up to the best things the Met has given us in recent years.

title: IT WAS A TYPICAL NIGHT FOR THE TYLENOL TASK FORCE
description: Donald F. Eddy and his partner, Robert P. Rebholz, of the Chicago Police Department's Tylenol Task Force have spent most of Wednesday afternoon on the phone with a Canadian psychic who goes into a long-distance trance whenever they ask a question.

title: COWENS'S STRANGE RETURN
description: During the 10 seasons that he played center for the Boston Celtics, seven as an all-star, Dave Cowens never needed any incentive against the Milwaukee Bucks. When Tom Heinsohn coached the Celtics, he used to say of Cowens and the Bucks, ''Dave ignites himself when he sees them.''

title: FEELING AT THE TOP THAT THE SPEECH WAS A WINNER
description: The Democrats were saying today that the only thing new about President Reagan's address to the nation Wednesday night was the use of electronic graphics. But at the White House some officials were viewing the President's performance as a possible turning point in the political debate over the economy.

title: BALLET: 'STRAW HEARTS' AND 2 OTHERS BY FELD
description: THERE are times when everything does go right in a dance company's life and the Feld Ballet's program Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater was perfect.

title: WILD JAILS AND A MISUNDERSTOOD OFFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What a shame you were not there. You missed a funny performance.''

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Antitrust Policy 'Open' Shipping Means Higher Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Spacious Gallic, steakhouse basic.
description: ALTHOUGH all sorts of gastronomic exotica can be found in New York restaurants, one luxury that remains elusive is space. A notable and sublimely comfortable exception is Le Perigord Park, at Park Avenue and East 63d Street, a formal French restaurant that took a turn for the better last year, when a new chef was hired. Last July there was further improvement when the traditional salon decor of the spacious dining room was refurbished with fresh green, gold and white paint, and lighting that is both comfortable and atmospheric.

title: Suspect in Tylenol Case Once Held in '78 Death
description: A man accused of trying to extort $1 million from the company that makes Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules was charged, but not tried, with the death of a Kansas City man in 1978, the authorities said today.

title: University President Named
description: Bryce Jordan, executive vice chancellor of academic affairs at the University of Texas, was elected president of Pennsylvania State University today, succeeding John Oswald, who is retiring. Mr. Jordan has been president of the University of Texas at Dallas.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M.

title: Greek President in Canada
description: President Constantine Caramanlis of Greece arrived here today on a five-day visit that will include Ottawa, Toronto and Montreal and give him an opportunity to meet representatives of the Greek-Canadian population of 350,000.

title: Rewards of Work At Pitney Bowes
description: George B. Harvey says he is a man who thrives on work, and he has worked his way to the top at Pitney Bowes Inc. of Stamford, Conn. The company announced yesterday that Mr. Harvey, 51 years old, will become chairman and chief executive when Fred T. Allen, 66, retires from those posts on Dec. 31. Mr. Allen, who joined Pitney Bowes after he graduated from Brown University in 1938, will continue as chairman of the board's executive committee.

title: SEARLE, G D, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $35 million and a charge for the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1.9 million

description: B-Including net gains of $777,000 for the latest 36 weeks and $2,180,000 for the yr-ago period from the sale of real estate

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
426-YEAR-OLD LIFE
description: To the Editor:

description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $1.2 million...C-After an extraordinary credit of $3.4 million and a loss from securities transactions of $1,023,000

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for book sales returns

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co., St. Paul, has named Charles G. Truzinski chief financial officer.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago per shr figures reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan 1982

title: Harvester Expects Continued Losses
description: The International Harvester Company expects to continue losing money for another year and says it could be forced into bankruptcy proceedings unless the market for its trucks and farm machinery improves.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN BANK (NYC) reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest 9 mos reflect a special loss of $117 million relatedto the liquidation of the U.S. Government securities positions assumed by ChaseManhattan Bank from Drysdale Government Securities and performance by Chase of obligations related to those positions

title: CANRAD-HANOVIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $73,600 for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: HOW PAINTERS SAW ENGLAND 200 YEARS AGO
description: IT has been a long time - 50 years or so, according to senior observers - since English 18th-century painting has been shown in bulk and on a scholarly basis in a dealer's gallery in New York. Hence ''British Life Through Painters' Eyes'' at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, can be called a genuine rarity. It is presented by the Leger Galleries from Old Bond Street in London, and it includes several paintings that by any standard are remarkably good. Quite apart from that, it looks stunning as an ensemble, with many a cunning surprise in the manner of its installation.

title: AUTHORITY ON WORKS OF STEPHEN CRANE
description: Robert Wooster Stallman, an authority on Stephen Crane, died Wednesday at his home in Storrs, Conn. He was 71 years old. Mr. Stallman taught American literature at the University of Connecticut for 36 years, until his retirement in 1975, and wrote and edited books and was widely published in literary journals.

title: 3 MOVIES, COMEDY ON CABLE SHOW
description: OF the three television movies this weekend, all featuring made-ontelevision stars, NBC's ''Honeyboy'' manages to drain the most out of a tired formula. ''Honeyboy,'' to be televisied Sunday at 9 P.M., offers still another version of the cocky kid from the city slums who is determined to become a champion fighter. From the Dead End Kids to any of the three ''Rocky'' movies, the story has proved numbingly durable.

title: Ex-Liberace Employee Sues for $113 Million
description: A 23-year-old man filed a $113 million suit against Liberace today, asserting the that the pianist had broken financial promises to him after the two had had an ''intimate sexual, emotional and business relationship'' for six years.

title: MARATHON RULES OUT MONEY
description: The New York City Marathon will not award official prize money to top finishers in the five-borough race on Oct. 24. The board of directors of the New York Road Runners Club had unanimously approved the prize money for this year's race. But Fred Lebow, the club president, said yesterday that concern over the future eligibility of runners for the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles overshadowed monetary considerations.

title: NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRUG MAKERS SUGGEST U.S. PACKAGING RULES
description: An organization representing the nation's major pharmaceutical manufacturers asked the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to enact regulations that would require sealed packaging of nonprescription drugs to avert tampering.

title: U.A.W. to Ask Chrysler For Immediate Raises
description: The United Automobile Workers prepared today to ask the Chrysler Corporation for an immediate pay increase for workers who overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract that tied pay increases to Chrysler profits.

title: Knicks Defeated By Nets
description: In their first meeting this season, the Nets of Larry Brown defeated the Knicks of Hubie Brown, 93-83, in an exhibition game last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mortimer J. Gleeson, 76, Dies; Retired Executive at Morgan
description: Mortimer J. Gleeson, a retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and a former commissioner of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: ART: REUBEN NAKIAN, 85, HIS NYMPHS AND SATYRS
description: ''OH, to be 85 again!'' the formidably productive Picasso is said to have remarked before his death at 92. And to look at the new show of works by the distinguished sculptor Reuben Nakian (at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, through Nov. 3) is to understand precisely what he meant. Mr. Nakian passed his 85th birthday in August, but his amazing energies don't show the slightest sign of abatement. From his studio in Stamford, Conn., he still turns out work in extravagant abundance, ranging from monumental sculptures to small, tabletop pieces - along with drawings, prints, pottery and book illustrations, all dealing with the erotic and mythological motifs that have preoccupied him since the early 1950's.

title: 1,441 ROUNDED UP, LEBANON REPORTS
description: Lebanese officials said today that the army's sweeps of West Beirut in the last 10 days had resulted in 1,441 arrests, the confiscation of tons of arms and ammunition, and the seizure of 23,000 forged identity papers and passports.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
SAN FRANCISCO TO APPEAL RULING ON GUN ORDINANCE
description: A spokesman for Mayor Dianne Feinstein, who had taken ofice after Mayor George Moscone was murdered with a pistol, said that a court decision invalidating a San Francisco pistol ordinance would be appealed to the State Supreme Court.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Plett Is Suspended
description: Willi Plett, a right wing for the Minnesota North Stars who incurred a match penalty one week ago for hitting Greg Stefan, a goalie for the Detroit Red Wings, with his stick, has been suspended without pay for eight games by the National Hockey League. The announcement was made from the league office in Montreal following a meeting on Wednesday in which Brian O'Neill, an N.H.L. vice president, spoke in Toronto with Plett and Lou Nanne, the North Stars' general manager.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kaiser Sells Stake In Mining Concern
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 45 percent interest in Comalco Ltd., an Australian mining concern, for $343 million in cash.

title: Verdi Leaves Clippers
description: The Yankees announced that Frank Verdi, who managed the Columbus Clippers to a first-place finish in the International League championship the last two seasons, will not return to the team in 1983. The Clippers won the playoffs in 1981, but they were eliminated this season.

title: RATES CLIMB IN QUIET TRADING
description: Short- and long-term interest rates climbed sharply yesterday in light but persistent selling. A major reason was said to be profit taking after the recent steep advance in the prices of Government securities. But some dealers also cited sharp declines in financial futures prices yesterday, which further depressed the credit markets late in the day.

title: Warning by Devine
description: College educators were told that if they fail to do something to clean up the growing scandals in intercollegiate athletics, they face the loss of their varsity basketball or football teams. Speaking at a convention of the American Council on Education in Minneapolis, Dan Devine, the former football coach at Arizona State, Missouri and Notre Dame, said, ''If we don't clean it up, we will have more San Franciscos and you people will be looking at empty stadiums all over the country.'' The University of San Francisco dropped its oncepowerful basketball program when the board of directors decided it could no longer control overzealous alumni.

title: No Headline
EXCHANGE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Milwaukee Toast to a Favorite Son
description: Harvey Kuenn was still sleeping at 11 o'clock this morning and his wife, Audrey, was rubbing her eyes and padding around the kitchen in a nightgown and a flowered housecoat.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Thorpe Tribute Can't Erase Past
description: Burt Lancaster, the actor who portrayed Jim Thorpe in a 1951 movie about Thorpe's life, was not appeased Wednesday by the International Olympic Committee's decision to restore posthumously the two gold medals that Thorpe won in the 1912 Olympic Games. ''I felt a certain cynicism that he didn't get it before,'' Mr. Lancaster said.

title: TIMELY HIT EARNS CHEERS FOR PORTER
description: T he cheers from the St. Louis fans were tentative when the ball left Darrell Porter's bat. But as the ball arched toward left field and it became apparent that it would fall safely and drive in two runs to tie the second World Series game at 4-4, there was a roar of anticipation that developed into a crescendo of delight.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY PLANS A NEW YORK BOAT TOUR
description: SHORTLY after the chartered Circle Line boat turns its bow southward from West 43d Street late Sunday afternoon, one of the two guides may suddenly point to a passing skyscraper and exclaim, ''What's that thing on top of the Empire State Building?'' Not satisfied with that, he will probably add details, pointing out hairy arms and legs. The startled passengers may gasp, gaze and then laugh, having fallen for the old King Kong gag.

title: NBC REVIVES A NEWS SHOW
description: ''NBC Magazine,'' a prime-time weekly news report that was dropped from the schedule in July, will be revived by NBC News next February, and Lloyd Dobyns, the co-anchor of ''NBC News Overnight,'' is expected to be named as its anchorman, according to officials at the network.

title: THEATER: BETH HENLEY, 'WAKE OF JAMEY FOSTER'
description: BETH HENLEY, one of the most gifted American playwrights to emerge in recent seasons, has made a classic young writer's error in ''The Wake of Jamey Foster,'' her new play at the Eugene O'Neill. What she has done, perhaps not even consciously, is rewrite her first success, ''Crimes of the Heart.'' And, as always in cases like this, the imitation is no substitute for the original. Without the stimulus of fresh inspiration, Miss Henley has coarsened and caricatured the people, humor and feelings that she created with such free-spirited verve the first time around.

title: REAGAN SON ON JOBLESS LINE
description: His father and mother could have helped tide him over. But their son the ballet dancer wanted to get through his temporary unemployment without the family's assistance, so Ronald P. Reagan is now collecting government assistance.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fireman Hurt in School Blast
description: Fumes from a classroom chemical spill forced teachers and pupils from Emerson Vocational High School today, and soon afterward an explosion severely injured an eye of a fireman who was ventilating the room.

title: ARMY SHIFTS PROCEDURES AFTER MEDIC'S DEATH
description: A murder case here has prompted the Army's Criminal Investigation Division to promise more sensitivity when dealing with the relatives of slain soldiers.

title: MIDLAND BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

title: 2D CYCLE OF 400 YEARS BEGINS FOR THE GREGORIAN CALENDAR
description: Now if, by chance, the ancestors of your ancesters happened to have left behind any old calendars, specifically that for the year 1583, hang onto it a bit longer. You can use it next year.

title: Trane Write-off
description: The Trane Company said it had laid off 100 salaried employees, taken a $10.1 million pretax write-off to discontinue its truck-trailer air conditioning business and merged its consumer products business into a unit it recently acquired from the General Electric Company. Trane said the shutdown charge reduced third-quarter earnings to $3.67 million, or 35 cents a share, from $10.5 million, or $1.03, a year earlier. Sales fell to $200 million, from $209.8 million.

title: VIRGINIA F. ZANUCK, SILENT MOVIE STAR
description: Virginia Fox Zanuck, widow of the movie tycoon Darryl F. Zanuck, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 83 years old.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: BOSTON (NBA) - Waived Tony Guy, guard and second-round draft choice from Kansas; Perry Moss, guard and third-round choice from Northeastern, and Panogoti Giannakis, ninth-round choice from Hellenic. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Released Pete Davis, free agent guard.

title: THE CITY
description: Three passers-by were injured yesterday afternoon when a gust of wind knocked down a 20-foot-tall mobile scaffold outside the World Trade Center.

title: NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: Republicans appear to be receiving more blame than credit from the electorate for the performance of the economy. They seem to be losing more support because of rising unemployment than they are gaining from lessened inflation, lower interest rates and a cut in income taxes.

FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RUMANIAN ACCORD ON EMIGRATION SET
description: The United States and Rumania have negotiated an agreement on easing problems for potential emigrants from Rumania, a State Department official said today.

title: WORLD TOUR OF DANCE AT HOME
description: WITHOUT leaving New York this weekend, dancegoers can visit Walden Pond, South America and an enchanted island on nobody's map. Or they can travel to pre-Christian Russia, to Bertolt Brecht's Berlin and to Atlantic City at the turn of the century. The method of transport is, of course, choreography.

title: WOMAN EXPLAINS URGE TO WRITE TO PRESIDENT
description: Judith McMurtrey, part of whose five-page letter expressing frustration about the economy was read aloud by President Reagan in his televised speech Wednesday night, said today that she and her family had not personally experienced ''starvation and problems of basic survival.''

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT TRIES TO PLAY BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
Reagan Plans to Assure Farmers on Grain Sales
description: President Reagan is expected to assure farmers Friday that they will not be deprived of grain sales to the Soviet Union because of tensions in Poland, Administration sources said today.

title: GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE SINGLE ROADBLOCK TO GUYANA'S RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicist Changes Mind At Nevada Fallout Trial
description: A Government attorney today forced a prominent physicist to alter his testimony that by the late 1940's scientists had all but abandoned the idea of a ''safe'' level of radioactive exposure.

9 More Amerasians Leave for the U.S.
description: Nine Vietnamese-American children ended a week in a refugee camp and boarded a jet for the United States today.

title: Interim Fire Head Appointed
description: Joseph E. Spinnato, a deputy fire commissioner, was appointed Interim Commissioner for the Fire Department by Mayor Koch yesterday to replace Commissioner Charles J. Hynes, who will leave his position on Oct. 22. Mr. Koch will later make a final decision on Mr. Hynes's replacement, said Dick Riley, a spokesman for the Mayor.

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRANCE TO PRODUCE NEUTRON BOMB WITH U.S. HELP, ALLIED AIDE SAYS
description: France has informally told some allied officials that it has decided to go ahead with production of a neutron weapon, one of the allied officials said.

title: Princeton Upheld In Plagiarism Case
description: A state appeals court ruled today that Princeton University acted properly when it withheld an honor student's diploma for a year because she had copied parts of a term paper without crediting the source.

title: LOCAL VOTE IN GREECE A TEST FOR SOCIALISTS
description: When Greeks vote next Sunday, they will be looking for solutions to urgent problems of pollution, garbage, traffic congestion, poor social services - for an improvement in the quality of life.

title: Tickets to Shows on Broadway
description: Following is the ticket availability, at press time, for Broadway shows Friday, Saturday and Sunday: A Chorus Line: All sections for all performances. Agnes of God: All sections for all performances.

title: Barclays Cuts Staff
description: Barclays Bank said yesterday that it had dismissed more than 100 employees at its New York operations after overly rapid expansion in this country.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Control Data Net Down 12%
description: The Control Data Corporation today reported net earnings of $38.8 million, or $1.03 a share, for the third quarter of 1982, a 12 percent decline from the similar 1981 period.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change in accounting

title: BEAU BRIDGES IN 'LOVE CHILD'
description: ''LOVE CHILD,'' which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, is the latest bit of evidence that a film's being based on a true story need not guarantee it an authentic air. In this case, the truth must almost certainly have been stranger than the determinedly simple movie it has engendered.

title: Hudson Prosecutor Pleads Not Guilty
description: Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr., the Hudson County Prosecutor, pleaded not guilty today at his arraignment on Federal bribery and extortion charges.

title: AT A CONVENTION, SONGS AND FOND ECHOES OF A WAR
description: A convention commenced here today with delegates who include some who see a compromise as a deal in which the other party gives up breathing.

title: DIRECTOR OF 'GOOD' TELLS STORY BEHIND THE DRAMA
description: It is almost 50 years since Adolf Hitler assumed power in Germany -nothing really to celebrate, but certainly something to reflect upon. The late C.P. Taylor's play ''Good,'' which opened Wednesday night at the Booth Theater, does just that as a drama that tells how a moral, liberal man, a teacher, gradually becomes a Nazi and an exterminator of Jews.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary charge of $22.5 million from settlement of its corrugatedcontainers antitrust case which had been pending since 1979...C-Net income

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brooklyn Heights Race
description: A two-mile race through Brooklyn Heights tomorrow at 9 A.M. will kick off the fourth Cranberry Street Festival on the street, from Hicks Street to Columbia Heights.

title: DANCE: OPEN PRESENTATION
description: NINE young performers gathered at the St. Mark's Danspace Sunday for the first of three consecutive Sunday night performances of something they call Open Presentation. Described in program notes as simply a ''weekly group activity, an opportunity for artists from different disciplines to share their work with each other,'' Open Presentation was begun in 1979 at Public School 122 but has not appeared publicly before.

title: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Yr to July 31
HEILEMAN, G, BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales figures are before excise taxes

title: American Philharmonic Cancels 2 Concerts
description: The financially troubled American Philharmonic Orchestra has canceled its concerts Monday and Oct. 31 at Avery Fisher Hall and is trying raise money to salvage the rest of its season and survive.

title: Big Money Supply Rise Expected
description: The Federal Reserve is expected to report today that the nation's basic money supply in the week ended Oct. 6 rose by an extraordinary $7 billion to $12 billion.

title: 100 YEARS OF YIDDISH THEATER CELEBRATED
description: It started with Boris Thomashefsky. A former choirboy from the Black Sea port of Odessa, the star-to-be of the Yiddish theater organized a small troupe of immigrant actors in 1882 to give the first New York performance of Avram Goldfaden's ''The Witch,'' a Yiddish operetta.

title: IF THE SOCIALISTS WIN THE SPANISH ELECTION
description: The expected victory of the Spanish Socialists in the general election Oct. 28 will make southern Europe almost entirely Socialist. The United States must put aside its fear that this will create a monolithic voting bloc - in the United Nations, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, or anywhere else - and make an effort to understand the new political currents in the Mediterranean.

title: PUBLISHING: KEEPING UP WITH THE SUCCESS OF 'CATS'
description: IN the 1930's, T.S. Eliot composed for his godchildren a series of poems about cats with such unlikely names as Growltiger, Skimbleshanks and Bustopher Jones. Published in 1939, ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats'' has been in print in the United States ever since, first in hard-cover and then also in trade paperback. In recent years, it has sold 2,000 to 3,000 copies annually.

title: Women's Bank May Get a New Bid
description: Ralph Vallone Jr., a lawyer in Puerto Rico, might bid for the First Women's Bank of New York in competition with a Brazilian company that announced a $15-a-share tender offer on Wednesday.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest periods reflect the merger on May 3, 1982 of the Shawmut Corp and Worcester Bancorp Inc on a pooling of interests basis; As a resultof the merger the results for 1982 and 1981 have been restated

title: A P.L.O. OFFICIAL SAYS ARAFAT IS FIRMLY IN CONTROL
description: A high-ranking Palestine Liberation Organization official said today that Yasir Arafat's leadership did not appear to be threatened by the serious policy dispute that erupted in the organization this week.

title: CBS Inc. Closes Plant in Indiana
description: CBS Inc. said its Records division would close its manufacturing plant here and consolidate operations at two other plants, idling 1,250 workers.

title: Mead Posts Loss; Boise Down
description: The Mead Corporation reported yesterday that a depressed forestproducts industry and the cost of an out-of-court antitrust settlement contributed to a loss of $42.7 million in the third quarter.

description: The Dow Jones industrial average, which had soared 108 points in the previous six sessions, fell below the 1,000 mark yesterday as some big institutions sold stocks to cash in their profits from the market rally.

title: Ford Skips Payout
description: The Ford Motor Company said directors had voted to omit the fourth-quarter dividend on outstanding stock. The action marks the fourth consecutive quarter in which Ford has omitted the dividend and is the first time it has not paid a dividend for a full year since going public in 1956.

title: Tribute for Lotte Lenya
description: Friends of the actress Lotte Lenya, who died last November, will mark the anniversary of her birthdate with a musical tribute Monday at 5 P.M. at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. Among those taking part in the public tribute will be Alexander Cohen, Jerry Orbach, Jack Gilbert, Tammy Grimes, Martha Schlamme, Alvin Epstein, Schuyler Chapin, Joel Chapin, Lucille Lortel and Jean Dalrymple.

title: MOYNIHAN AND MRS. SULLIVAN FAVOR CLOSING INDIAN PT. REACTORS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and his major opponent for the United States Senate from New York, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan of Brooklyn, agreed in a debate today that the Indian Point nuclear power plant should be closed permanently.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Not Amused H ow pornographic, insulting or otherwise offensive can video-game graphics be? Enough to warrant a protest, according to New York's chapter of the National Organization for Women, the American Indian Community House, Women Against Pornography and descendants of Gen. George Armstrong Custer.

title: BRAZIL MAKES HUGE LAKE, MINDFUL OF MAN AND BEAST
description: The foundations of the houses that lined the main street still poke through the thicket, and stone entrance steps rise above the rubble that was the bank. A deep hole at the first intersection as you drive into town held the fuel drums of one of Itacora's two filling stations.

title: QUIET IS RESTORED TO POLAND'S CITIES
description: Polish industrial centers where street fighting erupted in the last three days were reported to be mostly quiet today. But a demonstrator died in southern Poland a day after being shot during a protest against the outlawing of the independent union Solidarity.

THE EVENING HOURS
description: WASHINGTON IT was distinctly Sir Winston Churchill's night. Even the bronze statue of that legendary statesman at the entrance of the British Embassy, his arm raised in a jaunty V for victory, seemed to welcome guests as they rolled up in limousines Wednesday evening following the Ford's Theater premiere of ''Churchill,'' a one-man show starring the celebrated actor Roy Dotrice.

title: Mitsui U.S.A. President
description: Mitsui & Company has named Mamoru Tabuchi president and chief executive of its United States subsidiary. Mr. Tabuchi, 59, succeeds Koichiro Ejiri, who is returning to Tokyo to be chief executive of corporate planning for the parent company.

title: HUB KITTLE AND HIS PROTEGE
description: MILWAUKEE N obody at this World Series is having a better time than Hub Kittle, the 66-year-old pitching coach of the St. Louis Cardinals. You can hear his booming laugh across the clatter of a cocktail party or the babble of reporters. ''Isn't this great?'' he asks. ''I don't want this to end - at least until we win it.''

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Photo of Carlo Bini; A NIGHT AT THE OPERA: TRIUMPH AND DISASTER
description: It was both a wild and a wonderful night for opera. On one side of Lincoln Center Wednesday, the New York City Opera was enjoying a 14-carat triumph with its new production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide.'' Just across the plaza, the Metropolitan Opera was laboring through an evening likely to become legendary -for all the wrong reasons.

title: A MEDICARE MEANS TEST IS NOT 'WORTH EXPLORING'
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDE HINTS REAGAN WILL RUN
description: President Reagan does not like to walk away from an unfinished job and will probably seek re-election in 1984 if the people ''want him to carry on,'' a White House spokesman said today.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOWARD SACKLER, 52, PLAYWRIGHT WHO WON PULITZER PRIZE, DEAD
description: Howard Sackler, who won the 1969 Pulitzer Prize for drama for ''The Great White Hope'' was found dead yesterday morning in his studio in Ibiza, Spain, where he lived most of the year. He was 52 years old.

title: Minting of Coins To Aid Olympics
description: For the first time in 50 years, the Government will mint and sell gold coins, with delivery expected early next year, as a fund-raising project supporting the United States participation in the 1984 Olympics at Los Angeles, officials said today.

title: Advertising; Timely Aid From New Products
description: FACING the prospect of further client budget-cutting in the usually lucrative fourth quarter, ad agencies can take heart from the fact that corporations are keeping up the pressure in the new product area. That gives the future a rosy tinge since the one thing that new products need most is advertising.

Harris, today urged the judge in their trial to dismiss the conspiracy and misconduct-in-office charges against the two men because the state had not proved that they were guilty of creating a ''no show'' job for a former official.

title: French Credit Group
description: Some British and West German banks have withdrawn from France's planned $4 billion standby credit, banking sources said today. They said the withdrawal would not be sufficient to put the credit in doubt, but the sources were unable to specify which banks or how many were involved.

title: Article 222436 -- No Title
description: The International Monetary Fund is about to approve a $1.1 billion loan to South Africa, according to I.M.F. and Reagan Administration officials, despite strong objections by groups critical of South Africa's racial policies.

A CHINA-SOVIET THAW
description: After a generation of harsh political conflict and some armed skirmishes, the Soviet Union and China now seem seriously intent on achieving ''normal'' relations.

description: The American Medical Association told doctors today to be alert for adverse effects in patients exposed to TCDD, or dioxin, which is in the herbicide Agent Orange.

U.N. PANEL ATTACKS PRESS COVERAGE
description: A group of senior officials here has criticized Western reporting of the United Nations as ''grossly inaccurate'' and praised Soviet journalism for systematic coverage that generates ''continuing support.''

title: ISRAEL AND THE U.S. IN ACCORD ON NEED FOR EARLY PULLOUT
description: The United States and Israel agreed today on the need for an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon. They set up a working group to begin examining proposals for bringing about the withdrawal and providing security for Israel's northern borders.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would seek public comment over the next four months on a series of proposed rule changes that could result in a curtailment of shareholders' ability to make proposals from the floor at corporate annual meetings.

A CELEBRATION OF CHARLES JAMES
description: If New York's social season has any focus this fall, it may have a great deal to do with three black-tie events celebrating the work of the greatest couturiers of the 19th and 20th centuries. The first of these, entitled ''The Genius of Charles James, (1906-1978),'' opens to the public today at the Brooklyn Museum.
