People
description: * Walter E. Reichel elected executive vice president of Ted Bates/New York.

title: BREWER INFIELD THREAT TO CARDS
description: The St. Louis Cardinals stepped out of their airport bus today onto a strange field covered with Warren's A-34 Wisconsin cool-weather grass, and wondered if they had just lost a stride in the World Series.

title: UTAH SENATE RACE FINALLY HEATS UP
description: Three weeks before Election Day, Ted Wilson, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, has finally come out fighting.

title: SALVADOR DISPATCHES A 5,000-MAN FORCE TO COUNTER REBELS
description: The Government sent 5,000 troops backed by artillery, fighter-bombers and helicopter gunships into northern El Salvador today to counterattack what officials described as the strongest guerrilla drive in six months.

title: OUTBURST OF LATIN MUSIC
description: JAZZ and Latin music have been enriching each other for several decades now, and the common roots of the two forms in African music have been exhaustively analyzed. But jazz and Latin musicians rarely played together or learned from each other until the early 1940's. It took Mario Bauza, a Cuban trumpet player with a feeling for jazz, to convince young jazz musicians like Dizzy Gillespie that the rhythms and forms of Latin music had something to offer. And it was Mr. Bauza who shaped the original Latin-jazz fusion when he served as musical director for Machito's Afro-Cubans, the 1940's big band that was the forerunner of today's salsa orchestras.

title: WOOD TOOLS AT GARDEN
description: Woodworking enthusiasts and serious amateur furniture builders have a once-a-year opportunity this weekend. They will be able to see a wide selection of hand and power tools and many other items of interest at ''Excellence in Woodworking,'' a show in the Madison Square Garden Rotunda.

title: PPG DECLINES 16.4%
description: The Allied Corporation reported yesterday that 1982 third-quarter income was $81 million, or $1.95 a share, down 31.4 percent, from $118 million, or $3.15 a share, which included a nonrecurring gain from the sale of Canadian oil and gas properties.

title: It's Me Magazine Sold to Texas Company
description: It's Me, a magazine for large women founded in 1981 by the Lane Bryant Company, has been sold to the Happy Hands Publishing Company, Fort Worth, by Limited Stores, the company that acquired Lane Bryant. It was a cash transaction, according to Steven A. Bassion, publisher of the magazine and general manager of Happy Hands, whose other two magazines and newsletter do not carry advertising.

title: BUSHKIN BACK ON THE ROAD, AND HE PLANS TO REMAIN
description: JOE BUSHKIN, the jazz pianist who went into what ''The Encyclopedia of Jazz'' describes as ''voluntary retirement'' in the late 1950's, is not only back at work this weekend at the Cafe Carlyle but also, he says, he plans to stay on the road for the rest of his life.

title: 3 ARRESTS MADE IN TRAIN ACCIDENT
description: The police arrested three railroad employees today in connection with a train derailment that forced the evacuation of Livingston, La., for more than a week.

title: KARAMAZOV BROTHERS: JUGGLERS OF THE UNUSUAL
description: The Flying Karamazov Brothers do not fly, are not Russian and are not brothers. They are jugglers, but to leave it at that would be like saying that Dostoyevsky was a writer. The Flying Karamazov Brothers, who draw their inspiration from the Russian novel, draw their props from all around them - they juggle meat cleavers, umbrellas, bowling balls, books, cameras and cats. And this is all done to a backdrop of political jokes, brass instruments, Russian literature, meditation, physics and a heavy dose of vaudeville.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results for both periods were restated to reflect acquired banks

title: GRAINGER, W W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been reclassified to conform with the 1982 results

title: 4 OFFICERS INDICTED ON CHARGES INVOLVING DRUGS AND EXTORTION
description: Authorities investigating organized crime in Rockland County today announced indictments against seven men, including four police officers, on conspiracy, extortion, loansharking and narcotics charges.

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPACELINK LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition made as of May 31

title: CLOW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos include tax credits; results for the yr-agoand 9 mos have been restated to exclude sales of discontinued clay operations

title: Funds' Gain Reverses Trend
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds jumped $2.8 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $227.4 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: TAX CUTS WILL REQUIRE SPENDING CUTS, REGAN SAYS
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan says that the tax reduction proposals of his Republican running mate, Lewis E. Lehrman, cannot be carried out without substantial cuts in state spending and programs.

title: A Spanish Coup Leader Can Run for Parliament
description: A Madrid court ruled today that Lieut. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina, who stormed the Parliament building with 300 civil guardsmen in an attempted coup last year, was eligible to run for Parliament in the Oct. 28 elections.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reagan on New York S ince this is a city with a preternatural interest in whether people love it, a letter about to be put up for sale by the auctioneer Charles Hamilton seemed worth noting.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Jan 1982

title: 'RENTING UP' IN TODAY'S SOFTER MARKET
description: Before the Rockrose Development Corporation could start reconstructing the various industrial buildings of the Manhattan Refrigeration Company in the West Village as residential apartments, it had to let them thaw out.

title: Princess Stephanie Appears in Public Again
description: Princess Stephanie of Monaco made her first public appearance today since being injured in an automobile crash. She attended a memorial service here for her mother, Princess Grace, who died after the accident.

title: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
LAWYER-DRUMMER MAKES A CASE FOR HIS DAY GIG
description: PETE LA ROCA disappeared forever from the jazz world in 1968. Fans had known him since the late 1950's as a joyfully swinging drummer who had kicked up polyrhythms behind Sonny Rollins, John Coltrane, Freddie Hubbard and many others. He had even recorded two albums as a leader.

title: A PARK AVE. GET-TOGETHER BRINGS MOYNIHAN $25,000
description: With campaigns for public office becoming ever more expensive, some candidates are finding that smaller, more intimate fund-raising events can produce big dividends, especially if the site is a Park Avenue apartment, the entertainment is by a Broadway star and each guest is asked for ''$500 -minimum contribution.''

title: ARMY CHIEF REPORTS A 'RENAISSANCE'
description: For years, the nation's military leaders have been telling Congress that their budgets were inadequate, that divisions and ships and wings were not ready for combat, that neglected American forces would be unable to sustain themselves for long in battle.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Text of Reagan speech, page A20.
description: President Reagan, saying ''the time has come to cripple the power of the mob in America,'' today announced a plan to combat the distribution of narcotics by organized crime.

title: Bias Is Laid to TV Networks; Hispanic League Files Case Against Networks
description: A leading Hispanic organization filed a discrimination complaint today against the nation's top television networks, production studios and advertising agencies.

title: Seeing Triple
description: It seems that running long distances no longer is a challenge for some poeople. So for those who have mastered the marathon, there now is the triathlon, a combination of swimming, cycling and running.

title: CITY RESTUDYING ONE-OFFICER CARS FOR POLICE PATROL
description: Despite repeated failure to reach agreement with the police union, the Koch Administration has decided to try again to put one officer instead of two into patrol cars.

title: BRITISH COMPANIES IN BUY-OUT TREND
description: Until a few months ago, the 250 workers at the Midlands British Road Services depot here labored in the shadow of a bustling elevated expressway on behalf of the British Government, owner of their parent company, the National Freight Consortium. Now they have new masters - themselves.

title: Chinese Trade Surplus
description: Chinese exports to the United States hit a monthly record in August of $303.8 million, the United States Embassy said today.

title: DEVILS BOW, 5-3, FOR FIRST SETBACK
description: The Montreal Canadiens handed the Devils their first defeat, 5-3, tonight. The loss came in New Jersey's fifth game of the National Hockey League season.

title: ISRAELI ARMY PLANS TO COURT-MARTIAL 8 SOLDIERS
description: The army's Advocate General, Brig. Gen. Dov Shefi, announced today that eight Israeli soldiers would be courtmartialed for using violence against demonstrating Arabs in the occupied West Bank last spring.

title: Martin Denies Move
description: Billy Martin has denied reports that he was ready to leave the Oakland A's and manage the Cleveland Indians next season, saying that he would stay with the Oakland A's ''no matter what the offer is.'' Martin, in an interview with The Associated Press, said: ''I have no deals with anybody at this time.

title: A Surrogate Seller
description: As he left for a vacation in Europe, the owner of the San Diego Clippers turned over total control of the sale of his team to Alan Rothenberg, an attorney.

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN TO STEP UP CAMPAIGN ACTIVITY
description: President Reagan, stepping up his campaigning as Election Day nears, plans a series of appearances around the country in the next two weeks.

title: MUSIC: FOCUS ON DUFAY
description: Pomerium Musices, the vocal ensemble directed by Alexander Blachly, has achieved prominence and popularity in the early-music field through the simplest of means - the devising of compact programs that make stylistic points clearly and the performing of them with skill and good humor. ''Ye oldie'' costumes and props are not for this group.

title: Showing Sting
description: It would seem that Doug DeWitt, a promising middleweight boxer, is copying Thomas Hearns because he calls himself ''The Cobra.'' But he probably deserves the name more than Hearns, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, who was known as the ''The Motor City Cobra.''

title: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONCERT: ARTHUR BERGER
description: The Guild of Composers celebrated Arthur Berger's 70th birthday Thursday night at Christ and St. Stephens Church with young performers performing some of his music for piano solo, piano fourhands, chamber ensembles and voice.

title: Czech Leader to Visit Austria
description: President Gustav Husak will visit Austria next month, the first such visit by a Czechoslovak head of state, it was announced today. Mr. Husak was to have visited Austria last year, but the trip was put off after it was revealed that a Czechoslovak intelligence agent had lived in Vienna, with Austrian citizenship, posing as a political refugee.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS BIG GRAIN DEAL TO SOVIET UNION
description: President Reagan announced today that the United States had offered to sell 23 million tons of grain this year to the Soviet Union, a quantity nearly three times greater than the amount provided for under an existing sales agreement between the two countries.

title: NATIONAL CENTRAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRUE MESSAGE OF A 100-POINT S.A.T. LAG
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARMS REELING FROM RECESSION BLOWS
description: At the age of 42, J.B. Grothaus is as trim and lean as a college athlete, a condition he attributes to his Spartan struggle to survive for the last three years on 237 acres of prime farmland.

title: S.E.C. Ruling Leads to Suit
description: The Chicago Board of Trade announced today that it had filed a suit in the United States Court of Appeals against the Securities and Exchange Commission. The suit seeks to void the S.E.C.'s approval Thursday for the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the American Stock Exchange to begin trading in options on government securities, and for the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to offer options on foreign currencies.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Amid the Statistics, A Singular Case

title:
PATENTS;
A Double Plastic Cask For Nuclear Material
description: A shipping cask designed for the removal of spent nuclear materials from naval vessels has been invented for the Department of Energy.

title: CONNECTICUT NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Martel Team Enters Final Of Rosenblum Cup Contest
description: Members of an experienced American team headed by Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., were in a confident mood at the start of the final of the World Team Championship for the Rosenblum Cup here tonight.

title: Knicks Sign Orr to Offer Sheet
description: The Knicks, frustrated in their recent attempt to obtain Bernard King to strengthen their front line, yesterday signed Louis Orr, a 6-foot-9-inch forward, to a free-agent offer sheet.

title: A 'MENU' OF OPTIONS BY SOVIET ECONOMISTS
description: For several years, there have been reports of increased interest among economists in the Soviet Union and other Comecon countries in decentralized planning, flexible prices and incentives. The impression created by the Soviets has been that their work has been in an embryonic stage of development and relatively isolated. However, as a result of a recent trip to Moscow to observe the current status of this research, I think it may have progressed much further than was previously believed by American experts on Soviet affairs.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss after a loss of $6.7 million from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $20.3 million from discontinued operations...E-After a loss of $8.3 million from discontinued operations

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $95,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a charge of $117,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: Coroner to Open File on Munson
description: A.H. Kyriakides, the coroner for Summit County, has invited attorneys in a lawsuit to come to his office ''with or without a subpoena'' to look at his file on the death of Thurman Munson, the all-star catcher for the Yankees in the 1970s.

title: MOROCCAN SAYS P.L.O. AIDE WILL BE IN DELEGATION TO U.S.
description: A Palestine Liberation Organization representative will be among seven Arab envoys who will go to Washington next week for talks with President Reagan on their Middle East peace plan, Foreign Minister Mohammed Boucetta of Morocco said today.

title: CUOMO AND LEHRMAN CLASH OVER TV SPOT AND POSITIONS
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor, today stepped up his attacks on both his Democratic opponent, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and Governor Carey. He also warned that the state's financial situation next year might require a freeze on assistance to school districts.

title: Good News From Underground
description: New York's contract with a French-American consortium for the last 225 subway cars now planned is very good news. The simultaneous placement of the first $250 million in M.T.A. bonds at less than 10 percent interest is even better news. But the happiest report from underground is that the pioneering capital scheme of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's chairman, Richard Ravitch, works.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AAR Corp. said Synalloy Corp. and Barry Cohen, Synalloy's executive committee chairman, had increased their stake in AAR Corp. to 9.6 percent, from 8.5 percent.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VERBATIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
MITTERRAND DENIES DECIDING TO BUILD NEUTRON BOMB NOW
description: President Francois Mitterrand, commenting on a report that France had told some allied officials it would build a neutron weapon, said today that the ''moment has not come.''

title: 'HALLOWEEN III' MASKS TO HELP SCARE UP SALES
description: The three Halloween masks that form an integral part of the plot of a new movie, ''Halloween III: Season of the Witch,'' will also be an adjunct to the merchandising of the movie, which opens next Friday in 1,250 theaters across the country.

title: 7 HURT IN A BLAST AT TORONTO PLANT
description: Seven people were wounded, one of them critically, in a car-bomb explosion early today that damaged a Toronto factory that produces radar-evading guidance systems for the cruise missiles to be deployed in Europe.

title: BOMB KILLS SOLDIER AND A LEBANESE CIVILIAN
description: An Israeli soldier and a Lebanese civilian were killed today when a car bomb exploded in an Israeli-held mountain town 15 miles east of here.

title: FOSTER, L B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WADKINS AND KITE ADVANCE
description: Lanny Wadkins of the United States scored a 6-and-5 victory over Greg Norman of Australia in the $215,000 world match play tournament today and gained a berth in the semifinals against Severiano Ballesteros, the defending champion.

title: WHAT HOMICIDAL CHILDREN MAY HAVE IN COMMON
description: To the Editor:

title: Ticket Sales Rush Starts For Vatican Exhibition
description: Tickets for ''The Vatican Collections: the Papacy and Art,'' the exhibition planned at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from next Feb. 26 to June 12 went on sale yesterday at Ticketron and Teletron outlets around the country.

title: CALCULATING THE MONEY SUPPLY
description: They may not be aware of it, but the millions of Americans who are holding ''All Savers'' certificates maturing in October will probably create ''money'' this month.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Centerre Bancorp was formerly known as First Union Bancorp

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Linowitz Criticizes U.S.  On Latin America Ties
description: Former Ambassador Sol M. Linowitz said today that United States attitudes toward Latin America have been characterized by a ''sporadic and half-hearted concern'' that had led to a marked deterioration in relations.

title:
PATENTS;
A Combustion Engine For Toys and Machines
description: Frederick L. Erickson, a Fort Wayne, Ind., engineer, has invented a small internal combustion engine that operates quietly and with little or no exhaust. According to patent 4,353,331, granted him this week, it has one oscillating piston inside another. Mr. Erickson has built and tested prototypes, 7 cubic inches in size or smaller, to power model aircraft and bicycles.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Torrez Up for Trade
description: Mike Torrez, the 36-year-old right-hander who has won 174 games in a major league career that began with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1967, has been offered for trade by the Boston Red Sox. And, according to Haywood Sullivan, Boston's general manager, several clubs expressed interest immediately.

title: Filing by Unemployed Is Put Near 1982 Peak
description: Some 695,000 Americans filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits in the week ended Oct. 2, the second-highest level of the year, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS UP 11.6% IN QUARTER
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that gains from all areas of its operations as well as the recent prolonged rally on Wall Street caused net income in the third quarter of 1982 to climb 11.6 percent on an increase in revenues of 14.2 percent.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $947,000 or 33 cents a shr

title: LEAFLETS URGE POLES TO STRIKE NEXT WEEK
description: Leaflets were circulated in several Polish cities today calling for strikes next week to continue the protests over the outlawing of the independent union Solidarity.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Transfer Point For Young Amerasians

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in Business Day on Tuesday misstated the number of employees to be furloughed by the SmithKline Corporation. The five-day unpaid furlough affects only the 9,000 employees at SmithKline's Beckman Instruments Inc. subsidiary in Fullerton, Calif.

title: Coffee Prices Head Higher
description: Three of the nation's largest coffee roasters, citing ''rising costs of green coffee,'' yesterday announced increases in the wholesale price of 10 to 15 cents a pound effective immediately. The increases, the first this year, should be felt at the retail supermarket level within three weeks.

title: EQUALIZING RATES FOR INSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON BECAUSE young women have fewer automobile accidents than young men, they traditionally pay less for car insurance. But a little later in life, the insurance tables turn: Women pay higher rates for retirement benefits because they tend to outlive men by four to seven years.

title: Exxon Holding Equipment Sale
description: Exxon U.S.A. has scheduled what may be the nation's largest garage sale to unload millions of dollars worth of equipment from its defunct Colony Oil Shale Project.

title: GRACE, W R, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a special net gain of $33.7 million or 70 cents a shr from the disposition of Omnicare Inc...C-Including a gain of $65.1 million of $1.35 a shr from the disposition of Chemed; yr-ago results have been restated for pooling of interests

title: NORTH RIVER CLEANUP: WHERE THE FUNDS ARE
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENCY TO YIELD ON HERBICIDE ISSUE
description: The Veterans Administration has yielded to Congressional pressure in giving up control of an investigation into whether the herbicide Agent Orange damaged the health of soldiers in Vietnam.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $130,000 for the qr and 6 mos; results for the yr-ago 6 mos reflect an accounting change for foreign currency translations which increased net income by $119,000 or 5 cents a shr

title: Your Money; Broker C.D.'s: The Benefits
description: THE unusual combination of Federal deposit insurance and no-penalty negotiability can be found in a product being offered by many brokerage firms. Commercial banks and savings and loans associations have long issued certificates of deposit, but now these instruments are available from Wall Street.

title:
Patents;
Movement Monitor On Wrist
description: WASHINGTON AN activity monitor that can be worn like a wristwatch by a person who is moving about was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services by two staff specialists. About 100 of the monitors are in use at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: International Harvester paid $1.2 million to two former executives as part of a termination agreement, a prospectus prepared for a special stockholders meeting shows.

title: NICARAGUAN TELLS U.N. THAT U.S. WANTS TO UNDERCUT SANDINIST RULE
description: The Foreign Minister of Nicaragua told the General Assembly today that his country ''desired an understanding'' with the United States but that ''the response of the U.S. Government has been to attempt to impose on us its rigid East-West outlook.''

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Explosive Rivalry
description: The game is billed as the oldest college football rivalry west of the Mississippi. In the East, Yale played Columbia for the first time in 1873.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris pleaded not guilty to a charge that he wrote a worthless check for $489.23 to purchase a handgun on May 12. The former Dolphins running back is scheduled to begin trial Nov. 1, the same date he will begin trial on drug charges related to his arrest with four other men at his home in Dade County on Aug. 19.

title: De Gustibus; PIPES AND CIGARS: A DINER'S NEMESES
description: Anyone who has had a full-fledged head cold knows that when the sense of smell is impaired, the sense of taste suffers as well. An amateur experiment conducted to prove that point is one I remember from an elementary-school science class. We were told to hold our noses and eat slices of apple while breathing through our mouths, then to describe the flavor. The apple slice was peeled so the texture of the skin would not influence our judgment. Almost everyone thought it tasted just like a piece of raw potato.

title: Ford Expanding 11.9% Financing
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a new 11.9 percent retail financing program for 1982 Ford Escort and EXP and Mercury Lynx and LN7 cars. Ford said the program could save customers up to $850 per vehicle.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
U.S. IS DESIGNING A FASTER SYSTEM FOR REPORTING POISON DEATH DATA
description: To help avoid repetition of the seven Chicago area deaths from Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide, the Food and Drug Administration has quietly begun to design a system for rapid reporting of poison deaths.

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS FOR CENTRAL AMERICAN PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income figures for the yr-ago third qr and 9 mos have been restated for adjustment of depreciation rates in Dec 1981, retroactive to Jan 1, 1981

title: Eating Patterns Studied
description: The intensely competitive nature of American college sports has forced many athletes into bizarre eating habits that could harm their health after their competitive careers have ended, according to a four-year study of college athletes' diets. In a prepared speech on Monday, Sarah Short, a nutrition professor who conducted the survey, will tell the annual meeting of the American Dietetic Association in San Antonio that it is common for wrestlers to starve themselves and equally common for football players to gorge themselves with as much as 15,000 calories a day - as much as an average man eats in a week.

title: PENTAIR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 25 percent stock divd paid in Feb 1982

title: SEPTEMBER OUTPUT DECLINED AS PRICES OF PRODUCERS FELL
description: Industrial production fell again in September, indicating that the recession may not have ended, while the principal index of producer prices slipped, signaling more relief from inflation, the Government reported today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FUNNY ART

title: STYMIED BREWERS APPLAUD ANDUJAR
description: Until Ted Simmons's one-hop single hit Joaquin Andujar's right knee in the seventh inning tonight, sending him out of the game, the Cardinals' starting pitcher had throttled the Brewers' hitters and spoiled their heady return to County Stadium.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
FIRST CITY BANCORPORATION OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 results restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basi

title: Today Is Last Day To Register to Vote
description: Today is the last day to register for the Nov. 2 general election. Local polling places will be open for registration from 1 to 9 P.M. The Board of Elections has established a special telephone number, 267-9800, for those needing information on the location of their local polling places.

title: 10 JUDICIAL CANDIDATES LOSE APPEAL TO RUN AS DEMOCRATS
description: New York State's highest court made the final decision tonight that will bar 10 candidates for State Supreme Court in Manhattan from appearing on the Democratic line of the Nov. 2 ballot.

title: PAT FASHIONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rancher Agrees to End Sit-in on Missile Range
description: An 81-year-old rancher agreed today to end his three-day armed occupation of his former property on an Army missile range, and will leave Saturday accompanied by a Congressman, a spokesman for the lawmaker said.

title: Bonn Foreign Minister To Seek Re-election
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who split the ranks of the Free Democratic Party by taking it out of former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government, said tonight that he would seek re-election as party chairman.

title: What They Don't Say About Crime
description: As a political issue, crime is like the subways or the homeless. The less politicians understand the problems, the more assertive they are about remedies. By that measure, Lewis Lehrman understands a bit less than Mario Cuomo.

title: HOSPITAL TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAGIC MARKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Donald G. Robbins, Executive At Singer Company Until 1977
description: Donald G. Robbins Jr., retired senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Singer Company, died Monday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: BRAE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPUTER TRANSCEIVER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WESTERN PACIFIC RAILROAD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results reflect a significant sale of real estate

title: VYQUEST TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALLACE CAST IN UNFAMILIAR ROLE AS THE LIBERAL IN ALABAMA GOVERNOR RACE
description: It was virtually a quarter-century ago that a tiny, combative rural judge strutted in from nowhere to command Alabama's public stage, play on the fretting discontent of a nation and place his stamp on the political mind of America.

title: Cam Fella to Vie Against Merger
description: Cam Fella and Merger, who split the first two races of the Triple Crown of Pacing, will try to break the tie Saturday night in the $259,577 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: State Issues a Warning On Bass From Hudson
description: State health officials today warned against eating striped bass from the Hudson River more than once a month because of the high level of the deadly pollutant dioxin in the water.

title: AFTER 25 YEARS, CO-OP ENDURES AS STABLE SIGN
description: The roses are still in bloom at Morningside Gardens. Brilliantly pink and obviously well-tended, they are testimony to the success of the middle-income, cooperative housing development on Morningside Heights that was built 25 years ago to stem the deterioration pushing south.

title: Katherine K. Neuberger Dies; A Former Republican Official
description: Katherine K. Neuberger, a member of the State Board of Higher Education and a former member of the Republican National Committee, died today at Riverview Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: I.R.S. Penalty To Drop Jan. 1
description: The interest penalty for paying Federal taxes late will drop to an annual rate of 16 percent from 20 percent at the start of next year, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: ADIEU 'SUNRISE SEMESTER'
description: In the fall of 1957, the Columbia Broadcasting System, in collaboration with New York University, introduced an innovative television program called ''Sunrise Semester.'' This was the first time that a network and a university teamed together to use TV to enlighten rather than to simply entertain. The program was hailed by network officials, the news media and educators. Now, 25 years later, CBS has just replaced ''Sunrise Semester'' with a news broadcast from 2 A.M. to 7 A.M.

title: BEVERAGE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Dr. Leo H. Bartemeier, A Leading Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Leo H. Bartemeier, psychiatrist and psychoanalyst and former president of the American Psychiatric Association, died last Saturday at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 87 years old.

title: U.S. SAID TO OBJECT TO PLAN BY ISRAEL FOR A WITHDRAWAL
description: The United States has raised objections to an Israeli proposal that Palestine Liberation Organization forces leave Lebanon before other foreign troops, State Department officials said today.

title: The Chrysler Dilemma
description: ''We've done what we can afford,'' says a spokesman for Chrysler, but the corporation's workers plainly disagree. Frustrated by the anemic terms of the contract their leaders brought them last month, they have decisively rejected the pact.

title: KAISER CEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $926,000...C-Including a tax credit of $655,000 forthe qr and a net gain of $4,404,000 or 62 cents a shr fro the qr and 9 mos on the disposal of investments and other assets...D-Including a net gain of $4,651,000 or 65 cents a shr on the disposal of investments and other assets; Kaiser Cement commenced capitalizaing interest costs associated with the company's investment in China Cement Co Ltd of Hong Kong pursuant to a recent statement of the Financial Accounting Standard Boards

title: FIREFIGHT ON ALBANIA COAST STIRS SPECULATION ON INTERNAL WOES
description: A mysterious firefight late last month on the coast of Albania near the Greek island of Corfu, followed by a puzzling Albanian explanation, has led diplomats here who follow the affairs of Europe's most enigmatic country to believe that the Communist regime is facing a serious internal problem.

title: TWO BOUTS OF IMPORTANCE TO HAGLER
description: Up the Atlantic coast, Marvelous Marvin Hagler will interrupt his usual pre-fight preparations to take a rooting interest in two televised fights from two different hotels in Atlantic City today.
