title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAWKEYE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROBERT H. DAVIDSON
description: Robert H. Davidson, a former president and chief executive officer of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops Inc., Anderson Clayton Foods and PVO International, soybean producers and marketers, died last Sunday at Torrington (Conn.) Hospital after suffering a heart attack at his home in Litchfield, Conn.

title: Testimony About the System
description: A month ago, I wrote about how two decades had produced so little progress in bringing minority workers into the construction trades here and about how this failure - whether by intent, lack of initiative or blindness - belonged not only to the unions and contractors, but also to the government's enforcement bureaucracy.

title: Forstmann to Buy Beverage Company
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a privately held New York investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Beverage Management Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, for $24 a share, or $98.4 million, in a leveraged buy-out.

title: ALWAYS THERE IF OFTEN LATE
description: In this era of record-breaking trading days at the New York Stock Exchange, the ticker tape is mostly for show. If a trader really needs to know a stock price quickly, the best place to find it is at a desk-top terminal.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: MILWAUKEE He was not ready for the conservatism of St. Louis, and the city was not ready for his athlete's version of radicalism. That's the way love affairs get started. Now Ted Simmons is catching for the Milwaukee Brewers against his old team, the Cardinals, in the World Series. Going into last night's third game, he and his replacement, Darrell Porter, had been two of the hottest hitters in the Series, and their matchup one of the major themes in this refreshing Middle West battle of the beer towns. But last night as the Cardinals won, 6-2, Porter was hitless and Simmons had mixed success: An infield single that knocked Joaquin Andujar out of the game, a superb throw to second base to nail George Hendrick stealing and a catcher's interference call that led to the sixth Cardinal run.

title: Mobil Discount
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said that its gas customers would receive a 4-cent-a-gallon discount for cash purchases at most Mobil gas stations in the Southeastern and Middle Atlantic states beginning yesterday. Mobil said it was recommending the program to its dealers because of recent increases in the cost of handling credit cards and carrying receivables. In an effort to encourage cash sales, Mobil will charge dealers and distributors a 3 percent service charge on all credit card sales and will simultaneously reduce the wholesale price of gasoline.

title: ENVOY AT U.N. SESSION: A BLUR OF CONSTANT MOTION
description: So far as the public is concerned, the annual session of the United Nations General Assembly is an opportunity for ministers of some 130 countries to come to New York, deliver a pro forma speech to an almost empty chamber, drop in on a few parties and go home.

title: FIVE NOMINEES FROM BROOKLYN STILL CHALLENGED
description: Three weeks after the the Democratic primary, the nominations of a candidate for the House and two each for the State Assembly and the City Council from Brooklyn are being disputed amid charges and countercharges of fraud and forgery.

title: Books of The Times; Beyond the Evidence
description: TERRORISTS AND NOVELISTS. By Diane Johnson. 251 pages. Knopf. $14.50.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $6.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply, known as M-1, rose $6.9 billion in the week ended Oct. 6, an unusually large increase that reflected the cashing of ''All Savers'' certificates and an earlier-than-normal payment of Social Security checks.

title: SMOKE ALARMS: READER IDEAS
description: A report on the plight of New Yorkers with smoke detectors so sensitive that they continually give false alarms apparently rang a bell with other New Yorkers. Scores of readers of The New York Times either wrote or telephoned to say that they shared the problem described in an article that appeared on the Style page Sept. 18. ''All my neighbors complain about the dreadful noise,'' one person said. ''I guess it helps to talk about it.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Karate. 2. The canonization of the Rev. Maksymilian Kolbe, the Polish priest who volunteered to die in Auschwitz so that Mr. Gajowniczek might live.

title: Canadian Failures Rise
description: Canadian bankruptcies totaled 3,937 in September, up 50.9 percent from 2,609 in September 1981, the Consumer and Corporate Affairs Department reported today. Bankruptcies by individuals in September came to 3,007, up 51 percent from 1,991 in the period a year earlier, and business failures totaled 930, up 50.5 percent from 618. For the year so far there have been 30,374 bankruptcies in Canada, up 36.8 percent from 22,204 a year earlier.

title: Marchers Protest Raid on 43d St. Bar
description: Several hundred demonstrators marched through the Times Square area last night to protest what they called ''police brutality'' aimed at homosexual patrons of a bar on 43d Street east of Eighth Avenue.

title: BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Purchased the contracts of Bill Dawley, pitcher, and Dallas Williams, outfielder, from Indianapolis of the American Association.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $11,769,000 from the cumulative effect on prior yr of change in accounting

title: Conrail Undercuts Truck Grain Rates
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation set rail rates at almost half of comparable truck rates for corn and grains from the northwestern and north central parts of New York State to the dairy and poultry farms in the southern tier.

title: CITY ASKS JUDGE TO ALTER AGREEMENT ON HOMELESS
description: New York City has asked a judge to permit it to house homeless men and women in shelters that do not meet standards established in a court-approved agreement it signed last year, city officials said yesterday.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

PATENTS;
Keeping Driver Awake
description: Jean-Claude Fourcade of Le Chenay, France, has invented a device to warn the driver of a car if he falls asleep at the wheel. Mr. Fourcade was granted patent 4,354,179 this week for the apparatus, which detects any inclination of the driver's head and emits an audible warning. A published patent abstract says the equipment is installed within a housing that matches the contour of the ear.To get a copy of a patent, send the number and $1 to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

title: PLAYERS
description: MILWAUKEE ''A nd this is Mike Ramsey, baseball fans, the Cardinals' reserve third baseman, and a veritable vacuum cleaner out there in this fall classic. Mike, you've made 12 throws in the World Series and all of them have been in the dirt. How do you do it?''

title: COMMUNITY CHURCH MINISTER
description: The Rev. Vilma Szantho Harrington, the former co-minister with her husband of the Community Church of New York, died yesterday in Santa Fe, N.M., after a long illness.

title: U.S. TO ISSUE RULES ON CAPSULES SOON
description: Arthur Hayes Jr., the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today that regulations for tamper-resistant drug packaging might be issued as early as the first week in November and would be applied first to the most vulnerable items, such as capsules.

title: Narco Rejects Healthdyne Offer
description: Narco Scientific Inc., a producer of medical instruments and communications supplies, said that its board had voted unanimously to oppose Healthdyne Inc.'s recent offer to buy 710,000 Narco common shares for $30 a share. In a letter mailed to its shareholders, Narco urged them to reject Healthdyne's tender offer, calling it ''inadequate'' and not in their best interests.

title: MCGEE HITS 2 HOMERS AS CARDS TAKE 2-1 SERIES LEAD
description: Willie McGee, acquired by the St. Louis Cardinals from the Yankees during last year's World Series, became a star tonight in this year's World Series.

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $303,000 on the sale of marketable securities

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

PATENTS;
A Flexible Garment To Aid Burn Victims
description: A first-year medical student was awarded a patent this week for a flexible plastic garment to be used in treatment of body injuries, principally on the arms and legs.

title: Sikh Jail Protesters Ordered Freed in India
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today ordered thousands of Sikh political agitators released from jails in northern Punjab state.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by Zenko Suzuki to resign as Prime Minister of Japan was apparently the result of an intense power struggle within the Liberal Democratic Party.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acting Support For the Players
description: Vernus Palamidy, a 53-year-old stage actor, thinks the striking National Football League players deserve some sympathy. Their salaries may be high, he said, but their careers are short, the risks are high and they are working people.

title: 60 INDICTED IN UNDERCOVER INVESTIGATION OF FLORIDA DRUG TRAFFICKING
description: A trail of drug money through 47 bank accounts led to indictments today against 60 people in an undercover investigation, the Federal authorities announced.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Prince and the O.S.S.

title: Soviet Missile Tests End
description: The Soviet Union today announced the end of a round of missile tests that it said last week would last until Oct. 25 in two areas east of Midway Island in the Pacific. It said the areas would be open to ship and air traffic starting Saturday.

title: HONORARY DEGREES GIVEN BY HARVARD
description: A Nobel Prize winner was among five scientists and doctors awarded honorary degrees as the Harvard Medical School celebrated its 200th anniversary.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PEPPER, CONFIDENT HE'LL WIN, LENDS HAND TO OTHER DEMOCRATS
description: Here and in retirement communities all over America, Representative Claude D. Pepper is telling old people that he has met their enemy, and it is President Reagan and his economic advisers.

title: Kennedy to Debate Rival
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and his Republican challenger, Ray Shamie, have agreed to a debate Oct. 24 at Boston College, but their political aides disagree over who will be the moderator. Mr. Shamie's negotiators want the television commentator Howard K. Smith but charged that Kennedy aides reneged on their initial acceptance of Mr. Smith to lead the panel of four reporters. ''I don't think we ever agreed to that,'' Brian Delaney, a Kennedy campaign spokesman, said.

title: ATTACK ON FRENCH SHOW STIRS LITERARY SCANDAL
description: The French have a literary scandal, usually a delectable event here and as cyclically part of autumn as Brussels sprouts. This time, though, the issue is bitter and political, and basically one of who decides what is read in Socialist France.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shelley Feldman Sues Allegheny
description: Shelley Feldman Associates, a Miami-based consultant and manager in the food service equipment business, filed suit in the Federal District Court in Chicago against Allegheny International, its subsidiary the Sunbeam Corporation and the Welbilt Corporation.

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $31,000...C-Including a tax credit of $93,000...D-After an approximate charge of $165,000 from start-up costs for new contracts...E-Net income including a tax credit of $101,000; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: PAPER CHASE OF A WHISTLE-BLOWER
description: The paper trail tells much of the story. There is the receipt for the Polaroid Amigo 620 Camera, $50.76. Another receipt for two packets of Polaroid 600 film, $14.73, and a third for an airport parking fee of $18.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We think the P.L.O. has to leave first because they are the most dangerous elements. Then there must be a simultaneous withdrawal of Syrian forces and Israeli forces, and we hope that if there is a political readiness to do it by all the parties we could achieve withdrawal in the near future.'' - Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. (4:4.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quirks of the Calendar

title: TALKS HALTED, THEN RESUME
description: Negotiations between representatives of the National Football League Players Association and the league's Management Council stalled this morning over the issue of whether the union would have the right to sue the league after a new collective bargaining agreement is signed.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. RULES AGAINST IMPORTS OF STEEL
description: A United States Government agency ruled today that subsidized steel from Belgium, Britain, France, Italy, Luxembourg and West Germany had severely injured the American domestic industry.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1982
description: International The U.S. opposes an Israeli proposal that Palestine Liberation Forces leave Lebanon before other foreign troops, State Department officials said. They said that in the detailed discussions on Lebanon held Thursday by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir some specific problems arose that will probably take some time to resolve. The United States, acting as an unofficial intermediary between Israel and Lebanon and Syria has avoided presenting the Israelis with a detailed American plan, officials said, pending talks next Tuesday between President Reagan and President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. (Page 1, Column 4.) A U.S. offer to the Soviet Union of 23 million tons of grain will be guaranteed by President Reagan if it agrees during November to buy all of the grain, the President announced in a pre-election appeal for farm support of Republican candidates. Mr. Reagan also threatened ''strong measures'' to counter the ''growing tide of protectionism and export subsidies overseas.'' (1:5.)

title: British Inflation Eases
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.3 percent in September, the lowest in 10 years, from 8 percent in August, the Government announced today.

title: Cornerstone of Public Excellence
description: The cornerstone ceremony tomorrow at the new La Guardia High School near Lincoln Center will celebrate more than just the construction of another public school. It is a dream come true for the many educators, students and alumni of two very special institutions - the High School of Music and Art and the High School of Performing Arts - which will appropriately find their combined home in the new building.

title: Fine Proposed for Errors At Yankee Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, citing what it said were a host of operator errors in an April incident, proposed today that the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant be fined $40,000.

title: No Headline
description: Iraq Says It Killed 156 And Bombed Iranians

title: Interim Fire Chief Named by Koch
description: Joseph E. Spinnato, a deputy fire commissioner, has been appointed Interim Commissioner of the Fire Department by Mayor Koch. Mr. Spinnato will replace Commissioner Charles J. Hynes, who will leave his position on Oct. 22. Mr. Koch will choose a new permanent commissioner later, according to Dick Riley, a spokesman for the Mayor.

title: News Analysis
description: Lurking in the background of a major civil rights case before the Supreme Court is an issue of broad concern to hundreds of nonprofit religious, charitable and other groups that shun the racial discrimination practiced by the two private schools in the case.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iranian Talks To Resume
description: Negotiations between American banks and Iran will resume here Monday on how to settle bank claims for $1.4 billion from two escrow accounts at the Bank of England, banking sources said today.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company changed in its fiscal yr-end from Jan 31 to Dec 31; results from the yr-ago periods are for the qr and 9 mos ended Oct 31 1981

title: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eyedrop Victim a Suicide
description: A man who suffered severe eye irritation last week after using eyedrops contaminated by acid shot and killed himself at his home Thursday, the police said. Albert DeKal, 46 years old, was found dead in his home a day after laboratory tests showed that the eyedrops, Clear Eyes, contained an abnormally high level of acid.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Scare Tapers Off At the Poison Center

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of producer prices fell 0.1 percent in September, indicating more relief from inflation, the Labor Department reported. It cited big discounts in the auto industry, among the hardest hit by the recession. (Page 1.) Industrial production fell 0.6 percent in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The decline, the 12th in 14 months, was seen as a sign that the recession has not ended. (39.)

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEHERAN BLAMES U.S. AND LEFTISTS
description: A close aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was assassinated in a mosque today after a man detonated a grenade as he embraced the clergyman, Iran's official press agency reported. The assailant also died in the explosion.

title: DEVILS GET HOWATT FROM THE WHALERS
description: Patience, a trait that the aggressive and excitable Garry Howatt rarely displays on the ice, paid off for him yesterday off the ice when Howatt was finally acquired by the New Jersey Devils in a fourplayer deal with Hartford. Howatt forced a trade by refusing to play this season for the Whalers.

title: 'CONCRETE JUNGLE'
description: Two movies about women's prison opened here yesterday; ''Love Child'' is the more simple and serious and ''The Concrete Jungle'' the more blantantly junky. While neither one is exactly worth recommending, at least ''The Concrete Jungle'' starts off tawdrily and stays that way, which gives it a certain cheap momentum, if nothing else. This is a movie with characters named ''Cheeks'' and ''Spider,'' and with detectives who say things like ''Who's she coverin' for?'' ''Some punk, like always.'' If you're not enough of a B-movie fan to see the charm in that, keep away.

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EDWARD T. CARMODY, TIMEX CORP. COUNSEL AND PUBLIC DEFENDER
description: Edward T. Carmody, a lawyer who served for 25 years as public defender of New Haven County, died yesterday at his home in Middlebury, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: DOW DROPS AS RECORD WEEK ENDS
description: Prices dropped yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange completed a week in which the volume of trading was the heaviest in history. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, closed down 3.77 points, at 993.10. For the week the average rose 6.25 points, primarily because of declining interest rates.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 19
REDFERN FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15. 1. Because Don and Judy Quine, pictured above, got more than the usual kicks out of a sport, they formed an association to raise it to professional status. What sport is it?

title: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including income of $1,773,000 from the sale of land held for investment

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Klan Chief Files Charges After Assault on TV
description: Complaints were issued today against three suspects who allegedly were involved in a scuffle with the Ku Klux Klan Imperial Wizard, Bill Wilkinson, at a live television show.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PROPOSAL TO UNDERMINE A VITAL HOSPITAL PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTTING SEWAGE TREATMENT STANDARDS
description: Last month, New York City said it wanted to downgrade two sewage treatment plants that would clean the 200 million gallons of raw sewage pouring into the Hudson and East Rivers every day.

title: THE VISION OF WILLIAM HALSEY WOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. Aide Opens Talks On Air Base in Portugal

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods include operations of Marquette Cowhich was acquired in Apr

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Long Blue Line

title: Interest in Off-Year Elections Reported Highest Since 1970
description: More Americans of voting age say they are interested in this year's elections than in any off-year election since 1970, the Gallup Poll finds.

title: Producer Halts Sugar Exports
description: The Dominican Republic has decided to take its sugar off the international market until prices recover from their current 10-year low, a trade official said today.

title: OFFICER KILLS ASSAILANT OF WOMAN ON EAST SIDE
description: A plainclothes police officer shot and killed one of three men who were menacing a 30-year-old woman last night in the hallway of her Upper East Side apartment building, the police said. The other two suspects were arrested on charges of attempted rape, attempted robbery and illegal possession of weapons.

title: BRITISH SPRING STYLES: A MARK OF AUSTERITY
description: If simplicity characterizes the Italian fashion collections for next spring and summer, then austerity is the word for British styles. The pockets of punk are few, reflected in the coxcomb or Mohawk hairdos on the models at Zandra Rhodes or the clothes of an isolated designer, usually in his early 20's, who does elaborate one-of-a-kind concoctions of canvas and jewels to maintain the British tradition of quirky eccentricity.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MANUFACTURERS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-After securities losses of $3,593,000 for the qr and $7,357,000 for the 9 mos and after extraordinary credits of $115,000 for the qr and $251,000 for the 9 mos...D-Net loss after a securities gain of $20,000 and an extraordinary charge of $375,000...E-After a securities gain of $84,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,293,000

title: TRUDEAU AIDE FORESEES A NEW LOOK AT POLICIES
description: Canada's newly appointed Minister of Finance, Marc Lalonde, suggested yesterday that his Government might be willing to consider changes in policies that have drawn sharp criticism in the United States for posing a discriminatory barrier to American investment in Canada.

title: Court Dismisses Charge Of Sex Bias in Pension
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld Wayne State University's pension plan, which provides lower monthly payments to women than to men because statistics show women live longer than men.

title: Holmes to Fight Cobb
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion who last defended his title by stopping Gerry Cooney June 11, will make his next defense against Randall (Tex) Cobb next month on prime-time television. According to Don King, the promoter, the length of the National Football League players' strike will determine the date of the fight: It will be Monday, Nov. 22, if the strike is still on, and Friday, Nov. 26, if the strike has been settled.

title: ELI S. SILBERFELD
description: Eli S. Silberfeld, a lawyer for 53 years and former senior partner in the Manhattan firm of Danziger Bangser Klipstein Goldsmith & Greenwald, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: UNION SEEKS RAISE IN CHRYSLER TALKS
description: The United Automobile Workers went back to the Chrysler Corporation today in the hope of winning an immediate pay increase that would satisfy the huge majority of the rank and file that rejected the union's last contract proposal.

title: CHARTERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAFFS CUT BY 3 CABLE TV PROGRAMMING SERVICES
description: At a time when cable television is attracting fewer advertisers than expected, three programming services have cut back their staffs to help insure their survival.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd paid in Dewc 1981

title: CHANGES PROPOSED TO SPEED NUCLEAR LICENSING
description: The Department of Energy today unveiled a series of proposals it said would accelerate the building and licensing of nuclear power plants.

title: SIMILARITIES SEEN IN 5 LOS ANGELES SHOOTINGS
description: The police said today they were investigating the possibility that a series of five shootings, two of them fatal, were the work of a single killer who attacked his victims as they sat in automobiles.

title: OPERA: PAVAROTTI SINGS 'IDOMENEO'
description: It took the Metropolitan Opera nearly a century to get around to staging Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' possibly the greatest work of its Baroque type ever written, but they got it right the first time. For sheer depth of vocal talent, grasp of the grand style and impressive decor, Thursday night's first performance of Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production stood up to the best things that the Met has given us in recent years.

title: SALVADOR REBELS HOLD GROUND AGAINST GOVERNMENT ATTACKS
description: Guerrillas and Government troops clashed again today in central El Salvador, and the rebels held their ground on two northern fronts despite major counterattacks from the air and ground.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM RECEIVES HIGH PRAISE IN PARIS
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem, has been received enthusiastically by critics and public alike during its performances in Paris. The troupe was invited by the annual Paris Dance Festival at the last minute after the American Ballet Theater canceled its scheduled appearance because of labor problems.

title: Level Lowest In Five Years
description: Industrial production in September dropped for the 12th time in 14 months, hitting the lowest level in more than five years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: STAGE: CHONG'S 'ANNA INTO NIGHTLIGHT'
description: The setting for Ping Chong's ''Anna Into Nightlight,'' at La Mama, is a beautifully lighted, all-white living room, but it could be a room in an art gallery with a carefully designed environmental exhibition. Mr. Chong, who is the evening's author, director and designer, is a performance artist who unites theater, dance, movies and music into patterns that irradiate a stage with images, most of them visual. His cards of identity are covert; we catch clues on the wing, and the effect is entrancing.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Two brawny men move through New York City in a dark sedan, wearing sports clothes. Slowly they cruise the narrow side streets, staring at the sidewalks. The two look like professional football players moonlighting during the strike, or undercover police officers. Willis is voluble, Lee the strong, silent type. They take their work seriously.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a gain of $90,000 from a change in accounting

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONVICT HOLDING LAST OF 5 HOSTAGES AS STANDOFF AT HOSPITAL CONTINUES
description: A convict under siege at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn released a fourth hostage unharmed yesterday afternoon, but continued to hold a fifth man at gunpoint early today in a dingy basement locker room that was surrounded by scores of heavily armed police officers.

title: TOXICS DRILLED FOR AT WATERBURY SITE
description: Connecticut investigators have begun drilling at a downtown Waterbury toxic-waste treatment plant in search of hazardous chemicals that present and former employees have said were illegally dumped there.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 per shr figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball World Series: Brewers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Milwaukee, Game 4, 1:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880, 1:15 P.M.). Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, 8:30 P.M., second game of exhibition doubleheader at Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue. (Television - MSG Cable, 8 P.M.; tape at 1 A.M.). First game, Chicago Bulls vs. Atlanta Hawks, 6 P.M. Boxing Eusebio Pedroza vs. Bernard Taylor, 15 rounds World Boxing Association featherweight title fight, at Charlotte, N.C. Pedroza, 33-3-1 with 23 knockouts, is defending his title for the 15th time, more than any fighter in history of the division. Taylor is 18-0 with 10 knockouts. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.).

title: CASCO-NORTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Casco Northern is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ezra Cornell, Retired Lawyer; A Descendant of 2 Governors
description: Ezra Cornell, a retired senior partner of the New York law firm of White & Case, died Tuesday at his home in Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: U.S. CITES PIPE SANCTION IN MAKING FIRST SEIZURE
description: The United States Customs Service said yesterday that it had seized $3 million worth of American-made gas turbine parts owned by an Italian company that had been blacklisted for defying President Reagan's ban on the shipment of oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: CONNECTICUT INCUMBENTS TOP SPENDERS
description: The incumbents in the Connecticut statewide races this fall, United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Gov. William A. O'Neill, are heavily outspending their opponents, according to campaign finance reports filed yesterday and today with the Secretary of the State.

title: WESTWAY IS THE BEST WAY
description: When the history of New York City of the 1970's and 1980's is written, an unbuilt Westway will be seen as the major municipal tragedy of the era. Its absence will testify to the absurd, selfdestructive extremes to which anti-establishment politics can be carried.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $708,000 for the qr and $1,890,000 for the 9 mos and a charge of $1,764,000 for the 9 mos relating to the decision to further contract operations in the United Kingdom...C-After foreign currency translation losses of $1,331,000 for the qr and $2,287,000 for the 9 mos

title: OUTLAW NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: To the people of the United States: We American and Soviet physicians are united by our concern for the future of peace on Earth, for life on our planet. We may differ in our views on many issues, but in one respect we hold to our common point of view.

title: One Credit Short
description: Alfonso Averhart was the star of the Bishop Loughlin High School track team last year. His specialties are the 400-meter and 800-meter runs, but he also holds the New York State and Eastern State championships for 600 meters.

title: U.S. TO PAY FOR UPGRADING TURKISH MILITARY AIRFIELDS
description: The United States will pay for the modernization of 10 Turkish airfields so that they can be used by a variety of military planes, according to a Turkish Government statement released today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Albertson's Inc. filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of 1.2 million shares, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: Finland Oil Pact
description: Finland's state-owned oil import company, Neste Oy, will buy one million metric tons of crude from the Soviet Union for resale elsewhere, a company spokesman said here today. Oil market sources said some of the amount might have come originally from Libya, but the spokesman said he could neither confirm nor deny this.

title: FLORIDA COAST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,389,409

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Deadeye Dick
description: ''DEADEYE DICK'' is the life story, told by himself, of one Rudolph Waltz, born in Midland City, Ohio, in 1932 and now residing in Portau-Prince, Haiti, where he's the chef and co-owner (with his older brother) of a well-known hotel. Like many other books from the pen that brought us ''Jailbird,'' ''Slapstick'' and ''Welcome to the Monkey House,'' it's a riot of randomness. At age 12 young Rudy, schoolboy, fires off an unaimed round from a rifle belonging to his father's gun collection and accidentally kills a pregnant woman named Eloise Metzger, who's vacuuming her living room several blocks away when hit. Jailed for the deed, both Rudy and his eccentric father are viciously beaten by the police. (The cops bathe Rudy in ink and display him in a cage to selected visitors, who are encouraged to punch him out a little: ''I was regional theater.'') Lawsuits from the bereaved Mr. Metzger ruin the Waltz family financially (Rudy's father is heir to a drugstore chain fortune), and Midland Cityites bestow a mocking nickname on Rudy - the nickname that gives this work its title.

title: DANCE: THE WORKSHOP AT MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: Since 1973, the Yard has flourished as a summer workshop on Martha's Vineyard where dancers and choreographers gather to collaborate on new productions. And it has become traditional to show the resultant dances in the fall at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Maria Sirois To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alban Sirois of Ballston Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Ann Sirois, to Jonathan Penfield Shattuck, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Harwood Shattuck of Vineyard Point, Conn.

title: Rancher and Niece End Missile Range Protest
description: An 81-year-old rancher and his niece today ended a three-day armed occupation of the White Sands Missile Range and were escorted off the site, which was once the elderly man's ranch.

title: REAGAN SAYS GLOOM AND FEAR COULD STALL RECOVERY
description: President Reagan cautioned the nation today that economic recovery could be hindered by political opponents and other ''crepe hangers'' spreading a pervasive ''fear that we're adrift.''

title: Miss O'Donnell, C.F. Rogers Wed
description: Martha O'Donnell, daughter of Charles P. O'Donnell of Providence, R.I., and the late Mary Rita O'Donnell, was married in Providence yesterday to Charles F. Rogers Jr., son of Mrs. Rogers of Rumford, R.I., and the late Mr. Rogers. The Rev. Francis Mackin performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS.

title: Oklahoma Judge Orders Land Sold for Schools
description: The State School Land Commission has been ordered to sell all 766,000 acres of its holdings, valued at about $400 million, and to invest the money rather than gaining income by leasing the land.

title: ENGINE ONE WINS VOSBURGH
description: Two months ago, Conquistador Cielo, a 3-year-old son of Mr. Prospector who had won six consecutive races, finished third at odds of 2-to-5 in the Travers Stakes and probably lost his chance to be named the Horse of the Year. Yesterday at Aqueduct, Gold Beauty, a 3-year-old daughter of Mr. Prospector who had also won six consecutive races, finished third at 3-to-5 in the Vosburgh Stakes and probably lost her chance to be named the sprinter of the year.

title: FALL PROMENADE IN PROVENCE
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Change of Pace Counting the number of plays in public television's six-year Shakespeare series for which his colleagues have been executive producers, Shaun Sutton said: ''Cedric Messina did 12 and Jonathan Miller, 13. It's a lot of productions in a row and after a while you begin to yearn to do something that's not in iambic pentameter.'' ''King Lear,'' for which Mr. Sutton served as executive producer, will open the series's fifth season on Monday from 8 to 11 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Survey Finds That Jobs Are Key Voter Concern
description: Unemployment remains the dominant issue in the public's mind, outstripping such local issues as crime or taxes, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: GORDON GRAY 3d, CONCETTINA BENTIVEGNA TO BE WED
description: Concettina Bentivegna and Gordon Gray 3d plan to be married on Nov. 27 in Montreal. Miss Bentivegna is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Bentivegna of Montreal, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. Gray Jr. of New York and Virginia Garbers of Boston.

title: CASINOS OPPOSED
description: BRINGING casino gambling to Connecticut, which has been suggested as a way to raise additional money for the state and its cities without tax increases, is not a good bet for a majority of state residents, according to the statewide survey by The New York Times. Of those surveyed, 56 percent opposed casino gambling, while 36 percent favored it.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TOKYO
description: HENRY SCOTT STOKES is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: DEBORAH L. PIKE IS MARRIED
description: Deborah Louise Pike, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Haswell Pike of Summit, N.J. and Wilmington, Vt., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Steven Wiley Emmett, a Unitarian minister and psychotherapist. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Emmett of New York and Westport, Conn., and grandson of the Rev. John Corbin Wiley who performed the cermony in the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: 'GIGI' SANS MUSIC RETURNS TO STAGE
description: NEW HYDE PARK IN giving us ''Gigi'' as the Nassau Repertory Theater's opener, Clinton J. Atkinson, the artistic director, is getting to the stage source of the highly regarded film musical, which was turned into a lowly regarded stage musical. This is the 1945 Colette novella (later a French film) as adapted for the stage in 1951 by Anita Loos, who wrote ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.''

title: Mitzi Schroeder Wed to Roger Brooks
description: Mitzi Jeanne Schroeder, overseas program coordinator for Refugee Programs of the United States Catholic Conference in Washington, was married yesterday to Roger A. Brooks, an economic policy analyst for the Heritage Foundation, an independent public policy research organization, also in Washington. The Rev. Theodore Eastman, performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Chapel at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: The Magnetism Of Pragmatism
description: Helmut Kohl, West Germany's conservative new Chancellor, steered toward the center last week as the latest election returns compounded uncertainty over his coalition's future.

title: Nicolas Osborn to Marry Marietta Hill Whittlesey
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Granville Whittlesey of Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Marietta Hill Whittlesey, to Nicolas Courter Osborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Osborn of Salisbury, Conn.

title: CARIBBEAN CUT-RATE SEASON
description: Winter is fast approaching and with it will come the high season in the Caribbean. There are, however, still two months in which to sample the islands at about half the cost of a winter stay. While saving money is a strong reason to visit before rates change in mid-December, avoiding crowds and enjoying weather that is only slightly different from the more popular months - there are some rainstorms at this time of year - are added inducements.

title: Patrick Finegan Jr. Weds Mary Fogarty
description: Mary Elizabeth Fogarty, daughter of Mrs. Charles Franklin Fogarty of Darien, Conn., and the late Dr. Fogarty, was married yesterday to Patrick Gerard Finegan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finegan of the Bronx. The Rev. Pierre A. Botton performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: LIFE AND LIMBS ARE GROWING LONGER IN JAPAN
description: According to a recent survey, most Japanese are living long enough to make their country the world leader in male longevity - men are surviving to an average age of 73; and one of the leaders in female longevity - on average women are surviving to age 79.

title: Van Wie and Marsala First in Varsity Races
description: Jeff Van Wie of Suffern and Charles Marsala of New Dorp were winners of the boys' varsity races yesterday in the Golden Apple Cross-Country Invitational at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: DESPITE RECESSION, SALESMEN CAN STILL SMILE
description: ''T HERE are a lot of bucks in selling. Making $50,000 to $100,000 a year isn't hard if you're good. The reason is that a lot of salesmen these days are drones. There are still plenty of Willy Lomans out there. But if you have enthusiasm, if you like the product and if you think in terms of what the customer needs, there's no limit to how well you can do.''

title: STATE'S SCHOOLS ARE CRITICIZED
description: SCIENCE teachers in the state recently had a chance to hear that their curriculums might not be very relevant or good. Speaking at the New Jersey Science Convention in Cranford, Dr. Robert E. Yager, president of the National Science Teachers Association and a professor of science education at the University of Iowa, said that the single-minded pursuit of ''pure'' science in secondary schools in the last two decades had prevented high school students from acquiring a genuine interest in science and the necessary practical skills to cope with an increasingly technological world.

title: Bible Distribution Curbed
description: Gideons International, which has been distributing its Bibles for several years to fifth-@ and sixthgrade children in two Colorado towns, has been told to stop. Schools Superintendent Robert Turner said the school board decided to ban the practice this year at Loveland and Berthoud after receiving complaints citing court rulings that the Bible distribution violated the United States Constitution.

title: EMPTY LOT SOMEHOW REVIVED A CITY
description: As vacant city lots go, the one on Market Street downtown looks pretty standard. It is surrounded by a 9-foot chain link fence, and the grass is thick and brown and thighhigh.

title: SUSPICIOUSLY LIKE REAL LIFE
description: GROWING UP By Russell Baker. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $15.

title: LOCKHEED'S GRIP ON WASHINGTON
description: AFTER more than a decade of debate about how to revamp the military's fleet of cargo planes, both Congress and the Pentagon seem determined to purchase the C-5B - a cargo carrier that is just about identical to an older, troubled and highly criticized plane made by the Lockheed Corporation. Which only goes to show, as a former Pentagon official recently wrote, that in Washington's wars of military procurement, it is better to be on Lockheed's side than against it.

title: RICH ENOUGH TO BE CHEAP
description: Most rich people try hard not to call attention to themselves. It attracts too many nuisances: kidnappers, yacht salesmen, big organizations that panhandle for philanthropic causes. This is why rich people are notoriously cheap tippers. They're afraid a generous tip will unmask them.

title: No Headline
description: Washington Wins 6th, 34-17

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The two companies featured at the Theater of the Riverside Church this week are both directed by Asian-born choreographers who possess an interest in many forms of Eastern and Western dance.

title: Cora Louise Nutt Married
description: Cora Louise Nutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Tysen Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Brien Chemidlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Chemidlin Jr. of Fanwood, N.J. The Rev. Carl Arico performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church. The bride is production coordinator for McCall's Needlework & Crafts magazine. Mr. Chemidlin is a corporate auditor with Gulf & Western.

title: No Headline
description: GENE MAYER UPSETS CONNORS

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PHILHARMONIC GETS DRESSED By Karla Kuskin. Illustrated by Marc Simont. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row/ Charlotte Zolotow. $10.50. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: URBAN ARCHEOLOGY TREASURES ON EXHIBIT AT RUTGERS-NEWARK
description: NEWARK A relatively recent way of discovering the past, urban archeology, is the subject of a new exhibition at the Newark campus of Rutgers University.

title: N.F.L. TALKS STILL SNAGGED
description: The National Football League labor negotiations remained snagged today, the 26th day of the players' strike, on two of the few remaining noneconomic issues.

title: Michael Shapot Weds Chaye E. Zuckerman
description: Chaye Elaine Zuckerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Zuckerman of Longmeadow, Mass., was married last evening to Michael Jonathan Shapot, son of Hal Shapot of New York and the late Debbi Shapot. Rabbi Alex Weisfogel, assisted by Cantor Erno Grosz, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: PAPERBACK PUBLISHING'S LATEST PUSH
description: As the recession lingers, with lagging sales in everything from books to bungalows, some marketers and advertising folk are paying greater attention to the he-man male market with its longdemonstrated demand for certain products, which range from actionadventure fiction to full-flavor cigarettes and beer.

title:
CAREER DEVELOPMENT;
FIND THE COUNSELOR WHO IS RIGHT FOR YOU
description: FIVE people sit around a conference table, their eyes closed.F ifteen minutes pass in silence, broken periodically by instructions f rom the woman at the head of the table.

title: Home Advantage Can Fail, Too
description: To the Sports Editor: At the end of Charles Einstein's article (''The Best World Series Games? Take These Three, The New York Times, Oct. 10), it was pointed out that in each instance the winner was the home team. I was thumbing through a pro football encyclopedia recently to see that the 73-0 defeat of the Washington Redskins by the Chicago Bears in the 1940 National Football League championship game took place, of all places, in Washington.

title: CITIES USE PROPERTY TAX TO COVER LOSSES IN AID
description: Even though the property tax has been under assault by citizen groups across the country in recent years, cities are using it as a last resort to help make up losses in Federal revenue.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ONE way to reach a favorite author may not lead through library stacks and mounds of dusty manuscripts. So suggests Prof. William Howarth of Princeton, who, from 1972 to 1980, was editor in chief of ''The Writings of Henry D. Thoreau,'' published by the Princeton University Press.

title: IMMOBILE PIECES
description: Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, prosed purplish but correctly in stating: ''What is immobile must suffer violence. The light-winged bird will easily escape the huge dragon, but the firmly rooted big tree must remain where it is and may have to give up its leaves, fruit, perhaps its life.''

title: CORPORATE LINKS WORRY SCHOLARS
description: WHEN corporations entered into research contracts with universities a t the height of the post-World War II electronics boom, as often as n ot it was to help the company image. If the result was a new d iscovery with a commercial application, or a chance to hire some t alented graduate students, that was fine - no one counted on it.

title: U.S. REFUSES TO LET P.L.O. DELEGATE MEET REAGAN
description: The United States said today that it would refuse to welcome a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization as part of an Arab League delegation scheduled to meet with President Reagan next week at the White House.

title: THE INDIAN MARKET OF OTAVALO, ECUADOR
description: ANN ANABLE is an editor at New Woman magazine who writes frequently on fashion, beauty and travel.

title: Ex Libris
description: The average book thief might have been allowed to plea-bargain down to borrowing without a library card, but not James R. Shinn.

title: Military Analysis
description: Western intelligence sources say the Soviet Union, in the nearly three years it has had troops in Afghanistan, has apparently reduced the level of rebel resistance only marginally.

title: FARE GAMES AND THE FREQUENT FLIER
description: LISA BELKIN works in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: WHEN BOOKS BECOME 'VISUAL LITERATURE'; PHILADELPHIA
description: Consider Alison Knowles's ''The Book of Bean,'' a walk-in construction whose ''pages'' are eight feet tall. Or Jack DeWitt's ''Finger Food: Poems of Love, Sex and Dream,'' erotic poetry printed not only in ordinary type but in Braille. Or Suzanne Horvitz's ''Thou Hast Ravished My Heart and For Sick of Love Am I,'' a miniature volume of Xeroxed color images juxtaposed with text from the Song of Solomon.

title: WHAT TO DO WITH MONEY
description: WITH bank failures, bankruptcies and unemployment all rising, it is small wonder that people are concerned about money. One barometer of financial anxiety is the mushrooming of personal finance and money management books.

title: 17 ADDITIONAL SIRENS PLANNED FOR SYSTEMS IN INDIAN POINT AREA
description: The Consolidated Edison Company and the State Power Authority said they would install an additional 17 sirens within five miles of the Indian Point power plants in Westchester County to warn nearby residents in the event of a nuclear accident.

title: BEST SELLERS This Week Last Week Weeks on List; FICTION
description: 1 1 3 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 7 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 3 7 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 4 4 8 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 7 4 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic romance survives the stresses and strains of World War II. 6 5 11 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 7 6 8 LACE, by Shirley Conran. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Three decades in the lives of a coterie of members of the international glitter set.

title: Mauch's Strategy Second-Guessed
description: To the Sports Editor: Some of the strategic decisions made by Manager Gene Mauch in the American League Championship Series were quite perplexing. I would like to know how Tommy John, a pitcher the Angels acquired only about six weeks ago, suddenly became the indispensable ace of the starting pitching staff - to the extent that he had to pitch on three days' rest.

title: Nephew Frees Woman After 14-Hour Standoff
description: A state prison guard held his 60-year-old aunt hostage at gunpoint for 14 hours in her Bronx home before releasing her unharmed and surrendering late last night.

title: Rachel McPherson a Bride
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday Rachel Mc-Pherson, a film and television producer, was married to William Patrick McMullan 3d, a vice president of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Orrin S. McPherson of Monticello, Miss., and Mr. and Mrs. McMullan Jr. of Jackson, Miss.

title: WHY TV NEWS IS INCREASINGLY BEING PACKAGED AS ENTERTAINMENT
description: In just 10 months, Van Gordon Sauter has done more to change the face of CBS News than his three predecessors as president did in 15 years. Mr. Sauter replaced the executive producer of the evening news and overhauled its appearance; scuttled virtually everything on the morning news but Diane Sawyer, and introduced an entirely new broadcast; replaced bureau chiefs in a half-dozen cities; deemphasized news from Washington, D.C., and reshuffled major assignments in that bureau; and inaugurated five more hours of news programming weeknights between 2 and 7 A.M.

title: ADVANTAGES OF PAINTING WITH PADS INSTEAD OF BRUSHES
description: ALTHOUGH flat painting pads have been around for years, many doit-yourself home painters still have never tried them, even though on some jobs they can be faster and more convenient to use than either a brush or a roller.

title: PLANT DELAY PUTS LILCO IN A SQUEEZE
description: In the wake of the Long Island Lighting Company's announcement that the estimated cost of the Shoreham nuclear power station had risen beyond the $3 billion mark, financial analysts said last week that the utility's future financial health still depended on getting the plant into operation. There were signs that it may take longer to put Shoreham into operation than Lilco would like. These signs included the following:

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Pro Athletes' Agent Delights in Combat
description: In a remarkable flurry of activity, eclipsing the notice he achieved in one season when he passed for more yardage than any other college quarterback in the United States, Gary Wichard has managed in recent weeks to offend the following:

Haledon $102,500 479 Hobart Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*porch, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $1,890. title: MIDDLE ATLANTIC
description: THE Middle-Atlantic region contains some of the most vibrant areas f or employment and some of the grimmest, ranging from the Virginia s hipyards on the Eastern Seaboard, thriving as a result of increased d efense commitments, to the steel mills of northwestern P ennsylvania, which have been declining for two decades.

title: They'll Still Take Busing
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission last week reaffirmed its position that when all other paths to integrated education are blocked, busing is the way to go. Five of the six members voted to restate the commission's pro-busing policy, which the Adminstration and the panel's Reagan-appointed chairman have repeatedly opposed.

title: A PERFORMING ARTS CENTER?
description: Following are excerpts from testimony presentad at a public hearing, convened by State Senator John R. Dunne, Republican of Garden City and Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, Democrat of Long Beach, to consider ite acquisition and planning for a Long Island Performing Arts Center:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SENATOR John Glenn of Ohio will come to Westchester on Thursday, in the middle of a nationwide tour in support of fellow Democratic candidates, to help Mercy College in its annual fund-raising drive.

title: Lesser Creatures, Higher Virtues
description: There are doubtless many reasons Ling-Ling, the Washington Zoo's panda, has never produced progeny. But good taste is surely one of them.

title: MIDEAST SHORTCUT
description: To the Editor:

title: HOISTING HISTORY FROM AN ENGLISH HARBOR
description: THEY that go down in the sea for old ships sometimes come up with treasure troves, but rarely the ship itself. So when a British salvage operation last week raised the Mary Rose - King Henry VIII's joy when it sailed in 1511, his despair when it sank in 1545 - archeologists hit a gold mine.

title: Trouper's Trauma
description: Italian tenor Carlo Bini may still love American audiences - he says he does - but his affection must be akin to what plump pullets feel for Frank Perdue. Mr. Bini was yanked from his seat at the Metropolitan Opera to perform last week when an ailing Placido Domingo called it quits after the first act of Ponchielli's ''La Gioconda.'' Mr. Bini, who had not fully rehearsed the part, was wading into his first aria when some in the audience began behaving like rowdy teen-agers on a stalled subway. They laughed at him, booed him and engaged in fisticuffs with fellow patrons who demanded decorum. ''I'm a little bit unhappy,'' Mr. Bini confessed when the ordeal was over.

title: AT THE SHORE, IT'S A NEW, QUIET SCENE
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS THE weekend traffic jams of summer are a thing of the past, and on the Boulevard - the main north-south thoroughfare here - there is an embarassment of riches in parking spaces. Amusement rides have been silent since Labor Day and most boardwalk concession stands are open only on weekends, if at all.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON SYMPHONY PERFORMS BRAHMS'S SECOND
description: It has been said that the new concert halls take their sonic ideal to be the stereo speaker; it may be that orchestras are starting to do the same. When the Boston Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night, Seiji Ozawa's conducting made it sound as if the performance were a recording - suitable for background listening.

title: 9 Bombs Explode in Corsica
description: Nine bombs exploded in Ajaccio and Bastia, Corsica's two main towns, early today, causing serious damage but no injuries, the police said. Banks, shops and cars were hit. It was not known who was responsible.

title: DEAF STUDENTS JOIN THE HEARING WORLD
description: RIVERHEAD THE Cleary secondary program at Mercy High School will hold its first graduation ceremony next June and eight deaf students are expected to receive their high school diplomas. All eight, according to Sister Maura Costello, coordinator of the program for 25 deaf students who are ''mainstreamed'' into classes at the 575-student parochial school here, are interested in going to college or obtaining further career training.

title: U.S.C. DEFEATS STANFORD
description: John Elway passed for 239 yards today, the 26th time he has thrown for 200 yards or more, an N.C.A.A. record. But the Stanford quarterback was overshadowed by a solid, well-balanced Southern California attack that ran up a 41-21 victory before 75,185 fans at Stanford Stadium.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I would like to attend the Mozart Festival in Salzburg, Austria, from Jan. 21 through Jan. 30. Do you know of any travel program arranged around this event? - E.D., New York, N.Y. Answer:''Salzburg Mozart Festival and Vienna State Opera'' is the name of a tour offered by Dailey-Thorp Travel (654 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021; 212-486-95550), a tour operator that specializes in programs built around opera and other musical performances in Europe and North America.

title:
THE NATIONAL OUTLOOK ON EMPLOYMENT;
THE SOUTHEAST
description: THE job base in the service sector is expected to continue to expandi n the Southeast over the next few months, although at a slower pace a nd an uneven one, while employment prospects in manufacturing and c onstruction will continue to deteriorate.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON COLLEGE WINS ON LAST PLAY Syracuse

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, a section of the article about David Hare on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today is out of place. The last 12 lines of column 5 and the first 8 lines of column 6 should have appeared in column 5 after the phrase ''more clearly than those.''

title: Lisa J. Helmrich and Nathaniel Akerman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Helmrich of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jane Helmrich, to Nathaniel Howard Akerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Akerman of Springfield, Mass.

title: Australia Allows U.S. Flights
description: Australia has granted a United States request for extended use of its airspace by B-52 bombers on navigational training flights from Guam, Defense Minister Ian Sinclair said today. The opposition Labor Party and antinuclear groups, who feared the planes carried nuclear weapons, had protested the flights but Mr. Sinclair said the planes would carry no bombs.

title: Miss Cohen, P.J. Kurshan Are Engaged
description: Harriet Newman Cohen of Belle Harbor, Queens, and Philip M. Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha E. Cohen, to Peter J. Kurshan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Kurshan of Woodmere, L.I., and New York.

title: LEGISLATURE'S TROOPS TURNING TO THE JOB OF WINNING ELECTONS
description: Like generals of opposing armies, the leaders of the New York State Legislature are deploying their forces and mapping last-minute campaigns to control the Legislature's 206th session.

title: The Eastern Shore
description: To the Editor: As one with special interest in the history, waterways, architecture and food of the Chesapeake's Eastern Shore, I was pleased to see the articles by B. Drummond Ayres Jr. and Francis X. Clines (Travel, Sept. 12). One might get the impression from Mr. Clines, however, that Odessa, Del., was pioneered by Ukrainians. In fact, the place was called Cantwell's Bridge for 134 years until the state legislature, in 1855, renamed it to honor the - to them, oriental - Black Sea port in the hope that such would help the little port's commercial revival. Such renaming had begun with Smyrna (1806) and Leipsic (1814 - actually the state chose Vienna, but the locals had their own idea). In these names we see early evidence of Romanticism's fascination with the exotic and the antique.

title: NAVAJO LEADER IN STIFF RACE TO KEEP TRIBAL JOB
description: Peter MacDonald, the Navajo tribal chairman who is considered one of America's most powerful Indian leaders, is facing the most formidable challenge of his 12-year political career in the tribe's election Nov. 2.

title: WAGNER DOWNS MERCHANT MARINE, 17-0
description: Wagner College, ranked sixth in the country in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, continued its drive to the postseason playoffs with a 17-0 victory over the United States Merchant Marine Academy yesterday.

title: The Men At Third Base
description: Excellent article on the hardy souls who guard third base, and I would especially like to single out Graig Nettles (''Baseball's Amazing Acrobats,'' by Mark Goodman, Aug. 29). Amid the swirls of controversy that surround the Yankees, Graig holds his head high and continues to lead his team as a ballplayer, gentleman and Yankee captain.

title: Cops and Dumpers
description: Dumping hazardous wastes became more hazardous in New York State last week. A special team of 29 plainclothes officers, having completed two weeks of training, was dispatched to field offices in White Plains, Buffalo and Albany to combat the problem.

title: STAGE: 'FABULOUS 50s,' CLAUDE MCNEAL MUSICAL
description: Popular music of the 1950's - the fading of the traditional pop styles of the 30's and 40's during the first half of the decade and the doo-wop singing and Elvis-rock that colored the last half - is a rather slight and deceptive subject for parody or satire. The songs and vocal styles were often so ridiculous in themselves that there is little left for the parodist or satirist to add.

title: LEFTOVER COINS
description: To the Editor: At Kennedy International Airport there is a box for foreign coin donations set up by the Travelers' Aid Society. I always dump my spare change there. I assume they don't find it too difficult to convert small change. A.M. CUNNINGHAM New York

title: 19 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 19 food establishments it said had violated the health code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations and six that were closed for failing to do so.

title: THE BERLIN PHILHARMONIC-WHAT MAKES IT GREAT?
description: New York is a crossroads for the great orchestras of the world, but a visit here by the Berlin Philharmonic remains a rarity. Its last concerts in New York came six years ago. This week, as part of its 100th birthday celebrations, the Philharmonic returns to Carnegie Hall for four long-since sold-out concerts under its music director since 1955, Herbert von Karajan.

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1982
description: International The U.S. would sever connections with any United Nations organization, including the United Nations itself, that voted to exclude Israel from participation. The announcement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz also said that the United States was prepared to suspend all payments to the organizations. Suspension has been ordered for $8.5 million owed the International Atomic Energy Agency for the rest of 1982 because of its vote last month to withdraw Israel's credentials. (Page 1, Column 6.) Lifting Siberian pipeline sanctions imposed by the United States is part of a proposal the Reagan Administration has submitted to France, Germany, Britain and Italy. The proposal, which was presented before the latest clashes in Poland, commits the allied governments to a fundamental review of how to deal with the Soviet Union and how to use such pressure points as credit terms and techology transfers as leverage in any linkage of trade with Soviet behavior. (1:5.)

title: A 2d Man Pleads Guilty In Reagan Home Deal
description: A second businessman has pleaded guilty to a Federal charge that he lied on a loan application in an unsuccessful attempt to buy President Reagan's former home in Pacific Palisades.

title: JOURNEY THROUGH AFGHANISTAN
description: Jere Van Dyk, a freelance journalist, spent six weeks in Afghanistan last fall, gathering material for a series of dispatches that appeared in The New York Times. His book, ''In Afghanistan: An American Odyssey,'' will be published in the spring by Coward, McCann & Geoghegan.At 8:30 in the morning, Mohammed Hakkim quietly opened the door of my hotel room. I was staying at Dean's Hotel, in Peshawar, Pakistan, a single-story complex of rooms with creaky overhead fans and a high whitewashed wall to protect its guests from Asia. Mohammed looked me over - my baggy Afghan clothes, my Afghan blanket, the turban I had wound inexpertly about my head - and motioned me to follow him. ''We must go quickly,'' he said, ignoring the furtive looks of the hotel staff. ''These people are all spies.''

title: Rebels Attack; In Salvador
description: El Salvador's insurgents have long contended they can neither be defeated nor win militarily, but that conclusion hasn't kept them off the battlefield. They were pushing hard last week in at least half of the country's 14 provinces.

title: SCIENTISTS TO MEET AT A 'SEMINAR-IN-EXILE'
description: IN a gesture of support for Soviet scientists who have been refused permission to emigrate, the Committee for Concerned Scientists and Pace University's Dyson College of Arts and Sciences are sponsoring a ''Seminar-in-Exile'' today at the school's Pleasantville campus. Among the speakers will be Mark Azbel, a former leader of the Moscow ''Scientific Sunday Seminars'' and the author of ''Refusenik: Trapped in the Soviet Union.''

title: THE ROMANCE OF MARBLE RUINS
description: ERIC NEWBY is the author of ''A Short Walk in the Hindu Kush,'' ''The Big Red Train Ride'' and, most recently, ''A Traveller's Life'' (Little, Brown).

title: Susan See Married to Peter G. Brown
description: Susan Butler See, daughter of Mrs. Maurice V. King Jr. of Honolulu and the late Mr. King, was married yesterday to Peter Godley Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard W. Brown of Erie, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Chester Terpstra, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in the garden at Mabel Babcock's home in Honolulu.

title: MIDDLE MANAGERS ARE GETTING SQUEEZED OUT
description: ''I M an engineer,'' said the middle-aged man standing in a state unemployment-compensation line in Morristown, N.J., ''and Allied Corporation let me go at this age, along with quite a few others.'' Another unemployed middle-aged manager in the line, hearing his complaint, asked him what happened the last time there were mass dismissals a few years ago at the company. ''Oh, that time I managed to hide under the desk,'' the engineer replied.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOW CRAFTS BECAME BUSINESSES
description: WATERBURY HOW basic colonial handcrafts changed into profitable 19th-century trades when mechanical production methods were introduced is one of the main themes of a five-week lecture series sponsored by the Mattatuck Museum, 119 West Main Street here. Titled ''Made in Connecticut,'' the series, the first lecture of which will be given at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow, will also explore the ways in which Yankee craftsmen proved themselves equally creative builders of mass markets for the decorative objects they manufactured.

title: 'WIN' LEADER AMONG CASINOS IN JERSEY LISTED 3d LAST MONTH
description: Resorts International Hotel Casino, normally a leader in gambling revenues here, dropped to third in September. The month also saw some surprising changes in gambling revenue patterns.

title: BRITAIN'S BEST ON EXHIBIT
description: ERICA BROWN is a writer based in London.

title: By John Pareles; Music: '7th Cycle,' on War and Fertility
description: War and fertility were the literary themes of ''Seventh Cycle,'' a ''worldwide jazz'' suite presented Monday by Bill Cole at Town Hall. For it, Mr. Cole and his music director, Farel Johnson, percussionist, mustered a poet, an African drummer, a singer from the Abenake reservation in Canada and seven jazz avant-gardists. Mr. Cole, chairman of the Dartmouth music department, plays nasal doublereed instruments - French musette, Indian shenai and nagaswarm and Chinese sona - with surprising control.

title: FIBER OPTICS: A SUPER FUTURE FOR A VARIETY OF SPECIALISTS
description: FASTER than a speeding bullet. More powerful than a locomotive. Ablet o leap tall buildings, span oceans or thread its way through the h uman body. It's light pulses transmitted by way of hair-thin glass f ibers, or fiber optics, and it is opening a variety of careers to m en and women with science and engineering backgrounds.

title: EVERYTHING GOES RIGHT FO R TAFT'S COACH
description: Larry Stone is the football coach at the Taft School and if he was beaming after the game against Choate yesterday it was understandable. Not only did his team remain undefeated (4-0) by downing its rival, 38-31, at home, but his son, Jim, was the star of the upset victory. To make things sweeter, the triumph was Taft's first over Choate in five years.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A SALUTE TO AMERICA
description: WHITE PLAINS ''WOW,'' said 11-year-old Jeffrey Randolph as fireworks burst into the night sky above Bloomingdale's. Drawn by the noise at the store's front entrance, he stood transfixed by the sights and sounds: a brass band playing Dixieland marches; red, white and blue bunting; men in tuxedos and women in elegant dresses. Then he turned and saw someone in a white gown stepping out of a horse-drawn carriage. ''Look, look,'' he called out. ''Is that the Queen of England?''

title: '82 DEMOCRATIC GAINS, '84 DEMOCRATIC PAINS
description: Many Democrats expect that the sorry state of the economy will give them significant gains in next month's midterm elections -gains that could signal a broad liberal revival. They may be pleased this November, but, in the long run, they could well be disappointed. After all, similar interpretations of the 1970 and 1974 midterm elections were misleading, to put it mildly.

title: John Updike's Latest Novel, 'Bech' Sequel, Draws on Himself
description: It is a magisterial house, an elegant, white Colonial mansion that overlooks the sea. Beyond the neatly groomed garden of roses and marigolds, beyond the grove of trees already blushed with autumn colors, one can see the ocean and the Massachusetts coast, and, if one looks closely, a little piece of land known as Misery Island. Inside, Oriental rugs decorate the floor and an outsized mirror reflects the coming and going of guests.

title: HOMING IN ON PRINCIPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: KOREAN CULTURE
description: What is believed to be the first American symposium on Korean culture will be held from 8:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. Saturday in the Whitney Humanities Center of Yale University, 55 Wall Street, New Haven. ''Korean Culture Through the Arts: A Comparative View'' is free to the public and it was scheduled this year to commemorate the centennial of the treaty signed between the United States and Korea in 1882.

title: THE FED TAKES A RISKY NEW PATH
description: IN October 1979, with great fanfare, the Federal Reserve embarked on a grand new experiment for managing m onetary policy. Now, with somewhat fewer flourishes, the Fed appearst o have suddenly turned from that course.

title: PHONE FEUD OVER A DOG BITE IS STILL LIVELY AFTER 45 YEARS
description: Gertrude Jamison, 84 years old, tormented A. Douglas Thompson by telephone for 45 years, and she is at it again, he says, apparently by having circumvented a courtordered padlock on her phone.

title: Catherine Clapp Becomes a Bride
description: Catherine Adams Clapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Adams Clapp 3d of Southport, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married in Southport yesterday to Jeremy Granger Read, son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Charles Read of Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. Andrew L.C.C. Jones performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: COAST RIVALS FIGHT FOR MIDDLE OF ROAD
description: Two cautious counterpunchers are slowly backpedaling their way toward Nov. 2, when one of them will be elected Governor of California.

title: WORKING ON DEFENSE AT THE STADIUM GATE
description: I attended a high-school football game recently and was reminded of my introduction to the scene in an official capacity, more years back than I care to remember.

title: MERGER MANIA ADDS TO EXECUTIVE WOES
description: ONE of the old jokes about being an employee of a company involved i n acquisition or merger is that the employees get the mushroom t reatment. First they're kept in the dark, then they're stewed for a w hile and finally they're canned.

title: Letters; No Faltering
description: To the Editor:

title: PETROLEUM OVERCHARGES GOING TO ENERGY PROJECT
description: About $900,000 recovered from the Chevron Petroleum Corporation for overcharging its customers will be spent on a pilot program of energy conservation loans, state officials announced today.

title: Penn Loses Its First To Lafayette, 35-20
description: The quarterback Frank Novak set a school record for total yardage today to help the Lafayette upset previously undefeated Penn, 35-20.

title: Jo Ellen Hull Wed To A. S. Brisbane
description: Jo Ellen Hull, daughter of Mrs. Bryon D. Hull and the late Mr. Hull of Dodge City, Kan., was married yesterday to Arthur S. Brisbane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seward Brisbane of Upper Brookville, L.I. The Rev. William Jarvi and the Rev. Robert M. Hull, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kansas City, Mo.

title: VIDEO AT MALL GIVES CANDIDATES A STAGE
description: HAIRED man in a yellow cable-knit sweater stood with his arms folded intently, watching a program on a video screen. A woman pushing a shopping cart glanced at the screen, but kept walking. Others stopped and watched for a couple of minutes, then left.

title: HISTORIC AREA SUGGESTED IN DOBBS FERRY
description: TEN Victorian houses in Dobbs Ferry, one of them with a reputation for being haunted, will be the subject of a public walking tour today - and the tour may lead to the formation of a historic district to protect the area from encroaching development.

title: SALVADOR REBELS SEEM TO BE COORDINATING ATTACKS
description: The increased level of fighting this week in El Salvador's civil war may be an indication that this country's guerrilla factions are acting with greater coordination than they have in months, some military officials here believe.

title: TEXT OF SHULTZ'S STATEMENT ON THE U.N. AND ISRAEL
description: Following is the text of the statement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today on Israel's participation in the United Nations:

title: THE GREAT STAGNATION
description: As the November elections near and unemployment soars above 10 percent, the public comparisons of Herbert Hoover and Ronald Reagan become ever more frequent - and more partisan. The two Presidents, 50 years apart, are cast as the chief villains in the economic dramas of their respective eras, offering up optimistic forecasts in the teeth of dire economic portents. In one sense, the dual portrait is overdrawn: Their guilt has been much exaggerated, since in both cases the seeds of the problem were planted much earlier and germinated far beyond the boundaries of the United States. In President Reagan's case, he followed Republican and Democratic Administrations that had failed to cope with the raging inflation induced by Vietnam and the OPEC oil price shocks. His predecessors - and the leaders of most of the Western world - had inconsistently tapped on the monetary brakes, hoping to stop inflation but afraid of causing a major recession. President Reagan, however, slammed on the brakes, sending interest rates soaring, with severe consequences for the United States and the rest of the world.

title: Bruins 6, Oilers 6
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Luke Dufour scored in the third period to give Boston the tie. Dufour picked up a loose puck in front of Andy Moog, the Edmonton goalie, and flipped the puck over him with 5:04 to play.

title: Players' Pool a Record
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, the Milwaukee Brewers, the Atlanta Braves and the California Angels, who participated in the major league championship series this year, will divide a record pool of $4,500,467. The previous record was $4,142,340, set last year. The crowd at today's fourth game of the World Series, 56,560, was a record for a sports event at Milwaukee County Stadium.

title: ASTHMA WON'T STOP HER RUN
description: ASTHMATICS can run marathons. I say this because I plan to run and finish the New York Marathon next Sunday. I want only to avenge last year's race. Then I'll quit marathons, content to settle for more reasonable distances.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART One of the great names in art dealing is that of P. and D. Colnaghi, who were first established in London a very long time ago.
