During the period immediately after World War II, Colnaghi's was a kind of club in which anyone who cared for Old Master paintings and drawings was welcome to drop in and see what was in the racks. Many a farsighted purchase was made at that time, and the reputation of more than one English museum was much enhanced by acquisitions that came straight from Colnaghi's.

title: ANDRZEJ WADJA USES 'DANTON' TO EXAMINE THE WORKINGS OF REVOLUTION
description: Robert Goldberg is a New York-based freelance writer with a special interest in the arts.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NASSAU and Suffolk Counties are gearing for their annual influenza immunization programs. Suffolk is giving vaccinations against influenza and pneumococcal pneumonia through Nov. 5 at senior citizen and community centers. Nassau will give only influenza vaccine and its program will run from Oct. 28 through Dec. 7.

title: A TABLE RADIO CATERING TO THE MUSICALLY FASTIDIOUS
description: Heard any good radio lately? I don't mean a fancy stereo system, and I don't mean those shrill and shiny boxes lugged through city streets to add to the urban noise. No, I mean an honest radio - the kind that used to sit on the credenza or dining room table when people had credenzas and dining rooms. The very concept of such a radio is redolent with nostalgia, recalling memories - assuming you are sufficiently aged - of Franklin Roosevelt's fireside chats, Jack Benny, and on Saturday night Arturo Toscanini or Frank Sinatra, depending on your predilections.

title: YALE ENCOURAGING SCREENING TESTS TO FIND BIRTH DEFECTS
description: A GENETIC screening test is available to pregnant women in Connecticut that can help determine whether they are carrying a fetus with a neural tube (spine or brain) defect.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: HEMPSTEAD THE last time I sat in a stark, utilitarian room with young people while an instructor ran off a training film and then gave a lecture, not a few of us fell asleep and he would throw chalk at us. ''Wake that man up over there!''

title: U.S. PLANS BIG SPENDING INCREASE FOR MILITARY OPERATIONS IN SPACE
description: After a quarter-century of mostly peaceful exploration of space, the United States has begun a vast expansion of its military operations there.

title: MILTON BABBITT-JUGGLER OF STRICT SERIALISM AND POP
description: Next Sunday the Sequoia String Quartet, a Naumburg winner and the quartet-in-residence at California Institute of the Arts, will present the New York premiere of Milton Babbitt's Fifth String Quartet. Mr. Babbitt, known primarily as a formidable philosopher, father of the American serial school of composition, initiator - on an international scale - of the total organization of a musical work and recondite theorist whose abstruse prose bewilders friend and foe alike, spent much of his early life in pop music.

title: EUPHORIA OF BRITAIN'S NEW PARTY EBBS
description: Britain's fledgling Social Democratic Party ended its second annual conference today in modest spirits that contrasted sharply with the euphoric mood of a year ago.

title: AN ANGRY YOUNG BRITON OF THE 80'S BRINGS HIS PLAY TO NEW YORK
description: David Hare is tall, blond and smiling, the sort of ageless golden boy you can imagine striding with cricket bat and ball across the playing fields of the pukka school he did, in fact, attend as a teenager. But that elitist facade conceals perhaps the most original and arresting of the many left-wing young dramatists Britain has produced in recent years. As New York audiences will discover when ''Plenty'' opens Wednesday at the Public Theater, Mr. Hare is a writer profoundly and often eloquently at odds with the nation and class which gave him birth.

title:
THE MARKETPLACE;
BUSINESSES ACT TO INVOLVE MINORITY YOUTHS
description: AS bad as the record postwar unemployment rate has become, it is a lmost five times as bad for black youths. Now, with nearly one of e very two blacks between 16 and 20 on the unemployment rolls, a l arge number of the nation's businesses are refining strategies to b ring larger numbers of minority youths into the mainstream of the b usiness community. Some have provided jobs; others have focused on e ducation and training to make young people employable.

title: Judith A. Keefer, Architect Married
description: Judith A. Keefer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward B.C. Keefer of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Theodore A. Burtis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burtis of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Alan Ramirez performed the ceremony at the Brookville Reformed Church.

title: HOW A COMPANY LETS YOU KNOW YOU'RE WANTED
description: LOS ANGELES ROBERT G. MILNE joined the Atlantic Richfield Company 15 years ago as a data-processing analyst. Today, 11 jobs later, following ''very little in the way of formal career paths,'' he is the corporation's assistant controller.

title: U.S. GIVES ALLIES SOVIET TRADE PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration has given France, West Germany, Britain and Italy a draft proposal that could serve as the basis for lifting United States sanctions involving the Siberian pipeline, Administration trade officials reported today.

title: FLETCHER RETAINS HIS TITLE
description: Frank (The Animal) Fletcher, who said he ''started growing stronger when he started hurting me,'' bloodied and battered James (Hard Rock) Green to score a sixth-round knockout in defense of the United States Boxing Association middleweight title today.

title: WHAT AND WHO IS UP IN SPACE
description: SPACEWAR By David Ritchie. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: TWINS ARE FIANCES
description: Barbara Garnes of Pleasantville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Janine L. Garnes, to Joseph R. Casanova, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Casanova of the Bronx. Announcement has also been made of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Corneau of Bakersfield, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Coni N. Corneau, to the Future bridegroom's twin, Peter L. Casanova. Summer weddings are planned.

title: DEMOCRATS IN OHIO WOO DISENCHANTED DEFECTORS
description: Marcy Kaptur, the Democratic candidate for Congress here, was trying to stir up some enthusiasm in the small crowd. ''Come to my rally next week,'' she urged. ''We're serving kielbasi.''

title: PANEL TO MEDIATE RAIL DISPUTES
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. AN EMERGENCY panel began work last week to try to resolve contract disputes between railroad workers and the transportation agencies in Connecticut and New York that are preparing to take over Conrail commuter lines. But the need for the panel is being questioned by some union officials, who are concerned that the board may not be impartial.

title: A MATTER OF GOOD BREEDING
description: The Chinese have raised the simple act of rearing, preparing and serving duck to an art. In dozens of communes across the land, the plump and succulent Peking breed of duck is meticulously bred, fed and then forcefed until it offers the right proportion of tender meat and fat. As the Chinese grower's manual says, ducks are neither temperamental like turkeys nor individualistic like geese, but are properly docile creatures who "enjoy a quiet, collective life."

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: NEIL A.UPMEYER, former director of the state's Division of Elections, turned up a few surprises when he analyzed the results of the last five statewide elections for his ''1982 New Jersey Target Book.''

title: Elizabeth Whitman Married
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Sloan Whitman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Earle Whitman 3d of Devon, Pa., to John Studebaker Winder took place yesterday in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Richard W. Hess performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dodd Winder of New Haven and Peru, Vt.

title: BY WAY OF EXPLANATION; 3:00 A.M.
description: Is there anyone who hasn't awakened - bored, restless - at 3:00 in the morning? Who hasn't tottered to the kitchen, poured coffee or milk, sat down and thought?

title: WHO'S GOT THE PUMPKIN
description: SEVEN ways with a used pumpkin:

title: MANILA CRACKS DOWN ON 'SUBVERSIVE' PRIESTS
description: The Philippine military announced this week that a Roman Catholic priest had been arrested on the island of Samar after soldiers had found what were said to be subversive documents at the social action center he headed there.

title: TWO OLD TOWNS WITH NEW FACES
description: THE embers from Friday night's tailgate party had barely burned out when the next wave of Brewer fans squirted lighter fluid on the bricquets yesterday morning. The fans were just as resilient as the players.

title: Leftover Coins
description: To the Editor: Regarding the letter about those nonconvertible, leftover coins brought home from foreign lands (Travel, Aug. 29), my wife and I dispose of them in a way that we think is pleasant and practical.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS HIS ECONOMICS
description: While acknowledging more than ever before that unemployment was a major problem, President Reagan (right) said that his economic policies were attacking its root causes.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO STOCK THE LARDER FOR WINTER
description: FOR the serious vegetable grower who has a surplus of vegetables left at the end of the season, preservation or storage would seem to be preferable to abandoning them. Not only is it handy to have a larder filled with one's own produce to fall back on, but it is also likely that the quality of many vegetables will be superior to that obtained from produce markets.

title: SALUTE TO JUDY HOLLIDAY'S COMIC ART
description: Decked out in lurid glad rags and a platinum-meringue coiffure, she sashays around the set like someone kicked out of charm school after the first rhumba lesson. When trying to be refined, her voice is a stratospheric tremolo; when peeved or distracted, it's a meaty baritone with the treble knob turned to maximum.

title: Katherine K. Neuberger, 75; Ex-G.O.P. Committeewoman
description: Katherine K. Neuberger, a member of the New Jersey Board of Higher Education and a former member of the Republican National Committee, died Friday at Riverview Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: LEADER OF ARTS COUNCIL IS SUSPENDED IN JERSEY
description: The executive director of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts has been suspended without pay after being accused of trying to use state funds for photography lessons for former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne.

title: DANCE: ELINOR COLEMAN
description: Elinor Coleman seems interested in embellishing the moving body with fabric. Or perhaps it's embellishing fabric with the moving body. Whatever her artistic aims, the San Francisco-based choreographer remained safely on the unadventurous side of selfdescribed innovation in a performance of five dances Thursday at the Ohio Theater in SoHo.

title: Whose Park Is It, Anyway?
description: I have just finished reading ''Whose Park Is It, Anyway?'' (by Elizabeth Hawes, Sept. 5).

title:
DINING OUT;
A COUNTRIFED BISTRO IN BAYONNE
description: IT IS always heartening to learn of new restaurants being opened by enterprising young chefs and lovers of good food, and there seem to be more and more of them popping up around the state. A case in point, but in a most unlikely setting, is the Trilogy Cafe, which opened in Bayonne last November.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: IN THE GARDEN OF THE NORTH AMERICAN MARTYRS. By Tobias Wolff. (Ecco Press, $6.95.) These stories by an O.Henry Prize winner earned praise from a good many critics, including our reviewer, Le Anne Schreiber, who declared that they ''provoke our amazed appreciation.'' ''An Episode in the Life of Professor Brooke'' makes the extent of Mr. Wolff's talent most apparent, she said, adding that this 16-page story ''offers more complete satisfactions than most novels.''

title: BLACK HISTORY BEING REVISED IN ZIMBABWE
description: For decades, every schoolchild who grew up in this country, the former Rhodesia, learned that its history essentially began in 1855 when the Scottish explorer David Livingstone made his way to the great falls on the Zambezi River and named them after Queen Victoria.

title: LEHRMAN PLEDGES TO VETO NEW TAXES IF ELECTED
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for governor, said today that, if elected, he would veto any increase in taxes or fees approved by the State Legislature to close a budget gap.

title: Stephanie Halkias Wed
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday Stephanie Christine Halkias, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine John Halkias of Falmouth, Me., and Beirut, Lebanon, was married to Randall John Dalia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank John Dalia of New Orleans. The Rev. Robert Sullivan performed the ceremony. Mrs. Dalia and her husband received M.B.A. degrees from Tulane University. She is with the Chase Manhattan Bank and he with Price, Waterhouse & Company.

title: RETRAINING OF WORKERS BECOMES A PRIORITY
description: AT the age of 30, Brenda Harrison felt trapped. She lived with her t hree children in Washington, D.C., trying to make ends meet on the $ 12,000 a year she made from a job at the Veterans Administration, p reparing memorial certificates for the families of deceased soldiersa nd sailors. ''I was going to go nowhere,'' she said, ''It was just o ne of those dead-end jobs.''

title: A CON ED RETROFIT
description: With a chill autumn at hand and predictions of a hard winter to follow, the Consolidated Edison Company is about to open to the public an 80-year-old house in Bayside, Queens, that has been retrofitted with every practical conservation device and energyefficient appliances.

title:
ART;
MORE SCULPTURAL THAN ARCHITECTURAL
description: HEMPSTEAD IS it possible to think of Paris without the Eiffel Tower coming to mind? Built as an observatory for the 1889 Exposition, the engineering marvel, considered an eyesore by the taste-makers of the day, is now one of the world's most beloved monuments, summarizing the charm of an entire city in a single giant structure.

title: BEHIND EVERY SUCCESSFUL ROBOT IS A TECHNICIAN
description: THE robot, that blend of machine tool and computer built to perform t he most humdrum tasks with consistency, has become the key factor int he push toward the manless American factory. In the coming decade, a s companies in the United States forge ahead with computerized m anufacturing, the factory floor will take on ''Star Wars'' overtonesw ith batteries of robots, the so-called steel-collar workers, ' 'manning'' assembly lines.

title: PEDIATRICS NOW RANGES FROM BABIES TO TEEN-AGERS
description: COLIC and middle-ear infections still occupy the pediatrician, but this primary-care specialist's practice now often involves such matters as teen-age pregnancy, birth control, peer pressure, smoking and drugs. Why? Because, according to many pediatricians, this specialty has taken upon itself the vast responsibility of improving health care for adolescents.

title: CHAMBER: THE LASALLE
description: The LaSalle Quartet, which was formed by four Juilliard School students in 1949, has established itself as one of the most distinctive string quartets in the world, touring internationally and recording extensively. This season it is celebrating its 30th year in residency at the University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music. That anniversary prompted a concert Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall that was so excellent that in the future one will be happily willing to celebrate along with this quartet on any occasion it chooses, however parochial.

title: A $25,000 Reward Is Offered In the Theft of Two Paintings
description: A $25,000 reward is being offered for the recovery of two stolen oil paintings and the arrest of the thieves.

title: MARIO DEL MONACO, NOTED TENOR, DIES
description: Mario del Monaco, one of Italy's greatest tenors, died of a heart attack today, Italian news reports said. He was 67 years old.

title: GUNMAN FREES LAST OF 5 HOSTAGES AND SURRENDERS
description: A gunman holed up since Thursday in a basement room at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn ended his siege early yesterday with a live television broadcast and the peaceful release of the last of his five hostages.

title: WOMEN IN THE PRIESTHOOD
description: As one of the United Methodist Church's clergywomen, I thought that Marion Barthelme's article covered thoroughly and with sensitivity the wide range of issues associated with the entry of women into the ordained ministry.

title: ART OF THE WORLD, CREATURES OF THE DEEP; Journeys With Harvard Professors
description: Five trips to three continents are on the schedule in a series of tours being sponsored by Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum, one of the world's eminent teaching museums. Each of the tours offers the attraction of traveling with a renowned art historian, including curators and Harvard professors.

title: Jane Alyson Strauss Is Married on L.I.  To Lansing Reed Palmer, Lindsay Aide
description: Jane Alyson Strauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Strauss of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Lansing Reed Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Palmer of New York and Mount Desert Island, Me. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, the bridegroom's brother-in-law.

title: SOME WORKING TITLES
description: ARE you recently fired or generally burned out? A housewife returning to paid employment or a part-time assistant plumber looking for work in the Chicago area? Are you anxious about your resume writing, interviewing tactics, negotiating skills? Underemployed at your present job or undecided about what job you should look for in the first place? Well, there are countless books, specific and general, for what concerns you.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: Hot off the presses in Fairfield County this month are two new, almost identical monthly publications, aimed at the affluent, educated woman of the county, who, unlike women in the rest of the country, is still presumed to have not only a job but a well-paying one.

title: NEW ENGLAND
description: THE unemployment rate in New England mirrors the national average, b ut the region is still attractive to people seeking jobs in h ightechnology fields. The Boston area, with its many major u niversities and research centers, is the technology hub, but s outhern New Hampshire and Vermont have drawn some of the business.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE magnitude of the hazrdous-waste problem in New Jersey is evident in the many worried communities where dangerous substances have been found, at the meetings of dozens of ad hoc citizens' committees, on the agendas of established environmental groups and, perhaps most importantly, in the Legislature.

title:
COPRPORATE PHILANTHROPY;
A CASE FOR GIVING 2% OF PRETAX INCOME
description: CORPORATE profits continue to decline, unemployment is still on the i ncrease and legislative budget-cutting has affected a wide range of s ocial and public services.

title: STATE VOTERS' CHIEF CONCERN: JOBS
description: THE views of Connecticut residents on state fiscal matters illustrate why the General Assembly has so much trouble trying to put together a budget. The residents, as measured by a New York Times poll, do not want - by a wide margin - a state personal income tax.

title: 'COMPETITIVE STRATEGY,' NOT 'INDUSTRIAL POLICY'
description: ''Industrial policy'' may well be a buzz word in the 1984 Presidential campaign, for possible contenders as different as Edward M. Kennedy and former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally have already pressed the idea across the country as a solution to America's continuing economic woes.

title: QUOTATIONS FROM CHAIRMAN VOLCKER
description: THE following are excerpts from a press conference held by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, at the Business Council meeting Oct. 9, in Hot Springs, W. Va. The questions have been edited because of lapses in transcription. Mr. Volcker began the press conference with a statement.

title: Adam Ash Weds Laura N. Spence
description: Laura Newbold Spence, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald P. Spence of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Adam Miller Ash, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ash of Manhasset, L.I. Municipal Court Judge Sydney S. Souter of Princeton Township performed the ceremony at the former residence of Mrs. Harold Hochshild, a cousin of the bride.

title: THOMAS OBLIGES SIMMONS
description: When Gorman Thomas popped foul to the Cardinal catcher to start the seventh inning today, he continued a postseason struggle that had produced only three hits in 29 times at bat.

title: Son Born to Dryfooses
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ochs Dryfoos of Wilmington, N.C., on Oct. 2 in the New Hanover Memorial Hospital in Wilmington. The child, who has been named Robert Alexander, is a grandson of Mrs. Andrew Heiskell of New York and the late Orvil E. Dryfoos, who was publisher of The New York Times from 1961 to 1963, and a greatgrandson of Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger of New York and the late Mr. Sulzberger, who was chairman and publisher of The Times from 1935 to 1961. The child's mother, the former Mary Gertrude Racine, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Racine of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Time to Amend A Failed System
description: To the Sports Editor: I was pleased by the story concerning Kevin Ross (''Casualty of a Failed System,'' The New York Times, Oct. 3) and I'm sure I speak for many. It is about time that institutions take responsibility for the part they may play in an athlete's downfall, not just his or her accomplishments.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Iraq Reports Killing 60 Iranian Soldiers

title: BUCKNER IS EXPECTED TO GIVE THE CELTICS A BIG LIFT
description: Quinn Buckner became a Celtic last Sept. 10. But Boston's need for a point guard of his caliber had its roots four months earlier in Boston Garden.

title: Administration Plans a Wider War on Drugs
description: The Federal Government has been trying to do something about illegal narcotics since at least 1887, when Congress adopted restrictions on opium imports. But drug sales have climbed steadily, soaring in 1980 to an estimated $79 billion.

title:
DANCE;
A CHOREOGRAPHER EXPLORES LITURGY
description: AS a performing art, dance has witnessed a strong period of growth in the county the last few years. Less well known is the use of sacred dance in conjunction with religious liturgy and healing in the organized church. Carol Vassallo, a long-time county resident and former dancer, is pioneering the use of sacred dance in religous services in the county.

title: CRAFTS
description: CLINTON UNDER the deceptively unassuming title of ''Fiber 82,'' the Hunterdon Art Center has mounted an exhibition of works by seven women representing three generations of significant contemporary textiles.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: STATEN ISLAND TELEPORT IS SEEN AS A LINK TO FUTURE
description: TRENTON BORDEN R. PUTNAM, Commissioner of the state's new Department of Commerce and Economic Development, foresees satellite telecommunications as a principal component in a turnaround of New Jersey's economy.

title: FARMS SURVIVING IN DEVELOPED AREAS
description: SHOPPING centers and housing developments now stand where acre a fter cultivated acre once flourished, and suburban farmers are a lmost as rare as urban cowboys. But more than a few farms remain a ctive in largely developed areas.

title: 'AMADEUS' IN RED BANK
description: ''Amadeus,'' produced by its originators, the Royal Shakespeare Company, will be presented Saturday at the Monmouth Arts Center in Red Bank.

title: A Low Rating on The Environment
description: Ten environmentalist groups tied their sticks into a bundle last week and rapped the Reagan Administration for threatening the nation's ecology. ''Wherever you scratch the surface something disastrous is happening,'' said Jonathan Lash of the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: EUROPEAN SLUMP TUMBLES LEADERS LEFT AND RIGHT
description: It is clear now that the economy is the prime issue in next month's American elections, a fact European leaders can acknowledge grimly and say, ''Join the club.''

title: Bank Executive Weds Anita Elizabeth Alig
description: Anita Elizabeth Alig, a portfolio manager with the Manufacturers Bank & Trust Company, was married yesterday to Alain-Constantine Saman, a vice president of the European-American Bank & Trust Company in New York.

title: Miss Torres And Student Plan Nuptials
description: New York State Family Court Judge and Mrs. Frank Torres of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Analisa Nadine Torres, to Constantino Ramon Argimon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantino Argimon of Caracus, Venezuela.

title: A BOTTLE OF KETCHUP
description: A Bottle of Ketchup

title: PEKING FIRES ITS FIRST SUBMARINE-LAUNCHED MISSLE
description: China has successfully test-fired its first submarine-launched missile, the official New China News Agency reported tonight.

title:
CAMERA;
THE 'CORRECT' EXOSURE IS NOT ALWAYS THE BEST
WHEN COMPETITION IS ALSO A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: Diane Solway is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance.

title: PROSE AND POETRY
THE BLAME GAME
description: ''In recent weeks,'' President Reagan said on television the other night, ''a lot of people have been playing what I call 'The Blame Game.' The accusing finger has pointed in every direction of the compass, and a lot of time and hot air have been spent looking for scapegoats.''

title: No Headline
description: BALLESTEROS DEFEATS WADKINS

title: 'Bech Is Back'
description: SINCE 1970 Henry Bech has been one of John Updike's several alter egos. In ''Bech: A Book,'' Bech was the author of three novels and a miscellany and was beginning to find that leading the literary life was easier than writing. He was also a bachelor afraid to commit himself to marriage, and the fact that in this respect he was the opposite of Updike may have made him all the dearer to his creator. But in ''Bech Is Back'' his dry period has stretched to 13 years, and though the descriptions of poor Bech's collisions with rare book collectors, Third World cultural attaches and sexual hostesses in the Commonwealth countries may be funnier than ever, they are sadder. He is running out of stalling tactics. At last he relinquishes his timidities, marries his mistress, finishes a long-awaited, bestselling book called ''Think Big'' and exchanges his shyness for disillusion, thereby becoming a formidable literary figure. Henceforth if Bech gets into serious trouble he will be in the news, not merely quietly extinguished as a man or as an artist. And in accomplishing this ambiguously welcome transition, he is like Updike, which - though Updike evinces no undue interest in the books Bech writes -should keep him available for the future.

title: Boston
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE RACE FOR CONGRESS;
A CHALLENGE IN STRONGHOLD OF DEMOCRATS
description: IN past years when Herschel Klein was active in the political action committee of the company where he works, he grumbled about the troubles the Republicans seemed to have in finding a candidate to oppose the late Representative William R. Cotter, an entrenched Hartford Democrat.

title: POP: IGGY POP DOES NEW SONGS
description: Stripped to the waist and looking like a ravaged Peter Pan, Iggy Pop opened a three-night stand at the Peppermint Lounge Thursday with a wrenching, spasmodic performance. Mr. Pop's hunted-animal intensity matched his disturbing new songs, written with Rob DuPrey, the guitarist and keyboardist in his excellent backup quartet.

title: FACTORY CLOSINGS IN STATE SPUR CONCERN ABOUT JOBS
description: EVEN in Connecticut - a seeming oasis with 6.6 percent unemployment while the national rate is 10.1 percent -residents consider unemployment the most important problem in the state.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SALE OF LAND AT FORT TOTTEN
description: A Federal agency has recommended the sale of one-third of the land at Fort Totten, an Army installation in Bayside, Queens, according to city officials and community leaders. The base contains some of the last open spaces in the borough.

title: REVOLUTION WAS IN THE AIR
description: EL SALVADOR Central America in the New Cold War. Edited by Marvin E. Gettleman, Patrick Lacefield, Louis Menashe, David Mermelstein and Ronald Radosh. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Evergreen/Grove Press. Paper, $7.95. EL SALVADOR The Face of Revolution. By Robert Armstrong and Janet Shenk. Illustrated. 283 pp. Boston: South End Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $7.50. EL SALVADOR A Revolution Confronts the United States. By Cynthia Arnson. 118 pp. Washington, D.C.: Institute for Policy Studies. Paper, $5.95.

title: 'FREEZE' VOTE BEING SEEN AS INDICATOR
description: ALTHOUGH the nuclear-freeze referendum that will appear on the Nov. 2 ballot will have no legal force, its advocates see it as a sign of a powerful grass-roots movement that is certain to have an effect on Washington.

title: WHAT HAS GLENN GOULD LEFT US?
description: When Glenn Gould died the other day after a stroke at the age of 50, it occurred to me that many of his admirers could not have heard this phenomenal pianist play in person. They have had to base their judgment of his technical prowess and musicality on his records, simply because the Canadian eccentric stopped appearing in concerts and recitals nearly 20 years ago. As a result, it must be said with all regret, the legacy he left is tainted.

title: Giants Drop Bordley
description: Bill Bordley, who in 1978 was considered the best pitcher in college baseball after leading Southern California to the championship in the College World Series, has been given his unconditional release by the San Francisco Giants. Bordley, 24, won 26 games and lost only two in his final two years at U.S.C. But the left-hander developed arm trouble after two seasons in professional baseball and sat out the 1981 season after surgery. In a comeback attempt this season, he split 10 decisions in pitching for Fresno of the Class A California League. ... Ted Power, a right-handed pitcher, has been sold by the Los Angeles Dodgers to the Cincinnati Reds for cash. Power, 27, led the Pacific Coast League in 1981 with an 18-3 record, but in 1982 spent most of the season with Albuquerque, for which he compiled a 5-4 record with a 5.10 e.r.a.

title: A BAND FESTIVAL
description: ''WHEN high school bands play at football half times,'' says Naomi Lasher, secretary of the Ossining Music Parents' Association, ''half of the audience is out getting coffee or hot dogs. One of the best things about last year's Band Festival was that the crowd came purely for the music. It gave the kids an enormous boost, and I think it made both parents and youngsters more proud of what their school music programs have been able to accomplish.''

title: A QUESTION OF IDENTITY
description: The journalistic tradition in the matter of names depends on which side of the Atlantic you happen to be. American newspapers and their readers expect the winners of, say, a bridge tournament, to be listed as John Brown and David Smith, preferably with their home towns appended. European journalists are more casual and content to list Brown and Smith, without amplification, leaving the reader to guess which particular Brown and Smith are involved, and indeed whether they are male or female.

title: Miss Ward Has Bridal
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Margery Hill Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Ward Jr. of Centerville, Del., was married to James Mercer Garnett Jr., son of Mr. Garnett of New York and Jane Scott Garnett of Wilmington. The Rev. Albert P. Neilson performed the ceremony.

title: BOSTON
description: To the Editor:

title: ISSUES ARE THE OTHER SIDE OF THE COIN IN NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON REPUBLICANS in New Jersey opened their mail last week to find a desperate plea for help. ''My worst fears have now been realized,'' the letter read. ''I absolutely must raise over $250,000 in the next 14 days to pay for radio and television, or my campaign will stop dead in its tracks.''

title: Primary Residency
description: Question: I have been living in a rent-controlled apartment for the past 25 years. I have been unable to find work in my field in New York City and am thus forced to commute to work far enough from my apartment to have to rent a place to stay overnight for irregular periods of time. I am in New York City more than six months a year, vote here and pay city taxes. My apartment building recently changed hands. The new building owner has refused to accept my rent checks and maintains that I am illegally in my apartment because I have another residence. Does he have grounds to evict me? If not, what can I do to protect myself from eviction if I must leave the city for more than two or three days, or fall ill and must be hospitalized? ... D.W., Manhattan Answer: As long as your rent-controlled apartment is your primary residence, you can have other residences, take a round-the-world cruise or work in the touring company of a Broadway play. A spokesman for the Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance said that it was unlikely your landlord had grounds to evict you and that even if he did, he must begin an action to obtain a certificate of eviction. You must be given notice, so have someone watch your mail if you are out of town.

title: NEW ROCHELLE ENTICING ARTISTS TO USE ITS LOFTS
description: NEW ROCHELLE ''THE old joke went: If the 9:05 to New York ever stopped running, the covers of the country's most important magazines would not come out, because most of their important artists live in New Rochelle.''

title: CITY AND RESIDENTS AT ODDS ON RUPPERT RENEWAL
description: AS plans for the second and final phase of development on the f ourblock Ruppert Urban Renewal site on Manhattan's Upper East Side m ove through the last stages of New York City's labyrinthine review p rocess, community groups are at odds with the city over how densely p opulated the last undeveloped block should be.

title: SOMETHING HELPLESS THAT NEEDS HELP
description: ANGER By May Sarton. 223 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $12.95.

title: WASHINGTON
description: THE job picture doesn't look great. The nation's economy is still s truggling to find its way out of the second recession in three y ears, which has pushed the unemployment rate up to a post-World War I I record of 10.1 percent.

title: ISLANDERS CAPTURE 5TH VICTORY IN ROW
description: The Islanders won their fifth consecutive game tonight as they defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 4-1, in Nassau Coliseum. It was the first loss for the young Kings, who had won two games and tied two, but they won the respect of the Islanders for their tough, physical play.

title: COMPANY'S EMPLOYEES ARE URGED TO SERVE AS VOLUNTEERS
description: IN the past, companies traditionally showed their involvement in a community by having senior managers sit on boards of organizations and agencies. Now, employees at every level are being encouraged to serve as community volunteers.

title: ISLAND HEIGHTS SHOW OFFERS A CROSS-SECTION OF APPROACHES
description: ISLAND HEIGHTS THIS Ocean County community has the kind of evocative landscape that naturally draws artists to it. In fact, painters have been recording its lovely Victorian houses, its somnolent streets and its majestic views of Toms River for years.

title: Brandeis Names President
description: Evelyn E. Handler, a biologist and educational administrator, has been named president of Brandeis University. Dr. Handler, 49 years old, who has been president of the University of New Hampshire since 1980, was elected Thursday by the Brandeis Board of Trustees.

title: BY WAY OF EXPLANATION; Winner, Jim Thorpe
description: It was hardly a scandal that Jim Thorpe once got $60 a month for playing baseball. The true scandal is that for doing so, the grandees of the International Olympic Committee compelled him to return two gold medals he won in the 1912 Games.

title: CAM FELLA WINS MESSENGER STAKES
description: Cam Fella showed tonight why he deserves to be named pacer of the year. He equaled a track record in his elimination heat of the $259,578 Messenger Stakes, the third leg of the pacing triple crown, and went on to score a half-length victory in the final at Roosevelt Raceway.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO STOCK THE LARDER FOR WINTER
description: FOR the serious vegetable grower who has a surplus of vegetables left at the end of the season, preservation or storage would seem to be preferable to abandoning them. Not only is it handy to have a larder filled with one's own produce to fall back on, but it is also likely that the quality of many vegetables will be superior to that obtained from produce markets.

title: ODD THEORIES AND DEAD ENDS ARE PART OF TYLENOL INVESTIGATION
description: Who is the Tylenol murderer? For more than two weeks, a task force of 100 men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Illinois Department of Law Enforcement and suburban and city police departments have investigated clues, mulled over coincidences, run into dead ends, hypothesized and theorized, all in quest of the answer to the question.

title: THREE COMPOSERS WHO DREW INSPIRATION FROM THE SEASONS
description: From the beginnings of musical history, composers have been attempting to depict sonically the four seasons of the year. Our earliest extant musical seasons date back as far as Gregorian chants. We also know that seasonal songs were a part of Grecian culture. Many composers have offered their impressions of the cyclical nature of the earth. Examples come easily to mind, some of the more obvious being Mahler's ''Solitary in Autumn'' from ''The Song of the Earth,'' Schubert's song cycle ''Die Winterreise,'' Stravinsky's ''The Rite of Spring,'' and Delius's variety of summer works, as well as a myriad of popular songs of all stripe and quality.

title: COMPUTERS: WOMEN CATCH ON
description: THE arrival of the computer age was greeted with enthusiasm and hopeb y many women. It would be a new era free of the traditions, r estraints and discriminations that kept them down. No excuses here a bout size and upper-arm strength; no nonsense about sharing showers.

title: Bridgehampton Is Given Extra Laps
description: WITH so few race tracks in the Northeast, it has been sad to know that the sound of power mowers was going to replace the sound of racing engines at Long Island's only road course.

title: Vredeling
description: To the Business Editor: Greater transparency in the operations of multinationals is a stated objective of the European Community. Several legislative initiatives have been taken by the European Commission in an endeavor to achieve this goal. The ''Vredeling Proposal'' providing for the mandatory provision of information to and consultation with workers is part of this process.

title: AREA WRITERS TO GATHER
description: ''WRITERS in Westchester have particular needs,'' said Robert Reiser. ''There is more isolation here in the suburbs than in the city, and less opportunity for writers to get together.'' Mr. Reiser is one of the organizers of an all-day conference, entitled ''Writers in Crisis,'' to be held Saturday at the State University of New York at Purchase. He said he hoped it would be the beginning of future dialogues among the county's writers.

title: A SHOW FOR THE COUNTY'S 300TH BIRTHDAY
description: SCARSDALE FOR its 300th birthday, the county is getting a very nice present, indeed - an exhibition of its very own at the Scarsdale Historical Society, at 927 Post Road. The show, called ''A Celebration of Westchester,'' numbers nearly 60 items, roughly half of them paintings, the rest miscellaneous domestic artifacts, architectural ornaments and the like.

title: GALBRAITH REFLECTS ON VOTES AND MONEY
description: NEW ROCHELLE MANY in the crowd had gathered after a fund-raising dinner, not to watch basketball in the College of New Rochelle's gymnasium but to hear about arms buildups, vote buying, military expenditures and subverted democracy.

title: GREECE TO INSIST ON DEADLINE IN TALKS ON BASES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has issued a warning to the United States that if no agreement is reached on the American military bases in Greece within a specified time, the bases will have to go.

title: NURSING HOME BED SHORTAGE GROWS WITH NUMBER OF AGED
description: Health officials report a shortage of nursing home beds in many parts of the country, and they say that the problem will grow worse as the elderly population increases over the next few decades.

title: NEW FACES COMPETING NEW DISTRICTS
description: IN the three State Assembly races in northern Westchester, this is a year for new faces. With the area's two incumbent Assemblymen stepping down - one to retire from the Legislature and the other to seek a seat in Congress - the Assembly districts that cover northern Westchester and parts of adjacent counties are serving this year as battlegrounds for less-well-known aspirants.

title: THOMAS D. MACDOWELL TO MARRY SUSAN SHIEBLER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George L. Shiebler Jr. of Rockville Centre, L.I., of the engagement of theri daughter, Susan Anne Shiebler, to Thomas Dedd MacDowell of Littleton, Mass.

title: VENEZUELAN URGES U.S. ROLE IN GUYANA DISPUTE
description: A Venezuelan political leader says the United States has a ''moral responsibility'' to involve itself in finding a solution to the border dispute between Venezuela and neighboring Guyana.

title: Morgan in Spotlight For Bergen Catholic
description: Mike Morgan, a versatile junior tailback, scored three touchdowns and accounted for 168 of his team's 377 yards as Bergen Catholic downed Ridgewood, 34-7, today in Oradell.

title: 47TH STREET BLOCK RALLIES AGAINST PROSTITUTION
description: Most of the buildings on 47th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues are tenements. Some are newly renovated with potted flowers on the windowsills, and others are abandoned, their windows stuffed with cinder blocks.

title: ANXIOUS CONSIDERATIONS
description: A few weeks ago The New Yorker ran a cartoon in which a publisher is saying to a wild-eyed novelist, ''I'll level with you. Anger is bringing smaller and smaller advances.'' What he didn't say is that anxiety is what's selling these days. In fact, I was talking to a novelist whose latest book had been rejected by his publisher because it was deficient in anxiety. ''What sex was to the novel of the 60's,'' the publisher observed, ''or politics to the 30's, anxiety is to the 80's.''

title: DEVILS SET BACK PENGUINS
description: Hector Marini's third goal of the season with 38 seconds left gave the Devils a 6-5 triumph over the Penguins in the Civic Arena tonight. It was the seventh point in six games for the Devils, the best start in the history of the franchise, which moved to New Jersey this season from Colorado.

title: Lack of Doctor Brings Forfeit
description: The game was supposed to start at noon, and both teams were assembled at the Boys & Girls High School field in Brooklyn. There was only one element missing - the mandatory doctor.

title: International-Aid Organization Elects an Executive Director
description: Frank C. Kiehne has been elected the executive director of Private Agencies in International Development, a new organization that says it will seek to stimulate private assistance to underdeveloped countries.

title: Disarmament Has Its Own Rewards, Thanks to Nobel
description: Disarming an increasingly armed world may appear a hopeless task, but two toilers in that unpropitious field were rewarded last week for their persistence. Sharing the Nobel Peace Prize and $157,000 were Alva Myrdal of Sweden and Alfonso Garcia Robles of Mexico who, the Norwegian Nobel Committee said, have ''helped to open the eyes of the world to the threat mankind faces in continued nuclear armament.''

title: Jerri Sines Wed In Dallas Ritual To T. M. Mayer
description: Jerri Louise Sines, daughter of Mrs. Louis Playford Sines of Dallas and the late Mr. Sines, was married yesterday to Thomas Moers Mayer, son of Martin Mayer of New York and the late Mrs. Mayer. The Rev. James Garrett performed the ceremony at the University Park United Methodist Church in Dallas.

title: Suzuki Feels Bad Vibrations
description: Japanese politics, like gardens, are at their best when orderly and harmonious. So Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki apparently concluded last week in announcing a surprise decision to step down as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and thus as head of the Government.

title: 'GLOBE-TROTTERS' SETTLING DOWN
description: TARRYTOWN THE nomadic New Globe Theater has found a home here at the Music Hall - for a time. The organization, which was formed in 1973, started as a series of ''group readings'' in New York City and six years later evolved into a touring troupe that played engagements throughout New England, in the Middle West and on the East Coast. Nine months ago, two local bookings were announced - at the Music Hall and the Emelin Theater Library in Mamaroneck, but no one expected the company to take up residence in the area.

title: POETRY, NOT PILLS, EASE A PATIENT'S FEARS
description: HER name was Pat; we didn't get around to last names. She came into my hospital room the morning that I was to have a radical mastectomy. The operation was scheduled for 8 o'clock.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE By Barbara Delatiner; GREAT NECK SYMPHONY
description: With Ruth Laredo, the pianist, as soloist, the Great Neck Symphony opens its 38th season tonight. Miss Laredo, the first pianist to have recorded all of Rachmaninoff's solo works, will play that composer's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini,'' and the community orchestra, under Herbert Grossman's direction, will perform Dvorak's ''Carnival Overture,'' Queener's ''Pre-Classic Dance'' and Stravinsky's ''Suite From The Firebird.'' The concert is at 7:30 P.M. at the symphony's new performing site, the auditorium at Great Neck South Senior High School on Lakeville Road. For ticket information, call 482-9210. ISLAND SINGERS

title: A RIOT OF RANDOMNESS
description: DEADEYE DICK By Kurt Vonnegut. 240 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/ Seymour Lawrence. $14.95.

title: WOMEN FIND BAR TO BENCH A FAR JOURNEY
description: When the National Association of Women Judges was created in 1979, its founders expressed the hope that one day the group would prove obsolete. Since then, the organization has in fact taken some steps toward extinction.

title: Aircraft Ditches in Sea; Five on Board Missing
description: A large Colombian Air Force cargo plane with 13 persons aboard lost navigational control, missed Bermuda and ditched in rough seas in the Atlantic yesterday afternoon, the United States Coast Guard reported.

title: Women in the Priesthood
description: As a ministerial student at Harvard University and the former personal assistant to the Sub-Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, I read Marion Knox Barthelme's article ''A Woman's Life in the Priesthood'' (Sept. 5) with some interest - and a good deal of disappointment. I am surprised and angered by the subtle implication inherent in Mrs. Barthelme's writing.

title: PALMY DAYS OVER FOR A NAZI IN BOLIVIA
description: He has often be seen strolling down the street here, or sipping coffee in the late morning at the Cafe La Paz, where he sat at his favorite table, his back to the wall.

title:
OPINION;
WE MUST FILL THE GAPS IN SCHOOL BUDGETS
description: AMID wrangling between a Republican Governor and Democratic legislators, between taxes passing and taxes failing, between funds voted and funds vetoed, some major pieces of a ''basic'' state services program have been left out of New Jersey's current budget.

title: AN ITALIAN MENU WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: RIVA has been open for about a year in an upstairs location in Great Neck that previously housed two other restaurants for briefer tenancies. But Riva deserves a long run because it is certainly one of the better Italian restaurants in the area.

title: TASTY TUSCAN BREAD
description: Tu proverai si come sa di sale Lo pane altrui, e com'e duro calle L o scendere e il salir per l'altrui scale.

title: Spreading The Risk
description: Besides the sometimes self-defeating complexity of their design, nuclear power plants may also be plagued by a tendency to use employees like paper napkins. This potential shortcoming of the facilities is emphasized in a General Accounting Office report: As they age and require repair or modification, they expose more and more workers to higher radiation.

title: Union Wins a Defensive Struggle
description: Undefeated Union handed Plainfield its first loss, winning by 8-0 in a tight defensive game today in Plainfield. Union (4-0) took the opening kickoff 59 yards in 11 plays and scored on a 1-yard run by Keith Peace. Peace, a senior halfback, who ran eight times during the march for 45 yards, left the game in the second quarter after suffering an injury to his thigh. He has scored seven touchdowns this season. Plainfield (3-1) drove to the Union 9-yard line in the first half but lost the ball as time ran out. The Union defense was bolstered by Chris LaFragola, who had nine tackles, and by Quincy Brooks and Mark Caputo, who each had an interception.

title: NEW YORK: LOTS OF JOBS, BUT SKILLS ARE MISSING
description: THERE are more jobs available in the New York area right now than there have been in a long time, but f ew of them are for those who need them most: the thousands of u nskilled and undertrained workers left behind in the headlong f light of manufacturing from the metropolitan region.

title: Frankfurt
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
WICK FARM: REVOLUTION REMINDER
description: MORRISTOWN DURING the winter of 1779-1780, orderly rows of log huts and 10,000 Continental troops surrounded the small farmhouse of Henry Wick in Jockey Hollow, now a section of Morristown National Historical Park.

title: Flyers 4, Nordiques 3
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Bobby Clarke scored his first two goals of the season to help Philadelphia rally to its victory.

title: Glen Ridge Beaten
description: Carl Model returned a fumble 25 yards for a touchdown midway through the fourth quarter to pace Mountain Lakes to a 21-12 victory over Glen Ridge in Mountain Lakes.

title: CAMPUS DRINKING: 'CLOSE THE BARS'
description: Re: "Curbs Sought on Campus Drinking" Oct. 3: Stupidity is always irritating. Years ago, not that many years ago, alcoholic beverages were neither sold nor permitted on most college campuses.

title: THE MINIMAL HAZARDS OF NUCLEAR ENERGY
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING CO-OP LOANS
description: FOR as long as anyone can remember, it has been more difficult and m ore expensive to borrow money to buy a cooperative apartment than tob uy any other kind of home. Even in the best of times, co-op buyers h ave paid a higher mortgage interest rate - usually about 1 percent m ore - than buyers of condominiums and one- and two-family houses.

title: Filling the Void In Jakarta
description: The name of the American Ambassador to Jakarta was missing from the White House guest list last week when Indonesian President Suharto came to call. The embassy has been vacant for months, a vacuum filled by hurt feelings in Jakarta, the State Department and Congress and exacerbated by international character assassination and gossip about Mr. Suharto's friendships at the Central Intelligence Agency.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
WHO'S TO BLAME FOR THE ECONOMY?
description: WHY are we going through this immensely costly, painful and d angerous period of high unemployment rates? What caused it? If one listens to President Reagan, one hears the following story: T he Democrats, who have controlled the White House only four of the l ast 14 years, caused the inflation by their profligacy. Once the i nflation was under way, high unemployment rates followed, like the n ight the day. Untouched by human hands, one might say.

title: China Expects Grain Harvest To Surpass Record of 1979
description: China expects a record grain harvest this year, exceeding the 1979 record of 332.1 million tons, The China Daily reported today.

title:
INVESTING;
THE NEW STYLES IN SHORT SELLING
description: LAST week the Dow Jones industrial average reached 1,000 for the s ixth time in 17 years. In the past, a speculator who sold stock s hort whenever the Dow touched 1,000 would have made a lot of money. E ach time, the average subsequently fell at least 200 points.

title: Protesters Disrupt a Klan Rally in Boston
description: Police officers restraining man yesterday after fighting broke out at a Ku Klux Klan rally.

title: REPORTERS QUESTION STORY AT CLEVELAND PLAIN DEALER
description: Was the article on the front page of The Cleveland Plain Dealer last Sunday about a teamsters union vice president a retraction, or was it a news article about another development in a complicated case?

title: ST JOHN. THE BAPTIST BOWS
description: Mount St. Michael rallied to defeat St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., 30-26, yesterday in a Catholic High Schools Football League game, as Jimmy Spring scored the winning touchdown on a 24-yard run with 3:24 to play. It was Spring's second touchdown.

title: VOICES FROM THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: For more than a year a friend from work had been urging me to fix him up with a date. My problem -or, it seemed to me, his problem - was that his ideal woman sounded like a beautiful Boy Scout. Finally I complained that his unrealistic expectations were sexist to boot. He laughed. ''I'm not denying that. You find me a woman who's not a feminist, and we'll all be happy.''

title: No Headline
description: OHIO STATE BEATS ILLINOIS, 26-21

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Regardless of whatever success may have been attained on other stages in other cities, a New York debut still carried a special importance for a young artist. The late Glenn Gould used to refer somewhat disparagingly to New York as ''Debut Town''; a success won in Manhattan may have a disproportionate effect on future performances in other parts of the globe.

title: U.S. ORDERS SHIFT OF UPSTATE HYDROELECTRICITY
description: The Federal Government has ordered the State Power Authority to sell more cheap hydroelectric power to 51 municipal systems and less to three big upstate utilities.

title: CASTING ABOUT FOR THE CORPORATE ELITE
description: NOT long ago, the story unfolds, a hot candidate who had almost c linched the presidency of a conglomerate made a costly gaffe. T raveling to his final interview, he joined the pilot in the cockpit a nd started showing off with a series of disparaging cracks about t he company jet. A few hours later, the pilot told his next p assenger - the chief executive officer - that the prospect was a r eal wise guy.

title: JULIE ANN KAHN ENGAGED TO MICHAEL BRUCE KALNITZ
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Kahn of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Ann Kahn, to Michael Bruce Kalnitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kalnitz of Skokie, Ill.

title: IN LOVE WITH ALL THINGS MADE
description: THE ROMAN QUARRY And Other Sequences. By David Jones. Edited by Harman Grisewood and Rene Hague. 283 pp. New York: The Sheep Meadow Press. $27.50.THE LONG CONVERSATION A Memoir of David Jones. By William Blissett. Illustrated. 159 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.

title:
LEISURE;
IT'S TIME FOR INDOOR GARDENERS TO PLANT SPRING FLOWERS
description: Ursula Waldmeyer is a freelance writer.

title: NEW SERVICES FOR MENTAL PATIENTS
description: LEGISLATIVE and policy changes in the state in the last seven years have mandated that care of the mentally ill be provided in the least-restrictive environment possible. This approach, known as deinstitutionalization, has led to a greater emphasis on planning for the discharge of patients, to the development of an extended community-support system and to increasing concern for families of psychiatric patients.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRESH ITALIAN, FRESHLY MADE
description: IN Scotts Corners's attractive Colonial-style block of shops, Di Nardo's, a well-established neighborhood restaurant, turns out a competent pizza in the front room and serves more serious and expensive Italian cuisine in the rear dining areas. The items listed on the a la carte menu had a familiar ring. But, in fact, some of the dishes, far from familiar, were surprisingly contrived. Nevertheless, the food seemed to be fresh and freshly made. Choosing with care, diners could be assured of satisfying, well-cooked meals here if, in general, they avoid the tomato sauces - overcooked and blunt in flavor - and stick to simple preparations.

title: Nation Had Good Water Year, U.S. Geological Survey Finds
description: The United States completed a ''generally good'' water year on a wet note last month, the United States Geological Survey has reported.

title: PITT VICTOR OVER TEMPLE, 38-17
description: Wayne Hardin, Temple's football coach, said last Wednesday that Pitt's offense, Dan Marino in particular, was ''like a time bomb waiting to explode.''

title: Back is Disciplined
description: Richard Johnson, a senior running back who had scored three touchdowns and gained 243 yards in the first five games, did not accompany his Colorado teammates to their game yesterday against Oklahoma State.

title: The Lone Survivor
description: There is only one survivor from the University of San Francisco basketball team, whose varsity schedule was dropped this summer by college officials after disclosures of repeated violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: F.A.A. IN NEW TACK ON SAFETY SYSTEM
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has disclosed a basic change in its approach to the development and use of sophisticated airborne anticollision systems. It also announced plans to equip up to 19 airliners with the systems within two years to speed the accumulation of everyday experience.

title: EUROPE MARKET TALKS CENTERING ON POLAND AND TIES WITH U.S.
description: Common Market foreign ministers began two days of talks here today, with the discussions said to be concentrating on Poland and on strained relations between member nations and the United States.

title: Q&A WITH A CO-OP ADVISER
description: MARY ANN ROTHMAN is the administrator of the Council of New York C ooperatives, an organization that has a membership of almost 200 b uildings. On Saturday, the council, in conjunction, with the Real E state Institute, will sponsor an all-day cooperative housing c onference at New York University. The other day, Mrs. Rothman d iscussed some of the issues facing cooperatives and condominium a partments that will be covered in the workshops at the conference.

title: EUROPEAN DRAWINGS AT RUTGERS MUSEUM
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ANUMBER of important museum shows will be held in the Northeast this season, but few promise to be as prestigious as that now at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers.

title: P.L.O.-JORDAN LINK ASSAILED IN SYRIA
description: An authoritative Syrian newspaper aligned with the Government of President Hafez al-Assad today criticized the concept of a Palestinian-Jordanian federation. It also denounced Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, and King Hussein of Jordan, for discussing the concept in Amman this week.

title: Long Branch Wins, 20-17
description: Long Branch (4-0) scored a touchdown with just 42 seconds remaining and beat Red Bank Catholic, 20-17, today in Red Bank. Eric Johnson capped the 70-yard, 13-play drive with a 1-yard run.

title: Bayside Loses to Adams, 8-0
description: Bayside, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, has fallen on hard times. First it lost its star quarterback, Kevin Harmon, who underwent knee surgery after being injured last week. Now Bayside has lost its first league game, bowing by 8-0 to John Adams in Queens A Division play.

title: PERFORMERS: A NECESSARY EVIL
description: Anthony Burgess is a novelist, composer and critic.

title: U.S. VOWS TO HALT U.N. TIES IF ISRAEL IS DENIED ITS SEAT
description: The United States said today that it would withdraw from any United Nations organization, including the General Assembly, that voted to exclude Israel from participation.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO BITE WARSAW, FEED MOSCOW
description: President Reagan, angered over the ban on Solidarity, announced last weekend he was canceling normal tariff arrangements with Poland - the latest of several punitive actions this year limiting trade with Warsaw and Moscow. But six days later, although thousands of demonstrators had been beaten and tear-gassed in Polish cities in the meantime, Mr. Reagan made a further announcement on East-West trade: He offered to sell the Russians virtually all the American grain they could buy.

title: No Headline
description: An article in today's Connecticut Weekly, which appears in copies of The New York Times distributed in Connecticut, incorrectly describes the results of an opinion poll on the question of cutting services to avoid an income tax. Few of those polled said they wanted to cut services.

title: Randolph Sides, Ellen Walsh Wed
description: Ellen DeLury Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Walsh of Troy, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randolph Whitehouse Sides, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Sides of Mt. Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, assisted by the Rev. William C. Heffner of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mt. Kisco.

title: Canadiens Undergo Changes
description: A small boy no more than 4 years old, wearing a red Montreal warm-up jacket, tugged on Larry Robinson's pants leg as the all-star defenseman was leaving the rink after the Canadiens' noontime skate today. Josh wanted to know if Robinson would play against the Rangers tonight. Robinson explained that he couldn't, because he had hurt his shoulder.

title: Dr. Lynn Schackman Wed to Robert Wertheimer
description: Dr. Lynn Debra Schackman, daughter of Judith Schackman and the late Sidney Schackman of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Jay Wertheimer, son of Mrs. Abner Delman of New York and Dr. Lothar Wertheimer of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Judith Lewis performed the ceremony at Dr. and Mrs. Michael Handler's loft in SoHo.

title: Syracuse Judge's Ouster Is Urged by State Panel
description: Calling him an ''intemperate, biased partisan'' who often took the prosecution's side, a judicial panel has recommended that Judge Richard Sardino of Syracuse City Court be removed from office.

title: MIDDLE WEST
description: BECAUSE of the recession and rising unemployment - up 2 to 3 percent over last year in Middle Western states - it ish ard to forecast industry's need for workers in the region. Certain i ndustries, such as retailing and construction, are stalled but are e xpected to eventually make a moderate to strong comeback. The impacto f the recession and a switch in emphasis from manufacturing to s ervice industries is expected to have a greater effect on heavy i ndustrial states such as Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, than on o thers, such as Wisconsin.

title: ANDUJAR, HOBBLING, 7TH GAME PROSPECT
description: Joaquin Andujar, the leading casualty of the World Series, arrived at the ball park on crutches today and watched from the dugout as his team lost, 7-5. Before the game, Manager Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals said: ''I'd venture to say he could pitch a seventh game, if we have a seventh game.''

title: THEATER: 'A DOLL HOUSE' STAGED BY THE YALE REP
description: When we last saw Nora Helmer, in the outlandish Broadway musical ''A Doll's Life,'' she slammed the door - and turned into a Norwegian equivalent of Lola Montez. At the Yale Repertory Theater, we see Nora once again sequestered within her repressive marriage. However, if you want to know why she slammed that door, do not look to the Yale Rep for an answer.

title: OKRA:MUCILAGENOUS BUT MULTIUSEEFUL, MULTINATIONAL
description: OKRA, called lady fingers in India, where it is much beloved, is the central element in many African and Brazilian dishes and in the dark Creole gumbos of the South. It is a strange vegetable with a mucilagenous quality that is not loved by all. But I adore it, especially when it is stewed with onions and tomatoes or cooked with lamb as is done in North Africa. In Morocco they place okra and lamb with seasonings of garlic, cumin and coriander in a tajin, an earthenware pot with a large conical lid. They bake the pot in the oven and eat the stew with hot flat Moroccan bread dipped into the juices.

title: A NOVELIST'S NOVELIST
description: BECH IS BACK By John Updike. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: MALONE AND ERVING ON 76ERS: IS IT THE END OF FRUSTRATION?
description: HOUSTON IF it had been the climactic scene of a western, he would surely have been wearing a white hat and riding his aging but trusted steed as he returned to the place of past triumphs. Yet last Wednesday, when the former hero returned to where he had built his reputation as the most dominating center in professional basketball, Moses Malone was wearing blue and running. This time, he was one of the bad guys.

title: ON NAMIBIA, THE WAITING GETS LONGER
description: As a matter of diplomatic etiquette, American officials deny that there is any formal ''linkage'' between the perennial issue of independence for Namibia and Cuban withdrawal from neighboring Angola. But the two questions are tightly knotted and it's an open secret that the Reagan Administration tied the knot. The issue of Namibia - how to end South Africa's 67-year dominance over the vast, sparsely settled territory also known as South-West Africa - came first; when the United States accepted the proposition that the South African presence was illegal, the Portuguese were still firmly ruling Angola and Ronald Reagan had yet to be sworn in as California's Governor.

title: Peter Alexander Marries Anne Lyttleton Barnum
description: Anne Lyttleton Barnum, daughter of Anne Savage Barnum and William Milo Barnum, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter F. Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott F. Alexander of Belleair Bluffs, Fla., formerly of Greenwich. The Rev. James Kellaway performed the Episcopal ceremony at the former Ernest Thompson Seton estate in Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Brother of Guatemalan Chief Making Offer to Kidnappers
description: President Efrain Rios Montt's brother, Edgar Augusto, today offered to exchange himself for his kidnapped son, Jorge Mario Rios Munoz.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am not a madman.'' - Larry Van Dyke, shortly before he released his last hostage at a Brooklyn hospital.

title: MOLISSA FENLEY IS ENERGY IN MOTION
description: When a new personality appears on the already populated experimental dance scene and when a force of the whiplash variety is actually the hallmark of that dancer, one is quite naturally jolted into realizing there is something different here. And when Molissa Fenley, that 27-year-old dancer and choreographer tells you that she commonly runs a seven-minute mile, that she is a wind sprinter, that she is looking for a running coach and that her philosophical mentor is the British polymath, Colin Wilson, it is obvious that Miss Fenley is not in the same corner as her other ''New Dance'' colleagues.

title:
THE NATIONAL EMPLOYMENT OUTLOOK;
PACIFIC STATES
description: WITH the tides of economic recession in the Pacific region failing t o rise, the job market will continue to be rough going for all e xcept those equipped with highly specialized skills. Retrenchment i n the dominant aerospace, timber and high-technology industries is c reating damaging ripples in other manufacturing, retailing and s ervice areas that traditionally have provided most of the work.

title: Robyn Juback Is Married To Theodore W. Smalletz
description: At. St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Englewood, N.J., yesterday Robyn Grace-Ann Juback, daughter of Mrs. David Duchin of Fort Lee, N.J., and Cranston, R.I., and Robert Juback of Greensboro, N.C., was married to Theodore William Smalletz, son of Amelia Smalletz of Rockaway, N.J., and the late Samuel Smalletz. The Rev. James Boyce performed the ceremony.

title: SOAP BUBBLES GET A NEW ROLE IN OLD MATHEMATICS PROBLEM
description: ''A soap bubble,'' Mark Twain mused in a passage of ''The Innocents Abroad,'' ''is the most beautiful thing, and the most exquisite, in nature ... I wonder how much it would take to buy a soap bubble if there was only one in the world?''

title: Whalers 6, Canucks 5
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Pierre Larouche scored three goals and Ron Francis added five assists as Hartford gained its first victory of the season after two losses and two ties.

title: Sports of The Times; Cardinals' Willie McGee is Not 'E.T.'
description: FOR nearly six decades, the romance of the World Series for the St. Louis Cardinals has always glowed with some of baseball's most familiar nicknames. Bullet Bob Gibson. Stan The Man Musial. Country Slaughter. Harry The Cat Brecheen. Whitey Kurowski. Dizzy Dean. Pepper Martin. Ol' Pete Alexander. But a Cardinal in this World Series resents his nickname.

title: SEA CLIFF EYES CENTENNIAL
description: SEA CLIFF SPRUCING up for its 100th birthday celebration next year, the Village of Sea Cliff is building a new beach pavilion, and funds are available to restore commercial and residential structures.

title: REPORTS ON WASTE CONCERN WATERBURY
description: THERE was anger and frustration in this city last week, following disclosure of allegations by employees of a toxic-waste treatment company here that the concern had illegally buried or dumped dangerous chemicals into the Naugatuck River or the city's sewer system.

title: GREENWICH (5-0) BEATS NORWALK, 28-8
description: Greenwich ran its record to 5-0 with a 28-8 Fairfield County Conference Western Division victory over Norwalk. Greenwich is 2-0 in the Western Division, trailing McMahon (3-0).

title: POLAND: 'HYPOCRITICAL' U.S. REACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT'S BACKYARD AIRPORT
description: What do you give a special friend for her 65th birthday? Why, you invite her to your house for lunch, and then afterwards, head out back where your private airplane is waiting in the hanger that is attached to your house. Then you taxi out to the runway that is just behind your house, and fly off for a tour of the Statue of Liberty and other New York City high spots seen virtually eye-to-eye at 500 feet.

title: 'NO VACANCY' SIGNS UP IN REAL-ESTATE WORK
description: IN no area of the nation's economy have inflated interest rates had a more crippling effect than in the real-estate business, which helpst emper enthusiasm among those who have heard that fortunes can be m ade overnight in this field.

title: OPINION DIVIDED ON MILLSTONE 3
description: AS the Millstone 3 nuclear plant rises on the shore of Long Island Sound, its cost rises, too. And so does the controversy about whether it should be finished.

title: The Dirtiest War
description: It appears that about 300 men, women and children were slaughtered on July 17 in the remote Guatemalan village of San Francisco. Accounts of the massacre come from two survivors, interviewed separately in Mexico by our colleague Alan Riding. Perhaps they exaggerate when they say a Guatemalan soldier opened a child's stomach with a knife. But enough has happened to Guatemala to make such reports credible. And if the butchering of Indians bothers Guatemala's devout president, he manages wonderfully to hide his distress.

title: Canadiens Get 5 in 3d and Rout Rangers
description: Thirty-six seconds into the third period tonight, the Rangers had cut Montreal's lead to 3-2. But a nasty jolt awaited them.

title: DR. L.H. VINIS TO MARRY LUCY K. BROWN
description: Betsy Brown of Ossining, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lucy Katherine Brown, to Dr. Lawrence H. Vinis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack T. Vinis of Warrenton, Va.

title: Airport Parking
description: To the Editor: In reply to the question about long-term covered secured parking at Kennedy International Airport (''Q and A,'' Travel, Sept. 12), we wish to advise your readers that long-term parking under cover does exist at the airport. v. e at Park, Travel and Fly at Howard Johnson's directly across from Kennedy have such a facility at the lower level garage. Rates are $9 daily for a 24-hour period, which includes free transportation to and from the airline terminal of the driver's choice. RENEE SAVINO Queens

title: TED TURNER CHALLENGES TV NETWORKS
description: Ted Turner, the audacious cable entrepreneur and ultimate outsider, has the three major television networks over a barrel, and he could not be more delighted.

title: A BARRON'S COLLECTION OF 20TH-CENTURY MASTERS
description: THE United Technologies Corporation has been supporting the arts for only five years. But the range and quality of the exhibitions it has financed, in Hartford and other cities as well as abroad, have more than compensated for lost philanthrophic time. Ornamenting Wadsworth Atheneum through Nov. 28, the corporation's latest project is ''20th-Century Masters: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection,'' the sequel to an exhibition of old masters from the same collection that was circulated three years ago.

title: WOMEN IN THE PRIESTHOOD
description: The Episcopal Church has been unfair in seeming to encourage women to pursue the priesthood when, in fact, it cannot offer them holy orders which are accepted within the entire Anglican Communion. Confusion of sociological pressures of the moment with theological principles of the ages has laid a heavy burden on the shoulders of every Episcopalian, but no more heavy (I suspect) than on those women who find themselves ''all dressed up with no place to go.'' REV. THEODORE W. BEAN JR. Brooklyn, N.Y. ------

title: 27% OF JERSEY DRIVERS IN A POLL ADMIT DRINKING WHILE DRIVING
description: More than one in four New Jersey drivers admitted to drinking alcoholic beverages while driving, according to a poll released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: A RISING PIANIST AVOIDS 'INSTANT SUCCESS'
description: LONG BEACH FOR the young pianist Michael Boriskin, life on the concert stage is a series of three- or five-week national and European tours, punctuated by periods of intense study at his home here. It's a nomadic life, an ''if it's Tuesday, it must be Billings, Mont.,'' existence, but one he would not trade. For after almost 10 years of slowly building an international reputation as a soloist he feels he is on the brink of ''a major breakthrough.''

title: Index; International
description: Four conservatives enter contest for Japan's premiership 3 Squabbles plague Social Demo- cratic conference 3 150 countries mark World Food Day 4 Around the World 5 Catholic priest is charged with subversion in Philippines 6 Pacific islanders seek $500 mil- lion in damages from U.S. 7 Salvador guerrillas appear to be coordinating their attacks 8 Mexico to move Guatemalan refugees from tense border 9 Venezuelan calls for U.S. help in settling dispute with Guyana 10 Historians take new look at role of blacks in Zimbabwe 11 Canadians debate a bill to re- name nation's birthday 12 China reports successful test of submarine-launched missile 15 NATO diplomats plan strategy for Madrid parley 16 Syrian paper opposes P.L.O.-Jor- danian federation 18 Greece says talks on U.S. bases will be limited 21 Government/Politics Postponed project spurred a city's revival 30 Fear the greater threat, Presi- dent Reagan says 35 California gubernatorial candi- dates vie for middle of the road 36 Few surprises are expected in Senate elections 36 General Judge seeks unedited papers on draft registration prosecutions 23 Expert recalls evacuation plans for nuclear blasts 24 Around the Nation 28 Series boosts Milwaukee and St. Louis images 28 Few leads reported in slaying of bank official at Waldorf 45 Man charged in fatal Bronx ar- mored-car robbery 48 (1:4.) Health/Science E.P.A., citing health risks, says it will curb pesticide toxaphene 25 NASA develops an economy plan for close-up study of comet 61 For soap bubbles, new role in old mathematics problem 66 Education/Welfare Money is focus of college officials at parley 31 Arts/Entertainment Music debuts in review 72 Two films from 1981 New York Festival opening 72 ''The Fabulous 50's,'' Claude McNeal musical, opens 72 Adele Irving in Percy Grainger tribute 72 ''Doll's House'' at Yale Rep 73 Style Children of alcoholics: a troubled heritage 74 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines Soviet difficulties in Afghanistan 14

title: GETTING INFORMATION TO ASSESS A SCHOOL
description: There are no central offices set up specifically to provide home buyers with the information they need to assess a school or school district. Some real-estate brokers, aware of the interest in school quality, will introduce clients to local school officials and parentorganization leaders.

title: THE SOUTHWEST
description: THE jarring recession that has hit the oil industry has clouded whatu ntil recently seemed a bright outlook for geologists, petroleum e ngineers and other major occupations in the Southwest. Similarly, t he slump in the semiconductor industry has brought substantial l ayoffs in the Dallas area.

title: LOSING SLEEP OVER AIRPORT ISSUE
description: EAST FARMINGDALE ON Sept. 19 at 11 P.M., a curfew on night flights was imposed on Republic Airport. Twelve days later, the curfew was lifted by a Federal judge - and with it went the hope of many area residents that they might finally be able to coexist amicably with the facility.

title: 'ON BORROWED TIME' IS SIMPLE
description: ON the cover of the Hartford Stage Company program, there's a color reproduction of ''Corn'' (Grandma Moses, 1958). In the literal sense, the pastoral painting suits the play ''On Borrowed Time'' (Paul Osborn, 1938). In the sentimental sense, the name of the painting could just as well be the name of the play. The problem is that Mr. Osborn's work hasn't the freshness of real corn; even as a period piece, it's hardly digestible.

title: SUNDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball World Series: Brewers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, game five, at County Stadium, Milwaukee. The first-game starters, Mike Caldwell of Milwaukee and Bob Forsch, will oppose each other. Caldwell won the first meeting, 10-0. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 4 P.M.) Boxing James Broad vs. Danny Long, at Atlantic City, heavyweights, 10 rounds. Both are undefeated but unranked. Broad is 9-0 and Long 12-0. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Livingston Bramble vs. James (Bubba) Busceme, lightweights, 10 rounds. Bramble, from Passaic, N.J. is 12-1-1 and ranked eighth in the country by Ring Magazine.
