Busceme, from Beaumont, Tex., is 30-4, with 23 knockouts. He lost a World Boxing Council lightweight title fight to Alexis Arguello earlier this year. (Television - Channel 4, 1:30 P.M.).

title: HIS MEDALS RETURNED, HAS THE THORPE STORY ENDED?
description: IF legendary athletes were colors, Jim Thorpe would be dark gray. The careers of Jesse Owens and Babe Didrikson were the colors of sunlight, the bright sparkling flashes of a warm summer sun or the multi colors of a rainbow after a springtime rain. But Jim Thorpe's colors to me have always been the grays of an impending storm.

title: Thievery at Law
description: People victimized by dishonest lawyers had a fiscal remedy in New York State as of last March 19. They could file a claim with the State Clients' Security Fund for reimbursement of up to $25,000 of their losses.

title: Miss Reynolds Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Allis Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Parham Reynolds of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Thomas Patrick Mackell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Joseph Mackell of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Richard A. Brand performed the ceremony in the River Road Presbyterian Church.

title: Tappan Zee Triumphs By 22-20
description: Tappan Zee dealt Spring Valley its third straight P.S.A.L. loss - and fourth defeat over all - with a 22-20 victory. The Flying Dutchmen did all their scoring in the first half, on an 80-yard runback by Jim Johnson, a 6-yard rush by Jeff Slournoy and a pass from Pete Zonnevelg to Wendall Jackson.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS SUE THE U.S. FOR $500 MILLION
description: The residents of Enewetak atoll in the Marshall Islands have filed a lawsuit against the Federal Government for $500 million in damages, accusing the United States of neglect and broken promises after they were evacuated from their homeland in 1947 so that it could be used for a long series of nuclear weapons tests,

title: THE GROWING UP OF LILY SHIELDS
description: MY OLD SWEETHEART By Susanna Moore. 211 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95.

title: Wrong Identity
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE DETENTION OF JUVENILES: A POINT OF CRISIS AND SEPARATION
description: THE county has reached a crossroads in its treatment of juveniles who have been accused of crimes and who are held, while their cases are handled, in ''secure detention'' - what would be called jail if they were adults. This secure detention is, in fact, a period in limbo. Separated from family and home, in serious trouble and facing an unknown future, the young person is in a state of suspension. For most, it lasts for days or weeks, but for some it can last as long as a year.

title: West Islip Wins, 49-0
description: Undefeated West Islip and East Islip scored impressive League II victories to stay tied for first place with 3-0 records. They are 4-0 over all. West Islip routed Hauppauge, 49-0, and East Islip beat Half Hollow Hills, 38-0.

title: CRIME
description: For the last 10 years or so Tony Hillerman has been writing mysteries featuring Indian cops on reservations in New Mexico or Arizona. He takes his time on these books, and THE DARK WIND (Harper & Row, $12.95) is only the fifth of the series. This one features Jim Chee of the Navajo Tribal Police, who suddenly has a lot on his plate: a mutilated corpse, vandalism at a windmill, a plane crash in the desert, dead bodies and every indication that a big drug ring is operating in the area.

title: Susan Flansbaum, Nurse, Is Married to Gary Etkin
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue yesterday Susan Flansbaum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Flansbaum, was married to Gary Etkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Etkin.

title: WOMEN IN THE PRIESTHOOD
description: I noticed a recurrent theme of neutralization of difference in the article. I am not speaking of the macho fundamentalist's hang-ups over the difference between males and females, but of difference in a much broader sense.

title: Ethiopian Leaves Soviet
description: The Ethiopian leader Mengistu Haile Mariam left the Soviet Union today after five days of talks that were believed to have covered Soviet arms supplies to his country, the Tass press agency reported today.

title: MOUNTAIN STATES
description: AS recently as a year ago, the Rocky Mountain states were still a m agnet for job seekers from other parts of the country. But during 1 982, the area's booming mining and energy sector began to feel the e ffects of the nationwide slump. While still below the nationwide a verage, unemployment in the region shot up to record levels, r eaching more than 8 percent in Utah and Colorado, which is twice l ast year's rate.

title: A REVIVAL FOR FURNITURE
description: Furniture makers, after five depressed years, are predicting a major increase in industry shipments next year and the first half of 1984. They pin that hope on two factors: the higher consumer disposable income that is expected to accrue from the Federal income tax cuts, and the increased residential construction resulting from lower interest rates. Furniture sales are, of course, a direct beneficiary of new housing construction.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: CONNECTICUT is in the midst of a historic shift in employment, with a decline in traditional manufacturing industries and a rapid growth i n high-technology companies. The overall job picture is good for w orkers with the right skills. ''There are 58 firms in Connecticut n ow making fiber optics,'' said Anne Wingate, vice president of the C onnecticut Business and Industry Association, citing an example of af ield that is growing quickly. ''The really strong manufacturing in t he future probably will be in high-tech areas.'' Companies involved i n such advanced fields as robotics and biochemistry have also l ocated in Connecticut, she said.

title: ARTWORK?
description: According to Edward Larrabee Barnes, the architect, his design for the State University of New York campus at Purchase was ''necessarily institutional architecture.''

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey's economy is not mired as deeply in the r ecession as that of more industrialized states, it clearly has been l imping along all year and will probably continue to do so for s everal more months. Experts don't foresee a vigorous recovery until l ate next spring or early summer.

title: 'SORRY, NO EXPERIENCE' LINE BEGINS TO INCLUDE COMPUTER JOBS
description: YOU can't get a job unless you have experience, but you can't get e xperience unless you get a job, but you can't get a job unless you h ave experience ... This conundrum is almost as old as the job marketi tself - except in certain fields that are so new that experience s eems unimportant if not impossible to obtain.

title: REAPING INTELLIGENCE DOWN ON THE FARM
description: Despite President Reagan's offer last week to sell 23 million metric tons of American grain this year to the Soviet Union, which is facing its poorest wheat and corn harvest in seven years, the Agriculture Department predicts that Moscow isn't likely to import as much as it did last year.

title: CABARET: PATTI LUPONE SINGS
description: Patti LuPone, who has twice tried to build a cohesive cabaret act and failed, has moved tentatively in the right direction with the help of a new musical director, the guitarist and songwriter David Nichtern. And Thursday at the Bottom Line, where she opened a threenight engagement, Miss LuPone's successes almost balanced her failures.

title: Peter Halley Marries Caroline Stewart
description: Caroline Churchill Stewart, daughter of Mrs. Hampton P. Stewart and the late Mr. Stewart of Lakeland, La., was married yesterday to Peter Rudolph Halley, son of Mrs. Rudolph Halley and the late Mr. Halley. The Rev. Rufus J. Womble performed the ceremony at the Calvary Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Spending Cuts At Street Level
description: For many cities the ''new federalism'' looks a lot like the old short shrift. A study released last week by the United States Conference of Mayors found that the consolidation of Federal aid into block grants had shrunk funds available for human services programs while the need for them expanded.

title: ART IS THE ONLY TRUE THING IN LIFE
description: THE LETTERS OF GUSTAVE FLAUBERT 1857-1880 Selected, edited and translated by Francis Steegmuller. 309 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap/Harvard University Press. $15.

title: BEHIND THE FOOTBALL STRIKE: NEW QUESTIONS FOR LABOR
description: The professional football players strike, nearly four weeks old, is a confrontation over the use of new technology and workplace power, not just over money and a wage scale, some respected labor experts say.

title: Sewanhaka in Tie With Bethpage, 6-6
description: While undefeated Sewanhaka and Bethpage played to a 6-6 tie in the American League, both Hempstead and Garden City won to improve their positions in the league's Conference II-A and II-B races. Hempstead routed Wantagh, 38-0, and Garden City downed Mepham, 14-6.

title: REAGAN ROLLS WITH JOBLESS PUNCH, SWINGS BACK HARD
description: THE curve around which economic recovery lurks may be elusive. But that didn't stop President Reagan from mounting a personalized, televised appeal last week to ''stay the course.'' In gambling on voters' patience, Mr. Reagan has defied conventional political game plans. Few incumbent Presidents have so put their reputations on the line in off-year campaigns. But to White House aides, the risks of the strategy are far outweighed by the importance of preserving a friendly coalition in Congress. It is not that Mr. Reagan is unpopular, but that the recession all but guarantees Democratic gains that could jeopardize the Administration's aims. Since Labor Day, Mr. Reagan has been on the stump almost every week. When it was announced 10 days ago that unemployment rose to 10.1 percent in September, he only stepped up his drive.

title: Fleet of 150 Ready for Sound Invitational
description: A record fleet of 150 sailboats, including the leading East Coast and Canadian grand prix yachts, is expected to cross the starting line today on the western end of Long Island Sound in the opening of the three-day Long Island Sound Invitational Fall Series.

title: CAMDEN IS HOPEFUL ON FUTURE ROLE OF PORT
description: CAMDEN STRUGGLING like all other Atlantic Coast ports in the grip of a depressed economy, the South Jersey Port Corporation is turning to coal, once a king in the export market.

title: Phone Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: MORTGAGE ASSISTANCE
description: Andree Brooks's article ''Foreclosing on a Dream'' (Sept. 12) failed to note the special protections available to homeowners whose first mortgages are insured by the Federal Housing Administration, the Veterans Administration and some other Federal agencies. Lenders holding such mortgages are required to assist the borrower who cannot make his payments through no fault of his own.

title: FOR ENGINEERS, DIVERSIFICATION IS THE SPECIALTY MOST IN DEMAND
description: WHEN Robert Roy chose chemical engineering as his major at the M assachusetts Institute of Technology in 1978, he thought getting a j ob after graduation would be a snap. There was much discussion aboutt he critical shortage of engineers, and petroleum and pharmaceutical c ompanies, along with a wide range of other manufacturers, flocked tot he M.I.T. campus to woo new graduates in chemical engineering.

title: WHO'S MORE OLD-FASHIONED - STRAND OR ATGET?
description: Were it not for the dates staring us in the face, it would seem inconceivable that Paul Strand's abstractionist close-ups of automobile wheels, machine innards and porch shadows are of the same era as Eugene Atget's stately documents of Parisian storefronts and streets. For while the two men shared a taste for direct, unmanipulated photography, otherwise their pictures look radically different.

title: WHOSE PARK IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: No mention is made of one of the earliest wild inhabitants of Central Park.

title: 4 ENTER CONTEST TO BE JAPANESE PREMIER
description: Four top conservative politicians registered today as candidates for the presidency of the governing Liberal Democratic Party as a complex process proceeded to determine who will take over Japan's leadership after Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki's decision this week to resign.

title: Diogenes In Newark
description: What the prosecution failed to prove Newark's Mayor, Kenneth A. Gibson, knew shouldn't hurt him. So argued Mr. Gibson's lawyer last week in seeking to have charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office dismissed because witnesses couldn't - or wouldn't - tie the Mayor to a ''no show'' job he was accused of arranging for Michael A. Bontempo, a veteran city employee.

title: Walton Comes Back
description: Making his first appearance in a National Basketball Association game in more than two years, Bill Walton enjoyed a productive night for the San Diego Clippers in a 95-87 exhibition loss to the Phoenix Suns Friday night in San Diego. Walton, whose career has been bedeviled by an injury-prone left foot for four and a half years, scored 13 points and grabbed 10 rebounds in 26 minutes.

title: Oral Gold
description: To the Business Editor: Thomas J. Lueck's article, ''The Gold Bug Bites SmithKline (Sept.26), which concerned Ridaura, the new oral form of gold compound to be used in rheumatoid arthritis, has many inaccuracies.

title: Margaret E. Sherman Wed to T. J. Dewhurst
description: Margaret E. Sherman, daughter of John M. Sherman of Waltham, Mass., and the late Mrs. Sherman, was married yesterday to Terrence J. Dewhurst, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dewhurst of New York. The Rev. Donald W. McKinney performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn.

title: Danish Parliament Backs Economic Plan
description: The Danish Parliament approved the minority Government's tough economic package today, saving the country from the second general election in a year.

title: Maid Service Is Ended On Williams Campus
description: Maid service has been discontinued at Williams College, leaving students to vacuum and dust their own dormitory rooms.

title: MUSIC: GRANINGER BIRTHDAY
description: Because this year marks the centenary of Percy Grainger's birth, it was not unreasonable to hope that a significant assessment of his works might be forthcoming and that a representative sampling of them might surface in our concert halls. After all, it has been said that Grainger was an experimental composer ahead of his time.

title: ROY ELDRIDGE:JAZZ TRUMPETER FOR ALL DECADES
description: Roy Eldridge's feisty, crackling trumpet has been silent since he had a heart attack two years ago. At the age of 71, he now seems fit, vigorous and energetic but he has not resumed playing his horn since that illness. But if this has cut off the possibility of hearing Mr. Eldridge in person, it has finally inspired record producers to bring together the kind of overviews of his recorded work that have not been accorded to him before - the kind of collections that we have of the works of such jazz stars as Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Charlie Parker, Bix Beiderbecke, Jelly Roll Morton, Benny Goodman, Jack Teagarden and Woody Herman as well as Fletcher Henderson, Gene Krupa and Artie Shaw, in whose bands Mr. Eldridge played.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Bill Cosby to Temple U. Post
description: Bill Cosby, who dropped out of Temple University in his junior year to pursue a career as a comedian, was elected a trustee of the university this week at the board's annual meeting. The television star, who has promoted Temple throughout his acting career, will serve a four-year term on the 36-member board. He received a bachelor's degree in 1977 from Temple's School of Communications and Theater, after he had earned both master's and doctoral degrees in education from the University of Massachusetts.

title: Joseph S. Montgomery Marries Cecelia S. Congdon
description: Celia Sherman Congdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Congdon Jr. of Windemere, Fla., was married yesterday to Joseph Stephan Montgomery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Montgomery of Coshocton, Ohio. The Rev. J. Everett Bodge performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: CONCERT: MAHLER'S SIXTH
description: This week's three New York Philharmonic subscription concerts have introduced a conductor to Avery Fisher Hall audiences, Giuseppe Sinopoli. Mr. Sinopoli is an Italian who has made quite a stir both symphonically and operatically in the last four years. His biography bears a curious resemblance to that of Pierre Boulez, because both men came to conducting after establishing themselves as avant-garde composers.

title: A HUNGRY WORLD IS LOOKING TO US
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITALS STEP UP EFFORTS TO MAKE UP FOR FUND CUTS
description: Anumber of Long Island hospitals, facing severe cutbacks and in some instances elimination of federally financed service and research program grants, increasingly are looking elsewhere for supplemental financing, lobbying legislators for special appropriations and tapping resources in the private sector in order that programs be continued.

title: 3 HELD IN $250,000 MURDER PLOT
description: Three Queens men were arrested yesterday and charged with soliciting someone to kill an elderly woman while committing a burglary at her home, the Queens District Attorney's office said.

title: On Nastiness
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY has so far escaped the worst of the national r ecession, but cutbacks and job freezes by companies nervous about t he economy have reduced many employment opportunities, according to b usiness and education leaders. They are advising job seekers to p repare themselves for a more competitive market. ''Right now it's a t ight labor market,'' said Harold E. Vogt, president of the County C hamber of Commerce. ''Some of the employment opportunities have d ried up and the job search is going to become a much more difficult t ask than it's been in a long time.''

title: THE SPECTACLE OF 'CATS,'OR INFLATION BEYOND REASON
description: Imust say that those cats at the Winter Garden are making a spectacle of themselves. Indeed, it's the very best thing the sleekly coated creatures are prepared to do. We weren't precisely surprised, as we walked into the theater that had been extensively renovated as a resting-place for Andrew Lloyd Webber's fresh-from-London ''Cats,'' to note that the space once called a ''stage'' now spilled over its strangely missing apron to crawl upward and outward over the auditorium's balcony, boxes and even its celestial ceiling. We'd read about the rubbish heap that John Napier was designing to accommodate the prowling and the prancing of some 26 felines whose undulating tails and tigerishly striped legs Mr. Napier had also spent nights dreaming about. Yup, there it was, a somehow pinkish and prettified pileup of derelict automobiles, discarded copies of The New Yorker, overstretched bras (I think) and emptied-out cartons of Cat Chow. Just about as we'd imagined it, except for one thing. Its scale.

title: BOOM-AND-BUST THEORY SHINES LIKE NEW
description: In the midst of the Western world's economic plight and faint hopes for early recovery, what do the following have in common: the battle of Waterloo, the Vienna stock market crash of 1873, the ''Roaring 20's,'' the first oil price shock and Leviticus 25-10?

title: Deadeye Dick
description: ''DEADEYE DICK'' is the life story, told by himself, of one Rudolph Waltz, born in Midland City, Ohio, in 1932 and now residing in Portau-Prince, Haiti, where he's the chef and co-owner (with his older brother) of a well-known hotel. Like many other books from the pen that brought us ''Jailbird,'' ''Slapstick'' and ''Welcome to the Monkey House,'' it's a riot of randomness. At age 12 young Rudy, schoolboy, fires off an unaimed round from a rifle belonging to his father's gun collection and accidentally kills a pregnant woman named Eloise Metzger, who's vacuuming her living room several blocks away when hit. Jailed for the deed, both Rudy and his eccentric father are viciously beaten by the police. (The cops bathe Rudy in ink and display him in a cage to selected visitors, who are encouraged to punch him out a little: ''I was regional theater.'') Lawsuits from the bereaved Mr. Metzger ruin the Waltz family financially (Rudy's father is heir to a drugstore chain fortune), and Midland Cityites bestow a mocking nickname on Rudy - the nickname that gives this work its title.

title: Spain Formally Allows Plotter to Seek Election
description: The Board of Elections gave formal permission today to a rightist army officer to run for a seat in the Parliament, whose members he held hostage for 18 hours in a 1981 coup attempt.

title: Linda E. Chatman Wed to a Lawyer
description: Linda Ellen Chatman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Chatman of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday to Steuart Hill Thomsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stearns Thomsen of Baltimore and East Sullivan, Me. The Rev. Philip Watters and the Rev. C. Stephen Mann performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mendham, N.J.

title: Thorpe's Gold
description: It took Jim Thorpe one grueling week to triumph in the pentathlon and decathlon in the 1912 Olympics.

title: Unreal Conditions
description: To the Business Editor: Paul W. MacAvoy's argument for immediately deregulating natural gas, as espoused in ''The Time to Deregulate is Now'' (Sept.26), assumes unreal economic conditions.

title: THE CATSKILLS: NOT JUST HOTELS
description: LINDA CHARLTON is a writer who lives in Canaan, N.Y.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: THEATER Of the three Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals on Broadway, the longest running and most pretentious is ''Evita,'' which just entered its fourth year at the Broadway Theater. The show lacks credibility as a serious account of the Peron regime in Argentina, but it is a fine showcase for Mr. Lloyd Webber's skills as a tunesmith and for Harold Prince's inventiveness as a director.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Changing Images For Halloween

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NATO AIDES PLAN STRATEGY FOR MADRID POLICY
description: Diplomats from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have recently intensified their efforts to shape a common strategy for the Madrid conference on detente and human rights, which resumes next month. Their efforts are aimed at heading off another dispute between the United States and its Western European allies.

title: WHOSE PARK IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: The article on Central Park failed to mention an incident in the 1930's that might have changed the park's character. Around 1933, New York City faced a financial crisis so serious that it had to pay 6 percent interest for money on a three-year loan to tide it over.

title: A CHAT WITH A MASTER OF TELEVISED TALK
description: ''We went looking for Khrushchev and we couldn't find him,'' David Susskind said. ''He was in our office and then he was gone.'' Which was really too bad since any program celebrating the beginning of Mr. Susskind's 25th year in television broadcasting would surely have been enhanced by that familiar black-and-white kinescope of the late Russian premier having a wonderful time on American television.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS'S CHOICES
description: JAZZ Three years ago, the Duke Ellington Society asked David Chertok, the jazz film collector, to put together a program made up of film clips of Mr. Ellington and his musicians. This was conceived as a one-time event but it was received so enthusiastically that Mr. Chertok prepared another program the following year and still another last year.

title: E.P.A. PLANS TO CURB USE OF TOXAPHENE, A PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will restrict the use of toxaphene, which was once the most widely used pesticide in the country but has been identified as a possible cancer-causing substance, officials said today.

title: ATOM EVACUTAION PLAN RECALLED AT UTAH TRIAL
description: When the United States was considering building a second Panama Canal, in the early 1960's, the Atomic Energy Commission proposed making the excavation with 315 megatons of hydrogen bomb explosions. But the idea was scrapped because it would have meant evacuating 40,000 Central American Indians from fallout areas, an expert in the medical effects of physical phenomena says.

title: Setting Straight Thorpe's Record
description: To the Sports Editor: Jim Thorpe competed in ''two grueling competitions'' at the 1912 Olympic Games, as Gerald Eskenazi wrote in The New York Times (''Jim Thorpe's Olympic Medals Are Restored,'' Oct. 14).

title: A Matter of Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOLASTIC SPORTS RESTORED BY TOWN
description: A PUBLIC outcry in Somers has prompted the town's finance and school boards to restore the winter and spring interscholastic sports programs in the high school and middle school.

title: FOUR SENSES & IMAGINATION
description: VEDI By Ved Mehta. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.A FAMILY AFFAIR India Under Three Prime Ministers. By Ved Mehta. 166 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $14.95.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: 1953. A sequel to the author's ''Conflict and Crisis: The Presidency of Harry S. Truman, 1945-1948.''

title: Two Tracks To Albany
description: Perhaps the best thing that can be said for recession, as far as New Yorkers are concerned, is that it may make gubernatorial choices clearer on Election Day. Many political observers believe that conflicting fiscal approaches of the candidates are the sharpest in many years.

title: FOR MAGAZINES, A STRONG READERSHIP
description: The male special-interest magazine has been holding up relatively well, in circulation and advertising revenues, during the recession, Madison Avenue media experts report, and they predict that these more or less macho publications will continue to perform fairly well in the near future.

title: Zoos
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAREER DEVELOPMENT;
BROWSING FOR SOME LEADS TO JUST THE RIGHT JOB
description: IF you browse this fall in any well-stocked bookstore, you may feel o verwhelmed by the torrent of books attempting to show you how to f ind - or keep - a job. There are books for college seniors, books f or those over 40, books for career switchers, and books for those w ho have just been dismissed. There are books charting the rungs of t he executive ladder and books advising women how to go to work even i f ''your husband objects, your children are too young, and there's n othing you can do anyway.''

title: OLD-FASHIONED MOVIES ARE HERE TO STAY
description: Unless there is some sort of cataclysmic political or social upheaval, theatrical movies are not going to change much in the next 20, 30 or even 50 years. That is the message sent out regularly by the annual New York Film Festival, including the 20th, which wound up at Lincoln Center last Sunday night.

title: FINANCIAL PLANNERS ON RISE
description: IT is a career that was all but unknown a few years ago. Indeed, it is so new that the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the agency of the United States Department of Labor that keeps tab on such things, has published no information on it. Yet because of the growing number of investment alternatives and continuing changes in the tax laws, the field of financial planning has begun to blossom.

title: 3 Share Prize For Work on Prostaglandins
description: The Nobel Prize for medicine has been a rare feather in the European cap. But two Swedes and an Englishman won the award last week for their research on prostaglandins, hormones that affect a wide array of biological functions.

title: DEMOCRATS
description: Barbara Boxer says she wants to go to Congress to fight against Reaganomics and James Watt and for a nuclear freeze. Yet in this television state, that message has yet to get on television. She has come close to falling victim to the Democrats' biggest problems in House races this year, their lack of money.

title: No Headline
description: Israeli Soldier Is Injured In Clash With Syrians

title: No Headline
description: JUDGE CHASTISES U.S. IN A DRAFT REGISTRATION CASE

title: JURY HEARING SUIT BY PARENTS TO WIN DAMAGES FROM KILLER
description: A jury in Manhattan is hearing testimony in an unusual case involving a lawsuit to collect damages from the convicted killer of Bonnie Joan Garland, a 20-year-old Yale University music student who was slain five years ago.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW CHRISTMAS ISSUES STICK TO TRADITION
description: In line with forecasts for one of the coldest winters of the century, there is a white Christmas pictured on four of the 20-cent stamps the United States is putting out for the holiday. Another shows a traditional Madonna and Child which is outstanding in the warmth of its color and treatment.

title: MAKING IT IN WASHINGTON, AND NOT
description: IN THE CITY OF FEAR By Ward Just. 291 pp. New York: The Viking Press.$14.95.

title: Stacy Krestal Engaged
description: Mrs. Lawrence E. Krestal of Overbrook Hills, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Stacy J. Krestal, to Eliot D. Weinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weinman of Bayside, Queens. Miss Krestal is the daughter also of the late Mr. Krestal. A summer wedding is planned.

title: MONEY IS KEY ISSUE AT COLLEGE PARLEY
description: Among more than 1,000 college presidents and other educators, gathered here for the annual meeting of the American Council on Education, the most conspicuous figure was a five-foot mechanical robot.

title: Sikhs Take Over 5 Jails After Rejecting Freedom
description: Tens of thousands of Sikh prisoners who had been ordered freed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi refused to leave their jails in the northern state of Punjab today and seized control of at least five prisons, reports from the area said.

title: THEATRICS AND THE LAW
description: CLINGING TO THE WRECKAGE A Part of Life. By John Mortimer. Illustrated. 200 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $12.95.

title: NORTHERN SHOVELER; Anas clypeata
description: Size: 17 to 20 inches. Color: Male (shown), iridescent green head and neck; breast and tail white, with lower breast and belly chestnut; back and below tail greenish-black.

title: MEXICANS TO SHIFT GUATEMALA EXILES
description: Mexico has decided to start moving refugees away from camps on its border with Guatemala in the hope of discouraging the Guatemalan Army from making new incursions into Mexican territory in pursuit of suspected guerrillas, according to senior Mexican officials.

title: Ralph Brown 3d, Sharon McIntire Wed in New York
description: Sharon Lynn McIntire, daughter of Rita I. McIntire of Westport, Conn., and the late Russell McIntire, was married yesterday to Ralph Manning Brown 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown Jr. of Princeton, N.J. Bishop John B. Coburn of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts and the Rev. Judith T. Baumer performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Pulitzer Deadline

title: LED FURNITURE CONCERN
description: Delmar L. Kroehler, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Kroehler Manufacturing Company, died Thursday in the Hinsdale Sanitarium and Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Taking a Plunge On Prudhoe Oil
description: The major oil companies bellied up to the Interior Department's groaning board last week and offered $2.1 billion for drilling rights in the Diapir field of Alaska's Prudhoe Bay. Despite the current slump in the world oil market, they showed their eagerness to risk $100 million per well in the new leasing area, where an estimated 2.36 billion barrels of oil could produce revenues of $80 billion.

title: LEBANESE TIME BOMBS: ARMED FACTIONS AND FOREIGN FORCES
description: The ''Palestinian question'' is not just crucial to Israel. It is for Arabs too, as Yasir Arafat was pointedly reminded in diplomatic sparring with Jordan and Syria last week. And in Lebanon, Palestinians continued to weigh heavily among the political and military headaches deciding the future of a shaky new government.

title:
FASHION;
PARIS: HOURGLASS FIGURING
description: Ask French ready-to-wear designers what they are up to for spring summer 1982 and they tend to reach for a pencil. The silhouette they sketch is shaped like an hourglass, as they mumble: "appuye, souligne" ("lean on it, underline it"). The "it" being the waist.

title: WORLD SERIES PROVING TO BE A SHOT IN THE ARM FOR MILWAUKEE AND ST.  LOUIS
description: It is a most unusual scene for an orderly city, seldom given to outpourings of emotion even in good times. Shop windows are cluttered with ''Go Brewers'' placards. Banners abound on city light fixtures. Telephone operators answer calls with ''Home of the Brewers,'' and motorists drive through the city blaring their horns, the way New York City cab drivers do every day.

title:
PAPERBACK TALK;
Information Update
description: An all-day workshop on electronic publishing is scheduled to launch the annual meeting of the American Society for Information Science in Columbus, Ohio, today, and computerized access to information is a subject that will arise again as the convention progresses. But reports from giant national bookstore chains indicate that people still like deriving data from books.

title: EXHIBITS AT LIBRARIES: A DIFFERENT VIEW
description: I was disappointed to read Helen A. Harrison's article, "Library Art Exhibits: Too Often the Poor Relative" Sept. 26. It is true that many libraries are not suitable for art exhibits, but regarding the Bryant Library, I found an entirely different experience.

title: NEW REALITIES, OLD ENMITIES SHAKE UP ARAB ALIGNMENTS
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's Middle East peace initiative is becoming the focal point of a new alignment of moderate Arab states now taking shape. It is an alignment which, if its participants - Jordan, Egypt and Saudi Arabia - have their way, will eventually include the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Brushfire Battled Near Site Of Nuclear Plant in California
description: About 150 firefighters responded to a call to combat a brushfire that moved near the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant tonight.

title: PEWS INTO LOFTS
description: Jeffrey Rodman concedes that the rents sound high, especially considering that the building is not in the swankiest part of Manhattan. But, says Mr. Rodman, whose company, J. Rodman Realty, is the exclusive rental agent for the former synagogue at 257 West 93d Street, the owners intended originally to sell the apartments, and therefore ''put a lot more into it'' than goes into the usual rental building.

title: SENATORS EXAMINE HOPE CREEK
description: TRENTON PUBLICITY surrounding charges that Joseph Rodriguez, the state's Public Advocate, ''gave away the store'' when he signed the controversial Hope Creek I cost-containment agreement may give activists another crack at having muscle put into what they call a weak attempt to impose controls on the nuclear project.

title: Beryl Dickler Is Bride Of Roger John Leifer
description: Beryl Dickler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dickler of New York, was married yesterday to Roger John Leifer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Leifer, also of New York. Rabbi Irving Block performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: MARRIOTT MAY GAIN PLAYLAND EXTENSION
description: WHITE PLAINS COUNTY Executive Alfred B. DelBello and members of the Board of Legislators indicated last week that they would extend for one year the current contract with the Marriott Corporation to operate Playland Amusement Park, rather than decide now on various options regarding the park's long-term management.

title: LONG ISLAND
description: CAREER prospects on Long Island remain brightest for job seekers w ith technical backgrounds. Despite the recession most of Long I sland's defense-related and computer industries have continued to h ire new employees, and the growth in those fields has fueled smallerh igh-technology companies that serve as subcontractors.

title: THE NEW, HIGH-RATE BANK ACCOUNT
description: COMING soon at a bank near you: new opportunities to save money at t he highest interest rates the market has to offer at no risk to you.T he ads could be worded this way. But the promise is exactly what is i ntended in a new Government law intended to make banks and savings a nd loan associations competitive with their old nemesis, the m oneymarket funds.

title: Jill Paslow Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paskow of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Paslow, to John Frezados of New York and Athens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Frezados of Athens. A December wedding is planned.

title: Seton Hall Is Victor
description: Seton Hall Prep evened its record at 2-2 with a 24-0 victory against East Orange (1-3) in South Orange. Semos Gardner led the way with touchdown runs of 6 and 2 yards in the first half. John Stephens, a junior quarterback, took over in the second half with touchdown passes of 35 and 40 yards to Ray Guzzi. Stephens completed 6 of 9 passes for 150 yards as Seton Hall had a total offense of 300 yards.

title:
OPINION;
A LOOPHOLE IN THE STATE'S CRIMINAL CODE
description: IN 1979, the state's new Criminal Code went into effect. At the time, it was discovered that the section of the code dealing with sexual consent contained a terrible loophole.

title: Some Bus Stops
description: To the Business Editor: As chairman of the not-for-profit Scarsdale/Hartsdale V.I.P. Commuter (Bus) Association, I was interested in your article, ''And Now It's the Buses' Turn'' (Oct.3), which discussed the move to deregulate bus routes in the nation.

title: Singapore Piracy
description: Pirates, using the ancient tools of buccaneers - grappling hooks and long knives - were attacking vessels off Singapore and robbing crew members of cash and personal effects. As the total of reported incidents rose to 29 last year, the Maritime Administration in Washington issued a special advisory on Sept. 25.

title: FOR A P.L.O. INQUIRY
description: Once again Jews attending a synagogue have been the targets of an attempted massacre. This time it was in Rome. Before that it was Paris and Brussels. This time a 2-year-old baby was murdered and his 4-year-old brother -along with 36 other people - were hurt. As usual, the Palestine Liberation Organization has denied complicity. But complicity - as the world was quick to remind Israel after the Beirut massacre - is a complex and multifaceted concept.

title: CLOSE RACES SEEN FOR STATE SENATE
description: NEARLY two-thirds of Long Island's nine State Senate seats could be involved in close contests in next month's election, according to Democratic and Republican leaders.

title: '. . . But to Banish Halloween?-Never!'
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICER KILLS YOUTH MENACING WOMAN ON EAST SIDE
description: A plainclothes police officer shot and killed one of three youths who were menacing a 30-year-old woman Friday night in the courtyard of her apartment building on the Upper East Side, the police said yesterday.

title: ADULT-EDUCATION COURSES TAP A NEW MARKET
description: Thousands of New Yorkers are delving into a wide assortment of inexpensive adult-education courses offered by a half-dozen unaccredited, aggressive entrepreneurs. Subjects once considered esoteric - learning how to make sushi, fly balloons and meet lovers -have become commonplace.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: After traveling for many weeks in Japan, I find that it is the West that is inscrutable. Why, for example, do we always fumble in a restaurant for a 15 percent tip whether the service is excellent or mediocre? The Japanese simply add 10 percent to the bill.

title: Manchester United Ties And Extends Its Lead
description: Manchester United played a scoreless tie with Liverpool today and extended its lead at the top of the English League First Division soccer standing to 2 points.

title: KEEPING OUR TROOPS IN EUROPE
description: When President Reagan met with then Chancellor Helmut Schmidt during his trip to Europe last June, he complained about the peace demonstrations that had been taking place in West Germany over the previous year. Mr. Schmidt responded that Mr. Reagan should be glad that the Germans, who were marching for war 40 years ago, were now marching for peace. While the reply did not make much of an impact on either the Reagan Administration or the American public, it should have.

title:
CORPORATE PHILANTHROPY;
CHARITY AND BUSINESS SHOULDN'T MIX
description: TAKEN literally, the phrase ''corporate philanthropy'' is an o xymoron, i.e., a contradiction in terms. Philanthropy, properly u nderstood, is the voluntary sharing by an individual of his worldly g oods, in whatever degree, with those of his fellow creatures who arel ess fortunately circumstanced than he is.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO STOCK THE LARDER FOR WINTER
description: FOR the serious vegetable grower who has a surplus of vegetables left at the end of the season, preservation or storage would seem to be preferable to abandoning them. Not only is it handy to have a larder filled with one's own produce to fall back on, but it is also likely that the quality of many vegetables will be superior to that obtained from produce markets.

title: Maura Flynn Married To Andrew E. Pratt
description: Maura Elizabeth Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Flynn of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Andrew Emmet Pratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Pratt of Westport, Conn. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: COUNSELING OFFERED TO POLICE OFFICERS
description: PROGRAMS that offer counseling to police officers with emotional problems have been available in New York City and Philadelphia since the early 1970's. Now, New Jersey police departments are providing this aid.

title: TAXES ARE RISING AT THE LOCAL LEVEL
description: BECAUSE of cuts in State and Federal aid, rising expenses, deteriorating public facilities and no lessening in the demand for services, Long Island residents can expect to be paying more taxes at the local level.

title: Army Boxer, 19, Dies After Injuries in Bout
description: Despite protective headgear, a 19-year-old Army boxer has died of injuries he suffered during a tournament bout Oct. 9.

title: Susan Eschweiler Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Quintus Eschweiler of Pleasantville, N.Y., and Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Marie Eschweiler, to John Michael Rivlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Samuel Rivlin of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: No Headline
description: Tennessee Surprises Alabama By 35-28

title: Guerra Breaks a Leg In Spill at Santa Anita
description: Walter Guerra, one of the nation's top 10 riders in earnings, broke his left leg in a spill during the second race at Santa Anita today.

title: A DROP IN PRODUCER PRICES FOR SEPTEMBER
description: Producer prices declined in September at an annual rate of 1.7 percent, largely because of a sharp 6.3 percent drop in car prices as dealers tried to clear inventory to make room for 1983 models, the Labor Department said. Industrial production also fell, for the 12th time in 14 months. It slipped 0.6 percent last month, the largest drop since May.

title: BYRAM HILLS ADOPTS NEW SCHOOL PLAN
description: DESPITE some very vocal opposition from parents, the Byram Hills School Board voted unanimously last Tuesday to reorganize the district's elementary schools to better utilize space and equipment because of declining enrollment.

title:
CAREER DEVELOPMENT;
COUNSELING CENTERS: NOT FOR WOMEN ONLY
description: AYEAR ago, 31-year-old Bill Tally resigned from his job as in-house c ounsel for a chemical company. ''After six years of practicing l aw,'' he said, ''I decided I couldn't stand my job or the professiona day longer.''

title: FILMS: FROM '81 FESTIVAL, 'MURALS' AND 'EMOTION'
description: ''Mural Murals'' and ''Documenteur: An Emotion Picture'' were shown at the 1981 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 2, 1981. The films can be seen today in the main theater of the Bleecker Street Cinema and from Wednesday to Oct. 26 in the Agee Room of the Bleecker:

title: 150 NATIONS MARKING SECOND WORLD FOOD DAY
description: The second annual World Food Day, sponsored by the Department of Agriculture, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and 262 private voluntary organizations, was observed today in 150 countries.

title: HOT TUB PLAN STIRS DISPUTE IN COLLEGE TOWN
description: One can get a drink, watch topless dancers and get a massage on the strip that borders the University of Maryland, but as for hot tubs, some townspeople say things have gone too far.

title: Norway
description: To the Editor: The article ''Farm Visit in the Land of Fjords'' (Travel, Aug. 22) brought back many happy memories. Over 10 years ago my husband, Bruce Vanacour, and I also lived and worked on a Norwegian farm, but in the northern country above the Arctic Circle.

title: 'Friend of Animals' Draws Double Criticism
description: Being a ''friend of animals'' does not mean that one must assume a viewpoint verging on paranoia concerning innovative approaches to achieve protection for open lands.

title: OKRA: MUCILAGENOUS BUT MULTIUSEFUL, MULTINATIONAL
description: OKRA, called lady fingers in India, where it is much beloved, is the central element in many African and Brazilian dishes and in the dark Creole gumbos of the South. It is a strange vegetable with a mucilagenous quality that is not loved by all. But I adore it, especially when it is stewed with onions and tomatoes or cooked with lamb as is done in North Africa. In Morocco they place okra and lamb with seasonings of garlic, cumin and coriander in a tajin, an earthenware pot with a large conical lid. They bake the pot in the oven and eat the stew with hot flat Moroccan bread dipped into the juices.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW DIRECTOR SPEEDS GRADING SERVICE
description: Not so many months ago grading was the subject of a red-hot controversy between coin dealers in general and the American Numismatic Association. Much of the heat has dissipated since then - thanks, in large measure, to the efforts of Kenneth E. Bressett, the man who took over on Aug. 1 as director of the ANA Certification Service, the agency that authenticates coins and grades them.

title: LEBANESE ARMY REPORTEDLY KILLS 4 MOSLEMS AT SHANTYTOWN PROTEST
description: Lebanese Army soldiers opened fire on a group of Moslems protesting the leveling of illegal squatter dwellings, and at least four of the demonstrators were reported killed.

title: 'Monolithos'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW ATOMIC POWER COSTS JUST GREW
description: When nuclear engineers at Northeast Utilities set out to design a second power station for Millstone Point, the Ayatollah Khomeini wasn't factored into their calculations of how much the plant would cost or how much it might save consumers. But the Iranian revolution was easily the most significant event in the Millstone 2's economics, raising the price of oil so high that overnight the output of the plant became a bargain.

title:
MAILBAG;
MUSICAL QUALITY IN TOLEDO
description: To the Editor:$

title: DEMOCRATIC VISTAS
CAPITAL'S EFFORT TO BECOME 51st STATE IN PERIL
description: The District of Columbia's effort to become the 51st state has suffered a major psychological setback on the brink of a popular referendum.

title: CASE IN BEHALF OF RETARDED MAY DEFINE THEIR RIGHTS
description: IN the 19th century, there were institutions for orphans, poor people and the mentally retarded, but after decades of social change, two of those groups have found their way back into the community: the orphans through adoption and foster care, and the poor through the welfare system.

title: FOR PEKING, A MOVE TOWARD STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: AT CENTER STAGE IN WORLD OF THEATER
description: FOR Robert A. Lorelli, the day was moving toward a busy finish. At 5:30 P.M., he was scheduled to be at a cocktail party celebrating the newly refurbished City Center on 55th Street in New York City. At 8 P.M. he was scheduled to be in New Haven, meeting with aldermen about the renovation of the Shubert Theater. And at 9 the next morning, he was scheduled to be in Miami in connection with work on the James L. Knight Center, a 4,000-seat auditorium.

title: GOOD-VALUE CHINESE IN NORWALK
description: NORWALK A new Chinese restaurant has opened in Fairfield County and it is notable on two counts: It offers fine value for the money and it has resisted the trend to use Hunan or Sichuan in its title.

title: White Plains Stays Unbeaten
description: Tony Glover and Eric Mabin scored second-half touchdowns as White Plains rallied to beat Scarsdale yesterday, 20-7, and remain unbeaten.

title: POLITICALLY, FAIRFIELD ALIGNS WITH STATE
description: CONNECTICUT'S favorite feud - Fairfield County versus Everybody Else - holds true for some issues, but not for the major political races this fall, according to The New York Times Connecticut survey.

title: Lauri Eileen Bona Becomes Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Eileen Bona, to Glen Frederick Paporello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Paporello of Bergenfield, N.J.

title: CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS: A TROUBLED HERITAGE
description: The Governor's Conference on Children of Alcoholics began with the reading of a letter from Jason Rolbards, the actor. Mr. Robards wrote that he had been the child of an alcoholic, and he urged: "Please don't stop with the parents. Help the children, too."

title: SOLIDARITY'S LEADERS ARE UNDERGROUND - NOT BURIED
description: The monument near the gates of the Lenin shipyard is a remarkable sight, three towering steel crosses, each surmounted by an anchor, rising from a roughly welded base on slabs of stone over the city's skyline. It is all the more remarkable because it commemorates a failure of the country's Communist system: the 1970 shooting of workers protesting high food prices.

title: FORCE
description: WHEN last summer's Democratic state convention ended, the party found that it had put Governor O'Neill, a member of its conservative wing, on the same ticket with Toby Moffett, one of its most liberal members. Yet political analysts saw this as an advantage, thinking that each might draw support to the entire ticket.

title: The Loose Policy of Tight Money
description: The sighs of relief on Wall Street and Pennsylvania Avenue were almost audible when Paul Volcker spoke the magic words. ''The prospects are good,'' said the chairman of the Federal Reserve, for some future reduction in interest rates. The words alone should help the rebound from the deepest recession since 1937. And he implied that the Fed would not lightly choke off a recovery. ''The policy objective,'' he asserted, ''is to sustain that recovery.''

title: CANADA'S STRUGGLE WITH MONARCHISM GOES ON
description: Anglophiles and monarchists who steeled themselves to accept the maple leaf as a replacement for Britannia's stripes on their country's flag and then endured the changing of the national anthem from ''God Save the Queen'' to ''O Canada'' are now fighting a last-ditch battle to keep their country's birthday as Dominion Day rather than Canada Day.

title: CONCERT: RIP KELLER, PIANIST
description: The John Cage 70th-birthday celebrations aren't over yet; in fact, given Mr. Cage's centricity to the whole American experimental tradition, they may just keep right on going until we reach his 75th year. Wednesday night at Symphony Space, a young composer, conductor and pianist named Rip Keller addressed himself to Mr. Cage's complete ''Sonatas and Interludes'' (1948), which count as his most extensive score for prepared piano, and one of the major statements of his entire compositional career.

title: FEW SURPRISES OR CHANGES ARE SEEN IN SENATE CONTESTS
description: Senate elections, whose results proved to be the most unexpected element of the 1980 elections, now appear likely to produce more stability than surprise in 1982.

title: RIVERHEAD WITHDRAWS FARMS TO PROTEST SUFFOLK COURT PLAN
description: THE Riverhead Town Board has voted to withdraw prime farmland within the 78-square mile rural, agricultural town from future acquisitions under the widely acclaimed Suffolk County Farmland Preservation Program.

title: POLITICIANS DISCOVER A FREE LUNCH IN CABLE TV
description: AS batallions of workers strung wires through upstate New York and southern New Jersey over the past few years, cable television has changed the viewing habits of tens of thousands of people. This year, politicians are betting it can also change their voting habits.

title: HOBOKEN PROPOSALS
description: HOBOKEN DEVELOPERS have expressed interest in a proposal calling for a $500 million residential, commercial and retail project on the Hoboken waterfront.

title: SPORTS SPOTLIGHT FOCUSES ON AGENTS
description: HUNTINGTON CONCERN was etched on Jerry Asher's face as he sat in his office late one recent evening. Frank Tavaras, a shortstop, had just received his unconditional release from the Montreal Expos. Mr. Asher was pondering what course of action, if any, could be taken to prevent the former baseball all-star from joining the ranks of the unemployed.

title: Visiting Vineyards
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Frank J. Prial's article on visiting the vineyards (''Sharing the Rites of the Wine Harvest,'' Travel, Sept. 12). Could it be that the smiling workers enjoying the fruits of an earlier season in a Burgundian vineyard (as pictured in the article) are drinking from a Bordeaux bottle? ARNOLD POLTENSON Manlius, N.Y.

title: GREATER DEMAND FOR MODEST GOODS
description: The economic pinch has put large luxuries out of the reach of bluecollar men, thereby sharpening their demand for more modest pleasures and possessions, new research suggests.

title: 'A TREND TO PRUNE GROVES OF ACADEME'
description: I find Toby Anne Bird's accusation totally absurd Letters to the Long Island Editor, Sept. 26. Bruce Bawer knows full well what he's talking about "In Plain English, There's a Reason," Opinion Page, Sept. 12. The onus falls on her. It's she who's failed to grasp the point of his statement.

title: A DUBLIN SOUND
description: The Artane Boys' Band, named for the school where it originated in 1872 on the north side of Dublin, will give a concert at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Mulcahy Campus Center at Iona College, on North Avenue in New Rochelle.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO STOCK THE LARDER FOR WINTER
description: FOR the serious vegetable grower who has a surplus of vegetables left at the end of the season, preservation or storage would seem to be preferable to abandoning them. Not only is it handy to have a larder filled with one's own produce to fall back on, but it is also likely that the quality of many vegetables will be superior to that obtained from produce markets.

title: Mindy Geltzer Fiancee Of Gregory A. White
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morton B. Geltzer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mindy Susan Geltzer, to Gregory Alan White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. White of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: FLUTIST: DORIOT DWYER
description: Thirty years ago this month, Doriot Anthony Dwyer was appointed principal flutist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Miss Dwyer thus became the first woman to hold a principal chair with a major symphony orchestra - a suitable achievement for a musician who traces her genealogy (and middle name) back to the suffragist Susan B. Anthony.

title: Deborah M. McCarthy Wed to Walter Sawch Jr.
description: Deborah M. McCarthy and Walter Stephen Sawch Jr. were married yesterday in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., by the Rev. Thomas Rittenhouse.

title: A CHANCE ENCOUNTER SPANS YEARS
description: IT was 1948. I was 18, and the bright sun forecast a lovely day at the beach. As I sat gazing out at the water, I wondered who might drive out from New York City to help me enjoy the day at our summer house on Long Island. Being without a telephone, we never knew the answer to that question until we heard the car doors slam in front of our house.

title: WINNING BECOMES A SPARTAN TRADITION
description: AS the leaves brighten the mountains around Lake Mohawk, this is the best season of the year for the 13,000 residents of Sparta. It is a time when parents enjoy sunny Saturday morning tailgate parties before Sparta High School football games, a time when the boosters club meets to watch game films on week nights and a time when the cheerleaders have something to cheer about - the Spartans went into yesterday's game undefeated.

title: ARMY WINS, 20-14
description: Rich Laughlin, the third quarterback for Army, engineered a touchdown and ran 56 yards for the go-ahead score as the Cadets defeated Princeton, 20-14, at Palmer Stadium today.

title: A BOUNTY FROM PENNSYLVANIA; PHILADELPHIA
description: Aprofusion of clocks, a wealth of wardrobes, stacks of stitchery and a quantity of commodious chests create an amiable air of abundance in ''The Pennsylvania Germans: A Celebration of Their Arts, 1683-1850,'' an exhibition opening today and remaining through Jan. 9 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Prepared jointly over the last four years by the museum and the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur (Dela.) Museum, the show presents the most concentrated and comprehensive documentation of the Pennsylvania Germans' contribution to the arts ever assembled, and marks the 300th anniversary of the founding of Philadelphia, as well as Pennsylvania, and Germantown, the first settlement of German-speaking people on this continent.

title: Karen M. Kelsey Will Be the Bride Of David Thomas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Marion Kelsey Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Mayhew Kelsey, to David Fenton Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Thomas of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio.

title: Missing at Boston
description: On her way back to Harvard University after a Thanksgiving visit to her home in Glen Ridge, N.J., 25-year-old Joan L. Webster landed at a crowded Logan Airport at Boston on Nov. 28, 1981, went to the baggage area, where she was spotted by a friend, and then ''just vaporized,'' according to the police at Harvard.

title: Arizona Upsets Irish
description: The last-second heroics here today belonged to Arizona. Specifically, it came from Max Zendejas, who kicked a 48-yard field goal with no time left on the clock and made Arizona a 16-13 victor against Notre Dame.

title: New York City Calls Another Squeeze Play
description: Like chronic pains, New York City's fiscal problems are sometimes better and sometimes worse but never completely clear up. Budget officials are now faced with a $1.1 billion deficit for the coming fiscal year, $136 million in lost revenue due to a drop in personal income and sales taxes and a $1.45 billion tab for recent settlements with the unions representing city workers.

title: GERIATRICS FIELD OFFERS A PROMISING FUTURE
description: AFTER working as an aeronautical engineer for many years, Marilyn S hilkoff enrolled in graduate school to study gerontology, because h er job lacked social contacts and because, she said, of a growing s atisfaction she was experiencing in working with elderly people in h er neighborhood.

title: AUSTRALIA UNVEILS ITS NATIONAL GALLERY
description: Just five days ago Australia got itself a National Gallery. It had been a very long time in the making. In 1901, to be precise, people began to argue that the future capital city of Australia, wherever it was to be, would not be complete without a portrait gallery of Australian political leaders, past and present. That was the original project, and we must account it a mercy that it never came to fruition.

title: HEALTHY DRUGSTORES
description: Not exactly recession-proof but less vulnerable than other forms of distribution, drugstores are posting sales increases this year. Buoyant sales of cosmetics fueled by the rising number of working women, the penchant for one-stop shopping by shoppers for prescription drugs and the growing popularity of larger-sized packages have contributed to that increase.

title: WEARING DIAPHRAGM FOR 24 HOURS IS TIED TO TOXIC SHOCK RISK
description: Some women who wear diaphragms for 24 hours or more may face an increased risk of suffering toxic shock syndrome, according to a study by a group of researchers at the State University of Buffalo.

title: IT?
description: For a change, the housing industry got some good news last week: Interest rates for Government-insured home mortgages declined to 12.5 percent from 13.5 percent, the lowest rate in more than two years. Rates for conventional home mortgages are also on the decline and there has been a modest upturn in applications for building permits in some parts of the country.

title: COLUMBIA MISTAKES HELP YALE TRIUMPH
description: Yale routed Columbia, 36-10, today and the quality of the victory was such that the usually cautious Eli coach, Carmen Cozza, said afterward that his team now has as good a chance as any at winning the Ivy League championship.

title: COUNTY MAN 'TEACHER OF YEAR'
description: WHEN Stewart Bogdanoff was a student, he recalled recently, he had ''many great teachers'' who were ''genuinely concerned with my welfare.'' On Friday, the 42-year-old Mr. Bogdanoff will travel to Albany to accept an honor indicating that others have felt much the same way about him: The New York State Teacher of the Year Award, presented by the State Board of Regents.

title: Merger Defense
description: To the Business Editor: In his article, ''The Vanity of the Takeover Game'' (Oct.3), William Nordhaus lumps the recent Bendix mess, ''conglomerate'' mergers and ''major'' mergers, together in one big counterproductive heap. Neglecting any and all benefits of mergers, he hastens toward his inevitable call for legal restrictions on mergers.

title: LEAVING CHILDREN TO THE MERCY OF THE MARKETPLACE
description: In the past couple of weeks, each of the three commercial networks happened to offer an afternoon special that might leave the passing observer with the impression that children's programming is finally reaching the quality levels demanded by assorted pressure groups over the past decade. In fact, the state of children's programming on ABC, CBS and NBC is rapidly becoming a national disgrace, and a good many distressed watchdog groups are placing the blame on the laissezfaire doorstep of the Reagan Administration.

title: STATE BUDGET HELD AS KEY FOR AID PLANS
description: AYEAR after the first round of Federal reductions in human-service programs, leaders of several agencies in the county say the effect has so far been muted. But they quickly add that the current ''business as usual'' atmosphere is only temporary, a result of the lag between the Federal effort to shift responsibility to the states and implementation by the New York State Legislature.

title: MRS. FENWICK AND LAUTENBERG FACE DIFFERING IMAGE PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE Millicent Fenwick, the Republican candidate for Senator, says she does not feel the need to stress certain issues, wear certain clothes or act in certain ways simply because she is a woman.

title: '...But to Banish Halloween?-Never!'
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, THE HITS LINGER ON
description: TOMORROW night's tribute to Sheldon Harnick, who is celebrating his 30th anniversary as a lyricist, will include songs from his all-time flops and one that was discarded from his all-time hit, ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' because the director thought it was funny for all the wrong reasons.

title: REMOVAL IS ORDERED
description: Connecticut's Commissioner of Environmental Protection said yesterday that highly toxic compounds had been found at a wastetreatment company's sludge pile in downtown Waterbury.

title: 'TEMP' WORK BECOMES FULL-TIME WAY OF LIFE
description: AFUNNY thing happened to Richard J. Scanlon on his way to a permanent job earlier this year. A 5 3-yearold certified public accountant with an M.B.A. from the W harton School, Mr. Scanlon had been chief financial officer of the M ilford Rivet and Machine Company in Milford, Conn., before he was l aid off in the summer of 1981 because of a corporate consolidation. G etting nowhere writing job applications on his own, Mr. Scanlon was s igning up with a local employment agency when he was asked if he w ould care to register with its ''temps'' division.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Confidence Gap

title: MR. REAGAN'S COURSE
description: ''What better way to cap off a big week of momentum towards recovery,'' President Reagan asked Friday, ''than this morning's Producer Price Index report - down another one-tenth last month and up only 3.1 percent so far this year?''

title: ARMONK'S MR. Chili
description: WHAT do you get when you mix together some beef, tomato sauce, four varieties of capsicum peppers, onions, garlic, cumin seed, a pinch of salt, a sprinkle of coriander and a splash of red wine?

title: MAN CHARGED IN FATAL BRONX ARMORED-CAR HOLDUP
description: One of four suspects was arrested early yesterday and charged in Tuesday's Bronx armored-truck robbery in which one guard was killed and two other persons were wounded in a fusillade of automatic weapons fire.

title: PRINCETON
description: ASTROLL through the busy center of Princeton, amid all the plaid s kirts and boating loafers, provides a pretty good idea of what this f abled community is like. At the congested intersection of W itherspoon and Nassau Streets stand a bank, a bus station and the f ront gates of the university - three privately owned institutions t hat reflect three of Princeton's most distinctive and appealing c haracteristics: it has money, it is well educated and it is just a s hort trip (by bus, train, car or plane) from either New York or P hiladelphia.

title: Lynda Ann Leslie Is Married to Peter Haralambou
description: Lynda Ann Leslie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Leslie of Chicago, was married in New York yesterday to Peter Haralambou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Hadjicharalambous of Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Nicholas Augustine performed the ceremony at St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church.

title: RIGHT TO LIFE PARTY OFFERING FULL TICKET FOR STATE OFFICES
description: Four years ago, the Right to Life organization surprised many major-party politicians when its candidate for governor, Mary Jane Tobin, got more votes than Governor Carey received on the Liberal Party's line.

title: Strong Stuff In Waterbury
description: Rather than safely disposing of hazardous chemicals, the Environmental Waste Removal Inc. plant in Waterbury, Conn., was polluting the city with them, many residents had long suspected. According to a report last week in The New York Times, such fears seemed wellgrounded.

title: 26 GROUPS JOIN IN CAMPAIGN FOR ARMS FREEZE
description: Twenty-six national organizations with a combined membership estimated at 18 million have formed a coalition to campaign for a reduction in nuclear arms.

title: DESIGNING A HOUSE IN THE 80's FOR THE MASS MARKET
description: ACALIFORNIA builder named Greenlaw Grupe Jr. is a warrior in the s truggle to produce ''affordable'' houses for Americans. Mr. Grupe heads the Grupe Company in Stockton, Calif., which n ormally builds about 500 houses a year in the San Joaquin Valley e ast of San Francisco. He was one of a thousand developers, a cademics, planners and mortgage lenders who attended the annual m eeting of the Urban Land Institute in Houston earlier this month.

title: THE MEN AT THIRD BASE
description: It appears that Mark Goodman will say anything to make a point. To ''assure'' entrance into the Hall of Fame for Graig Nettles, Mike Schmidt, George Brett and Buddy Bell is absurd. Schmidt, maybe (if he continues his home-run hitting for another half-dozen years); Brett, possibly (if he can repeat his 1980 season), but Nettles (whose lifetime average is now below .250) and Bell (a journeyman at best), no way. PHILIP R. HOCHBERG Washington

title: DEFENDING DEFENSE
description: The military equipment industry has generally been thriving during the current economic downturn, but its top executives could hardly have been cheered by some of the talk at the recent Business Council meeting in Hot Springs, W. Va. At that meeting, the chairmen of several giant corporations urged the Reagan Administration to cut military spending in an effort to reduce the swelling Federal deficit.

title: A NEW PASTIME: PUBLIC ART CLEANING
description: CONSERVATION of artworks is rapidly becoming one of Hartford's more esoteric forms of entertainment. Last spring the Wadsworth Atheneum invited the public to sit in on the laundering of some of its 18thcentury tapestries and drew capacity crowds. Now the Old State House is publicly cleaning a prized possession of the State of Connecticut - a full-length portrait of George Washington completed by Gilbert Stuart in 1801. The sessions are scheduled from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Wednesday until the end of the month.

title:
TOPICS;
Noble Nobelist
description: In ''A Nobel Address,'' which led this column last Friday, an unnamed scientist explained his or her many admirable reasons for renouncing the Nobel prize.

title: NASA DEVELOPS AN ECONOMY PLAN FOR A CLOSE-UP OF A COMET
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has found a bargain-basement way for the United States to beat the Soviet Union and become the first nation to examine a comet.

title: WHAT AUTHORS DO
description: I AM not the kind of person who feels right about calling himself ''a writer,'' even. It sounds like something you would assert, falsely, in a singles bar. (A friend of mine once asked a young woman what she did. ''I'm a novelist,'' she said. ''Really?'' he replied. ''Would I have heard of any of them?'' ''I haven't finished it yet,'' she said.) I'll bet Jesse James, when asked what his line of work was, never said, ''I'm a desperado.'' He probably said, ''Oh, something in trains.''

title: BREWERS RALLY TO DEFEAT CARDS AND TIE SERIES
description: The submarines, Gorman Thomas was saying before the fourth game of the World Series today, ''are out there waiting for us. They are lurking in some estuary. But hopefully our sonar will be on track today.''

title: SQUAT THEATER EXPLODES CONVENTIONS
description: Roger Copeland teaches at Oberlin College and is co-editor of the anthology, ''What Is Dance,'' to be published soon by Oxford University Press.

title: HERB FARMS THRIVE ON 'ROMANTIC' CROPS
description: IN an old barn hung with baskets and bunches of fragrant, drying herbs, Adelma Grenier Simmons holds court each day. Her listeners, seated on folding metal chairs and squeezed into every available space, scribble notes as the woman in wire-rimmed spectacles, cape and skullcap extols the benefits of putting bay leaves in bags of flour - ''to keep the weevils out'' - and lining a baking tin with rose-scented geranium leaves when making a white cake, ''for a heavenly result.''

title: Sabres 9, Capitals 2
description: Gil Perreault scored three goals and made two assists to lead Buffalo to its first victory of the season. The Sabres had lost three times and tied one game. Washington trailed by 8-0 midway through the second period.

title: AS THE SCHOOLS GO, SO GO HOUSE PRICES
description: IT is a scene that repeats itself throughout the suburbs: Identical h ouses in separate communities selling for very different prices, onef etching almost twice as much as the other. Yet both were put up by t he same builder in the same year, both stand on similar-sized l andscaped lots and both have been well cared for.

title: POLICE REPORT FEW LEADS IN SLAYING OF BANK AIDE AT WALDORF
description: On the evening of Sept. 22, the body of Kathleen J. Williams was found in a stairwell on the 19th floor in the west wing of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Miss Williams, a 30-year-old vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Mexico City who was in New York on business, had been stabbed to death.

title: Flames 5, Jets 5
description: Phil Russell scored on a shot from the blue line with 2:38 remaining in the game to give Calgary a tie.

title: SALAZAR, BEARDSLEY AT RECKONING DAY
description: UNTIL Boston, Alberto Salazar was the proud prince, an unbeaten, unchallenged world-record holder. Dick Beardsley was serious and hard-working, improving with each new adventure, but hardly regal.

title: COLLEGE PROJECTS PUT OFF AS AGENCY FACES FISCAL WOES
description: A $40 million science center at Queens College and several other construction programs at the City University of New York and at a private college have been delayed by troubles at the New York State Dormitory Authority, officials of the authority and the City University said yesterday.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A third baseman, chasing a foul fly, catches the ball as his teammates throw up their hands to keep him from falling into the dugout. Is the catch legal?

title: Founder's Descendant Heads Dexter
description: David L. Coffin was born two doors away from where he works in Windsor Locks, Conn., and the company that he heads was born several years before the American revolution on the site that it still occupies.

title: Ostolozaga Takes Five-Mile Race
description: Luis Ostolozaga of Brooklyn, a former Manhattan College running star, won the New York Marathon Computer Race yesterday, a five-mile event in Central Park that was the final test for the computer system that will time next Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: 2 'NICE GUYS' VIE IN DEARIE-VELELLA ASSEMBLY RACE
description: Ever since they were both elected to the Assembly from the Bronx 10 years ago, Guy J. Velella, a Republican, and John C. Dearie, a Democrat, have suspected that they would one day face each other in an election.

title: STRAPHANGERS LOSE A FRIEND AT CITY HALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Fuel Strategy Taking Shape
description: WASHINGTON THE United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation holds a board meeting today to discuss some new strategies for aiding companies interested in building synthetic-fuel projects. Some people think that is just what's needed.

title: Drs. Pamela Ingber and Steven Stuchin Are Wed
description: The marriage of Dr. Pamela Sheryl Ingber, an assistant clinical professor at Cornell Medical College and an assistant attending psychiatrist at the New York Hospital, to Dr. Steven Andrew Stuchin, an assistant professor of orthopedics at the Hospital for Joint Diseases-Orthopedic Institute, took place yesterday at the Hotel Pierre. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Express Co., Baltimore, has elected to its board Leigh Carter, an executive vice president of B.F. Goodrich Co., and Daniel E. Emerson, an executive vice president of New York Telephone Co.

title: LOSS IS FIFTH
description: The Rangers made themselves very busy in the third period last night, playing industrious, eager hockey. But they were like children who try to cover up for bad behavior by scurrying around doing their chores, and nobody watching them was fooled.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Japan Ship Orders Off
description: Orders for ships to be built in Japan fell 59.4 percent in the first half, April to September, of the 1982 fiscal year, to 1.23 million gross tons, against 3.03 million tons in the same period of the 1981 fiscal year, according to the Japan Ship Exporters Association.

title: Spain's Pit and Pendulum
description: Next week's election may add Spain to Europe's growing Socialist club. A left-center government led by Felipe Gonzalez would mark a natural swing of the democratic pendulum; the ruling right-center regime is plainly tired and divided. But the Spanish pendulum swings over a sinister pit. The last Socialist victory, in 1936, ignited a civil war that yielded three decades of tyranny.

title: Sanguillen Says He Is Bankrupt
description: Manny Sanguillen, the former Pittsburgh Pirate catcher whose sporting goods store failed last year, has filed for personal bankruptcy. He listed debts approaching $67,500, and said that aside from property he co-owned with his wife, his assets totaled $16,490.

title: Central Americans To Seek Foreign Aid
description: Central American economic ministers are to seek $600 million in foreign aid to revitalize trade in the region.

title: BRIEFING
description: A lawyer with the Senate Select Committee on Ethics will be on hand as an ''observer'' at the Chicago trial this week of the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and four other men charged with trying to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, a Nevada Democrat seeking a fifth term.

title: No Headline
description: LEBANON ASSERTS ISRAEL STARTS PULLOUT FROM MOUNTAIN AREA

title: THE GAME PEOPLE PLAY OVER AT THE WORLD BANK
description: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development had a lovely little revolution the other day. It was not the sort of upheaval that left anyone hurt or disturbed traffic out on Pennsylvania Avenue, where the bank's world headquarters squats a few hundred yards from the White House. But it was nevertheless a significant revolution because it was the theoretical outcome of an unusual game. The game, which is a little like Monopoly, is played periodically by some of the bank's project and loan officers to keep themselves thinking creatively about global development problems.

title: Household's Chief Stresses Synergism
description: The buzzword around the offices of Gary G. Dillon, the new president and chief executive officer of Household Manufacturing Inc., is synergism.

title: 400 GATHER TO SEE LA GUARDIA H.S. GET CORNERSTONE
description: It was on Dec. 11, 1958, William Schuman recalled yesterday, that he went to the High School of Music and Art to tell the school's principal and members of the student body about his idea.

title: Baird Hersey Marries Judith C. Sillato on L.I.
description: Judith C. Sillato, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl V. Sillato of Rochester, was married yesterday to Baird Hersey, son of John Hersey, the author, of New Haven and Frances Ann Dougherty of East Hampton, L.I.

title: SUBURBS FEED FOLK SINGER'S SATIRE
description: About a year ago, Leo Berinati was just another former folk singer, working for a paper company and answering his musical muse by warbling to his wife while showering.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL'S 'MR. INDISPENSABLE'
description: There is in government a type of person who excels at being indispensable. The boss says he needs a memo first thing tomorrow; Mr. Indispensable stays through the night to get it done. The boss needs a few discreet telephone calls made to Senators and diplomats; Mr. Indispensable does it. The boss wants all the publicity; Mr. Indispensable recedes into the shadows.

title: Exemption for Andrew
