description: Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said the Andrew Corporation of Illinois has been exempted from sanctions against companies that supply equipment for the Soviet gas pipeline, allowing the antenna maker to fulfill a $3.5 million contract.

title: Knicks Suffer 5th Straight Loss
description: The Milwaukee Bucks defeated the Knicks, 99-93, tonight as New York suffered its fifth straight exhibition loss.

title: PARIS OPENINGS: FLAMBOYANT AND FULL OF FLAIR
description: Any worry that this city is in danger of being displaced as the center of the world's fashion action has been dispelled by the scene in the courtyard outside the Louvre. Thousands of fashion followers from all over the world gathered there daily, starting Thursday, nervously clutching admission cards. They arrived early for the spring and summer fashion shows that were invariably late, and they endured hourlong delays once inside, creating an atmosphere as tense as a rock show.

title: 5 Seized in Attempt To Rob a Bank
description: Five New York men were arrested early today as they tried to rob a bank in Farmington, according to officials.

title: Susan Jane Filenbaum Becomes the Bride of Lee Wolansky
description: Susan Jane Filenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Filenbaum of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Lee Michael Wolansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Wolansky of Cranford, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Belzer performed the ceremony at the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne, N.J.

title: Market Place; Madison Fund Extinction
description: MANY companies aren't doing too well for their stockholders. But the Madison Fund, for one, decided to do something about it. Its managers decided to sell the closed-end fund and then shut down.

title: Mr. Reagan's New Tack on Crime
description: Announcing a new White House drive against organized crime prior to a national election looks, well, political. There are no new funds for the program, and it offers no additional resources for what may be the most effective strategy: attacking the drug crops in other countries.

title: HUNGARY REAPS HARVEST OF ITS SHOWPLACE FARMS
description: Day after day, tractors pulling wagons laden with shining silver-green grapes chug along the roads in and around this village of 13,000 in the hills west of Budapest. The harvest is under way at the Mor state farm, and the news here and elsewhere in Hungary is good: once again, Eastern Europe's most successful farming country will have bumper crops.

title: Jeweldean J. Londa, 56, Dies; National Urban League Aide
description: Jeweldean Jones Londa, director of social welfare for the National Urban League, died Friday at University Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEW YORK'S SENATE HOPEFULS SPLIT ON ECONOMY IN DEBATE
description: The major-party candidates for the United States Senate, Florence M. Sullivan and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, disagreed strongly about the state of the economy and legislation on abortion and birth control, in a debate held here today.

title: 574 Suspected Leftists On Trial in Turkey
description: A total of 574 suspected members of a militant leftist organization go on trial in Ankara Monday in one of Turkey's largest trials since the coup of September 1980.

title: STEPHEN P. MUGAR
description: Stephen P. Mugar, founder of the Star Market supermarket chain and a philanthropist who donated to many New England colleges, died Saturday.

title: RESIDENTS OF PENNSYLVANIA STEEL COUNTRY WATCH SADLY AS THE MILLS CUT BACK
description: Four old men leaned against a railing, chatting and taking the afternoon air. They were talking about what a lot of the folks in Donora were talking about. The local McDonald's had closed. Shut right down, plywood nailed over the windows.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 18, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Publishers Honor Heiskell
description: The executive committee of the Magazine Publishers Association has named Andrew Heiskell, retired chairman of Time Inc., to receive the 1982 Henry John Fisher Award, which in the magazine business makes him ''Publisher of the Year.''

title: RISING COST OF INJURY CLAIMS CITED IN CITY STUDY
description: Damage and injury awards paid by New York City have increased more than tenfold since 1968, and now surpass the annual budgets of some principal city agencies, the City Comptroller said yesterday.

title: Robert E. Brett, Mobil Adviser And a Captain on Oil Tankers
description: Robert E. Brett, retired marine transportation adviser for the Mobil Oil Corporation and a captain on oil tankers before and after World War II, died last Thursday in Mount Eliza, Victoria, Australia. He was 75 years old and was a former resident of White Plains and Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Rodgers Captures Aussie Marathon
description: Bill Rodgers won the Melbourne Marathon today, cutting six seconds off the course record with a time of 2 hours 11 minutes 8 seconds.

title: Commodities; Platinum Picture Changing
description: PLATINUM is a Cinderella metal that has lacked glamour in recent years, compared with gold, but the situation is changing. In futures trading, the allure of precious metals often is measured by the spread in price between them. For example, gold for April delivery closed last Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange at $446.70 an ounce, while platinum for April delivery sold at $359.60 on the New York Mercantile Exchange - a spread of more than $85.

title: One Planet, One Recession
description: Japan's economy has been expanding for most of 30 years by more than 5 percent a year. This year, it's growing barely half that fast. And that's the good news. West Germany's economy is hardly growing at all. France has double-digit inflation. Brazil's total output was down last year for the first time in 25 years. Mexico and Poland can't pay their debts.

title: HE WILL ADDRESS THE U.N. TODAY
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon arrived in the United States yesterday for a five-day visit that is to include talks with President Reagan and an appearance today at the United Nations.

title: IN BEIRUT, MARINES' BATTLE CRY IS 'STRIKE THREE, YOU'RE OUT!'
description: This summer the area around Beirut International Airport resounded with the sound of gunfire in the fierce fighting between Palestinian guerrillas and Israelis. The other day, however, the most threatening noise was the sound of a softball ricocheting off a stack of C-rations, the result of a bad throw by a United States marine.

title: New Cadbury President Held Same Canada Post
description: Mounds and Almond Joy, the candy bars, have been doing very well, with their market share growing, says the new president of Peter Paul Cadbury Inc., their manufacturer.

title: Linda Wechsler Is Bride
description: Linda Hope Wechsler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald F. Wechsler of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Jay Settler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Settler of Coral Springs, Fla. Rabbi Melvin J. Glatt performed the ceremony at La Bonne Auberge in New Hope, Pa.

title: ENERGY STABILITY: DOUBTS RISE
description: In less than three years, the economics of energy consumption has been radically transformed. Industrial nations, which struggled through the early 1970's at the mercy of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, now find themselves confronting excess oil production capacity and declining demand for oil.

title: PRESSURES ARE INCREASING FOR ARMS RACE IN SPACE
description: Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist widely credited with inventing the hydrogen bomb, visited President Reagan at the White House recently to give him an idea for another revolutionary weapon. The device might be stationed in space or launched into space at a moment's notice. Its core would be a small nuclear bomb and its power would be delivered by lasers.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH 'DECRIMINALIZED' HEROIN
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN'S BILL OF HEALTH FOR SALVADOR BRUTALITY
description: On Oct. 1, just two months after the certification of the Salvadoran Government's respect for human rights that is required to keep United States weapons flowing to the Salvadoran Army, the case against suspects in the January 1981 murder of two American advisers and a Salvadoran Government official was abruptly thrown out of a Salvadoran court. This action reveals the junta's contempt for the law and gives the lie to President Reagan's certification that the regime has made a good-faith effort to investigate the murders of these two United States citizens and four more - the three nuns and lay volunteer killed in December 1980.

title: Lori Zabar Bride Of Mark Mariscal
description: Lori Segal Zabar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Zabar of New York and Crompond, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark R. Mariscal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Mariscal of Phoenix and Sedona, Ariz. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Medal to Miss Nielson
description: Sandy Nielson, a 17-year-old rider from Darien, Conn., won the American Horse Shows Association hunter-seat medal at the Penn National horse show today. She was judged the best of the 220 junior riders who competed in the finals. Louis Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., was reserve champion.

title: STAGE: 'GOSPEL,' A CARMINES SAMPLER
description: THE life, art, politics and ministry of the theater composer Al Carmines are virtuallly inseparable. Only now is it becoming easier to sift through his work for songs that transcend issues and enthusiasms of the moment. ''The Gospel According to Al,'' a celebration of Mr. Carmines's 20 years in the theater, begins the task with an impressive selection of 21 tunes, from seven musicals, in a revue format featuring five singers and a pianist.

title: Economic Analysis
description: It is now a year since President Reagan cut personal income taxes 5 percent and three and a half months since he cut them another 10 percent. But as yet the economic landscape remains almost barren of signs that the cuts have done much to help bring about a recovery.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The motto of our group is 'Jus sapienter curret,' or 'Justice runs prudently.'

title: PENSION TRUST SET TO BORROW MONEY TO MEET PAYMENTS
description: To cover Social Security payments to the elderly for November, officials of the Social Security agency say they plan for the first time to let the old-age trust fund borrow money. The authority to borrow was granted last year by Congress as a short-term response to a long-standing financial problem.

title: Couple Arrested After Threat In an Iowa Extortion Attempt
description: A couple has been arrested and charged with extortion after a threat to inject insecticide into food products unless a grocery distributor paid $800,000, the authorities said Saturday.

title: DANCE: LINDA KOHL OFFERS 2 PREMIERES
description: THE term ''music visualization,'' coined in early stages of American modern dance, may summon up an image of wafting to Debussy or churning to Bartok. In the case of Linda Kohl, whose company presented three of her dances Saturday at the Merce Cunningham Studio, the term is tempting because of the choreographer's keen and imaginative ear.

title: DAIMLER PLANS COMPACT CAR TO WIDEN CUSTOMER RANGE
description: Daimler-Benz, the West German auto maker that built its reputation on its luxury Mercedes-Benz limousines, is preparing to introduce its first compact car.

title: YOUNT SETS SERIES MARK, BUT HARDLY SEEMS TO NOTICE
description: One by one, the central characters in today's Brewer victory took their turn at the podium in the interview room, and each of them lavished praise on Robin Yount.

title: 14 KILLED IN CRASH OF PLANE ON COAST
description: A converted military plane carrying a group of skydivers stalled shortly after takeoff, crashed into a carrot field and exploded into flames this afternoon, killing all 14 people aboard.

title: NEW ISSUES POUR OFF THE SHELF
description: Corporations are scrambling back into the bond market. Many of them are seeking to shore up their financial positions and pay for past acquisiton sprees by issuing medium- and long-term debt securities, now that they can do so at reduced interest rates.

title: ISRAEL THANKS U.S. FOR OPPOSING PLANS FOR U.N. EXPULSION
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that Israel was gratified by United States support in opposing Israel's expulsion from the United Nations General Assembly and its technical conferences.

title: CARDINAL SUCCEEDS JUST TAKING A WALK
description: What does a utility player do during a World Series game? Some sit on the bench and act like cheerleaders. Others think about what they might be doing later in the game and prepare themselves accordingly. Steve Braun is among the second group.

title: Precinct 23 - One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically
description: It was shortly before 5 in the afternoon and Janice Bowman, a nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital, was walking south on Park Avenue toward her apartment in the East 80's.

title: 10% PRIME BY DEC. 31 HELD LIKELY
description: The prime rate, which dropped to 12 percent only last week, will fall further by year-end, perhaps as low as 10 percent, according to bankers attending the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here.

title: Polish Riot Policemen Patrol Major Steel City
description: Riot policemen with automatic weapons patrolled the steel city of Nowa Huta today to prevent further street fighting.

title: Tosco Sale to Koch Off
description: The Tosco Corporation has announced that it has ended plans to sell its Bakersfield, Calif., refinery for about $150 million to Koch Industries of Wichita, Kan., because the two companies could not agree on contract terms. Tosco said it would continue to operate the refinery, which it said was highly profitable, while exploring purchase inquiries from other parties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the 12th Congressional District in Brooklyn incorrectly attributed the quotation, ''It's the most daring attempt I've ever seen to steal an election.'' That charge was made by State Senator Major R. Owens.

title: No Headline
description: CHINA RENEWS FRENCH PARTY TIES; TALKS ON SOVIET LINKS TO CONTINUE

title: NEW ALERT RAISED ON RISKS OF BREAST CANCER
description: The American Cancer Society said yesterday that a six-year study of nearly 366,000 women found that the factors known to raise the risk of breast cancer were of little help in identifying the women who actually develop the disease. Even women without the high-risk factors should be considered at risk, the society said.

title: BANKERS STUDY NEW ACCOUNTS
description: Banks and savings institutions are now permitted to offer a new type of account to compete more directly with high-yielding money market mutual funds.

title: PIANO: CLAUDE FRANK PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: THERE is a nobility in failure, particularly if the attempt is as thoughtful and refined as Claude Frank's was Saturday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall, and particularly if the attempt is to play a composition as willfully difficult and stubbornly sublime as Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata.

title: ELECTION RESULTS IN GREECE REFLECT DISCONTENT WITH SOCIALIST REGIME
description: Greece's governing Socialist party appeared to have lost ground to the right and to the left in urban areas in the first round of municipal elections Sunday.

title: Bridge: For the 2d Time in 3 Years, Americans Wind Up in 2d
description: For the second time in three years a strong American team has had to be content with placing second in the World Team Championship, behind a determined quartet of fighting Frenchmen.

title: TV: A NO-NONSENSE 'KING LEAR'
description: WITH a new executive producer, Shaun Sutton, for the last two of its six seasons, ''The Shakespeare Plays'' tonight at 8 on WNET, Channel 13, confronts the monumental challenge of ''King Lear.'' The director is Jonathan Miller, who succeeded Cedric Messina as executive producer of the series two years ago. Starring Michael Hordern as Lear, this is not the colossal production that the play always commands in the mind's eye but seldom achieves in actual performance. Neither is it pedestrian. Whatever his occasional faults or excesses, Mr. Miller is never pedestrian.

title: Poll Reports That Many Oppose Legal Marijuana
description: National news is on pages A10, A12-14 and B9. Campaign Report, B6-7

title: RINALDO FACING A MAJOR TEST IN REMAPPED NEW JERSEY DISTRICT
description: Walter E. Fauntroy, Delegate to the House of Representatives from Washington, D.C., stabbed the air with his finger as he urged a predominantly black audience to vote for Adam K. Levin, the Democratic candidate in New Jersey's redrawn Seventh Congressional District.

title: ROUGH SEAS FOILS RESCUERS AT PLANE AFLOAT AFTER DITCHING IN ALTANTIC
description: Battered by high seas and howling winds, the wreckage of a Colombian Air Force cargo plane, with four survivors believed on board, remained afloat in the Atlantic yesterday as ships and divers stood by, unable to attempt a rescue in the harsh conditions.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FEAR TESTIFIES AT HEARINGS IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Outside the courthouse, armed police and county sheriff's officers stand in twos and threes, watching all who approach.

title: Bannister Rejects Mariners' Offer
description: Floyd Bannister has rejected the lastest contract offer from the Seattle Mariners and ''will be moving on'' to another ball club, says Tom Reich, his agent.

title: Advertising; New Shops For Schlitz, Williams
description: NOT the least of the changes that frequently accompany a corporate acqusition is an ad agency switch. And that's the way last week ended up, with a couple of big ones involving three agencies. One had been announced; the other came from one of the better sources.

title: 3 MEN ARRESTED IN A PLOT TO KILL FOR INHERITANCE
description: Investigators in Queens moved swiftly over the weekend to foil what they said was a plot by a man to kill his 80-year-old aunt for a $250,000 inheritance.

title: 'THE SECOND 'HONEYMOON'
description: MILWAUKEE BUD SELIG sat down every so often yesterday, but never for long. In his private box perched behind home plate at the fifth World Series game, the Brewers' president paced back and forth, took quick puffs on a thin cigar and suffered. But he has always wanted to suffer this way.

title: FRENCH LEAD WAY IN SUBWAY EXPORTS
description: New York City's decision to buy 225 subway cars from the Francorail consortium is another chapter in one of French industry's least-known success stories: the design and production of underground transport systems and equipment.

title: THE MYSTERY OF THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN ATHLETE
description: CHICAGO THERE is a fleeting aspect to a basketball player's career. The death of Bill Robinzine last month ended a life perhaps too much rooted in that transitory profession.

title: Youssef Wahby Dead at 82; Dean of the Egyptian Stage
description: Youssef Wahby, the leading actor of the Egyptian stage for four decades and a matinee idol in the 1930's and 40's, died today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 1 Satur- day gave an incorrect location for a campaign appearance by Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for Governor. Mr. Lehrman was in a restaurant in Queens at a breakfast attended by some students from Christ the King High School.

title: No Headline
description: John Henry Fourth in Return

title: Iran Pilot Defects in Vienna
description: An Iranian airline pilot who landed in Vienna on a routine flight Saturday said today that he had applied for political asylum in Austria. The pilot, Capt. Askeyhan Jahanfakhr, said he told the Vienna airport police of his decision after piloting his Iran Air Boeing 727 on a flight from Teheran.

title: Trout & Ries Wins Harrah's Marina
description: Four agencies in the New York area welcomed new business on Friday, and one of them even said, ''Harrah!'' That was Trout & Ries Advertising, and this was its novel way of greeting its new client, Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino of Atlantic City, which could be spending about $2 million in newspapers, magazines and on radio, positioning the new facility as being in the ''other Atlantic City.... On the Bay. Not the Boardwalk.''

title: MUSIC: SENSITIVE PETER SERKIN
description: PETER SERKIN'S splendid Saturday evening recital -part of the People's Symphony Concerts at Washington Irving High School - boasted not only exhilaratingly sensitive and intelligent pianism, but an ambitious and innovative program as well.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1982; The Economy
description: Bankers expect the prime rate to slip further in coming weeks, but they offer various reasons. Many at the American Bankers Association convention in Atlanta predict sluggish demand for credit because of the weakened economy; others talk about the inflow of funds from abroad. Fed policy seems to have had little to do with the decline in interest rates, they suggest. (D1.)

title: Sales Tax Receipts Lag in Connecticut
description: Sales tax revenues for the first two months of Connecticut's current fiscal year are running below expectations, but a state budget specialist said over the weekend that it was too early to be concerned about lagging revenues.

title: Holy Cross Tops Monsignor Farrell
description: Ralph Scarano completed two touchdown passes to John Miceli as Holy Cross defeated previously unbeaten Monsignor Farrell yesterday, 23-13, in a Catholic High Schools Football League game. Both teams are 4-1 over all and 3-1 in league play, although they are in different divisions.

title: Instant Replay
description: Craig Virgin, one of America's top-level distance runners, who hopes to qualify for the 1984 United States Olympic team in the 10,000-meter run and the marathon, will be available this week to offer expert advice to runners who plan to take part in the New York City Marathon next Sunday.

title: COMMON MARKET SEEKS U.S. TRADE TALKS
description: The European Common Market, alarmed at a split in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, plans to press Washington for an urgent resumption of talks on trade with Eastern bloc countries, British Foreign Secretary Francis Pym said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Was It, or Wasn't It?

title: 6 Abducted in Zimbabwe Are Reported Alive
description: Six tourists kidnapped by dissidents in Zimbabwe have been seen alive by villagers, the State Department told the father of an American youth among the group.

title: PASSING IN STYLE AT U.S.C.
description: Since the 1960's, the game-breaker for the University of Southern California usually has been its tailback. Mike Garrett, O.J. Simpson, Charles White and Marcus Allen, all of whom won the Heisman Trophy as running backs, were among the speedy heroes. This year, life at U.S.C. is different.

title: BIG BLUES ON THE SHOALS NEAR MONTAUK
description: foot Topaz sportfisherman heave against its docklines.

title: TRUTH IN FORECASTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara Kaplan Bride Of Michael A. Lane
description: Barbara L. Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Kaplan of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael A. Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Lane of Wantagh, L.I. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn Jewish Center.

title: VOLS SILENCE CRITICS
description: When Tennessee gained a 24-24 tie with undefeated Louisiana State Oct. 9, the Vols' coach, Johnny Majors, said, ''It was the best Tennessee game in two years.''

title: PLAY: 'ANGELS FALL,' LANDFORD WILSON'S APOCALYPSE
description: ''SOMETIMES I am amazed at how human everyone is,'' says the Roman Catholic priest (Barnard Hughes) at the center of Lanford Wilson's new play, ''Angels Fall.'' He may be amazed, but we're not. By now we've come to depend on Mr. Wilson's talent for finding the humanity in everyone he places on a stage, whether the setting be the Hotel Baltimore or the Talley family's Missouri farm. With equal depth, this writer can draw young people and old, men and women, Jews and Christians (both faithful and lapsed), hetero- and homosexuals, idealists and cynics. Mr. Wilson is one of the few artists in our theater who can truly make America sing.

title: RACE STILL ON FOR HORSE OF YEAR
description: Although only a handful of major stakes races remain on this season's calendar and many top horses are about ready to call it a year, several championship titles - including horse of the year - have yet to be decided.

title: Aloha Hawaii Wins
description: Aloha Hawaii, third against open company in the Hopeful Stakes, was an easy winner against New York-breds in the $56,400 Damon Runyon Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct. Aloha Hawaii scored by two lengths over Avion Francais, with Father Don Juan another nose back in third and Individual Lad, the 2-1 favorite, finishing sixth. Aloha Hawaii returned $14.80 for $2 to win and covered the seven furlongs in 1:25 4/5 under Gregg McCarron.

title: The Editorial Notebook; How to Cash a Check Instantly
description: A recent editorial lamented the common bank practice of denying access to checking account deposits for days, or even weeks, after the checks are cleared. The extra time caged by the banks earns them millions in interest, but is an infuriating inconvenience to depositors who need their money.

title: Impartial Observer
description: Every Sunday morning during the football season, a professor of mathematics at Penn State University enters the results of the weekend's major college games into a computer. When all the entries have been made, he pushes a button. In 10 seconds, the computer has ranked in order the top 108 teams in the country.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SCHINDLER'S LIST. By Thomas Keneal- ly. 400 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Bomb in Frankfurt Destroys Cars at U.S. Housing Center
description: A bomb exploded at an American housing complex here early today, destroying four cars owned by United States servicemen but causing no casualties, the West German police said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RIVALS' DEBATES IN SENATE CONTEST IN CALIFORNIA
description: Following are exerpts from debates between Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, candidates for the Senate from California, on domestic and international matters:

title: RECORD IN TAX-EXEMPTS
description: Spurred by lower borrowing costs, states and municipalities plan to sell a record $1.68 billion of tax-exempt bonds this week. The visible supply of new corporate debt offerings total $1.1 billion.

title: Addenda
description: * Johnson/Carroll & Associates, a new public relations and advertising firm at 2 Park Avenue, formed by Thomas A. Johnson and Robert F. Carroll.

title: OUTSIDE EFFORTS MADE IN STRIKE
description: While the National Football League labor negotiations continued at an apparently slow pace here today before recessing at midnight until 9 A.M. Monday, events that could significantly affect the talks and the players' strike, now 27 days old, were taking place elsewhere.

title: Pascal Is First In Chapin Run
description: Syl Pascal of Peekskill, N.Y., was the winner of the men's division yesterday in the second annual Harry Chapin Run Against Hunger at Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Pascal, who defeated Ben Murolo of Brooklyn by 14 seconds, covered the 6.2-mile course in 32 minutes 33 seconds.

title: BENCH AND BAR TAKE A FOUR-MILE RUN THAT FINISHES AT FOLEY SQUARE
description: The United States Court House in Manhattan has witnessed its share of legal jostling over the years, but nothing quite like yesterday morning, as more than 500 lawyers descended upon Foley Square in sweat pants, T-shirts and running shoes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OFF TO QUEENS

title: Death Rate at New Low in '79
description: The nation's death rate dropped to its lowest level in 1979 and life expectancy was at a new high, the National Center for Health Statistics reports.

title: LEHRMAN TAKES RACE TO PARK AS CUOMO GOES TO BROOKLYN
description: Mario M. Cuomo brought his campaign for governor to two predominantly Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn yesterday, while Lewis E. Lehrman, his Republican opponent, also did some running - clocking a snappy 32 minutes and 20 seconds in the five-mile New York City Marathon computer run through Central Park.

title: HOW THE DEMOCRATS IN QUEENS PICK JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: O Say Can You Sing?
description: Just like everyone else in Milwaukee last Friday, Frances Langford found herself caught up in the community's delirium over the Brewers as they prepared for their World Series game that night against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: KOCH SKIPS STONE, BUT NOT THE BLARNEY
description: Legend has it that if a wayfarer kisses the Blarney Stone he will receive the gift of gab. Mayor Koch decided against it this weekend and waved his car past Blarney Castle.

title: Black Hawks 6; Red Wings 4
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Rich Preston scored two goals as Chicago won its third straight. Detroit is without a victory in six games. Preston's goals came during a three-goal second period.

title: SENATOR JOE'S GHOST
description: It is a 30-second spot, shown often these evenings on Boston television channels. As the advertisement starts, there on the screen is a black-and-white still picture of Representative Barney Frank. A voice says:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sin as a Social Science

title: DENVER PAPERS WAGE BUSINESS BATTLE
description: After a couple of noisy opening shots that hinted of ferocious things to come, Denver's newspaper battle has settled into trench warfare that is being decided not so much by legions of reporters and editors as by the troops from circulation and advertising.

title: Tara A. Mahon Married To Paul Stuart Goldberg
description: Tara Anne Mahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent P. Mahon of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Stuart Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Goldburg of Rye, N.Y., and Paris. The Rev. Todd Jones of the Basking Ridge (N.J.) Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: LONNIE SMITH IS ON THIN ICE
description: MILWAUKEE SOME people think Lonnie Smith was the most valuable player on the Cardinals this season, maybe even the most valuable in the league. Nobody thought he was the most valuable on the Cardinals through the first four games of the World Series.

title: M.T.A. Cancels Japanese Loan
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has canceled plans to borrow $126 million from Japan to help finance its purchase of 325 subway cars from Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd.

title: TOUGH CAMPAIGNING RAISES EYEBROWS IN GENTEEL BAY STATE DISTRICT
description: This comfortable suburban town, with its neatly trimmed lawns, its reddening oak and maple trees and its cloistered, Gothic women's college, is home to affluent doctors, lawyers and businessmen from Boston. It is also the home of Margaret M. Heckler, a Republican member of the House of Representatives, whose eight terms make her the senior woman in Congress.

title: KOCH'S WORK CAMPS: A POSITIVE STEP...
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWN CONCENTRATES ON CHANGING VOTERS' MINDS
description: It was a friendly crowd in the predominantly Jewish Fairfax district, and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. pressed his way through a group of elderly women who all seemed to want to kiss him. ''You'll be our President,'' said one, 79-year-old Ceil Moss.

title: BREWERS WIN AND TAKE 3-2 SERIES LEAD
description: Robin Yount, whom Milwaukee fans repeatedly salute with chants of ''M-V-P, M-V-P,'' gave another display of his value to the Brewers today and sparked them to the brink of their first World Series championship.

title: BALLET: RAMBERT TROUPE MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: BALLET RAMBERT, whose roots go back to 1926, is both named after its late director, Dame Marie Rambert, one of the founding mothers of British ballet, and also one of the most famous dance companies in the world.

title: FOOTBALL RETURNS FOR 80 ON STRIKE
description: More than 80 National Football League players played football today. What's more, it was good, exciting football, though the hitting often appeared controlled, and the game was decided by a point on a field goal with 61 seconds remaining.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Thieves, a Warning

title: No Headline
description: BALLESTEROS BEATS LYLE IN PLAYOFF

title: SWEDEN TIGHTENS SUBMARINE RULES
description: The Swedish Government, angered and embarrassed by what it believes have been repeated incursions by foreign submarines, has ordered its navy to change tactics and seek to capture and humiliate future intruders, military specialists here said today.

title: London Fights Printing Of Book on Espionage
description: The British Government's chief law officer said tonight that he had won a High Court order to stop publication of a new book about M.I.5, the country's intelligence agency.

title: Mine Union Chief Lifts Authority of Treasurer
description: Sam M. Church Jr., who is facing a challenge for re-election as president of the United Mine Workers of America, has lifted the authority of the union's incumbent secretary treasurer, Willard A. Esselstyn, to sign checks on U.M.W. accounts.

title: TALKING POLITICS
description: Talking Politics ''He's still less prepared than me, but then so is Durenberger with his four years in the Senate.''-Eugene McCarthy, endorsing Mark Dayton, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate in Minnesota, whom he once called ''underprepared.''

title: HOSPITAL REMEMBERS REBIRTH OF O'NEILL
description: ''I AM looking forward to some fine spring day when I shall be able to pay the hospital a visit,'' Eugene O'Neill wrote the director of the Gaylord Sanitarium in Connecticut. ''If, as they say, it is sweet to visit the place one was born in, then it will be doubly sweet for me to visit the place I was reborn in - for my second birth was the only one which had my full approval.''

title: STAGE: SHEPARD'S 'WEST' REVIVED AND RESTORED
description: THE production of Sam Shepard's ''True West'' that opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater is an act of theatrical restitution and restoration. Two seasons ago, the Public Theater presented the New York premiere of this comedy - a production that was disclaimed in absentia by the playwright - and the work seemed, for the freewheeling Mr. Shepard, uncharacteristically heavy-handed.

title: SMALL-COLLEGE OFFICIALS TELL OF BIG NEED FOR MONEY
description: If the survival of small colleges depends on attracting publicity and, thus, philanthropists, littleknown Washington College should do rather well. But the 200-year-old institution with 720 students will not soon again match the extravaganza it staged here on Maryland's Eastern Shore this weekend.

title: Iran Reports Recapture Of Kurdish Village
description: Iranian security forces have recaptured a border village in clashes with Kurdish guerrillas fighting for autonomy in western Iran, Iran's national press agency reported today.

title: Levo Gives Devils a Winning Dimension
description: Both the coaches and the players on the New Jersey Devils agree: Tapio Levo provides a valuable dimension to the team.

title: DIVORCE, FATHERS AND PAIN
description: ''B EING a nurturing man makes you a wonderful father - but a very unhappy divorce,'' said Dr. John W. Jacobs, assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. ''It's a problem, because during the last two decades increasing numbers of fathers from all social classes have become more involved in child care, and very closely attached to their children.''

title: DECLINE IN RATES IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE
description: With the Federal Reserve all but advertising an easier credit policy, interest rates are expected to resume their downward trend this week despite the sudden and unnerving disappearance of buyers last Thursday and Friday. Money market specialists became even more convinced of this Friday, after the Fed reported a $6.9 billion jump in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Oct.6.

title: Sabres Defeat Oilers, 6-4
description: Phil Housley, a rookie defenseman, scored one goal and added three assists to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 6-4 victory tonight over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The surprising Devils have earned 7 points, with only one loss, after six games.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH 'DECRIMIMALIZED' HEROIN
description: To the Editor: One problem that Mr. Burstein chooses to ignore is that of driving while under the influence of a drug as mind-bending as heroin.

title: Westmoreland and Liddy Salute Young Collegians
description: Today's college students are different than those who protested the Vietnam War, retired Gen. William Westmoreland of the Army and G. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator, told a convention of former members of the military services, soldiers of fortune and admirers of the military Saturday.

title: ...OR A NEEDLESS BURDEN FOR CRIMINAL JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: PARLEY DOMINATED BY TYLENOL CASE
description: ''In our profession,'' said Marina Stajic, ''you have to expect to deal with the unexpected.'' The unexpected that arose for Mrs. Stajic and about 100 other forensic toxicologists gathered here for a two-day meeting this week was the puzzle of the seven Chicago-area deaths caused by cyanide placed in capsules of Extra-Strength Tylenol.

title: Mouthwash Burn Called Isolated Florida Incident
description: Detectives said today that four bottles of acid-spiked mouthwash found at a supermarket here were isolated cases.

title: Margo Blankstein Wed
description: Margo Anne Blankstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Blankstein of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Eric Louis Muller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Muller of Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Elihu E. Elefant performed the ceremony at the La Guardia Marriott Hotel in East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1982
description: International Greece's right and left parties appeared to have made inroads in urban areas on the governing Socialist Party. Substantial but incomplete returns from the first round of municipal elections in Athens and other major cities seemed to reflect some voter disenchantment with the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou. The losses for the Socialists means that they will be forced to depend heavily on Communist Party support in a runoff next Sunday. (Page A1, Column 4.) Sweden retaliated against repeated intrusions by foreign submarines by ordering its navy to change tactics and seek to capture and humiliate future intruders, according to military specialists in Washington. The new rules are to become effective next July 1, when a new antisubmarine weapon, being developed in Sweden, will be ready. (A3:1.)

title: EAST GERMAN MEETS ARAFAT
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, met the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasar Arafat, in Kuwait today, the East German press agency reported.

title: Silver Shadow Sail Winner
description: Silver Shadow, sailed by Jim Plaxton of Ontario, finished first on corrected time among the larger yachts under the International Offshore Rule in the first race of the Long Island Sound Invitational fall series today.

title: HEARINGS STIR DEBATE ON THEATER DISTRICT'S FUTURE
description: A heated debate over the future of the Broadway theater district has been sparked by the City Planning Commission's proposal for new zoning rules and tax incentives to stimulate midtown development on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: DEFENSE THAWARTS CARDS
description: ''If you had told me before the game that we'd get 15 hits,'' Darrell Porter said after the game, ''then I'd have told you that we were going to win.''

title: INTEREST RATE DROPPING 2 POINTS IN A STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM
description: The interest rate on a Federal education loan program for students and the parents of students will drop two percentage points Nov. 1, and financial aid officials are predicting a surge in new applications.

title: News Analysis; A SOVIET-CHINA THAW?
description: After an interval of three years, the Soviet Union and China are talking to each other again at an authoritative level. But officials on both sides say the deep differences that made the two nations antagonists for two decades seem unlikely to yield at any time soon.

title: TOUCHING A NERVE
description: President Reagan's greatest foreign policy blunder - agreeing with Peking to reduce arms sales to Taiwan - came about because he was persuaded that the mainland Chinese made a major concession that they never made.

title: ALBERT PETER GOVONI
description: Albert Peter Govoni, an author and an editor of detective magazines, died Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: VOLCKER'S MONETARIST POLICY: PAINFUL, COSTLY
description: The United States appears to be at the end of a three-year experiment as Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker's strict monetarist philosophy gives way to a more pragmatic approach.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trans-Atlantic Signs For Subway Systems

title: No Headline
description: McENROE KEEPS AUSSIE TITLE

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OMAHA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Phil Penningroth Wins Award for Teleplay
description: At a ceremony last night at the Museum of Broadcasting, Phil Penningroth received the 1982 ABC Theater Award for his teleplay ''Ghost Dancing.''

title: PLAN IS OFFERED TO SAVE MONEY FOR CITY TRANSIT
description: New York City's transit system could save millions of dollars if it used computerized fare cards instead of tokens, instituted a modern subway signal system and ran shorter trains and bigger buses, according to a report issued yesterday by a state advisory group.

title: BUSING THE HOMELESS
description: If New York City's economy were flourishing as grandly as its most visible industry - the proliferation of the homeless - we could rename the town Easy Street.

title: U.S. SHOULD REMAIN IN U.N., G.O.P. SENATE HOPEFUL SAYS
description: Florence M. Sullivan, the Republican candidate for Senator from New York, said yesterday that the United States should not withdraw from the United Nations if that organization bars Israel.

title: First Boston Net Triples in Quarter
description: First Boston Inc., the parent company of the First Boston Corporation, an international investment banking firm, announced yesterday that its profits for the September quarter more than tripled to a record $30.2 million, or $5.39 a share, from $8.8 million, or $1.56 a share, in the similar period last year. Total revenue for the latest period more than doubled, to $148.9 million, from $60 million.

title: WHAT'S NOT FAIR IN MEDICARE
description: To the Editor:

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A MOMENT OF SILENCE IN SCHOOLS APPROVED BY JERSEY LEGISLATURE
description: A bill that would require one minute of ''silent contemplation and introspection'' in New Jersey's public schools at the start of each day won final legislative approval in Trenton yesterday, but Governor Kean declined to say whether he would sign it into law.

title: CORPORATE MERGERS' VALUE
description: Having returned from the front lines of one of the most publicized takeover battles of recent times, I concede that some consequences of Bendix's proposal to acquire Martin Marietta, and some of Marietta's tactics for counteracting Bendix's efforts, were bizarre. But our original initiative and the final result were totally consistent with both the history of corporate growth and with the foremost objective of responsible management: improving the value of the shareholder's investment over the long term.

title: Indian Unit Rules In Tribal Dispute
description: The Connecticut Indian Affairs Council has invalidated a recall election and ruled that Trudie Ray Lamb is the rightful tribal chairman of the Schaghticoke Indians, a 400-member tribe with a reservation in the northwestern Connecticut village of Kent.

title: Union Commerce
description: The Union Commerce Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Cincinnati-based Southern Ohio Bank to the Ameritrust Corporation for $26.4 million. Central Bancorp, which is seeking to acquire Union Commerce, approved the transaction, it said. The agreement is still subject to approval by both boards of directors and the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Business and the Law; Questionable Tax Shelters
description: WASHINGTON THE questionable tax shelter schemes that have proliferated in recent years, costing the Treasury billions, may become much more dangerous for investors as well as promoters under some of the less conspicuous provisions of the $98 billion revenue bill enacted in August.

title: Dredging / Dumping; The Gill Unsilted
description: Central Park's Gill, the little man-made stream that forms the Azalea Pool in the heart of the Ramble, should flow again thanks to the city Landmarks Commission's ability to distinguish between a fine work of landscape architecture and a natural wilderness.

title: CANADA SEEKS ALLIES IN FIGHT ON ACID RAIN
description: Plastic Lake lay in stillness in this central Ontario region of heavy woods as a gentle shower fell from clouds that had picked up sulfuric pollutants from the smokestacks of the Ohio Valley.

title: A WORLD RESERVE PLAN
description: Many factors have been advanced to account for what is now recognized as a worldwide economic crisis. No doubt all have contributed, from the half-century ''Kondratieff cycle'' of technological progress, to wanton Government overspending, to selfindulgence and labor intransigence, to oil prices.

title: COOPER'S 'POSITIVE STOPPER'
description: When Frank Howard was a Brewer coach a few years ago, he peered down at Cecil Cooper and said, ''Son, do something positive every day.''

title: GTE Income Climbs 13.8%
description: The GTE Corporation, citing increased revenues in its telephone operations, said its third-quarter net income rose 13.8 percent, to $199.1 million, or $1.11 a share, from $175 million, or $1.03 a share, in the similar period last year.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third qr include a gain equal to 13 cents a shr from thesale of land in Texas and reflect a change in the yr-to-date accrual for federal income taxes

title: TROUBLE-SHOOTER GIVEN CHIEF'S POST AT MICRO Z
description: Things have not been going well at the Micro Z Corporation, and its board of directors has hired Joffe Marketing International in an attempt to turn the company around.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $29.9 million from a debt-for-equity exchange

title: Nebraska Baptist School Locked by Court Order
description: The police padlocked a Baptist church for the second time today, carrying out dozens of worshipers and ministers before locking the door to close a school reopened in defiance of a court order.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $60,000

title: Unser Returning
description: Bobby Unser, now 48 years old and a three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, will return to the big-car racing circuit next season after a year off. Unser will join Gordon Johncock, last year's Indianapolis winner, on the Pat Patrick Racing Team, taking the place of Mario Andretti. Paul Newman, the actor, and Andretti have joined forces to make up a new team with Newman to be the owner of the car that Andretti will drive.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results reflect the adoption of LIFO inventory accounting which reduced net income by $125,000 for the qr and $753,000 for the 9 mos

title: HUNGARIAN DISSENT TAKES A SOFT LINE
description: Late in August, a group of fewer than 100 critics of the regime of Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist leader, gathered by the Danube at the statue of Jozef Bem, a Polish general who fought alongside Hungarians in the abortive revolution of 1848.

title: CORNELL SCIENTIST GIVEN NOBEL PRIZE IN PHYSICS
description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded yesterday to Dr. Kenneth G. Wilson of Cornell University for his method of analyzing the basic changes in matter under the influence of pressure and temperature.

title: LAW SIGNED BARRING FUNDS TO DEVELOP BARRIER ISLANDS
description: President Reagan, creating the first major conservation law of his Administration, today signed legislation barring Federal subsidies for the development of the nation's barrier islands.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a Connecticut folk singer incorrectly identified the composer of ''I'm Proud to Be an Okie From Muskogee.'' The song was written by Merle Haggard and Eddie Burris.

title: ELLIS BANKING CORP (BRADENTON, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-After a $26.2 million loss relating to CII Honeywell and a $13.7 million British tax credit

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
Saxon Industries
description: Saxon Industries said the United States Bankruptcy Court had approved the sale of its business products division and the separate sale of a paper distribution operation.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $2,671,000 or 30 a shr resulting from a reduction in estimated loss from discontinuance of the company's Seabrook frozen food operations

title: COUNCIL PANEL VOTES TO INCREASE POLLUTION FINES
description: Violators of the city's air- and noise-pollution codes would face stiffer fines under a bill approved yesterday by the City Council's Environmental Protection Committee.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fannie Mae Losses Cut
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the country's largest diversified financial company, announced today that it had slashed its losses in the third quarter to $13.2 million from $79.5 million a year ago. The company, popularly known as Fannie Mae, said revenues rose 29.4 percent, to $1.85 billion, from $1.43 billion. Fannie Mae, whose main activity is handling Government-backed mortgages, credited its improvement to its decision to improve the performance of its assets and increase income from fees to insulate the company from unpredictable interest rate changes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fracturing a French Menu

title: A Warning Signal for Social Security
description: Sometime next month the trust fund that pays Social Security pensions will run out of money, but the pensions of 34 million eligible Americans are safe for the foreseeable future. Last year Congress gave the Social Security Administration permission to borrow from the Hospital Insurance Fund, which covers Medicare benefits.

title: POPE TELLS ALL PRIESTS IN ROME TO WEAR ONLY CLERICAL DRESS
description: Pope John Paul II has instructed all priests in Rome to wear only clerical dress. The instruction, which was the result of a letter to Ugo Cardinal Poletti, vicar general for Rome, is likely to be interpreted by church liberals as further evidence supporting their belief that Pope John Paul II is a church conservative eager to put an end to interpretations of the teachings of the Vatican Council that he deems too liberal.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago figures reflect an accounting change

title: BROOKS SHAKING UP LINE COMBINATIONS
description: When a hockey coach starts juggling his line combinations, it is sometimes a sign of panic and sometimes an attempt to slap complacent players into more-alert performances.

title: HOW TO STABLIZE THE PRICE OF SHIRTS, ETC.
description: To the Editor:

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
UMC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $315,000 from discontinued operations

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; TUESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1982
description: International President Amin Gemayel urged the world's governments to help rid Lebanon of all foreign forces. In an emotion-filled speech to the United Nations General Assembly, the new Lebanese leader said his nation had suffered for eight years from ''competing ideologies in the Arab world, the Palestinian armed and uncontrolled presence'' and ''recurring Israeli invasions and incursions.'' Later, addressing the Security Council, Mr. Gemayel singled out Israel as the chief obstacle to peace in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel's borders are all secure for the first time in history, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said in an address to a new session of Parliament. He said the situation was the result of his Government's policies. (A1:5.)

title: Cuba Will Free Poet Detained for 22 Years
description: Cuba has agreed to release the dissident poet Armando Valladares after being asked to do so by President Francois Mitterrand, the Government said today.

title: MARIO DEL MONACO, TENOR, DEAD AT 67
description: The death of Mario del Monaco on Saturday ended one of the most successful operatic careers of the post-World War II era. Mr. del Monaco, the Italian dramatic tenor and a leading singer at the Metropolitan Opera during the 1950's, died of a heart attack in Venice at the age of 67.

title: Greek Socialists Favored To Win Election Runoffs
description: Communist gains in local elections Sunday forced candidates of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist party into runoff elections in Athens, Salonika and 15 other large Greek cities.

title: SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNION METAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLOR HAS A POWERFUL EFFECT ON BEHAVIOR, RESEARCHERS ASSERT
description: WHEN children under detention at the San Bernardino County Probation Department in California become violent, they are put in an 8-foot by 4-foot cell with one distinctive feature - it is bubble gum pink. The children tend to relax, stop yelling and banging and often fall asleep within 10 minutes, said Paul E. Boccumini, director of clinical services for the department.

title: Asarco Refinery
description: Asarco Inc. announced it would suspend operations at its Corpus Christi, Tex., electrolytic zinc refinery on Oct. 30, idling about 325 employees. The company said it was closing the facility, which had been operating at 50 percent capacity, because of a lack of material resulting from depressed metal prices. A small crew will be retained to maintain the plant, it said.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary charges of $70.6 million for the qr and $134.5 million for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: Council Post Primary In South Bronx Today
description: A court-ordered special primary for the Democratic nomination for the City Council in the 11th council district in the South Bronx will be held today because of irregularities in the regular primary, held Sept. 23.

title: GIVENCHY AND CHANEL EXCITE PARIS
description: The couture houses dominated the runways with their ready-to-wear collections today and one would think the mood would be sober and refined. Not exactly. For various reasons, the collections carried their own brands of excitement.

title: No Headline
description: CAMPAIGN REPORT; REAGAN STRESSES 'GOOD NEWS' IN SPEECH TO RALLIES

title: Books Of The Times
description: FOUR FILMS OF WOODY ALLEN. ''Annie Hall.'' ''Interiors.'' ''Manhat- tan.'' ''Stardust Memories.'' 387 pages. Random House. $19.95; paper, $9.95.

title: LIFE AFTER BASEBALL
description: ST. LOUIS George (Doc) Medich and Manny Sanguillen are currently mere footnotes in the news, though their stories deserve greater attention. George (Doc) Medich is in his first and perhaps last World Series, and probably won't get into a game. Now a second-line starter for Milwaukee, he is considering retiring from baseball after this season.

description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1982; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.12 points, to 1,019.22, its highest level in nearly 18 months, on forecasts of further interest rate declines. Trading volume, however, was relatively light by recent standards, with a turnover of 83.8 million shares. (Page D1.)

title: 'The Boss'
description: Bess Wallace and her future husband met as second-graders, were Sunday school classmates and graduated from high school together. In the class picture - Independence High '01 - he's the boy in the back row wearing glasses; she's the girl in the second row wearing a bow in her hair.

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH GAINS
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said yesterday that third quarter net income was $7.4 million, about 7 percent above the $6.9 million reported in the same quarter in 1981. Sales, however, declined to $749 million, from $790 million in last year's third period.

title: WHEN A BANK DELAYS CLEARING A CHECK
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Style
description: In an effort to improve their public image, some National Basketball Association teams have instituted a dress code for players during the coming season that requires them to wear a sports jacket on all road trips, with designer jeans being the minimum standard for pants.

title: Advertising; MCI Aims At Market For Pagers
description: MCI COMMUNICATIONS was just another competitor to Ma Bell in the long-distance phone business. Then it discovered advertising, and it quickly drew away from the rest of the pack. Next week, it is going to start testing to see whether it can do the same in the more crowded field of telephone pagers - you know, the beepers you thought only doctors wore.

description: To the Editor:

ARTISTRY OF SCULLY DAZZLES
description: Radio is not a forgotten medium in sports broadcasting. Overlooked, yes, but not forgotten, especially when Vin Scully is calling the play-by-play of a baseball game.

title: Miss Garibaldi Gets Approval for Court
description: The New Jersey State Senate unanimously approved today the nomination of Marie Garibaldi, a tax lawyer and president of the New Jersey State Bar Association, as the first woman to serve on the state's Supreme Court.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $165,000 for the latest first qr and $376,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: CAR RULES WIN FAVOR
description: Grand Prix racing teams have surprisingly agreed to drastic rule changes ordered for next year to reduce speeds and increase safety.

title: Justices to Hear Citibank-Cuba Case
description: It has been 22 years since the revolutionary Government in Cuba expropriated 11 branch offices of the First National City Bank, since renamed Citibank.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON Earlier this month, on two successive days, the Council for Advancement and Support of Education awarded the Jefferson Medal to the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, and the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching released a document, ''Control of the Campus: a Report on the Governance of Higher Education.'' The proximity of the two events was coincidence, but the motive behind each was the same: fear. Fear, that is, that the colleges and universities are adrift and, without more effective leadership, are in danger of losing their independence.

title: FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Whitbread-Wile
description: Whitbread & Company said it had acquired the common share capital of Julius Wile Sons & Company from Nabisco Brands for $96.3 million in cash. The purchase includes a 49 percent interest in All Brand Importers Inc., a beer importer in which Nabisco is retaining a 51 percent stake.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chief Lawyer Leaving S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Edward Greene had resigned as general counsel and would be replaced by Daniel Goelzer, who joined the S.E.C. in 1974 and has been executive assistant to the chairman, John S.R.Shad, since 1981.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCIAL FEDERATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: IAN McKELLEN STARS IN A TWO-PART THRILLER
description: PUBLIC television'S ''Mystery!'' series turns to a two-part psychological thriller titled ''Dying Day'' tonight at 9 on WNET-13. John Bowen, the author, has devised a rather farfetched story about a prissy little man who hears his own murder being planned on an audio cassette he has come by on a train. Lending this strained exercise unusual interest is the casting. The little man is played by Ian McKellen, one of Britain's leading Shakespearean actors and the winner of a Tony Award for his Broadway performance in ''Amadeus.''

title: EDUCATION
description: TWO decades ago, California was widely considered a leader in public education, as a state that demonstrated a willingness to spend on schools to get results and as a state whose students surpassed national norms for learning achievement.

title: CHRYSLER REJECTS DEMAND BY UNION, RISKING A STRIKE
description: The Chrysler Corporation declared today that it would suffer a strike rather than grant the immediate hourly wage increase demanded by the United Automobile Workers.

TOWN HALL CELEBRATES ITS 61st ANNAVERSARY
description: Town Hall, one of the city's foremost concert halls, which has fallen upon hard times in recent years, celebrated its 61st anniversary Sunday afternoon with a concert and dinner and a report that it still needed $1.6 million of the $2 million fund-raising goal announced a year ago.

title: THE SILENT CARD
description: ST. LOUIS When the World Series resumes tonight, George Hendrick will resume his role as its least voluble player. The Cardinals' cleanup hitter is one of perhaps half a dozen major leaguers who decline, for various reasons, to discuss baseball with reporters. Steve Carlton, the Philadelphia Phillies' ace left-hander, has had that policy for several years. Ted Simmons adopted it early this season but when the Milwaukee Brewers won the American League East, their lionesque catcher known as Simba couldn't resist.

title: Poland's Ruler Marks A Year in Party Job
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski completed his first year as Poland's Communist Party leader today still facing an economic and social crisis despite the outlawing of his main challenger, the independent Solidarity union movement.

NO CAFFEINE-TUMOR LINK SEEN
description: A study involving almost 1,000 rats has found no link between caffeine consumption and the incidence of benign or malignant tumors, a researcher reports.

title: Victoria P. Street Dies at 77; A Figure in Scottsboro Case
description: Victoria Price Street, whose charge that she was raped by a group of young blacks on a train prompted the Scottsboro Boys trial of the 1930's, has died in Huntsville Hospital. She was 77 years old.

description: Speech Coach for Glenn

title: ALAIN DE ROTHSCHILD, BANKER AND JEWISH LEADER
description: Baron Alain de Rothschild, a member of the French banking family and a leader of the French Jewish community, died of a heart attack Sunday in New York City, where he had settled recently. He was 72 years old.

description: The 1981 per shr figure restated to reflect 10 percent stock divd in Mar

MILITARY STUDY GROUP SEES NO NEED FOR DRAFT
description: A Presidential study group reported today that there was no need for a draft in the foreseeable future because the military was attracting enough qualified enlistees.

title: Transamerica Net Off
description: The Transamerica Corporation announced yesterday that its profits in the third quarter dropped 50.1 percent, to $39.8 million, or 64 cents a share, from $79.8 million, or $1.23 a share in the comparable period last year. The diversified financial services and manufacturing company said that total revenues in the third quarter rose to $1.12 billion, from $1.06 billion the year before. James R. Harvey, president and chief executive officer, said that ''all our businesses have strong turnaround potential so that as the economy and insurance markets improve, our subsidiaries earnings should benefit substantially.''

title: Accord Is Reached On Waste Disposal
description: Connecticut's largest hazardous-waste disposal company agreed yesterday in Superior Court in Waterbury to treat and dispose of wastes in accordance with the law.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUPING UP THE POWER OF A PLAIN JANE
description: THE custom circuit board is to personal computers in the 80's what hood louvres, chrome skirts and ether injection systems were to Chevies and Fords in the 50's - means of customizing a Plain Jane, and souping up the power in a way not originally intended by the manufacturer, or at least not compatible with keeping the price within its market target.

title: FRENCH SET TAX BENEFITS TO ENCOURAGE EXPORTS
description: France's Socialist Government today announced new tax benefits to encourage French companies to increase exports and development, including bigger deductions for expense account meals and other business entertainment.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Glenn Is Forming Committee To Study Chances for 1984
description: Senator John Glenn's office announced today that an ''exploratory committee'' was being formed to evaluate the his chances of winning his party's Presidential nomination in two years.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
I.T.T.'s BRITISH OFFERING SOLD OUT, 13 TIMES OVER
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said its public offering of 40 million shares in a British subsidiary had been vastly oversubscribed, drawing bids for a total of 525 million shares.

title: AND WHAT ABOUT THE OTHERS?
description: The awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physics to one participant in a major scientific advance without including two others who had made important contributions to the same work has raised again the problem of allocating credit fairly in making the most highly regarded awards in science.

title: Judge Is Told of Effort To Quash A-Test Study
description: Government officials tried to cover up an employee's study showing radiation doses from atomic bomb tests were much higher than had been disclosed, a former Atomic Energy Commission scientist said in Federal court today.

title: SHARP RISE IN JAPAN IMPORTS FEARED
description: Government and industry leaders are expessing concern that Japanese imports will rise sharply as a result of the recent decline in the value of the yen, thus intensifying trade problems with Japan.

title: CHEMISTRY PRIZE GOES FOR RESEARCH INTO INTIMATE DETAILS OF VIRUS STRUCTURE
description: THE Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded yesterday to Dr. Aaron Klug, a South African-born scientist whose research has revealed the most intricate details about the structures of viruses and about some of the most important components within all living things.

title: Monsanto Off 42.6%; Merck Up
description: The Monsanto Company, a major producer of plastics, fibers and industrial and agricultural chemicals, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell 42.6 percent from an unusually strong quarter a year earlier, to $71 million, or $1.79 a share, from $123.6 million, or $3.09 a share.

title: KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MILITARY'S FUTURE IN SPACE: A MATTER OF WAR OR PEACE
description: The seemingly inexorable push toward expanded military operations in space has raised some of the most complex and difficult questions ever faced by the world's political and military leaders. Is this course truly inevitable, given the nature of man and international rivalries? Will it reduce the risk of war or merely lead to another, more costly phase of the arms race and turn man's newest frontier into a potential battleground?

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
French Unemployment Down
description: French unemployment figures registered their first quarterly decline in five years today, with 2,600 fewer people jobless at the end of September than at the end of June. Seasonally adjusted figures from the Employment Ministry showed 2,040,000 unemployed in September, 10,000 fewer than in August.

title: Bonn Backing On Steel Seen
description: The West German Cabinet will agree to a controversial plan to voluntarily limit European steel exports to the United States, Government officials said here today.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
DECLINE OF COPPER MINING STIMULATES COMMUNITY'S SEARCH FOR NEW INDUSTRY
description: When a community is dominated by one industry and that industry goes on the decline, unemployment and other signs of hard times seem to be inevitable.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday in SportsMonday with an article on the distance runners Alberto Salazar and Dick Beardsley incorrectly dated Salazar's marathon time of 2 hours 9 minutes 41 seconds. It was recorded in October 1980.

title: UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARABS URGE LIBYANS TO DROP BID TO OUST ISRAEL FROM THE U.N.
description: Arab diplomats urged Libya today to drop its attempt to expel Israel from the General Assembly. The Libyan delegate, Ali A. Treike, said that ''other countries are appealing to us'' and that ''we are studying their opinions.''

title: ISRAEL DISPLAYS DAYAN'S ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTION
description: One year after the death of Moshe Dayan, the Israel Museum here, the nation's largest storehouse of ancient treasures, has unveiled the general's archeological collection, considered to be one of the world's great private collections of biblical and pre-biblical antiquities.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain from an asset sale of $67.7 million

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Milwaukee Brewers, World Series, sixth game, at St. Louis. John Stuper, who allowed the Brewers six hits and four runs in four innings in the second game, again faces Don Sutton, who gave up five hits and four runs in six.

title: DEBATE CENTERS ON ASBESTOS CASE
description: The Labor Department's top lawyer is seeking to prevent regional attorneys from pressing a court case in which they have won a preliminary ruling protecting workers' rights to talk to reporters about job hazards, according to department officials.

title: NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RICHARD ALSTON'S VARIED 'RITE OF SPRING'
description: Any choreographer of Stravinsky's ''The Rite of Spring'' must contend with this ballet's legendary reputation. Fortunately, when Richard Alston tackled it for Ballet Rambert, he had a legend to guide him.

title: Two Bodies Found After Yonkers Fire
description: Two bodies were found today in the rubble left by a fire here that burned Sunday night and early this morning through three adjoining buildings that contained apartments and stores.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: LOTUS seeds that lay dormant in an Asian lake bed deposit for 400 years or more have been found alive and capable of growing into new plants. They are believed to be the oldest seeds ever to be proved still alive after long inactivity, and may possibly be the world's oldest living tissues.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Schein/Blatstein Gets Sportstyle Account
description: Fairchild Publications, which discovered a money-making machine when it used its Women's Wear Daily, a trade publication, as a springboard to bring out W, a consumer publication, will try the formula again. This time three-year-old Sportstyle, the Business Edition, is going to be joined by Sportstyle, the Consumer Edition, a monthly that is due out in April for the person with an active life style.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHAT'S NOT FAIR IN MEDICARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house cat seems to spend most of the day asleep. Why? It would seem that animals are most vulnerable when asleep and therefore would evolve to sleep less and less.

title: MOST IDEAS FOR STAMPS WON'T SEE AN ENVELOPE
description: Nearly everybody has an idea for a postage stamp, and not much reluctance about talking about it. Every year suggestions by the thousands are marched past a panel appointed by the Postmaster General to approve special commemorative stamps. At a meeting of the group the other day, the agenda was 89 pages long and included proposals for stamps honoring Thornton W. Burgess, the creator of Peter Rabbit; Louis Comfort Tiffany, the painter and decorator; Milton S. Hershey, the candy manufacturer, and William Barclay Parsons, designer of New York City's first subway line.

title: 2 IN SENATE RACE SPAR ON RECORDS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Representative Toby Moffett sparred tonight over each other's votes on social issues, as they debated with two other candidates for the United States Senate from Connecticut.

title: BALTIMORE ART MUSEUM ADDS WING
description: The Baltimore Museum of Art, noted for its Cone Collection of 19th-and 20th-century art, its holdings of primitive and decorative art and its Antioch mosaics, has been transformed by a new $4.5 million wing that was opened to the public Sunday.

title: MICHIGAN CAMPAIGNS FIND A COMMON THEME IN 15.9% UNEMPLOYMENT RATE; The 1982 Election: Michigan Eighth of 10 articles appearing periodically on states with important gubernatorial races.
description: When the national unemployment rate reached 10.1 percent for September, the question in much of the country was how important a political issue that number would be in the Congressional elections.

title: LEBANESE LEADER SEES REAGAN TODAY
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States viewed the talks Tuesday between President Reagan and President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon as crucial to the achievement of an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: UNITED BANKS OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. REFUSES WAIVERS TO 2 SEWAGE PLANTS
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has turned down applications to reduce the required level of sewage treatment at two plants in the New York metropolitan area, agency officials announced yesterday.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd in Dec 1981

title: EUROPE REACTS MILDLY TO GRAIN DECISION
description: The European allies of the United States have questioned the logic of the Reagan Administration's decision to make new grain sales to the Soviet Union, but appear to want to avoid additional polemical exchanges about East-West trade relations.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates Corp. of North America filed with the S.E.C. for $500 million of debt securities, with terms to be set at the time of sale.

title: DREDGING/ DUMPING; Poor 'Protection'
description: A dumping controversy concerning people, not wastes, has Suffolk County in a dither. The county legislature has declared a moratorium on settling additional welfare families in the predominantly black community of Gordon Heights.

title: CAT Scans in 3-D
description: A new and fairly simple mechanical device may be able to produce three-dimensional versions of the images taken by CAT scanners, nuclear magnetic resonance machines and ultrasound devices. All three machines, using different principles, create cross-section views of the body to aid doctors in diagnosing illnesses and finding trouble spots.

title: FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
French Assure India Of Nuclear Fuel Supply
description: A French Embassy official said here today that despite disagreement over safeguards, his country would be prepared to rush nuclear fuel for an American-built atomic power plant near Bombay if its uranium stocks dropped to a level that would not sustain the plant's operation.

title: MUSIC: SONATAS BY MA AND AX
description: FROM the beginning of their duo concert Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the contrasts between the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianist Emanuel Ax were striking. Mr. Ma is the consummate extrovert, inclined to demonstrative on-stage behavior and flights of impassioned phrasing. Mr. Ax, on the other hand, is more steady and reserved, sometimes seeming more interested in providing solid accompaniment for Mr. Ma than in creating a true musical partnership. However, the two men obviously enjoy working with each other, and they were warmly received by an overflow crowd.

description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a constitutional challenge to a law that makes deliberate mutilation of the American flag a Federal crime.

description: rays of 73 pipe welds at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power construction site were improperly altered, according to the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

title: OPERA: NEW CONDUCTOR FOR 'ROSENKAVALIER'
description: RICHARD STRAUSS'S ''Der Rosenkavalier'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday night with its first cast intact but with a new conductor, Jeffrey Tate.

title: Armco Reports $122.6 Million Loss in 3d Quarter
description: Armco Inc., the nation's seventh-largest steel company, yesterday reported a loss of $122.6 million in the third quarter, compared with earnings of $67.1 million, or $1.19 a share, in the comparable period last year.

title: PLANT USE OFF TO 69.1% LAST MONTH
description: More than 30 percent of the nation's manufacturing capacity sat idle last month, with factory use dropping to 69.1 percent, the lowest rate in more than seven years, the Government reported today.

description: The Labor Department said today that nine more states, including California, had become ineligible for extended unemployment benefits.
