DEVILS SET BACK FLYERS, 3-1
description: The Devils continued their surprising start to the National Hockey League season tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Reuters Names a New Editor For North American Services
description: Margaret Klein, financial services editor for Reuters North America, will become managing editor for the United States and Canada on Jan. 1, the company announced yesterday.

title: Viyella-Vantona Merger
description: Carrington Viyella P.L.C. and the Vantona Group said today that they had agreed to merge.

title: A CIGARETTE SHORTAGE 'PLAGUES' NO ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: MENDES-FRANCE, WHO LEAD FRANCE OUT OF INDOCHINA, IS DEAD AT 75
description: Pierre Mendes-France, a former Socialist Prime Minister of France who negotiated the end of his nation's power in Indochina in 1954, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 75 years old.

title: PHILIP SHUTZE, ARCHITECT, 92
description: Philip Trammel Shutze, a classical architect, died Sunday at Piedmont Hospital. He was 92 years old. Mr. Shutze designed some of Atlanta's landmarks in his 60-year career.

title: Market Place; Finding Small Growth Stocks
description: HINDSIGHT beats foresight, as the expression goes, but 20-20 vision may turn up small growth companies that will please investors seeking profits.

title: Excerpts from speeches, page A8.
description: In an emotion-filled speech to the General Assembly, President Amin Gemayel urged the world's governments today to help rid Lebanon of all foreign forces.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Give us peace, and we shall again astound the world.'' - President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly. (A8:6.)

title: COUPLE SOUGHT IN EXTORTION NOW TIED TO TYLENOL DEATHS
description: A fugitive Missouri couple already wanted for extortion were identified today as the ''primary leads'' in the investigation into the deaths of seven persons from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules.

title: American Conference Wins by 31-27
description: Ed Luther of San Diego threw a 54-yard touchdown pass to Seattle's Theotis Brown with 12 minutes 29 seconds remaining tonight, giving the American Conference squad a 31-27 victory over the National Conference team in the second all-star game sponsored by the National Football League Players Association.

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: KENNETH GEDDES WILSON
description: When Kenneth Geddes Wilson was 8 years old his grandfather, a teacher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, taught him how to perform mathematical computations in his mind. ''I would spend the time waiting for my school bus by figuring out cube roots,'' he said yesterday morning. Such an ability, following the early interest in science he evinced as a second-grader in a two-room schoolhouse in Woods Hole, Mass,, resulted some four decades later in winning the 1982 Nobel Prize in Physics.

title: PANEL MAKES FIRST AWARD TO WHITE MAN IN BIAS CASE
description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights announced yesterday that it had awarded more than $6,000 to a man who had been discriminated against by his employer because he was not of Hispanic descent.

title: U.S. Aide Cites Overload In Sky Divers' Crash
description: An airplane that crashed on a parachute drop zone, killing the pilot and all 13 sky divers aboard Sunday, was carrying twice as many passengers as was safe, a Federal investigator said today.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $569,000 for the qr and $515,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: Soviet Reports Chinese Fired On Vietnamese Border Area
description: The official press agency Tass reported today that Chinese forces fired on Vietnamese border areas on Oct. 8, the last day of Soviet-Vietnamese talks on improving relations with Peking.

title: In the Words Of Billy Taylor
description: Billy Taylor, a striking National Football League player, was looking for a temporary job as a football announcer. The former Giant halfback, now with the Oakland Raiders, did not get what he was hoping for - doing color on Canadian Football League games.

title: CAREY, CITING RISING DEFICIT, URGES ACTION BY LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Carey said today that the state's budget deficit had grown to $579 million and he called on the State Legislature to join him in a ''nonpartisan, post-election effort'' to deal with the problem.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, some copies of the Late Edition yesterday included page A12 (Washington Talk) twice and omitted page B10 (Style). Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: BAKER HELPS MRS. FENWICK
description: Frank R. Lautenberg of Montclair, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey, predicted today that he would score an upset over his rival, Representative Millicent Fenwick. In doing so, he compared his candidacy to that of Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for governor of New York.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kotar Transferred
description: The former Giants running back Doug Kotar has been transferred from a hospital in Newark to one in the Pittsburgh area for treatment of an inoperable brain tumor, his wife said yesterday.

title: Stands Pat on Hat
description: What's in a new hat? Nothing to equal an old hat, according to Mike Caldwell, the Milwaukee Brewers' pitcher who has won two World Series games while wearing a faded and soiled cap.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SEVENTH Avenue's designers seem to have dusted off their fashion h istory books and skimmed the pages for a little inspiration. Severals pring collections seem intent on reintroducing a grandiloquent styleo f feminine dress more reminiscent of John Singer Sargent's p aintings, or at least of the New Look of 1947, than of 80's m inimalism.

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $27.8 million or 38 cents a shr for the qr and $33.6 million or 46 cents a shr for the 9 mos and a gain of $7.9 million or 11 cents a shr for the 9 mos on the early retirement of debt...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $2.9 million or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $9.0 million or 13 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITAIN SEEKS TO KEEP ISRAEL IN A U.N. AGENCY
description: Britain, attempting to forestall a threatened United States withdrawal from the International Telecommunications Union, proposed today that the agency express alarm over the invasion of Lebanon but not vote to oust Israel.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a net provision of $150 million for the restructuring of operations and the revaluation of assets and a net gain of $18.1 million from the sale of the C.I.T. headqtrs building

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BOWERY DAYS

title: PITCHING DUEL FEATURES YOUTH AGAINST EXPERIENCE
description: It would be a mistake, Don Sutton said today, to believe that the sixth game of the World Series will be a onesided affair just because a rookie is pitching against a Series veteran.

title: STAGE: THE KARAMAZOVS, NEW-WAVE VAUDEVILLE
description: THE Flying Karamazov Brothers, four unrelated American lunatics, have been bounding across the country with their ''Juggling and Cheap Theatrics,'' a perfectly descriptive title for their unrestrained entertainment. The troupe is in residence this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presented in association with the Dance Theater Workshop. The result is an evening of airborne hilarity.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE DEBATE IMPORTANT IN FEW RACES
description: While support for a nuclear freeze appears to be widespread throughout the country, the issue seems to have become important in only a handful of races for the House and Senate, according to analysts in both major political parties.

title: DOW RISES BY 26.12, TO 1,019.22
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, surging ahead yesterday amid forecasts of further extended declines in interest rates, jumped 26.12 points, to 1,019.22, its highest level in nearly 18 months.

title: Another Retreat From Fairness
description: Properly chided for not keeping careful track of how cities spend their Federal community development grants, the Reagan Administration no longer intends even to try. Its Housing and Urban Development Department proposes to abandon the monitoring of a $3.5 billion program that is supposed to benefit low- and moderate-income people.

title: A MISSILE PACT WITH CANADA NEAR
description: The United States and Canada are close to an agreement that would permit Air Force B-52 bombers to launch cruise missiles into a Canadian target zone for testing over terrain similar to that of the Soviet Union, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Clippers Make Change
description: The San Diego Clippers of the National Basketball Association have a new general manager in Paul Phipps, a former business manager in the Dallas Mavericks organization.

title: CHINA, DOWN ON FARM, GROWS A FEW CAPITALISTS
description: Chen Zhixiong is a prospering peasant whose industriousness down on the farm in southeastern China's Guangdong Province has presented China's Marxist ideologists with a quandary.

title: Newlin Put on Waivers
description: The Knicks, who failed in their attempts to trade Mike Newlin during the offseason despite having offered to pick up part of his contract, placed the 33-year-old guard on waivers yesterday.

title: CENTRAL HUDSON GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
London Stocks Rise to Record
description: The value of all shares traded on the London Stock Exchange rose today to a record high, gaining some $3.4 billion.

title: Vatican Aides Clear Bank
description: An inquiry by legal advisers to the Holy See has cleared the Vatican bank of any financial liability to the Banco Ambrosiano, which failed last August, the Vatican's semi-official newspaper, Osservatore Romano, said today.

title: Maps by Computer
description: The first computer-generated topographic map has been published by the United States Geological Survey as part of an experimental program that could lead to the more efficient production of maps. The new map, drawn to a scale where one inch represents 2,000 feet, covers a 60-square-mile area around Birch Tree, Mo.

title: Chess: Soltis and Martz Share Title In U.S. Open Championship
description: The grandmaster Andrew Soltis of New York and the international master William Martz of Wauwatosa, Wis., tied for first place in the United States Open Championship in St. Paul. Each received a $1,650 prize for his winning score of 10-2.

title: Announcer Loses
description: On Sept. 30, aboard the U.S.S. Yorktown in Charleston, S.C., a fighter introduced as Raheem Tayib appeared on a Top Rank boxing card televised by ESPN. Randy Gordon, the cable television network's color commentator, quickly identified ''Tayib'' as Eddie Flanning, a welterweight from Savannah, Ga., who six nights earlier had been knocked out in the second round by Jose Baret at the Felt Forum. ''Tayib'' was knocked out in the fourth round by Billy Collins as Gordon, on air, bemoaned the fact that his audience was watching a ''ringer.''

title: FARM GROUPS SKEPTICAL ON GRAIN OFFER TO SOVIET
description: Farm organizations, grain traders and the commodities markets reacted skeptically today to President Reagan's offer on Friday to sell 23 million tons of grain to the Soviet Union. Experts said they did not expect Russian purchases to exceed last year's 14.8 million tons.

title: ISRAEL KEEPS AREA FROM LEBANESE
description: An advance squad of Lebanese troops arrived here today, but Israeli forces that moved in on Friday to keep peace between feuding Lebanese Christian militiamen and Moslem Druse refused to leave.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALLET: THE RAMBERT IN JAZZ IDIOM AND A REQUIEM
description: BRITAIN'S Ballet Rambert showed off several other New York premieres during its weekend debut engagement at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall. Neither of Saturday's works had the impact of the previous program, but the initial good impression of a vital and fresh company did persist.

title: THE DOCTORS WORLD
description: PERHAPS discovery is the crowning act in all research. However, as many episodes reveal, the full story of individual discoveries, no matter how great, is rarely told, and the process involved even more rarely fully understood. Professional journals tend to put forward only the findings of the research, omitting the blind alleys pursued, the serendipity involved, and the emotions displayed - in short, the humanity of the act.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect net reductions of $223,000 for theqr and $801,000 for the 9 mos from the adoption of LIFO inventory accounting and new F.A.S.B. rules for foreign currency translations

title: Article 230173 -- No Title
description: The slump in farm equipment sales resulted in a third-quarter loss of $63.5 million for the Allis Chalmers Corporation, compared with net income of $7.9 million, or 43 cents a share, in the third quarter a year earlier.

title: EUROPEAN PUSH BY G.M., FORD
description: The European subsidiaries of America's two largest auto makers, attempting to reverse their flagging fortunes, have introduced new models this autumn that highlight broad changes in the European production and marketing strategies of both companies.

title: MERCURY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POP: MISS MONTEVECCHI
description: LILIANE MONTEVECCHI, who won a 1982 Tony for her performance in ''Nine,'' is making her nightclub debut at Les Mouches, 11th Avenue at 26th Street, with an act that sets her entirely apart from what we have become accustomed to from performers doubling from musical theater to a nightclub.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the qr and $2.9 million for the 9 mos losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $7.3 million for the qr and $9.4 million for the 9 mos and foreign currency translation gains of $7.4 million for the qr and $11.9 million for the 9 mos...C-Including income of $600,000 for the qr and a loss of $1.4 million for the 9 mos from discontinued operations and foreign currency translation gains of $300,000 for the qrand $4.6 million for the 9 mos

title: ARIZONA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSH GIVES HIS VIEWS OF '84 ON NONSTOP CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: In the middle of a breakneck campaign of flying about the nation seven days a week to help scores of Republican Congressional candidates, Vice President Bush says he has developed a ''gut feeling'' that President Reagan should quickly declare for re-election to protect his program and his party.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air California, a privately held regional carrier in Newport Beach, said it would lay off 300 workers, bringing its total layoffs to 25 percent of the work force; 160 workers were laid off in August.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF: NO 'LIBERAL MOLE'
description: As a teen-ager, Elliot Abrams attended a private high school in Greenwich Village whose alumni included Angela Davis and Kathy Boudin. At Harvard, Mr. Abrams headed the campus chapter of the Americans for Democratic Action and supported Hubert H. Humphrey's Presidential bid.

title: Dinner at the White House
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT and Mrs. Reagan's State Dinner for Indonesia's controversial President and Mrs. Suharto was one of those routinely brilliant gatherings for which the White House is famous. Everything went exactly to plan, and the Suhartos, the blase Washington regulars and the dazzled first-timers went away suitably impressed.

title: WAS PRESIDENT'S 'FULL PARTNER'
description: Bess Truman, the widow of President Truman, died early yesterday after suffering congestive heart failure at her home in Independence, Mo. She was 97 years old.

title: 25% JERSEY FARE RISE APPEARS CERTAIN
description: Governor Kean and legislative leaders agreed today to study ways of bridging a projected $62 million revenue shortfall, but they conceded little could be done to prevent a 25 percent rise in bus and rail fares on Dec. 1.

title: Alicia Nafe, Ill, Leaves 'Carmen' in Washington
description: The Washington Opera has announced that Martha Senn would replace Alicia Nafe in the title role of ''Carmen'' for the company's opening night Oct. 30.

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PENN CENTRAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $8.4 million from the consummation of the reorganization plans of Ann Arbor Railroad Co and the Lehigh Valley Railroad Co; results for the latest periods reflect declines in net income of approximately $19.3 million for the qr and $11.9 million for the 9 mos and decreases in sales of $139.9 million for the qr and $245.3 million for the 9 mos attributable to the company's Jan1982 sale of Six Flags Corp

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of LIFO accounting for unpacked raisins

title: United-Japan Air
description: United Airlines announced that Japan Air Lines had agreed to help with ticket sales and ground operations when United inaugurates service to Tokyo in April 1983. James J. Hartigan, United's president, said that, effective April 2, his company's Boeing 747's will fly six weekly round trips to Tokyo from Seattle and one from Portland, Ore.

title: BREAKOFF IN TALKS POSSIBLE
description: The pro football labor negotiations reached perhaps their most critical point today. In private conversations, sources from both sides of the bargaining table acknowledged that the talks could be in trouble and possibly could be broken off.

title: LILLY, ELI, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BRINK'S WITNESS SAYS SHE SAW 'ENTIRE THING'
description: A woman whose sports car was trapped and later stolen at a police roadblock after last October's $1.6 million Brink's holduptestified today that she saw six armed men leap from the rear of a U-Haul truck and spray the scene with machine-gun fire for 60 seconds.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from an extraordinary credit of $4,688,000 for the qr and the 9 mos

title: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
END OF MEASLES IN U.S. EXPECTED BY 1983
description: THE Federal program to eliminate measles missed its target this month. But the United States still expects to halt the transmission of the viral infection by the end of the year, officials of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said yesterday. If the large nationwide immunization does succeed, the United States would become the first country in the world to vanquish the disease.

title: Japanese Loan to China
description: Japan is to lend about $250 million to China under an agreement signed today, the New China News Agency said. The money is to be used on a petrochemical project being built at China's biggest oilfield, Daqing, in Manchuria, on the Baoshan iron and steel complex near Shanghai and on railroad and port construction.

title: Ring Ratings Win
description: Even in New York, such football stars as Wesley Walker, Harry Carson, John Riggins and Mark Haynes were outdrawn in the television ratings game by such boxers as Tyrone Crawley, James Broad, Livingstone Bramble and James (Bubba) Busceme. The striking National Football League Players Association all-star game in Washington drew an overnight 3.0 rating and 9 percent audience share on Channel 9 locally.

title: DEMOCRATS PLEDGE JOB ACTION
description: Congressional Democrats, ignoring President Reagan's call to ''stay the course'' with his economic policies, are promising instead to push back-to-work legislation when the House and Senate return after the Nov. 2 elections.

title: Narco Scientific
description: Narco Scientific Inc. said it had filed an amended complaint in its lawsuit seeking to block Healthdyne Inc.'s unfriendly takeover attempt. Narco said the new counts, filed in United States District Court in Philadelphia, charge Healthdyne with violating Federal securities and antiracketeering laws by issuing misleading disclosure statements in connection with its tender offer Oct.13 for 711,000 Narco common shares. The complaint maintains that Healthdyne's acquisition of Narco would reduce competition in markets for infant warmers, monitors and phototherapy units.

title: BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a special loss of $3,925,000

title: JOSEPH MICHAEL LYDEN
description: The man credited with converting an ancient Chinese game of chance into keno died here Sunday at the age of 83.

title: Bridge: The Thread That Decided The '82 World Team Title
description: Winning a world title - and a secure place in the history of the game - and not winning it may hang on a single thread. The thread in the 1982 World Team Championship for the Rosenblum Cup proved to be the club queen on the 78th deal of an 80-deal match.

title: WARNER, TANDY UP
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a significant jump in earnings for the third quarter of 1982 compared with a very weak quarter last year. The increase came on improvements in most of the company's businesses except its consumer electronics operations.

title: Nissan-Alfa Deal
description: The Nissan Motor Company and Alfa Romeo will begin joint production of the Nissan Pulsar in Italy in April, an auto industry journal reported.

title: US HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHERWIN WILLIAMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pepsico Net Increases 11.3%
description: Pepsico Inc. announced yesterday that its net income in the third quarter ended Sept. 4 rose 11.3 percent, to $113.2 million, or $1.20 share, from $101.7 million, or $1.09 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales climbed to $1.9 billion, from $1.7 billion.

title: ROADBLOCKS FOR A MARATHONER
description: Odis Sanders gets blisters on his feet, and only yesterday he went to see his chiropractor for a back problem. Does it make any sense for Sanders to run in the New York City Marathon on Sunday?

title: League Reviews Korab Incident
description: The National Hockey League is expected to decide Tuesday whether to extend the suspension of Jerry Korab, the Los Angeles Kings' defenseman, who slashed Dale Hunter, the Quebec Nordiques' center, in the face last Thursday.

title: U.S. Home to Buy Brigadier Industries
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest on-site home builder, announced today that it had agreed to buy a controlling interest in Brigadier Industries, the nation's seventh-largest maker of mobile homes, for $25.4 million.

title: WINE EXPERT PRESIDENT OF CARILLON IMPORTERS
description: Michel Roux, a wine expert and a former French paratrooper, has been named president of Carillon Importers Ltd., the importing agent for Grand Marnier and Absolut Swedish vodka, among other wines and spirits.

title: PHONE GROUP PICKS EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
description: The North American Telephone Association, a trade group that represents the telephone equipment industry, has named Edwin B. Spievack its new executive director

description: B-There are no revs for the yr-ago periods because the company was in a development stage...C-Including a tax credit of $705,000 for the qr and the 9 mos...D-Net loss

title: The Face of Things to Come
description: Some people who work in the city but live elsewhere thought they had glimpsed the immediate future yesterday. A chill gripped the early morning air, and commuter trains were running fitfully - the way they do when winter causes signal switches to wheeze.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including losses from discontinued operations of $98,000 for the qr and $338,000 for the 9 mos

title: MELCHER, CONSERVATIVE TARGET, IN TROUBLE
description: Since 1805, when Meriwether Lewis and William Clark climbed their way through the northern Rockies, much of the history of Montana has been written by outsiders. There were the gold miners who flocked to Virginia City and Helena, there was the cavalry division that was defeated at the Little Big Horn and, today, there is the National Conservative Political Action Committee.

description: Shr earnings figures reflect an increased number of common shrs outstdng resulting from an exchange of stock for debentures in 1981 and a new cumulative preferred stock issued in May 1982

title: Oman May Lift Output
description: Oman plans to try to increase oil output by nearly 10 percent in 1983 to help offset the impact on development programs of lower than expected oil prices, oil industry sources said here today.

title: TURBOPROPS FOR SMALLER LINES
description: In this age of the jet airliner and the space shuttle, the aviation industry is turning new attention to an old idea - the airplane with a propeller.

title: ALTAMIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
REQUIRED READING
description: Time Problem

title: EXCERPTS FROM GEMAYEL'S 2 ADDRESSES AT THE U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from addresses by President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon to the General Assembly and to the Security Council, as made public by the United Nations: General Assembly

title: CAPITAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAROLINAS
description: SARA L. SAMSON, a graduate student in geology at the University of South Carolina, felt her shoe come loose while on a field trip near Batesburg, S.C., last March. What she saw when she bent to tie it was the first in a series of finds at that site this year that have won over many geologists to the controversial view that a broad chunk of North America, stretching from Alabama through Georgia and both Carolinas, is a foreign body - a visitor that came from across an ancient sea about 400 million years ago, was thrust up onto this continent and stayed behind when the sea opened again to form the modern Atlantic Ocean.

title: BORDERS NOW SAFE, ISRAELIS ARE TOLD
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin told Parliament today that ''for the first time'' a state of security existed on all of Israel's borders with Arab countries.

title: BRANIFF SETS DEAL WITH AN AIRLINE
description: Braniff International and Pacific Southwest Airlines announced yesterday a tentative agreement to form a joint venture in which some of the planes, employees and routes of the bankrupt Braniff would be operated by P.S.A.

title: Man Sought in Inquiry On Slaying at Waldorf
description: New York City police yesterday released a police artist's sketch of a man wanted for questioning in connection with the slaying of a bank executive at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Sept. 23.

title: The Ad Man Behind First Federal Passbook
description: A former New York ad man, now running an agency in Miami, is the man behind the current TV commercials being seen in New York, Boston and Washington, as well as throughout Florida, in which George Kennedy, the actor, promotes an airline passbook with a 10-year life.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES MOST OF CHARGES AT GIBSON TRIAL
description: A judge dismissed today 67 of the remaining 69 charges against Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and 51 of the remaining 53 counts against his co-defendant, former City Council President Earl Harris.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $319,000 for the qr and $200,000 for the 9 mos

title: Aid to Vietnam Voted by Food Agency
description: The World Food Program approved more than $180 million in aid to 15 countries today.

description: B-Including a gain of $547,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of marketable securities...C-Including gains of $7.3 million for the qr and $12.5 million for the 6 mos on the sale of marketable securities; shr earnings have been adjusted for aggregate stock distributions paid through Oct 1, 1982

title: UNCONSTITUTIONAL NEW YORK ABORTION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Kodak to Raise Copier Prices
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced that prices on its copiers and duplicators would be increased by up to 6 percent beginning Jan. 3 because of the rising cost of doing business and generally depressed business conditions.

title: REAGAN IS FACTOR IN CONNECTICUT RACE
description: Representative Stewart B. McKinney likes to call Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District ''the land of steady habits.'' One of its steadiest has been the election of Mr. McKinney, a Republican. Six times he has won, usually in walkovers.

title: GREECE'S SOCIALISM - CAUTIOUS, INDEPENDENT
description: The first 12 months of Socialist Government in Greece have disappointed those who predicted chaos at home and disruption in Greece's foreign alliances. They have also illustrated some of the common tendencies of the European Socialist parties.

No Headline
description: CONNORS DEFEATS TELTSCHER

title: GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEHRMAN OFFERS A PLAN TO ASSIST SMALL BUSINESS
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Governor, proposed a five-point plan today to ''get state government out of the way of small business'' and make New York what he termed a breeding ground for innovative small-scale entrepreneurs.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated for a 5 percent stock divd paid in Sept

title: 2 WEEKS OF TRAINING LIKELY AFTER STRIKE
description: When the National Football League player strike ends, the season will presumably resume, but not necessarily soon. Club physicians and trainers for the Jets and Giants say players may need at least two weeks to get into pre-strike condition.

title: Warning From Patriots
description: Pete Brock, Steve Grogan and Steve Nelson, three of the eight Patriot players who performed in Sunday's all-star game at Washington sponsored by the National Football League Players Association, received warnings before the game by telephone from Billy Sullivan, the owner of the team, and his son Patrick. Brock told The Boston Globe that Patrick Sullivan, the assistant general manager, had informed his lawyer that if Brock was hurt in the game, he would be in violation of his contract and that the guaranteed contract would be voided.

title: MARK PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

SHULTZ FORESEES UPSETS IN COMMUNIST NATIONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that recent developments in Communist countries ''suggest that a new age of democratic reform and revolution lies ahead of us.'' He said that while the United States would not seek to foment violent unrest, it also would not ignore those seeking to bring about change.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mexican Trade Surplus
description: Mexico had a $1.4 billion trade surplus in the first eight months of 1982, in contrast to a $3.4 billion deficit a year earlier, the Government announced Monday night.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLAYS
description: T he Carpenteria (Calif.) High School coach signaled his players to huddle near their 20-yard line, where he thought they would take over the ball.

title: EMBATTLED BINI RETURNS TO THE MET'S 'GIOCONDA'
description: Carlo Bini returned last night to the scene of his humiliation last Wednesday, when he was nearly booed off the stage of the Metropolitan Opera as Enzo in ''La Gioconda'' after replacing an ailing Placido Domingo in midopera.

title: CARDINALS DEFEAT BREWERS, 13-1, TO FORCE 7th GAME
description: In a game interrupted twice by rain for more than two and one-half hours, the St. Louis Cardinals hammered out a 13-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers early today and tied the World Series at three games apiece.

title: ART: BRAQUE SHOW FINDS HOME IN WASHINGTON
description: ''GEORGES BRAQUE: The Late Paintings 1940-1963'' at the Phillips Gallery in Washington is the right show in the right place. It also comes at the right time, in that Braque was born 100 years ago this year - an anniversary that no museum in New York thought it worth while to celebrate.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Total income figures for the latest periods include land sales of $40,870 for the qr and $5,292,589 for the 9 mos and rentals, royalites and other income of $1,715,393 for the qr and $5,155,885 for the 9 mos; total income figures for the yr-ago periods include land sales of $1,757,318 for the qr and $3,338,238 for the9 mos and rentals, royalties and other income of $1,836,660 for the qr and $5,369,461; shr earnings are per sub-shrs

title: Dutch Center-Right Bloc Agrees to Try Coalition
description: Leaders of the two main center-right Dutch parties have agreed on policies for a new coalition government, an official mediator's report said tonight.

description: B-Including a gain on the sale of real estate of $470,000 or 10 cents a shr...C-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $186,000 or 4 cents a shr for theqr and 6 mos

title: GOWNS BY WORTH: GILDED AGE'S OPULENCE
description: AS the nearly 400 guests entered the great hall with its marble floors, crystal chandelier and dramatic curving staircase, the mood was set. It was the opening-night party Monday at the Museum of the City of New York for ''The House of Worth: The Gilded Age, 1860-1918.''

title: June Shaplen, 58, Reporter, Writer and Magazine Editor
description: June Herman Shaplen, a writer and editor, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J. Mrs. Shaplen, a native of Rochester, began her writing career as a reporter for The Democrat & Chronicle in Rochester, after graduating from the University of Rochester in 1946.

title: JOAQUIN ANDUJAR GETS SECOND CHANCE
description: ST. LOUIS F or the first six games, the biggest factor in the World Series was Joaquin Andujar's right leg. Now the seventh game of the Series will depend on Andujar's heart as well.

title: CITICORP POSTS GAIN OF 55.6%
description: The nation's two largest banks yesterday reported their earnings for the third quarter, conveying two sharply contrasting reactions to falling interest rates.

title: 'STALKER,' RUSSIAN SCIENCE-FICTION
description: HOWEVER we may be doing in the arms race or the space race, we're winning the science fiction movie race by a mile. Andrei Tarkovsky's ''Stalker,'' a somber futuristic fantasy from the Soviet Union, attempts to build an apocalyptic vision out of the most impoverished materials imaginable. It's certainly not necessary to construct an Oz or an E.T. in the service of every film fantasy. On the other hand, the fact that film is a visual medium cannot entirely be ignored. ''Stalker'' offers the eye so little that it might well have made a better novel, or short story, than a nearly three-hour-long film.

title: THE CAPITALIST 'WITCHES' OF SALEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Youngstown Tops U.S.; With 20.9%; Jobless
description: Youngstown, Ohio, has the highest unemployment among major metropolitan areas in the nation at 20.9 percent, with Michigan and Alabama the hardest-hit states, Labor Department statistics showed today.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Royal Roberto Wins at Laurel
description: Royal Roberto rallied for a threelength victory over Uncle Jeff in the $69,750 Laurel Turf Cup today as the 60-day meeting at Laurel Race Course opened.

title: SUPERSTAR AND MAVERICK, DELOREAN NEVER FIT MOLD
description: Maverick. It is a word often applied to John Zachary DeLorean, a superstar of the American automobile industry who never seemed to fit the mold.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
LOCKWOOD WILL TALK ON THE EARLY 'VILLAGE'
description: Charles Lockwood, a writer on New York and its historical development, will lecture, with slides, about life in Greenwich Village during the early 1880's today at 6:30 p.m. in St. Jospeh's Church, 371 Avenue of the Americas, near Eighth Street.

title: WILLIAMS TO REJOIN TEAM
description: The Nets beat the Knicks, 87-82, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight in an exhibition game that answered few questions for either team.

title: CUOMO GIVES HIS PLAN TO FIGHT CRIME
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, said yesterday that if elected he would appoint a director of public safety ''to ensure that the billions of dollars New York State and local governments spend on criminal justice are put to work to wage a lean but successful campaign on crime.''

title: Council Primary Won By Castaneira Colon
description: Rafael Castaneira Colon easily won a special primary yesterday by defeating incumbent Councilman Gilberto Gerena-Valentin to become the Democratic candidate in the 11th council district in the South Bronx in the Nov. 2 election. Mr. Castaneira Colon gathered 3,573 votes to Mr. Gerena-Valentin's 2,310.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Education column in Science Times yesterday gave two incorrect figures for California high school seniors' Scholastic Aptitude Test scores. From 1972 to 1980, scores on the mathematics section dropped an average of 21 points. The average on the math section this year was 474.

title: NEW TURKISH CHARTER OFFERS 7 MORE YEARS OF MILITARY RULE
description: Turkey's military rulers today approved the final version of a new constitution assuring them seven more years in power if it is approved in a referendum on Nov. 7.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Editorial Notebook; Prix Fixe for Medicare
description: Richard Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is pushing the idea of fixed hospital payments to cut down on Medicare costs. And he points to New Jersey's early success with a similar system. But officials in New Jersey urge caution. Their fixed-payment system has saved money, they say, but has also created difficult management problems.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the yr-ago qr and 9 mos have been restated to conform with F.A.S.B.Statement No 52 which established new accounting standards for foreign currencytranslations

title: ISLANDERS WIN SIXTH IN ROW
description: Mike Bossy scored on a power play with 1 minute 14 seconds to play tonight, giving the Islanders a 5-4 victory over the Vancouver Canucks. Bossy's goal was his second of the game and ninth of the season.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Herzog Honored
description: The Sporting News today named Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals manager of the year. Herzog edged Milwaukee's Harvey Kuenn in the balloting of major league managers conducted for the weekly newspaper.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE GROMYKO'S MIND
description: To the Editor:

title: Honor of Sorts
description: The world's two lightweight champions are training for title fights at the same Palm Springs, Calif., hotel. So the bar at the Canyon Hotel, to honor Alexis Arguello and Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, named a pair of drinks for the boxers.

title: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $8.2 million for the qr and $18 million for the 9 mos

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BREADS BAKED ON THE STOVE TOP
description: THE first image conjured up by the word ''bread'' is that of a sliceable loaf, its shape a matter of custom and ethnic preference. Americans tend to think of all breads as baked in ovens - oblong loaves, flat breads, round loaves, crusty ovals or sticks of baked dough almost as sturdy as baseball bats. Baking, so goes the conventional wisdom, means cooking in ovens.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT might be supposed that thinking about one's last meal on earth would be so depressing that even imaginary appetites would shrivel. It isn't so. As a matter of fact, it's one of the newest diversions, even at a lot of dinner parties, and rather than fostering gloom and doom, it spurs a good deal of lively conversation.

title: TRUDEAU HAS 21 U.S. EXECUTIVES UP FOR CHAT
description: Unheralded, arriving in a squadron of sleek corporate jets, 21 senior executives of several of the biggest corporations in the United States arrived here today for private talks with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Cabinet about the investment climate here.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPUBLIC IN LOSS AS SALES LAG
description: The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $74.6 million as a result of the depressed economy.

title: CONCERT: VON KARAJAN LEADS THE BERLINERS
description: known Austrian virtuoso and musical icon, brought his famous instrument to Carnegie Hall last night for the first of three concerts and proceeded to show why he has become an almost unassailable hero for half the musical world, or more. He is, if not the greatest conductor still active, at least the most charismatic.

title: A FIT MRS. WAITZ TRIES AGAIN
description: Grete Waitz has run five marathons in her life. She won the first three and broke the women's world record each time. She would like to forget the last two.

title: GOULD SELLING PART OF ELECTRIC DIVISION
description: Gould Inc., a maker of high-technology electronics parts, said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell a significant portion of its electric motor division. While Gould would disclose neither the prospective buyer nor the terms of the transaction, analysts estimated the price at about $100 million.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUPER CALLS GAME 'BEST' PERFORMANCE
description: John Stuper, the Cardinals' rookie righthander who limited the Milwaukee Brewers to four hits in tonight's rain-interrupted sixth World Series game, called it ''the best'' performance of his career.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Early California Industries said its Comet Rice Inc. subsidiary had acquired all the stock outstanding of Pirmi Delta Inc., a rice miller in Greenville, Miss.; terms were not disclosed.

title: DAN RIVER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $686,000

title: FROM FRANCE, BARGAIN WINES
description: ARISING tide of inexpensive wine from Europe is rolling across the Atlantic to American consumers in response to sharply expanding demand here, and bargain bottles are showing up in stores all across the country. Not since the early 1970's have such attractive buys from France, Italy, Spain and Portugal, among other countries, been available here, and importers say the situation probably will get even better as time passes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no alternative than to agree to give parts of the land of Israel away if it will bring peace.

title: New Book Says Johnson Had a Secret Romance
description: A biographer says that Lyndon B. Johnson, married at the time and an ambitious Congressman, began a love affair in the late 1930's with the beautiful mistress of the man who published one of his district's most powerful newspapers, it was reported today.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOUNTY TO BRIGHTEN ANY TABLE
description: Robert Farrar Capon is an Episcopal theologian, author and food writer whose next book, ''The Youngest Day: An Island's Seasons in the Light of Grace,'' will be published next spring by Harper & Row.

title: DELOREAN, AUTOMOBILE EXECUTIVE, ARRESTED IN DRUG SMUGGLING CASE
description: John Z. DeLorean, the chairman of the DeLorean Motor Company, was arrested here today and charged with possession of more than 59 pounds of cocaine.

title: HASBRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock paid Aug 19

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Homemade Americana
description: First, Star Spangled Food, an East Side specialty shop, opened to sell only American fare. Then Bloomingdale's began a promotion featuring regional foods from the 50 states. Next spring Macy's will join the American bandwagon. All this activity can only be good for the thousands all over the United States who are engaged in cottage industries, producing small supplies of handmade regional foods known only in their neighborhoods.

title: Korab Is Suspended
description: The spate of recent punishments imposed for violent play in the National Hockey League continued yesterday when the Jerry Korab, a Los Angeles Kings defenseman, was dealt a six-game suspension after a match penalty he received in a game last Thursday at Quebec. The suspension includes two games Korab missed last weekend while awaiting his hearing before Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president. Korab drew the match penalty when he swung his stick at Dale Hunter of the Nordiques, catching him on the jaw and opening a wound that required several stitches to close.

title: MUSICAL: 'THREE TRAVELS OF ALADIN'
description: ''THE Three Travels of Aladin With the Magic Lamp'' brings Elizabeth Swados back to home ground. The new musical is playing at La Mama Annex, where the composer created her evocative scores for Andrei Serban's explorations of Greek tragedy. ''Aladin'' is a brief chamber opera, written in collaboration with Francoise Grund, who acts as author, director and designer.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''THE doctor said my cholesterol was O.K. but my triglycerides were too high. What does that mean?'' The questioner was not sure whether to worry. He is one of many thousands of people who periodically have a triglyceride measurement taken as part of a routine health checkup; if all Americans were tested at least one in 20 would be found to have triglyceride, or fat, levels in their blood that are generally regarded as ''too high.'' His concern was only partly relieved when he was told that his doctor was also probably uncertain about the importance of elevated triglycerides.

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $4.9 million or 19 cents a shr from the sale of real estat

title: HOW MANHATTAN DEMOCRATS PICK STATE SUPREME COURT CANDIDATES
description: To the Editor:

title: CANDIDATES FOR STATE ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: ROBERT ABRAMS, Attorney General since 1978 ... says they have been ''wonderful years, personally and professionally'' ... points in $1 million package of television ads to protection of the environment, halt to shipping radioactive wastes through cities, opposition to casino gambling ... ads also display his family ... in one ad, his 75-yearold father, Ben, hugs him and says, ''Bob, what a success'' ... son says laughingly that ''biggest job in this campaign is keeping my father from climbing poles to put up my posters'' ... born July 4, 1938, in the Bronx and brought up there ... now lives in Manhattan ... started in ''reform'' politics while still in New York University Law School ... was elected Assemblyman and Bronx Borough President ... ran unsuccessfully against Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz in 1974 ... differed with Governor Carey over power to hire out

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jury Selected at Trial Of Teamsters' Chief
description: Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall today swore in a jury of six men and six women who will hear the Government's case against Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, and four co-defendants. They are charged with attempting to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada.

title: VALLEYLAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
1. Return of the Stickpin
description: Now that women are back in suits and hats, look for the return of the stickpin, that versatile bit of decor that can be fastened to a lapel or a hat or to the neck of a shirt. Some interesting new pins are made of faceted crystal that started out as buttons in the 1920's. The haberdashers called Addison on Madison found a cache of the buttons in Paris and had them mounted on silver pins. They were meant for men's tie pins, but many women are buying them. The pins are $35; the shop is at 698 Madison Avenue (62d Street).

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS SAY THE ECONOMY WON'T PLAY IN PEORIA
description: In the Nixon Administration this farming and industrial community on the busy Illinois River became a pulse point of national politics when White House aides were encouraged to ask themselves if their ideas would ''play in Peoria.''

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VOTE SEEN AS MILD SETBACK TO GREEK SOCIALISTS
description: The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou enters its second year this week after receiving a mild setback in municipal elections last Sunday.

title: Westport's Offer
description: The Westport Company said yesterday that it was still offering $14 a share for the Northwestern Mutual Life Mortgage and Realty Investors, even though the management of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company rejected the offer. In a letter to Francis Ferguson, the chairman of Northwestern, Westport said it hoped he would reconsider the offer.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; Hunting Value At a Low Price
description: IN a bull market that offers few stocks at prices near their lows, Castle & Cooke could be appealing. But, as is so often true, anyone who might speculate in the stock must weigh the possible dangers.

title: SETBACK HANDED TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: A Western diplomatic source said today that Soviet ground forces in Afghanistan had staged a four-day assault on a rebel stronghold 12 miles northwest of the capital and had then withdrawn, leaving it in the hands of Afghan troops.

title: SMALL BANKERS FEEL THE PINCH
description: Despite the customary lavish receptions, this year's annual convention of the American Bankers Association is not a particularly joyous affair.

title: MEAT PIES: SUSTAINING FARE
description: ENGLISH cooking is often the subject of japes and jests, but I can recall a number of incredible meals in Britain, feasts that seem somehow more vivid in the memory now that fall has arrived and one's thoughts drift to hearty, sustaining fare. I remember enormous breakfasts in Scotland and Ireland and London for which the tables were laden with huge roasts of gammon ham, platters of grilled kippers and finnan haddie, grilled tomatoes and expertly scrambled eggs, delectable jams and preserves and a spectacular assortment of breads, crumpets, scones and the finest of sweet butter, plus coffee and tea.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Standard No 52 for foreign currency translations

title: Soviet Capital Struck By First Major Snow
description: A snowstorm with winds gusting to 34 miles an hour hit the Soviet capital today, bringing the first snow accumulation of the long winter.

title: PARIS-BONN MILITARY TIES: A TIME FOR REAPPRAISAL
description: France and West Germany are entering a phase of intense consultation on military matters that, according to French officials, may involve new tactics, joint production of weapons, and the possibility of a thinning out of French forces stationed in West Germany.

title: Apartheid and the I.M.F.
description: With its continued commitment to apartheid, South Africa makes itself a tempting target for pressure from groups offended by official racism. Thus its application for a loan from the International Monetary Fund is stirring objections in the United Nations and Congress. Outright rejection of the loan on political grounds would mean that the fund could no longer serve its global purpose - to help any member in trouble. But approval with proper strings attached could help lift the shroud of South African injustice.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Iowa Coach Angry
description: Hayden Fry has been coaching football for half of his 53 years, but the Iowa coach says the game has become so violent he has thought about quitting. ''It really makes me re-evaluate my employment, it's the only really distasteful part of coaching,'' Fry said as he spoke of injuries his players suffered in last Saturday's 29-7 loss to Michigan.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEITHER PRINCIPAL IN GIBSON TRIAL TAKES THE STAND
description: The defense in the conspiracy and misconduct trial of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and former City Council President Earl Harris rested its case today without calling either defendant to testify.

title: Real Estate; Shift Seen In Housing Outlook
description: THE tide is changing in real estate, according to Herve A. Kevenides, vice president and director of real estate economics and market research at the Chemical Bank. New growth in residential construction is expected, he says, at a time of decline for commercial real estate.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $58.3 million...C-Net income including a pretax gain of $82,304,000 for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of coal properties...D-Including a net gain of $4,632,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting changeand a pretax gain of $12,693,000 from the sale of coal properties and other item

title: A M'CARTHY TARGET
description: Reed Harris, a former State Department official who was one of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's earliest targets in his anti-Communist investigations in the 1950's, died of a heart attack Friday in Washington. He was 72 years old.

title: CONTINENTAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN RUMANIA, 'PLOTS' AND HARD TIMES
description: Despite moves by President Nicolae Ceausescu to maintain his tight control, Rumania remains gripped by an economic crisis that shows no sign of easing.

title: ECONOMY DEALS BLOW TO MEXICAN ART
description: Not many months ago, when Mexico's economy was booming and its private banks were busily investing in paintings and sculptures, the country's artists were flourishing as never before. Well-known names such as Rufino Tamayo and Jose Luis Cuevas brought record prices for their works at New York auctions, while even younger painters discovered that art was also business.

title: LED TRANSITION IN LONDON BANKING
description: Sir Siegmund George Warburg, the international banker, died Monday after a short illness. He was 80 years old and had been visiting London from his home near Lausanne, Switzerland, for medical treatment.

title: Donald Fagen Returns to 50's Roots
description: THE suburban neighborhood is quiet, the houses dark, except for a single light burning in an upstairs room. Inside, there's a teenager with his ear next to a portable radio. He's playing it softly, so his parents won't wake up, and he can barely make out the sounds through the static. ''I'm Lester the Nightfly,'' says the voice on the radio, ''with jazz and conversation from the foot of Mount Belzoni.'' The teen-ager listens, entranced, far into the night.

title: RIVAL COACHES PRAISE DEVILS
description: More desire, a new environment and a better blend of experience and youth are the main reasons the New Jersey Devils have been the surprise team in the National Hockey League, according to four of the coaches whose teams have played the Devils in the two-week-old season.

title: Baseball Roundup
description: Doug Rader, the former major league infielder who is now the manager of the San Diego Padres' farm club at Hawaii, has been interviewed as a candidate for the managing post with the Texas Rangers. Other candidates include Bobby Valentine, a scout for the Mets, and Jim Leyland, a coach with the Chicago White Sox. But Mike Ferraro, the Yankee coach who had been thought to be the leading contender, is now reportedly out of the running....The Baltimore Orioles placed two veteran but recently ineffective pitchers, Ross Grimsley and Don Stanhouse, on waivers.... Don Aase, the California relief pitcher who missed much of the past season because of an injued right elbow, has undergone surgery and is expected to miss all of next season.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Low Turnout Pleases Fund Event Planners
description: Senator John H. Chafee was not disappointed when only a half-dozen people attended his fund-raising event at a local fried chicken outlet. It was planned that way.

title: POLICE CONTINUE SEARCH FOR A BEARDED MAN SEEN IN TYLENOL PICTURE
description: A nationwide manhunt continued today for a Missouri man suspected of attempted extortion in the poisoned Tylenol case as experts using computers and other techniques to enhance photographic images worked to trace a man seen in a picture taken by a drugstore surveillance camera.

description: Nicaragua won a seat on the Security Council today in what diplomats here felt was a defeat for the United States.

Showers, Shelters
description: ''For the city to come in on the eve of winter and say 'we don't want to obey the consent decree' is not only shameless, but also heartless,'' said Robert Hayes of the Coalition for the Homeless. He was referring to New York's request that it be allowed to provide fewer lavatories and showers in shelters for homeless men.

title: TRIAL OF MISSISSIPPI EX-MAYOR RAISES WIDE BLACK ANXIETIES
description: Eddie James Carthan's election as the first black mayor since Reconstruction prompted euphoric predictions of a new dawn for blacks in this tiny Delta town.

description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. today announced a new subsidiary, the Toyota Motor Credit Corporation, to provide financing for Toyota dealers.

title: THEATER: 'THE GOLDEN LAND'
description: THE immigrant lives in a half world, with his feet planted, unfirmly, in the old country and the new. These two unsteady feet have been made to stand, quite steadily, in ''The Golden Land,'' a musical show that ran last weekend at the Folksbiene Playhouse.

title: Let Uncle Sam Do It!
description: There seems to be agreement around here that the Israelis and the Arabs can't agree on anything, but this is not precisely true. For they all seem to agree on one thing: that Uncle Sam could solve their problems if only he had enough gumption to follow their contradictory advice.

title: CAPITAL READING LISTS DISPLAY A POLITICAL BENT
description: While readers elsewhere in the nation were browsing through ''Life Extension'' last week to learn how to add years to their lives, many Washingtonians were riveted to ''Puzzle Palace'' in hopes of discovering how the National Security Agency spies on other people's lives.

title: GEMAYEL ASKS U.S. TO WEIGH INCREASE IN PEACE UNIT
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon asked President Reagan today to consider expanding the size and scope of the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon to help bring about an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces, a senior State Department official said.

description: Trading volume swelled above 100 million shares yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as prices of some blue-chip issues eased after recent strong gains. A number of stocks, meanwhile, responded to quarterly earnings reports.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MARIN MARINES

title: REAGAN'S PLAN OFFERS PALESTINIANS HOPE
description: occupied West Bank - Neither the Israeli Government nor the Palestinian people have endorsed President Reagan's peace initiative - but for very different reasons. The problem for Prime Minister Menachem Begin is that, to him, the plan seems unambiguous, and thus threatens to curtail the room to maneuver provided by the ambiguity of the Camp David accords. We Palestinians worry that the initiative may not satisfy our demands for a homeland, and yet, for us, there may be hope in what we see, precisely, as the ambiguity of the Reagan proposal.

title: Union Carbide Slumps 48.8%; Philip Morris Is Up 20.3%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that the impact of the recession on heavy industry had caused net income in the third quarter to plunge 48.8 percent, while sales dropped 10 percent.

title: COATTAILS
description: After dusk chased the flickering sunlight off the north Texas plain, 70 people gathered Tuesday night in the Chamber of Commerce offices to hear Jim Bradshaw, from nearby Fort Worth, contend that the latest surge in stocks proved ''President Reagan is on the right track and things are getting better.''

title: ABRAMS AND MISS SCLAFINI CLASH IN THEIR FIRST DEBATE
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams described his agency as ''primarily a civil office'' yesterday, then frowned as his opponent, Frances A. Sclafani, challenged his definition and called him a lawyer ''who has never tried a criminal case.''

BOC valued its total investment at about $130 million, including the cost of the 26 percent share BOC already holds in Mountain Medical, bringing its stake in that company to 52 percent.

description: BOTH science and poetry feed on analogies -between the earth and an apple, between the state and a human organism. So does economics, noting the similarities between a market economy and a balanced ecological system or the solar system, or between the years 1982 and 1929.

title: PARIS ELEGANCE, KOSHER NOUVELLE CUISINE
description: A strictly kosher restaurant serving nouvelle cuisine dishes behind bulletproof windows has just opened in Paris in a building that once was one of the city's most famous bordellos.

title: News Analysis
description: The Beirut massacre is poisoning the atmosphere of Israel's most important institutions: the Cabinet and the army.

title: PRICES WEAKEN LATE IN DAY
description: Prices in the credit markets weakened yesterday afternoon after opening on a strong note, dealers said. Although many analysts are predicting further declines in rates, traders said investors were not as willing to buy notes and bonds yesterday as they were earlier this month.

title: NEW ASIAN ALIENS CONCERN OFFICIALS
description: Refugees from the impoverished South Asian country of Bangladesh have begun making their way illegally into the United States by way of the Bahamas, the immigration authorities here said today.

description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin tonight won parliamentary approval of his tough stand on limited autonomy for the Palestinian Arabs of the West Bank and Gaza, along with his avowed intention not to relinquish control of these areas.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Express Credit Corp. filed with the S.E.C for $400 million of debt securities to be offered through various underwriters.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Terry Metcalf, the former running back and wide receiver for the St. Louis Cardinals and the Washington Redskins, was named director of player relations for the Washington Federals of the United States Football League. Metcalf is also to head a charitable foundation established by the club's chairman, Berl Bernhard, which will work with youth groups, high schools and charities in the community. ... The Oakland Invaders of the U.S.F.L. signed their first player, Cedric Hardman, the defensive end formerly with the San Francisco 49ers and the Oakland Raiders.

title: ELECTION IN SRI LANKA CAPITALISM VERSUS SOCIALISM
description: The eight million voters of this tropical island republic will choose in Wednesday's presidential election between free-wheeling, high-growth capitalism and something very near to a classic form of welfare socialism.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING UP 14.4%
description: With interest rates falling, the nation's builders started work on more new single-family houses in September than they did in any month for more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PSA's Head Facing More Responsibility
description: If all goes well, Paul C. Barkley, president and chief operating officer of PSA Inc., may soon be presiding over an airline double the size of its current 30-plane fleet and flying over a much larger geographic area.

OPERA: 'NOZZE DI FIGARO'
description: THE season's first performance of Mozart's ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' at the New York City Opera on Sunday night was a rare example of a Mozart opera well played, well staged and well sung. The work emerged as an operatic dance, a sequence of steps, with disguise giving way to recognition, discontent to reconciliation.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The ice skating rink at Rockefeller Center is symbolic of a great many things about New York City. Like the thick, musty smell of heat rising from long-cold radiators, or the display of bathing suits and caftans known in department store windows as resort wear, the opening of the skating rink is a sure sign that winter has come to the city.

title: Goodyear Layoff
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced the layoff of an additional 200 workers at its tire plant here. It had already laid off 650.

As a result, it said, it will charge $10.6 million against earnings for the second quarter ending Sept. 30. The company had previously charged $10.2 million against prior years earnings to cover back taxes.

CLAY POTATO COOKER
description: AS the days get shorter, so does the supply of fresh vegetables in most parts of the country. It is the time of year when many cooks turn their attention to hearty root vegetables such as the potato to get them through the dark months. It's not really that grim, though, for the potato is one of the most versatile and nutritious vegetables around. It can be baked, boiled, sauteed, deep-fried, stuffed, mashed and hashed as well as embellished in an endless variety of ways.

description: * Agrico Chemical Company, Tulsa, Okla., has named Duane C. Wise senior vice president-corporate development.

Lyon, a former associate dean at Pratt Institute.

description: Genentech Inc. said today that it expects to report a third-quarter loss but that it still planned to break even by the end of the year.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS RETRACT MONEY GUARANTEE
description: Negotiators for the National Football League told the Players Association today that the owners would no longer guarantee the players $1.6 billion during the life of a new collective-bargaining agreement.

title: N.B.A. Owners Will Be Briefed on Talks
description: The National Basketball Association owners will hold a special meeting today in Chicago at which they will be brought up to date on the progress of labor negotiations with the players association.

title: 20 Poles in Small Plane Defect to Swedish Town
description: Twenty Poles, including five children, flew today across the Baltic Sea in a small plane to Malmo, Sweden, and asked for political asylum, the police said.

title: AIDE SAYS LEBANON CONTINUES INQUIRY
description: A Government official said today that Lebanon was continuing its official investigation of the massacre of more than 300 people that took place Sept. 16 to 18 at two Palestinian refugee camps here.

title: Notre Dame Gets Award
description: Notre Dame has been named this year's recipient of the Academic Achievement Award, given annually by the Touchdown Club of Memphis to the member of the College Football Association that graduates the highest percentage of football players.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court Backs Dropping Of Drama on Beheading
description: The refusal of two public television stations to air a 1980 documentary-drama about the beheading of a Saudi Arabian princess did not infringe upon viewers' First Amendment rights, a Federal appeals court has ruled here.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS do most members of my family, I have an unabashed liking for meat loaf in almost any variety, and I like to include recipes for it in this column. However, readers have occasionally complained that they could not turn out a meat loaf in an hour. The preparation does require a bit of work, and the baking time, provided the loaf is made in a standard pan, is about 45 minutes or slightly longer.

title: JOSEPH ZIMMERMAN
description: Dr. Joseph Zimmerman, a metals economist and market analyst, and vice president of the Miles Metal Company for the last 21 years, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Energy Exchange
description: The Energy Exchange Corporation, Tampa, Fla., said it would accept oil and gas properties with a net exchange value of $285 million that had been tendered under its offer to exchange common shares for the properties. The transaction is subject to conditions specified in the company's July 21 prospectus/proxy statement.

title: No Headline

title: HUGH SHANNON, 61, SINGER AND PIANIST IN COCKTAIL LOUNGES
description: Hugh Shannon, a cocktail pianist and singer, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 61 years old. When Mr. Shannon returned to New York in 1963 after a career in Rome, Capri, Paris and the Virgin Islands, John S. Wilson wrote in The New York Times:

title: SPOKESMEN FOR TWO PARTIES DIFFER ON MEANING OF ECONOMIC CHANGES
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders argued tonight on national television over whether recent economic indicators, especially advances in the stock markets, meant that the country's economy was recovering.

title: Coast Dean Disappears After His Arrival Here
description: A California college dean disappeared last Friday after arriving in New York City for a speaking engagement, the police said last night. The dean, Dr. Daniel Jordan of the School of Education at National University in San Diego, was to have lectured here on Saturday.

title: Students Are Sleeping In Halls to Gain Jobs
description: Engineering students are sleeping in hallways at the University of Missouri to gain access to campus interviewers, administrators say.

title: CALIFORNIA G.O.P. WARY OF REAGAN VISIT
description: Republican strategists are worried about bringing President Reagan back to his home state for last-minute campaigning because they fear his presence would drive more Democrats than Republicans to the polls. The present intention is not to have him campaign in California, although the plans may change.

title: U.P.I. Wants a Splash From Lois, Pitts
description: ''We wanted someone who was splashy, exciting and aggressive,'' said William K. Adler, new director of information of United Press International, as he described the news service's selection of an ad agency. ''We knew we had to move fast and we couldn't have a stodgy, conservative approach. We had to show we were doing something exciting.''

title: Battle of the Beers
description: At the concession stands, the World Series between the beerproducing cities of Milwaukee and St. Louis is not going according to form. During the regular season, when the Brewers set a club attendance record of 1,978,896, Milwaukee fans consumed three million cups of assorted beers (Miller's, Schlitz, Pabst and Hamm's), an average of 1.516 beers per head (human, not foamy).

title: Reagan Trip to Carolina
description: President Reagan will campaign for Republican candidates in North Carolina next Tuesday and will present a Medal of Freedom to Kate Smith, the singer. Larry Speakes, deputy White House press secretary, announced the trip today, adding that the President would speak at a Republican campaign rally and would meet with Southern regional party chairmen.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Molitor's Bat Enshrined
description: Paul Molitor, the Milwaukee Brewer third baseman, was in St. Louis with his teammates last night for their World Series game with the Cardinals.

title: F.B.I. SAYS CRIME IS DOWN IN U.S. BUT HOUSTON REPORTS RISE OF 17%
description: The incidence of major crime fell significantly in the nation for the first six months of the year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. But crime rose by more than 17 percent in Houston, the largest rise for any city in the nation.

title: A SELF-CARE APPROACH TO DIABETES CONTROL
description: THERE were warning signs. First her hands tingled, then her tongue. Her lips burned. She broke out into a sweat. Her blood sugar was dropping dangerously low. She needed a can of soda, or orange juice, fast. The woman, a 26-year-old legal secretary, got as far the supermarket door before she fainted.

description: The Insilco Corporation said its board had approved a plan to sell its International Silver Company subsidiary and to phase out production at its plant in Meriden, Conn.

title: MOSCOW WANTS ISRAELIS OUT OF U.N. AGENCIES
description: A Pravda commentary today supported moves to expel Israel from international agencies operating within the United Nations framework, but the wording suggested that the Soviet Union would continue to be cautious about similar efforts to oust Israel from the General Assembly.

title: Monsieur Quixote
description: In the best sense of the term, Pierre Mendes-France was quixotic, a politician drawn to and undaunted by windmills. When his country was collapsing in 1941, Mr. Mendes-France scorned realism, escaped from Vichy and joined the Resistance at its coldest hour.

title: News Analysis
description: When the police requested Friday night that WABC-TV broadcast the full text of a statement from a gunman holding hostages at a Brooklyn hospital, ''we didn't have the time to sit down and debate the philosophic and ethical aspects of the request,'' the station's news director said yesterday.

title: ARMY HALTING JOINT TRAINING OF MALE AND FEMALE RECRUITS
description: The Army is ending its four-year experiment of combining male and female basic training, which began when the proposed equal rights amendment seemed likely to become part of the Constitution.

title: SUTTON STILL WAITING FOR TITLE
description: Don Sutton, the Milwaukee Brewers' starting and losing pitcher, messed up his chance tonight to assure himself something he has never achieved in his 17 years in the major leagues: being a member of a World Series champion.

WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Cardinals vs. Milwaukee Brewers, World Series, seventh and deciding game, if necessary, at St. Louis. The Brewers are going after their first world championship, the Cardinals their first in 15 years. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:20 P.M.) Boxing LeRoy Haley, champion, vs. Giovanni Giuseppe Gimenez, World Boxing Council's superlightweight title bout, 15 rounds, at Cleveland. This is Haley's first defense, and it comes against the W.B.C.'s No. 1 challenger. The undercard includes a 10-round bout between thirdranked Saoul Mamby of the Bronx, from whom Haley captured the title last June, and 13th-ranked Monroe Brooks. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Doug DeWitt vs. Teddy Mann, middleweights, and Paul DeVorce vs. Tony Tris, featherweights, 10-round co-feature bouts, at the Westchester County Center, White Plains; first preliminary, 8 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Vancouver Canucks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. The Ranger center Robbie Ftorek has recovered from a pulled groin muscle and is scheduled to play. But there is bad news, too, for New York: John Davidson, who had been playing well in his comeback effort in goal, has an ailing back again and will be out for a while. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Devils vs. Los Angeles Kings, at Inglewood, Calif. New Jersey goes after its third consecutive victory. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; 10:30 P.M.) Other Events Harness Racing: Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape.)

Now Mr. Cole, the Manhattan poet and anthologist, has uncovered remarkable new historical evidence. ''Did Dorothy Parker invent knock-knocks?'' he asks. ''This is a startling thought that came to me reading Edmund Wilson's notebooks and diary entries, 'The Twenties.' '' Here is Mr. Cole's report:

description: INDUSTRIAL designers have an identity problem, according to RitaSue Siegel. She operates a personnel firm in New York bearing her name, RitaSue Siegel Agency Inc., that specializes in placing industrial designers and other design personnel. Some of her clients work directly with companies, others do freelance jobs and still others work for consulting firms that are commissioned by companies.
