description: Koch Boycott

title: TV: JOYCE PLAY ON CABLE
description: THE work is minor. The production is rarely more than competent. But ''Exiles,'' being shown in two weekly parts on the Mobil Showcase segment of the Hearst/ABC ARTS cable channel, merits serious attention. It happens that the author of this Ibsen-drenched play is James Joyce, the centennial of whose birth was celebrated earlier this year. Act I will be presented tonight at 9. The remaining two acts can be seen next Wednesday at the same time.

title: VICTIM
description: A civil-trial jury decided yesterday that a convicted killer should pay $40,000 in damages to the parents of the victim. The verdict came on a lawsuit that the parents filed against the killer, Richard J. Herrin, now serving 8 to 25 years in prison for manslaughter. The victim, Bonnie Joan Garland, was a 20-year-old Yale University student when she was killed five years ago in her parents' home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: FOR FOREIGNERS, RED IS THE COLOR OF SOVIET CARPET
description: An American with fluency in Russian arrived in the historic town of Suzdal with his family only to find the entrance to the dining room at his hotel barred.

title: MORE STORES SEEK CAMERA MONITORS
description: Surveillance systems like one in Chicago that has given the lawenforcement authorities what may be a lead in the Tylenol murder case present problems for some civil libertarians, but the demand for them from stores, banks and other businesses is expanding, according to those who sell the systems.

title: Israeli Druse in Protest
description: Several hundred Israeli Druse marched today from Government offices in Jerusalem to the Parliament building to protest what they describe as harassment of the Druse in Lebanon by Christian Phalangists associated with Israel. Mayor Nawaf Halabi of Daliat el-Carmel said the Druse wanted the Government to stop supporting the Phalangists.

MAN IN EAST HARLEM ACCUSED OF A $6 MILLION CHECK SCHEME
description: A 52-year-old man who worked out of a garbage-strewn East Harlem apartment has been arrested on charges that he operated an elaborate check-cashing scheme that he said defrauded Chemical Bank branches of about $3,500 a day over the last seven years, for a total of about $6 million, the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. Settlement Reported On Two Fallout Claims
description: The Government made two cash settlements more than 20 years ago with people who said that their hair had fallen out and that they were burned by radioactive fallout from atomic tests, documents introduced today in Federal court showed.

title: General in Europe Retiring
description: Gen. Frederick J. Kroesen will retire next spring as commander of United States Army troops in Europe and will be replaced by Gen. Glenn K. Otis, the Pentagon announced today. General Kroesen will retire April 30, completing more than 40 years of active service. He has held his post in Europe since May 1979.

title: Bonn Prices Show Decline
description: Inflation in West Germany, as measured by wholesale prices, fell in September for the second successive month, the federal Statistics Office said today.

title: PUTTING A LID ON HOSPITAL COSTS
description: Pressed by the Senate Finance Committee's chairman, Bob Dole, and a frustrated Congress, the Reagan Administration has rightly abandoned free-market competition as the way to hold down inflation in health-care costs, and has proposed a mandatory lid to halt the stunning increase in Medicare hospital payments.

title: Lawyers Removed From I.B.M. Case
description: A Federal judge has disqualified several attorneys for the International Business Machines Corporation from representing the giant electronics concern in a civil suit aimed at regaining some of its reportedly stolen trade secrets.

title: VOLUNTEER GROUP FOR ELDERLY SHOWS ITS VIGOR ON 11TH BIRTHDAY
description: Some carried canes, others sported corsages and many demonstrated a mean fox trot as they danced old age away yesterday in the Roseland Ballroom.

title: PESSIMISM PREVAILS ON ULSTER VOTE TODAY
description: An effort will be made Wednesday to bring a greater measure of civil order to this province by means of the ballot. But practically no one expects it to succeed.

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pesticide Curbed in 3 States
description: A Federal district judge today issued a restraining order temporarily stopping three states from using the pesticide Ferriamicide to kill fire ants. Judge Harold H. Greene, in issuing the 10-day restraining order, said Mississippi, Texas and Arkansas could not use the product because the key ingredient, Mirex, was suspected of causing cancer. The three states were granted special exemptions by the Environmental Protection Agency to use the pesticide, which has been banned elsewhere.

title: EL AL DIRECTORS PROPOSE LIQUIDATING THE AIRLINE
description: The directors of El Al, Israel's national airline, decided tonight to ask the Government to liquidate the company because employees gave only limited support to a drastic reorganization plan.

title: New England Phone Names Chief Executive
description: Gerhard M. Freche, 51, has been named chief executive of New England Telephone effective Nov. 1. Since July 1 Mr. Freche has been president of the company, which covers the New England states except Connecticut and has 3.7 million customers.

title: COURT RULES ADDITIVES MAY STAY ON MARKET
description: Twenty-three color additives used in foods, drugs and cosmetics may stay on the market even though 20 years of tests have not proved them safe, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Columbia's Woes Go Beyond Field
description: Columbia's football team does not exactly roll along, even when it travels by bus. For the third season in a row, the Lions have had a losing road trip the hard way.

title: TALKING POLITICS
description: ''The liberal coalition is dying because most of its leaders are elitists.''

title: Article 232315 -- No Title
description: State-owned British Airways announced today that it lost 544.8 million, or about $926.1 million, in the fiscal year ended last March 31, following a loss of 145.1 million, or $246.6 millon, the previous year. The 1981-82 after-tax figure was one of the largest corporate losses ever recorded in Britain.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $377,000 for the rq and $6,246,000 for the 9 mos from the repurchase of mortgage backed bonds

title: Firestone Shares
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it plans to purchase up to 5 million of its 52.1 million common shares outstanding on the open market after Friday.

title: Top Officer Resigns At Orbanco Financial
description: Donald L. Tisdel, president and chief executive of the Orbanco Financial Services Corporation, resigned yesterday. The company cited ''significant policy differences'' with the board.

title: Q&A
description: Q. All my life I have heard of hardtack. Can you tell me where the name originated?

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mets Raise Prices
description: The Mets said yesterday that ticket prices for next year would be raised a dollar because of ''spiraling costs.'' Lower box seats will be raised to $8; upper box seats to $6.50; lower and mezzanine reserved seats to $6.50; upper reserved seats to $5; picnic grounds to $6, and general admission, sold on the day of the game only, to $3. Admission for senior citizens, on their days eight to 10 times a season, will be 75 cents, an increase of 25 cents.

title: LIFEMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANONYMITY FOR BRINK'S WITNESSES IS OPPOSED
description: Criticism by defense attorneys of the use of anonymous witnesses in pretrial hearings in the Brink's case intensified today after the presiding judge granted anonymity to a witness called by the defense.

title: Spending Rises 1%; Income Up
description: Spending by Americans rose a healthy 1 percent last month, while personal income edged up only three-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: PEOPLES BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JORDAN AS THE PALESTINIAN STATE
description: Jordan most certainly has a part to play in bringing peace to the Middle East, but it would have to go far beyond the limited role outlined in the Reagan peace initiative. President Reagan may not recognize this, but we Israelis cannot afford to ignore it.

title: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
DOMINANCE OF JOBLESSNESS AS ISSUE HELPING CUOMO IN GOVERNOR RACE
description: New Yorkers are considerably more concerned about unemployment than about crime, and this is pushing voters more toward Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, than his Republican-Conservative opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman, according to a New York Times survey just completed.

title: BIG V SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 50 percent stock divd in the form of a 3-for-2 stock split declared Oct 14

title: John Michelosen Dies at 66; Football Coach in Pittsburgh
description: John Michelosen, a former University of Pittsburgh football star who went on to Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League, died Sunday in San Diego after a heart attack.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCIENCE ADVISER MOVES BEYOND ROCKY FIRST YEAR
description: When George A. Keyworth 2d was chosen as President Reagan's science adviser 17 months ago, he had two big strikes against him.

title: Northrop Posts Sharp Advance
description: The Northrop Corporation yesterday reported net earnings of $16.5 million for the third quarter, up sixfold from $2.5 million in the 1981 quarter.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1982
description: International More peacekeepers in Lebanon are sought by President Amin Gemayel, according to a senior State Department official. He said the Lebanese leader had asked President Reagan to consider expanding the size and scope of the international force, which includes 1,200 marines, to help bring about an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces. Mr. Reagan, the official said, agreed to give ''serious consideration'' to the request. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel's Parliament approved the Government's tough stand on limited autonomy for the Palestinian Arabs of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, along with the leadership's avowed intention not to relinquish control of the territories. The 56-50 vote of approval followed two days of debate. (A8:3-6.)

title: Canadian Truck Rift
description: American truckers face difficulties in attempting to enter the Canadian market, but no proof exists that they are being discriminated against by the Canadian regulatory authorities, the Interstate Commerce Commission has concluded in a special report.

title: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DELOREAN MOTOR TO CLOSE
description: DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd., which has been in receivership for eight months, will be permanently closed, the British Government said tonight, ending its unsuccessful struggle to find a buyer.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2.7 million for the qr and $8.3 million for the 9 mos, a gain of $4.5 million for the qr and 9 mos from thesale of Omnicare common stock and a gain of $881,000 for the qr and 9 mos from the divesment of minority interest in the company's Australian licensee...C-Including income of $1.9 million from discontinued operations

title: AT TIME OF TYLENOL DEATHS, SUSPECTS WERE IN NEW YORK
description: A fugitive Missouri couple identified as ''one of the more substantial leads'' in the investigation into the deaths of seven persons from cyanide-filled Tylenol capsules were living at a New York City hotel at the time of the deaths in the Chicago area, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: GEMAYEL IS CALLED 'VERY UNGRATEFUL'
description: Comments by President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon about Israel during his trip to Washington and the United Nations were strongly criticized today by officials of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government and the opposition Labor Party.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5.3 million

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES FALLS 50.7%
description: American Airlines reported yesterday that it had net income of $17.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the third quarter, down 50.7 percent from $36.1 million, or $1.13 a share, in the third quarter last year, when there was an extraordinary credit of $21.7 million.

title: PHILIPS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RECESSION BATTERS JAPAN COAL TOWN
description: A deep economic chill is setting in on this coalmining community in Japan's northern island of Hokkaido. People are being thrown out of work. Their prospects of finding new jobs here are not good. Last year an explosion ripped through Yubari's newest mine, Hokutan Shinko, and killed 93 men. Now the mine has been closed. The accident speeded the decline of one of Japan's oldest, most remote industrial centers, which had been suffering for years from the depressed state of the coal industry. Yubari, a boom town of 120,000 people in the early 1960's, is down to 30,000 people and shrinking. Out of 26 mines that were worked in the 1960's, two survive.

title: BATON BROADCASTING INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug
description: B-Including a special gain of $973,748...C-After a special loss of $2,705,054...C-After a special loss of $2,705,054...D-Per Class A common shrs...E-Per Class B common shrs

title: Carpenters' Union President Will Retire at End of October
description: The president of the carpenters' union, William Konyha, said Tuesday that he would retire Oct. 31 as head of the 800,000-member union.

title: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreigncurrency translations

title: 9 EX-PATIENTS KEPT IN PRIMITIVE SHED IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Nine ragged, emaciated adults have been found living in primitive conditions in a tiny outbuilding at an unlicensed boarding home for former mental patients. State health officials said today that they were planning legal action against the boarding home's owner.

title: ROME BOMB ROCKS LEBANESE EMBASSY
description: A bomb seriously damaged the Lebanese Embassy here this evening, on the eve of a visit by President Amin Gemayel. The embassy was empty but the police reported that a bypasser was wounded by glass and taken to a hospital. Damage to the chancery and the rest of the building was reported to be serious.

title: U.S. BENEVOLENCE DELIGHTS HUNGARY
description: An unannounced decision by President Reagan to continue to treat each Eastern European country individually, rather than simply as part of the Soviet bloc, has been greeted with relief in Hungary.

title: ARABS IN U.N. DROP BID TO DENY ISRAEL ITS ASSEMBLY SEAT
description: President Amin Gemayel has told Washington that Lebanon cannot afford the political costs of a treaty with Israel. News analysis, page A10.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net loss; 1982 results include operations of Neison Travel Service acquired Nov 1981 and Roundtrip Travel acquired May 1982

title: CHARLES BLACK
description: Charles Black, a reporter who covered the Vietnam War from the soldier's point of view, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack.

title: Delmed Plant Approved
description: Delmed Inc. said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved the operations and facilities of its new plant here for the commercial manufacture of blood collection and processing products. The company added that it intended to expand the plant, and that it had purchased a plant in Ogden, Utah, formerly used by the Cutter Laboratories division of Bayer A.G., to manufacture peritoneal dialysis and other specialty solutions.

title: RUSSELL F. BURCH
description: Russell F. Burch, former president of the Magnuson Products Corporation, died Sunday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

title: A PLAY-IT-SAFE PHILOSOPHY PERVADES HIGH POINT MARKET
description: HIGH POINT, N.C. ''THIS is the first market in two years that has opened on an optimistic note,'' said Robert P. Gruenberg, general manager of the Southern Furniture Market, a wholesale center for more than 1,300 furniture manufacturers based here.

title: Bonn Rejects Plan For Steel Quotas
description: The West German Government today rejected a European plan to limit steel shipments to the United States, insisting instead on modifications that would almost exclude Germany from any limitations on its steel exports.

title: THE MULTIPLE DEBATES OF MILICENT FENWICK
description: To the Editor:

title: RACE FOR CONGRESS IS VIGOROUS ON L.I.
description: John LeBoutillier, the freshman Republican Congressman from Long Island whose occasional jabs at his Washington colleagues have brought him national attention, was complaining the other night that he was not as well known at home as he would like.

title: Poland Seeking GATT Support
description: Poland has asked the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to condemn the type of sanctions that Washington announced after the Warsaw Government banned the trade union Solidarity, diplomatic sources said today.

title: CHINA TRADE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a writeoff of certain back debt of $492,405...C-Net loss

title: PHOENIX THEATER MARKS 30TH YEAR
description: ''Alfred Prufrock and the Amazing Technicolor Waste Land,'' billed as a new collaboration between the composer and the lyricist of ''Cats'' - Andrew Lloyd Webber and T.S. Eliot -got a sympathetic hearing Tuesday night in the Citicorp building's Atrium when the Phoenix Theater staged a gala benefit for itself to celebrate three events.

title: Alarm Companies File A.T.& T. Suit
description: Twenty-nine security alarm companies have charged in a Federal antitrust suit that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has improperly restrained trade by trying to monopolize their business.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOBEL WON BY CHICAGO ECONOMIST
description: The 1982 Nobel Memorial Prize for Economic Science was awarded today to George J. Stigler, a University of Chicago professor, for his half century of research on the working of industry and the role of government regulation in the economy.

title: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sale of Britoil May Be Near
description: The sale of 51 percent of the Government-owned Britoil Ltd. to the public probably will take place around the middle of November and is unlikely to take the form of a tender, according to Philip Shelbourne, the company's chairman.

title: King Olav Asserts U.N.  Is Losing Effectiveness
description: King Olav V of Norway told the General Assembly today that the continuing reliance on force to settle international disputes was diminishing the effectiveness of the United Nations.

title: O'Neill Asks Bipartisan Move To Create Jobs After Election
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today that Democrats and Republicans in Congress should join in a post-election move to create jobs for the nation's unemployed workers.

title: Mrs. Reagan Going to Rites
description: Nancy Reagan, in a change of plans, expects to attend the funeral of Bess Truman on Thursday in Independence, Mo. The White House said earlier that both President Reagan and Mrs. Reagan had appointments that would keep them away. However, Mrs. Reagan's spokesman, Sheila Tate, said the First Lady had postponed dental surgery and would fly to Missouri.

title: RIVAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN ARCHITECTS' LABELS DON'T MEAN WHAT THEY SAY
description: THERE is a word that has become very much the fashion in talking and writing about architecture lately, and it is ''contextual.'' It is intended as a word of praise - good architecture, it is presumed, is ''in context,'' which is to say it fits in with its surroundings. Bad architecture does not - it violates its surroundings, creating awkward and jarring physical connections to the buildings around it.

title: FIRST LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Making Yourself Heard Without Losing Your Voice
description: F rantic days on Wall Street mean shouting matches for floor traders. The New York Futures Exchange has had enough of them since May -when it began trading futures contracts on stock prices - to bring on an epidemic of chronic laryngitis.

title: Executive Soccer
description: Steve Moyers was depressed. The young Cosmos star, second only to Giorgio Chinaglia in scoring on the team in the last North American Soccer League season, had a back problem to take care of and could not accompany the team, now in Australia, on a Pacific tour.

title: OUT OF LEFT FIELD, A BASEBALL ANTI-REVISIONIST
description: To the Editor:

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
L.I. HOSPITAL FIGHTS PATIENT'S PLEA TO END LIFESAVING TREATMENT
description: The case of a gravely ill diabetic who has told his doctors he wants to die has raised new questions about a patient's right to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment.

title: PLYWOOD EMISSIONS: PROBLEM CONTINUES
description: Leaders of the plywood industry told Federal regulators Tuesday that they had made giant strides in reducing dangerous emissions from their products, so regulation is unnecessary.

title: SmithKline Net Up 10%
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation announced today that its third-quarter net earnings were $118.8 million, or $1.44 a share, up 10 percent, from $108 million, or $1.31, a year earlier. Third-quarter sales rose 13 percent, to $762.1 million, from $674.3 million in the same period last year. ''Strong performance in the company's ethical pharmaceuticals business in the United States and continued growth in eye and skin care operations were the key factors in our progress during the quarter,'' Henry Wendt, president, said

title: CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd payable Oct 22

title: Japanese Car Import Curb
description: The United States will seek to extend the two-year ceiling on Japanese car imports for 12 months to protect the flagging domestic auto industry, according to the American trade representative, Bill Brock.

title: AN INCISIVE TEACHER: GEORGE JOSEPH STIGLER
description: At the University of Chicago's business school, a popular item of attire is a T-shirt showing a back view of an odd couple of economists strolling together down a leafy walk. The very short one is Milton Friedman, the monetarist who is considered the core of the conservative Chicago school of economics; the very tall one is George J. Stigler, a professor at the business school and a longtime champion of deregulation.

title: News Analysis
description: The principal political message that President Amin Gemayel left with President Reagan was that Lebanon could not afford to become another Egypt by signing a formal document of any kind with Israel, Lebanese and American officials said today.

description: B-Including a tax credit of $211,000 or 4 cents a shr...C-Net loss

title: U.S. Steel Chief Warns Of Strike Possibility
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation said today that the steel industry was willing to take a strike if it was the only way to bring down labor costs.

title: Texas Gas Sets Changes
description: Shareholders of the Texas Gas Transmission Company yesterday approved a corporate restructuring plan through the creation of a holding company, the Texas Gas Corporation. The restructuring, which is subject to receipt of favorable tax rulings, is to become effective on Jan. 1, 1983.

title: Treasury Prices Down a Bit; 2-Year Notes Yield 9.79%
description: Prices declined slightly for Treasury securities yesterday as traders and investors waited for new developments that would confirm widespread predictions of lower interest rates in coming weeks.

title: STAGE' 'RATS,' RODENTS RUNNING MUSICAL PACES
description: ''RATS'' is, as its program at Van Buren's advises us, ''a musical revue not based on a book by T.S. Eliot.'' It is, however, based on something much more familiar than the source of ''Cats'': the old Mickey and Judy ''Hey, Kids, Let's Put on a Show'' premise.
Attendance - 53,723. Net receipts - $890,158.97. Commissioner's Share - $134,722.65. Players Pool - $458,056.99. League and Club Series shares -$76,342.83. GAME TWO Attendance - 53,723.

title: DOW UP BY 20.32, TO 1,034.12
description: The stock market's most popular indicator - the Dow Jones industrial average - raced ahead 20.32 points yesterday to finish at 1,034.12, its highest level in nearly a decade. Analysts credited some surprisingly good earnings reports with providing part of the stimulus for the advance.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct 1, 1982

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1982
description: International The Arab countries have abandoned an attempt to expel Israel from the United Nations General Assembly, Arab diplomats disclosed. In an alternative policy, the 21 members of the Arab League agreed to express a symbolic reservation over Israel's credentials. On Saturday, the United States said that, if Israel was expelled, it would leave the General Assembly and suspend its United Nations payments. (Page A1, Column 6.) France is willing to send more troops to reinforce the peacekeeping force in Beirut, according to an offer made by President Francois Mitterrand to President Amin Gemayel, a French spokesman reported. He said no figures were mentioned. (A8:1-2.)

title: The Worm in the Bud
description: Fifty years ago, the paramount purpose of the Department of Agriculture was research. Now research, though it costs $826 million, accounts for barely 2 percent of the department's budget and evokes even less interest from its managers. Pockets of excellence remain, but the elaborate, once proud system of Federal and state agricultural laboratories is sliding steadily into desuetude and scientific irrelevance.

description: Salvador Police Search American News Offices

TRAPPER WHO KILLED OFFICERS IS CONVICTED OF MANSLAUGHTER
description: A 32-year-old trapper was found guilty today of voluntary manslaughter in the shooting deaths of two Idaho fish and game officers.

title: Jordanian Educator Deported By Israel From the West Bank
description: The president of a major university on the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered deported this week for refusing to comply with a new policy requiring foreign nationals employed in the occupied areas to disavow any connections with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian and Israeli sources said.

title: One Forced, Voluntary Minute
description: Once again the New Jersey Legislature has passed a bill to require public schools to set aside one silent minute at the start of each day. Nothing about prayer, mind you. The minute is ''to be used solely at the discretion of the individual student ... for quiet and private contemplation or introspection.''

description: At a bamboo temple in a Cambodian refugee camp north of here, a man in his 50's waited with six other members of his family to be taken by Thai soldiers to a village on the Cambodian side of the border.

title: Enserch Project
description: The Enserch Corporation said its Ebasco Services Inc. subsidiary was leading development of a $4.5 billion coal gasification and methanol complex at Chiriqui Grande in Panama. The company said the complex, which will begin operations in 1990, would produce about four million tons of methanol a year from 6.6 million tons of highsulfur coal from the United States.

title: Two Ex-K.K.K. Members Lose Appeal in Racial Assault Case
description: A state appeals court refused today to overturn the aggravated-assault convictions of two former members of the Ku Klux Klan, who pleaded guilty to firing gunshots into the home of a black family.

title: NEW FABRIC REFLECTS THE PAST
description: EIGHTEEN years ago French-born Manuel Canovas founded his own textile company with only five designs. Today he has a collection of more than 400 patterns. Mr. Canovas recently came to New York from his home in Paris to introduce 30 new designs in his collection. These cotton fabrics in florals, paisleys, plaids and solids are more classic than some of his previous works.

title: Toronto Group Says It Set Off Factory Blast
description: A group calling itself Direct Action has claimed responsibility for the bombing last week of a Toronto plant that makes guidance systems for American cruise missiles, the police said today.

title: Marshall Poetry Prize Won by John Logan
description: John Logan, a poet and professor of English at the State University of New York College at Buffalo, has won the 1981 Lenore Marshall/Nation Poetry Prize.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES AGAINST A 'MIXED' SCHOOL
description: The South African Government has decided to spend nearly half a million dollars to build an extra primary school for a northern town, ending a 50-year tradition of allowing Indian and mixed-race children to be educated together.

title: State Role on Energy
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The New York State Power Authority was conspicuous by its absence from your Sept. 23 article (''Aerial Photographs Reveal Heat Leaks'') on electric utilities' use of aerial photographs to detect heat loss in homes.

U.S. HISTORIC SITES IN CITY GUARDING AGAINST THEFTS
description: The burglars who broke into Theodore Roosevelt's birthplace last year were probably young, very ordinary thieves who entered the brownstone on Manhattan's East Side looking for objects they could steal easily and sell quickly, authorities say.

title: MRS. SULLIVAN ASSAILS A REPUBLICAN PANEL OVER DELAY IN FUNDS
description: Florence M. Sullivan, who is challenging Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in his bid for re-election, today criticized the National Republican Senate Committee, contending it was withholding contributions from her campaign.

title: L.I.R.R. STRIKE SET BY UNION FOR NOVEMBER
description: The union representing 1,500 conductors and trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road announced plans to strike at 12:01 A.M. on Nov. 22 unless its contract dispute is settled by that date.

title: Kaufman Sees New Fed Path
description: Henry Kaufman, chief economist for Salomon Brothers, the New York investment banking firm, predicted today that the Federal Reserve Board would not return to its monetary approach of the last three years.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $3.6 million for the qr and 9 mos from an insurance recovery on a fire, a charge of $4.1 million for the qr and 9 mos from a provision for discontinuation of the company's solvents business and the transfer of certainresearch and development and plastics div personnel and a gain of $1.3 million for the 9 mos from the sale of oil and gas interests; yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: LEON GOLDFARB
description: Leon Goldfarb, a successful plaintiff in a suit that charged that a provision of the Social Security Act unconstitionally discriminated on the basis of sex, died Sunday at a nursing home in Rockville, Md., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: 2 IN HOUSE BATTLE FOR THE SAME SEAT
description: Representative Leo C. Zeferetti strode down Fourth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn the other day, getting a wave and good wishes from a passing motorist every few steps. The four-term Brooklyn Democrat returned the greetings and continued south into a blustery wind, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge looming in the distance.

title: SAN JOSE WATER WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Army Asks Right to Bar Homosexual Sergeant
description: The Army, worried that a homosexual sergeant might have sexual relations with other soldiers, has gone back to Federal court to try to prevent him from re-enlisting.

title: Thomas Appleget, 89; Administrator at Brown
description: Thomas B. Appleget, retired vice president of Brown University and former vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, died Monday of emphysema at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 89 years old, and lived in Greenwich.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $1.3 million gain from sale of stock; latest 9 mos net also includes non-recurring gain of $403,000

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $27 million for the qr and 9 mos and a gain of $130 million for the 9 mos from the cumulative effect of an accounting chang

description: ST. LOUIS

title: Judge Clears McLouth Sale
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge George Woods approved the $46.5 million sale of the McLouth Steel Corporation to Cyrus Tang, a Chicago industrialist, after its chairman, Milton Deaner, said the offer was the only real one McLouth had received. Mr. Tang will also pay $35 million for inventories.

title: FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arab in Vienna Court Melee
description: A convicted terrorist tried to kick a judge today at the murder trial of an Arab accused of organizing a Vienna synagogue attack in which two people were killed.

WHEELABRATOR-FRYE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of Pullman Transportation and First Greatwest divisions

title: No Headline
description: VIENNA, Oct. 20 (AP) - Ilie Nastase highlighted the opening round of a $100,000 Grand Prix tournament today by defeating Nduka Odizor of Nigeria, 6-3, 6-2.

title: Advertising; How to Sell Ties: Try It In French
description: CAN you imagine a television commercial for neckties? You can? That's pretty good, since you've probably never seen one. But how about a 30-second spot for such a product that doesn't even mention style, fashion, fabric or any of the few redeeming qualities ties have?

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two Bulgarians Jump Ship
description: Two Bulgarian crewmen jumped ship early today at the Port of Astoria and went to the police, according to Carl Houseman, acting director of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in Portland. Mr. Houseman said he did not know whether the men had sought political asylum.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net losses from discontinued operations of $76,793 for the qr and $282,777 for the 9 mos and a net gain of $3,155,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of discontinued operations

title: Holding in Genentech
description: Genentech Inc., the San Francisco-based gene-splicing company, said yesterday that four Swedish concerns had bought about 6.5 percent of its common stock, or 571,428 shares, in a transaction valued at $20 million.

title: DELOREAN USED COMPLEX FINANCING TO SUPPORT A NETWORK OF COMPANIES
description: John Z. DeLorean, in trying to start a new auto company, operated through a tangled web of corporations, here and abroad, attracting financing from such blue-ribbon sources as the British Government and the Bank of America, and fending off questions from business associates and the Internal Revenue Service about how the money was spent.

title: 'DESTROYING CHILDHOOD!'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Having just sent our son off to the University of Massachusetts as a freshman, it was with great amusement that I read your column the other day about departed children leaving belongings behind.

title: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOANS FOR SOUTH AFRICA ASSAILED IN U.N. REPORT
description: A United Nations study sharply critical of the International Monetary Fund's loans to South Africa has languished unpublished for more than a year, according to U.N. officials.

title: Luci Johnson at Mayo Clinic
description: Luci Johnson, daughter of President Johnson, underwent diagnostic evaluations today at the Mayo Clinic. Betty Tilson, a spokesman for the Johnson family in Texas, said Miss Johnson, 35 years old, was suffering from an intestinal disorder.

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,784,000 for the latest 9 mos and $5,289,000 for the yr-ago 9 mos and including a credit of $16,295,000 for the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: BUSINESS PEOPLEf; Stockbroker Wins Bayly Proxy Fight
description: David T. Marantette 3d, a Detroit stockbroker, has won a proxy fight to replace directors of the Bayly Corporation, a Denver maker of jeans and casual wear.

title: SARGENT-WELCH SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $82,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,792,000...C-Including gains of $609,000 fromdiscontinued operations and $2,792,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations

description: Shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid in June 1982

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $7.2 million from the sale and exchange of investments

title: A ROAD BACK FROM ADVERSITY
description: I t was lunch hour in a Manhattan restaurant, and a waiter brought the order and placed a grilled cheese sandwich in front of Kent Waldrep. Discreetly, Waldrep's wife, Lynn, leaned over and cut the sandwich into pieces for him. Waldrep, 28 years old, a Dallas native and wearing a Western shirt and tie, bent forward in his wheelchair and, with only a little difficulty, handled his fork and took a bite of the sandwich.

title: U.S. WILL CUT USE OF SOUTH SEAS SITE
description: The United States agreed with the Marshall Islands today to cut its planned use of the Pacific chain as a missile test range by 20 years and to give the residents $6 million in aid.

title: Crackdown in Peru Ends After 2 Months
description: The Peruvian Government lifted a state of emergency today in the province of Lima and the adjoining port of El Callao. It said more than 34,000 people were arrested during the two-month state of emergency, and that the crackdown helped reduce terrorism.

title: Two Worlds In Five Boroughs
description: F resh figures from the 1980 Federal census show how polarized between rich and poor the city has become. Of the 3,132 counties in the United States, Manhattan ranks near the top in per capita income - No. 14.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Arvinair division acquiredin Apr

title: TED TURNER'S BEAR IS TREED BUT OUTWITS PURSUERS
description: Charleston County officials have tried peaches. They have tried doughnuts. And they have tried tranquilizers. But they have been unable to capture Booby, Ted Turner's 250-pound pet black bear, which is on the loose for a ninth day.

title: SAINT LAURENT: THE FITTED LOOK IS BACK
description: As the week of spring and summer fashion shows here drew to a close, the emphasis was less on costumes for the Folies-Bergere and more on clothes women might plausibly want to wear. Yves Saint Laurent and Valentino are responsible for this happier turn of events. Both are competent enough to get the effects they want without resorting to tawdry touches.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $1,411,000 from the repurchase of debentures

title: ULSTER IS AGAIN A REBEL TARGET
description: A Protestant political leader, James Molyneaux, was the target of terrorist bombers today for the second time in 24 hours as Northern Ireland voted for a 78-member representative assembly.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $2.5 million from a change in accounting

title: RANGERS' 4-GOAL PERIOD DEFEATS CANUCKS
description: The goal-scoring curve in last night's hockey game mirrored the style of the current Ranger team: swooping dramatically up and down. But it ended on an upswing for the Rangers, who defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 6-5, at Madison Square Garden.

title: 10,000 ATTEND FUNERAL FOR POLE, TURNING IT INTO RALLY FOR SOLIDARITY
description: Ten thousand people, many carrying banners declaring ''Solidarity Lives,'' crowded into a small cemetery here today for the burial of a demonstrator who was fatally shot by the police last week during clashes sparked by the outlawing of the Solidarity trade union.

title: GF BUSINESS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLEY'S COMET IS SIGHTED
description: After searching the skies on and off for nearly five years, astronomers have sighted Halley's comet for the first time since its last visit to the vicinity of the Earth back in 1910. The astronomers were pleased, but not surprised, to see that the illustrious comet, as predictable as ever, was on course and on time for its next encounter with the Sun in early 1986.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED SERVICES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Take a Labor Dispute, Add an Unusual Tactic
description: N ever mind stale jokes about workers demanding more bread while management says, ''Let them eat cake.'' It has been no-holds-barred on the East Side, where bakers of the Dumas Patisserie are on strike.

title: Ramada Debt Is Restructured
description: Ramada Inns said its lenders had agreed to restructure their existing debt agreement with the company, subject to final execution of documents.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, the obituary of John Michelosen yesterday omitted part of the first sentence. It should have said that Mr. Michelosen became head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers and later of the football team at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: MITTERRAND GUARANTEES GEMAYEL MORE TROOPS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France told the Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, today that he was ready to send additional French troops to Beirut to reinforce the multinational peacekeeping force there, a Mitterrand spokesman reported.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNION PACIFIC OFF 18.9%
description: Santa Fe Industries said yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell 1.2 percent, hurt by a 22 percent drop in earnings from its rail operations.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHARMED LIFE ENDS FOR BREWER PLAYERS
description: On the one hand, Paul Molitor was saying early today, the Milwaukee Brewers had done it four times and ''you just don't know if you can do it that fifth time.'' On the other hand, Molitor reasoned, ''If we've done it four times, why not five?''

title: Running Strong At 71 Years Old
description: At a news conference yesterday for Sunday's New York City Marathon, Leo Rybak met Marty Glickman for the third time. The first time was at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin when both were sprinters, Glickman on the United States team and Rybak representing his native country, Poland.

title: CONVERGENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN, IN ILLINOIS, TELLS OF PLAN TO AID AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS
description: President Reagan, campaigning in this economically distressed farm and industrial area, announced today that in the next three years the Agriculture Department would make available $1.5 billion in credits to spur farm exports and that the Farmers Home Administration would reduce loan rates effective Nov. 1.

title: NEBRASKA VOTERS IN RESTIVE MOOD ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S CAMPAIGN VISIT
description: The recession has finally arrived in this normally prosperous, usually optimistic corner of Nebraska, bringing with it a vague uneasiness and growing doubts that a quick recovery is anywhere in sight.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edward V. Regan
description: Often talks admiringly of his Democratic predecessor, the late Arthur Levitt, and attempts to emulate his independence of partisan politics ... irritated many Republican politicians in the process, a factor in his decision to drop out of the race for governor earlier this year ... campaign brochure, ''Ned Regan on the Taxpayer's Side,'' mentions only twice - and in small type - in eight pages that he is a Republican ... campaigns independently of Republican ticket, even questioning Lewis E. Lehrman's tax-cut program ... was on other side in 1966 when he was the Republican Party's ''sacrificial lamb'' against Mr. Levitt in 1970, losing by more than 1.3 million votes ... endorsed by Mr. Levitt in 1978 over a Democrat, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, and won his first term, the only Republican elected state official ... born and raised upstate 52 years ago, he operated a family business in Erie County before being elected Buffalo Councilman in 1965 ... after first statewide loss, he was elected Erie County Executive six years later and re-elected in 1975. Raymond F. Gallagher

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
MULTIHEAD HARDWARE
description: AN attractive line of bright-colored nylon door and wall hardware manufactured in West Germany, formerly available in the United States only through architects and designers, is now being imported in quantity and sold through retail outlets.

title: N.B.A. Weighs Pay Plan
description: The National Basketball Association, after almost three months of difficult negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement with the players, is reported to have proposed a formula that would tie salary costs to a team's revenues.

title: FOES OF ELEVATED TRANSIT LINE IN HOUSTON FEAR IT WILL THROW DOWNTOWN INTO SHADOW
description: The city of Houston has been plunged into a strident debate over a proposal to build an elevated rail transit line right through downtown.

title: Kings Beat Devils, 7-4
description: Marcel Dionne scored two goals, and Ernie Nicholls and Charlie Simmer added a goal and two assists each tonight to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 7-4 victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title: EXHIBITION OF WORK BY FEMALE ARCHITECTS
description: JUDITH STOCKMAN, the architect who designed the First Women's Bank in New York, is one of 66 female architects and designers whose work will be shown tonight by the Alliance of Women in Architecture.

title: Smoking Increases Risk Of Flu, Study Reports
description: People who smoke run a greater risk of contracting the flu, and when they do are likely to be sicker than nonsmokers, Israeli doctors have reported.

title: Wayward Missile Is Found
description: Portions of a Pershing P-1 artillery missile that overshot its target by 300 miles have been found near Creede, Colo., nearly 18 years after it was fired. A spokesman for the missile range said today that Army demolition experts were on the scene to recover parts of the second stage of the missile, found Tuesday by an unidentified hunter.

title: Gas Leak Kills 4 in Apartment
description: An elderly woman and a mother and two of her children were found dead in an apartment in Brooklyn's Canarsie section yesterday, the result of gas leaking from a stove, according to the housing police. A 4-year-old child was found alive in the apartment.

title: PACESETTER FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: Bowater Closing
description: The Bowater Southern Paper Company said it will close its newsprint mill here, the nation's largest, on Nov. 21 for 15 days because of declining sales.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Delta Air Lines plans to offer $88 million of tax-exempt bonds maturing in 1992, 1997, 2002 and 2012 to finance Atlanta airport facilities.

title: SCIENTIFIC DETAIL OVERWHELMS REGARD FOR HUMAN NEEDS AT MEDICAL SCHOOLS, PANEL SAYS
description: Medical students are being overwhelmed by scientific detail at the expense of basic skills and a regard for human needs, according to a panel of experts that has begun the first overall review in 50 years of the curriculum that leads to a doctor's degree.

title: U.S. Regrets U.N.'s Election Of Nicaragua to the Council
description: The State Department expressed regret today over the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to elect Nicaragua to fill the Latin American seat on the Security Council.

title: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BACHE FIRM FINED $400,000 FOR ROLE IN '80 SILVER CRISIS
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday fined a prominent brokerage firm $400,000 for permitting the Hunt brothers of Texas to speculate so heavily in silver as to endanger the firm's survival and then failing to give the stock exchange timely notice of the developing crisis.

title: ALCAN LTD. POSTS LOSS
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., the large Canadian producer, said yesterday that it lost $15 million in the third quarter compared with profits of $67 million, or 82 cents a share, in the same period of 1981. Revenues dipped to $1.19 billion from $1.22 billion.

title: Envoy to Mauritania Named
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Edward Lionel Peck, director of the State Department's office of Egyptian affairs, to be the ambassador to Mauritania. Mr. Peck, a career Foreign Service officer since 1957, has served in posts in Europe, northern Africa and the Middle East.

title: US LEASING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 mos reflect a loss equal to 34 cents a shr from discontinued operations; yr-ago results reflect losses equal to 8 cents a shr for the qr and 12 cents a shr for the 9 mos from discontinued operations; yr-ago resultshave been restated to reflect the company's investment in a savings and loan association as a discontinued operations

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADVERTISING
description: * Oliver Kiss, executive vice president and chief operating officer of McDonald & Little, Atlanta, resigned.

title: N.F.L. Wins on Right to Sue
description: The National Football League won an important decision today in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, as a three-judge panel cleared the way for the league to sue in state courts against players who participate in the union's All-Star League games.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TO books continue to proliferate as more and more people become involved with improving their homes and apartments, including the furnishings, rather than trying to find sometimes scarce and often much more expensive replacements. A good how-to book can be a valuable source of time- and money-saving information.

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd declared Oct 20, 1982

title: JERSEY'S INCOME TAX MUST BE REFORMED
description: To the Editor:

title: LEHRMAN'S PATH TO RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: As a student at the Hill School in Pottstown, Pa., Lewis E. Lehrman is remembered as an aggressive pupil who would pin down his teachers with pointed questions. He was, as one teacher recalled, a ''little brash.'' He went on to make the dean's list at Yale University and to win a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship for graduate work at Harvard University.

title: Dreyfus Plans National Bank
description: The Dreyfus Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking permission from the Comptroller of the Currency to set up a national bank.

title: Surgery for Bowie
description: Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch center who starred for Kentucky's basketball team two years ago but missed all of last season because of a stress fracture in his left shinbone, underwent corrective surgery in Memphis and might miss all of this season as well. Bowie had resisted surgery for months, hoping that alternative treatment might work. As a result of having the operation this late in the year, he is considered certain to be out of the lineup until mid-January at the earliest.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAGE: 'HOOTERS,' COMEDY BY TED TALLY, REVIVED
description: WHETHER you've previously seen Ted Tally's ''Hooters'' or not, you'll recognize the territory. In this 1978 comedy, which was revived at the Hudson Guild last night, the author of ''Terra Nova'' and ''Coming Attractions'' takes us to a Cape Cod beach motel where two libidinous, post-adolescent young men, armed with binoculars and beer, are stalking female prey. The heroes, Clint (Griffin Dunne) and Ricky (Paul McCrane), soon find what they came for - Cheryl (Polly Draper), an ''older'' woman in her 30's who they immediately decide is a ready and willing ''10.'' But Cheryl is accompanied by a less attractive pal, Ronda (Susan Greenhill), and that makes for the inevitable awkward complications.

title: FALWELL'S GROUP PUSHES VOTE DRIVE
description: At the Quint City Baptist Temple in Davenport, Iowa, the Rev. Olen Adams asks the 109 adults in his Sunday Bible class how many are registered to vote. All but a dozen raise their hands.

title: NOT EVERYONE IS SWEPT AWAY BY THE BONN BROOM
description: As a new team takes charge in Bonn, some West Germans may perhaps be forgiven if they find the contours of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's vaunted ''new beginning'' a bit blurry.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1982; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average soared 20.32 points, to 1,034.12, its highest level in nearly a decade. Blue chips led the way, but a wide majority of other stocks also rose, with analysts citing suprisingly good quarterly earnings reports. (Page D1.)

title: Westport Trust Bid Rejected by Insurer
description: The Westport Company, a real estate management and development concern, said yesterday that the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company had rejected its $14-a-share, $65.8 million offer to acquire Northwestern Mutual Life Mortgage and Realty Investors.

title: Support for a Winner
description: While the undefeated and top-ranked Washington Huskies continue aiming for a third straight trip to the Rose Bowl, some of the team's boosters have an aim of their own. The boosters have created a ''Keep Don Fund'' with which, by augmenting the outside income of Coach Don James, they hope to insure that he remains at the university.

WHEN SEVERAL GENERATIONS SHARE A HOME
description: OVER the past 20 years, most couples with children have lived in single-family houses, rearing their youngsters on their own. Their aging parents were probably renting an apartment someplace else. And the children, once grown, were quick to fly the coop and rent a place of their own.

title: Pacific Telephone
description: The Pacific Telephone Company, citing a slumping economy that has stalled new construction, said it will lay off 200 employees by the end of this year. The cutbacks, the first in seven years for the company, also include provisions for downgrading 900 employees to lower-paying jobs. The company, California's largest employer, has about 108,000 employees.

title: DRUG AGENCY WARNS PUBLIC ON INTOXICATION 'RELIEF' PRODUCTS
description: The Government says people who drink should not be misled by products that purportedly sober people up, adding that there is no scientific proof that anything can minimize inebriation and no drug has been approved for that purpose.

description: Thai Airways International said it had agreed to buy two Boeing 767 aircraft for about $120 million and that it had canceled a $116 million order for two European-built Airbuses.

description: President J.R. Jayewardene appeared certain of winning Wednesday's presidential election, gaining a second term in office, according to unofficial results released today.

description: Everyone calls her The Duchess, this remarkable woman who, at 86 years of age, is still very much a newspaper reporter. Her byline: Esther Van Wagoner Tufty.

title: NEW YORK MARATHON RUNNERS ARRIVING
description: Dave Horning will swim two miles from the 69th Street Pier in Brooklyn to Fort Wadsworth in Staten Island and then run the 26 miles 385 yards in Sunday's New York City Marathon.
