title: ALL OVER TOWN, THE BUSINESS OF NEWS IS BOOMING
description: When President Reagan holds a news conference, Tim Hillard always goes. ''I've never been called on,'' said Mr. Hillard, a Washingtonbased reporter for KOMO-TV in Seattle, ''but I always have a question ready. Last time I sat next to a lady who said she hadn't been called on since Eisenhower. I thought, 'Oh, no, could this be me?' ''

title: Opposition Chief Asserts Guyana Regime Will Fall
description: Cheddi Jagan, Guyana's Marxist opposition leader, today predicted the imminent downfall of the Government of President Forbes Burnham.

title: Banks Back French Credit
description: All the banks participating in France's $4 billion, 10-year standby credit have accepted the contract conditions, a spokesman for the coordinating lead manager, Societe Generale, said today. She said the credit would be signed next Wednesday, but she was unable to say when the Government might draw on the credit.

title: Burger King Steps Up War With McDonald's
description: If you missed the final World Series game on WNBC-TV last night then you don't know that while the Cardinals and the Brewers have settled their battle, the Burger King-versus-McDonald's war continues with the Pillsbury subsidiary sticking its thumb once again into the big guy's eye.

title: I.B.M. CUTS COMPUTER PRICES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced a sweeping series of price cuts on most of its small and midsized computers.

title: GOODRICH HAS LOSS
description: The Lockheed Corporation reported yesterday that lower interest costs helped more than double net income in the third quarter as sales advanced 4.8 percent.

title: Miss Sills on Warner's Board
description: Beverly Sills, general director of the New York City Opera, has been elected to the board of directors of Warner Communications. ''Her qualities of leadership, concern for others and broad knowledge of all aspects of the arts make her a splendid addition to our board,'' said Steven J. Ross, chairman of the board.

title: BOUDIN LAWYER SUGGESTS MIX-UP ABOUT IDENTITIES
description: An attorney for one of the Brink's defendants, Kathy Boudin, elicited in testimony today that eyewitnesses had placed two other women - Judith A. Clark and Marilyn Buck - at a roadblock ambush where two Nyack police officers were killed a year ago today in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery.

title: Storm Strikes Midwest, With Up to Foot of Snow
description: By The Associated Press A snowstorm, the first of the season in the Middle West, swept across the Corn Belt yesterday, bogging down the already late harvest with snow up to a foot deep, disrupting travel and snapping tree limbs still heavy with foliage.

title: 'Destroying Childhood!'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: ''The Nest Is Empty but the Birds Have Left Things Behind'' (Oct. 7) came as I was dredging out my son's room, hoping to discover a guest room in its depths. I had steeled myself to the piteous pleas from long distance of the 6-foot, 2-inch 23-year-old: ''You're destroying my childhood!'' And his whole childhood (and youth) is crammed into the room.

title: RISE IN JOBLESS FOR STATE IS 19% OVER 9 MONTHS
description: Unemployment in New York State increased less during the first nine months of 1982 than in any of the nine other major industrial states, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics for the Department of Labor.

title: LEHRMAN SAYS STATE SHOULD HAVE ADVOCATE FOR THE VICTIMS OF CRIME
description: Saying that criminal-justice procedures are biased in favor of the accused and deny the rights of victims, Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Governor, yesterday unveiled proposals to ''serve, protect and advocate for crime victims.''

title: THE GYPPED GENERATION
description: The burning issue of the 1982 election, which has been designated as ''too hot'' for candidates to discuss, is this: Shall we keep the Social Security system solvent by raising payroll taxes or by limiting future increases in benefits?

title: MIRRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tenneco Offshore
description: The Tenneco Offshore Company said today that it is proposing to hold a special meeting of its stockholders before the end of the year to vote on a plan of dissolution. Offshore oil and gas properties in which Tenneco Offshore has a partnership interest would be transferred to a royalty trust and units of the trust would be distributed to stockholders. Tenneco Offshore, a publicly held company, is managed by the Telleco Oil Company, a unit of Tenneco Inc.

title: Knight-Ridder Profit
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. today announced earnings of $23.8 million, or 73 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1982 - little changed from the $23.9 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier, despite a rise in operating revenues of 5 percent. Full-run advertising linage declined 9.1 percent. Daily circulation rose 5.6 percent and Sunday circulation was up 5.7 percent, largely as a result of circulation gains from the concern's newspapers in Philadelphia, Knight-Ridder said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house has a brick and cement front stoop that is about six feet wide. Chipmunks have been burrowing under this stoop and as a result it is beginning to sink and there is a half-inch-wide crack between it and the house foundation. What can I do to keep it from sinking any further?

title: GENE STUDIES HINT AT LINK TO CANCER
description: A gene known to be involved in the cause of cancers in birds has been linked in several ways to cancers of humans, according to new scientific reports.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SCHOOL CASE AGAINST 'DISRUPTIVE' PUPIL, 5
description: A 5-year-old boy hauled into court by school officials was cleared today. A circuit judge dropped charges against the child, whom school officials had accused of disrupting his kindergarten class. But the judge ordered a Welfare Department hearing to determine ''what to do with the child.'' In the meantime, Judge D.B. Daugherty ordered that the child be accompanied by an adult if he returned to school.

title: U.S. CITES DEFECTS IN A COLLAPSED ROAD RAMP
description: A Federal agency said Tuesday that four separate deficiencies in a highway ramp probably caused an April 15 construction accident that killed 13 workers in East Chicago, Ind.

title: U.S. Ordered to Present Its Case at Fallout Trial
description: A Federal district judge refused today to dismiss a lawsuit contending that fallout from nuclear bomb testing had brought death and sickness to hundreds.

title: WORK GAIN FOR G.N.P. IN QUARTER
description: The economy expanded at a weak annual rate of eight-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, far less than is necessary to absorb the widening pool of unemployed and below the second quarter's 2.1 percent growth rate, Government figures showed today.

title: AMERICAN DISTRICT TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third qr reflect a gain equal to 13 cents a shr from thesale of a property in Vancouver, B.C.

title: COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bannister Rejects Offer
description: The Seattle Mariners have resigned themselves to losing Floyd Bannister, the pitcher who led the American League in strikeouts this year, to the free-agent draft Nov. 10.

title: PRESTON TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IRAN'S VOTERS TO ELECT A BODY EMPOWERED TO PICK NEW LEADER
description: Iran announced today that elections would be held next month for an assembly of experts that would be empowered, when necessary, to find a successor to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolutionary leader.

title: YOUNG LAWYERS: A TASTE OF FAILURE
description: In high school they worked hard, did well and got into Harvard, Yale and Stanford. There they won honors and tickets to top law schools. Piling on still more academic achievement, they were courted by elite law firms and thronged to Washington to climb the next rung on the ladder of success.

title: THE NEW BREED OF CRAFT COLLECTORS
description: THEY have the classic symptoms of the collector: a chronic shortage of space, a blind spot for prices, an enthusiasm that can become feverish. Yet these collectors, their eyes fixed on the contemporary crafts movement, are a new breed. They're one part connoisseur, one part patron, one part curator. They snub such traditional collecting standards as age, provenance and investment value. And they tend to be practical people who want to touch and handle and, if possible, use their collections.

title: Article 234609 -- No Title
description: A box of Krugerrands valued at $170,000 disappeared on a flight from Johannesburg to London, possibly during a Nairobi stop, an airline spokesman said today. The coins were part of a 10-box consignment of Krugerrands, a South African coin minted for investors. The consignment was put aboard a British Airways flight in Johannesburg on Monday night, according to the official.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARVARD ADJUSTS GRADE IN HARASSMENT CASE
description: Harvard University moved this week toward developing stricter procedures for handling students' complaints of sexual harassment.

title: Technology; Broader Tests For Fuel Cells
description: AT a time when generous supplies of oil and gas are slowing the nation's investment in solar energy, biomass conversion and other alternative forms of power generation, the fuel cell is entering its second important phase of nationwide testing.

title: UNITED KENTUCKY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knicks Sign Williams
description: Sly Williams joined the Knicks at Monmouth College today for his first practice in almost seven months. This morning, the 23-year-old Williams signed a guaranteed one-year contract that will pay him $190,000 and a $40,000 signing bonus. negotiations between the Knicks and the free agent had stalled since Williams rejected the team's first offer in August.

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Includes a gain of $747,000 on asset sale

title: PARSONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1982

title: Deep Immunity
description: Since Oct. 1, when it sighted an alien periscope, the Swedish Navy has been searching a narrow channel on the Baltic coast for an intruding submarine. The world watches, but the pursuit of the elusive vessel is no sport for spectators.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $47,200 or 2 cents a shr from various nonoperating gains and recoveries...C-Including income of $39,000 or 2 cents a shr for the qr and $184,000 or 7 cents a shr for the 9 mos from various nonoperating gains and recoveries

title: Bridge: Bess Truman's Old Group Still Meets Every Tuesday
description: Throughout the United States there are many thousands of private bridge groups that meet regularly once a week. A handful have been in continuous action for half a century or more.

title: Market Place; Jamesway's Market Gains
description: WHEN poor business forces store closings, that's bad news for the operators, but it can be good news for competitors like the Jamesway Corporation.

title: Newest Legend
description: Earl Weaver became a sports legend yesterday with some help from Brooks Robinson, his former third baseman for the Baltimore Orioles. Weaver and Robinson went before television cameras in Atlantic City, where another episode was filmed in the television series called ''Greatest Sports Legends.''

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERCHANTS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

title: 160 UNION LEADERS WEIGH ACTION AT CHRYSLER
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers have spent two days weighing their limited options for responding to the Chrysler Corporation's refusal to consider an immediate pay increase.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including a credit of $3,990,000 or 19 cents a shr from the cumulative effect of a change to a production-varia ble depreciation method

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Washington Post Weekly
description: The Washington Post plans to publish a tabloid-size weekly next year for distribution outside the nation's capital.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POP: GO-GO'S AND SEAGULLS PLAY MADISON SQUARE GARDEN
description: ON the basis of their catchy hit singles, the Go-Go's and a Flock of Seagulls, who shared the bill Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, have become leading commercial lights of minimalist post-new-wave rock.

title: BRIEFING
description: Whither Weinberger?

title: ROLE OF U.S. IN EGYPT IS COMING UNDER ATTACK
description: A Cairo magazine published a series of articles this week that expressed concern over the growing number of American researchers and consultants working in Egypt.

title: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Steel Sale
description: The National Steel Corporation said it had agreed to sell the assets of three divisions of its Houston-based National Steel Products subsidiary for an undisclosed amount.

title: SEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: ACTING OUT THE SADAT KILLING
description: THE questionable craft of ''docudrama'' gets still another questionable workout tonight at 10 on the ABC News magazine program ''20/20.'' A segment entitled ''Moment of Crisis: The Assassination of Anwar Sadat'' uses a combination of actors and news videotapes to, as the publicity releases assert, ''reveal the true story'' behind the events in Egypt last April.

title: PATH THAT LEAD TO DELOREAN BEGAN AND ENDED WITH CASES OF MONEY
description: The chain of events that culminated in the arrest of John Z. DeLorean Tuesday on drug charges began last March when detectives in a city 70 miles north of here began to suspect that someone was illegally moving large amounts of money between California, Florida and points overseas.

title: Umpire Retires
description: Bill Haller, the American League's senior umpire, said that tonight's seventh game of the World Series would be his last as an umpire. Haller, 47 years old, has worked in the league for 20 years. This was his fourth World Series.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHMITT, ASTRONAUT NOW IN SENATE, STRUGGLES TO HOLD NEW MEXICO SEAT
description: E.T., phone home. Jack Schmitt needs help. As an astronaut, Harrison Schmitt flew to the moon in 1972, and that feat helped launch a political career that landed him in the Senate four years later. But this fall the re-election campaign of the New Mexico Republican seems to be in trouble.

title: UNUSUAL AND CRUEL
description: James C. McCray has been on death row in the Florida State Prison for eight years. Last March the Florida Supreme Court found that there had been a fundamental legal error at his trial. By a vote of 4 to 3, it set aside his conviction and death sentence and ordered a new trial.

title: Polaroid Net Up in Quarter
description: The Polaroid Corporation reported yesterday that net earnings for the third quarter rose 29.7 percent, to $8.3 million, or 26 cents a share, from $6.4 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier, although worldwide sales sank 11.8 percent, to $316.8 million, from $359 million.

title: HUBBELL, HARVEY, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAUTENBERG PICTURES MRS. FENWICK AS 'ECCENTRIC' WHO CAN'T DO JOB
description: Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, today intensified his attacks on the record and ability of his Republican opponent, Representative Millicent Fenwick.

title: Ex-I.T.T. Aide Named U.S. Playing Card Chief
description: Leslie J. Racey, a former executive with the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, has been named president and chief executive of of the United States Playing Card Company of Cincinnati.

title: A.D.L. CRITICIZES TV OVER COVERAGE OF LEBANON
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith released a study yesterday charging that network television coverage of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last summer was marked by numerous factual errors and exaggerations, a melodramatic portrayal of Israeli censorship, an overemphasis on battle scenes and an absence of broad historical perspective.

title: U.S. SHIFTS ON AID FOR HANDICAPPED
description: In a further concession to Congressional critics, the Department of Education has agreed to extend the time for public comment on proposed regulations dealing with education for the nation's four million handicapped children.

title: WAVE HILL SEMINAR ON HISTORIC GARDENS
description: WHEN the Puritans arrived in America in the 17th century, they brought with them enough provisions to last in the wilderness for two years. Packed among their books and bedding were apple scions, or twigs, to graft onto trees in the New World, seeds of all kinds, roses and herbs.

title: PAUL KELLER
description: Paul Keller, who was principal of Public School 187 in Little Neck, Queens, from 1954 to 1974, died Saturday in St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Whom to Throw the Book At
description: Why send criminals to prison? To rehabilitate, to deter, to define social values - or simply to incapacitate, by keeping criminals off the streets? In the ongoing criminal justice debate, the incapacitation motive has become steadily more attractive as it becomes clear that crowded, mismanaged prisons don't rehabilitate, deter or define.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
MURDER RULINGS IMPERIL AID TO SALVADOR
description: Salvadoran military officials are concerned that a lack of judicial action in the killings here of two Americans and a Salvadoran official could imperil United States military aid to El Salvador.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Israel didn't break the backbone of Lebanon, the P.L.O. did it.

title: IOWA GOVERNORSHIP RACE TIGHTENS UP
description: Roxanne Conlin, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate who disclosed in July that she paid no state tax in 1981, appears to have made a considerable comeback in her race against Lieut. Gov. Terry Branstad.

title: PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $6,171,000 from discontinued operations

title: STUDENTS BUILD A HOUSE AND SELL IT FOR $20,000
description: For less than $20,000, Edward McGoldrick bought a new three-bedroom house with handcrafted walnut cabinets, a skylight for solar heat, ceiling beams and aluminum siding. The house normally would sell for about $50,000.

title: 'Phony Savings' Seen In Reagan's Assertion
description: President Reagan was ''touting phony savings'' in suggesting that inspectors general in top Government agencies saved $5.8 billion in a recent six-month period, two House committee chairmen said today.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $328,000

title: TRADE-IN: THE BEST WAY
description: When the neo-anti-environmentalists are reduced to defending Westway by ad hominem attacks on its opponents, you know that Westway is in trouble.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Al Mills vs. Walter Ivory, junior middleweights, 10 rounds; Mario Maldonado vs. Bobby Patterson, middleweights, eight rounds, and Bob Quarry vs.

title: CARDS BEAT BREWERS, 6-3, TO WIN THE WORLD SERIES
description: One night after they faced elimination and survived, the St. Louis Cardinals won the World Series tonight when they rallied in the sixth inning of the seventh game and defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-3.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $21.7 million...C-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $30.6 million

title: FLORENCE BELL ILCH
description: Florence Bell Ilch, the owner of Bellhaven Kennels of Red Bank, N.J., which bred and developed many prize-winning collies, died Tuesday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank. Mrs. Ilch was 90 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: DRANETZ ENGINEERING LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Raised Eyebrow
description: Bill Walton's plan to begin his comeback with the San Diego Clippers by playing only one game a week this season is viewed by the new general manager, Paul Phipps, with something less than total enthusiasm. Phipps, who took over when Ted Podleski was dismissed Monday, said that, although he would ''love to see'' a fully recovered Walton playing full time, ''an absentee player can be a disruption'' to a team.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CBS AGREES TO PAY IN TWO LIBEL SUITS
description: CBS has settled two separate multimillion-dollar libel suits brought by public officials against television stations it owns and operates in Philadelphia and Chicago. The terms of the settlements were kept confidential.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERS
description: ONE of the more disturbing stories of child abuse to appear in recent weeks was that of the Illinois man who kept his son hidden for 14 years because he had been born crosseyed and, it was feared, was retarded. Though the eye problem had disappeared at about age 9 or 10, the father said he could not break out of the established pattern of deception. When an anonymous caller to a child-abuse hotline alerted the authorities, the boy was taken from his parents. He was found in a preliminary examination to be intelligent and free of physical impairment.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect the acquisition of Prince Manufacturing Inc on June 30, 1982 which has been accounted for on a pooling of interests basis

title: CHART HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VICTIM IN STAMFORD MURDER IDENTIFIED AS MISSING DEAN
description: A body found Saturday morning in a parking lot in Stamford, Conn., was identified last night as a dean from a California university who had been missing since he arrived in New York City Friday night, the police said.

title: Panhandle Suing Columbia Gas Unit
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation's pipeline unit said it had sued a subsidiary of the Columbia Gas System for its failure to purchase the minimum amount of natural gas called for in their contract.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITE WOMAN GUILTY OF TREASON FOR UNION WORK IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A 30-year-old member of the banned African National Congress was convicted today of high treason. The defendant, Barbara Ann Hogan, a former researcher at the South African Institute of Race Relations, is said to be the first white woman to be convicted of that crime in South Africa.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,630,000 for the qr and $10,371,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including income of $805,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $7,551,000 from discontinued operations, reclassified to reflect the discontinuance of the holloware operation in 1981

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * APC Investments Inc. said it had terminated its cash tender offer for up to 454,000 shares of Pacific Realty Trust at $37 a share.

title: Bristol-Myers Widens Profit
description: The Bristol-Myers Company yesterday reported a 15 percent profit increase for the third quarter.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK (CALIF) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: GARDEN WORKSHOPS
description: Art of Garden Design, Old Westbury Gardens, 71 Old Westbury Road, Westbury, L.I.; 516-333-0048.

title: THOSE FOR MATH DIP
description: Scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test by students in New York City's public high schools increased this year in the verbal section and declined in the mathematics section, ending up more than 35 points below the national averages in each category, according to figures released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures are in accordance with F.A.S.B. Standard No 52

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $5,210,000 for spinoff expenses

title: 'ONE TOUGH DOMINICAN'
description: ST. LOUIS H e has been calling himself ''One Tough Dominican'' for weeks now, relishing being the top pitcher on the St. Louis Cardinals. It is almost as if Joaquin Andujar has been purposefully changing his image from flake to enforcer.

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONCERT: BOWERY ENSEMBLE
description: THE Bowery Ensemble is a small contemporary music group giving three concerts in the Great Hall of Cooper Union this season, and although this may be only a drop in the overflowing bucket of musical activity in New York, the drop is certainly weightier than many. The Bowery musicians look back over chamber-music works, mostly of relatively recent vintage, and bring up a few that seem to them to merit further hearing.

title: Israel's Beirut Inquiry Hears First Testimony
description: A three-man panel looking into the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut began hearing testimony today in secret. The panel, headed by Chief Justice Yitzhak Kahan of the Supreme Court, held its first proceedings in a heavily guarded area on the campus of Hebrew University here.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $37.3 million for the qr and $30million for the 9 mos

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charges of burglary against the promising junior-middleweight boxer Tony Ayala were formally dismissed by a court in San Antonio after a local homeowner, James Carpentier, signed a statement saying he did not wish prosecution to continue. Ayala will fight next in Atlantic City on Nov. 20 as part of a prime-time card to be televised by NBC. His opponent will be Carlos Herrera. ... Doug Kotar, the former Giant running back now undergoing treatment in Pittsburgh for an inoperable brain tumor, received an invitation to dinner at the White House with several other football personalities but had to decline. ... Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the world Formula One driving champion in 1972 and 1974, said he might return to Grand Prix racing next year, heartened by rules changes designed to slow the cars and make them safer. ... Bruce Sutter and Jim Kaat, important residents of the St. Louis Cardinals' bullpen, have acquired an interest in Arndon, the fastest trotter in racing history, who was recently retired to stud and syndicated.

title: Savings Unit In Suit Accord
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had agreed to seat Sheldon Appel as a director and settle suits arising from Mr. Appel's attempts to be seated.

title: MARTIN DISMISSED BY OAKLAND A's AFTER 3 SEASONS AS MANAGER
description: Billy Martin, who has managed five teams in the American League, was dismissed by the Oakland A's today. A statement released by Roy Eisenhardt, the A's president, said the club did not blame Martin for the team's fifth-place finish this season after leading the team to the Western Division title the year before but added that he thought a change was necessary for the good of the A's.

title: S.E.C. STAFF FAULTS BROKERS IN REPORT ON '80 SILVER CRISIS
description: Six major stock brokerage firms risked losing hundreds of millions of dollars two years ago because they gave excessive credit to the Hunt family of Texas for silver speculation, according to a staff report of the Securities and Exchange Commission that was released today.

title: BLACKS' S.A.T. SCORES
description: In making public the median Scholastic Aptitude Test scores and comparing the performances of black, white and other minority students, George H. Hanford, the College Board president, has contributed significantly to eventual solution of one of the nation's most important social problems. That black students taking the S.A.T.'s score, on the average, 100 points lower than the national norm should not be surprising. The disturbing fact of consistent academic retardation of black students has been the basis of debate for decades.

title: Reversal at Kaiser Steel
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, the nation's 12th-largest steel maker, said yesterday that it had lost $24 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $21.5 million, or $2.99 a share, a year earlier. The company said revenues had declined 42 percent from the 1981 period, to $172.1 million.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Books: Steamy Isle
description: GOLDEN HILL. By Shirley Lord. 501 pages. Crown. $14.95.

title: NOXELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $1,539,000; 1981 figures were restated for FASB No 52

title: DANCE: JANE COMFORT PRESENTS NEW 'INCORRECT TRANSLATIONS'
description: JANE COMFORT'S new ''Incorrect Translations,'' performed Tuesday at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, may raise some unanswered questions, but it promises to be one of the most intriguing new works of the season.

title: Vietnam Attacks Thai Plane
description: Vietnamese gunners opened fire on a Thai reconnaissance plane near the Thai-Cambodian border today, but did not hit the aircraft, Thai military officials said. The plane returned to its base inside Thailand, the officials added.

title: TEN PRESIDENTS AND 'THEIR' JOBLESS RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Fees for 'Smaller Jobs'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I enjoyed reading Norma Skurka's article (''Helpful Decorators for Smaller Jobs,'' Oct. 7). We were very pleased to see the subject of the ''smaller job'' being given significant coverage.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
This Time, Carey; Asks the Questions
description: How to go about improving health-care facilities was the topic of a panel discussion yesterday at one of those high-powered luncheons at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. But when the moderator and chief question-hurler succumbed to health problems, an unlikely substitute was thrown into the breach at the last minute.

title: LUCKY STRIKE'S COMEBACK BID
description: It was the best-selling cigarette in America. With great hoopla, it made the big move over ''The Hump,'' as its nemesis, Camel, was known, during the 1930's. For people now in their 20's and 30's, this was often the brand their fathers and mothers smoked. Who can forget its sponsorship of ''Your Hit Parade,'' or that catchy string of letters - L.S./M.F.T. ''Lucky Strike Means Fine Tobacco.''

title: POSTAL EMPLOYEES WIN $400 MILLION
description: The Postal Service agreed today to pay a total of $400 million in back pay due employees because of violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act from 1974 to 1978.

title: CUOMO CALLS FOR IMPROVEMENTS IN AID TO THE ELDERLY
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for governor of New York, called yesterday for the elimination of mandatory retirement and the improvement of home health-care benefits for the elderly.

title: Profits Scoreboard
LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-After an accounting change produced a gain of $14,850,000...D-Net income after adjustment of receivable from U.S. Government produced a gain of $57 million

title: F.C.C. Clears Bell's Permit
description: Despite complaints that it is improperly favoring telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission today awarded the first construction permit for a cellular mobile telephone system to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Bowery Hires President
description: The Bowery Savings Bank has turned to a commercial banker to help guide it through the coming days of bank deregulation. The bank said yesterday that it had named Jerald Conway Newman, 50, executive vice president of the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, as its new president and chief administrative officer.

title: REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $91.5 million or 87 cents a shr from a payment by Kuwait of an arbitration award

title: GARCIA MARQUEZ OF COLOMBIA WINS NOBEL LITERATURE PRIZE
description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the author of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' was awarded the 1982 Nobel Prize for Literature today.

title: E.E.C. ALSO PLANS CURB ON ITS IMPORTS OF STEEL
description: Western European nations will reduce their steel imports by more than 10 percent next year, it was announced today. The purpose is to permit the sale within Europe of Europeanmade steel that can no longer be exported to the United States.

title: BRIEFING
description: Crime Panel Possibility

title: 'MONSIGNOR,' DISHONEST PRIEST
description: BRASH, handsome, ruthless, reckless, ambitious, brilliant and corrupt: these are the thrillingly paper thin qualities undoubtedly possessed by Father John Flaherty in the novel upon which ''Monsignor'' is based. As played by a more or less real person (Christopher Reeve), Father Flaherty cannot help but lose some of his two-dimensional luster.

title: TOURS FOR NEW YORKERS WHO LOVE TO EXPLORE
description: NEVER let it be said that New Yorkers do not love their city, despite the exuberant grumbling that identifies the species. Every weekend they pour into the streets of the five boroughs, ready to lay their skepticism aside and admire - and learn about - New York. Some explore haphazardly, opening themselves to the random sights and sounds and smells of the city. Others are more orderly about it, winding methodically through a neighborhood, guidebook and camera in hand. But most rely on the walking tours that have grown into a major weekend industry over the last 10 years or so, tours that explore historic or natural areas, that trace the footsteps of some noted New Yorker or simply offer a look in depth at a familiar landmark.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe the time has come to stop talking about talking about peace and start sitting down at the table, negotiating directly between Israelis, and Arabs, and the United States, and start achieving Palestinian rights, and start achieving the broader peace which is the key to the stability and security for Israel.'' - Excerpt from a State Department policy statement. (A1:6.)

title: REAGAN ASSIGNS THE BLAME FOR RECOVERY DELAY TO FOES
description: President Reagan, stepping up his appeals for patience in economically depressed farm communities, charged today that ''voices of fear and doom'' in the Democratic Party were threatening the chances of economic recovery.

title: FTOREK BACK IN MIDDLE
description: Robbie Ftorek of the Rangers spent a lot of time last season as the center for Don Maloney and Eddie Johnstone. So, when he was making his first start of the season Wednesday night, after missing the first seven games with a groin pull, Ftorek did not worry about getting synchronized with Maloney and Johnstone.

title: EXPULSION OF ISRAEL IS AVERTED
description: A Western compromise was approved by the International Telecommunications Union conference early today, averting the expulsion of Israel.

title: HOW VON KARAJAN SEES HIS CONDUCTING SUCCESS
description: The morning after Wednesday's triumphant Brahms concert at Carnegie Hall, Herbert von Karajan, conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, looked out over Central Park from his hotel suite with unfeigned delight. ''It's a wonderful sight,'' he said. ''I could look at it all day.''

title: Resorts' Big Gain On Bond Trading
description: The sharp decline in interest rates and the rally in Treasury bond prices has brought big profits for some speculators, including Resorts International Inc., a hotel and casino company. The company said it had sold all its bonds and bond futures for an after-tax gain of $43 million, which will be included in earnings for the third and fourth quarters this year.

title: PRIME COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: NO, there weren't as many security guards as there were guests, but t heir number was impressive. After all, this was a party in a d epartment store, and in addition to all the tempting merchandise a round, a number of the women were carrying a lot of highly visible e xcess weight. There were square-cut emeralds, diamonds of every s hape and size, and enough gold to rival Fort Knox, not to mention t he odd ruby and sapphire flashing from a finger or decolletage.

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Socal Finds 'Giant' Field
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it believed it had located a ''giant oil field'' off the coast of southern California. Socal said it based its report on wells drilled by its Chevron U.S.A. subsidiary and Phillips Petroleum around a jointly held tract off Point Conception. The tract was leased by the companies in May 1981 for $333.6 million, one of the most expensive offshore tracts obtained from the Federal Government.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figures have been restated for a 3 percent stock divd in May 1982

title: Coroner Convincing
description: An attorney for the widow of Thurman Munson, the Yankee catcher who died in the in the crash of his small jet three years ago, said that he was convinced the Summit County coroner had not withheld any important information about Munson's death. The attorney, Eugene Okey, is representing Diana Munson in her $42 million lawsuit against the Cessna Aircraft Corporation and Flight Safety International, the company that gave Munson flying instructions. Mr. Okey took depositions Wednesday from three detectives who searched the offices of the coroner, Dr. A.H. Kyriakides, on Sept. 17, and he said yesterday that he believed that a newspaper report concerning that search was ''much ado about nothing.''

title: ART: BOTANICAL BRONZES FROM NANCY GRAVES
description: AT producing exotic botanical specimens, the sculptor Nancy Graves could certainly give lessons to Luther Burbank. In her new show of polychrome bronzes at M. Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street (through Nov. 11), she's seemingly out to redesign the floriferous world, making surreal matches of albizzia pods and monstera leaves, antherium blossoms and palm fronds, fern stamens and bird of paradise flowers; joining disparate breeds of stalk, leaf, tendril, vine and pistil with such elegant plausibility as to call for a complete revision of garden handbooks.

title: INCO LOSS IN QUARTER A RECORD
description: Even before Charles F. Baird, chairman of Inco Ltd., told his board of directors today that he had sold Inco's two corporate jets, it was clear that the world's largest nickel company had seen better weeks.

description: The Reagan budget cuts were a ''bout of meanness.'' Moral Majority was ''the new righteousness.'' American policy toward Latin America was ''callous.''

R.J. REYNOLDS UP
description: Schlumberger Ltd., leading manufacturer of sophisticated oil well measuring equipment, reported yesterday that the severe drop in domestic oilfield activity resulted in a 3.3 percent decline in third-quarter net income. Revenues fell 4.8 percent.

title: India and Italy On the West Side.
description: IN the six years since Shah Jahan opened on Eighth Avenue, between 57th and 58th Streets, it has drawn a loyal following from neighborhood offices, Coliseum visitors, television personalities at nearby CBS studios and young dancers and show business hopefuls who appreciate the interesting food and moderate prices.

title: Former Guerrilla Leader Sworn as Chad President
description: A former guerrilla leader was sworn in as President of Chad today, four months after his rebel army took control of this battered capital.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RHYTHM: INTER-AMERICA BAND
description: RHYTHM is king in Jorge Dalto's Inter-American Band, a sextet with an occasional singer, all from Argentina, Brazil, Cuba, Puerto Rico and far-off Phildelphia. On stage at S.O.B.'s, where the group performed Wednesday and will return next Wednesday, Mr. Dalto's keyboards were flanked by a drum set, congas and timbales.

title: SOCIAL WHIRL MAKES THE U.N.'S WORLD GO ROUND
description: The invitations began dropping last month, like the first flakes of a blizzard. ''In honor of His Excellency, the Governor General of Canada, the Rt. Hon. Edward Schreyer, and Mrs. Schreyer,'' one of the first invitations began, ''the Ambassador and Permanent Representative of Canada to the United Nations and Mrs. Gerard Pelletier request the pleasure of ...''

title: WEICKER AND MOFFETT ASSURE ELDERLY OVER SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The two leading contenders for the United States Senate from Connecticut, Representative Toby Moffett and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., went their separate ways across the state today assuring elderly citizens that their Social Security checks were safe.

title: 'Cage aux Folles' will come back as Broadway musical.
description: ''WHEN I saw that film three-and-a-half years ago,'' Jerry Herman began, ''I walked out of the theater and said, 'That should be my next musical. That's the truth.'' The film was ''La Cage aux Folles,'' the much-loved French farce about an aging homosexual couple. As things are turning out, ''La Cage aux Folles'' will be Mr. Herman's next musical. Mr. Herman, who gave Broadway ''Hello, Dolly!'' and ''Mame,'' is writing the music and lyrics, and Harvey Fierstein, the author and star of ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' is writing the book. The producer is Allan Carr. The hope is to open the show on Broadway early next season.

title: U.S. Witness Outlines Fallout Responsibility
description: An expert on radioactivity acknowledged under cross-examination today that if the Government had expected fallout to drift over populated areas in the atomic tests in Nevada in the 1950's and 1960's, it should have warned people downwind to protect themselves.

title: TIPS FOR MARATHON FANS
description: WHAT is the perfect way to watch the New York Marathon? To run in it, surely - a privilege that will be denied all but 16,000 of the more than two million people who will turn out on Sunday to be part of it. The lucky entrants will see some authentic New York curiosities: Fort Wadsworth at dawn, for one, the Staten Island gathering point for runners on their day of days. Think of it: a tiny middle-American town just like John Glenn's, all tended lawns and flagpoles, surrounded by scrub forest aglow with October russets and golds. Incongruous, to be launched from that peaceable kingdom into the chaos of a race where a runner bashes around the corners of the city like a pinball, deafened and buoyed by the din of humanity.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''MONSIGNOR,'' the most recent movie to be directed by Frank Perry, opens today (a review appears on page C8). It's hard to realize that 20 years have passed since the great director Jean Renoir called Mr. Perry ''a young master'' and said his first movie, ''David and Lisa,'' was ''a turning point in the history of world cinema.''

title: A GARCIA MARQUEZ SAMPLER
description: After the death of a paterfamilias who had been chained to a tree in the garden, where he passed time muttering in Latin: A short time later, when the carpenter was taking measurements for the coffin, through the window they saw a light rain of tiny yellow flowers falling. They fell on the town all through the night in a silent storm, and they covered the roofs and blocked the doors and smothered the animals who slept outside. So many flowers fell from the sky that in the morning the streets were carpeted with a compact cushion and they had to clear them away with shovels and rakes so that the funeral procession could pass by. - ''One Hundred Years of Solitude''

title: MEMORIES OF FALL
description: N o.1. Fashion Note. Reggie, Reggie, Reggie, where were you? Packed my best three-piece suit, my only three-piece suit, just for you. Carried it on my wearying trek from Atlanta to St. Louis to Milwaukee to St. Louis and back home yesterday and never got to wear it to the ball park.

REAGAN'S COLLISION WITH AN ISRAELI CONSENSUS
description: T o the Editor: In his Oct. 7 Op-Ed article (''Arabs: Is Reagan Tenacious?''), Joseph Sisco expresses the fear that the Reagan plan might suffer the fate of its predecessor, the Rogers Plan, which was ''shot down by both Arabs and Israelis.'' He therefore concludes that American tenacity in adhering to the plan is vital for its success.

title: FOLLOW THAT CAB, BUT DON'T CROSS THAT ZONE!

KORCZAK ZIOLKOWSKI, SCULPTOR WHO PORTRAYED CRAZY HORSE
description: Korczak Ziolkowski, a sculptor who spent half his life carving a monument to Chief Crazy Horse of the Sioux Indians out of a granite mountain in the Black Hills, died Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

description: It is understandably inconvenient for Lebanon's new President, Amin Gemayel, that he got his job through the Israeli Army. Read against that embarrassing fact, his anti-Israel statements on a quick tour of the West are not at all discouraging.

title: G.P.U. Plans to Buy $1 Billion of Power

description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said it expects its capital spending to drop to $450 million (United States) next year from an estimated $625 million this year.

title: 'WOMEN'S MUSIC': DEBUT BY FERRON
description: based singer and songwriter who made her New York debut at Folk City on Wednesday, is one of the most powerful lyric voices to emerge out of the lesbian-oriented post-folk genre known as ''women's music.'' While the genre has produced a first-rate singer in Cris Williamson and a provocative rhetorician in Holly Near, until Ferron, it hadn't spawned a songwriter whose lyrics consisently rose above the inspirational versifying that gives so much women's music a pep rally predictability.

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'JINXED,' STARRING BETTE MIDLER
description: ''JINXED,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, is an entertaining jumble of a movie in which no two elements ever seem to be in sync for more than five consecutive seconds. At one point or another it's a comic melodrama, a Bette Midler vehicle, a romantic comedy and ''a Don Siegel Film,'' though there's very little to suggest the work of the man who made ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers,'' ''Charley Varrick'' and ''Escape from Alcatraz.''

title: Tool Concern Posts Losses
description: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company yesterday reported large losses for its fourth quarter and its fiscal year. The nation's largest manufacturer of portable power tools also said it planned to sell its money-losing gasoline chain saw operation and that its board had lowered the quarterly dividend to 13 cents a share from 19 cents in the third quarter.

She played with E.J. Kahn Jr., who is spending a couple of days each week in Boston working up a series on food for The New Yorker, and she beat him.

And there was the viral infection in his back that nearly killed him in the summer of 1981 and required surgery.

NOBEL LAUREATE'S WRITING BRINGS A WIDE VARIETY OF RESPONSES
description: At once fantastical and historical, lushly imaginative and politically topical, the writing of Gabriel Garcia Marquez has met with a variety of critical responses. He has been praised for his inventive use of modernist conceits and his ability to conjure up an entire continent in the imagination; at the same time he has been chided for ideological posturing and for writing short stories that tend to cramp his style and inhibit his formal powers.

title: Books Of The Times
description: SECOND HEAVEN. By Judith Guest. 320 pages. Viking. $14.95. ICAN'T complain that I wasn't moved by Judith Guest's ''Second H eaven,'' a new novel by the author of ''Ordinary People.'' I was m oved, I really was. I felt tense and worried in all the right placesa nd sighed with relief when I ought to have and cheered when the h eroine, Catherine (Cat) Holzman, snaps at her psychiatrist: ''I t hink you make a fetish out of refusing to give advice. It's not n atural. You should see someone about it.'' (Lo and behold, he then g ives advice!)

Lubbers, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, to issue a complaint against the league, could impede progress toward ending the strike.

title: RUSSIAN JEWISH MUSIC IN 2 WEEKEND CONCERTS
description: The history of Jewish music is the history of the Jews: migrations, displacements, ghettos, assimilations, traditions and modernizations. In Russia, Jewish music has tinges of Russian music; in Eastern Europe, it echoes with the inflections of Hungary and Rumania; in America, jazz has crept in. At the same time, the minor modes and dramatic melismas of cantorial singing - itself a heritage of Middle Eastern music - can be heard across cultures and across centuries.

title: Elizabeth Taylor Sues To Stop an ABC Drama
description: Elizabeth Taylor filed suit against the American Broadcasting Company and an independent film company yesterday in an effort to stop production and transmission of an unauthorized film biography.

title: Bridge: The Action Came Too Late For Americans at Biarritz
description: At 7 P.M. last Saturday in Biarritz, France, American supporters watching on BridgeVision - a sophisticated theater presentation that permitted a large audience to watch both play and players - had virtually given up hope. In the final of the world championship against France, their team trailed by 22 international match points with five deals remaining.

description: After a grand opening fanfare, little more has been heard about President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative. In the same way, the civil war in El Salvador, the U.S. quarrel with Nicaragua, the massacres in Guatemala have faded from the news.

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Pricing And Its Effect
description: THE I.B.M. game plan is straightforward: Advances in technology bring reduced manufacturing costs, so the International Business Machines Corporation can offer its equipment at lower prices - and thus become more competitive.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Atlanta Hawks signed Keith Edmonson of Purdue, their firstround draft choice to a multiyear contract. Edmonson, a 6-6 gurad, led the Big Ten Conference in scoring last season, averaging 20.6 points. ... The Dodgers denied a newspaper report in Los Angeles that they had reached a contract agreement with Steve Garvey, their first baseman, and thereby kept him from entering the free-agent draft Nov. 10. ... George Cumby, a linebacker for the Green Bay Packers, underwent successful arthroscopic surgery for the removal of cartilage from his right knee after being injured in an informal team practice Tuesday.

title: FUNDAMENTALISTS FIGHT NEBRASKA OVER SCHOOL
description: Rachael Robinson went to school today. Clad in red, white and blue, she and 15 other children filed silently into the Faith Baptist Church, which houses their school. At 8:30 sharp, they pledged allegiance to the American flag, then to the Christian flag and then to the Bible.

title: PROBING CONGRESSIONAL INTENT SEEMS AT BEST TO BE UNTIDY
description: It sounds so simple in the civics textbooks: Congress passes laws and the Supreme Court interprets them. But the Court's docket is full of cases in which the laws are so vaguely worded and the Congressional purpose so obscure that the Justices are forced to become mind readers. And occasionally, their annoyance over having to tackle yet another burden creeps into their opinions and speeches.

title: 'LITTLE GLORIA' AND A NEW NBC SERIES
description: THERE is no competition as far as the big production is concerned. ''Little Gloria ... Happy at Last,'' which begins Sunday night at 9 on NBC, with the second half starting Monday at 9, is about as opulent as the commercial networks dare to get nowadays. At the core of the story is the 1934 child custody fight for a 10-year-old heiress named Gloria Vanderbilt, the very same who is now selling her designer jeans on television commercials.

title: THE MX? NO.
description: Congress, in its lame-duck session, will finally have to face up to the most important strategic-weapons issue confronting America: whether to proceed with production of the MX missile. The outcome will determine the nature of our strategic arsenal for the next 15 to 20 years. The arguments against it are worth reviewing.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1982
description: International Direct Arab-Israeli talks are necessary to achieve a Middle East peace, according to a United States policy statement issued on the eve of a meeting between President Reagan and an Arab League delegation. The statement said: ''We believe the time has come to stop talking about talking about peace, and start negotiating directly.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) An accord on curbing steel exports to the United States from Europe was reached by Washington and the Common Market. Under the three-year agreement, the Europeans will reduce steel shipments to about a million tons below the 1981 level, which totaled 6.5 million tons. (A1:5.)

title: A Good Sign
description: For the first time in two years, Tim Leary is throwing without pain and the people who deal in Met futures are quietly ecstatic. Every day, the rookie who was being compared to Tom Seaver and Jim Palmer - until his budding career was almost dashed by injury and illness - has been throwing smoothly and painlessly at the Mets' instructional camp in Florida.

description: IT'S not until late in Act II that the audience hears the noise of breaking glass in David Hare's ''Plenty,'' but long before then, we've become terribly familiar with the harrowing sound of things going smash. A partial list of the evening's casualties would include at least three lives, one empire (the British), the egalitarian ideals of a generation and many of the conventions of the traditional narrative play.

title: CARLOS SAURA'S 'SWEET HOURS'
description: CARLOS SAURA'S fascination with the past has led him to the Oedipal impasse of ''Sweet Hours,'' a film about a man who longs hopelessly for his own boyhood. The film initially shows Juan (Inaki Aierra) in a subdued, languid mood, but it traces the ever more intense process by which he rediscovers his memories. A packet of his parents' old letters triggers Juan's desire to re-create his experience with his mother, whom his father abandoned. This mother-son relationship, we discover, was a pure, happy, sexy passion of the sort few men experience with their grown-up mates, let alone with their moms.

title: CUBANS ADD TO CITY'S MUSICAL LIFE
description: ''THEY call us boat people, but Columbus and his men were boat people, too,'' a Cuban musician now living in New York remarked recently. ''Boat people discovered and settled America, and we have something important to contribute to America also: our music.''

title: ROTATION HOME FOR BEIRUT MARINES MAY BE DELAYED BY THE PENTAGON
description: The Defense Department said today that the scheduled rotation home next month of the marines in Beirut might be delayed, as speculation grew that their role may be more extensive than originally planned.

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Munsingwear Chief Resigns
description: Munsingwear Inc. of Minneapolis said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Raymond F. Good, 54 years old, had resigned.

title: CARDS SOARED TO THE SUMMIT ON TRADES
description: The field on which they won the World Series was in tatters today, but the St. Louis Cardinals stood in splendor as the most heavily traded and suddenly successful team in baseball.

title: Navy Lifts a Curfew After N. Chicago Action
description: The North Chicago City Council, a week after a curfew for sailors had been clamped on a nightlife section of the city by the Great Lakes Naval Training Center, told Navy officials today that it would increase its patrol force in the affected area. The Navy responded by lifting the curfew that it had imposed on Oct. 14.

title: 'FIRST BLOOD'
description: VIETNAM is to ''First Blood'' as rape was to ''Death Wish'': it's the excuse for a rampage of destruction. Sylvester Stallone plays John Rambo, a former Green Beret who wanders into a tiny town in the Northwest, is mistreated by the sheriff, and spends the rest of the movie getting even. But unlike Charles Bronson in ''Death Wish,'' or the heroes of all the sleazy spinoffs that that film inspired, Mr. Stallone's Rambo isn't a cold-blooded killer. He's almost a Boy Scout, and a phenomenal Boy Scout at that. ''First Blood'' concentrates not on revenge, not on unmotivated mayhem, but on survival in the wilderness.

title: Workers, Despite Curb, Go on Strike in Ecuador
description: Workers defied a state of emergency and staged general strikes today in Ecuador's two largest cities to protest price increases on flour and gasoline.

title: Gergen Predicts a Shift To Left if Reagan Fails
description: A senior White House official said today that if President Reagan's economic effort failed, ''something much more radical'' than Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society would result.

title: Westport Plan Off
description: The Westport Company said it had dropped its offer to buy Northwestern Mutual Life Mortgage and Realty Investors for $14 a share, following the refusal by Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company to provide the financing Westport had requested for the bid. Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance has also made a bid for the realty trust, at $13.75 a share. Westport said it had filed suit in Massachusetts state court in Suffolk County to remove the trust's trustees and block that tender offer.

SCULPTURE: JOEL SHAPIRO IN WHITNEY EXHIBITION
description: NOWHERE around is there a sculptor quite like Joel Shapiro, whose retrospective exhibition has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art and can be seen there through Jan. 2. This is not to say that there is no one to whom he can be compared, but that in the end there is a Shapiro-note that no one else has struck.

title: Equipment Is Suspect
description: Responding to comments from Coach Hayden Fry of Iowa that the problem of injury in college football was becoming so serious that he was thinking of leaving the game, Dave Nelson suggested that one of the reasons could be the playing equipment.

title: RATES STABLE IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates were little changed to slightly lower in quiet trading yesterday. Securities dealers said investors seemed to be taking a breather after the heavy buying in August and earlier this month.

title: Unemployment Follows Fame
description: Jim Craig is a man without a job. The Boston Bruins recently bought out his contract and released him and now, at the age of 25, the former goalie for the United States Olympic team is still waiting for someone to give him a tryout.

title: MISS De LARROCHA RULES AS THE QUEEN OF PIANISTS
description: Music has its royalty, too. Artists have been represented as the King of Tenors, the Queen of Song, the Prince of Violinists, with other assorted nobility thrown in. Sometimes these designations arouse scornful smiles, if not downright raspberries. But nobody is going to put up much of a fight against calling Alicia de Larrocha the reigning Queen of Pianists.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: NEW SEASON OPENS AT RIVERSIDE
description: SAEKO Ichinohe, a Japanese dancer-choreographer who lives in the United States and whose works have been produced by several ballet companies, dipped into a large number of styles and idioms when her company opened its season Wednesday night at Riverside Church.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1982; International
description: The U.S. and the Common Market agreed on restraints on exports European steel to the U.S. Under the pact, which followed lengthy and often bitter talks, the U.S. set import quotas for the next three years. (Page A1.) Negotiators said Western Europe would reduce steel imports by more than 10 percent so that domestic producers could sell at home the steel they could not ship to the U.S. (D2.)

title: ON L.I., A MODERN CONDOMINIUM WITH A ROCOCO PAST
description: It was once one of the resort jewels of the East Coast, built on the Atlantic beach front here in the 1920's as a Riviera-style spa for New York's monied classes. Guests were entranced by its pink facade and fanciful rococo architecture, catered to by its staff and entertained by stars who performed under the open skylight of its circular nightclub. For nearly 50 years the 300-room Lido Beach Hotel pampered its affluent guests in the style to which they were accustomed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 14 on the 1981-82 Scholastic Aptitude Test incorrectly reported the number of students who voluntarily provided information on race or ethnic group. Of the 1,019,660 who took the test, 994,333 gave such in- formation.

description: B-Including a gain of $2.9 million from an exchange of stock for debt

DeLEOREAN ARREST JARS BRITONS
description: News of John Z. DeLorean's arrest in the United States on drug charges has shocked and dismayed officials in Britain, which had helped finance his failed sports car plant in Belfast.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, and Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, exhibition doubleheader, at Landover, Md. One week before the season opens, both the Knicks and the Nets still have some important roster decisions to make.

title: INTERPROVINCIAL PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; JWT Is Rehiring Accountant
description: AFTER a review of its performance before the recent financial scandal at the J. Walter Thompson Company, Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, has been retained once again by the JWT Group on the condition that it put up $2.4 million in cash and services. Accounting experts say that such an arrangement is extremely rare. And they agree that since Price Waterhouse handles JWT worldwide, at least a $1 million annual income from it is extremely possible.

title: Treasures of the Morgans.
description: TWO works acquired by J. Pierpont Morgan at the turn of the century and still in the possession of the Morgan family -J.M.W. Turner's ''Landscape with Walton Bridges'' and a Renaissance silver tazza, a pedestal-base shallow vessel - will be on the block next week at two of New York's leading auction galleries. Both are being sold for Catherine Morgan, widow of Henry S. Morgan, a grandson of J. Pierpont Morgan and son of J.P. Morgan Jr.

title: CLUES LACKING IN DEAN SLAYING
description: The police today pressed their investigation into the slaying of a California educator who was found stabbed to death here last Saturday.

title: ISRAEL FAULTS LEBANON ON TENT DELAY
description: A senior Israeli official in the Foreign Ministry said today that the Lebanese Government's disdain for the fate of homeless Palestinians in southern Lebanon was impeding efforts by a United Nations relief agency to erect tents to protect the refugees from imminent rain and cold weather.

title: UNITED STATES GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Second Best
description: Finishing second in the last three Kentucky Derbies has been something of a jinx for those runners-up. Laser Light, who finished second to Gato del Sol last May, has not won a race since, nor has Woodchopper, second to Pleasant Colony in 1981.

title: Money Funds Up $1.3 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose by $1.3 billion, to a record $228.7 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The latest increase came on top of a $2.8 billion rise in the previous reporting week.

title: ATTACK ON VOODOO II
description: ''The Republicans want us to stay the course with President Reagan's economic program; but I call that Voodoo II.''

title: Action Executive Is Selected
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Betty M. Brake as deputy director of Action, the volunteer agency grouping. Mrs. Brake, 62 years old, has been deputy assistant director of the Older Americans Volunteer Programs. She also was co-chairman and executive director of the President's campaign in Oklahoma in 1979-80.

title: Connors Is Ailing
description: Jimmy Connors, the world's top-ranked male tennis player after his victories at Wimbledon and in the United States Open this year, said that a back ailment would drastically limit his tournament schedule in 1983. Connors spoke in Melbourne, Australia, where his sciaticnerve injury forced him to withdraw this week from the Super Challenge round robin.

title: 'HALOWEEN III,' PLOTTING A JOKE
description: AS long as there had to be a sequel to John Carpenter's ''Halloween'' and ''Halloween II,'' both smash box office hits, ''Halloween III: Season of the Witch,'' written and directed by Tommy Lee Wallace, is probably as good as any cheerful ghoul could ask for.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. At the age of 86, ''the Duchess,'' who founded the Tufty News Service, is probably the oldest working newspaper reporter in Washington.

title: AULD ACQUAINTANCE-NOT FORGOT. ALTERED.
description: I was reared in Richmond, Va. It's increasingly painful to go back. There are so many headlong changes there (and elsewhere), caused by such things as population growth, the tendency to streamline, and a less desirable effect of showmanship: emphasis on form at the expense of content. There are few towns to which you can return without unpleasant surprises.

title: RACE FOR 28TH DISTRICT IN NEW YORK FOCUSING ON U.S. ECONOMY
description: Matthew H. McHugh has won four terms in the House of Representatives as a liberal Democrat from this largely rural and small-town district in which the Republican registration is 45.7 percent, compared with the Democratic figure of 31.9 percent.

title: Venezuela Refinancing
description: Venezuela has received offers to refinance $932 million of short-term foreign debt of two state agencies, the public credit director, Erika de Sullivan, said today.

title: 3 HUTTON OFFICIALS GO TO BACHE
description: News that three prominent executives of E.F. Hutton & Company had defected to Bache Halsey Stuart Shields hit Wall Street yesterday, touching off an indignant reaction from Hutton.

description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today pledged to maintain New York State's environmental standards and campaigned through the Hudson Valley.

description: A wave of vandalism and break-ins has strirred fears among Western diplomats here of a campaign of harassment against representatives of countries seen as unfriendly to Poland's martial-law administration.

description: Twenty years ago today, President John F. Kennedy publicly demanded that the Soviet Union remove its missiles from Cuba or else. And for 13 days, until agreement on their removal was reached, he thought that the chances of nuclear war were 1 in 3 or even.

title: French Output Down
description: French industrial production fell a provisional seasonally adjusted 3.1 percent in the combined months of July and August after falling a revised eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: Opportunity in Bolivia
description: ''The supply of heroin, cocaine, marijuana and other drugs is so great that we simply must reduce production before we can substantially reduce availability.'' Thus testified former Deputy Secretary of State Walter Stoessel at a Congressional hearing earlier this year. But try negotiating a drug control program with a weak and divided Lebanon, or with Soviet-occupied Afghanistan, or a Bolivia that was governed until a few weeks ago by drug-dealing generals.

title: DOW NEARS HIGH BEFORE FALLING 5.52
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, which reached its highest level in nearly a decade this week, came close yesterday to achieving its highest level in history before falling back in the final 90 minutes of trading.

title: FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'CANDIDE' STAR WANTS TO TRY EUROPE
description: Erie Mills, who is glittering and gay as Cunegonde in the New York City Opera's great new success, ''Candide,'' turns out in person to be a mixture of musical temperament, tough self-confidence and simple Middle Western good sense.

title: GARVEY AND PETRILLO
description: Ed Garvey, the lawyer calling the signals for the striking National Football League Players Association, is the epitome of the new-breed union leader - urbane, articulate, versed in the technological and histrionic aspects of the television era. But if his players win their demand for a guaranteed cut of the club owners' TV take, they will be embroidering a pattern set four decades ago by James Caesar Petrillo, an archetypal old-line unionist who boasted that he became president of the American Federation of Musicians only because he wasn't good enough on the trumpet to make a living as a card-carrying member.

title: TRUDEAU USES TV BLITZ TO SPELL OUT NATION'S PLIGHT
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau went on national television three times this week to dramatize the depth of his nation's economic problems and to urge Canadians to work together to solve them.

title: METROMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes $49,766,000 or $13 a shr relating to gains on dispositions and the retirement of debt

title: C.N.W. RAIL STAKE PUT AT $76.2 MILLION
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today set a price of $76.2 million for the Chicago and Northwestern Transportation Company, also known as C.N.W., to buy a half interest in the rail route to Wyoming's Powder River Basin coal fields built by the Burlington Northern Railroad Company.

title: 6 in Gang Accused of Plot
description: Six members of a street gang have been arrested on charges of plotting to assassinate two police officers in retaliation for the police killing of 19-year-old man. Five young men and a 16-year-old were arrested Thursday at six inner-city homes and charged with conspiracy to commit murder.

title: Dancers, Ballet Theater Resume Informal Talks
description: Negotiators for the management of the American Ballet Theater and the dancers' committee have resumed informal talks in hope of reaching agreement on labor contract talks, which were broken off Oct. 9.

title: And Available On Sundays, Too
description: This will be the fifth week without a paycheck for pro football's striking players. Not only have their salaries dried up, but so have many of their outside speaking engagements.

title: Edward W. Lewis Jr., Was Writer for A.M.A.
description: Edward Williams Lewis Jr., director of communications in the Washington office of the American Medical Association and author of a weekly column, ''Washington's Week,'' in The American Medical News, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Grass Looking Greener
description: The new United States Football League, which is scheduled to begin play next February, continues to be wary of pursuing National Football League players, believing that, strike or no strike, they are legitimately under contract. But there was no wariness yesterday on the part of Rich Mauti, a wide receiver for the New Orleans Saints, who said in an interview that he believed ''about 80 percent'' of the Saints would try for positions with the U.S.F.L. if the N.F.L. season is canceled because of the walkout.

Runners Warned
description: According to Rich Bunch, who studies such things, about two-thirds of the 16,000 runners in tomorrow's New York City Marathon will suffer foot, leg or knee injuries during their careers. If they know certain ground rules, said Mr. Bunch, they may avoid many of those injuries.

title: Tow-Truck Driver Is Found Slain
description: A 28-year-old tow-truck driver who had been questioned about last week's armored-truck robbery in the Bronx was found shot to death early yesterday in his truck. The police said the man, Victor Montez, had been one of many questioned about the Oct. 12 robbery in which one guard was killed and another guard and a bystander were wounded by four gunmen with automatic weapons.

title: Producer Of Tylenol Is Cleared
description: The Food and Drug Administration today officially cleared the subsidiary of the Johnson & Johnson Company that makes Tylenol of any responsibility for the contamination of pain-relief capsules that killed seven residents of the Chicago area.

title: PAYSON COLEMAN, NEW YORK LAWYER
description: Payson Coleman, managing partner of the New York City law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died Thursday at his home in Glen Head, L.I., after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Ozark Wonders Why
description: Danny Ozark, the former Philadelphia manager who was dropped as third-base coach of the Los Angeles Dodgers earlier this week in favor of Joe Amalfitano, does not understand why he was let go. Ozark said that neither Manager Tom Lasorda nor Al Campanis, the Dodgers' vice president in charge of player personnel, had expressed dissatisfaction with his performance.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Car Dealer in Bronx Convicted Of Faking Odometer Mileages
description: A wholesale dealer in used cars was convicted yesterday of rolling back mileage on the odometers of vehicles before selling them throughout the Northeast and in England, Sweden, Norway and the Middle East.

description: B-Net income; results for the latest 9 mos reflect writedowns totaling $3 million relating to the company's investment in McLouth Steel Corp and the Empire Iron Mining partnership

Still Fighting
description: On Nov. 9, Sugar Ray Leonard will announce his decision on whether or not he will resume his boxing career, and it will be a huge surprise if the undisputed welterweight champion continues fighting in the aftermath of eye surgery. Now it seems one of the boxers most likely to succeed Leonard as 147-pound champion is having trouble remaining at 147 pounds.

title: McRae Wants a Raise
description: Hal McRae, the major leagues' leader in runs batted in during the 1982 season, said the Kansas City Royals had rejected his contract demand and that as a result there was ''a 90 percent chance'' he would not return to the team next season. The 36-year-old McRae is eligible to enter next month's free-agent draft. The Royals' general manager, John Schuerholz, said the team had not given up hope of keeping McRae, who says he wants a three-year pact ''at the going rate for designated hitters.''

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

title: Brown & Sharpe Loss
description: The strikebound Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company said today that it lost $3.8 million in the third quarter versus income of $2.7 million, or 87 cents a share, in the 1981 quarter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle yesterday on voter turnout gave an incorrect home state for Bill Curry, Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives. He is from Farm- ington, Conn.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES MEASURE ON E.P.A.
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have authorized several new research programs at the Environmental Protection Agency and would have required the agency to appoint members of varied interest groups to its top science advisory committee.

South Carolina Sheriff Indicted on 3 Charges
description: Theodore McFarlin, South Carolina's first black sheriff since Reconstruction, was indicted today by a grand jury in a case in which white prisoners in his Williamsburg County Jail charged they were beaten by black inmates.

title: 6 Free Agents Top Baseball Draft List
description: Steve Kemp and John Lowenstein, who have already declared themselves free agents, qualified yesterday with four others as players who would require a professional as compensation if they sign with new teams.

title: Chemical Cuts Prime to 11 1/2%
description: Chemical Bank, the sixth largest bank in the country, yesterday announced a reduction in its prime lending rate to 11 1/2 percent from 12 percent, the lowest prime rate for a major bank since September 1980.

description: The Sad Lot Of a Literary Landmark

Ex-Rights Chief Warns U.S. on a Busing Stand
description: The man President Reagan dismissed as chief of the United States Civil Rights Commission said today that the Administration would shatter racial harmony if it tried to dismantle court-ordered school busing plans.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
News Summary; SATURDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1982
description: International The U.S. and Arab proposals for peace in the Middle East along with United Nations Security Council resolutions could be the basis for ''peace and coexistence'' in the region, King Hassan II of Morocco said after a meeting in Washington with President Reagan. The King, who is the leader of an Arab League delegation, did not specifically define what he meant by ''coexistence,'' nor did he mention Israel, but a senior State Department official said that his choice of words was important. Mr. Reagan said the meeting with the delegation was ''an important milestone'' toward ''a common objective, a just and lasting peace in the Middle East,'' and emphasized the importance of a negotiating process. (Page 1, Column 6.) Elections in Northern Ireland strengthened the political arm of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Incomplete returns gave Sinn Fein two more seats, for a total of five, in the 78-member assembly. The gains were widely regarded as a pyschological victory for the party, which entered only 12 candidates, all in urban areas where Roman Catholics are concentrated, which campaigned on a slogan of ''a ballot in one hand and a gun in the other.'' (1:5.)

title: KREISLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
