title: GRATEFUL WRIGHT MORRIS OUTGROWS REGIONALISM
description: Wright Morris has lived in California for the last 20 years, longer than he has lived anywhere else and exactly twice as long as he lived in his native Nebraska. But although his novels have been set everywhere from California to the Philadelphia Main Line, from Mexico to Europe, enough of them have been set in the cities and towns of the Great Plains that he is still regarded as probably the foremost spokesman for that region.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies of Weekend yesterday gave incorrect days and locations for performances by the pianist Alicia de Larrocha. She played last night at Avery Fisher Hall and will play today at 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y.

title: I.R.A. PARTY POSTS MORE ULSTER GAINS
description: More gains were announced today for the political arm of the outlawed Provisional Irish Republican Army in Wednesday's elections in Northern Ireland, causing widespread private expressions of dismay among officials in London.

title: COUPLE FIGHTS FOR THEIR VIETNAMESE CHILD
description: Lan Grady has not seen her 11-year-old son, Le Minh Tuan, since she left Vietnam eight years ago, but she has had a letter from him.

Scanning Text to Fix Spelling
description: WASHINGTON A process patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation is described as enabling the company's smaller computers and display writers to make automatic suggestions for correction of spelling errors.

title: HYBRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Burroughs to Shut Long Island Plant
description: The Burroughs Corporation announced it planned to close its Yaphank, L.I., manufacturing plant at the end of the year as part of a program to centralize its office systems and terminal products operations.

title: DISPUTE OVER A DISMISSAL CAUSES LEGAL AID STRIKE
description: More than 500 lawyers for the Legal Aid Society in New York City went on strike last night after failing to resolve a dispute with the society's officials over the dismissal of a lawyer from the Brooklyn office.

title: Fumes Overcome 40 at Queens Plant
description: Forty people were overcome by toxic fumes yesterday after a barrel of poisonous chemicals spilled at an automotive parts plant in Woodside, Queens. Fourteen of the victims required hospital treatment.

title: BRADLEY, MILTON, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEMP'S NATIONWIDE STUMPING STIRS THOUGHTS OF '84
description: Engulfed by well-wishers, his head barely visible above the throng, Representative Jack F. Kemp slowly picked his way through a crowd of 2,000 people, autographing anything from campaign brochures to straw hats.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JENNIFER O'NEILL IS SHOT IN HER WESTCHESTER HOME
description: Jennifer O'Neill, the actress and model, was shot and wounded at her home in northern Westchester County yesterday, the Bedford town police said.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lehrman and Cuomo File Spending Reports
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor, reported today that he had spent $7.3 million of his personal fortune on the campaign, bringing his total expenditures to $10.8 million -more than double his opponent's.

title: Democratic Leader Charges Reagan Is Burdening Farmers
description: The Democratic national chairman, Charles T. Manatt, says the Reagan Administration is unfairly singling out farmers to bear the brunt of its economic programs and budget cuts.

title: STATE WON'T PRESS LAST GIBSON COUNT
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that he would move for dismissal of a misconduct charge against Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson. He had been accused of creating a ''no show'' job for a former City Councilman.

title: Valerie Clarebout, 74, A Sculptor of Rockefeller Center Angels
description: Valerie Clarebout, the sculptor who created the triumphant herald angels that are the centerpiece of the annual Christmas display in the Channel Gardens of Rockefeller Center, died Thursday night in Southwood Community Hospital in Norfolk, Mass. She was 74 years old.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
ORDERS UP 0.2% FOR DURABLES
description: New factory orders for durable goods edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in September, with improvements for household items and machinery mostly offset by declines for automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMMONWEALTH NATIONAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3

PATENTS;
A Supersonic Plane With Adjustable Tail
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, El Segundo, Calif., received a patent this week for an aircraft capable of supersonic flight that has tail wings whose angle can be adjusted. The design is expected to be useful primarily in high-speed fighter planes, although it could be used in bombers.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
PONY EXPRESS
description: DALLAS F or all the convincing and conniving that is part of the formation of a big-time college football team, it is possible that when Southern Methodist plays at Texas today, with a high ranking and bowl bids at stake, the outcome will be determined in part by the wisdom and feelings of two women.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, exhibition game, at Johnson City, Tenn. 8:30 P.M. Boxing Donald Curry, North American Boxing Federation champion, vs. Marlon Starling, United States Boxing Association champion, 12 rounds, welterweights, unification bout, at Convention Hall, Atlantic City. Also, Ruben Munoz vs. Roger Mayweather, 12 rounds, U.S.B.A. lightweight championship. Curry has 14-0 record, with 11 knockouts and Starling is 24-0, with 16 knockouts. Munoz, the champion (14-1, 11 knockouts) is ranked sixth by Ring Magazine, Mayweather is unrankeed but also undefeated at 12-0, with seven knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Rangers, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8 P.M. Second meeting of the regular season between these rivals. Islanders are unbeaten in last seven games. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, WMCA, 570, WGBB 1240 and WALK 97.5 FM; 8 P.M.) Other Events College Football: Southern Methodist at University of Texas (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Arkansas at Houston (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.); Rutgers vs. Colgate 1:30 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 10:30 P.M., delayed tape.); Notre Dame at Oregon (Radio - WMCA, 570; 4:10 P.M.); Lowell at Fordham, 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-90.7 FM, 1:30 P.M.); Bucknell at Columbia (Radio - WKCR 89.9 FM., 1:15 P.M.); Kansas at Kansas State (Television -WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Cross-Country: Eastern States schoolboy championships at Van Cortlandt Park, 245th Street and Broadway, 1 P.M. Harness Racing: Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. Three Diamonds and Bambi Almahurst are the favorites in the two $40,915 divisions of the Lady Maud Pace for 3-year-old fillies.

title: Richard Ashley, Ex-President Of Allied Chemical Company
description: Richard C. Ashley, who resigned a week ago yesterday as president of the Allied Chemical Company and as a group vice president of its parent concern, the Allied Corporation, was killed Sunday in a car crash in Pulaski County, Va. He was 55 years old and had lived in Darien, Conn., for many years.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Convict Explains Rescue
description: A convicted killer who helped 12 other convicts pull two teen-agers from a burning car says he didn't do anything ''that a free person wouldn't have done.'' ''People were standing around yelling 'Get away, get away,' but all we saw were people inside the car,'' said Bobby Porter, who with the others rushed to the aid of the two last Friday. He was driving a busload of inmates when they saw the crash.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $3.4 million; the 1982 extraordinary credit for the qr and 9 mos is from recognition of tax benefits not previously reflected in financial statements; the 1982 operating net includes $1.2 million gain from reversal of tax reserve

title: BONN AND PARIS TO SEEK A COMMON MILITARY POLICY
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France was taking steps to consult with West Germany about nuclear strategy and that the two countries had decided to seek a common military doctrine in Western Europe.

title: RECESS IN TALKS IS LIKELY
description: The possibility arose today, and increased tonight, that the National Football League labor negotiations that have continued here since Oct. 12 might recess for a day or two as early as Saturday. The mediator involved may leave the talks, which have progressed slowly, if at all. In addition, the league owners are meeting Saturday, and the players have a meeting of team representatives scheduled Sunday in Washington.

title: HOW TV COVERS THE GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Mario Cuomo and Lewis Lehrman were on WABC-TV Tuesday night and Wednesday night. Each explained how he would curb violent crime if elected Governor of New York. What was unusual about their appearances was that they came during the nightly news program, rather than in the commercials with which both men have been bombarding viewers in the four weeks since they won their party's nominations.

title: SKY CHEFS TRIES OUT A HIGHWAY MARKET
description: To the traveler who takes for granted the grime and utilitarian drabness of a typical roadside rest stop, the slick restaurant-entertainment-service complex beside the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway here may come as something of a shock.

title: Motorola Extends Holiday Closings
description: Perhaps as many as half of Motorola Inc.'s 15,000 employees in the Phoenix area will be off the job for three extra days during both the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays, the company said today.

title: Increase in Money Lifts Rates; Fed Discount Inaction Cited
description: Short-term interest rates rose more than a quarter of a percentatge point and long-term bond prices fell sharply yesterday as credit market participants decided that the Federal Reserve was not acting to reduce interest rates as quickly as they expected.

title: Devils Lose by 3-1, Limited to 12 Shots
description: The Winnipeg Jets held New Jersey to only 12 shots on goal tonight as they scored a a 3-1 victory over the Devils.

title: N.A.A.C.P. WEIGHS BOYCOTT OF BEER COMPANY
description: Regional leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are opposing endorsement of Operation PUSH's boycott of Anheuser-Busch Inc. to win more opportunities for blacks. But the association's executive director insists that the national group has not decided its position on the boycott.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a charge of $139 million for the qr and 9 mos to cover expenses associated with the company's revitalization program...C-Net income

title: DIABETIC DIES AFTER L.I. JUDGE STOPS HIS LIFE-SUSTAINING CARE
description: A judge today ordered a hospital to discontinue life-sustaining treatments for a 41-year-old diabetic at his request, and within an hour the man died.

title: ORDER IS AFFIRMED FOR NEW PRIMARIES
description: An appellate court yesterday affirmed a State Supreme Court decision ordering new Democratic Congressional and Assembly primaries Tuesday in Brooklyn after charges of voting fraud.

title: OPERA: VERDI 'MASCHERA'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's two-year-old production of ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' which had its first performance of the season on Thursday night, shows once more how dangerous it is to let designers run the show. The staging, originally by Elijah Moshinsky but now credited to Paul Mills, takes aim at Verdian if not historical authenticity by setting the work in pre-Revolutionary Boston. That is where Verdi agreed to put it after a struggle with censors.

title: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Racing Days Over
description: Charlie Whittingham, the trainer of Perrault, says the 5-year-old horse has almost definitely run his last race. Considered the leading candidate for horse of the year until he injured a tendon during the running of the Marlboro Cup, Perrault will be syndicated and retired to stud before the end of the year, according to Whittingham. Perrault, who won the Arlington Million, is still the top moneywinning thoroughbred in the country this year, with earnings of $1,197,400.

title: Bridge: Chip Martel's Achievement; At Biarritz Aided a Sponsor
description: The recent world championships in Biarritz, France, produced a strong candidate for the title of the world's luckiest sponsor. The venerable French cognac manufacturer Martell had contributed substantially to the organization expenses and then found its name (give or take an ''l'') featured even more prominently than it had anticipated. Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., won the open pair title, and came within a whisker of completing a unique double by winning the open team title to boot.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,674,000...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,147,000 for the qr and $10,373,000 for the 9 mos

title: Seoul Sentences Critic Over Labor Comments
description: The Seoul District Criminal Court has sentenced the secretary of a Christian youth organization to 18 months in prison on charges of using the foreign press to defame the state.

title: CUBAN POET, JAILED 22 YEARS, ARRIVES IN PARIS
description: Armando Valladares, the Cuban poet who spent 22 years in prison for criticizing Fidel Castro and was freed after the personal intervention of President Francois Mitterrand, was reunited with his wife today on his arrival in Paris.

title: TRIBES SEEK RETURN OF GERONIMO'S REMAINS TO APACHE LAND
description: Outside the tribal offices here rises an equestrian statue of the warrior Geronimo, a sign of a new cultural awareness among Apaches and a symbol of resistance to the white man's world.

title: Arabs at U.N. Confirm End of Anti-Israel Move
description: Arab nations announced here today that they had decided against challenging Israel's credentials at this session of the General Assembly but warned that the issue could be raised again next year.

title: COAST JUDGES TARGET OF CONSERVATIVES
description: Conservatives, including some of the leading Republican candidates for office this year, have mounted a strong campaign to have the voters unseat three of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s appointees to the California Supreme Court.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Landaluce Choice
description: Landaluce, the 2-year-old daughter of Seattle Slew who has won her four starts by a total of 44 1/2 lengths, is a 1-10 favorite to remain undefeated Saturday in the $259,850 Oak Leaf Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: STEALING AN ELECTION
description: Someone is trying to steal an election in Brooklyn and so far they're getting away with it. The judge who issued the initial ruling in the case was either confused or something worse; he abdicated all responsibility for determining which side was to blame for the voting irregularities and he chose to ignore crucial evidence that would have helped him reach such a finding. Instead he threw out the results and ordered a new election for next Tuesday, which benefits the loser in the original vote, Vander L. Beatty, the man to whom the evidence seems to point.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In this state, there is no statute prohibiting a patient from declining medical treatment or a doctor from honoring a patient's decision. The court finds Peter's decision was based on a compelling desire to escape the grievous pain and suffering.'' - Justice Arthur D. Spatt of State Supreme Court, from his order halting dialysis treatments for Peter Cinque of Lynbrook, L.I. (1:3.)

title: CASCADE STEEL ROLLING MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Afghans Said to Attack The Soviet Embassy
description: Rebels fired rockets into the Soviet Embassy in Kabul, the Afghan capital, this week in the first major attack against the compound since the Soviet Union intervened militarily in Afghanistan in December 1979, Western diplomats said today.

title: Sanitationmen Re-elect Chief
description: Edward T. Ostrowski has been re-elected president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, a union spokesman announced yesterday. Mail ballots gave Mr. Ostrowski 3,443 votes, to 1,183 for Ronald Egers and 1,168 for James Condon.

title: Offer Is Accepted For CCI Shares
description: The CCI Corporation said the independent members of its board had accepted an increased offer from a senior management group of $16 a share in cash for all of the company's 6.3 million shares outstanding, for a total of $100.8 million.

Habre's Chad Cabinet Includes Former Foes
description: Hissen Habre, who promised to work for unity in faction-ridden Chad when he was sworn in as President on Thursday, has named a Cabinet.

description: An Federal undercover agent posing as a bank officer played a key part in the narcotics investigation that led to the arrest of John Z. DeLorean on drug charges, investigative sources confirmed today.

title: New Inquiry Reported
description: Wichita State's basketball program is again being investigated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association because of the possibility of recruiting violations, The Wichita Eagle-Beacon reported yesterday.

title: Child Abuse Benefit Lists Cluster of Stars
description: Loretta Lynn, Peter Allen, Judd Hirsch, Debbie Allen, Jennifer Holliday and Conrad Twitty are among the entertainers who will take part in a benefit for the National Committee for Prevention of Child Abuse tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Majestic Theater, 245 West 44th Street.

title: EX-HEADMASTER OF HORACE MANN
description: Dr. Mitchell Gratwick, headmaster emeritus of the Horace Mann School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, died Wednesday at his home in Flourtown, Pa. He was 82 years old and had lived in the Philadelphia area for the past 10 years.

title: NICARAGUAN INDIANS CAUGHT IN MIDDLE
description: As armed conflicts on the Nicaraguan-Honduran border threaten to lead to full-scale war, it is clear that United States policy toward Nicaragua, far from promoting pluralism, is in fact having the opposite effect.

title: WOLVERINE ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A REPRISE ON CANNED CHILI, WITH A NEW WINNER
description: As easy as it is to prepare and freeze a large supply of chili, those who are caught short, or who simply do not have the time or interest, consider canned chili a convenient alternative. The trick is to find good chili that suits one's taste as it comes from the can or that lends itself to doctoring.

description: China and the Soviet Union have quietly ended their first round of high-level talks in nearly three years without any hint of a thaw in their chilly relations.

title: THE DELOREAN: VALUE DEBATED
description: When John Z. DeLorean decided in the 1970's to produce a hot new sports car, his intention was to build an ''ethical'' auto. By that, Mr. DeLorean said, he meant one that did not disintegrate five years after it rolled off the showroom floor.

title: RIDING IN STYLE: A NEW HABIT
description: Along the curbs of the theater district the limousines wait, bumper to bumper, for the evening shows to break. In the mornings they drop their occupants at Elizabeth Arden; afternoons they park along Fifth Avenue in front of Cartier or await shoppers at Bergdorf Goodman and Saks.

title: A Remington Sculpture Brings Record $715,000
description: Frederic Remington's ''The Norther,'' a 22-inch-high bronze from 1900 that depicts a cowboy on horseback braving the winter winds, sold yesterday for $715,000, an auction record for any American sculpture.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $10,000 for the qr and a loss of $113,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: Standing in the Firehouse Door
description: Even in the 1980's social change comes slowly to the firehouse, as the squabble over New York City's female firefighters makes clear. In Jersey City, however, Mayor Gerald McCann is handling a firehouse integration dispute in a style more appropriate to the 1920's.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products filed offerings of up to $200 million of debt securities.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mint in Denver Produces Its Last Copper Penny
description: The last of the copper pennies has rolled off the presses at the Denver Mint.

title: Gene Mauch Resigns From Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct 22 (AP) Gene Mauch, who guided the California Angels to the American League Western Division title this season, has decided not to return as manager in 1983.

title: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TAYLOR, EX-PACKER, IN PLAYERS' CORNER
description: T he old guys, they played for the love of the game, and not for money, not like players today. Heard that one before? ''I pick up a newspaper now and read about the football players' strike,'' said Jim Taylor, ''and I say, 'All the power to you, boys. You deserve a fair share. The kind we didn't get.' And I hope they stick together, because they can't win if they try to do it individually. Gotta be a team effort.''

description: An Off-the-Cuffs Remark

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GEMAYEL RETURNS HOME AND CALLS TRIP A SUCCESS
description: President Amin Gemayel returned today from a trip to the United States, France and Italy, calling his tour successful and describing the leaders he met as ''extremely responsive.''

title: BRIEFING
description: That Williams Case

title: MUSIC: BERLIN'S BRAHMS
description: There are few orchestras that can elicit bravos merely by tuning up, but, believe it or not, Herbert von Karajan's Berlin Philharmonic actually stimulated that reaction on two nights this week at Carnegie Hall.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KNICKS GET KING FOR RICHARDSON
description: The Knicks acquired Bernard King, a high-scoring forward, from the Golden State Warriors yesterday in a trade for Michael Ray Richardson, their all-star guard, and future considerations.

title: ARAB DELEGATION MEETS PRESIDENT ON PEACE EFFORTS
description: King Hassan II of Morocco met with President Reagan today and said that ''peace and coexistence'' in the Middle East could be achieved on the basis of American and Arab proposals and United Nations Security Council resolutions.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Deere to Idle 1,300 In Waterloo, Iowa
description: Deere & Company announced that 1,300 workers at three Waterloo plants and a product engineering center would be laid off indefinitely effective Nov. 1.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Carlos Garcia-Mata, an Ex-Envoy
description: Carlos Garcia-Mata, a mathematician and the commercial attache in the Argentine Embassy in Washington before Juan Peron gained power, died of a stroke Tuesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: 3 IN JERSEY CLAIM SHARES OF $7.2 MILLION IN LOTTO
description: Three of the four winners in the Pick-6 Lotto game, including a brother and sister who independently selected the six correct numbers, appeared at the Statehouse today to claim their shares of $7.2 million, the largest prize ever awarded in a state lottery.

title: Olympic Training At Lake Placid
description: The facilities that were used for the 1980 Winter Olympics officially became the second Olympic training center for American athletes today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Will the Real No. 2065...

title: Ruling Party in Japan Divided On Choosing a New Premier
description: All-night talks to decide on a successor to Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki broke down here at dawn today amid signs of a widening split in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party over the succession.

title: KENNEDY'S CHALLENGE TO SOVIET UNION
description: President John F. Kennedy's bold challenge to the Soviet Union on Oct. 22, 1962, in a speech of extraordinary gravity, opened a twoweek period of international tension that many people will never forget. Here are some of the words that sent fear around the world that night.

title: MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-After a charge of $346,000 from the reversal of a tax credit...C-Net income including a tax credit of $241,000 and income of $447,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: JERSEY IS DENIED MORE TIME TO FILE CLAIMS TO TIDELANDS
description: A New Jersey appellate court ruled 2 to 1 today that the state could not have more time to claim property that was washed by the tides more than 40 years ago.

title: FIRST WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 25
GIBSON CASE WAS VALID, THE PROSECUTOR DECLARES
description: George L. Schneider, the Essex County Prosecutor, said yesterday that he had doubts from the start about winning the state's criminal case against Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark. But he said that there was sufficient evidence to prosecute the case and that he would do so again if he had to.

title: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Steel Loses $96 Million
description: The National Steel Corporation, the industry's fourth-largest producer, reported yesterday that it lost $96 million in the third quarter, contrasted with earnings of $34.6 million, or $1.85 a share, in the 1981 period.

title: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MRS. FENWICK SUGGESTS UNEMPLOYMENT RATE WON'T HURT HER AT POLLS
description: Representative Millicent H. Fenwick, campaigning for the United State Senate here, said today that a sour economy might cause her fellow Republicans some difficulty at the polls a week from Tuesday, but suggested that her image might make her immune to voter resentment.

title: 'LEGISLATIVE VETO' IS STRUCK DOWN BY APPEALS COURT
description: Laws that empower both Houses of Congress, acting together, to veto Federal agency rules were held unconstitutional today. The ruling was made by eight Federal appeals court judges, who acted unanimously.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $170,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: THE RISKS IN REDUCING U.S. FORCES IN EUROPE
description: The Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense has voted 12 to 1 to reduce American forces in Europe by 23,000 men. The surprisingly lopsided vote, last month, indicates that there may be considerable support for this position during Senate and House action on the defense budget in the short session of Congress in November. The subcommittee's action was shortsighted. It should be reversed.

title: GLENMORE DISTILLERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR THE CHILDREN
description: Beginning today, ''Dot and Santa Claus,'' an 80-minute Australian film for children, will be shown at matinees on weekends and holidays at the D.W. Griffith Theater.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $960,000 from the sale of Brown Printing Co; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: THE DANCE: CHAING CHING PREMIERE
description: A New York-based choreographer who originally received her dance training in Peking, Chiang Ching has a poetic sense of time and space. Her latest works were seen at Thursday's opening of her company's weekend engagement at Riverside Church.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $518,000 or 6 cents a shr from the installment sale of real estate; results for the latest third qr include an investment tax credit equal to approximately 10 cents a shr and associated with the acquisition of new equipment

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BAMBERGER TO ACT AS PITCHING COACH
description: In an unusual move to rescue their collapsed pitching staff, the Mets relieved Bill Monbouquette of his duties as pitching coach yesterday and said that Manager George Bamberger would handle the job himself next season. The also announced that Bud Harrelson was being replaced, at his request, as the first-base coach and infield instructor. Harrelson, for 13 years the team's shortstop, reportedly wants to spend more time at home and will become a commentator on the club's cable television broadcasts.

title: WOULD-BE 'GIANT KILLER' ON COAST FOCUSING ON BURTON'S PERSONALITY
description: The recession, offshore oil drilling and local jobs are all subjects that the candidates in California's Fifth Congressional District talk about, but the issue is the Democratic incumbent, Representative Phillip Burton.

title: Dr. James A. Brussel, Criminologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. James A. Brussel, a psychiatrist, criminologist and former assistant commissioner in the State Department of Mental Hygiene in charge of the New York City office, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market finished its second-heaviest trading week ever, with a total of 555 million shares changing hands. The Dow finished at 1,031.46 yesterday, down 5.52 points. For the week, though, the market's most widely watched average gained 38.36 points and neared a record high. (Page 41.)

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS GIVEN WIDE EDGE IN NEW POLL
description: The Socialist Party, led by Felipe Gonzalez, appears headed for a convincing victory in the Spanish general election in six days' time, according to an authoritative public opinion poll published today.

title:
PATENTS;
A Catalytic Process Curbs Oxide Emissions
description: A method to prevent nitrogen oxide emissions from gas turbines and boiler equipment was patented this week for the Environmental Protection Agency. The invention was made under a contract with the Acurex Corporation, Mountain View, Calif.

title: LEHRMAN CAMPAIGNING HARD ON RESTORING DEATH PENALTY
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for governor, campaigned across the state today emphasizing his commitment to restore the death penalty.

title: 5th N.H.L. Suspension
description: The National Hockey League, which imposed a total of nine suspensions all of last season for violence on the ice, has already meted out five since the 1982-83 season began two and a half weeks ago. The fifth was announced yesterday by Brian O'Neill, the league official in charge of disciplinary proceedings, and it will keep Dave (Tiger) Williams of the Vancouver Canucks out of action for six more games beginning next Friday, or sooner if Williams and the Canucks waive their right to appeal.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
MUST WE EXPORT JOBS FOR SUBWAY CARS?
description: To the Editor:

description: B-Net loss...C-Yr-ago comparisons are not meaningful because the company began service on Apr 30, 1981

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $45,000 for the qr and $152,000 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $25,000 for the qr and $50,000 for the 9 mos

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MISS MOLLER EXPECTS A RECORD
description: The winning women's time in the New York City Marathon has improved in seven of the last eight years. Lorraine Moller sees no reason why the trend should not continue in tomorrow's race.

title: HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including proceeds from life of $148,717 for the qr and 9 mos

title: NEBRASKA PASTOR FREED IN COURT CONTEMPT CASE
description: The Rev. Everett Sileven, the fundamentalist pastor of the Faith Baptist Church in Louisville, Neb., was freed from jail today in what was called "total victory" by supporters of his unaccredited school.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S FISCAL WOES: WHAT LED TO THEM AND WHAT IS BEING DONE
description: To cope with New York City's projected budget deficits of $300 million this year and $1.2 billion for the fiscal year that begins next July, Mayor Koch has imposed a hiring freeze and ordered agency heads to trim their budgets. Following are some questions and answers on the city's fiscal problems, with the answers supplied by city and state officials: Q. What are the reasons for the large deficits? A. Officials say there are three major reasons - Federal budget cuts, the sluggish economy and the contract that the city recently agreed to with its labor unions.

title: INTERGRAPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conviction in Casino Bombing
description: A man who said he gambled away a fortune at Harvey's Hotel was convicted tonight in the August 1980 extortion bombing of the Lake Tahoe resort.

title: 2d Quarterly Loss for Delta
description: Delta Air Lines yesterday reported its second quarterly loss this year, unusual in the Atlanta-based airline's recent history. Delta said it lost $16.1 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit in the 1981 quarter of $7.6 million.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses of $181,000 for the qr and $443,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations; the yr-ago revs amounts exclude revs from discontinued operations of $731,000 and $1,380,000 for the qr and 6 mos, respectively; the financial results for the qr and 6 mos periods have been restated to segregate the company's discontinued commercial text-processing business which was sold during fiscal 1982 and the shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Mar 1982

title: 5 KEY LEADERS OF THE OPPOSITION REPORTED KIDNAPPED IN SALVADOR
description: Five key members of the political branch of El Salvador's leftist opposition were seized in the capital this week, political sources and human rights groups here said today.

title: 2 Marines Rescued in Crash
description: Two United States marines ejected from their F-4 Phantom jet fighter and were rescued from their rubber raft early today in the Pacific Ocean 65 miles southeast of Okinawa, a Marine Corps spokesman said. They were not identified and the cause of the crash is being investigated. They were on a training mission from Kadena Air Base on Okinawa.

title: Amax Posts A Big Loss
description: Amax Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $97.1 million for the third quarter, compared with net income of $51.4 million, or 73 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. Sales for the metals producer fell 21.2 percent, to $517 million, from $617 million.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROME WARNS OF CORRUPTION
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill cut a ribbon on a housing project in Danbury this morning and hailed the project as an example of something that government had done well. Meanwhile, his Republican opponent, Lewis B. Rome, sought votes in four cities and complained that scandals in state government ''could mushroom into Connecticut's little Watergate.''

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: results for the latest 9 mos reflect a change of $778,000 from foreign currencytranslations due to the devalu7ation of the Mexican peso

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTA, GA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLEAN AIR ACT: A WHITE HOUSE WIND
description: When Presidents speak, people listen, particularly members of interest groups and others here whose bread is buttered by the political process.

title: Lonely Figure
description: Just minutes before Tuesday's exhibition basketball game between the Nets and the Knicks was to begin at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, a tall, lonely figure wandered from beneath the tunnels of the arena looking flustered and lost. The man was Butch Beard, who for nine years had been affiliated with the National Basketball Association as either a player or coach - six years with the Knicks.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-After a pretax charge of $6.5 million for redeployment of assets...C-Net incom

GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN APPROVES AMERASIAN ACCESS
description: President Reagan today signed legislation to make it easier for thousands of Asian-born children of American servicemen to enter the United States, and he bid them all ''Welcome home.''

title: VIDEO BOOTLEGGERS: BANE OF FILM STUDIOS
description: Most motion picture studio executives look at the future of their industry and see great potential in the emerging technologies of video transmission. James Bouras sees the cracks and worries about what will fall through.

title: Officials Discounting Nerve Gas Leak Report
description: Sensing devices that indicated a small leak of toxic nerve gas and the discovery of a dead cow caused concern this week at the Blue Grass Army Depot a spokesman said today. But he said it was possible the sensors had malfunctioned and that no leak had occurred.

title: Rains Leave 13 Dead in Spain And Make 30,000 Flee Homes
description: Heavy rain in three provinces killed at least 13 people, left 30 missing, forced 30,000 residents to flee and wrecked 10,000 cars, relief officials said today.

title: PLAYFUL KILLER WHALE MAKES A HOME IN HARBOR
description: A killer whale has been frolicking in Provincetown Harbor for more than a month, attracting large crowds and creating concern among scientists that the good life might be bad for its health.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income figures for the latest qr and 9 mos were insufficient to cover preferred divid requirements

title: Small Phone Units And Bell in Pact
description: The United States Independent Telephone Association and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached a new agreement on the formula used to divide long-distance revenues between A.T.& T. and many of the country's smaller independent telephone companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend yesterday on the New York Marathon included an incorrect name in its listing of well-known participants. Allison Roe announced during the week that because of injuries, she was withdrawing.

title: BADGER METER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INCENTIVE FOR WEST VIRGINIA
description: None of the current West Virginia or Penn State football players were born when the Mountaineers last defeated the Nittany Lions, 27 years ago today. The teams have met every year since 1946, making Penn State's 23 straight triumphs over West Virginia since a 14-14 tie in 1958 the longest current victory string over an opponent in an annual series.

title: PICTURES TO PROTECT VALUABLES
description: THIS week Cartier announced that it would offer ''protective p hotography'' to the public, a service in which its staff p hotographers would visit clients' homes to make permanent visual r ecords of their valuables.

title: News Analysis
description: Back in the 1950's, the American textile industry put pressure on the Government for protection against cheap imports. The Kennedy Administration gave in, setting ''temporary'' quotas that have not only lasted to this day, but have become part of an elaborate international market-sharing arrangement involving 40 countries. Now, many analysts see the new agreement for ''temporary,'' three-year quotas covering European steel exports to the United States as fitting a similar pattern.

title: VULCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Your Money; Picking Stocks For Individuals
description: FOLLOWING the surge in stock market prices that started in mid-August, many individual investors are once again purchasing equities after a long period of inactivity. And once again, these individuals have the problem of determining what stocks to buy.

title: DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
India
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Harnik Becomes Bride Of Dr. Paul Ort
description: Victoria Marie Harnik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Harnik of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married at the First Congregational Church there yesterday to Dr. Paul Joseph Ort, an orthopedic surgeon and assistant clinical professor of orthopedics at the New York University School of Medicine. The Rev. Herman Reisig performed the ceremony.

title: TEA: ELEGANT PAUSE GROWS POPULAR
description: Afternoon tea is refreshing, a respite. It can be a simple break in the day's routine or a private, personal evocation of another time. It has tradition and history, and to some it is important that it is quite English. To many the idea of afternoon tea is as important as the drinking of it. And while pausing late in the day for a cup of smoky Lapsang Souchang or fragrant, delicate jasmine, perhaps with a scone or a watercress sandwich, is not something new to New York, it has now become an increasingly popular social custom.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: GROUNDRUSH By Greg Barron. 309 pp. New York: Random House. $13.50. By MICHAEL MALONE

title: 1 Allied Dispute Ends, 2 to Go
description: Things were looking up last week in the Atlantic alliance as one trade dispute was settled and hope rose for resolving two others. After five months of often angry debate with Washington and among themselves, European steelmakers agreed to limit their exports over the next three years to about 5 percent of the American market, a drop of 1.3 percent from the 1981 level.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME NEW VARIETIES OF APPLES
description: AFTER having been given a bad name by Adam and Eve, the apple has made a steady upward climb to the top of the heap. As the No. 1 fruit in the country, this year's harvest will be some 204 million bushels, nearly a bushel for each of us. Of that number, 110 million will be sold fresh; the rest processed into a variety of products, including cider, juice and applesauce.

title: DERRING-DO AT THE OPERA
description: THREE years ago the Connecticut Opera was facing one of its bleakest seasons ever. With a $60,000 deficit for fiscal year 1979, the nation's sixth-oldest professional opera company had serious cash-flow problems, a five-year ticket sale slump and a 1,250-member subscriber list that had remained static for 35 years.

title: Russians Said to Have Built Submarine Base Near Japan
description: The Soviet Union has deployed attacktype conventional submarines at a new base in the Kurile Islands in the northwestern Pacific, a Japanese newspaper reported today.

title: MEDICAL CENTER GETS $1.5 MILLION WHITNEY GIFT
description: A $15 million gift from the estate of John Hay Whitney has been made to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, which is marking its 50th anniversary next week and also honoring the leading philanthropic families that built and supported the center.

title: BERNARDS WINS CROSS-COUNTRY
description: St. Bernards won the team title and had the two individual winnners in the seeded races at the Eastern States cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: HASSAN SAYS ISRAEL MUST GIVE UP LAND TO GET ACCEPTANCE
description: King Hassan II of Morocco said today that the Arab nations would recognize Israel, but only after Israel had withdrawn its forces from the territory occupied since the 1967 war.

title: No Headline
description: As Clifford May points out, there are a growing number of persons dedicated to the conservation of endangered species who are coming to the conclusion that traditional conservation methods may not be enough to succeed, given the vicissitudes of life today.

title: CURRY OUTBOXES STARLING
description: Sugar Ray Leonard was not impressed today as Donald Curry outboxed Marlon Starling in a dull 12-round contest to unify the North American Boxing Federation and United States Boxing Association welterweight titles.

title: WHY MUST I 'HAVE A NICE DAY?'
description: WHEN did it first start to catch on - this ''Have a nice day'' mania? I'm sure whoever first uttered that pleasantry never imagined the magnitude and adhesive quality it would have. Next to ''please'' and ''thank you,'' I can't think of any other words repeated as often, and as automatically.

title:
ART;
ELAINE DEKOONING'S VIBRANT PORTRAITS
description: PORT WASHINGTON WE have pretty well gotten away from the notion that a careful rendering of facial features is the most desirable attribute of a portrait painting. This attitude does not stop us from admiring the skill that such rendition involves, nor does it prevent us from enjoying the lifelike detail of an Ingres or a Raphael. It is simply that, in this century, we have come to see portraiture less as a recording device and more as an expressive tool, a means to capture subjective and emotional qualities of both the sitter and the artist.

title: Tristate Region Candidates Sing Their Own Tunes
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are not exactly a microcosm of America, but with the country's unemployment reaching 40-year levels, voters in the region - as nationwide - have made the economy, and proposals to fix it, a key campaign concern. But there are other issues, as the following reports indicate.

title: Tortola
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE RACES TEST REAGAN AND ECONOMY
description: PRESIDENT Reagan, the state of the economy, conservatism, Joseph M. Margiotta - and the advantages of incumbency - will be tested in five Congressional races on Long Island 10 days from now.

title: A ROUNDTABLE: SCORING THE S.A.T.
description: NOW is the season of discontent with the Scholastic Aptitude Test. In two weeks, more than 400,000 students nationwide will work through the 2 1/2-hour test, hoping their scores will endear them to colleges. Critics are already denouncing the examination for mismeasuring students' abilities, while the College Board, which sponsors the S.A.T., defends its fairness. Data released this year show that after a 20-year decline, scores rose slightly. Scores in New York City, announced last week, continued an increase begun two years ago, though they still hang 35 points below the national average. Explanations of increases are as controversial as explanations of declines. Black students improved more than white students, for example, though blacks averaged 100 points below the norm - a sign of educational deprivation to some, of intellectual inferiority to others. Four experts discussed the test's merits and deficits with Margot Slade, an editor of The Review. Excerpts follow. Aptitude, Intelligence or What?

title: A TRIBAL KING VISITS YALE
description: HEADS turned as the small, elegantly dressed man entered the paneled dining hall of Yale University's Timothy Dwight College, followed by several assistants carrying intricately painted canoe paddles, wall maps and a drum.

title: ARTS COUNCIL FACING THORNY ISSUES
description: EAST ORANGE THOSE who have worked closely with Clement A. Price over the last 14 years say that the 36-year-old educator is an ideal choice to take over the helm of the state's Council on the Arts.

title: 6 Die in Zimbabwe Bus Crash
description: At least six people were killed and 48 injured when a bus fell into the flooded Tuli River in the southwestern province of Matabeleland, the police said today. They said they were searching the river for two children missing after the bus ran off a road and fell into the river.

title: No Headline
description: MOSLEMS FAIL AGAIN TO END THE GULF WAR

title: THE RIGHT SETTING
description: Setting the table can be as important to the outcome of a meal as cooking the food, and an ill-considered table setting can be as offputting as turned wine or a failed souffle. Even so, it is surprising how often this aspect of a meal is hastily dealt with or even completely bypassed in the rush of getting everything else organized.

title: Landaluce Extends Streak to 5 Races
description: With about a sixteenth of a mile to go in the Oak Leaf Stakes at Santa Anita race track today, there was a sudden and surprising development: a horse was actually gaining ground on Landaluce. The track announcer yelped in astonishment and the 37,000 fans roared with surprise. Then Laffit Pincay Jr. merely tapped Landaluce twice with his whip, and the sensational 2-year-old filly was home free by two lengths.

title: Mason to Quit White House
description: A. Morgan Mason, 27-year-old son of the actor James Mason, will resign as a political aide to President Reagan after the election Nov. 2, a White House spokesman said today. Mr. Mason said in an interview published today that his decision had nothing to do with a controversy that developed when he invited the Los Angeles lawyer Marvin Mitchelson to the White House last month.

title: MAKING IT: MINORITY REPORT
description: BLACK LIFE IN CORPORATE AMERICA Swimming in the Mainstream. By George Davis and Glegg Watson. 204 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $14.95.

title: DANCE: MARIE CHOUINARD
description: Performance art is alive and well in Canada these days. Or so it seemed when Marie Chouinard, a young Montreal-based choreographer, appeared Wednesday at the Performing Garage.

title: TWO COUNTRY CLASSICS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sarah Newell is on the staff of the Book Review. GONE TO EARTH By Mary Webb. 288 pp. New York: Virago/The Dial Press. Paper, $7.95. PRECIOUS BANE By Mary Webb. 288 pp. New York: Virago/The Dial Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: U.S. ENVOY ASSAILS SALVADOR SEIZURES
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador today deplored the abductions of five key leftist politicians here this week as ''thoroughly regrettable'' and said he was ''reasonably certain'' they had not been done under Salvadoran Government orders.

title: Marcia McCord Is Bride
description: Marcia McCord, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. James I. McCord of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Richard Emery Verville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Verville of Bethel, Me. The bride's father, who is president of the Princeton Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony in the Miller Chapel of the Seminary. The bride is a legislative assistant in Washington to Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri. Mr. Verville is a partner in the Washington law firm of White, Fine & Verville.

title: Deciphering The Puzzles Of Simplicity
description: What seems simple to the eye can often be complex for the brain, defying easy explanation: the percolation of hot water through coffee grounds and basic cell structure, for example. For developing theoretical approaches and laboratory techniques to understand such complexities, an American physicist, Dr. Kenneth G. Wilson of Cornell, and a British chemist, Dr. Aaron Klug at Cambridge University, last week won Nobel Prizes in their fields. The prize brings recipients $157,000.

title: LIFE AMONG THE RUSSIANS
description: Marc Greenfield, a graduate student at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs, worked as an English editor for the Soviet Novosti Press Agency in Moscow from 1979 to 1981.From the window of my apartment on Leninsky Prospekt, I had a view of two ponderous, ornate, semicircular buildings that rose on either side of the broad thoroughfare several blocks away. They were the gate to Stalin's Moscow, symbolizing the dictator's concern with display. Beyond these monoliths, the road, with its solid, squat apartment houses, remained a showpiece of Soviet architecture for third-world dignitaries, whose limousines flew up and down the avenue in impressive motorcades to and from the Vnukovo airport.

title: PEACE LIES BEYOND THE OLD TRAILS
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H. WHERE the Little Dead Diamond and the Dead Diamond Rivers meet in the Academy Grant, a spot about 16 miles up a logging road that runs north of here, they call it Hellgate. This may have derived from the short, steep gorge in the main river's bed at that point, because hell does not lie beyond. Hell, if there is one, is in the opposite direction.

title: THE ARREST OF JOHN DELOREAN
description: John Z. DeLorean, (right), the flamboyant businessman who left the top ranks of General Motors to form his own automobile company in Northern Ireland, was charged with conspiring to sell cocaine valued at $24 million.

title: Anne F. Murphy Bride Of Michael Fitzgerald
description: Anne Frances Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Murphy of New York, was married yesterday in Jersey City to Michael Charles Fitzpatrick, son of Mrs. Madeleine Fitzpatrick of Rumson, N.J., and the late Charles Fitzpatrick. The Rev. David Cusick performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of St. Peter's College, from which the bridegroom graduated.

title:
OPINION;
RAISE THE PAY OF ACADEMIC PEONS
description: IF it is an axiom that the highest paying employers attract the most productive workers, the faculty of Nassau Community College, the highest paid teachers in New York State - and probably in most of the nation - is an elite community of scholars surpassing any other college faculty in New York State in creativity and productivity.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART No less than six alumnae of Sarah Lawrence College happen to be contemporary art dealers in Manhattan - Susan Caldwell, Alexander Milliken, Marcuse Pfeifer, Theo Portnoy, Ruth Siegel and Holly Solomon. What better excuse for a show at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery in Bronxville, N.Y. Each of the dealers picked three less-established artists from his or her stable, whose work generally reflects the spirit of the gallery itself.

title: CONCERT: URSULA OPPENS WITH PAUL ZUKOFSKY
description: The standard 19th-century repertory can often sound quite standard indeed. While two generations ago, a wide variety of musical styles could be heard, today, most players play most music quite similarly, and compositions have accumulated a century of received performance manners.

title: INDIAN TURNS KORCHNOI INTO HASTINGS PUDDING
description: The most sensational upset of the 1982 Lloyds Bank International Tournament in London was the defeat of Viktor Korchnoi by Barua, a 15-year-old Indian master. Not since Mir Sultan Khan defeated Jose Raoul Capablanca in the 1930-31 Hastings International Tournament has an Indian player made such a splash in an individual game.

title: A VOTE FOR NOSTALGIA
description: Social historians looking for more evidence of Americans' growing passion for their past can take note of the fuss in Weston, Conn., over the fate of three 100-year-old barns there. Early this year, town officials decided to sell the dilapidated barns, which sit on town land, believing them to lack any significant historic value.

title: CHAMBER: BAKELS'S ENSEMBLE
description: The Netherlands Chamber Orchestra presented a tasteful, stylish, but ultimately tedious program Thursday at Carnegie Hall. The ensemble under the direction of Kees Bakels was in New York as part of Carnegie Hall's Celebration of Chamber Orchestras.

title: WIN YOUR OWN GLEN COVE PASS
description: FOR $10, you too can play The Game of Glen Cove, a Monopoly-style board game sponsored by the city's Chamber of Commerce in which the luckiest ''chance card,'' labeled ''Soviet Mission,'' allows the bearer to pay no taxes, pick up a beach permit at City Hall and then proceed to Morgan Park - where the Russians were barred from swimming last summer.

title: A Pride of Volunteers
description: By happy coincidence for the military, thousands of young people who might be otherwise be unemployed have been caught up in a surge of patriotism and are enlisting in the armed forces. The conclusion as to their movtivation was offered last week by Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, but the fact is recruits are signing up for the all-volunteer services in numbers that make conscription unnecessary, the Military Manpower Task Force reported.

title: LEAVE BAD ENOUGH ALONE
description: Both political parties are pretending, as usual, that the future of the Republic depends on their winning a great victory in this year's Congressional elections, but maybe it would be better to have a scoreless tie.

title: HOME COOKING FOR 200 GUESTS
description: When the last of the Thanksgiving turkey is removed from its platter, the table is cleared, the dishes washed, the crystal put away and the guests bid farewell, the average host or hostess may take an aspirin and exhale a sigh of relief. Not Leslie Newman, who lives with her husband, David, in a spacious, whistle-neat cooperative apartment with a large, solidly designed and impressive kitchen on New York's Upper West Side. It is then that her thoughts turn again to food. For on the day after turkey day, she turns her head and hand to the most ambitious annual dinner plans of the year, her New Year's buffet for 200 and more guests.

title: No Headline
description: LENDL OVERPOWERS GERULAITIS IN FINAL

title: SUSAN SONTAG: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE
description: ''ASUSAN SONTAG READER,'' composed of selections Miss Sontag made from the two decades of her work, has just been published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux. I recently spoke with her about the ''Reader,'' her work in general and the controversial speech she made last February in New York. At a Town Hall rally in support of Poland's Solidarity movement, Miss Sontag criticized the American left's attitude toward Communism, unleashing a wave of attacks against her from all political factions from the extreme left to the extreme right, and feelings are still running high.

title: RICHMOND PROJECT MAY HEAL BLACK-WHITE RIFT
description: City officials and Marriott Corporation representatives have broken ground for a 403-room hotel and convention center that leaders here, like those involved in similar projects in other cities, hope will revive a worn-out downtown section.

title: No Headline
description: KNICKS WIN, 94-92

title: IN 'GOOD,' WEAKNESS SIMPLY BEGETS MORE WEAKNESS
description: As its title suggests, C.P. Taylor's ''Good,'' which has been brought to us in a sleekly accomplished production by Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company, is yet one more attempt to explain the subtle and insidious processes by which an ordinary, decent man can be persuaded to lend his hand to evil, specifically to the evil that was Nazi Germany. In spite of an inventive and furiously energetic performance by Alan Howard as the Good Person self-betrayed, and in spite of director Howard Davies's skilled management of supporting players who pop up puppetlike as needed, the evening's point is oddly blunted by a simple flaw in the writing. As drawn, the Good Person is neither good nor a person.

title: The Long and the Short
description: The Milwaukee Bucks, who already have the National Basketball Association's shortest player in 5-foot-8-inch Charlie Criss, now have the tallest, too. The Bucks claimed Chuck Nevitt, a 7-foot-5-inch rookie center from North Carolina State, after the Houston Rockets had waived him. ... Quintin Dailey, the Chicago Bulls' rookie guard, scored 20 points in his home debut in the Bulls' 137-136 overtime exhibition victory Friday night over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions "All Savers" Certificates 7.48 Tax-Exempt Bonds 9.69 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 8.73 Maximum rate at savings institutions Money Market Funds 9.10 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Home Mortgage 16.23 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 19.00 Continental Illinois, Chicago 21.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 25.00

title: THE NEWEST (BLEEP) MEMBER OF THE FAMILY
description: ISHOULD have known something was up when my husband phoned from the home computer show to announce that he would be delayed. ''What about the kids? - they have school tomorrow,'' I reminded him. ''They're fine,'' he answered. ''They're having a great time here playing with all the equipment. See you soon, dear.'' He hung up. At about 9:30 I heard him pull into the driveway. Car doors opened and slammed shut causing the dog to whimper and pace the floor. The children's voices filtered up to me in the bedroom.

title: NEWMAN IS PICKING UP SPEED
description: Fifteen years ago, Mario Andretti drove a Can Am car with Paul Newman's name emblazoned on its nose. No matter how hard Andretti worked, he could not get the car to go fast. Finally, he stepped out of the car, turned to the car's owner and said, ''I'll paint my name on the car - let Newman drive it.''

title: IT'S THOSE OVERTURES AND ARIAS THAT CHARM THE GOVERNOR
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN'S mood as he arrived at his office was decidedly up; he seemed to be ready to take on whatever problems awaited him. It was not a favorable legislative or political development that was uplifting him. Nor was it anything in the pile of mail he had gone through in 30 of the 75 minutes he had spent on the drive from his home in Livingston to the State House.

title: THE GENETIC ASSAULT ON CANCER
description: Two summers ago, when Robert A. Weinberg was asked what causes cancer, the distinguished molecular biologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology could only hazard a guess:

title: 5 Indicted in Houston In Gulf Extortion Case
description: A Federal grand jury indicted five Durango, Colo., residents on charges of attempting to extort $15 million from the Gulf Oil Chemicals Company by planting bombs at its facility at Baytown, Tex.

title: Rhyme and Reason
description: A Harvard University student who complained that she didn't make the grade because she wouldn't make out accepted another sort of pass from school officials last week.

title: WHEN IT'S FATAL TO RUFF
description: The recent world championships in Biarritz, France, were memorable in many respects. It was by far the biggest world championship ever played. With some 1,700 players from 55 countries taking part. For the first time in a pair championship, spectators were excluded and the players played with table screens. And thanks to the efforts of the president of the French federation, Jose Damiani, the audience watching the bidding and play on Vugraph were also able to watch superb color pictures, on closed circuit television, of the players at work.

title: Cyclist Raises Kidney Funds
description: Arnold Behrer, 27 years old, marked the fourth anniversary of his kidney transplant operation with a crosscountry trip on a 15-speed bike. He has pedaled 9,500 miles to raise money for the National Kidney Foundation and is scheduled to pedal back to his native Pittsburgh on Sunday afternoon.

title: MARATHON FORECAST: CLEAR SKIES AND A RECORD FIELD
description: Before last year's New York City Marathon, Alberto Salazar said he was willing to gamble for time. The result was a pre-race prediction, a stunning 4-minute-33-second mile along First Avenue, a driving finish and a world-record performance - 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds.

title: RUTGERS SNAPS COLGATE STREAK
description: Alan Andrews caught two touchdown passes from Jacque LaPrarie, and Bill Houston scored on a 94-yard interception return today as Rutgers sent Colgate to its first loss of the season, 34-17, at Rutgers Stadium.

title: BUTLER ROMPS OVER MORRIS CATHOLIC
description: Mark Tracey scored two touchdowns yesterday to guide Butler (5-0) past Morris Catholic, 22-8, in Butler. Tracey ran 33 yards for a touchdown in the second quarter, and Dan Dooley kicked the first of two extra points for a 7-0 lead that held until the final period. Morris Catholic (4-1) struck back when Paul Konklin hit Brian Finnegan with a 5-yard pass to complete a 79-yard drive. Finnegan's conversion run provided an 8-7 lead.

title: GETTING EVERYBODY INTO THE ACT
description: People now play home video games alone or against someone in the same room. But in the future, experts say, people might play video games against opponents across town or across the nation. That would be done by hooking the electronic game machines together over telephone lines or cable television systems.

title: A LIVELY FINISH
description: An exquisite way to end an evening of gastronomy is to serve one or more eaux de vie, the so-called fruit brandies that are fiery with alcohol yet convey a taste impression of the pears, strawberries, raspberries or other fruits from which they are distilled.

title: In Search of A Strategy to Limit Losses
description: WASHINGTON WHITE HOUSE aides last week quietly ordered up some district-bydistrict analysis of what the expected or, for that matter, unexpected Republican losses will do to President Reagan's governing coalition in Congress. The aim of this research project is not to shape the outcome of the Nov. 2 election. Instead, Mr. Reagan's advisers want to be armed on Nov. 3 to answer journalists who ask where the President will get votes to sustain his economic program.

title: DAVID MAMET PUTS A DARK URBAN DRAMA ON STAGE
description: David Mamet was sipping tea in front of the fireplace in his Chelsea duplex, whose spacious living room sports original artwork and a baby grand piano. In another room the telephone was ringing impatiently, and the playwright was complaining about how unpleasant it is to live in New York. ''The city's nuts,'' he said. ''It's a society that's lost its flywheel, and it's spinning itself apart. That's my vision of New York. It's a kind of vision of hell.''

title: SEARLE'S PUSH INTO SWEETENERS
description: IN the quest to satisfy America's craving for sweetness without c alories, saccharin, the controversial 80-year-old food additive, is t he clear leader. But now, competition threatens, particularly in the$ 3 billion diet soft-drink market, where saccharin holds an exclusiveg rip. Wending its way through the regulatory channels is aspartame, an on-caloric sweetener manufacturered by G.D. Searle & Company that m ay soon provide diet soft-drink makers with a choice.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SHEEPSHEAD BAY
description: AT the turn of the century, Sheepshead Bay was a favored resort of the rich. Most came for its race track, its fine seafood restaurants and the s alubrious sea breezes that blew in from the Atlantic. Lillian Russell, Diamond Jim Brady and Lillie Langtry were among t he famous folk who frequented Sheepshead Bay, and they were often s een strolling along the Emmons Avenue promenade overlooking the h arbor.

title: REAGANOMICS AND THE PRESIDENTS MEN
description: It was like a rerun from the 1980 Reagan campaign: The tall, athletic figure standing beside a huge cargo vessel, face wreathed in a characteristic lopsided grin as he placed a hard hat on his head and waved to a crowd of longshoremen. ''America's economy is ready to lead the world out of recession and into recovery,'' he declared as the workers cheered.

title: BOGUS PAMPHLET DISTRIBUTED TO TIMES NEWSDEALERS
description: Thousands of copies of a pamphlet apparently designed to look like a section of The New York Times were distributed to newsstand dealers last night, and several dealers said they had been asked to insert the pamphlet into the newspaper.

title: No Headline
description: Maine 21, UConn 7

title: No Headline
description: WALKER BREAKS RECORD

title: A FIX ON THE FUTURE
description: ''This is a tumultuous time in trade book publishing, a shakedown period. When it's over, fewer companies will be left and they'll be publishing a wider variety of materials.'' The prediction comes from Oscar Dystel, the man who became president of Bantam Books in 1954 when it was losing money and turned it into this country's preeminent paperback publishing house.

title: Linda Margaret Koch Is Married to Ollie Bass 3d
description: L inda Margaret Koch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Koch of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Ollie Adron Bass 3d, son of Mr. Bass of Rocky Mount, and Mrs. Lindsay Warren Bowen of Bath, N.C. Archdeacon Webster L. Simons performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Bath.

title: A Jet Set Drops In on Trudeau
description: Canadians have come to expect the unexpected flamboyant gesture from Pierre Elliott Trudeau. Last week, the razzle dazzle fell upon no fewer than 21 high-powered American corporate executives who were persuaded to come to Ottawa for a chat or two with the Prime Minister and his aides.

title: 2 PROTESTANT PARTIES DOMINATE ULSTER VOTING
description: Final results of Wednesday's polling for the 78-seat advisory assembly, announced today, gave the main Protestant-dominated parties 47 seats - 26 for the Official Unionists and 21 for the militant Rev. Ian Paisley's Democratric Unionists.

title: THE BROUHAHA OVER X-RATED GAMES
description: Roll over Pac-Man. Hot Stuff is here. The X-rated video game has arrived. In recent weeks, two companies have announced adult-only games bearing names such as X-Hot-Stuff and Bachelor Party. One company, the Computer Kinetics Corporation of Westlake Village, Calif., quietly introduced two X-rated arcade games for use in bars.

title: 82-STORY TOWER TO FILL GAP IN HOUSTON SKYLINE
description: ''Our feeling was that Houston had a sculpture garden of magnificent buildings, but somehow they did not all fit together,'' John T. Cater was saying the other day. What the city lacked, he went on, was ''something that would enable people flying over the city to say, 'That's Houston.' ''

title: NObel Laureate Has a Kind Word For Reaganomics
description: The Reagan Administration last week took heart in the economy's movement - the gross national product expanded eight-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter - but there was some question whether it was turning the corner or going in circles. While housing starts, the stock market and personal spending were up and one major bank dropped its prime rate to 11.5 percent, 685,000 newly unemployed persons lined up for jobless benefits and private economists told Congress things wouldn't be getting better very soon.

title: 7 Arrested in Cocaine Case
description: Seven Florida residents were arrested Friday by Federal agents who accused them of belonging to a $100 million-ayear cocaine-smuggling operation. The agents also seized about $675,000 in cash and 40 pounds of cocaine valued at $10 million, besides closing down what they called a ''cocaine-processing laboratory'' at a Hialeah home, a Federal official said.

title: Killer of 7 Sentenced to Life
description: Robert Lee Haggart, convicted Oct. 8 of killing his estranged wife and six of her relatives last February, has been sentenced to life in prison without parole.

title: FOOD AND FLOWERS
description: From a simple beginning, the idea of using flowers as decoration on a dinner table grew to alarming proportions. But today, decorating a table has become less and less formal, and the prevailing ideas of design leave much to individual taste. And, as it turns out, individuals have very definite ideas about what should and should not go on the table.

title: A COUPLE OF ARTISTS COME BACK TO JAZZ
description: EAST HAMPTON NUMEROUS students of the visual arts have ended up being musicians. Joni Mitchell, John Lennon, Jimmy Page, David Bowie and Captain Beefheart (Don Van Vliet) readily come to mind. Smaller in number, apparently, are those who successfully have transmuted their energies from music playing to visual art.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Return of Newhart

title: A WORLD OF FANTASY
description: Margaret Woodbury Strong was an obsessive collector, a person who never lost sight of the child within her, a woman with a Victorian delight in dolls, toys and bric-a-brac and a strong-willed eccentric - she lined the boundaries of her summer property with 40 artistpainted bathtubs filled with geranigeraniums. Heiress to a fortune in Eastman Kodak shares - at her death at the age of 72 in 1969 she was the largest single stockholder - she filled her Rochester mansion with what must surely have been the most comprehensive assemblage of collectibles under a 20th-century roof.

title: Bolivian Aides Ousted In Italian Fugitive Case
description: The Government has dismissed senior drug-control officials in the case of an Italian right-wing extremist who was extradited this month.

title: A GOOD MAN IN A BAD TIME
description: SCHINDLER'S LIST By Thomas Keneally. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: A COLONIAL SPOOF ON THE LONDON STAGE
description: LONDON ''Poppy'' is unlikely to rank high on the epitaph that the 54-yearold author of ''The National Health'' and ''Privates on Parade'' expects us prematurely to prepare for him. Several critics have sensed something wrong with it, and several of them have felt that the trouble was that an ironic pantomime had been transformed by Terry Hands's direction and Monty Norman's score into a sort of didactic show-biz spectacular, filling the Royal Shakespeare Company's big new Barbican Theater with song, dance and gaudy fun.

title: FRIEND OF PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: FUND STARTED BY KENT
description: KENT KENT's First Selectman, Robert A. Ward, was invited to a resident's home for cocktails last Sunday evening -and came away with a $100 gift for the town's endowment fund. Mr. Ward put the money in the bank the next morning and noted with pleasure that it raised the balance of the fund to $360.

title: TWO IN ARIZONA RELIGIOUS GROUP DIE IN GUN BATTLE WITH DEPUTIES
description: Law-enforcement officers were blockading a small Arizona town near the Mexican border yesterday in a confrontation with about 100 members of a faith-healing group in which two church members died.

title: MOSCOW REPLACING SYRIANS' MATERIEL
description: For weeks, military equipment provided by the Soviet Union has been arriving at the Syrian port of Tartus northwest of here to replace what Syria lost in its war with Israel in Lebanon.

title: THE SPORT OF FINDING ONE'S WAY
description: ON a fine weekend, along with the fishermen, picknickers, joggers and hikers at Blue Mountain Reservation here, there are likely to be men, women and children who belong to the Westchester Orienteering Club. The sport of orienteering, in which map and compass are used to aid in locating a series of checkpoints or controls, originated in Sweden in 1918 and was introduced to the United States in 1946. It came of age as a competitive sport about a decade ago and shows healthy signs of growth in the 80's. The county club, with a membership of more than 200 families, is one of some 100 groups nationwide.

title: TOURISTS SHUN SITES IN ISRAEL SINCE INVASION
description: Officials at the Tourism Ministry are dealing with a war-related problem: a severe drop in visitors since Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on pages 20-31 and 50-59. Campaign Report, pages 30-32. Producer Gets 40 Years On Marijuana Conviction

title: Nancy J. Brown To Become Bride
description: Brig. Gen. Donald D. Brown, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Brown, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy J. Brown, to Lieut. Andrew L. May, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. May of Nashville.

title: Sudanese Visits Egypt
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan met in this Sinai Peninsula town today to discuss ways to promote a sense of unity among the youth of their neighboring countries. This month the two countries concluded a pact to coordinate their foreign and domestic policies.

title: FOR WHOM ALFRED NOBEL CREATED A PEDESTAL
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE END OF THE WORLD A History. By Otto Friedrich. 384 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $19.95.

title: COLLEGE IN ROCHESTER DISCIPLINES STUDENTS IN THE SALE OF GRADES
description: Eleven students at the Rochester Institute of Technology have been disciplined for buying or selling grades, and 58 other students are to be questioned beginning this week.

title: Montclair Tied, Still Unbeaten
description: Montclair State, ranked fourth in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, stepped up to Division II football competition yesterday with an unbeaten record. But the Indians settled for a 14-14 deadlock against Central Connecticut State, a team without a victory, at New Britain, Conn.

title: Wesley S. Bruckno Weds Dr. Margaret M. Nepps
description: At the Kirkpatrick Chapel on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, N.J., yesterday Dr. Margaret M. Nepps, a supervising psychologist at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, was married to Wesley S. Bruckno, an urban planner with the Westchester County Department of Planning in White Plains. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Guido, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Wilhelm Schoenfeld, grandfather of the bridegroom and minister of the German Church of God in Midland Park, N.J.

title: NEW BUSINESS FOR OPIC
description: While the continuing global recession has caused many companies to cut back on overseas investment plans, activities of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation during the recently completed fiscal year indicate that the reluctance is not necessarily widespread.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Unforced individualism marks the dances of Jane Comfort and Sally Bowden. Miss Comfort, who has appeared with David Gordon and Kenneth King, has choreographed dances that draw on everything from the samba to deaf-signing but never stray far from the quiet, easy intelligence that informs their themes and movement.

title: Sheltering Wildlife
description: Each year New Jersey was spending $6 million to breed and manage some 50 species of birds and animals for hunters. But the state had never spent more than $50,000 a year to preserve its 600 nongame species.

title: Miss Perani Wed To a Bank Aide
description: Linda Perani, daughter of Alfred J. Perani of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Carol Perani, was married in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday to James Montaudevert Waterbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Waterbury of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Morris performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Takeover Laws
description: To the Business Editor: The irony of Prof. William Nordhaus's presentation, ''The Vanity of the Takeover Game'' (Oct.3), is that the solution he proposes - requiring approval of the acquisition by the shareholders of the companies involved - has been a traditional requirement of corporate law. Under the laws of most states, a merger must be approved by the board of directors and at least a majority of the outstanding shares of both the acquiring corporation and the ''target'' corporation.

title: Bus Skimping
