description: To the Business Editor: In ''And Now It's the Buses' Turn'' (Oct.3), your writer gives only a passing glance to the issue of safety. More should be said about the view of one company president who predicts that a greater excess of capacity will lead to skimping on equipment and maintenance.

title: BUT TAOR HAD A SWEET TOOTH
description: THE FOUR WISE MEN By Michel Tournier. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 255 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: DURING the Depression, the Works Progress Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt came into Hudson County and built two sports stadiums, a 28,500-seat behemoth in Jersey City and a 7,000-seat facility on Hudson Boulevard (now Kennedy Boulevard) in Union City.

title: Two Red Brigades Suspects Are Seized by Police in Rome
description: The police today reported the arrest of two people in connection with the suspected Red Brigades shooting of a plainclothes narcotics policeman on Friday.

title: RETREAT TO A MEXICAN SPA
description: EDEN ROSS LIPSON is an editor of The New York Times Book Review. BY EDEN ROSS LIPSON

title: N. Rockland Edges Ramapo
description: North Rockland, the defending P.S.A.L. champion, chalked up its fourth straight victory this year and 16th in a row over a two-year span by beating Ramapo, 10-7.

title: Honors for Yount
description: Robin Yount, the shortstop who is expected to reap the fruits of his superb season for the Milwaukee Brewers all winter, has already gained two honors in three days since the World Series ended. Friday, he won the Seagram's Seven Crowns of Sports award for baseball, barely beating Steve Carlton, the pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies. Yount donated his $10,000 check, in the name of all the Brewers, to the Midwest Athletes Against Childhood Cancer Fund. Yesterday, Yount was the only unanimous choice on United Press International's American League all-star team.

title: No Headline
description: BOWDOIN 28, COAST GUARD 13

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Ellis, the Princeton track coach and head coach of the 1984 United States Olympic team, will be inducted Thursday night into the New York University Sport Hall of Fame. Other inductees will be Norman Lewis, an intercollegiate champion in foil and epee fencing in the late 1930's; his brother, Bobby Lewis, captain of the basketball team that won its first 18 games in 1939-40, and Mal Graham, who in the mid-1960's broke most of the university's basketball scoring records. ... Arnold Messing, an all-American in 1968 and still nationally ranked in epee, was named fencing coach at City College, his alma mater. ... One of golf's celebrated figures, Keith Mackenzie, said he would retire next September at age 62 as secretary of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland.

title: CANDIDATES FOR FAMILY COURT JUDGE DEBATE
description: FOUR of the five candidates for Family Court appeared last week at a meeting in White Plains sponsored by the Westchester County Women's Council. The audience, which included many whose work brings them in contact with the court, questioned the candidates on a range of specific issues, including educational workshops for men and women who batter their spouses and children, orders of protection and the effect of a Right-to-Life endorsement in abortion cases.

title: U.S. VOICES REGRET TO FRANCE ON NEWS REPORT
description: The United States Ambassador to France expressed regret today to the French Government over an article that appeared in an American newspaper, and said he would ask the United States Attorney General's Office to determine how the newspaper had come to use classified embassy cablegrams in the article.

title: DEBUSSCHERE, BROWN TRY TO LIFT KNICKS OUT OF PAST
description: THE championship banners are nice remembrances, hanging above the court at Madison Square Garden like ribbons on a soldier's chest. So are the retired uniform numbers of yesterday's heroes, whose exploits made those championships possible.

title: Arab League Stops at the Brink On Ousting Israel
description: Most countries at the United Nations neither love their enemies nor listen to their speeches. Harsh and frequent condemnation - as when the General Assembly dumps on Israel - is also acceptable diplomacy. But throwing a member out of the club went too far, the 21-member Arab League conceded last week. A Libyan-led attempt to expel Israel was dropped by the Arabs and other Islamic countries in the face of near-universal disapproval. They retreated to another verbal assault on Israel in a letter of condemnation to be read during tomorrow's debate on credentials.

title: DOES IT PAY TO RENEGOTIATE A MORTGAGE?
description: MORTGAGE rates have fallen and many homeowners who had the m isfortune to buy at peak rates are now beset with a bit of envy. Theq uestion is whether there is anything they can do to get the cheaper r ates, and the answer is yes. Mortgages - even second mortgages and m ortgages on investment and business properties - can be r enegotiated, and such a move might pay if rates have fallen far e nough.

title: TETLEY LOOKS TO THE ORIENT IN HIS 'TEMPEST'
description: ''Too much schmattes,'' a patron remarked after all the fabricflying and cape-swirling in Glen Tetley's ballet ''The Tempest,'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Well, yes. But the billowing cloaks and rippling cloths are exactly what Mr. Tetley's visions of Shakespeare's play are about.

title: LEgislative Veto Bites Some Dust
description: In the latest stage of a legal battle among Government behemoths, the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington ruled last week that both Houses of Congress may not act together to veto Federal agency rules. The so-called legislative veto had been used to stymie a Federal Trade Commission rule that required used car dealers to tell buyers about defects and warranties.

title: Tax Credits: A Matter of Equity
description: As a grateful graduate of a parochial school, I note with sympathy Adele B. Gordon's evident illiteracy or simple obtuseness in her article (''The Three C's of Tax Credits,'' Oct. 3). Ms. Gordon first quotes President Reagan on the matter of competition between public and private schools:

title: MUSIC: VON KARAJAN'S BRAHMS CYCLE
description: There are few orchestras that can elicit bravos merely by tuning up, but, believe it or not, Herbert von Karajan's Berlin Philharmonic actually stimulated that reaction on two nights last week at Carnegie Hall.

title: FOR $325, A CHANCE TO ASSESS THE LEGACY OF THE BEATLES
description: The Beatles were the most: the most influential group in the history of rock, the most successful, the most idolized, the most idealized and, almost without question, the most talented.

title: Lori Newman Betrothed
description: Mrs. Sheila Barschi of New York and Jesse Newman of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Jan Newman, to Kurt Ian Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Schwartz of Winthrop, Mass. Miss Newman is an associate producer at WOR-TV in New York, where her fiance is an account executive with Michael B. Weiss Advertising Inc.

title: VINTAGE TEAS IN A TAIPEI SHOP
description: TERRY TRUCCO is a Tokyo-based writer.

title: PIANIST RETURNS TO CONCERT HALL WITH NEW LEAF
description: SIX years ago, Carol Mont Parker decided to make her professional New York debut as a pianist at Carnegie Recital Hall. As commonplace as this may seem, since each season scores of young musicians take that plunge, hoping that exposure to New York critics and audiences will lead to fame and fortune, it was different in Miss Parker's case.

title: ANTIDRAFT-REGISTRATION CAMPAIGN GOES ON
description: APRESIDENTIAL study group announced last Monday that enough men were volunteering for the armed services to make the need for a draft unnecessary.

title: Speedy Trial Act Is Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, reversing a lower court's decision, has upheld the Federal Speedy Trial Act and said it does not unconstitutionally usurp powers reserved to the courts. The court overturned an 1981 decision by Federal District Judge Joseph H. Young in Baltimore, who said the act, limiting trial delays, encroached on judicial authority.

title: To Our Readers
description: Some issues of The New York Times for Sunday contained an unauthorized political publication entitled ''Profiles of the Times'' that was distributed illegally to newsstands in Manhattan with instructions that it be inserted. The Times is conducting an investigation to determine the source of the fraudulent insertion. An article is on page 39.

title: IOWA CANDIDATE BASES DRIVE ON FAMILY'S CUTS IN U.S. AID
description: When Lynn Cutler, a Democratic candidate for Congress, argues against President Reagan's budget cuts, she is not talking about an abstract notion but about less money every month for her family. ''My own children are victims,'' Mrs. Cutler says.

title: MORTGAGES OFFERED BY STATE
description: SPECIAL low-cost mortgages carrying an interest rate of only 11 3/4 percent, approximately three percentage points below the prevailing rate at most private lending institutions around the state, will be offered to moderate-income buyers by the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority starting tomorrow.

title: Robert J. Gillispie, Lawyer, Marries Barbara A. Farrell
description: The marriage of Barbara Anne Farrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Farrell of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., to Robert John Gillispie, a partner in the New York law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander, took place yesterday at the Beacon Hill Club in Summit, N.J. The Lutheran ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Weinrich.

title: VATICAN AIDE DEFENDS POPE'S MEETING WITH ARAFAT
description: The Vatican has formally responded to protests by American Jews over the recent meeting between Pope John Paul II and Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Elizabeth Perry Married
description: Elizabeth R. Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Perry of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Mark M. Curran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Curran of New York. The Rev. Nicholas Stavrakis performed the ceremony at St. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church in Washington. The bride was graduated from the University of Virginia and her husband is studying fine arts at Virginia Commonwealth University.

title: Even Less Wine, Still Fewer Roses
description: Maybe its not his fault, but the legacy of fiscal responsibility that Governor Carey promised would remain in Albany after he left seems increasingly likely to be written in red ink. Last week, Mr. Carey warned that New York State faced a deficit of $579 million in the current fiscal year and perhaps a $1.8 billion gap in the following one.

title: YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN-IF YOU ARRIVE EMPTY-HANDED
description: IT began 12 years ago. After living, for five years, in a toosmall north-Manhattan apartment, we were understandably obsessed with space. Taunted by jammed drawers, closets that spilled their contents; confused by a bread box doubling as a medicine cabinet, a medicine cabinet substituting as a spice rack, we sought a suburban home rich with storage.

title: SUICIDE WAS IN THE SCRIPT
description: THE LIFE OF JOHN BERRYMAN By John Haffenden. 451 pp. Boston: Routledge & Kegan Paul. $22.50.

title: TAKING THE ZING OUT OF THE ARCADE BOOM...
description: The coin-operated video game explosion, which has sent children into arcades and parents into fits, at last appears to be slowing down.

title: On Campus Drinking: Case Against Curbs
description: In ''Curbs Sought on Campus Drinking'' (10/3), Hugh O'Haire depicts benevolent university administrators acting in the best interests of students by curtailing alcohol consumption on campuses all over Long Island. Mr. O'Haire's article exemplifies biased or naive journalism in failing to question why students have not independently identified and pursued their ''best interests,'' and in failing to consider why, after abandoning the role of in loco parentis in the 1960's, universities would again prefer it to non-paternalistic cooperation with students, faculties and staffs.

title: Military Analysis
description: American and Israeli military sources say that if Iran opens another offensive against Iraq, its direction will probably be decided by the outcome of a debate between leaders of Iran's revolutionary guards and the regular army.

title: PRODUCER PREPARING BALLOON CAMPAIGN KEYED TO PATRIOTISM
description: Ed Shaw, the Hollywood producer who sponsored a sweepstakes to get out the voters in California's June primary, says he will drop thousands of balloons, redeemable for a total of $12 million, in a nationwide campaign to arouse patriotism.

title: GOOD BEGINNINGS, HAPPY ENDINGS
description: First and last impressions are the ones that count most in meals and love affairs, as in so many other aspects of life. A lot can happen between ''Hello'' and ''Goodbye,'' but, in a sense, the way a relationship (or a dinner) begins and ends is really the whole story. Phrases such as ''Put your best foot forward'' and ''Always leave them when you're lookin' good'' are just two reminders of how important beginnings and endings are in human relations. (Middles do not seem to inspire epigrams.) At a dinner, the appetizer represents the best foot, and if the dessert looks good, so will the host or hostess.

title: DANCE: ART BRIDGMAN AND MYRNA PACKER
description: Art Bridgman and Myrna Packer danced about love and war on their collaboratively choreographed Thursday night program at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Mostly, however, they danced about love. They even danced about love when they were dancing about war.

title: SELF-SERVICE 'GAS': A HIGH-OCTANE ISSUE
description: MOTORISTS stopping for gasoline in New Jersey these days are likely to receive a letter detailing the pitfalls of self-service. The letters, which have been distributed to service-station owners and operators by the New Jersey Gasoline Retailers Association, are part of an all-out effort to forestall the passage of bills, now before the State Legislature, that would remove restriction against self-service gasoline pumps.

title: O'NEILL SELDOM MAKES WAVES --- OR ENEMIES
description: The last Republican to win a Connecticut gubernatorial race was Thomas J. Meskill in 1970, and he did it by winning Fairfield County. In the next two elections, Republican candidates lost their races partly because they lost the county, and in the last dozen years only one Republican, United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., former first selectman of Greenwich, has carried the state.

title: New Conducting Attire Is Defended by Previn
description: Andre Previn, music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony, said he was surprised at criticism about his new conducting attire - a sleeveless black jacket with a white shirt open at the neck.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in today's Westchester Weekly, which appears in copies of The New York Times distributed in Westchester County, incorrectly identifies Richard L. Brodsky. He is a county legislator.

title: Modern Fagin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parting Old Rules On Water Quality
description: ''Steel, not eel,'' was the rally slogan of Youngstown, Ohio, workers in 1976 when they convinced the Environmental Protection Agency to waive water quality rules for the Mahoning River. If proposals now under consideration at the E.P.A. are adopted as expected, however, the steelmen who still have jobs will not have to worry about their next case of Koehler's beer - at least not on account of some endangered fish.

title: REAGAN TO THE RESCUE
description: Nevada is a state with only four electoral votes and a 54 percent Democratic majority among registered voters. But President Reagan and Vice President Bush are campaigning here twice apiece this year, and the state has been flooded with Republican notables, from Howard Baker, the Senate majority leader, to Donald Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury.

title: NEW YORK POLL SHOWS STATE VOTERS AMBIVALENT ON BIG TAX CUTS
description: New York State voters consider themselves overtaxed, but appear unwilling to reduce taxes sharply if such cuts would reduce the level of services provided by state government, according to a New York Times Poll just taken.

title: Better Days For Gibson
description: Kenneth A. Gibson claimed throughout his month-long conspiracymisconduct trial that he was the target of a political fishing expedition. Last week, the Mayor of Newark was off the hook.

title: A GUIDE FOR THOSE BESET BY PROBLEMS IN HEATING
description: THERE is a warming thought for tenants and landlords faced with p ossibly the coldest winter in a century: Energy officials who are r esponsible for minimum heating requirements in multifamily dwellingsa re already preparing for the increased demand for information and s ervices. And these services appear to be working throughout much of t he New York metropolitan region.

title: NEW AMERICAN AT HOME ON SOCCER FIELD
description: Tabare Ramos, a junior at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, commands so much attention and respect from the defense that when he goes to the sideline for a drink during a game a couple of opposing players usually go with him.

title: OF WIMPS AND MEN
description: Campaigning for Governor of Illinois, former Senator Adlai Stevenson 3d charged that Gov. James Thompson ''is saying, 'Me tough guy,' as if to imply I'm some kind of wimp.'' The ''wimp factor'' immediately became part of the campaign's instant lore.

title: DEFENDANT ACTING AS LAWYER NOT ENTITLED TO EXTRA COUNSEL
description: A defendant who chooses to represent himself in court is not entitled to the assistance of court-appointed standby counsel, the New York State Court of Appeals has ruled.

title: NOT MUCH PASSION IN THIS 'STREETCAR'
description: ''THE enemy time,'' one of Tennessee Williams's quintessential phrases, reflects one of the playwright's timeless themes. With respect to his master work, ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' time has turned around, been benevolent. Its kindness, like that of strangers, has enriched and magnified the play's poetry, power and glory.

title: Red Cross Elects New Chief
description: Richard F. Schubert, a former president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, was elected today as president of the American Red Cross. He will succeed George M. Elsey.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE REFERENDUM: 'YES'
description: AS LUCK would have it, we have arrived at the 20th anniversary of the Cuban missile crisis and have progressed very little since October 1962 toward our national arms-control goals.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Last May, Shirley Horn, a pianist and singer from Washington, came to New York for the first time since she had been invited to make the trip 20 years ago by Miles Davis, who had asked her to share the bill with him at the Village Vanguard. She was welcomed warmly at the Vanguard and got a recording contract as a result of that appearance.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Hilmer Kenty vs. Roberto Elizondo, 10 rounds, lightweights; Mauricio Bravo vs. Pablo Baez, 10 rounds, welterweights, from Americana Hotel, McAfee, N.J. Kenty, the former World Boxing Association champion now ranked No. 3, has lost once in 23 fights and has returned to action after a retina operation. Elizondo, 24-3, is ranked eighth. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Mark Frazier vs. Dwight Walker, one of three 10-round middleweight bouts from Tampa Fla. Rematch of May 2 fight in which Walker was disqualified for low blows. Other fights are LeRoy Hester vs. Don Lee, and Bruce Johnson vs. Fred Hutchings. (Television -Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Minnesota North Stars, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M.; 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) Islanders vs. Black Hawks, at Chicago (Television -Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 8:30 P.M.).

title: ORGANIZED ELEGANCE
description: It seems only fitting that a favorite character of Kitty Carlisle Hart, a familiar television personality, an actress and singer and now chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, is that of Prince Orlovsky in Johann Strauss's ''Die Fledermaus,'' as both are renowned hosts. There the resemblance ends, however, as Mrs. Hart, unlike the jaded Russian prince, is an outgoing person whose parties are relished as much by her guests as by the hostess herself. ''I love to give parties. Everyone has their own form of indulgence; mine is giving parties,'' she says. It is lucky that she does - as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, she has more than her fair share of entertaining to do, and her guest lists are generally packed with distinguished names.

title: LAXITY ON AIR LAID TO D.E.P.
description: TWO of New Jersey's most influential conservation groups alleged last week that the state's Department of Environmental Protection had failed not only to control air pollution adequately, but also to plan to abate even greater pollution emissions expected in this decade.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NO-FRILLS NEIGHBORHOOD SPOT
description: THERE are special-occasion restaurants: those where people glad-rag and celebrate, drop a bundle and have no regrets. But there are other kinds of occasions and other restaurants to suit: neighborhood places diners in slacks and clean shirts frequent on Friday night, where they relax and feel at home.

title: The Big Fix
description: Not all successful executives can cut it as entrepreneurs. Police said last week that John Z. DeLorean had failed in a bid to make millions in the cocaine trade to shore up his ailing auto company. Mr. DeLorean, who was charged with possessing nearly 60 pounds of the drug, had been the $650,000-a-year heir apparent to the chairmanship of General Motors Corporation before he struck out on his own in 1973.

title: CYNTHIA PROPPER SETON, NOVELIST AND ESSAYIST
description: Cynthia Propper Seton, a novelist and essayist, died yesterday of acute leukemia in Northampton, Mass. She was 56 years old and lived in Northampton.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE empty house that sits on seven acres overlooking Cold Spring Harbor was first offered to Union Theological Seminary. The Seminary didn't know what use it could make of the 22-room mansion in Lloyd Neck so it didn't accept. The house, the country estate of the late Anna Matheson Wood, was built in 1878 on the site of Fort Franklin, a British strongpoint in the Revolutionary War. Her husband, Willis D. Wood, had once been a trustee of Union Theological Seminary.

title: Arline Wheat, C.W. Eltzroth 3d to Wed
description: Mrs. McCole Wheat of Alexandria, Va., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Arline Cornelia Wheat, to Carter Weaver Eltzroth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eltzroth Jr. of Boston. A Feb. 12 wedding is planned.

title: Article 242077 -- No Title
description: Princeton University has received a gift of $5.6 million from James C. Donnell 2d, a 1932 graduate and former chairman of the Marathon Oil Company, the president of the university, William G. Bowen, announced today.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SCOTTSDALE
description: TOM MILLER, who contributes to The Times from Arizona, is the author of ''On the Border: Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier,'' published in paperback this fall by Ace Books.

title: No Headline
description: Russell Baker's Boyhood Lacking Russell Baker's eloquence, I cannot properly express my gratitude for his ''Memoir of a Small-Town Boyhood'' (Sept. 12).

title:
ANTIQUES;
SIMPLE BEAUTY ALONG BACK ROADS
description: STOCKTON AMERICAN country antiques, with their simpliciy of line, old wood or faded colors, are easy to live with. A few pieces artfully placed in an uncluttered room can create the same kind of austere beauty that is seen in some Japanese rooms. The clean lines and subtle interplay of color and texture become the principal ingredients.

title: SIMPLE SOLUTIONS TO PRISON ILLS ARE ONLY ILLUSORY
description: FOR several years, the New Jersey Association on Correction has vigorously opposed the issuance of bonds for prison construction. In 1978, it went to court to challenge - unsuccessfully -the constitutionality of a bond issue.

title: SURGERY FOR OBESE: DOES IT SUCCEED?
description: IN THE quiet hills of Rockland County, N.Y., Dr. Rafael Capella is performing a relatively new operation that has attracted as much controversy within the medical profession as it has patients eager to try the procedure.

title: WHEN A TOWN NEEDS TO CHANGE
description: THERE is a lot of head shaking going on in Bethel. This bucolic borough in northwestern Fairfield County used to consider itself a reprieve from surrounding extravagance but now finds itself caught in the throes of its own naivete. Its pillars, posts and politics are peculiarly unsuited to either retreat or progress, and so it has become common for many street corner conversations to begin with, ''What is happening around here?''

title: Recalling Game 5 Of 1920 Series
description: To the Sports Editor: In his article ''The Best World Series Games? Take These Three'' (The New York Times, Oct. 10), Charles Einstein picked a trio of outstanding games that hardly anyone can disagree with. However, as he limited his selection to the post-World War II era I'd like to offer my choice as to the most memorable World Series game of all time, the Brooklyn-Cleveland fifth game of the 1920 Series.

title: REAGAN AND O'NEILL EXCHANGE CHARGES OVER THE ECONOMY
description: President Reagan and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., exchanged accusations on the economy today as the off-year election campaign went into its final 10 days.

title: A NEW BREED OF FARMER
description: BEFORE anything else, it was the soil - rich, dark and fertile - that attracted people to what eventually became the state's Farm Belt. Now, after 300 years, others are coming to plow what remains of that still fecund and fruitful soil, to sow and to reap.

title: HOW'S HE DOING?
description: THE REAGAN EXPERIMENT Edited by John L. Palmer and Isabel V. Sawhill. 530 pp. Washington, D.C.: The Urban Institute Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: THOSE IVIED WALLS CAN BE A PROBLEM
description: STONY BROOK LONG associated with the country's top colleges, ivy has grown into a major maintenance problem for the State University of New York at Stony Brook, forcing administrators to begin removing the vine from the 20-year-old campus.

title: Not the Flotsam And Not Jetsam
description: To the Sports Editor: I was upset by Charles Einstein's characterization of the 1945 Tigers and Cubs as ''the flotsam and jetsam of civilian leftovers.'' It was especially painful for me to read that the 1945 Series was the first he covered as a reporter.

title: FOR SOME, THE SEASON FOR LONGER TRIPS
description: W hen the hordes of summer visitors leave such sunny climes as Spain, Portugal, Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey, a relatively new and growing class of traveler - the American retiree -moves in. Now that winter is approaching, tour operators are aiming programs at people with unlimited time on their hands who can travel whenever they wish and who are attracted by the relatively low cost of off-season travel.

title: IDENTIFYING THE RISK FACTORS HASN'T NARROWED THE RISK
description: On a typical day, more than 300 American women will be found to have breast cancer and 100 others will die of the disease. The average American woman faces a 1-in-11 chance of developing breast cancer sometime during her lifetime. This risk is barely lower than the 1-in-10 chance a cigarette smoker has of getting lung cancer, although the survival rate for breast cancer is substantially higher -56 percent to 85 percent after five years. Women who detect a breast tumor in its early stages have the better chance of living longer.

title: THEATER: 'GREATER TUNA,' COMEDY
description: If you were driving through the mythical town of Tuna, Tex., and the Thurston Wheelis-Arles Struvie Morning News came on the radio, you would immediately switch the dial in search of Dolly Parton. At Circle in the Square (Downtown), where ''Greater Tuna'' opened Thursday night, there is no such recourse. Is there a Walkman in the house?

title: HOW POLICE FOUND LINK IN BURGLARIES
description: GREENWICH ON Oct. 4, the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested three Massachusetts men in New York City on Federal charges of interstate transportation of stolen goods. The charges against the three pertain to a burglary in New Jersey.

title: THE RIVETING RETURN OF SMILEY
description: The good news is that ''Smiley's People,'' John le Carre's sequel to ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,'' has been made into a marvelously riveting television film. The disquieting news is that it is having its American premiere on a commercial station, which means commercial interruptions adding up to seven minutes every halfhour. As an Operation Prime Time presentation, ''Smiley's People'' will be broadcast in two-hour segments over three successive Mondays, beginning tomorrow evening at 8 on WPIX/Channel 11 (rebroadcasts of each episode will be offered on the following Wednesday evenings).

title: AMABILE STARS FOR WALL
description: Bob Amabile kicked five extra points and a field goal and also scored a touchdown to guide Wall to a 37-0 victory over Point Pleasant Boro yesterday in Point Pleasant. Art Petracco ran for two touchdowns.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME NEW VARIETIES OF APPLES
description: AFTER having been given a bad name by Adam and Eve, the apple has made a steady upward climb to the top of the heap. As the No. 1 fruit in the country, this year's harvest will be some 204 million bushels, nearly a bushel for each of us. Of that number, 110 million will be sold fresh; the rest processed into a variety of products, including cider, juice and applesauce.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: GRAND TOURS AND DETOURS OF FLAUBERT
description: FRANCIS STEEGMULLER is the author of many books, including several on Flaubert. The second volume of his translation and annotation of ''The Letters of Gustave Flaubert'' is being published this month by the Harvard University Press.

title: Soviet Oil Output Up a Little; Gas and Coal Production Rise
description: Soviet oil production in the first nine months of this year reached 12.16 million barrels a day, compared with 12.13 million barrels a day in the same period last year, according to a report by the Central Statistical Board.

title: GIVING FULL DUE TO AN INFLUENTIAL MASTER'S ART
description: Toward the beginning of the 17th century, European art got itself a whole new cast of characters. Poussin was born in 1594. Bernini was born in 1598. Velazquez and van Dyck were born in 1599. Claude Gelee, better known either as Claude Lorrain or just plain Claude, was born in 1600. Between them, they turned European art right around. We cannot imagine Italian sculpture without Bernini, Spanish painting without Velazquez, Flemish painting without van Dyck or French painting without Poussin and Claude.

title: CHINA WITH A PORTUGUESE ACCENT
description: PAMELA G. HOLLIE is a New York Times correspondent based in Manila.

title: The Hard-Hit Rich
description: A pawnshop for the well to do - the Beverly Loan Company in Beverly Hills, Calif. - noted signs of economic distress among its clientele as 1982 began.

title: COMA PATIENTS ARE PRODDED TO RESPOND
description: OCEANSIDE SEVERAL weeks after her son fell into the family's backyard swimming pool and nearly drowned, JoAnne Mancini was sitting in the waiting room outside the pediatric intensive care unit at the Medical Center of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN Ihad a dream the other night that my daughter was 6 months old again and speaking sentences. There was something pleasant about that dream. I was transported back to her post-infancy and picked her up and showed her off. I pushed her carriage among people walking down the street and beamed as they nudged one another and marveled at this baby's ability to carry on a conversation.

title: IN POSITANO, A HIDDEN HAVEN
description: LESLIE BENNETTS is a reporter on the culture desk of The Times.

title: Pakistani Visits North Korea
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan arrived in Pyongyang, North Korea, today for a state visit, North Korea's official press agency reported.

title: Future Events Art, Ballet and Crafts
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Shop Early Oct. 25 - A preview and a cocktail party from 2 to 8 P.M. usher in the 23d annual Les Boutiques de Noel, traditional Christmas sale at the Center for Inter-American Relations to benefit Cancer Care, the Children's Aid Society, the Kips Bay Boys' Club, Visiting Nurse Service of New York and the center. Take care of all the names on your list at one fell swoop at booths set up by a diverse group of merchants from Maine to Florida. Tickets to the preview, underwritten by Dom Ruinart Champagne, $50 per couple from 988-0911 or 988-0981. Sale will continue Oct. 26 and 27 from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M,. and Oct. 28 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission, $3. Lunch, $5.

title: CLIENTS AND FRIENDS SALUTE TALENT AGENT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ORDINARILY, stage and screen stars do not hold celebrations for talent agents, but Milton Goldman is not your ordinary talent agent. Sir Laurence Olivier invites him to lunch, Sir John Gielgud seeks his advice and Lillian Gish and Helen Hayes are but two of what seem like thousands of ''dear friends.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1982
description: International Arab recognition of Israel will come only after Israel removes its forces from the territory it has occupied since the 1967 war, King Hassan II of Morocco said at a news conference in Washington. A day after he and a six-nation Arab League delegation discussed differing Arab and American peace plans with President Reagan, the King said the Middle East dispute had entered ''a new phase, not the conflict of war but of law and of rights.'' (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: 4 QUESTIONS ON THE BALLOT FACE VOTERS
description: TRENTON IN ADDITION to voting for candidates for the Senate and House of Representatives on Nov. 2, New Jerseyans will have a number of questions to decide that could have a more-immediate impact on public's safety and pocketbooks.

title: PERSONAL PANACHE
description: ike most accomplished things that look simple, entertaining at home is a complex art. There are some people who entertain with flair and flourish, and make it look effortless. They have panache.

title: A Cuban Poet Uncaged
description: Cuba has at last ended the shameful imprisonment of Armando Valladares, who has wasted in jail for 22 years for disagreeing with Fidel Castro. Mr. Valladares has nonetheless become known abroad through his poetry. But he has been crippled by polyneuritis, the legacy of a starvation diet by which he was punished six years ago.

title: DOW STAYS AHEAD IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 1031.46, a gain of 38.36 points for the week. But a rally attempt to reach a new closing high ran out of steam late in the week. The New York Stock Exchange had its second heaviest trading week on record.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS SCAN NEW VISTAS
description: ROCKY POINT WEARING dark pants, crisp white shirts and maroon suspenders, Frank Mueller and Robert Yarema stacked the glasses and polished the bar, setting up for a busy Saturday night at Avenues, a local discotheque. They appeared confident, relaxed, efficient. Yet both were relatively new to bartending.

title: OF BALLOT PROPOSITIONS IN 50 YEARS
description: A new national wave of statewide ballot propositions, the most since 1932, will be decided in the Nov. 2 elections. Most were submitted by liberal rather than conservative groups, a sharp reversal from the recent past.

title: Reagan Travels Widely, but Picks Spots Carefully
description: As President Reagan took the Rose Garden on the road once again last week, strategists were making last-minute recalculations of his route and the stops. The attention to detail and the stepped-up pace of Mr. Reagan's appeals ''to stay the course'' were keen measures of the White House concern about the midterm elections, now 10 days away.

title:
GUEST OBSERVER;
MR. RIGHT TAKES A BOW
description: Cyra McFadden is a writer who lives in San Francisco. Russell Baker is on vacation.

title: TAPE-ITIS IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY IN THE corridors of power in Hudson County politics, rumors of criminal investigations and imminent indictments have become a pervasive, some say obsessive, topic of conversation. And not without some justification.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My wife and I are planning to be in San Antonio, Texas at the end of January on business. We would like to go on from there to take a week's vacation. Can you suggest some trips using that city as a jumping-off spot? - S.L.S., South Nyack, N.Y. Answer:Southern Texas and northern Mexico can be cool during that time of year; you would therefore probably want to fly farther south for a vacation. The end of January, and February even more so, is the best time of the year to visit central and southern Mexico, particularly Mexico City, where the weather tends to be dry with brilliant sunshine during the day and cool, comfortable temperatures at night. From San Antonio it's a flight of about two hours on Eastern or Mexicana Airlines.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE CRYSTAL CHILD By Barbara Wersba. Illustrated by Donna Diamond. 36 pp. New York: Harper & Row/ Charlotte Zolotow. $9.50. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Quality Counts
description: ''Our horses leave a lot to be desired,'' said the attentiongrabbing ad in the financial pages last May 13. The message, placed by the New York Racing Association, explained: ''Each year our race horses produce over 250,000 cubic yards of high-quality manure.

title: SOME SOVIET FILMS BELIE THE OLD POLITICAL STEREOTYPE
description: MOSCOW Soviet films have a way of perennially surprising Western viewers. Ever since ''The Cranes Are Flying,'' ''Ballad of a Soldier'' and ''My Name Is Ivan'' first challenged the popular notion of Soviet movies as mass-produced propaganda some 20 years ago, the Soviet Union has generated a steady trickle of films that do not seem to be what Leonid I. Brezhnev had in mind when he demanded that the cinema be a ''militant helper of the party, an important factor in the formation of the world view of the Soviet man...''

title: SETTING THE TEMPO
description: Perhaps it is a skewed legacy from the 1960's, but rock bands do not immediately come to mind when one thinks of exemplary home entertaining. The popular image, nourished back then by many rockers and their promoters, was of dedicated musicians living on the fringe, incessantly on the move, snubbing conventional values. Home could be the back of a tour bus; dinner, Twinkies and a bottle of beer.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME NEW VARIETIES OF APPLES
description: AFTER having been given a bad name by Adam and Eve, the apple has made a steady upward climb to the top of the heap. As the No. 1 fruit in the country, this year's harvest will be some 204 million bushels, nearly a bushel for each of us. Of that number, 110 million will be sold fresh; the rest processed into a variety of products, including cider, juice and applesauce.

title: U.S. ADOPTS FIRST DISPOSAL RULES FOR LOW-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has approved the first Federal regulations for burying low-level radioactive wastes. The regulations, adopted Friday after four years of work, require that land disposal facilities be able to hold in low-level radioactive wastes for 500 years.

title: THE GREATER HAZARDS OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Mercedes Bosch Bride of Jay Nawrocki
description: Mercedes Bosch, daughter of Dr. Samuel J. Bosch and Zelmira Gainza de Bosch of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Andrew Nawrocki, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew L. Nawrocki Jr. of Dune Acres, Ind. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: CHAMBER: PHILOMUSICA PLAYS JACOB DRUCKMAN
description: The New York Philomusica has adopted Jacob Druckman as its featured composer for this season, and his '' 'Delizie contente che l'alme beate' after Francesco Cavalli,'' which was written in 1973 and is scored for woodwind quintet and tape, was included in the chamber ensemble's concert Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Publishing has been called the ''accidental profession'' because so many editors, publishers and agents started out to do other things. In addition, acquisitions are often the result of chance, and Lady Luck has a lot to do with whether a book ends up a best seller or a remainder. Here are several recent examples of how publishing acquired its nickname. From Television to Books

title: U.S. SEES PROGRESS IN CENTRAL AMERICA: REGION FEARS CHAOS
description: MEXICO CITY TWENTY months after pledging to ''draw the line'' in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration is now increasingly confident that leftwing movements have lost the political initiative throughout Central America and that the United States is fast recovering its traditional influence over the region.

title: RUSSELL BAKER'S BOYHOOD
description: Russell Baker writes that ''beyond Lovettsville lay Brunswick, that vision of Paradise.'' He mentions that Brunswick had a department store - it was Kaplan's.

title: Dr. Paul Traverse Weds Kate A. Lloyd, Illustrator
description: Kate Angeline Lloyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Lloyd of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Whitney Traverse, son of Prof. and Mrs. Alfred Traverse of Huntingdon, Pa. The Rev. Henry Sturtevant, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Lloyd home.

title: EPIDEMIC OF DENGUE FEVER SWEEPS NEW DELHI
description: Health officials here say that the capital has been swept by an especially virulent epidemic of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease that produces symptoms comparable to severe influenza.

title: No Headline
description: Notre Dame Ties Oregon, 13-13, on Late Field Goal

title: FOR FAMILY'S HEAD, 2 JOBS 'FOR BASIC THINGS IN LIFE'
description: Third article of a series appearing periodically on the effects of changing economic conditions on some American families.

title: UNDERGROUND SETS STRIKES IN POLAND
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union are calling for walkouts and demonstrations meant to lead to a general strike in Poland next spring, according to clandestine communiques received here today.

title: AS WORLD TURNS FOR ISLAND ACTRESS
description: EVERY now and then, Marilyn Raphael walks out the door of her ranch-style home in Merrick, hops on her bicycle (equipped with two baskets) and pedals off to the supermarket.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT RANGERS, 5 TO 2
description: After being outplayed, the Islanders came alive midway through the second period tonight and defeated the Rangers, 5-2, before a sellout crowd of 15,230 at Nassau Coliseum. This was the eighth consecutive victory for the Stanley Cup champions, and it was the second time this season they had beaten the Rangers. The first was on Oct. 11, when they won, 4-3.

title: THE MOMENT OF TRUTH MUST BE FACED
description: THE letter arrives in mid July. My application for the 1982 New York City Marathon has been accepted. Something's wrong though, something's missing. The elation I'd expected to feel is curiously absent. Instead, churning deep within is apprehension coupled with a gnawing, growing doubt. Will I really be able to do it?

title: 'Newcomer's' View Of State Commended
description: I was delighted by the Sept. 26 article ''What's Right With New Jersey,'' by Dr. Harold Eickhoff, president of Trenton State College. As is so often the case, it took a newcomer to remind so many native New Jerseyans of their state's physical beauty, cultural and ethnic diversity, ample recreational treasures and thriving businesses.

title: Melinda Reid Has a Bridal
description: Melinda Elizabeth Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wilbur Reid of Nutley, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert James Gerrard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrard of East Elmhurst, Queens. The Rev. Lawrence Roberts performed the ceremony in the First Baptist Church.

title: BIDDING FOR BARGAINS AT HOUSE AUCTIONS
description: JAMES J. LEON picked up a three-bedroom, Colonial-style home in F airfield, Conn., for $81,000 last year. He had the house painted, m ade some minor repairs and was able to sell it six months later for $ 98,000, which probably was the true market value of the house when h e bought it.

title: Doing What Comes Naturally; Old Reliable
description: The Romans thought it heralded the death of Agrippa. A few centuries later the Chinese thought it was connected with an emperor's demise; a few centuries after that, it supposedly meant Attila the Hun's defeat.

title: No Headline
description: Preservation For Profit Clifford May has contributed useful insight to world concern for the wildlife of Africa (''Preservation for Profit,'' Sept. 12). Kenya needs help and knows it. High-level international cooperation is the logical means by which the parsimony, subterfuge and corruption that have dogged conservation undertakings in East Africa, thus far, may be successfully circumvented. CLEMENT E. MEROWIT, Director, Friends of Africa in America Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Monitoring of WOR Called a Public Service
description: Prof. Roger N.Johnson (Opinion Page, Oct. 3) performed a valuable public service with his monitoring of WOR-TV's performance this past spring. It is vital that New Jersey residents have available to them news and information about events and decisions that take place in New Jersey and that affect their lives.

title: U.S. Atom Arms Tests At a Post-1970 Record
description: The United States has detonated more nuclear weapons this year than in any other year since 1970, although the Reagan Administration says it is still committed to a comprehensive treaty to ban all such tests.

title: SOVIET DIPLOMAT IN IRAN DEFECTS AND FLEES TO BRITAIN
description: A Soviet diplomat has defected from his post in Iran and fled to Britain, and officials here suggested that they thought he could give Western intelligence agencies extremely valuable information.

title: Sandra Bonomo Wed To Douglas A. Werner
description: Sandra Anne Bonomo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Bonomo of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas A. Werner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Werner of Riverside, Conn.

title: Manila Official Assails Priests Who Aid Rebels
description: The Government is concerned about radical Roman Catholic priests who join rebel forces, according to Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile.

title: ZESTY SPANISH SOUP
description: Humble native dishes centuries old sometimes find themselves raised to international celebrity through exportation. Such is the case with gazpacho, the cold Spanish soup served with garnishes.

title: HEYWARD IS THE KEY AT PASSAIC
description: Craig Heyward, a powerful junior tailback, ran for one touchdown and scored three more on passes from Michael Volpe as Passaic defeated Bloomfield, 31-14, yesterday in Bloomfield.

title: SMOKE DETECTORS: HOW THEY SHOULD BE POSITIONED IN A HOUSE
description: ALTHOUGH smoke detectors are required in all multiple-family dwellings in many cities, as well as in newly built single-family homes, many existing homes and apartments still do not have them - even though all fire experts agree that many lives could be saved each year if smoke detectors were installed in every residence.

title: Against the Freeze Referendums
description: One of four voters will be asked on Election Day to express an opinion about a ''freeze'' on nuclear weapons. Similar referendums, urging a negotiated halt in the arms race, appear on ballots in nine states, including New Jersey, and many localities, including Suffolk County, Washington, Philadelphia and Chicago. They pose a difficult choice.

title: APOLITICAL SCIENCE SUPPORTS THE FED
description: Wall Street likes the new Federal Reserve policy. Soon, Main Street will too. Like most economists, weighing the scientific weaknesses of monetarism, I don't know or care whether Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and his colleagues changed course because of White House and senatorial pre-election pressures.

title: CANDIDATE FOR FAMILY COURT WAS REBUKED BY JUDICIAL UNIT
description: LOUIS A. BARONE, a Republican Party candidate for Family Court Judge in the county, was privately disciplined last June by the State of New York Grievance Committee of the Ninth Judicial District.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: GOLDEN HILL By Shirley Lord. 544 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $14.95.

title: ZIMBABWE JAILS 'DISSIDENTS' AS THREATS
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government is making increased use of emergency powers inherited from the white minority regime that ruled this country when it was called Rhodesia.

title: NEIGHBORS PROTEST NEW CHURCH
description: The parish of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport is considered a small one, with only 1,400 families. Just a little over 800 of these families are active members. St. Patrick's Roman CatholicChurch of Huntington, which is only a few miles away, has over 3,000 families.

title: FIRE SETS BACK SELF-HELP UNIT
description: enter society, suffered a severe setback last month when fire destroyed 95 percent of the contents of its thrift shop here. The loss was estimated at $5,000 by Michael Shank, executive director of Concern. The shop, where some of the former patients are employed, provides funds for at least half of the group's annual needs.

title: Seibu Wins Opener
description: The former Chicago Cub player Steve Ontiveros and Takuji Ota hit homers to pace a 13-hit attack today as the Seibu Lions defeated the Chunichi Dragons, 7-3, in the opening game of the Japan Series.

title:
ART;
GOOD CONCEPT, INGROWN RESULTS
description: THE Sarah Lawrence College Art Gallery is presenting an exhibition with the intriguing title ''36-18-6-1,'' and the concept behind it is equally provocative.

title: PHILHARMONIC MUSICIANS VOTE TO ACCEPT A NEW 3-YEAR PACT
description: The musicians of the New York Philharmonic ratified a new threeyear contract yesterday by a vote of 83-18. The musicians had rejected two earlier management offers, but no performances were canceled.

title: STATES EARMARK LESS MONEY FOR HIGHER EDUCATION
description: The states this year appropriated the smallest increase in funds for higher education in two decades, and, if inflation is counted, half are spending less money than they did two years ago, according to an educational trade publicaton.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You obviously realize that we have entered a new phase in the Arab-Israeli conflict, not the conflict of war but of law and of rights.'' - King Hassan II of Morocco. (1:6.)

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IN PRAISE OF THE BEAUTY OF DIVERSITY
description: GROWING UP in the Bronx has its advantages. So has moving to New Jersey. When we packed to migrate in 1976, my wife and I expected our home in Toms River to be better than our three-room apartment on Tremont Avenue.

title: 6 Family Members Killed As Truck Hits Auto
description: A car pulled in front of a tractortrailer rig and was hit broadside, killing six members of a family and seriously injuring another, the police said.

title: RULE EASED FOR SHUTTLE RIDERS
description: The space agency, in a move that may increase the number of foreigners flying aboard the space shuttle, says it will relax the requirements for crew members who are not members of the agency, starting in 1984.

title: CHrysler Workers Pause to Reflect
description: With a bold contract rejection clenched in one fist and a strike authorization in the other, United Auto Workers officials looked into the face of a walkout against Chrysler Corporation last week - and blinked.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME NEW VARIETIES OF APPLES
description: AFTER having been given a bad name by Adam and Eve, the apple has made a steady upward climb to the top of the heap. As the No. 1 fruit in the country, this year's harvest will be some 204 million bushels, nearly a bushel for each of us. Of that number, 110 million will be sold fresh; the rest processed into a variety of products, including cider, juice and applesauce.

title:
THE MAKING OF A WRITER;
'ALL I CARED ABOUT WAS WOMEN AND ART'
description: FROM earliest childhood I heard my father play modern piano music: Stravinsky, Bartok, Schoenberg. But the public wanted Liszt's ''Hungarian Rhapsodies,'' not Stravinsky. As a result, the halls where he gave his concerts were half empty. And, since I love my father desperately, I idolized modern art and disdained the public that preferred Liszt to Stravinsky.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TINY VISITOR Written and illustrated by Oscar de Mejo. Unpaged. New York: Pantheon Books. $9.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: ASPECTS OF SYNERGY AT TWO EXHIBITIONS
description: SPARKILL, N.Y. IT SO happens that synergy, the cooperative action of forces or elements, is a factor in both shows under review this week. ''Synergy/Artists 1 Plus 1 Equals 3,'' which purports to examine the process via printmaking, will be on view through Nov. 7 at Thorpe Intermedia, the gallery at the Dominican convent (Route 340 in Rockland County).

title: Jet Makes Emergency Stop
description: A United Airlines jet made an emergency landing here this morning after an ''equipment malfunction,'' the airline said.

title: Carol Eliel Wed To F.T. Muller Jr.
description: Carol S. Eliel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Eliel of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married in New York yesterday to F. Thomas Muller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Muller of Northbrook, Ill. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: CROPPING: IN THE CAMERA OR IN THE DARKROOM
SCHOLAR IS CHALLENGING COLORADO CONGRESSMAN
description: Tom Cronin travels his mountain district wearing a blue pin-striped suit rather than tweedy jackets or lumpy sweaters, and he describes himself as a businessman who knows what it is like to balance a budget and meet a payroll. The lanky Congressional candidate with tousled hair and a Boston accent seems more at home in a corporate board room than in the halls of academe.

title: Lorie Jean Mayor Bride of Duncan McNeir Myers
description: Lori Jean Mayor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Mayor Jr. of Omaha, Neb., was married yesterday to Duncan McNeir Myers, son of Dr. and Mrs. W.P. Laird Myers of New York and Norwich, Vt. The Rev. Winthrop Yinger, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Depot Hotel in Sonoma, Calif.

title: IT'S TIME TO SEE IF CHANGES HELP
description: AFTER one of its most active offseasons, the National Basketball Association opens its 37th season Friday night with old faces in n ew places and questions about the effects that the moves will have. Trades and free-agent movement, along with the influx of rookies, i s expected to change the final rosters of the 23 franchises by more t han 35 percent from last season.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
POLITICAL BUBBLE, TOIL AND TROUBLE
description: IN economic policy making, Holloween is now celebrated on Election D ay. The magic potions promised to cure the nation's economic ills a re brought to the ballot box. The new governor or senator h enceforth promises to use them to create jobs, prevent inflation, a nd restore this nation's deserved position of leadership.

title: Miss Tucay Is Affianced
description: Brig. Gen. Domingo R. Tucay, Philippine Army, retired, and Mrs. Tucay of Pleasant Hill, N.C., formerly of Quezon City, the Philippines, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wilhelmina Fernandez Tucay, to Philip Fransioli Busby Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Busby of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., formerly of Westfield, N.J.

title: COMPUTER SYSTEM PAYING OFF FOR JERSEY HOSPITALS
description: New Jersey hospital officials say that a new way of paying hospitals for patient care has reduced waste and increased efficiency by shortening patients' hospital stays.

title: WHAT CURES FOR 'MALIGNANCY' OF TERRORISM?
description: AFTER a week of bullets and ballots, this British province had a new Assembly that seemed to have about as much chance for smooth sailing on its maiden voyage as another Belfast launching - the Titantic.

title: HORMONES TIED TO HEART ILLS
description: An excess of certain hormones may be responsible for heart disease and heart attacks in people who compulsively seek work, those who are impatient and other ''Type A personalities,'' according to a Duke University scientist.

title: Solzhenitsyn Assails U.S.  For Treatment of Taiwan
description: Alexander I. Solzhenitsyn criticized the United States today for establishing relations with Peking at the expense of Taiwan.

title: PROSPECTS
description: No Recovery Yet

title: U.S. EXPERTS DISPUTE LINK BETWEEN FALLOUT AND UTAH DEATHS
description: In the picturesque towns of southern Utah, where the air is hot and dry, people water their lawns generously. The more water people use, the deeper into the soil sinks cesium, a radioactive, metallic fission product that fell from the sky with fallout particles spewed by atomic bomb testing in nearby Nevada a generation ago.

title: POPE EASES STAND ON GENETICS
description: Pope John Paul II, tempering previous criticism of genetic engineering, said today that the transfer and mutation of genes was worthwhile if it was aimed at curing hereditary diseases or increasing food supplies.

title: Speak Truth
description: In another study of the medical profession, a poll revealed that four out of five Americans believe that signed consent forms required for hospital treatment are a legal maneuver to protect doctors. The report, fourth in a series by the President's Commission for the Study of Ethical Problems in Medicine and Biomedical and Behavior Research, criticized physicians for withholding bad news.

title: BACKLOG SLOWING DRIVER ROAD TESTS
description: GETTING a New Jersey driver's license used to run smoothly: Take a course of instruction, pass a written test and, after the 20-day mandatory waiting period, take a 15-minute road test at one of the state's 21 driver-qualification centers.

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN TROUNCES NORTHWESTERN, 49-14

title: RUNNING ON CRIME CAN GET SLIPPERY
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the Democrat, talks about muggers as the ''midnight mayors of the metropolis.'' Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican, has spoken of criminals as ''savages'' and drug pushers as ''vermin.'' Mr. Lehrman accuses Mr. Cuomo of being ''soft on crime.'' Mr. Cuomo says Mr. Lehrman's proposals won't work.

title: FANS OF THE MACABRE TO MEET AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN THE horrible, the weird, the ghastly and the bizarre will be celebrated next weekend in New Haven, when some 750 people flock to the Park Plaza Hotel for the eighth annual World Fantasy Convention.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE TWO BIG AUCTIONS THIS WEEK
description: Hundreds of leading coin collectors and dealers will gather this week in the ballroom of the St. Moritz Hotel in New York for two major auction sales starting Wednesday night.

title: Turkish Generals Unveil Their Plan
description: Turkey's ruling generals last week approved a new constitution that would keep Gen. Kenan Evren in power until the end of the decade, then promptly forbade ''criticism in any shape, form or manner'' of key parts of the proposed charter.

title: THE DANCE: CEMENT TO SOUFFLES
description: There are times when the performance art in vogue today takes the plunge into sheer narcissism. One of those times was Friday, when Richard Biles performed his ''If You Can Mix Cement, You Can Make a Souffle, or the Art of the Building Trades'' at his Chelsea studiotheater.

title: City Government Jobs in U.S.  Reported Down 3.6% in Year
description: Employment by city governments dropped by more than 90,000 between 1980 and 1981, the Census Bureau has reported. There were 3.6 percent fewer city workers in 1981, although payrolls rose by 9.5 percent.

title: WHEN IS A JUNKYARD NOT A JUNKYARD?
description: OCEANSIDE FIFTY families living here on pleasant tree-lined streets in wellmaintained homes that back on the Goelet Grand Canal have been complaining to the Town of Hempstead about ''debris, ground glass in the streets, rat infestation and continual noise'' emanating, they say, from across the canal, where operators of industrial yards ply their trade.

title: PENN DEFEATS YALE
description: Penn, cheered on by a boisterous homecoming day crowd, defeated Yale, 27-14, at Franklin Field today to retain first place in the Ivy League.

title: DIFFERENCES ON BILL ON CONVERSIONS
description: Differences on Bill On Conversions

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: SUMMITT By William P. McGivern. 491 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95.

title: Kean Ponders Meditation Bill
description: However interested lawmakers in New Jersey may be in legislating morality, Governor Kean appears disinclined to litigate it. So it seemed last week, as a bill requiring silent meditation in the state's public schools won the Legislature's blessing but, so far, not the Governor's.

title: 'Not a Word'
description: To the Business Editor: I was an asbestos worker. Recent articles and commentary in The New York Times discuss whether the Manville Corporation could, or should, or would get away with the bankruptcy maneuver to avoid paying compensation to those injured (or to their next of kin, when they die).

title: PEACE CORPS IS TO GO INTO HAITI FOR FIRST TIME
description: The Peace Corps is planning to send volunteers to Haiti for the first time in the agency's 21-year history, according to officials of the organization.

title: 'OLD GIRL' NETWORK DRAWS 200 TO THE Y
description: WHITE PLAINS ''WOMEN need their version of an 'old boy' network,'' said Grace Wasserman, director of the Vistas for Women program, at a recent conference sponsored by her agency and the Y.W.C.A. of White Plains and Central Westchester. The yearly Contact Network Conference, designed to provide women with a way to make business connections, is part of a three-year-old program that includes monthly meetings, career counseling and life-planning programs.

title: CABARET: MARTA SANDERS
description: Marta Sanders, a singer whose warm eyes and dark hair indicate her Latin heritage (half Argentine, half Texan), has such an easy presence during her performance at Sweetwaters, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, that she can make even her throwaway songs seem important. There is no pushing, no overemphasis in her singing, but, instead, an assurance and relaxation that come from confidence in what she is doing.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BICYCLE MAN Written and illustrated by Allen Say. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin/Parnassus. $12.45. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: NEW YORKERS TO VOTE NOV. 2 ON PROPOSAL FOR A CITY UTILITY
description: New York City voters will decide on Election Day whether to establish a municipal utility to buy and distribute power at a slight saving to city residents.

title: CRIME
description: Roy Harley Lewis, not to be confused with another British mystery writer named Roy Lewis, recently started a series centering on a bookseller named Matthew Coll. Coll is somewhat different from most of his breed: He is a former secret agent. That gave him all of the credentials needed to solve his first case, ''A Cracking of Spines.'' Now there is THE MANUSCRIPT MURDERS (St. Martin's, $10.95).

title: A DIZZYING TIME FOR ALL SAVERS
description: NEVER has there been a more difficult time for the saver. After years of roaring inflation ushered in enticing new high interestpaying savings instruments, the world has suddenly changed. A year ago, banks would pay up to 16 percent on some fully insured deposits. Now, with inflation becalmed, interest rates for savers are moving down-and fast. Last week, the highest banks would pay on fully insured deposits was about 9 percent.

title: Patrick Campbell to Become Carpenters' Union President
description: Patrick J. Campbell will become general president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners on Nov. 1, succeeding William Konyha, who is retiring.

title: GREEKS ARE VOTING IN RUNOFF BALLOT
description: The second round of municipal elections in Greece is to be held Sunday, and the governing Socialist Party is expected to win decisively with the help of the Communists, even though the two parties are sharply at odds on national policy.

title: JAMMED FREEWAYS LEAD SUNBELT TO MASS TRANSIT
description: They grew with a wild abandon, metastasizing into the deserts and swamps around them. They are the great new cities of the South and West, whose very urban existence and give-me-elbowroom style of life has depended on the ubiquitous automobile. Traffic congestion? Build another freeway.

title: THE ART OF DINNER CONVERSATION
description: Audrey del Rosario, who entertains constantly and quite formally, both in her New York apartment and her house in Jamaica, thought she'd have a fit one evening when her dinner guests got into four separate and heated political discussions.

title: SWEDISH FEAST
description: With a style unequaled by most hostesses, Ulla Wachtmeister, wife of the Swedish Ambassador, has made an invitation to that embassy one of the most coveted in official Washington, a city where the powerful turn down three or four invitations for every one they accept.

title: Barbara Feathers and J. Hunter Mackintosh Wed
description: Barbara Feathers, daughter of Lieut. Col. John Feathers, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Feathers of Harlow, England, was married yesterday to J. Hunter Mackintosh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Mac Intosh of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee Jr. performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE REFERENDUM: 'NO'
description: TWO decades ago, I was a member of a group of students in New York City who worked for the cause of nuclear freeze. We weren't very many and we weren't very loud. Obviously, we weren't very effective. But we believed. I have been taught - and I still believe - that the most democratic form of government is the town meeting or the constituent referendum. I have been sure for some time that to publicly oppose the idea of nuclear freeze now is, in an unsecured legislative district, unmitigated political folly.

title: Susan Kohlmann Wed To Michael H. Orbison
description: Susan Kohlmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Kohlmann of Riverdale, the Bronx, and South Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green to Michael Harris Orbison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tucker Orbison of Lewisburg, Pa. Family Court Judge Richard M. Palmer performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT WILL SELL BONDS FOR FINANCING AIRPORT RENOVATIONS
description: The State Bond Commission gave final approval Friday to the sale of $100 million in revenue bonds to finance a major improvement project at the state's largest airport.

title: 'DEAD' BILL TO CURB UTILITY PLANTS IS REVIVED IN THE ASSEMBLY
description: TRENTON ABILL calling for a panel to review the controversial Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant in Salem County is expected to come up for a vote in the Assembly tomorrow. Until recently, the measure had been considered dead.

title: BERNSTEIN'S 'CANDIDE' IS BACK AS A WINNER
description: The return of poor, abused ''Candide'' from the land of the dead and near-dead, a journey that has taken 26 years and may not yet be at an end, has to be one of the most heartening stories in the history of American theater. The success that the Leonard Bernstein musical is enjoying at the New York City Opera these days was built on a foundation of faith, hope and perhaps a little charity. Those of us who love the score are protective of it and eager to overlook flaws, as true cultists always are. We are even willing to swallow hard and allow the possibility that the revision and restoration of the work places it squarely in the operatic-singspiel tradition.

title: Cynthia Williams to Be a Bride Nov. 27
description: Cynthia Allen Williams, Washington correspondent for the Financial Times of London newsletters, and Howard Lee Solsbery, deputy director of the State of Texas Office of State-Federal Relations in Washington, plan to be married Nov. 27.

title: POTATO FEST
description: The once-lowly potato is lowly no more; figuratively speaking, that is. It is now the object of such esteem that Suffolk County's Farm and Education Center in Yaphank is staging a Potato Festival today devoted solely to the ubiquitous spud. From 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. the farm will be the site of various activities celebrating the versatile vegetable: From performances of folk-music odes to the potato; to a potato recipe contest (with The Times' Craig Claiborne as one of the judges); to ''Spud Sports'' events; to demonstrations of the potato's nutritional and culinary charms; to the free disbursement of the baked variety, heaped with butter. The farm is on Yaphank Avenue, off Exit 66 of the Long Island Expressway, and the Potato Festival is free of charge, if not of calories.

title: D.M. THOMAS ON HIS PUSHKIN
description: To the Editor:$

title: A REVIVAL
description: With the figure of Puck looking on from his perch above the doorway, the restoration of the building that still bears his name is nearing completion. Once the home of the satirical Puck magazine, the 1885 Greek Revival building at Houston and Lafayette Streets will soon be offered to artists, designers and architects as a ''prestige'' location for their offices, according to Peter Gee, a commercial artist and designer of the $6 million restoration.

title: Male Chauvinist Dog
description: The animal kingdom, or at least that part populated by dogs and cats, is rife with misalliances. But it is rare, maybe even unique, for the male of the species to be punished for promiscuity.

title: THE ECONOMIST AS PREACHER
description: Last week, George J. Stigler, a professor at the University of Chicago Business School, was awarded the 1982 Nobel Memorial Prize for Economic Sciences for his research in the fields of industrial structure and government regulation. The tall, 71-year-old professor, noted among his colleagues for both his sharp wit and his passion for the marketplace, recently completed his 13th book, ''The Economist as Preacher, and Other Essays.'' It will be published in December by the University of Chicago Press. Excerpts from the book follow. ECONOMISTS seldom address ethical questions as they impinge on e conomic theory or economic behavior. They (and I) find the subject c omplex and elusive in comparison with the relative precision and o bjectivity of economic analysis. Of course the ethical questions arei nescapable: One must have goals in judging policies, and these g oals will certainly have ethical content, however well concealed it m ay be. These lectures will explore some of the problems raised by e thical questions, using the history of economics as an important v ehicle in the exploration....

title: KEY WORDS STILL MISSING
description: Nearly two months after President Reagan called for ''a fresh start'' toward achieving peace between Arabs and Israelis, senior Administration officials were encouraged to assert last week that the American initiative was very much alive. But there was no major breakthrough and still no certainty the underlying American objective - broadening Arab-Israeli peace talks to include Jordan to speak for the Palestinians -would be achieved. There was also no indication of an early solution to the most pressing Middle East problem, the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces from Lebanon.

title: RITCHIE EXCELS AGAIN FOR 5-0 PARK RIDGE
description: Mike Ritchie, a senior fullback, rushed for more than 130 yards for the third straight game and scored three touchdowns as Park Ridge beat Newark West Side, 42-8, in Park Ridge.

title: BOLIVIA'S SEESAW POLITICS BRINGS BACK THE OUTCASTS
description: Political change can be rapid in Bolivia, which has averaged more than one government a year in its 157-year history. But, a Western diplomat said, musing on recent events, ''It can reverse itself just as fast.''

title: Gymnast's Suit Settled
description: William Lockard, a Stanford gymnast who sued the university for $18 million after he became crippled in a 1979 trampoline accident, has settled out of court.

title: SAUSAGES, 'SOLITUDE' AND A NOBEL
description: THERE was dancing in the streets of Macondo last week when they learned of Gabriel Garcia Marquez's Nobel Prize for Literature. Or perhaps flowers rained from the sky.

title: DROP IN U.S. ARMS SPURS DEBATE ON MILITARY POLICY
description: In the last 30 years the United States has spent $2,300 billion on the military, but the numbers of planes, ships, tanks, guns and most other nonnuclear weapons in the nation's arsenal have declined.

title: AN INN FIT FOR A QUEEN
description: ANDREE BROOKS is a regular contributor to The Times.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Accused In Injuries to 55
description: Two teen-age boys, apparently enraged over taunts and a thrown apple core, beat youngsters in a schoolyard, setting off a panic that left 55 children injured, the police said.

title: S.M.U. TOPS TEXAS TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: At the end, it was not the surprising new look of Southern Methodist University's Pony Express - with the senior tailbacks Eric Dickerson and Craig James lining up together in a power formation - that led the Mustangs to their wild 30-17 victory over Texas today at Memorial Stadium.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Two unusual and very different musical events are competing for attention this week in New York. On Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, the Group for Contemporary Music will celebrate Conlon Nancarrow's 70th birthday with two of his works - the String Quartet and the Study No. 41 for player piano.

title: 'MORNING SICKNESS' AND LIVER MAY BE LINKED, STUDY FINDS
description: ''Morning sickness,'' probably the most common and least studied problem of pregnant women, often lasts longer and hurts more than most male doctors realize and is certainly not limited to the morning, a Swedish study concludes.

title: TWIN ATTACK ON URBAN DECAY
description: THE SALE of $85 million in bonds to revitalize depressed urban centers - a sale that voters will be asked to authorize next week - is frequently associated with pending legislation to establish Urban Enterprise Zones.

title: 434 Audubon Works Fetch $1.5 Million
description: Art collectors and investors purchased 434 American bird engravings from a rare set by John James Audubon for a record $1,541,265 in a two-day auction last weekend.

title: CAPSIZED TRIMARAN CHANGES THINKING
description: In the North Atlantic storm, the Gonzo, a 60-foot trimaran, was running before the wind under a storm staysail and towing lines to slow down. Then a 30-foot wave threw the boat on its side and a second wave broke on top of it, covering the helmsman and the cockpit with water. Seconds later the Gonzo was floating upside down 350 miles southeast of Nantucket Island.

title: WEST POINT CHOIR
description: The West Point Cadet Jewish Choir under the direction of Ronald Fine is made up of 15 of the 49 cadets who make up the Jewish undergraduate group at the United States Military Academy at West Point, which has a student body of about 4,500. The choir will give a performance at 11 A.M. next Sunday at the Westchester Jewish Center, at Rockland and Palmer Avenues in Mamaroneck.

title: AN INVITING STOP FOR THE WAYFARER
description: NEWTOWN THERE'S something especially inviting about stopping for dinner at a country inn after an afternoon of foliage viewing. That was our goal recently as we drove through the hills and valleys around Bethel and Danbury. Presto, there it was, an inn unknown to us - Hawley Manor Inn. The outside conformed to preconceived standards: a rambling, gray clapboard house with white trim.

title: Six Are Hurt in Times Square As Cars in Crash Jump Curb
description: Six persons were hurt last night when two cars crashed and jumped the curb at 44th Street in Times Square and scattered a crowd of evening strollers, the police said.

title: 'FIND THE LIBRARY BEFORE THE LOCKER ROOM'
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: largest oil company in the country, has designed an educational kit that is being used in high schools in the metropolitan area. The kit, which includes a company ''Report to America's Youth,'' teaching aids and student handouts, provides a simplified, yet detailed analysis of the functioning of big business and of the petroleum industry in particular.

title: PRESERVATION FOR PROFIT
description: In a quest for some sort of ''wildlife elitism,'' persons at the forefront of ''conservation'' groups speak a bureaucratic lingo.

title: Test of Friendships
description: His Chinese hosts may have planned a few free lunches for visiting magazine pubisher Malcolm Forbes, but no free flights.

title: GEMAYEL BOWS ON WORLD STAGES
description: Lebanese President Amin Gemayel was asking for big numbers last week - a tenfold increase in the 3,400-man force of American, French and Italian peacekeepers plus 12 billion aid dollars to repair his country's tattered sovereignty. His requests made during six days of visits to President Reagan and French and Italian leaders, got a friendly but initially noncommittal reception in Washington, where the World Bank was organizing an aid consortium of Arab and Western lenders.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FIVE SPARROWS A Japanese Folktale. Adapted and illustrated by Patricia Montgomery Newton. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Donna W. Schulze Bride Of James Ballard in Illinois
description: Donna Wilson Schulze, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin E. Schulze of Mettawa, Ill., was married yesterday to James Richard Ballard, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Ballard of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. M. Clairborne Bell performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: 'STREETCAR' MAGIC SURVIVES
