description: STAMFORD ''THE enemy time,'' one of Tennessee Williams's quintessential phrases, reflects one of the playwright's timeless themes. With respect to his master work ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' time has turned around, been benevolent. Its kindness, like that of strangers, has enriched and magnified the play's poetry, power and glory.

title:
OPINION;
VOLUNTEERISM AND THE PRIDE OF A SMALL TOWN
description: CAN a small (pop. 7,500) Connecticut town, which has secured more than 1,000 acres of open space in 15 years by putting up $1.3 million of its own money as a match for Federal financing from the Department of the Interior, persuade James Watt, Secretary of the Interior, to join in a celebration of this successful partnership between the Federal Government and local leadership?

title: FLUTIE PACES BOSTON COLLEGE OVER ARMY
description: Amid the color and beauty of the autumn here on the banks of the Hudson, Boston College continued its string of successes by defeating Army, 32-17, before a capacity crowd of 40,397 on homecoming day at Michie Stadium.

title: BILLY MARTIN: LOSER WHO'S IN DEMAND;
description: BILLY MARTIN is available. Again. In any other profession, Billy Martin would be branded a loser, somebody who can't hold a job, somebody who creates more problems than he solves. But as a baseball manager, he somehow seems to be exempt from that stigma. Instead of being ostracized for his tendency to self-destruct, he is glorified for his history of turning a team into a contender as soon as he takes command.

title: RESTAURATEUR'S HOLIDAY
description: How does the proprietor of one of Manhattan's most prestigious and attractive restaurants entertain at Christmas? ''Very simply,'' says Gisele Masson, owner of La Grenouille. ''I'm never formal. I like to create a homelike atmosphere, unhurried and relaxed.''

title: CASSETTES APPEAL TO THE TASTE FOR MARATHON MUSIC
description: Paul Kresh writes frequently about recordings.

title: ...AND TRYING TO PUT IT BACK
description: Among the new technologies that arcade game manufacturers are counting on to generate new consumer enthusiasm are three-dimensional games and those incorporating the videodisk.

title: 'HYSTERIA' AMONG POSSIBLE CAUSES OF ILLNESS OF 125 AT GAME ON COAST
description: The police said today that copper sulfate inside a soft drink dispenser was the apparent cause of the illness of about 125 people at a high school football game Friday night.

title: THE SPIRIT OF SACRIFICE EBBS AMONG BONN'S RICH UNIONS
description: Last month, as Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's coalition stumbled toward its bickering demise, the rich and powerful German Labor Union Federation determined that it was time to flex its muscles against proposed cuts in the welfare budget. But the Schmidt government fell and was replaced by a center-right one led by Helmut Kohl. Without missing a beat, the union federation decided to go forward this weekend with the planned anti-Schmidt demonstrations in Frankfurt, Nuremberg and Dortmund - but now against Mr. Kohl.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Ones-of-a-Kind At Dobbs Ferry

title: CANNON'S FOE RUNS A RESTRAINED RACE
description: After Chic Hecht, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, finished his short speech to the Lake Tahoe Republican Women's Club, one of the questions was about Senator Howard W. Cannon's voting record.

title: A Frustrating Murder Case
description: In January the Reagan Administration must certify to Congress that El Salvador is improving human rights as a condition for continued aid. But last week American Embassy officials had to express frustration with the way Salvadoran justice seemed to want not to cooperate.

title: ST. JOSEPH ROLLS, 28-7
description: St. Joseph High of Trumbull, unbeaten in five games, defeated previously unbeaten Fairfield Prep, 28-7, in a Metro Bridgeport Conference game in Trumbull. New Canaan (4-1) surprised Greenwich, 18-8, in an inter-divisional Fairfield County Conference game at the losers' field.

title: DEFENSE TAKES 2 APPROACHES IN BRINK'S CASE
description: In five weeks of pretrial hearings into last October's $1.6 million Brink's robbery and triple slaying, two distinct themes have emerged from the defense team for Kathy Boudin as it confronts eyewitnesses against her.

title: UNEMPLOYED FEEL THE PAIN: ELDERLY EXPRESS THE WORRY
description: Ronald Reagan, at age 71, is the oldest person to serve as President of the United States. But increasingly, the elderly and their concerns are causing political difficulty for him, his Administration and some of his Republican allies running for Congress this fall.

title: CANDIDATES RELYING ON COSTLY AIR TIME
description: HARTFORD THE brief television commercial shows Representative Toby Moffett, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, walking toward the camera and talking about his working-class background and his support for Social Security.

title: No Headline
description: Holy Cross 17, Brown 6

title: PREPS
description: Northfield-Mount Hermon picked a good day to play its best game of the season. It was Parents Weekend at the Massachusetts school, and the home team put on a show in defeating its state rival, Andover, 23-7.

title: Missed Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: BROILED FARE WITH LITTLE FUSS
description: SEVERAL months ago, Ma Chaumiere opened in a bright, trim little house a short distance from the center of Smithtown. It makes a sincere effort to prepare and serve a varied selection of provincial and classic French dishes, but the results are generally short of satisfactory.

title: KAren A. Sulzberger Is Wed To Eric Martin Arthur Lax
description: Karen Alden Sulzberger of Washington, daughter of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York and Barbara Grant Johnson of Topeka, Kan., was married in Stamford, Conn., last evening to Eric Martin Arthur Lax of New York, son of Dorothy Lax of Lakeside, Calif., and the late Rev. John Martin Lax.

title: Recent Sales
description: Closter $115,000 80 Carlson Court *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old bilevel; *2*new patio, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,214. Edison $85,000 3 Barbara Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old split-level; *2*in-ground pool, central air conditioning; taxes $1,600. Emerson $84,000 133 Hartland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; *2*newroof, den; taxes $1,810. Totowa $58,500 76 Green Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*porch, 1-car garage; taxes $900. Wayne $92,000 150 Lake Drive East *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; central air-conditioning, *2*2 rooms and bath in basement, patio; taxes $1,934. Highland Park $134,900 44 North Seventh Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; *2*slate roof, fireplace, family room in basement; taxes $3,562. OTHER AREAS Port Chester, N.Y. $118,000 30 Argyle Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 52-year-old frame Cape Cod; *2*screened porch, family room; taxes $1,879. Darien, Conn. $245,000 11 Duffy Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 92-year-old converted carriage house; *2*large deck, half an acre, taxes $2,244. Oceanside, L.I. $56,000 75 Merle Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, *2*full basement, aluminum siding; taxes $1,200.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 1880, edited and translated by Francis Steegmuller. (Belknap/Harvard University Press, $15.)

title: JEFFERSON DEFEATS LAFAYETTE
description: After being stung by a 15-yard first-period field goal by Steve Sharpe, Jefferson roared back to down Lafayette, 36-11, and knock the Redmen from the ranks of the undefeated in the Brooklyn A-Division battle for first place.

title: No Headline
description: As Clifford May suggests, it seems to be the haphazard destruction of animal habitats for a burgeoning human population which is responsible for the increasing loss of wildlife rather than hunting or managed cropping of indigenous species.

title: RED RULERS AND BLACK HUMOR
description: THE JOKE By Milan Kundera. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 267 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: WHERE OYSTERS ABOUND
description: Wherever you turn in St. Marys County you find a midden of oyster shells. To Bob Shaw, the garrulous naturalist who manages the Chancellor's Point Natural History Center near St. Marys City in this historic, unpretentious, often bypassed corner of southern Maryland, the reason is simple: ''People have been eating oysters here for 10,000 years.''

title: COUNTY GIVEN GOOD REPORT ON ECONOMY
description: BOLSTERED by a stable labor force and a relatively low level of unemployment, the county's economy will remain strong during 1983, according to projections made by the state's Department of Labor. However, despite that optimistic outlook, department analysts and others caution that the factors that have worked to the county's advantage during the present recession may not provide long-term insulation from adverse economic conditions.

title: L.I.U. Soccer Victor
description: Derrick Lewis headed in a pass from Mickey Kydes at 7 minutes 45 seconds of overtime to give Long Island University a 2-1 soccer victory over Oneonta State at the winner's field in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: EASTERN MICHIGAN FAILS AGAIN
description: DeKALB, Ill., Oct. 23 - To his regret, David Pappas, the hypnotist for the Eastern Michigan University football team, was unable to accompany the squad here today for its attempt at breaking its losing streak at 25 games. The streak reached 26, the nation's longest, with a 10-0 defeat by Northern Illinois.

title: RUNNING FOR FITNESS IS FINE, BUT MORE MUST BE DONE
description: OVER the last 10 years running has become extremely popular in the United States. It is probably more popular here than in any other country in the world. We should all applaud this because it has been primarily responsible for getting millions of Americans involved in a healthy exercise program. This has probably been at least partly responsible for the reduction in the death rate due to heart attacks and other hypokinetic diseases.

title: The Wimp Era
description: For a long time, the common way to insult a politician was to call him a ''turkey.'' Republicans used to ridicule Jimmy Carter, for instance, by asking, ''Why does the President's staff always carry a frozen turkey on Air Force One?'' Answer: ''spare parts.'' But then came a change in fashion. ''Wimp'' became the political pejorative of choice.

title: TOXINS ARE FOUND IN BASS IN HUDSON
description: Striped bass in the Hudson River contain dangerous levels of toxic chemicals, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation, and the department has continued its ban on commercial fishing in the river.

title: COOKING GAME
description: Southern-born CeCe Kieselstein-Cord is a vegetarian, but that doesn't stop her from being an expert on cooking wild fowl. ''People tell me that my roast wild duck is the best they've ever had,'' she says. ''I'm sure glad they think so, but you couldn't prove it by me.''

title: Katharine Bennett Wed to Steven Nelson Johnson
description: The marriage of Katharine Carlyle Bennett, daughter of Mrs. Alfred McDowell Bennett of Wilton, Conn., and the late Dr. Bennett, to Steven Nelson Johnson took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Guthrie T. Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Sara Hunt Wed To T.A. Finch 3d
description: Sara Elizabeth Hunt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Jack Hunt of High Point, N.C., was married yesterday to Thomas Austin Finch 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Finch Jr., of Thomasville, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: 10TH ANNIVERSARIES AND SOME OPENERS
description: IN 1973, the fledgling Performers of Connecticut Inc., decided on a project that would seek out talented young musicians and provide them with performing opportunities. Now established as one of the prime movers in Connecticut cultural circles, the organization is celebrating its 10th anniversary with an alumni concert next Sunday at 4 P.M. in the Westport Town Hall Auditorium.

title: BALANCING RISK AND REWARD IN OPTIONS
description: ADYNAMIC of most bull markets is that as volume on the stock e xchanges increases, so does volume in options trading. To the i nfrequent investor as well as the experienced trader, the attractiono f options is that, with a relatively small pool of cash, they can p articipate in a myriad of investment strategies, particularly a ppropriate in a volatile market.

title: A MUSEUM MARKS ITS FIRST 400 YEARS
description: After the Louvre, the Uffizi in Florence is perhaps the most famous of all picture galleries. As we turn off the Piazza della Signoria and approach the entrance under Vasari's celebrated colonnade, one great picture after another comes to our minds. In the first room, we tell ourselves, we shall find the most impressive of Giotto's panel paintings, in the second we shall find Simone Martini's ''Annunciation'' from the Duomo in Siena, and thereafter there will follow Gentile da Fabriano's legendary ''Adoration of the Magi,'' Uccello's ''Rout of San Romano'' and Botticelli's ''Birth of Venus,'' portraits by Piero della Francesca, a mysterious unfinished altarpiece by Leonardo, Michelangelo's Doni tondo and Titians from Urbino. Indeed, if one were asked to name the most popular and widely known Italian paintings, they could well prove one and all to be the property of the Uffizi.

title: Lowell Amey Is Bride
description: Lowell Stewart Amey, daughter of Mrs. Francis Lowell Amey of New York and Southhampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Amey, was married yesterday to Theodore Charles Schultz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schultz of London. The Rev. Darwin Kirby Jr., the bride's godfather, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. The bride, is merchandising editor at Mademoiselle magazine. Mr. Schultz is an account executive for Katz Communications Inc. in New York.

title: SHOOTING OF JENNIFER O'NEILL IS BELIEVED ACCIDENTAL
description: The shooting of the actress Jennifer O'Neill Friday night in a second-floor bedroom of her home here was probably accidental, the police said today, but the circumstances remained a mystery.

title: A Blight Unseen
description: Question: I took title to a one-family house less than two months ago. Before the closing, I neglected to check out all the plumbing, and I am now faced with a stall shower that does not work. A plumber advised me that it would cost $800 to repair because it was intentionally sealed off to prevent a leak to the floor below. Since it appears that they misled me at the time of the sale by hiding this defect, do I have any recourse at this time against the sellers? ... J.S., Flushing, Queens Answer: Buyers do not always have recourse against defects after a deed has been transferred. Howard Goldson, counsel to the Long Island Board of Realtors, suggests that you consult a lawyer. If the plumbing problem was concealed, you could have grounds for a suit. If you do not have an lawyer, call the Queens Bar Association (291-4500), which will refer you to a lawyer who will charge $25 for a half-hour consultation.

title: NEW YORK: SHAPING UP
description: Given the state of the economy and the generally rocky condition of retail trade nationwide, one might expect America's top designers to soft-pedal into next season with safe silhouettes and well-proven solutions. But, in fact, just the opposite is the case. The fashion professionals now in New York for the spring and summer 1983 ready-to-wear showings instead will find - at least at most of the trendsetting, highest-priced levels - collections of clothes that are strong on new, markedly curvy silhouettes and on buoyant colors, with almost everything accented by catchy details.

title: Ann Smith to Be Wed
description: Ann Guthrie Smith and Philip Francis Rizzuto Jr. plan to be married Nov. 20 in Charleston, S.C. The future bride is the daughter of Mrs. Charles Joseph Miller of Kiawah Island, S.C., and the late William Faber Smith Jr. Mr. Rizzuto is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rizzuto of Hillside, N.J. His father, the former Yankee shortstop, is radio and television broadcaster for the New York Yankees.

title: LEHRMAN PREPARES FOR NEXT 3 DEBATES
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, declaring for the first time that he expects to win his race for governor, campaigned yesterday in a predominately Italian neighborhood of Brooklyn while his opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman, studied for three debates that are scheduled for today and tomorrow.

title: NORTHPORT GAINS TIE
description: Alan Squeri completed a 45-yard scoring pass to Craig McEwen, and Sarko Yepremian kicked his third extra point with 5:40 left to play to enable Northport to tie Sachem, 21-21, in League I.

title: RX FOR SWAYING SKYSCRAPERS
description: SINCE the 1950's, architects have, for both economic and esthetic r easons, stripped stone and masonry from skyscrapers and replaced r igid steel frames with lighter, more flexible frames made of s tronger steel. As a consequence, they have created buildings that s way in the wind.

title: HOT LINE CUTS DRUG FRAUDS
description: HACKENSACK MINUTES after the news broke on the Extra-Strength Tylenol deaths,- pharmacies in Bergen County began removing the drug from their shelves. They had been told to do so by the Bergen County Pharmaceutical Hot Line, which links drugstores in the county.

title: LACK OF RULING DELAYS FORMS FOR STUDENT AID
description: A delay in a ruling on a lawsuit filed against the Federal Department of Education will further hold up the printing and distribution of financial-aid forms for the 1983-84 school year, according to education officials.

title: UNBEATEN PITT TOPS STUBBORN SYRACUSE
description: Considering their records, 5-0 against 1-5, and the matchup of quarterbacks, Dan Marino against two freshmen, the Pittsburgh-Syracuse game in the Carrier Dome today might well have been programmed as a rout for the Panthers.

title: CANDIDATES VIE FOR 'CABINET'
description: WHILE the candidates for State Attorney General debated recently in the Old State House, about 15 people watched them. Rivals in the Lieutenant Governor race did not fare much better last week when they drew some 60 people to their debate in Torrington.

title: MEDIATOR RECESSES TALKS IN N.F.L.
description: The latest round of the National Football League labor negotiations ended today, and not unexpectedly. Sam Kagel, the 73-year-old private mediator who joined the talks 12 days ago, recessed them, suggesting that the parties ''re-examine and reassess'' their positions on the issues perpetuating a strike now 33 days old.

title: DIVERSE FACTIONS OF DEMOCRATIC PARTY SEEK CONSENSUS ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: As they strive to make economic issues a winning combination for the Nov. 2 Congressional elections, the longdivided Democrats may be working toward an opposition economic policy for the next Congress and the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: CBS Is Sorry
description: Politicians have a tough time proving libel, not necessarily because so much of what is said about them is true, but because the law makes it tougher for ''public figures'' to collect. It was a bit surprising, then, when CBS settled out of court last week with Philadelphia Mayor William J. Green. Mr. Green charged that CBS libeled him in March when it reported that he was under Federal investigation.

title: ALICE TULLY LOOKS BACK ON A BUSY LIFE IN MUSIC
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center opens its 14th season today in Alice Tully Hall, and the occasion also will see a kind of party - a tribute to Miss Tully on her 80th birthday (the actual birthdate is Sept. 11, 1902). That is only fitting, in view of the fact that it was Miss Tully who provided a good part of the funds for the hall named after her, and was also instrumental in the formation of the Chamber Music Society.

title: MET MUSEUM, VIOLS AND HARPSICHORD
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has gradually established itself as one of this city's leading purveyors of early music. Thursday night in the Grace Rainey Rodgers Auditorium, the museum opened its fall season of such concerts with an exquisite offering of music for viols and harpsichord by four contemporary masters of these early instruments and performing styles.

title: THE CARNEGIE INTERNATIONAL LACKS A CUTTING EDGE
description: PITTSBURGH The Carnegie International, Steel City's answer to Documenta and the Venice Biennale, hasn't looked as ''international'' as this for many years. With nearly 200 examples of painting and sculpture from 27 countries, including Japan, Brazil, Sweden and even New Zealand (besides, of course, the United States), the current, 48th edition of this hallowed triennial is a very different animal from those of the last decade or so. The big show was disrupted, between 1970 and 1977, not only by financial malnutrition but by construction of the Sarah Scaife Gallery of the Carnegie Institute's Museum of Art (in which it is now housed). And then its format was controversially altered by the museum's retired director, Leon A. Arkus, so that it served for a while as a vehicle for one- and two-artist retrospectives: of Pierre Alechinsky, Eduardo Chillida and Willem de Kooning.

title: PENN STATE POSTS 24-0 VICTORY
description: Penn State, which has not lost to West Virginia since 1955, today extended the nation's longest domination by one major team over another as the Nittany Lions defeated the Mountaineers, 24-0.

title: LASTING 'TEMPTATIONS'
description: The Temptations, perhaps the best loved of all the Motown groups of the 60's, will present a concert at the Ritz Theater in Elizabeth at 8 P.M. Thursday. Back with the group again after more than a decade are David Ruffin (absent for 14 years) and Eddie Kendricks (gone for 11).

title: Cardinal of Florence Has a Heart Attack
description: Giovanni Cardinal Benelli of Florence, one of the most influential Roman Catholic prelates, was in critical condition today after an acute heart attack, doctors said.

title: FAIR-WEATHER FRIENDS
description: BIG BUSINESS AND PRESIDENTIAL POWER From FDR to Reagan. By Kim McQuaid. 383 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.50.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing today in The Guide, section 2A, for a concert by the Opera Orchestra of New York is outdated be- cause of the tenor's illness. The solo- ists at Carnegie Hall Thursday will be Matteo Manuguerra, baritone, and Marina Krilovici, soprano.

title: ART TOUR OF ITALY, HOOFBEATS IN ARIZONA; The Renaissance Revisited
description: On the day after Christmas, a flight leaves from Kennedy Airport, bound for Rome -and beyond Rome, into the world of Fra Angelico, Raphael, Michelangelo, Ghiberti, Donatello, Bernini and Titian.

title: STATE EFFORT TO SAVE FARMS GAINS STRENGTH
description: CONNECTICUT'S cautious effort over the last four years to preserve at least some of the state's best farmland for future generations is expected to be strengthened at the next session of the General Assembly, according to key lawmakers.

title: FARMER BROWN TAKES REINS
description: TRENTON WHEN Phillip Alampi, who had been New Jersey's Secretary of Agriculture for 26 years, made it known that he was going to step down, people said he would be a hard act to follow. Through four administrations, Mr. Alampi had built up a reputation as a colorful promoter of the farming industry.

title: Testers Find Strong Acid In a Bottle of Eye Drops
description: The eye drop solution from a bottle of Visine A.C. purchased in the Washington area was replaced entirely with a solution of ''rather strong'' hydrochloric acid, causing temporary eye damage to a suburban woman, the Food and Drug Administration said tonight.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Last week's debut recitals in New York were unusually rich. Three were of outstanding quality, one showed promise for the future, and two more were solidly professional. One concert, on the other hand, should have probably never taken place.

title: SMOKE DETECTORS: HOW THEY SHOULD BE POSITIONED IN A HOME
description: ALTHOUGH smoke detectors are required in all multiple-family dwellings in many cities, as well as in newly built single-family homes, many existing homes and apartments still do not have them - even though all fire experts agree that many lives could be saved each year if smoke detectors were installed in every residence.

title: YOUTH HAS ITS DAY AS MOVIES FACE REALITY
description: As the toys in the children's bedrooms seen in the Hollywood films of my youth seemed never to have been played with, the children themselves appeared to be untouched by time or misuse, forever arrested at some mythical age that combined bright-eyed, childish innocence with knock-'em-dead, show-business savvy.

title: At Last, There's Joy In North Philadelphia
description: For years, Thomas Edison High School had known all sorts of futility on the football field.

title: TITANIUM'S WEAKNESSES
description: After four years of prosperity, 1982 has brought hard times for manufacturers of titanium, a light, strong and corrosion-resistant metal that is a key material for the aerospace and nuclear power industries.

title: Amazon
description: To the Editor: In reference to Edwin McDowell's article ''The Sorcery of the Amazon'' (Travel, Sept. 19), I would like to make a few additional comments based on a journey I made from Belem to Manaus in January 1981.

title: NEW LINKS FOR OLD
description: In keeping with the trend toward housing developments with a recreational theme, Jack Nicklaus, championship golfer and no slouch at other profit-making enterprises, will preside tomorrow at groundbreaking ceremonies to start the redevelopment of the St. Andrews golf club in Hastings-on-Hudson and the construction of 209 condominiums around it.

title: A Lisbon Takeover Is Ended
description: Employees called off their occupation of the offices of Portugal's biggest shipping company today after receiving assurances that last month's salaries would be paid, a spokesman for the workers said. The employees took over the offices of the state-owned Companhia Portuguesa dos Transportes Maritimos on Wednesday.

title: Executive Weds Katherine V. Bull
description: At the Memorial Church on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Katherine Virginia Bull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Bull of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and Scottsdale, Ariz., was married to Paul Richardson Baudisch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Baudisch of Bergenfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles E. Medcalf, a Methodist minister and uncle of the bridegroom.

title: 'BONGO MAN,' JIMMY CLIFF ON TOUR
description: Jimmy Cliff played the gun-toting reggae singer Ivan in ''The Harder They Come,'' which brought reggae and Mr. Cliff to international attention in 1973. With ''Bongo Man,'' a documentary, Mr. Cliff tries to change his image. Now, the film's adoring narration insists that he is a ''roots man.''

title: MEXICO'S CAMBRIDGE CONNECTION
description: CAMBRIDGE, England STRICT controls on imports. Foreign exchange curbs. Big budget deficits. Nationalization of the banks. Vast foreign borrowings. They are all part of a radical economic experiment under way in Mexico, an experiment put into place by Mexicans but one that reflects the startling ideas of a group of economists here at Cambridge University.

title: MINISTERS SEEKING TO REVITALIZE PREACHING
description: Calls for more socially activist preaching dominated a four-day conference at Riverside Church, but many of the nearly 1,000 participants questioned whether their sermons should constantly rally people to the barricades of social protest.

title: POSTMINIMALISM SHOW AT THE ALDRICH DISAPPOINTS
description: RIDGEFIELD DESPITE its ambitious scope and apparent seriousness, the ''Postminimalism'' exhibition at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art until Dec. 19 is a confusing and ultimately unsatisfying show.

title: U.S. FEARS ATTACKS ON NUCLEAR SITES
description: The United States has started an intensive new program intended to prevent terrorists from stealing nuclear weapons, according to officials of the Defense Nuclear Agency.

title: U.S.S. NAUTILUS TO RETURN TO GROTON AS MUSEUM
description: AFTER almost a quarter of a century traveling the oceans of the world and a pioneering voyage under the polar ice cap in 1957, the first vehicle ever to be propelled by nuclear power will be installed in Connecticut as a museum piece.

title: Daniel Dorff, Composer Weds Eiko Takahira
description: Eiko Fan Takahira, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Unshun Takahira of Tokyo, was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Daniel J. Dorff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Dorff of Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Ralph Moore, an Episcopal priest and director of the Christian Association of the University of Pennsylvania, performed a nondenominational outdoor ceremony on the banks of the Schuykill River at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: WITH A LITTLE GROWING EXPERTISE, COLUMNEAS ADD A TOUCH OF THE TROPICS
description: Tovah Martin is a writer and specialist in indoor plants.

title: 'ELITISM'?
description: Economics have finally caught up with the 131-year-old South Congregational Church in the Carroll Gardens Section of Brooklyn. Faced with a $9,000 heating bill this coming winter, the tiny congregation, who number about 20 on Sunday, have accepted an offer from Jean G. Miele, a Queens developer, to convert the three-story sanctuary into luxury apartments.

title: Regan Seeking to Curb State Credit-Card Abuse
description: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has said that he may ask oil companies not to honor state-issued credit cards unless Governor Carey or his successor imposes new controls over their use.

title:
OPINION;
NASSAU, BEWARE OF WEIGHTED VOTE
description: IN November, the voters of Nassau County will be asked to accept or reject a reallocation of weighted votes assigned to the members of its Board of Supervisors based not on population but on a distribution of ''voting power'' worked out by a computer.

title: Old Ways Are A Big Step Ahead
description: If the doctor won't call with his little black bag anymore, it may be because he feels lost without his $500,000 CAT scanner. Medical students are being swamped by science and technology at the expense of basic healing skills, a study panel of the Association of American Medical Colleges announced last week.

title: Kathryn Moser Is Bride
description: Kathryn E. Moser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Moser of Pearl River, N.Y., and Charles G. Enering, son of Charles H. Enering of Westwood, N.J., and the late Eileine Enering, were married yesterday in the Nauraushaun Presbyterian Church in Pearl River. The Rev. Sandy Shaw performed the ceremony. Mr. Moser is director of public relations for the Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York.

title: HUNGER FOUND TO GRIP RISING NUMBER IN CITY
description: Voluntary agencies and community groups all over New York City report marked increases in people who say they have no money for food.

title: Florida Suspends 4
description: The University of Florida said four basketball players would be suspended until Dec.1 for involvement in charging 326 unauthorized telephone calls worth $1,600 to the University Athletic Association.

title: WILL RATES GO LOWER OR CLIMB?
description: THE decline in mortgage-interest rates to their lowest point in two y ears has brought cheers from both home buyers and sellers and a f lutter of new activity. But it also has brought more uncertainty anda lot of questions to which there are conflicting answers.

title: THE CASE AGAINST SANCTIONS
description: The Case Against Sanctions Make no mistake about it, George Ball's article ''The Case Against Sanctions'' (Sept. 12) is the case for appeasement. In Mr. Ball's view there is no reason to punish Soviet actions and no means at our disposal for doing so.

title: Miss Becker Wed To Dr. Trepman
description: Pamela Sue Becker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Becker of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Elly Trepman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Trepman of Montreal. Rabbi Ben-Zion Gold, director of Harvard University Hillel, performed the ceremony at the Governor Morris Inn in Morristown, N.J.

title: G.O.P. CALLS PARLEY BY SATELLITE A HIT
description: In an elegant drawing room at the Union League Club in Manhattan, a group of wealthy Republican contributors sat and watched President Reagan on a large closed-circuit television screen. They did more than just watch. Four of them took turns using a telephone in the room to ask Mr. Reagan questions.

title: INDIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Date Is Set for Ex-Agent
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency, and two co-defendants, Edward J. Bloom of Palm Springs, Calif., and Donald R. Thresher of Houston, have been ordered to stand trial Nov. 29 on charges of smuggling 20 tons of plastic explosives from Texas to Libya. But attorneys for Mr. Wilson warned Federal District Judge Ross Sterling that the trial might have to be postponed because Mr. Wilson has been ordered to stand trial on Federal smuggling charges in Virginia on Nov. 15 and in Washington on Nov. 22.

title: No Headline
description: Sutton Leading by One After 54 Holes at 201

title: REALISTIC GOALS IN LEARNING TENNIS URGED
description: WITH the indoor tennis season under way, ''junior development'' programs have begun at centers countywide. Junior development is a euphemism for tennis lessons; at considerable cost, parents enroll their children for group instruction that continues until the spring. And the first thing they may ask the coach is, ''Can you make my child a top player?''

title: No Headline
description: Mrs. Truman Has Left Home to Government

title:
STAMPS;
HISTORIC BUILDING ON LAST 1982 STATIONERY ITEM
description: The final piece of United States postal stationery for this year is a 13-cent commemorative card in the ongoing Historic Preservation Series. It depicts a monumental Victorian edifice, the Old Post Office in St. Louis, Mo.

title: IN MONTCLAIR, $2.5 MILLION 'GALLERIA'
description: A $2.5 MILLION renovation project that its architect says will t ransform a 61-year-old commercial building into the shopping center o f the future is under way in the heart of Montclair's central b usiness district.

title: CRAFTS
description: THE concurrent appearance of symposiums, seminars and resource guides in various places points to a new seriousness in the art - and business - of collecting contemporary crafts. This is verified by an increasing number of craftspeople who make a living from their work.

title: Claire Lamb, John Monroe Are Engaged
description: The engagement of Claire Stuart Lamb to John Gordon Monroe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George Charles Lamb Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Monroe Jr. of Bakersfield, Calif.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: BLUES FOR CHARLIE DARWIN By Nat Hentoff. 203 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $11.50. GOOSEFOOT By Patrick McGinley. 251 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $13.95. THE KINDNESS OF DR.AVICENNA By John Pearson. 265 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $15.50.

title: ASSEMBLY RACE WITH RIPPLING EFFECTS
description: ELECTIONEERING this fall has scarcely penetrated the quiet precincts of the eighth floor, as the County Office Building concentrates on the run its ninth-floor occupant, Alfred B. DelBello, is making for lieutenant governor.

title: AM STATIONS, HURT BY FM, ARE GOING STEREO
description: KID CURRY, the disk jockey on KTSA, San Antonio, spun some unique sounds last July 23. It wasn't t hat any of his ''adult contemporary'' songs were all that different f rom normal radio fare. What was unusual about the broadcast was thatK id Curry's rock went out in stereo, and KTSA is an AM station.

title: Soviet-India Electronics Pact
description: The Soviet Union and India signed an agreement for cooperation in computer technology and electronics, the Indian Government has announced. A statement issued Friday said the agreement was signed after five days of talks between the Soviet Union's Deputy Radio Industry Minister, N.V. Gorshkov, and India's Deputy Electronics Minister, M.S. Sanjeevi Rao.

title: April Run Captures Turf Classic Again
description: April Run made a dazzling October dash through the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday and won the $476,800 Turf Classic for the second year in a row, this time by 6 1/2 lengths.

title: A TOUR OF DANCE WITH MARGOT FONTEYN
description: Long recognized as a great ballerina, Margot Fonteyn has, of late, become a successful dance writer. And now home audiences will be able to appreciate her as a television personality when her six-part BBC series, ''The Magic of Dance,'' begins tomorrow evening at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Janine Kushner Is Bride of Robert K. Brownstone
description: Janine Heath Kushner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kushner of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Keith Brownstone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Brownstone of Bel Air, Calif. Rabbi Paul Siegel performed the ceremony at the Tarrytown (N.Y.) Hilton Hotel.

title: PRICE OF HEATING FUEL RISES SHARPLY
description: THE more than 800,000 Long Island homeowners who heat with fuel oil have begun the new season with a jolt. Despite industry predictions of a plentiful supply and steady prices for No. 2 heating oil in the cold months ahead, the price of a oil has increased by as much as four cents a gallon in recent weeks.

title: MINORCA
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MAKING OF A HOCKEY DYNASTY
description: The New York Islander hockey rink is a brutal battering playground, but off the ice the players live in the lap of luxury: They fly by chartered jet. They vacationed in Bermuda this summer. They lounge in their locker room's new sauna. Secure on their fingers are the inelegant gold signet rings that boast of their stunning achievement - three consecutive National Hockey League championships in a scant 10 years' existence, a rise unparalleled in hockey history.

title: SEEKING HIS OWN POWER BASE, MUBARAK BUILDS ON NASSER'S
description: For many millions here, there is still magic in the name of Gamal Abdel Nasser and, as the architect of the 1952 revolution that deposed Egypt's tottering monarchy, he remains one of the nation's great heroes. When he died of a heart attack in 1970, it seemed that all of Cairo poured into the streets to mourn.

title: Helen Cooke Fiancee of Russell Pyne
description: The engagement of Helen Darlington Cooke to Russell Bradhurst Pyne has been announced by her father, Thornton Cooke 2d of Kansas City, Mo. Her fiance is a son of John Insley Blair Pyne of West Trenton, N.J., and Elizabeth Stuyvesant Pyne of Princeton, N.J.

title: Muddy Economics
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Economic Recovery That Won't Start'' (Oct.3), you make a valid point on the muddiness of the American economy. What Reagan policies have not done is give Americans a sense of excitment and a feeling of confidence in the future.

title: CONDOMINIUMS SOUGHT BY WEALTHY AND SINGLE
description: JERICHO CONDOMINIUMS, after a shaky start a decade ago, have caught on as a desirable form of housing with two active groups of buyers - the wealthy, who are willing to pay $145,000 and more for luxury units, and with the growing numbers of single persons looking for moderately priced units under $70,000.

title: A PIANIST REACHES FOR A WIDER AUDIENCE
description: Glenn Plaskin is the author of ''Horowitz,'' a biography to be published in March by William Morrow.

title: TRUMBULL EXHIBITION
description: John Trumbull, one of America's first great painters and a 1773 graduate of Harvard, gave a collection of his paintings to Yale College in 1832, where they were installed as the founding gift in America's first college art gallery.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
STREAKS IN THE HAIR THAT DON'T WASH OUT
description: THERE were two sets of faces at the 25th reunion of the class of '57. There were the faces of the real people, sometimes happy, sometimes sad, often with tiny lines around the corners of the eyes and mouth - but always mobile. And there were other faces, smiling stiffly for some long-forgotten photographer, frozen forever in black and white and worn now as I.D. badges on blouse collars and the lapels of suits.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: HOW is environmental quality altered when a highway is cut through a pristine mountain or when fresh-water wetlands disappear beneath a 200-unit housing development?

title: Massi Leads Harrison Past John Jay, 35-8
description: David Massi, a junior tailback. scored three touchdowns as Harrison overwhelmed John Jay, 35-8. Massi, who gained 100 yards rushing, helped give the Huskies a 7-0 halftime advantage with a 32-yard touchdown run.

title: A FUNNY MAN'S SAD STORY
description: WHERE HAVE I BEEN? An Autobiography. By Sid Caesar With Bill Davidson. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95.

title: Letters; Solar Heating
description: To The Editor: Your article on active solar space-heating, ''Warming Your House With the Sun'' (Oct. 3), illustrates some of the technical faults and deficiencies of active solar space-heating systems. I feel, however, that you overlook one very important fact when suggesting ways to avoid or overcome problems.

title: CAPITAL WATCHING A CLOSE SENATE RACE IN VIRGINIA
description: What may be the closest Senate race in the country is being fought here over a seat that has been held by the same political family for 50 years.

title: East Goes West In Sri Lanka Vote
description: The twain has met in Sri Lanka where last week a majority of voters in that Indian Ocean island endorsed Western-style capitalism and politics. President J.R. Jayewardene, who introduced the American presidential system to the country in 1978, was re-elected with almost 53 percent of the vote on a platform emphasizing private sector growth and virtually unfettered foreign investment.

title: RECORD $275,000 IS PAID FOR AN AMERICAN CHAIR
description: A Chippendale side chair, its front feet looking like hairy paws, yesterday became the most expensive American chair, and probably the costliest chair ever auctioned, when it sold to an undisclosed buyer for $275,000 at Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries in Manhattan.

title: Charlotte Ann Nichols Wed to Peter Leonard
description: The marriage of Charlotte Ann Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Nichols of Montclair, N.J., to Peter Graves Leonard took place yesterday at the Woman's Club of Maplewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leslie C. Smith, an Episcopal priest. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Leonard of Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: PICTORIAL RPELUDE TO TRICENTENNIAL
description: APICTORIAL history of Westchester has just been published in preparation for the county's 300th anniversary next year. The 200-page hard-cover volume, which includes 350 photographs, was the work of two experts on county history - both with the Westchester County Historical Society - and was financed by NBW Division of Lincoln First Bank. The book will be available at bookstores and at NBW branches starting tomorrow, and any profits from sales will be donated by the bank to the historical society's library.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 4 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 8 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power.

title: IS TALK OF HIGH TECH JOBS MORE POLITICAL THAN REAL?
description: The realization has sunk in among the business and political leaders of the industrial Midwest that even when the country's economy once again recovers, the factories and foundries of their region will continue to drag behind the rest of the country.

title: FOR WHOM ALFRED NOBEL CREATED A PEDESTAL
description: To the Editor:

title: MOBIL HOMES GAINING
description: For the past three years, the effect of high prices and mortgage rates has taken a toll on all home builders. Some have fared better than others, however, and manufacturers of mobile homes have weathered the industry's depression quite well. Since 1979, mobile homes have captured an increasingly bigger share of the shrinking new single-family home market.

title: STEEL'S MAN AT THE BARGAINING TABLE
description: PITTSBURGH LAST summer, after talks broke down between the United Steelworkers of America and the consortium of eight steel companies that negotiates with the union, the companies' chief negotiator, J. Bruce Johnston, did two things that raised a few eyebrows.

title: THE OWNERS AND PLAYERS HAVE A RIGHT TO SHARE TV MONEY
description: SAM KAGEL undertook an unenviable task. The mediator sought to cultivate a common ground whereby the National Football League owners and players could terminate their relentless tug-of-war. Unlike the tug-of-war within a professional football game, the dispute is not a tussle for turf; it is a struggle to preserve and maintain legal rights.

title: Xavier Tops Nazareth, 28-12
description: Lybron John scored touchdowns on runs of 36 and 54 yards to lead Xavier to a 28-12 Catholic High Schools Football League victory over Nazareth.

title: 30 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health named 30 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, the department named four that had been allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and three that had been closed after failure to do so.

title: Paul Joseph Cioffari Marries Barbara Kelly
description: Barbara Jean Kelly and Paul Joseph Cioffari were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Allison of Pelham, N.Y., friends of the couple. Town Justice Stephen Huff of Pelham performed the ceremony.

title: Minorca
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry on Congressman
description: An Indiana county prosecutor says he will begin an investigation into assertions that Representative H. Joel Deckard was intoxicated at the time of an Oct. 7 automobile accident. Prosecutor Joseph Koenig of Bartholomew County said Friday that he had accepted appointment as a special prosecutor in the case. Mr. Deckard, a Republican who is running for re-election, was involved in a one-car accident and was hospitalized for several days.

title: HOW POLICE USED SOCIAL RREGISTER AS KEY IN BURGLARY CASE
description: ON Oct. 4, the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested three Massachusetts men in New York City on Federal charges of interstate transportation of stolen goods. The charges against the three pertain to a burglary in New Jersey.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: THE MIDDLE EAST OF THE 1990's?
description: Unless South Africa's racial policies are fundamentally redesigned, they will eventually lead to a catastrophic racial conflict that will have serious ramifications throughout the Western world, and most especially in the United States.

title: THE UNADORNED PLEASURES OF AMALFI
description: LUCINDA FRANKS, winner of a Pulitzer Prize for national reporting, lives in New York.

title: GOOD BUYS IN TAPE DECKS
description: Ever since the cavemen of Lascaux decorated their dwellings with hunting scenes, human beings have consistently tried to preserve parts of their experience. It is the taproot of all art, perhaps fed by the urge to stop the flow of time - to arrest the moment in the stream of mutability.

title: N. EDISON BEATS WOODRIDGE BY 27-6
description: Marc Mofsowitz ran twice for touchdowns and led North Edison to a 27-6 victory over Woodbridge yesterday in Edison. Mofsowitz ran 19 yards in the first quarter and 20 yards in the second when North Edison (5-0) grabbed a 13-0 lead. In the third period, Jim Schedeneck completed a 50-yard touchdown pass to Bill Wickham and ran 30 yards in the last quarter for a score for North Edison. Woodbridge (2-2-1), which was held to 3 yards rushing and 86 passing, got its touchdown in the fourth period on Steve Gruskiewicz' 30-yard pass to Alex Palleija.

title: 'LUNCH HOUR' CAST SASTISFIES THE PALATE
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE Arena Players Repertory Company production of Jean Kerr's ''Lunch Hour'' begins, rather rudely, with a glare that produces the effect of an oncoming car flashing bright lights in your face. It is supposed to suggest the Southampton sunlight pouring into a beach house, and as the evening wears on, it turns out to be but a glimmer compared to the glaring void that's at the center of Mrs. Kerr's play.

title: 5 ARMENIANS HELD IN COAST BOMBINGS
description: Five Armenians, including one accused of carrying explosives on an airliner, have been arrested in a twoyear series of bombings aimed at Turkish diplomats and others in southern California, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: THE SCHOOL BOARD IN NEW ROCHELLE: TO APPOINT OR NOT
description: two years ago, New Rochelle voted to retain an appointed Board of Education. Once again, on Nov. 2, its citizens will go to the polls to decide, by referendum, whether to continue an appointed board or to change to an elected one.

title: THE ART OF FABLED FLOWERS
description: SAG HARBOR MARRIAGES may be made in heaven, but artistic collaborations can be another thing entirely. So when Myrna and Paul Davis, who in 17 years of marriage had led separate but complementary career lives as a writer and an artist, respectively, decided to join forces for the first time to produce the recently published ''Bouquet: Twelve Flower Fables,'' they didn't quite know what to expect from this new relationship.

title: Janet Matson and Ian Fox Exchange Vows in Indiana
description: Janet Suzanne Matson, daughter of Mrs. Robin H. Matson of Carmel, N.Y., and Joseph Richard Matson of New York, was married yesterday to Ian Joseph Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Fox of New York.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES TO BUCKNELL
description: Columbia lost another game yesterday in another lost season, but John Witkowski's performance won him a place in the school records. In a 42-25 defeat to Bucknell at Baker Field, Witkowski, Columbia's junior quarterback, established single-game school passing records for completions, attempts and total yardage. By connecting on 35 passes in 56 attempts for 406 yards, he broke records established by Marty Domres in 1968. Domres was a first-round pro draft choice in 1969 and is best remembered for his years with the Baltimore Colts.

title: A TELLING GLIMPSE OF ONE 'TERRIBLE PLACE TO BE KURDISH'
description: To the Editor:

title: British Defense Minister Is Visiting Falklands
description: The British Defense Secretary, John Nott, today became the first British Cabinet member to visit the Falkland Islands in 149 years of British rule.

title: PACIFIC ATOLLS SHOW FEISTY INDEPENDENCE
description: Disputes over nuclear policy, fishing rights and the Law of the Sea Treaty are eroding the warm relations, dating back to World War II, between the United States and the newly sovereign nations of the central and south Pacific.

title: John Bristol Glass Jr., Realty Official, Takes Martha Knox Vietor as Bride
description: Martha Knox Vietor, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Vietor, was married yesterday in Manhattan to John Bristol Glass Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Glass of Whiteville, N.C. The Rev. Thomas C. Bowers performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: NOT HERE TO WRITE BUT TO BE MAD
description: SELECTED STORIES By Robert Walser. Foreword by Susan Sontag. Translated by Christopher Middleton and Others. 194 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.50.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: LIFE ITSELF: Its Origin and Nature. By Francis Crick. (S&S/Touchstone, $4.95.) ''The doyen of modern molecular biology considers the grand panorama of cosmic evolution and offers the highly unorthodox proposal that life on Earth originally came from other planetary systems,'' wrote our reviewer, Carl Sagan. Tackling his daunting subject with wit and grace, Sir Francis Crick produced ''a kind of romp, a presentation of an entertaining and enchanting speculation not strongly supported by the facts,'' Mr. Sagan declared.

title: A Banker-Spy Deserts Poland
description: Polish banking and Polish espionage suffered simultaneous blows last week when Andrzej Treumann, who divided his life between the two activities, was discovered to have defected to the United States with his wife and daughter.

title: FAMILIAR FOES IN N.B.A. TALKS
description: Since the 1960's, David Stern and Larry Fleisher have stared at each other across the bargaining table, sometimes screaming, sometimes laughing, but always able to work out a solution.

title: NOT JUST A JACK-O'-LANTERN
description: AT this time of year, everyone, even the smallest children, know what pumpkins look like. But relatively few people are likely to be familiar with their flavor. When not carved with a grin and fitted with a candle, a pumpkin is likely to be seasoned heavily with ginger, nutmeg, cinnamon and cloves so that the taste of pumpkin is hard to distinguish from that of this spice mixture, essential to the classic pumpkin pie.

title: A CARDIAC PROGRAM IS RESHAPING LIVES
description: ''IDIDN'T believe in jogging, I believed in smoking,'' said John Wildnauer, a former County Budget Director and Administrator of General Services. But he has changed his mind since his heart attack last January. Mr. Wildnauer no longer smokes two packs of cigarettes a day; he's on a low-cholesterol diet and, because of the White Plains Y.M.C.A. Cardiac Therapy Program, he now jogs three times a week. ''That's more exercise than I've had in years,'' he said.

title:
DINING OUT;
A STEP IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION
description: IT IS gratifying to come across a restaurant that has actually improved since it was first reviewed. Such is the case with Cook Plaza Cafe, a small storefront establishment on a side alley in Madison, that earned a one-star rating on these pages two and a half years ago.

title: CRIME RATE DROPS IN STATE
description: THE number of crimes reported in Connecticut in the first six months of this year were down approximately 8 percent compared with figures for the same period in 1981, according to figures released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last week.

title: RAN HISTORIC FARM
description: John Lyman Sr., a figure in Connecticut agriculture, business and education, died Friday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. Mr. Lyman, a lifelong resident of Middlefield, Conn., was 86 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WILLIAM N. MONNIER of Newington admits he likes to ''stir things up.'' Mr. Monnier, 71 years old, was forced to withdraw as a Republican candidate for Judge of Probate last August after learning he was too old to serve under Connecticut's State Constitution.

title: DAVID ROCKEFELLER CITIES GOALS FOR HOUSING PLAN
description: David Rockefeller, the chairman of the New York City Partnership, an organization of civic-minded business executives, hopes that as many as 5,000 units of middle-income housing will be ''under way'' within a year as part of a project to build 30,000 units over the next five years.

title: A WINE CRITIC'S FEAST
description: People with a passionate devotion to wine are inclined to focus their entertaining on their favorite beverage, and I am no exception. Instead of cocktail parties, I give wine tastings, and planning for my dinner parties begins with deciding which wines I will serve.

title: Patricia Vignolo Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Vignolo of Westfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lawrence Vignolo, to Dr. John Hugh Charles Ranson of New York. He is a son of the Rev. Dr. Charles Wesley Ranson of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Grace Ranson.

title: FRANCO SUPPORTER MAKES A COMEBACK
description: Manuel Fraga Iribarne, known as one of the hard-liners of the Franco regime, has emerged as the only significant challenger to the Socialist leader, Felipe Gonzalez, in Spain's general election.

title: John Powers Will Marry Linda E. Gay
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Gay of Huntington Bay, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Linda Elizabeth Gay, to John Joseph Powers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Powers Jr. of Centerport, L.I.

title: HALLOWEEN CONTEST IN 30TH YEAR
description: NEXT Saturday, Scarsdale will be transformed. Shop windows usually displaying shoes, flowers and hardware will be covered with ghosts, goblins and witches.

title: SPECIAL CONCERT SERIES WARMS UP
description: THE Westchester County Senior Citizens Orchestra is busy making music again. Every Tuesday morning, its 35 members, whose ages range up to 92, gather for rehearsal in the large music studio of the Westchester County Center. Wielding the baton is a comparative youngster, the 28-year-old Noel Hart.

title: COCAINE TRAFFICKING AND ITS HUGE PROFITS LURING MIDDLE CLASS
description: The huge profits to be found in cocaine trafficking are luring more and more middle-class and upper-income Americans to the cocaine trade, law-enforcement officials say, and relatively few of them are being caught.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY BRITISH SPY GAVE SOVIET KEY DATA
description: A Soviet diplomat has defected to Britain in what is described as ''not an ordinary affair.'' Page 14.

title: Poprilo Scores 4 Touchdowns as Lawrence Wins
description: Don Poprilo, a junior halfback, scored four touchdowns for the second straight week as undefeated Lawrence (5-0) defeated Hicksville, 26-14, yesterday in an American League Conference I game. East Meadow also won its fifth straight, defeating Oceanside, 21-15, and remained tied with Lawrence for first place.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HISTORIC BEDSTEAD TO BE DISPLAYED
description: HARTFORD A MAJOR piece of 18th-century Connecticut furniture - the only bedstead known to exist today that has ever been attributed to the master craftsman, Eliphalet Chapin - is now part of the Connecticut Historical Society's collection.

title: Canucks Won't Appeal
description: The Vancouver Canucks said they would not appeal the seven-game suspension to Dave (Tiger) Williams, their belligerent left wing, though Coach Roger Neilson said he was surprised the punishment was so severe. Williams was involved in a stick-swinging incident Oct. 19 with Billy Smith, the Islanders' goalie, and was ejected for hitting Smith with his stick. Brian O'Neill, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, levied the suspension. ... Pierre Larouche, the high-scoring center for the Hartford Whalers, has been suspended for two games, including last night's game with Los Angeles, for missing a bed check, a Whalers' spokesman said.

title: DISPUTES CONTINUE ON FUEL PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTOND.C. DISPUTES over financing Government programs to help the poor pay their fuel bills are giving Connecticut officials a recurring headache.

title: Fragile Islands Get Protection
description: President Reagan put his signature on a bona fide conservation bill last week, perhaps because it appealed equally to fiscal conservatives and environmentalists. The new law will end Federal subsidies for development of coastal barrier islands.

title: West Germans Protest Kohl's Economic Policies
description: Thousands of West German workers took to the streets today to protest the economic policies of the new centerright Government.

title: Thwarting Graffiti
description: Locked in a losing battle with subway graffiti vandals, the New York City Transit Authority moved in August 1981 to bolster defenses at its subway yards, where most of the spray-can painting was taking place. At a cost of $1.5 million, it put up two 10-foot-high fences around a major yard in Corona, Queens, and unleashed patrol dogs between the fences.

title: CENTER FOCUSES ON GLOBAL POTENTIAL FOR SOUTH
description: Former Secretaries of State Dean Rusk and Cyrus R. Vance are meeting here with an audience of Southerners for a few hours of weekend ''off-the-record'' conversation on topics that span the globe.

title: DO ACADEMICS BELONG ON TV?
description: D.C. Denison is a staff writer for The Boston Phoenix.CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. There is still chalk on the back of Arthur Miller's gray suit jacket as he steps onto the brightly lighted set in Ellsworth Hall at Pine Manor College. Earlier in the day, Professor Miller was leaning against a blackboard teaching civil procedure, ''Class Actions and Injunctions,'' to his second-and third-year students at Harvard Law School. Tonight, however, he is aiming at a much larger audience as his television show, ''Miller's Court,'' a half-hour program on the law produced by WCVB-TV in Boston, begins taping another installment in its fourth and most ambitious season.

title: COLLAGEN AND COMPLEXION CARE
description: Collagen and Complexion Care June Weir's article ''The New Emphasis on Skin-Care Products'' (Sept. 26) has touched on a subject which is seen and discussed by more and more dermatologists in their daily practice.

title: A PROWLER OF CULTURE
description: In her introduction to the recent collection of the late Roland Barthes's work, Susan Sontag says that when people stop thinking of him as a semiologist or structuralist, Barthes will appear as ''a rather traditional promeneur solitaire, and a greater writer than even his more fervent admirers now claim.''

title: George Pew Jr. Weds Sandra Kennedy
description: Sandra Lee Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph George Kennedy of Havertown, Pa., was married yesterday to George Thompson Pew Jr., son of Mrs. Pew of Haverford, Pa., and the late Mr. Pew. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.)

title: WINNING IT FOR BUTCH
description: Dave Anderson

title: O'NEILL-ROME DEBATES: TAXES AND JOBS AT ISSUE
description: Following are excerpts from two debates between Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat, and his Republican challenger, Lewis B. Rome. The debates were held on Oct. 14 at Connecticut College in New London, under the sponsorship of the Southern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, and on Oct. 23 in Hartford in the Old State House, sponsored by the Connecticut League of Women Voters. Opening Statements

title: President Appointed At People's
description: In Connecticut, the People's Savings Bank has chosen an insurance executive, David E.A. Carson, to be its new president. The bank, with headquarters in Bridgeport, has assets of $2.4 billion and 40 branches.

title: LEVEILLE OF BRUINS HAS BRAIN OPERATION
description: Normand Leveille, a 19-year-old forward for the Boston Bruins, was reported in poor condition today after undergoing surgery for a brain hemorrhage suffered during a game against the Vancouver Canucks Saturday night.

title: BLACK HAWKS END ISLANDERS' STREAK AT 8
description: The Chicago Black Hawks, playing with an intensity that rarely faltered, came back from a 2-0 deficit tonight to break the Islanders' winning streak at eight games with a 4-2 victory.

title: Suzanne Trimel and Marc Charney, Editors, Wed
description: Suzanne Michele Trimel, a national news editor for United Press International in New York, was married yesterday to Marc David Charney, Caribbean news editor for The Associated Press in San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Timothy Lull, professor of systematic theology and ethics at the Lutheran Theology Seminary in Philadelphia, performed the interfaith ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Edward G. Trimel in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Jobs Fund Appoints a Leader
description: James Locke, former director of career training and economic resources for the Vocational Foundation Inc., has been appointed vice president and executive director of the New York organization, which trains and finds jobs for disadvantaged youths. Mr. Locke is a graduate of the University of Michigan. The foundation deals with youths between the ages of 16 and 19 who are referred by the courts, correctional institutions and community agencies.

title: Betsy Weisburgh Married To B.H. Silver in Stamford
description: Betsy Joy Weisburgh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Weisburgh of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Barney H. Silver, son of Mrs. E. Adrian Silver of Racine, Wis., and Bay Harbor, Fla., and the late Mr. Silver. The ceremony at the Weisburgh home was performed by Rabbi Solomon Kahn Kaplan, cousin of the bride, assisted by Rabbi Stephen H. Pearce.

title: POLL FINDS DANFORTH AND HIS OPPONENT IN MISSOURI RUNNING NECK AND NECK
description: A dramatic shift in voter sentiment since September has put State Senator Harriett Woods, a Democrat, even with John C. Danforth in their race for the United States Senate, according to a statewide poll taken earlier this month.

title: Political Analysis
description: In the final week of an election season, especially one that seems slow to define itself, like this year's, campaigners worry about things they cannot control, especially about the other guy.

title: THE FILLY WHO RUNS FASTER THAN COLTS
description: ARCADIA, Calif. WAYNE LUKAS has developed a sort of video game that could be called ''How Fast Is This Horse Going?'' He claims that you could try it out on ''the most knowledgeable horsemen in the world,'' and that ''not one in 5,000'' would get the right answer.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Harness Racing Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape.)

title: DeLorean Bid By Creditor
description: The president of a liquidating company says he may know by Monday if his company's bid to buy the DeLorean Motor Company will be approved by a British court-appointed receiver.

title: MONEY MAGAZINE PROFITABLE FOR TIME INC.
description: Rumor had it that time nearly ran out on Money magazine. Time Inc., that is. Five years ago, cynics at Time Inc. were betting that the giant communications company would fold Money, the personal finance monthly it introduced in 1972. Money was a money-loser. ''There were some questions about whether Money would survive,'' said Marshall Loeb, the magazine's managing editor.

title: Washington Watch; Agencies Do Some Boasting
description: WASHINGTON IT'S not just campaigning members of Congress who are boasting of their achievements these days. The Federal Trade Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission are doing it, too.

title: Bridge: Forcing Enemy to Signal May Bring Victory Closer
description: In bridge, as in war, interception and decoding of enemy signals can help make the difference between defeat and victory. With a little thought the declarer can sometimes induce a defender to send a revealing signal, and this happened on the diagramed deal from the 1982 Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: PLAYERS REAFFIRM SOLIDARITY
description: More than 80 National Football League players, including union representatives from all 28 teams, met for more than five hours today, and later the union leadership sounded the familiar battle cry that has been heard throughout the 34-day player strike: The union is strong and the owners should bargainin good faith.

title: Freed Nebraska Pastor Says Devil Is the Enemy
description: The Rev. Everett Sileven, back in the pulpit after a term in jail, told his congregation at the Faith Baptist Church today that the Devil was the enemy for motivating a judge and sheriff to jail him for contempt.

title: 2 CONNECTICUT CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR DIFFER ON STATE OF THE STATE
description: The candidates for Governor have met in debates four times, and William A. O'Neill, the Democratic incumbent, and Lewis B. Rome, the Republican challenger, have differed on almost all issues, reflecting their contradicting views on the state of the state.

title: AN END TO HATE
description: It is hard for outsiders to appreciate what many Israelis feel as Menachem Begin and Ariel Sharon corrupt the values of their country, turning it to the politics of militarism and hate. The official propaganda is effective, and no friend of Israel wants to hear bad news.

title: A Book Publisher Tries A Movie Magazine
description: Well before Joe Armstrong announced his intention to publish The Movies magazine next April, Harold Steinberg, head of Chelsea House Publishers, had made up his mind to bring out a movie magazine.

title: A Bad but Hopeful Steel Deal
description: American steelmakers can expect only token relief from last week's agreement to limit imports from Europe. And the deal sets an ugly precedent for protectionist initiatives that would further erode living standards in industrialized societies. Still, the effects won't be all bad. By eliminating legal penalties on Common Market steel exporters, the deal may make it possible to settle other trade disputes in embassies rather than courtrooms.

title: Pepsico Sets the Debut Of a Drink, Pepsi Free
description: Pepsico's new Pepsi Free, which you do have to pay for but which contains little or no caffeine, will be showing up on supermarket shelves this week, and its advertising on television and radio (courtesy of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne) breaks Nov. 7.

title: THE P.L.O. IS FAILING THE PALESTINIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAL ESTATE'S OBLIGATION TO MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Priest Puts Total of Missing at 15
description: A Roman Catholic priest said today that the number of labor and leftist leaders missing here had risen to 15.

title: PASSION YIELDS TO A QUIET CALM WHILE TROUT FISHING
description: hampered by failing light and failing eyesight -struggles to tie to his leader a fly that will approximate the natural insects emerging from the pool before him, insects that two-pound brook trout are devouring.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aminoil USA Inc., Houston, has elected Donald G. Barber vice president and controller.

title: SLOWER RATE DROP EXPECTED BY ANALYSTS
description: There is a widespread belief in the credit markets that short-term and long-term interest rates will decline further, though not as fast as expected and not without occasional interruptions.

title: Moral Majority to Hold Drive By Phone for 'Pro-Life' Votes
description: Moral Majority is planning an election-eve telephone campaign, financed by a special drive, urging its members to vote for ''pro-life, pro-traditional family and proschool prayer'' candidates on Nov. 2.

title: MAKERS OF THE REAL E.T. DEFY EARTHLY IMPOSTORS
description: E.T. may be afraid. He may be three million light years from home. But contrary to the advertising assertions of the company that made the top-grossing movie, ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial,'' he is not totally alone.

title: Turkey's Leader Opens Referendum Campaign
description: Gen. Kenan Evren, Turkey's military leader, opened a campaign in support of the draft constitution today with a televised speech in which he said that the armed forces would relinquish power only after having been convinced that the situation in Turkey will not deteriorate.

title: SALAZAR AND GRETE WAITZ FIRST IN MARATHON DIVISIONS
description: The finish in the women's division in the 13th New York City Marathon yesterday was not highlighted by the kind of down-to-thewire suspense that marked the men's race. But for Grete Waitz of Norway, the victory bore as much meaning.

title: LEHRMAN CLASHES WITH CUOMO ON TV
description: Lewis E. Lehrman and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo repeatedly accused each other of a ''lack of candor'' and ''misstatments'' yesterday in their campaigns for Governor. In two joint television appearances, they also clashed on the death penalty, the economy and many other subjects.

title: MOSCOW PRESSES NEW CRACKDOWN ON ALL DISSENT
description: The Administration is basing its Soviet policy on the assumption that there will be an early change in the Kremlin leadership. Page A9.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1982; The Economy
description: Third-quarter corporate profits were weak. Some companies benefited from lower interest rates and from cuts in spending made earlier in the year. But in many cases, the gains were offset by poor sales and such unexpected problems as the devaluation of the Mexican peso and its consequences for trade. (D1.)

title: STATES' INCOME AT $300 BILLION FOR FIRST TIME, U.S. REPORTS
description: State government revenues rose above $300 billion for the first time last year, but spending grew faster than income, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Pricing Crime
description: At the end of ''M,'' the German film classic, a woman says to the mob celebrating its capture of a child killer, ''But will this bring back our children?'' The mob falls silent. Nothing and no one can return what is lost to crime.

title: 5 DROWN AS FISHING BOAT CAPSIZES OFF JERSEY SHORE
description: Five men drowned and three others were missing and presumed lost today when a chartered fishing boat with 22 people on board foundered in choppy Atlantic seas. The 50-foot boat capsized within sight of the New Jersey shore about 40 miles south of New York City.

title: Navy Crew Wins on Charles
description: The heavyweight varsity crew of the Naval Academy successfully defended its men's championship eights title in the 18th Head of the Charles Regatta today.

title: N.A.S.L. PROPOSES U.S. TEAM
description: The creation of a professional team of American citizens to play as a franchise in the North American Soccer League next season is the most controversial proposal on the agenda for the N.A.S.L.'s annual meetings. They will be held tomorrow and Wednesday in San Jose, Calif.

title: Pharmacy's Wares Subdue 2 Gunmen
description: Two gunmen entered a Brooklyn pharmacy yesterday and briefly held two employees prisoner before collapsing from prescription drugs they took off shelves and consumed, the police said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A POET LECTURES

title: Swedes, on U.N. Day, Form a 'Bridge of Peace'
description: Thousands of Swedes joined hands and formed a four-mile ''human bridge of peace'' between the United States and Soviet embassies today to mark United Nations Day in a live international television broadcast.

title: PLANT WILL MAKE METHANE TRADE FOR HOT WATER
description: New York City is about to trade two products of sewage treatment - methane gas and cool, clean water - for hot water, in an unusual arrangement to save money and conserve energy, city officials said yesterday.

title: EDUCATORS PROPOSE CURES FOR AILING HIGH SCHOOL CURRICULUMS
description: Should American high schools adopt a uniform curriculum? Can they uphold educational standards and still ensure equality of opportunity? And is money available to make these and other changes?

title: Five Are Wounded On Queens Street
description: Five pedestrians were wounded -one of them critically - by gunfire from a van speeding through the Jamaica section of Queens yesterday evening, the police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Signs of the Times

title: Commodities; Those New Financial Options
description: LAST Friday the American Stock Exchange began trading in options on 10-year Treasury notes and the Chicago Board Options Exchange began trading in Treasury bond options. These events represented two more giant moves in the continuing transformation of the commodity industry.

title: Japan Vehicle Output
description: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses edged down 1.8 percent in September from a year earlier, to 968,161 vehicles, according to the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association.

title: THEATER: 'ROCK 'N ROLL! THE FIRST 5,000 YEARS'
description: THERE was something sleazy about the basic idea of ''Beatlemania'' - four ersatz moptops reducing the Beatles legacy to a plastic simulacrum. But the multiple-screen projections and other special effects that were created for the show by its authors, Bob Gill and Robert Rabinowitz, were genuinely fresh and appealing. It was only a matter of time until someone put them to more worthwhile uses, and ''Rock 'n Roll! The First 5,000 Years,'' which opened last night at the St. James Theater, does just that.

title: ISRAELI CABINET BACKS EL AL
description: The Israeli Cabinet today resolved to support the directors of El Al in their decision to dissolve the national airline if striking workers did not concede broader powers to management within 21 days.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: No Headline
description: MRS. WALESA PROTESTS 'HORRIBLE' SEARCH

title: WIND HAD NO SYMPATHY
description: The wind reached 23 miles an hour, with gusts, and resulted yesterday in generally slower times for the runners in the New York City Marathon. No one seemed happy about it. For example:

title: Police Say Tylenol Bottle Yielded No Fingerprints
description: The authorities were unable to find fingerprints on a bottle of cyanide-filled Tylenol capsules discovered last week, a police spokesman says.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS PULL WELL AHEAD IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: After a year in power, Greece's governing Socialist Party appeared to be winning a strong vote of confidence from the electorate in today's second and final round of municipal elections.

title: TWISTED REVIEW OF REAGAN'S WAR ON INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Kicking Feat
description: Bad news for football fans who hate to see victory and defeat decided by a smallish place-kicker. The Zendejases are five young men of Mexican heritage who are busily rewriting record books with their outstanding kicking feats in colleges and prep schools.

title: REFORMING WORK
description: While politicians and economists debate ways of shoring up the economy, a quiet revolution is taking place on shop floors and in offices across America. Dramatically increased employee participation in management and ownership is reducing alienation and improving productivity, in addition to changing the relationships among workers, managers and owners.

title: PLAN TO RAISE SOCIAL SECURITY TAX CALLED POSSIBILITY
description: Some Democratic members of the panel named by President Reagan to study Social Security reform might agree to an increase in the payroll tax as part of a package that would funnel some general tax revenues into the Social Security trust fund, according to commission sources.

title: A VISIT BY NOTRE DAME IS A VICTORY FOR ALL OF OREGON
description: 13 standoff with Oregon last Saturday resolved nothing on the field, but off the field the winners and the losers were easy to identify. Merely one of the hundreds of games played each weekend in the fall, the contest demonstrated that college football's role in America extends well beyond the playing fields.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Christian Militia Leader Pledges to Back Gemayel

title: MUSIC: MENOTTI SALUTE TO ALICE TULLY
description: TWO birthdays were celebrated last evening at Alice Tully Hall, one of them that of Miss Alice Tully herself. Actually, the benefactor for whom the Lincoln Center hall was named turned 80 years old last month, but any time musicians and music listeners decide to pay homage to Miss Tully is the right time.
