The occasion, which also happened to signal the start of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's 14th season of subscription concerts, brought out an audience of luminaries, including Gian Carlo Menotti. His ''Nocturne'' for Soprano, String Quartet and Harp, written in honor of Miss Tully, received its first public performance with a young protege of hers, Marvis Martin, taking the solo vocal part.

title: 2-Year-Old Listed as Critical After Being Mauled by Tiger
description: A 2-year-old boy was in critical condition today after he was mauled Saturday by a Siberian tiger that escaped from an unlocked cage at Lion Country Safari Animal Park, the authorities said.

title: FEW OF THE POOR QUITTING JOBS TO GET BACK ON WELFARE ROLLS
description: People removed from the welfare rolls because of Reagan Administration policies have generally stayed off welfare, despite many predictions that they would return.

title: U.S. IS PREPARING ITS POLICIES WITH A NEW KREMLIN LEADER IN MIND
description: The Reagan Administration has begun preparing policies toward the Soviet Union that are based on the assumption that there will be an early change in the Kremlin leadership and that it is important that the next Soviet leader have a clear idea of American views, Administration officials say.

title: Dead of 1942 Battle Honored at Alamein
description: Representatives of 25 nations offered prayers at El Alamein today and placed wreaths of flowers at monuments commemorating thousands of troops who died in the World War II battle 40 years ago.

title: Market Place; Seeking Gains In Real Estate
description: CAN a real estate partnership create a perfect investment (in a package of redeveloped, undeveloped and farm properties) that offers quick gains and a major tax shelter - and do so at no risk to the investor?

title: SHULTZ VISITING CANADA TO EMPHASIZE U.S. TIES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here this afternoon for a 24-hour visit intended primarily to underscore the symbolic importance of Canadian-American relations.

title: Advertising; People, Bic Seeking Agencies
description: TWO quite diverse advertisers are narrowing their agency searches - Time Inc.'s People magazine and the Bic Pen Corporation. People is closer to a decision.

title: MORTGAGE RATES HEAD DOWN
description: The recent sharp downward trend in mortgage rates is helping revive the moribund housing industry and giving home buyers increased hope of finding affordable living quarters.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Joe DiMaggio hit safely in 56 straight games, how many hits did he get during the streak and in how many total games that season did he hit safely? Was that a record, too? Also, what were DiMaggio's batting statistics for the entire season?

title: STAGE: PAMELA REED IN 'STANDING ON MY KNEES'
description: IF a dramatist wants to get the world on his side, there's one sure-fire way to do it: write a play about a protagonist who suffers from a tragic physical or mental handicap. But writers who take this path too often fall into the trap of believing that their job is done once they've selected their hero's or heroine's affliction. Instead of going on to create legitimate characters or drama, they settle for letting cruel nature run its predictable course through a field full of stick figures. The result isn't a play but a soap opera.

title: Yugoslav Devaluation
description: Yugoslavia has devalued the dinar by 16 percent in a move intended to increase exports.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LETTERS FROM SACHIKO. By James Trager. 218 pages. Atheneum. $12.95.

title: DEMOCRAT RUNS QUIETLY IN MASSACHUSETTS RACE
description: For five weeks, the general election campaign for governor here has been so quiet that one could have heard a word drop from the Democratic side, had Michael Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, uttered one.

title: WHY EGYPT IS LACKING I.M.F. REPRESENTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGERS DEFEAT STARS BY 4-2
description: The Rangers checked and forechecked more effectively than usual at Madison Square Garden last night, took advantage of their chances and defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 4-2.

title: Striking Differences
description: On Oct. 4 and 5, the advertising firm of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn conducted a national telephone poll of 396 adults on their reactions to the strike by National Football League players. Questioned were 213 married men who used to be regular viewers of N.F.L. games and 183 women who are married to regular television viewers of pro football.

title: DILLON S. MYER, WHO HEADED WAR RELOCATION AGENCY, DIES
description: Dillon S. Myer, who supervised the camps set up for 110,000 people of Japanese descent forced to leave the West Coast in World War II, died Thursday of cardiac arrest at a nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 91 years old and had lived for many years in the Washington area.

title: 4 MINOR PARTIES FIELDING CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR
description: The candidates of four minor parties will appear on the ballot Nov. 2 in New York, with two of them seeking to elect statewide candidates for the first time.

title: CROWDS MADE RUNNING EASIER
description: Brian Brown, a member of the staff of The New York Times Week in Review, ran in yesterday's New York City Marathon. It was his first marathon and he wrote this article after he finished in 3 hours 29 minutes 10 seconds for 5,076th place.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Electric Power System said it had temporarily idled two mining operations because of a reduction in coal supply requirements.

title: THE PAIN OF ARTHRITIS CAN CAUSE ISOLATION
description: SOMETIMES, John Murphy said, ''I wonder if I am really a man anymore. A man is strong, he can r un, he can play baseball with his kids. I cannot put up wallpaper inm y house, I cannot cut the grass, cannot get hold of my baby and hug a nd squeeze him. All those things have been eliminated from my l ife.''

title: MRS. LEHRMAN AND MRS. CUOMO: NEW LIVES
description: It was teatime in the living room of the Park Avenue apartment of Lewis and Louise Lehrman. Sunlight touched the pale green walls, hung with French and American Impressionist paintings, and a breeze ruffled the draperies. The five Lehrman children, home from school, were laughing and playing at one end of the vast apartment, decorated by Parish-Hadley, while, at the other end, the cook was preparing dinner.

title: Lisa Chanil Is Bride
description: Lisa Michelle Chanil and Mark Steven McElrath, graduates of the State University of New York at Cortland, were married yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., by Cantor Richard Berman. The bride, daughter of Leo Chanil of Bellerose, Queens, and the late Selma Chanil, is loan coordinator with the First National Bank of Chicago in New York. Mr. McElrath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferrell F. McElrath of Kingston, N.Y., is a systems programmer-analyst with Columbia Picture Industries.

title: Hearst Fills Redbook Posts
description: Hearst Magazines has just made some changes that really put its stamp of ownership on Redbook magazine, acquired last August from the Charter Company.

title: SOME CRIMINAL RECORDS SENT OUT BY F.B.I. ARE FOUND TO BE INACCURATE OR INCOMPLETE
description: Congressional researchers have found that almost half of a sample of criminal history records that the Federal Bureau of Investigation sent to the police, state agencies, banks and other institutions throughout the United States were incomplete or inaccurate.

title: Elizondo Stops Kenty in Upset
description: McAFEE, N.J., Oct. 24 (UPI) -Roberto Elizondo of Los Angeles scored an upset victory today over Hilmer Kenty, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, who was unable to continue after the second round of their scheduled 10-round fight.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1982
description: International A Socialist victory in Greece appeared to be near for the party that has governed the country for a year. In the second and final round of municipal elections Socialist candidates with Communist backing were firmly ahead of right-wing rivals in Athens, Salonika, Piraeus and the former right-wing stronghold of Ioannina and others. (Page A1, Column 6.) Further repression by Moscow appears to be settling over the Russians as the Kremlin moves in various ways to eliminate stirrings of unorthodoxy and dissent that it had stifled in previous clampdowns. Western diplomats in Moscow say that two principal factors appear to have contributed to more restrictions on Soviet life. These are the uncertainty over who will succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev as the Communist Party leader, and the deeply strained relations with the United States. (A1:5.)

title: THE HOPE OF LEBANON
description: The United States Government is now considering the request, made during the visit of President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon to Washington last week, for help in clearing Lebanon of foreign troops and rebuilding after seven years of bitter civil war. Both Christian victors and Moslem losers in that conflict seek to reconstruct the delicate fabric of communal balance that kept Lebanon largely stable from 1944 until the outbreak of the civil war in 1975. Although Mr. Gemayal's requests may seem extravagent to many in Washington, significant American participation in this process, as guarantor and honest broker, is a necessity.

title: CALM RESTORED IN ARIZONA TOWN WHERE 2 SECT MEMBERS DIED
description: A tense confrontation between members of a church and local police units was resolved this afternoon after the church posted bond for two members sought on traffic violations.

title: People
description: * Roger Mosconi joining the Marschalk Company as a senior vice president.

title: BOGUS SECTIONS OF TIMES GIVEN TO NEWSSTANDS
description: Thousands of copies of a pamphlet designed to look like a section of The New York Times were distributed to some Manhattan newsstands Saturday night, but dealers and Times circulation officials said yesterday that few of the pamphlets had actually been inserted and sold with the paper.

title: Gas Line Price Increase
description: Federal energy regulators have approved a $136 million increase in natural gas prices for the Cities Service Pipe Line Company, while leaving the case open for hearings on a narrow issue in the price dispute. The increase, which affects thousands of gas customers in Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Wyoming, Oklahoma and Texas, goes into effect today. It will be passed through by utilities to their customers.

title: CENSUS IMAGE OF NEW YORK: A CITY IN FLUX
description: The median income of households in New York City, when adjusted for inflation, declined by several thousand dollars in the 1970's. The city lost nearly seven times as many blue-collar as whitecollar workers in the decade, and the losses were heaviest in manufacturing, construction and retail and wholesale trades.

title: David M. Johnstone, 65, Dies; Connecticut G.O.P. Candidate
description: David M. Johnstone, a Republican candidate for the Connecticut House of Representatives, died of a heart attack Friday at Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He lived in Stonington, Conn., and was 65 years old.

title: Christine Froman Married to William Henry Nill Jr.
description: Christine Dina Froman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Froman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Henry Nill Jr., son of Mr. Nill of Westbury, L.I., and Jeanne Baurley Nill of Rye, N.Y., and Hampton Bays, L.I. The Rev. Donald Poole performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: A BOUNCING, ZESTFULL COMMAGER TURNS 80 TODAY
description: Taking the steps two at a time in his rubber-soled brown mocassins and trailing over a half-century of professorial and literary glory behind him, Henry Steele Commager, who will be 80 today, bounded into his seminar on the Bill of Rights at Amherst College, nodded to the 16 freshmen and sophomores facing him around the T-shape table and said without ceremony:

title: APPEAL LOST BY HOME RADIO STATION
description: A man who operates a classical music radio station from his one-room basement apartment in Gloucester, Mass., has lost his final appeal to the Federal Communications Commission to keep his license.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Fleet Financial Group is issuing $30 million of 10.5 percent convertible subordinate debentures due November 2007 through Warburg Paribas Becker/A.G. Becker.

title: Castilla Is Winner On Disqualification
description: Castilla was awarded first place in the $300,000 Yellow Ribbon Stakes today at Santa Anita after Avigaition impeded her a sixteenth of a mile from the finish and was disqualified.

title: Banker From Italy Gets L.I. Trust Post
description: The Long Island Trust Company has named Mario Arcari, who has spent his career at Banca Commerciale Italiana, as president and chief administrative officer.

title: WHEN IS UNEMPLOYMENT 'NATURAL'?
description: It has long been assumed, at least in political debate, that full employment in the United States is reached when the jobless rate falls to roughly 4 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Peete Wins 4th Event

title: KENNEDY AND SHAMIE DEBATE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy tonight attacked President Reagan's economic policies as ''ill-advised, illconceived and inequitable,'' while his Republican opponent, Raymond Shamie, accused Mr. Kennedy of being a ''part-time senator.''

title: AT END OF CAMPAIGN
description: In a campaign commercial, Representative Toby Moffett tells Connecticut voters that Senator Lowell Weicker opposes ''domestic-content'' legislation designed to protect the American automobile industry from Japanese competition. ''I'm for it, and that's one of the big differences between us,'' concludes Representative Moffett, the Democratic nominee opposing Senator Weicker, a Republican.

title: 3D-QUARTER PROFITS FELL 15% TO 20%
description: Corporate profits in the third quarter slumped 15 percent to 20 percent from the third quarter of 1981, economists estimate. Companies did benefit from spending cuts taken earlier in the year and from declining interest rates. But weaker demand and unexpected factors, such as the sharp drop in value of the Mexican peso, generally wiped out the gains.

title: DRAFT REGISTRY CASE ENMESHES U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration's method of prosecuting a relative handful of the 524,000 youths who have violated the draft registration law, in hopes of scaring others into compliance, has run into a tangled legal problem and an angry Federal judge in Los Angeles.

title: Heller Sees Recovery Lag
description: Walter Heller, an economist who served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, said today that there was no visible economic recovery for voters to consider before going to the polls next month. He compared President Reagan's plea to ''stay the course'' with the voyage of the Titanic.

title: Poll Says U.S.-Europe Friction Doesn't Affect Public Opinion
description: Policy differences between the United States and its European allies have apparently not affected public opinion in most Western countries, according to a poll conducted for The International Herald Tribune and the Atlantic Institute.

title: Sudanese Leaves Egypt
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Gaafar el-Nimeiry of the Sudan discussed Middle East events today before Mr. Nimeiry left Khartoum after a visit to Cairo, the official Middle East News Agency said.

title: New Elections Are Set By Hamburg Assembly
description: The Hamburg State Assembly voted today to dissolve itself and hold new elections on Dec. 19 to try to resolve a six-month political stalemate in the city.

title: Bomb Defused in Tel Aviv
description: Explosive experts dismantled a small bomb hidden in a soft drink at a bus stop opposite Tel Aviv's central bus station today, authorities said. The bomb was found by a civilian who told the police.

title: Deportation Sought for Man Accused in '43 Killing of Jews
description: The Government has moved to deport Bohdan Koziy, a 59-year-old native of the Ukraine who is accused of shooting to death a Jewish child and taking part in the murder of a Jewish family in 1943.

title: A FATHER AND HIS SON STICK TOGETHER
description: When the wave hit, nearly everyone aboard the Joan La Rie III was inside the cabin. It was 11 in the morning and it had been a good day. Vincent Mezzetti had hooked seven blues. Someone else had brought in 26. And the 50-foot boat was lumbering home in swells that seemed to grow larger by the minute. More and more people became seasick, and a few staggered onto the deck.

title: THE FORTRESS FAMILY
description: A generation ago, William Zeckendorf, real estate tycoon and visionary, assembled a group of the highest-powered men in America for 7:00 A.M. breakfast once a week to plot a revolution in American living.

title: SALAZAR WINS CITY MARATHAN IN A CLOSE DUEL
description: Alberto Salazar and Rodolfo Gomez staged a straining, side-by-side duel over the last six miles of the New York City Marathon yesterday before Salazar, in the event's closest finish, won his third consecutive title by only four seconds.

title: BRIEFING
description: Where the Money Is

title: Lion Mauls Man In Brooklyn Zoo
description: A Parks Department employee was mauled by a lion yesterday at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, but a visitor came to his aid by distracting the lion.

title: Transition Games
description: American basketball players with a touch of wanderlust have transported their highly polished skills to many foreign countries in the last couple of decades. Former college stars, unable to land berths in the National Basketball Association, have gone to such countries as Italy, France, Spain and Sweden to perpetuate their playing careers.

title: Baseball Typecasting
description: The ranking statistics that are used to determine which free agents require additional compensation are not the last word on players' relative performances, but they are the most comprehensive rating system baseball has undertaken. Nevertheless, there are some questionable matters found in the rankings.

title: ATOM-FUEL SHIPMENT PLAN STIRS A CITY
description: For 30 years, Stanley and Omadeane Talley have listened to the trains roar by their modest brick home 15 minutes before and after the hour, just like clockwork.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Friend of the Court
description: Ask a friend for advice and you sometimes get more than you bargained for. That may have happened to the Supreme Court when the justices heard William Coleman, their invited ''friend of the Court,'' argue against tax breaks for schools with racist policies. Here was a friend and professional peer who spoke straight from the shoulder.

title: Eric L. Stone Marries Katharine Martin
description: Katharine Burke Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Read Martin Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Eric Lewis Stone, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard David Stone of Sarasota, Fla., formerly of Weston, Conn., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Bartow-Pell Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, by the Rev. Christopher T. Webber, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville.

title: FOR SPANISH CENTRIST, ALL IS DOWNHILL
description: Many people in Spain talk about former Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez these days, and most regret the eclipse that seems to await him in Spain's third post-Franco general election next Thursday.

title: Choices for the City Council
description: Only some seats in New York's City Council are hotly contested in next week's general election. Ranging through the districts, we offer these special recommendations, giving weight to competence and incumbency. (Unless otherwise identified, all are Democrats, many with Liberal endorsements.)

title: 175 Arrested at Celebration
description: About 600 people stormed a bridge early this morning after a University of Wisconsin-Stout homecoming celebration, and the authorities arrested about 175 of them when they threatened to stop traffic on Interstate 94, the officials said.

title: CREDIT EXTENDERS WHO WANT TO HOLD DEBTORS IN BONDAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebrating a Renaissance At Jamaica Arts Center

title: ILLNESS LURKS BENEATH WEST BERLIN'S HIGH SPIRITS
description: This sentinel city, once the focus of high cold war drama, is stuck in a quiet and almost banal crisis of economic decline.

title: VARIETY LEADS TO OKLAHOMA VICTORIES
description: Oklahoma entered this season determined to make up for its 7-4-1 record of 1981, the worst in nine years under Coach Barry Switzer. But when the Sooners lost two of their first three games, some Oklahoma rooters became impatient and wanted Switzer ousted.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Executive Polish

title: Robin S. Flitt Married To Randy J. Schafer
description: Robin Sue Flitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Flitt, was married in Rivervale, N.J., yesterday to Randy Jeffrey Schafer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Schafer. Both families are of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Martin Freedman performed the ceremony at the Edgewood Country Club.

title: SPECIAL U.S. FORCE FOR PERSIAN GULF IS GROWING SWIFTLY
description: The Rapid Deployment Force, scheduled to become a full-scale military command on Jan. 1, is swiftly expanding in size as well as in its potential mission and area of operations, according to officers here and in Washington.

title: No Headline
description: MISS NAVRATILOVA TAKES FINAL, 6-3, 6-3

title: E.P.A. Gives Its Plan to Allow States More Say Over Water
description: The Reagan Administration has released a proposal to give states more power to decide how clean their lakes and streams must be.

title: Kornhauser & Calene Forms Fashion Group
description: Kornhauser & Calene Advertising Agency has formed a new unit called the Fashion Marketing Group, and has popped into it a new client called Daniel Axel Inc., a manufacturer of men's sportswear and swimwear.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Shopping for Schools At a Weekend Fair

title: Diane Sharon of H.B.O. Is Bride of Allen Nadler
description: Diane M. Sharon, a director at Home Box Office, was married in New York yesterday to Allen Nadler, a vice president and senior security analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: PANEL ON ECONOMY CITES SOCIAL COST
description: Economic policies that consider only profit bring substantial social cost that can be measured, a conference on jobs, productivity and industrial cities was told this week.

title: Moscow Is Said to Bar Jewish Chess Players
description: Dissident sources said today that the Soviet police had barred a group of Jewish chess players from visiting the former Soviet chess champion, Boris Gulko, who is on hunger strike to support his demand to be allowed to emigrate to Israel.

title: WHAT AMERICANS MUST KNOW ABOUT THE U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Arms Cache Found
description: A merchant and his two sons were arrested today after the police discovered a cache of Soviet-made arms in a cellar in the courtyard of their house, police sources said. They said the cache included one mortar, seven shotguns, five rifles, four revolvers and ammunition.

title: A.C.L.U. SEES ADMINISTRATION AS A DANGER TO CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: The head of the American Civil Liberties Union accused the Reagan Administration today of ''ideological opposition to civil liberties'' and said that the Administration and its supporters in Congress had been responsible for ''the most dangerous threats to civil liberties'' in recent years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in New York Day by Day on Thursday about the 1980 Federal cen- sus incorrectly listed the average per capita income for four boroughs. The correct figures are Queens, $7,588; Staten Island, $7,576; Brooklyn, $5,771, and the Bronx, $5,348.

title: FOR SANITATION, TOUGH CHOICES LOOM
description: For the city's Sanitation Department, adhering to Mayor Koch's directive to reduce all municipal budgets by 6 percent will require some delicate compromises, according to Norman Steisel, the agency's Commissioner.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The most awful dictatorship that humanity has known is the dictatorship of the proletariat.'' - Armando Valladares, a Cuban poet freed last week after 22 years in prison. (A8:2.)

title: Dali Is Sued By a Former Secretary
description: Peter Moore, a former secretary of Salvador Dali, filed a $360,000 suit against the artist Thursday. It was the second suit filed by Mr. Moore, a British art dealer, against the artist.

title: Richmond Race Won by O'Flynn
description: Sean O'Flynn of the University of Richmond, the favorite, won the fifth annual Richmond Newspapers Marathon today.

title: THREE IN BRONX FOUND TIED UP AND SHOT DEAD
description: Three persons, their hands and feet bound with electrical wire, were found shot to death in a Bronx apartment over the weekend, and the police said yesterday that they had established no motive for the crime.

title: TV: STENDHAL DRAMA AND A DANCE SERIES BEGINS
description: TONIGHT'S schedule is crammed with new series, including Alec Guinness in the masterly ''Smiley's People,'' on Channel 11, WPIX, at 8 (reviewed in yesterday's Arts and Leisure section), and Bill Moyers and Mortimer Adler in ''Six Great Ideas,'' on WNET, Channel 13, at 10, to be reviewed at a later date. That still leaves ''The Charterhouse of Parma'' and ''The Magic of Dance,'' both on public television, plus a new weekly situation-comedy series, ''Newhart,'' and, though not a series, an animated special about a cat, ''Here

title: Fred Siegel, Consultant, Marries Andrea Huppert
description: Andrea Huppert, daughter of Frances D'Arienzo of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Joseph Huppert, was married yesterday to Fred Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Siegel of Gloversville, N.Y. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein performed the ceremony at Harkness House in New York.

title: VIETNAM CRYPT IS STILL EMPTY
description: Between the tombs of the unknown soldiers of World War II and the Korean War at Arlington National Cemetery is a crypt that has remained empty for nearly a decade.

title: Wider Budget Deficits Seen
description: Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said today that her forecast of budget deficits of $155 billion in each of the next three years ''already looks a little optimistic.''

title: West Berlin Squatters In a Battle With Police
description: Squatters battled the West Berlin police with their fists into the early hours today in a fight over a housing shortage that has become a symbol of West German youth protests.

title: SALAZAR AND GRETE WAITZ FIRST IN MARATHON DIVISION
description: THE New York City Marathon is always a great race for atmosphere. Last year it became a great race for time, with Alberto Salazar setting a world record that still stands. Yesterday, it became a great race for competition.

title: ANXIETY, CALMNESS AS RUNNERS GATHER
description: Practice, practice - that is how they got to Lincoln Center in the first place, logging hundreds of miles in roadwork, doing their stretching exercises and eating the right stuff.

title: SCHOOL INFORMATION
description: Admissions representatives from more than 100 boarding schools across the country will be in town on Oct. 27 to meet informally with parents and children and give them information about their schools. The gathering, sponsored by the Parents League of New York as a public service, is to take place at the Day School, Church of the Heavenly Rest entrance, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street.

title: Hush Dear Wins
description: Hush Dear took command entering the stretch and held on to win the 27th running of the $118,600 Long Island Handicap by a length on the Aqueduct grass course yesterday.

title: SEPTEMBER TOOL ORDERS STILL POOR
description: The depressed machine tool industry showed little evidence of a recovery in September. Net new orders totaled $86.8 million, about the same as in August, but 53.7 percent below the level of September 1981.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Arrival and Departure Of a Mysterious Stranger

title: No Headline
description: GULF PEACE EFFORT TO CONTINUE

title: Christopher Daly, Anne Fishel Wed
description: Anne K. Fishel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Fishel of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Burke Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Daly 3d of Medford and Chatham, Mass. Rabbi Martin P. Beifield Jr. performed the ceremony at Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: WHAT AMERICANS MUST KNOW ABOUT THE U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: MAHLER'S NINTH
description: HIS arms hanging suspended from shoulders, his back straight and leaning forward, his hands caressing the air - Herbert von Karajan's conducting was an image of the sound itself as he led the Berlin Philharmonic in Mahler's Ninth Symphony on Saturday night, in his last appearance here this season.

title: NEW YORK BANK PROFITS SURGE
description: Despite problems in collecting on foreign loans, New York City's major bank holding companies reported strong earnings for the third quarter.

title: 'Mass Hysteria' Is Cited In Ailments in California
description: Mass hysteria was responsible for reports of more than 100 cases of food poisoning at a high school football game, a county health official said today.

title: FLOOD OF NEW ISSUES DUE
description: The United States Treasury is expected to announce plans Wednesday for a major borrowing in the first week of November. Elsewhere in the credit markets, the volume of new notes and bonds continues very heavy, with nearly more than $800 billion of corporate issues scheduled for sale this week, along with $2.1 billion of taxexempt issues, according to Salomon Brothers.

title: Magestri Wins Fall Sail
description: Magestri, a new custom C & C 39-foot sloop sailed by Peter Farlinger of Toronto, today won the Long Island Sound invitation fall series.

title: Fiona Vivienne Lunzer, Michael Scharf Married
description: The marriage of Fiona Vivienne Lunzer to Michael Scharf of New York took place yesterday at the Park East Synagogue, of which the bridegroom is president. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony.

title: HAWAII COURT SAYS WORK ON RESORT MUST END
description: A recent decision by the Hawaii Supreme Court has raised the possibility that $30 million in construction of hotels and condominiums on the island of Kauai may have to be razed because the developers started work despite the results of a 1980 referendum against the project.

title: POET FREED BY HAVANNA TELLS OF 7 YEARS IN UNLIGHTED CELL
description: Armando Valladares, a Cuban poet who was freed in Havana last week after 22 years in prison, said tonight that he had been kept for seven years in a cell without light.

title: I.M. PEI'S PEKING HOTEL RETURNS TO CHINA'S ROOTS
description: A procession of Chinese officials dressed in somber blues and grays passed through the lobby of the new Xiangshan Hotel, gaped at the spacious overhead skylight and then headed for the back door leading to the more familiar waterfalls, ponds, rocks and pine trees of the garden.

title: Comparator Chairman Resigns After Dispute
description: After a small company goes public, one of the things that it must be prepared to do is disclose some of its internal strife that it might otherwise have kept to itself.

title: JOB SEEKERS SPEND WEEKEND IN LINE
description: Clutching extra overcoats around them or slipping into discarded cardboard boxes, nearly 60 people slept on the sidewalk along East 26th Street this weekend to insure a place in line Tuesday morning when the New York City District Council of Carpenters hands out 2,000 applications for apprenticeship jobs. People at the front of the line had been encamped since Friday afternoon.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 25, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: HARVESTER CONTINUES WAGE CUTBACK
description: The International Harvester Company disclosed today that it had sent letters to its 9,700 domestic salaried employees informing them that the company would not restore a 5 percent cut in their pay until at least January. The company had said it might restore the deleted wages in November.

title: TRIAL OPENS IN SUIT BY FARM WORKERS
description: Opening arguments began today in a civil suit resulting from a feud within the United Farm Workers Union and a legal challenge to the authority of Cesar Chavez.

title: BELKNAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GETTING READY FOR A PRIME-TIME NEWS CONFERENCE
description: President Reagan, known widely as the Great Communicator, has endured 13 news conferences in his first 21 months in office. His predecessor, Jimmy Carter, held 38 in the same period.

title: Hughes Tool Net Down
description: The Hughes Tool Company the nation's largest supplier of oil drilling equipment, reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income plummeted 50.2 percent, to $11.9 million, from $23.9 million in the 1981 quarter.

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: These figures are corrected from Friday's editions

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $77,500 for the qr and $146,600 for the 6 mos

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE WORLD
description: Rebels threatened today to destroy any vehicle traveling in El Salvador's eastern provinces, paralyzing transportation in the region hardest hit by the guerrillas' two-weekold offensive.

title: TIMES CO. NET UP 4% IN QUARTER
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 4 percent, to $10.8 million, or 86 cents a share, from $10.4 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
ELI H. AXELBANK
description: Eli H. Axelbank, assistant principal of James Monroe High School in the Bronx, died Saturday at his Bronx home.

title: MARATHON PRIZES PUT AT $125,000
description: There were no world records in Sunday's New York City Marathon, but Alberto Salazar and Grete Waitz will be rewarded handsomely as champions.

title: OMNIMEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IRAN CHALLENGES ISRAEL'S RIGHT TO SEAT AT U.N.
description: In a move that caught virtually every delegation by surprise, Iran today challenged Israel's right to sit in the General Assembly.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big 3 Auto Makers Post Slight Sales Increase
description: The nation's three largest automobile manufacturers reported today that new car sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the Oct. 11-20 selling period, despite a slight decline at General Motors.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ SAYS IT KILLED 231 IRANIANS IN BORDER FIGHTING

title: AFFLUENCE AND SCRUTINY DIM ATHLETES' AURA
description: Once, an athlete was revered by the American public, placed on the same pedestal reserved for generals, Medal of Honor winners, movie stars, aviators and more recently astronauts. But to many people - historians, sociologists, educators, and older sports fans - there has been a major change in the athlete's image. Affluence, in many cases the result of bitter collectivebargaining victories by the various player associations, has brought a parade of agents, lawyers and financial advisers into the locker room, shattering the perceived innocence that many fans attached to athletes.

title: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,033,000 for the qr and $1,638,000 for the 9 mos

title: POPE CALLS ON CHINA TO RENEW RELATIONS WITH CHURCH
description: Pope John Paul II appealed today for a reopening of the relationship between the Roman Catholic Church and China, broken off in 1949 with the Communist seizure of power.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to exclude discontinued operations

title: GOOD BOUNCE SET THE STAGE FOR SHOCKER
description: Charles Nuttycombe was watching television with his wife on Saturday at their home in Newport News, Va. As coach of the Menchville High School football team, he was especially interested in one of his former players, now at Wisconsin.

title: Appeal Challenges A.T.&T. Breakup
description: The state of Maryland, two private concerns and the North American Telephone Association have appealed the antitrust settlement requiring the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: TRANS-CANADA RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for 9 mos to July 31
G.M. PROFIT MORE THAN EXPECTED
description: The General Motors Corporation today reported net income of $129.4 million for the third quarter, but this was the result of nonautomotive operations.

title: FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (TAMPA, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
SOPRANO: VICTORIA VILLAMIL
description: EVEN if her Saturday night recital of American Art Songs had been less compelling than it was, the soprano Victoria Villamil would have deserved high praise for her innovative programming and intelligent notes. Happily, Miss Villamil - who combined excellent diction and convincing histrionic ability with a dark, adaptable soprano voice - followed up her research with a strong performance at the Merkin Concert Hall.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People And Maps
description: If the views aired at a conference here on President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative are representative, the plan isn't going down at all well with the English-speaking countries.

title: TV: 2 NEW SERIES BOW
description: TV is introducing two series to its weekly schedule tonight. One, ''Gavilan'' at 9 o'clock , is a ''Magnum, P.I.'' lookalike. The other, ''St. Elsewhere'' at 10, is a ''Hill Street Blues'' lookalike. Television originality marches on.

title: POETRY CONSULTANT'S OFFICE IN AN AERIE
description: ''It's the best view in town,'' said Anthony Hecht, sauntering toward the window of his stately office with its perspective on the gleaming Capitol dome and the carpet of green that slopes beyond to the Washington Monument.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split on Aug 17, 1982

title: NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOEING IS OFF 25.8% AS SALES DROP 7.2%
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings dropped 25.8 percent and its sales declined 7.2 percent. The company cited a sharp fall in aircraft deliveries.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Special Visit To the Theater

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Rev figures represent billings

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings figure is adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd in May 1981 and a 3-for-2 stock split in Sept 1981

title: PANTRY PRIDE SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $270,000 for the qr and a loss of $3,892,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $8,174,000 for the yr...C-Including losses from discontinued operations of $112,000 for the qr and $3,892,000 for the yr an extraordinary gain of $162,588,000 for the qr and the yr an an accounting charge of $1,820,000 for the yr; yr-ago sales include sales from terminated supermarket operations of $58,763 for the qr and $316,598 for theyr; the company is listed on the Pacific, Boston & Philadelphia stock exchange

title: Ruvoldt Bids Court Dismiss Indictment
description: A defense attorney asked a Federal judge today to dismiss an extortion indictment against Prosecutor Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. of Hudson County.

title: I.M.F. Argentine Credit
description: The Argentine Government is close to agreement with an International Monetary Fund mission visiting Buenos Aires on the terms of a $2 billion credit package that includes a $1.5 billion loan, senior Government sources said today. Walter Robincheck, director for the Western Hemisphere of the monetary fund, will take a letter of intent to Washington on Tuesday, the sources said.

title: NOW IS THE TIME TO DEMILITARIZE SPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Settlement Made In Bo Rein Suit
description: The widow of Bo Rein, the former Louisiana State University football coach, has reached an out-ofcourt settlement on her $10 million damage suit over his death in January 1980.

title: EXAMS BAR PLAYOFF, COLGATE DECLARES
description: Colgate University has notified the National Collegiate Athletic Association that its football team will not participate in postseason playoffs because of a conflict with final examinations.

title: Alagaroo!
description: Times indeed have changed for the City College soccer team, which recently won its first Metropolitan Conference title since 1961 - before the American soccer boom, when the Beavers were a national powerhouse.

title: Diversifying Armco Promotes Officer
description: Robert E. Boni has been named chief operating officer of Armco Inc. and designated as the successor to the current president, D.C. Boone, when Mr. Boone retires Jan. 31.

title: CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect a provision of $333,000 subtracted for estimated costs of closing the Piermont mill

title: PINE POINT MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a net gain of $1.4 million on the sale of a subsidiary and a net credit of $1.1 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating income...C-Net income

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do astronomers decide how far away a star is?

title: HOW FILM WAS REPRESSED IN POLAND
description: A TRANSCRIPT of a film-censorship proceeding, sent secretly from Poland to the West, offers an unusual gimpse into the cultural policies of the regime in Warsaw.

title: 50 G.I.'s Seized in Drug Case
description: The United States Army said today that it had arrested 50 American soldiers on drug charges in a major blow against drug trafficking. The arrests last Friday raised to 87 the number of soldiers arrested here for drug offenses in the last eight weeks. A spokesman for the army's Criminal Investigation Division said an eight-week investigation had resulted in the confiscation of $343,000 worth of hashish, marijuana, LSD and amphetamines.

title: BATTLE FOR A FRENCH CONTRACT
description: Three sophisticated aircraft, two American and one the product of an Anglo-French collaboration, are competing for a multimillion-dollar French contract that may be the United States aviation industry's last big military sales opportunity in Europe for some time.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-Including a net gain of $53,000 from the extinguishment of debt...C-Includingtax credits of $220,000 for the qr and $816,000 for the 9 mos and gains on the disposal of facilities of $36,000 for the qr and $1,135,000 for the 9 mos

title: NO AGREEMENT ON NEW TALKS
description: The chief negotiators for the National Football League's players and its owners spoke by telephone yesterday to see what they could do to end the players' strike. But each side later remembered the conversation differently from the other, an indication that the strike was likely to cause yet another weekend, a sixth, of games not played.

title: UMPIRE WINS BIG ONE
description: Listen. You can still hear the World Series fading into the distance. In casual conversations on the street, on subway trains, in elevators, one can catch snatches of people recalling McGee's winged catch, Yount's record hits and subsequent disappointment, Sutter's invincibility, Herzog's ruminations, and Caldwell's dank and ravaged cap.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
O'Neill Shooting Called an Accident
description: Police officers in Bedford, N.Y., who interviewed the actress Jennifer O'Neill said yesterday that she shot herself accidentally last Friday with a .38-caliber revolver while she was trying to determine if it was loaded.

title: Northwest Air Net Up
description: Northwest Airlines yesterday reported a third-quarter net income of $27 million, or $1.25 a share, up 54.3 percent from $17.5 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 9 percent, to $574.9 million, from $527.3 million. Northwest said its operating income of $47.9 million surpassed that of any other quarter in its history.

title: EXPLORATION SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McDonald's Up 14.6%
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that net income in the third quarter rose 14.6 percent, to $86.9 million, or $1.45 a share, from $75.8 million, or $1.24 a share, in the 1981 period. Sales grew 10.4 percent, to $737.7 million from $668.1 million.

title: 2 NEWSMEN WIN CABOT PRIZES IN JOURNALISM OF THE AMERICAS
description: The 44th annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes in inter-American journalism have been announced by Columbia University. William Long, day city editor of The Miami Herald, and Daniel Samper, columnist and head of the investigative reporting unit of El Tiempo in Bogota, Colombia, will each receive a Cabot Gold Medal and $1,000.

title: POST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Healthdyne Gets Narco Shares
description: Healthdyne Inc. said 674,868 shares of Narco Scientific Inc. had been tendered to it following Healthdyne's $30-a-share bid for the medical equipment company.

title: Pennwalt Stock
description: The Pennwalt Corporation, a manufacturer of chemicals, health products and precision equipment based in Philadelphia, reported that a Denver investor had purchased 878,000 shares of Pennwalt common stock and 46,000 shares of convertible preferred stock.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a charge of $1,305,000 from the writedown of shareholdings in an unconsolidated affiliate

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Beverly Enterprises filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 1.2 million shares of common stock through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ceausescu in Yugoslavia
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, arrived here today on a visit. He was met at the airport by President Petar Stambolic.

title: LAST FINISHER: PRIDE AND JOY
description: Long after Alberto Salazar and Grete Waitz had won their titles, and four hours after the last finisher had supposedly reached Tavern-On-The-Green in Central Park, Linda Down crossed the finish line in the New York City Marathon on Sunday. The time of day: 9:30 P.M.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MITSUBISHI'S U.S. CAR VENTURE
description: In the beginning it was just Toyota and Datsun. Then Honda earned a place in the American automobile market. Others followed: Mazda, Subaru, Isuzu. This fall Mitsubishi, one of Japan's industrial giants, will try to carve out a segment in the increasingly crowded field of Japanese companies selling cars in the United States.

title: TOP OFFICIALS AID CANDIDATES IN U.S. SENATE RACE IN JERSEY
description: The Democratic and Republican candidates for the United States Senate turned to leaders of their own parties today for support in the last full week of campaigning before the election.

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STOCK PRICES SLIDE ON RATES WORRIES
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, the best-known measure of stock market prices, plunged 36.33 points yesterday as concern mounted that the decline in interest rates might be ending.

title: Excerpts from letter, page A22
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops made public a proposed pastoral letter today asserting that nuclear weapons could destroy the world and calling any first use of those weapons irrational and immoral.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BancTexas Group Inc., Dallas, formerly Commerce Southwest Inc., has elected Thomas J. Hodson executive vice president-finance and chief financial officer, and L. David Harrison executive vice president and treasurer.

title: COLLEGES WEIGH EXPANDED RULES ON WRITING SKILL
description: A controversial proposal under consideration at City College of the City University of New York would put the institution among a select group working actively to promote the teaching of writing skills in subjects other than English.

title: STAGE: SLAVERY RECALLED
description: FIRSTHAND memories of former slaves, recorded in the late 1930's under the Federal Writers Project, form the basis of James de Jongh's ''Do Lord Remember Me,'' a moving evocation of shared servitude. The collage of stories and pertinent songs of the period opened last night at the American Place Theater after a previous engagement several seasons ago at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater.

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $4 million or 60 cents a shr, from the sale of certain credit bureau operations and land; shr earnings reflect a 100 percent stock divd paid Sept 15

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLICE CHIEF'S GAMBLING TRIAL A TRIAL FOR TORRINGTON, CONN.
description: Two police officers stood beside a playground here the other day as several youngsters shouted at them the latest joke in town. ''If you want to place a bet,'' it went, ''call 911.''

title: U.S. INQUIRY DUE ON LOSS OF EIGHT IN BOAT SINKING
description: A Federal board of inquiry will convene in Manhattan tomorrow to investigate the sinking of a fishing boat with the loss of eight lives off Point Pleasant, N.J., on Sunday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Harmony and Speed When 77-year-old Nathan Milstein bowed out at the last minute from Sunday's annual United Nations Day concert in the General Assembly auditorium, it was Israeli-born Pinchas Zukerman who stepped in as pinch-hitter for the Beethoven violin concerto with the New York Philharmonic. It wasn't simple.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXXON, PHILLIPS, GETTY INCOME DOWN
description: The Exxon Corporation, blaming weak demand and a squeeze on profit margins, said yesterday that its net income for the third quarter fell five-tenths of 1 percent in spite of an unusually large gain from foreign currency translations.

title: SHULTZ ENDS A VISIT TO OTTAWA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended a 24-hour visit to Canada today that was intended to patch up differences between Washington and Ottawa.

title: Chile Will Consider Return of Exiles
description: President Augusto Pinochet said today that his Government would examine the cases of political exiles who fled or were expelled from Chile after the 1973 coup to consider whether to allow them to return home.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $545,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $9,493,000 on the sale of GEO Space Corp

title: Georgia Pacific, Indonesia Accord
description: The Georgia Pacific International Corporation has signed a joint venture agreement with the Indonesian Government to build a $410 million kraft paper plant in north Sumatra, the semiofficial Antara News Agency reported.

title: Cutback in Police Is Not Ruled Out
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that although he had no plans to lay off police officers the size of the police force might decline because the city's budget problems could prevent him from hiring officers to replace those who retire or resign.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NORTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ECONOMIC ANGER HURTING INCUMBENT
description: In the northern reaches of California, the leaves in the vineyards are turning from green to rust, and the people who live along the rugged coast, a world shrouded by dreary fog much of the year, are enjoying the last days of a brilliant Indian summer.

title: CORDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $251,000 from equity in income of Cordis Down Corp and anextraordinary credit of $300,000...C-After a loss of $833,000 from equity in loss of Cordis Dow Corp and an extraordinary credit of $30,000; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: ROYAL CROWN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income, including a tax credit of $21,000 for the qr and yr

title: Football Player Dies After Game
description: A 14-year-old lineman on the freshman football team at Northern Burlington Regional High School died in a hospital Saturday about six hours after having played in a game.

title: Hockey Player Still in Danger
description: Normand Leveille, a 19-year-old forward for the Boston Bruins, lay in poor condition with the support of a respirator today, his life still ''at risk'' from a brain hemorrhage that caused his collapse during a game here Saturday night, a spokesman for Vancouver General Hospital said.

title: Arby's Drops Lois Pitts
description: The word is going around that Arby's Inc., the Atlanta-based national chain of fast food restaurants specializing in roast beef sandwiches, has dismissed its advertising agency, Lois Pitts Gershon, after two years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gerrie Coetzee has fractured his right hand while sparring and has withdrawn from his heavyweight bout against Alfonso Ratliff in Atlantic City Saturday. Coetzee originally had been scheduled to fight Pinklon Thomas, but Thomas pulled out last week, saying he had injured his back in training. ... Michael Jordan, whose jump shot with 16 seconds left in the championship game last March gave North Carolina the N.C.A.A. basketball title, fractured his left wrist in practice and will wear a cast for three weeks.

title: Rates Climb, but Trend Is Doubted; 6-Month Bills Rise to 8.472%
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday in what many analysts described as a technical correction after the huge declines earlier this month. They said the latest wiggle in rates was not the beginning of a sustained increase.

title: CPT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kohl Fiscal Policy Criticized
description: West Germany's five leading economic research institutes today criticized policies of the new Conservative Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, arguing that a proposed tax increase and other revenue-raising measures could prolong the economic slump by stifling consumer demand.

title: AFFILIATED HOSPITAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUTLER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $931,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: Youth Honored At Series Is Dead
description: Robert Bartholf, the 17-year-old high school senior who threw out the first ball at the third game of the World Series, died of leukemia Saturday.

title: Cable TV's Prospects
description: Michael H. Dann, now a senior adviser to the video enterprises division of the American Broadcasting Companies, was a broadcast television executive for 25 years, serving as programming head at two networks - NBC and CBS.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1982
description: International Lebanese-Israeli negotiations, with United States participation, have been set and could start later this week in the Beirut area, according to a senior State Department official. The conferees, he said, will seek a formula for Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ariel Sharon told an inquiry in Jerusalem that he had not learned that a massacre of Palestinian civilians was occurring in Beirut refugee camps until Friday evening, Sept. 17, more than 24 hours after it had begun and about nine hours after it had been ordered halted by his senior officers. The Israeli Defense Minister spoke at the first open session of the judicial commission that was established to define the extent of Israeli responsibility in the killings. (A1:5.)

title: UNITED AMERICAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
ABC Reports Record Profit
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that it earned a record $35.5 million, or $1.22 a share, in the third quarter ended Oct. 2, up 4.1 percent from $34.1 million, or $1.19 a share, in the 1981 period.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DeLorean Motor Files Bankruptcy
description: The DeLorean Motor Company, the United States distribution company for the sportscar of the same name, filed today for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Gas Leaks Empty 16 Bronx Houses
description: Gas leaks forced the evacuation of 16 Bronx houses Bronx yesterday, officials said.

title: Chess: Hungary's Andras Adorjan Wins Tourney in Budapest
description: The grandmaster Andras Adorjan, who will play for the powerful Hungarian team in the Olympiad beginning Saturday in Lucerne, Switzerland, smoothly won the Elekes Memorial Tournament in Budapest with an 8 1/2-2 1/2 score.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH FILMS

title: ELECTRONIC MEMORIES & MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: Addenda
description: * Time magazine increasing its circulation rate base 2.3 percent, to 4.5 million, and its advertising rates almost 10 percent, with the Jan. 3 issue.

ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including unrealized foreign currency translation gains of $822,000 or 3 cents a shr for the qr and $4,591,000 or 18 cents a shr for the 9 mos and foreign currency translation losses of $1,807,000 for the qr and $5,133,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including unrealized foreign currency translation gains of $3,639,000 or 15 cents a shr for the qr and $16,879,000 or 68 cents a shr for the 9 mos and foreign currency translation losses of $3,023,000 for the qr and $9,918,000 for the 9mos

title: The Uranium Trade Ploy
description: America's uranium producers want Congress to limit future imports. Without protection, they argue, the nation could become dangerously dependent on foreign producers.

title: Dismissal Denied
description: Muddy Waters, the coach of the Michigan State football team, which has lost all seven of its games this season, altered his stand significantly as to whether his job was in jeopardy.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. Orders Wide Recall Of General Motors Cars
description: The Government today ordered that the General Motors Corporation recall 609,000 1978-model cars to correct pollution control problems.

title: Political Analysis
description: A few weeks ago, White House political strategists were saying that President Reagan's schedule for October was being kept flexible so that he could move rapidly into key states to help Republican

title: Strong Earthquake Hits Area of Central California
description: A strong earthquake rocked at least a 14-county area of central California today, but there were no reports of injuries or major damage in the sparsely populated area, the officials said.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 mos results were adversely affected by a month-long strike

title: ICAHN MAKES DUAL OFFER FOR DAN RIVER
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, offered yesterday to pay stockholders of Dan River Inc. either $15 a share or $18 a share for a big stake in the old-line Southern textile producer, depending on how the company reacts to the offer.

title: OUR JOB-CREATING WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stock Index Futures Off; Two End at Discounts
description: Not surprisingly, prices of all three stock index futures plunged yesterday along with the four actual market indexes. But two of the three index futures closed at discounts to the actual indexes and thus afforded traders a further insight into the behavior of these new markets, particularly the role played by dividend dates.

title: ANGRY BRITISH M.P.'S CHARGE SPY SCANDAL IS PLAYED DOWN
description: Angry members of Parliament accused the Government today of playing down the importance of a breach in security at a topsecret intelligence-gathering center in Britain.

title: U.S. RETIREES ARE THE 'PESO PRISONERS' OF MEXICO
description: Over the last few years, thousands of American retirees have moved to the little villages overlooking Lake Chapala, attracted by idyllic weather, inexpensive domestic service and the friendly peace of rural Mexico. It is not the only American colony in Mexico, but it has long been one of the happiest.

title: VOTER PROJECT IN SOUTH SET FOR REVIVAL
description: The Voter Education Project, once an aggressive leader of efforts in the South to register blacks to vote, appears poised for a revival.

title: Military Analysis
description: Despite Israel's victory over Palestinian guerrillas and Syrian troops in Lebanon last summer, Israeli intelligence officials say they are concerned over the pace of arms supplies to Arab nations. They say this could eventually erode Israel's superiority.

title: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from disc oper of $927,000 for the qr & $2,376,000 for the 9 mos;C-After income from disc oper of $385,000; the latest qr includes pretax foreign exchange gain of $578,000 compared to a similar gain of $806,000 in yr-ago period

title: RIO GRANDE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REDLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NUCLEAR DELUSION. Soviet- American Relations in the Atomic Age. By George F. Kennan. 207 pages. Pan- theon. $13.95.

title: Steel Import View Due
description: Bill Brock, the trade representative, will make a recommendation to President Reagan by Tuesday on how to handle what the specialty steel industry contends is a damaging flood of unfair imports, his trade office said today. Industry sources hope Mr. Brock will call for import curbs and that the restrictions will be more comprehensive than those contained in the agreement announced last week with the Common Market on carbon steel.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: TIME was, not too long ago, when a school administrator could be crucified as subversive for advocating the teaching of world affairs. Well into the 1950's, isolationists denounced one-world idealism as ''globaloney.'' But times have changed. The American Association of School Administrators (A.A.S.A.) and New York State Education Department have just demonstrated, independently, that the schools are ready for the once-suspect ''global education.'' Both urged principals to integrate a world view into the curriculum.

title: Damage Suit Is Settled In Death After Hazing
description: An undisclosed out-of-court settlement was reached today in a $64 million damage suit filed by the mother of an Alfred University student who died in a fraternity hazing in 1978.

title: Breaking a Silence
description: ARTHUR M. SCHLESINGER JR., liberal Democrat that he is, wasn't at all pleased with the Jimmy Carter Presidency. He'd wanted the White House for Senator Edward M. Kennedy and, as he kept saying for the next four years, albeit in wittily mordant prose, Mr. Carter was not just a Republican in Democrat's clothing but an incompetent one at that.

title: SIPPICAN OCEAN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices plunged, reflecting investor concern over the course of interest rates. Pension funds and institutional investors unloaded large blocks of stock, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 36.33 points, to 995.13, its second-biggest single-day drop ever. Trading volume was moderate, remaining well below recent record levels. The largest stock market decline occurred on Oct. 28, 1929, during the crash that preceded the Depression. (Page A1.)

title: New York Legislative Choices
description: In assessing Senate and Assembly candidates in next Tuesday's election, we give weight to incumbency and seniority. Here are our choices in races deserving special attention:

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clearest Lake Seen Becoming Cloudy
description: Often cited as the clearest lake in the world, Crater Lake in Oregon is getting progressively cloudier, and scientists think microscopic plant life could be the cause.

title: Lift Mark Is Set
description: Tom Hardman, a 29-year-old medical intern, set a world record for the bench press Saturday night, lifting 614.4 pounds in the Georgia Elite power-lifting championships, an event sanctioned by the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits Scoreboard
NATIONAL BANK OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $2,590,000

title: Brewers Rehire Kuenn
description: Harvey Kuenn will be back to manage the Milwaukee Brewers next season. The 51-year-old Kuenn was named interim manager as the successor to the discharged Bob Rodgers last June 2 and then directed the Brewers to the American League pennant.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLEY'S COMET: THE LONG HELLO BEGINS
description: SOME photons traversing more than a billion miles of space arrived at the earth 10 days ago, bearing a message long awaited. These particles of radiant energy, from sunlight reflected off a vagabond chunk of dirty ice, registered a faint impression on a silicon-chip sensor near the base of the great 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar in California. Astronomers saw the speck of recorded light and recognized its meaning. The most celebrated comet is now back in view, Halley's comet.

title: Zellerbach Talk On Sale of Unit
description: The Crown Zellerbach Company said it is holding talks on selling its 84 percent interest in Crown Zellerbach Canada Ltd. It did not identify the prospective buyer.

title: MARATHON COVERAGE ENLIVENED BY DETAIL
description: Unless you count chess, it's hard to imagine a sport less naturally suited to television coverage than the marathon. Watching phalanxes of emaciated-looking people run with moderate speed through city streets has to rate just below bowling as a spectator sport. In bowling, at least, there is the faint excitement of seeing pins go down. Running itself is monotonous; watching runners may induce narcolepsy.

title: WHY SUE THE C.I.A.?
description: On Oct. 4, the United States Supreme Court declined to hear a lawsuit I brought against the Central Intelligence Agency. I was suing under the Freedom of Information Act to get the list of ''well over 1,000 books'' that according to the Church Committee report of April 1976 had been ''produced, subsidized or sponsored by the C.I.A. before the end of 1967.'' Why should my case be of interest? Because it illustrates how easy it is for the C.I.A. and the courts to subvert the Freedom of Information Act, closing off the access to Government documents that the law is supposed to provide.

title: SETTLEMENT NEAR IN A PANTHER SUIT
description: The civil rights lawsuit stemming from a 1969 police raid in which two leaders of the Black Panthers were killed is close to being settled for $1.85 million, a Government attorney said today.

SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OTTER TAIL POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SOCIALISTS WIN A BIG MAJORITY OF MAYORAL RACES IN GREECE
description: Greece's governing Socialist Party has elected mayors in the overwhelming majority of cities and towns around the country, according to final results of municipal elections made public today.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Longer a Secret

description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $15.8 million from an exchange of stock for debentures...D-After a pretax charge of $43.6 million for reorganization and consolidation expenses

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE PAYMENT OF INTEREST POLAND OWES BANKS
description: The State Department announced details today of President Reagan's plan to suspend tariff benefits on imports from Poland because of its ban of the independent Solidarity trade union movement.

title: Wells, Rich Promotion
description: James B. Lawrence, 35-year-old stepson of Mary Wells Lawrence, chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene, has been named senior vice president and managing director of the Detroit office of the agency.

COLOMBIA WON'T BE CUP HOST
description: The Colombian Government dropped out yesterday as the host country for the 1986 international soccer tournament, the World Cup, thus opening the way for the United States, Canada or Brazil to take over the championship. The World Cup is the most important athletic event for much of Europe and Latin America.

GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIANIST: IVAN MORAVEC PLAYS JANACEK'S 'MIST'
description: THE admirers of Ivan Moravec seem to be growing from a minor cult into a near-political movement, and Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall they rallied together to relish their favorite pianist's art.

title: Cholera in Java Kills 39
description: A cholera epidemic has left 39 dead and more than 200 hospitalized in the central Java area of Banyumas, about 300 miles east of here, the newspaper Sinar Harapan said today. It quoted a health official as having said that a shortage of clean drinking water after a drought was believed to have caused the outbreak.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fortnightly Wins
description: Fortnightly, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., held off Caveat by a head yesterday to win the $75,000 Pilgrim Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Says 'Yes,' But His Face Says 'Maybe'

title: CROSS & TRECKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
AMERICAN BROADCASTING COS INC (ABC) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Egypt Raises Oil Prices
description: Traders in the European crude oil spot market reported today that Egypt had raised November prices for two types of crude. Gharib will cost $26.75 a barrel, up 25 cents, and Belayim $29, up 40 cents.

title: Historic Dates for Dow Average
description: Here is a chronology of historic dates for the Dow Jones industrials average: 1896: First appears in The Wall Street Journal. Jan. 12, 1906: Closes above 100 for the first time, at 100.25. Sept. 3, 1929: Reaches its closing peak for the bull market of the 1920's, at 381.17, less than two months before the Great Crash. Oct. 28, 1929: Records biggest drop ever, 38.33 points, closing at 260.64. July 8, 1932: Closes at its Depression low of 41.22, having fallen 89 percent in less than three years.

title: Advertising; The Role Of Reader Research
description: There were two areas of conflict as the annual meeting of the Magazine Publishers Association got underway at the Cerromar Beach Hotel here today. title: An Out-of-State Lew Plagues Rome's Race

Rome, also a Republican, who wants the job in Hartford. No voter will have to choose between the two, because they are running in different states, but Mr. Rome has taken to calling Mr. Lehrman ''my other competitor.''

title: STORM DELIVERS GUST OF WINTER TO NEW YORKERS
description: The northern edge of a harsh Atlantic storm surprised the New York metropolitan region yesterday with cold, gale-driven rain. It made life unhappy for many people caught without umbrellas and winter clothing, and was especially difficult for demonstrators in a Brooklyn park.

Owens.

title: SPORTS VIOLENCE SEEN AS RITUAL AMID THE CHAOS
description: TORONTO VIOLENCE in professional ice hockey, a scholar at the University of Maine suggests, has become as formal and ritualized as a medieval duel. ''Although fist fights are spontaneous and sometimes vicious,'' James Herlan, the scholar, said here last weekend, ''they are nevertheless subject to certain ceremonial prescriptions to determine the nature of the battle. The first important element is the throwing down on the ice of the protective gloves, an act that provides a marvelous connection with the medieval ritual of throwing down the gauntlet.'' Ushers show patrons to their seats; games begin with the solemn playing of the national anthems; the spectacle is divided into three acts, and players attired in stylized costumes zip about in a sort of speeded-up theater-in-the-round.

title: IOWA FARMERS GLOOMY ON OUTLOOK, BUT SEEN TO BEAR REAGAN NO ILL WILL
description: Even if recovery is in sight, as President Reagan asserts, the farmers, small-town merchants, and country bankers in this once prosperous area believe it will take up to two years for them to recoup from the worst recession they have endured in 42 years.

title: A PLATONIC RELATIONSHIP
description: ALMOST 20 years ago, Plato was born - not Socrates' younger associate, obviously, but Plato the computer-based educational system marketed by Control Data Corporation. Somehow I always thought it would have been more appropriate for Control Data to have invoked Aristotle's name, rather than Plato's, when baptizing the system. Plato, after all, was the creative tinkerer of words and Utopian dreams, who, in modern argot, would say, ''Let's grab life and really shake it up.'' Aristotle, his rational and scientific student, would reply, ''Let's find out what we have first, and then tear it down - if we have to.''

title: Lincoln Drops Frank

Frank, 51 years old, is the first college president and the first black to hold the N.C.A.A.'s highest elected position.

title: Angola Rebels Report Raids

A Lisbon-based spokesman for the Union for the Total Liberation of Angola, the anti-Government guerrilla group headed by Jonas Savimbi, said 600 prisoners who were not identified were released in one raid.

description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Representative Toby Moffett, meeting in their last debate before the Nov. 2 election, clashed again tonight over which one would be more effective for Connecticut in the United States Senate.

title: East German Guard Defects
description: A 22-year-old former East German border guard dodged mines and self-firing pistols mounted on frontier fences and crossed into West Germany early today, the authorities said. The defector, who was not identified, said he had left because he was dissatisfied with economic conditions in East Germany.

title: Libyan Oil Output Up
description: Libya has increased its crude oil production to more than 1.7 million barrels a day, the Middle East Economic Survey said today. The country's output, which had averaged 747,000 barrels a day in the second quarter, rose to 1.5 million a day in September.

title: OPERA: NEW SINGER IN 'FORZA'
description: THERE were some cast changes in Verdi's ''La Forza del Destino'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon. Lucine Amara, the Met's veteran soprano, sang Leonora, with Peter Glossop taking the role of Don Carlo and Renato Capecchi singing Fra Melitone.

title: POLITICAL NOVICE MAKING PLUCKY RUN AT KENNEDY
description: It is 20 years since Edward M. Kennedy was first elected here to the Senate, a seat he holds virtually as a matter of natural right in this Roman Catholic, Democratic and heavily Irish-American Commonwealth.

title: Phillips Finds 'Giant Oil Field'
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that its domestic oil production may double as a result of two discoveries off the coast of Southern California.

description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon told a judicial commission today that he had not learned that a massacre of Palestinians was occurring in Beirut refugee camps until more than 24 hours after it had begun.

OPTIMISM IS BUDDING IN CEDAR RAPIDS
description: This is the eighth article of a series appearing periodically on the effects of changing economic conditions on Americans in one small city. CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 26 - It is still more a feeling than a fact, but some business leaders here who have been waiting out this city's severest post-war economic slump are saying they have the distinct impression that things may be getting better.

title: Amnesty Group Reports On Political Killings
description: Thousands of people, especially in Central America, were killed last year on the orders of their governments, Amnesty International said in its annual report Wednesday.

EDUCATORS SEEK HELP FOR SCHOOLS
description: Leading educators yesterday charged their colleagues with the mission of convincing Americans that education deserves their support - and their money.

title: Top House Democrats Resist Social Security Action in '82
description: House Democratic leaders said Monday they would oppose any action on Social Security in the post-election session beginning Nov. 29, but would expedite action in the new Congress.

title: Wood Defendants' Kin Testifies in Texas Trial
description: A 25-year-old woman who is suspected of carrying the money to pay for the killing of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. testified today that she had ''no choice'' but to follow the orders of her mother and stepfather, two of three defendants in the case.

title: NEW YOUTH-CRIME COURT IS PROPOSED BY LEHRMAN
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Governor, today proposed changing the state's Family Court system by creating a separate adolescent court to handle all criminal cases involving juveniles under the age of 16.
