title: WATT OFFERS PLAN FOR 10 PROJECTS FOR WESTERN WATER DEVELOPMENTS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today announced that 10 Western water projects would be proposed at a cost of $258.5 million, the first such projects to be initiated by the Reagan Administration.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $986,000 or 83 cents a shr on the sale of remaining 30 percent interest the company's employee relocation company

title: IN ULSTER, 'SOLUTION' BRINGS PROBLEMS
description: Northern Ireland is a place that thrives on self-fulfilling prophecies of doom. Ever since James Prior, Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Affairs, began talking late last year about the creation of a new electoral body to deal with the future of the province, Ulster's most eloquent politicians have predicted its failure. Nevertheless, Mr. Prior, a pillowy-faced liberal Tory of apparently limitless optimism, plowed ahead with his plan, and last Wednesday the voters of the war-torn province elected their 78-member Assembly. For once, what happened in that election was worse than anyone predicted.

title: Chrysler Settles On B.B.D.& O.
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which had been searching for a second advertising agency, has selected Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as that second shop. B.B.D.& O. will be handling all domestically produced Dodge cars, all Chrysler trucks and Dealer Association advertising, which approaches $100 million annually.

RULING AIDS HOLDERS IN FUND SUITS

title:
WORKERS CAN BE CHOOSERS;
SOMERVILLE, Mass.-Your employer threatens to shut down the plant. You are given a choice: buy your job through employee ownership or lose it. More and more, this ''choice'' is forced upon workers as conglomerates shift investment away from industries with low return to more lucrative investment opportunities here and abroad.
description: This fall 11,000 steelworkers in Weirton, W.Va., face just such a decision. The National Steel Corporation has announced that it will cease to invest in its Weirton Steel Division, and has urged the employees to buy the mill.

MALE-FEMALE SPLIT ON POLITICS FOUND A KEY FACTOR IN POLLS
description: The split in political attitudes between men and women, a trend that Republicans have feared since women's unhappiness with President Reagan became clear in national polls last year, has emerged as a major factor in many 1982 election contests.

title: Prices Rise in Light Trading; Treasury's Plans Due
description: After two days of steep declines, prices rose in the credit markets yesterday in quiet trading that was dominated by traders' speculation that the Federal Reserve would announce a cut in the discount rate.

title: Real Estate; Talks Stall On Battery Lease Deal
description: TOP executives at the American Express Company and Olympia & York, the big Toronto-based development company, are still negotiating the exact terms of a lease whereby American Express would occupy one of four towers at Battery Park City, the six-million square foot commerical complex that Olympia is developing at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan.

title: THEATER: YIDDISH FARCE
description: THERE is something heartwarmingly familiar for Yiddish theater fans in ''The Showgirl,'' the musical that has opened at Town Hall under the aegis of the Shalom Yiddish Musical Comedy Theater, which is one of the more dedicated and talented preservationist groups in town.

title: ENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
1. Flash in the Mask
description: If you're going to a Halloween party this weekend, you might check out a mask that's rimmed with tiny colored lights that flash on and off. The trick is that the lights are operated by a nine-volt battery that is hidden inside the mask. Macy's Arcade has the masks in various colors, priced at $10.

title: HOW TO COPE WITH TRICK OR TREATERS
description: FOR people without children, or for those whose children are grown, the question of what to do on Halloween is one of life's most pressing. Should you encourage the extortionate ragamuffins or not? Following are some suggestions for dealing with this sticky situation.

title: KEY WITNESS IN TRIAL OF FORMER SPY IS FOUND DEAD
description: Kevin P. Mulcahy, a key witness in the Government's case against two former American intelligence agents charged with illegally aiding Libyan terrorists, was found dead today outside a mountain cabin in Virginia.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in September, bringing the annual inflation rate so far to 4.8 percent. The rate for the year is now likely to be 5 percent or lower. (Page A1.) The price index for the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose much more sharply, eight-tenths of 1 percent, because of increases in the cost of food, housing and transportation. (A25.)

title: Baltic Yields Treasure Of 17th-Century Ship
description: Divers have recovered a treasure of gold coins from the wreckage of the 17th-century man-of-war Kronan, the pride of the Swedish Navy before it capsized and exploded in 1676.

title: New Derailment in Louisiana
description: Ten cars of a Kansas City Southern freight toppled off tracks in northwestern Louisiana early today in the third derailment in Louisiana in a month. There was no fire and no one was injured.

title: CHURCH, STATE AND THE BOMB
description: In next week's Congressional elections, the voters in nine states will be asked to pass judgment on the nuclear arms race. But while most of them will probably come out for ''freezing'' the development of these weapons of mass destruction, this question has almost vanished as a major issue in the election.

title: N.F.L. PONDERS FEWER GAMES
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, suggested for the first time yesterday that the league might be able to play fewer than 12 games per team if the player strike is settled.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FROM ELLIS, A CASUAL WHIMSICALITY
description: IT was a great day for American sportswear. The clothes looked comfortable and a little whimsical. They were fresh enough to make a woman want to go out and buy something new when warm weather strikes. But not only women were involved. Both Adri and Perry Ellis, who showed their new fashion collections yesterday, made ample provision for men. Their men's clothes are casual and are closely related to women's styles.

description: Richard Jessup, author of ''The Cincinnati Kid'' and many other novels, died of cancer on Friday in Nokomis, Fla. He was 57 years old.

description: * Bergen State Bank of New Jersey said it had agreed to be acquired by Citizens First Bancorp. Shareholders will receive one share of $23 liquidation series A nonvoting preferred of Citizens for each Bergen common share.

title: TENNIS NO LONGER A SPORT OF DECORUM
description: Who are the most ill-mannered athletes in sports, the ones who apparently have little regard for sportsmanship? Tennis players seem to be mentioned more often than others, perhaps because tennis is a sport that focuses on individual achievement and because for many years it had a strict code of conduct. But that has changed significantly in the last 15 years.

'GENTRY,' IN RUSSIA
description: 19TH CENTURY Russia: a great country estate and a fine, somewhat dilapidated old house surrounded by bumpy, casually tended lawns; in the distance, serfs sing as they work in the fields; little girls in white muslin dresses play in the garden as their elders sit in the shade, picking at fresh raspberries and arguing lazily about everything except what's on their minds.

title: INTERNATIONAL CHAMPION IN 1930'S

He was 76 years old and lived at Templeton, his estate in Old Westbury, L.I. , where he maintained the Templeton racing stables. He also had a home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: I.R.S. FOUND TO OUTDO TAXPAYERS ON ERRORS
description: The Internal Revenue Service makes nearly twice as many mathematical errors in processing tax forms as taxpayers do in filling them out, a report to Congress said today.

description: A Federal District Court will hear on Wednesday a suit by the money market mutual fund industry to block a plan by Federal banking regulators to ask for public comment on a new savings account intended to compete with the money funds.

description: Violence by young people has become one of the most extensive and chronic epidemics in American society, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop told pediatricians meeting here yesterday.

description: The Swedish Navy has called off a three-week search for an alien submarine detected near a top-secret naval base, defense authorities said today.

title: Crane Pleads Not Guilty
description: Representative Philip M. Crane, the Illinois Republican who opposed Ronald Reagan for their party's Presidential nomination in 1980, today pleaded not guilty to charges of driving while intoxicated. Mr. Crane's plea was entered by his attorney, Michael Duffity. Judge Gary Thomas accepted the plea and set Dec. 14 as the date on which Mr. Crane can either change his plea or proceed with scheduling of a trial.

title: CALIFORNIA VICTOR WILL INHERIT A STATE IN THROES OF BASIC DEMOGRAPHIC CHANGE
description: The 1982 Election: California Last of 10 articles appearing periodically on states with important gubernatorial races. LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 - Californians are in the final days of a campaign that could result in the election of Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles as the first black governor in the United States.

description: The Air Force today awarded a $49.4 million preliminary contract to the Lockheed Corporation to begin building C-5B transport planes even though Congress has not passed a military appropriation for the current fiscal year.

AMERICAN IS SLAIN BY KENYAN PALACE SENTRY
description: A 61-year-old retired Ohio State University professor working for an American management consulting company in Nairobi, Kenya, was shot to death Sunday evening by a guard at the palace of the Kenyan President, a State Department official said yesterday.

title: The Pop Life; David Murray Comes Into His Own
description: THE tenor saxophone has long been a special instrument -an instrument of authority -in black American music. All the members of the saxophone family combine the flexibility of reed instruments and the power and brilliance of brass, but the baritone can be clumsy, the alto creamy and light. The sound of the tenor has weight, body and edge. It can be gruff, blustering or seductively romantic, but it is always richly masculine.

title: CONCERT: TRIBUTE TO TUCKER
description: THE Richard Tucker Foundation Gala, which took place Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, offered opera lovers both a chance to hear some important artists and to simultaneously aid the careers of rising young musicians. The annual event is held not only to commemorate the late tenor, but also to support the nonprofit foundation that bears his name.

title: Mistrial in Disneyland Death
description: The defendant in Disneyland's only homicide has been acquitted of first-degree murder, but may face retrial on a lesser charge. Judge Kenneth Lae of Superior Court declared a mistrial Monday after jurors announced they were deadlocked 11 to 1, in favor of convicting James O'Driscoll of second-degree murder. The jury reported it was unanimously opposed to a first-degree murder verdict, and Judge Lae acquitted the 30-year-old defendant of that charge in the stabbing death March 7, 1981, of Mel Christian Yorba, 18, of Riverside.

title: BRAZIL TO SEEK HOST'S ROLE FOR WORLD CUP
description: Backed by the other members of the South American Football Confederation, Brazil moved today to replace Colombia as the host of the 1986 World Cup soccer competition.

title: STAGE: 'MAGDALENA FLATS'
description: PRESTON JONES'S ''A Texas Trilogy'' was a classic case of Broadway oversell followed by overkill. This trilogy of connected plays about small-town Texas life was certainly not the masterpiece that some suggested but it showed unmistakable signs of dramatic talent. Because of its commercial failure, the trilogy was the last work by Mr. Jones to be produced in New York in his lifetime; he died in 1979 at the age of 43.

''Now I'm seeing Niarchos at 10:30 in Paris ... Giscard wants to see me on Wednesday morning ... I want to go to the Bunker dinner after the Fulbright dinner.''

description: ONCE you have assembled the foundation of your kitchen equipment repertory -quality pots, pans and knives - it may be time to consider certain specialty tools that could make your style of cooking more efficient and at the same time artistic.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY REJECTS EFFORT BY IRANIANS TO EXPEL ISRAELIS
description: The General Assembly sidetracked Iran's last-minute challenge to Israel's membership and voted today to accept the report of its Credentials Committee.

title: POP: 'CROWDS AND POWER'
description: ELLIOTT SHARP'S ''Crowds and Power'' made a well-organized racket when it had its premiere over the weekend at the Kitchen. Like Glenn Branca's symphonies, it uses a large ensemble - a crowd - to make simple musical gestures in powerful unanimity.

title: Lybrand Chairman, 62, To Practice Law at Last
description: When Norman E. Auerbach started out, his intention was to become a lawyer. But he went into accounting instead and wound up as chairman of Coopers & Lybrand, the big accounting firm.

title: SALVADOR OPPOSITION PROPOSES TALKS
description: El Salvador's leftist opposition announced here today that it had proposed unconditional negotiations with the Salvadoran Government to end the country's civil war and reduce tensions throughout Central America.

title: Auto Designer's Lawyer Says He Has Bail Accord
description: John Z. DeLorean's attorney said today that he had reached an agreement with Federal prosecutors on securing the automobile designer's $5 million bail and that he expected his client to be released from Federal prison here ''in a day or two.''

title: Jacobs Group Plans New Offer for Pabst
description: A dissident group led by financier Irwin L. Jacobs said today that it is planning another attempt to gain control of the Pabst Brewing Company, this time through an offer to buy 3 million shares, or 37 percent of those outstanding, for $24 each, or a total of $72 million.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: B-Including a gain of $9 million resulting from the exchange of 180,000 newly issued common shares for $25 million principal amount of the company's long-term debt

title: COLGATE SHIFTS PLAYOFF STAND
description: Colgate University's president today reversed his decision not to allow the school's football team to participate in postseason playoffs because of a conflict with final examinations.

INDIANS PULL AWAY FROM HIRING MARTIN
description: The teaming of Billy Martin and the Cleveland Indians, which seemed so near, all but collapsed yesterday. As a result, Mike Ferraro, the Yankees' first-base coach, again appears to be the leading candidate to manage the Indians next season, and Martin appears to be available to the Yankees if they want him.

title: CONE MILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: DOCUMENTARY, 'TO HEAR,' AND 'SHOCKTRAUMA'
description: TELEVISION has not lost its special fondness for the subjects of health and medicine. Last night, a new NBC series entitled ''St. Elsewhere'' began trying to accomplish for a hospital setting what ''Hill Street Blues'' has done for police precincts. This evening, a documentary on public television offers an essay on hearing, and a docudrama being syndicated on commerical television looks at some of the new medical procedures of ''trauma medicine,'' a discipline used to treat accident victims in severe shock.

title: U.S. LAYING GROUNDWORK IN BRIBERY-PLOT TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors continued building their case today in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four codefendants.

title: BEFORE 'PLENTY,' KATE NELLIGAN NEARLY LEFT THEATER
description: She is beautiful, fiercely intelligent and furious. Savagely funny, she excoriates her husband's stuffy diplomatic dinner party guests, hurls valuable antiques out the window, decides without consulting her husband to donate their house to a home for unwed mothers.

title: Advertising; Promoting Magazines
description: Those magazine executives who delayed the pleasures of the links, the courts, the surf or the pool this morning to attend the business session of the annual meeting of the Magazine Publishers Association might well have snared a bold moneymaking concept.

title: WOMAN WHO TURNED IN TAINTED TYLENOL IS SOUGHT
description: The authorities searched today for a woman who had turned in an eighth bottle of cyanide-tainted Extra-Strength Tylenol and falsely identified herself as a judge's wife.

title: Tests for Davidson
description: John Davidson, the Ranger goaltender with recurring back problems, will undergo tests this week at Lenox Hill Hospital to determine whether he will need surgery.

title: Mr. Reagan Inflates His Record
description: President Reagan, stretching a couple of points, took credit again yesterday for knocking down inflation after the Consumer Price Index for September showed another slight increase. Point one: the achievement is his to claim only to the extent that his policies brought on the recession. Point two: to many consumers, the statistical progress is irrelevant; they see only that prices are still rising, and so is unemployment.

ENDS AT 1,006.07
description: In a turbulent session marked by heavy trading, the Dow Jones industrial average finished yesterday at 1,006.07 with a gain of 10.94 points. Big-capitalization blue chips were the market's best performers.

title: AYALA IS WINNING HIS TOUGHEST BOUT
description: Tony Ayala Jr. did not duck the questions yesterday. In the ring, he does not mind taking a shot to the head, just so he could land one of his own. But it was always easier in the ring, face to face with his opponent.

title: U.N. Team Back in Bangkok For Chemical Warfare Inquiry
description: A United Nations team of chemical warfare experts has returned to Bangkok after a year's absence to renew its investigation into charges that Soviet-backed troops were using outlawed poisons in Cambodia and Laos.

title: ANTIDRAFT GROUP CITES U.S. REPORT
description: Draft Action, a group opposed to military conscription, made public today an internal Reagan Administration report that, it said, showed that there was little need for peacetime registration for a possible draft.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Teddy Comes Home

title: NEW SURVEY BY THE TIMES SHOWS WEICKER IS LEADING MOFFETT
description: In Connecticut's race for Senate, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is leading his Democratic opponent, Toby Moffett, among voters most likely to cast ballots in next week's election, according to the latest New York Times Poll.

title: DEFICIT IN REAGAN BUDGET AT RECORD $110.7 BILLION
description: The Administration reported today that the Government ran up a record budget deficit of $110.7 billion in the 1982 fiscal year, the first full fiscal year under Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

description: The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday a decline of more than 50 percent in its third-quarter earnings, and the company's top executive was pessimistic about the future.

WHAT A CORPORATION OWES ITS SHAREHOLDERS
description: T o the Editor: I imagine shareholders throughout the country are lamenting that they can no longer own stock in a company of which William Agee is the C.E.O. In his Oct. 19 Op-Ed article, ''Corporate Mergers' Value,'' he stated that the foremost objective of ''responsible management'' is ''improving the value of the shareholder's investment.''

A Song Laments Football Strike
description: Country and western music has always been linked to laments about broken romances and relationships. Now, two songwriters, Patti Clements of Arlington, Va., and Linda Mahoney of Northumberland, Pa., have decided to put the current National Football League players' strike to music -country and western style.

description: The purchase by Tang Industries Inc. of the McLouth Steel Corporation is being postponed about two weeks, McLouth officials said.

description: The owner of Marty's, an East Side restaurant and nightclub involved in a major Federal tax investigation, was convicted yesterday of possessing a small amount of cocaine.

Italy Wants to Revive The 'European Idea'
description: Italy today proposed a special meeting of the heads of government of the European Common Market to give new life to the idea of European institutional, political and economic integration.

description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $32.8 million. The deficit was narrower than the $38.7 million a year earlier, but it nonetheless underscored the airline industry's continuing difficulties.

LEGAL SERVICES TURMOIL
description: One of President Reagan's oldest nemeses is the federally financed program that provides legal assistance to the poor.

title: Bid for Ballot Spot Denied
description: Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court has refused to order Colorado to list a member of the Socialist Workers Party on its Congressional ballot. Justice White denied a request by Eileen Thournir of Denver that her name be placed on the First District ballot. The state denied her a ballot listing because she was not registered as an unaffiliated voter for one year.

title: Careers; Education For Global Vocations
description: SCORE one for the liberal arts. Oddly enough, it's a boost that comes in reaction to the Soviet approach to American culture. W. Averell Harriman's gift of millions of dollars for Russian studies at Columbia University has the aim of informing more college-educated students about life and business behind the Iron Curtain as well as teaching them to speak the Russian language.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Celtics Drop Two
description: In cutting their roster to 14, two over the limit with which they will be able to open the season, the Boston Celtics dropped two veteran guards: Chris Ford, a starter on the 1981 championship team, and Terry Duerod, on injured reserve much of last season. ... Mark Olberding, who had been sent to Chicago along with Dave Corzine in the trade that shipped Artis Gilmore to San Antonio, ended his holdout and reported to the Bulls. Chicago cut James Wilkes, a forward the last three years. ... Corny Thompson, the former Connecticut star, was placed on the injured-reserve list by the Dallas Mavericks and will undergo surgery for bone chips in his right elbow. He is not expected back for six weeks. ...Contract talks between the San Diego Clippers and their No.1 draft choice, Terry Cummings of DePaul, have broken off. ...Brad Branson, a 6-foot, 10-inch forward who played most of last season with Anchorage in the Continental Basketball Association, was acquired from the Cleveland Cavaliers by the Indiana Pacers.

title: PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A U.S.-THAI PRISON PACT IS READY
description: Attorney General William French Smith will sign a treaty here Friday that is intended largely to repatriate Americans being held in Thai jails on drug charges, the United States Embassy said yesterday.

title: Boyland Is the Victor In Assembly Primary
description: Assemblyman William F. Boyland defeated incumbent Assemblyman Thomas R. Fortune yesterday in a court-ordered rerun of the Democratic primary for the State Assembly in the newly drawn 55th Assembly District in Brooklyn.

WEICKER ATTACKS 'LABELING'

title: WARSAW APPROVES LAW TO PUNISH POLAND'S 'PARASITES' AND 'SHIRKERS'
description: The Polish Parliament passed a law today providing for forced labor, or even imprisonment, for ''shirkers'' and ''social parasites'' who could not prove they had gainful employment.

title: EDWARD F. GIBBONS, CHAIRMAN OF WOOLWORTH
description: Edward F. Gibbons, chairman and chief executive officer of the F.W. Woolworth Company, died yesterday in the Westchester County Medical Center, Valhalla, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Braniff-PSA Tie
description: The venture of Braniff and Pacific Southwest Airlines could begin flight operations before Braniff's creditors vote on the agreement, Judge John Flowers, who is overseeing Braniff's bankruptcy petition, said. He added that he does not expect creditors to vote on the PSA tie until spring. Howard Putnam, Braniff's chairman, has said he wants the venture to begin by Christmas.

title: REMATCH FOR JERSEY SHORE HOUSE SEAT
description: The election in the Third Congressional District, which stretches along the Jersey shore from Sandy Hook to Mantoloking, is a rematch of 1980: Representative James J. Howard, a Democrat, is being challenged again by State Assemblywoman Marie Sheehan Muhler, a Republican.

title: 15,781 at Toronto Game
description: An exhibition game in Toronto between the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Philadelphia 76ers attracted 15,781 spectators Monday night.

title: FOES FOR U.S. SENATE IN JERSEY DEBATE
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick and Frank R. Lautenberg met for their fifth debate last night, and, as they have throughout their campaign for the United State Senate from New Jersey, they focused on the economy and vigorously challenged each other's platform for improving it.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago third qr results include a gain equal to 26 cents a shr from an insurance settlement

title: Second of five articles: Is sportsmanship on the decline?
description: Every stride brought Ralph Hill closer to the leader and it looked as if the American's finishing kick would enable him to pass Lauri Aleksander Lehtinen of Finland. Hill would then have an unobstructed path to the finish line and a gold medal in the 5,000-meter run at the 1932 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. But as they sprinted those final yards, Hill's attempts to overtake Lehtinen failed. Every time he made a move, Lehtinen seemed to drift from left to right and left again as if purposely trying to cut off his pursuer. Thus, he was able to maintain his lead as Hill remained a few agonizing steps behind.

title: STANDARD OIL CO OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an inventory drawdown benefit of $90 million, a $44 million foreignexchange gain and an $82 million nonrecurring writeoff for the closure of the company's Feluy, Belgium, refinery

title: FIRST NEW CHEESE IN BRITAIN IN 300 YEARS
description: LONDON IT'S advertised as ''the mild blue full-fat soft cheese from the heart of England,'' but, in fact, it comes direct from the hard heads of experts at the Milk Marketing Board. It is Lymeswold, the first new English cheese in 300 years and the first creamy cheese in the European full-fat style to be made in Britain. After seven months of test marketing, it was introduced in a flurry of news releases on a largely unsuspecting public in September, with supplies immediately sold out.

title: P.L.O. USED SCHOOL RUN BY U.N. AGENCY
description: A trade school near Beirut run by a United Nations relief agency was used by the Palestine Liberation Organization for military courses for 781 students over two years, according to a report by the agency.

title: Leveille Unchanged
description: Normand Leveille, the Boston Bruins' star forward, suffered brain damage from the hemorrhage that caused his collapse during a game in Vancouver, British Columbia, Saturday, but its extent has yet to be determined, Nate Greenberg, a club spokesman, said yesterday. ''He's still unconscious and in poor condition,'' said Greenberg. ''There's been no change.''

title: GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR 17 years now Robert Juhren of Mount Kisco has been a hostage to fortune, commuting to the city on the Harlem Division. Despite every imaginable calamity, or possibly because of the irreversible physiological changes wrought by these experiences, Mr. Juhren's association with the iron horse has found poetic expression.

title: Grain Prices Increase; Recovery May Be Near
description: Grain futures prices rebounded yesterday, but the gains were linked more to the activities of spreaders than to any significant change in market conditions.

description: Security forces on both sides of the Northern Ireland border mounted major searches today for the body of a Protestant militia sergeant killed by Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

DIVIDEND HALVED TO 25
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that the depressed market for steel had resulted in a third-quarter loss of $82.4 million. The company also cut its dividend in half.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Monday about minor- party candidates in New York State incorrectly stated a position of the New Alliance Party. In fact the party seeks the 50,000 votes needed for a per- manent place on the ballot.

title: Market Place; The Fast Rise Of Chi-Chi's
description: CAN Chi-Chi's Inc., the fast-growing Mexican food chain, continue its sizzling performance in the stock market? The shares are at 24 7/8 - close to the year's high and nearly double the price at this time last year.

description: Both qtrs are for 16 week periods each and the 9 mos periods each consist of 40weeks

title: War in Falklands Cost Britain $1.19 Billion
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons today that the Falkland war against Argentina cost Britain about $1.19 billion.

description: The city's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board yesterday approved a tax abatement of more than $11.4 million to the F.W. Woolworth Company for restoration work on the exterior of the Woolworth Building, the company's ornate office tower in lower Manhattan.

title: Sect Members' Wounds Described in Autopsies
description: The two members of a Miracle Valley church who were killed in a confrontation with sheriff's deputies were hit by seven gunshots to the back, chest, side and hand, the authorities said today.

title: A GASCON CHEF BOASTS OF HIS REGION'S FOOD
description: IT took an express highway, and then a regional cookbook, to put Andre Daguin on the map with his fellow Frenchmen. ''Before the superhighway from Toulouse to Auch was completed a couple of years ago, you could sit in our dining room on a Saturday night and not hear a word of French spoken,'' said Mr. Daguin, a boyishly handsome Gascon who is the third generation chef to run his family's restaurant and hotel, Hotel de France, in this unspoiled southwestern town of 25,000 people.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most gratifying aspects of my life on Long Island is the ability to get in my boat or to put on a pair of boots, knowing full well that within an hour or so I can return to my own kitchen (or outdoor grill) with an ample supply of fish or seafood. Even if the season does not permit, I can find the freshest of fish and shellfish at any number of local markets.

title: FORD LOSS NARROWS IN 3RD QUARTER
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $325.4 million, mostly as a result of the company's poor showing in the United States and Canada.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fading Rivalry?

title: News Analysis
description: During the 1950's American colleges and universities agreed on a system in which the distribution of scholarship aid to students would be based on financial need.

title: Don King Seeks Pardon
description: Don King, who served four and a half years in an Ohio prison after his 1966 murder conviction, is one of nearly 100 persons with pardon and commutation requests before Gov. James A. Rhodes, who has promised to act on them before leaving office in January. Mark Long, an aide to the Governor, said he could not comment on whether the Governor would clear the prominent promoter's record. But King's lawyer, Clarence Rogers Jr., said that King's charitable contributions to the American Olympic effort, the United Negro College Fund, Cleveland churches and the Police Athletic League should weigh heavily in his favor.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rollins' Condition Held Fair
description: Edward Rollins, President Reagan's top political adviser, today was reported in fair and stable condition, recuperating from what an aide described as ''a slight stroke.'' Michele Davis, an aide, said Mr. Rollins had suffered ''a slight stroke, but no impairment.''

title: KROY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Political Analysis
description: The 1982 election campaign has already damaged the conservative coalition that dominated Congress in the last session, according to political analysts in both parties.

description: The latest qr net was increased by an after-tax foreign exchange adjustment of $8.2 million or 12 cents a shr, because of fluctuations in the Canadian-U.S. dollar exchange rate

title: British Jobless Down
description: Britain's record unemployment rate dropped this month to 3.29 million people, or 13.8 percent of the workforce, down from 3.34 million or 14 percent in September, the Goverment said today.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE DANCE: MEG HARPER
description: ''CLOSE/DANCING,'' the program that Meg Harper offered Saturday night at the White Dog Studio, contained lots of bright choreographic ideas, including an idea that other dancers who use this peculiar pillared space might borrow.

title: Richardson Fined $1,500
description: The National Basketball Association has fined Michael Ray Richardson $1,500 and Rick Robey $1,250 for an incident of violence during an exhibition game at Madison Square Garden Oct.16.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1982
description: International The disappearance of Salvadoran opposition figures last week prompted concern among Reagan Administration officials. As a result, they have told the Salvadoran Government that United States military aid will be halted unless the human rights situation there improves. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Salvadoran peace talks without any conditions have been proposed by the leftist opposition leaders in exile in Mexico. The call for negotiations to end the civil war appeared designed to take advantage of the insurgents' two-week military offensive and to test suggestions by the Reagan Administration that some political settlement might be feasible. (A8:4-6.)

title: CLAUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results reflect an accounting change

title: Canada Bell Appeal
description: The Canadian Government will appeal a Quebec Superior Court ruling allowing the Bell Telephone Company of Canada to form a holding company, Francis Fox, the Communications Minister, said. He added that the Government was concerned about the impact on phone rates and on regulation.

title: INSTACOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A JORDAN CABERNET SCORES IN TASTING
description: A cabernet sauvignon produced by the Jordan Vineyard and Winery placed first in a blind tasting of California cabernets from the 1978 vintage at the California Wine Experience, a convention of wine enthusiasts, collectors, producers and restaurateurs that took place earlier this month in San Francisco.

title: Xerox Slides 39.2% in Quarter
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter plunged 39.2 percent as sales edged up 2.4 percent. Xerox, the world's largest producer of copying and duplicating equipment, cited the weaker economy, lower pricing, company-wide resizing program charges, the currency fluctuations and on-going cost pressures.

title: ARAB BOY DIES IN WEST BANK RIOT
description: An Arab teen-ager was killed and another was injured in renewed rioting today in Israeli-occupied Nablus. Military sources said Government forces did not open fire in the disturbances.

title: REAL ELECTION ISSUE: DO NICKNAMES WORK?
description: The Nov. 2 election, we are told, will be a referendum on President Reagan's economic policies and his qualities of leadership and on the ability of the Democrats to put forward a convincing alternative. Perhaps. Another view is that Nov. 2 will offer the first large-scale test of the political efficacy of nicknames. Never before have so many candidates shunned their true names and chosen something more friendly.

title: Changing Habits
description: In 1973, 1976 and 1979, the A.C. Nielsen Company published a survey on the sports-participation habits of Americans. The 1982 Nielsen survey is completed, with some interesting developments over the last three years.

title: Scientists Pursue a Route Departing From Tradition
description: One of the many points on which the modern scientific bidder parts company from the traditionalist is in the attitude to reverse bids. A sequence such as one diamond, one spade, two hearts is of course strong, showing considerable extra values. The question is whether it should be treated as forcing or simply encouraging.

title: PARGAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 15 percent stock divd paid Mar 1982

title: Sears Up 28.5% In 3d Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer and a leading financial services company, reported yesterday a 28.5 percent higher net income in its third quarter ended Sept.30. The Chicagobased company said it earned $166.7 million, or 48 cents a share, against $129.7 million, or 42 cents a share, in the comparable 1981 period.

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.482 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.003 percent at last week's auction.

title: Kuenn Honored
description: Harvey Kuenn of the Milwaukee Brewers has been named American League manager of the year by The Associated Press, getting 47 of the 79 votes cast by a nationwide panel of sportswriters and broadcasters.

title: HENRY GELDZAHLER QUITS AS CULTURAL AFFAIRS CHIEF
description: Saying that he has ''other fish to fry'' at this point in his life, Henry Geldzahler, New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, walked into Mayor Koch's office yesterday with a bouquet of flowers in one hand and his letter of resignation in the other. Mr. Geldzahler's resignation will become effective Dec. 15.

title: LAKERS' COACH IS UNFAZED BY POOR START
description: Pat Riley could have come back this season impressed with himself because winning the National Basketball Association title in one's first season as a coach can do that. But as he prepared his Los Angeles Lakers to go against the New Jersey Nets in the annual Hall of Fame exhibition game tonight at Convention Hall, it was evident that he had not let his accomplishments change him.

title: BALDWIN APPEALS ASSET RULING
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, a leading financial services company, said yesterday that it was appealing a decision by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners to reduce the value of its insurance assets by $111 million.

title: Sports Stars Wed
description: The golf star Nancy Lopez and Ray Knight of the Houston Astros, one of baseball's best third basemen, have married in Pelham, Ga., at the home of Max Frostig, Knight's partner in a sporting goods store there.

title: 24 CONCERNS TO CLEAN UP WASTE DUMP IN INDIANA
description: In what the Environmental Protection Agency described today as the nation's biggest voluntary cleanup yet of a toxic waste dump, 24 companies have agreed to pay $7.7 million to remove wastes from a site in Seymour, Ind.

title: CITY OPERA: 'SUSANNAH'
description: CARLISLE FLOYD'S ''Susannah'' is such a mixture of implausible bombast and occasional musical insight that the audience at its first and only performance this season Sunday at the New York City Opera laughed at some ominous moments and was moved by others. But it would take a solemn believer to accept as literal the work's dramatic premise (based on the Apocrypha): that the uproar of a community, the death of a preacher and the scapegoating of a young, beautiful, innocent woman, could have come because four middle-aged men caught a glimpse of Susannah, bathing in a hidden creek in the woods while sinfully naked.

title: NEW YORK STATE MAY SOON FACE NEED TO BORROW
description: New York State may have to borrow money within the next three months to pay its bills, according to a letter sent to underwriters of state bonds. It would be the first time since 1975 that the state had to borrow money in the middle of its fiscal year to meet its day-to-day obligations.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: TOXOPLASMOSIS, the parasitic infection that contributed to Martina Navratilova's defeat in the United States Open tennis tournament last month - and from which she has apparently recovered - is a far more common and often more devastating illness than most people realize. The ultimate source of the parasite is also common: the cat. Half of the cats in this country sooner or later become infected with the parasite.

DARRELL PORTER: A HERO FOR 1982
description: W here have all the heroes gone? This question was asked in these pages yesterday in the first part of a series entitled ''The Changing Face of Sports.'' The prevalent view was that the Babe Ruths and the Mickey Mantles of today were less revered than the stars of the past because of greater public scrutiny, changing behavior and rising income.

title: AGREEMENT IS MADE TO TEST SLUDGE PILE IN CONNECTICUT

description: ''The Search for Alexander,'' a traveling exhibition of Hellenistic art that many Greek authorities consider the most important exhibition ever to leave Greece, begins the sixth and last stop on its American tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today.

STRIKE AT CHICAGO SYMPHONY SETTLED WITH 3-YEAR CONTRACT
description: A strike by the musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra was settled yesterday morning. The players voted, 94-4, to accept the Orchestral Association's latest contract proposal. The first three weeks of the season were canceled after the musicians rejected a proposal Oct. 5.

title: Ballet Theater Dancers Propose One-Year Pact
description: The American Ballet Theater, in the middle of a labor dispute with its dancers that resulted in a lockout Sept. 2, is considering a dancers' proposal. The offer calls for a return to work under a contract that would cover one year rather than the normal three years in the contract that expired Aug. 31.

title: REAGAN ACCUSES DEMOCRATS OF STRESSING ECONOMIC FEAR
description: President Reagan, pressing to protect his Congressional coalition in the dwindling days of the campaign, accused his critics today of ''playing with people's fears'' about the economy and turning the nightly television news shows into ''the network evening blues.''

WORKING, BUT POOR
description: The climb of unemployment to 10.1 percent has focused attention on the plight of the jobless, yet millions of the employed also suffer deprivation. Belying the Administration's claim that the 9 out of 10 workers who hold jobs are better off because of declining inflation, the number of working poor has grown alarmingly in the 1980's, according to Federal statistics, and many people in the middle class are unable to support themselves and their families adequately.

title: Advertising; Breaking Magazines' Rate Cards

title: U.S. SEEKS SALVADOR RECONCILIATION
description: The State Department said today that it favored reconciliation between the Salvadoran Government and the leftist opposition, but officials made it clear that the Reagan Administration was skeptical of a new call for peace by rebel leaders.

title: IRAN SAYS IRAQ MISSILES KILLED 21
description: Iran said today that Iraq had attacked the Iranian city of Dizful with missiles, killing 21 people and wounding 107.

title: Kaiser Sues Mitsui
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it sued Mitsui & Company U.S.A. and its Japanese parent, Mitsui & Company Ltd., claiming unfair and illegal trade practices in importing steel into the United States. Kaiser, which is seeking an injunction and an undetermined amount in damages, said the Japanese company and some of its employees recently pleaded guilty to Federal charges of falsely reporting transaction prices on imported steel.

title: The Neglected Child
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I read with great interest ''Hers'' by Joyce Colony in The Times of Oct. 21. Certainly the plight of the abused child is one of great national and local concern.

title: ARGENTINA AGREES ON SPENDING CUTS TO GET I.M.F. LOAN
description: The Argentine Government has agreed to make spending cuts that may prove politically unpopular as a condition for obtaining $2 billion in loans from the International Monetary Fund, Argentine officials announced today.

title: Leases by T.W.A.
description: The Trans World Corporation said its Trans World Airlines subsidiary would lease 15 DC-9 Super 80 planes from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for five years beginning next April, with an option for an additional 13 years. Details were not disclosed, but Trans World said the leasing arrangement for the 142-passenger craft would not require more borrowing or otherwise affect its debt.

title: Harcourt Brace Net Up
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said yesterday that its thirdquarter net income rose 19.1 percent, to $23.7 million, or $2.62 a share, from $19.9 million, or $2.26 a share, in the same quarter last year. The publisher's third-quarter revenue rose 8.4 percent, to $197.1 million, from $181.8 million in the 1981 period.

title: INQUIRY ON MASSACRE HEARS FROM DIRECTOR OF INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: The director of Israel's General Security Services testified for three hours today before the independent judicial panel investigating the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian civilians in the Beirut refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila.

title: McEnroe on Cup Team

title: POISON WORRIES LEAD TO PRECAUTIONS FOR HALLOWEEN

title: Geographic to Accept Drug and Alcohol Ads
description: With the January issue, National Geographic magazine, for the first time in its 92-year history, will begin accepting advertising for over-the-counter drugs, wine and beer.

title: CARIBBEAN INITIATIVE CAN HELP THE U.S.
description: The continuing debate in Congress over President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative has raised doubts among Caribbean leaders as to whether the measure will ever become law. Congress did not approve the initiative's $350 million aid package until six months after it was proposed. And the more important components of trade and investment incentives are still being held up by fear of their potential impact on the American labor force.

title: DOW STABILIZES WITH 0.28 RISE
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.28 points yesterday, closing at 1,006.35, after having swung widely on Monday and Tuesday. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that declined by a ratio of more than 2 to 1. On Tuesday the Dow, the best-known measure of stock market prices, advanced 10.94 points on rumors that the Federal Reserve's discount rate would be cut after that day's market close.

For 10 hours Tuesday there were long lines of applicants waiting for interviews at the city's first job fair. Those found qualified for the jobs, which were mostly professional with salaries of $9,000 to $19,000 a year, are to be called for additional interviews.

Up to this year, these patented plants have been available in white, red, salmon, lavender, peach, magenta and tangerine.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1982
description: International U.S. foreign policy was denounced by Leonid I. Brezhnev, who linked Soviet overtures to China to the tense relations between Moscow and Washington. Addressing Soviet military leaders, the Soviet leader said the Reagan Administration's foreign policy was marked by ''adventurism, rudeness and undisguised egoism'' that he said threatened to push the world into nuclear war. (Page A1, Column 6.) Three Ulster policemen were killed when a large bomb planted by Irish nationalists exploded under their car. Reports from the scene, 20 miles from Belfast, said the blast left a crater 60 feet wide and 40 feet deep and was heard five miles away. (A9:1.)

title: Guatemala Announces A Human Rights Panel
description: The Government said today that it was forming a human rights commission. The Government said the commission, including the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Public Health and Education, would ''show the world Guatemala respects human rights.''

title: WEST EUROPEANS MIGHT SAVE SHCHARANSKY
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: IN recent discussions about unemployment, little attention has been given to the new role it forces on many working wives - that of family wage earner. Because these women do have jobs, their complaints of added stress, overwork and altered goals have seemed of slight consequence. But even if they have worked for years, suddenly, when their husbands become unemployed, they must shoulder the full burden of monthly bills, insurance, taxes, loans and in some degree their customary housekeeping and child-rearing chores. This is not what they had envisioned when they took jobs, they admit. In the light of their new responsibilities, they are looking again at their potential as women.

title: TV: NEW COMEDY SERIES WITH PATTY DUKE ASTIN
description: DADDY, Sam Quinn, is chief of surgery at a Chicago hospital. Mom, Molly Quinn, has raised two children to their late teens and, after spending her spare time taking college courses, has earned a law degree and a job with the city as a prosecuting attorney. She no longer has time to be a totally devoted wife. He feels neglected and resentful. We are, in short, in the world of women's liberation and the adjusting of traditional relationships.

title: A NEW HISTORY OF ART FOR THE DECADE
description: WHILE Prof. H.W. Janson was alive there was simply no contest as to whose was the best one-volume history of art in the bookstores. His ''History of Art'' was a joy to read when it first came out in 1962, and it went on being a joy to read as he touched it up here and there in later editions.

title: CONTRADICTION AND COMPLEXITY CREATE A HOME
description: PHILADELPHIA AT first it seemed oddly beside the point to discuss the decoration of their dining room with Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. On one side of the table sat Mr. Venturi, the architect and visionary who wrote ''Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture'' in 1966. A treatise that shattered the sleek steel-and-glass authoritarian facade of modern architecture's International style, it largely inspired the current postmodernist movement. On the other side sat his wife, a partner with him in the firm of Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown. A firebrand in her own right, she wrote, with her husband and Steven Izenour, ''Learning From Las Vegas'' in 1972, which opened the collective architectural eye to the notion that the sprawl of honky-tonk landscapes represents a new and vital urban form.

title: CUOMO PLEDGES WOMEN 'REPRODUCTIVE FREEDOM'
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, pledged to a group of women yesterday that he would fight for ''reproductive freedom,'' and then went to a meeting with leaders of the Catholic Church in New York State.

description: In the customary boisterous atmosphere of Madison Square Garden, 17,431 people watched the Rangers defeat the Calgary Flames last night. Hammering out 41 shots to Calgary's 20, New York held on for a 7-4 victory.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1982; International
description: Argentina has agreed to make spending cuts that may prove politically unpopular in return for $2 billion of loans from the I.M.F., according to Buenos Aires officials. The loans are intended to help the nation with payments on its nearly $40 billion of foreign debt. It hopes Western banks will now let it postpone payments. (Page A1.)

title: CUOMO-LEHRMAN BATTLE IS QUIET IN UPSTATE AREA
description: Along the quiet two-lane roads here that link the single-stoplight towns, a new kind of crop has suddenly sprouted next to the withered cornstalks. On stakes plunged into the earth at irregular intervals wave the paper faces of political candidates, catching the attention of midstate voters in the week before Election Day.

Hijacking Attempt Fails At Los Angeles Airport
description: A man wielding a knife today tried to hijack a Trans World Airlines jumbo jet about to take off with 97 passengers aboard, but an off-duty sheriff's deputy wrested away the weapon and pushed the man out the door.

title: Times Mirror Declines 8.6%
description: The Times Mirror Company reported yesterday a third-quarter drop in earnings of 8.6 percent, to $32.8 million, or 96 cents a share, from $35.9 milllion, or $1.05 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: U.S. DRUG AGENTS ARE DENIED DATA

title: LEAD EXEMPTION TO END FOR SMALL U.S. REFINERS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will announce in New York Thursday new rules limiting the amount of lead in gasoline and ending a special exemption for small refiners, Administration officials said today.

title: War of Words
description: In the propaganda battle between players and management in the National Football League strike, the United States Post Office is carrying the mail, especially management's. Every week, usually twice, the N.F.L. Management Council sends to editors and reporters around the country a compilation of anti-union statements by players and commentators.

title: HIGHLY TOXIC SUBSTANCE FOUND AT 15 MISSOURI SITES
description: Dioxin, the most toxic ingredient of the defoliant Agent Orange, is believed present at 15 to 55 sites in Missouri and has been detected at several of them at levels higher than at Love Canal.

title: MUSIC: A NEW DRUCKMAN
description: JACOB DRUCKMAN'S ''Prism,'' which the New York Philharmonic played for the first time last night at Avery Fisher Hall, is of interest on two counts. First, it is a first-rate orchestral score in its own right, one of the finest by one of our finest composers. Second, it gives some hint, veiled though it may be, of what Mr. Druckman may have in mind for his first opera, a commission from the Metropolitan now tentatively scheduled for production in 1986.

description: As the 1982 campaigns come to an end, we can detect the first grumblings of an issue that could be significant in 1984. The issue is military spending: its amount and its nature.

title: MARION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RIVERSIDE YARNS LTD reports earnings for 9 mos to Sept 30
DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $57 million from the exchange of long-termdebt for equity; ry-ago results have been restated

title: Ken Noda, 20, to Play at White House
description: The White House announced today that Ken Noda, a 20-year-old pianist, would appear with the violinist Itzhak Perlman in the first program of this year's ''In Performance at the White House'' series.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARKANSAS GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATES IN CLOSE RACE
description: In what is widely viewed as the most negative campaign in the state's recent history, Arkansas voters seem likely to choose as Governor the man they dislike the least.

title: No Headline
description: Leafs Top Bruins, 4-1

title: Signal Plans Sale
description: The Signal Companies said it entered into a preliminary agreement to sell its interest in Golden West Broadcasters for $225 million cash to Gene Autry and Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company, an investment firm. As part of the deal, the television unit of Golden West would be sold to a new company formed by Kohlberg Kravis. Mr. Autry, who already owns 51 percent of Golden West, would become sole owner of the radio part of the business.

title: TOWER CHAIN PLANS NEW YORK STORE
description: THE long faces and dire predictions in the record industry notwithstanding, all is not gloomy, at least so far as a retailer called Tower Records is concerned. Tower, a West-Coast chain with more than 30 stores, including several in Japan, is noted for its in-depth stock, including classical selections, and it is scheduled to open a huge store in New York after March. It will join such other giants as J & R, King Karol and Goody's.

title: VECTOR GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATIRICAL ISRAELI REVUE DEFIES CENSORS' BAN, CAUSING AN UPROAR
description: A stinging satirical revue that was banned as seriously harmful ''to the basic values of the nation, the state and Judaism'' has caused an uproar in Israel and reopened the question of whether Israeli films and theater should be censored at all.

title: Judge Bars Tapes In Morris's Trial
description: A judge ruled Tuesday that tapes made with an electronic bug concealed on a police informant could not be used as evidence in Mercury Morris's cocaine-trafficking trial.

title: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEADING INDEX SEEN ON THE RISE
description: The index of leading indicators for September, the last major economic report to be issued before next week's congressional elections, will be up between five-tenths to seven-tenths of 1 percent, Government officials said today. The index will be released Friday.

title: CHAVEZ, IN CIVIL TRIAL, MAINTAINS RIGHT TO NAME UNION AIDES
description: Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers, told a Federal district judge today that his union's members had been given the mistaken impression by some staff members in the fall of 1979 that they were electing their union representatives while in fact the representatives were to be appointed by Mr. Chavez.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: NARCO WILL MERGE WITH HEALTHDYNE
description: Narco Scientific Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of baby incubators, will merge with competing Healthdyne Inc., the companies said today.

title: 'Wives of Scarsdale' Set For Manhattan Opening
description: ''The Merry Wives of Scarsdale,'' a new comedy by Allen Riesner, will open next Thursday at the Baldwin Theater, 160 West 74th Street.

title: ROBERTSON, H H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CREDIT MARKETS;
description: The Treasury announced late yesterday that it would sell $13 billion of new securities - two note issues and a long-term bond - in its November re-funding to raise $8.4 billion in new cash.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results include revs of $501,000 and net income of $219,000 or 1 cent a shr from a contract settlement; yr-ago 9 mos results include net income of $371,000 or 3 cents a shr, from a $687,000 settlement with the U.S. Government related to the loss of use of one of the company's training aircraft

title: 170 Held in South Africa
description: Officials arrested 170 people today in a predawn raid on a black squatter camp west of here, bringing the number of people arrested for being in the area illegally to more than 2,000 in a month, black township officials said. The people arrested face $75 fines or 90 days in jail.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH the types of paint used on metal and the methods for applying them are generally much the same as those used on wood, plaster and other surfaces, the preparation required before painting - and the type of primer or undercoat used on the metal - will often be quite different.

title: SAN FRANCISCO REAL ESTATE INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
TEACHING THE CRAFT OF MAKING QUILTS
description: For the beginner, there are ''Broken Dishes,'' ''Rail Fences'' and ''Pine Trees,'' and for the more skillful, the challenge of the ''Eight-Pointed Star.''

title: Hogs, Bellies Fall Limit In Odd Technical Selloff
description: Livestock futures crumbled yesterday, with prices of live hogs and pork bellies again declining by their daily permissible limits. Brokers attributed much of the declines to what they termed ''computer selling'' that ignored increasingly strong fundamental factors pointing to higher beef and pork prices this winter.

title: REPUBLIC AIRLINES reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
DOW CHEMICAL OFF 72%
description: The Dow Chemical Company, hard-hit by weak demand for its chemical products, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1982 plummeted 72.7 percent as sales dropped 12.7 percent.

title: Olympic Cost Contract Is Approved
description: The City Council gave final approval today to a contract with the Olympic Organizing Committee designed to indemnify the city against the cost of the Games in 1984. The pact covers expenditures of nearly $22 million.

title: The Ravines of El Salvador
description: Human rights outrages are an old story in El Salvador. What's new is Washington's current attitude. The Reagan Administration is saying plainly what it should have said a year ago - that if abuses don't stop, American aid will.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Silent On Spy Case Details
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher refused today to disclose any details of the reported security breach at a secret intelligence-monitoring center in Cheltenham.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,000 for the qr, a gain from discontinued operations of $472,000 for the 9 mos and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,450,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $134,000 for the qr and $148,000 for the 9 mos

title: G.O.P. Election Funds Far Surpass Democrats'
description: The three major national committees of the Republican Party have raised $168,825,871 in the first 21 months of the current election cycle, the Federal Election Commission reported yesterday. This is seven times as much as the $23,661,609 raised by their Democratic counterparts.

title: Diez Weismann Is Dead at 82; A Concertmaster With WQXR
description: Diez Weismann, who was concertmaster of radio station WQXR's chamber orchestra in the 1940's, died of a heart attack Monday in Stamford, Conn.

title: BANKS PLAN EFFORT FOR POOR LANDS
description: A group of 31 major banks agreed yesterday to establish an organization of international banks to coordinate their relations with less developed countries, William S. Ogden, vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, announced.

title: COMPUTERS TO COME WITH BOOKS AT DREXEL U.
description: Next fall's freshman class at Drexel University will be required to buy computers for use in classroom work.

title: BARGAINING POWER HARMFUL TO COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: City Opera Adds 'Candide' Performances
description: Because of demand, an additional performance of ''Candide'' at the New York City Opera has been scheduled, for Nov. 9.

title: CHRYSLER WORKERS' VOTE ONLY POSTPONES A CLASH
description: The decision by assembly line workers at the Chrysler Corporation to put off a strike and to continue negotiations on a new contract apparently only postpones a clash over what the workers expect and what the company says is its ability to pay.

title: EARLY CYANIDE DEATH NOT TIED TO TYLENOL, AUTHORITIES BELIEVE
description: The cyanide death of a woman here in August appears to have no relationship to the deaths of seven Chicago-area persons who ingested Tylenol with cyanide from Sept. 29 to Oct. 1, the authorities said today.

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NETWORK AUDIENCES DECLINING
description: DESPITE the opportunity to launch their prime-time schedules undelayed by a strike for the first time in three years, the three major television networks have suffered significant overall audience declines during the first four weeks of the new season.

title: Thinking Ahead
description: The United States Football League has not yet had its first practice session, but its commissioner is already predicting that the 12-team league, which will begin play next March, will expand to 16 teams in 1984. ''This is no minor league,'' said Chet Simmons in Birmingham, Ala., saying that 40 cities have expressed an interest in joining the new league. The U.S.F.L. also announced that it would play its first nationally televised regular-season game March 6.

title: TOURISTS FOLLOW STEPS, LITERALLY, OF 'THE EXORCIST'
description: Tucked away in Georgetown is a long stone staircase, shown in the photograph at right, that has become one of the capital's more subtle tourist attractions.

title: DRAMATIC NEW SPRING SHAPES BY CALVIN KLEIN
description: CALVIN KLEIN has changed his design direction, and such a dramatic turnaround is rare in the annals of fashion. His spring clothes, instead of being free and floating, are shaped quite close to the body. They have a definite form and a good deal of flash.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1.9 million for the qr and 6 mos from a change in Britain's tax law and a gain of $630,000 for the 6 mos on the sale of a building

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VICTIM'S FAMILY GETS $4 MILLION IN SUIT ON CRASH
description: A settlement was approved yesterday to pay approximately $4 million over a 30-year period to the wife and four daughters of a Westchester County business executive who was killed in the crash of an Eastern Airlines jet in 1975.

title: CONVICT IN SIEGE IS SENTENCED
description: The gunman who held five persons hostage in a Brooklyn hospital for a three-day siege that began a day before he was to be sentenced on a robbery charge was given a sentence yesterday of 15 years to life on that charge.

title: Corona Heater Account
description: The GLO-International Corporation has assigned Needham, Harper & Steers advertising responsibility for its Corona Portable Kerosene Heaters. The $2.5 million account, previously at Penny-Ohlmann-Neiman Inc., will be handled by the Dayton office of N.H.& S. It's estimated that 10 percent of the country's homes now have kerosene heaters.

title: SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COCAINE TREATMENT IS SAID TO CAUSE PARANOIA
description: Cocaine, known to have caused mental aberrations through nonmedical use, can also cause hallucinations and paranoia when used in hospitals in its liquid painkiller form, doctors warn.

title: ULSTER BOMB KILLS THREE POLICEMEN
description: Three policemen were killed in Northern Ireland today when a large bomb planted by Irish nationalists exploded under their car.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Voice of Experience On Handling Hostages

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEAD OF CO-OP BANK TO TAKE SABBATICAL
description: Carol S. Greenwald, president of the National Consumer Cooperative Bank in Washington, has agreed with the bank's board of directors to take a three-month sabbatical, starting Nov.1, ''to study her role in the bank,'' according to a bank official.

title: WORKERS CLOSE ISRAELI AIRPORT
description: Employees of El Al Israel Airlines forced the closing of Ben-Gurion International Airport today by blocking the runways with three jetliners. They were protesting the Government's decision, made Sunday, to liquidate El Al unless the work force accepted a reorganization involving big staff cuts.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes net from disc operations of $1,094,000 for the qr and $830,000 for the 9 mos and a loss on disposal of disc operations of $7,912,000 for the qr and $7,601,000 for the 9 mos, plus an extraordinary credit charge of $12,000 and $2,725,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net income which includes losses from disc operations of $348,000 for the qr and $228,000 for the 9 mos and an extraordinary credit of $1,185,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle Tuesday on the Voter Education Project incorrectly identified Geral- dine Thompson. She is executive di- rector.

title: MUSIC: THE CONTEMPORARY PLAYS NANCARROW CONCERT
description: Nonprofessional music followers who feel guilty at times about not keeping up with all the significant contemporary music composers and their works may take comfort in the fact that even specialists in those subjects fall behind now and then.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Tony Nelson vs. Andre (Sugarman) Cooper, 12 rounds, middleweights, at the Sands, Atlantic City, 8:30 P.M. Both fighters are undefeated.

title: TAX WOES SAID TO COST MARTIN
description: A tax bill of $100,000 owed to the Internal Revenue Service and a broken agreement to help clear that debt led to Billy Martin's dismissal a week ago as manager of the Oakland A's, according to his attorney, Eddie Sapir. In an article in Tuesday's San Francisco Chronicle, Mr. Sapir also was quoted as saying that a display of temper by Martin, in which he destroyed some furniture in his office in the A's clubhouse last August, was another factor in his dismissal.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $279,000 for the qr and $354,000for the 9 mos...C-After a loss of $99,000 for the qr and income of $70,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: NATO Work Stoppage Today
description: Civilian staff members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will stop work for two hours on Thursday to protest proposed pay cuts, staff organization officials said. Further actions and a possible disruption of autumn ministerial meetings are envisioned if there is no progress, the officials said.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Selected data on the United States Government's spending and debt contained in the Treasury Department's monthly statement, which was released yesterday. Amounts are in millions of dollars; fiscal years run from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30. Total Public Debt, Oct 25 $1,140,896 Interest on Public Debt, Aug. 9,476 Interest, Fiscal Year through Aug. 108,344 Actual Deficit, Fiscal 1981 57,932 Projected Deficit, Fiscal 1982 108,884 Projected Deficit, Fiscal 1983 115,018 Receipts, Fiscal Year through Aug. 558,072 Receipts, Period Last Year 558,993 Outlays, Fiscal Year through Aug. 667,021 Outlays, Period Last Year 603,260 Gold at end of July 11,148

title: CHANDLER RETAINS BANTAMWEIGHT TITLE
description: Jeff Chandler, with a nonchalance that bordered on boredom but was tinged with savagery, stopped Miguel Iriarte of Panama in the ninth round tonight of a one-sided World Boxing Association bantamweight title fight.

title: Jersey Fire Kills 2 And Injures 5
description: A teen-age girl and a 6-year-old boy were killed and five persons were injured today in a fire that engulfed their home as they slept, authorities said.

title: TALKING POLITICS
description: "You have to dissemble, you have to recognize that you can't say what you think about (an) individual because you may have to use him or need him sometime in the future. There's a lot of hypocrisy and so forth in political life.

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RETIREMENT AND PENSIONS: AN AMERICAN DILEMMA
description: To the Editor:

title: CONRAIL (CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $36.8 million for the qr and $71.6 million for the 9 mos from the sale of tax credits

title: N.F.L. TALKS TO RESUME
description: Both sides in the National Football League strike agreed yesterday to resume talks on Saturday. The announcement of the resumption came on the same day that the National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint alleging that the league had refused to bargain in good faith.

title: BARGAINING POWER HARMFUL TO THE COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OLD, BUT NEW

title: 2 Marines Drown in Japan
description: Two Marine Corps veterans of the Vietnam War drowned while trying to cross a small but deep stream in Okinawa during a reconnaissance training mission, United States military authorities said today. They were identified as Sgt. William A. Dibblee, 23 years old, of Spokane, Wash., who was said to have drowned while trying to help Cpl. Jose F. Hernandez, 32, of El Paso, Texas.

title: Article 252246 -- No Title
description: A $3 gold piece struck at the San Francisco mint in 1870 and believed to be unique was bought at auction early this morning at the St. Moritz Hotel for $687,500, the highest price every paid for a regular issue United States coin at auction.

title: McGinnis on Waivers
description: George McGinnis, who has played professional basketball for 11 years, yesterday was placed on waivers by the Indiana Pacers, the team he joined in 1971 when it played in the American Basketball Association. McGinnis, 32 years old, has two years remaining on his contract but he was dropped because of diminishing performances in recent years.

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $54,000...C-After loss from discontinued operations of $411,000 and extraordinary credits of $362,000...D-After income from discontinued operations and disposal of business segment of $54,000...E-AFter loss from discontinued operations and disposal of business segment of $43,000 and extraordinary credits of $362,000; the 1981 results were restated toreflect discontinuance of certain operations, in addition to adoption of LIFO method for inventory costs

title: Lewis Rome for Connecticut
description: Connecticut voters have a right to feel shortchanged by the gubernatorial contest now mercifully drawing to a close. William O'Neill, the Democratic incumbent, has conducted a soporific campaign so as not to jeopardize his 20-point lead in the polls. His Republican challenger, Lewis Rome, sought to increase his recognition factor with charges of mismanagement and malfeasance during the O'Neill tenure, but offered few clues about his vision of the state's future.

title: THE PURPOSE OF TERROR BY OFFICIAL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

description: B-Net income; results for the latest third qr include a loss of $21 million in the corporation's equity in Celanese Mexicana S.A.

title: PORTER, H K, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN HOCKEY, THERE'S A MINIMET SEASON
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. O n the understandable assumption that the Stanley Cup will be filled with champagne elsewhere next spring, perhaps by the New York Islanders for the fourth consecutive year, the New Jersey Devils wisely obtained viewing rights to the cup three weeks ago when they opened their first season in the Meadowlands.

title: U.S. WARY FOR JURY IN TEAMSTER TRIAL
description: The jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, is being treated with unusual protectiveness by Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall. He is providing the jurors with lunch at the taxpayers' expense.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL SEES REFUGEE CAMPS IN THAILAND
description: Attorney General William French Smith visited two of Thailand's refugee camps today and said several times that he was glad he did not have to determine which Indochinese refugees could go to the United States and which could not.

description: B-Includes a gain of $843,000 from early extinguishment of debt...C-After a gain of $404,000 from operating loss carryovers

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS ON GRAIN TO BEGIN
description: The United States will begin discussions with the Soviet Union Thursday on President Reagan's offer of 23 million metric tons of American grain. But some American market analysts doubt that the Russians will buy much more than the 8 million tons of American grain they are already expected to take under the bilateral grain trade agreement.

title: Conrail's Net Declines 8.6%
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said third-quarter net income fell 8.6 percent, to $59.3 million, or $2.34 a share, from $64.9 million, or $2.56 a share, in the corresponding period last year.
