title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.T.&T. PLANS SALE AT SEARS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would sell its telephones in Sears, Roebuck & Company stores under an agreement with the nation's largest retailer. Sales are to begin in about two weeks.

title: ALLIED SECURITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results include a pretax gain of $79,665 or 6 cents a shr on investment transactions

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KLA INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT SAFETY OF KEROSENE HEATERS
description: Sales of a new generation of improved kerosene heaters are increasing by more than 100 percent a year, and industry projections suggest that the devices will help heat about 10 million American households by the end of this heating season.

title: DANIEL M. KELLY
description: Daniel McGowan Kelly, a maverick Democratic Assemblyman from the West Side from 1951 through 1967, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan, where he had practiced law since his retirement as a Civil Court judge 10 years ago.

title: SFN NAMES CHAIRMAN, AN ACQUISITION EXPERT
description: John R. Purcell was named yesterday as chairman, chief executive officer and president of the SFN Companies, a big publishing holding company in Glenview, Ill.

title: AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods reflect an unusual nonoperating net charge of $178 million from a provision to realign and divest certain assets and operations and a net gain of $19 million, or $1 a shr from the sale of the company's major domestic paper-related operations to James River Corp on July 2, 1982

title: Democrat Describes Ad By Senator as a Smear
description: A top Democratic campaign official today accused Senator Harrison Schmitt, Republican of New Mexico, of conducting ''one of the most repulsive and least-justified smear campaigns in the history of American politics.''

title: BERTRAM NEWHOUSE, GALLERIES CHAIRMAN, 'DEAN' OF COLLECTORS
description: Bertram M. Newhouse, chairman of the board of Newhouse Galleries Inc., who was considered the dean of American art collectors, died in his sleep in New York last Friday. He was 99 years old.

title: N.A.S.L. Aid Promised
description: The North American Soccer League's annual winter meetings ended today with the 12 club owners pledging additional financial support to keep the league going. Some vowed to finance personally Team America, the potential 13th franchise, if the league's president, Howard J. Samuels, could not raise funds for it for the next outdoor season.

title: Alabama Court Disqualifies Election Foe of Black Judge
description: Justice Oscar Adams of the State Supreme Court is all but certain to become the first black elected to statewide office in Alabama since his fellow judges ruled his opponent off the ballot Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: POLISH LEADERS CONCEDE ECONOMY IS IN 'UNPRECEDENTED BREAKDOWN'

title: Big Winner
description: By riding the winner of the first race yesterday at Aqueduct, Angel Cordero became only the third jockey in thoroughbred racing history to reach the $70 million mark in career earnings. He joined Bill Shoemaker and Laffit Pincay in that exclusive club.

title: Bloedel Loss At $30 Million
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest products manufacturer, said it lost $30 million for the third quarter, following a loss of $8.4 million for the same period in 1981.

title: THEATER: MAMET'S 'EDMOND' AT THE PROVINCETOWN
description: ACCORDING to a fortuneteller who appears in the first scene of David Mamet's ''Edmond,'' everything in life is ''predetermined.'' If you can buy that, you just may believe Mr. Mamet's play, which tells of a respectable New York businessman who walks out on his wife to explore Manhattan's sleaziest wild side, and, ipso facto, plunges into degradation, madness and murder.

title: NESTLE-LE MUR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW LABOR ACCORD CUTS COST OF TRAIN CREWS, AMTRAK SAYS
description: W. Graham Claytor Jr., president of Amtrak, says the rail passenger service has reached an agreement for the first time to employ its own engineers directly in the busy Boston-New York-Washington corridor, a key to cutting operating costs over the next three years.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $524,000

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $432,000 on the sale of assets

title: 3 TELL U.S. INQUIRY OF FEARS BEFORE BOAT SANK OFF JERSEY
description: An inquiry was opened yesterday into the sinking on Sunday of a fishing boat off New Jersey with the loss of eight lives, and three survivors told of their apprehension from the start of the trip because of rough seas.

UNIVERSAL CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
COMPACT STEP STOOLS
description: FOLDING or multiple-function stools are particularly useful for apartment dwellers and those with limited space, especially as a handy substitute for regular ladders.

title: EMPIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUROLATOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Third of five articles: Impact of black athletes
description: On April 15, 1947, Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers' rookie first baseman, made a less-than-stunning major league debut at Ebbets Field in a game against the Boston Braves. In four trips to the plate, he grounded out twice - once into a double-play - flied out and reached base on an error. But Robinson's statistics on that day were trivial in relation to what he would later represent. For at 28 years old, he had become the first black in modern history to break the color line that dominated baseball for so long. Few, if any, events in America's sports history have created the kind of upheaval that Robinson engendered on the day he integrated baseball.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a special loss of $15.2 million

title: CHINA, POP. 1,008,175,288: ONE-FOURTH OF THE WORLD
description: After conducting the largest census in history, China announced today that it has a population of 1,008,175,288. That is nearly one-fourth of the world's population, which is put at 4.5 billion. And with a Chinese baby appearing on the scene every two seconds, this country continues to have a wide lead over the world's second most populous country - India - which has 700 million people.

title: Judge Extends I.B.M. Order
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge yesterday extended a temporary restraining order preventing three former employees from using secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation. The men are being sued for stealing the computer company's secrets, an I.B.M. spokesman said yesterday.

title: Eastern Air Suit
description: New York Air said it had been sued by Eastern Airlines, which is asking that the regional airline be prohibited from using the word shuttle in describing its service. In papers filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Eastern claims that such advertising violates its trademark rights to use the phrase ''Air-Shuttle'' and that it confuses the public. Michael E. Levine, president of New York Air, said in a prepared statement, ''We believe the suit to be without merit.''

title: REVERE FILES PETITION FOR CHAPTER 11
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc., known for its Revere Ware cooking utensils, said yesterday that it was unable to meet current obligations and had filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: STATE SAYS COSTS MAY FORCE OTB TO END OPERATIONS WITHIN 3 YEARS
description: New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, in the face of increased expenses and little or no growth in revenue, may have to discontinue operations within three years, according to a report released yesterday by the State Comptroller's Office.

title: DeLorean Bail Effort Unsuccessful on Coast
description: Attorneys for John Z. DeLorean fell short again today in efforts to satisfy court requirements for the posting of $5 million bail to free the automotive executive who was jailed on drug trafficking charges.

title: Major Expansion
description: Prince Khaled Abdullah of Saudi Arabia is in the process of acquiring the Belair Farm Ltd. in Fayette County, Ky., and the Ferrans Stud Farm in Ireland.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK

title: UNDER SHULTZ, A SHIFT TO A LESS PERSONALIZED ROLE

title: CHINA AFTER DENG
description: The next major political upheaval in China will take place four years from now. How can I be so vocally unequivocal? Simple: China's 10-Year Pendulum of Power. In 1946, Mao's Communists swept out the Kuomintang. In 1956, Mao's blundering Great Leap Forward tore the country apart and curtailed his power. In 1966, Mao took his revenge with the Cultural Revolution, which threw out the intellectuals and the bureaucracy. In 1976, the bureaucracy roared back and made criminals out of Mao's would-be successors. In 1986, if this power pendulum keeps swinging with its amazing regularity - de-Dengification, the return of Communist purity and the expulsion of the ''capitalist roaders.''

title: FENWICK-LAUTENBERG RACE NARROWS

THEATER: 'SOME MEN,' A STORY OF ALCHOLISM
description: WHILE John Ford Noonan's ''Some Men Need Help'' is not a memorable play, there are two images that linger on after the rest has vanished. One is of Philip Bosco, bounding into a spic-and-span suburban Connecticut kitchen wearing an amateur baseball uniform modeled after the Italian flag. Mr. Bosco, who normally turns up in grayer, more classical attire, looks quite mad in head-to-toe redwhite-and-green, and we share his glee in the prank. It's as if Ralph Richardson had suddenly been reborn as Charles Ludlam.

Premiere of Frank Zappa Special
description: Since 1974, the rock guitarist Frank Zappa has brought his band to New York for annual appearances on Halloween. Despite the runaway success of his song ''Valley Girl,'' the band is not touring this year, but Mr. Zappa has them on videotape. Sunday at the Ritz, he will give the premiere showing of ''The Dub Room Special,'' a 90-minute documentary of two Zappa bands, including footage from his 1981 Halloween show at New York's Palladium.

title: PUBLISHING: TRIBUTE TO LATIN AMERICA
description: UNITED STATES publishers of Latin American authors are gratified that Gabriel Garcia Marquez of Colombia was recently awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature, for it bolsters their conviction that some of today's most important and innovative writing is being done in the Spanish language. No one was more enthusiastic about the award than John Macrae 3d, publisher of E.P. Dutton & Company. ''I'm delighted that Garcia Marquez won it, because he's a major writer,'' said Mr. Macrae. ''And his winning it represents an important victory for serious writing.''

title: U.S. PREPARES JURORS TO HEAR F.B.I. TAPES IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: Federal prosecutors in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, and four codefendants began preparing the jury today to hear the first of scores of taped conversations.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $50 million relating to the costs associatedwith the withdrawal of Tylenol capsules

description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $51,129,000 for the qr and 9 mos resulting from the Chapter 11 filing of Revere Copper & Brass Inc, which is 33 percent owned by Asarco and pretax foreign currency translation credits of $13.8 million forthe qr and $39.6 million for the 9 mos...C-Net income including foreign currency translation credits of $400,000 for the qr and $8.6 million for the 9 mos

title: Woman Is Called Heroin Ring Head
description: A 33-year-old Queens woman was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges describing her as the head of a major heroin ring.

title: A KEY TO HUMAN GROWTH IS REPORTED FOUND
description: Scientists in California report that they have found and artificially duplicated a long-sought brain substance that is crucial to normal human growth.

title: TOWNSEND MARTIN, SPORTSMAN, AT 74
description: Townsend Martin, an investment banker, race-horse owner and breeder, and former part owner of the New York Jets football team, committed suicide last Friday at his home in North Castle, N.Y., in upper Westchester County. He was 74 years old.

title: BLAIR, JOHN, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BERNARD KING COMES HOME
description: Bernard King remembers the first time he saw a game in Madison Square Garden, nearly 10 years ago. He had always been too busy ''playing my own games'' to visit basketball's most famous arena, but when he was a senior at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn he was honored as an all-city player between halves of a Knick game.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $20.7 million...C-Net loss...D-Including income of $172.1 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $90.2million...E-Net loss including income of $52.7 million from discontinued operations

title: Asarco Loses $56.8 Million
description: Asarco Inc., whose 33 percent-owned Revere Copper and Brass subsidiary filed for Chapter 11 protection on Wednesday, said yesterday it lost $56.8 million in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with earnings of $6.3 million, or 7 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1981. Sales for the quarter dropped 18.2 percent, to $329.1 million, from $402.3 million.

title: GODFATHER'S PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bishops in Honduras Denounce New Violence
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of Honduras have denounced the rising tide of violence by both radical elements and authorities in the country, warning in a letter that it ''could end our democracy.''

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Builder Tells of Payoffs To Hudson Prosecutor
description: A New York developer struck a deal with the Government today and said he had funneled $115,000 in payoffs to the suspended Hudson County Prosecutor, Harold Ruvoldt, to bribe officials in Kearny and North Bergen.

title: IOWA FARMER IN THE BIG CITY
description: D ixon Terry, a tall, red-haired, red-bearded dairy farmer from Greenfield, Iowa., spent a whirlwind 24 hours in New York yesterday. Up to then he had never been east of Chicago, never been on a plane and never seen the ocean.

title: NETS MAY PURSUE RICHARDSON
description: As the Nets trimmed their roster to the 12-player maximum for Friday night's season opener by placing Mike O'Koren on the injured-reserve list today, talk persisted at practice about the possibility of adding Michael Ray Richardson to the team.

title: Shareholders Back Harvester Plan
description: The shareholders of the International Harvester Company approved overwhelmingly today a financial restructuring plan that will give Harvester's creditors a major share of the company's common stock.

title: Knight's Logic
description: Bobby Knight, the Indiana University basketball coach, says that he likes the college game the way it is and opposes ''fiddling'' with it - at least in principle.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Military Officers Hold Nicaragua Talks

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS WIN A BIG VICTORY IN NATIONAL VOTE
description: The Socialist Party won a landslide victory in the Spanish general election on Thursday, sweeping back into power 40 years after its bitter defeat in the civil war.

title: CECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Daily News Raising Its Price to 30 Cents
description: The Daily News will raise the price of its weekday papers a nickel, to 30 cents, beginning Monday, Joseph Kovach, an assistant managing editor, said yesterday.

title: In Memoriam
description: Without fanfare, Edwin H. Mosler Jr. of New York, who died last March, helped many of the world's best amateur figure skaters meet their expenses. He also raised money for the United States Olympic Committee.

title: 'NEW ODD COUPLE,' 'CHASTITY GULCH'
description: YOU have got to have a gimmick, the old show-business adage insists, and the producer Garry Marshall (''Laverne and Shirley'' and so on) has come up with a clever one for an ABC-TV series that starts tonight at 8:30. ''The Odd Couple,'' based on a Neil Simon play, is being brought back as ''The New Odd Couple.'' The difference is that this time prissy Felix, the photographer, and slobby Oscar, the sportswriter, are black.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices posted sharp losses, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 15.36 points, to 990.99. Analysts said investors were worried about Tuesday's elections, the course of interest rates and a somber new economic forecast. Prepared for the Fed, the forecast projects real economic growth of only 2 percent for 1983. (Page D1.)

title: FOR 2 DIVERSE BANDS, SWINGING'S THE MUTUAL GOAL
description: IF there is one hallmark of new ''progressive'' jazz, it is a willingness to redefine ''progress.'' Like today's visual art, it synthesizes ideas from all over, without preconceptions about history or geography - the stylistic blinders are off.

title: PAN AM, CUTTING COSTS, NARROWS ITS NET LOSS
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that its net loss had narrowed to $28.9 million in the third quarter, largely as a result of what analysts described as cost cutting. That compared with a loss of $79.8 million during 1981's third quarter, not counting a onetime gain of $500 million on the September 1981 sale of Pan Am's Intercontinental Hotels Corporation.

title: OREGON METALLURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New President at Y & R
description: ALEX KROLL, continuing his meteoric rise at Young & Rubicam, his one and only employer in the agency business, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest worldwide agency and heir apparent to Edward N. Ney, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an unusual gain of $8.1 million on the settlement of litigation

title: Dance: Latin-American
description: CELEBRATION was the order of the evening on Wednesday at the Grand Ballroom of the Hilton Hotel, when the Latin American-Dance Theater of New York and corporate friends led by General Foods threw a party to aid the company's scholarship fund. Wine and awards flowed, and the performers Hilda Bracero, Jose Molina and Eleanor D'Antuono and Raymond Smith turned up to help the company celebrate.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Abruzzi tradition on the East Side.
description: READERS often ask how restaurant ratings are arrived at, especially when a place is given two stars or more, even though some of its dishes are faulted. The answer is that a rating represents an averaging out of the kitchen's performance, balanced against price, service, atmosphere and a few other considerations, such as view or location.

title: Touch of Class Top Open Jumper
description: Conrad Homfeld guided Touch of Class to victory in the international open jumper competition tonight at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: PARTY AT GATEWAY PARK
description: The Federal Government is throwing a birthday party of sorts tomorrow for the Gateway National Recreation Area, the 26,000-acre park facility in New Jersey, Staten Island, Brooklyn and Queens that turned 10 years old this month.

title: Market Place; Oil and Gas Income Funds
description: OIL and gas properties, decidedly out of favor as tax shelters, may offer investors satisfactory income prospects even so. That's the argument put forth by companies that specialize in limited partnerships - groups that buy producing oil properties for income purposes. Petro Lewis and Damson are the leaders in oil and gas income plans, and Morgan Petroleum Inc. is a relative newcomer.

title: Five Die in Pittsburgh Fire
description: Five persons, including a community leader, Oshea Perry, were killed early today in an explosion and fire in a boarding house that they apparently operated, the authorities said. The bodies of Mrs. Perry, chairman of the Hill District Project Area Committee, and four men were found in the rubble. One resident, Lake Rutledge, 73 years old, was taken to the Central Medical Pavilion and for treatment of cuts and burns.

title: DANCE: IN JAZZ IDIOM, BY DANNY BURACZESKI
description: the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company, which opened Wednesday night at Riverside Church, is one of the more original dance groups around - attempting to deal with an area of dance that rarely lends itself to originality.

title: TIME TO GO BIPARTISAN
description: The Reagan Administration has gone on the defensive, facing a general recognition that its throbbing slogans worked no magic at home or abroad.

title: THE TRICKS AND TREATS AT THE MAGIC SHOPS
description: Transient terror, illusory monsters, scary trickery and a smattering of realistic gore are sensations we expect on Halloween. But this year, E.T., the friendly alien, has been insinuated right into the midst of such less gentle folk as Frankenstein, Wolfman, Dracula and last year's popular Halloween villain, Darth Vader.

title: EGYPT SEEKS TALKS ON BEACH DISPUTE
description: Egypt formally asked Israel today to resume negotiations over the future of a narrow strip of Sinai beach that both nations claim. The request came as work on an Israeli luxury hotel neared completion on the disputed, 750-yard stretch of beach south of the Israeli port city Eilat.

title: Bell Proposes Sales Plan
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposes to key future prices of its home telephones to inflation in its program of selling the phones to their users, the company said today.

title: Left-Wing Chief Stripped Of 7 Labor Party Posts
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party has ousted the radical leader Tony Benn from his power base on key party committees.

title: MORE SKINFLINTS, PLEASE
description: These are trying times for the international bankers, what with the Drysdale affair, the Penn Square mess down in Oklahoma, the mystifying imbroglio involving the Vatican's dollars in Italy, and the spectacular liquidity crisis in Mexico, a nation the bankers somehow deemed worthy of a whopping $80 billion in loans just before it was discovered that Mexico didn't have the money to pay them back.

title: A President for Dreyfus
description: As the winds of change blow through the mutual-fund industry, the Dreyfus Corporation, which manages $25 billion in 23 funds, announced yesterday the election of Joseph S. DiMartino as president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Howard Stein, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $9,960,000 for the qr and 9 mo

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Conigliaro, the 37-year-old former Boston Red Sox outfielder who went into a coma for four months after a heart attack last Jan. 9, has been returned to Salem, Mass., Hospital for treatment of his second bout with pnuemonia. ... Nikki Gianulias of Vallejo, Calif., became the leading single-season money winner in the history of women's bowling Wednesday when she won the Dallas-Fort Worth Classic. Her purse of $5,000 lifted her total earnings for this season to $43,375, topping the record of $41,270 set last year by Donna Adamek of Duarte, Calif. ... Art Whittington, who starred as a running back for the Oakland Raiders and is now with the Buffalo Bills, was arrested on a charge of issuing four bad checks for a total of $1,225 to a motel in Hamburg, N.Y. He was freed on $1,500 bail, and arraignment was set for tomorrow.

title: PLY GEM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago figures were restated for LIFO conversion

title: CUOMO CAMPAIGNS FOR JEWISH VOTERS
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for governor, campaigned for Jewish votes yesterday, saying he needed them to win on Election Day and to govern afterward.

title: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including securities gains of $267,000 for the qr and $4.7 million for the 9 mos...C-Net income including a securities gain of $678,000...D-Including a securities gain of $6.7 million

title: JOAN MONDALE: GONE STUMPING
description: The recorded voice on the telephone in the Mondale home in Northwest Washington says cheerily: ''Hi, this is Joan. Gone again.''

title: WHITE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings figures are fully diluted

title: MENTAL PATIENT DIES ON STATEN I. AFTER A SEDATION
description: A 27-year-old mental patient at the South Beach Psychiatric Center on Staten Island died Wednesday shortly after he had been injected with a sedative and placed in a straitjacket, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle Oct. 5 on the 1981 Scholastic Apti- tude Test incorrectly stated the aver- age math score of students with fami- ly incomes above $50,000. It is 509.

title: Cosmos Triumph
description: Vladislav Bogicevic's goal at the 40-minute mark led the touring Cosmos to a 2-1 victory over the South Korean national team today. The Cosmos were trailing, 1-0, when Johan Neeskens tied the score at the 25-minute mark. Giorgio Chinaglia assisted on both Cosmos goals.

title: BUILDER LINKS SINKING TO WATER BILGE
description: The builder of the fishing boat that capsized and sank Sunday off Point Pleasant, N.J., with the loss of eight people said yesterday that the probable cause of the sinking was excessive water in the bilges.

title: 'All Savers' Rates Decline
description: The interest rate on tax-exempt ''All Savers'' certificates will drop to a low of 6.66 percent for new deposits beginning Sunday and continuing through Nov. 27, Treasury officials said today.

title: TYLENOL RECALL EXPENSE IS PUT AT $100 MILLION
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would spend $100 million to withdraw Tylenol capsules from the market and cover the other expenses arising from the contamination of some capsules.

title: WISCONSIN ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1982

title: COUNTY TOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: The 1981 earnings have been restated to account for F.A.S.B. No 43

title: 2 Republicans Found Gaining in California
description: Mervin Field's latest California Poll shows the Democratic candidate for Governor, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, leading George Deukmejian, the Republican Attorney General, by only 6 percentage points. The margin was 47 to 41.

title: Auto Worker Layoffs
description: The number of auto workers reported on indefinite layoff rose to 247,767 this week, the highest level in six months, according to industry reports today.

title: QUICK ACTION VOWED ON AMERASIANS
description: Attorney General William French Smith said here today that the Reagan Administration would act ''just as quickly as we can'' to carry out a new law that permits the Asian children of American fathers to go live in the United States.

title: A FORBIDDEN WINDSHIELD THAT SAVES EYES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Bill Root Proves His Skill At the Table Is Still There
description: Many rare birds have the good sense to spend their summers in the North and their winters in the South. One of them is Bill Root, whose stature exceeds almost everyone else's in three ways: in physique (he is 6 feet 9 inches); as a bridge teacher, based half the year in New York and half the year in Boca Raton, Fla., and as a player.

title: RAYPAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $88,000 for the qr and $333,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $302,000

title: PARKWAY VILLAGE IN QUEENS GOING CO-OP
description: The people who opened a garden apartment development for United Nations personnel in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens 35 years ago probably considered it only logical to name the community Parkway Village.

NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Yr to July 31
HOW TO IMPROVE BLACK STUDENTS' TEST SCORES
description: To the Editor:

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A PSYCHIATRIST AND EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Abraham N. Franzblau, a psychiatrist, a leader in Reform Jewish education and a founder of the Hebrew Union College School for Teachers in New York City, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NABISCO TO ACQUIRE HUNTLEY & PALMER
description: Nabisco Brands, the cereals and snacks giant, will merge with Huntley & Palmer Foods P.L.C. of Britain, pending the approval of British shareholders, it was announced today.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rock: Eddie Money Is Back
description: AFTER a two-year career hiatus, Eddie Money, the former Brooklyn policeman turned successful rock singer, has recently returned to recording. And on Wednesday, Mr. Money, backed by a versatile hardrock quintet, appeared at the Ritz in an evening of solid meat-andpotatoes rock-and-roll. Mr. Money's popularity is rooted in his image as a hard-working journeyman musician.

title: SONAT OFFSHORE DRILLING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of Sonat Inc

title: PUMPKIN BUYING IN CITY OR ON FARM
description: ''IF you want to make a jack-o'-lantern,'' said a farmer selling pumpkins at the Union Square Greenmarket, ''just choose the shape you like.''

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POP JAZZ
description: JIM HALL and Ron Carter, who have been acknowledged jazz masters of the guitar and the bass, respectively, since the 1960's, are playing as a duo in New York this weekend and all next week for the first time in 11 years.

title: Coach Charges a Plot
description: Donnie Duncan, the Iowa State football coach, views a resolution approved by the university's student government this week as a ''personal vendetta'' against one of his players. The resolution says that participating in intercollegiate athletics is a privilege and that, as representatives of the university, athletes should be responsible for their behavior off the field.

title: WINDFALL AS NEW ISSUES ROLL IN
description: The recent drop in interest rates has led to a flood of new or proposed tax-exempt bond issues by local governments and authorities that will result in an unexpected windfall for the United States Treasury.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
FILINGS BY JOBLESS STILL AT HIGH RATE
description: The Labor Department today reported continued high levels of unemployment insurance claims, and both Democrats and Republicans predicted another increase in national unemployment in October.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Appeal for a Child

title: 5 big art sales next week.
description: This weekend art collectors and dealers will shuttle between auction houses to inspect millions of dollars worth of Impressionist and modern art, which will be offered in sales next week. Questions on the minds of participants involve the quality of the paintings and sculptures in these five sales and how well they will fare in the auctions, which take place next Wednesday through Friday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, and at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: J.M.W. TURNER PAINTING FAILS TO SELL AT AUCTION
description: J.M.W. Turner's ''Landscape With Walton Bridges,'' one of two important art works from the collection of J. Pierpont Morgan to be auctioned this week, did not sell yesterday when it was offered at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Beatlefest in Jersey
description: What is billed as the 10th official New York area Beatles Fans Convention - meaning it has Beatles approval - will be held at the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel, 2 Harmon Plaza, in Secaucus, N.J., from 5:30 P.M. to midnight today and noon to midnight tomorrow and Sunday.

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
U.N. AGAIN URGES HANOI TO PULL OUT OF CAMBODIA
description: By an overwhelming vote, the General Assembly called on Vietnam today to remove its 180,000 troops from Cambodia and permit Cambodians to choose their own government.

title: Muskie Given Campaign Role For Democrats in 2 TV Ads
description: The Democratic Party will be represented on television each of the two days before the election Tuesday with a five-minute film featuring Edmund S. Muskie, the former Secretary of State and Senator from Maine.

BASEBALL SOUTHERN LEAGUE - Approved 146- g ame schedule for 1983, two more games t han in the 1982 season. Extended con- t racts of Jimmy Bragan, league presi- d ent, and Bob Willis, vice president, t hrough 1985 season.

Entire Amtrak Train Catches Fire in California
description: An Amtrak train filled with commuters traveling from Los Angeles to San Diego caught fire tonight, setting two locomotives and all five cars ablaze and injuring five passengers, none seriously.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McDermott Plan
description: J. Ray McDermott & Company said its board approved a restructuring plan under which a subsidiary will make a tender offer for the parent company's stock.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 15 about the Gregorian calendar incorrectly gave the date of the day immediately preceding its first adoption. That date, the last to be reckoned according to the Julian calendar, was Oct. 4, 1582.

title: SPAIN IS CALM AS IT DISPLAYS ART OF VOTING
description: After six years of practice, Spaniards have mastered the art of voting and electing their leaders with a tranquillity and a thoughtfulness that are still cause for surprise.

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FARMERS' TIGHT HOLDING OF GRAIN LIFTS FUTURES
description: Producers' reluctance to sell grain and soybeans pushed futures prices higher today in moderate trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: THE RANGERS CLICK WITH POWER PLAY
description: In hockey, the good teams make the most of every advantage offered them. That includes the power play - a chance to play for two minutes with five skaters against the penalized team's four, or sometimes with five against three if the other team has two men in the penalty box.

description: B-Includes a foreign currency translation loss of $334,000 from the Mexico pesodevaluation...C-Net income

title: DIRECTOR RATES OSHA 'FAR BETTER THAN IT WAS '
description: When Ronald Reagan was running for President, no Federal department or agency came in for more scorn from him than the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

title: PAPA BACH WOULD BE PROUD, THEY'RE PLAYING SON'S OPERA
description: During his lifetime, Johann Christian Bach (1735-82) enjoyed a musical reputation that would have made his celebrated father, Johann Sebastian Bach, very proud of him. He wandered far afield from his birthplace, Leipzig. From 1754 to 1762, he lived in Italy, where he fell under the spell of Italian opera. He moved to London, where he became friendly with and a musical influence on the young Mozart, and gave the city's first solo piano concert.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM 3 FENWICK-LAUTENBERG DEBATES
description: Following are excerpts from three debates between New Jersey's candidates for the United States Senate, Representative Millicent Fenwick, the Republican nominee, and Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic candidate. One debate, sponsored by the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, was held Oct. 6 in Whippany. Another, conducted by WABC-TV in New York, was videotaped Oct. 21. The third, sponsored by the League of Women Voters, took place on Tuesday in Pomona. Opening Statements

title: MASLAND, C H, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $1,702,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,105,000 on the sale of property

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT SLUMPING DEVILS
description: As the two men walked side by side in the hall outside the Byrne Arena locker rooms tonight after the game, Lorne Henning knew how Billy MacMillan felt. Henning offered the only words of consolation that he could for a friend who is also a rival.

title: DeLorean Case
description: A bankruptcy judge handling proceedings against DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd. has decided to liquidate the company at the request of its biggest private creditor, Regie Nationale des Usines Renault of France.

title: 4 DAYS OF FILMS RECALL ARMY'S ASTORIA STUDIO
description: Adventurous moviegoers in the metropolitan area can learn a great deal about the first jazz singer of talking pictures this weekend or begin catching up on the last decade's films from Australia, New Zealand and Greece. They can also find out what Army film makers were doing all those years in Astoria, Queens (even film buffs may be surprised by some of the famous names and faces who helped them).

title: Satellite Business
description: Satellite Business Systems, the joint venture of Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Communications Satellite Corporation, announced that it would enter the residential longdistance telephone business. The company, based in McLean, Va., will be the fifth major entrant in the market. Its service will begin in late December in Washington, the company said, and will extend to Minneapolis and Philadelphia in January and to 17 other major markets by the end of 1983, the company said.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Crawford Indicted
description: Crawford Enterprises, its two top officers and seven other businessmen have been indicted on charges of paying almost $10 million in bribes to two former officials of Petroleos Mexicanos, the Mexican state oil company, it was announced. The indictment said the bribes were paid in connection with the sale of gas compression equipment to Pemex in the late 1970's.

title: SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd in Dec 1981

title: LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHORE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Silver Surplus Seen Ending
description: The glut that has troubled the silver market since 1979 will virtually disappear next year, Credit Suisse said today.

title: CITIZENS AND SOUTHERN IS BACK
description: Once the beacon of Southern banking, the Citizens and Southern National Bank of Atlanta was gravely wounded in the recession of 1974-75. It almost failed, its chief executive was forced out by regulators and it lost much of its glamour.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''B EVERLY and I survive a great number of parties - this is one of the best,'' Peter Greenough said as he peered through centerpieces of wild orchids, sheet music and ballet slippers. Mr. Greenough is Beverly Sills' husband, and the party was to honor his wife and George Balanchine for what will be the first joint performance of the New York City Opera and New York City Ballet. Since Monday night's party was hosted by Merrill Lynch & Company, which is helping to underwrite the Nov. 16 event, big names from business and society abounded.

title: 2 Laborites Win By-Elections; New Alliance Scores Gains
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party won two parliamentary by-elections on Thursday, but the new Social Democratic-Liberal Party alliance scored significant gains.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Fourth of five articles: Significant gains by female athletes
description: When women run their first Olympic marathon in 1984, Kathrine Switzer will be beaming like a proud parent. Miss Switzer ran in the Boston Marathon eight times - the first in 1967. That year, however, she was an uninvited, unwelcome guest because women were barred from the event. To Miss Switzer, the inclusion of the 26-mile-385-yard race in the Olympics is ''not just another event'' for women. It is, instead, a symbol of the strides women have made in the last decade, when they have broken through psychological, sociological, physical, financial and legal limits to improve their performances dramatically and shatter long-held perceptions about the roles of women in sports. ''The thing that excites me the most is the lack of a sense of limitations,'' said Miss Switzer, who is 35 years old. ''When I was first running marathons, we were sailing on a flat earth. We were afraid we'd get big legs, grow mustaches, not get boyfriends, not be able to have babies. Women thought that something would happen to them, that they'd break down or turn into men, something shadowy, when they were only limited by their own and society's sense of limitations.

title: PUERTO RICANS GRAPPLE WITH 22% UNEMPLOYMENT

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1982
description: International Spain's Socialists won a landslide victory in general elections, returning to power for the first since the 1936-39 civil war. Officials announced that the Socialists had gained a clear majority in the 350-seat Congress, and the leaders of all rival parties conceded defeat. (Page A1, Column 6.) Mass graves near Buenos Aires prompted a protest outside the presidential palace. The bodies of about 400 unidentified people have been found in 88 unmarked graves, and human rights groups linked the finding to the thousands of Argentines who vanished during the campaign against leftist guerrillas in the 1970's. (A12:3-6.)

What better basis for a blockbuster exhibition! - to say nothing of the spinoff potential for jewelry, books and other salables in museum shops. No wonder that, in some circles, they're calling ''The Search for Alexander'' the ''Son of Tut.''

title: IGOR SCHWEZOFF, BALLET DANCER
description: Igor Schwezoff, a dancer, choreographer and ballet teacher, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old. Mr. Schwezoff was born in St. Petersburg. He trained at the Leningrad Choreographic School. His first professional appearances were in 1926, with the Academic Theater of Ukraine. In the 1930's and 40's, he danced in revues in China and the Teatro Colon Ballet, Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and Colonel de Basil's Original Ballet Russe, as well as with Bronislava Nijinska. Mr. Schwezoff appeared in ''Prince Igor,'' ''Carnaval'' and ''The Firebird,'' and his uncaricatured playing of the comic General in David Lichine's ''Graduation Ball'' won him special acclaim.

title: A MATTER OF PURGING
description: THE JOKE. By Milan Kundera. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 267 pages. Harper and Row. $14.95.

title: ALCOHOLISM'S COST IS PUT IN BILLIONS
description: The economic cost of alcohol abuse may be as high as $120 billion in the United States each year, and treating alcoholism may cost less than not treating it, according to a Congressional report. ''The cost of treatment to the Government is a drop in the bucket compared to the cost to society,'' said Leonard Saxe, the report's principal author, who is an assistant professor of psychology at Boston University.

title: Sale of Arrows Is Seen Imminent
description: John Luciani, the Arrows' owner since their inception in 1978, will sell the team by Monday, the Major Indoor Soccer League and the Arrows' general manager said yesterday.

title: Theories About Coma
description: The brain hemorrhage that has left Normand Leveille of the Boston Bruins in a coma for almost a week after he collapsed in a dressing room in Vancouver last Saturday may have been caused by a severe blow to the head. Dr. Bruce Stewart, medical director for the Ontario Athletic Commission, said yesterday that the brain abnormality diagnosed by neurosurgeons who operated on the player for six hours contained a bundle of blood vessels that often tear from a hard blow. Leveille reportedly took several hits to the head in the four days before his collapse, and in the game he crashed head-first into the boards during the first period. Dr. Allan Ryan of Minneapolis, editor of Physician and Sports Medicine magazine, said he had viewed films of the game and believed that Leveille, who always wore a helmet, might have been injured by any one of several hits just before his collapse between the first and second periods.

title: SUNKEN SHIP OF BRONZE AGE FOUND OFF TURKEY
description: A sunken Bronze Age ship that underwater archaeologists hope will prove to have the oldest intact hull yet discovered has been found off the coast of Turkey. The wreck is in 150 feet of water near the port of Kas.

title: MADRID PREPARING FOR ORDERLY SHIFT
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, who lost his own seat as his party was all but wiped out in Thursday's general election, promised today that he would allow no power vacuum to develop in Spain while the country awaits a new Socialist government.

title: '82 F.C.C. Move Seen For TV Deregulation
description: The Federal Communications Commission probably will consider deregulating the television industry before the end of the year, despite a pending court challenge of its 1981 deregulation of radio, the agency's chairman, Mark Fowler, said today.

title: FLAVORING FOR THE EMOTIONS
description: Although perfume manufacturers have always advertised their wares as creators of mood (romance, mystery, innocence), there has been virtually no consideration of food flavors and seasonings for the same reasons. Yet there are many flavors that evoke special moods, and it might be worth considering some of the psychological and emotional responses to various seasonings, highly subjective though they may be.

Edmund Edmondson, 62, Dies; Headed U.S. Chess Federation
description: Lieut. Col. Edmund B. Edmondson, who as executive director of the United States Chess Federation helped guide Bobby Fischer to become the first American chess champion of the world in 1972, died Oct. 21 at a Honolulu hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Kaneohe, Hawaii.

title: THE SOCIAL SECURITY STEW SIMMERS
description: When Congress returns from the campaign trail, Social Security reform will be right at the top of the agenda. But since it is such a volatile and dangerous issue, the lawmakers will need all of their craft and courage to come up with a solution for the system's deep-seated financial woes.

title: REPUBLICANS FOCUS ON TROUBLE SPOTS IN CONGRESS RACES
description: Republican leaders, thrown on the defensive by their own polls showing a Democratic surge in mid-October, are striking back in regional trouble spots in an effort to hold their Senate majority and to stave off major Democratic gains in the House of Representatives.

description: An off-duty police officer was shot to death in Brooklyn early this morning, the police said.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1982
description: International East-West trade issues were discussed in Washington by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs and the ambassadors from Japan and key West European countries, the second such session this week. One of the results of the talks, which were conducted with considerable secrecy, might be the lifting of the Reagan Administration's sanctions on companies involved in the building of the Soviet-European natural gas pipeline. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Moscow wants to reduce tensions with the U.S., and would wait if necessary for the ''primitive anti-Communism'' of the Reagan Administration to pass, a high-ranking member of the Politburo said in a major speech that seemed intended to balance a speech Wednesday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, which was one of the harshest statements the Soviet leader has made about United States policy. Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Politburo member, said that Moscow remained committed to an improvement of relations with Washington in addition to its current efforts to end its bitter dispute with China. (1:4.)

title:
PATENTS;

description: A method of detecting a new form of viral hepatitis was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services by two researchers. Patent 4,356,164 was granted to Dr. Edward Tabor and Dr. Robert J. Gerety. Dr. Gerety is the author of a recently published book on the subject.

title: KNICKS BEATEN IN OPENER
description: The coach and the players on the Knicks were new, and so was the excitement from the crowd. But the result was familiar. Last night at Madison Square Garden, the Philadelphia 76ers, who have beaten the Knicks more than any other National Basketball Association team, defeated them again, 104-89.

title: POLAND'S CHIEF SAYS REGIME WILL LIMIT 'ACTIVENESS' OF U.S.
description: The head of Poland's military Government, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, plans to ''limit American activeness on Polish territory'' in retaliation for President Reagan's latest trade sanctions, the official Polish press agency P.A.P. reported tonight.

title: FEAR OF TAINTED CANDY PROMPTS WIDE CONCERN FOR HALLOWEENERS
description: Halloween, with its tales of witches and goblins and ghouls, has always been a holiday that mixed fun and fear. But this year, as children are getting ready to put on garish makeup, plastic noses and ghostly sheets, there is more fear than usual.

title: McAdoo Joins Lakers
description: Bob McAdoo, who joined the Los Angeles Lakers last Dec. 24, has signed a multi-year contract with them, a team spokesman announced yesterday. The deal was worked out more than a week ago, but legal technicalities held up the signing. McAdoo, reportedly frustrated by the red tape, returned to his New Jersey home last week to wait out the delay. Thursday night, he flew to Los Angeles and signed the contract four hours after his arrival.

A GAME FACE, BUT NO GAME
description: T omorrow is Halloween and Joe Fields is going to a party, but not as a football player. On Sundays at this time of year, Joe Fields usually dresses up as a New York Jet, complete with helmet, shoulder pads and game face.

title: THE THEATER: 'SEX AND DEATH'
description: Spalding Gray has turned his life into a performance art. The Performing Garage is his theater as home: he sits behind a table and he ambles through events of his autobiography for our amusement and edification. He is one of the most candid American confessors since Frank Harris, and his impromptu memoir-as-monologue could certainly appear between hardcovers, but the reflections take on added comic dimension in performance. Mr. Gray is an accomplished actor as well as sit-down comedian.

title: U.S. AND THAIS SIGN PACT ON REPATRIATING CONVICTS
description: The United States and Thailand signed a treaty here today that will allow nationals of each country who are convicted of serious crimes in the other to serve out most of their prison sentences in their homelands.

title: A 'CLASS REUNION' FOR NATIONAL LAMPOON
description: ''National Lampoon's Class Reunion'' is a crowded, not-very-funny movie with only a few things in its favor. One is that it pokes mild fun at horror movies, which gives it the faintest hint of topical wit. Another is that its oversized cast includes some talented performers, although no one has been given a sizable role. A third is a title song performed by Gary U.S. Bonds, and played at both the beginning and end of the movie. By the latter point, the mad killer has been caught and straitjacketed, and all of his classmates are bopping with their arms wrapped tightly around their own waists, doing a modified pogo dance in his honor.

AETNA'S OPERATING NET UP 10%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest publicly owned insurance company, said yesterday that its operating earnings rose 10 percent in the third quarter from the similar period in 1981, while revenues remained about the same.

title: FALCONBRIDGE NICKEL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TWIN CITY BARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Net Up at Peat, Marwick
description: Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, the New York accounting firm, said its worldwide fee income for the year ending June 30, 1982, rose 17.5 percent, to $1.15 billion, from $979 million the previous year. According to the company's annual report released yesterday, chargeable hours increased 7.5 percent in the year, to 28.4 million, from 26.4 million. The report also said that personnel grew to 25,700, from 23,100, while partners' capital increased 8.4 percent, to $295 million, from $270 million.

title: PEMEX INQUIRY URGED ON 'KICKBACKS'
description: With Mexico's incoming President promising a ''moral renovation'' of society after he takes office Dec.1, demands are mounting for an investigation of rumors that corruption has flourished in Petroleos Mexicanos, the huge state oil monopoly, over the past six years.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; the 1981 results have been restated to reflect the company's portion of the losses recorded by Continental Airlines, accounted for under the equityaccounting method and consolidated subsequent to Sept 10, 1981

title: 8 GROUPS PROTEST U.S. HOSPITAL PLAN
description: Eight organizations representing public health officials, the elderly and hospital employees urged the Reagan Administration today to abandon its effort to cut back Federal regulation of hospitals.

title: THE TIME IS TODAY
description: Author's note: Recently I fed several hundred pieces of political analysis that have appeared in American newspapers and magazines over the past several months into a computer programmed to simulate human writing. I then entered, ''WRITE: THOUGHTPIECE, EXECUTE'' and the computer produced the following:

title: Halloween Ghouls
description: Eight Halloweens ago, in a suburb of Houston, a little boy named Timothy O'Bryan went trick or treating. One of his treats was laced with cyanide; he died soon after swallowing it.

title: DANCE: BLACK CHOREOGRAPHERS' 'PARALLELS'
description: ''Parallels,'' a series of concerts by black choreographers, made its debut Thursday night in St. Mark's Church under the auspices of the Danspace Project with works by Rrata Christine Jones, Blondell Cummings and Ishmael Houston-Jones.

title: Du Pont's Net Off 29% in 3d Quarter
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter declined 29 percent, to $195 million, or 82 cents a share. It added that the quarter would have produced a loss without the earnings of its Conoco Inc. subsidiary.

title: Mets' Strawberry Slugging Away
description: Darryl Strawberry is doing so well in Venezuela that the Mets may be compelled to put him in right field soon after the start of the 1983 season. Frank Cashen, the club's general manager, would prefer not to promote Strawberry before his time, but he may be too good to resist.

title: IRANIANS VS. THE ISRAELIS AND IRANIANS VS. ARABS
description: Iran's unsuccessful attempt to force a vote in the General Assembly last week on Israel's credentials was motivated by revenge - against its Moslem brothers from Arab countries.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers Continue Strike
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers vowed yesterday to continue their eightday-old walkout over wages, job security and working conditions. In a rally near City Hall, several hundred people urged Archibald R. Murray, the executive director of the society, to resume negotiations with the lawyers' union, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys. But no further talks were scheduled.

title: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Supreme Court Upholds Bar to Texas Execution
description: The Supreme Court today refused to allow the execution of Ronald Clark O'Bryan, who killed his son with cyanide-poisoned candy in Texas.

title: THE BURDEN OF A BIG HARVEST
description: The fall harvest is almost over here in the grain belt. Rows of hay and stalks of corn stand in the rust-colored fields. Huge combines roll through acres of soybeans, gathering up and spewing out the last fruits of this year's bumper crop.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RICHARD T. RIVES, JUDGE ON COURT THAT HELPED INTEGRATE THE SOUTH
description: Judge Richard T. Rives, a member of United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, whose landmark legal decisions helped desegregate the South, died at his home in Montgomery, Ala., Wednesday after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Unenviable Mark
description: No one noticed at the time, but Bob Bourne set an Islander club record in the game against Calgary on Tuesday night. As a result of a fight with the Flames' Pat Ribble, he broke his nose for the seventh time and thereby he broke out of a tie with Mike McEwen at six apiece.

title: AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Buitoni Shifts
description: Reports in the food trade indicate that the Buitoni Food Products Corporation, Hackensack, N.J., has recently undergone a change in its top management as a result of declining sales.

title: 'No' on Riparian Rights
description: Since colonial times, coastal states have asserted claims to lands under water at mean high tide. But as tides receded, leaving ''riparian'' land high and dry, home builders and businesses moved in, even though the state retained title to the land.

title: FEDERATED INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Patents;
Aid for Stalled Elevators
description: WASHINGTON A new emergency system for elevators can detect a power failure, then take control of the stalled elevator, lower it to the ground floor and open the doors to release the passengers.

title: Streak Extended
description: For a while, Randy Smith saw his chance to break John Kerr's record of 844 consecutive games played in the National Basketball Association slipping away from him. But the San Diego Clippers needed a guard and, 24 hours before their opening league game last night, they signed Smith.

A NEW INSULIN GIVEN APPROVAL FOR USE IN U.S.
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the marketing of human insulin made artificially from gene-splicing techniques. It is the first such product of genetic engineering to be granted Governmental approval for human use.

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jobless Rate in State Reported Still at 8%
description: New York State's unemployment rate held steady in September at 8.4 percent, the State Labor Department reported today.

MOSCOW SAYS IT IS STILL COMMITTED TO IMPROVING TIES WITH THE U.S.
description: A high-ranking member of the Politburo said today that the Soviet Union continued to stand for a reduction of tensions with the United States and would wait if necessary for the ''primitive anti-Communism'' of the Reagan Administration to pass.

title: Judge Rules Homosexual Can Re-enlist in Army
description: The Army must let a sergeant who acknowledges he is a homosexual re-enlist despite his refusal to answer questions about his future sexual activity, Federal District Judge Barbara Rothstein has ruled.

title: Levin Making 2d Bid To Replace Rinaldo
description: Adam Levin, the Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives from the newly designed Seventh Congressional District in New Jersey, is a 33-year-old Westfield lawyer who is making his second attempt to unseat Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, a Republican. The last campaign was in 1974, the year Mr. Levin was graduated from the University of Michigan Law School.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
STANDARD-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33. 1. It may have been rhyme and reason that persuaded Anthony Hecht, pictured above, to accept his new job. What job is it? 2. A tabulation in a foreign country made headlines around the world. What count was it and why was it newsworthy? 3. George J. Stigler, the Nobel laureate in economics, took the prize for frankness at a recent meeting. With whom did he meet and what did he say?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report by The Associated Press in Metropolitan Report Oct. 23 incor- rectly identified two men indicted on charges of stealing silver. M.K. Venugopal is administrative assistant in radiology at Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. Theodore Lattof is a former administrative assistant in radiology at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Schwartzwalder Feted
description: Ben Schwartzwalder, who coached teams at Syracuse that won 153 games, lost 91 and tied 3 from 1949 to 1973, will be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame today during halftime of the game between the Orangemen and Colgate at the Carrier Dome in Syracuse. More than a hundred of his former players gathered last night for a dinner to honor the 73-year-old coach, who led Syracuse to the national championship in 1959 and to four Lambert Trophies as the best team in the East.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AVM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: DRUG IS EXPECTED TO GIVE LILLY BETTER IMAGE, IF NO PROFIT RISE
description: The granting of Federal approval yesterday to Eli Lilly & Company to make and sell a new form of insulin ''will be super for its image,'' a securities analyst said. But he added that the new medicine, a hormone that will be made from human rather than animal glands, would probably have little effect on the company's profits.

title: J.C. HALL, HALLMARK FOUNDER, IS DEAD
description: Joyce Clyde Hall, a quiet, reserved Nebraskan whose fondness for postal greetings helped him parlay two shoeboxes of imported postcards into the world's largest greeting card concern, Hallmark Cards Inc., died yesterday.

UNION GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Trial Dates Reset
description: Mike Strachan, the former running back for the New Orleans Saints who was sentenced Sept. 29 to three years in prison for selling cocaine to his National Football League teammates, has received a month's postponement of the start of his sentence.

title: Messerschmidt And Agfa Job Cuts
description: Two big West German companies said they planned to cut more than 6,000 jobs.

title: BRANCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOAT SURVIVOR TELLS OF SLOSHING WATER
description: A 16-year-old survivor of the Joan La Rie III, the fishing boat that capsized and sank Sunday off Point Pleasant, N.J., with the loss of eight lives, testified yesterday that he had heard water sloshing around below decks shortly before the boat sank.

title: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include gains on the sale of certain assets of $395,000 or 12 cents a shr for the latest 9 mos and $57,000 or 2 cents a shr for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN MOTORS PUTS LOSS AT $30.9 MILLION
description: The American Motors Corporation reported today a third-quarter loss of $30.9 million, which it attributed to the recession and the long automobile sales slump.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits Rise At Manville
description: The Manville Corporation, which filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Aug. 29, reported today that its net earnings for the third quarter of 1982 were higher than in the corresponding quarter in 1981.

title: A 3-TERM CONGRESSMAN WOOS NEW CONSTITUENCY
description: The senior citizens' center here is a traditional campaign stop for candidates for the House of Representatives. But when the three-term Republican incumbent in the Ninth Congressional District, Harold (Cap) Hollenbeck, arrived today, hardly anyone seemed to know who he was.

title: ERA OF THE NEW SADISM; What with the Tylenol-cyanide madness and the spiking of Halloween candy with common pins, I got to thinking about why this rise in sadism was taking place.
description: I know sadism isn't as important as, say, the DeLorean scandal, but the Feds have already cracked that case, and I wanted to be the first to unravel the cause of this new social disease.

title: LAWYER IS OFFERED TOP LEGAL AID POST
description: The board of the Legal Services Corporation offered the position of president today to a lawyer for a food processing company, passing over candidates who had drawn wide criticism from supporters of legal aid organizations and civil rights groups.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: Matsushita Profit Falls
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest maker of consumer electric and electronics products, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 8 percent from a year earlier. Matsushita put third-quarter earnings at $141.3 million, or 91 cents a share, down from $153.4 million, or 99 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up to $3.4 billion, from $3.39 billion.

title: U.S. SEEKS ACCORD WITH ALLIES ON END OF PIPELINE CURBS
description: Senior officials of the United States and key allies discussed a plan today under which the Reagan Administration would drop its sanctions against companies that helped to build the Soviet natural gas pipeline.

title: CRUM & FORSTER INSURANCE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. HOUSE CANDIDATES LEADING IN FUND RAISING
description: Despite the bad political news of the recession and discouraging national polls, Republican candidates for the House of Representatives have improved their prospects in Tuesday's elections with a surge of contributions that has overtaken the total raised by their Democratic rivals. As unemployment went up, so did Republican receipts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Crowning Achievement

title: FRANK'S NURSERY SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLGATE'S VICTORY
description: A fter their most emotional and significant victory of the year, one that was determined in campus offices rather than on a football field, the Red Raiders of Colgate University can now continue their season with the hope of becoming the best college football team in the country. The assumption is that Division I-AA, to which Colgate was banished before this season by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has become the nation's highest level of true college competition. The bowl contenders among the powerful Division I-A teams, by stepping into prime time and forming their own national football league, have gained nearly everything that the N.F.L. teams possess, except perhaps a reliable kicking game and a militant labor union.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a favorable adjustment of $5.7 million resulting from the settlement ofcertain litigation...C-After a favorable adjustment of $1,274,000 associated with a prior yr's loss provision for discontinued operations, and a gain of $1.5 million on the sale of the company's Expert Automation unit

title: U.S. ENVOY WARNS SALVADOR
description: Ambassador Deane R. Hinton warned today that United States aid to El Salvador could be halted unless the Government checks rightist ''thugs'' accused of murdering thousands of civilians.

title: IRISH SEEKING A RESURGENCE
description: Notre Dame opened the season against Michigan with such offensive power that the Irish consistently beat the Wolverines at the line of scrimmage before Michigan defensive players took half a step forward. It was Notre Dame's most impressive offensive performance since Gerry Faust became the head coach in 1981.

title: CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including a gain of $1.3 million from discontinued operations

title: U.S. SENATE RACE TOPS JERSEY ELECTIONS
description: In New Jersey elections, dominated by an intense United States Senate Race, drastically changed Congressional districts will pose a problem for some New Jersey voters at the polls on Tuesday.

title: FIFTH WHEELS
description: It appears that some of the ''Great American Eccentrics'' who were researched by Judson Hand, author of the recently published book by that title, lived in Westchester. Two of them were cave dwellers: Sarah Bishop occupied a cave near North Salem, and John Stoltus slept in a coffin inside a cave near the Hawthorne Circle, according to Mr. Hand, a former book review editor and feature writer for The New York Daily News.

title: 'NEW ' ORCHESTRAS
description: THE county's two oldest orchestras - between them they have given us 95 years of music - opened their seasons on consecutive Saturdays this month: for the Westchester Symphony on Oct. 16, it was the start of its 58th; last weekend, the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester embarked on No. 37. Both are community treasures.

title: COUNTY, G.M. WORK TO AID PLANT
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN WITH the auto industry hard pressed, county officials have begun to work with General Motors to explore ways to assure the continued operation here of the company's assembly plant, one of the county's largest employers.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LA BOHEME'
description: The New York City Opera is currently offering its production of Puccini's ''La Boheme,'' and Thursday night's performance featured neat, attractive, serviceable sets and staging by Lloyd Evans and Cynthia Auerbach and a consistently professional cast of singers.

title: Montclair St. Wins
description: Montclair State took over sole possession of first place in the New Jersey State Conference with a 25-13 victory over previously unbeaten Trenton State tonight at Sprague Field.

title: AN INSURGENT OF THE MIND
description: A MARGIN OF HOPE An Intellectual Autobiography. By Irving Howe. 352 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: U.S. PRIEST NAMED BY ANGLICANS
description: An American priest has been appointed to a leading executive position for the world's 65 million-member Anglican churches, Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, announced in London last week.

title: AUTUMN LESSONS; Stubborn Beauty
description: It might be because the frosts have been so late in coming or maybe because there weren't so many gypsy moths around this summer to sap the strength and spirit of the trees. Whatever the reason, the fall leaves -much later than they are supposed to - are still giving the parks and parkways a glorious piebald look.

title: A Cornucopia of Calendar
description: America has a new favorite pinup. E. T. hiding in a bunch of stuffed animals, E. T. examining the contents of a refrigerator, E. T. riding in a bicycle basket and E. T. in assorted other stills from his movie will adorn many a wall in the year to come. At the country's largest bookstore chains - B. Dalton and Waldenbooks - ''E. T.: The Extra-Terrestrial Calendar 1983'' (Putnam/Perigee) is the bestselling calendar this fall.

title: CHILDRENS'S BOOKS
description: THE MONSTER'S RING By Bruce Coville. Illustrated by Katherine Coville. 87 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 11)

title: Phebe Willits, R.A. Bergenheim to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Willits of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Phebe Willits, to Richard A. Bergenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Bergenheim of Cohasset, Mass.

title: Kathleen Ryan Married
description: Kathleen Anne Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Ryan of Mechanicsburg, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon in Kingston, N.Y., to Harry Wade Burkhart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burkhart Jr. of New Paltz, N.Y. Andrew Aurigemma, Justice of the Town of Esopus, performed the ceremony at Hoffman House, a restaurant.

title: DESPITE BULGING COFFERS, TEXAS GOVENOR IS IN A CLOSE CONTEST
description: Although he has raised nearly $12 million, possibly the largest campaign treasury ever accumulated in an American gubernatorial race, Gov. William Clements is fighting a stiff battle to keep his job.

title: Capitals 6, Blues 5
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Dennis Maruk scored two goals, including the game-winner with 6:19 remaining to lift Washington to victory.

title: THE SELF-CONTAINED TRAVELER
description: NEWS FROM THE GLACIER Selected Poems 1960-80. By John Haines. Illustrated. 157 pp. Middletown, Conn: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $8.95.

title: GUATEMALA RELIC HINTS AT AN EARLIER MAYA CULTURE
description: Archeologists excavating ancient ruins in Guatemala have found a pottery shard bearing one of the earliest known examples of Maya writing. The discovery is considered strong evidence that an advanced Maya civilization existed 300 to 500 years earlier than was previously thought.

title: POP: THE PSYCHEDELIC FURS
description: There are two kinds of tension at work in the Psychedelic Furs, who performed Friday at the Beacon Theater. One of them makes the band go - it's the tension between the band's pounding power chords and Richard Butler's vocals, which are sung in a frayed, weary tone, all gall and wormwood.

title: FASHIONS AFOOT IN MILAN
description: BERNADINE MORRIS reports on fashion for The New York Times.

title: No Headline
description: WALKER SETS SCORING RECORD

title: Brooklyn Man Arrested In Rape-Murder of Girl
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with throwing a teenage Queens girl to her death from the roof of a 13-story building after raping her, the police said yesterday.

title: WE ARE ANGRY BUT WE ARE ACTING
description: THE article (Opinion Page, Oct. 3) ''Civic Groups: A Vital Link to the Future'' by Diane Lundegaard prompted me to write concerning my experiences as a leader and my thoughts about the importance of an active and strong civic association.

title: FAUST HAS MANY GUISES, BUT GOETHE'S LIVES ON
description: Observing this year the 150th anniversary of Goethe's death and also taking note of a holiday, Halloween, which seems singularly appropriate to a play about witches and devils, the Classical Stage Company will today, for the first time ever in this country, present the whole of ''Faust,'' Goethe's epic poetic drama of diabolical temptation, earthly love, cultural history and much more.

title: TECHNOLOGY FURTHER CHANGES THE NATURE OF POLITICAL RACES
description: The last campaign advertisements have been delivered to television studios, the final appeals have been mailed, and by Tuesday evening, after the polls close, the shape of Congress and the nation's state houses will be clear. But it may be several months before the consultants and media advisers, who tugged harder than ever this year at the marionette strings of politics, have evaluated the techniques they used in this election.

title: PLAY FOR YOUR OPPONENT'S WEAKEST POINTS
description: The rule for playing the opponent is the same as for the position: Aim for the weakness, and if there is none, at least stay away from a confrontation with the enemy's maximum strength.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''BY NOW, we're very familiar with hidden objectives, violent endings and clandestine assignations,'' said Nan Buranelli of Lawrenceville.

title: FRESH OFFERINGS IN OPERA ADD UP TO A MIXED BAG
description: It took Richard Wagner 25 years to complete his greatest undertaking, the three-part music drama plus prologue known as ''Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' Ever since, mounting a Ring on the stage or, in more recent times, recording the cycle complete, has been regarded in operatic circles as the supreme challenge, possessed of that aura of monumentality many producers - even those with minimalistic tendencies - believe the public lusts after.

title: THE WOMAN IN THE WHITE SUIT
description: Black has been the popular shade for fall clothes. But now, as the fashion pendulum swings toward the holiday and resort seasons, white is surfacing as a favorite, particularly for tailored suits.

title: No Headline
description: Pitt Wins, 63-14, From Louisville

title:
GALLERY VIEW;
EARLY AND LATE BRAQUE IN TWO WASHINGTON EXHIBITS
description: 1963) has not had an overwhelming degree of attention in this country, certainly nothing on the order given his friend and fellow-innovator, Picasso. This, of course, has a great deal to do with the fact that after their investigative Cubist years, Braque settled down to develop a quiet, meditative art of still lifes and landscapes, while Picasso went on to gain, by dint of his protean talents and restless drive to make himself master of every medium, superstar status in the eyes of an international public.

title: ASSEMBLY CONTESTS ARE OVERSHADOWED
description: GREENWICH NOT since 1974 have Connecticut residents voted in the same election for a Governor and United States Senator, and political novices like Michael de V. Flinn and William Richter of Greenwich seem to be wondering whether many voters are paying much attention to them.

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: I believe that Nan Robertson will be saving many lives by ''going public,'' as did Betty Ford when she alerted us about breast cancer. I have two daughters, ages 17 and 21, and have continued to ''rant'' about toxic shock syndrome, but did not feel that I was making much of an impact. Of course, they both read every word of the article. RUTH PERELSON New York City ------

title: Sabres 3, Maple Leafs 3
description: Mike Foligno's goal at 6:04 of the final period gave Buffalo a 3-3 tie. The Sabres trailed, 1-0, at 4:31 of the first-period after Normand Auban, a Leafs' center, scored on a rebound.

title: FOUNDATION FINANCES CHILD-HEALTH PROGRAMS
description: The Ford Foundation has undertaken a new program to improve the health and mental development of poor children in the United States and in third world countries with grants expected to total $6 million in the next two years.

title: U.S. SEES OPPORTUNITIES AND RISKS IN MIDEAST AFTER WAR IN LEBANON
description: First article of a series appearing periodically on the new balance of power in the Middle East since the war in Lebanon.

title: '82 F.C.C. MOVE SEEN FOR TV DEREGULATION
description: -The Federal Communications Commission probably will consider deregulating the television industry before the end of the year, despite a pending court challenge, of its 1981 deregulation of radio, the agency's chairman, Mark Fowler, said today.

title: THEATER'S 3D LIFE DRAWS TO A CLOSE
