description: The best seat in the house at the New Westchester Theater in Tarrytown, N.Y., now sells for $25, and you have to take it home when you leave.

title: Allen True to Form
description: Proving that some things never change, even in a league that has yet to run a play, George Allen has traded a draft choice. Allen, now coach of the Chicago Blitz in the United States Football League, had routinely dispensed future draft choices for established veterans when he coached the Washington Redskins and the Los Angeles Rams in the National Football league. Now he has given up his first choice in the Jan. 4 college draft to the Washington Federals to acquire George Roberts, a 27-year old punter who played for the Miami Dolphins and San Diego Chargers, averaging 41 yards.

title: CAIRO PONDERS LEISURELY RETURN TO ARAB FOLD
description: It was nearly 2 A.M., and Nadi Fouad, a belly dancer, was performing to the cheers of an audience made up almost entirely of foreigners.

title: Guarding Space
description: One of the more unusual inventions announced in Washington last March was a thermonuclear warhead detector, intended primarily for examining orbiting satellites.

title: SUPERMARKETS WITH ALL THE FRILLS
description: Gourmet supermarkets are injecting the $241 billion grocery business with new life. Selling such deluxe items as lobsters, truffles, caviar and, in some states, European wines, these stores are a new lure for the so-called upscale consumers who left traditional food markets when specialty shops began appearing on the scene several years ago.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN ANTONIO
description: WAYNE KING is chief of the Houston bureau of The New York Times.

title: CASINOS SAID TO FAVOR NORTHERN RAIL LINK
description: HAMMONTON THE state's hotel-casinos are much more interested in developing train service between Atlantic City and New York than between Atlantic City and Philadelphia, a would-be railway operator disclosed last week.

title: POLITICAL FEUD ANGERS A CITY'S REAL ESTATE AGENTS
description: Distressed that constant feuding between the Mayor and City Council is ruining the reputation of this southern New Jersey city, real estate agents here have banded together to run them out of office.

title: F.A.A. Grounds 307 Copters
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered the grounding of 307 civilian helicopters of a type involved in three recent accidents until new rotor-speed warning devices are installed, the agency said Friday. A spokesman said telegrams ordering the warning devices were sent to all operators of the Robinson R-22 helicopters. The helicopters, manufactured by the Robinson Helicopter Company of Torrance, Calif., were involved in three accidents resulting in four deaths.

title: SECOND AVENUE EL
description: To the Editor The article on Turtle Bay (Oct. 10) made no mention of the Second Avenue elevated line.

title: FULTON FERRY REVIVAL: A CLASH OF IDEAS
description: APARTLY vacant industrial area along Brooklyn's East River w aterfront -considered to be as rich in development potential as it i s in architectural history - is the focus of stepped-up efforts to b uild a vibrant complex of recreational, commercial and, possibly, r esidential facilities.

title: East Islip Wins by 10-7
description: Ken Kanzler kicked a 32-yard field goal early in the fourth period to break a 7-7 tie and give undefeated East Islip a 10-7 League II victory over West Islip. It was the sixth triumph of the season for East Islip, including five in League II. West Islip dropped its first game in six starts and is 4-1 in the league.

title: GALVESTON: A 19TH-CENTURY ISLAND CITY
description: ROBERT REINHOLD is a national correspondent for The Times, based in Texas.

title: Brezhnev Signals A Tougher Line
description: Soviet generals, alarmed by the American military buildup and worried about their own economy's chronic weaknesses, got a well-publicized stroking last week by Leonid I. Brezhnev. In an unusual meeting at the Kremlin, the Soviet leader promised a special assembly of 500 marshals and generals that guns would still take precedence over butter.

title: Nicaragua Blames U.S. for State of Emergency
description: Nicaragua's Ambassador to the United States concedes that his Government's declaration of a state of emergency has stirred political tension in the country, but maintains that the situation is largely the fault of the Reagan Administration.

title: ANIMALS' RIGHTS DEBATED
description: NEW HAVEN ''AS HUMANS we have puffed up species pride that makes us feel superior to animals and justified in doing whatever we want to them,'' said Thomas Regan, an animal expert. This was part of his argument against the use of animals for food and experimentation at an Animal Rights Forum at Yale University earlier this month.

title: The Old Liberalism
description: St. Thomas More or Sandy Koufax? Somewhere between them lies the man who could well be the next Governor of New York.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week on new savings instruments misidentified a California bank that was offering a 12.45 percent return on its Wild Card certificates of deposit. It is the Union Bank in Los Angeles.

title: The Cost of Canceling
description: Question: My daughter rented an apartment in Gateway Plaza at Battery Park City. She signed a lease and gave a month's rent. She was told verbally by the agent that only $50 would be deducted should she cancel the lease. Prior to completion of the building, she canceled the lease. She was notified that the apartment had been rerented and that there would be a brokerage fee of $200 taken out of her deposit. Is such a practice legal? ... N.K., New Rochelle, N.Y. Answer: Here is how the owner's representative explains your daughter's situation. The leasing of Gateway Plaza is handled by Harbor View Leasing Corporation, a company set up by the owners.

title: REMARKABLE PLAYER
description: Until recently there were only three women who have come within striking distance of victory in a world open championship, and all of them were well-established stars, playing with partners and teammates of high rank in the game.

title:
DINING OUT;
A RENDEZVOUS FOR RAIL COMMUTERS
description: SOME restaurants make their patrons feel warmly welcome, even though they are not regulars. A few restaurants have polished service that is never overbearing, just thoughtful and appropriately paced. But to find these qualities coupled with Italian food that ranges from fairly good to excellent is indeed serendipity.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTERS TO ELECT SENATOR AND GOVERNOR
description: A Republican United States Senator and a Democratic Governor will test the willingness of Connecticut voters to split their tickets in Tuesday's election.

title: GLEN COVE VS. THE RUSSIANS: A THAW IS 'QUIETLY' PURSUED
description: The controversy that began last May when the Glen Cove City Council voted to bar Soviet diplomats from the city's beaches, tennis courts and golf course remains unresolved but not forgotten, at least by city officials.

title: Democrats' Plea Is Rejected For Time to Reply to Reagan
description: The Federal Communications Commission, by a vote of 6 to 0, has turned down an application by the Democratic National Committee and others for equal time on CBS-TV to respond to President Reagan's address of Oct. 13.

title: A Great Din at Legal Services
description: Few Federal agencies have endured rougher assaults on their existence than the Legal Services Corporation. Last year President Reagan tried to abolish it, but had to settle for a 25 percent budget reduction from Congress.

title: WOMEN GET NEW CENTER
description: ENGLEWOOD A center for women that will bring together a variety of groups and services is scheduled to open here next month. Believed to be the first of its kind in northern New Jersey, if not the state, it is the new home of the Women's Rights Information Center.

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: When Nan Robertson's executive editor said, ''Tell Nan we don't love her for her typewriter; we love her for her mind,'' he expressed a profound truth. Her courage and eventual triumph must have made a tremendous impression on people all over the world.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK DEVILS
description: Al Arbour, coach of the Islanders, gave the team a day off Sunday but, as he made clear, ''not on merit.'' His players were tired, and Arbour said they needed a rest.

title: Davis Premise Disputed
description: To the Sports Editor: Willie Davis's article proceeds on a false premise, namely, that the concept of a wage scale is somehow contrary to the freeenterprise system. Despite some recent, and perhaps well-founded, criticism of American labor, no one could fairly suggest that the unions have been wrong to fight for wage scales in various sectors of the economy.

title: Leopard Injures 6 in Uganda
description: A leopard injured six people at a village near here before a housewife killed it with an ax, officials said today.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Love for Travel WHEN Jorge Luis Borges first spoke at the Center for Inter-American Relations in New York, shortly after its opening in 1967, his address was on ''The Poet in Argentina.'' Since then, Mr. Borges, who has spent most of his life in his native Buenos Aires, has been back several times. He was there again earlier this month when some 60 friends and admirers turned out for a dinner in his honor.

title: GREEK PUBLISHER'S SOVIET TIES SPUR CRITICISM
description: A multimillionaire Greek businessman has become a focus of dispute here because of his extensive ties with both the Greek Government and the Soviet Union.

title: SHELTER ISLAND CHALLENGES STATE
description: SHELTER ISLAND A question of who is usurping whose authority has put the Shelter Island Supervisor in conflict with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: KNICKS LOSE TO BUCKS, 108-86
description: The Knicks continued to have problems establishing a consistent offense tonight and were overwhelmed by the Bucks, 108-86, at the Milwaukee Arena.

title: YALE'S ART GALLERY HONORS ITS FOUNDING FATHER
description: One hundred and fifty years ago last Monday the Yale Art Gallery - then known as the Trumbull Gallery - first opened its doors. Due jubilation has marked the anniversary - not least at a mammoth dinner last night at which the painter Robert Motherwell was scheduled to be the main speaker. And if you happen to be in New Haven at 3 P.M. this afternoon you can try to get into the lecture hall of the present Yale Art Gallery, where the Governor's Foot Guard Band, which has been in existence since the year 1775, will be making a brave noise with fife and drums.

title: The Reagan Team On Strike
description: The strike by the Reagan Administration's first team leaves television's Sunday-morning public-affairs shows without ball carriers for supply-side economics, and the fans are at loose ends. ''Each Sunday for years,'' says a well-bearded East Side gent, ''a few of us have been jogging over to the telly at Elaine's for a brainy brunch beneath a bust of Larry Spivak. Nothing fancy, a hamper with a crusty loaf, a small country pate and a six-pack of young fume blanc from the cooler.''

title: PEARS OF ALL SORTS FINDING WAY TO MARKET
description: PEARS are having an exceptionally good season this fall. These subtle, fragile fruits , sweet and juicy, are in their glory with a slice of Roquefort cheese and a glass of Sauternes. They are also delicious simmered in red wine to a rich ruby-red hue or baked and served with crushed amaretti cookies, a favorite recipe of mine that was given to me by John Bernard Myers.

title: Elizabeth Dale Kendrick to Be a Bride
description: Elizabeth Dale Kendrick, an assistant corporation counsel with the Office of the Corporation Counsel for the City of New York, and W. Michael Garner, an associate with Rivkin Sherman & Levy, a law firm with offices in New York and Washington, plan to be married Nov. 20.

title: Sumako Kase, the Wife Of Japanese Diplomat
description: Sumako Kase, the wife of Toshikazu Kase, Japan's first representative at the United Nations, died yesterday at her home in Kamakura, Japan, of cancer. She was 70 years old.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WESTCHESTER residents who approved formation of a public utility agency by a 5-to-1 margin in a referendum last March may finally get to see it become law this week. Republicans who control the Board of Legislators decided last week to meet tomorrow night on the issue, abandoning their threat to delay approval.

title: EAST END SEEKS MORE DOCTORS
description: TWO East End towns are considering a plan that would set aside $30,000 annually in loans for area doctors who agree to treat less affluent residents.

title: THEY CREATED DANCE WORKS AT THE BAUTHAUS, TOO
description: ''Form follows function'' and ''Less is more.'' Perhaps no two artistic slogans have filtered down into the popular consciousness as much as these two principles dear to the leaders of Germany's Bauhaus movement between the two World Wars. While usually applied to the modern ''International Style'' of the Bauhaus architects, these are ideas that permeated nearly every other aspect of Bauhaus activity - and which promise to be embodied in a reconstruction this week of six ''Bauhaus Dances,'' originally created by the Bauhaus painter and designer, Oskar Schlemmer.

title: JUDGES TELL PUBIC HOW COURTS WORK
description: OF the three branches of government, the judiciary is probably the one most shrouded in mystery. Judges often appear aloof, lost in dark robes and with a foreboding manner. The workers of the judicial system are seldom understood any better. Often accused of Machiavellian machinations, at times unjust and at best slow, the courts appear to the average citizen as an ominous maze best avoided.

title: One Man Killed, 2 Hurt At Concert in Houston
description: Two men were stabbed, one fatally, and another was shot in the head in separate incidents Friday night at a large outdoor rock concert that the authorities described as a ''huge mess.''

title:
CAMERA;
FOR SOMETHING DIFFERENT: TRY PANORAMAS
description: Howard Millard is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: Ellen M. Moylan Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice F. Moylan of Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Mary Moylan, to John M. McMillin 3d, son of Mrs. Dorothy F. McMillin of Somers, N.Y., and Mr. McMillin Jr. of Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Hillary Demby Is the Bride of Donald Malafronte
description: Hillary Demby, a hospital specialist in the municipal bond division of Standard & Poor's in New York, was married yesterday to Donald Malafronte, son of Mr. and Mrs. P.A. Malafronte of West Hempstead, L.I. New Jersey Superior Court Judge Frances Cocchia performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: directions, toward Democrats by unemployment and toward
A Costly Miscalculation
description: Joseph Nzau of Kenya, the leader most of the race, broke stride when he thought he had crossed the finish line, and Nick Rose of England passed him to win the 9.3-mile Tulsa Run today. Rose was clocked in 43 minutes 46.1 seconds over the 15-kilometer course; Nzau's time was 43:47.

title: IN RED BANK, A 'NORMANDY VILLAGE'
description: ''A LOT of people thought we were ridiculous for doing this,'' said Elaine Sourlis, who with her husband, Theodore, is building the Courts of Red Bank, a 40,000-square-foot office-condominium complex in the heart of the 1.8-square-mile community.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BEHIND OUR SCHOOLS' PROBLEMS
description: IT IS time to stop kidding ourselves about the causes of the problems we have with public education in New Jersey. Unless we do, we will continue to focus on the wrong solutions.

title:
GARDENING;
THE SPOOKY LORE BEHIND SOME PLANTS
description: o'-lanterns. These seem to have evolved into something much more than a carved pumpkin with a crooked smile and twinkling eyes.

title: Levittown Division Wins, 7-6
description: Unbeaten Levittown Division defeated previously unbeaten Roosevelt, 7-6, to tie New Hyde Park for first place in the National League Conference I race with a 5-0 record. It was the 14th straight victory over two seasons for Levittown Division. Roosevelt had won four games.

title: Sahara Rebels Will Quit The O.A.U. Temporarily
description: The Polisario guerrilla movement has agreed to withdraw temporarily from the Organization of African Unity to pave the way for a meeting of African leaders, a guerrilla spokesman said today.

title: Philanthropy
description: To the Business Editor: Irving Kristol's ''Charity and Business Shouldn't Mix'' (Oct.17), is misleading. There is no contradiction in the phrase ''corporate philanthropy;'' and advocates of a quantitative standard for corporate giving are not muddled.

title: Hollis Sutherland Married to Broker
description: Hollis Ann Sutherland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Sutherland of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to George Carl Christophersen 3d, son of Mrs. Kenneth Rehberger of Glen Dale Heights, Ill., and the late Mr. Christophersen. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: St. John's Winner Over Hofstra, 49-46
description: Todd Jamison, once a student at Hofstra, rushed for five touchdowns and passed for a sixth score yesterday in rallying St. John's to a 49-46 victory over the Flying Dutchmen at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: STANFORD WINS; MARYLAND VICTOR

title: Gene-Spliced Insulin Receives Speedy Approval
description: In the remarkably short time of five months, the Food and Drug Administration last week gave Eli Lilly and Company the right to manufacture insulin using gene-splicing techniques. The new product - Humulin - should be available without a prescription sometime in the next year.

title: Israeli Officials Kept a Check On Sharon in the Lebanon War
description: Four Israeli Cabinet ministers formed a private committee to keep a check on Defense Minister Ariel Sharon during the war in Lebanon because they did not trust him, the Israeli radio reported today.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Handicapping OTB's Future
description: Like many of its patrons, New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation seems to be facing long odds. It's not that horseplayers are winning too many bets, but that they aren't placing enough of them to cover OTB's sharply rising costs.

title: Transactions; FRIDAY BASKETBALL
description: LOS ANGELES (NBA) - Signed Bob McAdoo, forward, to multiyear contract. Placed Clay Johnson, guard, on injured reserve. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Placed Charlie Criss, guard, on injured reserve.

title: LAISSEZ-FAIRE LANDSCAPE
description: Russell W. Peterson, president of the National Audubon Society, was Republican Governor of Delaware from 1969 to 1973 and headed the Council on Environmental Quality under Presidents Nixon and Ford.

title: LIBRARIES IN CRISIS: PATERSON'S WOES A 'MAGNIFICATION'
description: PATERSON THIS city's library system - a fountain of culture and education for successive waves of immigrants and their families - is teetering on the brink of collapse.

title: Policeman Slain Near Rome
description: Two unidentified gunmen shot and killed a policeman at a beach area near Rome as he drove home with his wife and two infant daughters, the police reported today.

title: Claudia Powell, C.E. Vieth Wed
description: Claudia Mary Powell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Powell of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Edward Vieth, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Vieth of Davenport, Iowa. The ceremony was performed at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Conn., by the Rev. James J. Dennis, assisted by the Rev. Paul E. Kritsch, a Lutheran minister.

title: ONe Less Link To Libya
description: Kevin P. Mulcahy suspected that being a key witness in the Government's case against two rogue intelligence agents might be detrimental to his health. After his death last week, Federal investigators began trying to determine if he was right.

title: Monica Dougherty Bride Of W.F. Gray Jr., Lawyer
description: Monica Mary Dougherty, daughter of Cornelius Vincent Dougherty of Seaford, L.I., and the late Mrs. Dougherty, was married yesterday in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York to William F. Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Yonkers. The Rev. Robert Collins performed the ceremony.

title: F.A.A. RAISES AGE LIMIT FOR NEW AIR CONTROLLERS
description: The maximum age for new air traffic controllers has been increased to 35 years, from 30 years, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Lynn Helms, disclosed today.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY OVERPAYMENTS CAN'T BE COLLECTED, JUDGE SAYS
description: A program of the Social Security Administration to recoup overpayments received by elderly people in New York State seven and eight years ago has been barred by a Federal court as being too harsh.

title: FEMINIST GAINS: A WRITER'S UPDATE
description: ''WE are still standing and fighting in place,'' said Marilyn French, the author, feminist and scholar, referring particularly to the failure of the proposed equal-rights amendment.

title: Francis Newton Carpenter 3d Marries Ellen Spira
description: Ellen Spira of Racine, Wis., was married yesterday in Milwaukee to Francis Newton Carpenter 3d of Chicago. Circuit Court Judge Charles Schudson, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Performing Arts Center.

title: 'ORPHAN' DRUGS: A STRUGGLE FOR RELIEF
description: WHEN the fall television season began, Sharon Dobkin of Brooklyn packed her bags, got into her wheelchair, and kissed her husband and 1-year-old son goodbye. She was off to Hollywood.

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES REPORT DROP OF 3.8% IN FRESHMAN CLASSES
description: Full-time freshman enrollment at the nation's private colleges and universities is down 3.8 percent this fall, an academic research group has found.

title: Guatemalan Government Says It Uncovered Plot
description: The Government said Friday night that it had uncovered a new plot to overthrow it, but declined to release any details immediately.

title: WHY, RACING FANS ASK, MUST A HORSE BE DESTROYED?
description: In a sport with hallmarks of grace and beauty, in a sport like thoroughbred racing, there is nothing quite like a mid-race breakdown to stir the public's emotions.

title: Sports of The Times; Good Chords in the Garden
description: Twenty-six years of coaching, and Hubie Brown had the quivers. Twenty-six years of coaching, and Hubie Brown was home. After one night in Madison Square Garden, it was as if he had never worked anywhere else.

title: SWING VOTE MAY BE THE KEY IN THE STATE
description: NASSAU and Suffolk, with 17 percent of the statewide vote in the 1980 and 1978 elections, could provide the ''swing'' votes in the hotly contested election for Governor, Republican and Democratic politicians feel.

title: EVEN BANKERS DRESS UP FOR COAST HALLOWEEN
description: Deep in the noontime shadows of the downtown Broadway Plaza, ghouls, witches, jellybeans and Pac-Men crept out of their offices Friday to mingle with the usual sidewalk traffic.

title: Proposition Explanation
description: Regarding the article (''Nassau, Beware of Weighted Vote, '' Oct. 24), written by a longtime foe of Nassau County's economical and constitutional ''weighted'' vote legislative system:

title: PINCAY: CHANGED BUT STILL PUSHING
description: THREE years ago, Laffit Pincay Jr. finally won a long struggle with his weight, a struggle that had shattered his physical and mental health and nearly ended his spectacular career. He calls himself a changed man now, appreciative of how close he came to selfdestruction and determined never to regress.

title: Butterfly Chase
description: A San Francisco company that develops land found itself sidetracked early this year in a rare biological project on San Bruno Mountain. ''We have spent $800,000 chasing butterflies,'' reported the company president, Sherman Eubanks.

title: Camacho a Unanimous Victor
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho, who readily admits how good he is, easily outpointed previously undefeated Melvin Paul today in a 10-round lightweight contest at the Sands Hotel and Casino. The outcome was no surprise to anyone else, either.

title: HAWAII TO PRESS MARIJUANA RAIDS
description: Gov. George Ariyoshi, who ordered National Guard troops into a foray against an armed band of marijuana growers last year, says he would do it again if necessary to combat Hawaii's illegal plantations.

title: MIDTERM ELECTIONS: TEST OF A 'MANDATE'
description: As the midterm campaigning has progressed, Democratic charges that the Reagan program is economically unworkable and socially unfair have intensified. So have White House rebuttals, as the President - to the distress of some Republicans - has taken the lead in turning the Congressional elections of '82 into a referendum on Reaganomics. The Week in Review asked three specialists in domestic policy to evaluate the impact of the Administration's course on people, cities and states and to explore longer-term effects. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor in the Carter Administration, is president of the National Policy Exchange, a Washington-based research and policy organization, and professor of economics and national policy at The Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas in Austin; E.S. Savas is Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for policy and research, and Isabel V. Sawhill is codirector of The Urban Institute's ''Changing Domestic Priorities'' project and coeditor of the recent Institute study, ''The Reagan Experiment.'' They talked with John Herbers, national correspondent of The New York Times, Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. Excerpts from their discussion follow.

title: No Headline
description: HAGLER WINS ON A KNOCKOUT

title: Heavier Hand In Warsaw
description: The Warsaw military regime dragged Poland deeper into the shadows of Soviet-style suppression last week. Parliament rubber-stamped laws modeled on the Soviet and Czechoslovak systems, enacting forced labor and jail penalties for ''social parasites'' who cannot prove they have jobs and for juvenile delinquents and drunks.

title: SALMON MISS CEREMONY
description: New York State's first fish ladder for salmon was dedicated this week at the Willsboro Dam on the Bouquet River near the western shore of Lake Champlain, but no salmon came.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Cornucopia Of Bargains

title: NUCLEAR WASTES
description: SEVERAL times each week, low-level radioactive wastes are transported, uninspected, over New Jersey highways to dumps hundreds of miles away.

title: JUDGE DEMBITZ: A LIFE IN FAMILY COURT
description: Last week was Nanette Dembitz's final one on the bench as a judge of the Family Court of the State of New York and, she said, she was taking things easy. But when one is a self-proclaimed ''workaholic,'' taking things easy is not always so easy to do.

title: College Weapons
description: Jobs for librarians were declining, but those for security guards were rising. As a result, the news report said last February, Montgomery County Community College in Blue Bell, Pa., was ''replacing a library science program'' with ''a weapons training program that the college says will be the first of its kind in the country.''

title: SCOTT CURD TO MARRY BETH H. GAMBACCINI
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Gambaccini of Ridgewood, N.J., have annonced the engagement of their daughter, Lieut. Beth Horan Gambaccini, U.S.A., to Lieut.

title: THE STATES LOOK AT SUPPLY SIDE
description: THE foray by the Reagan Administration into supply-side economics h as come full circle. Tax cuts have turned into tax increases and t hose economists who predicted that tax cuts would spur economic g rowth, regardless of the size of any budget deficit, no longer hold s way within Washington's corridors of power.

title: NATIONAL FUNDS MOSTLY ABSENT
description: WASHINGTON EXCEPT for the Senate race between Millicent Fenwick and Frank R. Lautenberg, the national party campaign committees have not been a major factor in the New Jersey elections this year.

title: 31 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health named 31 food establishments last week that had violated the city's health code. In addition, the department cited two restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and 12 that were closed for failure to do so.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MUSIC 152, YEAH, YEAH, YEAH
description: DOBBS FERRY MUSIC 152 was a sellout. The students didn't stand in line all night waiting for tickets, or hang around a box office hoping for a cancellation. But in the words of its professor, Gary Axelbank, the course at Mercy College was ''just like a concert - it filled up as soon as it was announced.''

title: Alice B. Chrystie Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Alice Belknap Chrystie to Peter Hunt Wyman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Chrystie of Short Hills, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Stephen V.R. Donahue of Katonah, N.Y., and Thomas H. Wyman of New York and Southport, Conn.

title: 2 ARE SOUGHT IN THE KILLING OF PHYSICIAN
description: On the evening of Sept. 14, Dr. Philip M. Wald, an obstetriciangynecologist affiliated with Beth Israel Medical Center and Cabrini Hospital, left his office at 145 East 16th Street in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan. He had intended to move his car, which was parked nearby, to the front of the building where he had his office.

title: Twinkle, Twinkle Salazar
description: Winning the New York City Marathon may not be easy for Alberto Salazar, but it's certainly becoming a habit.

title: AN OLD CHURCH AWAKENS TOMORROW
description: BROOKLYN EACH year on All Saints' Day, Nov. 1, Brooklyn's Old Trinity Church awakens from its slumber. The antique pewter communion service is taken from its vault at the back, the 18th-century embroidered altar linens are carefully freshened, the original prayer book and Bible are dusted, and the Rev. Ronald A. Glaude, the rector of Trinity Church, conducts a traditional All Saints' Day service.

title: JOAN SUTHERLAND RETURNS TO THE MET IN 'LUCIA'
description: Like many sopranos, Joan Sutherland longs for a larger repertory and smaller hips. Unlike many sopranos, Joan Sutherland knows she needs neither gimmicks nor glamour, for she is still going strong at 56, unparalleled in the flamboyant bel canto roles she has made her own for more than a quarter-century.

title: Art and Lace In Brussels
description: Art from the glorious past and art from this sometimes surreal century are the focus of two exhibitions in progress in Brussels. Brussels lace - the fragile, costly handwork that was coveted by princes and emperors, that made the city's reputation and was the object of industrial espionage long before that term was fashionable - is featured in an exhibition running until Nov. 15 at the Brussels Museum of Costume and Lace.

title: AREA HOUSING SHORTAGE CROWDING WHITE PLAINS WOMEN'S Y RESIDENCES
description: ''THEY'RE awfully nice girls, and you don't like to push them out into the streets,'' said Sally Hoover, resident director at the White Plains Y.W.C.A. - but that's what she often has to do.

title: COME, JOSEPHINE
description: A flying machine will join with horseless carriages in the new-car show at the Bergen Mall Shopping Center in Paramus Wednesday through Saturday.

title: A CORPORATE CRAVING FOR HAUTE CUISINE
description: While the gourmet food business is supported mainly by young urban people aged 25 to 45, one of its segments -catering - is getting its biggest boost from high-level corporate executives.

title: Primitive Peoples
description: To the Editor: We object unequivocally to the treatment of primitive peoples as presented in the articles, ''Venturing Into the Primitive World'' (Travel, Oct. 10). As anthropologists with a combined field experience of over 50 years in varied parts of the world, we were offended by the imperial condescension of the touristic perspective pursued in the articles, namely, primitive areas approached as living museums for the curious observer - complete with tour-leading anthropologists and deluxe accommodations in the villages and/or on ships offshore.

title: Steinbrenner's Ode
description: George Steinbrenner, in Gainesville, Fla., attending the football game between Florida and Auburn yesterday, received the usual question about the possible hiring of Billy Martin as Yankee manager.

title: FOR THIS PRO, TENNIS PLAYING AND UNION LEADING DON'T MIX
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON described his Presidency as a ''splendid misery.'' Although my experience as president of the Association of Tennis Professionals, the players' guild, has not been nearly so splendid or as fraught with misery as Jefferson's Presidency, I would nevertheless have to concur. Certainly, my friends would say it has wreaked havoc on my playing career, and I guess my wife, Jan, would say it has been more time-consuming than splendid. But when it was suggested by Butch Buchholz, the A.T.P. executive director, that I stand for election, it seemed the right thing to do.

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''Special Interest'' listing for Monday in The Guide, section 2A, in- correctly includes the television re- broadcast of the four-part mini-series ''QB VII.''

title: The Talk of Jim Thorpe
description: It was an Indian summer day here, and if the town seemed squeezed in the narrow gorges between mountains that autumn has brushed with gold, there was nothing cramped of spirit among the Thorpians basking once more in a renown drawn from their illustrious namesake and renewed attention to a pair of related issues. The heat of a national political campaign seemed far away, and if there was a hotbed of anything here, it was at Weiksner's Bar. Weiksner's, as Steve Duffy, one of its aging habitues, put it, is a sort of warm bed of Chunkerism.

title: A THIRD PARTY RUNS FULL SLATE IN THE ELECTIONS
description: CONNECTICUT voters will discover, when they go to the polls Tuesday, that the Democrats and Republicans will be joined on the ballot by a full slate of Libertarians.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: 1880, edited and translated by Francis Steegmuller. (Belknap/Harvard University Press, $15.)

title: LAST-MINUTE PURSUIT OF VOTES
description: IT is nearing the end of a very long campaign. Governor William A. O'Neill decided in the spring to run for re-election; his Republican opponent, Lewis B. Rome, started a leave of absence from his law firm over a year ago, so he could campaign full time.

title: 4 FORMER U.S. OFFICIALS CALL FOR A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Four former Government officials have renewed their call for a freeze on nuclear weapons, saying in a letter to The New York Times that they are convinced that ''it is in the best security interests in our nation and in the world.''

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: NO
description: It seems strange that the beginning of the strategic disarmament negotiations by the United States and the Soviet Union has not slowed public clamor for a nuclear weapons freeze.

title: ILLUSIONS OF ILLUSIONS
description: SCREENPLAY By MacDonald Harris. 249 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95

title: MUSIC:DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Wendy Young's debut recital Tuesday at the Abraham Goodman House presented the interesting case of an artist whose strengths and weaknesses spring from precisely the same elements in her playing. Miss Young plays the harpsichord with energy and finesse, and even the most giddy of cross-hand diversions present no technical problems; happily, her trill has nothing of the electric doorbell to it.

title: NEW WARNINGS OF TAINTED CANDY HEIGHTEN WORRIES OVER HALLOWEEN
description: Amid fresh warnings of contaminated candy, families across the New York metropolitan area prepared to celebrate a fearful version of Halloween today, curbing or abandoning traditional trick or treating.

title: Track Robbery Passes Million Mark in Purses
description: Track Robbery missed the track and stakes record by only two-fifths of a second and increased her career earnings to more than $1 million today in winning the $170,025 Spinster at Keeneland.

title: A SMALL SHOW, BUT STIMULATING
description: NEWARK ''CRAFTS of the 80's: Fiber, Metal and Clay,'' a small selection of works by master craftsmen, has been mounted at the Newark Museum to stimulate interest in a coming series of lectures by the exhibitors.

title: U.S. COURT REINSTATES LIBEL SUIT AGAINST A.P.
description: A Federal appeals court has reinstated a libel suit about an Associated Press story that named a Pennsylvania lawyer among individuals ''with alleged mob ties.''

title: Isabelle Kayaloff Wed to William Else
description: Isabelle Jacqueline Kayaloff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Kayaloff of New York, was married yesterday to William John Else, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Else of Sheffield, England. The Rev. Stephen Rodgers, assisted by the Rev. Beatrice Blair, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: PROTESTS RISE AGAINST OCEANSIDE LANDFILL
description: OCEANSIDE FOR years Oceanside residents have believed that this community, utilized as a main dumping ground for the Town of Hempstead's refuse and perceived as a major solution to the town's garbage disposal problem, was itself being dumped on.

title:
CHALLENGER HAS UPHILL BATTLE IN EFFORT TO UNSEAT THE ESSEX COUNTY;
EXECUTIVE
description: NEWARK ESSEX COUNTY voters will decide Tuesday who will run their county government for the next four years as County Executive. They also will elect a sheriff.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS ARE GROWING ARTICULATE AGAIN
description: I wonder if we ever pause for a moment in the day's occupation to give thanks for the fact that our plays are growing articulate again. We might, we well might. You will recall that, for quite a stretch there, we were regaled almost nightly with a calculated illiteracy, with a fumbled syntax that was supposed to represent life at its most real. Now, I am both surprised and pleased to say, playwrights are showing signs of having second thoughts. Within the past week two plays - one British, one local - haven't hesitated in the least to allow their characters to complete well-organized speeches without interruption from the sidelines or without internal hems and haws to suggest that the material was being improvised. The writing was unabashedly writing, and in so asserting itself it managed to make decidedly interesting a couple of narratives that had rather shaky premises. It overrode the weaknesses with its precision and/or its passion.

title: The Prime Time for Waterfowling
description: THERE has been waterfowl hunting throughout New York State this month in all areas but, with the exception of Long Island, a full commitment to the endeavor has not yet been made.

title: Is Big Brother Prone to Error?
description: ''Garbage in, garbage out'' is a jocular old dictum in the computer field. The saying takes on ominous tones, however, if the program contains the criminal records of 36 million Americans.

title: MORE HEADY DAYS FOR SPAIN: FIRST VISIT BY A POPE TODAY
description: After the emotionally draining events of the last 48 hours, which saw the election of the first left-wing government here in more than four decades, Spain is now girding itself for the first visit it has ever received from a Pope.

title: A ONCE-AND-FUTURE HALLOWEEN TALE
description: THE sentiment was noble, but the execution was faulty. By Halloween of 1960, I had outgrown prepackaged Raggedy Ann costumes and draped-sheet cliches; I was ready to make a statement through what I chose to wear.

title: McBurney, Unbeaten, Finds Road To Success
description: The percentages say the visitors usually lose more games than they win against the home team. Not so for McBurney, the team without a field.

title: Schmidt Now an Elder Statesman
description: Until the moment of his defeat in the Bundestag last month, Helmut Schmidt fought to remain Chancellor of West Germany, daring his opponents to match his popularity in elections. But the defeat seems to have taken something out of him: Last week, he announced he would no longer be the Social Democratic Party's candidate for chancellor in elections scheduled for March.

title: CALIFORNIA CONSERVATIONISTS PRESS NEW EFFORT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30(AP) When the first settlers crossed the High Sierra into California, they found a sea of grass covering almost 23 million acres. Today only 10,000 of those acres remain unchanged.

title: Florida 19, Auburn 17
description: Jim Gainey's 42-yard field goal with one second left to play, his fourth of the game and second in the final three minutes, lifted Florida to a dramatic victory in the Southeastern Conference game.

title: BAYSIDE WINS BY 34-0 TO GAIN PLAYOFF SPOT
description: Bayside, the P.S.A.L. champions for the last three seasons, squeaked into this year's playoffs by scoring all of its points after intermission in a 34-0 victory over Beach Channel in a decisive Queens A division game.

title: Swiss Hand Over Banker Tied to Scandal in Italy
description: An Italian financier wanted in Italy in connection with the Ambrosiano Bank scandal was turned over by the Swiss police to Italian authorities today at a frontier post near here, the police said.

title: CONGRESS CONTESTS MAKE G.O.P. WARY
description: Last summer, Republican strategists believed that even if Democrats won some of the 13 new Congressional seats in the South and Southwest they would be conservatives like the Democrats who had been supporting President Reagan.

title: Maria Regina Clinches Title
description: Maria Regina routed Fordham Prep, 35-16, yesterday to clinch the Division II championship of the Catholic High Schools League with a 6-0 record.

title: Fayre McDonnell Will Become Bride Of William Atchley Mynatt Jr. Dec. 11
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James F. McDonnell Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Southampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Louise Fayre McDonnell, to William Atchley Mynatt Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Mynatt of Asheville, N.C.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN 1975, planners proposed linking the Wanaque Reservoir in Passaic County with the Oradell Reservoir in Bergen County to correct deficiencies in the supplies of the Hackensack Water Company and the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission, which serves many Northern New Jersey communities.

title: Ellen Turton Engaged To Stephen E. Porter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Turton of Orlando, Fla., formerly of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Eugenia Turton, to Stephen Earle Porter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Eugene Porter of Westport, Conn. The wedding is planned for May.

title: A SCULPTOR COMES INTO HER OWN
description: Although Louise Bourgeois has been a respected, if not revered figure in the New York art world since her first one-person show in 1945, widespread interest in her work is relatively recent. Partly because of her discretion and aversion to self-promotion, partly because she has been carried along by her own current, outside the mainstream of modernism, she has had no one-person museum show and she has not been the subject of a major publication.

title: 2 Held in Attack in Thailand
description: An army sergeant and a civilian have been arrested in northeast Thailand on suspicion of being involved in last July's assassination attempt on Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, an army spokesman said today. The spokesman said army authorities were interrogating the two men to determine if they were responsible for the rocket-propelled grenade attack on General Prem's motorcade.

title: NIXON ADMIRER COLLECTS FOR FUN
description: NEWTOWN WEARING her Richard Nixon bracelet with the elephant charm, Marianne Kopko waited to catch a glimpse of the Presidential candidate at a campaign stop in Bridgeport. Triumphant, the fifth grader returned to school that afternoon with confetti in her hair and the news that ''I waved at Nixon and I touched his limousine when it went by.''

title: PAIN RELIEVERS FOR TUITION HEADACHES
description: Beloit College in Wisconsin is running newspaper advertisements showing a serious-minded gentleman with angular features and a black top hat. Underneath the picture are the words ''We're looking for another D.K. Pearsons.''

title: PAKISTAN'S LEADER TO CONFER IN INDIA
description: On Monday, for the first time in a decade, the leaders of India and Pakistan are to sit down and begin talking about how to bring lasting peace between their countries.

title: Holy Cross 34, Boston U. 21
description: BOSTON (AP) - Peter Muldoon scored one touchdown and passed for another in the first half for Holy Cross (7-1). Mark Covington plunged for two touchdowns, Andy Clivio carried 25 times for 116 yards, and Tony Melink kicked field goals from 34 and 30 yards. Holy Cross built a 34-7 lead against the Terriers (4-3), who lost only the third time in 22 home games since 1978.

title: No Headline
description: Harvard Gets 6 Interceptions, Wins, 34-0

title: Sports of The Times; The Return of Mike Gminski
description: WHEN he was hospitalized with a staph infection in his spine 14 months ago, the doctors didn't tell him that they feared he might die. But even if they had, Mike Gminski would not have understood what they were talking about.

title: SOMETHING FROM THE GOOD OLD DAYS
description: AS a child, she loved to ride in the car along the roads of New York's Columbia County. It was on these roads, in the 1930's and 40's that Francene Flesch would peer through the windows of her father's Ford in search of the signs for Burma-Shave.

title: YEMEN ACTS TO STEM THE TRADE IN RHINO HORNS
description: In what may be a significant reprieve for the endangered African rhinoceros, a total ban on imports of their horns has been decreed by Yemen, the world's single biggest market for the poacher-supplied item.

title: Francis Xavier Lynn Weds Antonetta Lisa Marando
description: Antonetta Lisa Marando, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore G. Marando of Crystal River, Fla., formerly of Commack, L.I., was married yesterday to Francis Xavier Lynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lynn of Kings Park, L.I. The Rev. Salvatore Greco performed the ceremony at the Smithtown (L.I.) Gospel Tabernacle.

title: MOTORIST IN BROOKLYN IS SHOT BY A GUNMAN FIRING FROM BUILDING
description: A gunman shooting from a 17-story apartment building in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn wounded a passing motorist yesterday, the police said.

title: NETS BEATEN BY 76ERS, 110-99
description: It was billed as the first confrontation between Moses Malone of the Philadelphia 76ers and the Nets' Darryl Dawkins since the two young, controversial centers changed teams this season. But in the end, the 76ers' 110-99 victory tonight before a sellout crowd of 18,482 in their home opener at the Spectrum was much more than that.

title: CALCULATED DOSES OF SHOCK
description: THE ORCHIDS By Thomas H. Cook. 264 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95.

title: PROBLEMS BESET UNICEF DRIVE
description: TONIGHT is Halloween, and in most Westchester communities diminutive witches, tramps, and perhaps this year some extraterrestrial creatures will be roaming the streets. However, far fewer children will be trick-or-treating than in years past, and even fewer will be carrying the once-familiar orange cardboard cartons to trickor-treat for Unicef. If you live in Tarrytown, Bronxville, the city of Rye, Larchmont, Pleasantville or Hastings-on-Hudson, for instance, have your pennies handy; but in Scarsdale, Chappaqua, Armonk, and most of the more densely populated urban areas, with the notable exception of White Plains, chances are that Unicef will pass you by.

title: Darlene Ann Bossen Wed To Steven Roy Danielsen
description: Darlene Ann Bossen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Bossen of Massapequa, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Roy Danielsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Danielsen of Harvard, Mass. The Rev. Paul O. Lutze performed the ceremony at Our Redeemer Lutheran Church in Seaford, L.I.

title: DESIGN
description: In this Paris apartment for the peripatetic fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld, the French interior designer Andree Putman explores the high-tech mode. Right: No-nonsense furnishings contrast with the ceiling's thick patisserie. Top left: A stereo dominates the mantel. Below: In the bedroom, bookstacks on wheels and movers' quilts are strictly functional.

title: VARSITY THE LOSER IN BOARD SCRIMMAGE
description: STAMFORD SINCE it will close down next June, only 22 years after it opened, Rippowam High School has not survived long enough to establish a football tradition as rich, for example, as one of its two intracity rivals, Stamford High. Still, Rippowam, despite its relatively small male enrollment, has known its moments of glory on the gridiron.

title: IN HAWAII, POI IS THE STAFF OF LIFE
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Hawaii.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: YES
description: It is becoming increasingly clear that a mutual, verifiable nuclear freeze is the essential first step in any effort to break the chronic upward spiral of nuclear arms.

title: AN AMERICAN EXHIBITION DISPLAYS JAPAN'S FLORAL ART
description: The Japanese have a way with chrysanthemums and the The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is showing how. ''Kiku-Ka Ten'' or chrysanthemum flower exhibit, which opened last week in The Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, is a magnificent example of their horticultural art.

title: No Headline
description: Canadiens Gain Tie

title: Anne Balcer Is Married
description: Anne Elaine Balcer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Balcer of Ottawa and Barkmere, Quebec, was married yesterday in New York to Gavin Angus Macrae-Gibson, son of Jeanette Espeja-Valencia of Barcelona and Dr. Neil K. Macrae-Gibson of Bromley, Kent, England. The Rev. David A. Garcia performed the ceremony at St. Mark's-in-the-Bowery Episcopal Church.

title: WOMEN GET ADVICE ON REPULSING AN ATTACKER
description: THE woman was walking home from a neighborhood store one evening when a man approached her from behind and suddenly gripped her elbow with a force that broke the skin and sent an arrow of pain coursing through her arm from shoulder to wrist.

title: CLAIRE FERGUSON PLANS WEDDING
description: Clarence Clyde Ferguson of Boston has announced the engagement of his daughter, Claire Oberon Ferguson, to Joseph Anthony Garcia, son of Col. John A. Garcia, U.S.A, retired, and Mrs. Garcia of Alexandria, Va.

title: Bishop Named for Kentucky
description: The Rev. John J. McRaith, vicar general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of New Ulm, Minn., has been named by Pope John Paul II as the new Bishop of the Owensboro Diocese. The 47-year-old vicar general will replace Bishop Henry J. Soenneker, 75, who is retiring after 21 years as Bishop of the Owensboro Diocese, which covers 32 counties in western Kentucky.

title: GREENWICH 20-6 VICTOR
description: Greenwich and Stamford Catholic registered important Fairfield County Conference Western Division victories, setting the stage for their showdown next Saturday.

title: IS MALE INSTINCT TAKING US TO THE EDGE?
description: ICARUS became so obsessed with the power of his newly invented wings that, despite his father's warning, he flew too close to the sun. The wax that held his wings together melted and he fell to his death in the Icarian Sea, according to Greek mythology.

title: Devils Tower
description: To the Editor: In ''The Spell of Devils Tower'' (Travel, Aug. 29), Kay Eldredge was incorrect in stating that the Devils Tower is composed of granite. The rock is actually phonolite porphyry.

title: PROPOSITIONS FACE ISLAND'S VOTERS
description: WHEN Nassau County voters enter the voting booth on Tuesday, there will be one proposition on the ballot, along with the names of candidates for Federal, State and local office. In Suffolk County, there may be two, one or none.

title: PENN STATE CRUSHES BOSTON COLLEGE, 52-17
description: The yards and the touchdowns came easily today for Curt Warner and Todd Blackledge, Penn State's celebrated running back and quarterback. Warner scored three touchdowns and ran for 183 yards, and Blackledge passed for three touchdowns and 243 yards as the Nittany Lions trounced Boston College, 52-17, at Alumni Stadium for their seventh victory in eight games this season.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Jim Dow's panoramic photographs prove that however little art and baseball have in common, they are not mutually exclusive. Dow has photographed every major-league baseball stadium in the country - all 26, from the Angels' Anaheim Stadium to the house that Ruth built - and the results are spectacular.

title: Princeton Upsets Penn on Late Kick
description: Chris Price kicked a 42-yard field goal that barely cleared the crossbar with 25 seconds remaining to give Princeton a 17-14 upset of Pennsylvania today before a crowd of 20,249 at Palmer Stadium.

title: Making a Case for Fitness
description: To the Sports Editor: In his article ''Running for Fitness is Fine, but More Must Be Done,'' (The New York Times, Oct. 24, 1982) Col. James L. Anderson missed the point of road racing and contributed to the maze of obstacles we as health-care professionals have put in the way of people doing what comes naturally, moving.

title: 18 Whales Die in England
description: British fishermen said 18 whales died after being stranded on a sand bar at the mouth of the Haven River near this city on England's east coast. The fishermen said they found more than 20 whales on the sand bar and that most of them died when the receding tide grounded them. They said the whales were probably searching for food at the mouth of the river.

title: Future Events Fall Fabrics
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Role Models Nov. 3 - Mary F. Rockefeller, the philanthropist, and Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, will be honored as New York's outstanding women of 1982 at the annual ''Salute to Women Achievers'' luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York. At the event in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom the honorees will receive the Elizabeth Cutter Morrow Award, named for the longtime Y.W.C.A. board member and Smith College trustee, who was no mean achiever herself. Mrs. Morrow, a poet, was the wife of Dwight W. Morrow, United States Senator and Ambassador to Mexico, and mother of Anne Morrow Lindbergh. The 1982 award will be in the form of a gold medallion designed and crafted by Norma Zotos, who teaches at the Y.W.C.A. Craft Students League. Tickets to luncheon, a benefit for the Y.W.C.A., $150.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of Oct.17 incorrectly identified the ship that salvaged part of a Russian submarine from the Pacific Ocean floor in 1975. It was the Glomar Explorer.

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: If one is lucky enough to survive an ordeal such as Nan Robertson's, certain emotions (like impatience and bitterness) can inhibit the recovery period during a long rehabilitative process. Nan Robertson is a remarkable woman who refuses to dwell on negative energies. More patients should demonstrate her great determination, patience and stamina. JANET MOLLO, R.N. North Providence, R.I. ------

title: Map; ASSEMBLY RACE IN THE NEW 18TH WATCHED FOR MANY REASONS
description: PERHAPS more than in any other election race on Long Island this year, there is a special sense of history among the three candidates in the oddly shaped territory that has been marked off under reapportionment as the new 18th Assembly District in Nassau County.

title: JOB CUTS CAUSE LOSS OF HEALTH COVERAGE FOR OVER 16 MILLION
description: More than 16 million Americans have lost health insurance coverage as a result of unemployment, and many appear to be deferring necessary medical care, according to health officials.

title: Quake in North Vietnam
description: A strong earthquake shook a region near Vietnam's northern frontier with China, the Vietnam News Agency reported today. The agency said the quake struck Wednesday and registered 6.6 on the Richter scale, setting off tremors that were felt in most parts of northern Vietnam. It gave no reports of damage or casualties.

title: Violence, With A Vengeance, Strikes Ulster
description: The election of an Assembly in Northern Ireland 10 days ago was supposed to establish the beginnings of political order. Instead, what the chief of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Sir Jack Hermon, called ''debased tribalism'' was once again governing relations between the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority.

title: Protest Over Dailey
description: About 25 pickets were outside Chicago Stadium last night to protest the presence of Quintin Dailey, the Bulls' rookie guard, who has pleaded guilty to assaulting a student nurse at the University of San Francisco, where he was an all-American. Nettie Sabin, a spokesman for the group, said, ''We're here because we want to let everyone know we don't accept him as a role model for anyone.''

title: ACTIVISTS TAKING NEW POLITICAL ROLES
description: Grass-roots activist groups that promote the causes of consumers, poor people, environmentalists and women are working this year for the first time in behalf of candidates for national, state and local office.

title: India
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME FOR A NEW PARTY
description: We are continually urged by political commentators not to undermine the two-party system. But do we really have a two-party system anymore? Or are we fast approaching a zeroparty system?

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: Certainly, being able to type the toxic-shock-syndrome article was a victory - but the real news is that Nan Robertson is back - as good as ever. WAYNE L. TYSON Stamford, Conn.

title: AUTHOR OF 'BLOOD AND MONEY'
description: Tommy Thompson, author of ''Blood and Money,'' 'Celebrity'' and other books, died of liver cancer Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 49 years old.

title: BOTH PARTIES VIEW ELECTION AS A TEST OF REAGAN POLICIES
description: Republican and Democratic leaders pressed their conflicting arguments on unemployment and Social Security yesterday in preparation for an election that the White House regards as a referendum on President Reagan's economic policies.

title: HE RECALLS HUNGARY'S RESTLESS YOUNG
description: Annette Insdorf is the author of the forthcoming ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: A NEW LOOK FOR 'DANIEL'
description: Janet Tassel writes frequently about the arts.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN A VISA IS REQUIRED
description: For American tourists traveling to dozens of foreign countries, the advance work does not end with a valid passport, an airline ticket and a hotel reservation. In many of these countries, under widely varying circumstances, it is also necessary to get a visa beforehand - and the lack of one could mean being turned away at the border.

title: U.S. MIDEAST ENVOY REPORTS PROGRESS
description: Morris Draper, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, today reported the first progress in the preliminary negotiations aimed at bringing about the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: Football Player Dies After Leaving Game
description: Travis Kelly, the punter for North Carolina A.& T., was helped off the field today after complaining of a severe headache, and later died in a hospital.

title: JAZZ-ROCK: EVERYMAN BAND
description: The Everyman Band, which played Thursday at the Bottom Line, is a derivative jazz-rock quartet saved by its choice of influences. It usually mimics Ornette Coleman's Prime Time, the Pat Metheny Group or Weather Report, which means it plays bop-to-funk grooves that can turn polytonal.

title: Perry 'Proves' a Point
description: Gaylord Perry says he finally has ''proof'' that he was not throwing a ''doctored'' pitch when ejected in Seattle last Aug. 23 by Umpire Dave Phillips. The 43-year-old hurler, who has admitted in a book that he often used foreign substances on the ball, was interviewed on a syndicated television program, ''Lie Detector.''

title: AN UGLY CAMPAIGN
description: This ugly midterm campaign of charge and countercharge, distortion and demagoguery has appropriately come to a climax among Halloween's spooks, goblins and witches.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ALL kinds of committees spring up at election time to promote one candidate or another only to disappear when the last vote is counted. The committees have all kinds of names that will, it is hoped, arouse voters to pay attention.

title: Red Cross Names President
description: Richard F. Schubert, the former president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, has been named president of the American Red Cross.

title: WHAT SET THE MIND OF THE SOUTH THINKING?
description: THE WAR WITHIN From Victorian to Modernist Thought in the South, 1919-1945. By Daniel Joseph Singal. Illustrated. 453 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press.Cloth, $27. Paper, $12.

title: STAMP SHOWING MARTIN LUTHER IS APPROVED BY POSTAL SERVICE
description: Postmaster General William Bolger has approved a stamp honoring Martin Luther, the founder of the Lutheran Church and a father of the Protestant movement, according to a Postal Service spokesman.

title: LEADING INDICATORS RISE IN SEPTEMBER
description: Leading economic indicators rose five-tenths of 1 percent in September. The reversal from the August decline of two-tenths of 1 percent was led by a sharp surge in stock prices. The gain in the index, the last key economic gauge to be released before Tuesday's elections, was welcomed by the Administration whose economic policies are an issue in the elections.

title: INDIA
description: To the Editor: Since Leh, Ladakh, is my favorite town in India, I was very pleased to see it mentioned in Michael T. Kaufman's article. It is still very Tibetan Buddhist in culture, much more so than Tibet itself since the Chinese occupation. Anyone planning to go there should have a little more information before starting out. Flights into Leh were increased to three a week last summer, but reservations should be made well ahead and weather conditions make for frequent cancellations.

title: Nuclear Point
description: To the Business Editor: I'm glad you finally got there, but why did it take you until the last two paragraphs of ''Nuclear Plants Plagued by Costly Equipment Breakdowns'' (Oct.10), to reach the point?

title: Military Analysis
description: Western intelligence sources say Iraq's use of surface-to-surface missiles Wednesday to strike at a town 60 miles inside Iran may signal the opening of a new strategy.

title: HONG KONG RACES AHEAD DESPITE UNCERTAINTY
description: The recent wave of economic uncertainty that swept this colony has been attributed partly to the question of whether the New Territories will remain British after Britain's 99-year lease expires in 1997.

title: STUDENTS FOCUSING ON SKILLS
description: ENROLLMENTS at community colleges and two-year technical institutions throughout the state are climbing, according to the Connecticut Board of Higher Education.

title: FAIR PUTS UNION SQUARE PARK BACK ON ITS SOAPBOX FOR A DAY
description: Once host to political rallies and strolling families, now the home of street vendors and drug dealers, Union Square Park returned to its past for a few hours yesterday.

title: KEAN LINK TO UTILITIES DENIED
description: TRENTON IN TESTIMONY given here last week, the state's Public Advocate declared that Governor Kean ''was not in bed with the utilities'' with respect to the highly criticized cost-containment agreement that is designed to control the expense of finishing the controversial Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant in Salem County.

title: AUTUMN LESSONS; Competition Eating
description: Until recently the world was divided into those who eat to live and those who live to eat. But about 10 years ago the United States spawned another species of feeder: the competitive mouth.

title: Research Through Deception
description: Morton Hunt's article ''Research Through Deception'' (Sept. 12) perpetuates two common misunderstandings about deceptive research: that emotionally engaging work on important issues requires deception, and that deception permits us to study things one otherwise could not. On the first point, dramatic studies do not require deception. Prof. Philip Zimbardo's prison simulation, cited in the article, is not an instance of deceptive research. What minor deceptions it employed were unimportant to the study, and easily dispensable. Zimbardo's ''guards'' and ''prisoners'' were volunteers who knew what they were agreeing to, at least as much as Zimbardo did. They were the experimenter's partners, not his dupes.

title: WORKERS UNEARTH OLD COINS
description: A backhoe hauled up a hoard of pre-Civil War gold and silver coins from a construction site, and welldressed bank employees and bystanders rushed into foul-smelling clay muck to grub for money.

title: OFficialdom Pays In Panther Case
description: Chicago police said that when they stormed an apartment in search of armed Black Panthers 12 years ago, a shoot-out ensued. Survivors of the raid - two Panther leaders were killed; four of seven others were wounded - said it was more like a shoot-in, and sued.

title: TEXAS TO ALLOW REFERENCES TO V.D. IN TEXTBOOKS
description: Raymon Bynum, the State Commissioner of Education, ruled Friday that textbook publishers may include references to venereal diseases, despite a staff recommendation to delete them.

title: ROUSSELOT IN TIGHT RACE FOR NEW SEAT
description: Can a southern California conservative from the right wing of the Republican Party find true happiness in a Congressional district that has a majority of Democrats and Hispanic residents? And, in the process, can he defeat a Democratic, Hispanic rival?

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Tadd Dameron was one of that small number of jazz composers who wrote a significant repertory of compositions that have become standards. But unlike others in that group - Jelly Roll Morton, Duke Ellington, Charles Mingus, Thelonius Monk - Mr. Dameron, a pianist, was not a distinctive performer and he never reached the acclaim or fame of Mr. Morton, Mr. Ellington, Mr. Mingus or Mr. Monk.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Barry, coach of the San Francisco basketball team when the university dropped the sport during the summer, will serve as baseball coach at El Camino High School in San Francisco. ... Jimmy Connors and Bjorn Borg will play in a $100,000 match Nov. 21 at the San Francisco Civic Center, with the winner reportedly receiving $75,000. Borg is preparing to return to the Grand Prix circuit next year. ... Brad Shearer, the defensive tackle who won the Outland Trophy as the nation's outstanding lineman while at Texas in 1977, has sued the Chicago Bears in Federal court in Austin, Tex.

title: Bugging Trains
description: When a Long Island Rail Road crew discovered two hidden voiceactivated tape recorders aboard its train in December 1981, the railroad defended the bugging as legal, the United Transportation Union called it ''Gestapo tactics'' and illegal, and the Nassau County District Attorney's office said it was investigating what might be a felony.

title: Socialists Win Most Greek Cities
description: After a year in power at the national level, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and the Socialists were a little worried after a first round of municipal elections two weeks ago indicated erosion in their popular support. But with some help from the Communists, the Socialists came through in the second round last week to win 173 out of 276 mayoral posts in the big cities and towns. Socialists were also believed to have won a majority of 6,000 small communities.

title: No Headline
description: S.M.U. VICTOR BY 47-9

title: 7-CENT INCREASE BEING SOUGHT FOR DIAL-IT SERVICES
description: The amount New Yorkers pay to dial ''976'' numbers for time, temperature, race results and other recorded announcements would rise from 9 cents to 16 cents on Jan. 1 under a rate increase being sought by the New York Telephone Company.

title: 100 Nigeria Policemen Said to Be Riot Victims
description: The official Nigerian press agency reported today that about 100 police officers were apparently among more than 300 people killed or captured in four days of fighting with Moslem militants 750 miles northeast of here.

title: Pearl S. Buck
description: To the Editor:

title: PERVASIVE USE OF COCAINE IS REPORTED IN HOLLYWOOD
description: The use of illicit drugs in Hollywood has become so pervasive that companies that insure movies have begun to amend their policies to reflect drug-related risks, and some people in the entertainment industry maintain that drug abuse is affecting the content and quality of films and television programs produced here.

title: MORGAN EXCELS FOR BERGEN CATHOLIC
description: Mike Morgan, a junior tailback, ran for four touchdowns yesterday to increase his season total to a state-leading 108 points as he led Bergen Catholic to a 41-0 defeat of Fair Lawn in Oradell.

title: A HUMORIST WHO CELEBRATES SMALL TOWN AMERICA
description: ST. PAUL It was Saturday afternoon, several hours before ''A Prairie Home Companion'' was to go on the air, and Garrison Keillor was lounging with an Oakland A's cap pulled low over his forehead and thinking out loud about waterbeds for cats.

title: PLAYERS WILL MEET
description: A new strategy by the players' union to end the six-week-old National Football League strike might be worked out today when the 28 teams' player representatives meet in New York, where talks between management and the union resumed yesterday after a one-week layoff.

title: GUIDE PRAISES THE STATE
description: HARTFORD ''WHEN I first moved to Connecticut, I thought it was some kind of feudal principality, ruled by insurance companies.'' But Michael J. Boyle got over this first impression, he said, and eight years later he is singing the state's praises in a new Connecticut Guidebook which he calls ''a sort of Farmer's Almanac, travel guide, cookbook and garden book rolled into one.''

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: Asbestos Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: INTELLIGENCE AT WORK
description: TERRORISTS AND NOVELISTS By Diane Johnson. 257 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.50.

title: TERMITE GAS EXCEEDS SMOKESTACK POLLUTION
description: For several years scientists have been warning that carbon dioxide added to the atmosphere by increased burning of fuel is likely to alter world climates, like a greenhouse, by inhibiting the escape of heat into outer space.

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: Not only did Nan Robertson demonstrate how much of the capacity to conquer the impossible there is in her, but she gave millions the reassurance that there are still, in the medical profession and in the healing services, people who combine the ultimate in knowledge with concern and compassion and who identify with those entrusted to their care. ABE RASKIN New York City ------

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: What is so important is that Nan Robertson has done a real service in educating the American public to the symptoms of toxic shock and to the high risk involved in the use of tampons.

title:
STAMPS;
13-CENT HOLIDAY ISSUE
description: Recognizing the fact that for many Americans every penny counts, this Wednesday the United States is putting out a special 13-cent stamp for use on Christmas postcards, which have become increasingly popular in the last few years.

title: Off the Air
description: Music lovers in Gloucester, Mass. were relieved to learn that they would continue to get classical music from FM broadcasts. The sad news for many was that the music would no longer be provided by WVCA-FM and Simon Geller.

title: HALLOWEEN AT YALE
description: Halloween, originally the druidic New Year's Eve, will be observed by the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History from 1 to 4:45 P.M. today. ''Before the spread of Christianity the Celts celebrated New Year's Day on Nov. 1, coinciding with the seasonal harvest,'' a spokesman for the museum said.

title: Audrey Walker Is Married to Peter G. MacDonald
description: Audrey Merwin Walker and Peter Grant MacDonald were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. by the Rev. Craig W. Casey.

title: NORTH EDISON ROLLS TO 29-13 VICTORY
description: Marc Mofsowitz, a senior running back, carried 22 times for 177 yards and scored three touchdowns to guide North Edison past East Brunswick, 29-13, yesterday in East Brunswick.

title: ROCK: ROBBIE KRIEGER QUINTET
description: Robbie Krieger, the erstwhile guitarist of the Doors, has been involved in a number of musical projects over the last decade, including the formation of one of the first American reggae bands. Now Mr. Krieger has put together a purely instrumental rock band that includes the drummer Bruce Gary and the guitarist Berton Averre, both refugees from the Knack, the Los Angeles-based ''power pop'' band that experienced a meteoric rise and fall.

title: International
description: Labor union protests in West Ger- many continue 3 New violence and old grudges plague Ulster 3 Ohio concern buys option to buy De Lorean plant in Ulster 3 American minister gets high post in Anglican Communion 5 Around the World 7 The future of Hong Kong's New Territories remains uncertain 8 Greek publisher's Soviet ties spur criticism 10 Leaders of India and Pakistan to meet tomorrow 11 Egypt remains in touch with Arab world 16 Government/Politics F.A.A. raises age limit for new air controllers 30 Grassroots activists taking new electoral roles 36 Reagan and Kennedy air conflict- ing views 37 Congress races in South and Southwest worrying G.O.P. 38 California conservative is in tight race for new seat 38 Despite bulging coffers, Texas Governor is in close contest 38 ''Sacrificial lamb'' giving Sena- tor Wallop a battle in Wyoming 38 Administration is assailed by groups on worker protection 39 Connecticut voters to elect Sena- tor and Governor 40 Race for U.S. Senate highlights Jersey elections 40 General Around the Nation 26 Defendant in judge's killing pic- tured as ambivalent assassin 27 Orlando idea for rail system wins U.S. grant 31 Two shipwreck survivors rescued by Soviet ship in Atlantic 32 Brink's pretrial hearings end first phase 34 Off-duty police officer slain in Brooklyn 44 Fear still prevalent over con- taminated candy on Halloween 45 Health/Science Pottery shard may indicate an earlier Maya civilization 42 Arts/Entertainment Takacs Quartet, Hungarian chamber ensemble, in recital 72 Music debuts in review 75 Donizetti's ''Il Duca d'Alba'' is played 77 Style Judge Dembitz's life in Family Court 78 The pain of changing schools 78 Obituaries Tommy Thompson, author of ''Blood and Money'' 44 News Analysis Drew Middleton assesses Iraqi- Iranian war situation 6

title: AN OLD STRATFORD-ON-AVON FAMILY
description: ZANE HICKCOX KOTKER is a writer who lives in Massachusetts.

title: Nora Immerso Married
description: Nora Immerso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Immerso of Hicksville, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Joseph Hildreth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hildreth of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Michael Flynn performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church.

title: Mary Pendergast Is Wed in Capital To David Vladeck
description: Mary Katherine Pendergast, associate chief counsel for enforcement, Food and Drug Administration, in Rockville, Md., and David Charney Vladeck, a staff lawyer with the Public Citizen Litigation Group in Washington, were married there yesterday at the couple's home. The Rev. Francis Moan, a Roman Catholic priest and Rabbi Harold White, both of Georgetown University, officiated.

title: IS THE GULF BETWEEN 'POP' AND 'SERIOUS' DIMINISHING?
description: There is a disturbing rift in the world of music. That is the gulf between the popular and the elite - between so-called ''serious'' art music on the one hand and jazz and rock on the other. There is always such a range, in any art form, and the distance everywhere between the extremes is wide. But music seems more polarized now than the other arts. Fortunately, there are a few signs that the gulf may be narrowing.

title: T.J. Flournoy Is Dead at 77; Inspired Musical on Bordello
description: Former Sheriff T.J. Flournoy, who fought efforts to close the brothel that inspired the hit musical ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' died Wednesday at his home here. He was 77 years old and had a long history of heart problems.

title: INVESTORS' CONCERN RISES OVER POLICY ON VALUATIONS
description: AWEST SIDE investor bought a Broadway apartment house with g roundfloor stores a few months ago against the advice of his lawyer. The lawyer warned him that the assessed valuation would triple if h e paid the price he had agreed to. He warned that the assessment w ould give no consideration to the terms of the sale - how much in c ash and how much in loans - or to the current assessment of c omparable properties nearby.

title: ONE BILLION AND GROWING
description: China has as many head counters as some nations have heads to count - 5.1 million, to be exact. But they were all needed to complete the country's first census in 18 years.

title: GOOD VALUE, ESPECIALLY THURSDAYS
description: NEW MILFORD THE restaurant at 31 Bank Street, which takes its name from its address, is in a building that formerly housed a funeral parlor and a furniture store. In its current metamorphosis, the orange-red brick turn-of-century building has been impeccably restored.

title: STASTNYS AND NORDIQUES TOP RANGERS, 5-4
description: The Rangers rallied but could not catch up to Quebec and the Stastny brothers tonight. The Nordiques wound up with a 5-4 victory, handing the Rangers their fourth loss in five road games this season.

title: RESEARCH THROUGH DECEPTION
description: The vast majority of human psychological research does not involve deception. In some cases, this research is hurt by a subject's expectations of deception due to past experience with deceptive experiments.

title: GENERATIONS OF HORRIBLE FUN
description: GEORGE MILLS By Stanley Elkin. 508 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: Headliners; Poet's Ordeal
description: Freedom is sweet though not without scars for Armando Valladares, who has just arrived in Paris from Havana where he spent 22 years in prison.

title: POP AND JAZZ: FRAN WARREN, JOE CABOT
