description: Fran Warren gets the top billing at Michael's Pub, where she will be singing until Nov. 13, but her act is really a close collaboration between her and Joe Cabot, her musical director for many years.

title: 402 CANDIDATES RUNNING HARD
description: HARTFORD CALL it a sign of the times: there are just 208 Federal and state jobs available, but 402 candidates have spent the last few weeks running hard to land them. The employment decisions will be made on Tuesday, when more than a million Connecticut voters are expected to go to the polls.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Spain is experiencing a renewal with what is at times the uncertainty of an adolescent taking his place in society at large. There are inflamed attitudes, and unfortunately violence and demagogy are not absent among us.'' - Archbishop Gabino Diaz Merchan, president of the Spanish Episcopal Conference. . (12:4.)

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1982
description: International Opportunities for Middle East peace are regarded by Reagan Administration officials as unparalleled in the short run in the aftermath of the war in Lebanon. But they fear that in the long run new power realities are tugging toward impasse. The Administration's strategy is to convince Arab moderates and Palestinian leaders that it is ''either now or almost never'' - either recognize Israel and give King Hussein of Jordan the green light to negotiate over the West Bank and Gaza, or face the prospect of de facto incorporation of these territories into Israel. (Page 1, Columns 1-2.)

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Commemorative Stamp Series is big business for the United States Postal Service - net revenue $99 million last year -and also for several Connecticut artists who have designed one or more of the stamps, which note important people, places and events of cultural, social and historical significance.

title: NOTRE DAME PASSES DOWN NAVY, 27-10
description: Notre Dame's offense had more spark today than it had displayed in the last six weeks as Blair Kiel threw his first two touchdown passes of the season on the way to a 27-10 victory over Navy at Giants Stadium.

title: ARTS GROUPS, BUOYED, ACT TO UNIFY
description: FLUSHED with the success of an exhibition that attracted unprecedented crowds during the Nassau County Celebration of the Arts, the county's 16 art organizations are finding a surge of interest in forming a united body.

title: BUSINESSES 'ADOPT' A SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: SMITHVILLE THREE years ago, at a conference in Atlanta, Dr. Philip E.Geiger, the Galloway Township Superintendent of Schools, heard a Battle Creek, Mich., school administrator explain how the Kellogg Corporation had adopted one of Battle Creek's schools.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: My dog has Halloween. She barks all week, rising to a frenzied crescendo on the night itself. She caroms about the house, hackles abristle, hurling herself at the doors and windows. Even in her sleep she moans, growls and whines.

title: Surviving Toxic Shock
description: It was Sunday evening. I was sitting alone. My world was in order. I picked up The New York Times Magazine and did not put it down until I had finished every word of Nan Robertson's article (''Toxic Shock,'' Sept. 19).

title: PRESIDENT AND KENNEDY AIR CONFLICTING VIEWS
description: President Reagan, expressing ''sorrow for those bearing the burden of unemployment,'' argued today in his final radio address before Election Day that his economic policies were working and deserved ''more than the 13-month trial they've been given.''

title: AS DARKNESS DESCENDS, WRAITHS ARISE
description: PLEASE do not read this story yet. Today is Halloween and the tales that follow are best read later, when the night's black mantle has descended. They tell of an earlier time, when the county was young. The stories are available to all who would wearily wander among the quaint and curious volumes of forgotten lore. Each time, they appear in a slightly different fashion, but their essence, their spirit, remains. The world today has largely let them slip away and perhaps that is for the best, because they are merely folklore, bits of irrelevant local superstition. Or are they? Consider first, if you will, the bloody story of the village of Nanichiestawack.

title:
PERSONALLY SPEAKING;
SPIRIT HAS VANISHED FROM HALLOWEEN
description: AT the risk of sounding like a monster, I have to say that Halloween has become about as much fun as having the Avon lady calling. No sneakiness, no tricks, no imagination and certainly no spooks.

title: Katharine Lewis Bride Of John K. Bouckley
description: Katharine Elizabeth Lewis, daughter of Mrs. John Baer Lewis of Manasquan, N.J., and the late Mr. Lewis, was married yesterday to John Kenneth Bouckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth G. Bouckley of Walton-on-Thames, England. The Rev. Ralph Barret performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Manasquan.

title: WHY DON'T PEOPLE VOTE ANYMORE?
description: I'VE always made a point of voting, even in the primaries, but somehow this September the motivation was especially hard to come by. Finally, a few minutes before the polls closed, my conscience got the better of me and I headed down to the firehouse to cast my ballot.

title: Big College Game In August Backed
description: A proposal for a football game in August between major colleges that would probably be played in Giants Stadium for the first three years has received support from more than a half dozen colleges. Those colleges have endorsed a change in National Collegiate Athletic Association rules to allow such a game.

title: 180,000 PROTEST AGAINST KOHL POLICIES
description: More than 180,000 West Germans took to the streets today in a renewal of trade union protest against unemployment and reductions in social benefits.

title: BUYING HOMES FOR STUDENTS
description: SOME parents who are trying to cut college costs have found that it m akes economic sense to buy their son or daughter an off-campus h ouse, cooperative or condominium.

title: OSBORN DRAWINGS ON WAR AT STORRS
description: ad hominem and collective. The first, if political and scurrilous enough, is more likely to fell its perpetrator than its target; the second generally is guaranteed to make the audience feel superior, since it is obviously about somebody else. More safety valve than catalyst, satire, nevertheless, is viewed as one of democracy's most valuable tools and Robert Osborn is one of the more vociferous exponents of the collective type.

title: NASSAU COLLEGE AND THE FUTURE
description: Garden City Sean A. Fanelli has been the president of Nassau Community College for the last seven weeks. In that time the college's academic reputation has been called into question by the association that accredits major colleges and universities, and the union representing 750 part-time faculty members has staged an eight-day strike.

title: CHAMBER: THE TAKACS QUARTET
description: The Takacs Quartet, a young string ensemble from Hungary, is playing its first concerts in the United States this fall, and Friday evening it paid a visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The program was a beautiful blending of the unusual and the substantial, with quartets by Haydn and Beethoven, Webern's Six Bagatelles and the Bartok Second String Quartet.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
NATURE'S WAY
description: Just because the frost is on the pumpkin there's no reason to stay close to hearth and home; autumn is still with us and opportunities abound to take to the outdoors to see what Mother Nature has wrought. For example, at 1 P.M. every Sunday and Saturday through Dec. 5, the naturalists at Nissequogue River State Park in Smithtown are hosts to two-hour ''Autumn Nature Walks,'' as well as special lecture programs at 10 A.M. Today's is devoted to ''Plants of Nissequogue,'' while Saturday's delves into ''Pond and Stream Life.'' The walks and lectures cost $1 each, with children under 12 admitted free, and reservations must be made by calling 265-1054.

title: CORNELL REPLACING LOANS WITH WORK PROGRAM
description: Cornell University has announced a $7 million student work program that college financial-aid officials say is unique among high-cost colleges.

title: WHY REAGAN RUNS
description: This has been a crazy Halloween election, dominated by bogey-men and dirty tricks, and one of the many puzzling things about it is why President Reagan chose to play this children's game.

title: BRINK'S HEARINGS END FIRST PHASE
description: The first phase of pretrial hearings in last October's $1.6 million Brink's robbery and triple murder ended this week on a negative note for defense lawyers.

title:
GARDENING;
THE SPOOKY LORE BEHIND SOME PLANTS
description: o'-lanterns. These seem to have evolved into something much more than a carved pumpkin with a crooked smile and twinkling eyes.

title: Davis's Views Applauded
description: To the Sports Editor: Hooray for Willie Davis. His comments (''The Players Are Threatening the System,'' The New York Times, Oct. 10) should be mandatory reading for all football players on strike.

title: 'SACRIFICIAL LAMB' GIVING WALLOP A BATTLE IN WYOMING SENATE RACE
description: In the beginning, back in the balmy days of August when the campaign was just getting under way, there were few people in Wyoming who gave Rodger McDaniel a ghost's chance of upsetting Malcolm Wallop, the Republican incumbent, in this autumn's race for the Senate.

title: TECHNOLOGY PRODUCES
description: As in past economic downturns, productivity during the current recession has experienced a cyclical decline. However, the drop in output per man-hour during the current slump has been far less severe than its two immediate predecessors.

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: A 42-year-old off-duty police officer was fatally shot early yesterday on a Brooklyn street after he intervened in a dispute between a man and a woman, the police said.

title: ENEMIES REAL AND IMAGINED POISON MOOD IN ZIMBABWE
description: The young man, a librarian, almost whispered when he owned up to his real feelings about the army roadblocks and patrols that have been conspicuous recently in the black suburb where he lives on the rim of Zimbabwe's second city. ''When I am with my Ndebele friends,'' he said, ''I tell them I don't like the roadblocks. I say I mind them because they make me late. But I don't mean it. I like to see the army here.''

title: Mary Carter Jordan Is the Bride of Clyde F. White
description: The marriage of Mary Carter Jordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Jordan of Avon, Conn., to Clyde Fredin White, son of Edward White of Granby, Mass., and the late Mrs. White, took place yesterday at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Lyman Potter performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bogota $90,000 54 Gray Street *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old split-level; *2*cathedral ceiling in living room, 2-car garage; taxes $2,251. Closter $75,000 23 Old Hook Road *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fireplace and *2*cathedral ceiling in living room, basement; taxes $2,223. Emerson $106,000 60 Dorchester Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split level; *2*new roof and water heater, basement; taxes $2,083. Hillsdale $127,000 37 Buena Vista *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old Tudor; fireplace in living *2*room, 2-car garage, den-solar room; taxes $2,413. Rochelle Park $87,900 40 Cedar Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level; *2*patio, garage; taxes $1,114. Washington Township $163,000 318 Pond *2*Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old town house; *2*fireplace in family room, skylight in stairwell, *2*monthly charge $100; taxes $2,613. OTHER AREAS Redding, Conn. $185,000 14 Mallory Lane *2*3 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; *2*sauna, large deck, 4.2 acres; taxes, $2,100. Larchmont, N.Y. $158,000 198 Garden Road East *2*3-bedroom, 3-bath, 53-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; *2*eat-in kitchen, pantry, 2-car garage, 0.2 acre; taxes $4,360. Smithtown, L.I. $138,000 109 Oakside Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*2 acres, paddock; taxes $4,430.

title: ROLE OF THERAPY BECOMING BROADER
description: On the morning after Thanksgiving, 1970, Jacqueline Mayer Townsend of Meadow Lands, Pa., awoke to hear her infant daughter crying. Mrs. Townsend moved to get out of bed, but could not get her right side to respond. She turned to her husband, John, to tell him something was wrong, but she could not speak. She began to cry, as she was to do many times in the weeks ahead, at her nightmarish helplessness.

title: BEFORE THE VOTES ARE COUNTED, SOME CONCLUSIONS SEEM CLEAR
description: Most elections acquire whatever long-range significance they may have after they have been held. But Tuesday's voting, especially for House and Senate, is already clearly established as a public test not merely of an Administration in power but of a different approach to government, Ronald Reagan's determined attempt to shrink the influence of Washington in American life.

title: REPORT ON INFORMANT RELEASED
description: A newly released report said the Federal Bureau of Investigation covered up the violent activities of Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., but his lawyer said the Government knew it was not getting ''a Sunday school teacher'' when it asked Mr. Rowe to infiltrate the Ku Klux Klan.

title: 'POOLING' AIDING FIVE COLLEGES
description: WITH the cost of higher education increasing rapidly, educators are exploring new methods of delivering services. In the county five colleges have formed the Westchester Social Work Education Consortium, an undergraduate social-work program that pools resources and facilities. Members of the group are the College of New Rochelle, Marymount in Tarrytown, Concordia College in Bronxville, Iona College in New Rochelle and Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry and its Bronx extension.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Light Side of the Galaxy

title: ATOMIC DREAM & NIGHTMARE
description: THE CULT OF THE ATOM The Secret Papers of the Atomic Energy Commission. By Daniel Ford. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.THE DAY AFTER MIDNIGHT The Effects of Nuclear War. Based on a Report by the Office of Technology Assessment. Edited by Michael Riordan. Illustrated. 143 pp. Palo Alto, Calif.: Cheshire Books. Paper, $7.95.

title: BARONE TERMED NOT QUALIFIED
description: THE Westchester County Bar Association and the Westchester Women's Bar Association both have found Louis A. Barone not qualified to serve as a Family Court Judge in the county.

title: Michael Neuberger to Marry Barbara Ann Suglia
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Suglia of New York and Miller Place, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Suglia, to Michael Joseph Neuberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Neuberger of Stratford, Conn. The marriage will take place on Dec. 18.

title: THE FINAL UPHILL TEST FOR BRONCO II
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. THE sun was blinding. Dan Rivard squinted as he looked through the windshield and said: ''I can't see a thing. Guess I'll put the pedal on the floor and go by radar.''

title: 'A VICIOUS TRIBALISM' ALARMS ULSTER
description: The murder of three Ulster policemen by the Irish Republican Army has brought warnings that continued political drift and ''vicious tribalism'' are introducing a new round of violence to this British province.

title: Rooting for the Red Sox
description: I am a freshman college student, recently uprooted from home in Chicago, and the need for new sports loyalties has become apparent to me (''Odysseus at Fenway,'' by Emily Vermeule, Sept. 26). Here at Wesleyan, I am transplanted halfway between Boston and New York, and no team to root for.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
WHAT'S BEHIND TODAY'S DISINFLATION
description: OF all the economic developments during the last three years, the d ecline of inflation has been one of the most dramatic and welcome. T he raw numbers tell the story: From a peak of 13.3 percent per year i n 1979, the rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index moderated t o 8.9 percent in 1981 and, based on figures released last week, it h as risen at an annual rate of only 4.8 percent this year.

title: Haas, With 65 for 197, Leads Golf by 5 Shots
description: Jay Haas, performing ''the best stretch of putting I've ever done,'' shot a 65 today and took a five-stroke lead at 197 after the third round of the $400,000 Walt Disney World Golf Classic.

title: CITY AND TENANTS DIFFER ON CO-OP RESALE RULES
description: The Koch administration and tenants in 18 city-owned buildings in Manhattan have now agreed on a $250 purchase price for the apartments the tenants occupy, discarding the possibility that the city would charge a higher price based on the units' market value.

title: Engine One Scores Stuyvesant Victory
description: Engine One left the fans at Aqueduct with something to remember him by and something to look forward to next year, with a two-length victory yesterday in the $112,000 Stuyvesant Handicap.

title: by Terence Smith; Terence Smith, the editor of The Times's Washington Talk Page, was bureau chief in Jerusalem from 1972 to 1976.
description: Micha Bar-Am was slouched in an easy chair in a Manhattan apartment, rubbing his eyes with the knuckles of both forefingers, as if to erase the fatigue of four months of photographing the war in Lebanon. He was in town for the opening last month of an exhibition of his photographs, titled

title: Farrell Wins Cross-Country
description: Monsignor Farrell and Archbishop Molloy were winners in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's sectional cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Food
description: There is a new sophistication to foods that can be ordered for holiday gift-giving. From Champagne-filled truffles to red-pepper wreaths, a world of alluring culinary gifts is only a letter or phone call away.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A BOND ISSUE THAT DESERVES VOTER APPROVAL
description: WHY DO we believe that New Jersey voters should approve, as an excellent use of limited public resources, the $85 million Community Development Bond Act that will be on the ballot Tuesday?

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Dorothea Rockburne used to be about as austere as it is possible to be in her choice of materials. Working with virgin sheets of carbon paper, rather than with the gamut of luxuries that technology has put at the painter's disposal, she nonetheless wrought a strange magic.

title: COMEDIE FRANCAISE: BACKSTAGE AT A PARIS TRADITION
description: JOHN RUSSELL is chief art critic for The New York Times.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 5 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 9 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 3 9 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 4 4 10 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 6 13 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 6 5 6 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic romance survives the stresses and strains of World War II. 7 10 3 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: fourth volume of s.f. stories in ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 8 7 10 LACE, by Shirley Conran.

title: A Doctors' Parley Joins Call for Nuclear Freeze
description: An international group of physicians, including a Soviet cardiologist, called today for a worldwide freeze on production, testing and deployment of nuclear weapons.

title: Bayside Alumni Do Well
description: As Bayside High School defeated Beach Channel yesterday to make the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs again, its stars of three past city champion teams were doing well on college fields.

title: PLAYHOUSE HUMMING AGAIN
description: GREAT NECK THE people who run the Playhouse Theater on Middle Neck Road are working against time to complete the finishing touches for the theater's re-opening on Thursday night when the DiCapo Opera Theater is to present Puccini's ''Tosca,'' starring the community's own Elaine Malbin.

title: BALLOT ISSUES FOR PROPERTY OWNERS
description: WHEN voters in New York and New Jersey troop to the polls this T uesday, they will pull levers not only for the candidates of their c hoice but also for a variegated batch of referendums, some of which d irectly affect private and commercial property owners. Connecticut r esidents will vote on four referendums, but none involve issues a ffecting property owners.

title: MEN JUST CAN'T DO WOMEN'S WORK
description: ISHOULD explain at the outset that I am not one of those male chauvinists who feels that a husband's job is to putter around the toolshed and the garage while his wife spends roughly 100 percent of her time cooking, mending and vacuuming. I am quite at home in our kitchen, where I frequently bake bread, rolls and pastries; I have no problem with a needle and thread, having been taught at age 7 how to sew on a button so it never comes off again; and in 25 years of marriage, I have had ample time to earn my wings as pilot of our Hoover upright. As for the toolshed and the garage, I made sure when I bought my house that it didn't have a toolshed, and although it does have a garage, I spend as little time in it as possible - and certainly not puttering.

title: D. H. Harman 3d, Leigh Chapman Wed in New York
description: The marriage of Beverly Jean Chapman, daughter of Mrs. John Cary Chapman of Glens Falls, N.Y., and the late Mr. Chapman, to Daniel Howard Harman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harman Jr. of Martinsburg, W. Va., took place in Manhattan yesterday. The ceremony was performed in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell, the rector, and Retired Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan of New York.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP ASSAILS REAGAN ON WORKER PROTECTION
description: The Reagan Administration has ''slammed the door on American workers'' by neglecting its legal responsibility to enforce job safety and health standards, the Sierra Club charged today.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEMS BARGAINING TO HOLD DOWN UNION GAINS
description: Many mass transit agencies around the country, operating in a poor economy and facing reduced Federal assistance, have begun this year to hold down workers' gains in bargaining with unions.

title: Swarthmore 28, Ursinus 14
description: A 36-yard touchdown run by Ed Meehan broke a 14-14 tie and helped Swarthmore gain its first 7-0 start in the 104 years the school has fielded a football team. Swarthmore led at 14-6 on touchdown passes of 32 yards and a school-record 88 yards from the quarterback Mike Reil to Glen Bennett, a freshman split end.

title: NEW TOOLS SHOWN TO ASSIST DISABLED
description: A symposium on ''Designing for the Disabled'' drew hundreds of occupational and recreational therapists, rehabilitation engineers, architects and educators last week to learn about improvements in design and technology for the handicapped.

title: HAPPY 'MIKADO'
description: PORT JEFFERSON THE good news is that Theater Three has come up with a merry and mellifluous ''The Mikado.'' There is no bad news. Under James G. Vaughan's direction, the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta's purity is preserved. Purists will be pleased. Add a dash of superimposed fun and a smattering of modernism so that it doesn't come out creaky, and no one should be displeased. Samples: ''Let the Punishment Fit the Crime'' is sung in Britishmusical style, replete with derby and twirling cane. The Mikado is announced as ''The Henry Kissinger of his race,'' Nanki-Poo's address is given as East Hampton and there's assorted funny business involving oversized, unfurling fans and hyper-giggling maidens.

title: WINE
description: They are using classic French technology, equipment and skills, as well as grapes of French origin grown in northern California vineyards, to make products that they refuse to call Champagne, for they know that the only true Champagne comes from France. Their refusal is influencing other California producers, and someday, perhaps, the practice of borrowing the French name will be abandoned altogether in this country.

title: PEDDLING PATE IN PALO ALTO
description: With supermarkets fighting back in the fancy-food wars, some of the specialty stores are taking a new tack and branching out. Food shops like the Silver Palate, Dean & Deluca and Trois Petits Cochons were established in New York City with minimal capital in the 1970's. Now, buoyed by their success in the Big Apple, these three establishments - unlike many of their culinary counterparts - are marketing their own gourmet food products nationally.

title: MARKET PROVIDES THE NEEDS OF HOME WINE MAKERS
description: PLEASANTVILLE THE sign in front of 134 Marble Avenue reads Prospero's Farm Market and Garden Center, but the yard, piled high with glass casks and wooden barrels plus numerous crushers, presses and fermenting tanks, beckons the home winemaker inside. There, in the recently built cinderblock garage, bulging crates of Alicante, Thompson seedless and muscat grapes have been arriving from California at the rate of 15,000 cases a week since the middle of September.

title: 'SEWN PAINTINGS' AT IMAGES GALLERY
description: THE fiber artist Benjie Lasseau had planned to become a painter - until she discovered during her academic training at the Boston Museum School that she was allergic to turpentine. Understandably, she made the prudent decision to switch the focal point of her studies, although she did not intend to make textiles her new area of concentration. Her background encompassed such diverse disciplines as printing, woodworking, graphics, and photography, with little emphasis on fiber. Discovering that she loved the latter, she pursued it, beginning with small patchwork designs. One day she realized that, as she put it, ''more people were looking at my patchworks than at my pictures,'' and it was this realization and her love for the medium that prompted her to experiment with textiles more and attempt to employ them seriously as a means to translate her artistic statements.

title: A RENEWAL
description: When it was about to open in 1964, the Franklin National Bank building at 410 Madison Avenue, at 48th Street, was regarded as a suburban curiosity. Georgian in style, brick-faced, with marbleframed doorways, it contrasted starkly with the modern glass-andsteel structures going up around it.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FOLK ART AT THE NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK IN THE winters of 1930 through 1932, the Newark Museum presented two shows on American folk art (one on paintings and one on sculpture), making them the first major museum exhibitions in the country to feature these crafts and paintings from America's past.

title: Lisa Raskin To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Raskin of New York and Santa Fe, N.M., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Abby Raskin, to Russell Andrew Janis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Janis of Traverse City, Mich.

title: 1835 SHOWCASE
description: In today's depressed housing market, even an elegant, historic house on a five-acre plot in Princeton, N.J., can be tough to sell.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DISPUTE ON OLYMPIC DESIGNS
description: Controversy continues to plague the U.S. Treasury's Olympic coin program - a venture whose seemingly uncontroversial aim is to honor and help finance the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles. The problems started with the protracted legislative fight over how many coins should be issued and how they should be marketed. Now another battle appears to have begun concerning the designs of the three coins that were ultimately authorized.

title: DO ANGELS PLAY MOZART FOR GOD?
description: MOZART By Wolfgang Hildesheimer. Translated by Marion Faber. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: DAY CARE CENTERS AIDING ELDERLY SEEK FUNDS
description: HARRY GARSON settled into a folding chair, opened a book, and grinned. ''Let's get down to bagels,'' he said to the smiling elderly people who sat in a circle of chairs around him.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF GOOD CHEESE
description: HELEN WEISSMAN is a writer and a rare-book dealer. Madge Rosenberg contributed to the research. Both live in New York.

title: WILD CARDS COULD RUIN REAGAN'S RUN OF LUCK
description: Important changes -some expected, some not -have taken place in the nation and its institutions in the two years between Ronald Reagan's election to the Presidency and Tuesday's off-year balloting. By and large, it is the anticipated ones that should help Mr. Reagan and his Republicans this week and the unpromised ones that could damage his efforts to remake American government along the laissezfaire lines of an earlier era.

title: William Saroyan
description: To the Editor:

title: HER MUSIC SCHOOL IS ALSO A MEMORIAL
description: LONG ISLAND has a new music school. Behind its founding lie the stories of two remarkable women. One of the stories is that of Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi, the 44-year-old Argentine-born pianist and teacher - a child prodigy who fought back from the threshold of death after a harrowing automobile accident at age 23 to resume her concert and recording career.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
SHOULD THE ELDERLY GET HANDOUTS?
description: THE other night, I went to bed an ordinary, living, breathing, taxpaying human being. The next day, my 60th birthday, I awoke a senior citizen.

title: SURVIVING TOXIC SHOCK
description: Already armed with more knowledge of life-threatening illnesses than I should care to have, I had difficulty bringing myself to read Nan Robertson's account of her painful encounter with and recovery from toxic shock. But I'm glad I did. Not only was I rewarded with a thoroughly professional, nonalarmist examination of the causes and treatment of her illness, but of far broader benefit, I was enriched by the experience of witnessing this remarkable woman's determination to survive her trauma with her dignity and optimism intact. L.G. BLANCHARD Houston ------

title: Lake District
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's mouth-watering description of the food at the Sharrow Bay Hotel in ''Lake District Feasting'' (Travel, Oct. 10) took us back 10 years when my husband and I, while driving through England, had an incomparable luncheon there overlooking Lake Ullswater. Beautifully cooked and charmingly served, it was a soulpampering experience.

title: Teacher Offers Guide In Judging Candidate
description: A Williams College psychology professor says voters can learn whether the candidate they are considering will turn out to be a dud by reading biographical sketches of the office-seekers in newspapers and magazines.

title: SAKHAROV SAYS K.G.B. STOLE PERSONAL PAPERS
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished dissident physicist, said in a letter disclosed today that Soviet security agents had stunned him, smashed the rear window of his car and taken his unpublished memoirs, diaries and other personal papers.

title: IT'S TIME FOR A HARD LOOK AT DEFENSE
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum resigned as chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers last August and returned to teach at Washington University in St. Louis. The following excerpts were taken from his first major policy speech since returning to private life, presented last Friday at the annual policy conference of the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University. AT a time when, alas, economist jokes are in vogue, I would like to a dd my favorite wisecrack about our profession: If all the economistsi n the world were laid end to end, it might be a good thing.

title: Jean M. Antos Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Antos of Bayonne, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean M Antos, to Dr. Michael G. Popik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Popik Jr, of Metuchen, N.J. Dr. Popik is a radiologist at the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Jacobi Hosptial in the Bronx. with a lot of stress and strain.''

title: S.A.T.: A GUIDE TO POINTS
description: NEXT Saturday is the day for the Scholastic Aptitude Test, which many colleges use as a guide for admission. Here are some suggestions for helping your son/daughter succeed on this grueling three-hour examination:

title: Standout Running Paces Dobbs Ferry
description: Rich DiGuglielmo and Rocky D'Agostino accounted for five touchdowns yesterday as unbeaten Dobbs Ferry overwhelmed Hastings, 47-0. DiGuglielmo scored three times and rushed for 102 yards and now leads the county with 13 touchdowns this season. D'Agostino had two touchdowns and 145 yards rushing. Coach Frank Violante's Eagles have shut out four of five opponents and have allowed just one touchdown in winning fives games this season. Dobbs Ferry has won 21 of its last 22 games.

title: U.S. May Allow Entry of Doses Of Drugs Approved Overseas
description: The Food and Drug Administration is proposing that small amounts of ''legitimate'' drugs approved in other countries but not in the United States be allowed into this country for personal use, a spokesman said Friday.

title:
ART;
BEHIND THE EXHIBIT, IDEAS THAT FRAME IT
description: PURCHASE ART exhibitions organized around a principle having nothing to do with quality often turn out rather oddly. ''Area Codes 914 and 203'' at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, which despite its title was not chosen by the telephone company, is puzzling both in terms of the reasons for its conception and the art works it contains.

title: A PRESIDENT ON HIS PEERS
description: LEADERS By Richard Nixon. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.50.

title: SUSPECT IN TYLENOL EXTORTION IS ARRESTED IN NEWARK
description: A 35-year-old unemployed Newark man was arrested by Federal agents yesterday after two youths picked up a package purportedly containing $100,000 that had been demanded in an extortion letter sent to Johnson & Johnson, the parent company of the maker of Extra-Strength Tylenol, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night.

title: KEep the Cash In Christmas
description: The time may be right for a raise, Chrysler workers concluded last week, but not for the strike it would have taken to try to win one. Heeding the advice of union leaders, they agreed to extend their contract until early next year, when a another round of negotiations will begin.

title: THE POLISH CONNECTION
description: COURIER FROM WARSAW By Jan Nowak. Illustrated. 477 pp. Detroit: Wayne State University Press. $24.95.

title: TAX REVENUES FALL IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The economic recession has begun to cut into tax collections in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, raising fears of budget deficits and forcing officials to ponder painful choices.

title: WALT WHITMAN: AUTUMNAL POET
description: WHEN I recently visited the Heckscher Museum in Huntington to see the ''Land of Whitman'' exhibition, which explores the great poet's artistic legacy, I knew why I have always loved the autumn season. Simply, to love a poet is to love all seasons. And since autumn on Long Island is the quintessence of Whitman's vision of beauty and devotion to ''all sights and sounds eternal,'' this is a perfect time to blend the time of year with our native son's insightful genius.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Political Economics

title: LAKE DISTRICT
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT GOING GENTLE AT ALL
description: A LIFETIME BURNING By Ellen Douglas. 212 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: CRASHING THROUGH THE LOOPHOLES
description: MOTOR vehicle injuries claim more children's lives each year than do all diseases combined. In an attempt to save some of those lives, Connecticut joined 22 other states last spring in enacting a child auto restraint law. Since Oct. 1, state law has made it illegal to let a child under 4 years old travel in an automobile unless secured in a federally approved safety seat or a seat belt.

title: LILCO-BOKUM CASE DRAGS ON
description: delayed proceedings in the Long Island Lighting Company's multimillion foreclosure case against its New Mexico uranium supplier, thought to be near resolution, have been postponed again.

title: CHANGING SCHOOLS: IT CAN HURT
description: When 10-year-old John and his parents moved to this community, it was the family's fourth move in five years. For John, it was nearly one move too many.

title: The New Right
description: Three men were sitting on a squalid West 84th Street stoop in Manhattan the other day when Lewis L. Lehrman's limousine eased between double-parked cars.

title: DETROIT LOOKS AHEAD
description: For Detroit, the only good thing one can say about 1982 is that it is nearly over. All in all, this is likely to be the auto industry's worst year since 1958.

title: 'NATURE' IS PUBLIC TV AT ITS MOST IMPRESSIVE
description: There's no doubt that, in the midst of assorted funding crises, public television is beginning to look like a graveyard for old movies. ''Unedited, uninterrupted and free!'' blare the somewhat sheepish ads, making promises that are not completely true. But the system can still come up with impressive pockets of programming that demonstrate the power not of yesterday's films but of today's television. One good example can be found these days on the Sundayevening schedule being offered by WNET/Channel 13.

title: No Headline
description: Celtics Rally to Defeat Hawks, 112-97

title: POLISH PRIMATE OPPOSES SOLIDARITY'S CALL FOR STRIKE
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, said today that he was against a general strike called for Nov. 10 by the outlawed labor union Solidarity because he felt that it would only trigger new repression.

title: WHAT'S GONE WRONG AT BLACK ROCK
description: THERE is no better symbol of corporate invincibility than Black R ock, the sleek, granite-clad headquarters of CBS Inc. For years, theb roadcast giant has been synonymous with profits, prestige and W illiam S. Paley, one of the century's great entrepreneurs and the m an who turned a struggling radio network into a $4 billion c ommunications empire.

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN TRIUMPHS BY 52-14

title: No. Rockland Streak at 17
description: North Rockland ran its winning streak to 17th games yesterday by edging Tappan Zee, 13-0. Greg Johnson tallied both touchdowns for the Red Raiders, scoring on runs of 1 and 7 yards.

title: Parrish Museum Explains Change
description: We read with interest the article (''Shift on Parrish Show Protested,'' Oct. 3) by Helen A. Harrison, whose judgment we admire. We wish to clarify the change in the Parrish Art Museum's present policy in the way it conducts annual exhibitions of the works of regional artists, and especially to correct some misconceptions about that policy that seem to be abroad among artists and others.

title: HAUPPAUGE IN MIDST OF INDUSTRIAL BOOM
description: FUELED mainly by the expansion of high-technology companies, a b uilding boom is tranforming Hauppauge, in Western Suffolk County, a nd even a depressed national economy does not seem to be slowing thep ace of development.

title: More Olympic Injustice
description: To the Sports Editor: The chance juxtaposition of two Views of Sports articles (''His Medals Returned, Has the Thorpe Story Ended?'' and ''Asthma Won't Stop Her Run,'' The New York Times, Oct. 17) reminds me of another Olympic injustice.

title: BIshops Assail Underpinnings Of Deterrence
description: Nuclear weapons doctrine, a stepchild of science that often seems immune to science's admonishments, last week received comeuppance from a committee of Roman Catholic bishops. ''We seek to encourage a public attitude which sets stringent limits on the kinds of actions our government will take on nuclear policy in our name,'' the draft of a proposed pastoral letter said.

title: FERRYING BETWEEN ASIA AND EUROPE
description: JOSEPH B. TREASTER is a reporter for The Times.

title: ELECTION SPENDING RISES IN NEW YORK
description: A weekend of heavy last-minute spending in the New York area topped off two gubernatorial and three senatorial campaigns in elections being watched nationwide as tests of President Reagan's economic policies.

title: NORTH SALEM
description: THERE are no traffic lights on the 100 miles of roads that wind t hrough the hills and fields of North Salem, just stop signs. The n earest supermarket and movie theater are in neighboring towns. And c able television has yet to be hooked up.

title: Another Lecture On Topic 'A'
description: Hoping, perhaps, that a new messenger could deliver the message more convincingly, the Administration last week dispatched Under Secretary of Defense Fred. C. Ikle to San Salvador, rather than a State Department envoy.

title: AMENDMENTS ARE ALSO ON BALLET
description: HARTFORD IN addition to choosing candidates for Federal, state and some local offices on Tuesday, Connecticut voters will be asked to decide the fate of four amendments to the State Constitution. The proposed amendments, which deal primarily with the functions of the judiciary and the legislature, have been largely forgotten in all the speeches by the candidates running for office and have attracted the attention of only a few editorial writers.

title:
ART;
PRINTMAKING BY HAMPTONS ARTISTS
description: MANY of today's outstanding painters and sculptors also turn their hands to printmaking, either occasionally or on a regular basis. Artists of every persuasion, from Photo-Realists to Pop to Abstract Expressionists, are now producing graphics as a natural adjunct to their work in other media, whereas only a few years ago printmaking seemed a limited field, attractive only to the specialists.

title: Do-or-Die Day For People, Propositions
description: Polls and pundits last week continued to predict down-to-the-wire races in some contests for governor and the United States Senate in the tristate region. In New York, however, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, appeared to take a sizeable lead over his Republican opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman, as the week ended. But as Mr. Lehrman noted, most polls had shown Mr. Cuomo trailing in the Democratic gubernatorial primary in September.

title: BROADWAY LURES THE CORPORATE ANGEL
description: For decades, the mainstay of Broadway has been the angel, the private investor prepared to gamble relatively small sums on a show or producer that struck his fancy. Now, however, the angel is being superseded by the institution, a decidedly less celestial creature whose money comes mainly from Hollywood.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: THE CASE FOR AN AMERICAN 'YES'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW, IMPORTANT SPRINGTIME AT NO EXTRA CHARGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Selling Tax
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The New Styles in Short Selling'' (Oct.17), you state that if the stock sold short becomes worthless (due for example to the bankruptcy of the company), the short seller never has to buy back the shares sold short.

title: MARYLAND VICTOR
description: Willie Joyner, a running back who lost his starting job a week ago, came back today and scored two touchdowns in leading Maryland to a 31-24 upset victory over North Carolina before 51,319 stunned fans at Kenan Stadium.

title:
GARDENING;
THE SPOOKY LORE BEHIND SOME PLANTS
description: o'-lanterns. These seem to have evolved into something much more than a carved pumpkin with a crooked smile and twinkling eyes.

title: ...AND ON STATEWIDE BALLOTS
description: IF there is any sure sign that issues have competed with personalities in this year's campaigns, perhaps it is that many statewide ballots seem to have nearly as many ideas to choose from as people. From freezing nuclear weapons to banning handguns, voters will weigh the merits of more proposals this week than at any time in the last 50 years.

title: Sending a Message
description: In a mid-October survey, pollsters Penn and Schoen asked whether people intend to vote mostly for a particular candidate or mostly because of national issues. Two-thirds said ''national issues.'' The public, distressed by double-digit unemployment, wants to send Washington a message on Tuesday. What's the message?

title: Stevens Asserts Court Takes Too Many Cases
description: Justice John Paul Stevens says the Supreme Court agrees to decide ''far too many cases,'' and he has cited 36 recent cases as possible examples.

title: MAKING A BET ON TECHNOLOGY STOCKS
description: AFTER taking a drubbing in the final months of the bear market, t echnology stocks have roared back with a vengeance. The gain in the i ndex of 117 high-technology stocks compiled by Hambrecht & Quist, t he San Francisco securities firm, has been so great, in fact, that f rom early August to last week it had shot up 60 percent, o utdistancing broader market averages by 25 percent.

title: SATIRIST DRAWS TO RELEASE FEELINGS
description: SALISBURY WHEN it came time to decorate the brochure for his exhibit of drawings about the horrors of nuclear war, Robert Osborn was rather partial to a study of two bloated figures, viciously entwined, titled ''The Folly Defies Belief.'' But he decided instead on a marching figure gaily waving a flag.

title: GROWING PAINS AND JOYS
description: SUMMER CROSSING By Steve Tesich. 373 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: Miss Wollens Is Affianced To Executive
description: The engagement of Debra Wollens to Jonathan Newhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Newhouse of New Orleans, has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wollens of Manhasset Hills, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: CONCERT: EVE QUELER LEADS 'ALBA'
description: ''Of the more than 25 works given,'' read the Carnegie Hall program notes for the Opera Orchestra of New York, ''almost all belong to the undeservedly neglected class.'' Whether the neglect that has attended Donizetti's ''Il Duca d'Alba,'' which Eve Queler offered on Thursday, is really so undeserved might be debated. But it is certainly of historical interest; it certainly has its moments, and Miss Queler and her troops did honorably by it.

title: THE INS AND OUTS OF PERSONAL BANKRUPTCY
description: THE advertisements in the legal columns of the local paper have b ecome familiar: ''Bankruptcy!'' they flash. ''Relief from debt in o ne day. May keep home, car, cash, etc. Stop foreclosure, wage a ttachment, or will defer your lawsuit.''

title: NEWSPAPER STORY
description: THE ALMIGHTY By Irving Wallace. 403 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: CRUISE ALONG THE YANGTZE
description: JEFFREY SCHEUER is a New York writer and book reviewer.

title: GOLF FOR A GOOD CAUSE
description: WEST ORANGE MORT FRIEDMAN is an amateur doing a professional's job, and so far his record has been perfect: seven successful fund-raising golf tournaments in seven years.

title: POSTINGS
description: What can be done to give warmth to a modern office complex made of hard materials like glass? To accomplish this, the Prudential Insurance Company has commissioned a tapestry for its 400,000-square-foot RiverPark office complex straddling the Darien-Norwalk border near exit 13 of Interstate 95 in Connecticut.

title: YONKERS WARD SYSTEM FACES NEW TEST
description: YONKERS THE future of the ward system, under which Yonkers has been governed for most of its 110 years as a city, goes before the voters Tuesday.

title: OHIO CONCERN BUYS OPTION TO PURCHASE DE LOREAN PLANT
description: Consolidated International of Columbus, Ohio, has paid a substantial sum for a 45-day option on buying John Z. De Lorean's closed sports-car plant in Northern Ireland, the car company's receivers said today.

title: A HOME'S COST, HERE AND THERE
description: Suppose, because of a job change, you have to move to another city. Suppose further that you want to continue living in the kind of house you are leaving.

title: Random Crime, United Defense
description: If people have begun to think the only safe medicines are sealed medicines, it is no wonder. Seven people died of cyanide-filled Tylenol capsules in Chicago and four of its suburbs a month ago. Authorities have recovered eight tainted bottles; the last, found only a few days ago, with a mixture of cyanide and Tylenol suggesting that more than one person is responsible for the poisonings.

title: 70% OF PROGRAM'S TRAINEES SAID TO KEEP JOBS
description: A study of a job training program in New York City found that 70 percent of the trainees were still holding jobs at the end of a year, according to Herbert Bienstock, former regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He said the findings contradicted President Reagan's assertion that job-training programs were a ''boondoggle.''

title: CHOICE OF COURSE
description: ASMALL story from the campaign of one Republican incumbent up for re-election on Tuesday frames a question central to the midterm Congressional voting. The incumbent is Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota. The story is of his recent encounter with a woman collecting free powdered milk at a Government food distribution center. ''I've got two hungry children to feed,'' she told him. Her husband was unemployed. But, she later said, she still supports Ronald Reagan's economic program; his solutions require sacrifices. The question is this: Will voters this week extend to other Republicans the same indulgence many Americans seem willing to extend to the President?

title: Army Routs Columbia
description: Gerald Walker ran for 177 yards on 25 attempts and Elton Akins ran 100 in one swoop today, helping Army to rout Columbia, 41-8, before a crowd of 30,363 at Michie Stadium.

title: IN SCHISGAL'S THEATER, ZANINESS IS ALL
description: BALTIMORE Murray Schisgal is coming back to Broadway next Thursday after an eight-year hiatus. His beard is a bit grayer, his paunch is a fraction smaller and his mood approximates the rage and anxiety of a victim returning to the dark corner where he was last mugged.

title: EIGHT CONGRESSIONAL RACES TO WATCH IN THE REGION
description: The 'Alaskan' Solution

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection was expected to announce yesterday the formation of a new Committee on Ocean Waste Management. The announcement was to be made at a statewide conference on ocean dumping at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SOUTHPORT CHURCH SETTING FOR SHOW
description: SOUTHPORT LATE each autumn, a dedicated committee of parishioners produces one of Connecticut's fine antiques shows to raise funds for the maintenance of the Southport Congregational Church at 524 Pequot Avenue.

title: THEY STAKE OUT THE FRONTIERS OF POP
description: In 1978, two refugees from Manhattan's loft jazz circuit began playing a new kind of music at CBGB, Hurrah, and other new wave rock clubs. Somebody called the new music punk-funk, and the name stuck. As a generic description, it was reasonably appropriate. One of the new music's avatars, a saxaphonist who called himself either James White or James Chance, sometimes acted out the aggression in his music by picking fights with audience members, who began calling him ''that little punk.'' The other punk-funk avatar, James (Blood) Ulmer, made a name for himself by grafting his wildly agitated guitar playing onto black dance rhythms that were decidedly funky, though a far cry from the disco-funk that was then in full flower.

title: Wendelin Evans To Be Wed Dec. 4
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Evans of New York, Fishers Island, N.Y., and Essex, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendelin Jean Evans, to Warren Arthur Knight Jr., son of Mrs. William S. Wallace of Olean, N.Y., and the late Mr. Knight of Sarasota, Fla. The wedding will take place on Dec. 4.

title: THE CLERK'S RACE: A QUEST FOR IDENTITY
description: WHEN Andrew Spano, a New Rochelle Democrat, decided last April to challenge George Morrow for the job of County Clerk, he said that one of his first and most-important tasks would be to make the job better known. Most Westchester residents, he said, had no idea what the County Clerk did.

title: 2 CLAVIERS ARE BETTER THAN ONE
description: BLOOMFIELD TRUNDLING around two prized harpsichords, each eight feet long and weighing more than 150 pounds, is all in a day's work for Elaine Comparone, who is about to start a month-long, 24-concert tour of Essex County.

title: ON THE FRONTIER OF A NEW ECONOMICS
description: ELECTION day, November 1932. America's economic problems were the dominant issue - the only issue - in the landslide Presidential victory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. The economy was in collapse and F.D.R. had pledged to create jobs for the nation's 12 million unemployed - while somehow managing to balance the Federal budget. Little did he know then that eventually he would embrace the radical ideas of a Briton named John Maynard Keynes, who advocated huge deficit spending to bring the United States out of its depression.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE FATE OF THE EARTH. By Jonathan Schell. (Avon, $2.50.) ''The Fate of the Earth'' may be a book that changes history. Public figures and critics both applauded Jonathan Schell's analysis of nuclear peril when it ran serially in The New Yorker and appeared in hard-cover earlier this year. Our reviewer, Kai Erikson, called it a ''marvelous work'' and suggested that its three parts might still profitably ''be read as separate essays - with pauses for thought in between.''

title: Warriors 117, Rockets 110
description: World B. Free and Lorenzo Romar combined for 42 points to pace the Golden State victory. Free had 22 points as the Warriors won their second straight and Houston lost its second straight.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The Murray Louis Dance Company, opening on Tuesday, will be the first modern-dance company to play the newly renovated Joyce Theater, home of the Feld Ballet. The theater was conceived by Eliot Feld as a performing space that would also serve the needs of modern-dance companies and Mr. Louis will be treating New Yorkers to several new works.

title: AUSTRALIAN COURT DRAMA ENDS
description: One of Australia's most sensational murder trials ended this week in the northern city of Darwin when a jury refused to believe a story told by a clergyman's wife that a wild dog had carried off her 9-month-old daughter two years ago.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Judging from many ''Year of Luther'' tour advertisements it looks as if many Americans will be interested in visiting East Germany next year in connection with the 500th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther. What is the possibility of four older people, one of whom speaks fluent German, making the trip on their own? What are the visa requirements? How can we find smaller, less-expensive hotels if accommodations have to be paid for in advance? And would it be better to rent a car in East or West Berlin? - M.C.H., Charleston, S.C. Answer:Yes, four older people could travel independently in East Germany, and having a German-speaking person in the party would certainly make it easier.

title: SOCKS FAVORED BY SHOPLIFTERS
description: SOCKS are in first place, women's cologne second and steaks third among supermarket shoplifters, according to an 18-month survey conducted by Checkpoint Systems, a company in the Gloucester County community of Thorofare that makes electronic antitheft devices.

title: Carole Southall Wed to Hermon Telyan
description: Carole Rose Southall, acting director of development for the United States Committee for UNICEF, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Hermon Telyan, an architect, planner and real-estate investor. The Rev. Arten Ashjian performed the Armenian orthodox ceremony at St. Vartan Cathedral.

title: GREENWICH MARKS A MUSICAL BIRTHDAY
description: THE Greenwich Philharmonia played itself ''Happy Birthday'' (in the witty little arrangement by Igor Stravinsky) and the audience celebrated with champagne at intermission.

title: Shipwreck Survivors Say 2 Swam to Their Deaths
description: A delirious man who said he was going for ''beer and cigarettes'' and another who said he just wanted ''to go home'' jumped out of a rubber lifeboat drifting in the Atlantic and swam to their deaths, two shipwreck survivors said.

title: Iran Says Its Artillery Pounded Iraqis in South
description: The Teheran radio said today that Iranian artillery pounded Iraqi military positions on the Shatt al Arab waterway in southern Iraq in the last 24 hours.

title: DANCE: OHAD NAHARIN AT RIVERSIDE THEATER
description: One of the great pleasures of watching dance is the chance to see the human body extending itself beyond familiar limits. It is a chance that comes only occasionally, but Ohad Naharin opened up that vista Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church with dancing that was sensuous, amazingly supple and of an unusual, purely physical eloquence.

title: FOR A CHANGE, A CLASH OF IDEAS AND INTELLECTS
description: Whatever else turns out to be true of New York's 1982 campaign for governor, it will have been a contest between two powerful, stubborn and searching intellects with sharply contrasting ideas about how the world does, and should, work. ''This is a campaign of ideas,'' Lewis E. Lehrman has said, over and over, and it has proven true not only of his race but also of that of his adversary, Mario M. Cuomo.

title: WHERE FRANCE HOLDS SWAY
description: French 18th-century furniture reigns supreme today in the antiques field, as popular among aristocrats of government, banking and industry everywhere as when Versailles was home to the rulers of France. Whether prices will continue to spiral, as they have for more than a decade, will be seen when one of the finest sales of French furniture to be held in New York in 10 years, takes place Saturday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: STUDY SAYS HISPANIC WORKERS DON'T GET ENOUGH STATE JOBS
description: A nonprofit group has charged that the growing Hispanic community in New York has been denied its ''fair share'' of state government jobs for more than a decade by both Republican and Democratic administrations in Albany.

title: 'AMOR BANDIDO,' 1979 MELODRAMA FROM BRAZIL
description: ''Amor Bandido'' (Outlaw Love), Bruno Barreto's 1979 Brazilian film that opens today at the Cinema 3, is a contrived little romantic melodrama about a baby-faced Sao Paulo punk named Toninho, who struggles to make ends meet by murdering cab drivers for their money, and Sandra, the pretty Rio de Janeiro hooker who becomes his mistress.

title: TRENTON
description: MANY voters in New Jersey will be looking in vain for a familiar name Tuesday, the day they go to to the polls to elect a United States Senator and fill the state's 14 seats in the House of Representatives. In addition to picking Congressmen, voters will decide a contest for Essex County Executive and scores of local elections, as well as five ballot questions.

title: Margaret Maurice Caswell Wed to Terry Robards
description: Margaret Maurice Caswell, daughter of the late Albert T. Maurice and the late Virgil Taylor Ensign of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Terry Robards, wine critic of The New York Times. Mr. Robards, who lives in Bronxville, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Robards of Southern Pines, N.C.

title: SELLING COMPUTERS SECOND HAND
description: Here's a little beauty. Owned by a small, Midwestern company that only used it for occasional letters and reports. A real cream puff. Less than two years old, has the original 64K memory, plus a new video screen and reconditioned disk drives. Go on, run your fingers over that responsive keyboard, listen to the printer purr. This baby sold for $13,000 new. You can have it for $7,500, including delivery and installation.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Detroit Pistons vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis; Phoenix Suns vs. Nuggets, at Denver. Maurice Lucas, a former Knick and Net, is with the Suns, his fifth N.B.A. team. The Nuggets were the first N.B.A. team to score more than 100 points in all 82 games last season. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M. and 10 P.M.) Boxing Leon Spinks vs. Jesse Burnett, 12 rounds, cruiseweights, at Americana Hotel, McAfee, N.J. Spinks, the former heavyweight champion, is the No.1 World Boxing Council contender in this new 195-pound division. Burnett is ranked No. 9. The winner will assume the vacant North American Boxing Federation title. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.) Roger Stafford vs. Fernando Castro, 10 rounds, welterweights, from Miami. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.).

title: Ready to Underwrite Murder in Guatemala?
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW CIRCUIT BROADENS A RECORDER'S SONIC RANGE
description: It seems historically appropriate that one of the most remarkable cassette recorders made today is of Danish origin. After all, it was a Dane - Hans Christian Oersted - who first discovered the relation between electricity and magnetism back in 1820, and yet another Dane - Valdemar Poulsen - who invented magnetic recording at the end of the last century. Poulsen's primitive device, using piano wire magnetized by the voice current from a telephone, emitted only feeble sounds and could not compete for popular acclaim at the time with Edison's blaring tin horn. Still, it established the principle of recording sound in the form of electrically induced magnetic patterns; and though scarcely remembered today, Poulsen knew a moment of glory when his invention was shown at the Paris World's Fair of 1900 and caught the fancy of the visiting emperor of Austria. It is ironic that Franz Joseph, that venerable monarch who so resented the intrusions of modernity into his ancient realm that he never spoke on the telephone or rode in a motor car, thus became the first ruler to preserve his voice through the medium of electrical recording.

title: WHEN THE CHEERING STOPS SOCIALISTS' TROUBLES START
description: As youthful supporters sang, danced and careened through the streets of Madrid beeping car horns in celebration of the Socialist Party's impressive sweep in elections to Parliament, cooler heads in the organization's temporary headquarters in the Palace Hotel early Friday morning measured the truly daunting tasks ahead. There was general agreement that one night of merrymaking was about all the party could afford.

title: A CRITIC CASTS A KINDLY EYE ON TEXAS
description: JACQUES BARZUN is a writer who lives in the East and lectures in the West. He is an honorary citizen of Dallas and a Kentucky Colonel, and hopes to be made an admiral in the Texas Navy. His ''Critical Questions'' has just been published by the University of Chicago Press.

title: CONVICTED KILLER DESCRIBED AT TRIAL
description: For the most part, Charles Voyde Harrelson, the convicted killer-for-hire who is accused of assassinating Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., appears relaxed as he listens to the case being built against him. He chats with his attorney, mugs at reporters and smiles with delight at testimony about his skill with a rifle or a deck of cards.

title: FRESH FODDER FOR REFLECTION: THE SAVORY JUNK MOVIE
description: Sitting in Loew's State 1 the other afternoon enveloped in Stygian darkness, wearing a foolish, ear-to-ear grin in the presence of ''Monsignor,'' I suddenly realized with guilt that my colleagues and I have for too long been too flip and too self-righteous about junk movies of such rare distinction. I don't know when I've had a better time at a willfully witless movie than watching ''Monsignor,'' which is both ''a Frank Yablans presentation'' and ''a Frank Perry film.'' You may not remember it, but Mr. Yablans brought us ''The Other Side of Midnight'' and Mr. Perry is the director that the late, great Jean Renoir, in a moment of lunatic generosity, once called ''a young master.''

title: Fiscal Fears Coming True
description: Until the Legislature flexed its muscle and finally passed expensive new programs over Governor Carey's objections in July, the lawmakers and the Governor fiercely debated the condition of New York's fiscal health. Legislators, with programs to protect, contended that it was fair; Mr. Carey insisted that it was poor and would get worse if the lawmakers had their way.

title: Who's Final Concert To Be on Pay TV
description: The Who's final concert on its North American farewell tour Dec. 17 will be televised on pay-per-view systems by 20th Century-Fox Pay-Television.

title: INCREASE IN POACHING IS REPORTED IN MANY STATES
description: Acting on an anonymous tip, a Texas game warden stopped a group of men early this year as they prepared to leave a motel in Falfurrias, a small town 60 miles southwest of Corpus Christi.

title: COINS SOLD FOR $687,500 EACH
description: Two 19th-century coins were sold for $687,500 each on Thursday, the highest price ever paid at auction for regular-issue United States gold coins. The sales took place at two sessions in the auction of the United States gold-coin collection of the late Louis Eliasberg, a Baltimore banker.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO TURN D.C.INTO STATE NO. 51
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberation in Spain
description: You don't have to be Spanish to celebrate the news from Madrid. Nor need you be a Socialist to take heart in the convincing majority won by Felipe Gonzalez's party in this week's free election. There will be time enough to consider what it means for American diplomacy. Consider first what it means for Spain.

title: SLUMP IN SERVICE SECTOR
description: Slowly but surely, the impact of the recession is beginning to hit the service sector, the area of the economy that for the last decade or more has been resistant to downturns.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT MIXUPS, STATE SAYS, ARE EXCEPTIONAL
description: A northern New Jersey man who was laid off last summer by the company he had worked for for 28 years complained that he had reported to his local State Unemployment Office for six weeks before receiving any benefits.

title: Scientists Find Key to Growth
description: The substance crucial to human growth lies deep within the brain, eluding efforts to extract it. Two scientific teams have now tracked this substance to another location -in a rare pancreatic tumor - and determined its chemistry. The achievement, by groups led by Dr. Roger Guillemin and Dr. Wylie Vale, both of Salk Institute in La Jolla, Calif., is being reported separately: Dr. Guillemin's in this week's issue of Science and Dr. Vale's in the journal Nature later this month.

title: LIZA A. LERNER TO BE BRIDE IN JUNE OF D. PORTER BIBB 3D
description: Mrs. Alan W. Livingston of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Alan Jay Lerner of New York and London, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Liza Ann Lerner, to D. Porter Bibb 3d, son of Mrs. Margot Clark Bibb of Amagansett, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Terrific Honorific
description: Where you stand on the use of Ms. usually reflects where you stand on feminism. The earliest spotting of that term was on a 1767 gravestone in Plymouth, Mass. (''Here lies Interrd the body of Ms. Sarah Spooner''). That early usage - perhaps by an absent-minded chiseler -was reborn in the late 1960's as a blend of Mrs. and Miss.

title: POP: ANNE MURRAY AND BAND
description: Decorous, pleasant and reliable are apt adjectives to describe Anne Murray, the Canadian folk-pop contralto who has enjoyed a steady commercial success for more than a decade. But there are also moments when Miss Murray, who sang with a 30-piece backup Friday at Radio City Music Hall, can be downright compelling.

title: Orlando to Distribute Water-Saving Devices
description: The City Council will spend $564,000 to install water-saving devices in all 41,000 homes in Orlando.

title: EMOTIONAL APPEALS ARE MADE QUIETLY
description: Much of New York's 1982 race for governor has been fought over the air, with millions of dollars of television and radio ammunition. But supporters of Mario M. Cuomo and Lewis E. Lehrman are waging a second, virtually invisible campaign for the allegiance of the state's voters. The weapons are the telephone and the postage stamp, and they are being wielded with uncommon, and perhaps recordbreaking, vigor.

title: Hotel Dressed Up for Voters
description: Voters will be greeted by a 10-foothigh figure of Uncle Sam and will be served red, white and blue cake under crystal chandeliers when they cast their ballots Tuesday at the Mansion Hotel's polling booths. ''My polling place always gets a great voter turnout because people don't like voting in smelly garages and basements,'' said Bob Pritikin, who operates the landmark hotel.

title: BISHOPS' TWO VERDICTS ON DETERRENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: THERE'S A KNACK OR TWO TO USING PAINT OR VARNISH REMOVER
description: WHEN faced with the job of removing paint, varnish or other finish from furniture, cabinets or woodwork, the do-it-yourselfer generally has two choices: He can sand or scrape off the finish , or he can use a chemical paint and varnish remover.

title:
GARDENING;
THE SPOOKY LORE BEHIND SOME PLANTS
description: o'-lanterns. These seem to have evolved into something much more than a carved pumpkin with a crooked smile and twinkling eyes.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BUNGLING BALLERINAS Written and illustrated by Ellen Shire. 32 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $5.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: A WEDDING ALBUM ON VIDEOTAPE
description: ''SO many brides are preoccupied by their wedding day,'' said newlywed Renee LaSalandra of Norwalk, ''that they don't remember anything about it.''

title: KEENE'S CAREER ON A FAST TRACK
description: THERE is nothing slow about Christopher Keene. He talks fast, he walks fast and his musical career is certainly on the fast track. At the age of 35 he was recently named artistic supervisor of the New York City Opera; he signed a new three-year contract with the Long Island Philharmonic, which performs its second series of concerts this weekend; he continues, for this year at least, as music director of the Syracuse Symphony and New York State's Artpark; and he has been scheduled as guest conductor this season with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic.

title: POLL FINDS POPULARITY OF PRESIDENT MODIFYING IMPACT OF JOBLESS ISSUE
description: As the Congressional campaign nears its end, the public is being tugged sharply in opposite directions, toward Democrats by unemployment and toward Republicans by declining inflation and by President Reagan's popularity, The New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: TRIAL BY FIRE A People's History of the Civil War and Reconstruction. By Page Smith. 1,038 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill. $29.95.

title: Catherine Coakley Becomes a Bride
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday Catherine Mary Coakley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Coakley of Gallatin, Tenn., was married to Dennis Raymond Belisle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Belisle of Forestdale, R.I. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: THE NUMBER ONE WOMAN ON SEVENTH AVENUE
description: FOR an industry whose raison d'etre is to clothe the feminine form, t he apparel business has surprisingly few women at the top. Those whoh ave arrived, such as Liz Claiborne, tend to be designers whose senseo f fashion, rather than business acumen, led to their success.

title: NOW, THERAPY BY THE BALLOT
description: In what is believed to be the first time that the question of a specific medical treatment's advisability will go directly to voters, citizens of Berkeley, Calif., will decide on Tuesday whether local hospitals should give mental patients electric shock therapy.

title: ORLANDO IDEA FOR RAIL SYSTEM WINS U.S. FUNDS
description: Officials here have won a $420,000 Federal grant that they hope will lay the foundation for a $537 million privately owned rail system to serve Orlando and its tourist sites.

title: Florence Golden Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Golden of Hempstead, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Florence Michele Golden, to Bruce David Pavalow, son of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Pavalow of Syosset, L.I. A May weddding is planned.

title: M.T.A. SEEKS CHANGES IN CONRAIL WORK RULES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which will take over Conrail commuter operations in New York and Connecticut on Jan. 1, has proposed sweeping changes in old and costly union work rules as part of its program for rehabilitating the rail services.

title: WOMEN AND HEROINES
description: In ''Becoming a Heroine'' the critic Rachel Brownstein shows how reading novels has influenced women's conceptions of themselves, and in ways that are not always to their advantage. In ''Having It All'' Helen Gurley Brown suggests that the only fictions you can trust are your own. As she sees it, the best way for a woman to become a heroine in the story of her life is to plot it herself. Instead of being influenced by fiction, Mrs. Brown advises women to create fictions about themselves and use them to influence others.

title: Elizabeth Friese Is Engaged to Thomas P. Mulvey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Beryl Nevins Friese of Pleasantville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Nevins Friese, to Thomas Patrick Mulvey, son of Mrs. Thomas Patrick Mulvey of Hyde Park, Mass., and the late Mr. Mulvey. A Dec. 11 wedding is planned.

title: Autumn Lessons; The Boston Compact
description: The racially embattled city of Boston isn't often the source of upbeat news these days. The school system, especially, has been a focal point of turmoil.

title: A ROOMFUL OF PEARLSTEINS AT SUMMIT
description: SUMMIT THERE are few images as quickly recognizable as a Philip Pearlstein nude, unless it's a barn by Andrew Wyeth (coincidentally, the two artists share a methodical cold-bloodedness in their approach to reality).

title: PURCHASE CONTINUES BATTLE OVER ZONING
description: PURCHASE TO Charles G. Balancia, a Town Councilman of Harrison, ''zoning is forever'' and this is why, he says, the town must move cautiously in deciding the future of the Pforzheimer property here.

title: 'The Phony War'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Tennis Showdown

title: OF PAPANDREOU AND POLITICS OF CHANGE
description: The Socialist Party took this town last week, as it did most cities and towns in Greece's first municipal elections since the party came to power nationally last year. A poster of Communist origin showing lugubrious factory chimneys spouting black smoke over a radiantly green countryside pointed up one major problem that the Socialists, better than anyone else, were able to exploit.

title: A Moving Delay Costs Finance Unit a Bonus
description: The city's Finance Department started shifting about half of its offices from Manhattan to Brooklyn yesterday. The move is costing the city more than expected, and it leaves behind a building whose future is far from certain.

title:
AETNA REHABILITATES HARTFORD FACTORIES;
HARTFORD
description: A QUARTET of rundown factory buildings a few blocks from the State Capitol has been transformed into attractive office space by Aetna Life and Casualty. Though the rehabilitation of 19th-century mills and factories has become quite popular, until now major corporations have not been very active in it. Aetna's decision to move two of its departments to the ''wrong side of the tracks'' is considered a trendsetting one.

title: BRINGING PET GRIEF OUT IN THE OPEN
description: FOUR years ago I had to fight to keep a straight face when I heard that someone wouldn't be in work today because her dog had died. That night, the story provided me and my dinner companions several good, long laughs. Taking off because your dog died.

title: A VIVID AS WELL AS GRAPHIC ARTIST
description: ROCKWELL KENT An Anthology of His Work. Edited by Fridolf Johnson. 358 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $60.

title: In Brooklyn Once Is Enough
description: The Democratic primary in Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District may have been a great show, but the Court of Appeals last week called off the scheduled encore. By a 5-to-2 decision, the state's highest court canceled the rerun between State Senator Major R. Owens and State Senator Vander L. Beatty on the ground that there was no evidence that Mr. Owens, the winner by fewer than 3,000 votes, was responsible for misconduct in the election.
